title: Street Art Way Below the Street
description: A vast new exhibition space opened in New York City this summer, with a show 18 months in the making. On view are works by 103 street artists from around the world, mostly big murals painted directly onto the gallerys walls.

title: In a First, Brazil Elects a Woman as President
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Dilma Rousseff was elected the countrys first female president on Sunday, as Brazilians voted strongly in favor of continuing the economic and social policies of the popular president, Luiz Incio Lula da Silva.

title: A New Search Engine, Where Less Is More
description: Start-ups and big companies alike have tried to take on Google by building a better search engine. That they have failed has not stopped brave new entrants.

title: Candidates Advance Final Arguments
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans made their closing argument on Sunday for capturing control of Congress, assailing President Obama as a champion of wasteful and excessive government, as Democrats countered that returning power to Republicans would embolden corporations and the wealthy with disastrous results for middle-class Americans.

title: A New Focus on Cargo Security
description: One of the bombs discovered Friday was flown, apparently unscreened, in the cargo holds on two passenger planes in the Middle East. The potentially deadly lapse exposes a U.S. air security loophole The Lede previously discussed in a post in January and another in August.

title: World Series Game 4: Giants 4, Rangers 0
description: Having returned home, the Rangers won on Saturday and seemed to energize a World Series that had opened in lopsided fashion. But after losing to the San Francisco Giants, 4-0, on Sunday, the Rangers find themselves in a Texas-size hole.

title: Young Voters Say They Feel Abandoned
description: MIAMI  Two years ago, the University of Miami could not get enough Barack Obama. The campaign rally he held here felt like a rock concert, his face appeared on T-shirts all over campus, and pro-Obama volunteers registered 2,000 new voters.

title: Suspect in Printer Bombs Gains Notoriety
description: As my colleagues Mark Mazzetti and Robert F. Worth report, American officials said that the two bombs discovered in printers on Friday were assumed to have been made by Ibrahim Hassan al-Asiri, whom authorities described as Al Qaeda in Yemens top bomb-maker and a man who loaded explosives into his brothers body in a 2009 suicide attack that failed to kill Saudi Arabias intelligence chief.

title: On an Indian Reservation, a Garden of Buddhas
description: ARLEE, Mont.  On a rural American Indian reservation here, amid grazing horses and cattle, a Buddhist lama from the other side of the world is nearing completion of a $1.6 million meditative garden that he hopes will draw spiritual pilgrims.

title: Rally to Shift the Blame
description: In his new role as a political leader, which is what you call somebody if he hosts a rally on the Washington Mall for over 200,000 people, Jon Stewart was a little hemmed at the Rally to Restore Sanity on Saturday. Because sanity should know no party, partisan rhetoric was not on the teleprompter.

title: In Season of Surprises, Title Race Is Muddled
description: While this college football season has not provided the relentless spate of high-caliber upsets like the 2007 season, when Louisiana State won the national title with two losses, it certainly has delivered on surprises.Consider that with five full weeks remaining in the regular season, three of the top five teams in the Bowl Championship Series standings  No. 3 Texas Christian, No. 4 Boise State and No. 5 Utah  come from outside of college footballs six power conferences.

title: Russian Activists See Change in a Humble Protest
description: MOSCOW  There was nothing grandiose about the demonstration in Triumfalnaya Square in Moscow on Sunday night.

title: Senate Race Wont Leave Wrestling Ring
description: HARTFORD

title: A Difficult Final Weekend on the Trail
description: CLEVELAND  The upper deck was mostly empty when President Obama closed out the campaign season Sunday afternoon with a rally on the campus of Cleveland State University here. His aides looked grim, fiddling with their BlackBerrys as Democratic National Committee staffers scurried to get a crowd estimate from fire marshals: 8,000 in a hall built for 13,000.

title: Patriots Knock Out Favre and Grab Control of Division
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  If that was how it was going to end for Brett Favre, it would have been appropriately dramatic. His chin bloodied, his eyes closed, Favre lay on a cart as it took him in to the locker room for stitches, the quarterback looking more like a punch-drunk boxer than the iron man of the N.F.L. who kept his streak of starts alive Sunday. It is now at 292 straight despite fractures in his left ankle that had turned much of the football universe into amateur orthopedists.

title: Potashs Fight Against Takeover Resembles Cadburys
John Salazar Ad
description: Representative John Salazar's closing argument in Colorado's Third Congressional District.

title: Paul Kolton, Leader of Major Exchange, Dies at 87
description: Paul Kolton, who became the first full-time paid chairman of the American Stock Exchange without ever having worked as a stockbroker, died on Wednesday in Stamford, Conn., where he lived. He was 87.

title: Guard Led 3 Americans Across Iran Border, Released Hiker Says
description: The three American hikers accused of espionage by Iran stepped off an unmarked dirt road  inadvertently crossing from Iraq into the Islamic republic  only because a border guard of unknown nationality gestured for them to approach, the lone hiker to be released said Sunday.

title: 2 Reviews Cost Jets in Game of Position
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Jets Coach Rex Ryan flipped a red flag all of about two feet to the turf, and the home crowd obediently roared. He had lost his first replay challenge 10 minutes earlier, but that was not going to stop Ryan from questioning the officials again.

title: ImClone Ex-Chief Embarks on New Biotech Venture
description: Samuel D. Waksal is not letting his past stand in the way of his future.

title: Man Is Charged in Killing of Clerk at Queens Deli
description: A 29-year-old man was arrested early Sunday and charged with killing a clerk at a bodega in Queens during a robbery on Oct. 23, law enforcement officials said.

title: Giants Pitchers Take Pride in Their Serious, and Comic, Relief
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  When the fracas erupted and about 50 agitated athletes and coaches squared off for a potential brawl in Game 6 of the National League Championship Series, the Giants relievers did what relievers do: they poured out of the bullpen and ran toward the point of contention. The Giants, a team characterized as a band of bearded, rampaging, thong-wearing crazies, seemed to be itching to fight the bigger and more intimidating Philadelphia Phillies.

title: The Election on TV and Online
description: Two old media outlets, ABC and CBS, have new media partners for Tuesdays midterm elections.

title: Term Limits Are Popular but Draw Less Fervor
description: How important is the question of term limits in New York City?

title: After Delays, a Vote for a President in Ivory Coast
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  With a mixture of disbelief and hope, citizens in this strife-torn West African nation, once a beacon of prosperity for the region, voted Sunday in an oft-postponed presidential election, the first in 10 years.

title: Rangers Lee Expects to Be Razor Sharp in Game 5
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.

title: Weekend Warriors of the Down-Ballot Races
description: The battle for New York governor between Andrew M. Cuomo, the Democratic nominee, and Carl P. Paladino, the Republican, has captured the most attention by far in the statewide elections this year. But as Republicans seek an Albany comeback after two years of scandal, dysfunction and one-party Democratic rule, the stakes are also high in the campaigns for state attorney general and state comptroller, where polls suggest the Republican and Democratic candidates are in races that are still relatively close.

title: Lottery Numbers
With Victory, Republicans Would Face Uncertainty
description: MIAMI  If voters engineer the Congressional makeover that strategists in both parties now expect, the implications for governance over the next two years, and for Americas political future, remain a mystery. Ascendant Republicans will have to juggle the Tea Partys determination to block President Obamas agenda with centrist voters desire for the two parties to work together on jump-starting the economy.

title: In Albany, Democrats Face Losing the Senate
description: ALBANY  Two years after seizing control of the State Senate for the first time in more than four decades, New York Democrats are in grave danger of losing their narrow majority on Tuesday.

description: NEWARK

description: Accounts

title: Strickland, Foley Hoping Voters Will Split Tickets
description: Earlier tonight, we talked about how candidates can sometimes find themselves swimming upstream through no fault of their own. If they have little support elsewhere on the ticket  a decent Democratic gubernatorial nominee burdened by a weak Democratic Senate candidate, or vice versa  they may find some voters whose primary interest is in another race simply voting the party line against them.

title: Alaska Voting Forecast: Chance of Count Chaos
description: ANCHORAGE  The wrinkles of a write-in campaign in an Alaskan election could mean it takes weeks before anyone knows whether Senator Lisa Murkowski pulled off a political miracle.

title: Boehner Offers G.O.P. for 2010 Version of Change
description: HANOVERTON, Ohio  The speaker in waiting was waiting to speak, perched atop a bale of hay on a small platform outside the Spread Eagle Tavern, where the windows were draped with patriotic red, white and blue bunting.

title: Revisiting an Outrage With Gallows Humor
description: Cynicism and compassion are not easily  perhaps not possibly  summoned at the same time. The challenge facing the new musical The Scottsboro Boys, which dares to present ugly American history as bawdy burlesque, is to keep audiences dancing nimbly between the two states of feeling, enticing us to cackle knowingly at the plague of racism at one moment, and arousing sorrow and sympathy for its victims the next.

title: Lucky Magazine Creates Web Videos for Its Birthday
description: Instead of putting candles on a cake to celebrate its 10-year anniversary, Lucky magazine is lighting up its December issue with more than 100 online videos connected to each editorial page in the magazine.

title: To Other Teams, Oregon Remains a Blur
description: LOS ANGELES  Late in the fourth quarter of top-ranked Oregons blowout victory at Southern California on Saturday night, the Ducks executed a play that epitomized how they have climbed to the top of the Bowl Championship Series standings.

description: The most expensive Senate battle in the country. A chance for Democrats to win the governors office for the first time since 1986. Two Congressional seats once thought to be safely Democratic now viewed as vulnerable.

title: Harry Mulisch, Dutch Novelist, Dies at 83
description: Harry Mulisch, the Dutch novelist whose gift for writing with clarity about moral and philosophical themes made him an enormously influential figure in the Netherlands and earned him recognition abroad, died at his home in Amsterdam on Saturday. He was 83.

description: Everyone on Wall Street is waiting on the Fed.

title: Last Word: Theodore C. Sorensen
description: Theodore C. Sorensen was President John F. Kennedy's political strategist, confidant and his favorite speechwriter.  Mr. Sorensen helped craft some of the president's most memorable lines.

title: Economic Reports This Week

title: A Battle of Plaid Shirts and Conflicting Visions

Ron Johnson, a Republican, stood in a suit and tie before a crush of supporters in a ballroom on Friday night and reminded them why a plastics manufacturer whom most voters had never heard of a year ago  or, as he described himself, just a guy from Oshkosh  had decided to mount a challenge for the United States Senate.

title: The Colorado Rivers Future
description: Last month, Ken Salazar, the secretary of the interior, committed $1.5 million to establish a study group focusing on the Colorado River basin. Modest as the dollar amount sounds, this is a very good investment. The study will be the first of three river basin studies  called the WaterSMART program  aimed at measuring the nations water demands and resources, including the potential impacts of climate change.

title: Mugged by the Moralizers
description: How many of you people want to pay for your neighbors mortgage that has an extra bathroom and cant pay their bills? Thats the question CNBCs Rick Santelli famously asked in 2009, in a rant widely credited with giving birth to the Tea Party movement.

title: Sorry State of Gun Control
description: As a new Congress looms, we suggest lawmakers travel to Washington by way of West Virginia and an obscure federal building called the National Tracing Center. There they can see workers laboring through unmanageably high backlogs of handwritten paper records submitted by the nations gun dealers. This is Congresss handiwork  at the behest of the gun lobby and to the detriment of public safety.

title: How We Got Here

And not surprisingly, they were more and more likely to identify as Democrats.

As befitting this so-called year of the pitcher, the San Francisco Giants on Sunday paraded out the final member of the first entirely homegrown World Series rotation in 24 years. All of their starters are in their 20s and under club control for at least the next two seasons. Imagine the possibilities, Aubrey Huff said. This team, said Huff, the Giants first baseman, has a chance to do something special for quite some time.

title: This Week in Small Business: Is the Horror Over?
description: MANY SMALL BIZ OWNERS HOPING FOR A CHANGE TOMORROW? As the election looms, President Obama continues to talk about how his administration is helping small business. But a survey issued last week said that most small-business owners are voting Republican. Another poll finds that nearly 80 percent of the business community believes that business interests would best be served if the Democratic Party lost majority control of either the House or the Senate. David Leonhardt of The New York Times says job losses overshadowed the presidents accomplishments. The president pleads for patience with Jon Stewart and promises to start focusing on the deficit next term. Blogger Justin Fox explains the deficit. A new graphic shows how Americans feel about the recession. The national debt is projected to reach three times the size of the economy in 2050 and Reuters columnist James Pethokoukis doesnt think the Presidents deficit panel is on track.

title: The Temporary Vegetarian: Vegan Ma Po Tofu
description: Ma Po tofu is supposed to bring sweat to your face, and numbness to your mouth, said Susur Lee, the executive chef of Shang in Manhattan and Lee in Toronto. His famous dish of silken tofu is made fiery with hot bean paste, Thai birds-eye chilis and ground Szechwan pepper, and rounded out with soy sauce, vegetarian oyster sauce and garlic. It is best eaten over soothing, bland rice.

title: I.B.M Said to Seek to Buy Fortinet
description: Fortinet, a maker of network security systems, has received a takeover approach from International Business Machines, two people close to the situation told Bloomberg News.

title: Not-So-Great Scott: More Alternate Realities for Back to the Future
description: While the rest of us were wondering how Back to the Future might have turned out if it had starred Eric Stoltz instead of Michael J. Fox, Saturday Night Live was contemplating even more esoteric casting possibilities and realizing that maybe history turned out for the best.

title: Paddy OPrado to Make an Appearance
description: Liz OConnell is a professional horsewoman who works at Anstu Farm in Millbrook, N.Y. She is a member of the New York State Task Force on Retired Race Horses and is active in rehoming off-the-track thoroughbreds. She is a graduate of Cornell Universitys College of Agriculture and Life Sciences.

title: Earlier Flight May Have Been Dry Run for Plotters
description: WASHINGTON  American intelligence officials in September intercepted several packages containing books, papers, CDs and other household items shipped to Chicago from Yemen and considered the possibility that the parcels might be a test run for a terrorist attack, two officials said Monday night.

title: Anyone Want to Help Build a Reactor?
description: A partnership between Constellation Energy and Electricit de France to build a new reactor in Maryland has broken up, with Constellation concluding that the economics are unfavorable because of electricity market conditions and the terms demanded by the Energy Department for a loan guarantee.

title: Mixed Day for Markets Ahead of Elections and Fed
description: Shares on Wall Street closed mixed on Monday ahead of midterm elections and expected changes in monetary policy.

title: When Internet Companies Slip, Recovery Is Hard
description: Executives trying to turn around struggling Internet companies inevitably voice confidence that a revival is just around the corner.

title: 300 Years of Movies
description: Dont be put off by the inclusion of requisite scenes and familiar nuggets of dialogue from Citizen Kane, Sunset Boulevard and Jaws in Turner Classic Movies seven-part documentary series Moguls and Movie Stars: A History of Hollywood, which premieres Monday night. The program is far less interested in myth-telling than in breaking down the gears of Tinseltowns myth machine. Unlike a lot of histories that have been made, were not a series of clips of the highlights of the great movies, says Jon Wilkman, the series director, writer and producer. Instead, he tells The Moment, its about how Hollywood functioned. Its a history of Hollywood power  who had it, howd they get it, what they did with it and howd they lose it.

title: Wilmington Trust and M&T Bank to Merge
description: Wilmington Trust and the M&T Bank Corporation said on Monday that they would merge, creating a major lender in the eastern United States and a global provider of wealth management.

title: Old, New, Borrowed and Bruce: Springsteens Video for Save My Love
description: Given the opportunity, who wouldnt want to turn back the clock to the late 1970s and jam with Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band? Apparently not even Mr. Springsteen himself can resist the temptation: in Thom Zimnys new video for the song Save My Love, from Mr. Springsteens coming album The Promise, the Boss gets to revisit the glory days of 1977 as he and his bandmates were gearing up to record Darkness on the Edge of Town. Thats appropriate enough, since Save My Love was originally written and produced for the Darkness sessions collected on The Promise, though the version youll hear in the video is a new one that Mr. Springsteen recorded this year.

title: The Final Push to the Voting Booth
description: Those who would be New Yorks representatives are hard at work making their final appeals to voters in a last push before Election Day.

title: Grossman Over McNabb: Did Shanahan Make Right Call?
description: They may need a rally to restore sanity at Redskins Park before this story is over: Mike Wise of The Washington Post on a quarterback drama that has just begun:

title: New Eruption Drives More Indonesians to Shelter
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Mount Merapi unleashed another violent explosion Monday, driving thousands more people from their homes as the Indonesian authorities admitted to shortcomings in handling two natural disasters  a volcano and a tsunami  that have killed nearly 500 people in the last week.

title: QE In The GD
description: Via Brad DeLong, David Beckworth counters my disheartening discussion of Japans experiment in quantitative easing with the example of monetary policy in the Great Depression. So, a few comments and some data.

title: Let the Melbourne Cup Party Begin
description: Kerry Lonergan has kept his bookmaker driving a Mercedes Benz for years. Hes also had shares in many slow racehorses, and like all owners, remains convinced that the next one he buys will be the next Secretariat. He lives in Brisbane, Australia.

title: George Hickenlooper, Film Director, Dies at 47
description: LOS ANGELES  George Hickenlooper, a director whose credits include an Emmy-winning documentary about the making of Apocalypse Now and a film starring Kevin Spacey as the disgraced lobbyist Jack Abramoff that is scheduled to open in December, died on Saturday in Denver. He was 47.

title: The Wind in the Gallows
description: This Halloween weekend, co-vocabularists have generously reworked book titles for spine-chillingeffect.

title: Nokia Taking a Rural Road to Growth
description: On Saturday at dawn, hundreds of farmers near Jhansi, an agricultural center in central India, received a succinct but potent text message on their cellphones: the current average wholesale price for 100 kilograms of tomatoes was 600 rupees ($13.26).

title: Morning Take-Out
description: 60 Minutes has a special on what its like to be unemployed for nearly two years  in Silicon Valley.

title: Send Us Your First Yuletide Sightings in New York
description: Doesnt it seem that Christmas dcor arrives earlier and earlier every year? Now that Halloween has passed, we suspect that some people are already placing little drummer boys and nutcrackers on their front lawns, stringing up lights on their porches and decking their halls with candles (and with menorahs, too). Bryant Park is getting dressed for the occasion. We even saw a faux tree in a store in SoHo the other day. We need you, our readers, to send us dispatches from your neighborhood, your street, your house, of these early yuletide sightings.

title: Cleary Gottlieb Elects 4 Partners
description: Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton called itself an international law firm long before it became trendy to do so. The firm, which is based in New York, underscored its global reach on Monday when it named four new partners and four new counsel from all over the map.

title: Gulf Seafood Is Safe, Officials Say
description: Extensive testing of Gulf of Mexico seafood by federal scientists has found only minute traces of the dispersant Corexit, which was used to break up oil from the BP spill, officials say. About 1.8 million gallons of dispersant were applied to the waters surface and at the wellhead, nearly a mile undersea.

title: House Proud
description: In 1924, the French designer Jean-Michel Frank collaborated with Herms on a collection of furniture, including the Confortable armchair and sofa, the elegant, cubic forms of which made it one of the most admired  and widely copied  designs of the 20th century. This month in Paris, for the inauguration of its new home division, Maison, Herms is reintroducing these and other Frank pieces, including a straw-marquetry screen, a shagreen-covered vanity and the designers X-base dining table. Robert Chavez, the president and C.E.O. of Herms USA, sees a very exciting potential in the U.S. for the Jean-Michel Frank by Herms collection, given the customer demand for furniture with the Herms label. Previously, the companys furniture was limited to Pippa, a small collection by the architect Rena Dumas, who designed Herms stores and who was married to Jean-Louis Dumas, the chairman of Herms from 1978 to 2006. (Rena died in 2009, and Jean-Louis in May.) Their son, Pierre-Alexis Dumas, the companys artistic director and a sixth-generation member of the founding Herms family, said starting Maison with historic designs was a deliberate strategy: We had to go backward to understand our roots and to go forward into the future. And in that future  April 2011, to be exact  the company will unveil further Maison collections, this time by a roster of (yet to be revealed) contemporary designers.

title: Sprint Cup Chase Remains Tight After Talladega
description: Weve gone through seven races, and you can throw a blanket over the three of us, said Kevin Harvick after the race at Talladega Superspeedway on Sunday.

title: Wanted: Buyers Who Are a Lot Like the Sellers
description: Robert Rosenblum, an author of more than 30 novels, may not know who will buy the Greenwich Village town house where he has lived with his wife, Constance Simo, for the past 24 years. But like any writer, he has characters in mind.

title: Numberplay: Sum Fun
description: Heres an equation: 12 = 3. Twelve equals three. Hmm.  Doesnt make sense. Can you fix it by adding a plus sign?.

title: CNN Hires Producer for Piers Morgan Tonight
description: Piers Morgans forthcoming talk show on CNN now has an executive producer, Jonathan Wald.

title: Bayside, Queens, 7:28 A.M.
description: Daniel M. Donovan Jr., the Republican candidate for attorney general, spoke to students from LaGuardia Community College on a campaign stop at the Long Island Rail Road station in Bayside, Queens.

title: How to Make an Engineering Culture
description: James Dyson, the British industrial designer, is best known for the innovative, high-performance appliances that bear the family name  cyclonic vacuum cleaners with powerful suction and fans that generate a breeze without blades.

title: Giving Thanks for Vegetables, Not Turkey
description: Everyone knows the best foods at Thanksgiving are the side dishes. Why fill up on turkey when you can gobble down the best fruits and vegetables of the fall harvest?

title: Another New Twist in Rear Window Dispute
description: An Alfred Hitchcock thriller may wrap up its loose ends in under two hours, but a longstanding legal dispute over whether the 2007 movie Disturbia infringes on the copyright of Hitchcocks Rear Window and its source material is far from over.

title: Monday Night Matchup: Texans at Colts
description: Houston Texans (4-2)at Indianapolis Colts (4-2)8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPNLine: Colts by 5.5

title: Seeking Help for Gambling Addiction
description: Is treatment for gambling addiction different than for other addictions? Whats the best way to get the compulsive gambler to stop? What can family members do to encourage treatment, and to protect themselves? These are among the questions recently posed by readers of the Consults blog.

title: Monday Reading: More on the Mortgage Mess
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Pushy Parents, Struggling Freshmen
description: Two news articles, on two continents, reaching two separate conclusions, caught my attention over the past few days.

title: Quantitative Easing, the Song
description: From the folks who brought you Double Dippin, heres a Barry White-esque musical take on the Federal Reserves expected announcement this week:

title: No Need to Dress Any Differently
description: A buccaneer in a smoking jacket, a Rastafarian in a body suit of brilliant color, and a man dressed as a demonic marmot all gyrated to the interplanetary vibrations as the 14-piece band snaked a cosmic conga line through the crowd, bedecked in Egyptian headdresses and spangly regalia.

title: Roadside Attraction
description: If youre going to build your dream house in a city that revolves around cars, why not plant it right on the side of a freeway? Ronnie Self, an architect, has done just that on a plot of land in a gritty but art-filled neighborhood with unobstructed views of the downtown skyline in Houston.

title: Unions Fear Rollback of Rights Under Republicans
description: Organized labor is deeply worried about what happens after Tuesday.

title: This Weeks Health Industry News
description: If the Republicans gain control of the House of Representatives in Tuesdays election, as expected, attention shifts from the campaign trail to what the G.O.P. can do in practical terms to try to unravel pieces of the newly enacted health care overhaul.

title: Its Getting Scary in Texas
description: These are not heady days in the land of 10-gallon hats. People are clearly not reading the command on the license plates because EVERYBODY is messing with Texas. The sporting scene is starting to look like the backdrop of those spaghetti westerns, tumbleweeds bouncing mournfully across the landscape.

title: Communications Chief to Depart NBC
description: In a move widely expected inside NBC Universal since Jeff Zucker announced he was departing as chief executive, Allison Gollust, the executive vice president of corporate communications, has told her staff she too will be leaving the company when the takeover by Comcast is completed.

title: Respectable Bass From a Small Base
description: For its small six-and-a-half-inch circumference, the JBL On Stage Micro III, an iPhone and iPod speaker dock, pumps out a surprising amount of bass.

title: And Then There Was Nun: Patina Miller Will Star in Sister Act on Broadway
description: Now heres a bit of news we presume Whoopi Goldberg wont walk out on. The coming Broadway production of Sister Act, the musical adapted from her hit 1992 comedy, has found its lead, and to those of you who were hoping the New York transfer would retain the star of its original West End production, your faith has been rewarded.

title: When Money Alone Doesnt Qualify a Buyer
description: When we sell or pass down beloved possessions, out of necessity or just desire, we often hope that the new owners will treasure them as much as we did. We want the buyer of that used car we had in college, the one we cant afford the insurance for, to take as good care of it as we did. Maybe better. We want the friend who gets our old party dresses to party in them, too.

title: Jurors Note Imperils Trial to Sentence a Killer of 3
description: NEW HAVEN  The sole remaining alternate juror in the death-penalty trial of the man convicted of killing three members of a Cheshire, Conn., family tried to pass a note written on a napkin last week suggesting a romantic meeting with a court officer.

title: Respecting Muslim Patients Needs
description: A woman in her mid-30s wearing a hijab, the traditional Muslim head covering, comes to an urgent care center complaining of leg pain. The first thing she asks: Are there any woman doctors around?

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: Consumer Spending Up as Incomes Fall
description: Another reason to be concerned about the sustainability of consumer spending growth: Consumer spending eked upward in September (rising 0.2 percent), but incomes fell slightly (down 0.1 percent). Consumers were able to spend more only because they decided to salt away less of their paychecks, reducing their savings rates.

title: Berlyn, a New Restaurant for BAM
description: The prime restaurant location for visitors to BAM has changed hands but remains in a Germanic mode like its predecessor, Thomas Beisl. Ursula and Jonas Hegewisch, she from Chicago, he from Hamburg, Germany, both once living and working in Berlin, have found room to display their collection of vintage pewter bric-a-brac, including a few gnomes. We wanted to recreate the real Berlin atmosphere, Ms. Hegewisch said. The chef, Steven Linares, is learning to prepare German food, she said. Among the dishes are a type of corned beef mixed like a hash with beets and pickles, spatezle with cheese, some sausages, and maultaschen, a kind of big ravioli with a vegetable filling served in mushroom broth. Rote grutze, a red berry dessert, will be on the dessert menu, and German and Austrian selections will dominate the wine list. The tent on the west side of the restaurant is winterized and will open in a couple of weeks to expand the seating; 25 Lafayette Avenue (Ashland Place), (718) 222-5800.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: Joe DAndrea and Joe Zandstra joined Magnani Caruso Dutton, New York, in new posts. Mr. DAndrea becomes director for mobile development; he had been the principal of Liquid Joe, Basking Ridge, N.J., a company he founded. Mr. Zandstra becomes creative director; he had been vice president and chief creative officer at Qais Consulting, Singapore.

title: Q&A: Hitting the Right Mark
description: Q.

title: The Cost of Insuring Teenage Drivers
description: A new study from Insurance.com shows how much a parents insurance policy can go up when a teenage driver is added.

title: The Woman Who Had the World Enthralled
description: From the start Cleopatras story was larger than life: epic in scale, mythic in symbolism and operatically over the top in its grandeur and its spectacle. As Stacy Schiff describes it in a captivating new biography, Cleopatras meeting with Julius Caesar was a singular, shuddering moment, when two civilizations, passing in different directions, unexpectedly and momentously touched.

title: Dexter Watch: A Lethal Bond
description: We are midway through the current season of Dexter, and we can certainly see a glimpse of what is to come: Lumen and Dexter are soulmates, two people whose psychologies have been shaped almost entirely by extreme violence. The final scene with them in Ritas old bathroom perfectly evoked their like-mindedness and their potential for the kind of real connection that Dexter has never experienced. Yet it also revealed his totalizing fear of actually having that kind of bond.Michael C. Halls performance here was really powerful: his face seemed to quiver and his body to recoil without actually doing so, as Lumen outlined her biography  her fear of marriage and of stifling convention, her need to breathe and experience thrills in life beyond having the right kind of china. Of course, this terror of dull, suburban normalcy is exactly what keeps Dexter so restive. He saw himself with frightening clarity in Lumen and is clearly afraid of what it might mean that the fates have delivered to him a woman who would not only accept his proclivities but also share them.

title: 9 Coney Island Boardwalk Businesses Lose Leases
description: An updated version of this story that appeared in the newspaper can be read here.

title: A New Restaurant for the Benjamin Hotel
description: This grand caf, the National, has been interpreted in a very conservative style by David Rockwell with cream walls, dark furniture, leather banquettes and geometric tile; and by Geoffrey Zakarian, whose mainstream menu features oysters, mussels, caesar salad, a few sandwiches, steak frites, roast chicken and trout, for a place that is open morning until night. (See: Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner and Dessert (pdfs)). The space had previously housed restaurants by Larry Forgione and then Terrance Brennan, and the hotel was once the Beverly; The Benjamin, 557 Lexington Avenue (50th Street), 212-715-2400, thebenjamin.com.

title: TimesCast | November 1, 2010
description: A look at Senate races in Washington state and Alaska and the psychology of partisanship.

title: In Video: Why You Are Voting
description: The New York Times asked its readers to create videos that explained what issue or event had the most influence on their decisions at the polls.

title: A Versatile Vegetable for Hard Times
description: Whenever I think about budget dishes, cabbage is the vegetable that comes mind. Fortunately, the alarming surge in cabbage prices that has hit South Korea hasnt occurred here, and big heads of green cabbage are still among the best deals you can get at the farmers market. Medium cabbages weigh 2 to 2 1/2 pounds. I paid $1.50 for three heads last week and got six dishes out of them, each serving at least four people.

title: 4G Wireless Reaches the New York Area
description: 5:20 p.m. | Updated Added Sprints introduction of a New York 4G service.

title: What Were Reading: Paris vs. New York
Prize Is Created for Gay Literature for Young Readers
description: The American Library Association has added an award for gay and lesbian literature to its annual prizes for childrens books. The prizes, which include the prestigious John Newbery and Randolph Caldecott medals, will be announced on Jan. 10.

title: A Big Bet on Exco and Natural Gas
description: 4:55 p.m. | Updated Does the rich premium being offered to take Exco Resources private point to a recovery ahead for battered natural gas prices?

title: Terror Trade Tax
description: The disclosure that the two bombs from Yemen may have been intended to blow up cargo planes over the ocean raises the possibility of pressure for a new round of spending that will be a drag on world trade and the world economy, even if it is deemed necessary.

title: Keeping Score: How the Rangers Can Beat Lincecum
description: In this pitching-heavy postseason, the news media have heaped hype on the top playoff hurlers. Roy Halladay, Cole Hamels, Matt Cain and now Madison Bumgarner have all been given their due 15 minutes of fame for dominating in the postseason. And despite a shaky last outing, everyone seems to presume a Texas victory in Cliff Lees starts.

title: Adam Rapoport Will Lead Bon Apptit, Publisher Confirms
description: Confirming rumors that circulated on Friday, Cond Nast announced on Monday that Adam Rapoport has been named the next editor in chief of Bon Apptit. Mr. Rapoport lives in New York and is currently style editor at GQ, where he has worked for more than 10 years. Prior to that he was the restaurant editor at Time Out New York, and an editor and writer in the publications department of the James Beard Foundation.

title: Connections Moves Are Worth Watching
description: Matt Carothers is the host of :58 Flat and Blinkers Off on TVG, as well being one its regular analysts. He started playing the horses long before the law allows.

title: 100 Years of WWD
description: Womens Wear Daily, the quippy and quirky trade paper of the garment industry, marked its centennial with a commemorative magazine out Monday that traces the evolution of fashion and alsoof its own coverage of fashion. For the cover, its editors came up with a pretty novel approach to illustrating 100 years of putting out a paper: a montage of notable designers, celebrities and socialites assembled as if they were the audience of a runway show. Yves Saint Laurent, Coco Chanel, Karl Lagerfeld, Ralph Lauren and Jackie Kennedy are in the front row; Andy Warhol, Claude Montana and Cindy Crawford are all the way in the back, so you cant imagine that anyone will be complaining too much about their placement (as long as they were included).

title: When a Debt Collector Calls for Debt You Dont Owe
description: In a recent New York Times article, Debt Collectors Face a Hazard: Writers Cramp, David Segal detailed how debt buyers had been using an assembly-line approach to financial paperwork well before the recent foreclosure mess and how the debt buyers often end up pursuing the wrong person.

title: A Step That Is New: James Franco Work Studies Threes Company
description: From our standpoint the closest thing approaching a dramatic moment on Threes Company was the tension of whether audiences would accept Jenilee Harrison as a replacement for Suzanne Somers. But James Franco, as is his wont, sees more in that retro two-girls-and-a-guy comedy than just double entendres and the loveless marriage of the Ropers, and has made it the subject of a new work to be presented at the New Frontier program of the Sundance Film Festival in January.

title: First It Was Diapers. Now Shop for Soap (and Similar) Online.
description: A little bit of soap, the old song goes, will never wash away my tears. But what might a whole lot of soap do? Not to mention detergent, paper towels, sponges, disinfecting wipes and more than 25,000 other health, beauty and household products.

title: The End Of Western Civilization
description: Gauti Eggertsson writes in to follow up on my piece on quantitative easing in the Great Depression. He points me to a 2008 paper (pdf) in which he shows that the coming of FDR, combined with Americas exit from the gold standard, was seen by markets as a huge regime change; it was, said FDRs own budget director, the end of Western civilization.

title: Contract Extensions Elude Much of 2007 N.B.A. Draft Class
description: 3:12 p.m. | Updated The Hawks and Al Horford agreed on a five-year, $60 million contract extension before Mondays deadline, the Atlanta Journal-Constitution reports.

title: Recipes for Chocolate Desserts
description: Cakes, puddings and other ways to put chocolate to work come Valentines Day.

title: The Morning Line: Zenyatta Has Already Won
description: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

title: Macroeconomics Is Hard
description: Im getting some fairly hysterical reactions to todays column, many of them along the lines of Youre an idiot  I know what its like out there in the real world of business etc..

title: C.F.T.C. Is Set to Get Tougher on Fraud
description: Peter J. Henning follows issues involving securities law and white-collar crime for DealBooks White Collar Watch.

title: Modeling the Midterms
description: As long as Im writing about where the Democrats went astray, I should say something about the liberal enthusiasm for political science models proving that structural factors and only structural factors  unemployment, changes in personal income, the number of seats in play explain the Democratic Partys looming midterm rout. The Democrats would need to lose more than 45 seats in the House of Representatives, Jonathan Chait recently argued, citing one such academic model, for this election to count as a real referendum on Obamas leadership. Invoking a different political scientist, Kevin Drum suggested that about 70 percent of the seat changes this Tuesday are the result of forces beyond the Democrats control, leaving just 30 percent of any conservative swing to be pinned on day-to-day politics and policy choices.

title: The Rent Is High, but These Prices Are Low!
description: Jimmy McMillan, the irreverent candidate for governor and aspiring musician from the Rent Is Too Damn High Party, can add another first to a bizarre list of accomplishments that include steampunk facial hair and dropping an album only days before the election: first candidate for governor to become an online pitchman.

title: Weird Sunday Marked by Quarterback Follies, Cowboys Slide
description: Maybe the N.F.L can chalk up Sundays weirdness to Halloween and move along to the second half of the season. It was hard to think supernatural forces were not involved when you had a head coach trying to explain away the benching of his starting quarterback by saying the player doesnt have as good a command of the two-minute drill as the backup does. Or when a megastar quarterback indulges in unattractive and protracted lauding of his own abilities.

title: Clinton Facing Heat on Oil Sands Pipeline
description: Battle lines have been hardening over the proposed Keystone XL pipeline over the last couple of weeks. The pipeline, which will stretch from Alberta in Canada to refineries on the Gulf Coast, would nearly double the United States capacity to import oil made from Canadian oil sands. Canadian oil sands are a plentiful and secure source of oil, but the extraction process is high in carbon dioxide emissions and takes a toll on pristine Canadian forest ecosystems.

description: FRANKFURT

title: Adam Rapoport Will Lead Bon Apptit
description: Confirming rumors that circulated on Friday, Cond Nast announced on Monday that Adam Rapoport has been named the next editor-in-chief of Bon Apptit. Read the full post on the Diners Journal blog.

description: Washington Post: Meat farmers angry over limits in antibiotic use.  Sam Sifton

title: Shopping in Belgium: All-Purpose Antwerp
description: This city, known for its cutting-edge design talent, keeps its avant cred with a slew of new concept stores that offer everything from edgy fashion to high-end furniture to four-star dining.

title: Grey Nomads
description: Peripateticretirees in Australia.

title: Afghan Police Unit Defects to Taliban, Leaving Burning Station Behind
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  For months, American and Afghan officials have been promoting a plan to persuade masses of rank-and-file Taliban fighters to change sides and join the government. The tactic, known as reintegration, is one of the big hopes for turning the tide in the war.

description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y.  I got the chance last week to drive Hyundais coming $60,000 luxury sedan, the Equus, here in the Hudson River Valley.

description: This proposal, out of Britain, reminds me of President Obamas campaign idea to give students financial aid for participating in community service projects:

title: Pictures of the Day: Indonesia and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Indonesia, Germany and New York State.

title: The Caucus: Tossup in Alaska
description: Scott McAdams, the Democratic candidate for Alaska Senate, has an unexpected chance in the three-way race.

title: The U.S. Energy Deal Boom
description: Natural gas prices may be down 20 percent this year and crude oil may be trading sideways, but deal-making in the energy sector is surging.

title: The Claim: Always Store Vitamins in the Medicine Cabinet
description: THE FACTS The medicine cabinet may seem like an ideal place for keeping vitamins and supplements. But research suggests otherwise.

title: The Morning Skate: A Missed Opportunity, a Capital Revival, a Flameout in Calgary
description: The N.H.L. has slapped a three-game suspension on Danny Briere for this incident from the end of the Flyers-Islanders game from Saturday night.

description: Jackie Calmes and Michael D. Shear discuss what happened in recent weeks to make the three-way race for Alaskas Senate seat a tossup.

title: Fortinets Shares Take Wild Ride on Deal/No Deal
description: 4:25 p.m. | Updated After its shares climbed as much as 22 percent on Monday following a report that I.B.M. was interested in a takeover, the network security company Fortinet said Monday afternoon that no deal was in the works.

title: Recipes: Soups, Chips and Sauts
description: Toni Landau writes, Once a week I make a big pot of vegetable soup that I serve before dinner and have available for midday snacks. Her recipe:

title: Northern Manhattan Subway Riders Say Rats Abound
description: Rodents, the traditional scourge of New York City, are having a rough year. The rise of the bedbug seems to have rendered rats a has-been pest, a mere nuisance to be ignored rather than read about in countless alarmist trend articles. The bedbug is a breakout media star; the rat is, well, still a rat.

title: Immigration and the Elections
description: David Shipley, the Op-Ed editor, speaks with Lawrence Downes, an editorial writer, about the immigration issues that have played out in this election cycle.

title: The Complexities of Campaign Spending, and In Adding It All Up
description: Last month, The New York Times reported in separate articles that the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees had spent $7.9 million, $5 million and $91 million on Tuesdays elections, while The Wall Street Journal reported that the spending was actually $87.5 million. It would seem impossible that all of these numbers could be right. But it is possible they are. The question is how you count spending.

title: Start-Ups: Can You Handle the Truth?
description: Recently, I learned about the Silicon Valley entrepreneur and strategy consultant Sramana Mitras useful Web site for start-ups. Ms. Mitra founded three companies, two of which were acquired, and she is the author of the Entrepreneur Journeys book series. Earlier this year, Ms. Mitra began One Million by One Million (1M/1M), an educational initiative that hopes to help one million entrepreneurs reach $1 million in revenue.

title: Cede Political Turf? Never! Well, Maybe.
description: No matter how it turns out, at least one message from the midterm election is clear: this is not a moment of harmonic convergence.

title: Premonitions of Danger at Baghdad Church Held Hostage
description: Seven weeks before he died, Father Thaer Abdal was standing beside the gnarled stone grotto to the Virgin Mary in Sayidat al-Nejat church, an extremely worried man.

title: Once Pleasant, Now Paladino
description: Who knew there was a place in Manhattan called Paladino Avenue? We do, now, because there was a small fire this afternoon (stove fire, apartment 2A; no injuries; under control at 1:11 p.m.) at 50 Paladino Avenue in the Wagner public housing complex in East Harlem. The street connects First Avenue and the F.D.R. Drive near 120th Street.

title: The Race to Dominate the Smartphone Market

title: Its Alive: Big Audience for Debut of The Walking Dead
description: Were about to discuss zombies, so you can see the cannibalism joke coming a mile away: viewers ate up the premiere of The Walking Dead, the new AMC series, adapted from the comic books written by Robert Kirkman, about humans struggling to survive in a world overrun by flesh-eating ghouls. The first episode of the show, which had the good fortune to make its debut on Halloween night at 10 P.M., was watched by 5.3 million people, AMC said, making it the largest audience for any original series on the channel. (By comparison, the season finale of the AMC drama Mad Men, on which the dead do not reawaken and are simply made fodder for black comedy, drew 2.44 million viewers.) Not surprisingly, The Walking Dead performed particularly strongly with audience members aged 18 to 49, drawing 3.6 million viewers in that demographic. In a statement, AMC president Charlie Collier said, Its a good day to be dead, and well just leave it at that.

title: The Politics Game: Playing Midterm Election Bingo
description: Overview | How can students use news coverage to bolster their knowledge of the electoral process as well as their understanding of specific elections? In this lesson, students learn about the midterm elections by playing a game of Midterm Election Bingo. They then create their own election bingo games about historical elections or the electoral process.

title: NASAs Quest to Send a Robot to the Moon
description: For $150 billion, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration could have sent astronauts back to the Moon. The Obama administration judged that too expensive, and in September, Congress agreed to cancel the program.

title: Federal Appeals Court Weighs Arizona Law on Immigrants
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona and her team of lawyers defended the states strict new immigration law in a federal appeals court on Monday, facing a panel of three judges who sharply questioned the way the law would be carried out. Lawyers from the Justice Department argued that central parts of the state law were unconstitutional and would interfere with federal law enforcement.

title: Giants Championship History
description: The Giants franchise has won five World Series titles, but hasnt won a championship since 1954, when the team was still playing at the Polo Grounds in New York. A look at their previous World Series triumphs.

title: Fresh-Faced Agudelo Has the Red Bulls Smiling
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J.  The moment Juan Agudelo had been waiting for all his young life came Saturday night when he became the first player from the Red Bulls academy to start a game for the senior team in M.L.S.

title: The Spa Half-Hour
description: There was a time in the not-so-distant past when every big hotel needed a spa. Leisure travelers demanded it, and business travelers did, too  to reward themselves, their clients or their employees with lavish massage and steam-filled weekends in opulent settings.

title: Fed Is Poised to Aid Economy, but Impact Is Cloudy
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve is all but certain to move to spur the nations sputtering recovery this Wednesday, but most economists say it is unlikely to have a big impact on employment and growth.

title: In Cambodia, Clinton Advocates Khmer Rouge Trials
description: BANGKOK  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton visited a former Khmer Rouge torture house in Cambodia on Monday and urged the nation to proceed with trials of the former regimes surviving leaders in order to confront its past.

title: The Timing of Social Security
description: Several readers have objected to my assertion, in todays column, that Social Security was passed amid strong economic growth, rather than at the bottom of a recession. After all, wasnt the program created during the Great Depression? So it was  but not, crucially, during F.D.R.s first year in office, 1933, when the unemployment rate crested at 25 percent and economic growth was nowhere to be seen. Instead, the program was signed into law in August 1935, by which point the jobless rate was down to 20 percent and falling and the economy was growing at a brisk 8.9 percent clip, after growing by over 10 percent in 1934. By way of contrast, Barack Obama signed the health care bill in March of 2010, when unemployment had barely ticked down from its Great Recession high and G.D.P. growth was still anemic  as, indeed, it remains to this day. Of course it goes without saying that the overall economic situation was worse in the Depression. But Roosevelt could legitimately claim that the country had turned the corner (and, just as importantly, that the 1934 midterms had confirmed his political mandate) by the time he turned from economic policy to old-age entitlements. Obama, on the other hand, got his entitlement passed in the first 15 months of his administration  but one of the (many) reasons its been a harder sell than Social Security, I suspect, is that the country is still waiting for real growth to return.

A form of autism therapy has been shown in randomized trials to significantly improve I.Q., language and social skills in toddlers with autism, and researchers say it has even greater potential if it can be started earlier, reports todays Science Times.

title: Far Out | AVAF
description: Assume Vivid Astro Focus, the art collective spearheaded by the Brazilian-born, New York-based Eli Sudbrack and the Paris-based Christophe Hamaide Pierson, has gained notoriety for its happenings, videos and gallery-covering wall art created in a palette that ranges from psychedelic to incandescent. In keeping with their maximalist philosophy, the artists test our capacity for visual overload with AVAF, a new book from Rizzoli International that comes with a mask and poster no less, along with several thousand photographs, sketches and notes documenting artworks performed and installed at the Whitney and Athens biennials, Los Angeles MoCA, and Deitch Projects gallery. The Moment spoke with Sudbrack about the duos strobe-lit visions of utopia.

The music is neither symphonic nor dramatic but a sparsely orchestrated, cantata-like setting of three excerpts from Platos dialogues. It received a rare outing on Sunday afternoon at Zankel Hall, with James Levine conducting the Met Chamber Ensemble.

title: Election Day Q. and A.

Sure, we can see lots of colors during the day, but turn down the lights and, well, did you know that a large bucket of popcorn can accommodate an entire womans shoe without tipping over?

But if you werent, there may be help, from 3qubits, a mobile phone software company started by two Ph.D. mathematics student at Cambridge University in England. He might be running some, and walking some, a New York Road Runners spokesman said after the group heard from a Chilean consular official. This, he told a crowd that was sparse for a neighborhood that prides itself on political activism, is the most important election in my lifetime.

Those arent the same thing: Ben Bernanke isnt a dictator, and the evidence suggests that hed be substantially more aggressive in both his actions and his rhetoric if he werent constrained by the need to bring his colleagues with him.

description: Year in and year out, the New York Police Department proudly broadcasts its statistics for major crimes. And each year for more than a decade, its numbers have showed how reports of murder, rape, robbery, serious assault and theft have hit historic lows.

title: Harlem Learns Immortalizing Mays Isnt Easy
description: The last time the Giants won the World Series, Dwight D. Eisenhower was president, Elvis Presley was starting out and On the Waterfront won the best picture Oscar. The team also played in New York at the Polo Grounds, where Willie Mays roamed center field and lived so close that he could walk to the ballpark.

title: The Opt-Out Solution
description: Americans dont save enough. In 2005, Americans personal savings rate was negative for the first time since the Great Depression  instead of piling up savings, we are piling up debt. According to Financial Engines, an investment advisory firm that has surveyed the 401(k) retirement savings plans of 2.8 million people, only 28 percent of savers are on track to retire on 70 percent of our final salaries  and 70 percent may not be adequate to pay for health costs or travel. Worse, only one third of American workers participate in 401(k) savings plans at all.

title: 5 Reasons Democrats Could Beat the Polls and Hold the House
description: While our forecast and a good deal of polling data suggest that the Republicans may win the House of Representatives on Tuesday, perhaps all is not lost for the Democrats. Heres one possible scenario for how things might not end up as expected.

Given the importance of transparency in the markets, he asks, shouldnt something be done about these legal, if aggressive, maneuvers?

title: The Rehabilitation of a Champion
description: Meb Keflezighi awoke daily at 7:10 a.m. in Mammoth Lakes, Calif., this fall, stretched his quadriceps and abductors, did his squats and leg lifts, hoisted his three small, giggling daughters over his head for core strength and arrived early for his 8:30 team practice.

title: Rangers Owner Rips Yankees Fans, Then Apologizes
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  With the Cliff Lee free-agency sweepstakes set to begin, one of the Texas Rangers new owners launched a preemptive strike on Monday by criticizing Yankees fans for their violent and apathetic behavior during the American League Championship Series.

title: Religion and the Liberal State Once Again
description: Nothing gets the juices and the comments flowing better than a column on religion and the liberal state. But before attempting a response to the issues raised by readers of my previous column, I would like to offer a couple of clarifications.

title: East Timor Presidents Clemency Extends to His Attackers
description: GLENO, East Timor  Gasto Salsinha, retired rebel and failed assassin, says it is probably politics that explain why he is free to roam East Timors cloud-covered hinterlands rather than languish in prison.

title: As the Boardwalk Is Remade, 9 Fixtures Are Told to Leave
description: From behind the bar at Rubys, hard on the Boardwalk in Coney Island, Cindy Jacobs Allman commiserated with customers and other business owners slowly grasping that their livelihoods  as well as a familiar part of the citys landscape  would soon be gone.

title: Stability in West Bank Transforms a City of Chaos
description: NABLUS, West Bank  A mass wedding that took place here one recent balmy evening was the latest step toward the rebranding of this Palestinian city from a focus of chaos and violence to a model of stability in the West Bank.

title: Day After Speaking Out, Moss Is Waived by Vikings

title: Democrats Outspend G.O.P. in TV Ads in House Races

In Senate races, however, Republicans outspent Democrats.

title: Secretary General Ignores Pleas to Ask China to Free Nobel Peace Prize Winner
description: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon on Monday ignored pleas from human rights activists to ask President Hu Jintao of China to release from jail the new Nobel Peace Prize laureate, Liu Xiaobo. Despite Mr. Bans statements that he considers human rights a priority, his spokesman, Martin Nesirky, said the secretary general avoided the subject when he met the Chinese leader in Beijing. Mr. Ban, above, also did not congratulate Mr. Liu. As a permanent Security Council member, China can veto a second term as secretary general for Mr. Ban.

title: Turkey: Separatist Group Denies Link to Bombing Causing Panic in Istanbul
description: The separatist Kurdistan Workers Party, known as the P.K.K., denied Monday that it had any connection to Sundays bombing in central Istanbul that wounded 32 people and caused widespread panic. The bombing coincided with the end of a two-month cease-fire that the group had declared to clear the way for political talks in an effort to end its conflict with the Turkish government. In two statements to the Firat News Agency, the group disavowed the attacks, and then announced an extension of its unilateral cease-fire until the end of the 2011 general elections.

Now it is their turn.

title: Australia and India Raise Interest Rates

title: Republicans Are Clear Underdogs to Flip Senate
description: While Republicans retain a plausible path toward taking control of the Senate on Tuesday night, it would involve their winning at least two seats in which they appear to be underdogs, while simultaneously avoiding upsets in several other races in which they are narrowly favored. Unless the Republicans have a significant wind at their backs and are overperforming in most parts of the country, their chances of doing so are slim.

title: Texas: DeLay Trial Opens
description: Opening arguments began Monday in Austin in the trial of Tom DeLay, the former House majority leader, on state charges of money laundering, as prosecutors told a jury that Mr. DeLay had taken part in an illegal scheme to route $190,000 in corporate money to Republican candidates. A defense lawyer countered that none of the money was given directly to Texas politicians and asserted that Mr. DeLay was guilty only of being a better politician than his Democratic opponents. The contributions helped Republicans take over the Texas House in 2002, paving the way for the passage of a redistricting plan  designed by Mr. DeLay  that gave Republicans more control over the states Congressional delegation. In her opening statement, the prosecutor, Beverly Mathews, said: There is nothing wrong with Republicans trying to dominate the political world. But the means to achieve that gain must be lawful.

title: Colorado: Mine Expansion Is Denied
description: A federal judge has voided a permit for the expansion of an operating coal mine on the Navajo reservation, calling for a more thorough review of the projects impact on the environment and on cultural sites. In a decision issued Friday, the judge, John L. Kane of Federal District Court, ordered an agency of the Interior Department to reassess the permit. The agency granted the permit for the mining of 4,800 more acres at the Navajo Mine in 2005 after concluding that the proposal would have no significant environmental impact. Navajo Mine is operated by BHP Billiton.

title: Demi Lovato Leaves Tour for Rehab
description: Demi Lovato, the 18-year-old pop singer and Disney star, has withdrawn from a concert tour to check into a rehabilitation facility, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Lovato, a star of the Disney Channel series Sonny With a Chance and its popular Camp Rock television movies, and whose albums include Dont Forget and Here We Go Again, had been performing with the Jonas Brothers, another Disney act. But her representatives said in a statement she left the tour over the weekend to address emotional and physical issues. The statement added: Demi has decided to take personal responsibility for her actions and seek help. She is doing just that. Demi and her family ask that the media respect her privacy during this difficult time. The statement did not specify what treatment she was receiving or the location of the facility. In a 2009 interview with The New York Times, Ms. Lovato talked about her rapid ascent to fame, saying, Some days I get really excited, and some days I get scared because I feel like I have to live up to certain pressures.
