title: As Clinton Visits, Malaysia Promises Fair Trial for Dissident
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  The Malaysian government pledged Tuesday that the opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim would receive a fair trial on sodomy charges, a nod to Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clintons call for the case to be conducted transparently.

title: No Trumpeting of Low-Level Crime Data
description: Since the end of 2002, the New York Police Department has not made public its statistics on reports of lower-level crimes: a vast trove of complaints about matters like misdemeanor thefts and assaults, marijuana possession and sex offenses other than rape. The lack of data seems odd considering the departments heralding of historically low levels for major crimes like murder, rape, robbery, serious assault and theft, every year, especially when one considers that the New York Police Department is one of only two of the 500 police departments in New York State that do not make such data available. [NYT]

title: Pre-Mortem
description: Obviously, Democrats are going to do badly today, the only question being how badly. And well be drenched in punditry, most of it about how Obama overreached, etc..

title: Dealers Choice
description: In Switzerland, a sans-serif, politely modern, supersleek, always tidy, adamantly neutral country, where everything uniformly ticktocks, lock-step, you might begin to think each new building and interior were designed by the same architect. Switzerland even has a typeface  Helvetica  named after it (the country is also known as Confoederatio Helvetica), in which no letter steps out of line. But an eBay purchase led me to Zurich, where I found the serif, the dingbat and the curvy character, all in one: Arthur Rooks.

title: Focus Hocus Pocus
description: If theres one piece of conventional pundit wisdom that annoys me most, its the constant refrain that Obama was wrong to pursue health care, that he should have focused on the economy instead.

title: Pelosi Finds Inspiration in Giants World Series Win
description: With polls suggesting a tough Election Day for Democrats, the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, continues to find inspiration in the unlikely success of her hometown San Francisco Giants.

title: German Letter Bomb Is Found After Athens Blasts
description: BERLIN  A package bomb addressed to the German chancellor and shipped by air from Greece was found in her offices mailroom on Tuesday, even as Athens was shaken by a second day of letter bombs aimed at foreign embassies.

title: One by One, Saddam Husseins Aides Are Returning to Tikrit. In Coffins.
description: TIKRIT, Iraq  For years, this town served as the well from which Saddam Hussein drew many of his closest aides. One by one, they are now returning, after meeting their ends in jail cells or on the gallows.

title: Other Departures at Tribune Company in Wake of Randy Michaels Resignation
description: When Randy Michaels, the embattled chief executive of Tribune Company, resigned on Oct. 22, many employees wondered what would become of many longtime associates he brought in from his days in radio at Clear Channel. That question was answered, at least in part, on Monday when several executives with ties to Mr. Michaels announced that they would be leaving as well.

title: Och-Ziff Posts Gains as Assets Rise
description: The Och-Ziff Capital Management Group, the hedge fund manager run by Daniel S. Och, reported quarterly distributable earnings of $52.1 million, up from $32.4 million in the period a year earlier, on higher fee income resulting from net inflows.

title: Critics Picks Video: Please Vote for Me
description: This week A. O. Scott looks back at the 2007 documentary Please Vote for Me, about three students in a cutthroat election for third-grade class monitor at an elementary school in China.

title: Police in Russia Raid Bank of Billionaire
description: MOSCOW  Masked police officers armed with automatic weapons conducted a raid on Tuesday of a bank belonging to the billionaire Aleksandr Y. Lebedev, who owns Russias pre-eminent opposition newspaper and two London-based newspapers, The Evening Standard and The Independent.

title: Math Rage
description: A number of my recent blog posts have involved pointing out adding-up constraints: you cant have some people spending less than their income unless others spend more than their income, all the worlds currencies cant devalue against each other, etc..

title: Republicans Will Win More Governorships (But Democrats Could Get More Votes)
description: Of the 37 governors races on Tuesdays ballot, only 12 are in much degree of doubt. Democrats should win the races in New York and Arkansas and  barring abnormally bad polling  also those in California, New Hampshire and Maryland.

title: G.O.P. Captures House, but Not Senate
description: Republicans captured control of the House of Representatives on Tuesday and expanded their voice in the Senate, riding a wave of voter discontent as they dealt a setback to President Obama just two years after his triumphal victory.

title: Rising Seas and the Groundwater Equation
description: Worldwide overpumping of groundwater, particularly in northern India, Iran, Mexico, northeastern China and the American West, more than doubled from 1960 to 2000 and is responsible for about 25 percent of the rise in sea level, according to estimates in a new study by a team of Dutch researchers published in Geophysical Review Letters.

title: Delphi and WiTricity Developing Wireless Electric Car Charger
description: The auto supplier Delphi and a partner, the WiTricity Corporation, are developing a hands-free charging technology to transfer electricity over short distances without physical contact.

title: Normal Heart Looking Likely for Broadway
description: Last months one-night-only reading of Larry Kramers play The Normal Heart on Broadway is poised to return as a full production in the spring, Mr. Kramer and the theater producer Daryl Roth said in interviews on Monday, with Joe Mantello on track to reprise his performance at the reading as Ned Weeks.

title: Liberals and Buckley Nostalgia
description: In the course of a denunciation of conservative writers (starting with yours truly, and this column in particular) for expressing even the remotest sort of sympathy toward the thuggish, Bircher, conspiracist, head-stomping, racist-tolerant Tea Partiers, Ron Rosenbaum indulges in a common liberal fallacy:

title: Is Obama a Keynesian?
description: Noneconomists weigh in:

title: Voters Encounter Scattered Problems
description: Updated, 5:45 p.m. | New Yorkers using the new computerized voting system seemed to encounter fewer problems on Tuesday than they did during the September primary, when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg complained of a royal screw-up by the citys Board of Elections.

title: Tuesday Reading: The Cost of Wasted Food
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: The Mumbai Consensus
description: A people-centric approach to economic policy.

title: Why Retire Zenyatta?
description: Zenyatta is a perfect 19 and 0. On Saturday she will attempt to win her 20th race and continue her march to history. I dont think anyone, bar the connections of each of her foes on Saturday, will be rooting against her. And if Bob Baffert is correct, even those with horses in the race will start rooting for her when she overtakes their horse.

title: Well Rounded
description: The project that put the Bouroullec brothers, Ronan and Erwan, on the map in 1997 was their Disintegrated Kitchen. Now the design duo from Brittany aims to stock your kitchen with a new series of stoneware, glass and stainless steel dinnerware and serving pieces designed for the Italian manufacturer Alessi. The Ovale collection plays with multiple variations on a slightly asymmetrical, rectangular silhouette with rounded corners. This sounds simple enough, but the Bouroullecs delicate balance between whimsy and refinement will make even the biggest design snob smile. The reasonably priced collection (from $14 for the smallest mocha cup to $275 for the elegant stainless steel ice bucket) will be in stores just in time for the holidays  hint, hint.[?][?][?]ANDREAS KOKKINO

title: 'Don Pasquale'
description: The soprano Anna Netrebko in an excerpt from a performance at the Metropolitan Opera. (Video courtesy of the production)

title: T.I. Returns to Prison
description: The rapper T.I. reported to a federal prison in Arkansas on Monday, less than a year after he was released, to begin serving an 11-month sentence for violating his probation, The Associated Press reported.

title: Corona, Queens, 5:07 A.M.
description: Deyjauneh Billups, a poll worker from Corona, Queens, enters the polling station at Louis Armstrong Elementary School, Public School 143, blocks from her home. Ms. Billups, 21, a student at LaGuardia Community College, was one of many college students recruited by LaGuardia in an effort to build civic awareness and involvement, while at the same time helping voters by placing tech-savvy students in polling sites. LaGuardia officials received a grant from the United States Election Assistance Commission to recruit the students.

title: Flowering Inferno
description: When Prince George received his mother, Queen Mary, for lunch, Constance Spry, who did his flower arrangements, deployed carnations, her bte noir, in conventional containers, which she loathed. But when the queen wasnt around, the flowers were more likely to be kale and lichen-crusted branches massed in serving pieces that Spry raided, to the amusement of her royal client, from his Meissen dinner set.

title: Running Boom Fuels Two Top Races One Week Apart
description: For more than a quarter-century, the glitzy and glamorous New York City Marathon, with its elite roster of runners and metropolitan majesty, has managed to coexist comfortably with the gritty and ground pounding Marine Corps Marathon, held just a week earlier.

title: Japans Auto Parts Makers Try to Anticipate Shift to Electric Cars
description: HAMAMATSU, Japan  People here refer to it as electric vehicle shock.

title: In Food Waste, an Environmental Toll
description: One-quarter to one-half of all food produced in the United States is wasted, our colleague Tara Parker-Pope reports at the Well blog. And much of that perfectly good food is evidently tossed away in the home.

title: Gear Giveaway Ruled Out for McMahon Voters
description: Like one of those wrestling matches that always seems to be ready to end until a seemingly vanquished wrestler gets off the mat to fight again, the curious collision of wrestling gear and Connecticut voting took one more turn Monday.

title: The President Plans a Post-Mortem
description: President Obama plans to talk about the results of Tuesdays elections at a news conference Wednesday afternoon in the East Room of the White House, his staff announced.

title: The Case Against Predictions
description: I was all set to offer my airtight, foolproof predictions for tonights glorious restoration of the American Republic/triumph of hatred and anger over sanity and sweet reason, but then I read Jonah Lehrers column on the research of one Philip Tetlock, a Berkeley psychologist who noted, in the mid-1980s, that pundits predictions often seemed wildly off the mark. Like any good social scientist, he decided to quantify their failures:

title: Keeping Score: How Good Was the Pitching in the Postseason?
description: For all the commentary in the regular season that this was the year of the pitcher, I expected to be disappointed by the pitching in the postseason. Rarely do postseasons play out according to the expected narrative, but if anything, the pitching of this postseason exceeded expectations.

title: Champions League: Too Many Players Missing Too Much Soccer
description: Ahead of the World Cup last summer, we reported on the number of injuries  serious and niggling  that plagued players who endured scores of games during the long league and cup seasons in Europe. Today, a full seven weeks before many European leagues will take a holiday break, fixture congestion has caught up with a number of players who will miss Champions League games this week.

title: By Honoring Their Past, the Giants Were Duly Rewarded
description: Karma counts. This is a lesson everybody needs to remember. Honor the past, because it is still out there.

title: At Marathon, the President of Mile 8
description: Every year on the same Sunday at 10:15 a.m., Michele Randall-Williams stands on Fourth Avenue between Dean and Pacific Streets in Brooklyn and prepares for the world to rush by.

title: Astoria, Queens, 6:20 A.M.
description: At Public School 17, in Astoria, Queens, a scanner inspector, Rosemary Alvarez, 27, tried to help Donald P. Kernan Jr., who had filled out the ballot incorrectly. But Mr. Kernan became frustrated, and he left without voting.

title: A Pioneer in Green Business is Fired
description: .Seventh Generation, one of the first businesses built around the needs of green consumers, has fired a co-founder, Jeffrey Hollender.

title: In Ratings Game, Football Beats Baseball
description: Richard Sandomir posed the question on a blog post here last week: Can Saints-Steelers Outdraw Game 4 Sunday Night?

title: Outside Looking In
description: Introduction: A Bookworm's Confession

title: Engagements With History Punctuate a Lifetime in Books
description: Square, colorless, stodgy, unthreatening. Those are some of the adjectives that the prolific journalist and historian Garry Wills uses to describe himself in Outside Looking In, his pointillistic new memoir.

title: Immigrant Job Gains, Native-Born Job Losses
description: Weve written before about the two-track economy emerging in the United States. One dividing line between the two tracks, it seems, may be immigration status: In the year after the official end of the most recent recession, native-born workers lost 1.2 million jobs while foreign-born workers gained 656,000 jobs, according to a new analysis of government data by the Pew Hispanic Center.

title: Rose Catherine Finds Footing on the Grass
description: The Breeders Cup Turf Sprint is a baby, compared to the Breeders Cup races that have been run since 1984, the year of the events inception. This year, the race is three years old, just like one of the fillies that will be contesting it.

title: Quote Unquote | Faux Modesty
description: Alber Elbaz tells Vogue UK about his collaboration with H&M. Dont worry, Alber, I am sure you can get honorary membership.

title: The N.H.L. Halloween Party: Watch Your Candy at All Times
description: The N.H.L. took a rare night off on Sunday, one of the only nights of the season without a single game. Apparently that was no accident.

title: All the Good Dogs Youve Loved Before
description: As I get older, and especially since I learned two years ago that I had an aggressive prostate cancer, I linger even longer and more lovingly over the past. But Im not just tugged at by the satisfactions of mere nostalgia. In following those lonely and haunted dirt roads back to my childhood, Im on a quest to try to understand the adult Ive become.

title: Inflation: An Important Clarification
description: Just to be clear: when I say that a period of higher inflation would help the economy, it proves that Im an immoral totalitarian leftist. When the former chairman of the Bush Council of Economic Advisers says the same thing, its perfectly reasonable economics.

title: A Secondary Market for Group Deals
description: Sites offering group deals like Groupon and Living Social seem relatively new. But a secondary market for the deals has already popped up.

title: Oracle Strikes in Search for Niche Software Makers
description: Six weeks ago, Oracles chief executive, Larry Ellison, said that his deal-happy company planned to set its sights on software makers that cater to specific industries. It found one on Tuesday.

title: Holocaust Film Shoah Will Have New Release in December
description: Claude Lanzmanns epic Holocaust documentary, Shoah, will receive a new release to mark its 25th anniversary, using two 35 mm prints of the film that will be shown at Lincoln Plaza Cinemas and the IFC Center in December, IFC Films said on Tuesday.

title: A Night for the Misfits
description: It was a night for the misfits, a bunch of guys you hadnt heard of until recently, bouncing across your television screen Monday night. The Giants literally bounced upon winning San Franciscos first World Series, a fun-loving cast of characters that included rookies, castoffs, retreads and waiver wire pickups.

title: Jihadist Economics
description: From comments, Just John says:

title: The Artists and Oddballs Under a Tent
description: Dont think of it as spending six hours at the circus, a brain-numbing prospect for some grown-ups. Think of it as investing six hours in an elegant eavesdrop-on-our-family reality show that puts all the noisy, obnoxious examples of that genre to shame.

title: What Were Reading: When Youre Most Likely to Get Dumped
End-of-Life Care for Patients With Advanced Dementia
description: Its hard for physicians to determine with much precision how long anyone with a terminal disease can expect to live, but its particularly challenging when the disease is advanced dementia.

title: Honda Chief: There Will Be a Market for Electric Vehicles
description: Its starting to look like there will be a market for electric vehicles, said Takanobu Ito, the chief executive of Honda, according to Reuters.

title: An 80-Year Run for Nuclear Reactors?
description: With the so-called nuclear renaissance looking smaller and slower than predicted, some in the nuclear industry are focusing on running existing plants longer  not only for their initial 40-year licensing period and the 20-year extension already allowed, but for a second 20-year extension.

title: Davis Not Feeling the Burn, but Clippers Do
description: Clippers point guard Baron Davis is known for being a bon vivant. Hes a fixture on the Hollywood scene, thanks to his numerous friendships with actors and musicians. Hes also charismatic on the court.

title: Election Day: Answers From Michael D. Shear
description: 5:26 p.m. | Updated With this years head-scratcher of an election, there are often more questions than answers. But Michael D. Shear, The Caucuss lead writer, will try to balance it out. He is answering select reader questions about Tuesdays elections, the Tea Party movement, President Obama and more.

title: TimesCast | November 2, 2010
description: Voter mood on Election Day; a look at the anticipated Republican swing and taking in the results on multiple screens.

title: Olbermann Shelves Worst Persons in the World
description: Keith Olbermann, the top anchor on MSNBC, is shelving his daily segment Worst Persons in the World, and says he is thinking about ending it permanently.

title: The Morning Line: Waiting for the Main Breeders Cup Act
description: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

title: Vain Glorious | Dr. Perricones Super New Line
description: What: Super, a new botanically based skin-care line from Dr. Nicholas Perricone.

title: Men Will Pause for a Cause, Survey Suggests
description: For many years, the assumption on Madison Avenue has been that cause marketing  doing well (selling products) by doing good (helping causes that matter to consumers)  plays more strongly with women than men. That may not be the case, according to a new survey.

title: Capturing Albanys Political Theater
description: On the Lens blog today, as we await news from the polls, were reading a compelling interview with Nat Brooks, a photographer who covers Albany for The New York Times, and browsing an 18-image slide show of Mr. Brooks political photography from the past several years. More on Lens.

title: 5 Options for Congress to Cut Taxes
description: WASHINGTON  The Bush tax cuts expire in 58 days.

title: Trove of Gershwin Materials Moving to Library of Congress
description: A large archive of material related to the songwriting team of George and Ira Gershwin will be moved from San Francisco to the Library of Congress, The Los Angeles Times reported. Before Ira Gershwins widow, Leonore, died in 1991, she said that she wanted the archive eventually to go to the national library, but her will allowed for her nephew, Michael Strunsky, to keep it in California for as long as he wanted first.

title: Derivatives Still Special After Overhaul
description: Stephen J. Lubben writes about bankruptcy and debt issues for DealBook.

title: An Overlooked Tax Increase
description: Roberton Williams of the Tax Policy Center makes a good point. Why arent we paying more attention to the tax increase that is coming at the end of the year when certain stimulus provisions expire?:

title: A Midterm Revolution?
description: Well, the day everybody (except probably Nancy Pelosi) has been eagerly awaiting is upon us, and The Thread will have breaking coverage of the midterm elections all afternoon and evening.

title: Bucks: A Secondary Market for Group Deals
description: A secondary market for the group deals offered on sites like Groupon and Living Social has already popped up, reports Jennifer Saranow Schultz on the Bucks Blog.

title: Airgas Open to a Deal, at $78 a Share
description: The long and winding takeover battle over Airgas took a new turn on Tuesday as the company told its unwanted suitor, Air Products and Chemicals, that its willing to hold talks over a deal.

title: American Speech: Lingo of the Shoe Salesman (1934)
description: by David Geller

title: TimesCast: Finally, Election Day
description: Tuesdays TimesCast is all Election Day: voter mood, a look at the anticipated Republican swing and a variety of ways to take in all the results.

title: Tasting Mourvedre Wines
description: In researching wines made from the mourvedre grape, the subject of my column, I repeatedly ran across the assertion that mourvedre was newly fashionable. I found very little evidence of this.

title: MTV Apologizes to Glaad for Jersey Shore Segment
description: Though there are a great many things that the cast and producers of Jersey Shore should have to say theyre sorry for, the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation has received an apology from MTV for a recent episode of that series that included what the alliance called one of the most blatantly transphobic scenes aired anywhere on television in the last few years.

title: Case Study | Underpinnings
description: What do bartenders, policemen and servicemen have in common, aside from a general shared fondness for the restorative powers of a good drink? Would you believe shirt garters? Whats that?

title: Sutherland and Patric Join a Starry Team for That Championship Season
description: The actors Kiefer Sutherland and Jason Patric will play the brothers James and Tom Daley this spring in the first Broadway revival of That Championship Season, the 1973 Pulitzer Prize-winning play about friendship, regrets, and basketball, the producers announced on Tuesday. Brian Cox, Jim Gaffigan, and Chris Noth will round out the ensemble cast, under the direction of Gregory Mosher (last seasons A View from the Bridge).

title: Borne Back Ceaselessly to His Long Show
description: F. Scott Fitzgerald fans who beat back to the Public Theater for a second viewing of Gatz, the nearly seven-hour coup de thtre reading of The Great Gatsby, might assume that the man who is there again too, usually by himself in the last row and often with an iPad, must be one of them.

title: Second Trial Ends for Russian Oil Tycoon
description: MOSCOW  The second trial of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky adjourned here on Tuesday to await the judges verdict, which the jailed former oil tycoon said would be a test of Russias commitment to the rule of law, even as he expressed little hope of being cleared and spared another decade or more in prison.

title: Coordinated Bombings Strike Across Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  Insurgents unleashed attacks across Baghdad on Tuesday night, setting off more than a dozen coordinated bombs in a bloody declaration of their ability to thwart the governments efforts to secure Iraqs largest and most important city.

title: Ford Fiesta R2 Rally Kit: Convert Your Compact Into a Racecar
description: Though Ford has positioned its Fiesta subcompact as the quintessential urban runabout, the brands racing division sees the car suited to more rugged duty.

title: French Doctor Arrested on Insider Trading Charges
description: By THOMAS KAPLAN

title: Transit Court to Provide Interpreters by Phone
description: New York Citys transit court, where subway scofflaws are summoned to address charges of fare beating, littering and other minor crimes, can be confusing from the get-go, with its deli-style ticketing system and claustrophobic hearing rooms.

title: Battle of the Butchers
description: It was hardly a World Wrestling Federation smackdown. But there was enough of a red-meat frenzy to excite a fiercely appreciative audience of aficionados.

title: Justices Debate Video Game Ban
description: WASHINGTON  In a lively and sometimes testy Supreme Court argument on Tuesday over a law banning the sale of violent video games to minors, the justices struggled to define how the First Amendment should apply to a new medium.

title: Merely Affluent vs. Truly Rich
description: Most people know that the top income tax rates used to be much higher than they now are. Whats much less known is that the top brackets started at much higher income levels than todays top brackets do. In other words, the tax code used to draw sharper distinctions between the merely affluent and the truly rich.

title: Spill Cleanup Proceeds Amid Mistrust
description: SOUTHWEST PASS, La.  A couple of weeks ago, enormous orange-brownish strings of something were seen floating out here in the open water near the mouth of the Mississippi.

title: Evil Personified
description: Via Media Matters, Andrew Breitbart has identified the new Axis of Evil, the power base of the left:

title: Thank You, India
description: Who needs to travel to unravel the mysteries of the world? The designers Anupama Sukh Lalvani and Sonal Sood bring a little bit of India to the Upper East Side with the debut of their En Inde line, a collection of intricately woven neckpieces made from organic wood, shell, silver and steel. Accented with precious metals and stones, the pieces (from $195) include necklaces, rings, earrings, bracelets and jeweled purses. Available at Soigne K boutique, 717 Madison Avenue; (212) 486-2890.

title: Facebooks Initial Crew Moving On
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Facebook, the most successful start-up of the last decade, is only six years old, and an initial public offering is still a way off.

title: Referees Voice in the Broadcast Booth
description: Stadium booths, sidelines and studios are packed with former players, managers and coaches, some blathering with more intelligence than others. But where are the former referees and umpires who can make the sort of quick, informed judgments that can give broadcasts something fresh?

title: Im a Loner, Dottie, a Wrestler: Pee-wee at the Mat
description: Like an ancient proverb says: May you live in interesting times, or at least long enough to see Pee-wee Herman as a guest on the WWE Raw wrestling program.

title: TimesCast | The Republican Wave
description: There is an expected Republican wave in the House, but by how much?

title: Vegetarian Comfort Food at Thanksgiving
description: The traditional Thanksgiving table is filled with comfort foods like cheesy casseroles, creamy potatoes and marshmallow-topped sweet potatoes. But the cookbook authors Bruce Weinstein and Mark Scarbrough offer a new spin on traditional comfort foods by packing them with fall vegetables.

title: In Waikiki, Fears That Construction Will Spoil Beach
description: In the public imagination, Waikiki Beach is a pristine strip of sand bracketed by coconut trees and outrigger canoes.

title: Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, 12:46 P.M.
description: Talibah Newman, with her 10-month-old niece Noa Miles, casting her vote at Public School 22 in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn.

title: TimesCast | Voter Mood in Ohio
description: At the polls in Columbus, Ohio, on Tuesday, voters were motivated by a sense of responsibility, not anger.

title: Yiddish Troupers Showbiz Scrapbook
description: At 88, Fyvush Finkel is jauntily shuffling down memory lane, from Shakespeares Venice to the heyday of Second Avenue theater, as the star of the warmhearted new show opening the 96th consecutive season of the National Yiddish Theater  Folksbiene.

title: Literary Tree-Spotting
description: The fall book season is shaping up to be particularly good for books with an arboreal bent. Among the notable titles is a 30th-anniversary edition of The Tree, by John Fowles, which the Book Reviews Jennifer Schuessler calls a hard-to-summarize meditation on art, nature, individualism and mortality  sort of a cross between Thoreaus Walden and John Bergers Ways of Seeing, with a dash of The Gift, Lewis Hydes cult-classic manifesto on creativity, thrown in for good measure.

title: Literary Tree-Spotting
description: The fall book season is shaping up to be particularly good for books with an arboreal bent. Among the notable titles is a 30th-anniversary edition of The Tree, by John Fowles, which the Book Reviews Jennifer Schuessler calls a hard-to-summarize meditation on art, nature, individualism and mortality  sort of a cross between Thoreaus Walden and John Bergers Ways of Seeing, with a dash of The Gift, Lewis Hydes cult-classic manifesto on creativity, thrown in for good measure.

title: Voters Turn Out for Midterm Elections
description: The fate of the Democratic Congress was put before voters Tuesday in midterm elections that drew Americans to balloting stations starting before dawn.

title: A New Ace for a New Era
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  He is not Curt Schilling, filled with burly bombast, or Josh Beckett, a gruff and scruffy Texan. He is not Bob Gibson, a snarling intimidator, or Jack Morris, a mustachioed gunslinger straight from the Old West.

title: Debris Falls at Garden, Postponing Knicks Game
description: Asbestos concerns set off by fallen debris at Madison Square Garden forced the postponement of the Knicks game Tuesday night and put the self-proclaimed Worlds Most Famous Arena in a state of limbo.

title: The Morning Skate: Blues Chemistry, Stamkoss Star and Nashs Minus
description: The Blues are off to a strong start, earning 14 of a possible 18 points and are the only N.H.L. team with as few as one loss in regulation. They are undefeated in five home games, a big reversal from last season when they were .500 on home ice. Theyve won four straight, gotten three of four points in games against the Blackhawks, and have played like the team many thought theyd be last season, but werent.

title: Tensions Run High, and Quirks Run Wild
description: Perfect Harmony, a stage comedy about high school singers, first turned up at the New York International Fringe Festival in August 2006, in the midst of the High School Musical mania that Disney had set off that January.

title: Blogging History: Interpreting Civil War-Era Primary Sources
description: Overview | In this lesson, students examine the new Times Opinionator series Disunion, which follows the Civil War as it unfolded. They then analyze Civil War-era primary sources to use as writing prompts for their own contributions to a Civil War blog.

title: When Print Isnt Plentiful, the Futures Not So Fun
description: Why are there so many fonts? Is a font a kind of language, a work of art or both? What does the ubiquity of Times New Roman say about us as a culture? Such questions rattle through your mind during the happily long history lesson about typography at the start of Jordan Harrisons Futura, a thought-provoking drama that does not live up to its potential.

title: The Library
description: Other e-book readers pale in comparison to the Amazon Kindle.

title: Idaho Court Punts on Oil Shipments
description: Efforts to block shipments of giant oil processing equipment along a historic stretch of Highway 12 in Idaho, which I wrote about two weeks ago, were dealt a blow by the state Supreme Court there on Monday  or so it would seem.

title: Going Heavy With the Garlic
description: How much garlic is too much?

title: The Heated Debate Over Proxy Access
description: Proxy access is a hotly debated topic. Advocates contend that loosening the limits on proxy access will empower shareholders, heighten board accountability, restore shareholder confidence and result in more economically run public corporations. Detractors refute these propositions and assert that proxy access is a Potemkin village that will pre-empt state law, enable special-interest shareholders to hold up companies and otherwise provide corporations with few of the benefits that its proponents argue, other than increased costs to comply with new regulations.

title: Interest Checking for Small Businesses?
description: A little-known amendment to the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act could reshape the way small businesses bank. The amendment, added in the House of Representatives with no debate, repeals a law that prohibited financial institutions from paying interest on business checking accounts, which are known as demand deposit accounts. The prohibition had been part of the Glass-Steagall Act and was in force for nearly 70 years.

title: In Waiting for Superman, a Scene Isnt What It Seems
description: One of the many affecting scenes in the documentary Waiting for Superman shows a mother on a personal tour of a high-performing Harlem charter school she wants her son to attend. She looks with perceptible longing at baskets of books and welcoming classrooms, and says Wow when told how children struggling with reading, like her first grader, Francisco, receive tutoring.

title: Election Night Viewing Guide
description: As you buckle in for tonight, here is FiveThirtyEights hour-by-hour, district-by-district guide for watching the election returns, updated with our latest House forecast.

title: In the Seychelles, Open Air and Ocean Views

title: Now in the Mix | Nomia
description: A cool (and stunning) 5 foot 11, Yara Flinn is readily mistaken for a runway clothes hanger. But if the Brooklynite designer appears on the catwalk, its to take a bow at the end of her show. Not that she isnt her own best model. Now only in her second season and with her first runway show under her belt, Flinn is clearly looking at her own downtown style for inspiration. Im always thinking of comfort  physical or psychological  its about the great fabrics like stretch silk, she says. Translation: no-brainer, well-made pieces like slouchy jumpsuits, cropped crepe tees and ombre chiffon sash dresses. And, at prices ranging from $150 to $500 a girl could easily go all out. I never usually wear a complete Nomia look, the 27-year-old designer insists. Ill incorporate an American Apparel or Salvation Army T-shirt to my wool and mesh leggings and biker jacket with a pair of vintage roper boots from Capezio. Her do try this at home advice: just add some pieces from Uniqlo (their jeans have a great fit and dont stretch out), Metropolis Apparel (43 Third Avenue) and Beacons Closet (88 North 11th Street, Brooklyn).

title: A Water Bottle That Filters as You Drink
description: Before that 26.2-mile run or a simpler jog around the park, runners might want to add this Bobble reusable water bottle to their equipment. Its made from recycled plastic and has a built-in charcoal filter. After an initial rinse, to flush out charcoal particles, the bottle, which can be squeezed and has a squirting top and snap-in cover, can be reused, but should be washed regularly. It was created by the industrial designer Karim Rashid. The manufacturer says that the plastic complies with federal consumer standards for reuse, and that it is free of BPA, PVC and phthalates.

title: Selling Salts of Many Colors and Shapes
description: Jennifer and Mark Bitterman opened the Meadow, a shop with a narrow yet broad inventory in Portland, Ore., four and a half years ago. Narrow because they specialized in salt, chocolate, wine and flowers. Broad because they carry more than 100 kinds of salt and close to 400 different chocolates, mostly in bars.

title: Armenian Walnuts, Steeped in Syrup
description: They look like black olives, but they are whole walnuts, picked green in the Ararat Valley of Armenia, and steeped in sugar syrup until they turn lush, sweet, tender and irresistible, a little like marrons glacs, only moister. They are made by Harvest Song, a company that specializes in excellent Armenian preserves. The walnuts are a perfect foil for pungent cheeses, pt or roast duck or game. You can also nibble them after dinner or slice them to decorate pumpkin pie. And that manhattan? Drop a preserved walnut in the glass instead of a maraschino cherry.

title: Dancing Stars Beat World Series Winners
description: Dancing With the Stars outdrew the final game of the World Series in the ratings on Monday night as 19.6 million viewers watched the ABC reality show, according to Nielsens estimates. The two-hour installment of the dancing competition, which celebrated its 200th episode by bringing back dozens of former contestants, boosted ABC to No. 1 on the night. Fox ranked second over all with its World Series coverage, which drew slightly higher preliminary overnight ratings than Game 4 on Sunday. Final ratings for that game showed an average of 15.5 million viewers tuned in. CBS placed third on the night, and NBC was fourth.

title: Dosa Garden
description: THERE are plenty of reasons to dine on Staten Island: atmospheric, old-school Italian and German joints; stellar pizza; an intriguing range of Mexican foods; the citys best Sri Lankan; and, since last year, Dosa Garden, a South Indian restaurant in the Tompkinsville neighborhood, a short cab ride up Victory Boulevard from the ferry terminal. Its talented chef and owner, Karuppiah Chinniah, hails from Chettinad in the southern state of Tamil Nadu, an area known for its intricately spiced dishes, many of them nonvegetarian. Unlike many of the citys other South Indian menus, half of Dosa Gardens is dedicated to meat.

title: Smallest College Endowments Perform Best, Study Finds
description: College endowments returned an average of 12.6 percent in fiscal 2010  and, unusually, the smallest endowments performed better than the largest ones, according to preliminary data from 80 colleges and universities gathered for the comprehensive Nacubo-Commonfund Study of Endowments to be released in January. According to the data, institutions with assets under $25 million had an average return of 14.1 percent, compared with 12.3 percent for those with assets over $1 billion. Smaller endowments tend to be invested more than larger ones in traditional assets such as domestic equities, which performed well in the rebound from the previous years sell-off, and fixed income, which benefited from declining interest rates. The institutions spent an average of 4.3 percent of their endowment in fiscal 2010, and on average, annual giving paid for 6.2 percent of their operating budgets.

title: Israel: Defying Ban, Palestinians Renovate East Jerusalem Schools
description: Prime Minister Salam Fayyad of the Palestinian Authority said Tuesday that the authority had helped renovate 14 schools in East Jerusalem, in defiance of Israeli claims of sovereignty over the area and its ban on Palestinian political activity there. He went to a school in Dahyiat al Barid, on Jerusalems outskirts, to dedicate a section the authority had helped renovate, but Israel barred him from entering a refugee camp within the municipal boundaries for another ceremony. He said at the dedication that it did not matter if he was stopped. We are translating steadfastness into facts on the ground, he said. The Palestinians hope to make East Jerusalem the capital of their future state.

title: Vikings Ills Run Deeper Than Moss
description: It took Brad Childress and Randy Moss exactly four weeks to find out that every negative thing they had heard about one another was true. title: Belgium: Archbishops Aide Resigns
description: The spokesman for the head of the Roman Catholic Church in Belgium, Archbishop Andr-Joseph Lonard, quit Tuesday, saying he could no longer speak for a man who had spoken harshly of AIDS and homosexuality and sympathized with some pedophile priests. The resignation of the spokesman, Jrgen Mettepenningen, 35, came just days after the archbishop promised to keep silent on the sexual-abuse scandal in the Belgian church until at least Christmas. Mr. Mettepenningen said the archbishop was out of touch with Belgian Catholics, adding, At times, he behaved like a loose cannon who thinks everybody else is wrong.

I relayed some luxe details Id read: like, it is a source for Jean Claude Jitrois and Alexis Mabille, hard-to-find labels in this country. The owner, a woman of goodly fortune, was splashing out on wild extras like engraved black plexiglass shopping bags and customer car service via private Bentley.

title: Niger: Voters Approve New Charter
description: Voters in a referendum accepted a new constitution that will limit presidential powers and begin a return to civilian rule. The electoral commission said Tuesday that turnout on Sunday was a record 53 percent and that 90 percent of voters favored the constitution. Among other provisions, the document would re-establish a limit of two five-year presidential terms, which was thrown out by in August 2009 by President Mamadou Tandja. He was ousted in a military coup in February.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The Election Day polls were based on questionnaires completed by voters as they left voting places on Tuesday throughout the country.

title: Independents Fueled G.O.P Gains
description: Democrats lost significant support Tuesday among nearly all demographic groups in a midterm election that was a referendum on President Obama and a Democratic-controlled Congress in a stubbornly weak economy.

title: In Republican Victories, Tide Turns Starkly
description: Somewhere along the way, the apostle of change became its target, engulfed by the same currents that swept him to the White House two years ago. Now, President Obama must find a way to recalibrate with nothing less than his presidency on the line.

title: Rubio Continues Quick Rise in G.O.P. With Win in Florida Senate Race
description: CORAL GABLES, Fla.  Jeb Bush said he had to fight back tears when he introduced the victor in the Florida Senate race, Marco Rubio, the right man at the right time. Mr. Rubio, when he took the stage amid the palm trees at the Biltmore Hotel, in front of a mostly bilingual crowd, was no less emotional  about his uphill battle to defeat a popular governor, and about what he described as his abiding faith in the dream lived out by his immigrant parents.

title: Wednesday: Many a Little League Rooter
description: With todays theme, some entries went in quickly while others needed to be pieced together.

title: A Victorious Paul Vows to Stick to Message
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ky.  From the earliest days of his campaign, even before his Republican primary victory that shook up the Kentucky political establishment, Rand Paul has pledged not to compromise. And that was the message he returned to on Tuesday night as he celebrated a Senate victory over his Democratic opponent, Jack Conway, the state attorney general.

title: G.O.P. Makes Gains Toward Narrowing the Gap in the Senate
description: Republicans improved their lot in the Senate on Tuesday but were foiled by Democrats in a few key states with a high number of independent voters in their bid to capture both houses of Congress.

title: The Senate Races
description: Republicans improved their lot in the Senate but were foiled by Democrats in a few key states.

title: Election 2010
description: Voters in Tuesdays elections sent President Obama a loud message: They dont like how hes doing his job, theyre even angrier at Congressional Democrats and they gave the House back to the Republicans. The Republicans spent months fanning Americans anger over the economy and fear of big government, while offering few ideas of their own. Exit polls indicated that they had succeeded in turning out their base, and that the Democrats had failed to rally their own.

title: In House Victories, Republicans Oust Old and New Democrats Alike
description: Republicans captured the House Tuesday by ousting powerful Democratic committee chairmen as well as newcomers who faced a voter backlash after supporting an aggressive Democratic legislative agenda for the past two years.

title: Election Night Live | Opinion 9:45pm ET
description: The Times's David Shipley and Charles M. Blow discuss the quantitative side of this election.

title: Major Technical Difficulties
description: Behind closed doors in Washington, American officials are shaping an overhaul of the 1994 federal statute that requires phone and broadband carriers to ensure their networks can be wiretapped.

title: Mr. Ban Pulls His Punches
description: In a meeting with President Hu Jintao of China in Beijing on Monday, the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, discussed climate change and efforts to ease tensions on the Korean peninsula. Mr. Ban also nudged China to play a greater role in peacekeeping and in finding political solutions to conflicts in Sudan and Somalia.

title: They Really Are Giants
description: Lets remember this later when we are locked in to professional football and the gloom of winter. Lets remember it when rich baseball teams go on their off-season spending binges, packing the payroll with talent for their annual open-checkbook march to the playoffs.

title: Katrinas Unfinished Business
description: New Orleans is finally rebounding from much of the devastation wrought by Hurricane Katrina. But five years later, a big problem remains: blighted neighborhoods. To attract a vibrant middle class, these neighborhoods need to be repaired and restored, or, at the very least, stabilized. Residents who have been unable to rebuild because storm relief grants were too small or unfairly calculated need more help from the city and state.

title: The House Races
description: Republicans captured control of the House of Representatives, riding a wave of voter discontent.

title: Election Night Live | News 10:15pm ET
description: The Times's Megan Liberman and Jim Roberts analyze the latest story lines and what to expect in the coming hour.

title: Cuomo Cruises to Win in New York Governors Race
description: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, completing a painstakingly plotted comeback from political ruin nearly a decade ago, won a resounding victory on Tuesday in the race for governor of New York, easily beating his Republican rival, Carl P. Paladino.

title: Apparently, My Congressman Is Still A Rocket Scientist
description: NJ-12 has been called for Rush Holt.

title: Blumenthal Wins in Connecticut to Take Dodds Senate Seat
description: Richard Blumenthal, the longtime attorney general of Connecticut, withstood a $50 million spending assault, his own major missteps and a brutal climate for Democrats on Tuesday, defeating the professional wrestling tycoon Linda E. McMahon to capture a Senate seat being vacated by Christopher J. Dodd.

title: A Guide to the Caribbean on a Budget
description: If you have your low-budget heart set on high-end islands like St. Barts or St. Martin or Turks and Caicos this winter, with enough research and flexibility you may be able to pull it off. But the real way to keep costs down is to head to the lower-cost islands that actively compete for travelers with light wallets.

title: Election Night Live | News 10:45pm ET
description: The Times's Megan Liberman and Michael D. Shear discuss the salient points of this election.

title: Was It Worth It?
description: We dont know the final extent of the Democratic losses yet. But we do know the questions that liberals and Democrats will be asking themselves tomorrow morning. Was it all worthwhile? Was the 111th Congresss flurry of legislative activity worth the backlash it helped create? Were the health care bill and the stimulus worth handing John Boehner the gavel in the House of the Representatives? Did it make sense to push and push and then keep on pushing, even after the polls and town halls and special-election outcomes made it clear the voters were going to push back?

title: Corrections
description: WORLD

title: Election Night Live | News 11:15pm ET
description: The Times's Megan Liberman and Jackie Calmes on the challenges President Obama faces with Republicans in and out of congress.

title: Perry Re-elected in Texas Governor Race
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Gov. Rick Perry won a resounding victory over his Democratic challenger, Bill White, a triumph for the conservative Republican governor who was early to embrace the antigovernment Tea Party movement.

title: Defeated in Delaware, but Scarcely Sounding It
description: DOVER, Del.  Nothing could save the Tea Party candidate here, Christine ODonnell. Not her folksy appeal, not her headline-grabbing gaffes, not even, it turns out, her witchcraft.

title: $68.9 Million Modigliani Gets Auction Season Off to a Healthy Start
description: Classic images from art history, a doe-eyed female nude by Modigliani and a seminal Monet waterlily attracted bidders from around the world on Tuesday night at Sothebys sale of Impressionist and modern art.

title: Wall Street Closes Higher at the End
description: Squawk boxes barked the news over the trading floor at Barclays: the Fed was back in.

title: How Obama Saved Capitalism and Lost the Midterms
description: If I were one of the big corporate donors who bankrolled the Republican tide that carried into office more than 50 new Republicans in the House, I would be wary of what you just bought.

title: Solar-Panel Maker to Close a Factory and Delay Expansion
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Solyndra, a Silicon Valley solar-panel maker that won half a billion dollars in federal aid to build a state-of-the-art robotic factory, plans to announce on Wednesday that it will shut down an older plant and lay off workers.

title: Phys Ed: Will Training in the Heat Improve Your Performance in the Cold?
description: Can training for hot weather help you to perform better when the temperature outside begins to drop? That question, the answer to which intuitively would seem to be a resounding no, became the inspiration for a new study by scientists at the human physiology department at the University of Oregon. For the study, published last month in The Journal of Applied Physiology, researchers recruited 20 highly trained competitive cyclists from the universitys cycling team and local cycling clubs and put them through a series of laboratory performance tests, including a time trial, under both hot and cool conditions.

title: Word of the Day | jibe
description: jibe \jib\ noun and verb

title: In News Coverage, Tea Party and Its New Personalities Hold the Spotlight
description: The Tea Party movement was the big media news in the elections on Tuesday, and it was also a big topic behind the scenes at news organizations.

title: Election Night Live | News 11:45pm ET
description: As the Republicans take the house majority, The Times's Megan Liberman and Michael D. Shear discuss the ramifications for Democrats.

title: Tight Deadline for New Speaker to Deliver
description: In leading his party to midterm triumph, Representative John A. Boehner, the next speaker of the House, is not at the endgame. He is at the beginning of the next and harder fight.

title: Schneiderman Is Elected New Yorks Attorney General
description: Eric T. Schneiderman, a Democratic state senator from the Upper West Side of Manhattan who doggedly  even desperately  clung to Andrew M. Cuomos coattails in the closing days of the campaign, was elected by a comfortable margin on Tuesday to succeed him as New Yorks 65th attorney general.

title: Cuomo on a Collision Course With Unions
description: It was perhaps the most memorable line from Eliot Spitzers 2006 campaign for governor of New York, a pithy promise as well as a threat: Day 1, he declared, everything changes.

title: Google Settles Suit Over Buzz and Privacy
description: Google informed users of its Gmail service Tuesday evening that it had settled a class action lawsuit brought against it by some users who were upset by the way the company rolled out its Buzz social networking service.

title: Tea Partiers and Republican Faithful Share Exuberant Celebrations
description: WASHINGTON  This is what a red wave looks like here, at least in election night party terms, circa 2010: hugging, high-fiving, Heineken-toasting Tea Party insurgents (in Dont Tread on Me garb) and establishment Republican types (business casual) united and rejoicing in a night of Democratic pain.

title: Thomas DiNapoli Re-Elected Comptroller in a Tight Race
description: Thomas P. DiNapoli, the Democratic state comptroller, narrowly defeated Harry Wilson, the Wall Street trader turned first-time candidate, allowing Mr. DiNapoli to return for a full term as the states chief financial officer.

title: In Governors Races, Republicans Make Gains
description: On an Election Day with one of the largest number of governors races in memory, Republicans gained governorships across the country, and particularly in the political battlegrounds of the industrial Midwest where Democrats have dominated in recent years.

title: Patrick Hangs On as Massachusetts Governor
description: BOSTON  Gov. Deval Patrick won a second term in Massachusetts on Tuesday despite an aggressive challenge from his Republican opponent, Charlie Baker.

title: Child Thrown From Balcony To His Death
description: A 2-year-old boy was thrown to his death from the balcony of a seventh-floor apartment in Queens on Tuesday night by a distraught woman who had been living with his family, the authorities said.

title: Struggle by Democrats to Guard House Seats
description: Republicans captured six Congressional seats in New York and New Jersey on Tuesday night, riding a wave of voter dissatisfaction that swept Democrats across the country out of power.

title: Late Voting Delays Results for Connecticut Governor
description: Thomas C. Foley, a wealthy Republican businessman, and Dannel P. Malloy, a former Democratic mayor of Stamford, were locked in a tight race to become Connecticuts next governor, according to preliminary returns early Wednesday.

title: Once Again, City Voters Approve Term Limits
description: New Yorkers voted overwhelmingly to limit politicians to two consecutive terms on Tuesday, undoing a highly contentious change to the law pushed through by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg two years ago.

title: In California, Boxer Wins Senate Race, and Brown Is Governor
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Feeling pessimistic, but bucking the national trend, California voters decided against a pair of untested Republicans in favor of old-school Democrats on Tuesday.

title: Election Night Live | 12:15am ET
description: As the night comes to a close, The Times's Megan Liberman and Matt Bai analyze the new reality in politics and the balance of power in Washington.

title: Nathan Deal and Republicans Win in Georgia
description: ATLANTA  Leading an apparent Republican sweep of the state, Nathan Deal, a conservative former congressman, won Georgias governorship on Tuesday by stifling a comeback attempt by the states last Democratic leader, former Gov. Roy E. Barnes.

title: Shannon Tavarez, Nala in Lion King, Dies at 11
description: Shannon Tavarez, who won a featured role on Broadway in The Lion King at an open audition for child actors, and who spent seven months performing in the show before receiving a diagnosis of leukemia in April, died on Monday. She was 11.

title: Charlie ODonnell, Whose Voice Was Fixture on TV, Dies at 78
description: Charlie ODonnell, whose resonant off-camera voice was a fixture on American television for decades, most notably in heralding the opening of the game show Wheel of Fortune for 28 years, died on Monday at his home in Sherman Oaks, Calif. He was 78.

title: Adapting a European Tool to U.S. Mortgages
description: Covered bonds, a financing tool popular in Europe since the 18th century, are winning converts in America as a new way to finance residential and commercial mortgages, Julie Satow reports in The New York Times.

title: News Quiz | November 3, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Democrats on Verge of Retaining New York State Senate Majority
description: On an otherwise disappointing night for New York Republicans, the party appeared to be on the verge of either retaking the State Senate or throwing the chamber into a tie, but a few key races remained undecided in the early morning hours.

title: California Rejects Marijuana Legalization
description: OAKLAND  California voters rejected a ballot initiative on Tuesday that would have legalized marijuana for recreational use, but disappointed supporters of the measure lighted up anyway outside their campaign headquarters here and vowed to continue pushing for a day when cannabis is treated like tobacco and alcohol, not heroin and cocaine.

title: Republican Kirk Wins Obamas Old Senate Senate
description: CHICAGO  In a stinging defeat for Democrats on President Obamas home turf, Representative Mark Steven Kirk, a Republican, won a narrow victory for the United States Senate over his Democratic rival, Alexi Giannoulias, the state treasurer whom the president had endorsed to take over his former seat.

title: Harry Reid Keeps His Seat as Democrats Hold Senate
description: LAS VEGAS  Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader and a symbol of the Democratic establishment, fought back a fierce challenge from Sharron Angle to win re-election on Tuesday in a contest that offered a stark test of the Tea Party against one of the most effective political operations in the nation.

title: Cypress Lane Founder to Close the Hedge Fund
description: Shafiq Karmali, a former Goldman Sachs trader, is shutting his hedge fund and returning investors money a little more than a year after starting it, three people briefed on the decision told Bloomberg News.

title: In Iowa, Voters Oust Judges Over Marriage Issue
description: DES MOINES  In a rebuke of the state supreme court with implications for judicial elections across the country, voters here removed three justices who participated in a ruling last year that made the state the first in the Midwest to permit same-sex marriage.

title: In G.M. Comeback, a Big Role for Washington
description: When executives from General Motors begin pitching its public stock offering to investors this week, they will extol the companys financial turnaround, its snazzy new lineup led by the plug-in Chevrolet Volt, and its growing operations in China and other international markets.

title: Write-in (Murkowski) Performs Well in Alaska
description: SEE UPDATE:

title: Riding Along With the Candidates
description: Andrew M. Cuomo cruised to victory as governor of New York, Kirsten E. Gillibrand retained her Senate seat and Richard Blumenthal, Connecticuts attorney general, was elected to the U.S. Senate.

title: S. Korea Fires Warning Shots at Boat
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The South Korean Navy fired warning shots at a North Korean fishing boat on Wednesday after the vessel strayed across the two Koreas border on the Yellow Sea, the Defense Ministry said.

title: A Georgia Democrat Retakes the Lead
description: ATLANTA  A Democratic congressman in Georgia has now taken the lead in a race in which his Republican opponent had been declared the winner.

title: Facebooks Early Employees Are Moving On
description: Facebook, the most successful start-up of the last decade, is only six years old, and an initial public offering is still a way off, Verne G. Kopytoff reports in The New York Times.

title: Solar Firm to Close a Factory and Delay Growth
description: Solyndra, a Silicon Valley solar-panel maker that won a half billion dollars in federal aid to build a state-of-the-art robotic factory, plans to announce on Wednesday that it will shut down an older plant and lay off workers.

title: Tea Party Triumphs in Rural Colorado
description: DENVER  Scott Tipton, a Republican businessman backed by the Tea Party movement, defeated a three-term Democrat incumbent, Representative John Salazar, in Colorados Third Congressional District.

title: S.E.C. Weighs Rules on Unfettered Market Access
description: Unlicensed high-frequency traders will no longer be able to gain unfettered, or naked, access to public markets under a rule being considered by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: PhosAgro Weighing Potash Bid, Russian Report Says
description: PhosAgro, a major fertilizer producer in Russia, is said to be preparing a bid for the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan to rival the $39 billion offer from BHP Billiton currently under consideration in Ottawa.

title: Toomey at Helm of a Republican Wave in Pennsylvania
description: ST. DAVIDS, Pa.  Pat Toomey, a former Republican congressman, defeated Representative Joe Sestak, a Democrat, on Tuesday in a razor-thin Senate race in Pennsylvania that was not called for hours after polls closed.

description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from The Timess article Sometimes, Lucky Numbers Add Up to Apartment Sales.

description: Last year, when Marc Andreessen set up shop on Sand Hill Road, the tree-lined home to Silicon Valleys venture capital firms, he was already a big name.

title: How Much Food Does Your Family Waste?
description: How much of the food that is in your refrigerator right now will end up in the garbage can? The Well blogs From Farm to Fridge to Garbage Can tells of studies that show 93 percent of people buy food they never use. Are you and your family among them? Why do you think food goes to waste in so many homes? How do you think that could be prevented?

description: The second trial of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the jailed former oil tycoon, adjourned on Tuesday to await the judges verdict, which Mr. Khodorkovsky said would be a test of Russias commitment to the rule of law, even as he expressed little hope of being cleared and spared another decade or more in prison, Michael Schwirtz of The New York Times reported.

description: As a 21-year-old military photographer in West Germany with few skills, I set off one day in 1963 to seek advice from the best news photographer I knew. That was Francis J. Grandy, the chief photographer for Stars and Stripes in Europe, a post he held for 35 years.

description: Dell has agreed to buy Boomi, a cloud-computing services start-up, in an effort to shore up its ability to provide software over computer networks.

title: Greece Halts Overseas Mail as Bombs Cross Borders
description: ATHENS  After a season of bitter and widespread protests over austerity measures to address its financial crisis, Greece faced new turmoil on Wednesday as the authorities investigated an elaborate bomb plot in which relatively mild explosive devices were sent to embassies in Athens as well as to the leaders of Italy and Germany.

title: Wall Street Hopes to Gain as Democrats Lose House
description: After the midterm elections on Tuesday, Wall Street may get another crack at reshaping financial regulations more to its liking. The shifting of the House of Representatives back to Republican control  with a big pickup of at least 58 seats  could help the financial industry ease some of the most onerous aspects of the new regulatory regime.

title: Wellspring Raises $1.2 Billion for Latest Fund

title: History Goes Up in Flames on Fawkes Night
description: Please to remember, the fifth of November, a tale of gunpowder, treason and plot. So begins a common British nursery rhyme commemorating a foiled attempt 400-odd years ago to blow up the British Parliament and restore a Catholic monarch to the throne. The leader of these efforts, Guy Fawkes, was eventually executed for his actions, but his memory lives on each November as Britons everywhere host firework displays and bonfires in remembrance of the occasion.

title: Mall Owner Westfield Plans $3.5 Billion Spin-Off

title: Viktor Chernomyrdin, Russian Ex-Premier, Dies at 72
description: MOSCOW  Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, who served as Russias prime minister during the turbulent transition to a free-market economy in the 1990s and who founded the state-owned gas monopoly Gazprom, died Wednesday morning, the Russian government announced. He was 72.

title: China Stages Naval Exercises
description: BEIJING  Chinas Marine Corps held major naval exercises on Tuesday in the South China Sea, state-run media reported on Wednesday, massing 1,800 troops and more than 100 ships, submarines and aircraft for a live-fire display of the nations growing military power.

description: HONG KONG  Reaction across Asia to the U.S. elections on Wednesday was muted as attention focused on the planned tour by President Obama to the region, scheduled to begin Friday in India.

Great skill to have, said Mr. Garner, who went on to complain about how much he was going to have to pay a pro to build a decent Web site. Why not ask her boys to do it? the customer asked. He could pay them whatever he thought the results were worth. He thought about it. Why not? he replied.
