description: HERES the way our financial lives were supposed to look right about now: Our parents would be living comfortably off their pensions, while their investments hummed along at a smooth 6 percent annual return, building toward our inevitable six-figure inheritance.

title: A Dancing School for Little Adults
description: Children at the Barclay Classes learn the box step, the cha-cha and the fox trot.

title: Up Front: Liz Phair
description: Liz Phairs classic first album, Exile in Guyville (1993), was a direct song-by-song response to the Rolling Stones Exile on Main Street.

title: Life
description: I think the first record I bought was Little Richards Long Tall Sally. Fantastic record, even to this day. Good records just get better with age. But the one that really turned me on, like an explosion one night, listening to Radio Luxembourg on my little radio when I was supposed to be in bed and asleep, was Heartbreak Hotel. That was the stunner. Id never heard it before, or anything like it. Id never heard of Elvis before. It was almost as if Id been waiting for it to happen. When I woke up the next day I was a different guy. Suddenly I was getting overwhelmed: Buddy Holly, Eddie Cochran, Little Richard, Fats. Radio Luxembourg was notoriously difficult to keep on station. I had a little aerial and walked round the room, holding the radio up to my ear and twisting the aerial. Trying to keep it down because Id wake Mum and Dad up. If I could get the signal right, I could take the radio under the blankets on the bed and keep the aerial outside and twist it there. Im supposed to be asleep; Im supposed to be going to school in the morning. Loads of ads for James Walker, the jewelers in every high street, and the Irish sweepstakes, with which Radio Lux had some deal. The signal was perfect for the ads, and now we have Fats Domino, Blueberry Hill, and [expletive], then it would fade.

title: Stray Cat Blues
description: Hes been a global avatar of wish fulfillment for over four decades and managed to eke more waking hours out of a 24-hour day than perhaps any other creature alive (thanks, Merck cocaine and amphetamines!). As Keith puts it: For many years I slept, on average, twice a week. This means that I have been conscious for at least three lifetimes.

title: Asked and Answered | Anton Corbijn
description: After directing the indie Joy Division biopic Control and the George Clooney thriller The American, as well as scores of music videos for groups like Nirvana, U2 and Depeche Mode, Anton Corbijn is back to where it all began for him: portraiture. No matter the strata of their celebrity, Corbijn manages to draw out something as yet undiscovered from his subjects. Inwards and Onwards, on view at Stellan Holm Gallery until Dec. 15, is a small selection of Corbijns black-and-white portraits of the creative people whose orbits have intersected his own. Rockers like Tom Waits and Anthony Kiedis mingle with painters such as Richard Prince and Lucian Freud. Corbijn holds them all in equal regard.

title: Cuba Dance Notebook: A Thrill for Young Fans
description: HAVANA  Laura Carolina Medina clutched a ballet shoe scribbled with autographs as she stood outside the Karl Marx Theater here on Wednesday, her young eyes sparkling with excitement after American Ballet Theaters first performance on the island in 50 years.

title: A High-Speed Derailment
description: Representative John Mica of Florida, the senior Republican in line to take the reins of the House Transportation Committee in January, is unhappy with the way the Obama administration awarded $10 billion in federal stimulus funds for high-speed rail projects.

title: 2010 SEMA Show: From Hot Rods to Exotics to Hybrids
description: The annual Specialty Equipment Market Association trade show in Las Vegas is an opportunity for companies selling aftermarket automotive accessories to let their imaginations run wild. Refinish a Rolls-Royce in black primer? Hot-rod a hybrid? Is one engine enough? Why not two? There are no limits. Nearly one million square feet of exhibit space inside the Las Vegas Convention Center is packed with one display after another, and aisles that seem to stretch for miles; what there is no room for inside spills out into the parking lots, to the nearby Sands Convention Center, and even various casinos.

title: Making Mortgage Lending a Family Affair
description: MATT RADO is in the market for his first home, but the 41-year-old in Santa Ana, Calif., does not plan to get a loan from a bank. Instead, Mr. Rado, who works in sales for a technology company, plans to have his retired parents lend him the money.

title: Rene Zellweger Selling Upper East Side Apartments
description: THE tabloids have delighted in reporting on the sightings and juicy tidbits that would seem to suggest the romance between Rene Zellweger and Bradley Cooper has been heating up over the last several months. And now they may have more to chew on: Ms. Zellweger is selling her two Upper East Side apartments.

title: Dancing School Gives Children a Taste of the Elite
description: Clad in a sharp navy blue jacket over matching culottes, Andr Altherr stepped into the center of the ballroom and placed one hand firmly on Isabel Stitts waist. With his other, he clasped one of her white-gloved hands, his red tie highlighted by her scarlet dress and matching headband.

title: In Feingolds Loss, Independents Turn on One of Their Own
description: MIDDLETON, Wis.  The irony was lost on no one. Senator Russ Feingold, a liberal with a fierce streak of independence who crusaded against the influence of money in politics, was toppled Tuesday in a campaign awash in the kind of unregulated cash he had struggled to keep out of the system.

title: Whats a Pooled Trust? A Way to Avoid the Nursing Home
description: NOW that most baby boomers parents have been retired for many years, perhaps even decades, whats left of their retirement income often isnt enough to pay for the rising costs of long-term care.

title: Kanye West Sorry for Pulling Race Card on Bush
description: Kanye West, the hip-hop star who accused George W. Bush of racism during the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, said that he now thinks he was too quick to pull a race card and can connect with the former president on a human level.

title: In Cheshire Triple-Murder Case, Jury to Weigh Sentence
description: NEW HAVEN  The prosecution called for the death penalty during closing arguments on Thursday in the penalty phase of the trial of Steven J. Hayes, the man convicted of killing a woman and her two daughters in a home invasion in Cheshire, Conn.

title: A Childs Legacy Is More Than Money
description: MOST people hear the word inheritance and think about money. I dont  or more precisely, its the least of my worries when it comes to my young daughter.

title: A Guarded Optimism in Myanmar as Vote Nears
description: YANGON, Myanmar  During nearly five decades of military dictatorship, the impoverished population of Myanmar has become accustomed to hearing soldiers shout orders. And now comes a more unusual request from the ruling generals: Vote!

title: Income Security in Your 80s, Bought in Your 60s
description: WOULD you be willing to place a bet that youll live past the age of 80? What about 85?

title: TimesCast | November 4, 2010
description: Anxiety takes hold in Baghdad; the G.O.P. strategy and Microsoft's Kinect takes gaming to a new level.

title: Nuggets Deploy Mystery Man in Middle
description: Advice for fans attending Denver Nuggets games: make sure to get a program, so you can identify Gary Forbes.

title: Raising Cash From the Less Usual Places
description: SUPPORTING a family can be tough in a good economy. Add todays tight credit market, high unemployment and depressed home prices, and theres a good chance many stuck in the generation sandwich are thinking about last resorts for obtaining additional cash to pay for expenses like senior living care.

title: Guiding a Child to Financial Independence
description: LAST spring, Jamie McGurk, an independent producer in Los Angeles, knew that the rough economic climate would make it difficult for her 22-year-old daughter Stephanie to get a job. So when Stephanie decided to move back home after graduating from Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., her mother was delighted. We didnt get to spend that much time with her when she was on the East Coast, so it was the best thing ever, she said.

title: BHP: Loves Labors Lost
description: By HEIDI N. MOORE

title: New Mac Airs: Beautiful and Usable
description: Ill be straight with you: Ive always been a sucker for the MacBook Air, which looks more like a sheared-off, ridiculously thin piece of an airfoil than an aluminum laptop. I actually bought one. I used it as my main laptop for about a year.

title: Graves May Solve Mystery in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  They were 20 men, kidnapped in broad daylight soon after they arrived at the Pacific resort city of Acapulco for what their families said was a guys vacation.

title: Porsche Club Awaits a Lovingly Restored Classic
description: A coming automobile raffle adds some credence to that old saw about membership and its privileges.

title: Revisiting Nancy Majola in the Video Series Soccer City
description: During the 2010 World Cup, Nick Fitzhugh and Pete Muller traveled to South Africa to produce a documentary series and film about the cultural significance of soccer in the country. They shared some of their stories with us while based in Alexandra  a four-square-kilometer township in Johannesburg inhabited by about 1.5 million people  the series focuses on five people whose lives have been defined by soccer.

title: Industry Aims at Medicare Board
description: In the new political reality in Washington, the drug industry, hospitals and doctors groups are setting their sights on the elimination of a little-known provision of the health care overhaul that some experts identify as the biggest cost-cutter of all.

title: At Bloombergs, High-Calorie Candy From Mickey Mouse
description: During trick-or-treat time last Sunday, intrepid Times staffers visited the homes of the candidates for governor, where they were handed fistfuls of Junior Mints and Laffy Taffy, sniffed by Carl P. Paladinos dog and greeted by Andrew M. Cuomo himself.

title: Joe Drapes Breeders Cup Picks, Day 1
description: Lets ease into the first day of the Breeders Cup with our eyes on the Juvenile races. There is value to be found in the Juvenile Fillies and the Juvenile Fillies Turf. Those races, along with the Filly and Mare Sprint, are worth looking at for longshots to enhance your bankroll for Saturday. But go easy  Saturday is where the bombs go off.

title: 'Women on the Verge'
description: Patti LuPone sings "Invisible" from the new Broadway musical "Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown," based on the 1988 film. (Video courtesy of the production)

title: What Were Reading
description: Nations Restaurant News: Chipotle developing a fast-casual Asian concept. Korean tacos for all?  Sam Sifton

title: Georgia Shops for Fleet of Eco-Friendly Cars
description: MOSCOW  Never let it be said that the government of Georgia thinks small.

title: Rescue of Chilean Miners Will Be Recounted in Book
description: The Chilean miners have been rescued, so let the book deals begin.

title: Obama to Visit India, and Both Sides Hope to Expand Ties
description: MUMBAI, India  As President Obama pays his first visit to India this weekend, he may want to take his lead from Mary Kay.

title: Elsewhere: The Boffo Lingo of Varietys Slanguage
description: Explaining that from its launch in 1905, Variety has used its own, distinctive slanguage in headlines and stories, the magazine recently published a glossary of insider terms.

title: Court Says Fisk University Can Sell Stake in Art Collection
description: Fisk University in Nashville has gained approval to sell an ownership stake in its Stieglitz Art Collection to the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in Bentonville, Ark., the university announced.

title: Red Bulls Surrender One-Goal Edge Against Earthquakes
description: Postgame Update |Red Bulls Surrender Lead and Series

title: Songs in the Key of Lit: Ways to Use Music to Study Literature
description: Overview | How can music help illuminate literature? And how can literature teach us about music? In this lesson, students read a review of a musical performance based on Platos dialogues and then set a literary work they have studied to music in order to bring out or enhance its meaning.

title: Hevesi Adviser Is Said to Accept Plea Deal in Pension Scandal
description: Hank Morris, who was once the top political adviser to Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi and a prominent Democratic consultant, has reached a plea agreement with the office of Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, people with knowledge of the deal said Thursday.

title: Listening to Patients Living With Illness
description: Wiry, fair-haired and in his 60s, the patient had received a prostate cancer diagnosis a year earlier. When his doctors told him that surgery and radiation therapy were equally effective and that it was up to him to decide, he chose radiation with little hesitation.

title: Life After a Lifesaving Treatment
description: Doctors often treat patients based on the best chances for recovery. But they often neglect to explain how a patients life might be changed after the cure.

title: Sparky Anderson Dies at 76;Won World Series With Reds and Tigers
description: Sparky Anderson, who managed Cincinnatis powerful Big Red Machine to baseball dominance in the 1970s and became the first manager to win World Series championships in both the National and American Leagues, died on Thursday at his home in Thousand Oaks, Calif. He was 76.

title: Fly-by of Comet Sets NASA Astir
description: A fly-by of a comet went off flawlessly Thursday morning, giving giddy scientists only their fifth close-up look at the nucleus of a comet.

title: The States Role in Gambling Addiction
description: Gambling was among the issues on local ballots in Tuesdays election. But do lotteries and other state initiatives promote gambling addiction? This was among the questions recently posed by readers of the Consults blog. Dr. Timothy Fong, co-director of the gambling studies program and an associate professor of psychiatry at the University of California, Los Angeles, responds. For more information, see Dr. Fongs earlier responses in When Is Gambling an Addiction? and Seeking Help for Gambling Addiction.

title: Dolphins and Xenops on the Last Field Day
description: Friday, Oct. 29

title: Iraq: The Forgotten War
description: Anxiety takes hold in Baghdad, as it sees some of the worst violence since 2003.

title: Photo of the Week
description: Two men sitting on a bench enjoy some sunrays at midday in the center of Frankfurt am Main, as temperatures grew unusually high for the autumn season.

title: Artifacts | Moths and Mercenaries
description: Funny how no coincidence ever really seems accidental. Certainly the gods must be smiling at whatever has put new shows by Wangechi Mutu and Adam Helms in back-to-back Chelsea galleries. Their unexpected juxtaposition creates a parallel universe that is both beautiful and chilling.

title: Some Men Are an Island
description: An obsessively plugged-in writer is assigned to six days on Little Deadmans Cay, an uninhabited, mostly unpowered island in the Bahamas.

title: The Concession Call That Still Hasnt Happened
description: Updated, 12:43 p.m., Nov. 5| Maybe Carl P. Paladino should just give up. More than 48 hours after he first tried to concede defeat in the governors race with an obligatory phone call to Andrew M. Cuomo, he had yet to reach him, a delay Mr. Paladinos campaign manager called ridiculous.

title: A Weekend in St. Martin/St. Maarten
description: Despite dense development, St. Martin/St. Maarten  the half-French, half-Dutch island  remains a stunningly picturesque place with some of the Caribbeans most arresting scenery.

title: Video Analysis: Old Fears in the New Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  After a week in which more than 120 people were killed by a series of bombs and gun attacks across the Iraqi capital, Times correspondent Anthony Shadid  wrote: The year 2010, which could be remembered for a partial American withdrawal and the election of a government meant to preside over the departure of the rest of those troops, may be recalled differently: the time when a new Iraq  the term still offered by diplomats and a ruling class ever more divorced from those they rule  looked broken.

title: A New Mortgage Refinancing Calculator
description: With mortgage rates so low, many consumers are considering refinancing their mortgages. If youre one of them, youre probably trying to figure out the best strategy for handling closing costs. A new calculator from the mortgage data and publishing company HSH.com aims to help you.

title: The Morning Skate: Shrinking Teams, Shrinking Heads and a Rough Day for Goalies
description: Discussions like yesterdays about the attendance woes of the Columbus Blue Jackets always gets people thinking about the fate of the weaker franchises of the N.H.L. Relocation is a frequent suggestion, especially with fans in Winnipeg and Quebec City clamoring for clubs to call their own again.

title: How We Learned to Recycle
description: Garbage shame is such a normal part of todays parental discourse (No, you cant have an AquaPod! Its a waste of packaging!) that most of us dont think about it anymore. Landfills leak climate-changing methane. Plastic water bottles stretch to the moon and back.

title: Reading Dogs and Untrained Boys
description: It is generally agreed that humor is subjective. Looking across the recent crop of picture books that specialize in gently absurd comedy, one can imagine grown-ups wondering if kids will get the joke. But that would underestimate even very young childrens ability to appreciate the incongruous, the nonsensical, the flat-out eccentric.

title: The Caucus
description: After losing badly in the 2008 elections, Republicans began a blue-print of the strategy that led to this week's House takeover.

title: Former Hevesi Aide Morris Settles Charges
description: From Danny Hakim at City Room:

title: Oil and Gas Bribery Case Settled for $236 Million
description: WASHINGTON  Six oil and gas service companies and a prominent freight-forwarding company agreed to pay about $236 million in criminal and civil penalties in one of the largest corporate bribery cases ever to focus on a single industry, federal authorities said Thursday.

title: Just Over the Page, a Parallel Universe
description: For years a gulf in the book world has been widening. The digital age has brought about a separation between a books story and its platform, its medium of delivery. The same story can now make its way to the reader by iPod, iPad or iPhone; by Kindle, Nook or Sony Reader; by laptop or desktop; or of course, by the old-fashioned printed page. As the options increase, the platform itself becomes more transparent and, some would argue, irrelevant. Todays reader has grown so used to encountering pages of different shapes, sizes and technological eras that he or she hardly notices the page itself anymore.

title: Now Ive Said My ABCs, Tell Me What My Social Values Should Be
description: Sorry, Sesame Street and Dora the Explorer. Moms want preschool TV to be more about teaching children social skills and less about pushing clear academic goals  at least thats what Disney executives say new internal research indicates.

title: The Corner of Bitter and Sweet
description: Its not just any big red lollipop. Its the biggest, sweetest treat in the first take-home goodie bag from the first birthday party Rubina has ever attended. That makes it a treasure to have and hold as long as possible  well, overnight in the fridge, anyway, for enjoying the next morning, after a night of happy dreams.

title: Theater Talkback: When Shabby Shines
description: Gatz, the marathon reading of The Great Gatsby now at the Public Theater, is set inside a dowdy office where the digital age doesnt seem to have dawned. Watching this show (when it played at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass.) made me appreciate how much beauty there can be in places were life feels most vacant: abandoned buildings, parking lots, empty classrooms, edge-of-town restaurants, dowdy motel rooms.

title: Apple Invites Developers to Submit Mac Apps
description: Developers who have created applications for Apple products, including the iPhone, iPad and iPod Touch, beganreceiving e-mail invitations on Wednesday to submit applications to the coming Mac App Store.

title: Harrison Is Fined Another $20,000
description: James Harrison has said he still doesnt know what he could have done differently on his hit to a Cleveland receiver three weeks ago that drew a $75,000 fine from the N.F.L. and became one of the prime examples in the leagues crackdown on hits to the head.

title: In Connecticut, Two Men Prepare to Be Governor
description: Thursday was the first full day of work for the transition team of Dannel P. Malloy, the Democrat who was certain he was the winner in the race for governor of Connecticut.

title: When a City Feels Like Home
description: If youre reading this sandwiched between a stroller and a students overstuffed backpack on a New York City subway, consider the big picture: Youre traveling along hundreds of miles of track, a triumph of awe-inspiring urban planning. And despite the scale of it all, youve no doubt found a way to appreciate more intimate aspects of city life  a favorite coffee shop, a picnic spot, a shared interest with an eccentric neighbor (or perhaps thats you). While the big plan allowed the city to grow, the warmth of its communities is what make it a home. Through these different lenses, three new picture books celebrate city life.

title: A Beautiful Relationship
description: Bink is cheerful, fearless and messy. Gollie is skinny, precise and superior. Bink is heart and Gollie is head. Of such contrasts is the best-friend relationship forged. In this three-chapter picture book, written in dialogue, Gollie seems to call the shots  at first. Shes taller. Shes worked on her vocabulary: Here I am where none but a few have ventured. What an extraordinary accomplishment. She makes pronouncements: I must inform you that you are giving a home to a truly unremarkable fish.

title: Tracking a Needle in a Haystack of 45,000
description: For years, fans at the New York City Marathon have waited hopefully on the citys streets for their friends and family to run past on their 26.2-mile journey. With little or no idea where the runners are on the course, spectators are left to watch the kaleidoscope of humanity surge by, from the gazellelike leaders to the weekend warriors struggling to reach the finish line.

title: September Rally Pushes Hedge Fund to Close
description: A relatively new hedge fund announced its own death knell this week, citing turbulent conditions and an unfortunate bet against the market for the decision to shutter the firm, which managed nearly $300 million in assets at its peak.

title: App Smart Extra: Password-Protecting Photos
description: If youve ever worried about someone stealing your logins and passwords, this weeks App Smart column offers some solace, in the form of secure password keepers.

title: Theater Listings: Nov. 5  11
description: Theater

title: A Vegan Chef Dishes Up Thanksgiving
description: The Los Angeles chef Chloe Coscarelli is best known for winning the Food Networks Cupcake Wars with her dairy- and egg-free cupcake recipes. But Ms. Coscarelli, a recent graduate of the University of California, Berkeley, and the Natural Gourmet Institute in New York City, also has a passion for vegan savory foods, particularly at Thanksgiving.

title: Rare Winner for Southern Democrats
description: ALBANY, Ga.  In an election cycle with few success stories for Democrats, the unlikely re-election of Representative Sanford D. Bishop Jr., 63, in Georgias Second District, has lifted the spirits of demoralized liberal Southern Democrats.

title: Fear Darkens Czech Uranium Mining Town
description: STRAZ POD RALSKEM, CZECH REPUBLIC  The national uranium company in the Czech Republic, Diamo, has been working for years to keep toxic waste left by decades of uranium mining from poisoning some of the countrys largest underground stocks of fresh water or reaching the Elbe River.

title: NBC Cancels Undercovers
description: NBC is ending the run of what was once one its most promising new series of the season with the decision that it will not order any more new episodes of the series Undercovers.

title: Mental Health Days From School
description: On Monday, Jody Becker walked her girls to school. (The same school she wrote about here on Motherlode.) Her kindergartener was cheerful, but her second grader was dragging after a night of trick or treating. By the time they reached the front door, the older girl was saying she felt sick, so Becker detoured over to the school nurse and signed her daughter out for the day.

title: First Look | Linda Farrow Luxe
description: The British designer Linda Farrow was one of the first to see the vision thing as a fashion thing  she started her namesake eyewear line back in 1970. Over the years, Farrows glasses have provided chic cover for everyone from Yoko Ono to Kanye West. Now, Linda Farrow Luxe is introducing a special collection of 50 frames that includes both updated styles from the archives and new designs curated by Simon Jablon, Farrows son and the managing director of the brand. Every year we push the collection in design and technicalities but still have the same essence, Jablon says. Take, for example, the large Jackie O. cat-eye frames covered in cream, taupe, gray, aubergine or black snake. The retro style is modeled above by the actress Nathalie Love, who appears  alongside her best friend, the artist Louis Eisner  in a campaign by the photographer Tim Barber that is, well, worthy of framing.

title: All You Need to Know About the Workouts
description: Bruno De Julio has been a workout analyst and thoroughbred owner for the past 20 years. He is the author of Bruno on Workouts: Exposing the Mystery and can be found daily at Racing With Bruno and Grade One Racing.

title: Neighborhood Joint | The Brecht Forum
description: At the Brecht Forum, a community center on West Street, communists (and others) gather daily for activities serious and entertaining, like a Marxist version of Monopoly.

title: Where Marxists Pontificate, and Play
description: IF communists have a reputation for anything, it is seriousness. (And if you have seen old photos of Karl Marx, you know that he did not smile much.) But at the Brecht Forum, a community center on West Street where revolutionaries and radicals gather daily to ponder and to pontificate, they also play. (Smiles abound.)

title: Clip: 'Four Lions'
description: A scene from the satire "Four Lions," directed by Chris Morris.

title: Was That a Plea From Bernanke?
description: Laurence H. Meyer, a former Federal Reserve governor, said the following in todays Times:

title: Fresh Eruptions of Indonesian Volcano
description: Indonesias Mount Merapi volcano erupted again late on Thursday, just hours after six more people were killed by a spectacular early-morning eruption.

title: High-Risk Insurance Pools Are Attracting Few
description: After the health care law passed, concerns emerged immediately that a $5 billion appropriation would not be nearly enough to cover the hordes expected to enroll in a network of new insurance pools for people with pre-existing conditions. The governments health care actuary projected that hundreds of thousands of otherwise uninsurable people would rush to gain coverage this year, and that the money would be exhausted by 2012.

title: Ireland Plans More Budget Cuts to Reassure Bond Investors
description: The Irish government, in its latest step to salvage its fiscal credibility, said on Thursday that it would step up its program to cut the deficit by proposing 6 billion euros ($8.5 billion) in savings for its 2011 budget.

title: No Comment, Please
description: Over the years, some of my husbands business clients have become friends. Recently, one of them left his wife of 20 years, a dear friend, only to take up with another woman in a whirlwind, post-every-feeling-on-Facebook, talk-about-your-great-sex-life kind of affair. My husband doesnt want to offend his client, but may I nudge him toward more modesty, at least until he starts divorce proceedings?

title: With Conan on the Way, Leno a Late-Night Loser to Letterman
description: In a development that NBC certainly doesnt need with Conan OBrien about to mount his late-night comeback on Monday, Jay Leno, who replaced Mr. OBrien on The Tonight Show in January, lost across the board in ratings to CBSs David Letterman last week.

title: The Way Home Is Through Huapapa
description: Monday, Nov. 1

title: The Other Mendelssohn Finds a New Champion
description: Fanny Mendelssohn, a gifted pianist, composer and conductor who was overshadowed in her lifetime by her famous younger brother, Felix, is primarily remembered today for her short piano pieces and songs. But her catalog of almost 500 works also includes three sacred cantatas; Das Jahr, a large-scale piano work; and concert arias.

title: Every Little Horse He Names Is Magic (Or Just About)
description: Like Jerry Moss, Sting is no stranger to success. Sting achieved superstardom as the frontman of the rock trio, The Police, on Mosss A&M Records label. So perhaps it seems fitting that the most decorated racehorse that Moss has ever owned is named after the bands third album, Zenyatt Mondatta.

title: Thursday TimesCast: The Republican Revival
description: In Thursdays TimesCast, how House Republicans plotted their way back to the majority.

title: Enthusiasm Gap Was Largest in Presidential Swing States
description: There are various ways to measure the enthusiasm gap that was manifest on Tuesday night. For example, exit polls suggested that an equal number people identifying as Democrats and Republicans turned out on Tuesday night. By contrast, Democrats led by 7 points on this measure in 2008.

title: Living With Music: A Playlist by Bill Peschel
description: Bill Peschels new book, Writers Gone Wild, has just been published.

title: Living With Music: A Playlist by Bill Peschel
description: Bill Peschels new book, Writers Gone Wild, has just been published.

title: G.M.s Roadshow Makes a Stop on the Web
description: As General Motors executives sprint through a nine-day roadshow for its $10 billion initial public offering, you may be curious about what exactly the auto makers pitch is.

title: Canterbury Tales in Staten Island and Other Budget Fun
description: I only preach of avarice and the like, and in this way induce them to be free in giving cash  especially to me, says the Pardoner in Chaucers famous tales. Well, save your cash, because the miser is offering a weekend of free readings, talks and Friday Night Lights.

title: Lantern Slides at Getty Museum and American Museum of Natural History
description: A COLORFUL HISTORY,

title: Bayou's Quagmire for Goldman
description: Goldman Sachs is hoping to overturn a $20.6 million fine for its role as a clearing firm for the hedge fund Bayou. Wall Street firms say that their job is to clear the trade, not police the clients.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Four Lions'
description: Chris Morris, the director of the terrorism satire Four Lions, discusses a scene from his film.

title: Amok on the Road to Daddydom
description: Early in Due Date the odd-couple main characters, Peter and Ethan, visit a pot dealer. As Ethan (Zach Galifianakis) checks out the bud, his reluctant companion, Peter (Robert Downey Jr.), waits in the living room with the dealers two children. Peter has been kicked off a plane and forced into a car with Ethan, and he isnt happy. He swats away the childrens questions and mocks the girl, and her brother, who looks about 9, bounces a toy off Peters head in seeming retaliation. One thing leads to another, and Peter punches the boy in the stomach so hard that the child doubles over, which certainly gives the expression belly laugh new meaning.

title: House Tour: East Marion, N.Y.
description: WHAT Five-bedroom ranch house overlooking Long Island Sound.

title: Ragtag Group of Survivors, Fending Off Fires and Rage
description: There was a moment on Wednesday night, as the Brooklyn Academy of Musics Next Wave Festival rolled inexorably forward, when I had the wild hope that someone might shout Fire! in the crowded theater of the Howard Gilman Opera House.

title: Pictures of the Day: Costa Rica and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Costa Rica, Indonesia and Switzerland.

title: Movie Listings for Nov. 5-11
description: Movies

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Nov. 5-11
description: Pop

title: Interview: Damien Chazelle
description: The director Damien Chazelle discusses the idea behind "Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench," his indie  black-and-white musical shot in 16 millimeter.

title: Announcement of New Jackson Album Is Kind of a Thriller
description: Hey, you: Do you like Michael Jackson? Have you spent the last eight months anxiously trolling the Internet for news of his posthumously assembled album of outtakes and unfinished tracks? Are you O.K. with long, tease-filled marketing campaigns? Yes?

title: Touch of Croatia in Judiths Story
description: Spirituality, in its myriad guises, is the express concern of the White Light Festival, a novel multidisciplinary series now running at Lincoln Center. Yet even positioned amid masterworks by Bach and Brahms, an electronic installation inspired by Renaissance church music and a dance derived from martial arts, Judith, a semistaged dramatization of a 16th-century epic on a biblical theme, made for a curious fit. Katarina Livljanic, a Croatian singer and musicologist, presented the works New York premiere with members of the Ensemble Dialogos at the Kaplan Penthouse on Wednesday evening.

title: Marathoners and Other Runners Find Benefits in Sprinting
description: LAST fall, when my usual strength workouts were starting to feel tired, and my six-mile runs were stuck at just under an hour, my trainer suggested adding sprints to the mix.

title: Pictures of the Day: Costa Rica and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Costa Rica, Indonesia and Switzerland.

title: Where Marxists Make Merry
description: If communists have a reputation for anything, it is seriousness. (And if you have seen old photos of Karl Marx, you know that he did not smile much.) But at the Brecht Forum, a community center on West Street where revolutionaries and radicals gather daily to ponder and to pontificate, they also play. (Smiles abound.)

title: Jazz Listings for Nov. 5-11
description: Jazz

title: Ear-Catching, Modern Madrigals for String Quartet
description: It says a lot for Stephen Hartkes Night Songs for a Desert Flower (2009) that when the Brentano String Quartet performed the work alongside quartets by Haydn and Beethoven at Zankel Hall on Wednesday evening, it seemed fully a part of the continuum: a modern extension of the musical language those composers spoke and as eloquent in its way as the music of its celebrated predecessors.

title: On His Own, Still Summoning the Drama
description: Sam Newsome compresses a lot of energy into the sound of his soprano saxophone, but he isnt out to overwhelm you with it. Hes a clear-headed improviser, adept with space and tension. He has an outsize command of the horn, especially in the realm of extended technique: split-tone multiphonics, slap-tongue articulation, seamless circular breathing. What you notice most in his playing, though, is the tight drama of unfolding logic.

title: When Dinner Dress Is Fan Regalia
description: In the in-box this week: questions about where to eat before the big game and after turning the big 5-0. Send your dining puzzles to dinejournal@nytimes.com or Twitter.com/samsifton.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Nov. 5-11
description: Classical

title: A Mixed Forecast for the Housing Market
description: WHEN it comes to the housing market, predictions are perilous business. A market that looked as if it was verging on a renaissance one month could, depending on the factors that go into analyzing it, look pretty lousy the next.

title: Dance Listings for Nov. 5-11
description: Dance

title: The Fake Scandals Begin
description: One of the things those of us who remember the 90s really dont miss is the parade of fake scandals  the endless investigations into alleged White House misdeeds (140 hours of sworn testimony into allegations that the Clintons had misused their Christmas card list).

title: Yankees to Play Santa, for a Price
description: The Yankees hope to ring in the Christmas season with their fans this year. For the first time, the team is hosting a Breakfast With Santa on the mornings of Dec. 4 and 5 at the Hard Rock Cafe at Yankee Stadium.

title: Long-Form Journalism Finds an Online Friend
description: Anyone whos spent time writing for the Web knows the basic rule: Keep it short. Attention spans, we are told, are collapsing faster than pig houses on Angry Birds. At this rate, municipalities wont just fluoridate their city water supply, theyll have to Ritalinize it as well.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Nov. 5-11
description: Art

title: White House Pushes Back on Tax Cuts for Wealthy
description: While President Obama again signaled interest in finding common ground with Republicans in the wake of their electoral triumph, the White House on Thursday drew a firmer line against making permanent Bush-era tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans.

title: Spare Times for Nov. 5-11
description: Around Town

title: Dear FloFab: Fine Dining for Beginners
description: Each week, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: Mets Suspend Clubhouse Manager
description: 9:46 p.m. | Updated Charlie Samuels, the Mets longtime clubhouse manager, has been suspended after the team learned he was tied to a law-enforcement investigation into illegal gambling, according to a lawyer briefed on the matter and a law-enforcement official.

title: Spare Times: For Children, for Nov. 5-11
description: Betsy Is Bored, Bored,

title: Microsoft Advances Gaming
description: On Wednesday in Times Square, consumers lined up in anticipation for Microsoft's new gaming product, the Kinect, which went on sale at midnight.

title: Life After Soaps
description: Generations of New York actors have derived steady work and income from daytime serials but that work is disappearing as longtime soaps end.

title: The Blissed-Out Rhythms of the Young and in Love
description: Visually distinctive and aurally delightful, Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench has style to burn. A soulful black-and-white commentary on love, art and their competing demands, this Boston-based musical from Damien Chazelle floats on a wave of spontaneity and charm.

title: New Yorks Rare Family Compounds
description: RESTORATION work is under way on the facade of the town house at 16 East 84th Street, one of a neo-Georgian triplet of dwellings built in 1901 by the socially prominent King family.

title: Forest Gems
description: A look at some of the forest areas in four New York City boroughs.

title: China: New Subway Line Planned for Beijing
description: Trains on the longest subway line in China will make a trial run before the end of the year, traveling a 30-mile route between southwest and northwest Beijing, Xinhua, the state news agency, reported Thursday. The route connects an existing line with a new 14-mile extension. City officials say they hope the new line will help alleviate clogged roads. In recent months, Beijing residents have complained that traffic in and around the city has been worse than anytime in years. A recent traffic jam from outside Beijing toward Inner Mongolia lasted for 10 days and drew international attention. Xinhua reported that Beijing has four million cars on the roads, and the city is one of the most congested in the world. Beijing plans to open four other new lines by the end of 2010.

title: Potholes Along the Laugh Track
description: WHAT glories await a brave, wisecracking upstart who decides to pursue a career in stand-up comedy? If you can distinguish yourself at the microphone, maybe youll earn your own headlining tour, movie roles or a television show, or a spot on the lineup of the New York Comedy Festival, the annual celebration of setups and punch lines that started on Wednesday and runs through Sunday. But prepare for a few rites of passage: antagonistic crowds, unglamorous performance spaces, living out of a suitcase while crisscrossing the country from club to club. And dont expect any of that to change, even after youve become a household name.

title: Nbc To Cancel Undercovers
description: NBC is ending the run of what was once one of its most promising new series of the season with the decision that it will not order any more episodes of Undercovers. The show had been highly anticipated because it came from the executive producer J. J. Abrams of Lost and it had kicked off a bidding war among the networks last year when Mr. Abrams pitched the idea. The show, about two spectacular-looking undercover agents who also happen to be a married couple running a high-end catering business, was also notable because its stars were black. Scheduled on Wednesdays at 8 p.m., the show never took off in the ratings, and the numbers that arrived Thursday for the previous night revealed it had hit a new low. Only about 5.8 million viewers tuned in. NBC said it would probably still broadcast the six remaining episodes that have been produced.

title: Mirs Odd Homage to Dutch Masters
description: Ever the contrarian, the Catalan painter Joan Mir rebelled by turning to the old masters. And not just any old masters: he started with the homely genre scenes of Jan Steen and Hendrick Sorgh, with their stock characters of misbehaving maids, soused guests and impish children. In the Metropolitan Museums Mir: The Dutch Interiors, these presences become floating, Surrealist apparitions  unmoored and ambiguous but still mischievous.

title: I Feel Bad About My Memory
description: Nora Ephron worries about a failing memory in the title piece of I Remember Nothing, her inviting new collection of essays. But even her most amnesiac readers still remember I Feel Bad About My Neck, the 2006 collection that this new book closely resembles. That resemblance is helpful in some ways and alarming in others.

title: Generating Inflation Expectations
description: A number of readers have asked how the Fed can change inflation expectations when it has little or no current traction  that is, what can the Fed actually do?

title: The God-Science Shouting Match: A Response
description: In reading the nearly 700 reader responses to my Oct. 17 essay for The Stone, (Morals Without God?) I notice how many readers are relieved to see that there are shades of gray when it comes to the question whether morality requires God. I believe that such a discussion needs to revolve around both the distant past, in which religion likely played little or no role if we go back far enough, and modern times, in which it is hard to disentangle morality and religion. The latter point seemed obvious to me, yet proved controversial. Even though 90 percent of my text questions the religious origins of human morality, and wonders if we need a God to be good, it is the other 10 percent  in which I tentatively assign a role to religion  that drew most ire. Atheists, it seems (at least those who responded here) dont like any less than 100 percent agreement with their position.To have a productive debate, religion needs to recognize the power of the scientific method and the truths it has revealed, but its opponents need to recognize that one cannot simply dismiss a social phenomenon found in every major society. If humans are inherently religious, or at least show rituals related to the supernatural, there is a big question to be answered. The issue is not whether or not God exists  which I find to be a monumentally uninteresting question defined, as it is, by the narrow parameters of monotheism  but why humans universally feel the need for supernatural entities. Is this just to stay socially connected or does it also underpin morality? And if so, what will happen to morality in its absence?

title: The Really Strange Bedfellows That New York Politics Made
description: If you have followed the strange tale of Eliot Spitzer  and who hasnt these days, what with his running a vigorous rehabilitation campaign  you get the sense that the former governor of New York must have read his share of Greek classics. In Alex Gibneys new documentary, Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer, Mr. Spitzer says that hubris played a role in his stumble. Like Peter Elkinds recent book, Rough Justice: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer, the movie quotes from a 2005 speech in which Mr. Spitzer jokingly describes a T-shirt that he was given with Hubris is terminal on it. After being exposed, Mr. Spitzer told an aide, Welcome to a Greek tragedy.

title: Near Vukovar, Serbias President Apologizes
description: Serbias president, Boris Tadic, crossed the Danube on Thursday to meet his Croatian counterpart, Ivo Josipovic, and together the two men visited memorials to both Serb and Croat prisoners and civilians who were executed during the fierce battle for control of the city of Vukovar nearly two decades ago.

title: A Social Media Firestorm About Apple Pies
description: The blogosphere is abuzz this afternoon with a story about Monica Gaudio, a writer who found an article she wrote in 2005 about the evolution of English apple pie recipes in a food magazine called Cooks Source. The issue? Ms. Gaudio said she had never been contacted by the publication about using her article. Thanks to the Internet, the debate has been playing out on the likes of Twitterand Facebookand the authors own LiveJournal page, where Ms. Gaudio wrote about how she tried contacting the publication after a friend told her he had seen her article in it. According to the post, Ms. Gaudio contacted Judith Griggs, the magazines editor, and asked for the following:

title: Is It Really a Pension? Its a Problem
description: Is Social Security a pension plan?

title: Stay Tuned for Soap Stars Next Acts
description: IF people at the Knitting Factory recognized Jake Silbermanns cornflower-blue eyes last month, they were too cool to let on. The handsome Mr. Silbermann, looking considerably more pulled together in a sport coat and sweater combo than most of the 20-somethings attending the Royal Flush film festival at this Brooklyn club, took questions from the small audience following a screening of his short film Stuffer.

title: New Yorks Rare Family Compounds
description: Family compounds were always few and far between in New York City. But traces of some of the old enclaves can still be seen.

title: New Policy on Safeguarding Information
description: President Obama on Thursday rolled back a proliferating array of markings by which federal agencies have kept unclassified information from the public, issuing an executive order intended to create a uniform way of handling such information.

title: Marital Strife and C.I.A. Obligations
description: Fair Game, directed by Doug Liman from a screenplay by the brothers Jez and John-Henry Butterworth, is partly, maybe even primarily, the portrait of a modern marriage under stress.

title: The Rich, Detailed Fullness Found in Empty
description: The Buddhist influence on art of the past 50 years is, like much else in the Buddhist worldview, immeasurable. Grain of Emptiness: Buddhism-Inspired Contemporary Art, at the Rubin Museum of Art, wisely doesnt attempt such a survey. Instead it offers up an eclectic, not-the-usual-suspects group of five artists: Sanford Biggers, Theaster Gates, Atta Kim, Wolfgang Laib and Charmion von Wiegand.

title: Seeping Out of Houston, Slowly
description: THROUGHOUT the 1990s, DJ Screw pioneered hip-hops slide into the psychedelic. From his base on Houstons south side, his method of slowing and manipulating records, a style that came to be known as chopped and screwed  or just screw music  took rap to a state of primordial ooze. His music was woozy and immersive, elastic and gummy, and also an apt companion to the prescription-grade cough syrup that was one of the citys favored narcotics. He was the figurehead for the style up until he died, from an overdose of codeine in combination with other drugs, in 2000.

title: Democrat Wins Illinois Governor Race
description: CHICAGO  Gov. Patrick J. Quinn was declared the winner of the race for governor of Illinois by The Associated Press this afternoon.

title: Is Microsofts Xbox Kinect Racist? No.
description: On Wednesday night, the gaming site GameSpot posted an article raising the question of whether Microsofts new Xbox Kinect  the facial and body-recognition system that allows you to play video games by simply moving your body, no controller required  had difficulty recognizing faces with dark skin tones.

title: What Springsteen Kept to Himself
description: Colts Neck, N.J.

title: Meager Means, Rich Imagination
description: The self-taught artist Eugene Von Bruenchenhein was a slight man of meager means. Born in Marinette, Wis., in 1910, the son of a sign painter and shopkeeper, he never finished high school, and once the family moved to Milwaukee, lived most of his life in a small house built by his father. He was too short to serve in the Army during World War II. He worked in a flower shop and then a bakery, and after health problems forced an early retirement in 1959, when he was 49, he got by on a Social Security check of $220 a month until his death in 1983.

title: Some Venti Tunes to Go With That Latte
description: TIMOTHY JONES would blush at the notion, but hes one of the quiet shapers of American culture.

title: Protracted Wait for G.M. Payback
description: Taxpayers will have to wait a while to reclaim the money invested to keep General Motors out of the scrapyard. The carmaker is running far more smoothly after declaring bankruptcy last year: it earned as much as $2.1 billion in the three months to September, its third straight quarter of profits. But the terms of G.M.s coming share sale show that, once public, the stock will have to as much as double before its biggest shareholder, the United States government, gets close to breaking even.

title: A Powerful Chorus Harmonizing Dark Phrases of Womanhood
description: Tyler Perry has been led out to critical slaughter so many times, it might seem a wonder that he continues to make movies. Except that Mr. Perry addresses his movies to black audiences and, until recently, has shown relatively little interest in crossing over. His enormous commercial success with a mainly black audience and the often ferociously hostile reviews from mostly white critics might seem symptomatic of an insurmountable racial divide. Black people love him and white people dont get him, and that sort of thing, which might be somewhat true but ignores that another important dividing line runs along taste and not color.

title: A Draftsman Who Turned More and More to Dynamism
description: Degas was an end and a beginning, a bridge between the neo-classicism of his teachers teacher, Ingres, and the painting of modern life by that scruffy band of outsiders known as the Impressionists. He was a draftsman of preternatural gifts, the last major artist in a line going back to Giotto to make exacting delineation of the real world a central drive. But in his acute attention to empirical experience, stripped bare of the academic apparatus of myth, historicism and moralizing, he also was a quintessentially modern man.

title: Week 9 in Fantasy Football: Matchups and Q. and A.
description: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 9. They also answered reader questions earlier this week. Read their answers below and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

title: Once on Sleepy Beat, Regulator Is Suddenly Busy
description: Cotton, sugar, silver, wheat: in investment circles, commodities like these are hot.

title: Louisiana Rethinks Its Sand Berms
description: In a story in late October, I reported on the continuing effort by Louisiana to build sand berms in the Gulf of Mexico to block and capture oil from the BP spill. Back in June, BP ponied up $360 million for the berms, of which roughly $140 million was left.

title: In New York City Parks, a Fall-Color Tour
description: STANDING atop the breezy peak of Moses Mountain on a recent afternoon, I was struck by the juxtaposition of two facts: One, all I could see in any direction was a dense canopy of red maple, oak and hickory treetops, the leaves revealing autumns first golden blush. Two, I was in Staten Island.

title: Paradise or Prison?
description: David Carr unplugs for six days on Little Deadman's Cay.

title: Politics and Baseball: Where the Wild Things Are
description: What a week in fashion it was, and Im not even talking about the long drum roll up to the Lanvin sale at H & M. Rather, I refer to the exuberant displays of hair and fashion we saw in politics and baseball.

title: Breathe In, Breathe Out, Fall in Love
description: IN the front hall of the Victorian house was a laminated sign that said Shoes, and underneath it a row of Birkenstocks and Danskos stretched along the wall. I could hear voices coming from the meditation hall upstairs, so I figured people were already finding their seats. I sat down and pulled off my motorcycle boots, wishing every object had its own little sign. If only my ex-boyfriend had worn a sign the night before that said ex-boyfriend, I would not have slept with him.

title: Harebrained Plans by Half-Wits
description: Terrorism is stupid. Terrorists are stupid. It seems to me that these truths have not been sufficiently acknowledged, especially by movies, which tend to imagine terrorists as the diabolically clever authors of complicated conspiracies. But surely the recent historical record suggests that for every extremist mastermind scheming in a cave somewhere, there are innumerable stooges, fools and copycats, their dreams of glory tethered to half-baked ideas and harebrained plots. Incompetence married to zeal is hardly benign  dumb people have done their share of damage in the world  but it can nonetheless be funny.

title: Sacrificing Some Star Power to Reinvent the Patriot Way
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Tom Brady and Deion Branch sit next to each other in the New England locker room, a throwback to a time when Bradys hair was more buzz cut than Bieber and the Patriots were the N.F.L.s darlings instead of its dominators.

title: All the Presidents Memories
description: We seem to be witnessing a renaissance in protests  if thats the word for it  against political books. When Sarah Palin went on a bus tour last fall to promote Going Rogue, a man at the Mall of America threw tomatoes at her. When Tony Blair appeared in Dublin to promote his memoir, A Journey, people threw eggs and shoes. During Karl Roves recent tour in support of Courage and Consequence, a handcuff-carrying activist tried to arrest him for war crimes  twice. Thank goodness George W. Bush, whose Decision Points hits stores on Nov. 9, already comes with a Secret Service detail.

title: Porgy and Bess Will Be Reincarnated  As a Musical
description: Suzan-Lori Parks, the Pulitzer-Prize winning playwright of Topdog/Underdog, and Diedre Murray, the musician and composer, are developing a new version of Porgy and Bess that features rearrangements of George Gershwins famed score and plays down its roots as an opera.

title: Two Say Pelosi Should Step Aside as Leader
description: With Speaker Nancy Pelosi still deliberating about her future, some House Democrats are not waiting to make their own feelings known.

title: 'The Dutch Interiors'
description: A look at how Joan Mir transposed some of Steen and Sorghs figures into his own works.

title: A Stoic Marine Undone by Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: You could bounce quarters off the taut abdominals of Alexandra Everett (Dreya Weber), the blond, self-assured protagonist of Ned Farrs film A Marine Story. A Marine major who has served four deployments in Iraq, Alexandra is first seen returning to her hometown in the California desert in the summer of 2008 and briskly walking the 10 miles from the train station to the house where she grew up.

title: Who Got the Most Bang for Their Bucks?
description: After all the talk about the impact of independent groups on this years midterm elections, the debate over at least one important question can now begin in earnest: Which groups were the most effective?

title: Animated Ambiguity, Featuring a Big Head
description: Michael Jacksons Bad, blasted near the end of Megamind, the witty 3-D animated deconstruction of superhero movies from DreamWorks Animation, encapsulates the paradoxes of a story in which evil morphs into good and vice versa. There was always something innately silly in Jacksons wispy-voiced, childlike affectation of macho ferocity. My first reaction to a singer whose clout suggested a crooked finger more than a clenched fist was, Oh, come off it, little boy.

title: Accommodations Angst
description: EXTRA time. More breaks. A small, quiet room. Seeking such accommodations on entrance exams can be a journey of angst for students with learning disabilities and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. A new set of federal regulations, published in September and effective in March, could smooth the path.

title: Special Section on the Sandwich Generation
description: Aging parents run short on money just at the time that they need specialized care. Adult children fail to launch and move back home with their parents. And people in their 40s, 50s and 60s are stuck in the middle, supporting the older and younger generations amid their own uncertainty about continued employment.

title: Wealthy and Worried, India Is Rich Arms Market
description: A big item on President Obamas India to-do list this weekend is securing a $5 billion deal for Boeing to sell 10 of its C-17 cargo planes.

title: A Games Big Players
description: Jews and Baseball: An American Love Story chronologically name-checks historys most famous Jewish ballplayers, from the 19th-century pioneer Lipman Pike to the current Red Sox mainstay Kevin Youkilis. The film tosses off instantly forgettable fun facts before pausing to dwell on two superstars: Hank Greenberg, who played first base and outfield for the Detroit Tigers in the 1930s and 40s, and Sandy Koufax, the Dodgers legendary lefty from the 1950s and 60s. Both men made national headlines when they decided not to play in important games on Yom Kippur.

title: Name Debate Echoes an Old Clash of Faiths
description: CRDOBA, Spain  The great mosque of Crdoba was begun by the Muslim caliphs in the eighth century, its forest of pillars and red-and-white striped arches meant to convey a powerful sense of the infinite. With the Christian reconquest of Spain in the 13th century, it was consecrated as a cathedral.

title: McConnell Eases Talk of a Thaw
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Mitch McConnell, the minority leader, said Thursday that the only way his party would succeed in advancing its agenda was to ensure that President Obama was defeated in two years, seemingly bringing a quick end to post-election professions from both sides about working together.

title: Cleopatra
description: That Egyptian Woman

title: Femme Fatale
description: Papyri crumble away. What remains of her home is 20 feet underwater. She died before Jesus was born. Her first biographers never met her, and she deliberately hid her real self behind vulgar display. A cautious writer would never consider her as a subject. Stacy Schiff, however, has risen to the bait, with deserved confidence. Saint-Exupry: A Biography and Vra (Mrs. Vladimir Nabokov) demonstrated her mastery of the form. The Great Improvisation, Schiffs analysis of Benjamin Franklins years in Paris, revealed a different genius: the intellectual stamina required to untangle the endlessly tricky snarls created by the intersection of human personalities and international relations.

title: Tea Party Moves Quickly to Flex Muscle
description: WASHINGTON  The incoming leadership of the new House Republican majority hardly had a chance to relish its dismantling of the Democrats before the Tea Party came calling in the form of Representative Michele Bachmann.

title: Social Security: Pension Plan or Transfer System?
description: Sixteen years ago, I wrote a column on Social Security, and got more negative mail than I have ever received before or since for anything I have written. You can read samples here, here, here, here, here, and here.

title: Nomination for Massachusetts Chief Justice
description: BOSTON  Gov. Deval Patrick, newly elected to a second term, nominated Justice Roderick L. Ireland on Thursday to be the first black chief justice of the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court.

title: Gal Takes Straighter Path, Hoping to Have It All
description: There are enough funny lines and successful bits of comic business scattered through Casper Andreass Violet Tendencies  an ugly-duckling fairy tale about a woman with lots of gay friends who is looking for love herself  to keep you amused as long as your expectations arent particularly high, or if your primary agenda is to ogle the beefcake. Two men in bed: I love you. Whats my name? Pause. I am so in love with you.

title: Western Meets Horror
description: Western meets horror in the Australian high country in Red Hill, a galloping revenge tale that uses young blood to unearth old sins.

title: Citigroup Prevails in Lawsuit Over EMI Deal
description: By PETER LATTMAN

title: Vermont Nuclear Plant Up for Sale
description: Entergy Nuclear, evidently convinced that the Vermont legislature will not allow the company to run the Vermont Yankee nuclear plant for another 20 years, announced on Thursday that the plant was up for sale.

title: Ready for New Yorks Streets After Defying Death in Mine
description: Edison Pea blinked in the glare of camera flashes and shook his head as if in disbelief that he was in New York to run the marathon. Humble in his crisp black suit and brown shoes, he may be a miner by trade, but he is a runner at his core. Nothing daunts him now, not even singing an Elvis solo.

title: Donor Groups Find Success in Elections
description: After all the talk about the impact of independent groups on this years midterm elections, the debate over at least one important question can now begin in earnest: Which groups were the most effective?

title: With Debut of Conan, Marketers Join Team Coco
description: EARLIER this year, millions of comedy fans, college students, Harvard alumni and insomniacs joined Team Coco, the fanciful name for devotees of Conan OBrien that sprang up during his final days at NBC. Now, the ranks of Team Coco are being swelled by major marketers like AT&T, General Motors, Microsoft and the News Corporation.

title: Damage Control
description: In the time since my Home Fires post, Death and Memory, was published, Ive received a number of illuminating and often quite touching responses from readers. Id like to address some of them here.

title: A Freshman Year to Remember
description: From the title on down, Cherry is an icky, sticky movie, designed to titillate and tug the heartstrings at the same time. It starts out looking like a freshman-year coming-of-age story, as Aaron (the Ed Westwick lookalike Kyle Gallner) is driven by his domineering mother and ineffectual father to an unnamed Ivy League college, where he meets his roommate, an oversexed future frat boy. (The suspiciously small campus was actually in Kalamazoo, Mich., a center of both higher learning and film-production tax credits.)

title: Disney Junior to Focus on Social Values
description: LOS ANGELES  Move aside, Sesame Street and Dora the Explorer. Mothers want preschool television to be more about teaching children social skills and less about pushing clear academic goals  at least thats what Disney executives say new internal research indicates.

title: With Second Tier, a Hotter Stove This Winter
description: Last winter, when a relatively weak class of free agents prompted many teams to fill their needs through trades, the refrain around baseball was just wait until 2010. But with Roy Halladay, Josh Beckett and Joe Mauer having signed contract extensions, and with other stars losing their luster or recovering from injury, a once-deep pool of top talent has given way to a group that, as it did last year, centers on an ace and two outfielders.

title: Plumbing the Head
description: This is the eighth in a series.

title: Jet Engine Failure Causes Worry on Manufacturer
description: The blowout of an engine on Qantas Flight 32 on Thursday was the latest in a series of problems involving Rolls-Royce engines and analysts said it raised serious questions about the companys ability to develop the engines for the newest generation of commercial and military airplanes.

title: After Months of Feuding, Obama Makes Overture to Business Group
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is moving to cool down his war with the United States Chamber of Commerce, one of the most bitter political feuds of the last two years.

title: Higher Levels of Lead Seen in City Tap Water
description: New York City health and environmental officials on Thursday advised residents to run their tap water for at least 30 seconds before drinking or cooking with it after testing showed a rise in the percentage of homes with elevated levels of lead.

title: India: The Next Generation
description: Ahead of President Obama's visit, young Indians shared their thoughts on the relationship between the two countries.

title: A Motel Stay Leads to Creepy Happenings
description: There are lots of reasons why horror filmmakers keep checking their characters into seedy motels: theyre cheap, reliably creepy and, with luck, will spark latent Psycho associations among viewers old enough to make them. Sometimes the strategy works  Identity (2003) and Vacancy (2007) are two of the more recent examples  but not even the Bates Motel itself could save the mess that is Beneath the Dark.

title: Obama Aide Adjusts Course for a Comeback
description: WASHINGTON  At a time of tumult, the corner office in the West Wing is a center of calm. With the rest of Washington in a frenzy over the shellacking President Obamas party took in this weeks elections, his new chief of staff quietly and methodically plots out a refashioned White House to manage his recovery.

title: Heisman Front-Runner Is Focus of Investigation
description: MADISON, Miss.  The N.C.A.A. is investigating Auburn Universitys recruitment of Cam Newton, a star quarterback and front-runner for the Heisman Trophy. John Bond, a former Mississippi State quarterback, said on Thursday that he was approached by a former teammate about a specified payment that would be required to secure Newton.

title: Baghdad Studio of Feisty TV Station Shut Down in Dispute With Iraqi Government
description: BAGHDAD  Baghdadiya, a satellite channel that broadcasts out of Cairo, is best known outside Iraq for its reporter Muntader al-Zaidi, who threw his shoes at President George W. Bush at a news conference in 2008.

title: Silence Before the Storm
description: The words of a president can convey  or conceal  a great deal of meaning. As the United States approached the central crisis in its history, there was no reason to expect great eloquence from the man whose election had precipitated that conflict. Abraham Lincoln was often described as an uncouth barbarian, and had received the least education of any presidential nominee in American history, save Andrew Jackson. Yet there he was in the fall of 1860, standing before the American people, the embodiment of their hopes and fears. In this politically charged atmosphere, the words that flowed from his pen, and his equally expressive silences, did a great deal to define the conflict coming into view. This occasional feature in the Disunion series will probe Lincolns language, looking at his speeches and public pronouncements during the long transition between his election eve on Nov. 5, 1860, and his First Inaugural Address on March 4, 1861.

title: The Sweet Tune of Perfection
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Jerry Moss has survived cancer. He has been inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. He is a Bronx native who went to college in Brooklyn but found a life in California, a good one. Still, he remains a Yankees fan, a devoted one.

title: For Obama, Foreign Policy May Offer Avenues for Success
description: WASHINGTON  The elections on Tuesday gutted the Democrats on the House Armed Services Committee, paved the way for a pro-Israel Cuban-American to preside over the House Foreign Affairs Committee and removed the most antiwar Democrat from the leading Senate foreign policy committee.

title: A Big Game Saturday. Good Luck Finding It.
description: The only televised college football game on Saturday between undefeated top 10 teams will not be on ESPN, CBS, ABC, ESPN2, ESPNU or Versus. It will be carried by a network that is not available to every cable home in the country and isnt even rated by Nielsen.

title: Pirated Films From Nigeria Are Seized in Brooklyn
description: For years, fans in Brooklyn have devoured films from Nigeria, paying $3 for bootlegged copies of the latest releases at utilitarian stores in the Flatbush neighborhood that distribute cellphones, calling cards and an evenings entertainment.

title: Scholars Reconsidering Italys Treatment of Jews in the Nazi Era
description: Italians took everything from Ursula Korn Seligs family during World War II, including a hotel the family owned on the Riviera and the money they carried after fleeing Germanys persecution of Jews in 1938.

title: Murray Wins Senate Race in Washington
description: In one of the nations straggler election contests, Senator Patty Murray of Washington won the Senate race in Washington state, narrowly defeating Dino Rossi, who conceded Thursday afternoon.

title: In Florida, a C.E.O. Prepared for Cuts
description: MIAMI  Many of the newly elected Republican governors have said they want to run their state like a business. But few have been as brash and bold in corporate life  or with their economic campaign proposals  as Rick Scott, Floridas new chief executive.

title: Lottery Numbers
How the Tea Party Fared
description: At least 44 candidates associated with the Tea Party won their races on Tuesday.

title: California Shifted, and So Did Jerry Brown
description: LOS ANGELES  Jerry Brown has seen this before: a budget in crisis, a Legislature divided, a state confronting the possibility that its glory days are behind it.

title: Delays at New York Airports Arent Improving, U.S. Says
description: Flights through New Yorks three major airports are delayed or canceled more often than anywhere else in the nation, and the governments efforts to correct the problem have so far come up short, the federal Transportation Department said Thursday.

title: For G.O.P., Big Ambitions Face Daunting Obstacles
description: WASHINGTON  Republican leaders in Congress are preparing to take power in two months with ambitious and sometimes contradictory goals for economic and fiscal policies, leaving little common ground with President Obama and much uncertainty about the potential impact on the nations problems.

title: Sonia Sotomayors Last Laugh
description: Justice Sonia Sotomayor is accustomed to being underestimated and to surpassing the expectations of her doubters. So Ill wonder if she even took the time to ponder the leak last week of a May 2009 letter to President Obama from a famous Harvard law professor lobbying for the selection of Elena Kagan to replace Justice David H. Souter, whose retirement had recently been announced. Im quite sure it is the professor, Laurence H. Tribe, rather than Justice Sotomayor, who is mortified by the revelation that he had dissed the soon-to-be-nominee, a graduate of Princeton and Yale Law School, as not as smart as she seems to think she is.

title: To Harlem Churchgoers, Marathon Is a Nuisance
description: There is dancing along the streets. Gospel, soul and salsa music blare from speakers and bandstands. Spectators jockey for position on sidewalks and side streets, while thousands of runners pass in dribbles and waves. Crowds cheer.

title: Iran Says It Gave Afghans $500 Million
description: Iran has given $500 million in official assistance to Afghanistan for infrastructure and other reconstruction projects in recent years, Mahmoud Barimani, a senior Iranian Foreign Ministry official, told the United Nations General Assembly on Thursday. Mr. Barimani accused the United States and its allies of destabilizing Irans neighbor and increasing the violence there rather than solving the countrys problems. In 2006, Iran reported that its aid had totaled $200 million. Last month President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan admitted that Iran had given his office bags of money worth millions of dollars. Mr. Barimani did not mention those payments.

title: German Artist Wins $100,000 Prize
description: Hans-Peter Feldmann, a German artist known for creating carefully conceived installations from everyday images, has won this years Hugo Boss Prize, the Guggenheim announced on Thursday night.

title: Bank of America Fights Pressure on Mortgages
description: Bank of America on Thursday rebuffed claims by a lawyer for several big investors, including the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, that it should buy back troubled mortgages because the loans were made improperly.

title: 'Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown'
description: Photos from the new Broadway musical.

title: Friday: Secret Phrase Contest
description: Because todays crossword involves a contest, it is being offered free to readers. Click here to download a PDF of the puzzle as it appears in the print edition.

title: Heres Your Valium, Whats Your Hurry?
description: Theyre giving out the wrong drug at the Belasco Theater, where Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown opened on Thursday night. As in the 1988 Pedro Almodvar movie that inspired this star-jammed musical, Valium is consumed in large quantities by many characters. That is so pharmaceutically irresponsible. What this production needs  immediately and intravenously  is Ritalin.

title: Human Development Report Shows Great Gains, and Some Slides
description: UNITED NATIONS  The world has made significant progress in income, education and health over the past 40 years, but the gains have been uneven and in some places war and the ravages of AIDS shortened life spans, according to a United Nations report on Thursday.
