If you want to read one of the books deluxe copies  the hand-numbered, hand-signed edition that comes with a slipcase, a special color photo frontispiece and a $350 price tag  youll have to wait even longer, until Nov. 30.

title: My Week in Collections
description: Human resources, strategic planning, lean manufacturing, cost cutting, social-media marketing, concept this, buzzword that, blah, blah, blah. In the end its all about money  specifically, getting someone to give you some. And thats what Ive been doing a lot of lately: trying to get a whole bunch of people who owe me money to pony up.

title: BlackRock Fund to Finance and Securitize U.S. Mortgages
description: A BlackRock fund will begin financing United States home loans this month customized for a new breed of residential mortgage-backed securities that avoids the conflicts tainting many of todays private issues, Reuters reported.

title: Jim Brown Should Be No. 1, but What About Most Underrated?
description: The NFL Network concluded its series on the N.F.L.s greatest players by naming Jerry Rice No. 1. Scroll to the bottom of the post for its top 10. Andy Barall,  who writes about pro football history for The Fifth Down, gives his No. 1 pick and his choice for the most underrated player. His top 10 is also at the bottom.

title: Penn Tops Ivy League in Profit
description: The University of Pennsylvania, the Ivy League school founded by Benjamin Franklin, outperformed its wealthiest peers by avoiding many hard-to-sell assets like real estate, according to Howard Marks, former chairman of the universitys investment committee, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: James Kwak criticizes Bank of America for mortgage-backed doublespeak.

title: Warming Up to British Hopes
description: Kate Miller is head of racing media for William Hill Company in England and works with the odds compilers in the companys Leeds office. She also is the daughter of the former racecourse bookmaker Charlie Miller, and knows her way around horses.

title: Obama Recasts Asia Trip as Jobs Mission
description: Talk about bad timing.

title: Explosions Strike 2 Mosques in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A suicide bomber detonated an explosives-laden vest inside a mosque in northwestern Pakistan during midday prayers on Friday, government officials said, a strike apparently aimed at people who had declined to support the Taliban.

title: Georgia Holds 13, Saying They Spied for Russia
description: MOSCOW  Georgias Interior Ministry announced Friday that it used a former Soviet officer to infiltrate Russias military intelligence service, uncovering dozens of covert agents working in Georgia.

title: Indonesias Volcano Erupts Again
description: MAGUWOHARJO, Indonesia  A powerful overnight eruption of Mount Merapi created chaos for Indonesias disaster response effort on Friday after an explosion of hot gases and debris killed scores of people and sent more than 160,000 villagers fleeing to underprepared evacuation camps.

title: The Pushback Against Dodd-Frank Begins
description: Now that Republicans have taken over the House of Representatives, theyre itching to tamp down the new financial services regulations passed by Congress this summer.

title: Was That a Lost Reference on 30 Rock?
description: Sure, its only one gag, but its like Hemingway referencing Fitzgerald, the Beatles acknowledging the Rolling Stones, or when the characters from Diffrent Strokes would cross over to Silver Spoons.

title: Democrat Declared to Win Conn. Governors Race
description: Three days after Connecticut was thrust into an unflattering national spotlight because of an embarrassing series of election mishaps, Dannel P. Malloy, the Democratic candidate, emerged victorious Friday over his Republican rival, Thomas C. Foley, in their bitter battle to become the next governor of Connecticut.

title: A.I.G. Reports $2.4 Billion Loss in 3rd Quarter
description: By MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

title: Zenyattas Inspiration Brings a Songwriter Back to Horses
description: In a bucket list moment, Julie June Stewart woke up at 4 a.m. and bought a ticket to the 2008 Belmont Stakes. She hasnt stopped going to the races since  when she isnt taking on a wildfire, hurricane or volcano as the nations leading expert in disaster airspace coordination.

title: Mapping Ecosystems, the Better to Conserve Them
description: Environmentalists have a special affinity for maps. Whether terrestrial or marine, the environment and its ills are tied to a geography that can be expressed in a rectilinear scale.

title: Complaint Box | Complaint Box
description: About a year ago, I submitted a lighthearted complaint to this section about my undying disdain for the stinky ginkgo trees in the Queens neighborhood in which I lived at the time. The editor expressed interest but regretfully told me that there were simply too many complaints to publish. Maybe in the future, I was told.

title: Jobs Data Highlights the Challenges for Washington
description: Good, but not good enough.

title: Strengthening Hurricane Swipes Haiti
description: LOGNE, Haiti  Hurricane Tomas swirled far enough offshore Friday to spare Haiti yet another catastrophe.

title: France to Investigate LVMH Stake in Herms
description: By CHRIS V. NICHOLSON

title: Video Shows Indonesians Fleeing Volcano
description: Updated | 4:07 p.m. As my colleague Aubrey Belford reports from Indonesia, the latest and most powerful eruption of the Mount Merapi volcano in central Java, late Thursday night, killed dozens of people and sent more than 160,000 villagers fleeing an explosion of hot gases.

title: BBC Staff Strikes Over Changes to Pension Plan
description: LONDON  Journalists at the British Broadcasting Corporation started a 48-hour strike Friday morning to protest planned pension cuts, causing some disruption to global programming.

title: Age Of Diminished Expectations
description: So, we have a strong jobs report  with total employment still 7 1/2 million less than it was three years ago, we had job gains slightly higher than the number needed to keep up with population growth.

title: Tension and Levity in Sao Paulo
description: INTERLAGOS, Brazil  I arrived in the paddock this morning under clear skies and very hot weather, but as the day progressed, the thickened clouds came and it rained. Theres a brilliant sunset as I write. Sorry to write about the weather, as if I have nothing else to say. No, in fact, the different kinds of weather is just an example of the different senses of atmosphere in the paddock.

title: Tension and Levity in Sao Paulo
description: INTERLAGOS, Brazil  I arrived in the paddock this morning under clear skies and very hot weather, but as the day progressed, the thickened clouds came and it rained. Theres a brilliant sunset as I write. Sorry to write about the weather, as if I have nothing else to say. No, in fact, the different kinds of weather is just an example of the different senses of atmosphere in the paddock.

title: Graphic Books Best-Sellers: Its  Superman?
description: Superman: Earth One, the first in a new series of graphic novels from DC Comics, is perched at No. 1 on the hardcover list. This installment, written by J. Michael Straczynski and illustrated by Shane Davis, wonders what would happen if the origin of the Man of Steel were told in the present day. The story not only chronicles the young Clark Kents journey to becoming Superman, but shows how he lands his job at The Daily Planet (which in this retelling is suffering from declining readership. Great Caesars Ghost!).

title: Bankers Trust
description: Theres something for everyone at F.D, the philanthropist and collector Fiona Druckenmillers new Midtown boutique. That is, if the everyone in question is seeking exquisite new and vintage jewels (the shop boasts an impressive cache of period Cartier and Van Cleef & Arpels), watches, sculptures, Art Deco furniture, photography, first-edition manuscripts and swanky barware. The interior, designed in collaboration with the dcor firm Pamela Banker Associates, is best described as cozy chic. We wanted it to be homey and welcoming, not intimidating, Druckenmiller says. People will hopefully feel comfortable enough to linger, have a coffee or glass of wine, and spend time learning about the objects that interest them.

title: Letter: The Womens Empowerment Issue
description: The Womens Empowerment Issue was an enlightening, challenging, inspirational read. What an amazing set of women were featured, from the courageous undocumented U.C.L.A. women to the marvelous president of Liberia, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, not to mention the inspiring venture philanthropists who have put their safe lives on hold to help others. Thank you for lifting up such a diverse group of women and for reminding us all of the difference we can make to empower women.

title: Fantasy Politics
description: Throughout his recent run for Senate, the Florida Republican Marco Rubio made a big deal of the sacrifices his Cuban immigrant family made so that I could live the American dream. By campaigns end, he was using the phrase so regularly that spokesmen for his Democratic opponent, Congressman Kendrick B. Meek, were reminding reporters that Rubio did not have a patent on it. The American dream mattered a lot in this election. Americans for Prosperity, a conservative activist group, laid out plans for repealing President Obamas health care reform and fighting environmental regulation at its Defending the American Dream Summit two months ago. The president, meanwhile, closed this falls campaign with an exhortation to restore the American dream for not just some, but for every, every, everybody in this great land. If both sides agree that the dream is imperiled, and that recovering it is a top national priority, then it may be this dreamof ours is not a unifying idea but a vague slogan, no more to be trusted than any other piece of campaign rhetoric.

title: Stats Appeal
description: Over the past year, friends and readers have sent me a number of reports from something called OkTrends, which offers up data-driven assessments of online behavior, like The Big Lies People Tell in Online Dating. Often these are enjoyable, and Ive even passed some along to others. I was dimly aware that OkTrends drew its conclusions from mining the data of OkCupid, a dating site. But I never thought much about that; Im not in the market for online dating. Even so, this informal distribution of entertaining research is also a de facto distribution of buzz for the OkCupid brand. Here, it seems, is data mining as marketing.

title: A Life in Pictures
description: At 29, youre the subject of a new book, Sophie Crumb: Evolution of a Crazy Artist, an album of drawings that was edited by you and your parents. It opens with a series of full-page color reproductions of crayon compositions you did as a 2-year-old. Can your parents be accused of exploiting you?  Thats hilarious. How can it be exploitation when Im well paid?

title: The Sons Against the Widow
description: Four months after he remarried, my father died in an accident. During his brief second marriage, he often told family and friends, Whats mine is mine, and whats hers is hers, indicating that he wanted his estate to go to me and my brother, as stipulated in his will. (My mother died from cancer about five years ago.) But New York law allows a spouse to claim about one-third of that, and his widow intends to, despite my fathers wishes, although she has resources of her own. This is legal, but is it ethical? NAME WITHHELD, LONG ISLAND

title: The Headache That Wouldnt Go Away
description: My arm  something is biting my arm! The 26-year-old woman struggled to sit up in bed. Whats wrong? her husband asked, alarmed and suddenly wide awake. His wife didnt seem to hear him. Suddenly, her whole body began to jerk. Although he had never seen a seizure, the young man knew immediately that this was one. After a long and terrifying minute the jerking stopped and his wife lay quiet with her eyes closed, as if she were asleep. When he couldnt wake her, he picked up the phone and dialed 911.

title: Letters: Party and Punishment
description: While I agree wholeheartedly with Virginia Heffernans assessment in The Medium that the partying, out-of-control woman is a particular object of fear and revulsion, I find it unfortunate that she used my comments as grist for her argument. My comments are not reserved exclusively for celebrities  or for women. Let me be clear that I would have offered that same comment had the subject in question been a man. Furthermore, the use of my comments to support Heffernans thesis that we demonize fun-loving women requires a complete disregard for the context in which they originally were made. I was responding to a question about what lengths I would go to, as a father, should one of my children (I have 17-year-old triplets) develop a life-threatening addiction, all other measures having been exhausted.

title: Letter: An Uncompromising Woman
description: Anyone who knows the situation in Liberia would take issue with Daniel Bergners characterization of President Sirleaf as an uncompromising woman. Any leader of a country in a situation like Liberias will have to compromise every day in every way with giant donors like the World Bank, the E.U. and the U.S. State Department, not to mention the competing interests and demands of a war-ravaged population and a political class that is constantly fighting over a very small plate of spoils.

title: Letters: Coming Out Illegal
description: My husband and I both work to send our kids to college in California. We vote, pay taxes, do volunteer work and obey the law. The story about the illegal immigrants attending school with in-state tuition made us both livid. These illegals have no right to be in our country, and yet California, with huge financial problems, gives them in-state tuition! Whats wrong with this picture? Who gets to pick and choose which laws to enforce? Why should illegals get a break on anything?

title: The Rise of the Tao
description: YIN XINHUI reached the peak of Mount Yi and surveyed the chaos. The 47-year-old Taoist abbess was on a sacred mission: to consecrate a newly rebuilt temple to one of her religions most important deities, the Jade Emperor. But there were as yet no stairs, just a muddy path up to the pavilion, which sat on a rock outcropping 3,400 feet above a valley. A team of workers was busy laying stone steps, while others planted sod, trees and flowers. Inside the temple, a breeze blew through windows that were still without glass, while red paint flecked the stone floor.

title: Letters: Calling Mr. Mom?
description: What started as a discussion of womens lack of parity in the workplace devolved into a discussion about parental roles and responsibilities in and outside the home. When will womens lack of equality in the workplace be viewed as a valuable issue in its own right, rather than having to be related to motherhood? Parity has not been reached by childless women either, and we face the additional discrimination that workers without families face: the expectation that we cover for colleagues who are caring for sick children, work late because we dont have to pick up kids and support financing for on-site child care. Maybe once weve made more progress for working mothers, we can focus on treating all workers equally, whether they choose to procreate or not.

title: Letters: The D.I.Y. Foreign-Aid Revolution
description: It was a pleasure to read Nicholas D. Kristofs article on do it yourself foreign assistance. The efforts of private American citizens to advance human-development causes at the community level are exceptional stories that are frequently untold.

title: Prize Descriptions
description: I visit Wikipedia every day. I study the evolving entries for Internet-specific entities like World of Warcraft, Call of Duty, Foursquare and Picasa, often savoring the lucid exposition that Wikipedia brings to technical subjects that might not be expected to inspire poetry and for which no vocabulary has yet been set.

title: When Brother Becomes Sister
description: When my brother Dennis, now known as Dee, announced that he was transsexual, he gave me the Jan Morris book Conundrum. He explained that before he could do anything drastic  that is, undergo what is delicately referred to as gender-reassignment surgery  he had to have permission from a psychiatrist and live as a woman for a year. I let myself hope that Dennis would be content to stay semi-in-the-closet so he could keep his job teaching music at a Catholic school in the Bronx, that he might be content to feel subversive playing the organ in the choir loft while wearing ladies underpants. I should have known better: Dennis had always been capable of achieving with surprising speed things that seemed impossible, like saving up from his paper route to buy a pool table while in grade school. Within days of telling me he was transsexual, he was taking hormones. They stopped hair from growing on his hands and arms, encouraged breasts to grow (but not enough to please him) and discouraged male hormones, causing, eventually, a form of chemical castration.

title: Some People Find the Marathon Annoying
description: The New York City Marathon is this Sunday, which means thousands of runners making their way through every borough, innumerable fans, and many flavors of blaring music. Many regard the marathon as a joyous occasion, but others see it as a serious disruption in their lives, Trymaine Lee reports in The Times. And nowhere is the conflict between excited supporter and annoyed city dweller more apparent than at mile 21, or 138th Street in Harlem, when the marathon turns down Fifth Avenue for the final stretch. As some runners hit the wall and others push themselves for the finish, the race cuts a swath through the daily lives of the neighborhoods residents, for good or ill.

title: Citigroup Prevails in EMI Lawsuit
description: British financier Guy Hands had sought $8 billion from the banking giant over his ill-fated acquisition of the troubled music company EMI Group. The jury awarded him nothing.

title: The Entente Frugale
description: Nickname for a new 50-year Anglo-French military treaty.

title: Week 9 N.F.L. Matchups
description: Chiefs (5-2) at Raiders (4-4)Sunday, 4:15 p.m.Line: Raiders by 2 1/2The last time the weekly previews led off with a Chiefs-Raiders capsule, Len Dawson squared off against Daryle Lamonica, and Red Smiths analysis was peppered with Laugh-In references.

title: Why Zenyatta Matters
description: Leslie Knauf is a writer, editor, marketer and horsewoman in upstate New York who has been attending the races at Saratoga for nearly 50 years. She began riding horses at 9 and owned several thoroughbreds over the years that she rode for pleasure. She is confident they taught her far more than she ever could teach them.

title: Stretch Work: From Young To Old(er)
description: ON the surface Jonah Bokaer is nearly ethereal, with brown eyes that melt and a tendency to speak in near-whispers. But when he laughs  hearty and devilish  a more tangible side shines through: its as if Mr. Bokaer, 29, is an old man stuck in a young persons body.

title: Friday Reading: High-Risk Health Insurance Programs
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: The Week Ahead: Nov. 7  13
description: Art

title: Vain Glorious | Sex in a Bottle
description: When Frederic Malle, the master French perfumer, proclaims that his latest fragrance is one of his best ever, its nothing to sniff at. He knows from perfume. To celebrate his companys 10-year anniversary, Mr. Malle teamed up with one of his favorite noses  Dominique Ropion- to create Portrait of a Lady, a heady mixture of ingredients such as Turkish rose essence, raspberry, cassis, cinnamon, patchouli heart, ambroxan and musk. The resulting scent- lushly feminine, with a sensually earthy dry-down courtesy of the patchouli- is fragrant proof that this lady has some serious sex appeal. Available next month for $280 (100 ml) at Barneys New York, or join the waiting list at Malles Editions de Parfum, 898 Madison Avenue; (212) 249-7941.

title: New York Philharmonic Gets Approval for Trip to Cuba
description: The New York Philharmonics Cuba strategy worked. The United States Treasury Department has issued a license for the orchestra to visit Havana sometime next year, a Philharmonic spokesman said in an e-mail late on Thursday. (The orchestra was in Luxembourg, wrapping up a European tour.) The Philharmonic last year canceled the trip because the Treasury Department had denied permission for its patrons  who were paying for the visit  to go along, viewing them as tourists and thus not allowed under United States sanctions. The orchestra tried to get around the problem by adding an educational concert and listing the patrons as docents. The spokesman, Eric Latzky, said approval came late Wednesday. The dates still have to be worked out.

title: Putting Nutrition at the Head of the School Lunch Line
description: THE lunch menu at my sons elementary school  Public School 29 in Brooklyn  looked very tempting recently: vegetarian chili, sofrito brown rice, confetti corn salad, pico de gallo, salad bar, milk. Making the menu even more appealing was the price: $1.50.

title: Inside the List
description: SATISFACTION: Keith Richardss autobiography, Life (reviewed by Liz Phair on the cover of the Nov. 14 Book Review), hits the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 1, unsurprisingly. (My favorite line, from Page 524: Ive been cooking bangers all my life, and I only just found out from this lady on TV that you have to put bangers in a cold pan.)

title: What Were Reading
description: Village Voice: Robert Sietsemas 10 most challenging dishes in New York City. Respect.  Sam Sifton

title: More About Password Security
description: In my post about password security last week, I suggested that a good way to come up with different passwords for every site without having to remember or store them is to make up a simple routine or algorithm that converts the name of a site into an eight-character password.

title: Outside Boston, the Charming Larz Anderson Auto Museum
description: The Larz Anderson Auto Museum in Brookline, Mass., which bills itself as Americas oldest car collection, recently named a new curator and director of public programs, Sheldon Steele, who spoke of the museums origins in a recent interview at the museum.

title: Jury Begins Deliberation on Penalty for Killer
description: NEW HAVEN  The jury considering the fate of the convicted killer in the Cheshire home-invasion case deliberated on his penalty for the first time on Friday and sent out two notes indicating a deep division on the central question of the trial: whether or not the defendant, Steven J. Hayes, is to be sentenced to die.

title: Harmonious Is Ready for Her Close-Up
description: In a bucket list moment, Julie June Stewart woke up at 4 a.m. and bought a ticket to the 2008 Belmont Stakes. She hasnt stopped going to the races since  when she isnt taking on a wildfire, hurricane or volcano as the nations leading expert in disaster airspace coordination.

title: A Long Way From Boy Chorister
description: IN Elijah, the Old Testament oratorio by Felix Mendelssohn, the prophet has but one bar to collect himself before cutting loose with 1 Kings 17:1 (As God the Lord of Israel liveth, before whom I stand, there shall not be dew nor rain these years, but according to my word). Then the overture begins, and Elijah takes his seat for about 20 minutes, until called on to bring a child back from the dead, rout the priests of Baal and deal with the wicked royals Ahab and Jezebel.

title: A Man and His Bad Dreams: Coppola Turns a Nightmare Into a New Film
description: Just the memory of trying to get Marlon Brando to perform his lines in Apocalypse Now should be enough to provide Francis Ford Coppola with a lifetime of nightmares. But Mr. Coppola, the director whose films include The Godfather and The Outsiders, dreams of more universal terrors, and it was one such vision that inspired his coming film, Twixt Now and Sunrise, which he is currently shooting and plans to release next year.

title: Another Volcanic Eruption Raises Death Toll in Indonesia
description: An overnight blast from Mount Merapi pushed the number of deaths to more than 100 and spewed ash over several villages.

title: Medina Senghore and Kareem Collie
description: WHILE rules are useful  if not essential  to establishing order in a love life, the trick is knowing the precise moment to throw them out.

title: Beyond Tourism
description: The conviction that traveling in general, and walking in particular, can bring inspiration and even enlightenment is a very ancient one, and it exists in many cultures across the globe. As the old adage, taken up by the wandering scholars of medieval Europe, had it, Solvitur ambulando (It is solved by walking). In the sixth century B.C., the Indian saint Mahavira is said to have received enlightenment while walking, and the idea is still current. I recently met an itinerant Jain nun who told me: This wandering life, with no material possessions, unlocks our souls. There is a wonderful sense of lightness, living each day as it comes. For her, journey and destination became one, thought and action became one.

title: Cuban Plane Crash Kills 68 People
description: MEXICO CITY  Working amid dense thickets of thorny trees, rescue workers retrieved cockpit voice and data recorders on Friday from the wreckage of a plane that crashed in central Cuba, killing all 68 people aboard, Cuban media reported.

title: Neighborhood Watch
description: In three previous novels and a book of short fiction, Gish Jen draped her characters troubles in a mood of antic good humor, then gradually allowed those troubles to reveal themselves. In Typical American, readers came to understand, through Jens adroit storytelling, the disappointments beneath the resilience of the Chinese immigrants Ralph and Helen Chang; in Mona in the Promised Land, Jen gave us the identity struggles of the couples American-born daughter. Still more complex were the varieties of emotional experience among the Wong family in The Love Wife, whose chorus of voices began with an exuberant clamor and ended up somber, reflective and hushed.

title: The Diary of a Killer in Chechnya
description: Every so often a lengthy newspaper or magazine article arrives that all but demands a fuller and even longer treatment. Such was the case in the Oct 31. issue of The Sunday Times magazine in London, which published translated excerpts from the diary of a Russian spetsnaz officer who served for more than a decade as one of the Kremlins shadowy fighters in the Chechen wars. (Access to the article is protected by a pay-to-view firewall; to read it, youll have to buy at least a temporary subscription.)

title: Wall Street Schadenfreude
description: By HEIDI N. MOORE

title: Jousting Justices
description: In these equable days on the Supreme Court, when dissents are fashioned as polite disagreements and Antonin Scalia and Ruth Bader Ginsburg are the best of friends, it is hard to imagine a time when the court was a roiling caldron of ill will. But so it has been at various points in its history  nine scorpions in a bottle, in the phrase attributed, perhaps erroneously, to Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr.

title: Cuba Dance Notebook: Its the Dancers Turn to Watch
description: HAVANA  The dancers of American Ballet Theater and a few members of New York City Ballet had the chance to rest their legs and watch a bit of dancing themselves during a visit Thursday to Cubas National Ballet School.

title: Rock Star
description: View slide show >>

title: In Oregon, Elder Sleuths Size Up Local Businesses
description: File under: What a smart idea.

title: Application Inflation, and Extra Time on the SAT and ACT for Students with Disabilities
description: The latest edition of Education Life, The Timess quarterly supplement, will be published this weekend and, as always, there is lots of news you can use for college applicants and their families.

title: 90 Chefs, 340 Waiters and a Sea of Rabbis
description: David Scharf is planning a little get-together on Sunday in Brooklyn: dinner for 4,500 Hasidic rabbis.

title: Wasting Away
description: You know those delicate debut novels, the ones that take place in coastal Maine, in which, if the author is searching for any truth at all, its only for a small, particular one? Well, Hate: A Romance, Tristan Garcias first effort, is not among them. Its frenetic and French, for a reader who knows Deleuze from Derrida, who will chuckle when Garcia refers to the domestic troubles of Althusser. (Thats a joke, by the way, but you may need Wikipedia to figure it out. I did.)

title: The Lay of the Land
description: Where are we? Answers drift across the woods and salt marshes in John Caseys beautiful, elegiac new novel. One person after another takes a bearing, sets a course, loses the way, makes a correction.

title: Extra Time for College Admissions Tests
description: Students with learning disabilities or attention deficit problems can ask for special accommodations when taking college admissions tests. However, guidance counselors and disabilities advocates say the process can be onerous, an issue explained in todays Education Life feature.

title: Macys, Like Journey, Doesnt Stop Believing
description: For the third holiday season in a row, the Macys division of Macys Inc. will run a Christmas campaign that carries the theme Believe.

title: Growth on a Finite Planet  So Far, So Good
description: .When was the last time the United Nations issued a major report that was upbeat? They exist but are hard to find. Well, this weeks release of the 2010 Human Development Report, on the 20th anniversary of this effort to track human progress, was summarized this way:

title: A World Unto Themselves
description: When Leo Tolstoy formulated his dictum that all happy families are alike, he overlooked at least one counterexample, albeit drawn from a world quite foreign to his own: the household of John and Abigail Adams. The happiness of our family, Abigail noted in 1788, seems ever to have been so interwoven with the politics of our country as to be in a great degree dependent upon them.

title: Wages And The Slide Toward Deflation
description: I get a fair number of comments to the effect that worries about deflation are all wrong, look at commodity prices. Ive tried in the past to explain why we should focus on sluggish, sticky prices, not volatile prices like commodities  hence core inflation. But let me add another point: arguably the stickiest, sluggishiest prices are those of labor. So why not focus on wages?

title: Up Front: Eliza Griswold
description: As the daughter of the presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church in the United States, Eliza Griswold brought along some unusual personal baggage when she set out to research The Tenth Parallel, her recent book about the clash between  and within  Islam and Christianity along a geographical line from West Africa to Indonesia.

title: The Nobelist and the Pygmies
description: Whether he sets his tales in Africa, England, his native Trinidad or anywhere else, V. S. Naipaul is always writing about V. S. Naipaul. In this respect, The Masque of Africa: Glimpses of African Belief, his 30th book and 16th volume of nonfiction, is not different. This latest journey to the continent is part of a larger whole, the developing narrative of a single consciousness.

title: Hundreds Were Raped on Congo-Angola Border
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  More than 600 women and girls were recently raped along the Congo-Angola border during a mass expulsion of illegal immigrants, according to the United Nations.

title: Comparing Recoveries: Job Changes
description: Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics. Chart by Amanda Cox. Horizontal axis shows months. Vertical axis shows the ratio of that months nonfarm payrolls to the nonfarm payrolls at the start of recession. Note: Because employment is a lagging indicator, the dates for these employment trends are not exactly synchronized with National Bureau of Economic Researchs official business cycle dates.

title: Police-Car Windows Smashed in Brooklyn; Suspect Is Shot
description: Updated, 4:29 p.m. | A man who smashed the windshield of a police car with a large rock in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, early Friday morning was shot during a scuffle with an officer who confronted him, the police said.

title: Far From the Track, a Horseplayer Makes His Picks
description: I remember way back in the golden age of racing, that being three years ago for me, looking forward to the sports biggest day. The Breeders Cup, was the day I marked on the calendar months in advance and couldnt wait for it to get here. It was the bright light in my dreary existence. I knew that somehow, someway, I would be at a simulcast center enjoying my favorite day of the year. But alas, all good things must come to an end, at least in my life. There is no simulcast center available anymore in my area. Due to time and budget constraints, venturing further away from home is inapplicable at this time. Now, the day that couldnt get here soon enough, is taking too long to go away.

title: Is That Bottle Talking to Me?
description: When youre selling vodka, a product that has what some critics say is a limited differential of taste, purveyors of ultrapremium brands have had to find other ways to compete.

title: An Uncertain Nuclear Countdown
description: If the clock is ticking on the lifetime of the Vermont Yankee nuclear plant, when will it actually close?

title: Grace and Culture Intertwined
description: American Indian art is some of the most beautiful ever made anywhere on earth. Some of us have loved it as long as we can remember. And with a new permanent-collection installation at the National Museum of the American Indian in Lower Manhattan, we can love it even more.

title: Better All the Time
description: The thesis of Kevin Kellys bold new book begins with its title. How can technology  an inanimate collection of human inventions  want anything? According to Kelly, a professional tech-watcher and former editor of Wired magazine, its because technology is like a living organism, animated by the same evolutionary forces that resulted, over eons, in the human brain. Moreover, for Kelly, the whole process has been progressive and predictable: the eventual appearance of the BlackBerry was immanent in the Big Bang.

title: The Renault Engine Deals
description: People at the Red Bull team, which has dominated the season with 14 pole positions in 17 races and with seven victories, spent much of the season complaining about a lack of power from its Renault engines. On Thursday, Christian Horner, the team director, responded to a remark from the Ferrari team director  who said if he had the Red Bull car his team would have won the title already  by saying that if he had the Ferrari engine his team would have won the title already.

title: The Renault Engine Deals
description: People at the Red Bull team, which has dominated the season with 14 pole positions in 17 races and with seven victories, spent much of the season complaining about a lack of power from its Renault engines. On Thursday, Christian Horner, the team director, responded to a remark from the Ferrari team director  who said if he had the Red Bull car his team would have won the title already  by saying that if he had the Ferrari engine his team would have won the title already.

title: Holy Warrior
description: Who better to review a 1,000-page Jewish book that comes out in the fall than the author of an 800-page Jewish book that came out in the spring? Adam Levins first novel, The Instructions, appears a summer after my own novel Witz, whose title translates to joke, though its no laughing matter: its about the Last Jew in the World. And did you hear the one about Chaim, who was stranded on a desert island? When the rescuers finally arrived they found hed built two fully equipped synagogues out of palm trunks and homemade rope. Curious, they asked him, Why two? Chaim answered, One I pray in, the other Ill never step foot in. In the spirit of that joke, consider one of our books the Jewish novel youll never begin and the other the Jewish novel youll never finish.

title: Lost in Jurez
description: The veteran British journalist Ed Vulliamy is visiting Ciudad Jurez, epicenter of Mexican border violence, when a massacre occurs at a drug rehabilitation clinic in an impoverished neighborhood on the outskirts of town. The year before, more than 1,700 people had been killed in Ciudad Jurez; in the previous week, 75 were slain, including one who was beheaded. Ciudad Jurez has the worlds highest homicide rate. And drug gangs armed with military-grade weapons usually reserved for professional soldiers all but control the city. The day after the massacre, Vulliamy rushes to the clinic and produces a gruesome report.

title: Weekend Competition: Emotive Conjugations
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to devise what the philosopher Bertrand Russell called emotive conjugations  irregular verbs which encapsulate a moral flexibility by which we judge others more harshly than ourselves.

title: Now Online | T Design & Living Winter 2010
description: The Yankees may not have made it all the way this year, but Ts winter Design & Living issue offers plenty of good reasons to cheer for the home team. Our cover story singles out half a dozen young designers who are making it big in the Big Apple. Elsewhere in the issue, Pilar Viladas tours the architect Tom Kundigs latest house and discovers it to be as comfortable on the inside as it is rugged on the outside; Sandra Ballentine drops in on the public art maven Yvonne Force Villareal and gets an eyeful of her colorful private life; and William Middleton visits a little modern house on a big freeway. We meet the knit wit Donna Wilson, whose kooky creature comforts are on display this month at the Future Perfect stores in Brooklyn and Manhattan, and shadow the design worlds stealth supplier, the American born, Zurich-based dealer Arthur Rooks. Jonathan Adler rekindles an old flame  the Malm floating fireplace  and Fred A. Bernstein writes about the horrors of being a houseguest. No place like home indeed!

title: Jobs Are Growing, Even in Manufacturing
description: Just after the election, we learn that the jobs numbers were better than we thought. Im sure President Obama was pleased when he got the word.

title: Recipes From the Cabbage Patch
description: For home cooks on a budget, cabbage remains one of the best culinary bargains around, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health.

title: Get Me Out of Here
description: A month before the invasion of Iraq, in the grim winter of 2003, officials in the Bush White House invited me and one of my colleagues to come discuss their plans for post-Saddam Iraq. Publicly, President Bush had not yet chosen to go to war. But the decision was so preordained that his top national security aides were eager to explain that they had thought through the endgame in a way no previous occupants of their offices had when Washington went to war in Korea, Vietnam or the Persian Gulf. For several hours they described their detailed plans to remove the Baathist leadership and replace it with technocrats who would get the country humming again. The United States and its allies would quickly become a light-footprint peacekeeping force.

title: Fox News Topped Networks on Vote Night
description: The Fox News Channels midterm election coverage attracted more viewers than any of the broadcast networks coverage, according to the Nielsen Company.

title: Soccer Matchups to Watch This Weekend
description: SATURDAY

title: Hard Times
description: The economic recession that never seems to end for working-class Americans is making itself felt in the crime fiction of authors whose regional roots run deep. Dennis Lehane, not the cheeriest of writers in the best of times, seems downright depressed about the way things are going in New England. In MOONLIGHT MILE (Morrow/HarperCollins, $26.99), he brings back Patrick Kenzie, the private detective from Dorchester, Mass., whose anti-establishment attitude and class rage fueled the violence of his earliest novels, to paint a bleak picture of nice towns coming apart at the seams.

title: Editors Choice
description: FINISHING THE HAT: Collected Lyrics (1954-1981) With Attendant Comments, Principles, Heresies, Grudges, Whines and Anecdotes,  by Stephen Sondheim (Knopf, $39.95.) Sondheims analysis of his songs and those of others is both stinging and insightful.

title: A Different Kind of Sex Talk With Teens
description: The age at which Europeans and Americans first have sex is the same  17, on average, on both sides of the Atlantic. The percentage who use birth control from the start? In Holland its 64 percent and in the United States its 26 percent. The percentage who have regrets about their first time, wishing they had waited: 63 percent of boys and 69 percent of girls in the United States, and only 5 percent of boys and 12 percent of girls in the Netherlands. Teen pregnancy rates: three to six times higher here than in Western Europe. S.T.D. rates: 20 to 30 times higher here than Holland. H.I.V. rate? Theirs is six times lower.

title: Paperback Row
description: WHEN EVERYTHING CHANGED: The Amazing Journey of American Women From 1960 to the Present, by Gail Collins. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $15.99.) From downtrodden secretaries in the 1960s to the campaigns of Hillary Rodham Clinton and Sarah Palin, this is a smart, engaging look at American womens strides and the hurdles they still face. Collins, a columnist for the New York Times Op-Ed page, combines capsule histories and the drama of the era with the memories of regular women who lived through it all. These were times, Collins writes, in which women were not meant to compete with men, to act independently of men. . . . Then, suddenly, everything changed. The cherished convictions about women and what they could do were smashed in the lifetime of many of the women living today. SARAH FROM ALASKA:  The Sudden Rise and Brutal Education of a New Conservative Superstar, by Scott Conroy and Shushannah Walshe. (PublicAffairs, $15.95.) Conroy and Walshe covered Palins vice-presidential campaign for CBS and Fox News, respectively, and their book underscores the vigor of her crusading populism and a political record that is decidedly blurred. MOLLY IVINS: A Rebel Life, by Bill Minutaglio and W. Michael Smith. (PublicAffairs, $15.95.) Self-invention is a central thread in this biography of the witty, passionate liberal columnist who died in 2007.

title: Five-Link Friday: Sacrilege Takes Various Forms
description: Among the many reasons to be thankful you live in a such a diverse city, there is this: Diwali. For it is on this Friday that the Department of Transportation recognizes the Hindu festival of lights, and in its municipal beneficence, suspends alternate side of the street parking rules. Hallelujah.

title: China Assails Nobel Peace Prize as Card of West
description: BEIJING  Accelerating its assault on the award of the Nobel Peace Prize to the Chinese dissident Liu Xiaobo, China denounced the prize on Friday as a political tool of the West, and an official warned that countries acknowledging the honor would bear the consequences.

title: Behind the Scenes, a Race of Logistics
description: With more than 43,000 participants, 2.5 million spectators and a course that stretches over 26.2 miles and 5 boroughs, the New York City Marathon is more than a sporting event, it is a vast international spectacle.

title: India on $200 Million a Day? Not!
description: Critics of President Obamas are abuzz with the charge that the American government will spend $200 million a day, or a total of $2 billion, to send the president on the 10-day mission to four countries that began today.

title: Family Celebrates Life of Slain N.B.A. Player on His Birthday
description: Its good sometimes to get a reminder about what really matters in life. Arguments over playing time, controversies over Twitter posts and other daily dramas in the hoops world do not seem to be that important in the long run.

title: Its Beauty-and-the-Beast Time Again
description: A global initiative unprecedented in National Geographic Societys storied 122-year history.

title: Young Wall Street Parties Like Its 2007
description: If its after-hours parties are any indication, Wall Street is officially back in business.

title: Sony: The Ghost of Christmas Past
description: When I was a kid (around 25 years ago), Christmas was a time of family, food and the searing-hot hope that I would be in possession of some new gadget come the morning of Dec. 25. And no matter what that gadget was, it was likely to have one common feature: The name Sony printed somewhere on it.

title: Is That Bottle Talking to Me?
description: Eric A. Taub, over on Gadgetwise, talks about a new bottle of vodka from a Dutch company that uses LED technology to stand out from the crowd. An electronic band of bright blue lights can be programmed to display one of three scrolling messages, with each one up to 255 characters in length. Luckily for those who like to store their vodka in the fridge,even in sub-zero temperatures, the display keeps on working.

title: A Yearbook Dedicated to Inclusion
description: SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J.

title: So, Runner, Whats on Your iPod?
description: When the announcement came last week that the Sony Walkman was no more, I got nostalgic. That little yellow box and its successors changed my relationship with music  and running.

title: Pregame Huddle: Fight for No. 1
description: Oregon has earned its No. 1 ranking, but teams like Alabama and Auburn are still in the hunt.

title: The Morning Line: Theres News Beyond Zenyatta
description: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

title: When the Economy Revs, Trucks Roar
description: There is a truism in Detroit that the health of the economy can often be gauged by sales of trucks. Now, as the economy seems to be recovering, albeit slowly, more ad campaigns for truck brands are being introduced.

title: A Fans Guide to Booing, N.H.L. Version
description: To boo or not to boo? That is the question, at least according to Maple Leafs General Manager Brian Burke, who this week called Toronto fans disgraceful for booing the teams captain, Dion Phaneuf. But is he right?

title: A Star to Steer By
description: You know the Little Prince, of course: the golden hair and ruddy cheeks, the long scarf trailing in the Sahara wind, all familiar from Antoine de Saint-Exuprys beloved 1943 parable. But what about the pilot? Saint-Exupry made sketches of the narrator of The Little Prince, but the airman  whose crash-landing gives the Princes planet-hopping philosophical adventures their frame  never makes an appearance in the books final version.

title: Angels, Demons and Blockbusters
description: For an industry supposedly in decline, book publishing still offers welcome surprises. Years ago, anyone who admitted to writing young adult books  more likely, books for teens at a cocktail party would be faced with a blank look. Are you ever going to write a real novel? was the common response. But ever since the success of books as different as Laurie Halse Andersons Speak (1999), a grittily realistic portrait of sexual violence in high school, and Twilight, its become clear that writers have at least as much freedom in Y.A. books as they do in adult fiction, as well as an audience that is loyal, smart and self-renewing. Sherman Alexie, Nick Hornby, Jane Smiley and Oscar Hijuelos write for young people now, and if they see fit to mention it at a party, they are likely to hear, How can I get into that?

title: Spellbound
description: Salman Rushdies new childrens novel arrives under circumstances that are, to put it mildly, less anxious than those that surrounded his first, Haroun and the Sea of Stories (1990). Rushdie has said he conceived Haroun before the fatwa that was issued in response to The Satanic Verses, in 1989. But Haroun was difficult to detach from its fraught moment. After all, its hero was struggling against forces determined to silence storytelling, a plot point that couldnt help reminding you that the author was, too.

title: Interactive Books (E Not Included)
description: Years ago, I was a supporter of a new literary movement, one that uprooted the traditional tenets of narrative in modern fiction: Choose Your Own Adventure.

title: When Stories Had Sharp Teeth
description: When I was 10, I found an ancient collection of Grimm fairy tales in the basement. I cracked the dusty black cover, not expecting much (I knew Cinderella and Snow White and their stupid hair and trilling voices from movies Id outgrown) and was transfixed. These stories were sick, serious and bloody. Cinderellas sisters did what to their feet? I sat on that cold basement floor and read the entire thick volume (a 1920 version, with sinuous Art Deco illustrations by Elenore Abbott).

title: A Life Preserved in Clay
description: The slaves best known to most Americans are ones who escaped. Harriet Tubman, Frederick Douglass, Sojourner Truth: fugitives and then freedom fighters. Very rarely do we hear about individual slaves who made a name for themselves while in bondage. One who did, quite literally, was an extraordinary artist known by his first name only: Dave.

title: BMW to Build Megacity Electric Car in Leipzig
description: When you get your drivers licenses in 10 years you will drive an electric BMW, Norbert Reithofer, chief executive of BMW, said to the children of workers at the automakers factory in Leipzig, Germany, on Friday.

title: No Food Network or HGTV as Scripps and AT&T Feud
description: There is another programming blackout affecting AT&T U-verse customers but this time the programmer says its not about money.

title: Serving Up Healthful School Lunches
description: Todays Patient Money focuses on school lunch money, how its spent and what you get for it.

title: Seasoned Collaborators, Back on Track
description: JOHN FORD found his muse in the laconic, masculine John Wayne, while Don Siegel liked featuring a taciturn Clint Eastwood in his thrillers. The director Tony Scott has found his go-to hero, an often flawed, seemingly ordinary guy who rises to the occasion, in the Oscar winner Denzel Washington. Together the unlikely pairing of the British action director who specializes in fast-paced, stylized action flicks (Top Gun, The Last Boy Scout) and an American leading man typically associated for his stirring portrayals of inspirational men like Malcolm X and the football coach Herman Boone, have made five films together. In their latest, Unstoppable  the others are Crimson Tide, Man on Fire, Dj Vu and The Taking of Pelham 1 2 3, from last year  Mr. Washington plays a veteran engineer who must safely halt an out-of-control locomotive in Pennsylvania carrying combustible liquids, with or without the assistance of his headstrong rookie conductor (Chris Pine). The movie is loosely based on an actual incident in which a train in Ohio traveled 66 miles without a crew member on board.

title: TimesCast | November 5, 2010
description: Threat of flooding in Haiti; a better-than-expected jobs report and politics in the social media age.

title: The Alessi Effect
description: For the last three decades, the Italian home products manufacturer Alessi has been at the forefront of design, producing instant icons like Michael Gravess bird-whistle teakettle (above), Philippe Starcks infamous Juicy Salif juicer and Richard Sappers elegant espresso pot  a fixture on many a yuppies high-end cooktop. The Philadelphia Museum of Art is celebrating the 90-year-old company with an exhibition, Alessi: Ethical and Radical, which opens Nov. 21. Central to Alessis success is its creative mastermind, Alberto Alessi, a grandson of the founder, who has run the company since the 1970s. Hes absolutely unique in the amount of time and money that he has spent on design, said Kathryn Hiesinger, the exhibitions curator. Included in the show are planned reissues of designs from the 1920s, 30s and 40s, a time that Alberto Alessi describes as predesign, before the rise of glossy designer products  which is ironic coming from the man who helped invent the category. But, as Heisinger explained, Alberto is now in his minimalist, simplicity mode; hes against overdesign. Well, hes been right before.

title: QE Madness
description: It has been really interesting to watch some of the commentary over quantitative easing by the Fed: while people like me see the Feds actions as way too timid, theres a substantial faction out there that sees them as the end of Western civilization. Right now the most popular story on Bloomberg is Jim Rogers saying that Bernanke doesnt understand economics, that hes debasing the currency.

title: Breaking Down Day 2 of the Breeders Cup
description: Matt Carothers is the host of :58 Flat and Blinkers Off on TVG, as well as being one its regular analysts. He started playing the horses long before the law allows.

title: Benmosche: Im Feeling Very Good
description: While the American International Group continues its effort to remove the federal governments massive ownership stake in itself  incurring a $2.4 billion loss for its third quarter in the process  theres another consideration hanging over the insurer: the health of its chief executive.

title: Pelosi Says She Wants to Remain House Democratic Leader
description: WASHINGTON  Despite steep losses for her party in Tuesdays elections, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California said on Friday that she would run to remain the leader of the House Democrats, even as some of her colleagues urged her to step down.

title: When Poison Was a Cinematic Antidote
description: A MILESTONE in American independent film and the inciting spark for what came to be known as the New Queer Cinema, Todd Hayness first feature, Poison (1991), has always stood for much more than itself. The whole world is dying of panicky fright, reads its opening title, an apt epigraph for a contemplation of difference, affliction and stigma that arrived at the height of the AIDS crisis and became a lightning rod in the culture wars of the 1990s.

title: Tevye Remembers: Harvey Fierstein on Bock and Stein and Fiddler
description: The recent deaths of Jerry Bock and Joseph Stein, two of the creators of the musical Fiddler on the Roof, prompted us to ask Harvey Fierstein, Broadways most recent Tevye, to reflect on the show and its meaning. His reminiscence follows:

title: For Long Term, Men Favor Face Over Figure
description: THE GIST Men keen on a short-term relationship are more interested in checking out a womans body than are those looking for long-term love.

title: Debunking the Myths of the Midterm
description: Every election develops its own mythology, usually before the official results are even certified, and this weeks was no different. And like all mythology, the narrative that is being woven around the midterm elections by Bulfinches from both parties is a blend of history, facts and, yes, myths.

title: Leaving the Locker Room for a Law Firm
description: Kevin Clauson has been on the job as an associate at a law firm for less than a week, and he has not yet needed to get a single stitch.

title: Joe Drapes Breeders Cup Picks, Day 2
description: 2:34 p.m. | Updated Crown of Thorns has been scratched.

title: On the Street | Fall Dressing
description: The style of the decade was at its peak, the mixing of separate pieces to form a total look that has everything to do with how it is worn.

title: Resources | Abraham Lincoln and the Civil War
description: Updated: April, 2015

title: Olbermann Suspended From MSNBC for Campaign Donations
description: Click here for the most recent version of this story.

title: Should Democrats Blame Waxman and Markey?
description: Environmental advocates and backers of the House climate change measure have been scrambling this week to dodge the blame for the drubbing that Democrats took in the midterm elections.

title: When Best Isnt Good Enough
description: A FEW years ago I got this note from a mother in my sons class. Hey, we both end our e-mails with Carpe Diem! Hope the parents in class wont confuse us, ha-ha! Naturally I thought she was kidding, and wrote back saying our different names might be a tip-off we were not the same person. Oh, sure, she said, but Ive used Carpe Diem forever. People know me by that one. It would be great if you used something else from now on. Thanks!

title: Charging Ahead in First Big Wave Contest for Women
description: LINCOLN CITY, Ore.  Women have surfed some of the biggest and scariest waves known to man. They have challenged the towering peaks at the break called Mavericks in northern California. They have elbowed into the crowded wave lineup on Hawaiis North Shore. They have pulled into heavily loaded barrels of water at Teahupoo in Tahiti. But they had never had their own big wave contest  until Wednesday.

title: Nebraska Attorney General Looking at Senate
description: The 2012 election cycle is up and running.

title: Leaked Video Shows Clash at Sea Between Chinese and Japanese Ships
description: Japans government is trying to find out how video clips, apparently shot by its Coast Guard during a confrontation with a Chinese trawler in September, ended up on YouTube this week.

title: Need to Know
description: SHORTAGE AND DEMAND As the population ages and as 30 million newly insured enter the system in the wake of health care legislation, the market for nurses is among the largest projected for any occupation. Between 2008 and 2018, more than 580,000 jobs have to be filled, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics  a 22 percent increase over today.

title: Modern Vintage
description: A Zaha Hadid-designed wine tasting pavilion (above) or stemless Riedel wineglass may seem commonplace now. But they are manifestations of a cultural shift that happened after the so-called Judgment of Paris in 1976, in which a number of California wines were deemed superior to their French counterparts. On Nov. 20, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art will open How Wine Became Modern: Design and Wine 1976 to Now. Organized by Henry Urbach, the museums curator of architecture and design, the exhibition  which is designed by the architects Diller Scofidio and Renfro  explores the evolution of wines visual and material culture. It includes a gallery devoted to the subject of terroir, a commissioned wall work by Peter Wegner that charts more than 200 paint colors with names like Cabernet and Crush, and a look at, among other issues, the effect of architecture on wine tourism. The museum knows the subject well, having organized the first architectural competition for the design of a winery, in 1985. The winner was the architect-artist team of Michael Graves and Edward Schmidt, resulting in Clos Pegase, the prototype of the modern designer winery.

title: 45, Male and Now a Nurse
description: BALTIMORES gritty Levindale section is a world apart from Ponce Inlet, Fla., the upscale barrier island where Rich Van Rensselaer owned a boutique liquor store and coffee shop before becoming a trauma nurse. If you had asked Mr. Van Rensselaer in 2004 if he thought he would trade in life in Margaritaville for scenes from The Wire  treating gunshot wounds, drug overdoses and unmanaged diabetes in one of the citys busiest emergency rooms  he might have assumed you had been to one too many of his wine-tasting events.

title: The China Boom
description: IN her ballroom dance class, Li Wanrong has learned to tango and cha-cha. At lunch one day, she tried a strange mix of flavors  pepperoni pizza, the spicy sausage and oozing cheese nearly burning her tongue. Then there was that Friday night before going clubbing for the first time when new friends gave her a makeover, and she looked in the mirror to see an American girl smiling back wearing a little black dress, red lipstick and fierce eyeliner.

title: What Do You Mean I Cant Take This Course?
description: WINDSOR G. HANGER, a 2010 Harvard graduate from Asheville, N.C., had been excited to finally squeeze in a course called Painting Day and Night senior year after recreational dabbling while in high school. But then she showed up the first day to find 25 others with a similar vision. Thirteen would have to disappear. To her shock, the instructor sprung an impromptu test, asking everyone to spend the next few hours painting still lifes.

title: Theres More Than One Way to Apply to College
description: AS if college hopefuls didnt have enough decisions to make, heres one more: which application to use.

title: The Perfect (College) Match
description: CHOOSING a compatible college is a life decision right up there with choosing a compatible mate, and the new service WiseChoice.com leverages that analogy. Students complete a five-part questionnaire whose Likert-scale cross-examinations resemble a dating sites, and for good reason. eHarmony was our model, says Lori Grandstaff, a vice president. The profile, along with academic and financial input, informs the free computer-generated psychoanalysis.

title: Algebra Refigured, Totally
description: MATH is not an easy subject. For many, the corollary conclusion is that learning math is unavoidably unpleasant.

title: On the College Essay
description: Generally, topics about bodily functions, body parts, how much you love your boyfriend/girlfriend, or a play-by-play of your game-winning goal dont say much about how you will contribute to a small community. And Proof-reading is essential  make sure you arent writing about Muslin extremism or being abducted into the National Honor Society.

title: A Is for Abstinence
description: BELOW is a handy chart for abstinence advocates. A study by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has found a decided link between celibacy and good grades. Among high school students who earn mostly As, 32 percent have had intercourse, compared with 69 percent of their peers with Ds and Fs. And on risk-taking measures like consuming alcohol or using condoms, the better students were also the more cautious.

title: Going Clubbing
description: THE student tour guide probably recognized the dazed look on our faces. We had driven six hours through cornfields to visit Grinnell College. The Iowa cornfields ended at the very edge of campus. We are in the middle of nowhere, he acknowledged.

title: Organized Play
description: Student photographers rove their campuses. This issue: Humans vs. Zombies, quidditch, medieval combat. Text by Rebecca R. Ruiz

title: Early Extracurriculars
description: A timeline of early student organizations.

title: Loan Payback
description: ON Oct. 28, the Department of Education published new rules meant to protect students from overly aggressive and deceptive recruiting by for-profit institutions, and to provide consumers with information like whether graduates earn enough to pay back their student loans. The government has zeroed in on for-profit programs as the industry has grown  enrollment tripled from 2000 to 2008, to 1.8 million  and as federal student aid they dole out has increased nearly sixfold. (Recent video shot by secret shoppers with the Government Accountability Office shows recruiters misleading applicants about potential earnings and financial aid.)

title: At Registration, to the Savvy Go the Spoils
description: NEXT week, undergraduates at New York University will go online in the middle of lectures or skulk out of classes where computers arent allowed. Over the last few weeks, Cornell students set their alarms at sunrise.

title: Banning the Bottle
description: STUDENTS new green cause: promoting that most quotidian of beverages  tap water. According to the Earth Policy Institute, 86 percent of plastic water bottles in the United States end up as garbage. Not to mention the $2 students shell out for a bottle.

title: Looking for Students Like Me!
description: IT was early in my junior year, before my college search had begun in earnest, that the letters started coming. It began as a trickle, but I was quickly inundated. One stands out in my mind: a letter informing me in a manner both presumptuous and peremptory that at long last my college search was over. Soon after, I received a letter from clairvoyant admissions officials at another college, asking me to gaze into the future with them and envision myself at their school. Having already learned of the end to my college search, I was confused to find myself frolicking on the greens of another university.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Sondheims Music, Eli Wallach and More
description: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

title: Ex-Banker Brings Roadshows to the Masses
description: After months of anticipation, General Motors is finally moving ahead with its initial public offering. And for the last 24 hours, the place to turn for the details has been  of all places  a Web site called RetailRoadshow.com.

title: Week 10 College Football Matchups
description: The first week of November is a melancholy time in college football. The season is in full swing, but the end is in sight. A good or bad start can be erased with wins or losses in November. This week the Mountain West takes center stage as a pair of top-five teams battles for a conference crown as well as maybe a spot in a Bowl Championship Series game (or even a shot at a national title). In the South, Alabama travels to Baton Rouge with the SEC West in the balance. At the same time, Texas Christian plays Utah. It would be a good Saturday to be in front of several televisions. Oklahoma State hosts Baylor (yes, Baylor) with each team in control of its destiny in the Big 12 South. There is a logjam at the top of the Big 10. How will that shake out? There are only a few Saturdays left.

title: Fort Tryon Park, 7:35 A.M.
Obama Is Not Likely to Push India Hard on Pakistan
description: NEW DELHI  Senior American military commanders have sought to press India to formally disavow an obscure military doctrine that they contend is fueling tensions between India and Pakistan and hindering the American war effort in Afghanistan.

title: Some Pointers on Fridays Races
description: Jonathan Socolow, who works in Moscow, is an avid horseplayer.

title: Financial Strategies for Every Age
description: 5:38 p.m. | Updated  Tara Siegel Bernard has just posted another interesting article on aging parents and their finances: Stepping In When a Parent Can No Longer Cope.

title: Luxury in the Caribbean: 7 Over-the-Top Retreats
description: When it comes to luxury in the Caribbean, there is no shortage of offerings.

title: Luxury in the Caribbean: 7 Over-the-Top Retreats
description: If money is no object, almost anything can be arranged, from a private no-fly zone to an en suite recording studio.

title: The Feature Presentation: Our Classic Picks
description: The Rails contributors and a special guest picker make their Breeders Cup Classic selections.

title: MSNBC Suspends Olbermann for Political Contributions
description: Keith Olbermann, the popular, left-leaning host of MSNBCs Countdown, has been suspended indefinitely after it was disclosed that he made political contributions to three Democratic candidates in the waning days of the midterm campaigns.

title: Boehner Reaches Out to G.O.P. Governors
description: The presumptive House speaker, John A. Boehner of Ohio, wants to establish a partnership with Republican governors and state lawmakers to work toward stopping the expansion of federal power in Washington.

title: Fashion Duo Flouts Physics
description: GROWING up is in many ways like drifting down to earth as your helium-filled illusions of childhood burst, one by one, from Santa Claus to financial freedom, leaving you finally and firmly grounded.

title: Incumbent Wins Spirited Election in Tanzania
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  President Jakaya Kikwete of Tanzania was re-elected with 61 percent of the vote, the countrys election commission said Friday, after a spirited contest marked by competitive campaigning but marred by relatively poor turnout, unusual delays, street protests and allegations of vote rigging.

title: Pictures of the Day: Indonesia and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Indonesia, Haiti and Pakistan.

title: Where Did God Go in Afghanistan?
description: Ten thousand feet over Fort Benning, Ga., and I was praying for my life. Literally. I was about to jump out of a C-130 airplane to earn my Airborne wings. I desperately wanted my chute to open. Under my breath, I whispered Isaiah 40:31: but those who hope in the LORD/will renew their strength./They will soar on wings like eagles. At service the day before, the minister had handed out bookmarks inscribed with that passage.

title: A New Record for Political Ads
description: It wasnt just your imagination: there really was an uptick in political ads this year.

title: In Construction, Homes Are the Good News
description: AFTER a rapid plunge, the pace of residential construction in the United States has stabilized. But any respite for the economy that could have been provided by the end of that decline has been more than offset by a drop in privately financed nonresidential construction.

title: Dead Coral Found Near Site of Oil Spill
description: A survey of the seafloor near BPs blown-out well in the Gulf of Mexico has turned up dead and dying coral reefs that were probably damaged by the oil spill, scientists said Friday.

title: More Bite (and Bark) From Astons Pretty Baby
description: TESTED: 2011 Aston Martin V-12 Vantage

title: Britax Child Safety Recalling 23,000 Car Seats
description: Britax Child Safety Inc. is recalling about 23,000 of its Chaperone infant car seats, according to the Consumer Product Safety Commission.

title: Chic in Review | Gisele Forever
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Rubio to Give G.O.P. Weekly Address
description: Some call senator-elect Marco Rubio the great right hope. Others say he is the Cuban Barack Obama.

title: Stepping In for a Parent With Alzheimers
description: As my grandfathers mind slipped away, first slowly, then quickly, as Alzheimers disease moved in, he tried to be reassuring. I remember the important things, he would tell us.

title: Republican Concedes in Illinois Governors Race
description: CHICAGO  A day after The Associated Press declared Gov. Patrick J. Quinn the winner of the Illinois governors race, his Republican opponent, Bill Brady, conceded.

title: Caribbean Hurricane Update
description: With peakvisiting season just weeks away, St. Lucia is racing to clean up the island in the wake of Hurricane Tomas, which brought tourism to a halt for much of the week.

title: To Every Bargain, a Season. Or So It Seems.
description: WE were thinking of buying a Ping-Pong table a few months ago and checked prices. They seemed high and we put it on the back burner. Then my sons started clamoring for one again, so my husband checked online.

title: Creating Stars and Enemies
description: MARTIN SCORSESE might be the only film buff alive with both the clout and the passion to put together The Elia Kazan Collection, a boxed set that assembles 15 Kazan films from three distributors. Though 20th Century Fox Home Video is releasing the collection  Fox controls eight of the films in the set (four of which are appearing on DVD for the first time)  it also includes important Kazan films from Sony (On the Waterfront) and Warner Brothers (East of Eden, but also Baby Doll, A Face in the Crowd, Splendor in the Grass and America America, making its DVD debut).

title: 2011 Aston Martin V-12 Vantage
description: The V-12 Vantage has the looks, luxury and pedigree to get away with highway robbery.

title: The Bakers Apprentice: Cheesecake
description: Emily Weinstein, who wrote a series on this blog about learning to cook, is now learning to bake with Dorie Greenspan, a food writer and the author of several cookbooks, including most recently Around My French Table.

title: War Reconstruction Fraud Draws Big Fines
description: WASHINGTON  A New Jersey-based construction and engineering company has been hit with the largest fines ever imposed on a contractor working in the war zones of Iraq and Afghanistan, after a whistle-blower revealed that the company had been overbilling the government.

title: Band in the Van
description: J. Roddy Walston and the Business have toured the country for years in a former church van.

title: When Boys Dress Like Girls for Halloween
description: When a 5-year-old Kansas City boy decided he wanted to be Daphne from the Scooby-Doo cartoon series for Halloween, his mom bought him the costume. While the boys friends liked the pink velvet dress and orange wig costume, some of the mothers at his school expressed disapproval.

title: At the SEMA Show, Some Parts Are Better Than Others
description: LAS VEGAS  The wildly customized cars may get most of the coverage at the SEMA Show, but the annual convention is about introducing, buying and selling auto parts.

title: Drama Overshadows Unrivaled Belles Win in Ladies Classic
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  The first day of the Breeders Cup started with an altercation between the jockeys Calvin Borel and Javier Castellano over rough riding. It ended with confusion and concern about whether one of the favorites in the Ladies Classic, Life at Ten, was healthy enough to be in the $2 million race.

title: In Memoir, Bush Addresses 9/11 Policy Controversies
description: Former President George W. Bushs forthcoming memoir, Decision Points, will probably receive close scrutiny by people who have followed the legal and policy debates that arose over his administrations approach to the war on terrorism.

title: A Church Van? Its With the Band
description: ONE drizzly afternoon last month, J. Roddy Walston and the Business, a gritty four-piece rock n roll outfit from Baltimore, were congregated around their tour van after performing three songs in the WNYC studios in SoHo.

title: Planning for an Aging Parents Financial Needs
description: This weeks Your Money column discusses ways to help people with Alzheimers disease and other forms of dementia manage their money.

title: Book Review Podcast: Stacy Schiff on Cleopatra
description: This week: Stacy Schiff discusses her new biography, Cleopatra: A Life; Julie Just looks back on her five years as the Book Reviews childrens books editor; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: Interactive: Bush Addresses 9/11 Policy Controversies in Memoir
description: Former President George W. Bushs forthcoming memoir, Decision Points, will probably receive close scrutiny by people who have followed the legal and policy debates that arose over his administrations approach to the war on terrorism. The book, obtained by The New York Times ahead of its publication date, covers, among other topics, five areas that address Mr. Bushs use of presidential powers and his view of executive authority. In an interactive feature, The Timess Charlie Savage takes a closer look at Mr. Bushs decisions.

title: Far From Home, Guineans Prepare to Cast Their Vote
description: Manden nko Radio was abuzz on a recent Wednesday night. Despite the hiss and crackle of cellphone static, the radio program  actually a massive, New York-based conference call for Guinean expatriates  draws hundreds of listeners.

title: Food Photography: How to Shoot Ugly Food
description: Andrew Scrivani (@Andrew Scrivani) is a freelance photographer who contributes to The New York Times. He writes the blog Making Sunday Sauce.

description: Photographs from Indonesia, Haiti and Pakistan.

title: BMW Vision EfficientDynamics Plug-in Hybrid Sports Car Gets Go-Ahead
description: One of the more radical sports car concepts from the 2009 Frankfurt motor show has been given the green light.

title: New Yorks Next Frontier: The Waterfront
description: STANDING on the roof of the Edge, a luxury waterfront condominium project under construction in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, you cant help but be taken in by the grand sweep of the Manhattan skyline.

title: A Van That Rocks
description: In the last four years, J. Roddy Walston and the Business say they have put almost 160,000 miles on their Ford Econoline van.

description: Here is some reader response via e-mail to my most recent column from last Sunday, Sharing Secrets at Arms Length.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Vandaag, the new East Village restaurant serving northern European fare, will team up with Rolling Orange bike shop for a Dutch-style bike tour. Starting off in Brooklyn (at 269 Baltic Street) and then wheeling across the Brooklyn Bridge to lower Manhattan before ending up at the Union Square Greenmarket, riders will also get a tasting of ingredients from chef Phillip Kirschen-Clark. The 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. tour costs $45 and reservations can be made my e-mailing tourandtaste@vandaagnyc.com.
