description: Images from the exhibition at the National Museum of the American Indian.

title: A Potpourri of Deal-Making
description: This was a busy week for the nation, but also an eventful week for deal-making. The arbitrage favorites: Airgas/Air Products and Potash/BHP Billiton both had price-shifting events.

title: Slow-Motion Fusion, Direct From So Paulo
description: There was a determined stillness to the set by the Brazilian songwriter Lusa Maita at S.O.B.s on Wednesday night, as she made her United States debut. She brought songs from her lissome album Lero-Lero (Cumbancha).

title: Book Review Podcast: Stacy Schiff on the Life of Cleopatra
description: This week: Stacy Schiff discusses her new biography, Cleopatra: A Life; Julie Just looks back on her five years as the Book Reviews childrens books editor; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: Onyewu and Ibrahimovic Come to Blows at Milan Practice
description: Theres always tension between attackers and defenders who regularly do battle on the soccer field. Even in training, players on the same team can develop a tense rivalry. But things boiled over at Milanello on Friday during an A.C. Milan training session, according to multiple reports from Italy, including this one, in Italian, from La Gazetta dello Sport.

title: Exploring Trusts for the Disabled
description: With the battle over taxes and estate planning techniques about to heat up, one type of planning vehicle has avoided contentious debate: the special-needs trust. These trusts are supposed to supplement the benefits a disabled person receives from the government  paying for additional services or equipment not otherwise covered  but not to supplant them.

title: Antibiotics Research Subsidies Weighed by U.S.
description: Worried about an impending public health crisis, government officials are considering offering financial incentives to the pharmaceutical industry, like tax breaks and patent extensions, to spur the development of vitally needed antibiotics.

title: Fighting the Alienating Newspeak Gobbledygook
description: As a modern prayer, this might serve: Lord, spare us from the tedium and pettiness of office life! Of course the qualities that make an office soul-chilling also make it the perfect setting for absurdist satire, a form that had special relevance for writers in the old Eastern bloc countries yearning to speak free. And what better stand-in for the state, with all its baffling whims and cruelties, than the office?

title: Dr. Weils Simple Roasted Root Vegetables
description: Sometime the best foods at Thanksgiving are the simplest, cooked in their natural state with minimal spices to let the original flavor shine through.

title: Fed Chief Defends Action in Face of Criticism
description: JEKYLL ISLAND, Ga.  The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, on Friday defended the central banks decision to inject $600 billion into the American economy, in the face of objections from European and Asian officials about the weakening of the dollar that is likely to result from the action.

title: On the Run in New York
description: On Sunday, 45,344 runners traversed all five boroughs in the 41st running of the New York City Marathon. Review the race route to the right and photos from the marathon.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 5
description: Photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Dead Coral Found Near Gulf Oil Well
description: Dead and dying coral reefs were found this week in a survey of the sea floor near BPs blown-out well in the Gulf of Mexico, scientists say. The scientists say it it highly likely that the reefs were damaged by the BP oil spill.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 5
description: More Photographs

title: Following Tradition at Army, After Detour at Air Force
description: WEST POINT, N.Y.  Inside Armys practice facility, a good punt away from Michie Stadium, Jared Hassin bolted out of his stance in the backfield and turned the right corner with an option pitch, leaving only a view of the No. 7 on the back of his black jersey.

title: Yes, a Recovery Did Begin
description: Brad DeLong says that there was no economic recovery earlier this year, so its wrong to say that the recovery faltered.

title: Look of the Moment | Flame On
description: The Look: Head-to-toe red  from the fiery mane to the flirty feathers.

title: A Nightclubbers Quiet Retreat
description: Jayma Cardoso, the nightclub impresario and Scott Campbell, a broker, are busy even for New Yorkers. Their streamlined apartment was designed to be a refuge.

title: The Sanctuary of the 400 Shoes
description: HOW busy is Jayma Cardoso, the Brazilian-born nightclub impresario?

title: Lauren Denenberg, Jordan Bettman
description: Lauren Beth Denenberg, a daughter of Debbie and Bruce Denenberg of Plymouth Meeting, Pa., was married Saturday evening to Jordan Alex Bettman, the son of Shelli and Gary Bettman of Saddle River, N.J. Rabbi Saul Grife officiated at the Plaza Hotel in New York.

title: Kristin Hoffman, Justin Jankowski
description: Kristin Nicole Hoffman, a daughter of Eileen C. Hoffman and Kerry A. Hoffman of Cherry Hill, N.J., was married there on Saturday to Justin Michael Jankowski, a son of Jamie P. Jankowski and Edward Jankowski of New York. The Rev. Jeremiah J. McCarthy, a Roman Catholic priest and a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Catholic Church of St. Mary.

title: Hiroko Hosaka and Ryan David
description: Dr. Hiroko Hosaka and Dr. Ryan Douglas David were married Saturday in Irvington, N.Y. Lawrence L. Strang, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at Sunnyside, a house museum that was the home of Washington Irving.

title: Hilary Zwerdling, Nicholas Papas
description: Hilary Chasman Zwerdling and Nicholas William Papas were married Saturday in the Abbey Room of the Boston Public Library. Andrew M. Stone, a friend of the couple authorized by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate, led a service that incorporated Jewish and Greek Orthodox traditions.

title: Renita Jablonski, Joshua Podwoski
description: Renita Jablonski and Joshua Podwoski were married Friday evening at the Shrine Church of St. Stanislaus in Cleveland. The Rev. Michael Surufka, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Elizabeth Alexander and David Wade
description: Elizabeth Evans Alexander and David Eckels Wade were married Saturday evening at the First United Methodist Church in Cleburne, Tex. The Rev. Dr. Barry E. Hughes, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Tali Farhadian and Boaz Weinstein
description: Tali Farimah Farhadian and Boaz Ronald Weinstein were married Saturday evening at the Central Synagogue in Manhattan. Rabbi James E. Ponet performed the ceremony, with Cantor Angela Warnick Buchdahl taking part.

title: Susan Ambler, Ashley Ebersole
description: Susan Margaret Ambler, the daughter of Robin P. Ambler and Scott K. Ambler of Miami, was married Saturday to Joseph Ashley Ebersole, the son of Nancy T. Ebersole of Washington and the late Joseph L. Ebersole. The Rev. Lisa Ann Saunders, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Johns Church Lafayette Square in Washington with the assistance of the Rev. William P. Billow Jr., also an Episcopal priest.

title: Anne Fernandez, Christopher Webber
description: Anne Marie Fernandez, a daughter of Ofelia R. Fernandez and Guillermo A. Fernandez of Miami, and Christopher Maddra Webber, the son of Catherine Johnson Webber and Carl M. Webber of Champaign, Ill., were married Saturday in Miami. Msgr. Jude ODoherty, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Epiphany.

title: Erika McGlone, Judson Kauffman
description: Erika Marie McGlone and Judson James Kauffman were married Saturday at the Gedney Farm in New Marlborough, Mass. The ceremony was led by Jack Conboy, a friend of the bridegroom who was granted permission by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate at the event.

title: Brooke Reichert, John Richardson
description: Brooke Morgan Reichert, the daughter of Carol E. Reichert and William H. Reichert of Hobe Sound, Fla., was married Saturday to John Dustin Richardson IV, the son of Lynn M. Richardson and Mr. Richardson III of Robesonia, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Robert S. Norris, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Royal Poinciana Chapel in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Brad Weinstein, Bryan Tallevi
description: Brad Scott Weinstein and Bryan Mancini Tallevi were married Saturday at Saltwater Farm Vineyard in Stonington, Conn. State Senator Andrew M. Maynard, who is also a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated.

title: Jennifer Gilman, Jeffrey Baumstein
description: Jennifer Gilman and Jeffrey Baumstein were married Saturday evening at the Roosevelt Hotel in New York. Rabbi Michael Paley officiated.

title: Courtney Gadsden, Spencer Mandell
description: Courtney Dittmann Gadsden and Spencer Allen Mandell were married Saturday at Belle Mer, an events space, in Newport, R.I. The brides mother, the Rev. Carol D. Gadsden, who is an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Anjanette Cabrera and Brian Murphy
description: Anjanette Cabrera and Brian Daniel Murphy were married Saturday at St. Martin of Tours Church in Brooklyn. The Rev. John Tobon Arango, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Allegra Glashausser, Michael Price
description: Allegra Walsh Glashausser and Michael William Price were married Saturday at the New Leaf Restaurant and Bar in New York. Justice Eugene M. Fahey of State Supreme Court in Buffalo and Rochester officiated.

title: Lee Phillips and Richard Young
description: Lee Morris Phillips and Richard Guy Young were married Friday at Alchemy, a restaurant on the grounds of CopperWynd, a resort in Fountain Hills, Ariz. The Rev. William W. Clinkenbeard, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Elizabeth Quin, John McCann
description: Elizabeth Gage Quin and John Robert McCann Jr. were married Saturday in Sarasota, Fla. The Rev. Mann Satterwhite Valentine VI, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of Sarasota.

title: Julia Schmidt, Frederick Shuart III
description: Julia Angelika Schmidt, a daughter of Dusanka Magovac Schmidt and Adalbert M. Schmidt of Los Angeles, was married there Saturday to Frederick Harrington Shuart III, the son of Mr. Shuart Jr. of Maywood, N.J., and the late Ruta Valters Shuart. Msgr. Kevin Kostelnik, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Cathedral of Our Lady of the Angels, where he is the pastor.

title: Erika Storella, Daniel Dwyer-Heidkamp
description: Erika Storella and Daniel John Dwyer-Heidkamp were married Friday at the Municipal Marriage Bureau in Manhattan. Blanca Martinez, a staff member of the Office of the City Clerk, officiated.

title: Rachel Stone, Daniel Sabreen
description: Rachel Linde Stone, the daughter of Rikke L. Stone and Peter G. Stone of Nyack, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Daniel Adam Sabreen, the son of Paula Sabreen and Robert Sabreen of Westfield, N.J. Cantor Elizabeth Goldmann officiated at the Hilton Pearl River in Pearl River, N.Y.

title: Jade-Snow Moy, David Joachim
description: Jade-Snow Margaret Moy and David Sanford Joachim are to be married Sunday at Round Hill House, an event space, in Washingtonville, N.Y. The Rev. Sara Henderson, an interfaith minister, is to perform the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Courtney Schneider and Robert Farkas
description: Courtney Lee Schneider and Robert Michael Farkas were married Saturday evening at the Pleasantdale Chateau, an event space in West Orange, N.J. Rabbi Arnold Gluck officiated.

title: Ronni Favors and Bill Colavito
description: Ronni Favors and Bill Colavito were married Saturday evening at the Palm House at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Donna Walker-Kuhne, a minister of religious ceremonies for Soka Gakkai International USA, a Buddhist lay organization in Manhattan, led a Nichiren Buddhist ceremony.

title: U.S. News & World Report to Become Online Only
description: U.S. News & World Report, the magazine that in recent years has gone from a weekly, to a semimonthly to a monthly, will no longer exist as a regularly printed publication.

title: A Brooklyn Apartment Beckons
description: AS a born-and-bred Manhattanite, Kirsten Abrams never considered living in any other borough.

title: Running Less and Cross-Training More
description: When I was younger runner, I came across a tip from a collegiate champion in a magazine, a tip called the 2 percent rule. In distance running, the champion asserted, 98 percent of all training should be running and the remaining sliver dedicated to cross-training.

title: Turn Piles of Waste Into Piles of Cash, City Asks
description: Except when visualizing alligators in the sewers and lost fishbowl pets, New Yorkers rarely think about what happens to the stuff that drains from sinks and toilet bowls. But 1.3 billion gallons of wastewater go down the tubes every day, where it begins a long and expensive process before it is buried and forgotten.

title: Running New York in His Prime Was a Priority for Gebrselassie
description: Haile Gebrselassie posed a question: Do you think Im old?

title: Paying Off a Mortgage
description: PAYING off a mortgage or even paying down the balance early might seem enticing to most borrowers. Theres the big savings in interest payments and the freed-up cash flow that can result, not to mention the emotional benefit of wiping out what for most people is the largest financial burden of a lifetime.

title: Thoughts On Pelosi
description: Im not objective here  Ive sort of made a point of not hanging out with politicians, but I have spent some time with Nancy Pelosi, and like her. Im also, of course, not an expert on political maneuvering.

title: Secret Cars Kept Under Wraps, in Public
description: CELEBRITIES wear disguises to dodge the paparazzi. Isnt that Brad Pitt under the tweed flat cap and shades? Mel Gibson behind the silly mustache? Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen wearing cat whiskers?

title: Mets and Takahashi Part Ways
description: Hisanori Takahashis time with the Mets is over after one successful season, and he will seek another team in free agency beginning Saturday.

title: Outstanding in a Class of One
description: WHEN a vehicle maker cannot decide exactly how to classify its product, consumers (and reviewers) are bound to struggle as well.

title: Waltz, Tango and Polka, With a Brazilian Accent
description: The Brazilian pianist Marcelo Bratke has recorded music from all over the repertory, but his performances in New York lately have been devoted to the music of his country, particularly that of Heitor Villa-Lobos and Ernesto Nazareth. His program at Zankel Hall on Thursday evening, though billed as a tribute to Villa-Lobos, was split between the two, with dances by Nazareth (and, as an encore, a movement from Milhauds Saudades do Brasil) making up the second half.

title: Loaded, Unlocked: Cadillac Made Life Easier for Thieves
description: IT is not the sort of list that automakers aspire to top: in August, the Highway Loss Data Institute, an industry research group affiliated with the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, named the Cadillac Escalade as the vehicle with the highest rate of insurance claims for theft. The group reported that 2007-9 Escalades had a claim frequency of 10.8 for every 1,000 insured vehicles, about five times more often than the average passenger vehicle.

title: After a Lone Hand Beckons, Grief, and Lipstick on a Naked Woman
description: Before the start of SuperGabriela, a two-part work presented by Cosmin Manolescu & Serial Paradise Company at Performance Space 122 on Thursday evening, a hand appeared through the folds of a black curtain. It was more silly than spooky, like a glimpse of Thing from The Addams Family.

title: Pleading Sanity
description: Two days before his suspension from MSNBC, the anchor talked about his partisanship. At his Rally to Restore Sanity, Jon Stewart complained about the shrieking tone of cable news. Were you watching when a montage juxtaposed footage from your news show with that of Glenn Becks? I saw that. I was sitting at home, with my notebooks for the election, in that Saturday haze that anybody who does five shows is still in until the middle of the afternoon on Saturday. I was thinking: Thats odd. I wouldnt think of myself in those terms. Why is my videotape there?

title: Taming the Courtney Monster
description: The singer and actress Courtney Love hopes for a comeback with a new album with her band, Hole.

title: Courtney Love: Id Like to Be Trusted Again.
description: ON Monday night, at a screening of the movie Due Date, Courtney Love told a reporter from Style.com that she was trying to take better care of herself.

title: Stuffed Cabbage, a Classic Worth Revisiting
description: STUFFED cabbage, or at least, the kind served in diners and made by millions of grandmothers of Eastern European descent, is a sweet-and-sour affair. The sweetness comes from any range of ingredients  honey, ketchup, sugar, you name it  and the sour from citrus or vinegar. Its almost always too sweet, and the sourness somehow lends no balance at all. But the concept is a good one.

title: A Vegetable Wellington, Fit for a Duke
description: EVER since the weather turned cold and blustery, Ive had puff pastry on the brain in buttery, flaky profusion.

title: Top Player Withdraws From World Championship Competition
description: Magnus Carlsen, the No. 2 player in the world (No. 1 if the results of the Pearl Spring tournament in China that ended last week are included in the rankings), has withdrawn from the competition to select the next challenger for the world championship.

title: A Rural Suburb With a Flinty Past
description: BRANCHVILLE, a hilly corner of Ridgefield in Fairfield County about 50 miles from Midtown Manhattan, gets its name from a railroad junction of the late 1800s. Its air was once smoky from mills that churned out glue and varnish. Its land was scarred by miners in search of granite, quartz and mica.

title: Hard Times, Sometimes Unvarnished
description: Just as the newly unemployed look back in wonder and dismay at the money they used to squander on shopping sprees and restaurants, viewers in a recession may regret the time wasted on Jon & Kate Plus 8 or Keeping Up With the Kardashians.

title: Reviewing the 2011 Aston Martin V-12 Vantage
description: In Sundays Autos section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the 2011 Aston Martin V-12 Vantage:

title: Big Fish in Small Theaters Often Find a Big, Scary Ocean on Broadway
description: Broadway or death. The reigning wisdom of theater producers these days is that if a play is ever going to grow up  that is, be taken seriously, receive lots of attention and, above all, make money  it can do so only on Broadway.

title: Sunday Preview
description: In this Sundays Travel section, David Carr goes off the grid on a private island in the Bahamas. No more than a small rise of volcanic rock, shells and sand lying all by its lonesome off Long Island in the Bahamas, he writes, Little Deadmans Cay would seem well cast either as a paradise or prison with palm trees.

title: Inside Carmens Lusty Lair, The Walls Keep Closing In
description: The tenor Brandon Jovanovich offered a chilling reminder of the perils of a toxic love affair when Richard Eyres production of Carmen returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday evening.

title: Special-Needs Trusts: Report Your Experiences
description: In this weekends Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan writes about the ins and outs of special-needs trusts, which are trust accounts for disabled people that can help them preserve eligibility for government benefits and supplement those benefits as well.

title: Netgear Wants to Wirelessly Connect New Televisions
description: Netgear, the maker of a number of wireless products, has a plan to beat its competitors, which include Belkin and Cisco, and double its revenue in the coming year. It involves the television.

title: Footnote
description: The Metropolitan Opera said William Shimell would replace Wolfgang Holzmair and sing the role of Don Alfonso in Cos fan Tutte this season. The production opens on Tuesday. The Met said that Mr. Holzmair had a sinus infection.

title: In Other Gershwin News
description: A large archive of material related to the songwriting team of George and Ira Gershwin will be moved from San Francisco to the Library of Congress, The Los Angeles Times reported. Before Ira Gershwins widow, Leonore, died in 1991, she said that she wanted the archive to go eventually to the Library, but her will allowed for her nephew, Michael Strunsky, to keep it in California for as long as he wanted. Mr. Strunsky, 76, who lives in San Francisco, attributed his decision to transfer the archive partly to his getting older and partly to the fact that royalties and licensing fees for Ira Gershwins work, which he had used to support the archive and keep it open to researchers, had declined in recent years. The archive will join other large holdings of Gershwin material at the Library of Congress.

title: Before Suspension, Mets Rodriguez Moved in With Clubhouse Manager
description: Shortly after a judge in Queens ordered Francisco Rodriguez to stay away from his girlfriend because he had an altercation with her father at Citi Field in August, Rodriguez moved in with someone many Mets players have grown to trust over the past two and a half decades: the teams clubhouse manager, Charlie Samuels.

title: First Look | J. Crew Men
description: I just wanted to capture the momentum of the day, says Frank Muytjens, the head designer of mens wear at J. Crew. Equipped with a Canon EOS 7D camera, Muytjens drew out the ease and effortlessness of J. Crews spring 2011 collection on his models leading up to the presentation yesterday at Milk Studios. It can get crazy backstage, but its always a calm and organized chaos, Muytjens says. This mentality complements the Americana feel derived from Cy Twombly, Irving Penn, naval uniforms and Prouts Neck: Its a clean, fresh look but with a lot of texture  disheveled dressy. Fabrics with metal yarns woven in  nubby rustic yarns for sweaters, but in a fitted silhouette. Highlights include a reworked gray hoodie elevated through toggle and button closures, paired with vintage patchwork detailed shorts. The collection hits stores on Feb. 11.

title: CBS Leads
description: Two top CBS sitcoms on Thursday delivered their highest ratings since their September season premieres, and ABCs Private Practice drew a large audience for an episode that dealt with the rape of a character. According to Nielsens estimates, CBS was the nights most-watched network with The Big Bang Theory (13.9 million viewers) and $#*! My Dad Says (10.9 million). ABC saw surging ratings for the episode of Private Practice (10.2 million), called Did You Hear What Happened to Charlotte King? Fox ranked third with new episodes of Bones (9.1 million) and Fringe (5 million), while NBC struggled with comedies.

title: The Female Scientist, the Biggest Secret
description: Women abound in plays about science. How else would writers simplify lofty concepts for the audience without some wife, sister or comely student fetchingly furrowing her brow at the brilliant fellows and saying something along the lines of, Wait, let me get this straight ...?

title: Stuffed Cabbage Without the Sweet Sauce
description: Stuffed cabbage need not be difficult, nor do you have to serve it in a ketchupy, sickly sweet sauce. Made with a well-spiced tomato sauce, it can be really good. I made stuffed cabbage with lamb and rice for this weeks Minimalist.

title: A Clever Defense From a Hard-to-Find Play
description: A few bridge deals are especially appealing because they require an unusual play that would not occur to many.

title: Documentaries and Ties That Bind or Unravel
description: IN 2002, while he was making Capturing the Friedmans, his investigation of a notorious child-abuse prosecution on Long Island, the director Andrew Jarecki received a piece of documentary wisdom. When this is over, Sheila Nevins, the president of HBO Documentary Films, told him, you will have had one of the most amazing experiences of your life. Youll understand your subjects in a way you dont understand your own family.

title: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 5
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a haunted house in Chelsea, children learning about the Second Avenue subway, the World Wrestling Entertainments fan appreciation day and more.

title: Unyielding, an Oligarch vs. Putin
description: I wish I had enough space to reprint in its entirety Mikhail B. Khodorkovskys closing statement, as his latest sham trial in Russia came to an end earlier this week. I have never been so moved by the words of a businessman.

title: The Facebook Skeletons Come Out
description: AMONG the many firsts in the 2010 elections, it is safe to assume that the following words had never before been uttered about a future member of Congress, This is a candidate who is probably best known for getting drunk and having sex on television.

title: In Bridgeport, a Key to Revival
description: BRIDGEPORT

title: Son and Father Pierce Autisms Veil
description: Neighbors, friends and teachers were dropping hints  some subtle, others pointed, even cruel  that something was not right with Timothy Archibalds first child, Elijah.

title: A Boy Wants to Dress Like a Girl
description: Sound familiar?Head on over to the Well blog, and join the conversation.

title: Man Started Flight Elderly and White, and Ended It Young and Asian
description: Updated | Saturday | 11:18 a.m. Air security professionals, and immigration officials, are puzzling over the possible implications of an intelligence alert issued by Canadas Border Services Agency this week about a man who boarded a flight to Vancouver in Hong Kong disguised as an elderly white man and then removed a head and neck mask during the flight to reveal that he was, in fact, young and Asian.

title: A Sugar and Salt Solution for Haitis Cholera Epidemic
description: Twenty years ago I witnessed what seemed to be a medical miracle in a village deep in Bolivia: a nearly lifeless child dehydrated by severe diarrhea was given sips of a sugar and salt solution and recovered in a couple of hours. Curious about this simple yet lifesaving mixture called oral rehydration solution, I learned that United States-funded scientists had discovered it in 1968 in then-East Pakistan as a simple, cheap alternative to intravenous treatment. Defying all expectations, the researchers learned that at the right proportions, oral rehydration could resurrect even severely dehydrated adults suffering from cholera.

title: Sparks Fly Over a High Line Park in Jersey City
description: JERSEY CITY

title: Real Estate Q & A
description: Sublet Fees in Co-op Buildings

title: British Troops Accused of Abusing Iraqi Detainees
description: LONDON  A lawyer for 200 Iraqis demanding a public inquiry into what they have described as brutal mistreatment by British soldiers in a secret detention center near Basra told the High Court in London on Friday that the abuse amounted to Britains Abu Ghraib. The assertion was buttressed with video recordings that appeared to show British interrogators bullying, humiliating and threatening a detainee.

title: Banks Brace for Costly Fights Over Mortgage Mess
description: By NELSON D. SCHWARTZ

title: F.D.A. Questions Drug Store Tests for Sexually Transmitted Diseases
description: 8:41 p.m. | Updated with Rite Aid comment

title: A Beethoven Opus Strains a Quartet
description: Four empty chairs; four music stands awaiting scores; four professional musicians, bathed in spotlights, facing the audience and struggling to explain what makes a string quartet tick.

title: Robert K. Futterman
description: Mr. Futterman, 51, is the founder and chief executive of Robert K. Futterman and Associates, an independent brokerage and consulting firm specializing in urban retail markets. RKF, as the company is known, was responsible for leasing the retail space in the Time Warner Center, and it currently serves as an adviser to the Port Authority for the World Trade Center redevelopment.

title: The Alternate Universe of Isiah Thomas
description: In a parallel universe, LeBron James is a Knick, running the break with Eddy Curry and Jamal Crawford; Larry Brown was never hired and Isiah Thomas was never fired, nor found liable for sexual harassment.

title: In Salvation, Its Sometimes the Priest Who Needs Comfort
description: A priest walks into a filthy apartment to administer last rites. For someone whos supposed to comfort the dying, youre kind of dark, he is told.

title: For Gays, New Songs of Survival
description: AT first listen, We R Who We R, the current single from the pop singer Ke$ha, sounds like just another entry in her glitter-caked catalog of dance hits. Eccentrically spelled song title? Check. Effervescent electro-pop production courtesy of the megaproducer Dr. Luke? Check. Ample use of Auto Tune? Double check.

title: Others? A Mystery, Thank Goodness
description: Who wouldnt want to live in this house? Or just in the library, which constitutes most of the set of Yale Reps moving new production of A Delicate Balance, Edward Albees 1966 Pulitzer Prize winner. Its an almost frighteningly grand room with tall, multipaned windows and dark paneling from floor to sky-high ceiling. The bar  the rooms spiritual center  fills at least half a dozen bookshelves.

title: On Health Care, Dying and the Value of Life
description: ITS different from my other shows, said Anna Deavere Smith.

title: A Rarity, Young World Chess Champion Is an American
A Duchess With a Common Touch
description: EDENSOR, England

title: A Political Play From the 40s, Very of the Moment
description: State of the Union is a very funny, very smart play. And when it won the Pulitzer Prize, people must have thought: Oh, good. Now that all the manipulation and dishonesty in presidential politics have been exposed, things will change and the American government can go back to serving, and existing for the good of, the people.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,349 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: One Night, Two Orchestras and Widening Ambition
description: OVER the past 25 years, the Westchester Philharmonic has built a reputation as perhaps the countys premier purveyor of large-scale orchestral works, but the philharmonic may soon have to share its musical turf. The Westchester Chamber Orchestra, which has quietly established itself with well-received accounts of smaller works, intends to expand the size of its ensemble and the scale of its offerings.

title: The Pelosi-Bachmann Conundrum
description: While the results of Tuesdays midterm election are mostly clear  thanks, Washington State, Connecticut and Illinois for beating my deadline; still waiting on you, Alaska  and  Minnesota  there are plenty of questions about the future.

title: NASA Delays Shuttle Launching After Finding Hydrogen Leak and Crack
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  The shuttle Discovery, already delayed three times by technical problems and bad weather, was grounded again Friday, this time by a potentially dangerous gaseous hydrogen leak in a vent line attached to the ships external tank.

title: An Unavoidable Collision
description: When, on a Friday afternoon in December 2000, a black woman, her 2-year-old strapped to her back and her 3-year-old and 5-year-old in her arms, left a South African squatter camp and stepped into the path of a speeding commuter train, it was no accident. But the white motorman who unavoidably plowed into them   he was an accident, a random accessory to the mothers despair.

title: Still Life Americana: Beyond Fruit
description: Can there be such a thing as an American still life? A pretty good case is made for it in the opening galleries of American Still Life: Treasures From the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, N.Y.

title: For Some Women, Elite Start Could Mean a Lonely Race
description: It is hard to imagine that any of the more than 43,000 people scheduled to run in the New York City Marathon will be wanting for company during their 26.2-mile tour of the town. But because the elite women start before the rest of the field, several national-class women could find the race something of a solitary endeavor.

title: Officers Extortion Conviction Prompts Calls for Full Exoneration of Norfolk Four
description: WASHINGTON  The recent conviction of a Virginia police officer supports the case for full exoneration of the Norfolk Four, former sailors convicted of rape and murder, who received conditional pardons from Virginias governor last year, lawyers for the men said.

title: Middle Eastern Flavors, and Hookahs, Too
description: IF you are in the George Street neighborhood of New Brunswick and hungry for good, basic Middle Eastern food and fresh salads, Kairo Kafe is your place.

title: From Rugs to Kebabs
description: Before Ali and Fatima Khayatian opened Honey, a cozy grocery and cafe in Teaneck, they sold Persian rugs wholesale.

title: A Lincoln Photograph  and a Mystery
description: Washington, Nov. 6, 1860

title: Immigrants Pilot Lessons Spur Inquiry by the U.S.
description: BOSTON  Federal officials could not explain Friday how more than 30 immigrants charged with being here illegally got clearance to take flying lessons at an airstrip outside Boston.

title: Return From Injury Is Stunning to Everyone but Himself
description: RENTON, Wash.  The scar curves just above Leon Washingtons right ankle, its path snaking three inches up his leg. Each time Washington looks down there, he is reminded of an injury so gruesome  as if stolen from a horror movie  that his former Jets teammates fast-forwarded the play on film.

title: Action Sought On Gay Policy
description: The Log Cabin Republicans, a gay rights group, asked the United States Supreme Court on Friday to allow a California trial judges order barring enforcement of the dont ask, dont tell policy on gay members of the military to go back into effect. The group asked the court to vacate a decision Monday by the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit to keep the policy in place until it considers the governments appeal of the state judges decision. (AP)

title: A Formula for Good Wine
description: Richard Pisacano has a winning formula for turning fine North Fork grapes into first-rate wines: He has Roman Roth do the winemaking at Wlffer Estate.

title: A Lifetime With H.I.V.
description: What is it like to be born with H.I.V.? How does it affect your outlook? Four young adults speak about their lives.

title: Aperitif, a French Bistro, Roams Far Afield
description: APERITIF is a French bistro and much more than that. This Rockville Centre newcomer, which opened in late July, is owned by the Sage Bistro Restaurant Group, which also has Sage Bistro in Bellmore, Brasserie Persil in Oceanside and Sage Bistro Moderne in Woodbury. The two owners, Peter Oktas and Julio Velasquez, met when they worked at Bistro Cassis in Huntington. Mr. Oktas was the manager, Mr. Velasquez the chef.

title: Indian to Go, and Plenty of It
description: Occupying a narrow, cheerfully lighted storefront, Ambadi, a carry-out Indian food shop in White Plains, has just celebrated its sixth birthday. From its opening days as a vendor of Indias street food, the place has worked, year by year, to expand its menu in response to public demand. Apparently, busy diners from the surrounding business community wanted more than a couple of samosas to go. The menu now offers a long list of entrees.

title: Shell Presses for Drilling in Arctic
description: HOUSTON  Eager to win approval for its stalled plan to drill for oil in the Alaskan Arctic, Royal Dutch Shell is beginning a public lobbying campaign, including national advertising, on Monday. As part of the effort, the giant oil company is promising to make unprecedented preparations to prevent the kind of disaster that polluted the Gulf of Mexico earlier this year.

title: Census Finds Single Mothers and Live-In Partners
description: More than a quarter of the unmarried women who gave birth in a recent year were living with a partner, according to a Census Bureau report that for the first time measured the percentage of unmarried mothers who were not living alone.

title: Italian Pastas Meet the Arabian Nights
description: AT Eclisse Mediterraneo Cucina, a new restaurant in White Plains, richly flavored Persian dishes share the menu with gorgeous labor-intensive Italian pastas  and whichever style you choose, youre bound to bump into the unusual and the unusually delicious.

title: Doing Good by Default
description: At the end of Tuesdays Fixes column about changing the default choice from opt in to opt out for decisions like putting money into a 401(k) account, donating organs or taking an AIDS test, I asked readers to send in their own ideas about where else the opt-out default could be applied for the common good.

title: Living In | Branchville, Conn.
description: This hilly corner of Ridgefield, more moderately priced than some parts of Fairfield County, was once an industrial zone with glue factories and stone quarries.

title: Black and Republican and Back in Congress
description: WASHINGTON  For the first time in over a decade, the incoming class of Congress will include two black Republicans, both of whom rode the Tea Party wave to victory while playing down their race.

title: 2010 Faltered as a New Year of the Woman in Politics
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Patty Murray of Washington is still the same self-described mom in tennis shoes she was back in 1992, when she was ushered into Congress in what some called the Year of the Woman. But this week, Ms. Murray barely eked out a re-election victory, in a cycle that will see no increase in the number of women in Congress  and possibly even a decrease in the House.

title: Of Airlines and Aerobatics
description: MY parents were economists who worked to improve conditions in the developing world. We lived in Latin America and Africa before settling in the United States. These circumstances exposed me to travel and different cultures, creating in me a passion for aviation and adventure.

title: Direct From the Farm: Homey Yet Elegant Italian
description: THE menu looks sensational. Grilled octopus with salsa verde. Salumi. Pizza Margherita. Spaghetti carbonara. Veal saltimbocca. And it tastes sensational.

title: Fresh From the Roaster
description: Well before arriving at the modern, glass-sheathed headquarters of Omar Coffee you will sense your proximity to it. Thats because every day, starting at 7 a.m., its 500-pound-capacity roaster churns into action, filling the air with the pleasingly smoky fragrance of beans being processed.

title: Tea Party Rooted in Religious Fervor for Constitution
description: Late on the afternoon of Election Day, James Renwick Manship joined the assembly of Tea Party supporters outside the Capitol. He wore a cravat, a powdered wig, a tricorn hat and a brass-buttoned coat in the blue and buff colors of the Continental Army. Such is the standard attire of his vocation portraying George Washington.

title: Safer Football, Taught From Inside the Helmet
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  Alan Pelc has been taught how to block since his Houston boyhood, how to push and pulverize and punish oncoming defenders on the football field. This was different. He was learning how not to punish himself.

title: A Suicide More Complex Than a Slogan
description: In one of the last updates he posted on his Facebook page, Joseph Jefferson sounded like yet another young gay person succumbing to overwhelming social rejection, if not outright bullying.

title: Its Official: Republican Concedes in Illinois Race
description: A day after The Associated Press declared Gov. Patrick J. Quinn the winner of the Illinois governors race, his Republican opponent, Bill Brady, did too.

title: A Tailor, Called Upon by Designers and Politicians
description: When the trend-setting fashion designers Marcus Wainwright and David Neville of Rag & Bone wanted a top-of-the-line mens wear maker for their hip brand, whose door did they knock on? Martin Greenfields.

title: Latinos Reached Milestones in Midterm Races
description: PHOENIX  There was plenty of grim news for Latinos in Tuesdays election results: three Latino congressmen were voted out, the odds of an immigration overhaul appeared to diminish and  here in the state that gave rise to the strictest immigration measure of all  hardliners were re-elected amid vows to continue cracking down on illegal immigrants.

title: A Seaside Home in Turkey
description: Mica Etergun, the New York interior designer, took a stone ruin and turned it into a luxurious vacation home.

title: U.S. News & World Report to End Monthly Publication
description: U.S. News & World Report, once part of the triumvirate of newsweeklies but reduced now to a spare monthly, will print its last issue for subscribers in December.

title: Dividends From Fannie and Freddie Surpass Aid
description: WASHINGTON  The federal government made a profit of $1.1 billion in the third quarter on its huge bailout of the mortgage finance giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, even as the two companies continued to lose money on bad loans.

title: Coaches Shouldnt Be Immune to Penalties
description: The new N.C.A.A. president, Mark Emmert, has an idyllic view of what the intercollegiate athletic experience, at its best, could be.

title: Running for Your Life
description: IT was still dark when Dr. Thomas A. Farley got to Central Park on a cool October morning and started stretching his grasshopperlike legs, blending into the background in black shorts and a T-shirt. He was training for the New York City Marathon, and would not let a sore Achilles tendon stop him from a four-mile run.

title: Jill Clayburgh Dies at 66; Starred in Feminist Roles
Breeders Cup Opens With Controversy, Including a Fight
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  The first day of the Breeders Cup started with an altercation between the jockeys Calvin Borel and Javier Castellano over rough riding. It ended with confusion and concern over whether one of the favorites in the Ladies Classic, Life at Ten, was healthy enough to be in the $2 million race.

title: As H.I.V. Babies Come of Age, Problems Linger
description: WARWICK, R.I.  Theyve been telling me since age 3 that I would die, Tom Cosgrove said quietly. Then age 6, age 8, age 10.

title: Finding a Spot in the Wild
description: Anglique Kidjo, 50, the Grammy-winning African pop star, savors the rare Sundays when her touring schedule allows her to be home with her family. She lives with her husband, Jean Hbrail, and daughter, Nama, 17, in a condominium in Park Slope, Brooklyn. After growing up in Benin, in West Africa, Ms. Kidjo spent 14 years in France, then moved to New York in 1997. On Thursday, she performs at Carnegie Hall.

title: To Capitalize on Low Bids, Navy Hopes to Name 2 Winners for Ship Contract
description: The Navys new littoral combat ships are supposed to be quick enough to run down coastal patrol craft and diesel submarines.

title: Zenyatta Is Hard to Beat, and Harder to Ignore
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  It takes some kind of horse to get people talking about horse racing beyond the Kentucky Derby and the other Triple Crown races. Cigar was the last one to capture the imagination of casual sports fans by tossing off a 16-race winning streak over his 1995 and 1996 seasons, winning the Breeders Cup Classic and Dubai World Cup in that span.

title: Olbermann of MSNBC Suspended Over Donations
description: Keith Olbermann, the leading liberal voice on American television in the age of Obama, was suspended Friday after his employer, MSNBC, discovered he made campaign contributions to three Democrats last month.

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: THE FETCH CLUB, a haven for pampered pooches, fills a space where Fulton Fish Market smells once wafted. There is certainly no odor in this deluxe dormitory for dogs  the air is ionized and purified. The water is filtered, and the food is organic.

title: With New Resources, Urban Students Are Encouraged to Apply to College
description: YONKERS, N.Y.

title: An Actress of Feminist Ethos
description: The actress Jill Clayburgh, known for her portrayals of strong, independent women, has died.

title: Campaigning for Others, Christie Proves a Star Near and Far
description: One of the biggest winners of the elections this week was not on any ballot. Gov. Chris Christie, campaigning for fellow Republicans from California to Massachusetts, trailed perhaps only Sarah Palin as the booster most sought after by his partys candidates, and most avidly received by the party faithful.

title: Cities as Hubs of Energy and Climate Action
description: Nov. 7, 8:25 p.m. | Updated A pair of energy and development specialists from the mayors offices in New York City and Los Angeles are going global.

title: Despite Losses, Nancy Pelosi Will Run for House Post
description: WASHINGTON  Despite severe election losses that cost her party the House, Speaker Nancy Pelosi said Friday that she would run to remain the leader of House Democrats even as some of her colleagues urged her to step aside.

title: Saudis Warned U.S. of Attack Before Parcel Bomb Plot
description: WASHINGTON  Saudi intelligence officials warned the United States in early October that Al Qaedas affiliate in Yemen was planning a terrorist attack using one or more aircraft, three weeks before a plot to send parcel bombs on cargo planes was foiled at the last minute, American and European officials said Friday.

title: Gimelstob Bets That Expert Will Get Him to Finish
description: The former professional tennis player Justin Gimelstob has never run a marathon, but now he has $10,000 and a great deal of pride at stake in his first one on Sunday. So he was only too pleased when Laura Skladzinski offered to help. Even though she is only 25, Skladzinski has more than enough experience for the two of them.

title: Political Funds Remain an Asset for Many Ex-Lawmakers
description: WASHINGTON  Henry Bonilla, a Texas Republican and former member of Congress, has tapped into his political piggy bank to fly around the United States, eat at some of San Antonios finest restaurants and to cover bills at luxury hotels like The Breakers in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Corrections
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: Education Unit Lifts Washington Post Company
description: The Washington Post Company said third-quarter profit more than tripled on sales growth in its higher education unit, which is facing government scrutiny, and a pickup in advertising revenue in its newspaper business. The company, which publishes The Washington Post, said it earned $60.9 million, or $6.84 a share, up from $17.1 million, or $1.81 a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 7.3 percent, to $1.19 billion. Earnings doubled at the Kaplan education unit, which accounts for almost two-thirds of revenue. Still, enrollment growth for higher education programs slowed, and the company said that pending government regulation of commercial colleges and a new free-trial period for students might hurt earnings. Revenue at the newspaper division rose 5 percent to $163.4 million. The Posts print ad sales rose 3 percent to $72 million. Stock in the Post Company, which is based in Washington, rose $14.48, or 3.8 percent, to $398.38.

title: Fluors Shares Surge on Improved Business Outlook
description: Shares in the Fluor Corporation, the construction company, surged nearly 10 percent in response to the companys announcement that its order backlog had expanded 18 percent and that it would increase its share buybacks. On Thursday, Fluor raised its share repurchase program by 7.2 million shares to a total of 12 million shares, or 6.7 percent of its outstanding stock as of Oct. 29. The company said its order backlog rose to $33 billion in the third quarter amid new project awards for infrastructure, mining, oil and gas, including an oil sands project in Canada. The increase marked the second consecutive quarter of expansion, Fluor said. Stock in Fluor, which is based in Irving, Tex., rose $4.73, to $54.53.

title: Weekly Pick Em: Showdown in Utah
description: On Saturday, all eyes will be on the Mountain West. At least all the eyes that can be. Texas Christian will travel to play Utah in one of the more intriguing matchups between undefeated teams this season. Both teams have established themselves as top-notch programs in the past decade, but they find themselves lagging behind Boise State this season when it comes to non-B.C.S. teams cracking the B.C.S. This game provides a chance for each to showcase why they should be considered among the countrys elite. Another team that is hoping for some national recognition is Baylor, which beat Texas last week and is hoping to go into Oklahoma State and upend the Cowboys. Nick Saban is sure to get a, ahem, loud reception when Alabama takes the field against Louisiana State. Perhaps Les Miles can draw on some of his magic and help the Tigers beat back the Tide. Arkansas and South Carolina face off in another marquee SEC matchup, while Arizona will look to slow down Stanfords offense in a key Pac-10 game.

title: The Votes Are In. Eloquence Didnt Win.
description: If the American political process had any integrity, winning candidates would grab the microphone on election night and say, Hey, all you haters out there, guess what? I so totally won! Now Im the boss of you. This is going to be awesome.

title: Saturday: Poinciana Feature
description: Since the contest in Fridays puzzle is still open to entries (until midnight Sunday), well continue with our contest-hint ban in todays comments.

title: Learning to Love Foreclosures?
description: In the most recent mortgage mess, the Obama administration has  oddly and disturbingly  been arguing that foreclosures are, in effect, good for the economy and should proceed apace as banks get their snarled paperwork in order.

title: The Grizzly Manifesto
description: I think it is time to take back the mama grizzly.

title: China Blusters On
description: Theres apparently no limit to Chinas arrogance, not to mention its tone-deafness. According to The Timess Michael Wines, China this week formally asked European nations to boycott the Oslo ceremony where the Nobel Peace Prize will be awarded  in absentia  to the imprisoned Chinese democracy activist, Liu Xiaobo.

title: Working With India
description: President Obama will spend three days in India beginning on Saturday  the longest foreign stay of his presidency. Indians are still feeling anxious and insufficiently loved. But the trip is a clear a sign of the importance that Mr. Obama places on the relationship. As he should.

title: Thats the Latest
description: Its no surprise that triumphant Tea Party politicians are seeking ranking posts within the incoming House Republican majority. But their likely speaker, Representative John Boehner, already has a problem with Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota, the doyenne of conservative insurgents.

title: Tone-Deaf in D.C.
description: It would be easy to misread the results of Tuesdays elections, and it looks as if the leaders of both parties are doing exactly that.

title: Two Arrests in Shooting Death of 5-Year-Old
description: LOS ANGELES  It was a real-life Halloween nightmare: 5-year-old Aaron Shannon Jr. was posing for pictures in his Spider-Man costume in the backyard of his familys South Los Angeles home when men opened fire from a nearby alley. Aaron was hit in the back of the head and died in the hospital the next day.

title: N.F.L.s Union Files Complaint to Agent
description: The N.F.L. players union Friday issued a disciplinary complaint to the N.F.L. agent Ian Greengross for the reported actions of his associate Kenny Rogers.

title: Have It Your Way
description: Bacon, egg and cheese on a roll, toasted, with ketchup and mayo. The cash register clangs.

title: Germany: 18-Year-Old Faces Charges of Terrorism Over Internet Videos
description: An 18-year-old man was arrested in northwest Germany on Friday on charges that he posted three videos on the Internet in October threatening terrorist attacks unless a convicted terrorist serving a 12-year prison term was released, the police said. The police said the suspect, whom they would not identify because he might be tried as a juvenile, uploaded three crude yet threatening videos onto YouTube. He also downloaded bomb-making manuals from the Internet, but was unable to make explosives because he did not have money for materials. In the videos, the man hid his face while claiming to speak on behalf of what he called the German mujahedeen. He demanded the release from prison of Daniel Schneider, the leader of the so-called Sauerland Cell, whose members were convicted in March 2010 for planning attacks on United States military installations in Germany. The police said that there was no evidence that the suspect was linked with Al Qaeda or any terrorist groups but that he had become a dangerous longer.

title: Lottery Numbers
U.N. Chief Says He Discussed Human Rights Privately in China
description: United Nations Secretary General Ban Ki-moon addressed mounting criticism that he was notably soft on Chinas human rights record by saying that he had raised the issue in private during his visit there this week. Mr. Ban said that China was on the path to political reform and building a society based on the rule of law. I hope that the Chinese government will further expand the space for civil society and take further steps that reflect and uphold its commitment to international human rights standards, he said at a news conference. He stopped short of calling on China to release imprisoned dissident Liu Xiaobo, the winner of this years Nobel Peace Prize, an award that infuriated Beijing. China is one of five permanent Security Council members that can veto Mr. Bans quest for a second term starting in 2012.

title: Elderly Are Cut From Meals Program
description: Dorothy Hinks may be enfeebled but she is proud.

title: For Some Catholic Schools, Its Admission Test Time
description: Breathless, with beads of sweat forming on his brow, Jahumi Harrigan, 23, hurried into the gym at Cathedral High School on East 56th Street on Friday morning, hand in hand with his 13-year-old sister, Asha.

title: Britain: Citizenship Restored to Cleric Wanted on Terrorism Charges in U.S.
description: A British government ruling stripping the Egyptian-born Muslim cleric known as Abu Hamza al-Masri of his British citizenship was struck down Friday by a special immigration court. But government officials said the courts action would not affect the governments plan to extradite the cleric to the United States, where he is wanted on terrorism charges. Officials in the office of Home Secretary Theresa May said no decision had been made on whether to appeal the immigration courts ruling to a higher British court. The immigration panel upheld the claim by lawyers for Mr. Hamza, 53, whose real name is Mostafa Kamel Mostafa, that losing the British citizenship he gained through marriage in 1986 would leave him stateless, because Egypts government has revoked his Egyptian citizenship. He has carried his fight to avoid extradition to the European Court of Human Rights. He is wanted in the United States, where he is accused in connection with a plot to establish a terrorism training camp in Oregon, and is alleged to have had a role in planning a terrorist ambush in Yemen in 1998 in which 16 foreign tourists, some of them Americans, were taken hostage. Four hostages were subsequently killed.

title: Rangers Keep Devils Winless at Home
description: NEWARK  Misery compounded misery for the Devils on Friday night. After a long, unsuccessful trip, they returned to the Prudential Center and were outplayed by the Rangers, 3-0.

title: France: Protesters Block Train Carrying Nuclear Waste
description: Protesters blocked a train carrying nuclear waste back to Germany on Friday, chaining themselves to train tracks a few hundred yards from the railway station in Caen, in northwestern France. The train, with 11 carriages of treated nuclear waste and 3 carriages full of riot police officers, was headed to Gorleben, Germany. The waste, which was created in German nuclear power plants and treated in France by Areva, was returning for storage in Gorleben, in Lower Saxony. The protesters called the shipment the most radioactive ever, an accusation contested by Areva, which had melted the waste, mixed it in glass and put it into containers. The German Parliament approved a bill recently extending the life of the countrys 17 reactors by 12 years, although they were supposed to have been shut down in 2020.

title: Success Comes to Knicks From Unexpected Places
description: Toney Douglas got the ball last, cradling it near midcourt as fans rose for an ovation and the clock hit all zeroes. This might not be the precise image that the Knicks cast for themselves after their free-agent shopping spree in July, but it might be the most fitting.

title: France: Roma Expelled From Church
description: About 13 Roma were expelled Friday from a church just south of Paris, the third expulsion of Roma in the past few days. The 13, including two adolescents, had been in France for a decade and had been moved from a squat. They took refuge in the church of St.-Nicolas de St.-Maur-des-Fosss hoping for better lodging, but were removed after the priest there signed an expulsion order. On Wednesday, two encampments of Roma  one nearby at Crteil and the other in Lyon, were also emptied by the police. France was sharply criticized this summer for a more intense effort to expel Roma who are non-French and who overstay their three-month visa, and for breaking up illegal encampments of Roma and traveling people, including French citizens, who have been living on land not designated for them by municipalities. France says Romania and Bulgaria must do more to integrate their Roma citizens, and spend more of the money the European Union provides for that purpose. But the Roma say they are not wanted in Romania.

title: Climate Panel Offers Ways to Raise Cash to Cope
description: UNITED NATIONS  After grappling with a fundamental deadlock between rich and poor nations over climate change, a high-level United Nations panel on Friday proposed a smorgasbord of ways to raise $100 billion annually to help developing countries cope with global warming.

title: Hearing the Returns with Mr. Lincoln
description: In 1860, a cub reporter named Samuel R. Weed scored the assignment of a lifetime when his St. Louis newspaper sent him to spend Election Day with the man who might become Americas president. Surprisingly, no one else had thought of it, and Weed arrived to find a relaxed Abraham Lincoln, greeting him as calmly and as amiably as if he had started on a picnic.

title: U.S. Islamic Web Site Is Taken Down
description: LONDON  A United States-based extremist Islamic Web site was taken down on Friday after the British authorities complained of a post praising a young woman who stabbed and nearly killed a British lawmaker over his support for the Iraq war.

title: A Quick Adjustment for Wall
description: WASHINGTON  Most rookies say the speed of the game is the biggest difference between college and the N.B.A. John Wall doesnt really have a problem adjusting to the quicker pace. Its the players that have been in the league who will have to adjust to him. Already regarded as one of the fastest players with the ball in his hand, John Wall was a blur Tuesday night in the Wizards home opener against the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events on Long Island
description: Comedy

title: Events in New Jersey
description: Comedy

description: A look back at the big news stories of the week. A news program produced by France24 in collaboration with The International Herald Tribune.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Comedy

title: Violence After Sentence in Oakland Killing
description: OAKLAND  Protesters vandalized storefronts and clashed with the police here on Friday night after a white former transit police officer was given what they considered to be a light sentence for the killing an unarmed black man. But protests initially seemed less violent than others that have surrounded the controversial case.

title: Charles McDowell, Commentator, Dies at 84
description: Charles McDowell, a retired columnist for The Richmond Times-Dispatch who brought a folksy manner to a regular stint on the PBS program Washington Week in Review and to a prominent role in Ken Burnss PBS series The Civil War, died Friday. He was 84.

title: Exporting Our Way to Stability
description: AS the United States recovers from this recession, the biggest mistake we could make would be to rebuild our economy on the same pile of debt or the paper profits of financial speculation. We need to rebuild on a new, stronger foundation for economic growth. And part of that foundation involves doing what Americans have always done best: discovering, creating and building products that are sold all over the world.

title: Drug Gang Chief Reported Killed in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  The Mexican authorities said Friday that a leader of the Gulf drug gang had been killed in Matamoros during a day marked by street fighting between soldiers and gunmen that paralyzed the city, which is across the Rio Grande from Brownsville, Tex.

title: Maddow Says Olbermanns Suspension Shows Difference Between MSNBC and Fox News
description: By suspending Keith Olbermann for contributing money to Democratic candidates, MSNBC appears to be trying to differentiate itself from the Fox News Channel, which does not discourage employees from making personal donations to candidates or political causes.

title: Shirley Verrett, Opera Singer of Power and Grace, Is Dead at 79
description: Shirley Verrett, the vocally lustrous and dramatically compelling American opera singer who began as a mezzo-soprano and went on to sing soprano roles to international acclaim, died Friday morning at her home in Ann Arbor, Mich. She was 79.

title: Elite Moscow Tournament Off to a Fast Start
In India, Obama Courts Corporate America
description: MUMBAI, India  President Obama, fresh off a stinging electoral defeat for Democrats, opened a 10-day tour of Asia on Saturday with a courtship of corporate America, including private meetings with American business executives who are here for his visit and an announcement that he will lift longstanding restrictions on exports of closely held technologies to India.

title: The Weekend Word: Regroup
description: From Todays Times:

title: Russian Journalist Beaten in Moscow
description: MOSCOW  A journalist for the popular daily newspaper Kommersant was seriously injured Saturday morning in an attack that his editor said was probably connected to his work.

title: NATO Investigates Report That Afghan Soldier Killed 2 G.I.s
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  NATO and Afghan officials on Saturday said they were investigating reports that an Afghan soldier turned his weapon on American troops, killing two soldiers.

description: Jim Squires is the breeder of the 2001 Kentucky Derby winner, Monarchos, and the author of Horse of a Different Color and Headless Horsemen.
