description: Three points about the Jets heading into the Detroit game, or three more than they had against Green Bay:

title: A Sudden End for Democratic Entrepreneurs in Congress
description: Almost exactly a year ago, The Agenda introduced  readers to the 11 entrepreneurs among the freshman class in the House of Representatives. Now, after an election that has turned control of the House over to the Republicans (and left the Senate more evenly divided), only six of them will become sophomores  all four Republicans, but just two of seven Democrats. Five Democrats lost their re-election bids, and none of those races were particularly close.

title: Brian Jones Previews Texas Christian-Utah
description: Brian Jones is a studio analyst for CBS College Sports Network, which will televise the Texas Christian-Utah game at 3:30 p.m. Eastern. He can also be seen every Tuesday night during the season as part of The Tony Barnhart Show at 9 p.m. and Inside College Football at 10.

title: The Abolitionists Epiphany
description: Boston, Nov. 7, 1860

title: Champions League Chalkboards
description: Beginning with this installment, the Goal blog is inaugurating a new feature that offers a statistical (courtesy of OPTA) and graphic representations of select matches from the European Champions League. At the end of each week when matches are played, the editor of zonalmarking.net, will provide analysis powered by the Total Football iPhone/iPad app, which is available at totalfootballapps.com and the iTunes App Store. Similar Chalkboards can be dissected at the Web site of the Guardian of Britain and at the zonalmarking Web site.

title: Filming Secretariats Story While Learning a Sport
description: Randall Wallace knows a thing or two about show business. He wrote the screenplay for Braveheart, which won the Academy Award for best picture and earned him a nomination for best original screenplay in 1996. He is also a novelist, songwriter, producer and director, and even has a black belt. What he is not is a horseman, and yet one would never guess that after viewing Secretariat, which he directed and which has grossed more than $46 million domestically.

title: When House Effects Become Bias
description: Perhaps now that the election is over and things are slightly calmer around here, we can take questions from readers a little more often  or even do a mailbag column once in a while.

title: Fighting Words
description: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy was unrepentant in the face of criticism that he intervened to win the release of a 17-year-old Moroccan runaway arrested for theft. The girl told prosecutors she dined at Mr. Berlusconis villa but denied having sex with him.

title: Laugh Lines
description: JIMMY KIMMEL

title: Hyatt Introduces Hypoallergenic Hotel Rooms
description: If youre the sort of traveler who cant leave home without your antihistamine, Hyatt may have a solution for you: a hypoallergenic guest room.

title: Prime Number
description: The dollar amount in political contributions that Keith Olbermann, the top anchor on MSNBC and a leading liberal voice on American television, made to three Democratic candidates last month. Mr. Olbermann was suspended indefinitely on Friday without pay. The suspension underscored the clash between objectivity and opinion in television journalism. Most news media outlets discourage or prohibit contributions by employees. But Michael C. Moynihan, a writer for the libertarian magazine Reason, asked, Isnt it unfair to hold Olbermann, who is one of the most partisan people on television (if not the Earth), to the same standards as, say, Brian Williams?

title: Back Then: 1946
description: In 1946, President Harry S. Truman was midway through his first term when Republicans who had pilloried him as a symbol of the New Deal seized control of Congress for the first time in 14 years. One Democrat, Senator J. William Fulbright of Arkansas, had a novel idea for Mr. Truman, who had no vice president at the time. Heres how The Associated Press reported it, quoting Mr. Fulbright:

title: The Morning Line: Spotlight Shines on Borel
description: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

title: Coral Die-Off Took Scientist by Surprise
description: Early on in the BP oil spill, I interviewed some marine biologists who had spent nearly a decade charting a series of deepwater coral reefs in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Childrens Books With Online Extras
description: Got tweens at home? In this weeks Sunday Book Review, I take a look at three young-adult novels (Spaceheadz, by Jon Scieszka with Francesco Sedita; Patrick Carmans Skeleton Creek: The Crossbones; and The Search for WondLa, by Tony DiTerlizzi) that expand their storytelling powers beyond the printed page and onto the Web, using fake and real Web sites as well online video to add to the reading experience.

title: The Obamas in India
description: President Obama announced a host of new trade deals with India, supporting tens of thousands of American jobs, as he began a 10-day Asian trip on a determinedly domestic note.

title: Zenyatta, a Hungry Superstar
description: Horses like to be horses. But it is hard for handlers to allow their horses just to be horses, when preparing them for a $5 million race. Details are fine tuned, training is designed to have the horse peak at the precise moment the gates open for a race they have been preparing for a year.

title: The Man Who Made the Marathon
description: George A. Hirsch is the founding publisher of New York magazine, the longtime publisher of Runners World and the chairman of the New York Road Runners.

title: Breeders Cup Takes Back Seat in France
description: Update Workforce, the morning-line favorite for the Turf, has been scratched because of the firm condition of the Churchill course.

title: G.O.P. Senate Group Still in Millers Corner
description: 2:24 p.m. | Updated

title: Jule Sugarman, Director and Architect of Head Start, Dies at 83
description: Jule Sugarman, a primary architect of Head Start, the federal support program for millions of poor preschoolers, died Tuesday at his home in Seattle. He was 83.

title: In Venezuela, a New Wave of Foreigners
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  On this booming continent, oil-rich Venezuela is the exception: South Americas only shrinking economy this year. Officials are rationing hard currency. Government takeovers of private businesses are increasing. One prominent financial analyst recently had just two words of advice for investors here: Run away.

title: Bernanke And The Shibboleths
description: Everyone hates quantitative easing. The inflationistas believe that its the end of Western civilization (but as a correspondent points out, we want them to believe that; similar beliefs about the end of the gold standard helped recovery in the 1930s); meanwhile, the rest of the world is furious at the Feds actions.

title: Portrait of the Electorate: Table of Detailed Results
description: A look at which groups voted for the Democratic or Republican candidate for the House of Representatives.

title: Rightward, March: The Midterm Exit Polls
description: How bad was it for Democrats last week? By nearly every demographic measure, the party lost ground, significantly in some cases.

title: Starting From Scratch on Day 2
description: I was sitting in the press box at Churchill Downs. It was quiet. No sound was coming from the many televisions, and the people who had time to talk had already left; everyone else was typing.The lights, those lights that were to make this first night-time Breeders Cup racing so special, were still on, illuminating an empty racetrack.

title: Acrostic: Powerful Stratego Piece
description: Whew! The answers in todays acrostic arent all eight letters long, so I dont need to take up valuable blog space lauding that (as I did with the previous two acrostics). Even better, the answers arent all three letters long, which would take up valuable space in the Sunday magazine section, pages perhaps.

title: While Warning About Fat, U.S. Pushes Cheese Sales
description: Dominos Pizza was hurting early last year. Domestic sales had fallen, and a survey of big pizza chain customers left the company tied for the worst tasting pies.

title: Geoffrey Crawley, 83, Dies; Gently Deflated a Fairy Hoax
description: Were there really fairies at the bottom of the garden, or was it merely a childhood prank gone strangely and lastingly awry?

title: America and India: The Almost-Special Relationship
description: NEW DELHI  At a panel discussion last week on relations between India and the United States, Strobe Talbott, the former American diplomat, told an audience of Indian business leaders that he had learned a valuable lesson about India: Do not hyphenate it. As in Indo-Pak. (Or, in a close cousin of a hyphen, as in Chindia.) The audience smiled at his epiphany: India matters because it is India.

title: Why the Government Is Promoting Cheese
description: Have you noticed your restaurant food getting cheesier lately? It may be due to the efforts of Dairy Management, a marketing creation of the United States Department of Agriculture. The role Dairy Management plays in the national promotion of cheese is explained in an investigative report from the New York Times reporter Michael Moss.

title: Discover Card Forges Tie to the N.H.L.
description: Just over two months ago, Discover Card acquired the naming rights to the Orange Bowl for four years and to the 2013 B.C.S. national championship game. On Monday, Discover will announce that it is the official credit card of the N.H.L. in the United States and the presenting sponsor of its 2011 All-Star Game in Raleigh, N.C.

title: Are Rising Commodity Prices An Inflationary Signal?
description: Right now everyone seems to believe that rising commodity prices are telling us to beware of inflation. I think thats dead wrong. Partly thats because the sticky prices are the ones to worry about. But its also worth having some perspective on commodity prices themselves.

title: Texas Considers Medicaid Withdrawal
description: Some Republican lawmakers  still reveling in Tuesdays statewide election sweep  are proposing an unprecedented solution to the states estimated $25 billion budget shortfall: dropping out of the federal Medicaid program.

title: QE Is Not CM
description: Yes, I know: YHTMAAAIYP*. But: as a followup to my shibboleths post, Im a bit shocked at the way so many people are treating US quantitative easing as somehow equivalent to Chinese currency manipulation.

title: John Boehner and the Politics of Crying
description: WASHINGTON  A presumptive new speaker of the House; so much to consider. Where will John Boehner stand on energy policy? Will he be able to manage Michele Bachmann? And how often will he weep?

title: Racings Holy Grail: the Pick Six
description: David Buc Geier helps run the Corner Cocktail, a tavern in the horse-racing hinterland of Kansas City, Mo. He has as many opinions and ideas on the Sport of Kings as he does un-cashable tickets in his desk drawer.

title: Tag-Along Marketing
description: Everything is in place for location-based social networking to be the next big thing. Tech companies are building the platforms, venture capitalists are providing the cash and marketers are eager to develop advertising.

title: After 90 Years, Whats Another Marathon?
description: Four days beyond his 90th birthday, it might be enough for Jon Mendes to celebrate having the original parts and warranty on his knees and hips.

title: Now Appearing: George W. Bush
description: WASHINGTON  When the hip-hop star Kanye West says he can connect with George W. Bush, perhaps it is time to think about whether America has begun to reconsider its 43rd president.

title: All I Want for Christmas: Wins by the Ladies
description: Kate Miller is head of racing media for William Hill Company in England and works with the odds compilers in the companys Leeds office. She also is the daughter of the former racecourse bookmaker Charlie Miller, and knows her way around horses.

title: U.S. Vote Could Derail Russia Ties
description: WASHINGTON  The Republican election victory last week was fueled by opposition to President Obamas economic and domestic initiatives, but it could undo his central foreign policy achievement, his new partnership with Russia, and embolden anti-American hawks in Moscow.

title: New Mangini Embraces Old One
description: BEREA, Ohio  Perhaps Eric Mangini reached his lowest point in January. He was eating too much, sleeping too little and wrestling with a chewing tobacco habit. His job as the Cleveland Browns coach was fraught with uncertainty.

title: The Horse to Bet: Girolamo
description: Jonathan Socolow, who works in Moscow, is an avid horseplayer.

title: Zenyatta Just Misses Breeders Cup Victory
description: Zenyatta, 19-0 coming into the race, gave her all, coming from last to present a challenge at the finish, but it was Blame who stuck his head out to win the $5 million Breeders Cup Classic on Saturday night at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Ky.

title: In Japan, U.S. Defends Fed Actions
description: KYOTO, Japan  The United States confronted growing restiveness with its economic policy on Saturday as leading Asian countries resisted its call to set limits on trade deficits and surpluses while also warning that the decision to pump more money into the American economy would have harmful global repercussions.

title: Democrats Divided on Tax Cut Strategy
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration and Congressional Democrats are struggling for a strategy to deal with the soon-to-expire Bush-era tax cuts, each side uncertain whether the other is up for a fight with Republicans in the wake of the Democrats election trouncing  or whether they could win, in any event.

title: The Story of Mancuso: A New Chapter, but Its Still in the Context of Vonn
description: In the eight months since the Vancouver Winter Olympics, Julia Mancuso has surfed on the islands of Maui and Hawaii, vaulted off a Swiss Alps cliff in an extreme ski competition, vacationed on Easter Island, served in her sisters wedding and put in weeks of training on snowy slopes in New Zealand and Chile.

title: Still Here
description: Now thats a surprise: Joe Nocera on the joys of Stephen Sondheim.

title: American Sikhs Decry Screenings
description: WASHINGTON  Three national Sikh advocacy and civil rights organizations have said federal transportation officials plan to always search turbans at airport screening stations, even if wearers pass through state-of-the-art body imaging scanners.

title: Running Backs Shift, but Bond Holds Tight
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Brandon Jacobs shrieked. He was standing at his locker at the Giants practice center a few days before Halloween when one of his teammates startled him, then momentarily disappeared.

title: U.S. Workers Are on Alert After Breach of Data
description: WASHINGTON  Federal workers at the General Services Administration are on alert against identity theft after an employee sent the names and Social Security numbers of the agencys entire staff to a private e-mail address.

title: Whats in That Slice?
description: Cheese consumption in the U.S. has almost tripled since 1970, adding calories and saturated fat into the American diet at a time when obesity rates are climbing. But since 1995, a nonprofit marketing corporation created by the government has been working with retail chains to increase the amount of cheese in their products, including Dominos American Legends line.

title: Hulkenberg, of All People, Scores Pole in Sao Paulo
description: INTERLAGOS, Brazil  Murray Walker, the great Formula One television broadcaster in Britain, was famous for his (often unintentional) bons mots, and one of his most famous was, Anything can happen in Formula One, and it usually does.

title: Hulkenberg, of All People, Scores Pole in Sao Paulo
description: INTERLAGOS, Brazil  Murray Walker, the great Formula One television broadcaster in Britain, was famous for his (often unintentional) bons mots, and one of his most famous was, Anything can happen in Formula One, and it usually does.

title: Jets Star Guard Combines 305 Pounds of Power With the Little Things
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Brandon Moore is a 305-pound right guard for the Jets who is not merely considered the best player at his position in the N.F.L., but also tougher than a boot  or so his coach, Rex Ryan, gushed on consecutive days last week.

title: In Efforts to End Bullying, Some See Agenda
description: HELENA, Mont.  Alarmed by evidence that gay and lesbian students are common victims of schoolyard bullies, many school districts are bolstering their antiharassment rules with early lessons in tolerance, explaining that some children have two moms or will grow up to love members of the same sex.

title: Alaska Writes a Senator Back Into Contention
description: ANCHORAGE  Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska played many novel roles in her historic run as a write-in candidate. She was the insurgent incumbent, the maverick moderate, the outsider from the establishment, the underdog boasting about her seniority.

title: He Saw Trouble Coming. Now He Sees It Going.
description: ARE we finally coming out of the woods, economically speaking?

title: When a Rig Moves In Next Door
description: IN the sparsely populated pastures of De Soto Parish in Louisiana, the ability to extract gas from shale  which can involve a process known as fracking  has been welcomed as an economic windfall. Some residents call it a gift from God.

title: Political Books Best-Seller List
description: Obamas Wars by Bob Woodward made its debut at No. 1 in the latest survey of political best-sellers in October as American voters were preparing to render their verdict on how the nation is being governed.

title: White Democrats Lose More Ground in South
description: It was less than 50 years ago that a young man named Lewis McAllister Jr. won a special election to become a Mississippi state representative.

title: Chasing Pirates: Inside Microsofts War Room
description: AS the sun rose over the mountains circling Los Reyes, a town in the Mexican state of Michoacn, one morning in March 2009, a caravan of more than 300 heavily armed law enforcement agents set out on a raid.

title: Myanmar Votes in Election Controlled by Military
description: YANGON, Myanmar  Polling places appeared nearly empty around Yangon on Sunday as the rest of the city went about its business in the first election in this closed and tightly controlled nation in 20 years.

title: A Manager Who Stuck to His Guns and Fired Away
description: To everyone in baseball he was Sparky Anderson; hardly anybody called him George. But as a manager, he was not just a spark. He was a bonfire who sometimes burst into a three-alarm blaze.

title: For David Lee, a New Team, a New Town and a New Look
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  This is how David Lee realized he was truly wanted here. The Los Angeles Lakers had just handcuffed Lee, holding him to no points and handing the Warriors their first loss of the season. That night, Golden States first-year coach, Keith Smart, called him.

title: Can the Fed Draw a Virtuous Circle?
description: TWO momentous events occurred last week, and what was most startling for the financial markets was that they were so utterly predictable. As if on cue, the markets rose.

title: Bloomberg Questions U.S. Inquiry Into China Trade Practices
description: HONG KONG  Criticizing China was a popular campaign tactic for Democrats and Republican candidates alike in many campaigns this year, but Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York was quick to leap to Chinas defense on Saturday.

title: Working (and Living) the Company Way
description: SEEN through the wide arc of history, ours is an edgy, mistrusting moment. Since the financial crisis two years ago, Americans have shown persistent skepticism about large corporations. According to a Pew Research Center report earlier this year, for example, only 25 percent of those surveyed say big business has a positive impact on how things are going in the country.

title: Taking On a Second Mortgage to Pay the Foreclosure Lawyer
description: For some Florida residents, the price of getting out of foreclosure will include taking on a second mortgage  payable this time to their lawyers.

title: At 102, Outliving Friends, Family and Her Savings
description: Mary Spencer was born during the Roosevelt administration. Theodores.

title: When a Camcorder Becomes a Life Partner
description: YOU can shoot compelling video these days even when you have your hands full.

title: $27.5 Million for 9/11 Workers
description: A group of workers who claimed they suffered health problems as a result of being exposed to debris from ground zero during its removal and transfer to a landfill on Staten Island stand to receive $27.5 million in a settlement announced on Friday.

title: Ask Your Mentor for Help, Not for Brownie Points
description: This interview with Martha S. Samuelson,  president and C.E.O. of the Analysis Group, a consulting firm, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Bernanke Attempts to Soothe Doubters
description: JEKYLL ISLAND, Ga.  Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, continued on Saturday to rebut critics who feared the central banks latest bid to stimulate the economy could trigger dangerous inflation down the line and antagonize other countries by weakening the dollar.

title: Yemen Judge Orders Arrest of Qaeda-Linked Cleric
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A Yemeni judge on Saturday ordered the forcible arrest of Anwar al-Awlaki, the American-born cleric who is believed to play an important role in the regional branch of Al Qaeda.

title: How Portable Is Your Life?
description: MOVING can be one of the most stressful events in life, although it can also be a great adventure. The option may seem especially tempting today, as some regions have much brighter job prospects than others amid the overall employment slump.

title: Estate Tax Issue Offers Quick Test for Congress
description: AFTER their election victory on Tuesday, Republican leaders in the House promised progress on many fronts, including a turn toward more fiscal discipline and less economic uncertainty.

title: 18 Bodies in Acapulco Grave Identified as Kidnapped Men
description: MEXICO CITY  The 18 bodies discovered in a mass grave just outside Acapulco have been identified as those of most of the 20 men who were kidnapped as they arrived last month for a brief vacation at the Pacific beach resort city, Mexican state authorities said Saturday.

title: Savoring Baghdad, Where Each Night Is a Battle
description: BAGHDAD  Who owns the Iraqi night?

title: Letters: Roots of Innovation
Letters: When Jobs Go Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: Apple and I.B.M. Arent All That Different
description: EVERY once in while, there are symbolically intriguing historical moments in the corporate world, and one of them occurred last month. On Oct. 18, Apple and I.B.M. reported their quarterly results, and Apples total profit surged past I.B.M.s.

title: The C.F.L., and Learning to Love the Rouge
description: A madcap finish in a recent C.F.L. game. Enjoy the implications of the rouge.

title: Replay Isnt the Kind of Review That Will Make Umpires Better
description: Missed calls by umpires during the past baseball season prompted Commissioner Bud Selig to say he would examine the umpiring and replay systems. One reason the expansion of instant replay in baseball is objectionable is that it advances the notion that umpires are an addendum to the game, a necessary evil.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Recovery for Wall Street Pay
description: Bonuses will be up this year, according to an influential study by compensation expert Alan Johnson.  His research indicates pay in financial services will increase about 5 percent this year.

title: More On Shibboleths
description: A few more thoughts on the problem of shibboleths in the face of a depressed world economy:

title: Republican Gains Cheer a Former Power Broker at His Money-Laundering Trial
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  On the day after Republicans trounced Democrats in the midterm elections, Tom DeLay strolled around a courtroom here with an American flag lapel pin, looking carefree and chatting with strangers at his money-laundering trial with the habitual charm of a seasoned politician.

title: Princess Haya Re-elected President
description: Princess Haya bint al-Hussein of Jordan was overwhelmingly re-elected as the president of the International Equestrian Federation on Friday after a contentious campaign that marked the first time in the federations history that an incumbent president had been challenged. Princess Haya won in the first round of voting at the federations general assembly in Taipei, Taiwan, capturing 90 of 124 votes. Her opponents, Sven Holmberg of Sweden and Henk Rottinghuis of the Netherlands, received 23 and 11 votes.

title: Falling Back
description: Six poems to mark the end of daylight saving time.

title: The Cost of a Vote Goes Up
description: The votes are in; the money has been counted. We can start assessing the damage to American democracy caused by the Supreme Courts decision to allow corporations, unions and their lobby groups a free hand to deploy their money to elect the candidates of their choice. Already one thing seems certain: Votes are getting more expensive.

title: Throwing the Bums Out for 140 Years
description: Stanford, Calif.

title: Our Banana Republic
description: In my reporting, I regularly travel to banana republics notorious for their inequality. In some of these plutocracies, the richest 1 percent of the population gobbles up 20 percent of the national pie.

title: Judges Were Independent. Then They Were Defeated.
description: To the Editor:

title: Long Live Lady Luck
description: One of the most striking things about our recent midterm elections is that foreign policy played absolutely no part in the voting  and for that we have Lady Luck, and some good intelligence work, to thank. In fact, in the past year weve won the lottery five times in row. How often does that happen?

title: Plenty of Work for the Lame Duck: The $4 Trillion Question
description: The Bush-era tax cuts are set to expire at year end. That means the lame duck Congress has tough choices to make and not a lot of time to make them.

title: Barack Obama, Phone Home
description: AFTER his shellacking, President Obama had to do something. But who had the bright idea of scheduling his visit to India for right after this election? The Democrats failure to create jobs was at the heart of the shellacking. Nothing says outsourcing to the American public more succinctly than India. But the White House didnt figure this out until the eve of Obamas Friday departure, when it hastily rebranded his trip as a jobs mission. Perhaps the president should visit one of the Indian call centers policing Americans credit-card debts to feel our pain.

title: Compounding a Conflict of Interest
description: AS hard as it sometimes is to write a story, it can be much harder to un-write one that should never have been published.

title: Civil War Lessons in Honesty and Manipulation
description: To the Editor:

title: Message in a Soda Bottle
description: To the Editor:

title: Divided We Thrive
description: Washington

title: Plenty of Work for the Lame Duck: And Other Urgent Business
description: Taxes are not the only heavy lifting for Congressional leaders in the lame duck session. Before they can go home for the holidays  to celebrate or lick their wounds  there is a lot more of the peoples work left to do.

title: Blindsided: A Presidents Story
description: WASHINGTON

title: Facing the Scourge of Alzheimers
description: To the Editor:

title: Federation Rankings Reflect a Youth Movement
description: Every two months, the World Chess Federation ranks the top players. In addition to the main list, there is one for the best players under age 21. Increasingly, the lists hold many of the same names.

title: For States G.O.P., Now Flush, Risks on the Horizon
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

title: F.S.U. Coach Suspended
description: The A.C.C. suspended the Florida State womens coach Mark Krikorian for one game and fined the university $25,000 for not taking several starters to the league tournament. Krikorian left the players home from the tournament in an apparent attempt to rest them for the N.C.A.A.s. Without them, Florida State lost its A.C.C. opener to Wake Forest. Florida State must forfeit its A.C.C. tournament expense reimbursement of roughly $15,000. (AP)

title: First Openly Gay Episcopal Bishop to Retire
description: Bishop V. Gene Robinson, whose consecration as the first openly gay bishop in the Episcopal Church set off a historic rift in the global Anglican Communion, announced to his New Hampshire diocese on Saturday that he intended to step down.

title: In Presidio, a Grasp at the Holy Grail of Energy Storage
description: Dozens of gray compartments, lined neatly in rows, inhabit a boxy concrete building on the edge of the impoverished border town of Presidio. The only sound, aside from occasional clanking, is the whirring of air-conditioners to keep the compartments cool.

title: The Texas Shuffle
description: A roundup of notable new songs from the states great artists.

title: Sunday: Leading Articles
description: Todays theme involves the sort of wordplay I really enjoy in a Sunday puzzle. Its a simple but clever twist, and novel as far as I know.

title: Black Business Leaders Ponder Mayoral Election
description: Generations of the citys black business leaders have played a vital yet largely unsung role in the struggle for civil rights and black political and economic empowerment in Chicago  from the Great Migration in the early 20th century to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.s battle for open housing in the 1960s to the victory of Harold Washington in the 1980s to the making of a black president on a warm November night in Grant Park two years ago.

title: Fair Photo or Cheap Shot?
description: The Times ran a striking photograph of President Obama at his post-election news conference last Wednesday and it wasnt long before readers responded with an outpouring of messages to the Public Editor, all complaining of the newspapers decision to use this closely-cropped photo of Mr. Obama.

title: Redistricting Reality Ahead for Cocky G.O.P.
description: James Warrenwrites a columnfor the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: As City Employees Tighten Belts, Some Elected Officials Are Reluctant to Adjust Theirs
description: When aldermen vote Nov. 17 on a budget for 2011, they are expected to help close the citys $655 million fiscal hole by again requiring all employees to take almost five weeks off without pay.

title: Readers Comments on Inequality
description: My Sunday column wrestles with growing economic inequality in America  and the sad reality that our income gaps look like those of a classic banana republic. I didnt have space in the column to look at why the gaps have grown larger, but this is explored at some depth in the Slate series that I mention and link to in the column. Its not fundamentally about tax policy, but my hunch is that it has a good deal to do with social mores and acceptability.

title: If Not The Man, Kane Takes on Role of The Reveler
description: Jay Blunk was a newly appointed Blackhawks executive in June 2008 when he was struck by how easily Patrick Kane was able to move through a passenger terminal at OHare International Airport. The then-19-year-old Blackhawk was (and is) one of the bright young stars in hockey, having won the Calder Trophy as National Hockey League rookie of the year for the 2007-8 season.

title: In Whitman and Fiorina, Candidacies That Did Not Compute
description: Jonathan Weber writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

title: New Role for Gavin Newsom, but Fuzzy Guidelines on What It Will Be
description: The sun reflecting off his slicked-back hair, Mayor Gavin Newsom took the microphone Wednesday afternoon and smiled upon the sea of humanity crammed into the Civic Center to celebrate the Giants World Series victory.

title: In Oakland, Defeat of Measure Isnt the End
description: The television news crews that descended on Oakland last week to cover the outcome of Proposition 19, which would have legalized marijuana in the state, are now long gone, along with the high hopes of many local cannabis entrepreneurs.

title: Pelosi Urges Unity and Says She Will Work Toward Democratic Rebound
description: In a letter to colleagues, the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, who is seeking to remain as minority leader despite her partys steep election losses, urged House Democrats to unite behind her and even said she hopes to help ousted lawmakers return to Congress in two years.

title: Obama Invokes Gandhi, Whose Ideal Eludes India
description: NEW DELHI  Not long after Barack Obama was elected president, the United States Embassy in India printed a postcard showing him sitting in his old Senate office beneath framed photographs of his political heroes: the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Abraham Lincoln and the great Indian apostle of peace, democracy and nonviolent protest, Mohandas K. Gandhi.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu: Nov. 7
description: With the midterm election results still rolling in, this Sundays television talk shows focus on the lame duck session of Congress that begins in just over a week, and the next session, when Republicans will control the House.

title: Sweat | Already a Winner, With 26.2 Miles to Go
description: Update, Monday, Nov. 8 | Click to read how Carmens marathon day turned out.

title: Nightlife Still Lively in Baghdad Neighborhood
description: An upswing in violence in Baghdad has not stopped local residents from stepping out in the evening to the colorful lights and diversions of the Karada district.

title: G.O.P. to Fight Health Law With Purse Strings
description: WASHINGTON  As they seek to make good on their campaign promise to roll back President Obamas health care overhaul, the incoming Republican leaders in the House say they intend to use their new muscle to cut off money for the law, setting up a series of partisan clashes and testing Democratic commitment to the legislation.

title: No Sentence Yet, but Jurors in Cheshire Killings Offer a Hint of Their Thinking
description: NEW HAVEN  Jurors considering the fate of the convicted killer in the Cheshire, Conn., home invasion case deliberated for a second day without reaching a verdict Saturday on whether to impose a death sentence, but sent a note indicating that they remained focused on arguments that could spare the life of the defendant, Steven J. Hayes.

title: Syracuse Still a Win Away From a Trip to a Bowl
description: SYRACUSE  The rejuvenated Syracuse football team had one final chance to win on Saturday, but Orange fans seemed to know a lost cause when they saw one. Most of the big crowd had hustled toward the exits at the Carrier Dome, not even pausing for another look.

title: In the Midst of Controversy, Auburns Newton Dazzles
description: AUBURN, Ala.  The group hug for Cam Newton started on the tailgates outside Jordan-Hare Stadium here Saturday. Signs fit for a political rally were leaning up against cars or being carried around on wooden sticks: Dont Hate on Cam and Yes, We Cam.

title: Off Center Stage, T.C.U. Bolsters Case With a Rout
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Texas Christians resounding victory over Utah on Saturday could be watched by only a limited cable television audience, so T.C.U. Coach Gary Patterson used an analogy from plain old network television to sum up his teams chances of playing for the national title.

title: Sign Hill
description: South San Francisco proudly advertises its history to every passing motorist northbound on Highway 101. Industry has changed, though, since the signs 1923 construction: biotechnology has replaced steel mills and slaughterhouses.

title: Zenyatta Misses History by a Head
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Her owners, Jerry and Ann Moss; her trainer, John Shirreffs; and for that matter anyone who had watched and loved the great racemare Zenyatta knew that the real running  the edge-of-the-seat-drama  really didnt start until she turned for home. Nineteen times before, Zenyatta had looked desperate and in trouble at the top of the stretch. Nineteen times before, she had found a gear to rocket past her rivals in the final strides.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: College Football Replay: Nov. 6
description: Photographs from the days college football games.

title: $27.5 Million Settlement for 9/11 Workers
description: A group of workers who claimed they suffered health problems as a result of being exposed to debris from ground zero during its removal and transfer to a landfill on Staten Island stand to receive $27.5 million in a settlement announced on Friday.

title: Long Island House Seat Is Back in Play
description: A new vote count on Long Island appears to have called into question the apparent victory of an incumbent Democratic congressman on Long Island.

title: Bronx Family Mourns a Baby and Protests a Fathers Arrest
description: A homemade placard outside the stately old apartment building on Davidson Avenue in the Bronx told of the heartbreak inside on Saturday.

title: Vows: Hiroko and Ryan
description: Two doctors, Hiroko and Ryan, met in an emergency room in a children's hospital. She had Snoopy stickers on her ID badge and he was coincidentally wearing Snoopy socks. A love affair was sparked.

title: Turnout Appears Light in Myanmars Election
description: YANGON, MYANMAR  Polling places appeared nearly empty around Yangon on Sunday as the rest of the city went about its business during the first election in 20 years in this closed and tightly controlled nation.

title: Obama Pointedly Questioned by Students in India
description: MUMBAI, India  When Michelle Obama, the first lady, introduced her husband to a group of college students here on Sunday, she urged them to ask him tough questions.

title: New Guides to Istanbul Offer Insider Tips
description: Thanks to a handful of new books by locals in the know, visitors to Istanbul can now delve even deeper into this citys delights.

title: Jets-Lions Subplot to Watch: Suh vs. Brandon Moore
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The television cameras in Sundays Lions-Jets game will focus on the telegenic battle between Matthew Stafford and Mark Sanchez, and why not? Well see two sophomore quarterbacks, each taken in the first five picks of the 2009 draft, with promising futures, winning smiles and boyish good looks. But in the trenches is where the real main event on Sunday may be: the Lions Ndamukong Suh versus the Jets Brandon Moore.

title: Charlie Whitehurst a Juicy Target for Giants
description: Its a strange run-up to an N.F.L. game when a lot of people are just hoping that a quarterback (Charlie Whitehurst) will leave the field in one piece.

title: Wag The Me
description: Um

title: The Man Who Blesses Horses
description: In a bucket list moment, Julie June Stewart woke up at 4 a.m. and bought a ticket to the 2008 Belmont Stakes. She hasnt stopped going to the races since  when she isnt taking on a wildfire, hurricane or volcano as the nations leading expert in disaster airspace coordination.

title: Meltzer Misleads
description: Reading Allan Meltzers latest, you might think that the CPI and the PCE deflator  two alternate measures of inflation  were telling dramatically different stories about what was happening to the US economy. But heres what they actually did:

title: Newts in November
description: On our walk with the dogs to Catfish pond on Saturday, my younger son and I, along with a neighbor, mused on the wondrous lives of newts, specificallythe eastern newt. Heres a video snippet:

title: A Breeders Cup Convert
description: Kate Miller is head of racing media for William Hill Company in England and works with the odds compilers in the companys Leeds office. She also is the daughter of the former racecourse bookmaker Charlie Miller, and knows her way around horses.

title: Hey, Ms. Traffic Agent, a Break for a Working Stiff?
description: It is an old strategy among parcel delivery drivers in New York City: Leave a parking summons tucked on your windshield and hope the ticket agent walks right past your illegally parked truck, believing it has already been ticketed.

title: Hollywood Actors Reach Tentative Deal Early on New Contract
description: LOS ANGELES  With little fanfare, Hollywoods movie and television production companies and actors unions early on Sunday morning said they had agreed tentatively to a new three-year contract that provides a 6 percent increase in wages and increased health and benefits contributions by the companies.

title: Protesters Rally in Seoul Ahead of G-20 Summit
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Tens of thousands of protesters held a peaceful, almost festive, rally in Seoul, South Korea, on Sunday to protest the Group of 20 summit meeting that begins here on Thursday.

title: Weir Wins Mens Wheelchair Division
description: As the men or womens elite runners jostled their way through Brooklyn, a sprint to the finish was under way in Central Park in the wheelchair division of the New York City Marathon.

title: Gebrselassie Retires After Dropping Out
description: 1:01 p.m. | Updated Haile Gebrselassie announced after he dropped out of the New York City Marathon that he is retiring from running.

title: New York City Marathon as It Happened
description: When world record holder Haile Gebrselassie dropped out of the New York City Marathon just more than halfway through, it opened the door for a different man from Ethiopia to grab the stage and Gebre Gebremariam took advantage.

title: Liable, Bible
description: Its fairly clear from the comments on my second shibboleth post that some people didnt get the reference in the excerpt. So, your Sunday Gershwin:

title: Gebremariam Wins Mens Race in Debut
description: Growing up in Ethiopias northernmost region of Tigray, Gebre Gebremariam studied Haile Gebrselassie in school, memorizing his medals and records, learning what it took to be a legend.

title: Live Analysis: Jets 23, Lions 20, OT, Final
description: The team that ripped off five straight wins earlier this season seemed to forsake their Jets uniforms, leaving behind a sloppy, mistake-prone, ugly new incarnation of Gang Green over the past two weeks. But the final moments of a 23-20 overtime win in Detroit on Sunday may have reawakened the sleepwalking Jets.

title: Vettel Drives to Victory in Brazilian Grand Prix
description: Updated | 3:30 p.m. ET

title: Vettel Drives to Victory in Brazilian Grand Prix
description: Updated | 3:30 p.m. ET

title: An Untested Two Set the Womens Pace
description: Before this year, Edna Kiplagat had developed a distant relationship with the marathon. She had run the event just once, finishing 10th in the Las Vegas Marathon in 2 hours 50 minutes 20 seconds. Her coach and husband, Gilbert Koech, felt that she needed time away from the 26.2-mile distance and instead focused on developing her career in shorter road races.

title: The Morning Line: Racings Heartbreak
description: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

title: For Stanford, Dreams of the Rose Bowl
description: STANFORD, Calif.  As the Stanford players exited the field after their 42-17 victory against Arizona on Saturday night, they were met by a fan waving a poster that read, WAKE UP AND SMELL THE ROSES.

title: Greek Premier Claims Victory in Local Elections Seen as a Referendum on Austerity
description: ATHENS  Since he was elected a year ago, Prime Minister George Papandreou has struggled to satisfy two difficult and seemingly mutually exclusive constituencies: international financial markets and Greeks.

title: Boos for Childress, Inside Stadium and Out
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Brad Childress, the embattled Minnesota Vikings coach, expected boos and catcalls at the Metrodome on Sunday, and you didnt have to walk into the building to hear them.

title: Morality Tales as Horror and Suspense
description: Last November, Doubleday published John Grishams Ford County, a collection of short stories from a man whose specialty is full-length legal drama. These stories were revelatory. They showed how much verve, suspense, instruction and moral ambiguity Mr. Grisham could pack into bare-bones plotlines. He could accomplish in 40-page virtual synopses what he normally does in 400-page novels.

title: Running With the Elites
description: Some of the worlds top runners competed for the New York City Marathon title, with the veterans edged by the newcomers.

title: Texas Two-Step
description: Hmm. Do you remember how Texas showed that conservative policies work  it was weathering the slump just fine, it had a balanced budget, and so on?

title: Pentagon Openings Give Obama Options
description: WASHINGTON  With critical decisions ahead on the war in Afghanistan, President Obama is about to receive an unusual opportunity to reshape the Pentagons leadership, naming a new defense secretary as well as several top generals and admirals in the next several months.

title: Live Analysis: Giants 41, Seahawks 7, Final
description: In training camp, the Giants were overshadowed by their splashy New York counterparts, and after their back-to-back losses in September, there seemed to be little reason to pay them any mind.

title: Scottsboro Boys Is Focus of Protest
description: A group of about 30 people gathered on Saturday afternoon in front of the Lyceum Theater to protest a matinee of the new Broadway musical The Scottsboro Boys, which retells the story of nine African-Americans between 12 and 19 who were falsely convicted of raping two white women in Alabama in 1931. The show, written by the celebrated team of John Kander and Fred Ebb and directed by the Tony-winning director Susan Stroman, uses the minstrel tradition to tell the story of how racism infected the judicial system.

title: Web Browsing Takes a Social Turn
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Silicon Valley is awash in tales of the PayPal Mafia, the tight-knit group of PayPal alumni who have helped one another start and finance a crop of new companies.

title: At Mile 16, Gebrselassie Ends His Race, and Career
description: Word spread Saturday that the great Haile Gebrselassie of Ethiopia had a knee problem. Then came a message from his Twitter account Sunday morning that seemed casual and ominous.

title: A New Bridge, Too Far to Notice
description: The marathon course featured a $600 million change this year  although many runners said they did not notice.

title: Clayburghs Unforgettable Unmarried Woman
description: In the most famous scene in Jill Clayburghs most influential movie, her character reacted to the news that her husband wanted to leave her. Ms. Clayburghs Erica responded with such naturalness, confusion and wounded pride that she captured the imagination of a generation.

title: How Liable is Goldman?
description: Professor Eric J. Pan talks about the role of clearing firms and possible consequences of the Bayou case.

title: She Who Belts Out the Uncertainty
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Carrie Underwood poses with the microphone, grips it firmly as an athlete might, pulls it slowly away from her mouth as she hits the biggest, longest notes. When her right arm is bent at 90 degrees, and her heads tilted back just so, she exudes victory. Miniaturized and cast in gold plate, she would look perfect slapped atop a trophy, maybe one for winning a televised singing competition.

title: In Rediscovered Osborne Play, Glimpse of Angry Young Writer
description: When an unknown John Osborne revolutionized British theater in the 1950s with his furious, establishment-battering autobiographical play Look Back in Anger, it wasnt the first script he had written in which he challenged postwar conformity.

title: The Fine Art of Card Reading, Courtesy of a Top Practitioner
description: Jeff Meckstroth of Tampa, Fla., is known as one of the worlds most imaginative declarers. He again proved that his reputation is justified in the diagramed deal, which was Board 4 of the final session of the World Open Pairs in Philadelphia last month.

title: An Elephant, a Jellyfish and a Man With a Lot on, and in, His Mind
description: Apparently you can go home again. You just have to be prepared to confront another version of yourself when you get there, a version who may not be at all sympathetic to the intrusion.

title: Luminaries and Hopefuls Join to Ensure Choreographys Future
description: If ballet is to have a future, it needs new choreography. Let nobody doubt that steps are being taken to make that future happen. The New York Choreographic Institute is dedicated to promoting the development of choreographers by providing dancers, rehearsal space and time, symposiums and seminars on choreography and other theater arts, and choreographic fellowships with individual companies.

title: An Ensemble Sheds a Spotlight on New and Unusual Repertory
description: The Riverside Symphony, one of New Yorks feistier freelance ensembles, has made a point of playing new works and rarities, and giving young soloists a spotlight in concertos. The orchestra is celebrating its 30th anniversary, and, true to form, it opened its season at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday evening with an ambitious program in which the closest it came to the standard repertory was in Schumanns Genoveva Overture and Sibeliuss Seventh Symphony: works you can go many seasons without hearing in concert.

title: The Porous Bernstein Border
description: Consider the two sides of Leonard Bernstein as fraternal twins gazing at each other across a divide. One is a dazzling Broadway melodist, the other a classical composer in search of a universal musical style. The two confronted each other on Saturday evening at the David H. Koch Theater in a concert, Lucky to Be Me: The Music of Leonard Bernstein, devoted to vocal pieces from both sides of the fence.

title: The Mulch, the Tunics, the Lunges
description: In Wilderness, a new movement installation presented by Dance Theater Workshop at the Invisible Dog Art Center, Yanira Castro continued her mission of fleshing out the relationship between two groups of people: those doing the watching and those doing the performing.

title: Speech and Harm
description: As every public figure knows, there are certain words that can not be uttered without causing shock or offense. These words, commonly known as slurs, target groups on the basis of race, nationality, religion, gender, sexual orientation, immigration status and sundry other demographics. Many of us were reminded of the impact of such speech in August, when the radio host Dr. Laura Schlessinger repeatedly uttered a racial slur on a broadcast of her show. A public outcry followed, and ultimately led to her resignation. Many such incidents of abuse and offense, often with much more serious consequences, seem to appear in the news by the day.

title: A Cuban-American Cultural Exchange Comes Full Circle
description: HAVANA  Kevin McKenzie, artistic director of American Ballet Theater, stood by a fluted pillar in a lofty studio at the National Ballet School here on Friday, keeping time with his hands as a group of male students practiced jets in a circle.

title: Monday: Utterance
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  I particularly admire puzzles that tell a story as you solve them from top to bottom. We dont quite have a story today but theres a little surprise near the end that, if things work out correctly, makes you revisit the theme with a new appreciation. The first three theme answers start with words that are roughly synonyms. The final one starts with CATCH, another synonym, but the full answer, CATCH PHRASES, provides further justification for the first three. Nicely done.

title: Aronian Grabs Early Lead at Tal Memorial
A Ceremony for Jews Who Fought for Germany
description: FRANKFURT  German soldiers, including one wearing a skullcap with his uniform, filed silently through a leaf-covered cemetery in Frankfurt on Sunday to lay wreaths at a memorial for 467 Jewish soldiers killed fighting for the kaiser during World War I.

title: An Airy Touch Delivering Emotional Heft
description: Of all the terms that could describe a pianists work, rightness is probably among the least precise. Yet again and again as Alessio Bax performed at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Friday night, everything in his program unfolded with an ease, precision and beauty so seemingly effortless that the music appeared to live and breathe of its own volition.

title: Onto Streets of New York, the Miner Perseveres
description: Edison Pea could be forgiven for having to slow to a walk at times during the New York City Marathon on Sunday. His training, after all, came via subterranean loops of only a few miles at a time, with the tunnels of a collapsed gold and copper mine for a course and sawed-off work boots for footwear.

title: Italian Leader Urged to Resign by Former Ally
description: ROME  A former political ally-turned-adversary of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi called on Sunday for the Italian leader to resign and make way for a new government with a revamped legislative program and a broader political base.

title: Ash in the Air, Confusion on the Ground
description: GEMAMPIR, Indonesia  As this village emptied around her, and the Mount Merapi volcano boomed not too far uphill behind a veil of dust, Puranti stood crying here on Sunday afternoon, frozen with indecision. A few hours earlier, her relatives had gone back to fetch fresh clothes in their village  farther uphill toward Mount Merapi, in an area so close to the volcanos rim that it had been evacuated days before.

title: American Ballet Theater in Cuba
description: Dancers experienced moments artistic, historical and personal during their visit to Havana.

title: Guinea Votes in Its First Democratic Presidential Election
description: CONAKRY, Guinea  After weeks of delays, ethnic tensions and clashes between the police and rival groups of supporters, this mineral-rich but poor West African nation quietly went to the polls Sunday to choose its first-ever democratically elected president.

title: Joyce Theater Announces Its Spring Lineup
description: Ronald K. Brown and his dance company Evidence will kick off the Joyce Theaters spring season with a world premiere set to the music of Stevie Wonder, the theater announced. The piece, On Earth Together, created to celebrate the companys 25th anniversary, will run Feb. 8 to 13. Other companies will present well-known pieces and new works during the season, which runs through August. Highlights are to include the world premiere of Dark Habits (March 8 to 13), an examination of fashion and drama from Keigwin + Company; and the New York premiere of Chapters From a Broken Novel from Doug Varone & Dancers, with a score played live by David Van Tieghem, the composer (March 15 to 20). The Merce Cunningham Dance Company, which has been presenting works at the Joyce since 1984, will offer perhaps the most somber performance of the season. In its last program there before the company disbands in December 2011, it will perform some of its most famous pieces, including CRWDSPCR and Antic Meet (Mar. 22 to 27). And in June the Gotham Dance Festival expands last years lineup with two programs of works by the choreographers Monica Bill Barnes, Brian Brooks, Kate Weare and Patrick Corbin, along with six emerging artists in its Summer Sampler Matinees, on Saturdays and Sundays.

title: Dreamworks Animations Megamind Is a Megahit
description: DreamWorks Animation has another hit on its hands: Megamind, the story of a supervillain turned superhero, which reached No. 1 with an estimated $47.7 million in its opening weekend at the North American box office, according to Hollywood.com, a compiler of box-office statistics. That result is better than the opening for the studios hit How to Train Your Dragon, which sold $43.7 million in its first weekend, but lower than initial results for its pictures like Kung Fu Panda and Monsters vs. Aliens. In an unusual move Megamind, distributed by Paramount Pictures, saved a substantial part of its television marketing push to avoid competing with midterm election ads; 40 percent of the films TV advertising budget was spent over the past week. The comedy Due Date (Warner Brothers) was second, with a strong $33.5 million. The Lionsgate drama For Colored Girls, adapted by Tyler Perry from Ntozake Shanges seminal play, For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow is Enuf, was third with a solid $20.1 million. The ensemble action film RED (Summit Entertainment) chugged away in fourth place with $8.9 million for a new total of $71.9 million. Saw 3D (Lionsgate) was fifth with about $8.2 million for a new total of $38.8 million.

title: A Free Evening of Arts for the Military
description: The actors Adam Driver (Mrs. Warrens Profession) and Joanne Tucker (Little Doc), both below, will present an evening of free jazz and readings for military personnel, veterans and their families on Monday night at American Airlines Theater. It will be the first performance by their group, Arts in the Armed Forces, since it gained nonprofit status in September. David Cromer will direct performances by actors including Eric Bogosian, Susan Sarandon, Dianne Wiest and Lauren Ambrose, among others, in honor of Veterans Day. Mr. Driver, a former Marine lance corporal, said by telephone on Sunday that the idea for the company came from a need that he and Ms. Tucker, whom he met while studying theater at Juilliard, noticed for more culturally diverse entertainment for the troops. We called U.S.O. events mandatory fun, Mr. Driver said of his time in the Marines, citing an event that included a skateboarding demonstration and a contest to win a date with a San Diego Chargers cheerleader. You couldnt help but feel marginalized. Now they hope their organization will encourage dialogue between artists and military members. In a place where emotions are not talked about, there seemed a need, Mr. Driver said. Putting words to feelings is a powerful thing, and theater was the best way for me to do that. The readings include works from the playwrights John Patrick Shanley, a former Marine who will introduce the evening, Charles Fuller (A Soldiers Play) and Stephen Adly Guirgis (The Little Flower of East Orange). Their plays have a grittier edge, Ms. Tucker said, but are not necessarily about the military. The program begins at 8 p.m.

title: Footnotes
description: Career Transition for Dancers will celebrate 25 years of helping performers on the road to post-stage careers with a gala on Monday at City Center. Angela Lansbury will be the host, with a performance lineup that includes dancers from Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and American Ballet Theater, along with numbers from 42nd Street and Chicago. Tickets and more information: careertransition.org. ... Jules Feiffer, above, the creator of the long-running Village Voice comic strip, will give a tour of his life using a slide show of his own comic strips, as well as those from his mentors and contemporaries, during a presentation to benefit the Writers Guild of America, East Foundation. Mr. Feiffer won a Pulitzer Prize in 1986 for his work as a cartoonist and was nominated to the Comic Book Hall of Fame in 2004. In March his autobiography, Backing Into Forward, was published by Nan A. Talese/Doubleday. The benefit will be held at 8 p.m. on Nov. 15 at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.

title: Obama Says Vote Turned on Economy
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said in an interview broadcast Sunday night that he views last weeks mid-term Congressional elections as a referendum

title: U.S. Revises Offer to Take Sudan Off Terror List
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has told Sudan that if it allows a politically sensitive referendum to go ahead in January, and abides by the results, the United States will move to take the country off its list of state sponsors of terrorism as early as next July, administration officials said Sunday.

title: Days of Our Lives Renewed for 2 More Years
description: In a welcome bit of news for the daytime soap opera segment, NBC will announce on Monday that it is renewing its only daytime soap, Days of Our Lives, for two more years.

title: No Decision on Penalty in Cheshire Triple Murder
description: NEW HAVEN  The jury considering whether the convicted killer in the Cheshire home invasion case is to be sentenced to death ended its third day of deliberations on Sunday without reaching a verdict.

title: Scientists Join Forces in a Hostile Climate

In California, voters wrestled with the question of legalization for recreational use  with issues of health, crime and taxes all coming into play  then voted no.

title: Lincoln Wins. Now What?
Plan for Electric Cable to Grid Nears Deadline

description: This week, Washington starts to regroup.

description: Landry Fields, the Knicks rookie guard, had toned down his act by the second time he was called for a foul  one for three shots  in 64 seconds late in the third quarter Sunday. Rather than looking as if he were horribly aggrieved, Fields merely tried to change the officials minds by pointing upcourt.

title: Doctor Prepared for the Worst at Marathon
description: On Sunday morning at 7:30, Dr. Stuart Weiss, the medical director of the New York City Marathon, was holding a coffee with one hand, gesturing with the other, and moving at the stereotypically brisk pace of an emergency room doctor. Walking in and out of the white medical command tent in Central Park, he was focused, he said, on Whats missing? Whats missing? Whats missing?

title: For Afghan Wives, a Desperate, Fiery Way Out
description: HERAT, Afghanistan  Even the poorest families in Afghanistan have matches and cooking fuel. The combination usually sustains life. But it also can be the makings of a horrifying escape: from poverty, from forced marriages, from the abuse and despondency that can be the fate of Afghan women.

description: Sitting at a dining room table festooned with papers, colored folders and laptop and iPad screens in his Upper West Side apartment, Benji Sternberg, 13, rattled off correct answers to a slew of homework questions, peppering them with wisecracks and occasional bursts of song.

title: The Jets Finally Get Going With a Hurry-Up Offense
description: DETROIT  Like a college student who waited until the last minute to study but somehow pulled an A, the Jets were a little cocky and a little sheepish after their comeback 23-20 overtime victory over the young Detroit Lions on Sunday.

description: CANTON, Ohio  The event was a reunion for people who were never supposed to meet, commemorating an act of charity that succeeded because it happened in secret.

title: With Book, Bush Is Back in Spotlight

That the interviewer will be Matt Lauer, the co-host of the Today show, reveals calculations by Mr. Bush and his advisers, as well as a campaign by NBC.

title: Giants Put on a Highlight Show, Using the Seahawks as Extras
description: SEATTLE  The Giants did not beat the Seahawks on Sunday so much as they battered and embarrassed them. They gained nearly four times as many yards, held the ball for more than twice as long, committed fewer penalties, converted third downs more efficiently, forced more turnovers, and on and on it went.

title: Phone Apps Aim to Fight Harassment
description: It was almost a year ago that a subway ride turned Violet Kittappa into an activist.

title: Eagles Quick Strikes Doom the Depleted Colts

The Eagles were out-highlighting a usually explosive offense hampered by injuries that made it look like a high-performance car with a very flat tire.

title: Now in Power, G.O.P. Vows Cuts in State Budgets
description: Republicans who have taken over state capitols across the country are promising to respond to crippling budget deficits with an array of cuts, among them proposals to reduce public workers benefits in Wisconsin, scale back social services in Maine and sell off state liquor stores in Pennsylvania, endangering the jobs of thousands of state workers.

title: A More Personal View of a Detainees Trial
description: The trial of Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani has attracted intense interest as a test of the Obama administrations strategy to try Guantnamo detainees in civilian court. title: D.E.A. Deployed Mumbai Plotter Despite Warning
description: WASHINGTON  American authorities sent David C. Headley, a small-time drug dealer and sometime informant, to work for them in Pakistan months after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, despite a warning that he sympathized with radical Islamic groups, according to court records and interviews. Not long after Mr. Headley arrived there, he began training with terrorists, eventually playing a key role in the 2008 attacks that left 164 people dead in Mumbai.

title: Yankees Start the Wooing of Lee Immediately

title: My Endless New York
description: I CAME to New York University in 1987 on a whim. The Thatcherite assault on British higher education was just beginning and even in Oxford the prospects were grim. N.Y.U. appealed to me: by no means a recent foundation  it was established in 1831  it is nevertheless the junior of New York Citys great universities. Less of a city on a hill, it is more open to new directions: in contrast to the cloistered collegiate worlds of Oxbridge, it brazenly advertises itself as a global university at the heart of a world city.

title: MSNBC to Lift Olbermann Suspension on Tuesday

title: A New Leader for the Democrats
description: Nancy Pelosi has been an extremely effective speaker of the House for four years, shepherding hundreds of important bills toward passage and withstanding solid Republican opposition. Her work in passing health care reform and strong ethics oversight achieved what many thought was legislatively impossible. But is she really the best the Democrats can come up with as their leader as they slip into the minority?

title: Doing It Again
description: Eight years ago Ben Bernanke, already a governor at the Federal Reserve although not yet chairman, spoke at a conference honoring Milton Friedman. He closed his talk by addressing Friedmans famous claim that the Fed was responsible for the Great Depression, because it failed to do what was necessary to save the economy.

title: The Next Campaign
description: Trounced in Tuesdays elections, some Democratic leaders are already plotting a 2012 comeback based on the same brutal big-money tactics employed so effectively this year by Republicans. Harold Ickes, a top Democratic operative and fund-raiser, told The Los Angeles Times that it was a mistake for the White House to discourage profuse spending in a fistfight. Steve Phillips, a California fund-raiser, said fellow Democrats need to learn from the right wing.

title: Two Mines

So it was a welcome break with grim history when the Labor Department asked a federal judge last week to shut down a Kentucky mine owned by the Massey Energy Company. The mine has been cited for about 700 safety violations this year alone.

title: Portions and the Power of Suggestion
description: How small is a small portion? No food chain quite agrees. A small soda at Long John Silvers, for example, is 20 ounces of liquid; a small at Pizza hut is 16. But these labels matter. The label assigned to a portion affects its apparent size, according to a study soon to be published in the Journal of Consumer Research.

title: In Grief and Defiance, Baghdads Christians Return to Scene of Attack

Some came in mourning black, many in tears, most in a spirit of quiet defiance.

It may look chaotic from the outside, with one player signing for $8 million over two years and another for $80 million over five years, but spending has followed a fairly consistent pattern.

The museum has inaugurated a new 97,000-square-foot basement space that links it to the adjacent Muse dArt Moderne. Initially created in 1937 for the the World Expo, the space had been sealed up for years. It is now to be reconverted into a contemporary art space by 2012  but in the meantime, the derelict environment is serving as an inspiration to one artist.

title: A Quant in Love: Boaz Weinstein and Tali Farhadian
description: Boaz Ronald Weinstein and Tali Farimah Farhadian were married on Saturday evening at the Central Synagogue in Manhattan. Rabbi James E. Ponet performed the ceremony, with Cantor Angela Warnick Buchdahl taking part, The New York Times reports.

title: Why Ndamukong Suh Was Chosen to Kick an  Extra Point
description: The rookie defensive tackle Ndamukong Suh missed what turned out to be a crucial extra-point attempt against the Jets on Sunday. But theres no mystery as to why he was chosen for the duty after the Lions Jason Hanson was injured. Suh is good at it.

title: Boehner Faces a Series of Challenges as Speaker
description: Republicans in the House will hold their first official transition meeting Monday night as they prepare to install Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio in the speakers office in January.

title: The Temporary Vegetarian: Vegan Broccoli Spigarello
description: In early October, during the opening weeks of Lincoln, the $20 million, 150-seat restaurant at Lincoln Center that was five years in the planning, Jonathan Benno, the chef, said he would be happy to demonstrate one simple, tasty side dish.

title: A Prince of Brunei Takes On 2 Former Advisers
description: For sheer titillation, what can beat a trial involving a feud between two British lawyers and a prince of Brunei, a harem, X-rated statues and a $500 million yacht whose name we cant mention?

title: Bank of America May Pay Bonuses in Shares
description: Bank of America is running out of time to fulfill a promise to raise more capital by year-end and may be forced to make up the shortfall by paying some bonuses in stock rather than cash, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Blame Is King for a Day
description: Sid Gustafson, D.V.M., is a novelist and equine veterinarian specializing in thoroughbred sports medicine and equine behavior. He currently practices regulatory veterinary medicine, representing the safety and welfare of thoroughbred racehorses.

title: Eli Lilly to Buy Avid for Up to $800 Million
description: Eli Lilly said on Monday that it had agreed to buy Avid Radiopharmaceuticals for an upfront payment of $300 million, and up to $500 million more based on future performance.

title: Harry Potter and the Inexplicable Simpsons Meta-reference
description: Though it can be difficult to get excited for Halloween-themed television programs a week after the holiday, the producers of The Simpsons did their best to get over that roadblock by resorting to some good old-fashioned star power. For a segment called Tweenlight that at least began as a parody of the Twilight books and movies, the show recruited as the voice of its hunky young vampire none other than the white-hot British heartthrob at the center of a money-minting fantasy film franchise: Daniel Radcliffe, the Harry Potter star. (Evidently, no one from the Lord of the Rings was available.)

title: This Weeks Health Industry News
description: Gatherings of insurance executives and public health doctors this week will be looking at possible changes to the health care overhaul from dramatically different perspectives.

title: Obama Nudges India To Lead
description: President Obama gave a fine speech this morning to the Indian parliament  and to China and Pakistan, which clearly were intended audiences as well. That emphasis on how democracy isnt an impediment for a developing country seeking economic growth was all about China. Likewise the stress on the links between two great democracies amounted to a studied contrast with Sino-U.S. relations, especially in the aftermath of the Liu Xiaobo Nobel Peace Prize.

title: I.S.S. Backs Blackstone Bid for Dynegy
description: 5:16 p.m. | Updated Dynegy won important support for its $4.7 billion sale to the Blackstone Group on Monday as an influential shareholder advisory firm endorsed the transaction, a little more than a week before shareholders vote on the deal.

title: WWFD? WSWC?
description: So our monetary policy gurus are framing their debate in theological terms: What Would Friedman Do? How sad.

title: Portrait of a Demanding Boss
description: When Andrew M. Cuomo takes over as governor on Jan. 1, he will bring a management style that is demanding and focused, insistent on results and disinclined to entertain dissent. In interviews with more than 50 former aides and colleagues, The Times found a picture of his leadership emerging: He sets his sights on a few priorities, frequently to underscore his political goals, plots several steps ahead and is fixated on avoiding mistakes.

title: Barbarous Relic Watch
description: So Robert Zoellick wants us to return to return to a modified gold standard. Brad DeLong pronounces him the stupidest man alive; thats much too kind.

title: About That AOL Article
description: 3:31 p.m. | Updated We were trying to figure out how to put our reactions to The Wall Street Journals report on AOLs hiring advisers into words. But as it turns out, Kara Swisher of All Things Digital  a Dow Jones property like the Journal  said pretty much what we wanted to say.

title: A Private Conversation Becomes Painfully Public
description: In retrospect, it probably was not such a good idea to confide in Rupert Murdoch. Billionaires, it turns out, can be just as indiscreet as the rest of us.

title: Chinese Animation
description: The Chinese Government and investors are pouring money for the first time into the animation and film industry, causing a radical transformation in China's entertainment landscape.

title: Superstar! The Molly Shannon Story
description: There are those performers whose outgoing characters are the polar opposites of their shy, retreating selves, and then there is Molly Shannon. In her six seasons at Saturday Night Live, Ms. Shannon embodied tireless, talkative creations like Sally OMalley, the 50-year-old dancer; Jeannie Darcy, the hopeless stand-up comedian; and, of course, Mary Katherine Gallagher, the Catholic schoolgirl with dreams of superstardom. Many of those same qualities are on display in Ms. Shannons performance in the Broadway musical Promises, Promises, in which she plays Marge MacDougall (a role she took over from the Tony winner Katie Finneran), a barfly who lands in the lap of Chuck Baxter (played by Sean Hayes) on the worst possible night. And they are all characters with which she shares a thing or two, if a recent telephone interview with the enthusiastic, impassioned, occasionally out-of-breath Ms. Shannon is anything to go by.

title: Giants Are Besting Jets With Big Margins
description: Unlike the Jets, who have been scratching out victories, the Giants have been dominating.

title: Rally Stalls on Worry About Europe, but Gold Soars to $1,400 an Ounce
description: Stocks were mixed on Monday, while gold soared to a new nominal high and the dollar edged up as concerns resurfaced over financial struggles in Europe.

title: A Loss Happens but Doesnt Diminish Zenyatta
description: In a bucket list moment, Julie June Stewart woke up at 4 a.m. and bought a ticket to the 2008 Belmont Stakes. She hasnt stopped going to the races since  when she isnt taking on a wildfire, hurricane or volcano as the nations leading expert in disaster airspace coordination.

title: Im creative. Youre quirky. Hes bonkers.
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared emotive conjugations  irregular verbs with which we judge others more harshly than ourselves.

title: Bank Chiefs Say Growth in Economies Is Still Uneven
description: BASEL, Switzerland  Central bank chiefs warned Monday that economic growth remained uneven, especially in industrial countries, as new data reinforced fears of a slowdown in Germany, Europes biggest economy.

title: Oil Spill Panel Opens Hearings
description: The presidential commission investigating the causes of BPs oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico has opened two days of hearings and is presenting its preliminary findings. A live feed is here. So far the presentation has been chock full of graphics and digital animations about the structure of the Macondo oil well, as John M. Broder reports.

title: It Sleeted!
description: Let it be known that at 9:19 Monday morning, as bitter gusts blew in from the northwest and temperatures hovered in the low 40s, the light rain spattering the south side of West 42nd Street between Broadway and Avenue of the Americas was briefly mixed with sleet.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: 2 Blasts Near Shiite Holy Sites in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Two car bombs aimed at Iranian pilgrims exploded near two of the holiest shrines for Shiite Muslims in Iraq on Monday, as Iraqi leaders met in an inconclusive effort to resolve their countrys long political deadlock.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: Michael Alvarez joined the Telemundo Communications Group in a new post, vice president for New York advertising sales, handling duties that include serving as a sales lead for the Telemundo network sales New York office and managing a team of account managers for the New York region. He had been senior vice president for branded content and sponsorships at the New York office of Intersport. Telemundo is part of the NBC Universal unit of General Electric.

title: Are Credit Card Lines Growing? No.
description: 12:04 p.m. | Updated

title: Are Credit Card Lines Growing? No.
description: 12:04 p.m. | Updated

title: Whats Gained, and Lost, In an Era of Virtual College Searches and Applications
description: How did technology become both my new BFF and my arch-enemy? I find myself lusting for any iGadget that I can afford, wouldnt think of going on vacation without my Kindle, and tell students how lucky they are to be able to Google their college searches. Life is good and clean and quick and secure when its online.

title: On Our Radar: Texas Battles Climate Regulation
description: Texas officials step up their efforts to strip the Environmental Protection Agency of its authority to regulate the states carbon dioxide emissions, the highest in the nation. The attorney general, Greg Abbott, has filed seven lawsuits against the agency in the last nine months related to climate rules and other environmental controls. [The Los Angeles Times]

title: Mr. Gibbs Sides With the Press in India
description: The White House press secretary, Robert Gibbs, is known for his angry tirades directed at reporters.

title: Video of Russian Journalists Beating
