description: MOSCOW  A graphic video said to show a reporter being beaten nearly to death on a street here appeared on a Russian news Web site on Monday, illustrating the severity of an attack that drew attention from domestic and foreign groups defending journalists rights.

title: Stojakovic Odd Man Out in New Orleans
description: Forward Peja Stojakovic used to be one of the most feared shooters in the N.B.A. His smooth delivery, which rarely broke down under game pressure, was a thing of beauty.

title: The Other Texas Republican on Book Tour
description: Former President George W. Bush is not the only Texas Republican on book tour.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: A page one story by Landon Thomas Jr. on Monday looks at Irish debt, and what it portends for Europe. John Bruton, former prime minister of that embattled nation, assures us via Bloomberg that a default is unthinkable  short-sellers, beware. The ever astute Morgan Kelly, however, warns that while bad loans to developers have caused great grief so far, greater grief awaits the Irish when their long recession finally causes a wave of mortgage defaults. And finally, looking back to 2006, what do you want to bet that Malcolm Gladwell wants to revise this analysis. Toward the end of the Irish expansion, growth was built on cheap debt, a real estate bubble and a smattering of fraud.

title: My Friend FRED
description: Some readers have asked about the graphs that show up in some posts; many of them come from FRED, the terrific data site of the St. Louis Fed. FRED lets you both create and customize charts of US data, and lets you create permalinks to the charts too  a significant convenience in my case, because for technical reasons creating a non-FRED chart requires me to move back and forth between the Times and Princeton VPNs.

title: Kill Americans, Says Yemeni-American Cleric
description: Updated | 1:57 p.m. In a new video message posted on a jihadist Web forum on Monday, Anwar al-Awlaki, an American-born cleric based in Yemen whose most inflammatory sermons were withdrawn from YouTube last week, said that the killing of Americans by Muslims requires no special sanction.

title: Dexter Watch: Vigilante Partners
description: Fans of the short-lived ABC drama Eli Stone were surely happy to see its star, Jonny Lee Miller, turn up on Dexter on Sunday night. I know I was. Mr. Miller aces just-shy-of-sleazy charm, though here he is a full-on sleaze and psychopath: a motivational speaker named Jordan Chase who seems to appeal to sexually disenfranchised average Joes. Its a guy not unlike the one Tom Cruise played in Magnolia, if that character had led a band of deranged torturers, which Chase seems to be doing.

title: Monday Reading: When to Pay Off Your Mortgage
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Red Bull Wins Formula One Constructors Championship
description: Red Bull Racing clinched its first ever Formula One constructors championship at the Brazilian Grand Prix on Sunday, but the landmark moment was overshadowed by the teams decision not to institute team orders to give its driver Mark Webber a better shot at the drivers title.

title: Fed Action Gets an Unexpected Endorsement From India
description: NEW DELHI  When the United States Federal Reserve announced last week that it would buy $600 billion in Treasury bonds to help bolster the economy, it quickly came under attack from Germany, Brazil and China, which said America was trying to devalue the dollar to the detriment of other nations exports.

title: Monday: The $29,000 Client
description: This week, as I explained on Friday, Im writing daily posts about my experiences during a recent week trying to collect money from my customers.

title: Health Commissioner Blazes the Trail
description: Practicing what he preaches, Dr. Thomas A. Farley, New York Citys health commissioner, finished Sundays marathon in 3 hours 18 minutes 28 seconds  very respectable for a 54-year-old man, though a full three minutes slower than his own prediction.

title: Toyota Turns to Consumers for Ideas
description: From our colleagues at the Media Decoder blog:

title: Numberplay: Beating Impossible Odds
description: One of the hallmarks of great puzzles is that when you encounter them for the first time, you get the feeling that they are impossible. Like Alex, our hustled victim, and the way he felt about the pizza puzzle a few weeks ago, you think: That just cant be. There must be some mistake. In the very best puzzles, some residue of this feeling remains even after you know the answer. Todays puzzle is of this type. It concerns a historical scenario very similar to that of the prisoners and light bulb puzzle a couple of months ago.

title: Now Drinking | Beyond Tequila in Mexico City
description: Ever since the diminutive mezcalera La Btica opened in Mexico Citys fashionable Condesa neighborhood on Cinco de Mayo 2005, mezcal has steadily risen from hipster novelty to ubiquity in restaurants, neighborhood pubs and classic cantinas alike. Savvy chilangos have reappraised the countrys rich alco-history, looking beyond tequila  and lately even mezcal  for new sources of national pride and connoisseurship.

title: Judge Upholds Award Against Goldman
description: A federal judge on Monday denied a request by the investment firm Goldman Sachs to throw out a record-setting arbitration award that was levied this year.

title: Death Penalty for a Killer of 3 in Connecticut
description: NEW HAVEN  A jury voted on Monday to impose the death penalty on a habitual criminal who took part in a home invasion in Cheshire, Conn., that left a woman and her two daughters dead, a crime of such inexplicable cruelty and randomness  the family was apparently chosen after being spotted in a shopping center parking lot  that it upended a debate about capital punishment.

title: More FREDding
description: Just a quick illustration of why I  along with the Fed and everyone else whos serious about these things  use core inflation rather than headline inflation to measure trends. Heres core versus headline CPI growth for the past decade:

title: Label Says Thats Michael Jackson on New Michael Jackson Song
description: You put Michael Jacksons name on a record, youd think its a given that Jackson is somehow involved in the material it contains. But the Epic Records division of Sony Music now finds itself in the unusual position of having to reaffirm that the King of Pop really did provide the vocals for a new release being put out under Jacksons name  and to make clear that Prince is not connected to the album.

title: Volcano Is No Deterrent to Presidential Visit
description: NEW DELHI  Neither rain nor sleet nor snow  or, more precisely, volcanic ash  will keep President Obama from his Indonesian homecoming this time, the White House says.

title: Report Reveals Forces Destroying Atlantic Bluefin Tuna
description: A powerful and innovative international journalistic effort has revealed the web of interests  from boat captains to European government agencies to fish auctions  behind the devastation of Atlantic bluefin tuna.

title: The Saddest Exacta I Ever Cashed
description: Jeff Deitz M.D. practices in New York and Connecticut. Two decades before he psychoanalyzed his first patient, his father taught him to read the form at Pimlico.

title: A Series of Small Booms
description: Wednesday, Nov. 3

title: Investigator Finds No Evidence That BP Took Shortcuts to Save Money
description: WASHINGTON  The lead investigator for the presidential panel delving into the BP oil spill said on Monday that he had found no evidence that anyone involved in drilling the doomed well had taken safety shortcuts to save money.

title: Los Angeles Philharmonic to Broadcast Live in Movie Theaters
description: First operas, then ballets and now, increasingly, orchestras. The Los Angeles Philharmonic has joined the movement to transmit performances live to movie theaters. The orchestra announced Monday that it would beam three performances conducted by Gustavo Dudamel later this season, reaching 450 theaters in the United States and Canada.

title: With Appeals, an Execution, if It Happens, May Be Many Years Away
description: NEW HAVEN  The death sentence voted by jurors on Monday for Steven J. Hayes, the man convicted of the Cheshire, Conn., killings, does not mean he is likely to be executed any time soon. In fact, it has merely started a new chapter that may last far longer than the response, investigation, hearing and trial touched off by the events of July 2007.

title: New York University Ad
description: Promotion for the master's program in hospitality industry studies at New York University's Tisch center.

title: Bloomberg Called Obama Arrogant, Murdoch Says
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York apparently made some not-so-nice remarks about President Obama to a fellow billionaire, Rupert Murdoch, who passed it along to an Australian newspaper.

title: Cuomos Signals on Silvers Leadership Unclear
description: CAROLINA, P.R.  Andrew M. Cuomo will not be sworn in as governor of New York for seven weeks, but his jockeying with the Legislature has already begun.

title: Ads for N.Y.U. Have Their Words in the Clouds
description: Every cloud, so they say, has a silver lining. These days, clouds are also lined with words, and a campaign from New York University seeks to take advantage of that.

title: They Will Not Be Missed
description: In addition to depriving the Democratic Party its House majority, this political season has cost us the services of three of the countrys most prominent centrists  Evan Bayh, the Indiana Democrat who grew so tired of the Senate that he declined to run for re-election; Charlie Crist, the Florida governor and Senate hopeful who left the G.O.P. to run, and lose, as an independent against Marco Rubio; and Arlen Specter, who was defeated in Pennsylvanias Democratic primary after he switched parties to avoid a primary challenge. Ive written critically about each of these figures before (Specter here, Crist here and here, Bayh here), but I think its worth pausing a moment, amid all the midterm analysis, to emphasize what they represented and why they wont be missed.

title: Flooding Raises New Cholera Fears in Haiti
description: ST. DENIS, Haiti  Three medical workers arrived at a clinic near here over the weekend on a mission to deliver supplies and spread the word about preventing a deadly cholera outbreak from getting worse after the torrential rains brought by Hurricane Tomas.

title: Banned Hits Return, Along With Confusion
description: When the N.F.L. announced a crackdown on hits to the head and neck a month ago, Bill Polian, the president of the Indianapolis Colts and a member of the competition committee, said he was a little surprised by the uproar over the well-publicized handful of blows that spurred it. He almost sounded optimistic about the state of tackling.

title: First Ladys Dance Moves Woo Indian Crowds
description: NEW DELHI  While President Obama is wooing India with promises of increased trade and United Nations clout, his wifes charm offensive has included serial hugs and a talent for Indian dance.

title: Bloomberg Says Daughter Is Recovering After Fall
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said his younger daughter, Georgina, was faring reasonably well Monday after being injured on Friday when she fell off the horse she was riding during an equestrian tournament in Syracuse.

title: Too Many Investors Are Actually Collectors
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog, and other drawings are available on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

title: Friendship Parallels a Strategic Partnership
description: NEW DELHI  Three decades and two oceans stand between President Obama and Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India. But on a dais here after a joint news conference on Monday, the two men, neither known for their social ebullience, were inseparable: the youthful, lanky American presidents arm firmly fixed on the older mans shoulder, Mr. Singh grinning widely with his arm wrapped tightly around Mr. Obamas waist.

title: TimesCast | November 8, 2010
description: An unexpected announcement from President Obama; former President Bush returns to the spotlight and the future of mining under the sea.

title: For One Real Estate Investor, Vinyl Siding Never Lost Its Shine
description: Like many creative professionals who live in Williamsburg, Lewis Canfield possesses a Renaissance mans variety of passions and hobbies. He worked in the movie industry, profited from the Internet boom, dabbled in art, developed an interest in womens perfume scents and now buys, sells and renovates Brooklyn real estate.

title: A Small-Business Barometer in Astoria
description: Marino & Sons Fish Market opened on 30th Avenue in Astoria, Queens, in 1932, fulfilling the dreams of a scrawny teenager from Sicily who had been peddling fish from woven baskets along the streets of Manhattan.

title: What Were Reading
description: The New York Post: Say what? Seven of the 14 C-rated New York City restaurants sampled by reporters were hiding their dirty-restaurant grades. They face fines up to $1,000  Glenn Collins

title: Will Gebrselassie Reconsider? Countrymen Hope So
description: The marathon world-record holder Haile Gebrselassie announced his spur-of-the-moment decision to retire from the sport after he dropped out of the New York City Marathon on Sunday, but his fellow Ethiopian athletes and fans, and others close to him, believe he may reconsider the decision.

title: Catching Up With Jane Birkin
description: Jane Birkin may be best known for her namesake Herms bag and her scandalous duet with Serge Gainsbourg on Je Taime  Moi Non Plus, but these are only specks of sequins in her glittery 45-year career. At 64 years young, Birkin has recorded more than 20 albums, acted in more than 65 films, worked as a designer, a model and a muse, and actively supported a slew of humanitarian causes. Along the way she even picked up an Order of the British Empire title.

title: With Stunning Rally, Zenyatta Wins Over Critics
description: Horse racing let us down a lot last weekend. We saw a disgraceful and indefensible jockey fight in the winners circle; a perplexing series of events that led to Life At Ten jogging around the track at Churchill Downs under the lights; a fatal injury to Rough Sailing in the Breeders Cup Juvenile Turf.

title: Despite Protests, Waste Arrives in Germany
description: BERLIN  After three days of protests and occasional violent clashes with the police, a train hauling 123 tons of nuclear waste finally arrived Monday in northern Germany. The nuclear waste, which had been reprocessed in France, was transferred to trucks that were expected to encounter a final gantlet of protesters en route to a storage facility near the former Gorleben salt mines.

title: In the U.S., Sticker Shock in Reverse
description: When I dropped off a rental car recently in New York City after visiting my daughter at her colleges parents weekend, I suffered a severe case of sticker shock. I had been cursing myself for forgetting to refuel the midsize car in New Jersey before re-entering New York. Now I would be stuck paying New York gas prices.

title: Joan Nathans Jewish-French Thanksgiving
description: The best cookbooks do more than provide new recipes  they tell a story of food and culture that can teach and inspire home chefs.

title: 7 People Killed Since Saturday Night
description: Updated, Tuesday, Nov. 9, 11:05 a.m. |The mini-spike in murders that has pushed the homicide rate up 15 percent so far this year continued with three more killings this morning, following four on Saturday night and Sunday. Through Sunday, there were 459 murders this year, compared with 399 at this time last year, the police said this morning. Here are the seven new killings:

title: College Sticker Prices Rising, but So Is Financial Aid
description: The College Board recently released its latest report on college costs, and it is chock-full of nutritious charts and graphs. One takeaway is that while sticker prices for college tuition may be rising, for the typical student out-of-pocket higher education costs have actually fallen in recent years, thanks to more generous financial aid.

title: Obama Presses to Complete Free-Trade Deal With South Korea
description: WASHINGTON  The White House is intensifying negotiations with South Korea on revising a free-trade agreement negotiated by the Bush administration, even though the accord still faces opposition from Democratic politicians, labor unions and the Ford Motor Company.

title: Stargazing Under a Brighter, Greener Light
description: Amateur astronomers in this city dont have it easy. The brightest lights in New Yorks nighttime burn from Broadway marquees and skyscraper windows, obscuring Orion, Gemini and the Dippers from their rightful place in our sky.

title: Challenge Heard on Move to Kill Qaeda-Linked Cleric
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge heard a legal challenge on Monday to the Obama administrations decision to authorize the killing of Anwar al-Awlaki, even as Mr. Awlaki, the American-born cleric tied to Al Qaeda and now hiding in Yemen, called for new attacks on the United States in a video posted to the Web.

title: Carrots: Digging Deeper for Fall Flavor
description: The interior of my refrigerator is filled with an orange glow. For one thing, its just that time of year (stay tuned for pumpkin recipes). For another, I bought several pounds of carrots recently for a huge Moroccan salad that Id planned to add to an already ambitious menu for a book party. But by the time I finished making frittatas, farro salad with beets and beet greens, fixings for black bean tostadas, and tahini and chard stalk dip for 100 people, there simply wasnt time to make that beautiful salad. I left several pounds of carrots in my refrigerator.

title: U.S. Sets New Rules for Packages on Cargo Planes
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Monday moved to tighten air cargo security, banning large toner and ink cartridges from passenger flights and demanding new inspections on high risk shipments headed to the United States on all-cargo flights.

title: The Morning Line: A List of Believers
description: Bennett Liebman is the executive director of the Government Law Center at Albany Law School and a member of the board of directors of the New York Racing Association.

title: Izinyoka
description: A South African term for those who steal electricity  based on the isiZulu word for snakes.

title: South Korea Drops Its Call for Apology From North
description: SEOUL, South Korea  In a shift that could pave the way for new talks on the dismantling of North Koreas nuclear weapons program, the government in the South has quietly abandoned its demand that the North apologize for the sinking of a South Korean naval vessel, no longer making that a condition for the nuclear talks or other future exchanges.

title: Brian Eno: Seven Sessions on a Milk Sea
description: The first video installment of a new improvised composition featuring Brian Eno with Jon Hopkins and Leo Abrahams.

title: Lehman Lawyers Seek a Fresh $90 Million
description: Richard S. Fuld Jr., the former chief executive of Lehman Brothers.

title: Vinyl Siding: Love It or Hate It?
description: Some people think its a scourge on neighborhoods. Bloggers devote Web sites to mocking its worst examples. While vinyl siding may seem like a material that simply protects homes from the elements, it draws every element of opinion about its appearance and presence in neighborhoods.

title: A Prime Retail Spot, but No Takers
description: Queens has the highest retail vacancy rate in New York City  at 13.7 percent, it is nearly double the rate that Manhattan had in the second quarter of this year. But if theres one spot where empty storefronts are a rare commodity, it is on Roosevelt Avenue, between roughly 72nd Street and 84th Street, a bustling commercial district on the edge of Jackson Heights.

title: Principles for Managing Climate Management
description: The final report has been issued from the Asilomar Conference on Climate Engineering Technologies that was held last spring in Pacific Grove, Calif.

title: Vintage Brand and Corporate Names to Be Auctioned
description: A cache of venerable brand and corporate names, not used for years  and, in some instances, decades  is to be auctioned next month in New York.

title: The Morning Skate: Head Check Rule Comes Under Fire
description: Its just like the N.H.L. to pat itself on the back and trumpet its great accomplishments, then turn around and stab itself in the back, or at least shoot itself in the foot. Its a pathology the league has exhibited repeatedly when it comes to changes designed to improve the game.

title: An Early Demise for A Life in the Theater
description: Broadway has its first commercial failure of the 2010-11 season: David Mamets play A Life in the Theater, which stars stage and television star Patrick Stewart and the former Greys Anatomy actor T.R. Knight, will close on Nov. 28, five weeks ahead of the originally scheduled end of the run.

title: First Look | George Esquivel for Fratelli Rosetti
description: Fratelli Rosettis latest collaboration, with George Esquivel, the recent Council of Fashion Designers of America inductee, has us beaming with patriotism. The America satchel  a flexible leather bucket bag in natural leather, sea blue, white and black  promises to be as covetable as the designers signature handmade shoes. Its so minimal in design  in terms of shape and structure, Esquivel says. But the true beauty of the bag is revealed when it is put to work. Indeed, the shoulder strap can be removed transforming the tote into a proper purse; a bag inside the bag can be carried on its own as an evening clutch. The America is available in mid-November, but the collaboration will continue through the fall 2011 season with more carry-alls to come. Now thats our idea of the American dream.America satchel, $1,200. Available at Fratelli Rossetti flagship locations, call (212) 888-5107.

title: Israel Plans 1,000 Housing Units in East Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM  Israel has published plans for some 1,000 new housing units in a hotly contested area of Jerusalem, advancing the approval process at a delicate time when the United States is pressing Israel to renew a freeze in settlement construction and get stalled peace negotiations with the Palestinians back on track.

title: Myanmar Refugees Spilling into Thailand
description: BANGKOK  Clashes between an ethnic rebel group in Myanmar and government soldiers have pushed a flood of at least 10,000 refugees across a river into Thailand, one day after Myanmar held its first election in 20 years.

title: An Ode to Vinyl Siding in Williamsburg
description: A real estate buyer and seller points out some examples of vinyl-sided homes in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: Salon Names New Editor
description: Salon, the Web site that helped pioneer online journalism before many newspapers and magazineshad even thought about the Internet, is changing editors.

title: World Bank President Advocates  the Gold Standard?
description: This proposal was somewhat unexpected, considering the source:

title: Arrest in Fatal Shooting at a Chelsea Diner
description: The only suspect in the recent fatal shooting at a West 14th Street diner has been apprehended in North Carolina, the authorities said.

title: A Change of Heart for a Hedge Fund Manager
description: Lars Kroijer got rich charging investors fat fees as a manager of his hedge fund, Holte Capital.

title: Sanofi Asks Genzyme to Keep Path to Deal Open
description: Sanofi-Aventis on Monday sent a letter to Genzymes chief executive, asking that the biotech giant not seek to block its unsolicited takeover bid by altering its board or using anti-takeover laws in its home state, Massachusetts.

title: A Game of Inches
description: Zenyatta was beaten for the first time in her career. For many of us watching the Breeders Cup Classic at Churchill Downs, it was a rollercoaster of emotions throughout and there was a huge deflated feeling afterward.

title: Here He Comes: the Improvisational Music of Brian Eno
description: Unless you are Stephen Hawking, there is a good chance that Brian Eno is smarter than you. But thats O.K., because rather than using his intellect for nefarious purposes or taunting you with his superior exam grades, Mr. Eno, the musician, producer and multi-hyphenate, channels his powers into artistic pursuits. To promote his new album, Small Craft on a Milk Sea, he has started a series of videos, titled Seven Sessions on a Milk Sea, documenting improvised performances at his London studio with the musicians Jon Hopkins and Leo Abrahams. An entry, titled Signal Success, can be seen above, and subsequent videos will be posted at Mr. Enos official Web site, brian-eno.net/seven-sessions. Now leave him be so he can play six simultaneous chess games and prove the existence of cold fusion.

title: Deal Gives Amazon a Diaper Strategy
description: 8:15 p.m. | Updated  Amazon.com is changing its diaper strategy.

title: A Temporary Place for the Food Trucks of Tavern on the Green
description: And now: Tavern on the Avenue of the Americas.

title: Going Into Detail: Developing Proofreading Skills
description: Overview | How can we learn to pay closer attention to detail in writing? How can we put knowledge about grammar and mechanics into practice? In this lesson, students consider errors in signage and other textual displays and create lists of common errors to check as they proofread. They then practice proofreading and develop strategies, taking into consideration the possible consequences of making language mistakes.

title: A Treasure Trove of Japanese Art for St. Louis Museum
description: A collection of nearly 1,400 Japanese prints and related works has been donated to the Saint Louis Art Museum, the museum is to announce on Tuesday. Charles and Rosalyn Lowenhaupt have donated their entire collection of works on paper, amassed over the past two decades. They also gave all of their books, exhibition catalogs and research materials to the museums Richardson Memorial Library.

title: Very Old Bones, Back Underground
description: Over the past 17 years, thousands of pieces of human remains dating back to the 18th century have been unearthed in the course of construction projects in and around City Hall.

title: Tuition Reimbursements for Jobless Graduates?
description: In this weak economy, many recent, and soon-to-be, graduates of colleges and graduate schools are having a difficult time finding jobs, leading at least one to ask whether its possible to get back money spent on tuition.

title: Republican Concedes in Race for Connecticut Governor
description: The Connecticut governors race is finally over.

title: Slumber Spas
description: Theres no rest for the weary these days, at least if the number of spas offering guided sleep treatments is any indication. Yelo Spa in New York City is adding targeted power naps to its menu for ailments like jet lag, stress and hangovers.

title: Cowboys Fire Wade Phillips
description: 5:17 p.m. |Update

title: Oil Traveled Up the Gulf Food Chain, Scientists Say
description: While officials in Washington pick apart the sequence of events that led to the release of nearly five million barrels of oil in the Deepwater Horizon disaster, scientists are still trying to figure out where all of that oil went.

title: GrubHub Gets a Cash Delivery
description: 1:24 p.m. | Updated  Correcting number of restaurants in partnership with GrubHub.

title: The Walking Dead Will Live On in a Second Season
description: Good news for undead zombies who consume the flesh of the living and the television viewers who love them: AMC said on Monday that it has officially ordered a second season of The Walking Dead, its original series adapted from the comic books written by Robert Kirkman about human survivors in a world overrun by the ambulatory deceased. (Catchy phrase, no?) Though AMC ordered just six episodes of The Walking Dead for its first season, it seemed a virtual certainty that the show would rise again when its debut episode, broadcast on Halloween, broke a ratings record for that cable channel by drawing 5.3 million viewers, the largest audience it had recorded for an original series. AMC, which is also the home of the serial dramas Mad Men, Breaking Bad and Rubicon, said the second episode of The Walking Dead was watched by more than 4.7 million people.

title: Afghan Government Drops Corruption Charges Against Aide
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan government has dropped all charges in the controversial corruption case against an aide to President Hamid Karzai, said the official whose office oversaw the case.

title: The Caucus: 'Decision Points'
description: Former President George W. Bush is expected to begin a book tour for his new memoir, "Decision Points," with an appearance on NBC on Monday night.

title: In Surprise Move, Codas Chief Executive Resigns
description: In a move that surprised many observers of the electric-car industry, Coda Automotive announced Friday that its chief executive, Kevin Czinger, had resigned. The move comes shortly before the public debut of Codas electric sedan. According to Coda, Mr. Czinger will be replaced by its board co-chairman, Steven Heller, on an interim basis, pending a search for a chief executive with deep manufacturing, marketing and sales strengths.

title: The Newest, Latest Parenting Trend
description: Two recent articles are cause for a lot of chatter on parenting Web sites, highlighting, as they do, new trends that are not actually new and may not actually be trends.

title: Pictures of the Day: Thailand and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Thailand, India and Germany.

title: Glimpsing a Scientific Future as Fields Heat Up
description: About 25 years ago, before I came to The Times, I had a job interview at U.S. News & World Report. I really wanted the reporter position, and it seemed to me that things were going well. Then I was asked, What will be the important medical news next year?

title: What Were Reading: For God or Government
For Edge on Alzheimers, Testing Early Treatments
description: Much of the research on Alzheimers next year will be about going back in time, trying to determine when and how the brain begins to deteriorate.

title: Genes as Mirrors of Life Experiences
description: For decades, researchers have ransacked the genetic pedigrees of people with mental illness, looking for common variations that combine to cause devastating conditions like schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. The search has stalled badly; while these disorders may involve genetic disruptions, no underlying patterns have surfaced  no single gene or genes that account for more than a tiny fraction of cases.

title: The Perils of Presidential Dancing
description: As my colleague Heather Timmons reports, video of Michelle Obama dancing with Indian children during a state visit has won hearts in India. Twice in two days, The Times of India reported, the First Lady demonstrated in Mumbai that she could swing to desi beats with the best of them, pulling off matkas and jhatkas [dance moves involving swaying hips] like a seasoned performer.

title: British and U.S. Law Firms Merge
description: Partners at two law firms  Squire, Sanders & Dempsey in the United States and the Hammonds of Britain  agreed to merge on Monday, the latest in a series of trans-Atlantic consolidations.

title: New Lines of Attack in H.I.V. Prevention
description: The hottest news in AIDS in the last year was the partial success in a South African clinical trial of a microbicide  a gel women can put in their vaginas to kill the virus before it can infect them.

title: Photo Replay: Nov. 8
description: A view of the day in sports, with Allen Iverson arriving in Turkey and two women making hockey history.

title: Mendes Crosses Finish Line of 5-Borough Trek
description: Jon Mendes of Manhattan, who walked the New York City Marathon on Sunday four days after his 90th birthday, crossed the finish line of the 26.2-mile course after nine-plus hours.

title: Pictures of the Day: Thailand and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Thailand, India and Germany.

title: House Panel Asks F.D.A. About Inspections in Puerto Rico
description: In a sign of what may be the new kind of post-election scrutiny of the Food and Drug Administration, leading members of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform sent a letter Monday to the agency asking whether understaffing at a district office led to oversight problems of drug manufacturing.

title: Going Public With Open-Book Management
description: The last time we counted, we found that more than a million people have been touched by open-book management through the SRC family. While thats an impressive number, its far short of, say, the 300 million people living in the United States. One way that we could bump up the number would be to get organizations in the public sector to try opening their books.

title: Eurofile | Back to Bucharest
description: Disappointed to find that much of central Paris now serves up the same street-level visual refrain as most American cities  Gap, Zara, Starbucks, Subway  friends visiting from Boston yearned for an urban adventure. Where could they go for a long weekend that hadnt yet been subjected to the centrifuge of globalization? Bucharest, I replied, and they laughed out loud. Bucharest!? Is there anything to see there? And what about the hotels and the food?

title: Voices Raised to Echo Higher Worlds
description: Whatever a listeners spiritual bent (or lack thereof), surely only a zombie would have been unmoved by the transcendent singing of the Tallis Scholars on Sunday afternoon in the White Light Festival at Lincoln Center.

title: Miracles of Light Mix Audio and Visual
description: As if anticipating the earlier encroachment of darkness brought on by clocks turned back for the season, some of New Yorks concert halls have come aglow in a metaphorical sense. Spiritual illumination is the express concern of the White Light Festival at Lincoln Center, which continues through next week. And at the Rubin Museum of Art, a new chamber-music series bears a similarly luminous banner: Resonating Light.

title: Bill Campbell on Coaching RockMelt and Google vs. Apple
description: In Silicon Valley, where even mid-level executives seem to be escorted by public relations handlers, Bill Campbell is a bit of an exception. An elder statesman of the tech industry, he prefers to remain out of the limelight.

title: Cyclists Condemn Prosecutors Decision
description: Last week The Vail Daily News reported that an Eagle County, Colo., prosecutor had declined to press felony charges against Martin Joel Erzinger, a financial manager who allegedly fled the site of a crash with a cyclist in July.

title: Singer Marked by a Sense of History
description: Even as a teenager leading a punk-rock band Paul Weller looked back. His 1970s band, the Jam, was openly fond of Mod-era British Invasion songwriting from a decade earlier. Since then Mr. Weller has maintained a long, steady career in Britain, where hes fondly known as the Modfather. His concert on Sunday night at the Best Buy Theater was sold out; many audience members had British accents.

title: The Obamas in India
description: The first couple  working on both diplomatic and charm campaigns  have been an unexpected success during their trip to India.

title: She Got Her Gold. More Important, She Earned Her Gold.
description: For Sundays Metropolitan section, Carmen Pelez, wrote a Sweat column describing her soul-wrenching decision to run the New York City Marathon in the face of monumental self-doubt. I may not have a runners body, but I have a runners heart, she wrote. Heres what happened Sunday.

title: Critics' Picks: 'American Psycho'
description: A. O. Scott looks at Mary Harron's film adaptation of the Bret Easton Ellis novel about a Wall Street serial killer.

title: Dispatches and Details From a Life in Literature
description: Herzog, the title character of Saul Bellows 1964 novel, is famously a writer of letters he never sends, letters to friends, rivals, relatives and strangers; letters that satisfy his craving to explain, to have it out, to justify, to put in perspective, to clarify, to make amends. The letters are, by turns, cranky, coruscating, clever and cerebral: the outpourings of a man overflowing with ideas and grievances, and reeling from the complications of his life and the stubborn mystifications of the world around him.

title: Microsoft Places Big Bets on New Smartphone
description: In 2007, when the Apple iPhone first went on sale, Microsofts operating system dominated the American market and Apple essentially commanded zero percent. Now its the other way around, with Apple the top smartphone in the United States and Microsofts Windows Mobile operating system stagnating around 3 percent.

title: Phillips Takes the Fall for a Season in Ruins
description: For weeks, Wade Phillipss perplexed countenance seemed to mirror the Dallas Cowboys season gone awry: nobody could quite figure out how things had gone so wrong for a team that began the season talking about hosting a Super Bowl. Nobody  especially Phillips, it seemed  knew how to stop the Cowboys slide from Americas Team to N.F.L. doormat.

title: Excerpt: 'The Fashion Show'
description: The model and entrepreneur Iman is a host and judge of the design competition.

title: The Measure of Love in Zenyattas Finest Hour
description: Carole-Terese Naser follows thoroughbred racing from Six Horses Sanctuary, an equine retirement facility, in central Maine.

title: 2011 Musical America Winners Announced
description: Musical America, which publishes the Musical America International Directory of the Performing Arts and maintains the Web site musicalamerica.com, has announced the winners of its 2011 Musical America Awards. Its musician of the year is the violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter, soon to begin a season-long stint as artist in residence at the New York Philharmonic. The composer of the year is Thomas Ads; the conductor, Rafael Frhbeck dr Burgos; the vocalist, the baritone Simon Keenlyside; and the educator, Vivian Perlis, the founder of Yale Universitys Oral History of American Music. The awards are to be presented at Carnegie Hall on Dec. 13.

title: The Fashion Cop Is on the Beat
description: Were it not for The Fashion Show: Ultimate Collection, whose second season begins Tuesday on Bravo, our universal impression of the Somali-American supermodel Iman, an entrepreneur who is fluent in five languages, would surely have remained positive. Iman is 55 and looks 37. She designs handbags, jewelry and other accessories for a line called Iman Global Chic, which translates the looks of her African heritage for a Home Shopping Network audience that might not otherwise be exposed to such adventuresome style. Additionally she does charity work for organizations like Raising Hope for Congo, and she is Mrs. David Bowie.

title: Late Inspiration Carries Gimelstob to the Finish
description: The brevity of the congratulatory note was satisfaction in itself. Andy Roddick, in Switzerland for a tennis tournament, sent a text to Justin Gimelstob on Sunday night saying simply: Well done, Sir. Send me wiring instructions.

title: Spalding Gray Archives Acquired by University of Texas
description: Describing his travels in Thailand while filming a small role in The Killing Fields, Spalding Gray, the actor, author and monologist, compared the experience to  among other things  a stay at a pleasurable prison. Though the experience, preserved in his indelible performance piece Swimming to Cambodia, found him famously concluding that he knew what it was that had killed Marilyn Monroe, the notebooks and journals that formed the basis of that monologue will surely be treated to a better stay at their new permanent residence at the University of Texas at Austin.

title: In a First, Guineans at Home and in N.Y. Vote for President
description: The sun had barely risen Sunday morning as thousands of New Yorkers in four patient lines sipped coffee on a cold and quiet Harlem block. The group, Guinean expatriates about to vote in their countrys first democratic presidential election, clutched their voting cards with anticipation.

title: A Gambling Town Bets a Museum Can Compete
description: BILOXI, Miss.  Just months before a quirky little museum designed by the architect Frank Gehry was set to open in this Gulf Coast resort town, the waves from Hurricane Katrina lifted a three-story floating casino, slot machines and all, and slammed it into the project.

title: After Breast Cancer, Women Prefer Silicone Implants
description: Women who receive silicone implants after breast cancer surgery are happier with their reconstructed breasts than women who receive saline implants, a new study shows.

title: Rare Hits and Heaps of Misses to Pay For
description: Research, in any field of science, is not the risk-free business that might easily be supposed from the confident promises of scientific spokesmen or the daily reports of new advances.

title: A Direct Hit of Drugs to Treat Brain Cancer
description: It was a desperate measure, for a desperate disease. Fourteen months ago, Dennis Sugrue let doctors thread a fine tube through his blood vessels and up into his head, so they could spray the drug Avastin directly into the part of his brain where a tumor had been cut out. It was an experiment, devised mainly to find out whether the procedure was safe, and to gauge how much Avastin the brain could tolerate. But Mr. Sugrue, then 50, was hoping the experiment would also free him of cancer.

title: Dark or White? (Not the Turkey)
description: WHEN my family gathers for Thanksgiving, we dont fool around. Were cooking for, count em, 35 mouths or so, and most of them like to drink wine. So we cant be concerned with a dainty meal, a fancy bottle, china and crystal. Our mission: Get a ton of good food ready before people start gnawing on the table legs, and give them plenty to drink.

title: They Both Go Well With Stuffing
description: WHITES

title: DealBook Debate: Foreclosures
description: Document problems in the foreclosure process have raised questions about the culpability of banks.

title: The Warner Music Archive
description: The company has launched an ambitious project to sort its nearly 100,000 boxes worth of stored music memorabilia.

title: Of Sleet, Roaches and Wal-Mart
description: The morning began with idle chatter about sleet before quickly moving to the weightiest subject of life and death.

title: Predicting the Future in Science  or Not
description: What can we expect from science and medical research next year? The possibilities are discussed in a special report in this weeks Science Times.

title: Pairings: Potted Shrimp
description: Why not give a nod to the mother country on Thanksgiving? The early colonists had no thought of severing all ties and, when it came to food, adapted to the provisions available on American shores while maintaining a taste for pie and tea.

title: ESPN Breaks Up Sunday Night Baseball Team
description: ESPN ended its 20-year association with Jon Miller and Joe Morgan as the voices of Sunday Night Baseball on Monday. They declined to renew Morgans contract and have asked Miller if he wants to stay on as the radio voice of the Sunday night games. Discussions are continuing.

title: That Mad Men Look? Its Vintage Janie Bryant
description: Janie Bryant was having trouble focusing. As the costume director of Mad Men, shes been in the spotlight before, but last month, when she was in town to promote her first book and receive a giant award for her work from Fashion Group International, she was really spinning.

title: Commodity Prices
description: For everyone who thinks that we should view commodity prices as the right measure of inflation: theyre very, very volatile. Heres the annual rate of change in the IMF commodity index over time:

title: Scratching Under the Vinyl Era
description: The images have been scattered about in dusty and moldy warehouses, relics of the pre-Internet age when photography was integral to selling music, and the photographers  names like Irving Penn, Annie Leibovitz, Lee Friedlander and Robert Mapplethorpe  went on to become nearly as famous as the subjects they captured and defined.

title: Critics Picks Video: American Psycho
description: In this weeks Critics Pick, A. O. Scott looks at the Wall Street satire American Psycho,adapted from the Bret Eaton Ellis novel and directed by Mary Harron. The film follows the Wall Street trader and serial killer Patrick Bateman (Christian Bale), from his mundane daily routines to his brutal acts of violence. But Mr. Scott sees the film, in some way, as a comedy of manners. Its often very funny, he says, though the overall tone is almost as cold and inhuman as the main character himself.

title: Jets-Browns Is Next Battleground for Ryan vs. Ryan
description: The Ryan brothers remember only highlights from their infamous fight at Southwestern Oklahoma State. It started in a dormitory and spilled outside, where two friends broke their noses while attempting to restore peace.

title: The Flash Crash, in Miniature
description: BlackBerrys were buzzing inside Progress Energy in Raleigh, N.C.: in a blink, the 102-year-old utility had been virtually wiped out on Wall Street.

title: Strides in Materials, but No Invisibility Cloak
description: Blame it on Harry Potter.

title: Disunion: The Civil War
description: An unfolding history of the major events of the Civil War, starting with the election of Abraham Lincoln.

title: Olbermann Apologizes to Viewers, But Not to MSNBC
description: 6:15 p.m. | Update In an aggressive statement questioning the legitimacy of his two-day suspension from MSNBC, Keith Olbermann addressed his fans Monday night, saying that they were responsible for his scheduled return to the air on Tuesday, following revelations that he had contributed to the campaign funds of three Democrats in last weeks election.

title: 2010: An Aligning Election
description: Elections with results as dramatic as this years are sometimes referred to as realigning elections. The term  although somewhat ambiguous and overused  usually refers to an election in which one party not only gains a significant amount of power, but coalitions also shift, the signature of which is usually that the rising party performs particularly well in certain geographic regions or among certain demographic groups.

title: More Seats for Freshmen at G.O.P. Tables
description: When there are a whole bunch of new friends coming to town, you want to make them feel welcome. When they are new fellow members of the House of Representatives, you might also take a polite pre-emptive strike.

title: Steinbrenner on Veterans Ballot for Hall of Fame
description: The Hall of Fame announced Monday that George Steinbrenner, the longtime Yankees owner who died in July, was one of 12 candidates who will appear on the ballot of the latest incarnation of the veterans committee, which meets at the winter meetings in December.

title: A Novel Tactic in Climate Fight Gains Some Traction
description: WASHINGTON  With energy legislation shelved in the United States and little hope for a global climate change agreement this year, some policy experts are proposing a novel approach to curbing global warming: including greenhouse gases under an existing and highly successful international treaty ratified more than 20 years ago.

title: Hard Steps to Walk a Fine Line in Scottsboro
description: In the new Broadway musical The Scottsboro Boys, a black actor plays the part of Samuel Leibowitz, a white Jewish lawyer from New York who defends nine African-American youths wrongly imprisoned for raping two white women in the Alabama town Scottsboro in 1931.

title: Mining the Seafloor for Rare-Earth Minerals
description: For decades, entrepreneurs have tried to strike it rich by gathering up ugly potato-size rocks that carpet the global seabed. Known as manganese nodules, the rocks are plentiful in nickel, copper and cobalt, as well as manganese and other elements, but lie miles down in inky darkness. Building giant machines to vacuum them up, despite much study and investment, has never proved to be economic.

title: Jewish Critic of Israel Chosen to Speak at Frankfurts Kristallnacht Commemoration
description: Updated | Tuesday 2:48 p.m. Reports on German news sites indicate that the Kristallnacht memorial in Frankfurt passed off without incident on Tuesday evening. A photograph of the event on the Web site of Sddeutschen Zeitung showed the keynote speaker, Alfred Grosser, and Dieter Graumann, a leader of Germanys Jewish community, smiling together.

title: Quantum Computing Reaches for True Power
description: In 1981 the physicist Richard Feynman speculated about the possibility of tiny computers obeying quantum mechanical laws. He suggested that such a quantum computer might be the best way to simulate real-world quantum systems, a challenge that today is largely beyond the calculating power of even the fastest supercomputers.

title: How Cancer Acquired Its Own Biographer
description: In Dr. Siddhartha Mukherjees lab, a Stanley Kubrick-like space at the Herbert Irving Comprehensive Cancer Center at Columbia University, enormous white freezers with digital temperature readouts keep tissue at 80 below zero. Sterile work stations with transparent hoods and bacteria-scattering blowers emit an unearthly blue light. And there is a bountiful supply of mice that, thanks to the addition of a jellyfish gene, literally glow either red or green in the dark.

title: Football Remains No. 1
description: Despite the Green Bay Packers blowout victory over the Dallas Cowboys, NBCs Sunday Night Football extended its streak as the No. 1 program on television on that night for the ninth consecutive week. Nielsens preliminary estimates show the game up slightly, compared with the matchup a week ago between the Pittsburgh Steelers and the New Orleans Saints, which drew 18.1 million viewers opposite the World Series. CBS, in second place, got an assist from an overrun of its afternoon football coverage, which lasted throughout the 7 p.m. hour and helped lift CBSs 60 Minutes in the 8 p.m. hour. ABC placed third over all, behind NBC and CBS, and Fox was fourth.

title: A Civil War Timeline
description: To mark the sesquicentennial year of the Civil War in 1861, The Times has prepared an interactive timeline covering events from Lincolns election on Nov. 6, 1860, through the imposition of martial law in St. Louis on Dec. 26, 1861. The timeline contains pictures and drawings from the Times archive and the Library of Congress along with links to the original Times articles. There are also links to Topic pages on individual subjects and an overview of the war, with searchable archive articles, resource lists and essays by historians and from authoritative reference sources, along with an extensive recommended-reading list. More material will be added as the commemoration progresses. Visit the timeline

title: And Now, Predictions Well Back 100 Percent
description: Its a fools errand to make precise predictions about the future. Even the famously prescient often fall on their faces.

title: Critics Choice: New CDs
description: KID CUDI

title: Mets Alderson Adds More Depth  to Front Office
description: The Mets dont have a manager yet, and their bullpen minus Hisanori Takahashi is looking mighty thin, but their front office continues to grow in imposing fashion.

title: A Happy 125th Birthday for the Osborne
description: The film historian Robert Osborne could not have been happier that the crowd sang, Happy birthday, dear Osborne on Sunday night, not dear Mr. Osborne or dear Bob. It was not his birthday.

title: Justices Hear Case on Taxing of Students
description: WASHINGTON  How do you draw the line, Justice Sonia Sotomayor asked at a Supreme Court argument on Monday, between a student who is working and a worker who is studying?

title: Indian Point Reactor Shut Down After Transformer Blast
description: A transformer exploded on Sunday evening at the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant in northern Westchester County, N.Y., causing a fire and an automatic shutdown of the reactor, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Monday. No one was injured and no radiation was released, the commission said.

title: Scientists Probe Beak Trouble in Alaskan and Northwestern Birds
description: Nov. 10, 11:55 p.m. | Updated Federal biologists are intensifying research on a large and unexplained rise in the frequency of deformed beaks in a wide range of bird species from Alaska through the Pacific Northwest, including British Columbia. The deformities reduce the birds ability to feed, clean themselves and raise young, according to the scientists, from the United States Geological Survey. [Nov. 9, 8:46 a.m. | Updated  Ive posted an interview with two of the biologists.]

title: Hints on Dark Matter and a Wealth of Planets
description: Both planetary science and cosmology are ripe for big news in 2011, the former in its effort to find planets beyond the Earth and the solar system that could harbor water and thus life as we know it, and the latter in the unending effort to figure out what the universe is made of.

title: For NASA, Closer Looks at Mercury and Mars
description: On Earth, 2011 will be another tumultuous year for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration: its space shuttles will be retired, and it will have to wrangle with Congress and the Obama administration over a rocket and a destination for the United States human spaceflight program.

title: Ambac Files for Bankruptcy
description: Ambac Financial Group, the troubled bond insurer, filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday after seeking to negotiate a plan with its biggest creditors.

title: Last Gasp for Factory Bequeathed by Soviets
description: BAIKALSK, Russia  When the aging paper mill in this Siberian town is transforming logs into rolls of cardboard that resemble giant thread spools, Eduard Merkulov not only has a paycheck but also faith in the future. Maybe there is a place in the new Russia for a middle-aged laborer like him, calloused hands and all.

title: Troubles on Russia's Lake Baikal
description: Workers at an ailing paper mill in Siberia are clinging to their jobs in the face of financial pressure and criticism from environmentalists.

title: What Happens to Health Care Now?
description: To the Editor:

title: Government Surveillance
description: To the Editor:

title: Vicious Economic Circle
description: To the Editor:

title: Company Accused of Firing Over Facebook Post
description: In what labor officials and lawyers view as a ground-breaking case involving workers and social media, the National Labor Relations Board has accused a company of illegally firing an employee after she criticized her supervisor on her Facebook page.

title: Assessing Alzheimers
description: To the Editor:

title: Change Will Not Come Easily to the Security Council
description: The idea of overhauling the Security Council, even by the slow standards of the United Nations, has been under negotiation for about 18 years with no end in sight. Vague talks initiated under the auspices of the Open-Ended Working Group, mocked as the never ending committee, gave way in 2009 to what was supposed to be real negotiations.

title: Caution Ordered as 9/11 Deadline Nears
description: As the deadline approached for more than 10,000 ground zero workers to opt into a multimillion-dollar settlement with the city and its contractors, the federal judge overseeing the cases said on Monday that it would take several more days to tally and verify the huge influx of responses.

title: Players Case Stays in State Court
description: The N.F.L. and other sports leagues were dealt another setback Monday when the Supreme Court said it would not review a lower court decision that said players could challenge positive drug tests in state court.

title: No. 2 House Democrat Will Try to Retain Post
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, the No. 2 Democrat in the House, said Monday that he would try to hold on to that position when his party slips into the minority next year as the leadership of House Democrats remained in turmoil one week after devastating election losses.

title: Fighting Bullying With Babies
description: Imagine there was a cure for meanness. Well, maybe there is.

title: In Second, and Mulling an Olympic First
description: At a news conference a couple of hours after she finished second at the New York City Marathon, Shalane Flanagan hinted that she might compete in the United States marathon trials for the 2012 London Olympics.

title: Census Reports Money Transfers
description: The Census Bureau reported Monday that United States households transferred $11.7 billion to friends and family members abroad in the year that ended August 2008. Of those who transferred, 84 percent were foreign born, the bureau found. The amount of money was far lower than that reported by other organizations like the World Bank, which estimated that transfers from the United States totaled nearly $50 billion in 2008. An analyst with the bureau said the discrepancy stemmed in part from different ways of accounting. Aaron Terrazas of the Migration Policy Institute said illegal immigrants, a large source of money transfers, tended to be undercounted in census surveys.

title: After the Flash Crash, More Reasons for Anxiety
description: Since the financial world was set on edge on May 6 when the Dow Jones industrial average fell about 700 points and then largely recovered, similar flash crashes have occurred with alarming frequency, The New York Times reports. They have occurred in more than a dozen individual stocks.

title: Beware Bonds With High Risk and Low Protection
U.S. Report Faults Christie, as Prosecutor, on Hotel Stays
description: WASHINGTON  When he was a top federal prosecutor, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey routinely billed taxpayers for hotel stays whose cost exceeded government guidelines, according to a report the Justice Department released on Monday.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,357 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: DAntoni Fires Back at Report That He Criticized Ex-Knick Lee
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y. The Knicks are 3-3 and not in a position to overlook opponents. But on Monday, instead of being asked questions about the Milwaukee Bucks, whom the Knicks visit on Tuesday, Coach Mike DAntoni was asked about David Lees return to Madison Square Garden with the Golden State Warriors on Wednesday.

title: Obama Visits a Nation That Knew Him as Barry
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The two houses where he spent part of his boyhood stand pretty much the way they did when he went back to Hawaii four decades ago. The two schools he attended have grown larger but, in spirit, remain unchanged. Some of his old friends can still be found around the neighborhood.

title: Tax Cut Timing Is Proving Problematic for Democrats
description: WASHINGTON  When one party controls the White House and Congress, it controls the calendar for what gets done and when. So how is it that Democrats ended up in such a fix over what to do about the expiring Bush-era tax cuts?

title: The Impossible Dream
description: One of the most frustrating tendencies of mainstream leaders in the United States is their willingness, year after debilitating year, to embrace policies that have no hope of succeeding.

title: Would Deal for Lee Look Good at Age 38?
description: Say what you will about A. J. Burnett, whose erratic performance last season gave critics plenty to work with. But the biggest concern about Burnett before the Yankees signed him was health, and that has not been an issue. This is exactly what Darek Braunecker promised.

title: Britain and France Make a Deal
description: Britain and France last week announced that they would begin a new era of defense cooperation intended to conserve their military power at a time of shrinking military budgets. The plan involves sharing nuclear weapons research and other expensive weapons development programs, pooling aircraft carriers in times of crisis and jointly training rapid-reaction brigades that can fight side by side under a single commander.

title: Disciplinary Proceedings Begin for Contador
description: The International Cycling Union has asked Spanish cycling officials to begin disciplinary proceedings against the three-time Tour de France winner Alberto Contador, the Spanish rider who tested positive for a banned drug at the Tour more than three months ago.

title: Sibling Bond Strengthens Amid the Ordeal of Cancer
description: Justina Mejia has become fluent in the language of cancer.

title: Seasonal Slippage
description: Just about now, I remember that the trees on this farm will be bare for the next six months. It always comes as a surprise. The maples and hickories have mulched themselves with their own leaves, and they seem to have gone rigid now that they carry so much less sail in the wind. Everything that can die back has done so. The last of the woodchucks have gone down their burrows. The tide of dormancy is rising all around me, and on a rainy day with the woodstove going, I wonder whether Ill sink or swim.

title: The Return of the Risk Arbs
description: Keith M. Moore, a managing director at MKM Partners in Stamford, Conn.

title: U.S. Loss Reveals a Shrinking Talent Gap
description: In sports, it is always fascinating to watch Goliath struggle (unless you root for Goliath; some people do).

title: 2 Charged With Fraud of Millions From Pianist
description: In August 2004, Roger C. Davidson walked into a computer services shop on Main Street in Mount Kisco, N.Y., seeking help with his virus-plagued computer.

title: Azerbaijan: Ruling Party Takes Majority of Seats in Elections
description: The ruling party in Azerbaijan, a former Soviet republic led by a strongman president, dominated parliamentary elections on Sunday, according to preliminary results released Monday.

title: The Woe-Is-Us Books
description: Last week, as I was preparing a presentation for still another conference on the fate of the liberal arts in our time, two things happened.

title: Georgia to U.S.: Dont Tread on Me
Thrust Into the Glare by a Race She Wasnt Running In
description: As she rang in 2010, Susan Bysiewicz seemed unstoppable. Polls pointed to her as the favored Democrat to be Connecticuts next governor, a dream since her days at Yale, and she had begun mapping out exactly how she would change the state.

title: Spinning Art, or Money, Out of E-Mail
description: In 1994, a 31-year-old journalist trying to expand her connections began hosting parties for other media people. She started out poring over mastheads, inviting editors at various publications by phone, then, in time, by fax. Later, when e-mail became ubiquitous, she e-mailed 10 at a time through her AOL account, which was all that service allowed at the time.

title: Plucked From Their Web Writing to Promote a Vaseline Brand
description: IF youve been complaining about dry skin on the Internet, Vaseline may have heard you. With winter just around the corner, the brand is announcing a new advertising campaign for its Vaseline Intensive Rescue skin cream product, sold by Unilever. The campaign represents the first time Vaseline has used crowdsourcing to find product spokeswomen.

title: Lottery Numbers
Blame the Blue Dogs Theory for Democratic Losses Doesnt Add Up
description: WASHINGTON

title: Miller and Morgan Done on Sunday Night
description: ESPN ended its 20-year association with Jon Miller and Joe Morgan as the voices of Sunday Night Baseball on Monday. They declined to renew Morgans contract and have asked Miller if he wants to stay on as the radio voice of the Sunday night games. Discussions are continuing. Each announcer is a Hall of Famer. Morgan entered as a player in 1990, and Miller received the Ford C. Frick Award from the Hall of Fame this year in recognition of broadcasting excellence.

title: Warped Justice
description: In reaching a plea deal to end the prosecution of Omar Khadr, a former child soldier held at the Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, detention center, the Obama administration achieved its political goal of avoiding having this disturbing case be the first to go to trial under its revamped military commissions. But this is not a legal victory anyone can feel proud about.

title: Orchestras on Big Screens: Chase Scene Needed?
description: The performing arts have long been holdouts for unfiltered, direct connection between audiences and performers in a digitized, electronic and screen-laden world.

title: Midnight Deadline for 9/11 Settlement Nears
description: With a midnight deadline looming for more than 10,000 ground zero workers to opt into a multimillion-dollar settlement with the city and its contractors, a federal judge said it would take days to determine whether 95 percent of the workers had accepted the settlement  the threshold required for it to take effect. If ratified, the settlement, which would pay up to $712.5 million, would officially end the lawsuits by firefighters, police officers and others. Read about the settlement deadline on the Green blog.

title: Iran Rejects Accusations Regarding Nuclear Inspections
description: Iran rejected accusations on Monday that it is refusing to cooperate with United Nations inspectors seeking to determine whether it is developing nuclear weapons. The director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, Yukiya Amano, told the General Assembly that the Islamic republic had failed to provide the required cooperation to confirm that all the countrys nuclear material was for peaceful purposes.

title: After Vikings Rally Succeeds, Coachs Humor Fails
description: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn.  Cracking a joke that requires context can be tricky, especially for a coach whose job is a topic of national debate.

title: The Private Way Around the Checkpoints
description: I KNOW a lot of you will be interested in this tip, judging from the huge response I got to last weeks column on the new regime of even stricter security and more aggressive body pat-downs at airport checkpoints.

title: A Lack of Transparency in S.E.C. Disclosure Rule
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission headquarters.

title: Qantas to Keep A380s Grounded After Discovery of Oil Leaks
description: Qantas Airways will keep its fleet of six Airbus A380s grounded for at least another 72 hours after oil leaks were discovered in the engines of three planes, the companys chief executive said Monday.

title: A Blow to the Courts
description: Like the rest of this years political campaign, state judicial elections were awash in cash and blaring attack ads. The spectacle raises legitimate doubts about the impartiality of even the most respected judges.

title: Ryan Grasps for Ways to Reduce Jets Penalties
description: The Jets have won six of their first eight games, some more convincingly than others. Their 23-20 overtime victory Sunday over the Detroit Lions was not one of their most dominating efforts, but Coach Rex Ryan was happy that the team persevered. To a point.

title: Italy: Cardinals to Ponder Response By Church to Sexual Abuse Cases
description: More than 200 cardinals meeting at the Vatican later this month for a consistory to nominate 24 new cardinals will participate in a Nov. 19 day of reflection and prayer on pivotal issues facing the church, including its response to cases of clerical sexual abuse, the Vatican said in a statement on Monday. The discussion will also focus on religious freedom in the world, relations with other religions and procedures for accepting disaffected Anglicans into the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Remote in Hand, Manning Quietly Takes Control
description: Eli Manning brings the running backs together each Thursday for a meeting. Sometimes with a remote control in his hand, Manning stands before them and reviews game footage that he cut up and packaged, with members of the coaching staff looking on. Every Friday, Manning does the same with the receivers.

title: Salon Editor Leaving to Write Book
description: Salon, the Web site that helped found online journalism before many newspapers and magazines had even thought about the Internet, is changing editors.

title: Prosecution Closes in Trial of Detainee
description: Describing how a young Tanzanian man had joined a crew of terrorists inspired by Osama bin Ladens call to attack Americans anywhere in the world, a federal prosecutor asked a jury in closing arguments on Monday to convict him for his role in the deadly bombings of two United States embassies in East Africa.

title: DePodesta Sees Familiar Faces on Mets
description: The Mets put the finishing touches on a strong, intellectually based, Harvard-flavored front office Monday with the appointment of Paul DePodesta as the vice president for player personnel and amateur scouting.

title: Bloggingheads: Dealing With China
description: Heather Hurlburt, left, of the National Security Network and Eli Lake of The Washington Times discuss how the U.S. can influence China.

title: At Legal Fringe, Empty Houses Go to the Needy
description: NORTH LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Save Florida Homes Inc. and its owner, Mark Guerette, have found foreclosed homes for several needy families here in Broward County, and his tenants could not be more pleased. Fabian Ferguson, his wife and two children now live a two-bedroom home they have transformed from damaged and abandoned to full and cozy.

title: Licensing Fees the Main Topic of Oracle Testimony
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Lawrence J. Ellison, Oracles chief executive, added star power but no fireworks to a copyright infringement trial pitting his company against its rival SAP.

title: Repeal of Dont Ask, Dont Tell Faces Struggle in Congress
description: WASHINGTON  Prospects for Congress to authorize repeal of the dont ask, dont tell policy face new uncertainties as time runs out for the Senate to act and strong objections remain among Republicans and the most senior ranks of the military.

title: The Crossroads Nation
description: Bill Clinton used to talk about building a bridge to the 21st century. President Obama talks about laying down a new foundation. But Clinton was always vague about what the land on the other side of that bridge was going to look like, and Obama is vague about what edifice is going to go on top of that foundation.

title: Michael Seifert, SS Guard at Camp in Italy, Dies at 86
description: Michael Seifert had settled into a quiet retirement in Vancouver, British Columbia, living in a little white stucco house, gardening in the backyard. A former lumber mill worker, he had a seemingly pristine, if prosaic, background.

title: Flier Patience Wears Thin at Checkpoints
description: As the Transportation Security Administration scrambles to address vulnerabilities in procedures for screening cargo, it is facing growing criticism from travel industry groups over the escalating security measures for passengers.

title: Olbermann Offers Apology to Fans, but Not to MSNBC
description: In an aggressive statement questioning the legitimacy of his two-day suspension from MSNBC, Keith Olbermann told his fans Monday night that they were responsible for his scheduled return to the air on Tuesday after revelations that he had contributed to the campaign funds of three Democrats in last weeks election.

title: Tuesday: Meandering
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Back in September, we had a David J. Kahn puzzle where a ring of circles spelled out the first opera in Wagners Ring Cycle (Across Lite, Solution, blog.) Todays puzzle has a meandering path of circles spelling out an appropriate line from a poem in J.R.R. Tolkiens fantasy series, The Lord of the Rings. Who says that New York Times puzzles dont cater to the full cultural gamut?

title: Gay Couples to Sue Over U.S. Marriage Law
description: Joanne Pedersen tried to add her spouse to her federal health insurance on Monday. She was rejected. Again.

title: Chance Encounters of the Best Kind
description: I TRY to look at business travel as a great opportunity to have new experiences in different cities or countries. We all know that travel is a hassle and getting worse every day. But sometimes, the fates smile and travel brings some unexpected rewards.

title: Cheshire Case Jurors Speak on Death Verdict
description: NEW HAVEN  Day after day since Sept. 13, they sat in the jury box. They had to look at photographs of children who were burned while tied to their beds. They sat feet from grieving family members.

title: Convey, Former Boy Wonder, Turns Comeback Kid
description: 5:42 p.m. | Updated  On Wednesday, M.L.S. named Bobby Convey its comeback player of the year.

title: Kashmirs Fruits of Discord
description: New Delhi

title: A New Bush, a Lot Like the Old One
description: He said he still felt sickened that no weapons of mass destruction were ever found in Iraq. Yet former President George W. Bush said that his worst moment in the Oval Office came when the rap star Kanye West claimed that the president didnt care about black people.

title: Publishers to Get More Revenue Share From Amazons Kindle
description: Amazon.com said Monday that it would give magazine and newspaper publishers more of the revenue that it collects from the periodicals sold via the Kindle Store.

title: Howard Van Hyning, Percussionist and Gong Enthusiast, Dies at 74
description: Howard Van Hyning, a New York City Opera percussionist who long ago became entranced with a rare set of gongs constructed for Puccinis Turandot and eventually acquired them, allowing City Opera and other companies to perform the work as the composer intended, died on Oct. 30 at his home in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. He was 74.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Records Fall at Auction of Contemporary Masters
description: Crowds jostled and jammed their way into Phillips de Pury & Companys spanking-new Park Avenue salesroom on Monday night to watch as some contemporary masters, like Warhol and Murakami, topped expectations and others, like Cindy Sherman, Felix Gonzalez-Torres and Rudolf Stingel, brought record prices.

title: Voices: What's Next in Science
description: Here are prognostications for science in 2011 from 10 leading figures in 10 widely scattered disciplines, from genomics to mathematics to earth science.

title: Amazon Increases Kindle Royalties to Publishers
description: Amazon.com said Monday that it would give magazine and newspaper publishers more of the revenue that it collects from the periodicals sold via the Kindle Store.

title: Carl Sagan, an Astronomer Who Excelled at Popularizing Science, Is Dead at 62
description: Carl Sagan, an astronomer who became one of the nation's best-known scientists by enthusiastically conveying the wonders of the universe to millions of people on television and in books, died yesterday at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle. He was 62 and lived in Ithaca, N.Y.

The largest power failure in history blacked out nearly all of New York City, parts of nine Northeastern states and two provinces of southeastern Canada last night. Some 80,000 square miles, in which perhaps 25 million people live and work, were affected.

title: Publisher Is Chosen to Oversee Imprint at Penguin Group
description: David Rosenthal, the publisher who was ousted from Simon & Schuster in June, has been named the president and publisher of a new book imprint at Penguin Group USA, the publishing house said on Monday. He will begin in January.

title: Low Rates Hurt Bonds for Housing
description: It is not just retired savers who are struggling with a sharp reduction in their investment income as interest rates hover near zero. Hundreds of affordable housing projects across the country are feeling the pain, too.

title: New Winter Festival at Alice Tully Hall
description: Lincoln Center, which is still hip-deep in transcendence in its new White Light Festival, a wide-ranging exploration of spirituality in music and other art forms, will announce plans on Tuesday for a late-winter counterpart: the Tully Scope Festival, based in Alice Tully Hall and running from Feb. 22 to March 18. Intended to display the refurbished halls versatility, the festival will present relatively small-scale presentations spanning the centuries from the Baroque, in programs by William Christie and Les Arts Florissants (music of Rameau) and Jordi Savall and Hesprion XXI (music of Spain and Mexico), to the present, with Heiner Goebbelss semistaged concert work Songs of Wars I Have Seen, of 2007. The festival opens with For Morton Feldman, a two-concert celebration of the life and music of that American composer, including his late work For Samuel Beckett, with performances by the International Contemporary Ensemble, Axiom and the Clarion Choir, on Feb. 22 and 24. Les Percussions de Strasbourg will offer the New York premiere of Grard Griseys Noir de ltoile and a Xenakis program. The guitarist and singer Tyondai Braxton, above, and the Wordless Music Orchestra, and the kamancheh (a stringed instrument played with a bow) player Kayhan Kalhor and Brooklyn Rider present other contemporary programs. Roger Norrington conducts the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment in works of C.P.E. Bach. The pianist Louis Lortie plays Liszts Annes de Plerinage. And when Emanuel Ax performs Schubert piano works and songs (with the baritone Simon Keenlyside), transcendence is not beyond the realm of possibility.

title: F.D.A. Urges Two Steps for Safer CT Scans
description: The Food and Drug Administration has concluded that manufacturers of CT scanners should do a better job of training and educating those who use their equipment, and that the machines themselves could be made safer by warning operators that a dangerously high radiation dose is about to be administered.

title: Proficiency of Black Students Is Found to Be Far Lower Than Expected
description: An achievement gap separating black from white students has long been documented  a social divide extremely vexing to policy makers and the target of one blast of school reform after another.

title: Kno, a Tablet for College, to Debut at $599
description: We already knew that the Kno, a tablet computer designed for college students, would be bigger and heavier than Apples iPad. It will also be pricier.

title: IMG in Brazilian Sports Joint Venture
description: IMG Worldwide, the sports and entertainment giant, has formed a joint venture with the Brazilian conglomerate EBX Group to develop sports businesses in Brazil, the latest in a series of moves by IMG to push into the worlds fastest-growing economies.

title: Word of the Day | tawdry
