description: tawdry \t-dre, t-\ adjective

title: Conan Debuts, With Some Self-Mockery
description: Conan OBrien returned to late-night television Monday after a 10-month absence, with the host mocking his departure from NBC and his arrival on cable.

title: The Neediest Cases Fund: A Brief History
description: Adapted from an article in The New York Times.

title: News Quiz | November 9, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: The Neediest Cases Fund
description: For more than 100 years, The New York Times has asked readers for contributions to its Neediest Cases Fund, to give direct assistance to troubled children, families and elders. The first years contributions totaled $3,630.88. The total now is about $6 million a year, and over the years the Fund has raised more than $275 million.

title: Some Ran, Others Cheered
description: WHO were among those running in and watching the 2010 New York City Marathon?

title: Daily Lexeme: Thaumaturgy
description: Todays word, in association with the august Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Hochtief Loses Australian Front in Bid to Block Takeover
description: Germany may have killed the hopes for a deal in Australia, but it doesnt look like regulators in Canberra are ready to return the favor.

title: Test Yourself | English, Nov. 9, 2010
description: Test your grammar skills with todays question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the Times article Stories of Hope and Hardship of Los 33.

title: Barclays Profit Hit by Big Loss at Investment Banking
description: Barclays, the British bank, said Tuesday that its profit fell 76 percent in the third quarter from a year earlier, dragged down by an accounting charge at its investment banking unit that overshadowed a stable underlying picture.

title: Barclays Profit Hit by Big Loss at Investment Banking Unit
description: Barclays, the British bank, said on Tuesday that third-quarter profit fell more than 75 percent from a year earlier, dragged down by a loss at its investment banking unit.

title: Vodafone Selling Its Stake in Softbank
description: The Vodafone Group said on Tuesday that it expected 3.1 billion ($5 billion) from the sale of its stake in the Japanese mobile carrier Softbank.

title: When Privatization Increases Public Spending
description: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

title: Worldwide Dance Celebrated in Madrid
description: Most people think the only dance to be found in Spain is flamenco. But for more than 30 years, a contemporary dance scene has been developing, with Spanish choreographers producing rich and varied repertoires. Foreign companies are also finding enthusiastic audiences there.

title: On the Muzzle Brake of the AMD-65 and Other Reader Contributions
description: The At War blog is well past one year old now, and one of the most gratifying results of its brief but busy life has been the level of engagement it has drawn from readers. Material posted here, seemingly small or not prominently displayed (at least compared to a front-page treatment in the newspaper), routinely generates heavy e-mail feedback in addition to the comments visible under each post. For the staff that makes At War possible, reader feedback has produced many news and investigative tips, led to new sources and helped some of us learn new things.

title: In Global Forecast, China Looms Large as Energy User and Maker of Green Power
description: Chinas push for rapid economic development will dominate global energy markets and be the single biggest force in spurring higher oil prices and carbon emissions linked to climate change over the next quarter-century, the International Energy Agency reported on Tuesday.

title: How Do You Use Wikipedia?
description: According to Virginia Heffernan, who writes the column the Medium in The New York Times Magazine, Wikipedia has become an essential catalog, especially when it comes to digital artifacts and the Internet itself. Do you use Wikipedia? If so, what for, and why?

title: Pimco Chief: Feds Move Is Not Enough
description: Mohamed El-Erian, Pimcos chief executive, said in an interview with DealBook that the Federal Reserves decision to buy up to $600 billion in government bonds does not go far enough. The plan, informally known as QE2, could reduce the risk of deflation and a double-dip recession, but will fail to overcome an unusual period of low growth and stubbornly high unemployment that may linger for years.

title: Kindler, Yoga and the Art of Deal-Making
description: The irrepressible Robert A. Kindler, vice chairman and head of global mergers and acquisitions at Morgan Stanley, is a busy man these days, even in a slow market. In the past year he has advised CF Industries Holdings in its successful hostile offer for Terra Industries and its defense from an unsolicited Agrium offer; Qwest Communications in its $10.6 billion acquisition by CenturyLink; and Continental Airlines in its business combination with United Airlines.

title: China Bars Travel for 2 Rights Advocates
description: BEIJING  Two prominent legal scholars and rights advocates bound for an international law conference in London were blocked from leaving China on Tuesday on vague charges that their departure might endanger national security, they said.

title: The Early Word: Whither Dont Ask
description: From Todays Times:

title: Nick Folk Didnt Know He Had Won the Game
description: The Jets Nick Folk kicked the overtime winner against Detroit on Sunday as if he didnt feel the pressure of a game-deciding play. It turns out he didnt. He thought the Lions would get a possession if he made the kick. In the off-season, the N.F.L. changed its overtime rules for the postseason, not for the regular season, but Folk wasnt aware of that distinction.

title: Q&A: Getting Personal With AOL
description: Q.

title: A Presidential Visit Under the Volcano
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  It looks like the volcanic eruption in Indonesia could interfere with President Obamas visit after all.

title: The TV Watch: A Joyously Self-Referential Return to Late Night
description: Its official. TBS is the Sherwood Forest of late-night television, and Conan OBrien is its Robin Hood, leading his band of merry followers to basic cable to battle against the usurper host of The Tonight Show.

title: The Writing on the Wall
description: Entering the two genderless lavatories at the end of each night rekindles my faith in the creative spirit and the innate generosity of humankind, even when those humans may be sated or slightly smashed or flat-out crapulent. The bathroom walls  every square inch of all eight walls  are composed of blackboard and supplied with chalk in many colors in narrow channels along shallow shelves.

title: Editors Note: The New DealBook
description: Welcome to a whole new DealBook!

title: Glimpses of an Everyday Past in Iraq
description: I was greeted by snapshots when I first entered Iraq in 2003. Relatives clinging to snapshots of loved ones gone missing, pleading for help. Snapshots of family members killed in errant bombings, stained with the tears of grieving family members. Snapshots of happier times, proudly displayed by Iraqis kind enough to invite me into their homes.

title: In Myanmar, Opposition Concedes Defeat in Vote
description: BANGKOK  The main military-backed party won an overwhelming victory in the first election in 20 years in Myanmar, according to international news agency reports from inside the country, in a vote that was carefully engineered by the military to assure its continued grip on power.

title: Sanchez Says Jets Are His Only Girlfriend
description: It was a good line by Mark Sanchez.  In a Sunday Sitdown interview with the NFL Networks Steve Mariucci, he said the Jets were his only girlfriend. Viewers can decide how much of that was in jest, and some of it surely was.

title: Chevron to Buy Atlas Energy for $4.3 Billion
description: 8:41 a.m. | Updated Chevron announced on Tuesday that it would acquire Atlas Energy for $4.3 billion, including the assumption of debt, in the most recent deal by an energy company to expand in the natural gas sector.

title: Fed Move 'Not Enough'
description: The chief executive of Pimco, Mohamed El-Erian, says the Federal Reserve's decision to buy $600 billion in government bonds, called QE2, does not go far enough.

title: Sara Lee Selling Bakery Unit to Grupo Bimbo
description: Sara Lee said on Tuesday that it would sell its North American bakery unit for $959 million to Grupo Bimbo, the Mexican baking company. The deal is expected to close in the first half of 2011.

title: Bird Sleuths Stymied by Deformed Beaks
description: In the Pacific Northwest and Alaska, the United States Geological Survey is distributing flyers seeking to enlist bird watchers in the hunt for beak deformities that hint at the spread of a new disease or other as-yet unidentified environmental problem:

title: A Confronter of Killers Meets His Match
description: It was just three weeks ago that City Room caught up again with Philip Carlo, the writer who reveled in the darkest corners of the human psyche.

title: Bright Passages
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: Bright Passages
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: As His Receivers Fall, Philip Rivers Stands Alone
description: Chase Stuart contributes to the Pro-Football-Reference.com blog and to Footballguys.com.

title: Bush Is Back, but Too Late for Democrats
description: They say that in comedy, timing is everything. George W. Bush is proving that the same holds true for former presidents.

title: Cheap or Clean? The Energy Dilemma
description: As Tom Zeller Jr. and I wrote in Mondays Times, the recession has had a significant effect on renewable energy projects like wind farms. But it is not only wind energy that is suffering. As prices for conventional energy decline, so does interest in energy conservation and in nuclear plants, experts say.

title: Unesco Backs Off Philosophy Day in Iran
description: PARIS  The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization decided Tuesday to pull the plug on another embarrassment to its reputation, dissociating itself from this years celebration of philosophy, to be held in Iran in less than two weeks.

title: Who Says Palin Doesnt Read Newspapers?
description: 11:23 a.m. | Updated Remember the ribbing that former Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska took in the 2008 campaign about not being able to name a newspaper she reads?

title: Haughty-Culturists
description: Pretentious gardeners.

title: Google Introduces Visual Previews of Search Results
description: Even though most people think searching on Google is fast, Google is obsessed with shaving more milliseconds off the time it takes people to search.

title: A Summit on Aging Drivers
description: The car-keys discussion tends to light up the comments section whenever we post about it. The whole issue of older drivers  how safe they are or arent, how states should determine that, how families should respond when someone clearly seems a danger to himself and others  can be confounding, full of emotional overtones as well as pragmatic questions.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: The Cayman Islands predicts 1,200 new hedge funds will register there this year. Justice Department, take note.

title: Obama Pledges Expanded Ties With Muslim Nations
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  President Obama, renewing his call for better relations between the United States and the Muslim world, used a long-awaited homecoming trip to this island nation to make a symbolic visit on Wednesday morning to the largest mosque in southeast Asia  even as he declared that much more work needs to be done to fulfill the promise he made 17 months ago in Cairo of a new beginning.

title: Asked & Answered | Oriol Balaguer
description: If you ask the Spanish pastry chef and chocolatier Oriol Balaguer what he did before he opened his Chocolate & Confectionary Studio in Barcelona eight years ago  launching his eponymous brand a year later  hell tell you he was a sweets chef at a restaurant for seven years. It just so happens that restaurant is El Bulli. Because Balaguers a humble sort of genius, its not until you see his compositions or bite into one of his violet-cassis-filled dark-chocolate pods that you realize youre in the presence of a dessert deity. For those who cant access his freestanding boutiques in Barcelona, Madrid or Tokyo, New Yorks Borne Confections stocks the chocolate products (and, for the holiday season, the panettone). Thats where T caught up with him while he was in town for a certain event that celebrates his favorite things: design, architecture and, yes, gastronomy.

title: A Murderer Is Sentenced to Die
description: A jury  sentenced Steven J. Hayes to death on Monday for his part in a home invasion in Cheshire, Conn., in which a woman and her two daughters were killed, in a crime of such incomprehensible savagery and randomness that the trial upended a debate about capital punishment. [NYT] The sentencing followed trial that lasted nearly two months, during which jurors were exposed to images of depravity and horror no human being should have to see, as Judge Jon C. Blue of State Superior Court said while thanking them. (Also see The New York Post and The Wall Street Journal.)

title: Goldman Had Just 2 Down Trading Days in 3rd Quarter
description: Goldman Sachs reaped more than $75 million in trading revenue on 31 separate days in the third quarter, an impressive showing, but down from previous quarters this year.

title: We Are Not The World
description: A bit more on commodity prices: among other things, all of those pointing to rising commodity prices as a sign of runaway U.S. inflation seem oddly oblivious to the fact that commodity prices are a global phenomenon, driven by world demand  that the United States doesnt drive these things.

title: Markets Fall for a Second Day as the Dollar Improves
description: Stocks were mostly lower on Tuesday for a second straight session as the dollar strengthened and oil prices declined in late trading, eroding earlier gains in the energy sector.

title: Ryan Murphy Brings a Bullying Story to Glee
description: In the first five episodes of its sophomore season Glee has addressed topics as ephemeral as The Rocky Horror Picture Show and the music of Britney Spears, and as enduring as the nature of religious faith. In Tuesday nights installment it turns to subject matter that is timely and also substantial: the episode, called Never Been Kissed, finds Kurt Hummel (an openly gay character played by Chris Colfer) antagonized by a bully who harasses him because of his sexuality, and it addresses the consequences of Kurts decision to stand up to his tormentor.

title: New Haven, Seeking to Get More Students Into College, Will Pay Tuition
description: Public high school students in New Haven now have another reason to go to college: free tuition.

title: The Diplomacy of Cross-Border Bankruptcy
description: Provisions within the Dodd-Frank overhaul of financial regulations call for studying the possible creation of an international resolution authority to deal with institutions on the brink of collapse. Just how hard creating such a mechanism would be can be seen by the limited progress in this regard on the corporate bankruptcy side.

title: Will Zidane and Materazzi Ever Hug It Out?
description: The feel-good story of the week may just not be true. How sad. I had been so happy to read that Zinedine Zidane and Marco Materazzi had hugged and made up during an impromptu meeting in Milan last week.

title: G.M. Is Saying Goodbye to Mr. Goodwrench
description: For more than three decades, Goodwrench has been the name of the service department of General Motors dealers. Its ad mascot was Mr. Goodwrench, a pleasant, clean-cut mechanic (though he was played with more sass by Stephen Colbert in a series of commercials in 2003, including the one you can see above).

title: Confusion Over Program to Spot Illegal Immigrants
description: In 2008, the Bush administration announced an ambitious new program to help federal officials detain and deport illegal immigrants held on criminal charges by using fingerprints collected by local police departments.

title: Tuesday Reading: Medical Residents and Taxes
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Plug My Ride
description: It used to be much simpler to earn your environmental stripes, but these days anything short of brewing your own biodiesel gets you dirty looks in yoga class. At least Hertz is making things a little easier. Beginning in late December, customers in New York, Washington, D.C., and San Francisco, and on select college campuses, will be able to rent a Nissan Leaf, the first mass-market, zero-emissions electric car. The Leaf can go about 100 miles on a full charge, so if youre planning on roving into the wilderness of no charging stations (Hertz is working on building an infrastructure of stations nationwide), youre better off with the slightly less saintly hybrids, like Priuses and Volts, also available. Rest assured, for those vacationing without a vegan or a sense of environmental outrage, there is still fun to be had: Mustangs, Sebrings and Caddies galore. Go to hertz.com.

title: For Tepper, Washington Is an Investment Guide
description: The hedge fund manager David Tepper has done well again by betting on the moves of Washington.

title: HCA Plans $2 Billion Dividend
description: HCAs private equity owners are getting another big payday.

title: Fela! Is Sued for Copyright Infringement
description: 11:19 a.m. | Updated

title: The Myth of Record-High Gold
description: Note: The original, shorter version of this post has been restored below. A longer version appeared in Wednesdays edition of The Times.

title: Without Lifers Like Jeter, Yankees Lose Their Aura
description: No major league team is more conscious or protective of its history than the Yankees. They have won 27 World Series and created the YES Network, which never replays a classic game they lost.

title: Now on Taxi TV: Salvo in Terror-Trial Debate
description: The television in a New York City taxicab is a good place to get an update on the weather or learn about a new tourist attraction. It is also, starting Tuesday, a medium for one of citys most contentious political debates.

title: Pablo Schreiber, Jennifer Carpenter in Gruesome Playground Injuries
description: One of the more challenging acting assignments of this Off Broadway season, Rajiv Josephs romantic drama Gruesome Playground Injuries, has cast the roles of two self-sabotaging childhood friends who jump back and forth in time between the ages of 8 and 38. Pablo Schreiber, a Tony Award nominee for the 2006 revival of Awake and Sing!, will play the manic Doug, and Jennifer Carpenter, who stars on the Showtime series Dexter as the title characters sister Debra Morgan, will play the pained Kayleen in the New York premiere at Second Stage Theater this winter, publicists for the show said on Tuesday.

title: The Morning Report: Chevrons Natural Gas Play
description: Welcome to The Morning Report, where you can find everything you need to know in the world of deal-making at a glance. Tuesdays big stories include:

title: Tuesday: Can We Do This Net 30?
description: This week, as I explained on Friday, Im writing daily posts about my experiences during a recent week trying to collect money from my customers.

title: Cholera Moves Into the Beleaguered Haitian Capital
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  A cholera outbreak that had been largely confined to the countryside has now begun to spread in the teeming capital filled with overcrowded, unsanitary earthquake survivor camps, prompting the authorities on Tuesday to brace for a more severe epidemic than previously thought.

title: Wells Vegetarian Thanksgiving 2010
description: Delicious no-meat recipes for your holiday table from some of your favorite chefs and cookbook authors.

title: Movie Studios Support Debut of Conan on TBS
description: The executives at TBS who sell commercial time during Conan, their new show with Conan OBrien, ought to be breaking out in a chorus or two of Hooray for Hollywood.

title: How Do You Advise Your Child to Slow Down, and Wait?
description: For Nicole and many of her peers, the college waiting game has officially begun. These next five weeks until Dec. 15  the day she learns the fate of her early decision application  will, I imagine, pass very slowly. But Nicole is hardly sitting back, watching the clock tick with her feet up on her desk. Life as a high school senior is full steam ahead, kind of.

title: Czech Transport Minister Loses Drivers License
description: The transportation minister for the Czech Republic has been banned from driving for six months and fined 5,000 Czech crowns (or $283) for driving with a fake license plate on his Maserati,  The Associated Press reported.

title: Pelosi and the Rayburn Precedent
description: Democrats who support Nancy Pelosis bid to remain her partys leader in the House  over the objection of more conservative Democrats  have been pointing to a historical precedent. The legendary Sam Rayburn of Texas did stay on as minority leader after Democrats lost control of the House in 1946 and again in 1952, and no Democratic speaker has faced a similar dilemma since. (Tom Foley of Washington had the job in 1994 when Democrats were turned out and he lost his bid for a 15th term.)

title: Gant Brings Back That Yalie Preppy Look
description: Gant, the ne plus ultra of preppy attire, is going back to its roots and setting up shop in one of New Havens most historic buildings. Opening on Nov. 22, the Gant Campus Store  set in the site of the former Langrock Fine Clothes mens department store  will house a selection of Gant, Gant Rugger and Gant by Michael Bastian. The Gant brand is also working with Yale for a spring re-release of the defunct Yale Co-op shirt collection, which was manufactured during the 1960s. (Every card-carrying Yalie owned at least one of these Co-op shirts back in the day.) The Moment caught up with the Gant president and chief executive, Ari Hoffman, to find out more about the homecoming.

title: Food Photography: To Illustrate or Not?
description: On Monday, Melissa Clark (@goodappetite) posted a question on Twitter about whether or not cookbooks should contain pictures.Matt Armendariz (@mattarmendariz), a food blogger and photographer, took a poll on the matter. I weighed in wondering if the opinions I shared with Times readers in an article I wrote on this very issue five years ago should be revised. I asked if, with the increase of people taking pictures of their prepared food, cookbook authors would be wise to include pictures to provide reference for budding shutterbugs. Since many of you come here to learn about taking better food pictures, I would love to know what you all think. Should cookbooks always include photography or not? Please post your thoughts here.

title: Will Florida Governor Pardon Morrison Before the Musics Over?
description: As Charlie Crist walks on down the hall to the end, beautiful friend, of his term as governor of Florida, he still has a few items on his agenda. Among them: the possibility that he could pardon Jim Morrison, the lead singer of the Doors, for convictions stemming from a 1969 concert appearance in Miami.

title: Obama and China Play Rival Suitors to Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Less than a day before President Obama touched down in Jakarta on Tuesday, a high-level Chinese delegation wrapped up a three-day official visit here by announcing that Beijing would invest $6.6 billion in desperately needed infrastructure improvements. The announcements emphasis on roads, bridges and canals  not to mention its timing  laid down a not-so-subtle challenge to Mr. Obama: Show your Indonesian hosts the money.

title: Inflation Delusions
description: Wow  so the official right-wing line seems to be that all the talk about falling inflation is a leftist plot  that real people know that prices of real things like groceries are soaring. I should have guessed that from the ravings of our resident troll (singular  internal evidence suggests that there is only one).

title: SunChips War Spreads to Canada
description: In early October, Frito-Lay said it was scaling back its effort to replace the conventional packaging for its SunChips brand with a compostable, plant-based bag in the United States.

title: Talking With Depression-Era Parents About Money
description: Many people who lived through the Great Depression tend to view money through aprism thats different from the rest of us. They may be less willing to openly talk about financial matters, experts say, or they may simply prefer to keep their affairs to themselves.

title: Let the Kvetching Begin
description: The N.H.L.s annual general managers meeting is taking place in Toronto today, and several of the biggest front office names will be arriving with plenty on their mind. All indications are that they could be in for a long day.

title: Jordanians Go to Polls Under Cloud Of a Boycott
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Voters went to the polls in Jordan on Tuesday in a parliamentary election that was boycotted by the countrys main opposition group. The vote is likely to bolster allies of the Jordanian monarchy, but it could also deepen alienation from the political process.

title: Boone Plots Different Path Back to N.B.A.
description: The former N.B.A. center Josh Boone hopes hes on the road less traveled back to the league. Boone, who played four seasons for the Nets, couldnt find a guaranteed gig the N.B.A. this year.

title: Using Poetry as a Way to Survive
description: A series of recent documentaries about education have offered clear-cut narratives about how to save Americas schools, through policies like increased school choice, or freeing schools from their bureaucratic shackles. But a new education film that made its premiere this weekend has a different aim: it wants to show how hard change actually is.

title: Jack Levine, a Painter Who Twinned Realism and Satire, Dies at 95
description: Jack Levine, an unrepentant and much-admired realist artist whose crowded history paintings skewered plutocrats, crooked politicians and human folly, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 95.

title: Fab Confab | IHT Luxury Conference
description: The International Herald Tribune is hosting its 10th annual luxury conference today and tomorrow. In keeping with previous conferences, the IHT has chosen a theme that captures the fashion mood of the moment. This time round, the focus is on heritage and, not surprisingly, the event is being held in London. Suzy Menkes, the IHT fashion editor for the past 22 years, is grilling speakers like Alber Elbaz, Karl Lagerfeld, David Lauren and Christopher Bailey on far-ranging topics, including whether luxury brands need a history to have a future and how quality and craftsmanship can be meaningful in the era of fast fashion. In the video above, Elbaz reveals how his own heritage is defined by something his mother once told him: be big in work but small in life.

title: What Were Reading
description: Financial Times: Jancis Robinson on what oak barrels do to wine, obviously and less obviously, and how fashion for oaky flavors is changing.  Eric Asimov

title: Money in Piracy Attracts More Somalis
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The monsoon season has ended. The Indian Ocean is calm again. For Somalias pirates, that means one thing: it is a busy time of year.

title: Some Companies Shift Health Costs to Better-Paid
description: With health care costs climbing even higher during this enrollment season, more employers are adopting a tiered system to pass on the bulk of those costs to their employees by assigning bigger contributions to workers in top salary brackets and offering some relief to workers who make less money.

title: Cowboys Bad Decisions Add Up Under Jones
description: With Jerry Jones, the Cowboys owner, finally dropping the inevitable coaching ax on Wade Phillips, a decision he arrived at weeks after everyone else, including his players, mentally cleaned out Phillipss office, you may join the voting on what ranks as the worst of Joness decisions. The list is so long that the doomed hiring of Phillips is currently somewhere around No. 10.

title: Higher Pay, Higher Insurance Costs
description: With employers asking workers to bear an increasing share of the burden of higher health care costs, some companies are trying to spare their lowest-paid workers.

title: No Criminal Charges Sought Over C.I.A. Tapes
description: WASHINGTON  Central Intelligence Agency officials will not face criminal charges for the destruction of dozens of videotapes depicting the brutal interrogation of terrorism suspects, the Justice Department said Tuesday.

title: Has Attachment Parenting Imprisoned Mothers?
description: As promised, more discussion about the essay by Erica Jong in this weekends Wall Street Journal. I found it to be a mishmash of old accusations against overinvolved parenting. Katie Allison Granju is the author of the book

title: In Curt Exchange, U.S. Faults Israel on Housing
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas criticism of new Israeli housing plans for East Jerusalem, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahus even sharper retort, have thrown the Middle East peace talks into jeopardy, with the dispute over Jewish settlements looming as a seemingly insuperable hurdle.

title: What Jim Webb Didnt Do
description: As an example of the kind of centrist failure I was talking about yesterday, heres David Paul Kuhn interviewing Senator Jim Webb, Democrat of Virginia:

title: Your Friends Are Making You Fat and Lazy
description: Your friends are making you fat and lazy, according to a new working paper.

title: The Annual Discussion: Wines for Thanksgiving
description: Over at Saignee, one of my favorite wine blogs, the proprietor, Cory Cartwright, is letting off an amusing amount of steam. Basically, he feels hes surrounded by Thanksgiving idiots, offering the same trite wine suggestions they foist onto the populace each year.

title: Will Crist Pardon Jim Morrison Before the Musics Over?
description: As Charlie Crist walks on down the hall to the end, beautiful friend, of his term as governor of Florida, he still has a few items on his agenda. Among them: the possibility that he could pardon Jim Morrison, the lead singer of the Doors, for convictions stemming from a 1969 concert appearance in Miami. Dave Itzkoff has more on ArtsBeat

title: A Gluten-Free Thanksgiving
description: When Silvana Nardones son Isaiah was diagnosed with gluten intolerance three weeks before Thanksgiving, the Brooklyn mom knew she faced a particularly challenging holiday meal. But as the owner of a bakery and founding editor of the food magazine Every Day With Rachel Ray, Ms. Nardone was up to the challenge.

title: Skewering Plutocrats and Human Folly
description: The realist artist died Jack Levine died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 95.

title: Oh, Zarkana': New Cirque du Soleil Show Gets a Suitably Weird Name
description: Cirque du Soleil, the Montreal-based circus company whose show titles have given us such linguistic innovations as K, Kooz and Zaia, has arrived at a name for the new acrobatic production it will open next year at Radio City Music Hall. And that name is

title: From 45th St. Perch, Watching Musicals Come and Go
description: Late September, Saturday, 8 a.m. A deep sleep is interrupted by what sounds like the worlds largest vacuum cleaner, and then cries of alarm: Watch it! Watch it!

title: Retweet | Karl on Coco
description: One of many gems by Karl Lagerfeld at the International Herald Tribunes annual luxury conference, currently in session:

title: TimesCast | November 9, 2010
description: Obama's visit to Indonesia cut short; U.S. marriage law challenged and Conan back on the airwaves.

title: Goldman Fined $650,000 for Lack of Disclosure
description: The Wall Street firm Goldman Sachs learned in mid-2009 that one of its traders had been formally notified by the Securities and Exchange Commission that he was the subject of an investigation. But Goldman did not tell other regulators about the inquiry for about seven months, a violation of securities regulations.

title: Indonesian Minister Blames Michelle Obama for Handshake
description: Immediately after a ceremony on Tuesday welcoming President Obama to Indonesia, the countrys conservative Muslim information minister took to Twitter to argue that Americas first lady, Michelle Obama, was entirely to blame for a televised handshake between the two that has left him open to charges of hypocrisy.

title: Newton Faced Suspension at Florida
description: The redemptive narrative of Auburn quarterback Cam Newton, the front-runner for the Heisman Trophy, has taken another turn.

title: Notes from the Underground | Alexander Cowings
description: The multi-talented Alexander Cowings brought together several forms of performance in his explosive show at the Producers Club in midtown Manhattan. Joined by the dancer Calvin Booker, the two performed the seldom-seen art of hip hop tap, championed by Savion Glover in the 1990s with the hit show Bring In Da Noise, Bring In Da Funk. Cowings crooned a number of original R&B diddies, backed by a live band of drums, electric guitar, and stand-up bass, marking intervals in the music with furious bursts of tap dancing. The evening ended with a powerful performance by Cowingss mother, Kim Kalesti, and an open tap jam.

title: Q&A: New York Options for a Christmas Shopper
description: I will be traveling by myself to Manhattan in the first part of December to Christmas shop. I like the area near the Plaza Hotel for its proximity to concerts and good restaurants. Can you recommend restaurants where I would be comfortable dining alone, and some lodging and cultural locations? No limit on expenses.

title: Behavior: Too Much Texting Is Linked to Other Problems
description: A study suggests that the high school students who spend the most time texting or on social networking Web sites (or both) are at risk for worrisome behaviors including smoking, risky sex, depression, eating disorders, drug and alcohol abuse and absenteeism.

title: The S.E.C., Whistle-Blowers and Sarbanes-Oxley
description: Congress seems to love whistle-blowers.

title: 'Long Story Short'
description: Colin Quinn in an excerpt from his new Broadway show, directed by Jerry Seinfeld. (Video courtesy of the production)

title: Broadway Theaters to Dim Lights for Clayburgh
description: When Broadways 40 theaters dim their marquees at 7 p.m. Tuesday to honor the life and acting career of Jill Clayburgh, who died on Friday, one house will stand out more than the others: The Broadhurst, where Ms. Clayburghs daughter, Lily Rabe, is now giving a critically acclaimed performance as Portia in The Merchant of Venice. Ms. Rabe took time off last week to be with her mother and father, the playwright David Rabe, and family members but returned to the production Saturday night.

title: Mother Charged With Murder in Death of Malnourished Girl
description: The mother of a drugged and malnourished 4-year-old girl who weighed 18 pounds when she died in September has been indicted on murder charges, Brooklyn prosecutors said Tuesday.

title: Honoring the Presidents Mother
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  President Obama was welcomed as a hometown boy made good  exceedingly good  when he arrived here Tuesday afternoon. But long before he became president, his mother, Stanley Ann Dunham, touched many lives in Indonesia, where she worked as an anthropologist, becoming a pioneer in microfinance and creating services like credit and savings for the poor.

title: American Speech: Jargon of Fistiana (1933)
description: by Robert E. Creighton

title: In Its First Night, Conan Is a Champion
description: In what is almost certainly the largest audience that has ever tuned in for a television appearance by the curator of the Leavenworth Nutcracker Museum, the debut of Conan, the new late-night show starring Conan OBrien, got off to a strong start Monday night. In his first outing on TBS at 11 p.m., Mr. OBrien (who, you may have heard, had a network gig before moving to basic cable) drew an estimated 4,155,000 viewers, according to TBS.

title: Recipes for Health: Salads
description: Browse a variety of healthy salad recipes.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Thailand and Saudi Arabia.

title: Mitsubishi Reveals U.S. i-MiEV Ahead of L.A. Auto Show
description: When Mitsubishi said it was planning on bringing its i-MiEV electric car to America, you were probably thinking what I was thinking  yeah, right. The tiny car, which has been available in Japan since last year, is slightly bigger than a fish tank and about as attractive as a walrus  not to mention its odd name.

title: ArtsBeat: In Its First Night, Conan Is a Champion
description: Dave Itzkoff reports that the debut of Conan, the new late-night show starring Conan OBrien, got off to a strong start Monday night. In his first outing on TBS at 11 p.m., Mr. OBrien (who, you may have heard, had a network gig before moving to basic cable) drew an estimated 4,155,000 viewers, according to TBS.

title: 3 Senators Renew Call to End Dont Ask
description: With the effort to repeal the militarys dont ask, dont tell policy facing uncertain prospects in Congress, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, the Connecticut independent, and two Senate Democrats, Mark Udall of Colorado and Kirsten Gillibrand of New York, on Tuesday reiterated their call for allowing gay soldiers to serve openly.

title: Former Glaxo Lawyer Indicted
description: A former vice president and associate general counsel for the British pharmaceutical company GlaxoSmithKline has been indicted on charges of making false statements and obstructing a federal investigation into illegal drug marketing, the Justice Department announced on Tuesday.

title: E.P.A. Subpoenas Halliburton on Fracking
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said Tuesday it had subpoenaed Halliburton for information on the chemicals it uses for hydraulic fracturing, a natural gas drilling technique involving the high-pressure injection of water, sand and chemicals deep underground to break up rock formations.

title: Black Caucus Opens Door to Republicans
description: The Congressional Black Caucus has a message for a pair of black Republicans newly elected to the House: Our doors are open.

title: A Room With a Broadway View
description: Steve Kenny, in a new About New York column, takes a look inside an apartment on West 45th Street, near Eighth Avenue, with a great view of the Al Hirschfeld Theater, where the new musical Elf is in previews.

title: Wall St. Fuels a Rise in Wages in Manhattan
description: Illustrating just how much faster Wall Street rebounded from the recession than the rest of New York Citys economy did, the federal Department of Labor reported Tuesday that wages rose by nearly 12 percent in Manhattan at the beginning of the year, even as they fell in every other borough. (See report here.)

title: The Morning Skate: Is the Shootout in Danger?
description: Lots of the buzz surrounding todays meeting of N.H.L. general managers concerns the proposal by Floridas Dale Tallon to institute a coachs challenge. One reason that proposal has gotten so much attention is that it was sparked by a game involving the Maple Leafs and anything involving the Maple Leafs is almost guaranteed to generate a disproportionate amount of buzz.

title: 'The Four Brooklyns'
description: An excerpt from the workshop of "In the Footprint" (formerly known as "Brooklyn at Eye Level"), performed by the composer Michael Friedman at the Brooklyn Lyceum in 2008. (Video courtesy of the Civilians)

title: Broadway Has Told the Story of the Scottsboro Boys Before
description: The new Kander and Ebb musical  The Scottsboro Boys at the Lyceum Theater is not the first time that the harrowing tale of nine African-American youths falsely convicted of rape in 1931 Alabama has been presented on Broadway. The author and screenwriter John Wexley [pdf] dramatized the story in a 1934 play, They Shall Not Die, [pdf] that was produced by the Theater Guild and staged at the Royale Theater (now known as the Bernard B. Jacobs).

title: DeMint and Cornyn Work Together This Time
description: Senator John Cornyn of Texas could be excused for being a bit peeved at his fellow Republican senator, Jim DeMint of South Carolina.

title: Apartment Therapy | Creative Growth at Manhattan House
description: Nothing says If you lived here, youd be home now like a model apartment. But with a glut of new apartments gathering dust bunnies on the market, real estate developers are upping the ante on the marketing tool.

title: Success at Different Speeds
description: Lets be clear: you should not ask to solve the puzzle with only one letter on the board, even if you do have a very good feeling about the answer.

title: Political Polls and Pundits: Parsing the Midterm Election Results
description: Overview | What do the 2010 midterm election results mean for the country? What can exit poll data tell us about how Americans are thinking about politics and government? In this lesson, students closely examine the exit polling data and analysts interpretations to better understand the midterm election results.

title: Head of Cooper-Hewitt Wins British Design Award
description: Bill Moggridge, the director of the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum in Manhattan, and the man who designed the first commercial laptop computer in 1982, was awarded the 2010 Prince Philip Designers Prize by Britains Design Council on Tuesday. Mr. Moggridge, who assumed his post at the Cooper-Hewitt in March, is the first designer to lead the museum, which is part of the Smithsonian Institution.

title: G-20 Expected to Endorse Bank Rules
description: BASEL, Switzerland  The Group of 20 is expected to endorse new capital requirements for the worlds banks this week, even as banking groups assert that they will undercut bank profits, hurt lending and eliminate jobs.

title: E.U. Fines 11 Airlines Over $1 Billion in Cargo Cartel
description: BRUSSELS  The European Commission on Tuesday fined 11 airlines and air carriers a total of 799.5 million for participating in an air cargo cartel.

title: Bloomingdales and Penney Join Holiday Ad Throngs
description: With Halloween past and Thanksgiving on the way, Bloomingdales and J.C. Penney are sharing their plans to woo consumers for the Christmas shopping season.

title: For Dieters, the Advice Never Ends
description: Over the years in my quest to lose weight, friends, family members and, most recently, readers of this blog, have been generous with their advice. They tell me, often with a passion that borders on the fanatical, that the key to weight loss is (fill in the blank).

title: E.U. Signals Tough World Trade Policy
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union signaled on Tuesday that it would pursue a more aggressive trade policy, including bringing more cases to the World Trade Organization and negotiating more bilateral deals with countries like India and those in Southeast Asia.

title: Nike's 'Girl Effect' Video
description: A video from Nike challenges conventional poverty campaigns.

title: Five Jobless Workers Per Opening in September
description: There were five unemployed workers available for every job opening in the United States in September, according to a Labor Department report released today. The ratio rose slightly from August but has generally been trending downward since the recession ended in June 2009.

title: Hearst Official to Replace Klein at Helm of City Schools
description: Read the latest version of this article that appeared in the newspaper.

title: HCAs Owners Reap Handsome Returns
description: Remember those halcyon days of 2005 to 2007, when private equity firms routinely snapped up companies for $10 billion or more? Heres a question: Today, more than three years after the credit crisis closed the window on the these so-called megabuyouts, whats the most successful of the lot?

title: With New Mantra, Raiders Rise Again
description: ALAMEDA, Calif.  Nothing was going right for Oakland quarterback Jason Campbell against the Kansas City Chiefs. After another mistake-marred possession in the first half of his biggest game as a Raider, Campbell sat slumped on the bench.

title: Charting Chinas Energy Explosion
description: If your gasoline and electricity bills go up in the years to come, and you want to blame someone other than yourself, a new report by the International Energy Agency has some ammunition for you.

title: World Trade Center Waterfall
description: Water has begun flowing, on a test basis, in the north pool of the National September 11 Memorial at Ground Zero.

title: He Doesnt Need Sheet Music. He Can Fake It.
description: The mayor loves the piano, he has said in the past. Thats why he doesnt play it.

title: A123 Batteries Slated for Chinese Electric Car
description: A123 Systems ofMassachusettssaid Tuesday that its lithium-ion batteries were going into a new subcompact electric sedan to be introduced in 2012 by SAIC Motor, among the largest automakers in China.

title: Called the Boss Unqualified? Not Me, Says Olbermann
description: Keith Olbermann, host of the MSNBC program Countdown,called the publication of a supposed e-mail exchange between him and a Philadelphia columnist, Stu Bykofsky,a fraud on Tuesday.

title: China Looms Large in Luxury Industry's Vision
description: LONDON  When Chinese shoppers stride into a Gucci store these days, they had better be shown the highest quality of the couturiers haute de gamme.

title: A Single Site for Online Shopping Discounts
description: By shopping in the online malls of credit card issuers, hotels and airlines, you can earn loyalty program reward points or cash back for your purchases.

title: Sergeant Accused of Killing Afghan Civilians Faces Hearing
description: JOINT BASE LEWIS-McCHORD, Wash.  A lawyer for the Army staff sergeant accused of being the ringleader in the killings of three Afghan civilians tried to cast doubt on the charges Tuesday at a hearing that will determine whether the soldier faces a court-martial.

title: Now Showing | Visible Panty Line
description: Part old-school gymnasium, part downtown gallery, the first VPL store from the British designer and former stylist Victoria Bartlett is further evidence that the label with a funny name  VPL is short for Visible Panty Line  is a serious concern. Bartlett says she chose the eclectic interior, which brings to mind onesie-clad musclemen doing chin-ups, in order to evoke a vintage gymnasium, since the VPL aesthetic was originally based on vintage undergarments. Besides, she adds with a nudge, Im inspired by a life well-lived  Im not stuck on minimalism.

title: In Iquitos, Turning Science Into Words
description: Saturday, Nov. 6

title: News Corp. Reels In a Top Educator
description: 4:39 p.m. | Updated Rupert Murdochs News Corporation, signaling an interest in education, has hired Joel Klein, the New York City schools chancellor, as an executive vice president.

title: Photo Replay: Nov. 9
description: A view of the day in sports, including the womens world volleyball championships in Japan.

title: Like Parent, Like Child
description: Theres an adorable photo of my mother, cracked and faded by now, (the photo, not my mother), sitting in a wash bucket (yes, it was empty) next to which was propped a mop. She was maybe 9 months old.

title: Stephen Starr to Open an Italian Restaurant in the New-York Historical Society
description: Yet another well-known food personage is bringing an haute Italian restaurant to a historic institution on the Upper West Side.

title: Report Suggests Rise in Shareholder Activism
description: Many executives are preparing for what could be a rough ride amid growing concern that shareholder activism will intensify in the next 12 months.

title: Paterson Wants New York to Slash Greenhouse Gases
description: After a 10-month study, Gov. David A. Paterson is leaving his successor an ambitious environmental plan to reduce New Yorks greenhouse gas emissions by 80 percent by the middle of the century.

title: What Were Reading: Paying to Turn Traffic Lights Green
Poll: The Economy Trumps Health Care
description: Its not health care, stupid, its the economy.

title: The Clash of the Interdealer Brokers
description: The rough-and-tumble world of interdealer brokers just got a bit uglier.

title: For California, a Rebuff on 2 Pollution Plans
description: When it comes to airborne pollutants, small particulates are recognized as the worst of the bunch. In California alone, state estimates indicate, more than 9,000 people die prematurely each year from exposure to the deadly soot.

title: Dont Ask, Dont Tell: Dont Lose Focus on the Mission
description: The author is an active-duty Marine sergeant in his mid-20s. He enlisted in 2002, served two tours in Iraq, and is now back in the United States, where he is a member of OutServe, an organization of gay and lesbian members of the United States armed services. He has asked that his name not be published.

title: The Future of Mining Under the Sea
description: Tuesday's Science Times is a special issue on the year ahead in science, including a story on mining for rare earth elements under the sea.

title: Metropolitan Museum to Revamp Its Plaza
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art plans to undertake a multiyear redesign and renovation of its plaza on Fifth Avenue and said it had selected a landscape architecture firm, OLIN, to lead the project. In a telephone interview the Mets director, Thomas P. Campbell, said that the need to replace the museums two fountains, which have been turned off for several years, led to a broader discussion of the plazas layout. Obviously the front steps are one of the great gathering points in New York, but the rest of the space is perhaps less successful, he said. Apart from the steps, he said, the rest of the space, including the fountains, would be completely rethought. He would not specify a budget but said, Obviously, its going to be an expensive undertaking. A museum trustee, David H. Koch, has pledged $10 million for the project. The Met expects to complete the renovation by 2015.

title: Voting Was Smoother on Election Day, Council Finds
description: Following the mishaps with the new computerized system that marred voting during the primary election, the City Council decided to ask voters about their experience on Election Day.

title: Teachers Death Exposes Tensions in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES  Colleagues of Rigoberto Ruelas were alarmed when he failed to show up for work one day in September. They described him as a devoted teacher who tutored students before school, stayed with them after and, on weekends, took students from his South Los Angeles elementary school to the beach.

title: The Dress Finally Fits: Harvey Fierstein to Star in La Cage aux Folles
description: Harvey Fiersteins two Tony Awards for best actor resulted from his signature talent playing women, as the drag artist Arnold Beckwith in his play Torch Song Trilogy (1982) and as house frau Edna Turnblad in the musical Hairspray (2002). He also won a Tony in 1984 for writing the book of the musical La Cage aux Folles, which centered on the drag performer Albin, a role that won Tonys for George Hearn in the original La Cage and for Douglas Hodge in the current Broadway revival.

title: The Yosemite Photographers
description: Photographs by Earl Brooks, A. C. Pillsbury, Harry Pidgeon and Ansel Adams.

title: Ansel Adams or Not? More Twists
description: In the beginning, there was just Rick Norsigian, a California man who announced in July that he believed that he had purchased lost negatives of Ansel Adams for $45 at a garage sale.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Thailand and Saudi Arabia.

title: An Alternative to Alternate-Side Parking Rules
description: Every New Yorker has seen them or been one of them: motorists napping in cars idling in the street, or maybe knitting a sweater or reading Moby Dick while waiting for the alternate-side parking prohibition to end.

title: All Orbs but No Surrender at This End of the Rainbow
description: As a self-described terrestrial person whose feet are firmly planted on the earth, the singer Jane Scheckter marvels at the longtime fascination of songwriters with heavenly orbs, especially the moon. Seven songs in her new show, The Moon, the Stars, Albert Einstein and Love, have moon in the title, and seven others have star or stars. There is also a rainbow, a stairway to paradise and Never Never Land.

title: Los Angeles on Two Wheels
description: Although known for its car culture, the city can be managed on a bike.

title: Los Angeles on $100 a Day
description: WHEN I told people I was visiting Los Angeles for a week without setting foot in a car, one word came up more than any other: impossible.

title: How a Little Man Became a Big, Big Marine in World War II and Beyond
description: When the legendary Marine Corps general Victor Krulak was a boy, his father, a jeweler, gave him two pieces of advice. The first was: Nobody ever learned a bad habit from a horse. The second: You will be short, and you will be bald. But you dont have to be fat.

title: Bubbles of Energy Are Found in Galaxy
description: Something big is going on at the center of the galaxy, and astronomers are happy to say they dont know what it is.

title: Turkey: Europe Seeks Changes on Speech Freedoms
description: Turkey must make strides in safeguarding freedom of speech and of the press if it wants to join the European Union, says a report released Tuesday on the countrys progress in complying with the unions standards. Among the examples cited in the European Commissions report were a multibillion-dollar tax penalty on a media group that has been critical of the government and the jailing of more than 100 journalists under a law that limits criticism of the state.

title: Russia: Beaten Journalist Now Faces Slander Charge
description: Prosecutors pressed criminal slander charges on Tuesday against a journalist who was savagely beaten two years ago, though it appeared that they were eager to end the case quickly, with a $100 fine the most severe potential punishment. Still, the case against the journalist, Mikhail Beketov, has been widely condemned. Mr. Beketov, an outspoken journalist in the Moscow suburb of Khimki, was beaten so viciously that a leg and three fingers had to be amputated, and he is unable to speak. Mr. Beketov has been accused of defaming the Khimki mayor, Vladimir Strelchenko, by saying that he was involved in the blowing up of Mr. Beketovs car, which predated his beating.

title: France: 5 Arrested on Terrorism Charges
description: The authorities have arrested five people suspected of intending to commit terrorist acts in France, said Agns Labrgre, a spokeswoman for the Paris prosecutors office. Those plans included the assassination of the moderate rector of the Great Mosque of Paris, according to Bernard Squarcini, chief of the French domestic intelligence service, Agence France-Presse reported. About two dozen people have been arrested in recent weeks on suspicion of involvement in terrorism, and France has been on high alert against an attack.

title: In Brooklyn, Dramatizing Real Discord
description: So theres ULURP, begins the second song in a new musical about Brooklyn. ULURP is the Uniform Land Use Review Procedure/Which required community involvement and public review/Of all kinds of New York City land-use projects.

title: World Cinema Foundation
description: Images from the films appearing in the World Cinema Foundation program at BAMcinmatek.

title: Brazils Best, Restored and Ready for a 21st-Century Audience
description: The French film critic Georges Sadoul called it an unknown masterpiece and once flew all the way to Brazil, in vain, in hopes of seeing a complete version. Orson Welles, in Brazil in the early 1940s to make a movie of his own, did view it in its entirety and pronounced the experience fabulous. More recently, both David Bowie and Caetano Veloso have also promoted it.

title: Plenty of Perky, Even This Early
description: If you spend enough time with Rachel McAdams, its easy to get lost in the pleasure of her company, or at least become enjoyably distracted. Effortlessly likable, she has a way of keeping you tethered to her character even when your attention begins to wander. Such is the case in Morning Glory, a passably amusing romantic comedy with a laugh-strewn script thats almost undone by the hard sell of an enterprise that drills every emotional beat into your head, an approach that suggests that the filmmakers see their audiences less as viewers with thinking brains and more as patients with thick skulls.

title: Homes for $600,000
description: A three-bedroom historic house in Bozeman, Mont., a two-bedroom apartment in Eureka, Calif., and a one-bedroom former firehouse in Philadelphia.

title: What You Get for ... $600,000
description: BOZEMAN, MONT.

title: Once Rivals, Cuomo and Paterson Present a United Front
description: They have been friends, members of New Yorks political aristocracy and rivals  sometimes bitter rivals  for the states highest office. But on Tuesday, the departing governor, David A. Paterson, and his successor, Andrew M. Cuomo, presented themselves as partners.

title: In Uruguay, a House of Stone
description: A four-bedroom house in Punta del Este is on the market for $2.9 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Uruguay
description: A FOUR-BEDROOM HOUSE IN A GATED COMMUNITY IN JOS IGNACIO, URUGUAY

title: Captivating the Eye, Challenging the Brain
description: The words that hover around Bruce Conner  avant-garde, experimental, collage, Beat, artist  arent likely to get the average moviegoer out the door and into a theater seat. Neither is the title of the current Film Forum retrospective devoted to him, Bruce Conner: The Art of Montage. But there is no reason for anyone to dread the two alternating programs of Conner shorts, 70 and 75 minutes long. There is plenty of pure pleasure to be had from these films, for the eye and the heart as well as for the brain.

title: Glamour Salutes Its Heroines
description: MONDAY evening, on the stage of Carnegie Hall, Julia Roberts was performing the role of celebrated actress, making a delightfully amusing yet touchingly self-deprecating speech at Glamour magazines annual Women of the Year Awards. She held up a shiny red trophy composed of interlocking dinner-plate-size rings and asked what the heck it was supposed to be.

title: Supreme Court Weighs Class-Action Suits
description: WASHINGTON  The most significant business case of the Supreme Court term so far involves a $30 charge for what was said to be a free mobile phone.

title: A Plane Ride Into the Alaskan Wild, Trout Aplenty
description: LARSEN BAY, Alaska  Jay Wattum, a bush pilot for Kodiak Legends Lodge, sang snatches of the song Highwayman as he banked his float plane, a de Havilland DHC-2 Beaver, south over Karluk Lake near the southwest corner of Kodiak Island.

title: Marilyns Stuffing
description: Adapted from Fragments by Marilyn Monroe (Farrar, Straus & Giroux; $30)

title: Marilyn Monroes Stuffing Recipe Stars in a Remake
description: THE image of a bombshell cooking her way to nirvana may seem old-hat now, thanks to Nigella, Giada, Padma and the like. But back in the 1950s, a Hollywood starlet was not expected to squander her talents (or risk her manicure) chopping onions.

title: Suspect in Psychiatrists Killing Ruled Unfit for Trial
description: A man accused of slashing to death a psychologist on the Upper East Side was declared mentally unfit to stand trial on Tuesday and will be sent to a state psychiatric center until he is deemed competent for court.

title: 32 New York Catholic Schools to Close
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York on Tuesday proposed closing 31 elementary schools and a high school next year in what church officials said was the largest school system reorganization in its history.

title: U.S. Says Holocaust Fund Was Defrauded
description: While fleeing the Nazis in 1941, an 11-year-old girl dodged airplane bombs as she crossed the Dnieper River in Ukraine, ultimately finding refuge in Donetsk, where she and her mother lived in hiding until the liberation of 1944.

title: The Pasadena Project, and Others
description: A look at some Scientology building efforts.

title: In Pasadena, a Model for Scientologys Growth Plan
description: PASADENA, Calif.  The opening of a Scientology center in this citys Old Town neighborhood was a significant local event. Church members spent $10 million to buy a historic four-story building and $6 million more to restore it to its 1906 luster before a gala dedication ceremony on July 18.

title: A Sly Campaign That Has Fun With the Product and the Form
description: A campaign for Kahla, the coffee liqueur from Mexico, is taking an offbeat tack that is indicative of a change in how marketers speak with consumers.

title: Republicans Maneuver to Oust Their Leader
description: WASHINGTON  Turning their attention to the 2012 presidential election, Republican leaders are digging in for a battle over control of the Republican National Committee, judging that its role in fund-raising, get-out-the-vote operations and other tasks will be critical to the effort to topple President Obama.

title: A New Round in a Long Coal Battle
description: BECKLEY, W. Va.  When advocates for judicial reform point to examples of how money can influence courtroom decisions, they often cite as exhibit A the case of Hugh M. Caperton.

title: Health Rules Are Waived More Often
description: As Obama administration officials put into place some of the new rules that go into effect under the federal health care law, they are issuing more waivers to try to prevent some insurers and employers from dropping coverage and also promising to modify other rules because many of the existing policies would not meet new standards.

title: Federer Says He Asked IMG About Bets
description: PARIS  Roger Federer said Tuesday that he had sought a detailed explanation from Ted Forstmann, the head of his management company IMG, after a lawsuit charged that Forstmann had increased a bet on the 2007 French Open final after consulting with Federer.

title: Currency Move Changes S. Korea Plan
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The Federal Reserves decision to pump $600 billion into the American economy has put South Korean government officials in a difficult spot.

title: From Ex-Mental Hospital to a New Mixed-Use Life
description: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich.  Until it closed in 1989, the Traverse City State Hospital was among the largest employers in this small city in northern Michigan. Two new commercial and residential construction projects are bringing the old asylum, renamed the Village at Grand Traverse Commons, closer to regaining that distinction.

title: Democratic Strategists Say Damage Control Prevented More Election Losses
description: WASHINGTON  As bad as election night was for House Democrats, top party strategists say it could have been far worse.

title: A Cheese for Scooping
description: Mike Gingrich, an owner of Uplands Cheese in Dodgeville, Wis., has made just one cheese for the last 10 years: Pleasant Ridge Reserve, in a firm, deeply nutty-tasting Alpine-style. Then, three years ago, Uplands hired Andy Hatch, a young cheesemaker who was keen on making his own mark. The result? Rush Creek Reserve.

title: Hill Country Chicken
description: 1123 Broadway (25th Street); (212) 257-6446; hillcountrychicken.com.

title: Dining Calendar
description: All About Chocolate

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: A New Chelsea Bakery Worth a Detour
description: A neighborhood bakery is how Jay Muse describes his latest Lulu Cake Boutique. Even if your neighborhood is not Chelsea, you might strongly consider a detour.

title: The Holiday Turkey Steps Out for a Smoke
description: Tyler, Tex.

title: A Greek Prepared-Food Shop on the Upper West Side
description: After working for years in his fathers Manhattan food markets, Paul Likitsakos, above, has opened his own Greek prepared-food shop, Anthis. Named for his daughter, its the size of a dolls house. Every inch is taken up with trays and platters of specialties, most of them from the stores compact kitchen. Moussaka and pastitsio, under cloudlike bchamel, are from family recipes. There are also flaky spanakopita; dips like baba ghanouj and tzatziki; thick yogurt with honey or figs; and sweet pastries.

title: Lavo
description: THE imaginary mailbag this week spilled forth an imaginary request from an imaginary jock. I endeavored to answer him.

title: The Harrison
description: 355 Greenwich Street (Harrison Street), TriBeCa; (212) 274-9310; theharrison.com.

title: Chefs Tips for the Thanksgiving Meal
description: IF you want to talk turkey about cooking Thanksgiving dinner, get a professional chef in New York City on the phone. In matters of experience and scale, they have much advice to offer the rest of us, whether were preparing an off-a-truck Butterball for the 20th time or a $150 heritage bird for the first.

title: Fatty Cue Brussels Sprouts
description: Adapted from Fatty Cue, Brooklyn

title: Concrete Steps to Nowhere
description: Like many observers, Ive been wondering how Republicans are going to deliver on the mandate they believe voters gave them last week. After all, its a lot easier to say youre going to close a yawning budget deficit without raising taxes than to set out plans for doing so, because the plans will involve cutting programs that people like.

title: Ask.com to Return to Old Service
description: SAN FRANCISCO  After failing to make any headway as a search engine, Ask.com is largely abandoning the effort and will now become a question-and-answer service.

title: New Connecticut Governor Faces Fiscal Woes
description: A week into his transition, Dannel P. Malloy can finally, officially, call himself Connecticuts governor-elect. Now, maybe he can remind himself why he wanted the job in the first place.

title: Mets Candidate Has a Record of Rebuilding
description: When Terry Collins took over the Anaheim Angels  as they were then known  in 1997, the franchise was reeling. The team had experienced an epic collapse down the stretch in 1995, and fallen to 91 losses the next season. A nucleus of talented young players needed direction and discipline, and the organization lacked credibility in the shadow of a more accomplished neighbor.

title: In These Lean Days, Even Stores Shrink
description: SANTA ANA, Calif.  A temporary wall slices the Anchor Blue store here in half. On one side are abandoned dressing rooms, a few mannequins and no customers. On the other are racks jammed with clothing and accessories  and more customers than ever coming into the store.

title: Lottery Numbers
Welcome to DealBook
description: DealBook reinvents itself with an expanded team of journalists and a host of new tools at its disposal.

title: Challenges Await U.S. at Group of 20 Meeting
description: WASHINGTON  Anyone wondering what President Obama will face when he arrives in South Korea on Wednesday for a global financial summit meeting need look no further than an announcement by Chinas leading state-endorsed rating agency, which downgraded the United States credit rating on Tuesday  and provocatively questioned American leadership of the global economy.

title: A 24-Karat Safety Net for Investors
description: Think of it as the Tea Party of investments.

title: Mets Wont Necessarily Follow Moneyball Path
description: By hiring Paul DePodesta as the vice president for player personnel and amateur scouting, Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson has reunited much of the management team that helped spawn the Moneyball legend in Oakland.

title: Busy Mother Gets Help to Focus on Her Life
description: Susana Ramos, 35 and recently separated from her husband, lives in the Inwood section of Manhattan, in a cramped two-bedroom apartment in the back of the building, behind which black garbage bags pile up. She lives in that neighborhood to be close to her parents, so they can help her with her children when she is at work.

title: Bush Interview Is a Bust for NBC
description: A rare appearance in prime time for former President George W. Bush finished a disappointing fourth place in the ratings in its time slot on Monday. The NBC News special Matt Lauer Reports, featuring an interview with Mr. Bush, who was promoting his memoir, attracted a modest audience of 7 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates, fewer than its rivals in the 8 p.m. hour, including Foxs House (9.7 million); CBSs comedies How I Met Your Mother (9.1 million) and Rules of Engagement (8.6 million); and the first half of ABCs two-hour Dancing With the Stars, which averaged 20.4 million from 8 to 10. NBC was fourth for the night over all, trailing ABC, CBS and Fox.

title: Congo Republic Declares a Polio Emergency
description: An explosive outbreak of polio is taking place in the Congo Republic, with 201 cases of paralysis found in two weeks and 104 deaths, the World Health Organization said Tuesday.

title: At HCA, Hot Debt Markets Offer Chance at Big Payday
description: So long as investors are throwing money into the bond markets, private equity firms are taking advantage by cashing out of their investments in a hurry.

title: How $25 Billion in Savings Can Evaporate
description: Note to the incoming Republican majority in the House: Eliminating government programs that do not exist does not save money.

title: Radioactive Material Leaks Into Mohawk River
description: WASHINGTON  Several hundred gallons of water contaminated with radioactive materials from a 1950s nuclear research site spilled into the Mohawk River near Schenectady on Oct. 25, prompting an investigation by the United States Energy Department.

title: Stage Set for Showdown on Online Privacy
description: WASHINGTON  After do not call lists became popular, more than 90 percent of people who signed up reported fewer annoying telemarketing calls. Now, privacy advocates are pushing for a similar do not track feature that would let Internet users tell Web sites to stop surreptitiously tracking their online habits and collecting clues about age, salary, health, location and leisure activities.

title: Letting Diageo in Could Help Trade in China
description: Scotland has Scotch and China has white liquor. Baijiu, a clear drink that is 50 percent alcohol, is Chinas national pride.

title: New York Schools Chancellor Ends 8-Year Run
description: Joel I. Klein, who presided over a radical reorganization of the New York City school system and drew praise and criticism for efforts to raise test scores and hold teachers accountable for them, resigned on Tuesday as chancellor after eight years in the job.

title: DealBook: A Female Wall St. Financial Chief Avoids Pitfalls That Stymied Others
description: Ruth M. Porat has a knack for escaping unscathed from tough situations.

title: Government in the Cheese Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Who (if Anyone) Should Help With the Homework?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Glaxo Executive Is Charged in Drug Fraud
description: In a rare move, the Justice Department on Tuesday announced that it had charged a former vice president and top lawyer for the British drug giant GlaxoSmithKline with making false statements and obstructing a federal investigation into illegal marketing of the antidepressant Wellbutrin for weight loss.

title: Scrutiny Takes Toll on For-Profit College Company
description: Stanley H. Kaplan started his tutoring business in the basement of his parents Brooklyn home in 1938. As standardized tests became a bigger fixture of American education, his company became a national operation, preparing millions of students for the SAT, LSAT, MCATs and other tests.

title: Chevron to Buy Atlas Energy in a Competition for Natural Gas
description: Chevron on Tuesday became the latest energy company to set its sights on unconventional natural gas exploration, announcing that it had reached an agreement to acquire Atlas Energy for $3.2 billion.

title: Wednesday: Heaved Sounds
description: anyone lived in a pretty how town(with up so floating many bells down)spring summer autumn winterhe sang his didnt he danced his did

title: Back to the Ancient Days of Angst and Irritability
description: Long Story Short, which opened at 45 Bleecker in the East Village in August, has moved to Broadway. It opened on Tuesday night and plays through Jan. 8 at the Helen Hayes Theater, 240 West 44th Street; (212) 239-6200 or telecharge.com. Following are excerpts from Charles Isherwoods review, which appeared in The New York Times on Aug. 17; the full text is here.

title: The Enduring Myth of Golds Record High
description: Washington

title: Schools Chief Has Much in Common With Boss
description: Cathleen P. Black earned a reputation in publishing as a tough-minded chief executive who never left her employees guessing what she wanted. A student of management, she wrote a book about strategies for success in the corporate world. She thrived as head of a large media company, showing little interest in politics or a public-service job  until, it seems, a big one suddenly opened up.

title: Ex-Detainees Defense Calls Him Qaeda Dupe in Its Closing
description: The first former Guantnamo detainee to be tried in civilian court was used by Al Qaeda to assist in the 1998 bombings of two United States embassies in East Africa, his lawyer told a jury in his closing argument on Tuesday.

title: Bush Recollection Puts Spotlight on Miscarriage
description: The image of a mother handing her teenage son a jar containing the remains of her just-miscarried fetus may be a disturbing one.

title: Vodafone Selling Stake in Softbank
description: The Vodafone Group said Tuesday that it plans to sell securities in the Japanese wireless operator Softbank Corporation for 3.1 billion ($5 billion).

title: Eisners Studio and AOL Pair Up for Web Series
description: In a deal to be announced Wednesday, Michael D. Eisners Web studio, Vuguru, will produce half a dozen scripted Web video series for AOL.

title: N.H.L. Proposes Letting All-Star Captains Pick Reserves
description: N.H.L. general managers have proposed a new format for selecting players for the All-Star Game, which has failed to generate interest among fans in recent years.

title: Why Rush to Cut Nukes?
description: THE sweeping Democratic midterm losses last week raise serious questions for President Obama and a lame-duck Congress. Voters want government brought closer to the vision the framers outlined in the Constitution, and the first test could be the fate of the flawed New Start arms control treaty, which was signed by President Obama and President Dmitri Medvedev of Russia last spring but awaits ratification. The Senate should heed the will of the voters and either reject the treaty or amend it so that it doesnt weaken our national defense.

title: Recalling History on a Day of Light and Darkness
description: BERLIN  Germans felt the push and pull of their history again on Tuesday, when Nov. 9 came up on the calendar. That is the day in 1938 when Hitlers gangs attacked Jewish property in a prelude to the Holocaust, and the very same day 51 years later when the wall dividing East and West was breached, signaling the end of the cold war.

title: A Rare Goal in Another Loss to a First-Place Team
description: The Rangers worked tirelessly, and they entertained their fans at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night. They kept the score close, but for the second straight game they fell at home to a red-hot team on a winning streak.

title: Joel Kleins Tenure
description: Joel I. Klein, who presided over a radical reorganization of the New York City school system, stepped down as chancellor after eight years in the job.

title: Corrections
description: THE ARTS

title: Raiders Are Hoping to Heal
description: ALAMEDA, Calif.  After putting together their first three-game winning streak in eight seasons, the Oakland Raiders have this weekend off. Will the Raiders, who are off to their best start since the 2002 season, when they went to the Super Bowl, gain rest but lose momentum?

title: After a Personal Scandal, a Small Political Upswing
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Recently, Gov. Mark Sanford of South Carolina watched The Blind Side, the Oscar-winning movie about a white woman from Memphis who mentors a homeless black teenager. The film so touched my heart, the governor said, that he wrote a letter to the woman who inspired the character, praising her acceptance and unconditional love.

title: Containment-Lite
description: Dont believe everything you read in the paper. Take this headline that appeared a couple weeks ago, when I was in New Delhi, in The Hindustan Times: U.S. Not Seeking to Contain China: Clinton. It was referring to a statement made by Secretary of State Hillary Clinton while on a swing through Asia. No, Washington is not trying to contain China the way we once did the Soviet Union, but President Obama didnt just spend three days in India to improve his yoga.

title: Phone Apps to Navigate Traffic
description: DREADING traffic jams this holiday season? There are apps for that. The advent of GPS-enabled cellphones has generated a wave of applications, many of them free, that turn drivers into veritable traffic reporters.

title: Driver Beware: Deer Collisions Peak in Mating Season
description: These are fraught weeks for drivers, deer and the nations car insurers: costly auto-deer collisions make a special jump during the mating season, usually October through December, and peak each November.

title: Kevin Rubs It In
description: My Mom used to say, When youre blue, wear red. America took that advice on Election Day, and you can color Kevin happy. My conservative brother celebrated by doing his year-end political letter early. Here is his tour dhorizon:

title: States Out of Balance
description: The Republican Partys most visible triumph last week was in the House of Representatives, but the more lasting  and possibly more destructive  result was in statehouses across the country. Republicans won more than 690 new legislative seats, taking back at least 19 state chambers and 10 governors seats from Democrats. Republicans previously had been in full control of nine states; now they will fully control at least 20.

title: From a Former Rival: Making the Case for Pelosi
description: To the Editor:

title: Electric Cars of the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Atheist Groups Promote a Holiday Message: Join Us
