description: Just in time for the holiday season, Americans are about to be hit with a spate of advertisements promoting the joy and wisdom of atheism.

title: Buehrles Gold Glove Announcement Is Bobbled
description: Mark Buehrles second career Gold Glove award led to an error by his wife, Jamie, who congratulated her husband in her Facebook status Monday night. The post was deleted a short time later.

title: Washington Worries About New Power Couple
description: WASHINGTON  At one of those ritualistic Washington dinners where the commander in chief is expected to perform stand-up comedy, President Obama once noted that he had an affinity for Representative John A. Boehner, the Republican leader.

title: The Fed vs. the G-20
description: When President Obama arrives in Seoul, South Korea, on Thursday for the summit of the Group of 20 leading economies, he will be met by blistering criticism of the Federal Reserves plan for quantitative easing  pumping $600 billion into the weak American economy over the next eight months.

title: CT Scans for Lung Cancer
description: A government-sponsored study has found that annual CT scans could reduce the mortality rate from lung cancer in very heavy smokers and former smokers by 20 percent. Its leaders suggest that many thousands of lives could be saved annually. This exciting advance still raises serious questions for individuals and their doctors and for the economics of the health care system.

title: Editors Note: Blogs on NYTimes.com
description: The blogs on NYTimes.com have been experiencing technical difficulties, occasionally preventing readers from accessing them. And because of problems updating the blogs, some news posts will be found in corresponding sections; some posts for DealBook, for instance, can be found at nytimes.com/business.

title: Justice Stevens on Invidious Prejudice
description: A great deal of what public figures have said about the proposed Islamic cultural center near ground zero in Lower Manhattan has been aimed at playing off fear and intolerance for political gain. Former Justice John Paul Stevens of the Supreme Court, on the other hand, delivered one of the sanest and most instructive arguments for tolerance that we have heard in a long time.

title: Utility Official Suspended for an E-Mail Masquerade
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A Pacific Gas and Electric executive has been suspended with pay for using a fake name to join an online discussion organized by opponents of so-called smart meters, the utility company said on Tuesday.

title: Russia, Iran and Drug Interdiction in Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Eager Collectors Snap Up Pop Art at Sothebys Auction
description: It was to have been Warhols night. Waiters in black served Coca-Cola in old-fashioned green-glass bottles to the throngs of collectors and dealers who packed Sothebys salesroom on Tuesday night, an homage to a 1962 Coke bottle painting by the artist that was on offer.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,360 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Food Network and HGTV Back on AT&T System
description: HGTV and the Food Network are back on AT&Ts U-serve television system after an almost three-day lapse.

title: Knicks Revert to Old Form in Lopsided Loss
description: MILWAUKEE  Brandon Jennings, the point guard the Knicks could have drafted slithered past them again. David Lee, the All-Star forward they traded to chase after other free agents visits Madison Square Garden on Wednesday. As much as the Knicks try to turn the page they cannot avoid the past.

title: Emilio Massera, Leader of Brutal Argentine Junta, Dies at 85
description: BUENOS AIRES  Emilio Massera, a leader of the military junta of Argentinas bloody dictatorship and the former head of the countrys most notorious political prison, where an estimated 5,000 people were tortured and killed, died here on Monday. He was 85.

title: Phys Ed: Do Protein Sports Drinks Work?
description: Could sports drinks be improved with the addition of protein? That question has long gripped physiologists and nutritionists. Its well established that the carbohydrates (sugars) that sweeten most sports drinks aid performance. They provide immediate fuel for straining muscles, keep blood-sugar levels stable and allow you to work out for a longer period of time or at a higher intensity, or both, than if you dont swallow any extra fuel. But why wouldnt taking in protein, together with carbohydrates, during a workout or race make you even more speedy and durable? Protein, after all, is what muscles fundamentally are made of, so it seems reasonable to imagine that adding it to sports drinks could provide some additional benefit.

title: Word of the Day | mosaic
description: mosaic \mo-za-ik\ noun

title: Officials Try to Rescue Cruise Ship
description: It was supposed to be a luxurious seven-day cruise to the Mexican Riviera. But two days in, this majestic vacation for thousands of passengers turned into an unpleasant journey on the high seas.

title: Britain: Decision Pending on War Crimes Charges
description: A defense ministry lawyer told a panel of high court judges on Tuesday that three British soldiers filmed abusing Iraqi detainees held by British forces in southern Iraq may face war crimes charges. As the court completed hearings on a petition for a public inquiry into the treatment of more than 220 former detainees, the lawyer, Philip Havers, said that evidence against the soldiers had been passed to Britains military prosecutors, who will decide whether there is a criminal case against the soldiers under a 2001 British statute on war crimes, which penalizes any actions against prisoners of war that amount to outrages upon human dignity, in particular humiliating and degrading treatment.

title: France: Pension Bill Signed Into Law
description: President Nicolas Sarkozy said on Wednesday that he had signed into law his contentious pension-reform bill after the Constitutional Council gave its blessing to the measure. The bill, which prompted strikes and demonstrations for weeks, raises the age by two years both for minimum retirement benefits and for a full pension. The law will go into effect next July. Mr. Sarkozy, left, had made a major issue of the bill as a symbol of his ability to stand firm and to prove to the financial markets that France can reduce its budget deficit.

title: Posada to Have Knee Surgery
description: Yankees catcher Jorge Posada is scheduled to have surgery Wednesday to repair a torn meniscus in his left knee, according to a person in baseball briefed on the matter. While the operation is not serious, it underlines the age issues that the Yankees have to confront with Posada, who turned 39 this past season and may be entering the final year of his major league career.

title: Mother of Girl Who Died Is Charged With Murder
description: The mother of a drugged and malnourished 4-year-old girl who weighed 18 pounds when she died in September has been indicted on murder charges, Brooklyn prosecutors said Tuesday.

title: Argument for 9/11 Trial Site, Now Playing in Citys Taxis
description: The television in a New York City taxicab is a good place to get an update on the weather or learn about a new tourist attraction. This week, it is also a medium for one of citys most contentious political debates.

title: Auction Records Fall at Phillipss Sale of Contemporary Masters
description: Crowds jostled and jammed their way into Phillips de Pury & Companys spanking-new Park Avenue salesroom on Monday night to watch as some contemporary masters, like Warhol and Murakami, topped expectations and others, like Cindy Sherman, Felix Gonzalez-Torres and Rudolf Stingel, brought record prices.

title: $25 Billion in Cuts, if the Math Worked
description: Note to the incoming Republican majority in the House: Eliminating government programs that do not exist does not save money.

title: Rudolf Barshai, Conductor and Violist, Dies at 86
description: Rudolf Barshai, an orchestral conductor who built a prominent career in the West after defecting from the Soviet Union in the 1970s, died on Nov. 2 in Basel, Switzerland. He was 86 and lived nearby in Ramlinsburg.

title: News Quiz | November 10, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Chevron to Buy Atlas in Race for Natural Gas
description: Chevron became the latest energy company to set its sights on unconventional natural gas exploration, announcing on Tuesday that it had reached an agreement to acquire Atlas Energy for $3.2 billion.

title: A Womans Journey From an Artists Barn to a Mansions Walls
description: On Sunday, a sturdy centenarian from Maine named Doris Bryant Makas stood in an opulent Upper East Side mansion and stared across a hundred years out to a sandy spit of land in the ocean, and saw herself.

title: Secret Gifts During the Great Depression
description: WHO was B. Virdot?WHO is Helen Palm?

title: For Morgan Stanley C.F.O., a Hard Road Ahead
description: Ruth M. Porat has a knack for escaping unscathed from tough situations.

title: Insurgent Seized Aboard Afghan Airliner
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  At least one passenger suspected of being an insurgent managed to board an Afghan airliner bound for the Middle East before the authorities ordered the plane to return to Kabul, Afghan and NATO officials said Wednesday.

title: Singapore Air Pulls 3 Airbus Jets From Service
description: HONG KONG  Singapore Airlines pulled three of its A380 superjumbo jetliners from service on Wednesday after tests revealed oil stains on their engines, the airline said on Wednesday.

title: A Lesson in Control
description: A Stanford M.B.A. named Roy Raymond  comes up with an idea for a high-end place  and calls it Victorias Secret. After five years he sells the company to Leslie Wexner and The Limited Happy ending, right? Except two years later, the companys worth $500 million and Roy Raymond jumps off the Golden Gate Bridge.

title: To What Piece of Technology Would You Write a Love Letter?
description: New York Times technology columnist David Pogue recently wrote what he called a love letter to the Canon S95 camera, so impressed was he with details like its huge light sensor and tiny size overall. If you were to write a similar letter to the piece of technology that means the most to you  whether you own it or just covet it  what device would you write to and what would you say?

title: At HCA, Debt Markets Yield Big Payday
description: So long as investors are throwing money into the bond markets, private equity firms are taking advantage by cashing out of their investments in a hurry.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Nov. 10, 2010
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from The Timess article Toyota Says 65% of Recall Repairs Are Completed.

title: Return of the Samurai
description: Tokyo Bay, Nov. 10, 1860

title: How (and Where) Lincoln Won
description: The Civil War was the largest, bloodiest conflict fought on American soil, but today its geography  from elections and secession to the back-and-forth of military struggle  is often obscure. This article is the first in a series in which Susan Schulten, a historian at the University of Denver, uses maps to illuminate the secession crisis and the war it produced.

title: In Jakarta Speech, Some Hear Cairo Redux
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  In a much-anticipated speech focusing on development, democracy and religion, President Obama sought on Wednesday to strengthen Americas ties with Indonesia, a rising Asian power with the worlds largest Muslim population. But his intended audience was also elsewhere in the Muslim world, especially in the Middle East, where he began talking last year of a fresh start between the West and the Islamic world.

title: Daily Lexeme: Bumbard
description: Todays word, in association with the superior Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Met Is to Repatriate to Egypt Artifacts From King Tuts Tomb
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is voluntarily returning 19 artifacts to Egypt that had been in its collection for decades and that Met curators recently determined came from Tutankhamens tomb, the museum said on Tuesday.

title: Scouting the Steelers, and Looking Ahead for the Jets
description: If you love football, there were plenty of reasons to want to catch the Steelers-Bengals game on Monday. Was it a division rivalry? Check. Were there good player matchups? Check again. The Steelers are, well, the Steelers. With the Bengals, Carson Palmer, Terrell Owens and Chad Ochocinco and Company always provide entertainment.

title: Montmartre Art Studios Open to Public
description: Few neighborhoods in the world are as associated with art as Montmartre in Paris. Since the middle of the 19th century, it has been attracting artists with its enchanting location overlooking Paris, the domed Basilica de Sacre Coeur, winding, cobblestone streets and cozy cafes. Monet, van Gogh, Dali and Picasso are only a few of the great names associated with the district.

title: War and Conscience: Expanding the Definition of Conscientious Objection
description: Since Vietnam, the militarys rules governing conscientious objector status have effectively required service members to declare themselves pacifists in order to qualify. Conscientious objection, as defined by military regulation  (pdf) is a firm, fixed, and sincere objection to participation in war in any form or the bearing of arms.

title: Q. and A. With Eric Mangini
description: BEREA, Ohio  I spent a day at the Cleveland Browns facility two weeks ago to report this article on Eric Mangini that I wrote last Sunday. Mangini gave me a few hours of his time, some of which we spent touring the facility, most of which we dedicated to an interview. The gist of that day is in the article, but there were quotations, ideas and themes I did not get into. Here are excerpts.

title: Q&A: Buffing Up Chrome With Browser Extensions
description: Q.

title: China Sentences Activist in Milk Scandal to Prison
description: BEIJING  A former journalist who became the public face of a campaign seeking justice for children harmed by tainted dairy products was sentenced Wednesday to two and a half years in prison on charges that his efforts disrupted social harmony.

title: For Entrepreneurs, a Lesson in Keeping Control
description: A Stanford M.B.A. named Roy Raymond ... comes up with an idea for a high-end place ... and calls it Victorias Secret. After five years he sells the company to Leslie Wexner and The Limited ...Happy ending, right? Except two years later, the companys worth $500 million and Roy Raymond jumps off the Golden Gate Bridge.

title: A Smarter Strategy for Hiring a No. 2
description: Over the past two weeks, Ive read Adriana Gardellas case study and follow-up blog post about hiring a No. 2 with great interest. The pieces discuss the advantages of using a recruiter and whether it makes sense to hire someone who will focus on tasks or on vision, and they make a lot of good points. Based on my own experiences, however, I have an alternative suggestion: Dont!

title: Teenage Dreams and Nightmares: Talking Never Been Kissed With Ryan Murphy of Glee
description: Warning: this post contains spoilers.

title: Officers Tie British Cuts and Risk to Falklands
description: LONDON  A group of retired British admirals has publicly attacked the decision of Prime Minister David Camerons government to scrap Britains only aircraft carrier and its entire fleet of Harrier jump jets, saying it exposes the Falkland Islands to renewed attack by Argentina.

title: Rapper Finds Order in Orthodox Judaism in Israel
description: JERUSALEM  The tall man in the velvet fedora and knee-length black jacket with ritual fringes peeking out takes long, swift strides toward the Western Wall. Its late in the day, and he does not want to miss afternoon prayers at Judaisms holiest site.

title: Now Accessorizing | Kilian Hennessy
description: Kilian Hennessys delicious scents have inspired a handbag collection. By Kilian, the perfumers first foray into accessories, consists of six beautifully crafted clutches that go on sale exclusively at Bergdorf Goodman in New York on Dec. 8. Inspired by art deco jewelry artists like Jean Despres and Grard Sandoz, the Swarovski-crystal-encrusted and stingray-accented evening bags (priced from $1,995 to $2,995) are made from lacquered plexiglass and salute the timeless elegance of Judith Leiber and the high-impact style of Joan Collins.

title: Obama Nears a Deal to Reduce Trade Imbalance
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Obama administration officials said Thursday that they were close to securing a compromise agreement to help reduce vast trade imbalances, a step that could ease conflict among the major world economies over commerce, currency and monetary policies.

title: G.M., Days Away From Stock Offering, Posts $2 Billion Profit
description: DETROIT  A week before its initial public offering, General Motors reported its largest quarterly profit in 11 years on Wednesday, showing that the slimmed-down automaker no longer needed huge sales to generate significant earnings.

title: Deadline Extended for 9/11 Settlement
description: New York City is giving more than 10,000 workers an extra eight days to decide whether to settle their lawsuits over illnesses they attribute to exposure to environmental hazards during the rescue and cleanup work at ground zero.

title: Haider Ackermann Takes Manhattan
description: Haider Ackermanns spring collection of pleated maxi skirts was one of the most lauded shows of the season, but if youre wondering what the designer may reference for fall, look in your own backyard. The Colombian-born, Belgian-trained Ackermann, who is in New York for a lightning visit, says he has been keeping his eyes wide open during his stay. The youth culture here is really cool to look at, Ackermann said Tuesday at a special personal appearance at Saks. I stayed uptown and downtown and I loved seeing the different types and attitudes. Even watching runners in Central Park and along the Hudson is apparently grist for the mill. Theyre absolutely lovely, he said. I will translate everything Ive seen into my next collection.

title: The Story of Stuff 2.0: An E-Waste Sequel
description: Just a few weeks ago, I was despairing over how difficult it is to recycle e-waste in New York City even though nearly every computer and MP3 player package today has a cute little green admonition to please recycle. This week, I see a bit of light on the horizon.

title: Tentative Deal in Iraq Keeps Maliki in Power
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs leaders reached a tentative agreement late Wednesday night to create a unity government embracing the countrys major ethnic and religious factions, ending an eight-month political impasse and returning Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to power for a second term as prime minister.

title: Biking Los Angeles
description: I set out to see if I could make it in Los Angeles on $100 a day. Its possible, it turns out. But only if you do away with a car. Now, I know what youre thinking. Los Angeles, the sprawling metropolitan region that is home to both the Hollywood Hills and the Valley, on a bike? Well, I found it not only possible but enjoyable. In truth, I was liberally aided by the surprisingly nimble public transportation system. But I rode 15 to 40 miles a day on trips to Beverly Hills, along the coast, downtown and to Pasadena. Highlights from my trip (and some cool photos) are already online. Now, if youll excuse me, Ive got to get back to my very demanding research of frugal Buenos Aires.

title: A Journey From an Artists Barn to a Mansions Walls
description: On Sunday, a sturdy centenarian from Maine named Doris Bryant Makas stood in an opulent Upper East Side mansion and stared across a hundred years out to a sandy spit of land in the ocean, and saw herself.

title: Families Struggle to Care for Veterans
description: When Jim Hewes, a San Diego painter and Vietnam veteran, received the diagnosis of colorectal cancer in February 2008, his wife, Libby, suddenly became his aide, therapist, homemaker and advocate  his everything. Through long months of chemotherapy, radiation and surgery, she dressed wounds, changed colostomy bags and tried to hold onto her own equilibrium.

title: The Great Cyberheist
description: One night in July 2003, a little before midnight, a plainclothes N.Y.P.D. detective, investigating a series of car thefts in upper Manhattan, followed a suspicious-looking young man with long, stringy hair and a nose ring into the A.T.M. lobby of a bank. Pretending to use one of the machines, the detective watched as the man pulled a debit card from his pocket and withdrew hundreds of dollars in cash. Then he pulled out another card and did the same thing. Then another, and another. The guy wasnt stealing cars, but the detective figured he was stealing something.

title: Gremlins
description: As some readers no doubt noticed, all Times blogs were down for a long time  from early yesterday afternoon until some time this morning. No, I dont know what it was about, although the tech people are saying something about an infection from Dealbook.

title: Fathers and Sons Stand to Gain in Atlas Deal
description: Chevrons $3.2 billion deal for Atlas Energy promises a big payday for two fathers  and their sons, too.

title: U.S. Trade Gap Narrows; New Jobless Claims Drop
description: The United States trade deficit narrowed in September, with American exports at their highest level in the last two years, according to government figures released on Wednesday.

title: B-Rating America
description: OK, actually A+ rating America. Via Calculated Risk, China has created a new, independent rating agency  and it has now sharply downgraded the United States:

title: Trash-Can Defense Against Robber Wins High Praise
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly hailed the shopkeeper in Park Slope, Brooklyn, who fended off a robber with a plastic trash can as a hero.

title: RTE Gets Palinized
description: The Journals Real Time Economics, having had the audacity to point out that Sarah Palins attack on quantitative easing was factually challenged, gets a blast from the barracuda. As I read it, they seem somewhat shocked  it sounds as if theyre deeply surprised at being accused of villainy simply because they pointed out that the facts are somewhat at variance with what politicians on the right are saying.

title: G.M. Posts $2 Billion Quarterly Profit
description: From our colleagues at Business Day:

title: Now Drinking | Boxed Water Is Better
description: Youve got to have a hard sell and catchy slogan if youre a bottled water company trying to introduce your product in New York City, which is reputed to have some of the best tap water in the world. After all, this is a place where people have tried to actually bottle the tap water. Sometimes, though, a straightforward approach is best. And so the entrepreneur Benjamin Gott named his company Boxed Water Is Better.

title: Testing Begins on 9/11 Waterfalls
description: There has been a rainbow this week at ground zero.

title: Lott and Daschle Offer Advice on Getting Along
description: As Harry Reid and Mitch McConnell, the Democratic and Republican leaders in the Senate, prepare for battle in the next two years, two men who held those posts in the last decade say there are ways to improve the tone in Washington.

title: LVMH Defends Its Big Stake in Hermes
description: Pierre God, vice president of LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton, told the French financial daily Les Echos in an interview published on Wednesday that his company had respected both the spirit and the letter of the rules, and explained why LVMH had opted to take a more than 17 percent stake in Herms, rather than cash out of its equity swaps.

title: Letting the Estate Tax Die
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.11/11/10 | Updated to fix garble

title: Jeters 5th Gold Glove an Error, Metric Says
description: Within an hour of Tuesdays announcement of the American League Gold Glove awards, editors at Baseball-Reference.com summed up the general reaction to Derek Jeters latest victory at shortstop: We cant believe it either, a notation briefly on the site said.

title: F.D.A. Unveils Proposed Graphic Warning Labels for Cigarette Packs
description: WASHINGTON  Federal drug regulators on Wednesday unveiled 36 proposed warning labels for cigarette packages, including one showing a toe tag on a corpse and another in which a mother blows smoke on her baby.

title: Wall Street, Starring Chaplin and Fairbanks
description: They were among the most famous actors of their day and the best of friends: Douglas Fairbanks and Charlie Chaplin. During World War I, they teamed up with Mary Pickford and toured the country at rallies to help sell Liberty bonds to help finance the war effort.

title: Holocaust Fund Is Victim of Fraud, Prosecutors Say
description: A fund dedicated to collecting reparations for Holocaust survivors from the German government was defrauded of more than $42 million over 16 years by a group that included six employees and custodians of the fund. [NYT]

title: Whos the Front-Runner?
description: Public Policy Polling offers more grist for my Sarah Palin is not the 2012 Republican front-runner mill. They have 2012 polls out for California, Colorado, Connecticut, Illinois, New Hampshire, and Pennsylvania, and Mitt Romney is ahead in four of them (and ahead by a mile in New Hampshire), while Mike Huckabee leads in two. Palin performs respectably across the board, but she never breaks 20 percent; her numbers are similar to Newt Gingrichs, who regularly polls in the mid-teens. In general, Romney leads because he wins moderates by a mile and then splits conservatives with the other candidates, while Palin generally polls in the single digits among moderates. But its worth noting that Romneys formula can easily fall apart:

title: Oklahoma! Revival in D.C. Generates Broadway Buzz
description: Only two musical revivals are set for the 2010-11 Broadway season so far  How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying and Anything Goes  and the word is that only one other revival, Godspell, is possible right now. Which means it looks like there wont be enough shows to fill the four slots in the musical revival category of the Tony Awards come spring.

title: Show Us Your City: The Duckmaster Tours Memphis
description: A few weeks ago, we asked readers to give us the local point of view by submitting a short travel video that shows why their city, town or neighborhood is amazing. This week, Jason Sensat, Duckmaster at the historic Peabody Hotel, shows viewers a few of his favorite places to take the family in Memphis, Tenn.

title: Electronic Dating Violence
description: The use of technology to humiliate or intimidate a romantic partner.

title: Is Josh Freeman the Class of the 2009 QB Class?
description: Editors note: We seem to have solved the technical problems here and at the other New York Times blogs. Thanks for your patience.

title: Gran Turismo Creator Picks 1969 Chevy Camaro for Next Version
description: While the world waits for Sony Computer Entertainment to formally announce a release date for Gran Turismo 5  Sonys online Style store says it will go on sale on or about Nov. 30  the games creator, Kazunori Yamauchi, seems to be pushing ahead with version 6.0.

title: Are Parents Just Saying No to Marijuana Legalization?
description: Among other disappointments for liberals last Tuesday was the failure of Californias Proposition 19, which would have rewritten state law to allow local jurisdictions the right to regulate and tax the use of marijuana for personal consumption.

title: Olbermann: Policy Needs to Be Adapted to Modern Journalism
description: Keith Olbermann returned to his MSNBC program, Countdown, on Tuesday after a two-day suspension with words of thanks to viewers who supported him, including about 300,000 who signed a petition calling for his reinstatement.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Refreshing this page gives you live updates of the mess Irish bonds are in. (Hat tip to Joe Weisenthal.)

title: Turkish Action Movie on Gaza Flotilla Raid Unlikely to Calm Regional Tensions
description: Updated | 2:30 p.m.After viewing the trailer for a new Turkish action movie, in which the hero travels to Palestine to exact revenge on the Israeli commander who ordered the raid on the Gaza flotilla, in which nine Turks were killed, the Israeli news site Ynet News suggests, The already tense relations between Israel and Turkey are about to get even more strained.

title: Cashman in Arkansas to Talk to Cliff Lee
description: Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman is in Arkansas on Wednesday to meet with the free-agent pitcher Cliff Lee and his family, according to a person in baseball briefed on the matter.

title: A McQueen Retrospective at the Met
description: Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty, an exhibition of the fashion of the late British designer, will open at the Costume Institute on May 4, the Metropolitan Museum of Art said today. The exhibit will include designs from Mr. McQueens postgraduate show at Central Saint Martins in 1992 until his final collection in 2010. He died in February.

title: So She Thinks She Can Dance? Tyne Daly Testing the Waters For a Ballroom Revival
description: Tony-winning actress Tyne Daly (Gypsy) and Jerry Mitchell, the Broadway choreographer-turned-director (Legally Blonde), began a workshop this week to prepare for a Nov. 17 reading of the 1978 musical Ballroom, which was Michael Bennetts first project following the triumphant 1975 Broadway debut of A Chorus Line.

title: White House Editing Caused Drilling Ban Dispute
description: Some 11th-hour White House fiddling with an Interior Department report on offshore drilling safety wrongly implied that engineering experts had endorsed a political decision to impose a six-month ban on deepwater drilling, the departments inspector general concluded in a finding made public this week.

title: Bag of Tricks
description: Bucking the trend for rustic satchels, some luggage designers are boldly traveling forward. Delsey has developed a way to prevent surprise overweight charges: two bags in the companys Helium Fusion Lite 2.0 line ($120 and $130; delsey.com) have a built-in scale that triggers a red indicator when your luggage tops 50 pounds. At Tumi, where all-black Alpha rollers are standard business issue, innovation comes in a splash of color. The new Accent Your Alpha program ($50 at Tumi boutiques; tumi.com) lets road warriors distinguish their bags with monogram patches, zipper pulls and luggage tags in six punchy hues. And while youre waiting in baggage claim, you may wish you had Travelteqs Trip, a sit-on carry-on (above; about $1,100; travelteq.com). The aluminum frame has wheels that pivot outward to stabilize, the telescoping handle acts as a seat back, and an upholstered seat invites you to take a load off. Upgrade to the fully loaded model with battery-powered stereo speakers, and time will fly.

title: Wednesday Reading: Investing in Gold
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Black Democrats in New York Face Imminent Loss of Clout
description: Even as Democrats gathered in the ballroom of a Manhattan hotel last week to celebrate their partys sweep of statewide offices in New York, a sober realization began to dawn among some in the crowd: What once seemed like a new golden age for the states black political establishment could be on the verge of an abrupt collapse.

title: Growing List of House Democrats Oppose Pelosi as Leader
description: The speaker of the House, Nancy Pelosi, looks ahead to the new Congress in an op-ed column in USA Today on Wednesday, but she continues to face a small rebellion within her own party about returning as Democratic leader.

title: About Last Night (and This Morning)
description: Dear Readers: Thank you for your involuntary patience while City Room and the rest of the nytimes.com blog universe suffered a spell of frequent crashes starting late Tuesday afternoon. We seem to have things under control now. Read while you can.

title: Club Form and Forgiveness Earn Players International Opportunities
description: An interesting series of international friendly matches takes place later this month, and national team managers are beginning to fashion their squads. A few call-ups to note:

title: Tallying the Price of Human Progress
description: I admit it. Im a selfish blogger.

title: The Ritholtz Uncertainty Principle
description: Barry Ritholtz has a nice column on Bloomberg:

title: The Idiots Guide to Publishing
description: Matthew Swanson and Robbi Behr are idiots. No, really  the couple (after bidding a Steven Slater-esque adieu to their previous careers as graphic designers) founded Idiots Books, an independent press run out of their Maryland barn. There they live, work and raise two children. Swanson writes and Behr illustrates, and together they distribute their snide, satirical works through a bimonthly subscription service. (Titles include The Baby Is Disappointing, a sarcastic paean to parenting, and Facial Features of French Explorers, a microanalysis of the craniofacial quirks of adventurers like Samuel de Champlain.) They also maintain a blog about their lives.

title: The Idiots Guide to Publishing
description: Matthew Swanson and Robbi Behr are idiots. No, really  the couple (after bidding a Steven Slater-esque adieu to their previous careers as graphic designers) founded Idiots Books, an independent press run out of their Maryland barn. There they live, work and raise two children. Swanson writes and Behr illustrates, and together they distribute their snide, satirical works through a bimonthly subscription service. (Titles include The Baby Is Disappointing, a sarcastic paean to parenting, and Facial Features of French Explorers, a microanalysis of the craniofacial quirks of adventurers like Samuel de Champlain.) They also maintain a blog about their lives.

title: Punishing a Bad Report Card?
description: Report card time. That has always been a fairly good day at Alyssas house in Houston. This time around, though, things arent going so well, and Alyssas mother is looking for some advice. Heres the comment she left Tuesday on an unrelated post:

title: Wooster Group Plans New York Premiere for Vieux Carr
description: The downtown experimental theater troupe Wooster Group will hold the New York premiere of its latest multimedia stage work, Tennessee Williamss Vieux Carr, at the Baryshnikov Arts Center from Feb. 2-27, publicists for the Wooster Group said Wednesday.

title: A Bonus Bump on Wall Street
description: As further proof that Wall Street is not Main Street, the Department of Labor has reported that wages grew 12 percent in Manhattan from January to March, lifted by a rebound in Wall Street bonuses.

title: Guares Gamble of Epic Proportions
description: THE director George C. Wolfe vividly remembers the day in 2004 when John Guare handed in his new play A Free Man of Color, his first epic work for the stage. The Public Theater had commissioned Mr. Guare to write a play about race and class in New Orleans around 1801, on the eve of the Louisiana Purchase. The play was to be modeled on 17th century English Restoration comedies, reflecting their interlocking, ribald plots that lampooned the social classes. The commission had been made in 2002, but Mr. Wolfe, then the head of the Public, hadnt heard from Mr. Guare in two years.

title: More Supporters Say Michael Jackson Is Singing on Michael Jackson Song
description: For those of you keeping score at home, the tally of people who say that a recently released single attributed to Michael Jackson does indeed contain vocals by the King of Pop has gone up by two.

title: Amtrak Allies Acela With Nets and Devils
description: Amtrak appears undaunted by New Jersey Governor Chris Christies decision to halt construction of a second set of rail tunnels under the Hudson River to Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan.

title: What Were Reading
description: New York Post: The city has failed to collect 90 percent of the fines owed by street vendors.  Nick Fox

title: A Character He Can Sink His Phobias Into
description: NEXT weekend the Tony Award-winning actor Denis OHare opens on Broadway in Elling, playing an anxious mental patient trying to re-enter society. But if youre a fan of the HBO series True Blood, in which he plays the arrogant and acerbic Russell Edgington, the vampire king of Mississippi, what you no doubt want to hear about are his fangs.

title: Heat Still a Work in Progress
description: When LeBron James, Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh agreed to join forces on the Miami Heat, the comparisons to the 72-win 1995-96 Chicago Bulls began almost immediately. With Tuesdays overtime loss to the Utah Jazz, perhaps that talk can now cool off.

title: Activision Sees Latest Call of Duty Game Breaking Records
description: On Tuesday Activision, the maker of popular video games including Guitar Hero and Tony Hawk, began selling the latest version of one the companys most popular game franchises, Call of Duty: Black Ops.

title: The Sifty Fifty Thanksgiving List
description: The Sifty Fifty is a list of 50 of my current favorite restaurants in New York City. (Its part of The Scoop, a free New York Times iPhone app that can be downloaded from the iTunes store; you can also check out the list, with a map, online.)

title: Concern at Promises, Promises for Kristin Chenoweth
description: Audience members at Promises, Promises were concerned at the end of Tuesday nights performance when star Kristin Chenoweth did not appear for the curtain call beside cast mates Sean Hayes, Molly Shannon, and others  some of whom looked disconcerted. The arrival of an ambulance near the stage door was troubling, too. But Ms. Chenoweth, the original Glinda in Wicked and a Tony Award winner for Youre a Good Man, Charlie Brown, appears to be all right. A publicist for the production said on Wednesday that Ms. Chenoweth, 42, experienced dizziness after her final scene and was unable to take her curtain call. Per standard policy, the production stage manager called an ambulance and emergency medical technicians examined the actress in her dressing room. She was diagnosed with mild dehydration and was released shortly thereafter. Ms. Chenoweth is taking off the Wednesday matinee to rest and is expected to return to the show for the Wednesday night performance.

title: In the Midst of Extraordinary Wildlife
description: Noah Snyder-Mackler, a graduate student at the University of Pennsylvania, is studying the evolution of social behavior in the gelada, a primate found in Ethiopia. Scientist at Work will check in from time to time with Mr. Snyder-Mackler, whose expedition continues into December.

title: Along Jamaica Bay, a Landfills Visual Legacy
description: Nathan Kensinger, photo-chronicler par excellence of the citys neglected corners , has just published the last installment of a three-part photo essay on Edgemere in the Rockaways, home to both what the city called the longest continuously operating dump in the United States until it closed in 1991, as well as a 20-block city-owned stretch of abandoned oceanfront.

title: G.M. Officials Stick to Earnings Script
description: General Motors executives are spending nine days crisscrossing North America and Europe, talking up next weeks initial public offering to as many potential investors as will listen.

title: From Erica Jong
description: Dear Lisa Belkin:

title: You Supply the Movie, Rifftrax Supplies the Laughs
description: I used to love Mystery Science Theater 3000. It ran on TV from 1988 to 1999, and cracked me up every time. You can read up on it on Wikipedia, but the basic idea was you watch a really terrible old movie, usually a sci-fi B movie. At the bottom of the screen, you see the silhouettes of three professional hecklers as they talk to the screen and riff on the awfulness of the movie and the acting.

title: Guest Post: English, Improved
description: by Jonathon Keats

title: Doping Rules Extra Consequences
description: On paper, the swimmer Jessica Hardy appears to be a lock to compete in the 2012 London Olympics. She broke the world record in the 100-meter breaststroke last year and has swum fast enough to qualify for four events at the United States Olympic trials.

title: Wednesday: The Check Is in the Mail
description: This week, as I explained on Friday, Im writing daily posts about my experiences during a recent week trying to collect money from my customers.

title: London Tuition Hike Protests Turn Violent
description: LONDON  A demonstration against government proposals to cut education spending and steeply increase tuition for university students turned violent on Wednesday as protesters attempted to storm the building that houses the Conservative Party.

title: Cheating Charges Embroil Auburn and Newton
description: If we didnt know any better, we might suspect the Southeastern Conference was getting jealous. It was falling behind in scandal and mayhem news. For a while there, Southern California was stealing all its thunder. While everyone fixated on the Reggie Bush fiasco, the SEC was left waving in the background, Hey, the N.C.A.A. is looking into the recruiting hostesses at Tennessee! Well, now its got something to really crow about: the prohibitive favorite for the Heisman Trophy is drawing allegations the way Lindsay Lohan draws paparazzi.

title: Seeing a Patient Outside the Hospital
description: I was having lunch with another nurse outside the hospital when I spotted a former patient of mine.

title: China Still Bans Rare Earth to Japan
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese government is continuing to block shipments of crucial strategic minerals to Japan, according to industry executives, analysts and a Japanese official.

title: Hall of Famers Who Played for One Team
description: Derek Jeter is not yet a Hall of Famer but he is heading into his 16th full season with the Yankees. Few players in the free-agent era have remained with one team for as long as Jeter; players are more likely to leave teams for more money elsewhere.

title: Sydney Sips
description: Australian drinking culture took a serious hit during the temperance movement: for the better part of the 20th century, pubs were required to close by 6 p.m., a restriction that fostered binge drinking (the notorious six oclock swill) and dampened any creativity behind the bar. But an interest in cocktail craft has sprung up in cities down under, starting first in Melbournes small, speakeasy-style laneway bars and taking hold most recently in Sydney. In 2007, new laws made it easier and cheaper to open bars here, resulting in an onslaught of pocket-size watering holes that are big on character, from buttoned-up botes to faux dives.

title: Young Forward Gives Cavaliers New Bounce
description: NEWARK  The temptation is to burst into superlatives, to see the leaping and the soaring and the dunking and to let the imagination wander. Sometimes J. J. Hickson, the Cleveland Cavaliers stringy, pogo-stick forward, inspires a little irrational exuberance.

title: For Edge on Alzheimers, Testing Early Treatments
description: Much of the research on Alzheimers next year will be about going back in time, trying to determine when and how the brain begins to deteriorate.

title: Your Money Partnership With Marketplace Radio
description: We here at the Your Money/Bucks team have recently teamed up with American Public Medias Marketplace Money radio show to swap stories and collaborate on coverage.

title: Brandon Jacobs Sits Out Practice With Illness
description: Giants running back Brandon Jacobs did not participate in practice Wednesday because of an unspecified illness.

title: Video of Student Protests in London
description: Updated | 4:10 p.m. As my colleague Sarah Lyall reports, tens of thousands of students took to the streets of London on Wednesday to protest government cuts that will lead to a large increase in tuition fees at British universities.

title: I Really Did Think It Was the Right Time, Klein Says
description: During his eight years at the helm of New York City public schools, Joel I. Klein emerged as one of the citys most divisive figures. On Tuesday, he announced that he would step out of the limelight to become an executive vice president responsible for education and technology at Rupert Murdochs News Corporation.

title: Stage Scenes: John Guare
description: A look at productions of the playwrights work.

title: One Gunman Accused of Killing 40 in Philippine Massacre
description: MANILA  A police officer who witnessed the massacre of 57 people in the southern Philippines last year testified on Wednesday that 40 of the victims were gunned down by a local official as they pleaded for their lives.

title: Exclusive Video | When Karl Met Suzy
description: In a conversation with Suzy Menkes, at the IHT luxury conference in London, the Chanel designer discusses the history of the label, the recent sale of Herms stock and his aprs moi, le dluge approach to his legacy.

title: U.S. Dodges Bullet in Busy Hurricane Season
description: One of the most active hurricane seasons on record is coming to a close, although you might be forgiven for missing it if you live in the United States. In an exceptional run of good luck, the nation avoided a direct hit by a hurricane for the second year in a row.

title: Glamour Celebrates Its Women of the Year Awards
description: The awards, which were held at the Museum of Modern Art, included tributes to a diverse cast of women of remarkable achievement: actors, athletes, pop stars, designers, humanitarians and heads of state.

title: Tata Motors Offers Safety Upgrades to Prevent Nano Fires
description: In response to a handful of cases of its Nano subcompact cars catching fire, Tata Motors has issued safety upgrades to the exhaust and electrical systems, Agence France-Presse reports.

title: TimesCast | November 10, 2010
description: Tensions dominate G-20 summit; Nancy Pelosi's political future and the Latin Grammy Awards.

title: New NYC Schools Commish Might Want to Start With Mayors Office
description: The appointment of Cathleen P. Black as the next Chancellor of New York City schools by Mayor Michael Bloomberg arrived with a great deal of fanfare, but there were a few kinks in the announcement that suggest that Ms. Black, who ran a publishing enterprise, Hearst Magazines, may want to start her education efforts with her boss, the mayor (or more likely, his press minions):

title: Panel Seeks Social Security Cuts and Higher Taxes
description: WASHINGTON  The chairmen of President Obamas bipartisan commission on reducing the national debt outlined a politically provocative and economically ambitious package of spending cuts and tax increases on Wednesday, igniting a debate that is likely to grip the country for years.

title: Penney, Other Retailers, Detail Holiday Ad Plans
description: Now that J.C. Penney has introduced a campaign devoted to stimulating sales at its store in Manhattan, the retailer is unveiling its national Christmas ad campaign.

title: College Kids These Days
description: David Brooks: Gail, one of the things I get to do in this job is visit college campuses. This has made me more relaxed as my own kids apply to college. Ive learned that if you put me in an unmarked room with students from any of the top 100 colleges in the country, and let me have a one-hour discussion with them, I wouldnt be able to tell if I were at the school that was No. 1 in the U.S. News ranking or No. 100. There are a lot of smart kids everywhere.

title: In-Flight Fire Endangers Delivery Date for Boeing 787
description: Boeing halted test flights on Wednesday of its 787 Dreamliner, a day after an onboard fire forced an emergency landing, reinforcing expectations that the long-awaited plane faced more delays.

title: Report Questions the System Used to Flag Rikers Island Inmates for Deportation
description: As the Obama administration steps up efforts to deport immigrants held on criminal charges, federal officials in New York City have long been on the job. At the citys main jail on Rikers Island, immigration officers comb through lists of foreign-born inmates, then question, detain and deport about 3,200 of them a year.

title: Richard Nixon: Zombie Hunter
description: Last spring, Seth Grahame-Smith scored a best seller with Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter, in which the 16th president slashes away at legions of undead political enemies.

title: Richard Nixon: Zombie Hunter
description: Last spring, Seth Grahame-Smith scored a best seller with Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter, in which the 16th president slashes away at legions of undead political enemies.

title: Jazzs Millsap Equals Instant Offense
description: Things looked bleak at halftime for the Utah Jazz on Tuesday night, as the team was headed toward a big loss to the Heat in Miami. The Jazz was down by as much as 22 points in the second quarter, overwhelmed by LeBron James and Company.

title: The Risk-Taking Edge of West Coast Women
description: When Deborah Perry Piscione moved to Silicon Valley after a career in media and foreign relations on the East Coast, it wasnt the weather or wealth that amazed her. It was the women.

title: Fox Business Network Hires Lou Dobbs
description: The former CNN anchor Lou Dobbs will host a daily program on the Fox Business Network starting early next year, the network said Wednesday.

title: The Cost of Driving Away With the Gas Pump
description: After filling up her cars tank with gas, a friend of Bucks recently started to drive away with the gas nozzle still in the car.

title: Unserious People
description: OK, lets say goodbye to the deficit commission. If youre sincerely worried about the US fiscal future  and theres good reason to be  you dont propose a plan that involves large cuts in income taxes. Even if those cuts are offset by supposed elimination of tax breaks elsewhere, balancing the budget is hard enough without giving out a lot of goodies  goodies that fairly obviously, even without having the details, would go largely to the very affluent.

title: FIDE Picks Grischuk to Take Carlsens Place, If Not Fill His Shoes
description: Less than a week after Magnus Carlsen of Norway, the No. 2 player in the world in the official rankings (and No. 1 in unofficial but more up-to-date calculations), made his surprising announcement that he was withdrawing from the cycle to select a challenger for the world championship, the World Chess Federation announced Wednesday that he will be replaced by Alexander Grischuk of Russia, No. 6 in the world.

title: What Do East Coast Women Need to Learn About Entrepreneurship?
description: In a just-published New York Times article, Pamela Ryckman explores whether the most financially successful West Coast women, particularly those in Silicon Valley, are more entrepreneurial than their East Coast counterparts  and, if so, whether something can be done about that disparity.

title: Jay-Z and Charlie, Together on Stage
description: All those hoping to see Jay-Z interviewed by Charlie Rose at the Brooklyn Museum next week should make haste to museumtix.com or the Brooklyn Museum Visitor Center for tickets. Jay-Z, ne Shawn Carter, will be talking to Mr. Rose about his first book, Decoded (Spiegel & Grau, 2010).

title: Vain Glorious | Revlons Fire & Ice
description: In Revlons 1952 ad for the Fire & Ice Collection, Richard Avedon photographed model-of-the-moment Dorian Leigh in a sparkling silver gown framed by an amorphous tuft of red fabric (a copy of a Balenciaga cape), her hands drawing attention to her blood-colored manicure and lipstick. One of the most indelible ads in fashion history, the image was part of a niche campaign that included a Peggy Olsen-worthy tagline  Are you made for Fire & Ice?  and a bizarre questionnaire that asked, Have you ever wanted to wear an ankle bracelet? and Does gypsy music make you sad? While a lot has changed since 1952, Fire & Ice has a new shelf life now that Revlon has re-released three lip-and-tip pairings ($4.79  $ 8.99). The ad, shot by Mario Testino, restages the original, with a few notable exceptions  the actress Jessica Biel stands in for Leigh, ankle bracelets are so last century, and that dress is no knockoff.

title: Who Wrote the Book on the New Schools Chief? She Did
description: Years ago, when Cathleen P. Black, New York Citys newly appointed schools chancellor, was named president of USA Today, she was undermined by a colleague. Im not going to be reporting to you, he told her.

title: Induct Steinbrenner? Lets Think About This
description: This is all happening so fast.

title: UPDATED: Kanye West Criticizes Today Show for Brutal Interview
description: 1:56 p.m. | Updated

title: The Onion Strikes Comic Gold With Biden Spoofs
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has never smashed a Whac-A-Mole game in a drunken fit. He has never invoked Freedom of Information laws to find out a female federal employees work schedule. And to the best of anyones knowledge, he has never washed his car in the White House driveway.

title: Owners and the Hall of Fame: A Mixed Bag
description: George Steinbrenner, the polarizing Yankees owner who will appear on the National Baseball Hall of Fame ballot of the veterans committee, would be among a small group of team owners enshrined in Cooperstown and the first of the expansion era (1973 to present), which he helped shape.

title: Talk to You? Make It Worth My While
description: From Ayn Rand to Rand Paul, libertarian self-interest appears increasingly part of the mainstream conversation about how people get along with one another. But did it really have to come to this: At Columbia University, the profit motive is being harnessed to get students to be more friendly to one another.

title: Training Wheels for Charity
description: THE jewelry designer Joan Hornig believes that you can lead people to philanthropy, but that only a very special incentive can make charity second nature to them.

title: Next to Normal to Close on Jan. 16
description: Broadways Next to Normal, which in April became only the eighth musical to win the Pulitzer Prize for drama since 1918, will end its run on Jan. 16, 2011, after 21 preview performances and 733 regular performances at the Booth Theater, lead producer David Stone said on Wednesday.

title: Lou Dobbs to Join Fox Business
description: The former CNN anchor Lou Dobbs will become the host of a daily program on the Fox Business Network starting early next year, The New York Times reports.

title: E.P.A. Issues Guidance on New Emissions Rules
description: Seeking to reassure major power plant and factory owners that impending regulation of climate-altering gases will not be too burdensome, the Environmental Protection Agency emphasized on Wednesday that future permitting decisions would take cost and technical feasibility into account.

title: Where the Bubbles Are
description: Jesse Eisinger is a reporter for ProPublica, an independent, nonprofit newsroom that produces investigative journalism in the public interest. This is his first column for DealBook.

title: Catch Me If You Can Nabs Its Broadway Cast
description: Some of Broadways most-watched singer-actors have signed on for the coming musical Catch Me if You Can, with the Tony Award winner Norbert Leo Butz (Dirty Rotten Scoundrels) and Aaron Tveit (Next to Normal) assuming the lead roles of an F.B.I. agent and a charming scoundrel who were played by Tom Hanks and Leonardo DiCaprio in the 2002 movie of the same name, the producers announced on Wednesday.

title: Boehner: Ill Fly Commercial as Speaker
description: John A. Boehner, the House speaker-to-be, pledged today that he would still fly commercial airlines to his home district in Ohio after he becomes the second person in line to assume the presidency next year.

description: Images from past productions.

title: Whats Next: Updating Science Textbooks With New Discoveries
description: Overview  | How are discoveries and breakthroughs made in science? What kinds of scientific developments merit inclusion in course textbooks? In this lesson, students consider the nature of scientific research and explore recent and anticipated advancements in science. They then create digital supplements to update their own science textbooks.

title: Tommy Hilfiger-Customized 1989 Jeep Grand Wagoneer Up for Auction
description: As part of a charity fund-raiser to celebrate the centennial of the fashion industry periodical Womens Wear Daily, the designer Tommy Hilfiger has donated a personally customized 1989 Jeep Grand Wagoneer to be auctioned for charity.

title: Countries See Hazards in Free Flow of Capital
description: LONDON  In China and Taiwan, regulators are imposing fresh restrictions on stock market investments by foreigners. In Brazil, officials have twice raised taxes on foreign investors. Even in South Korea, host to this weeks Group of 20 meeting, pressure is building on the government to take similar steps.

title: A Star Chef Celebrates Fall Vegetables
description: When executive chef Michael Anthony from New York Citys Gramercy Tavern added a series of vegetable tasting dishes to the celebrated restaurants menu, he wasnt trying to attract vegetarian diners.

title: Calling On the City to Extend East Side Bike Lanes
description: Bike advocates would like to keep the Upper East Side from becoming a kind of Waterloo for protected bicycle lanes.

title: Letter: Traveling While Fat
description: To the Editor: In response to Rob Goldstones Tricks and Trials of Traveling While Fat (Oct. 24), I ask: has Mr. Goldstone seriously considered a diet? Wouldnt he be a healthier traveler after shedding some of his 285 pounds? Instead of going to Fiji, where bulk is revered, or choosing a larger seat, try smaller meals and more exercise.

title: The Sugarplum Diet
description: ACT I of The Nutcracker ends with snow falling and snowflakes dancing. Yet The Nutcracker is now seasonal entertainment even in parts of America where snow seldom falls: Hawaii, the California coast, Florida. Over the last 70 years this ballet  conceived in the Old World  has become an American institution. Its amalgam of children, parents, toys, a Christmas tree, snow, sweets and Tchaikovskys astounding score is integral to the season of good will that runs from Thanksgiving to New Year.

title: Resisting the Online Tracking Programs
description: If you have ever worried about specifically aimed ads that seem aware of your private moments on the Web, such as looking at sites for kitten-heel pumps, eczema medications or how to get out of debt, here is something else to fret about.

title: Letter: Literary Asheville
description: To the Editor: The recent 36 Hours article about Asheville, N.C., (Oct. 24) omitted two important literary sites. The boyhood home of Thomas Wolfe, at 52 North Market Street, shows visitors some of the influences on one of Americas great novelists. In nearby Flat Rock is the home of the American poet and biographer of Lincoln, Carl Sandburg, who moved to the area in 1945 to allow his wife to continue to breed champion dairy goats. The farm and the Sandburg home are a National Historic Site. Any trip to Asheville would be enriched by visiting these homes.

title: Bruins Forced to Reconfigure Forward Lines
description: From The Montreal Gazette Habs Inside/Out blog, this post examines the Boston Bruins, who have gotten off to a good start and will be in action tonight against the Pittsburgh Penguins, a game that will be televised on the NHL Network.

title: The Nutcracker Chronicles: The Marathon Begins
description: Readers who ever shared the stage with Drosselmeyer, watched a loved one dance with him or simply attended a cherished performance of The Nutcracker  I have a request: send us your photo memories and comments on this very American holiday classic.

title: Field Report: Palm Reader
description: In Los Angeles, where appearances matter, the palm trees that line Sunset Boulevard are strictly for show. To find a palm that bears fruit, you need to drive two and a half hours southeast. In the scrubby Coachella desert valley, oases of date palms rise from the gray-brown dust  acres of spiky green fronds on spindly stems supporting thousands of pounds of zahidis, barhis and other varieties. Its like the edible back lot for the set of California: The Movie.

title: Pictures of the Day: England and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from England, Iraq, Afghanistan and Washington.

title: Top 10 Must-Have Apps for the iPhone, and Some Runners-Up
description: Im always surprised when I come across people who have yet to fill their iPhone with apps. The most often cited excuse? Not enough time to sift through 300,000 apps to find the good ones.

title: Some Video Editing Is Possible on an iPod Touch
Victim Recounts Deadly Knifing in China
description: Wu Zunwei, 14, was injured, and his cousin, Wu Junpei, was killed in an April 2010 attack by Yan Jiaquin, a diagnosed schizophrenic.

title: Magic Show
description: Designers and cultural producers are in the business of divining the future. Now, thanks to a new exhibition at the National Arts Club, some of the worlds leading creatives have made a full-fledged jump to the dark side. Curated by Stacy Engman, Contemporary Magic: A Tarot Deck Art Project features the minor and major arcana as reinterpreted by 78 art and fashion world luminaries who were each matched with a card based on themes that recur in their work. Among the newly anointed mystics are Karl Lagerfeld (King of Wands), Marc Jacobs (Knight of Pentacles), John Currin (Ten of Cups) and Tracey Emin (the Empress). And in an occult line call that would have taken a master magician to adjudicate, Mickalene Thomas gets the nod as the High Priestess.

title: A Personal Story of Sexual Harassment
description: Earlier this week, I wrote about a new iPhone application that allows women to report street harassment in seconds. The application, available on iTunes, and its forthcoming Android counterpart, grew out of ihollaback.org, a Web site where women post stories of sexual harassment, groping and other unsavory incidents.

description: Photographs from England, Iraq, Afghanistan and Washington.

description: Sudden tragedy trumps creeping disaster in attracting humanitarian aid.

title: Yemen Bomb Could Have Gone Off at East Coast
description: LONDON  A package bomb from Yemen removed from a cargo plane in Britain on Oct. 29 could have exploded at dawn over the American East Coast, Scotland Yard said in a statement on Wednesday.

title: Aronian Holds Lead at Tal Memorial, Chased by Many
The Caucus
description: Nancy Pelosi will likely be the next House minority leader, but not all Democrats are happy about it.

title: The Tonys Find a Home. The Bad News? Its Small. The Good News? Its Actually on Broadway.
description: When the Tony Awards first moved from a Broadway theater to Radio City Music Hall in 1997, the main reason was size  Radio City could accommodate nearly 6,000 people, many more than even the largest Broadway house. Once the giant music hall booked Cirque du Soleil from June through September of next year, though, the Tonys were forced to hunt for new real estate for the 65th annual awards ceremony.

title: Behind Sanofis Letter to Genzyme
description: A letter sent this week by Sanofi-Aventis to the directors of Genzyme offers some insight into the behind-the-scenes drama playing out in Sanofis $18.5 billion hostile takeover bid.

title: Garth Fagan Dance at 40
description: The company celebrated its 40th anniversary at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday with premieres of dances by Mr. Fagan and Norwood Pennewell.

title: Turning 40, but Still Flying Through the Air Like a Picture of Ease
description: Garth Fagan Dance has been around for 40 years (it began as Bottom of the Bucket, but ... Dance Theater). And Norwood Pennewell has been with the company for all but eight of those years, a remarkable career for any dancer, but more so in light of the exacting rigor of Mr. Fagans oeuvre. You have to have serious chops to pull off those endless, off-center balances, disparate movement languages and space-eating leaps, and Mr. Pennewell  along with Nicolette Depass, the troupes other miraculous veteran  never disappoints.

title: A Change in Season and Regimen
description: IF Lisbeth Salander, the dark-lipped, pierced dynamo of Stieg Larssons Millennium trilogy, wanted to soften her look a bit, November would be a good time to get rid of one of her tattoos. That also goes for LeBron James, whose Loyalty tattoo, scrawled across his rib cage, has attracted derision since he left Cleveland for Miami.

title: Beauty Spots
description: WHOA, NELLY Ralph Lauren has introduced the Big Pony Collection, a new line of fragrances intended for men ages 18 to 30. In a nod to the fact that a polo team has four members, there are four scents named for supposedly desirable attributes of young men today: Sporty (lime and grapefruit), Seductive (dark chocolate and musk), Adventurous (mint and ginger), and Stylish (mandarin and kyara wood). All come in colorful flasks ($50 to $65 each).

title: Cisco Reports Higher Profit But Sees Some Weaknesses
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A tepid forecast from Cisco Systems on Wednesday sent the tech giants shares down sharply during after-hours trading and shook Wall Streets confidence that the economy is recovering.

title: Income And Life Expectancy
description: Ive referenced this before, but heres the Social Security Administration study. Look at Table 4: since 1977, the life expectancy of male workers retiring at age 65 has risen 6 years in the top half of the income distribution, but only 1.3 years in the bottom half.

title: The Seduction of Lovers, Plotted at a Faster Pace
description: The list of significant conductors who have never worked at the Metropolitan Opera grew shorter on Tuesday night, when William Christie made his company debut in Mozarts Cos Fan Tutte, a revival of Lesley Koenigs simple, sunny and charming 1996 production. Though Mr. Christie has conducted at leading opera companies in Lyon, Zurich and elsewhere, his major contributions have come from Les Arts Florissants, the early-music ensemble he founded in 1979, based in France.

title: Quirky, Eclectic and Precise
description: The opening dance quartet of Neil Greenbergs new (like a vase), at Dance Theater Workshop on Tuesday night, has a low-key air, cultivated but quirky, mildly camp and somewhat arch. The movements contain enough contrast and variety to hold your attention but not to change your breathing. This dancer prances on half-toe while her torso tips one way and then another, while that dancer stretches on the floor. But they make it feel as if it were just for insiders: interesting if youre interested.

title: Android Is 2nd in Mobile Sales, Gartner Says
description: According to a new mobile phone report released Wednesday by Gartner, the technology research company, sales of smartphones and mobile devices continued to surge in the third quarter.

title: 5 Tips for Searching Gmail
description: A 2009 research report about e-mail usage found that at least 247 billion messages are sent in a single day. Thats more than 2.8 million little e-mails that fly around the Internet every single second.

title: Madoffs Wares Go on the Block
description: Care to cook your breakfast in the Madoff familys toaster oven? Limber up on their yoga mat? Safeguard your family with their carbon monoxide detector?

title: New York Harbor, Then and Now
description: Since 1909, the city has tested the waters within New York Harbor to measure their overall quality. The effort started when the harbor, with nearly 600 miles of waterfront and about 240 miles of shipping channels, received hundreds of millions of gallons of raw sewage discharged straight from the sewer pipes.

title: Shelf Life | On the Case
description: It feels a little sacrilegious to call anything stamped Louis Vuitton a doorstop, but Louis Vuitton: 100 Legendary Trunks (Abrams; $170 for the deluxe edition, above) qualifies by heft alone  its nearly 500 pages and weighs about 10 pounds. The exhaustive, lushly illustrated book traces the history of Vuitton luggage; carry-ons these are not, either in spirit or in scale. There are engineering innovations (a bed that folds into a trunk, for the 19th-century explorer Pierre Savorgnan de Brazza), concept-only wonders (the Jetsons-esque Mars Trunk, which opens to reveal a mini cocktail bar and CD and book storage) and trunks customized to hold the inspirations and playthings of writers and artists (books for Ernest Hemingway, surgical knives for Damien Hirst). An accompanying exhibit is on view at the Carnavelet Museum in Paris until Feb. 27, 2011.

title: A New Hired Gun for the S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced Wednesday that Joseph K. Brenner, a partner at WilmerHale, has been selected as chief counsel of the division of enforcement.

title: In the Case of a Terrier, No Pets Allowed Is Overruled
description: Charlie the teacup Yorkshire terrier can stay.

title: A Long-Delayed Alliance, Cohesive and Potent
description: Better late than never  far better. AfroCubism, the group of Malian and Cuban musicians who have made an album together and who performed at Town Hall on Tuesday night, is a long-delayed collaboration. Its a musical chemistry experiment that Nick Gold, the founder of World Circuit Records, tried to assemble in 1996 by bringing Malian musicians to Havana to work with elder-generation Cuban musicians, for trans-Atlantic Afro-Cuban fusions.

title: A Last Look at South American Birds
description: Sunday, Nov. 7

title: In Boston, Listening to a Young Playwright Adept at Silence
description: BOSTON  What you notice most about Shirley, Vt., is how quiet it can get. This is not the silence classically associated with small-town America, a noiselessness that probably doesnt exist anymore anyway. There are, after all, cellphones in Shirley.

title: Gap, Its U.S. Sales Tepid, Joins the Rush to China
description: SHANGHAI  With sales in the United States sluggish, one of Americas best-known apparel brands  Gap Inc.  is joining the rush to enter Chinas fast-growing consumer market.

description: Airbnb, the service that matches budget-minded travelers with locals who are willing to rent out an extra bedroom, is getting a nice room upgrade.
