title: Uganda Seen as a Front Line in the Bioterrorism Fight
description: ENTEBBE, Uganda  The laboratories of Ugandas Ministry of Agriculture, Animals, Industry and Fisheries sit on the top of a quiet hill on a turnoff near the airport, behind an eroded fence. At the end of a hallway is a room with an unlocked refrigerator.

title: Opposition to Power Line at a Fjord Runs Deep
description: NORHEIMSUND, Norway  Change comes hard around these deep fjords on the west coast of Norway. When the first hotel went up in this town in 1857, the pious townsfolk protested: hotels brought drinking, they feared, and loose women.

title: BJs Shares Pop on News of Potential Sale
description: Investors piled into shares of BJs Wholesale Club on Wednesday like shoppers at one of its warehouses hunting for big deals, pushing the stock up 12.6 percent as the company prepared a potential sale of itself.

title: Judge Rebukes State Agency Over Atlantic Yards Timetable
description: It comes too late to halt construction, but a judge has issued a stinging rebuke to the state agency overseeing the $5 billion Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, finding that it made totally incomplete representations in legal papers about how long it would take the project to get built, in what appears to be yet another failure of transparency.

title: Brad Mehldau Is a Jazzman in a Classical Mood
description: Brad Mehldau, a star in the jazz world, has lately been asserting himself in classical precincts as well. He has written song cycles for Rene Fleming and Anne Sofie von Otter, and both singers have recorded those works with Mr. Mehldau at the piano. His solo and ensemble recordings have touched on his classical leanings too. They show him grappling with formal notions of structure and thematic development, and seeking a balance between the precisely defined gestures of composed music and the freedom and spontaneity of improvisation.

title: Title Insurance Concept Spreads Into Art Sales
description: Though standard in real estate transactions, the concept of title insurance, which guarantees that a seller is the free and clear owner, has been resisted by the art world.

title: Book Review: Jet Age  The Comet, the 707, and the Race to Shrink the World
description: In 1958, fewer than 1 in 10 American adults had ever traveled in an airplane. More than half a century after the worldwide sensation of the Wright Brothers, and almost 20 years since the Pan Am Clipper began service across the Atlantic, flying was still widely considered a vehicle for daredevils and tycoons. To cross an ocean, civilians and soldiers alike usually went by boat.

title: Near Madrid, a House of Concrete I-Beams and Steel Girders
description: A Spanish architect built the house he shares with his partner and two children using pieces of infrastructure.

title: Peace in the Pursuit of Maine Clams
description: This film has been designated as a Critics' Pick.

title: Refining The Elevator Pitch
description: Young people starting programs for social change attend a one day boot camp designed to refine their pitch.

title: The Perfect Dress for Making a Statement
description: MADE in Dagenham is not remotely what you would call a fashion film. Set in 1968, in an automobile factory outside London, it is a dramatized account of the landmark labor dispute between the Ford Motor Company and a group of female sewing machinists who demanded equal pay with men. Archival footage from this period does not suggest the actual participants in the action were the style icons of their day.

title: Via Twitter, Kanye West Chafes at Today Interview
description: An interview between Kanye West and Matt Lauer for NBCs Today show flared into a Twitter storm when, on Tuesday night, Mr. West wrote that hed been ambushed by Mr. Lauer, a Today host. Mr. West said he intended to respond to remarks by former President George W. Bush, who has said that Mr. Wests criticism after Hurricane Katrina  that Mr. Bush did not care about black people  was one of the most disgusting moments of his presidency.

title: The New Icons of Fashion
description: ANNA DELLO RUSSO lives in a glass house  the virtual kind  her subtlest gesture or sartorial quirk scrutinized by her legions of fans. Pecking at their keyboards, those online viewers wax effusive. She is like Coco Chanel to me, one admirer exclaimed on The Sartorialist, the popular blog. Isnt she fabulous ... so jolie laide, gushed another on The Fashion Spot; a third posting on Ms. Dello Russos blog, to her: I love when you wear pink.

title: A Searching Look at Combat Wounds to the Spirit
description: Part of the mission of Wartorn: 1861-2010, an HBO documentary about post-traumatic stress disorder, is to see that its subject is taken seriously. That kind of special pleading, however necessary, can have a dulling effect on a film, and Wartorn sometimes starts to feel prim and preachy. But it also has its share of quietly devastating, haunting scenes, echoes of the nightmares that veterans are bringing home with them from Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Add Edwards to List of Jets-Browns Story Lines
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Jets Coach Rex Ryan brought props to his news conference Wednesday: a blond wig, a Cleveland Browns cap and a brown XXXXXL T-shirt with a pillow underneath. Then he poked fun at the Browns defensive coordinator, his twin brother, Rob.

title: How the Best Got That Way: Finding Plays
description: Experts often seem to be luckier than the less capable, but it is usually because they find plays that make life difficult for their opponents. This deal features the winners of the World Open Pairs in Philadelphia last month, Bobby Levin and Steve Weinstein.

title: Its a Tablet. Its Gorgeous. Its Costly.
description: Every time theres some new hot, heavily hyped gadget from Apple, it takes only a few months for the copycats to crop up. IPod? Zune! IPhone? Android!

title: Cancer as Old Foe and Goad to Science
description: On its first page The Emperor of All Maladies sets forth its intention: to be a definitive history of how cancer has been understood, treated, feared and politicized throughout all of recorded human history. Thats a staggeringly tall order. Yet the author, Dr. Siddhartha Mukherjee, seeks to make it even taller. His book also aspires to be a biography of cancer, even though Dr. Mukherjee (a cancer specialist and researcher with stellar credentials) cannot exactly explain what that phrase means.

title: Putting Star Power Behind Good Works
description: THE telephone connection was fuzzy, ruffled around the edges by Hurricane Tomas, bearing down on Haiti, where Sean Penn had agreed to an interview from the tent in a refugee camp where he was living.

title: Therapy Dogs at Work
description: Therapists who work with autistic children have found that some useful treatment comes with four paws and fur.

title: Kelly Hoppen Introduces an iPhone App
description: Kelly Hoppen, the English interior designer, has published six books. She also owns a store in West London and holds an occasional five-day master class (for which she charges about $4,700, including tax). I have a multimillion-pound business, she said.

title: For Autistic Children, Therapy on Four Legs
description: SHADOW, a black Labrador retriever, knows how to interact with people without overreacting to them  a necessity for a well-trained therapy dog, said her owner and handler, Ani Shaker.

title: Going Korean
description: Pedicures are disgraceful.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: A Social Web Browser
description: Netscape alumni are introducing a browser called RockMelt that integrates social media into the browser. On this weeks Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein talks to Miguel Helft, a technology reporter for The New York Times, about how this new browser works. Mr. Helft says RockMelt makes it easy to post to Facebook, Twitter and other sites and communicate with friends. But users must log in because RockMelt manages interactions with social networking sites in its data center. Given the competitiveness of the browser market, RockMelt can anticipate challenges, Mr. Helft says.

title: Nike Harnesses Girl Effect Again
description: FIFTEEN years ago, Nike made a splash with an advertising campaign known as If you let me play. The ads drew considerable attention  and praise  because they advocated the benefits for girls and young women of participating in sports.

title: No Bridge Too Far: Literary Agents Move to Brooklyn
description: When David Black contemplated moving his 21-year-old literary agency to a new office space this summer, he had one nagging worry: the East River.

title: Can a Nerd Have Soul?
description: THE SINGER Mayer Hawthorne was born almost 13 years after the Supremes Motown classic You Cant Hurry Love first lit up radio waves and dance floors. He was a toddler when the songs bass line, maybe the most famous in the history of pop-and-soul music, was amplified and repackaged as the basis of Daryl Hall and John Oatess No. 1 hit Maneater; it was also suited up and sent back into action by the likes of the Clash, Katrina and the Waves and even other Motown artists. Something about those repeated eight notes  originally played by the Motown house bassist James Jamerson in 1966 as if small shocks were being delivered to his index finger  continued to evoke, across a span of decades, the tachycardic rush of new love or lust.

title: Campaigning for Friends as Much as for Sales
description: DURING the economic downturn, many brands turned to nostalgia marketing to strike a reassuring chord, like General Mills selling Trix and other varieties in retro boxes, Nationwide Insurance resurrecting its Nationwide is on your side slogan and Bumble Bee Tuna reviving its Yum, yum, Bumble Bee jingle.

title: A Wireless Speaker(phone) for Smartphones
description: Jawbone, maker of all kinds of earpieces for mobile phones, has branched out into the speaker business. Its first foray, the four-pack-of-butter size Jambox, seems to have succeeded right out of the gate.

title: Prostate Cancer Drug Gets Lukewarm Review
description: There is only moderate evidence that the newly approved prostate cancer drug Provenge helps patients, according to an analysis done for Medicare that was made public on Wednesday.

title: The Turban Makes a Glamorous Comeback
description: Once linked to grannies in housecoats, the turban has a new association for young women.

title: The Head Wrap Comes Back, Again
description: WEARING a turban demands confidence. You have to believe, truly believe, in your look. You have to commit  its a turban, after all. And if you use hats to hide uncooperative hair or to keep a low profile, the turban is not a smart choice.

title: A New Canvas Store in SoHo
description: Andrew Corrie, a British ex-banker, introduced Canvas two years ago as a collection of furnishings with the tag line Simple Sustainable Style. Since then, what began as a hobby inspired by serving on the board of the nonprofit group Aid to Artisans has grown into a proper brand with more than 300 products artfully showcased in its first store.

title: The Egle Table Lamp From Artemide
description: The new Egle table lamp can multitask: the diffuser rotates 300 degrees, and the stem rotates vertically and horizontally. The base, which is slightly concave, doubles as a reflector and a jewelry tray. The 10-watt LED bulb, which throws out a circle of light some two feet in diameter, provides both direct light and  if you aim the diffuser so the light reflects off the base  an ambient glow.

title: The Hazel Effect
description: THE street addresses of my life, and there have been a great number of them, have often felt less like home to me than the places Ive written about. The New Canaan, Conn., of 1973, when I was writing about it in the early 90s. The Arizona of the near future, in a recent novel. I love landscapes of the imagination, less so the topographies of the so-called real world. And I suspect thats the case with many writers of fiction.

title: Sales at Alessi, Waterworks, John Robshaw and Others
description: On Nov. 11 only, Alessi will mark down all items in its stores 20 percent (a Michael Graves tea kettle, regularly $175, is $140); 130 Greene Street (Prince Street), (212) 941-7300, and 30 East 60th Street (Madison Avenue), (212) 317-9880, alessi.com.

title: Patrick Jouin on Reconciling Functionality With Aesthetics
description: Patrick Jouin, the Paris-based designer, has a diverse portfolio that includes hotels, lamps and space age-like furniture made with a process known as selective laser sintering. And a surprising number of his projects are food-related  restaurant interiors for Alain Ducasse, a pasta pot and cutting board for Alessi, flatware for Puiforcat, a special spreader for Nutella, and a Champagne bucket and saber for Mumm, to name a few. Many of these objects are now on display in Manhattan, at the Museum of Arts and Design, in Patrick Jouin: Design and Gesture, an exhibition that runs through Feb. 6.

title: A Final Cocoon: Dying at Home
description: THERE is some confusion about the cause of the liver disease that has given Fred Kress a short time to live. The 46-year-old handyman and house painter, who lives outside of Baltimore, had had hepatitis C, which causes liver damage, for several years. Doctors at one point suggested that alcohol abuse may have been a contributing factor, which makes no sense, Mr. Kress and his family say, because he was never much of a drinker. The real culprit, he now believes, was chemical: he didnt wear the right mask when he was painting houses, and when he did his craft projects, making alien masks out of fiberglass resin, he worked in a small, windowless room, ignoring all the warning labels on the supplies he used.

title: A Barter Network for Designers on a Budget
description: After a years trial period, OurGoods.org, an online barter network for designers and artists in New York City, is open to the public. The site promotes the swapping of skills, space, labor and art objects; designers on a budget will find an expanding list of offerings, including custom wallpaper, vintage fabrics and lessons in soap making and upholstery.

title: Plant Experts Picks for Hardy Indoor Plants
description: Houseplants for shady windows, dry winters and inept gardeners.

title: Hard to Kill: Houseplants for the Inept
description: FOR years now, my foyer has been a halfway house for indoor plants  that is, halfway between a cozy berth in someone elses home and a paupers grave in my backyard.

title: Drug Suits Raise Questions for Doctors, and Juries
description: Judith Graves, a 67-year-old retired investigator for the United States Army, developed a rare medical condition called jawbone death after taking Fosamax, a drug used by millions of American women with thinning bones.

title: Shopping With Nancy Fitzpatrick
description: The owner of the historic Red Lion Inn in Stockbridge, Mass., picked out furnishings for guest rooms with a distinctive sense of style.

title: Walter Isard, Economist Who Studied How Regions Evolve, Dies at 91
description: Walter Isard, an economist who founded the field of regional science, inspiring social scientists to study the relationships between such factors as geography, migration and land use in local or regional economies, died on Saturday at his home in Drexel Hill, Pa. He was 91.

title: Gleeful Gore at Players Theater
description: When you see a good show, you like to come away with a keepsake: the ticket stub, the program, perhaps a T-shirt purchased in the lobby. The people behind Play Dead apparently know this, because they make every effort to send you home with a fellow audience members entrails stuck in your hair or lodged in your tote bag.

title: Guest Room Furnishings
description: AS the owner of the historic Red Lion Inn in Stockbridge, Mass., and a developer of the Porches Inn in North Adams, Mass., Nancy Fitzpatrick has spent plenty of time designing and renovating guest rooms.

title: A Titan of Business? Just Call Him Coach
description: Joe Moglia became the head coach of the expansion Virginia Destroyers of the two-year-old United Football League on Wednesday  his first coaching job in 27 years.

title: FedExs Chief on the Payoff of Corporate Giving
description: Frederick W. Smith, chairman and chief executive of FedEx, doesnt publicize his own giving much, but enthusiastically supports his companys efforts, which he said in an interview pay dividends in many ways.

title: Sprint Gets an iPhone, Sort Of
description: Update: Added calculations regarding the amount of data per minute was used when placing an VoIP call.Thanks to the wonder that is Voice over Internet Protocol, better known as VoIP, people have long been able to make phone calls from computers or, say, an iPod Touch.

title: Raise High the Bridge Beam for a House in Spain
description: Las Matas, Spain

title: U.S. Blocks Irans Bid for a U.N. Board Seat
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United States orchestrated the defeat of Irans push to gain a seat Wednesday on the board of the new United Nations organization dedicated to gender equality around the world, in keeping with the broader American strategy to isolate Iran.

title: In Case of Disaster, Carriers Stand Ready to Airlift Aid
description: WAYNE YANKOVICH was at his home in Indianapolis on his day off when he heard that an earthquake had just struck Haiti. His wife, Louise, was downstairs watching CNN and immediately relayed the news.

title: The Special Pain of a Slow Disaster
description: THE water came slowly, masking its power with sluggishness. But Farooq Tariq, a human rights activist long accustomed to helping hapless civilians through Pakistani disasters, knew it meant trouble.

title: Knicks Walsh to Have Surgery
description: 8:53 p.m. | Updated Donnie Walsh, the Knicks president, said he would have hip-replacement surgery next week and would return to the team as quickly as possible. Walsh, 69, has relied first on a wheelchair and then a walker since undergoing neck surgery in June to remove bone spurs.

title: Italian Studies Regains Spot on the List of AP Courses
description: The Advanced Placement Italian Language and Culture program  which began in 2005 and was suspended last year because too few students were participating in it to warrant the cost  will be reinstated next year, and its AP exam will again be offered in May 2012.

title: Promising Catcher Appears Ready for Pinstripes
description: The Yankees gave $2 million to Jesus Montero in July 2006, outbidding the Mets, the Boston Red Sox and the Cleveland Indians. Their investment got them a stocky 16-year-old hitting prodigy from Venezuela and the belief that they had signed their next great catcher.

title: Trading Up: Military Jackets
description: Military jackets recombine elements of various archetypes to create subtly masculine coats with a bit of brass-button flair that are anything but standard issue.

title: Ex-KB Home Chief Receives Probation
description: Bruce E. Karatz, a former chief executive at KB Home, was sentenced on Wednesday to five years of probation after he was convicted in April of hiding from auditors and regulators that he had backdated stock options.

title: Morgans (Brief) Response to ESPNs Move
description: Joe Morgans first comment since ESPN declined to renew his contract with Sunday Night Baseball this week was short and succinct.

title: Standard Issue: Just High Military Style
description: ITS no secret that former soldiers often feel that their years of service go unsung  even today, on a day dedicated to veterans. But our men and women in uniform get an indirect homage every day of the year, given the undisputed sway the military holds in one realm: the wardrobe. From brass-buttoned blazers and A-2 leather bomber jackets to khaki trousers and camouflage cargo pants, it has bestowed more clothing styles on the civilian closet than any other walk of life.

title: The Haggling Begins for Troubled Assets
description: It is the biggest rummage sale in Wall Street history  what one investment company calls the Great Liquidation.

title: A Butcher Who Lacks a Killer Instinct
description: John McFadden Jr. jokes that his fate was sealed when he was born the same year his father bought Staubitz Market, a butcher shop in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, that was established in 1917. Mr. McFadden, 43, got his start in the family business at age 10, sweeping up blood-soaked sawdust (the traditional butcher-shop floor covering). Now co-owner with his father, 74, he lives a few blocks from the shop with his wife, Christine Kim, 44, and their son, Aidan, 5, in Carroll Gardens and has a woodworking shop upstate.

title: Trial of 2nd Man Will Revisit the Horror of a Triple Murder
description: Connecticut is catching its collective breath after the diet of appalling details that spilled out daily from the trial of Steven J. Hayes, who got the death penalty on Monday for his role in the Cheshire home invasion that left a woman and her two daughters dead.

title: Economic Crisis Sidelines Fate of the Worlds Poorest
description: WASHINGTON  Last year, after a personal appeal from President Obama in which he cited his own familys experiences in Kenya, world leaders gathered at the Italian hill town of LAquila pledged $20 billion over three years to help millions of the worlds poorest farmers grow enough food to feed themselves  a landmark achievement organizers said in a report.

title: No Room in This Town for Change Brought by an Inn
description: SALISBURY, Conn.

title: Disclosure Runs Into 140-Character Limits
description: If you bought Yoplait yogurt recently, you may have noticed more than the usual nutritional data on the container. Those with pink lids bore the slogan Save Lids to Save Lives and a promise to donate 10 cents for each lid sent in, up to $1.6 million, to Susan G. Komen for the Cure, an organization that supports breast cancer research.

title: U.S. Struggles to Restore Middle East Talks
description: WASHINGTON  With tensions between the United States and Israel flaring again over Jewish settlements, the Obama administration and its allies worked feverishly on multiple fronts Wednesday to put Middle East peace talks back on track.

title: Monopoly by Marc Jacobs
description: MARC JACOBS is the Michael Bloomberg of the West Village and also its Sam Walton. Jane Jacobs would have loved him, if she wasnt overcome by conniptions at his oozing influence over her beloved neighborhood streets. He is a colonialist, an extender of brands, and in very good shape.

title: At Some Nail Salons, Feeling Pretty and Green
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The bottles of nail polish at the Nova Nail Spa include Sky Sparkle blue, Hot Blooded pink and I Feel The Earth Move brown. But the predominant color at Kim Phams chic salon is health-conscious green.

title: New Yorkers From Mexico Escorted Miner in Race
description: Millions of people around the city and the world watched and cheered Edison Pea as he ran in the New York City Marathon on Sunday.

title: Pledge to Give Away Fortunes Stirs Debate
description: WITHOUT a doubt, the biggest event in philanthropy this year was the Giving Pledge, a commitment by 40 of the wealthiest Americans to give away at least half of their fortunes, about $600 billion.

title: Jeffersons Army of Nation Builders
description: Swarthmore, Pa.

title: A Bonanza of Riches for Bank Rescuers
Quintin Dailey, Gifted but Troubled Player, Dies at 49
description: Quintin Dailey, a talented but troubled basketball player whose missteps, including a sexual assault conviction, contributed to the University of San Franciscos decision to drop its storied basketball program for three years, died Monday in Las Vegas. He was 49.

title: As Donors Retrench, Challenges for Universities
description: AS the stock market soared for two decades, college and university endowments swelled with gifts. Over the last 10 years, contributions to higher education have risen an average of 4.1 percent a year, despite the downturn.

title: Cooking and Shopping With Mom and Dad
description: Four lessons from South Florida, where I spent part of last week helping my parents get settled. (They spend the winter there.) We were together two nights, and I opted to cook.

title: With New Coach, Cowboys Hope to Stop Their Free Fall
description: IRVING, Tex.  Two days after firing its coach, Americas favorite 1-7 football team returned to practice, which meant the Dallas Cowboys returned to their crazy version of normal, which meant the circus returned to Valley Ranch. Around here, they call that Wednesday.

title: What Everything Means
description: I cant stop thinking about the elections. Last weekend I saw 127 Hours, and all I could think about was that this was a metaphor for the lame-duck session of Congress.

title: Pooling Small Contributions, Hoping for Big Results
description: IT was just about a year ago that Kelsey Warner had a chance to help save someones life.

title: The Rich Are Different From You and Me. They Give More.
description: AT the top of the economic ladder, many Americans are generous with their wealth and time, supporting efforts to meet basic human needs, education, the arts, religion, the environment, animal welfare and more.

title: Giving a Gift and Getting a Return
description: FOR retirees increasingly worried as interest rates on their savings accounts and money market funds have plunged below 1 percent, an appeal from their alma mater or a respected charity, offering a return of 5 percent or more on a charitable gift annuity, can seem like a rare opportunity.

title: Charities Wrestle With Tax Uncertainty
description: A GROWING number of charities are persuading donors to create a little-known kind of endowment as the troubled economy and this years hiatus from the estate tax create problems for charities that depend on major lifetime gifts and on bequests.

title: Looking for a Job? Try a Nonprofit
description: OVER the last few years, as corporations fired workers en masse, some of the newly unemployed began sending their rsums to nonprofits. But often the job picture there was just as bleak  even as the need for services became greater.

title: Online Giving, One Person at a Time
description: SHORTLY after the devastating Typhoon Ondoy made landfall in the Philippines last year, Wendy Harman, social media director at the American Red Cross, noticed that her organization had hit the trending topics list on Twitter, a list of the social networks most-discussed subjects. Thousands of people around the world were posting the Red Crosss toll-free phone number and asking their friends to donate to the rescue effort.

title: Boston Museum Grows by Casting a Wide Net
description: ABOUT four years ago, at the suggestion of a mutual friend, Ronald C. Wornick paid a call on Malcolm A. Rogers, the director of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, looking for a home for the contemporary decorative art that he and his wife, Anita, collect.

title: As Millions Seek Work, an Overhaul in Retraining
description: TALK to a displaced worker who has just finished a retraining program, and chances are youre talking to someone who still doesnt have a job.

title: Helping Veterans Find Civilian Jobs
description: MANY veterans are finding that jobs in this difficult economy require skills and training they do not have. Government data shows a higher unemployment rate for recent veterans than for the general population.

title: Foundations With a Limited Life
description: TRADITIONALLY people who set up private foundations  either during their lifetimes or through an estate plan  envisioned an entity that would carry on their philanthropy for generations. But lately, some founders or their immediate successors are spending their full endowments and closing down. Other donors are creating new foundations with a limited life span.

title: Young Activists Practice Their Pitches for Nonprofits
description: THE recruits at boot camp are getting their final briefing before going into action.

title: Fly-Fishing Group Offers an Escape From the Hospital
description: THE South Platte River in Colorado ran cold and clear that Sunday, clear enough even for Rhonda Carey to see the fish she was trying to catch. The wind was so strong, she recalled, that the volunteer who was helping her had to hold on to her hip-waders to keep her upright.

title: Yahoo Hires a Time Inc. Ad Man
description: Yahoo has hired Wayne Powers, a former Time Inc. executive, to revive its slumping as sales business as its North American ad sales senior vice president.

title: Womens Group Cites 12 Districts in Title IX Complaint
description: A womens legal group filed complaints Wednesday with the federal education department alleging that 12 school districts nationwide  including New York, Chicago and Houston  are violating federal law by failing to offer equal opportunities to boys and girls who play high school sports.

title: Photo Sharing on the Go Is the Latest Hot Investment Niche in Silicon Valley
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In Silicon Valley, the three words on the tips of everyones tongues are mobile, social and local.

title: H.P. to Pay $16 Million to Settle Suits
description: WASHINGTON  Hewlett-Packard has agreed to pay $16.25 million to the federal government to settle whistle-blower lawsuits alleging that contractors working for the company lavished meals and gifts, including yacht trips and Super Bowl tickets, on school district officials in Texas to win contracts for computer equipment.

title: Would the South Really Leave?
Times Will Rank E-Book Best Sellers
description: In an acknowledgment of the growing sales and influence of digital publishing, The New York Times said on Wednesday that it would publish e-book best-seller lists in fiction and nonfiction beginning early next year.

title: For Now, a Rebel Just Wants to Fit In
description: NASHVILLE

title: Knicks and Fans Honor Lee on His Return
description: In five years as a Knick, David Lee became an elite rebounder, a skilled scorer, an All-Star and a fan favorite. But points came more easily than victories, so when Lee was asked, upon his return, to share his best moments, he was stumped.

title: Telescope Is Behind Schedule and Over Budget, Panel Says
description: The planned successor to the Hubble Space Telescope, designed to peer to the edges of the universe and beginning of time, is running about one-third over its $5 billion budget and more than a year behind schedule, an independent review panel reported Wednesday.

title: Browsing: Shopping Snapshots for Nov. 11
description: Handbags that carry the essentials in style; sporting fashion; and more.

title: Some Fiscal Reality
description: The draft proposal by the chairmen of President Obamas deficit-reduction commission was a welcome antidote to the low-minded debate that dominated the midterm elections, in which politicians all vowed to reduce the deficit but offered no credible plans.

title: Scouting Report
description: SALES

title: Lottery Numbers
F.C.C. Investigates Google Street View
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Communications Commission said Wednesday that it was investigating whether Google had violated laws when it collected Wi-Fi data as part of its Street View photo project.

title: Liars Club
description: If common sense were currency Michele Bachmann would be broke, and holding a tin can by the roadside just now. Alas, because we live in an age where hyperbole is gold, Bachmann is rich.

title: Early Write-In Count in Alaska Favors Senator
description: JUNEAU, Alaska  The first fraction of write-in ballots counted in the Alaska Senate race appeared promising for Senator Lisa Murkowski and spoke well of Alaskans ability to spell: with 19 percent of precincts counted Wednesday, election officials say she received about 98 percent of all write-in ballots cast.

title: Life in Shadows for Mentally Ill in China
description: XIZHEN, China  After five months in a rundown ward at the Hepu County Psychiatric Hospital, Yang Jiaqin no longer suffers terrifying hallucinations. Still, his wife dares not mention children, not even their own, for fear of unleashing the demons that possessed him one day last spring.

title: U.S. Tweaks Message on Troops in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is increasingly emphasizing the idea that the United States will have forces in Afghanistan until at least the end of 2014, a change in tone aimed at persuading the Afghans and the Taliban that there will be no significant American troop withdrawals next summer.

title: After 92 Days of No Lights, Seeing One at the End of the Tunnel
description: Though it has been the site of some hard times, Cherry DeLeons Harlem apartment feels warm and inviting. Soft R&B plays on the stereo. The walls are covered in bright colors and decorative touches. On the bedroom wall hang two framed portraits of a younger Ms. DeLeon, with crimped, bleached hair and a style straight from the 1980s.

title: Communities Embrace Veterans of Vietnam War
description: MANASSAS, Va.  Charles Howell, a Vietnam War veteran, wore his camouflage Army jacket and jungle hat in public for the first time in more than 40 years recently, when he attended the Veterans Day parade in this Civil War battleground city. He said he no longer cared about possible negative reactions to his military service.

title: A Special Court for Veterans
description: Philadelphia

title: Bachmann Drops Leadership Bid
description: That sigh of relief you heard?

title: Waiting for Senator McCain
description: Senator John McCain has long defended the rights of military servicemen and women. It is a particular disappointment that he is vowing to filibuster the Pentagons spending bill unless a measure repealing the dont ask, dont tell policy is stripped out  or he is satisfied about its effects on morale and readiness.

title: Mayor Takes Idea of Education Outsider to New Level
description: The notion of who can run a large public school system has shifted radically in the past decade, as lawyers, bankers and budget experts with little classroom experience  beyond sitting in one  have been tapped as superintendents and chancellors throughout the country.

title: Alaska May Offer a View to Future Elections
description: WASHINGTON  Its tempting to write off anything that happens in Alaska politics as just plain weird, the result of irregular sunlight or too many low-altitude flights. And maybe that explains whats happening in the countrys last undecided Senate race, where Senator Lisa Murkowski now seems likely to pull off an unlikely victory as a write-in candidate, after having been ousted by a Tea Party candidate in a Republican primary in August.

title: Thursday: Degrees
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Thursdays are special. Ive called Thursday the playful Scherzo of the puzzle week because any crazy twist is possible. For many solvers, its the day they most look forward to  wild innovation but still not as hard as late-week themeless crosswords.

title: A Stain on Her Marxist Mantle
description: Dramas of fractured families have become the Duane Reade drugstore of the New York theater, so plentiful that another story of squabbling over the dinner table cannot expect to offer much in the way of jolting surprises. But as its fiery title implies, After the Revolution, a fine and fiercely well-acted new play by Amy Herzog that opened Wednesday night at Playwrights Horizons Peter Jay Sharp Theater, has more on its mind than recycling familiar grievances for a couple of hours of entertainment.

Future schools chancellors in New York City will benefit from several important reforms put in place during the tenure of Joel Klein, who resigned this week after eight years as chancellor under Michael Bloomberg, the first mayor to have direct control of the nations largest school system.

But with his Democratic caucus reduced, and Republicans set to take over the House, Mr. Reid may want to brush up on his magic skills: passing bills next year, or even just keeping his senators unified, may require gravity-defying tricks.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,361 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Wednesday:

title: Decision Near on Site of Terrorism Trial
description: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said Wednesday that the Obama administration was close to a decision on a trial for Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four other men accused of planning the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. Mr. Holders remark to reporters prompted both Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, and Representative Peter T. King, Republican of New York, to repeat their opposition to a 9/11 trial anywhere in New York State. Most Republicans have said the 9/11 defendants should be tried by a military commission at Guantnamo Bay; Democrats have been divided, with some asserting that a federal criminal trial is the right forum. Mr. Holders comments came as a federal jury in Manhattan began deliberations in the case of the first former Guantnamo detainee, Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani.

title: Administration Asks Court to Let Dont Ask, Dont Tell Law Stand
description: The Obama administration said the Supreme Court should let the military continue to bar openly gay and lesbian people under the dont ask, dont tell policy, arguing that a change in the law should come from Congress, not the courts. The acting United States solicitor general, Neal Katyal, the administrations top courtroom lawyer, urged the justices on Wednesday not to reinstate a federal judges order that had temporarily suspended the law. Virginia A. Phillips, a federal judge, declared the law unconstitutional in September, and a Republican gay rights group is seeking to put that ruling into effect immediately. A federal appeals court put Judge Phillipss order on hold.

title: Lichtenstein Tops Warhol in Auction at Christies
description: Two Pop masters, Warhol and Lichtenstein, vied for bragging rights at Christies auction of postwar and contemporary art on Wednesday night  and although Warhol dominated sales at Phillips de Pury and Sothebys earlier this week, Lichtenstein managed to take the lead.

description: Washington on Wednesday became the second state to ban energy drinks that combine alcohol and caffeine amid rising concern that the beverages are dangerous.

title: Russia: Journalist Is Convicted of Slander
description: A crusading Russian journalist who was crippled in a brutal beating two years ago was convicted on a criminal slander charge on Wednesday. Despite criticism from rights groups, prosecutors in a Moscow suburb, Khimki, had refused to drop the charge against the journalist, Mikhail Beketov. A judge found him guilty of slandering the Khimki mayor, Vladimir Strelchenko, by accusing him of involvement in blowing up Mr. Beketovs car. Mr. Beketov was fined a nominal amount, which was then suspended. Mr. Beketov made the comments at issue well before he was beaten. No one has been arrested in that crime.

Tom Carper of Delaware, a Democrat, and George Voinovich of Ohio, a Republican, wrote to President Obamas commission on reducing the federal debt, proposing the measure. They suggest that 10 cents of the increase go toward paying down the debt, and the rest toward transportation infrastructure. [The Hill]

title: Gwyneth Paltrow Is Country-Stronger Than Expected
description: In case you missed Wednesday nights broadcast of the Country Music Association Awards or Jon Caramanicas take on the event in Thursdays New York Times, heres our brutally expedient wrap-up on the night: something something Miranda Lambert, yada yada yada Brad Paisley, blah blah blah Taylor Swift, et cetera et cetera Gwyneth Paltrow sang with Vince Gill. Thats correct: Ms. Paltrow, the Academy Award-winning actress and lifestyle guru, was backed up by Mr. Gill for a performance of Country Strong, the title track from a coming movie in which she plays a down-and-out country musician. Mr. Caramanica wrote that the surprise of Ms. Paltrow and Mr. Gills collaboration was that she didnt need his steadying hand nearly as much as some of the nights other performers. Were in no position to judge because were still astounded her cover of Bette Davis Eyes charted in Australia, and that was 10 years ago.

description: SEOUL, South Korea  Josef Ackermann, chief executive of Deutsche Bank and head of the Institute of International Finance, said on Thursday that the financial regulatory overhaul under way in much of the world, through the Dodd-Frank overhaul in the United States and the Basel III bank capital requirements, had to be put into effect in a fair way.

title: Maison Bellaishs Home Away From Home
description: On the stores opening day Daria Werbowy stumbled in and fell in love with the collection, said Victor Bellaish, the designer behind Maison Bellaish. Who could ask for a better first customer? Since its inception in 2006, the young Tel Aviv-based brands whimsical and romantic pieces were available by appointment only; but the recent opening of an outpost in New Yorks Meatpacking district at 36 Little West 12th Street will change all of that. Silk dresses, blouses, and meticulously adorned made-to-order lace and crystal evening gowns come out of a nostalgic art-nouveau atelier within the minimally decorated boutique. I am able to build more of a relationship with the Bellaish woman in an intimate salon, said the designer, who is known for being on-hand to personally fit every client. Maison Bellaish is home to the boundless woman. She doesnt need to be trendy because she knows a beautiful fabric and a great shape.

description: In our weekly Poetry Pairing series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poems themes. description: My take on Alan Simpson and Erskine Bowles deficit reduction proposal closely aligns with Ramesh Ponnurus comments  which is to say, Im largely favorable, with some caveats surrounding our shared hobbyhorse of pro-family tax reform. And having used this weeks column to gripe about Republican policy unseriousness, Im heartened that the deficit proposal has been greeted respectfully, not only by right-of-center journalists and economists, but by some actual Republican politicians as well.

description: More than three weeks after we called for comments on your financial regrets, we continue to receive your self-kicking missives  on everything from love to career choice to child rearing. To make sense of this phenomenon, we asked Jay S. Kwawer, Ph.D., the director of the William Alanson White Institute of Psychiatry, Psychoanalysis and Psychology, for context and understanding. Read on for his analysis.

title: Dino De Laurentiis, Prolific Film Producer, Dies at 91
description: Dino De Laurentiis, the high-flying Italian film producer and entrepreneur whose movies ranged from some of Federico Fellinis earliest works to Serpico, Death Wish and the 1976 remake of King Kong, died on Wednesday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 91.

description: LONDON  The European Union stands ready to offer a financial lifeline to Ireland, an official said on Thursday, as bond investors apply pressure that threatens to derail Europes fragile economic recovery.

title: Russia Hunts Double Agent Who Betrayed Spies, Newspaper Says
description: Updated | 4:20 p.m. A Moscow newspaper reported on Thursday that the Kremlin has dispatched an assassin to hunt down a suspected double agent it blames for betraying the Russian spies arrested in June by the United States.

title: Judge Chides Prosecutors in KB Home Case
description: A federal judge in Los Angeles lambasted federal prosecutors late Wednesday at the sentencing of Bruce Karatz, the former chief executive of KB Home, who was given five years probation following his conviction on charges related to backdating stock options.

title: Asked & Answered | Anna Sui
description: For three decades the designer Anna Sui has tickled a hard-nosed industry with unabashed imagination and the kind of fairytale twinkle that is straight out of childhood ballerina boxes and teenage diaries. At their most fanciful, her clothes summon a dream of fun-loving womanhood, of idols and heroines: Janis Joplin, Marie Antoinette and Marisa Berenson on the dance floor, all in a single collection. But reverie hardly explains Suis loved and labored mtier. She started her eponymous collection in 1981 while working a day job, and opened her New York boutique in 1992  the first of 300 sales outlets  just a year after her first runway show. Since 1997, Sui has also parlayed licensing deals in cosmetics, accessories and spin-off clothing lines that extend from Turkey to Japan. A new anthology published by Chronicle Books suggests that the lynchpin of her unique career is encyclopedic curiosity as much as commercial acumen, studied process and a deep respect for the techniques and traditions of her craft.

title: Thursday Reading: Title Insurance for Art
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Heres a Surprise for Underground Art Lovers: Handcuffs
description: The New York City police have arrested 20 people for trying to enter the abandoned subway station that is home to the formerly secret guerrilla exhibition of underground street art that was revealed to the public this month.

title: 2012 Contenders to Bet Against

title: Fewer Veterans to Honor on Their Day
description: The number of military veterans living in New York City has shrunk by one-third since 2000, according to the census. They now constitute just 3.6 percent of the population over 18 years old, compared with 5.7 percent a decade ago.

title: Spider-Man Musical Teams With Syfy Channel
description: In a rare partnership for a Broadway show, the coming musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark has struck a deal with Syfy, the imagination based cable outlet formerly known as the Sci-Fi Channel, to be the shows lead media partner for television and Internet commercials, promotions and contests.

description: Showing a willingness once again to open its checkbook to lure big names, the Fox Business Network said on Wednesday that it had hired Lou Dobbs, the former CNN anchor, to head a daily program.

title: Met Says Levine Is Much Better After Illness Forces Withdrawal
description: James Levine, the music director of the Metropolitan Opera, withdrew from a performance of Don Pasquale at intermission Wednesday night because of a stomach virus, the Met said. Joseph Colaneri, an assistant conductor at the house, stepped in and led the final act. The Met said on Thursday that Mr. Levine, 67, was much better and planned to conduct the opera on Saturday, as scheduled. Mr. Levine has suffered a series of health problems in past years, most recently back trouble that resulted in spinal surgery in April. The problems have forced him to cancel many performances at the Met and the Boston Symphony Orchestra, where he is also music director.

title: Madison Square Park, 10:50 A.M.
After Saying Ciao, College Board Brings Back A.P. Italian
description: Next year, high school students will again have the opportunity to take the Advanced Placement Italian Language and Culture program, which was suspended last year, just four years after it began, because the level of interest did not, apparently, justify the cost.

title: Grants Awarded for Preservation of New York Sites
description: Eight projects to save historic and culturally significant sites in New York City have been awarded grants by the National Trust for Historic Preservation, the trust announced. The recipients include the Friends of the Upper East Side Historic Districts in Manhattan, and the Louis Armstrong House Museum and the Free Synagogue of Flushing, both in Queens. The grants, which range from $2,000 to $10,000, were financed by Robert and Elizabeth Jeffe, longtime supporters of historic reservation. Ms. Jeffe is a board member at the trust.

title: For Mayor of White Plains, a Trial and an Unclear Future

In the past nine months, though, local politics have crept into the conversation, after a domestic violence scandal involving the mayor became public.
