description: Images of coffee cocktail at the Randolph on Broome.

title: Tipsy Diaries: Beans With Booze
description: Frank Bruni, a former restaurant critic for The Times, explores how coffee and liquor mix at the Randolph in SoHo.

title: Attention Sports Fans: N.H.L. Is Playing Hockey
description: We interrupt our regularly scheduled programming for an update on the N.H.L.  for those of you watching most major American networks, yes, the season started a month ago  and the absolutely riveting slow-speed pileup that is the New Jersey Devils.

title: Greek Jobless Rate Hit Record High in August
description: Greeces jobless rate rose to a record 12.2 percent in August, while the nations progress in reducing its deficit appeared to slow, government data showed Thursday.

title: Red Rooster Harlem, Still Not Ready, Offers an Amuse-Bouche
description: This isnt even a preview, its an amuse-bouche, Marcus Samuelsson said of a three-hour bash Wednesday night for 300 invited guests at Red Rooster Harlem, his coming restaurant on Lenox Avenue near West 125th Street. Though the $2 million, 100-seat Red Rooster was scheduled to open two months ago, its estimated time of arrival is now late November to early December, a spokesman for Mr. Samuelsson said. The party was a chance to see how the space works, Mr. Samuelsson said.

title: Greater Firepower, Fewer Shots
description: There were about 29,000 police officers on the job in New York City in 1971, compared with the roughly 35,000 officers employed today. Officers in 1971 carried six-shot revolvers, not the sleek 16-shot semiautomatic pistols that hang from the waists of most of todays officers.

title: A Panel Discussion on the New York Taxi of Tomorrow
description: On Tuesday night, the Design Trust for Public Space sponsored a panel discussion about the future of the New York taxi at the Museum of the City of New York. The trust was also the sponsor of Taxi 07, which issued policy proposals about the taxi industry in New York and displayed eight concept vehicles at the New York auto show in 2007.

title: Crippled Cruise Ship Reaches Shore
description: SAN DIEGO  They arrived at the dock just after 8 a.m., hanging off the balconies at every level, clapping and cheering, looking something like a boatload of refugees eager to debark in a prosperous land. Here, after all, they would be able to get hot showers, toilets that flush and fresh food.

title: Aides Comments Cause Stir as White House Discusses Tax Strategy
description: 12:41 p.m. | Updated White House officials met on Thursday morning with allies from several progressive organizations to discuss strategy for the battle over whether to extend the Bush-era income tax rates, and the session took on added interest after reports circulated that the administration might cave in to Republican demands on the issue.

title: Seneca Seeks Proxy Fight at Dynegy
description: Seneca Capital, Dynegys largest shareholder and a staunch opponent of the energy companys proposed $4.7 billion takeover by the Blackstone Group, on Thursday made good on its promise to mount a proxy fight against the company.

title: Spiking Coffee, Opening Eyes
description: Is it supposed to snap you to attention or slide you deeper into your buzz? Help you wind down or get you wound up? Ive never really understood spiked coffee. In hitching caffeine (a stimulant) to alcohol (a depressant), it strikes me as a curiously self-canceling experience. Like wearing sun block to a tanning parlor. Or eating a Krispy Kreme on an elliptical.

title: IHT Luxury Conference | Christopher Bailey
description: In a conversation with Suzy Menkes, at the IHT luxury conference in London, Burberrys Chief Creative Officer Christopher Bailey discusses staying relevant in the digital world, shoe malfunctions, and the philosophy behind the companys signature trenchcoat.

title: When Portland Picks at Top of Draft, the Law of the Land Is Murphys
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Benjamin Rash purchased the custom-made Trail Blazers jersey specifically for the game on Nov. 4. It bore a cruel, David Stern-unapproved reminder of Portlands past and a link to its present.

title: If You Were Asked About Chancellors Job, Tell Us
description: In many ways and in many words, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has said that his surprise choice of Cathleen P. Black for the new schools chancellor was a result of a wide-open search for the most qualified candidate.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Chicago Tribune: Vending-machine moguls are protesting after a new Food and Drug Administration report estimated that workers will have to spend 14 million hours per year to comply with new calorie-count sticker laws.  Glenn Collins

title: Nets to Be Partners With Team in Springfield, Mass.
description: In another sign that the Nets new owner, Mikhail D. Prokhorov, is willing to pay to enhance the franchises infrastructure, the organization struck a deal to become the single affiliate partner with the N.B.A. Development Leagues Springfield Armor.

title: Stalled South Korea Trade Deal Is Setback for Obama
description: SEOUL, South Korea  From Seoul to Washington, business leaders, foreign policy analysts and diplomats were convinced that President Obama would wrap up a free trade accord during a meeting with President Lee Myung-bak of South Korea on Thursday.

title: Play About Martin Luther King Now Aiming for Broadway Next Fall
description: The much-anticipated Broadway production of The Mountaintop, Katori Halls acclaimed play about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on the eve of his assassination, is now looking likely for fall 2011, with Samuel L. Jackson (Pulp Fiction) and Halle Berry (Monsters Ball) poised to star, according to two executives involved in the production.

title: A Gift Card Guide for the Holidays
description: Updated | 9:03 p.m.

title: Controversial Radio Host Declines D.C. Job
description: 1:04 p.m. | Updated Joyce Kaufman has decided not to become Allen Wests chief of staff in the wake of a series of news media reports about controversial statements she has made, including the Caucus report below.

title: The Role of Experience in the F1 Title Showdown
description: I have been thinking for a while that Fernando Alonso probably has an advantage over Mark Webber and Sebastian Vettel in the fight for the drivers title because Alonso has won it twice, and the other two are going for a first-time title.

title: The Role of Experience in the F1 Title Showdown
description: I have been thinking for a while that Fernando Alonso probably has an advantage over Mark Webber and Sebastian Vettel in the fight for the drivers title because Alonso has won it twice, and the other two are going for a first-time title.

title: 2012 Debate Planning Begins
description: In a repeat of the last presidential election cycle, the Ronald ReaganPresidential Library and Museum is planning on hosting the firstRepublican primary debate of the 2012 cycle with NBC News andPolitico.

title: Name This Cocktail
description: At the Randolph at Broome, a downtown bar whose proprietors are tracing a bold new frontier in coffee cocktails, there are five coffee cocktails, tapping such spirits as rum, bourbon, cognac and Cherry Heering, a liqueur. I write about these cocktails in the latest installment of the Tipsy Diaries.

title: TimesCast | November 11, 2010
description: Iraq keeps Maliki in power; the debt commission and the White House on YouTube.

title: Renaissance Hotels Starts Concert Series
description: Hotel perks usually come in the form of chocolates with turndown service, free Wi-Fi or a breakfast buffet. Now Marriott is offering a nontraditional perk: concerts.

title: Heroin Mill Raided on West 43rd, Authorities Say
description: The authorities called it a mill, conjuring images of journeymen cranking out their wares for market or sawing huge logs or elves making cookies, but for the word that preceded it: heroin.

title: Theater Talkback: Thinking About Gatsby After Seeing Gatz
description: I finally got Gatzed last weekend.

title: Q&A: Adding Angkor to a Vietnam Bike Trip
description: Im taking a two-week bike trip from Hanoi to Ho Chi Minh City (with some driving) in February. Is it feasible to add a trip to Angkor Wat from Hanoi (before the bike trip) or Ho Chi Minh City (at the end)?

title: A TV Show for ODonnell?
description: Is a television show next for Christine ODonnell, the failed Republican Senatecandidate in Delaware?

title: Wines of The Times: Cotes du Rhone
description: It is such a familiar wine, almost a synonym for a not-too-fancy French red. Yet few wines can match Ctes du Rhne in exemplifying the myriad changes that have transformed the French wine industry in the last 20 years.

title: On Deficit Proposals, a Failure of Will and Not Ideas
description: Forgive me if my expectations are low that Congress will soon adopt any of the latest recommendations for getting the countrys fiscal house in order. But weve seen all these ideas before.

title: In Vermont, Taking the Roads Less Traveled
description: WOODSTOCK, Vt.  The last time I left the safety of marked roads was in a desolate area of Baja California. My husband was at the wheel of a 4x4, and I was trying to hide my terror from our two schoolchildren as we scraped over rocks and teetered near cliffs. We hadnt seen a soul in four hours, and we were lost. I was taking stock of the ice chips just in case. For me ever to try jeeping again, there had to be a powerful incentive.

title: Madison Square Park, 11:20 A.M.
description: Joshua Berrios of the Air Force Reserves, waiting to march in the Veterans Day Parade.

title: Ristretto | Roaster of the Year
description: If you go by conventional wisdom, coffee is to the Pacific Northwest and the foggier parts of Northern California what high school football is to Texas: theyre better at it because of coaching, culture and an advantageous gene pool. But anybody who follows coffee knows that the rest of the country has its share of talent. Just look at Conscious Coffees of Boulder, Colo., one of two roasters named Roaster of the Year last week.

title: Doubts Rise on Bedbug-Sniffing Dogs
description: If any heroes have emerged in the bedbug epidemic sweeping households, movie theaters, retailers, schools, offices, you-name-it nationwide, it is surely bedbug-sniffing dogs.

title: The Volt Recharges My Batteries
description: Ive been fascinated by the Chevy Volt since the day I heard about the concept.

title: Ariel Sharon to Be Moved Home
description: JERUSALEM  Ariel Sharon, who had a major stroke while prime minister of Israel nearly five years ago and has since been in a coma in a hospital room, is expected to be moved to his ranch in the Negev Desert in the coming days.

title: MetLife to Stop Offering New Long-Term Care Policies
description: MetLife announced Thursday that it plans to discontinue the sale of new long-term care insurance coverage.

title: Tangled Web of Rubicon Unravels at AMC
description: Days after ordering a new season of its hit horror series The Walking Dead AMC has swung its scythe at another original drama, announcing on Thursday that it would not pick up more episodes of its conspiracy thriller Rubicon.

title: Exploring Lenovos Pathway to the Future
description: With rivals Hewlett-Packard and Dell making headlines in the acquisitions market this year, the Chinese computer maker Lenovo reminded investors this week that it was also in the hunt.

title: Fed Efforts to Revive Economy Find Critics
description: Can you remember when the Federal Reserve was above criticism? When politicians vied for Alan Greenspans favor and fell all over themselves praising his wisdom?

title: Pogues Posts: The Volt Recharges My Batteries
description: On his blog, David Pogue tests out the Chevy Volt, which has fascinated him since the day he heard about the concept.

title: Inzaghis Goal Poaching Days May Be Over
description: A week after Filippo Inzaghi scored twice in the Champions League against Real Madrid, setting three career scoring records, his season is over and his career in jeopardy. Inzaghi, a 37-year-old A.C. Milan forward, hurt his anterior cruciate ligament and damaged the meniscus in his left knee in his teams 3-1 victory over Palermo on Wednesday.

title: Inquiry Revived in Beating of Russian Editor
description: MOSCOW  Law enforcement authorities on Thursday unexpectedly reopened the investigation into the brutal beating of an outspoken newspaper editor whose case had come to symbolize the dangers facing journalists in Russia.

title: Simpsons Renewed by Fox for a 23rd Season
description: The Simpsons was renewed for another season on Fox on Thursday, allowing the animated series to surpass the 500-episode mark.

title: The Morning Skate: The Kovalchoke
description: Sometime in the future, when the story of the Devils Ilya Kovalchuk era is written, this may be the signature moment

title: Karachi Counterterrorism Office Is Bombed
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Armed attackers stormed a police compound in a heavily guarded quarter of central Karachi on Thursday night, detonating a car bomb in a direct strike at the governments counterterrorism forces.

title: Hows That Outdoorsy Stuff Working for Ya?
description: Sarah Palin says her new series on TLC is not a reality show, and she has a point. The show is not an outdoorsy version of celebrity-dysfunction shows like Keeping Up With the Kardashians or The Hasselhoffs.

title: Drowning in a Sea of Health Complaints
description: The patient was a classic worried-well type of patient  a thin, 50-year-old educated woman with a long litany of nonspecific, unrelated complaints and tight worry lines carved into her face. She unfolded a sheet of paper on that Thursday morning in my office with a brisk snap, and my heart sank as I saw 30 lines of hand-printed concerns.

title: Noah Takes Garnett Off Pedestal
description: It can be a disappointing truth: when youre an adult, meeting a childhood idol can be a letdown. Your kid imagination made the athlete or performer out to be something that wasnt grounded in reality.

title: BBC Journalists Call Off Strike
description: BBC journalists have called off a strike scheduled for next week, saying on Thursday that management had agreed to meet with union leaders to try to resolve a dispute over proposed pension cuts.

title: Open Books: Street View and Love Edition
description: Say what you will about the privacy concerns raised by Google Street View, it does provide one valuable service besides the ability to virtually visit Johannesburg: catching criminals in the act.

title: Vocabulinks
description: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

title: For Cats, a Big Gulp With a Touch of the Tongue
description: It has taken four highly qualified engineers and a bunch of integral equations to figure it out, but we now know how cats drink. The answer is: very elegantly, and not at all the way you might suppose.

title: Dallas Coach Hyndman Finds Success in the Pros
description: Schellas Hyndman spent 24 years as the mens soccer coach at Southern Methodist University before jumping to the pro ranks as coach of F.C. Dallas in 2008. In three seasons with the Major League Soccer club, he transformed the perennial also-ran into a playoff team, the first time since 2007, and has Dallas on the verge of its first M.L.S. Cup appearance. On Thursday, those accomplishments were recognized when Hyndman was named the leagues coach of the year.

title: British Politician Arrested for Twitter Joke
description: An English politician was arrested on Thursday for joking on Twitter that a columnist he disagreed with should be stoned to death.

title: For Rock Band, Final Gig at Viacom
description: 4:15 p.m. | Updated

title: Dear FloFab: The Kitchen Dropped My Dinner
description: Each week, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: Las Vegas Casinos Are a Last Bastion for Smokers
description: LAS VEGAS  The notice on the door to the hotel-casino was emphatic. The Westin Casuarina is a Smoke Free Environment. Thank you for not smoking. Just beyond, four people were hunched over slot machines the other afternoon, wisps of cigarette smoke swirling around them as they happily puffed away.

title: Popcast: Shyne, Josh Groban and More
description: Whatever happened to Shyne, the rapper and former Sean Combs protg who spent much of the last decade in prison? This week on Popcast, The Timess music podcast, Dina Kraft, a reporter in Israel, talks about tracking Shyne to Jerusalem, where he has begun a new life as an Orthodox Jew.

title: Cocoa Beach
description: Chocolate lovers will soon find plenty to satisfy their sweet tooth on the Caribbean island of St. Lucia. In December, the upscale British chocolatier Hotel Chocolat (which has a Stateside flagship on Bostons Newbury Street) will make good on its name by opening a boutique resort on Rabot Estate, its 140-acre cocoa plantation in the shadow of the twin-peaked Pitons. The hotel will offer guests the full chocolate-making experience, including taking part in the cocoa harvest while learning about the companys philanthropic program to benefit local farmers. The idea is to let our customers have the same experience that we have every time we step onto the estate, says Angus Thirlwell, who co-founded the company 17 years ago with Peter Harris. Should chocolate-making wear thin, guests, who stay in contemporary West Indian-style cottages, can also hike Gros Piton, embark on a fruit-tasting safari and dine on dishes like sauted prawns with chocolate tapenade.

title: Greenlights Target of Scorn: The Fed
description: David Einhorn, manager of the hedge fund Greenlight Capital.

title: Millers Chances of Victory Dim as Alaska Senate Write-In Count Begins
description: Results from the first day of tallying write-in ballots in Alaska suggest that Senator Lisa Murkowski, who ran a write-in campaign after being defeated in the Republican primary by Joe Miller, is very likely to win another term.

title: How Cats Lap
description: Scientists studied the physics of feline drinking.

title: How Broken Must College Football Be to Fix It?
description: It is time for my annual foray into the lower depths of higher education  that is to say, the business of Bowl Championship Series football as perpetrated on or near centers of learning.

title: A Slaughtered Tiger Tally
description: At least 1,069 tigers have been killed by poachers over the last decade, according to an analysis of seizures of tiger parts by Traffic International, a wildlife protection group based in Britain. Less than 3,500 tigers are thought to remain in the wild.

title: Madison Avenue Salutes Veterans
description: For years, retailers have marked Veterans Day with sales. Now, other types of consumer marketers are starting to sponsor advertising campaigns timed to the holiday.

title: Cholera Spreads to the Haitian Capital
description: An outbreak that had been largely confined to the countryside has now begun to spread in the teeming capital filled with overcrowded, unsanitary earthquake survivor camps.

title: When a Bedbug Find Is a Dogs Main Meal Ticket
description: Bedbug-sniffing dogs have been lauded for their radar-like ability to detect bedbugs that are hidden from human sight. But there have been growing concerns about false positives  when a dog incorrectly signals that bedbug are present  within the pest-control industry, and from consumers, too.

title: Defector Aided in Thwarting Russian Spies, Article Says
description: MOSCOW  A Russian newspaper reported Thursday that a senior official in Russias Foreign Intelligence Service had provided the information that enabled the United States to break up a ring of Russian sleeper spies in June.

title: Death of a King; Cautious King Took Risks In Straddling Two Worlds
description: King Hussein of Jordan, who died yesterday at 63, successfully straddled two worlds in more than four tumultuous decades on the throne.

title: Dow Jones Finishes Above 1,000
description: The Dow Jones industrial average closed above the 1,000 mark yesterday for the first time in history.

title: Bradley Names U.S. Roster for South Africa Trip
description: United States Coach Bob Bradley announced his roster for the Americans friendly against South Africa in Cape Town later this month. He decided to give five players who have never before played for the national team an opportunity.

title: Cooking Lights No-Meat Thanksgiving Meal
description: As one of the most popular food magazines in the country, Cooking Light pays attention when readers start clamoring for a particular type of food. And lately, it seems, theyve been asking for more vegetarian dishes.

title: The Quiet Side of Being a Soldiers Other Half
description: WHY do movies always show dead people with their eyes closed? asks my husband from the living room couch. We are halfway through The Hurt Locker.

title: Japans Farmers Oppose Pacific Free-Trade Talks
description: IWAMIZAWA, Japan  Atsushi Kono considers it the gravest threat to his familys farm in a century of rice-growing: a free-trade initiative that could dismantle Japans sky-high protective farming tariffs, finally opening up the country to cheap, foreign produce.

title: With Pieces in Place, Rangers Still Need Overtime
description: If ever there were a game the Rangers were going to win, it was Thursday nights.

title: Bush Memoir Gives Short Shrift to His Pardon Record
description: WASHINGTON  Former President George W. Bush tucked a paragraph into his newly published memoir Decision Points about how he decided to handle a late flurry of pardon-seekers who used special access to the White House to press their cases:

title: For Years a Constant, the Giants Line Is Now a Patchwork
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In the upper left corner of his locker, center Shaun OHara has taped a yellowing newspaper photograph of the Giants offensive linemen sitting on the sideline, from left tackle to right tackle.

title: Theater Listings: Nov. 12  18
description: Theater

title: 'Elf' on Broadway
description: Sebastian Arcelus and cast members perform the number "Christmastown." (Video courtesy of the production)

title: Seeing Things | Doug Aitkens House
description: The artist Doug Aitken has a lot going on: new pieces; the installation of an important early work; a new house; and the staging of an art/music happening for the upcoming benefit gala at The Museum of Contemporary Art, to name a few of his current projects. As he explains it, a lot of directions in my work merged like a meteorite and created friction.

title: Taking a Dream for a Few Spins
description: I WAS the youngest of three and the only girl in a family in which football was king, so life itself was a contact sport. So it should be no surprise that I was drawn to kinder, gentler physical activities (and those that involved sparkly costumes). But when I asked to add figure skating to my list of weekly activities, my mother said no. She thought ballet, tap, jazz, gymnastics, violin lessons and Brownies were enough.

title: House Tour: Nyack, N.Y.
description: HOW MUCH $695,000. Taxes: $17,663.

title: From House of Tiffany, a Line of Pottery
description: Louis Comfort Tiffany promoted his leafy and floral ceramics with the same hyperbole that he used for his glass lampshades and windows. His ads described his pottery vases and lamp bases as entirely different from anything heretofore shown. He had such faith in their market potential that when hundreds of dollars worth of pots went wrong in the kiln one afternoon, Mr. Tiffany is not discouraged and has gone at it again, the staff designer Clara Driscoll wrote to her family in Ohio.

title: Cuomo Names Transition Team
description: Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Thursday who would lead his formal transition efforts as well as the membership two committees of transition advisers, encompassing a wide cross-section of business, labor and political leaders.

title: Fords Trick TracKey for the 2012 Mustang Boss 302
description: Ford says the idea behind the TracKey, an ignition key that alters the engine management system in the 2012 Mustang Boss 302 to turn it into a street-illegal racecar, came during an all-night brainstorming session between Mustang team members. I wonder how many Bond movies they watched that night.

title: Schools Wary of Prep Powerhouses in Football
description: CLIFTON, N.J.  The fans in the home-team rooting section were stunned when visiting Don Bosco Prep called a timeout with about two minutes left in the first half in an attempt to regain possession of the football.

title: Operation Dragon Strike
description: American soldiers are taking part in an operation to drive the Taliban from the southern part of Zhari District in Kandahar.

title: Conan Ratings Slip, but He Leads in Younger Viewers
description: 3:50 p.m. | Updated On his third night as a cable star on TBS, Conan OBrien saw his ratings slip again, but not as much as they had from night one to night two.

title: A New Star in the Tablet Space
description: Surf the web, take photos and get app-happy with Samsung's Galaxy Tab. But please don't call it an iPad.

title: Modern Minstrelsy: Exploring Racist Stereotypes in Literature and Life
description: Overview | What are the roots and legacy of minstrelsy and the Scottsboro Trials? How can stereotypes be used not only to reinforce a bias, but also to satirize that very bias? In this lesson, students learn about the minstrel tradition, consider how it echoes through stereotypes of African-Americans today and explore the legacy of black stereotypes and the Scottsboro Trials in popular culture, history and literature.

title: A Slice of Life. Or Three!
description: Reading may be the cheapest way to travel this holiday. And you can plan a European excursion with the help of eight contemporary fiction writers at the New Literature From Europe festival, sponsored by the French Embassy in the United States. The festival begins on Tuesday with Haunting the Present, a reading by each of the authors, who include the French writer and film director Philippe Claudel (Ive Loved You So Long) and, from Poland, Olga Tokarczuk (Primeval and Other Times). Panels and discussions continue on Wednesday and wrap up on Thursday with a second reading from each author in his or her native language, followed by a reception. (Times and locations vary: 212-439-1447, newlitfromeurope.com; free.)

title: The Burger Wars Continue
description: Escalating Manhattans quality-burger wars, Schnippers has signed a lease in 1 Madison Avenue on the north side of East 23rd Street, virtually across the street from the original Shake Shack in Madison Square Park. Read more on Diners Journal

title: Help for Veterans Assisted Living Costs
description: With only a fraction of veterans using Veterans Affairs benefits and health care services, many senior veterans and their families may not be aware of a benefit that could cover some of the costs of living in an assisted living community.

title: Facebook Chooses North Carolina for New Data Center
description: Following in the footsteps of Google, Yahoo and Microsoft, which are building ever-growing networks of data centers, Facebook said Thursday that it will build a new data center in Forest City, N.C. This will be the second data center that Facebook is building from the ground up. Its first center in Prineville, Ore., is under construction and is expected to open next year. Facebook also leases data center space  and in some cases entire data centers  in several other locations, including Santa Clara, Calif.

title: Homegrown, With a World View
description: Young designers are now the focus of a New York City initiative to provide mentors and new retail concepts. Others are trying to save the garment district, where many factories have closed or laid off workers and raised prices. Fabric costs are up, especially for cotton, and just about everyone who deals with manufacturing in China knows you cant get a minimum of anything: 1,000 blouses maybe, but not 100. Department stores threaten to cancel orders if a delivery is late. Meanwhile fast-fashion companies reap the rewards of being nimble and democratic while grabbing the ideas of others. Prestige labels hold on to their heritage. And consumers wonder: Wheres your app?

title: Viewpoints: Wall St. After the Elections
description: The New York Timess Joe Nocera and Andrew Ross Sorkin talk about the recent midterm elections, and what the result means for Wall Street. Will the Republican-controlled House of Representatives chip away at the financial reforms championed by the Obama White House?

title: A Different Way to Cook Meat
description: My wife, Jackie, and I had something to celebrate a couple of weeks ago, which we did in part by going out to dinner at our favorite fancy restaurant, Jean Georges. The final course was loin of lamb with a crust of ground dried black trumpet mushrooms, and  apart from the fact that it was a terrific recipe, a version of which you can read in Jean-Georges: Cooking at Home with a Four-Star Chef by Jean-Georges Vongerichten and Mark Bittman  it was just so perfectly cooked: glistening bright red against the black of the coating, edge to edge, with no gray stratum near the outside. I was dazzled by the precision.

title: Choosing a Headmaster, With a Lot of Care
description: The Ethical Culture Fieldston School announced on Wednesday that Damian J. Fernandez, an international relations scholar and top administrator at the State University of New York Purchase College, would become its new headmaster.

title: Fill-In | Vice President Biden and The Onion
They Must Be Giants
description: If you think big, says the tag line for the 1,000-acre Baha Mar resort about to break ground in the Bahamas, think bigger. Sound ridiculous in a recession? Its more of a harbinger than youd imagine, at least in the travel world: led by Las Vegass CityCenter and the Marina Bay Sands Singapore, a new wave of mega-scale complexes that were conceived during the boom have recently opened their doors, with several more in development, from the Alps to Abu Dhabi. I think its the future, says Andy Cohen, executive director of the architecture firm Gensler, which worked on CityCenter and has a similar mixed-use project brewing in Shanghai. Whether its sports, entertainment or retail, the ability to have all that variety in one place is key. People want choice.

title: If Mets Want Beltran to Waive Clause, Hell Listen
description: Heading into the final season of his seven-year contract, Mets center fielder Carlos Beltran said on Thursday that he would listen to a request from the team to waive his no-trade clause.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from South Korea, Saudi Arabia and Russia .

title: Mehldau Is a Jazzman In a Classical Mood
description: Brad Mehldau, a star in the jazz world, has lately been asserting himself in classical precincts as well. He has written song cycles for Rene Fleming and Anne Sofie von Otter, and both singers have recorded those works with Mr. Mehldau at the piano. His solo and ensemble recordings have touched on his classical leanings too. They show him grappling with formal notions of structure and thematic development, and seeking a balance between the precisely defined gestures of composed music and the freedom and spontaneity of improvisation.

title: New Chancellors Political Donations Tell a Mixed Tale
description: She gave $1,000 to Senator John McCain when he ran for president in 2000. She donated $500 to Hillary Rodham Clintons Senate campaign in 2004. And, since 2003, she has poured $3,500 into the re-election bids of Representative Henry A. Waxman of California.

title: In Kutna Hora, Near Prague, Contemporary Art Amid Medieval Charm
description: THE sun streamed down on the hilly, cobbled streets of the Czech town of Kutna Hora, but I didnt feel its warmth. I was 130 feet underground in a dark, dripping, medieval mine shaft, clutching a 50-year-old hydroxide lamp. Ahead of me, my claustrophobic fianc, Tod, identifiable by the gleam reflecting from his hard hat, navigated the narrow, chilly hand-carved passages.

title: If You Go
description: By car, you can get from Prague to Kutna Hora in about an hour by driving east along the E50 and E65 highways. Trains run regularly from Pragues Hlavni Nadrazi and Masarykovo Nadrazi, but the 97-koruna trip (about $5.40 at 18 Czech koruna to the dollar) can take under an hour or almost two depending on whether you catch the express.

title: The Hair Box
description: Haircuts and shaves have been available at a storefront in SoHo for over 100 years, though the prices have gone up a bit.

title: Arrest Made in Shooting Over Candy Bar
description: Tips to the Crime Stoppers hotline led to an arrest on murder charges in the Bronx Wednesday, the police said.

title: Ancient Roman Shrine, Restored, Reopens to Public
description: ROME  The Temple of Venus and of Rome  once one of Romes most majestic shrines  reopened to the public on Thursday after a long restoration. This temple has been both a school and course of study for many, said Claudia Del Monte, who began working on the restoration 23 years ago and directed the project.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Nov. 12-18
description: Pop

title: On the Trail of Green Rocks
description: George E. Harlow, curator of gems and minerals at the American Museum of Natural History, has been studying jadeite for many years and has returned to the fault line that is the Motagua Valley in Guatemala. This is the first of two posts from Dr. Harlow.

title: Movie Listings for Nov. 12-18
description: Movies

title: Media Matters Chief Says He Will Lunch with Murdoch
description: Whos coming to lunch with Rupert Murdoch? Its David Brock, the chief executive of Media Matters, which exists in large part to criticize Mr. Murdochs News Corporation.

title: A Straight Razor, a Warm Towel, a Fading Art
description: OUTSIDE the Hair Box, a green storefront rooted on Spring Street, the red, white and blue candy-striped pole was motionless. Inside, Georgiy Ibragimov, 50, draped a seersucker barber cloth over Michael Hirshoren, who had just eased into one of three worn leather chairs.

title: Jazz Listings for Nov. 12-18
description: Jazz

title: Other Options for Puff Pastry
description: In my column on Wednesday, I wrote about the buttery joys of puff pastry, which is, along with butternut squash, Brussels sprouts, and newly picked Honeycrisp apples, one of my favorite autumn ingredients. I know what youre thinking, and its true that technically puff pastry isnt seasonal you can buy it any time of the year. But if youve ever tried to roll out puff pastry in a humid New York summer, youd understand my point. Its best saved for sweater weather.So I like to do my bit for the seasonal cuisine movement by eating loads of puff pastry in the cooler months.Here are a few of my favorite ways to bake with puff pastry.

title: Dance Listings for Nov. 12-18
description: Dance

title: For Eloises Mother, Life Wasnt All Dandelions
description: Ive discovered the secret of life, Kay Thompson, the eccentric entertainer and Eloise author, once said. A lot of hard work, a lot of sense of humor, a lot of joy and a lot of tra-la-la!

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Nov. 12-18
description: Classical

title: What Were Reading: Bernanke, Unsung Hero
Seeking Guidance on Dodd-Franks Diversity Clause
description: As Wall Street scrambles to comply with the regulations of the Dodd-Frank financial overhaul, one little-noticed provision has executives scratching their heads.

title: Tumult and Triumph in Black and White
description: Too bad Fidel Castro cannot come to New York to see Cuba in Revolution, an intensely absorbing exhibition at the International Center of Photography. It would warm his heart and make him pine for the glory days of the late 1950s and early 60s, when his tiny, swashbuckling band of soldier intellectuals overthrew the corrupt government of Fulgencio Batista and prevailed over the forces of corporate capitalism and organized crime. The improbable, undeniably stirring tale of the rise and triumph of the Fidelistas is told by 180 pictures made by 30 photojournalists, including native Cubans like Ral Corrales and Alberto Korda and international stars like Henri Cartier-Bresson and Burt Glinn.

title: Major Gift of Furniture to National Gallery of Art
description: The National Gallery of Art in Washington has been promised one of the most impressive collections of American furniture still in private hands, along with a group of Dutch old master paintings and watercolors by seminal American artists like Winslow Homer and Childe Hassam.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Unstoppable'
description: Tony Scott, the director of Unstoppable, discusses a sequence from his film.

title: Amazon Under Attack for Sale of Pedophile Book
description: Whether they like it or not, most technology companies, including Apple, Google and Amazon, are no longer simply technology companies, but are also content creators and curators.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from South Korea and Saudi Arabia, and at Veterans Day commemorations.

title: Native Son
description: On his first visit home to Taiwan since Michelle Obama catapulted his name into the fashion stratosphere, the designer Jason Wu was greeted by paparazzi, velvet ropes and tons of fans. Here, the glory of Taiwan, as Wu is now known in his birthplace, talks about his return to Taipei, where change is in the air but the old ways arent forgotten.

title: Frank Bruni on Ippudo
description: The restaurant Ippudo is where many of New Yorks most devoted fans of ramen, the Japanese noodle soup, practice their devotion.

title: Iraqis on Political Deal: Meet the New Boss
description: BAGHDAD  As Iraqi lawmakers moved fitfully toward seating a new government this week, reactions around the country were swift, emotional and  like everything else here  staunchly divided.

title: Fleeting Liaisons and Missed Connections
description: The choreography of Eryc Taylor is sincere, well intentioned, earnest, inoffensive, old-fashioned, neat and forgettable. His hourlong program of five pieces on Wednesday at Joyce SoHo was called Pushing Boundaries, but it is hard to know what boundaries were being pushed here that were not pushed more memorably several decades ago.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Nov. 12-18
description: Art

title: Playing the Renegade With Eroticism or Rage
description: Sanctified art movements aside, most artists worthy of the name are loners and renegades. They operate without licenses  or Ph.D.s  striving to be themselves as only they can, as clearly and intensely as possible.

title: Crack Open a Bud And Sway Existentially
description: Four more years! Joey Truman shouts at the beginning of now and nowhere else, a performance work by Iver Findlay and Marit Sandsmark. Mr. Truman is shirtless, wearing jeans and clutching a Budweiser, his bleached hair glistening. (He has just rubbed lotion in it.) In short, he doesnt seem the type to care much about political rhetoric, yet he repeats the line several times; his body ripples in spasms. Loosely cupping his hands as if they were holding marbles, he quivers back and forth: a boxers moves, deconstructed.

title: Google Presents New Image Ads to All Advertisers
description: Googles bread and butter has been search ads  the few lines of text that show up alongside search results that are based on the keywords that people search for. But for some advertisers, especially online retailers, those arent necessarily the best type of ads.

title: Interview: Lena Dunham
description: Lena Dunham, the director, writer and star of "Tiny Furniture," discusses how she crafted the film.

title: Spare Times for Nov. 12-18
description: Around Town

title: Viewpoints: Wall Street After Elections
description: Columnist Joe Nocera and DealBook Editor Andrew Ross Sorkin talk about what the recent election means for Wall Street and financial regulation.

title: Doing the Loco-Motion, Somewhat Slowed Down
description: Lynda Carter, the onetime Wonder Woman, isnt the first performer to lose her bearings in pursuit of that elusive quality known as hip. Wicked Cool, the misleading title of her new show, her third in four years at Feinsteins at Loews Regency, might be an effective headline in a fragrance ad  or not. But it doesnt describe a program dominated by songs from the 1960s and 70s or the busy arrangements for an overbearing pop quintet and two backup singers who threaten to drown her out.

title: Spare Times: For Children for Nov. 12-18
description: RAPTORS IN FLIGHT

title: Dominick Dunnes Comfy Chair and a Jaguar Named Audrey
description: PERHAPS no life was more intensely scrutinized by Dominick Dunne, the gimlet-eyed chronicler of the rich and infamous, than his own. In the offices of his Connecticut and Manhattan homes, framed Vanity Fair and TV Guide articles edged up against portraits of him aside political and Hollywood bigwigs. Autographed books, inscribed by Truman Capote, Jackie Collins, Jimmy Carter and Andy Warhol  his signature sealed with a Campbells soup can  lined Dunnes shelves. Even his furniture had tales to tell.

title: Arctic Drilling Poses Untold Risks, Study Concludes
description: Now that the moratorium on deep-sea oil and gas drilling has been lifted by the Obama administration, the battle for the Arctic is heating up again.

title: British Bankers, Your Employers Are Listening
description: Britains financial services watchdog isnt kidding around when it comes to stamping out leaks and market abuse.

title: As Complex as the Music She Plays
description: IT seems safe to predict that the violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter will play a run of concerts with the New York Philharmonic in 10 years or so, as she did in 2000 and as she is doing again this season, as artist in residence. After all, unless she were finally to act on occasional vague hints of an early retirement, Ms. Mutter, now 47, should still be at the height of her considerable powers.

title: Girl Undefined: Post-College but Pre-Real World
description: Pitched unsteadily if shrewdly between honest self-reflection and squirmy narcissistic indulgence, the low-budget indie Tiny Furniture is one of the bigger itsy-bitsy movies to hit this year. It was written and directed by the newcomer Lena Dunham, who also plays the leading role of Aura, a recent college graduate who returns to her familys TriBeCa loft and promptly tries to crawl back in the womb. What makes this womb without apparent view especially notable is that Ms. Dunhams own mother, the artist Laurie Simmons, plays Auras mother, while her real sister, Grace, plays Auras on-screen sibling.

title: Driving Miss Daisy in Talks to Extend
description: The producers of one of Broadways biggest hit plays of the fall, Driving Miss Daisy, are talking to stars Vanessa Redgrave and James Earl Jones about continuing in the show through the spring rather than close on Jan. 29 as planned, according to people on the business side of the production. They said they expected resolution one way or another soon.

title: Esprit de Corps at a Shelter for Veterans
description: On Thursday morning, Luis Crossman, 61, slipped his still-lean, 61-year-old body into a faded green jumpsuit and zipped it up. He pulled on his black army boots and put on his aviator shades and black cowboy hat. He tied a kerchief around his neck.

title: E.U. Responds to Iran About Talks on Nuclear Program
description: BRUSSELS  Talks on Irans nuclear program moved a step closer Thursday as the European Union foreign policy chief, Catherine Ashton, agreed to one of two dates for discussions suggested by Tehran, a diplomat said, although Ms. Ashton proposed an alternative location.

title: A Senator Secedes  Reluctantly
description: Charleston, S.C., Nov. 12, 1860

title: Keeping Score: Viewing the N.B.A. Through a Statistical Lens
description: Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: Where Hair Is King, Until Its Cut
description: Outside the Hair Box, a green storefront rooted on Spring Street, the red, white and blue candy-striped pole was motionless. Inside, Georgiy Ibragimov, 50, draped a seersucker barber cloth over Michael Hirshoren, who had just eased into one of three worn leather chairs.

title: Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Identity
description: PHILADELPHIA  Not far from where the National Museum of American Jewish History is opening its new building on Friday for a weekend of celebrations, the Liberty Bell can be seen with its biblical inscription: Proclaim liberty throughout all the land unto all the inhabitants thereof. The balconies of this $150 million museum overlook Independence National Historical Park, where the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution were signed. The National Constitution Center is on the other end of the park, and next month, just across the mall, the Presidents House  the executive mansion where George Washington and John Adams lived when Philadelphia served as the nations capital  will be the site of a museum, with a focus not just on liberty, but also on slavery.

title: I Think I Can: Trying to Stop a Crazy Train Hurtling to Disaster
description: The picture book Big Bigger and Biggest Trucks and Diggers comes with what its publisher describes as an action-packed 30-minute DVD so children can watch their favorite machines at work, digging, hauling, and dumping. Although it clocks in at 68 minutes longer and features big trains instead of big trucks  along with a long-haul star in Denzel Washington  Unstoppable, the latest from Tony Scott, brings to mind those popular peewee entertainments that allow youngsters to explore the world of backhoes and soil compactors. Or as Big Bigger and Biggest promises, the biggest machines in action!

title: Draw for 2011 Copa America
description: For the ninth time since it was first played, as the South American championship in 1916, Argentina will host the Copa Amrica, July 1-24.

title: Still Waiting: An Update on Still-Unresolved Races
description: Election Day was over a week ago, but there are still a number of unresolved contests around the country. By popular request, heres a recap of where things stand. In almost every one of the races listed below, local officials have not finished  or have not started  counting absentee and provisional ballots.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Unstoppable
description: Sugar puffs and potato flakes. Those were the two main ingredients the director Tony Scott used to simulate grain spraying out into the sky when a train is hit in a scene from his new film Unstoppable. Mr. Scott discusses some of the techniques he used to shoot the action sequence involving colliding trains, a helicopter and some harrowing stunt work. Read Manohla Dargiss review of the film here.

title: Checking Out, and Donating, Too
description: The customer swiped his loyalty card at the Safeway supermarket on Market Street in San Francisco last month, and a message appeared on the display: Care to make a donation to fight breast cancer today?

title: The Controversial Whitney Museum
description: WHITHER the Whitney? Yes, its got a swell building designed by Renzo Piano under way in the meatpacking district, to be finished in 2015. But what about its structure at 75th and Madison, where Jacqueline Kennedy attended the ribbon-cutting in 1966? Ornery and menacing, it may be New Yorks most bellicose work of architecture.

title: Clyde Summers, Advocate of Labor Union Democracy, Is Dead at 91
description: Clyde W. Summers, a law professor who played a pivotal role in writing the 1959 federal law that guaranteed democratic rights to union members, died on Oct. 30 at a retirement home in Germantown, Pa. He was 91.

title: Shooting to Top the Charts Again
Battle Lines Drawn Over Medicaid in Texas
description: A week after newly emboldened Republicans in the Texas Legislature floated a radical cost-saving proposal  opting out of the federal Medicaid program  health care experts, economists and think tanks are trying to determine just how serious they are, and if it would even be possible.

title: Jewelry and Tableaus in the Same Tent
description: For the second year in a row the dependable design fair Modernism has teamed up with the younger Art20, giving visitors to the Park Avenue Armory a concentrated look at 20th-century art and design. The marriage of these two fairs has allowed both to ride out a difficult economy. It has also nudged painting and sculpture into close contact with furnishings, jewelry and decorative objects, producing a kind of friction that rarely occurs in museums.

title: Questions in Joliet Area About Coal-Ash Threat
description: The blue house is small and weathered, but for Leon Bilbrew, it is his castle. His hunting dogs are in cages in the yard, and the walls inside his Joliet home are lined with pelts of beaver, albino raccoon and skunk that he has trapped. He keeps beehives and sells the honey at farmers markets.

title: Week 10 in Fantasy Football: Matchups and Q. and A.
description: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 10. They also answered reader questions earlier in the week. Read their answers below and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

title: Pressure Under Grace
description: A relative of mine recently married a devoutly religious woman. Dinner at their home is preceded by holding hands and saying a short blessing. I get it: their place, their rules; no problem. But recently, at a restaurant, they grabbed their neighbors hands and waited for everyone to do the same  which we all uncomfortably did  then bowed their heads for a moment of silence. Could I have refused?

title: Drawing Funny
description: This is the ninth in a series.

title: Weimar Film: Shadows, Yes, but Also Light
description: German cinema of the Weimar years has given us some of the most famous images in film history: Cesare the somnambulist (Conrad Veidt) loping through the crooked alleys of The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari, the proud hotel doorman (Emil Jannings) reduced to a quivering washroom attendant in The Last Laugh, the robot Maria (Brigitte Helm) coming to life circled by rising rings of electricity in Metropolis.

title: 2 Tea Party Favorites Vie for Leadership Job
description: The new House leadership position that Republicans created just for freshman will likely inject a Tea Party voice into high-level decision-making as soon as the nextCongress convenes.

title: In West Chelsea, a High Line Boomlet
description: THE view of West Chelsea from the roof of 540 West 28th Street, a new condominium at 11th Avenue, prompts a somewhat irrational question: what housing crash?

title: The Dancers Still Kick, the Soldiers Still Topple
description: The enduring success of the Radio City Christmas Spectacular, high-kicking for 78 years, is partly from the appeal of womens legs. Obviously. The palatial Art Deco theater also adds crucial glamour. Then theres the benefit of having both Santa and the baby Jesus onstage, the most commercially viable double act since Nathan Lane and Matthew Broderick.

title: Margarito and Camp Apologize to Trainer
description: GRAPEVINE, Tex.  For months, Antonio Margarito talked about how his fight Saturday against Manny Pacquiao would help restore his reputation. Instead, his sullied reputation took another hit this week.

title: Earl G. Graves Lists Scarsdale Estate
description: NOT long after the August 40th-anniversary celebration for his pioneering magazine, Black Enterprise, Earl G. Graves, one of the countrys most prominent black businessmen, has listed his 21-room colonial home on five acres in Scarsdale, N.Y., for $11.5 million.

title: In Chengdu, China, Remaking Sichuan Food
description: IN a private room in a mysterious little restaurant in Chengdu, my fellow diners goaded me to eat the turtle. It was soft-shelled, they said  as if that made it more enticing. They laughed and joked in Chinese, which I do not speak. Eating turtle grows a mans bank account, my translator said. I didnt get the meaning at first. Then it sunk in.

title: A Culinary Awakening in Chengdu
description: In the belly of Sichuan, a new food scene is growing.

title: Global Warming and Common Sense
description: People are going to die, pipes a childs voice at the beginning of Cool It, Ondi Timoners cacophonous portrait of the Danish economist Bjorn Lomborg, whose 2001 book, The Skeptical Environmentalist, earned him the ire of the green movement and an accusation of scientific dishonesty. That accusation didnt stick, but Mr. Lomborgs reputation as a global-warming denier has been tougher to shake off.

title: On the West Side, New Condos with an Old Look
description: GREGG WOLPERT, the developer of a new 76-unit condominium on the Upper West Side called the Laureate, did not have to look far to come up with a style for the building. He says he merely had to glance out his bedroom window in the Apple Bank at Broadway and 73rd Street.

title: Sprawling Cinema, Tamed to a Stage
description: Were it not for the gorgeous costumes  sweeping silken kimonos and samurai armor made of glistening black patent leather  Ping Chongs Throne of Blood, a new production from the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, would be as boring to look at as it is to listen to.

title: Fehr Sets Meeting With the Canucks
description: Donald Fehr was scheduled to meet with the Vancouver Canucks players on Friday, the last of 30 meetings he is conducting with the players of every N.H.L. team ahead of their vote on whether to approve him as executive director of the N.H.L. Players Association.

title: Web
description: The origins of our Webified age were hardly auspicious. Two decades ago, Tim Berners-Lee, a British software programmer at the CERN physics-research laboratory outside Geneva, was sketching out a global system for sharing information over the Internet. A March 1989 document that he drafted with the drab title Information Management: A Proposal had met with minimal internal interest. Berners-Lees group leader, Mike Sendall, was mildly intrigued and allowed him to keep tinkering on the project, calling it vague, but exciting.

title: A Peoples History
description: More photos from the National Museum of American Jewish History.

title: Assertive Chinese Held in Mental Wards
description: LOUHE, China  Xu Lindong, a poor village farmer with close-cropped hair and a fourth-grade education, knew nothing but decades of backbreaking labor. Even at age 50, the rope of muscles on his arms bespoke a lifetime of hard plowing and harvesting in the fields of his native Henan Province.

title: The (Un)Making of an Art World Satirist
description: Modern art is a con. I am the worlds greatest con artist.

title: 36 Hours in Seoul
description: HASTILY rebuilt after the Korean War, Seoul is shedding its once-gritty image to become one of Asias most glittering metropolises. Under its design-obsessed mayor, Oh Se-hoon, the city has been spiffed up with everything from sleek bus shelters to decked-out bridges. Whats more, it was named this years World Design Capital by an international design alliance. But thats just the beginning. Seoul has a booming contemporary art scene, fashionable stores throughout the urban landscape, and a thriving pop and youth culture that now rivals that of other Asian capitals like Tokyo.

title: A Weekend in Seoul
description: Hastily rebuilt after the Korean War, Seoul is shedding its once-gritty image to become one of Asias most glittering metropolises.

title: Even After 30 Years, the Film of the Moment
description: When it was first shown in the United States in 1980, Jean-Luc Godards Every Man for Himself was greeted as a new beginning for a filmmaker who had spent the last decade exploring the foreign land known as video. Mr. Godard himself, who as a young man had worked in the Paris publicity department of 20th Century Fox, helped pave the way for his return to cinema with a big promotional push for what he called his second first film. The first (feature) was of course Breathless.

title: A New Look at the Horrors in Rwanda
description: Shake Hands With the Devil, Roger Spottiswoodes plodding dramatization of the mass slaughter in Rwanda, is not to be confused with Peter Raymonts superb, similarly titled documentary.

title: Renegade Painters
description: A look at new exhibitions of works by William N. Copley and Peter Saul.

title: Netanyahu and Clinton in Extended Talks on Mideast
description: WASHINGTON  In a marathon day of meetings in New York on Thursday, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton worked to salvage peace negotiations that stalled last month over Israels refusal to extend a freeze on settlement construction in the West Bank.

title: Radio City Christmas Spectacular
description: Scenes from the 2010 production.

title: J. R. Ewing Shot Down Communism in Estonia
description: Imagine growing up in the Estonian capital city, Tallinn, during the cold war and discovering Dallas transmitted by television from Helsinki across the Gulf of Finland. Life in the 1970s was drab in Estonia, then a Soviet republic under the thumb of Moscow.

title: Yes, Theres a Shortfall; Thats the Starting Point
description: How big is the states budget shortfall? It depends on whos doing the math.

title: Romantic Dissatisfaction and Career Frustration
description: Plumbing yuppie fears may not be your first choice of an evenings entertainment, but Helena From the Wedding has a little more to offer than many films of its type. Among its achievements is the kind of comfortable, shaded acting we expect from seasoned professionals and a script (by the director, Joseph Infantolino) that almost scarily captures the cadences of whining white privilege.

title: Past Lives Wrapped in Mystery, Present Ones in Limbo
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Selling Ford Around the World, From Detroit
description: THE senior creative executive at Team Detroit, the consortium of WPP units that works on the Ford Motor account in North America, is getting a new role with a worldwide focus.

title: Cultures United to Honor Separatism
description: Corte, France

title: ESPN Baseballs Inevitable Change
description: In early 2002, when the John Madden-Pat Summerall team called its final N.F.L. game together, they celebrated and reminisced about a 21-season partnership that began at CBS and ended at Fox. Madden was off to ABCs Monday Night Football and Summerall stayed at Fox for one more full season.

title: The Logistician of the Holocaust
description: Eichmann, an English-language drama produced in Hungary and already shown around the world since its release in 2007, claims the moral high ground of being based not just on a true story but on official Israeli interrogation manuscripts. The filmmakers are so eager to armor themselves with facts that they open with both an encyclopedia entry (the Holocaust) and a dictionary entry (Adolf Eichmann).

title: The Winning Strategy in Oakland: Concentrate on Being 2nd or 3rd Choice
description: As cameras flashed Wednesday night, Jean Quan stood on the steps of Oakland City Hall and studied the results from the mayors race.

title: Veterans Day Roundup
description: Elected officials and other notables marked Veterans Day all around the world on Thursday, with President Obama making an appearance in South Korea and his wife, Michelle, surfacing in Germany.

title: The Life of a Contract Killer
description: If the aim of The Magician is to prove that the life of the average hit man is as grindingly tedious as that of the average road sweeper, then mission accomplished. Not enlivened by colorful characters, photogenic locations or clever dialogue, this spectacularly uninteresting Australian mockumentary zeroes in on Ray (played by the writer and director Scott Ryan), a contract killer in Melbourne.

title: After Losing Son, Arum Takes a Step Back
description: GRAPEVINE, Tex.  Inside another hotel convention center, promoting another fight, Bob Arum appeared in vintage form Thursday afternoon. He shook hands. Smiled. Did interviews. Patted backs. Persuaded. Fanned controversy. The usual.

title: Somalias Wars Swell a Refugee Camp in Kenya
description: DADAAB, Kenya  When Abdullahi Salat came here as a young boy in 1991, fleeing civil war in his homeland, Somalia, little more than shrubs and a few tents dotted the landscape. The woman working for the United Nations who greeted him at this safe haven, then nearly empty, showed him to his own tent and sprinkled a handful of seeds into his palm.

title: Producer of La Strada and Serpico Dies
description: Dino De Laurentiis, the high-flying Italian film producer and entrepreneur whose movies ranged from some of Federico Fellinis earliest works to the 1976 remake of King Kong, died at 91.

title: For Sale: A $160,000 Apple Computer
description: True computer nerds, do I have a deal for you!

title: Newsweek and Daily Beast Have a Deal
description: Tina Brown is back in the world of print.

title: 4 Are Accused of Running Heroin Mill in Midtown
description: The new tenants at 317 West 43rd Street made little impression on their neighbors, until the police came calling.

title: Start-Ups Follow Twitter, and Become Neighbors
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When Joe Fernandez, a tech entrepreneur, moved his start-up here last spring, a big goal, he said, was to be best friends with the Twitter guys. His theory was that by hanging around with executives at one of the hottest tech companies today, some of the magic could rub off.

title: Glenn Becks Attacks on George Soros Draw Heat
description: The Fox News host Glenn Beck was criticized Thursday by the Anti-Defamation League, a leading Jewish advocacy organization, in response to a televised segment about the financier George Soros and the Holocaust.

title: To Congress With the Mantra, Why Not Me?
description: MOLINE, Ill.  Bobby Schilling has spent the last decade perfecting his pizza crust. (The secret? A hint of whole wheat flour in the dough.) But this year, like dozens of other previously apolitical Americans, the cheerful father of 10 looked at the Congressional candidate arena and got to thinking, Hey, why not me?

title: Auburn Stars Father Sought Signing Money, Recruiter Says
description: The star Auburn quarterback Cam Newton will likely face greater N.C.A.A. scrutiny after a series of allegations by Kenny Rogers, a recruiter with financial ties to an N.F.L. agent, that could affect Newtons eligibility.

title: N.C.A.A. Says Turkish Center Cant Play at Kentucky
description: Kentuckys chances for a deep run in the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament took a significant hit Thursday when the N.C.A.A. ruled that the freshman center Enes Kanter was permanently ineligible.

title: Police Arrest 20 Who Tried to Sneak Into Unused Subway Station Filled With Art
description: The New York City police have arrested 20 people for trying to enter an abandoned subway station housing the formerly secret guerrilla exhibition of underground street art that was revealed to the public this month.

title: A Slaveholders Diary
description: Nov. 12, 1860On Friday morning, Nov. 9, 1860, Keziah Goodwyn Hopkins Brevard, a 57-year-old widowed plantation mistress, who lived some 10 miles east of Columbia, SC, wrote in her diary, Oh My God!!! This morning heard that Lincoln was elected. In the breathless entry that followed, she recorded her thoughts and fears:

title: The Freshest of the Freshmen
description: Newly-elected members who have never held elected office.

title: Disney Ends Strong Year With Quarter Thats Soft
description: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company reported unexpectedly soft fourth-quarter earnings on Thursday, hurt by a calendar quirk, the shift of some ESPN revenue to the third quarter and continued weakness in the theme park business.

title: Cuomo Names Transition Team and Panels, Spotlighting a Hope for Broad Support
description: Governor-elect Andrew M. Cuomo announced the leaders of his formal transition team on Thursday, along with two committees of advisers, each encompassing a wide array of business, labor and political leaders.

title: Deficit Reduction Plan Draws Scorn From Left and Right
description: WASHINGTON  By putting deep spending cuts and substantial tax increases on the table, President Obamas bipartisan debt-reduction commission has exposed fissures in both parties, underscoring the volatile nature and long odds of any attempt to address the nations long-term budget problems.

title: Photo Replay: Nov. 11
description: A look at the day in sports, from the World Fencing Championships to the Paris Tennis Masters.

title: Big School Problems Await New Chancellor
description: In introducing herself this week to a surprised city as the next New York City schools chancellor, Cathleen P. Black asked for the one thing that may prove to be impossible.

title: A Republican for Higher Taxes
description: David Stockman has never been one to shy away from a roaring economic-policy debate. The former boy-wonder budget director in the first Reagan administration and the architect of Reagans supply-side economic policies, Stockman has been very busy lately rejecting the tax-cutting recommendations of Republicans in Washington and arguing that we must get our fiscal house in order or watch our way of life continue its decline. As an imperialist power, he says, America is in danger of being at sundown. Stockman, who turned 64 on Wednesday, has always been ahead of the curve on tax and fiscal issues, and it appears that he is ahead of it again this time, too.

title: Little Harm Found if Gay Ban Is Lifted
description: WASHINGTON  The draft of a new Pentagon report comes to the conclusion that repealing the dont ask, dont tell law will not cause overall harm to the military but might cause temporary disruptions, people familiar with the report said on Thursday.

title: His Job Is to Make Public Obamas Candid Side
description: WASHINGTON  Arun Chaudhary is the White Houses ultimate fly on the wall.

title: Reality Hits the Knicks, and It Looks Like a Pick-and-Roll
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The task always seems so much easier on the day they put on the hat and smile for the cameras. Reality hits later, abruptly, leaving the N.B.A.s best and brightest looking stunned.

title: Backdating Scandal Ends With a Whimper
description: Before Lehman Brothers imploded, before Bernard L. Madoffs arrest and before the global economys near-collapse, there was the backdating of stock options.

title: In Alaska Voters Spelling Bee, Shes the Queen
description: JUNEAU, Alaska  Spelling is central to the Alaska Senate race. And Gail Fenumiai, potentially the elections ultimate arbiter, has extensive experience in the field.

title: Obama Takes Asia by Sea
description: Stockbridge, Mass.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,362 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following Americans on Thursday:

title: Lottery Numbers
Parish Schools Pessimistic After Warning of Closings
description: Late into the night after learning that the Archdiocese of New York might close his 130-year-old parish school, Msgr. Howard Calkins sat at his desk in the rectory of Sacred Heart Church in Mount Vernon, making lists: Why the school should stay open; how the school could do a better job raising enrollment.

title: Friday: Contest Results
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Before we get to the contest, I have a few notes on the Friday puzzle. I sometimes take a monotonous beating on a Barry C. Silk creation, but this one seems both fair and clever with some terrific clues.

title: Older, but No More Mature
description: The sounds filling the Stephen Sondheim Theater on 43rd Street are not the Broadway melodies you might expect to hear in a house recently renamed for the revered master of the American musical. They are, instead, the happy gurglings and raucous cheers of a thousand reborn inner children romping around a favorite playground.

title: Quants and Morgan Stanley to Part
description: For nearly two decades, the mathematical whiz Peter Muller and his secretive band of traders have helped power Morgan Stanley to bigger profits.

title: Resurrecting a Village by Buying Up Main Street
description: MOUNT MORRIS, N.Y.  For several years, Greg OConnell moved stealthily, buying building after building along a run-down stretch of Main Street here.

title: With Training and Faith, Getting Closer to a Dream
description: As he stood on a street corner in Jacksonville, Fla., and handed a $10 bag of marijuana to an undercover police officer, Theorpia Eugene Carter did not see the heavens open up or hear choirs of angels sing. Yet he remembers it as the moment that God changed his life.

title: Congo Republic: Amid Polio Outbreak, Groups Begin Immunization Campaign
description: International aid organizations said Thursday that they were starting a campaign to immunize three million people in three countries to fight a new outbreak of polio. The service organization Rotary International said it would give Unicef and the World Health Organization $500,000 total for the campaign, set to begin Friday in Pointe Noire, a coastal city where about 100 people have died in an outbreak that appears to have an unusually high mortality rate. From there, they will spread out to the rest of the country, neighboring Democratic Republic of Congo and Angola, with the goal of vaccinating three million people of all ages by years end. Normally, polio drops are given only to small children, but many teenagers and adults in central Africa are unprotected.

title: Suddenly, SoHo Heeds Law on Artists Lofts
description: As SoHos iron-boned, sprawling lofts became gold mines over the past two decades, co-op boards, banks, brokers and the city itself winked at a rule requiring that they be reserved for working artists.

title: No Verdict in Terror Trial of Ex-Detainee
description: A federal jury in Manhattan was sent home for the weekend by a judge on Thursday after failing to reach a verdict on the second day of deliberations in the case of Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani, the first former Guantnamo detainee to be tried in civilian court.

title: Making Video From the White House
description: White House photographers joke that you can't take a good picture of President Obama without Arun Chaudhary, the first official white house videographer, being somewhere in the frame.

title: The Minds Eye
description: Sight Reading

title: The Resilient Brain
description: Those whose familiarity with Oliver Sacks extends only to his vivid book titles  The Island of the Colorblind, An Anthropologist on Mars, The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat  may picture his writing as a gallery of grotesques, a parade of the exotically impaired. Sacks, a practicing neurologist, does specialize in case studies of highly unusual patients. But even as he entertains and diverts with his dramatic tales, Sacks has always been up to something else: he is gently educating us about the frailties and flaws  and the strengths and capacities  of normal people, those whose afflictions are of the most ordinary sort. You may never have confused your spouse for an item of outerwear, but have you ever failed to recognize the face of an acquaintance? Fumbled for a word that eluded your grasp? Read a sentence three times and still didnt get it?

title: For Pick to Lead Schools, One Man Left to Persuade
description: The man who will decide whether Cathleen P. Black, a publisher with no educational leadership experience, is qualified to lead the nations largest school system is himself a career educator known for his efforts to better prepare teachers for the classroom.

title: Harold P. Ford, C.I.A. Analyst, Dies at 89
description: Harold P. Ford, who joined the Central Intelligence Agency shortly after its creation and became one of its most influential analysts, died Nov. 3 in Gaithersburg, Md. He was 89.

title: The Pulse

title: Waving the Flag
description: Who says Congress cant get its work done? On Sept. 30, the House of Representatives passed the All-American Flag Act on an enthusiastic, bipartisan (we assume) voice vote. If the Senate steps up, the federal government will be required by law to buy only flags entirely made in the U.S.A., down to the last fiber.

title: Video Games and the First Amendment
description: If the Supreme Court renders justice in a case it heard this month, Schwarzenegger v. Entertainment Merchants Association, it will strike down a California law barring the sale or rental of violent video games to anyone under 18. That would end a violation of free expression  but not prevent the states from finding other ways to support parents who do not want their children to play violent games.

title: The Hijacked Commission
description: Count me among those who always believed that President Obama made a big mistake when he created the National Commission on Fiscal Responsibility and Reform  a supposedly bipartisan panel charged with coming up with solutions to the nations long-run fiscal problems. It seemed obvious, as soon as the commissions membership was announced, that bipartisanship would mean what it so often does in Washington: a compromise between the center-right and the hard-right.

title: When a Woman Runs Against a Woman
description: To the Editor:

title: National Greatness Agenda
description: Elections come and go, but the United States is still careening toward bankruptcy. By 2020, the U.S. will be spending $1 trillion a year just to pay the interest on the national debt. Sometime between now and then the catastrophe will come.

title: Finally a Deal ... Maybe
description: After eight months of wrangling, Iraqs leaders have agreed on the outlines of a new unity government. We hope it proves to be a real accomplishment. Sectarian anger is rising. And Iraq needs legitimate, representative rulers to address years of neglected business.

title: Torre Gala Gets Everyone Talking
description: It has been three years since Joe Torre stopped managing the Yankees. But his presence is still cause for a Yankees reunion, which turned into a reason to discuss the organizations free-agent plans.

title: Honoring Veterans
description: Tens of thousands of people marched up Fifth Avenue in Manhattan in a Veterans Day salute.

title: In Search of a Jade Host Rock
description: George E. Harlow, curator of gems and minerals at the American Museum of Natural History, has been studying jadeite for many years and has returned to the fault line that is the Motagua Valley in Guatemala. This is the second of two posts from Dr. Harlow.

title: Presidio Project Entwines Nature Into Artworks
description: Its a bright morning in the Presidio in San Francisco, and Andy Goldsworthy is trudging around a muddy forest clearing as he examines felled eucalyptus trees.

title: Energy Monitoring at U.T. Produces Savings 2 Ways
description: Five years ago, with energy prices soaring, John Graham, the director of the basketball arena at the University of Texas, decided to measure the use of electricity and other utilities in real time. He soon found that the Frank Erwin Center, the teams home, spent $3,500 on utilities in a single day.

description: Rolls-Royce, the aircraft engine maker, confirmed Friday that a specific component in the turbine area caused an oil fire that forced an Airbus A380 operated by Qantas Airways to make an emergency landing in Singapore last week.

title: How Would You Like to Help Our World?
description: For the past four years, a New York-based organization called DoSomething.org has been hosting day-long workshops to help young people learn how to pitch their ideas for making the world a better place. What idea would you pitch? What does the world need more of? Less of? How can you and other young people make it happen?

title: Paris Photo Fair Covers the Spectrum
description: Paris turns into photography paradise in November, as the annual Paris Photo fair hosts 106 exhibitors from all over the world, including 91 galleries and 15 book publishers. From Nov. 18 to 21 at the Carrousel du Louvre (99 rue de Rivoli; www.parisphoto.fr), works by over 1,000 artists dating from the 19th century to the present, in styles from documentary and photojournalism to fashion and fine art, will be on display. Though many works will be out of most visitors price range, inexpensive photographs will be on sale as well.
