title: Tip of the Week: Locking Up Your Screen
description: Need to step away from your computer for a few minutes and dont want anybody snooping around your screen? In most recent versions of Windows, you can just press the Windows key and the L key to quickly put up the login screen  which will not go away until the computers password is entered. Once you type in the password, the login screen goes away and Windows picks up right where you left off with your open files and programs.

title: G-20 Endorses New Reserve Rules for Banks
description: FRANKFURT  The Group of 20 endorsed new rules Friday that would sharply increase the amount of shock-absorbing capital that banks must hold in reserve, but left open numerous details including how to deal with institutions whose failure could rock the whole financial system.

title: Obama: Pelosi an Outstanding Partner
description: SEOUL  President Obama on Friday gave his tacit endorsement to House Speaker Nancy Pelosis bid to stay on as Democratic leader after January, calling her an outstanding partner for me.

title: After Struggles, Obama Seeks Lift in Japan
description: YOKOHAMA, Japan  President Obama, looking to wrap up his sometimes rocky economic tour of Asia on a high note, said Saturday that he made no apologies for doing whatever I can to bring jobs to the United States. And he vowed to pursue trade partnerships and American investment in the region so that he could put the United States back on a path of discovering, creating and building the products that are sold all over the world.

title: A QuickBooks Alternative for the Accounting-Phobic Owner
description: There are plenty of well regarded accounting tools out there, including the kind you use through a Web site. Well, of course there are. Just about the only thing that all companies have in common is a need to keep track of the money coming in and going out, so youd expect to find an offering for every sort of business  except, that is, for the 96 percent of American companies that employ 10 or fewer people.

title: Staggered Boards and Company Value
description: A background issue in the battle between Airgas and Air Products and Chemicals is the effectiveness of staggered boards and what academic research has to bear on the issue.

title: Liberals Fear Obama Is Caving on Their Agenda
description: Halfway through his four-year term, President Obama faces a liberal constituency that is disappointed about the lack of progress on their core issues and quick to jump to negative conclusions about his motives.

title: Crowds Hope for Release of Myanmar Leader
description: BANGKOK  Security was tight around the home of Myanmars pro-democracy leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, in anticipation of her possible release Saturday from house arrest, where she has spent 15 of the past 20 years.

title: On Late Night, Jeff Goldblum and Biz Markie Make the Best of Friends
description: Though Jeff Goldblum may be a certifiable genius  a certifiable something  his wiry energy is an ingredient that can yield unpredictable results. Combine him with an ordinary housefly or with Ed Begley Jr. and the outcome can be horrifying. But put him on a stage with a piano, the Roots and the rapper Biz Markie, as Late Night With Jimmy Fallon did on Thursday, and what you get is a cover of the Bizs Just a Friend that isnt cynical or satirical, just exuberant and fun. (Someone should write an article about that.)

Today fuel-efficiency, accessibility and a sobering sense of minimalism are the driving forces behind transportation design. From skies to subways, these latest concepts  some arriving shortly and others still en route  will change the way we travel by eliminating frills and lightening the load.

description: 1:29 p.m. | Updated belowAn earnest non-scientist probing the relationship of people, climate and energy travels the globe describing his menu for avoiding dangerous global warming.

title: Post-Tea-Party Nation
description: Republicans lost the presidency in 2008 in large part because of the worst economic crisis since World War II. Republicans have now regained the House of Representatives for the same reason. In the interval, Republicans ferociously attacked the Obama administrations economic remedies, and there certainly was a lot to attack. But the impulse to attack, it must be recognized, was based on more than ideology; it also served important psychological imperatives. Not since Jimmy Carter handed the office to Ronald Reagan  arguably not since Herbert Hoover yielded to Franklin Roosevelt  had a president of one party bequeathed a successor from another party so utter an economic disaster as George W. Bush bequeathed to Barack Obama. And while the Bush administration took wise and bold steps to correct the disaster, the unpopularity of its Troubled Asset Relief Program bequeathed the Obama administration a political disaster alongside the economic disaster.

title: Housewives of God
description: Priscilla Shirers marriage appears to be just the sort of enlightened partnership that would make feminists cheer. On an average morning in their house in suburban Dallas, Shirer and her husband, Jerry, are up around 6:30, fixing breakfast for their three small boys. While Priscilla, 35, settles in to work at home and care for their 2-year-old, Jerry, 42, shuttles the older two children to school and heads to his office. He spends much of the day negotiating her speaking invitations and her book contracts. In the afternoon its often Jerry who collects the boys from school. Back home, Priscilla and Jerry divide chores and child care equally. He will most often jump in and do the dinner dishes, Priscilla says. We dont have, these are wife tasks and these are husband tasks. . . . Kids are not a wife-mommy thing.

title: The Most-Hated Son
description: Last winter, after more than three decades of silence, I desperately wanted to see my mother before it was too late. Not to make amends, really. I wanted to see her once and not be afraid. I had been courting her in recent years, sending flowers, fruit and candy for her birthday and holidays, asking to visit. She acknowledged my gifts with terse handwritten notes. She sent back the designer jelly beans with the scrawl I prefer dark chocolate. In the past, she ignored me completely, or her response ended with you stupid idiot. We were making progress. Yet she still refused to see me.

title: Think About Pink
description: A friend of mines 12-year-old daughter has taken to wearing a bracelet, one of those rubber, Lance Armstrong-style affairs, that says on it, I  Boobies.

title: Walgreens Tackles Food Deserts
description: Among students of the contemporary metropolis, food deserts have become a widely known problem. The term is generally used to describe urban neighborhoods where there are few grocers selling fresh produce, but a cornucopia of fast-food places and convenience stores selling salty snacks (though, strictly speaking, the term can be applied to rural or suburban areas, too). Often the problem afflicts low-income areas abandoned or shunned by food businesses that focus on better-off consumers; the residents of food deserts, apparently, are not providing enough profit to be offered more healthful grub. These are places where the market for nutritious sustenance has essentially failed.

title: Studies in Hyperreality
description: The rearview mirror looked odd, even ominous. It spread nearly a yard across the top of the taxis windshield.

title: The Anti-Antibiotics Doctor
description: When my husband and I planned a trip to Machu Picchu and the Galapagos, tour leaders warned that medical facilities would be limited and advised us to bring any medicine we might need, including antibiotics. Although my husband frequently gets bronchial infections, his doctor refused to write a prescription for antibiotics, asserting that it was unethical to provide a medication to someone not actually ill. As it turned out, my husband developed pneumonia, and the trip was ruined. Was this doctor overly rigid? NAME WITHHELD, NEW JERSEY

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Midtown Goes Downtown
description: The new titles on the manga list this week all belong to VIZ Media and illustrate the diversity of their publishing line: a romance in Otomen, demon-slaying in D.Gray-Man and a slice-of-life story about trying to make it in the manga industry in Bakuman.

title: Hameo
description: A hammy cameo.

title: Letter: The Playboy and His Power Games
description: Chip Browns article about the New Jersey Nets owner, Mikhail Prokhorov, was fascinating, but it omitted a strand of the billionaire Russians life story that could have been illuminating. In addition to his roles in banking and industry, Prokhorov has been president of the Russian Biathlon Union for over two years, and he is credited with turning around a moribund organization tarnished by doping. It would have been interesting to read more about Prokhorovs work in that sport, since the Nets seem to be in need of a similar reversal.

title: As a Neighborhood Shifts, the Chain Stores Arrive
description: It was one thing when a Duane Reade opened last year in a new tower on the waterfront in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. But the resistance got vocal when a second one opened its doors last week  on Bedford Avenue, the throbbing heart of Williamsburgs shopping district.

title: A Review of Cool It
description: In Fridays Times, our colleague Jeannette Catsoulis reviews Cool It, the new documentary about the Danish economist Bjorn Lomborg, whose 2001 book The Skeptical Environmentalist challenged mainstream thinking about the threats posed by global warming.

title: Letter: The Cancer Sleeper Cell
description: I was transfixed reading Siddhartha Mukherjees article. I thought I was reading an account of my own daughters epic saga with cancer. Two years ago, two days before her 36th birthday, Rachel was given a diagnosis of leiomyosarcoma, a rare soft-tissue cancer that can be associated with a cancer predisposition syndrome called Li-Fraumeni (L.F.S.). As in the case of the psychologist mentioned in the article, Rachel, too, had been nearly asymptomatic. Following an airplane trip from Philadelphia to Albuquerque, she had an edema in her legs that her internist attributed to long periods of sitting on planes. Initial tests revealed nothing unusual. When the edema persisted, more tests were ordered, and the CT scan showed Stage 4 cancer. We were told that her cancer could be managed but not cured.

title: Letters: The New Momism
description: Momism may be a clever strategy in a season of populist rage, as quoted in the Judith Warners column. I get that. Michelle Obama and Sarah Palin, both overtly proud of being mothers and often using that status for political gain, have even more in common than the article implied. They both live with their childrens fathers, have adequate income, college education, power and advantage. The status they have achieved, regardless of how, is their common denominator. But at a time when Americas poor mothers are struggling to feed, educate and keep their children safe, sometimes without the support of a partner, being a mom elicits a whole different meaning for millions of women the article never mentions. Being a grizzly for them means fighting with the welfare folks who may have inadvertently canceled their food stamps; standing up to an absentee landlord when the heater breaks in the middle of winter; or figuring out how to manage a lottery system so her kid can get into the one decent magnet school in her city.

title: Protecting Yourself From the Cost of Type 2 Diabetes
description: ONE in 10 Americans has diabetes, and if present trends continue, one in three will suffer from the disease by the year 2050, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Already this incurable, chronic and often debilitating illness costs the countrys health care system a staggering $174 billion a year.

title: The Cost of Diabetes Care
description: Todays Patient Money explores the various costs associated with diabetes as well as suggestions for how patients can save money on their care.

title: Letter: Questions for Garry Wills
description: I question why Garry Wills would portray himself as a grumpy old man throughout his interview, saddening all of us who are well aware of his journalists eye for detail when he has written about others throughout the years. For those of us who have followed Wills, read his words, his books and his opinions, we would have hoped his responses would enlighten us. Sadly, he comes across as rude, lessening our estimation of the man.JOAN LARSENPark Forest, Ill.

title: Letters: Good News, Bad News
description: I was troubled by Rob Walkers slipshod correlation in his otherwise fascinating examination of the Gaps recent logo problems. In seeking to argue that the publicity generated by the logo might be good for the companys sales, he cites a recent paper in Marketing Science that found that negative book reviews in The New York Times bolster obscure authors sales and hurt established authors sales. The bad publicity, the paper argues, serves to increase awareness of the book, which in turn fuels sales. Walkers analogy with the Gaps logo issues, however, is poor, and comparing apparel and books is a mismatched venture at best. In the analogy, Gap jeans are novels, but a more accurate publishing parallel would be an imprint redesigning its logo, something that most likely has never caused much of a stir outside of publishing house offices. Why? The Gap has builta brand on its logo, while books are judged one product at a time. Although his theories on publicity are interesting, Walkers apples-and-oranges argument is a blatant attempt to place a scientific basis behind his theories on the Gaps logo.

title: Young Manhattanite Is a Beacon on the Blog Scene
description: ON THE SCREEN In a list on its home page, the group blog Young Manhattanite offers 13 definitions of itself, including a random Tumblr page and blogging Illuminati. Both are accurate, as is this: YM is a cipher of insider chatter. It is like a nuclear launch code, admits its founder and lead blogger, Andrew Krucoff.

title: Letter: Creeper! Rando! Sketchball!
description: It was with great dismay that I read Ben Zimmers recent On Language column on the new wave of slang sweeping todays college campuses. In particular, I was appalled when my last name  Rando  was associated with unfamiliar, suspicious or anxiety-producing outsiders. I have spent a good part of my life carefully concealing this fact from my friends and co-workers, building a sterling reputation as someone who can be trusted and embraced by society. My cover is now blown irrevocably. Yet I ask for no apologies and expect no sympathy. My only hope is that people around the world use this as a cautionary tale; slang is not something to be taken lightly.

title: Letter: Funeral for a Friend
description: In regard to Virginia Heffernans Medium column, I also mourn the demise of the analog telephone, along with the etiquette and manners that went with it. The days when people were out in public and simply unavailable for phone calls seem like a long-ago dream. Today, you are subjected to everyones business, both private and professional, at all times and with little regard to the people around them. The greatest loss is that with e-mail and texting, you cant hear someones voice, emotion and inflection in a conversation  definitely a step backward, not forward.

title: Friday Reading: The Bedbug Detection Industry
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Letter: Cutting the Cord
description: Ive heard countless stories of teens being insufferable on the eve of their college departure, butting heads with parents (especially moms). This is the first time Ive heard of a mom instigating the trouble, and I applaud Rene Bachers Lives column for its honesty in the matter.

title: Letter: The Art of Social Change
description: Kwame Anthony Appiah makes the wonderful point (Oct. 24) that if Westerners and Europeans were more culturally sensitive to local contexts and worked with villagers rather than parachute in with Western values and ideas, change might be better adapted to local needs. Im glad Appiah uses foot binding in China as his chief positive example of change rather than female genital cutting (F.G.C.)  not mutilation, as your subtitle suggests. I remember being in Kenya in 1980 when women from that country came back from the U.N. conference on the status of women in Copenhagen, angered by Western womens cultural insensitivity to what Kenyan (and other African) women viewed as their issue. Female circumcision is limited to northern Africa and along the eastern coast. It was rarely seen in central and southern Africa. It is time that The Times Magazine adopted the more appropriate term cutting, which both Appiah and Nicholas Kristof use in their articles, rather than the socially charged term mutilation. Times reporters have changed over the past 10 years and adopted F.G.C. as the operative term. Its time the magazine followed suit.

title: Letter: Questions for Melinda Gates
description: I kept waiting for Deborah Solomon (Oct. 24) to capture the essence of Melinda Gates: her deeply informed and joyful hands-on immersion in her philanthropies. Instead, Solomons tough and relevant questioning crossed over into the snarky and superficial. All the other remarkable aid workers written about in the same issue were treated with seriousness, without the apparent bias of being seen through a prism of immense wealth. I was very sad to see Melinda Gates diminished in this way.

title: Wanderlust | Patch NYC in Boston
description: Patch NYC has come a long way since its debut collection, 15 years ago, of crocheted hats made by the mother of John Ross, the brands co-owner. The company has grown over the years to include both fashion and home items, all with a modern twist on a vintage look. Enough, in fact, to fill a store, which opened in the South End of Boston two weeks ago. Our collection had expanded into a lot of new categories, and we wanted a space where we could show everything together, explained Ross, referring to himself and his co-owner, Don Carney. We found an ideal space in the back of a brick-lined courtyard in our favorite Boston neighborhood, and it felt like a perfect location to create a Patch NYC world. That world includes the companys jewelry, scarves, candles and pillows, along with original art by Carney, who hails from Boston. Also in the mix are a selection of porcelain from the Brooklyn-based designers Klein Reid, ceramic sculptures by the Boston-based artist Steve Murphy and vintage decorative objects and Indian textiles. Ross and Carneys mothers are still involved  theyre currently working on framed needlepoint art that will be sold at Barneys.Patch NYC, 46 Waltham Street, Boston; (917) 292-2640.

title: The Week Ahead: Nov. 14-20
description: Classical

title: Letter: End-of-Life Duty
description: Randy Cohens advice to the celebrity spokesperson (Oct. 24) regarding the employer that he or she discovered had unfair labor practices here and abroad was dead on and succinct  quit your job. However, he failed to explore a nobler and more elegant solution. The celebrity in question could use his or her status as a spokesperson to effect change in the companys labor policies. Either publicly or privately, the celebrity should let the company know that he or she is not comfortable promoting a company whose practices are inhumane and simply ask them to change these practices. A win-win for all. The company gets P.R. brownie points for being conscientious, laborers are provided a more lucrative and safe working environment and the celebrity remains employed.

title: Adam Pinsker, Manager and Adviser of Arts Groups, Dies at 79
description: Adam Pinsker, an arts administrator who managed orchestras, chamber music ensembles and dance troupes and who successfully advised dance companies on how to survive by professionalizing their management, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 79 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Syrian Arts: A Cultural Dissent
description: To the Editor:

title: Nomura Wins Ruling Against WestLB
description: 2:13 p.m. | Updated Nomura, the Japanese investment bank that bought Lehman Brothers international operations in 2008, has won a High Court ruling in London against WestLB, the German regional lender, over a structured note deal that caused losses during the financial crisis.

title: Stephen Sondheim: Good Grief
description: To the Editor:

title: Bruce Springsteen: Remember the Clash
description: To the Editor:

title: A Pitman Praiser
description: To the Editor:

title: Must-See TV
description: To the Editor:

title: In Iran, Hailing Detroit With Vintage V-8s
description: THE scene has been played out so many times as to border on clich. It begins with an impromptu meet-up of two Chevy Camaros, each announcing its prowess with a V-8 rumble. Then, despite good-natured banter between the drivers, an unspoken challenge is made. Finally, a tire-smoking showdown ensues.

title: A Despots Garage Is Open for Tours
description: THE Shah of Iran, who ruled from 1941 until he was overthrown in a 1979 revolution, was an auto aficionado with a taste for European classics and exotics. During his authoritarian reign, he assembled a large collection  how large is anybodys guess  that included vehicles specially built for him.

title: Nissan Recalls 501,000 Trucks in U.S. for Steering Problem
description: 10:55 a.m. | Updated

title: Its Not Over Till the Svelte Mama Sings
description: EARLY this fall the mezzo-soprano Isabel Leonard stood beside the grand piano in the Central Park West apartment of Edith Bers, her voice teacher since her Juilliard days, inhaled deeply and revealed her latest accomplishment: taut, well-defined abs. Admirable by any standard, they were all the more impressive because on May 17 Ms. Leonard gave birth to Teo, her son with her husband, the New Zealand baritone Teddy Tahu Rhodes (famous for his own steely six-pack).

title: Joe Girardi, the Recruiter
description: Joe Girardi is confident the Yankees will improve their roster in the off-season and he is eager to help recruit big-name free agents like Cliff Lee.

title: Ieva Jokubaviciute and Vladimir Valjarevic on Berg
description: Ieva Jokubaviciute, Vladimir Valjarevic, pianists; Marjorie Elinor Dix, mezzo-soprano. Labor Records LAB 7086; CD.

title: Pictures Seldom Played
description: FOR those who like to stump their musical friends with the old guess-the-composer game, a good puzzler would be Sea Piece With Birds.

title: Running for President of Haiti, but Stumping in U.S.
description: BOSTON  It was a typical late-October campaign event, with spectators straining to see a candidate, talk of change and pleas for support, but with one major difference  no one in the room could cast a ballot in the election.

title: EADS Chief Sees Future in Emerging Markets
description: PARIS  Countries in Europe are tightening their budgets and imposing austerity measures. But Louis Gallois, who runs the largest European aerospace and military contractor, is not worried.

title: Timeless Stories in Period Costume
description: Forget the fros, the saffron robes and the 60-cent taxi meter drop, the Horn & Hardart, the Doubleday and the showroom on Broadway with Chevelles for sale. Paul McDonoughs New York City, 1973-1978 summons all these memories for anyone old enough to recall when city buses were green. But the pictures are really not about memory. They are, instead, timeless narratives, perfectly current in their story line. They are suffused with detail and a lot of wit. They repay close examination. And you can see them on Lens.

title: Muscle Cars in Iran
description: Classic-car events attract considerable attention in Iran.

title: Friday: Did I Make Money This Week?
description: This week, as I explained last Friday, Im writing daily posts about my experiences during a recent week trying to collect money from my customers.

title: Forgiving the Unforgivable?
description: Some relationships are truly beyond repair. And yet, even then, we try. In the Lives column in The New York Times Magazine this weekend, Frederick Woolverton writes about the 30-year silence between him and his mother, who, he says frankly, hated me.

title: Emanuel to Make It Official
description: CHICAGO  If there is any shred of doubt left about whether Rahm Emanuel, the former White House chief of staff, is running for mayor of Chicago, it will be erased on Saturday, when Mr. Emanuel is scheduled to announce his candidacy.

title: Icahn Raises Dynegy Stake and Offers Credit Line
description: 4:24 p.m. | Updated Carl C. Icahn has raised his stake in Dynegy and will extend the company a $2 billion line of credit if its proposed takeover by the Blackstone Group is rejected and other financing cannot be obtained, according to a regulatory filing.

title: Potluck
description: Mark Kurlansky is among our most intelligent, prolific and literate writers about food: not cooking, not restaurants, but food. Cod: A Biography of the Fish That Changed the World and Salt: A World History are both comprehensive, valuable and as entertaining as food nonfiction gets. And Kurlansky ranges even wider. Hes written a popular history of the Basques, a book on baseball and one on European Jewry. Edible Stories is his third work of fiction.

title: The Best 5-4 Team in the N.B.A.?
description: With two losses on its home court in three days  to Boston on Thursday and to Utah in overtime on Tuesday  the Miami Heat is 5-4.

title: Back to the City
description: In 1974, Armistead Maupin, then a young journalist, covered a story on a Safeway supermarket in San Francisco that had become a popular pickup spot. Local customers, gay and straight, were not, as it turns out, shopping only for wheat bread and alfalfa sprouts, nor were they willing to talk to a reporter. Undaunted, Maupin created his own spokeswoman: a fictional young Midwesterner named Mary Ann Singleton.

title: Hello, Columbus
description: Lean, tattooed and hunky in the way of a young Henry Rollins, Brian Reaume is living the life of a gay indie Brooklyn or Bay Area artist. He lives in what real estate agents call a transitional neighborhood, in a house filled with midcentury furniture and quirky art by him and his friends. In a small shop on a funky strip of cafes, bars and galleries, he sells his paintings along with the vintage housewares that he collects with the shops co-owner, Nancy Carlson, who lives upstairs. Two years ago he created Theres No Truth in Silence, an installation in his studio  which is among a warren of artists spaces in an old warehouse  that drew thousands one weekend with its controversial use of the American flag, a swastika, a cross and a chair emblazoned with the word fag.

title: Farmers Water Deals Stir Debate
description: Two farmers in Californias San Joaquin Valley are proposing to do with their water rights what farmers around the country have done for decades: sell them  to developers.

title: Reading Hot Rod in Tehran
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Jim Koscs writes about car enthusiasts in Iran, with a special focus on the Tehran Caf Racers, an affiliate of a club based in Florida. In what may come as a surprise, a number of the cars treasured by the clubs members are American muscle cars:

title: Speaking of Understatements
description: I RECENTLY drove 1,500 miles in the new Audi A8. But Im not sure anyone noticed.

title: This Weekends Top Soccer Matchups
description: The outstanding matchups around the world this weekend:

title: Student Crossword | India
description: Complete our Student Crossword to see what you know about India and its history and culture. You can find the answers here.

title: Gran Turismo 5 to Be Released on Nov. 24
description: Sony announced the latest  and hopefully, last  release date for its Gran Turismo 5 driving simulator for the PlayStation 3. The game will hit store shelves on Wednesday, Nov. 24. And with less than two weeks to go, theres a pretty good chance that this latest release date will stick.

title: For Freshmen House Members, Which Orientation to Choose?
description: Newly elected members of Congress are arriving in Washington this weekend for the equivalent of freshman orientation  but which orientation to attend?

title: O.K., Seriously  Who Was Interviewed for Chancellors Job?
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said he searched for the best possible schools chancellor before picking Cathleen P. Black, the chairwoman of Hearst Magazines. But so far, we havent heard the names of any others who were in contention. Indeed, The Times has been unable to turn up any evidence that the mayor considered anyone besides Ms. Black, a complete outsider to the world of education, to replace Joel I. Klein.

title: Obama Abroad: Ways to Teach About the Presidents Asia Trip
description: Note: Our Friday lesson plans focus on an important interdisciplinary topic in the news each week, and this week the big news is President Obamas ten-day trip through India, Indonesia, South Korea and Japan.

title: Carrots: Raw, Roasted, Baked and Simmered
description: Whenever I buy a bunch of carrots, I end up eating them just as they are  raw, crunchy and delicious. But this week Martha Rose Shulman inspires us to get more creative with carrots, a versatile vegetable that can be used to create nutrient-rich sauces, salads, soups and even cake.

title: Forget Decades and Distance. Its Still Giants-Dodgers.
description: The Giants recent World Series victory may have brought pure joy for many San Francisco-ites, but for fans of the Giants who once watched the team at the Polo Grounds, the victory was double-edged.

title: 2011 Audi A8
description: For people who appreciate the subtle exterior, the A8 is a terrific drive.

title: Contenders for Title Take Top Four Spots in Abu Dhabi Practice
description: The first practice sessions of the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix set the stage perfectly for the last race of the season, which will decide the title among four drivers. The four remaining contenders finished in the top four spots, and interestingly, the man with the least chance to win the title, and therefore the one who has the least amount of pressure this weekend, was also the fastest man on track on Friday.

title: Contenders for Title Take Top Four Spots in Abu Dhabi Practice
description: The first practice sessions of the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix set the stage perfectly for the last race of the season, which will decide the title among four drivers. The four remaining contenders finished in the top four spots, and interestingly, the man with the least chance to win the title, and therefore the one who has the least amount of pressure this weekend, was also the fastest man on track on Friday.

title: Afghanistan: Change You Cant Sit and Talk About
description: CHAHAR DARA, Afghanistan  When President Obama gave his major speech on Afghanistan a year ago, he called not only for sending an additional 30,000 American troops to the war, but also for expanding the role of civilian experts in rebuilding the nations shattered government and economy. A new policy was born: the civilian surge.

title: Garfield Creator Apologizes for National Stupid Day Cartoon
description: Garfield may hate Mondays, but Thursday wasnt a banner day for that cartoon cat, either. Jim Davis, the creator and author of Garfield, apologized for a comic strip published on Thursday that some readers said was insensitive to the Veterans Day holiday.

title: A Head Start for Fabio Trabocchi Downtown
description: When Villa Pacri opens in the meatpacking district on Nov. 23, Fabio Trabocchi, formerly of Fiamma, will be consulting chef. But until then Mr. Trabocchi will be working on the menu[pdf] downstairs in the more casual La Gazzetta.

title: Who Sets Chinas Monetary Policy?
description: My column this morning mentions how upset the Chinese are with the Federal Reserve, but it does not discuss one very good reason they have to be upset: Ben Bernankes monetary policy is not what China needs these days. It needs to tighten, as is shown by rising inflation there.

title: Ralph Lauren and the Digital Age
description: David Lauren, Senior Vice President of Polo Ralph Lauren, tells Suzy Menkes about future plans for his father's global company and strategy for what is now the biggest store, its e-commerce website.

title: The Bakers Apprentice: Brownies
description: Emily Weinstein, who wrote a series on this blog about learning to cook, is now learning to bake with Dorie Greenspan, a food writer and the author of several cookbooks, including the recent Around My French Table.

title: Spheres of Influence
description: Timothy Garton Ash specializes in what he calls (quoting George F. Kennan) the history of the present. He is a historian with the journalists urge to be there, and a journalist with the historians knowledge of where he is. These qualities have made him one of the most reliable and acute observers of the past present, able to report on events as a witness and, simultaneously, assess them with a coolness of judgment that almost always holds up over time.

title: For Some, Tough Entry Into G.M.s I.P.O.
description: Individual investors who want to buy a piece of the new General Motors when it goes public next week may be out of luck.

title: Miamis Big Three Stumble Along
description: Its kind of a shame really, that the Miami Heat has started the season 5-4, having been thumped twice by the Celtics already. The Big Three had such potential to be the N.B.A.s hated villain. LeBron Jamess universally hated free agency reality show was sublime; getting people to scowl at the otherwise likeable Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh was genius. The forever-gelled Pat Riley lurking in the background? Oliver Stone couldnt have constructed this better. But now, theyre stumbling along like a band of misfits and its impossible to conjure up anything close to mass indignation. Its more like a mass yawn.

title: Italian Cultural Groups Stage Protest
description: ROME  Hundreds of Italian cultural institutions took part in a nationwide protest on Friday against a series of measures passed recently that critics say will stifle cultural development in Italy.

title: Week 11 College Football Matchups
description: Its getting down to it. Only a couple of weeks of college football left. Pay attention people. Soon it will be February and you will be cold and wishing college football was still on. Makes me kind of sad to even type that. This week maybe without a signature blockbuster game, but its got plenty of conference action.

title: Summit Shows U.S. Can Still Set Agenda, if Not Get Action
description: SEOUL, South Korea  It could have been far worse.

title: Weekend Competition: Lying to Children
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to share the lies they have told to children.

title: Anthony Gets Hot, Future With Nuggets Still Murky
description: Carmelo Anthony is used to rumors. He can handle the speculation about his future, but he doesnt want the whispers affecting his Denver Nuggets teammates.

title: The Mind of a Disease
description: All patients begin as storytellers, the oncologist Siddhartha Mukherjee observes near the start of this powerful and ambitious first book. Long before they see a doctor, they become narrators of suffering, as Mukherjee puts it  travelers who have visited the kingdom of the ill.

title: Mean Girls and Bad Mommies
description: One of the most refreshing scenes in the movie The Kids Are All Right comes when 15-year-old Laser has it out with his jerky pal, Clay. They trade a barbed sentence or two, shove each other, and then bam! With a punch to the face, the friendship is over.

title: Gina Lollobrigida. Need We Say More?
description: The Most Beautiful Woman in the World walked into Harry Cipriani on Fifth Avenue in black boots and a riding-hood-red cloak, and for the only person in the room expecting her, it perhaps was a trick of the imagination, but it seemed as if the whole restaurant lost its train of thought for a second. Then it righted itself, and the matre dhtel hustled over, and the woman became wrapped in warm Italian greetings and air kisses before finally removing her big sunglasses.

title: Film of Paul Bowles Short Story Rediscovered
description: The tale had all the hallmarks of a baroque Paul Bowles short story, set among the remaindered possessions of Bowles himself: a film director gets a call from a stranger, who says he has stumbled across an original print of the filmmakers long-lost first film in a windowless Tangier apartment, coated in dust and insect powder. The director, Sara Driver, at first thought the call might be a joke, but for reasons almost as strange as fiction, she kept listening.

title: Curators Choice | Tim Gunn for Ahalife
description: Ahalife, the two-month-old Web site that offers its readers one guest-curated item every 24 hours, includes departments like Dress Me, Optimize Me and Design Me.

title: Twentysomethings, Getting By in New York
description: Four young New Yorkers discuss their creative strategies for making ends meet while still managing to have fun.

title: New and Living in the City
description: Twenty-something transplants discuss their moves to New York and how theyre adjusting to their adopted city.

title: 20-Somethings Living the Small Life in New York Apartments
description: For New Yorkers in their 20s, a postage-stamp bedroom in a shared walk-up in an iffy neighborhood is a lucky find. Who cares about home when theres a big city out the door?

title: The Price 20-Somethings Pay to Live in the City
description: ABE CAVIN QUEZADA, a 22-year-old aspiring music producer, lives with two roommates in a three-bedroom apartment in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. Mr. Cavin Quezada, who works as an unpaid intern at Electric Lady Studios in Greenwich Village, has kind words for his building, a renovated tenement near Marcus Garvey Boulevard, and for his apartment, for which he pays $500 a month and has a 10-by-6-foot bedroom. But as for the neighborhood, he is less enthusiastic.

title: A Challenger for Steele as Head of R.N.C.
description: The Republican Partys embattled chairman, Michael S. Steele, has drawn his first, but perhaps not his last, challenger: Saul Anuzis, the former Michigan party chairman who made it to the final rounds of voting when Mr. Steele was elected nearly two years ago.

title: Editors Choice
description: CLEOPATRA: A Life,  by Stacy Schiff (Little, Brown, $29.99.) Its dizzying to contemplate the ancient thicket of personalities and propaganda Schiff penetrates to reconstruct the Macedonian-Egyptian queen in all her ambition, audacity and formidable intelligence.

title: Inside the List
description: ROYAL FLUSH: Keith Richardss well-reviewed Life is sitting pretty, if thats the word, at No. 1 in its second week on the hardcover nonfiction list. Meanwhile, a pack of new celebrity books is nipping at its heels. Unbearable Lightness, the actress Portia de Rossis memoir of her anorexia, enters at No. 3. (De Rossi may be the first prime-time television star to score a blurb from Jonathan Safran Foer.) Ricky Martins Me plops down at No. 5, trailed by the confessions of Howard Sterns producer, Gary DellAbate, They Call Me Baba Booey. (Funny, thats what I call Ricky Martin.) And then theres Autobiography of Mark Twain, Vol. 1, from the biggest celebrity in 19th-century America (No. 9), and Cleopatra, Stacy Schiffs biography of the Ptolemaic tabloid queen, new at No. 11.

title: Paperback Row
description: FOOTNOTES IN GAZA, written and illustrated by Joe Sacco. (Metropolitan/Holt, $23.) Saccos reputation for combining graphic artistry and investigative reporting was established with Palestine and Safe Area Gorazde. Footnotes reconstructs two long-forgotten mass killings of Palestinians during the Suez crisis of 1956, when the Israeli Army swept into the Gaza Strip. Saccos gripping, important book . . . stands out as one of the few contemporary works on the Israeli-Palestinian struggle likely to outlive the era in which they were written, Patrick Cockburn wrote in the Book Review.

title: Spy vs. Spy
description: Inside the Central Intelligence Agency, it came to be known as The Italian Job, a botched operation in 2003 that snatched a radical cleric off a Milan street in broad daylight and spirited him to Egypt, where he says he endured months of torture at the hands of his Egyptian jailers.

title: A Good Day to Die
description: In the Indian wars of the 1870s, Sioux tribesmen used a tactic against the United States Cavalry known as a brave run or a dare ride. An Indian warrior would gallop close to the American soldiers, drawing their fire. The purpose was partly practical  to get the soldiers to waste their ammunition  and partly psychological  to taunt. The Sioux sometimes showed their contempt for their enemies by appearing naked or nearly so, displaying their genitals and buttocks. Then the Indians would close in. Soldiers always tried to keep an enemy at bay, to kill him at a distance, Thomas Powers writes in The Killing of Crazy Horse, his richly textured account of clashing civilizations on the Great Plains during the late 19th century. The instinct of Sioux fighters was for exactly the opposite: to charge in and touch the enemy with a quirt, bow or naked hand while he was still alive. There is no terror in battle to equal physical contact  shouting, hot breath, the grip of a hand from a man close enough to smell. The whites were repulsed by the smell of Indians  an odor resembling a mixture of smoked beef, muskrat and polecat, according to a correspondent for Frank Leslies Illustrated Weekly quoted by Powers; a pungent, musty odor something like that of combined smoke and grease, Lt. William Philo Clark, a cavalry officer, wrote. For the Sioux who wanted nothing to do with whites, visceral differences like smell were only the beginning, Powers writes. The Indians particularly resented white treatment of Indian women. Many whites beat or abused Indian women, exploited them sexually after capture in battle, and sometimes bought them for cheap trinkets and liquor and later cast them aside.

title: The Hipster in the Mirror
description: A year ago, my colleagues and I started to investigate the contemporary hipster. What was the hipster, and what did it mean to be one? It was a puzzle. No one, it seemed, thought of himself as a hipster, and when someone called you a hipster, the term was an insult. Paradoxically, those who used the insult were themselves often said to resemble hipsters  they wore the skinny jeans and big eyeglasses, gathered in tiny enclaves in big cities, and looked down on mainstream fashions and tourists. Most puzzling was how rattled sensible, down-to-earth people became when we posed hipster-themed questions. When we announced a public debate on hipsterism, I received e-mail messages both furious and plaintive. Normally inquisitive people protested that there could be no answer and no definition. Maybe hipsters didnt exist! The responses were more impassioned than those wed had in our discussions on health care, young conservatives and feminism. And perfectly blameless individuals began flagellating themselves: Am I a hipster?

title: The Ancestral Home
description: Unlike memoirs that are secretly novels, Who Occupies This House admits its a novel pretending to be a memoir, a family scrapbook that includes photos, newspaper clippings, posters, letters, diaries, short autobiographies and more. The spaces between these documents are filled by a 60-something Manhattanite who, after 9/11, feels compelled to research, reconstruct and occasionally simply imagine several generations of her Irish-American forebears, some of whom lived and died in a house in Pelham, N.Y.

title: Original Sins
description: I come from Chattanooga, a city on the Tennessee River that sits on and near land that was taken from the Cherokee Nation and that saw some of the most significant fighting of the Civil War three decades later. It is impossible to grow up there without a sense of historical immediacy. As a child I would feed ducks in a pond outside the house from which Chief John Ross was driven, and more than once I found Mini balls from the Battle of Missionary Ridge in our yard.

title: Cat and Mouse
description: There once was an 80-year-old father of eight, the contours of whose life bore an uncanny resemblance to those of the noted German writer, political activist and public intellectual Gnter Grass; his children even remembered accompanying him to a Nobel-like gala in Stockholm, complete with tuxedos and velvet gowns.

title: TimesCast | November 12, 2010
description: The people of Swat, Pakistan; Republicans raising cash and Sarah Palin's new reality show.

title: Japans High-Speed Trains Lines Expand
description: Japans high-speed bullet train system is expanding, reducing transit time to tourist attractions in remote corners of the country.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Amateur Gourmet: Three desserts to make with apples: baked apples, apple cake and apple cobbler.  Samantha Storey

title: Tudor Jones Doubts Feds Bond Buying
description: Paul Tudor Jones, the successful currency trader, says that fixing the gross misalignment of Chinas currency against the dollar would do more to lower unemployment in the United States than the recent move by the Federal Reserve to buy large quantities of Treasury bonds.

title: Barclays to Reimburse Gay Workers for Health Benefit Tax
description: Gay people who are lucky enough to work for employers that extend health benefits to their same-sex partners are still at a disadvantage: they must pay an extra tax on the value of those benefits that heterosexual married couples do not pay.

title: After a Life in Law, Focusing on Simple Pleasures
description: For more than 30 years, Neil L. Selinger had his hand in major securities litigation cases that played out in New York courts. He represented several municipal pension funds in the case against WorldCom, the telecommunications company that reported some $11 billion in false profits. He helped to obtain a nearly $80 million settlement for investors of Philip Services Corp., a Canadian resource recovery company. In 2007, Mr. Selinger stepped away from the practice of law to pursue his interest in writing and volunteer endeavors.

title: Book Review Podcast: The Emperor of All Maladies
description: This week: Charles McGrath on Siddhartha Mukherjees biography of cancer, The Emperor of All Maladies; Pamela Paul on two new books about mean girls and mean moms; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: The Luke Walton Rule
description: In the last round of collective bargaining negotiations in 2005, a novel clause was included in the final agreement that came to be known as the Amnesty Clause. It allowed N.B.A. teams to designate one of the outstanding contracts on their payroll as being exempt from the end-of-season luxury tax calculations. For example, if a team had a payroll of $256 billion dollars against a luxury tax threshold of $40 billion, and one of their players was earning $220 billion alone, using the amnesty clause on that player would then put that team under the luxury tax threshold (as their payroll for luxury tax purposes was now considered to be only $36 billion). The player still got his money, and the teams got the reprieve  everyone, indeed, was a winner.

title: Blocking, Tackling and Studying Diseases
description: STANFORD, Calif.  Owen Marecic is known for bone-crushing tackles and bleeding the clock, so it was strange to hear him talk about becoming woozy while watching knee replacement surgery as part of a summer internship at Stanford Hospital.

title: Two-Match Ban for Mourinho
description: Never at a loss for words, either on the touchline or cast as a cheeky puppet in a long-running satire, Real Madrid Coach JosMourinho drew a two-match ban from the Spanish federation on Friday. Mourinho was sent off last Wednesday in Madrids 5-1 win over Murcia in Spains Copa del Rey after insulting Referee Jose Luis Paradas Romero.

title: Celines Eye Candy
description: Heres a twist for the holidays: your favorite new Celine accessories are wrapped up like candy. Leopard print flats ($690 at Barneys New York) remind us of Tootsie Rolls, while the yellow sandals ($595 at The Webster, Miami) are as sweet  and tart  as lemon drops.

title: Week in Pictures, Nov. 12
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

title: The Mirage of Lower Trade Imbalances
description: WHEN the going gets tough, governments complain about trade.

title: Tell Us About Your Worst New York Apartment
description: Nic LaFrance, a 20-year-old aspiring model and actor who moved to New York last summer, spent his first months in the city living with two men and a woman in a studio they sublet above an upholstery store in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The space, small to begin with, was so jampacked with furniture, the roommates barely had space to move around.

title: In Losing a Mentor, Young Becomes One
description: Nashville

title: Two Pediatrician Moms Offer Baby Advice
description: New parents often turn to their pediatrician for basic advice about caring for a newborn. But outside the doctors office, they often seek advice from books or other parents.

title: A New Home for the Louwman Museum in the Hague
description: The Louwman Museum in the Hague, the national automobile museum of the Netherlands, recently opened a new home thats in a parklike area of the city, amid villas and next door to the royal palace.

title: The Estate Tax and the Laffer Curve
description: Richard H. Thaler is a professor of economics and behavioral science at the Booth School of Business at the University of Chicago.

title: Weekend Fare
description: The annual Chocolate Show with exhibits, tastings, cooking demonstrations and chocolates for sale will be held throughout the weekend, 10 a.m. to 7 p.m. Saturday and from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. on Sunday at the Metropolitan Pavilion, 125 West 18th Street. Tickets are available at $28 for those over 12 from chocolateshow.com, $30 at the door. Each adult can bring two children 5 to 12 free; additional children are $8 each.

title: A Screenwriters Hogwarts Decade
description: LONDON

title: Support Grows for Expansion of Ozone Treaty
description: This week I reported on a push by a number of nations to expand the scope of the Montreal Protocol, the treaty designed to deal with the degradation of the Earths ozone layer, to begin to address global warming. Several countries, including the island nation of Micronesia, joined by the United States, Mexico and Canada, are proposing to phase out a family of industrial chemicals known as hydrofluorocarbons, or HFCs, which have a minimal effect on the ozone layer but are highly potent greenhouse gases.

title: New Director of Fannie-Freddie Oversight
description: President Obama on Friday nominated Joseph A. Smith Jr., the banking commissioner in North Carolina, to head the agency that oversees the mortgage lending giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

title: Sex-Tip App?  New Schools Chief Promotes It
description: When he announced that Cathleen P. Black, the chairwoman of Hearst Magazines, would become the next chancellor of New York Citys schools, Mayor Michael Bloomberg touted Ms. Black as uniquely qualified for the role.

title: The Lunch Box: Clearing Out Leftovers
description: Samantha Storey is trying to make her packed lunches less boring, one box at a time.

title: Peripheral Vision
description: One recent, drizzly Sunday, I met the artist Vik Muniz at his Ipanema home to drive from Zona Sul, the beachy, bathing-suited Rio of Copacabana lore, to the less renowned poorer part of the city in the north. As we whizzed up Avenida Brasil through an area called Mare, Muniz indicated a cluster of favelas arrayed around a public pool called Piscino de Ramos and quipped, You have to think of Rio as St. Tropez  surrounded by Mogadishu.

title: Media Decoder
description: Sarah Palin's reality TV show keeps the potential Presidential candidate in the public eye.

title: High Praise for Stanfords Marecic
description: STANFORD, Calif.  Outside the locker room, Owen Marecic was being interviewed last Saturday when Jim Harbaugh, the Stanford coach, sidled up to him.

title: The Fantasy of the N.H.L. All-Star Fantasy Draft
description: The N.H.L. announced a bold new format for the all-star selection process this week. Under the new plan, a pair of captains will draft the teams during a televised event in what the league is calling a fantasy draft.

title: How Many Bums Did the American People Throw Out?
description: Much has been written about the American peoples decision to throw the bums out in the recent midterm election.

title: Molly Meltzer and Derek Evans
description: IN the fractured world of American politics, Hollywood is still seen as a solidly liberal haven. But take a closer look and you can find a divide between those in the entertainment industry whose gobs of money support social causes and those called upon to selflessly deliver on the promises.

title: An Indian-Spiced Thanksgiving
description: For years, fans of cookbook author Madhur Jaffrey have complained to her that Indian cooking seems too complicated. As a result, Ms. Jaffrey decided to create a cookbook filled with some of the most simple Indian dishes she could find or create.

title: Its After Midnight? Lets Get This Party Started
description: IT used to be that when the band went home, the guests were right behind them, but at Linda Moschellos wedding next June, the real party is not expected to start until after the reception. Around midnight, her guests at the Palace at Somerset Park in Somerset, N.J., are to be ushered into a pseudo nightclub in the halls west ballroom, complete with lounge furniture, colored lights and walls hung with white fabric. The finishing touch: servers passing out tequila shots.

title: Mortgage Preapproval Is Harder to Get
description: FOR some people, an important first step in buying a house is getting a mortgage preapproval.

title: The Caucus: 2012 Fund-Raising
description: A few of those perceived to be contenders for the 2012 presidential race have already started the money race.

title: 60s Hollywood: Power Shifted (or Did It?)
description: THE story of what is often called New Hollywood, the era of the easy riders, raging bulls, to borrow the title of Peter Biskinds 1998 best seller, has been told numerous times. It goes something like this: By the early 1960s the old studio system was in shambles, run by old men who, out of touch with the times-they-are-a-changin, were churning out pricey duds like Cleopatra to shrinking, indifferent audiences.

title: Bite-Size Indies in Competition on Your Couch
description: THE Times Square throng was thinning on a recent, about-to-be-rainy Sunday evening when the JumboTron outside the W Hotel sparked to life. Film Festival in a Box, it announced. And then the movies, short films with titles like Laundry and Petes Beach and actors the crowd had never heard of, started. The effect was immediate: Tourists actually lowered their cameras. Theatergoers stopped checking prices at the TKTS booth. The lost looked up from their street maps. They watched. They tried to listen. They madly dialed the 800 number they were told would provide audio. Failing that, they even talked to one another.

title: Glenn Beck Sees George Soros as Iran Does
description: As my colleague Brian Stelter reports, the Fox News host Glenn Beck was accused this week of deploying a symphony of anti-Semitic dog whistles in his lengthy attack on the political activities of George Soros, a billionaire investor and philanthropist Mr. Beck repeatedly described as a puppet master who collapses regimes.

title: In Park Slope, a Little Breathing Room
description: AS newlyweds, Brian and Bridget Applegate spent two years squeezed into a small one-bedroom on the Upper East Side.

title: App Smart Extra: The Best Free Apps for the iPhone
description: This weeks App Smart column runs down the top 10 iPhone apps, for those with too little time to sift through the iTunes store.

title: Reviewing the 2011 Audi A8
description: Writing in Sundays Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the 2011 Audi A8. Mr. Ulrich found the exterior styling to be surprisingly staid:

title: Glad Bags
description: We told children to think about how pictures tell a story like in fairy tales, says the Marni designer Consuelo Castiglioni about the latest chapter in her ongoing project to help underprivileged children. We hoped to stimulate their creativity and make something that could be sold with the proceeds going back to bettering their hospitals and schools. The three resulting tote bags feature vintage Marni prints on one side and drawings by children from East Asia and South America on the other. Eighty percent of the proceeds will go to childrens developmental programs geared toward learning and creativity. It seemed like the natural thing to do around the holidays, adds Castiglioni. To celebrate the innocence of a childs imagination.

title: Cracks Emerge in Wall St.s Unity
description: When politicians and the populace assailed Wall Street during the financial crisis, its top executives kept up a united front, characterized mostly by stoic silence balanced by big and quiet political donations.

title: Greater Choice Doesnt Make You Happy
description: The more options you have, the less happy you are, at least if youre a heavy TV watcher. From the abstract to a new working paper:

title: Pregame Huddle: Cam Newton and the SEC
description: Can Auburn stay undefeated despite the off-field distractions of its star quarterback Cam Newton?

title: The Final Skate
description: The horn will sound today signaling the end of my postings on The Timess Slap Shot blog, but before going into that, heres our final skate through the N.H.L.:

title: Lesson Plan From a Departing Schools Chief
description: This isnt rocket science, Joel I. Klein was saying, too modestly.

title: H.I.V. Discrimination Law Fails in Chinese Court
description: BEIJING  In a rare, public test of the nations law prohibiting discrimination against people with H.I.V., a Chinese court on Friday ruled against a man who said he was wrongly denied a teaching job after his prospective employer learned he had the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Police Seeking Two Sexual Assault Suspects
description: Two sexual assault suspects are being sought in separate cases in Manhattan, the police said.

title: The First Cog in the Star Machine
description: FOR Charles Spencer Chaplin, 1914 was a very good year. In January he was a minor British vaudeville star who had just signed a contract to appear in a series of comedies produced by the Keystone Film Company.

title: Planning for Income and Estate Taxes in an Uncertain Time
description: CONGRESS is coming back next week, but no one is hazarding a guess as to how lawmakers will handle the issue of estate and income taxes.

title: Straining to Make Midmarket Deals
description: With names like Chevron, Sara Lee and Amazon dominating the deal pipeline, there is plenty of evidence to suggest that the mergers and acquisitions recovery is well under way. But while that may be the case for the countrys largest corporations, midsize businesses are still straining to get deals done, according to Dave Maney, a co-founder of Headwaters Merchant Bank, a midmarket investment bank.

title: Finishing the Hat
description: To the Editor:

title: Eroticized Landscapes
description: To the Editor:

title: Creative Liberal Tension
description: To the Editor:

title: Ak-47s Incalculable Cost
description: To the Editor:

title: Officer, Scholar, Senator
description: To the Editor:

title: Hollywoods Vanishing Have-Nots
description: NIGEL COLE, the British director of 2003s Calendar Girls, was only half joking when he said, In England we only make films about the working class or the aristocracy.

title: Living In | Hunts Point-Longwood, the Bronx
description: Reconstruction has accelerated as the city has sought to restore population by shifting to subsidizing income-restricted rental apartment buildings.

title: A Parallel Universe to TV and Movies
description: HAS any art form  or entertainment category or visual medium or whatever you want to call it  grown so large so fast as the online serial, while remaining so consistently outside the mainstream cultural conversation? Quick, name a Web series. Well wait.

title: Therapy? Not His Cup of Tea
description: IN a season that trumpeted the return of Debra Winger, it is the Indian actor Irrfan Khan who has generated some of the loudest buzz on HBOs In Treatment. Mr. Khan, familiar in this country from the movies The Namesake and Slumdog Millionaire, and something of an idol in his own, has applied his soulful gaze and talent for nuance to the role of Sunil, a Bengali widower in his mid-50s who reluctantly enters therapy after being transplanted from Calcutta to Brooklyn to live with his son and American daughter-in-law.

title: A Bollywood Star on the Couch
description: Irrfan Khan, whose name is typically preceded by the great Indian actor, arrived at The New York Times recently with the aplomb of a rock star. A mini-entourage of handler and groomer trailed Mr. Khan, best known in this country for The Namesake, Slumdog Millionaire and A Mighty Heart, while his driver waited outside. During an interview in the cafeteria, fans broke in to pay their respects. As he waited by the elevator bank, women shyly asked to have their pictures taken with him. Mr. Khan politely granted the requests.

title: Some Early Returns on Early Admission
description: With some colleges permitting students to wait until Nov. 15 to file their early applications, it is too soon in this early-admission season to draw broad conclusions on whether such programs continue to grow in popularity over all.

title: Giants Steve Smith to Miss Cowboys Game
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants potent offense will be without one of its most dangerous weapons Sunday, and possibly longer.

title: Miriam Haskell, Old Kid on the Block
description: Why would anyone pay $80,000 on old bijoux made from glass beads, wire, imitation pearls and gilt-metal filigree? Thats the price the collector Susan Kelner Freeman paid in the 1980s for a rare collection of vintage Miriam Haskell jewelry, which by then was seriously dclass.

title: Number of Uninsured Rises, Report Says
description: The number of uninsured adults in the United States continues to rise, with one in four adults under 65 reporting they were without health insurance at some point in the last year, according to a recent report from the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Video: Cam Newton and the SEC
description: Can Auburn stay undefeated despite the off-field distractions of its star quarterback Cam Newton? And can Florida fend off South Carolina to win the SEC East title? Connor Ennis and Paul Myerberg discuss on this weeks edition of the Pregame Huddle.

title: Issa to Push for Postal Service Changes
description: Rep. Darrell Issa, Republican of California, who is set to become chairman of the Oversight and Government Reform Committee in the next Congress, said on Friday that he would push for major changes at the Postal Service, which has announced an $8.5 billion annual loss.

title: A Slow Renaissance for a Struggling Neighborhood
description: FOR those who neither live nor work in the South Bronx, its most enduring images are of buildings aflame in the 1970s and the crime-infested, rubble-strewn streetscape of the 1980s, when the areas infamous 41st Precinct was popularized in a Hollywood movie as Fort Apache, the Bronx.

title: Study Ties Ovarian Cancer and Hormone Therapy
description: More bad news about postmenopausal hormone therapy: a new European study reports that women who take the hormones are at significantly increased risk for ovarian cancer, which is rare but often fatal.

title: Cindy McCain Breaks with  Her Husband in Gay Rights Video
description: Speaking in a video for an ad campaign aimed at ending the bullying toward gay teenagers, Cindy McCain, the wife of Senator John McCain of Arizona, sounds like shes talking about her husband when she faces the camera and says: Our political and religious leaders tell LGBT youth that they have no future.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: The Nutcracker, Josh Groban, Harry Potter and More
description: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

title: Steinbrenner Wrote Himself Into Amherst-Williams Rivalry
description: The Williams College and Amherst College football teams will meet for the 125th time on Saturday. Their long and storied rivalry has had its requisite share of instigators, perhaps none more unlikely than the sportswriter who stoked the coals 59 years ago. Of course, that writer, George Steinbrenner, ultimately went on to bigger and better things.

title: Amherst-Williams Endures, but Coolidge Jabs Dont
description: It is impossible to find tickets for the most anticipated football game in New England this weekend. They do not exist.

title: David J. Wine
description: Mr. Wine, 52, is the managing partner of Olivers Realty Group, a development, investment and brokerage company that he started in September, after 32 years at the Related Companies. Mr. Wine was Relateds vice chairman, and some of his most notable projects there included the Time Warner Center residences and the Superior Ink condominiums and town houses in the West Village.

title: Q & A
description: A Leaky Roof Awaiting Attention

title: Tax Planning When the Rules Are Uncertain
description: Paul Sullivans Wealth Matters column this week offers a few suggestions on year-end financial planning, even when its impossible to know what Congress will  or wont  do about income and estate taxes in their lame-duck session that begins next week.

title: Heidi Keeps Her Word
description: Last month, when Gretchen Jones was named the winner of Project Runway over Mondo Guerra, the decision was unpopular not only with a lot of the shows viewers, but seemingly with Heidi Klum, the shows co-host, as well.

title: Demand Grows for Over-55 Rentals
description: IT used to be your home was your castle, said Lisa Kelly, who manages several rental complexes for people 55 and over. Nowadays nobody wants a castle, or a mortgage  especially if you are older.

title: Westchester Homes in Winners Circle
description: FOUR residences in Westchester County  two multifamily and two single-family homes  are among 13 winners of the 2010 Design Awards given every year for the past 20 by the 600-member Westchester-Hudson Valley chapter of the American Institute of Architects.

title: Nominee to Oversee Fannie and Freddie Is Named
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will nominate North Carolinas chief banking regulator to run the federal agency that regulates and controls the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the White House announced Friday.

title: Theater Groups Team Up to Help Playwrights Develop Works
description: Clubbed Thumb, a New York theater company that commissions and develops new plays, and Off Broadways Playwrights Horizons are collaborating on a series of weeklong lab workshops to help American writers hone their new projects for the stage  one attempt at the kind of support systems that playwrights have been pleading for.

title: What Were Reading: Calorie Receipts
Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Haiti and Pakistan.

title: Habitats | Sullivan Street
description: Deborah Clearman, an artist and writer, lives in a five-story walk-up in West SoHo.

title: A Writers Start-Over Home
description: IF ever a building could be said to have a defining characteristic, its the small co-op on Sullivan Street in West SoHo wreathed by a fat wisteria vine.

title: Militant Gets Life Sentence in Lebanon
description: CAIRO  A Lebanese military court on Friday sentenced 24 people, including Omar Bakri Mohammed, the Syrian-born militant who was barred from Britain in 2005, to life in prison for belonging to a terrorist group and inciting violence.

title: Just Dont Call It A Gala
description: For his first MoCA Gala, Jeffrey Deitch, the museums newly installed director, will not be serving up rubber chickens to a crowd of women in ball gowns and men in monkey suits. Instead, he gave full creative license to the Los Angeles artist Doug Aitken, who promises to hijack the polite (read: dull) concept of a museum benefit dinner and turn it into a real happening. Here, Aitken dishes up a sneak peek of the event which takes place Saturday, November 13.

title: Northern Lights to Be Heard, Not Seen
description: Into each concertgoers life a little uncertainty must fall. For a presenter the key challenge is not simply to offer the unfamiliar, but also to provide a context in which an audience can approach and appreciate it. The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center demonstrated the right way to do it on Tuesday night at Alice Tully Hall.

title: A Verdict on Controlled Oil Burns and Cancer Risk
description: Fumes from oil burned by spill-response teams in the Gulf of Mexico did not contain enough cancer-causing chemicals to pose a risk to human health, two new studies from the Environmental Protection Agency conclude.

title: New Terrain for Barefoot Riverdancer
description: Some performers are forever associated with one production, so that you never expect to see them in any other context or even on the street. When the Irish step-dancing phenomenon Riverdance first traveled the world in the 1990s, its female lead was the redhead Jean Butler.

title: The Importance of the Milton Robson Car Collection Auction
description: With the economy showing some signs of a pulse, blue-chip prewar classic cars and European sports cars have shown some renewed vitality in the market. At the Monterey auctions in August, $172 million worth of collector cars exchanged hands. In the upper end of the market there is a great deal of liquidity, Robert Ames, a commercial real estate investor and car collector in Portland, Ore., said at the time.

title: Ground Time for the Flockless Bird
description: Pavel Zustiaks latest dance begins, as many seem to these days, with slightly sinister underpinnings: there is a darkened, empty stage and an ominous grumble of an electronic score. But his opening creates some spooky distance for a reason. Mr. Zustiaks new piece, Bastard, the first part of a trilogy, The Painted Bird, is loosely inspired by Jerzy Kosinskis novel of that title about a boy making his way through Europe during World War II.

title: A Language of Their Own, Tinged With Funk
description: Henry Threadgill played a long new work on Thursday at Roulette for the first of his three nights there. It was called In Frontispiece, written for his semi-jazz band Zooid with the Flux String Quartet, and it was messy on the ears.

title: Daisy Khan, an Eloquent Face of Islam
description: DAISY KHAN had never seen so many Jews in her life. The year was 1974, and Ms. Khan, an awkward, artistic 16-year-old who had just emigrated from India to the suburban Long Island enclave of Jericho, N.Y., was attending her first day of school in America.

title: Watchlist: A New Look at Web Video
description: Beginning this Sunday in Arts & Leisure, a new column called Watchlist will sample the vast and largely uncharted world of Web video  not dancing Filipino prisoners or Baby Bob Marley, but the thousands of online serials, Webisodes, cartoons, talk shows, newsmagazines, reality shows and other formats that have sprung up over the last decade as a quick-and-cheap parallel world to television and film. The first column looks at current works like the serials Riese on Syfy.com and Kids Reenact at Babelgum.com, Larry Fessendens audio-drama project Tales From Beyond the Pale and the latest episode of Lisa Kudrows Web Therapy.

title: Look of the Moment | V.B.s Tangerine Dream
description: The Look: A dress that gives new meaning to the words juicy couture.

title: A Soldiers Torment in Vietnam and at Home
description: How is this for a story with operatic potential? A prisoner of war held for nearly a decade returns home to find that his wife has moved on, his nation has changed beyond recognition, and he is unable to find his bearings in the society he fought to defend. It is Monteverdis Ritorno dUlisse in Patria in reverse: the story of the returning warrior, but in this thoroughly modern version, everything has gone wrong, and redemption is out of reach.

title: Ban on Gays in the Military Stays in Effect
description: The militarys dont ask, dont tell policy restricting openly gay, lesbian and bisexual people from serving will remain in force while a legal challenge is considered by a federal appeals court, the United States Supreme Court declared Friday.

title: Qing Dynasty Relic Yields Record Price at Auction
description: LONDON  As treasure-in-the-attic stories go, the 18th-century Chinese vase sold at a suburban auction house in outer London on Thursday night will be hard to beat.

title: Dostoyevskys Sick Man Hits YouTube
description: Guess whos getting ready for his YouTube close-up?

title: A Guide to the Cosmos, in Words and Images Dazzling and True
description: In his new book "Far Out, A Space-Time Chronicle," photographer and journalist Michael Benson has reprocessed images from the Hubble Space Telescope and other telescopes to take readers on a lush tour of some of time's creations.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Haiti and Pakistan.

title: Here Comes Rhymin Simon, on a Different Label
description: Coming pretty soon to a record store near you (if you are lucky enough to have a record store near you): a whole bunch of deluxe reissues of Paul Simon albums, with a different record company logo on them.

title: Gaines, Livingston and the Defining Power of YouTube
description: In basketball, sometimes the stories write themselves.

title: Nightly Business Report Cuts Jobs
description: Nightly Business Report,  the business newscast on PBS, laid off eight people on Friday, or about 20 percent of the staff, in the first major change since it was acquired in August by a new company, NBR Worldwide.

title: Six House Races Remain in Limbo
description: Representative Ben Chandler has been declared the winner  again  of his close House race in Kentucky. But six other House races remained in limbo Friday, meaning some incumbent Democrats will be on hand for the lame-duck session next week unsure about whether they will return in January for the 112th Congress. And some potential Republican freshmen will arrive for orientation uncertain about whether they will ultimately serve in Congress next year.

title: Finding a Bed Among Central Parks Trees
description: There is no shortage of places in Manhattan where visitors can spend the night. Luxury hotels offer lavish suites that can run thousands of dollars, and youth hostels have beds for as little as $20. At least one flophouse survives on the Bowery. And, of course, there is couch-surfing  countless travelers bunk with old friends or near-strangers for little more than an owed favor.

title: Antiques Books
description: Antiques trade promoters are running ads lately headlined Every Collector Add a Collector. Enthusiasms can spread, in other words, if sellers and buyers talk up their obsessions. In that spirit of sharing, this seasons most entertaining books about antiques reveal how owners have learned about the sweep of history by buying one type of useful or decadent object.

title: Coffee Table Books
description: One of the best things about Antonia Frasers new memoir, Must You Go? My Life With Harold Pinter, is watching this warm and literate couple trade books, and sometimes perform readings, on birthdays and holidays. When it came to celebrations, printed words were never far from their minds.

title: Sleeping in Trees
description: Cory and Dana Foht, twins from Florida, have spent some 20 nights over the past two months 25 feet up the side of a tall American elm tree in Central Park.

title: Twitters Biz Stone Talks About Growth and Local Ads
description: Biz Stone, a co-founder of Twitter, and Sean Garrett, the companys director of communications, visited The Times this week to talk about the current state of Twitter and plans for the company over the next few years.

title: For Dinner Tonight: Los Angeles
description: Its pretty clear that most of the thought, time and money spent on Skyline went into the fabrication of the alien creatures who descend on Los Angeles and start feeding on humans at a pace reminiscent of the afternoon rush at In-N-Out Burger. These extraterrestrial locavores  they consume their food right where its harvested  are a cross between the Alien and Audrey the man-eating plant in Little Shop of Horrors, except that they come in sizes ranging from large car to small building.

title: Smart Meters Draw Complaints of Inaccuracy
description: NOLANVILLE, Tex.  Sgt. John Robertson 2nd, an Army mechanic at nearby Fort Hood, is fuming about the so-called smart electric meter his local utility has installed on the side of his tidy, 1,800-square-foot home.

title: Book Review Podcast: The Emperor of All Maladies
description: This week: Charles McGrath on Siddhartha Mukherjees biography of cancer, The Emperor of All Maladies; Pamela Paul on two new books about mean girls and mean moms; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: Book Review Podcast: The Emperor of All Maladies
description: This week: Charles McGrath on Siddhartha Mukherjees biography of cancer, The Emperor of All Maladies; Pamela Paul on two new books about mean girls and mean moms; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Book Review Podcast: The Emperor of All Maladies
description: This week: Charles McGrath on Siddhartha Mukherjees biography of cancer, The Emperor of All Maladies; Pamela Paul on two new books about mean girls and mean moms; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: A Painstaking Devotion to Preserving Lancias
description: Berkeley, Calif.

title: Art Books
description: Digital may be destiny, but when it comes to holiday gifts a printed book in hand is still worth a thousand e-books bobbling around in the ether. Why? The luxe factor.

title: In Match Between Computers, a Costly Blind Eye to the Odds
description: The 14th World Computer-Bridge Championship was held last month in Philadelphia.
