Seven programs from six countries, including Bridge Baron and Moose Bridge from the United States, played a preliminary round robin. This was followed by semifinals, from which the two most successful programs over the last decade reached the final, Jack from the Netherlands and WBridge5 from France.

title: Group Says Camel Packs Lure the Young
description: R.J. Reynolds is introducing special-edition packs of Camel cigarettes that play off the images of cities that have a hip image  drawing fire from antismoking groups who say they are marketing to youth.

title: Graphic Books
description: Its been another exciting year for graphic books. It began in January, when Yen Press announced it would print 350,000 copies of its adaptation of the novel Twilight by Stephenie Meyer. Readers later witnessed the struggles of a Jewish rug maker in Market Day, by James Sturm. They were treated to Dash Shaws stylized Bodyworld. And they met the misanthrope known as Wilson in the latest from Daniel Clowes. The year closes with a mix of social issues, superheroes, slackers and Shakespeare.

title: Replacement Parts, Built From Scratch
description: Much of the work requires an eye for detail.

title: Anheuser-Busch Files Suit Against M.L.B.
description: Budweisers decades-long connection to Major League Baseball frayed Friday when the giant brewers parent company, Anheuser-Busch, alleged in a federal lawsuit that baseball reneged on an agreement reached earlier this year to extend the beer makers sponsorship.

title: Mentalist Lifts CBS
description: The Big Bang Theory and The Mentalist topped the ratings on Thursday as CBS racked up another No. 1 night. According to Nielsens estimates, The Mentalist delivered the evenings largest audience with 13.8 million viewers. Greys Anatomy (11.1 million) and Private Practice (8.3 million) helped ABC finish second on the night while Fox eked out a third-place finish with Bones (9.1 million) and Fringe (4.8 million). NBC was fourth, attracting its most viewers with The Office (7.7 million).

title: New Details on Full-body X-Ray Scanners
description: How safe are those full body scanners being used at airports?

title: Suddenly the Cold War Is a Cool Event
description: I never play games twice. But Call of Duty: Black Ops has made a very happy liar out of me.

title: Reuniting (if With Issues) and Why It Feels So Good
description: Television has been broadly feminized for so long now  from the catfight agendas of the reality universe to the womens-magazine sensibility of the morning news shows  that any network marketed specifically to women has had to find new ways to patronize its audience.

title: White Light Festival
description: Violinist Gidon Kremer with Kremerata Baltica in the New York premiere of "Silent Prayer" on Thursday, part of the White Light Festival.

title: Mixing Spirituality With a Bit of Fun
description: The overarching, some might say overreaching, theme of the White Light Festival at Lincoln Center is to explore music as an expression of spirituality. As the festival continues, the participating artists keep coming up with intriguing choices of musical works that invite listeners to look inward, including two programs on Thursday night.

title: Proposal Recommends Charging Admission at the Smithsonian
description: In New York, a visit to the Museum of Modern Art will set you back $20, but down in Washington, the Smithsonian Institution, which is 70 percent federally funded, has long been free. That would change under a proposal by the national commission charged with reducing the deficit. In a draft report Wednesday, it recommended that the Smithsonians federal appropriation be cut by $225 million, or roughly 30 percent, and that the institution make up the loss by charging a $7.50 admission fee.

title: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 12
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a terror trial; small businesses in Astoria, Queens, and Mount Morris, N.Y.; and Veterans Day.

title: The Cerebral Set Picks Up a Paddle
description: Under most circumstances a celebrated young novelist and a well-known bookseller would be close allies. But for a few minutes on Wednesday night, Jonathan Safran Foer, the author of Everything Is Illuminated and Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close, and Nancy Bass Wyden, the proprietor of the Strand bookstore, were heated rivals as they faced off across a Ping-Pong table in the David Rubenstein Atrium at Lincoln Center.

title: A Brewery, Behind the Scenes
description: Some food- and beverage-producing plants discourage visits by the public; others grudgingly tolerate them. Then there is Cottrell Brewing Company in Pawcatuck, which is so welcoming that the bottom of its six-pack holders depict a roadmap with directions to the brewery. Tours are available, the text reads. Please call for details.

title: A Bustling Scene With Classic Italian Fare
description: DARIENS culinary landscape has been changing lately  for the better. And the convivial  Scena Wine Bar & Restaurant, a creation of the Siguenza brothers, Vicente and Kleber, who also own Cava in New Canaan and 55 Degrees in Fairfield, fits right into the general upswing.

title: Young, Gifted and Outrageous: Can Odd Future Survive Popularity?
description: When Tyler, the Creator speaks, should you listen?

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 12
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Butternut Squash Salad
description: Mark Bittman makes a simple yet scrumptious raw vegetable salad.

title: A Movable Feast, Popping Up Anywhere
description: LAMBERTVILLE, N.J.

title: iPad Apps That Provide Recipes and Avoid Strife
description: Anyone who has prepared a Thanksgiving family dinner knows that the emotional minefield is laid long before the turkey goes in the oven. I speak of the annual quandary over whose recipe to use. Is it going to be Moms pumpkin pie or your mother-in-laws? Either way, you risk offending half the family.

title: Nonprofit Funds Grant Process Is Audited for Possible Conflicts
description: The inspector general with oversight of the federal governments Corporation for National and Community Service is looking into the grant process of its Social Innovation Fund, a $50 million program meant to expand promising nonprofits.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 12
description: More Photographs

title: Court Ruling Limits Scope of State Law on Terror
description: After Robert T. Johnson, the Bronx district attorney, successfully used New York States antiterrorism law to prosecute a gang member who had killed a 10-year-old girl in a gun battle, he said the verdict was significant in determining an appropriate punishment for someone who had snuffed out the life of an innocent child.

title: Brussels Sprouts Aplenty
description: Perhaps brussels sprouts, which are now in season, are better seen than eaten. With high-end florists reaching for fruits and vegetables (Lady apples with chrysanthemums! Artichokes with roses!), stalks of brussels sprouts are enjoying a kind of decorative vogue, and millions of grateful children are relieved to see them anywhere but on their plates.

title: Where the Ambience Is Adjustable
description: THE first time my family and I entered Somers 202 Restaurant & Grill, it was through the bar  a boisterous, fun room with six flat-screen televisions tuned to sports and plenty of folks enjoying the restaurants full menu as well as its drinks. We went on to the dining room, and I kept the vibe up by ordering a delicious aa martini from the specialty martini list (which manages to surprise with unusual choices like Pom and lemon basil). We continued the casual mood with two appetizers  three flavorful little sliders on sweet buns and spicy chicken wings  and a crispy brick-oven pizza with succulent shrimp.

title: Raw Butternut Squash Salad With Raisins and Ginger
description: 1 butternut squash (about 1 1/2 pounds), peeled, seeded and grated

title: Vegetables for Thanksgiving, Served Natural and Raw
description: ALTHOUGH Im not suggesting you bite into a raw hunk of butternut squash or gnaw on a head of cabbage (though the latter can actually be pleasant), theres great pleasure to be found in feasting on autumn vegetables served raw, with a minimum of preparation. With a little shredding, grating, chopping, slicing or mincing, the tough, sometimes starchy character of late fall vegetables yields, allowing their robust flavors to take center stage.

title: A High-Water Mark for Profits
description: The work force may still be struggling, but corporate profits appear to be heading toward a record (nominal) high, according to a new analysis from Deutsche Banks economics research team.

title: A Deficit of Respect
description: Heres this weeks Beltway Best-Seller:  Read it while its hot.

title: Drought in the Amazon, Up Close and Personal
description: Thursday, Nov. 11

title: Judge Considers Case of Mel Gibsons Leaky Court File
description: LOS ANGELES  At a hastily called session here on Friday, a family court judge was briefed by lawyers in the Mel Gibson paternity case about what appeared to be information leaked from a confidential court file to the Web site TMZ.com.

title: Zest, Heat and Aroma, by the Jar, Pouch or Bin
description: HUNTINGTON STATION, N.Y.

title: Using Root Vegetables Raw
description: The end of warm weather doesnt mean the end of fresh, local, even raw vegetables. Check out this weeks Minimalist column and see how to use fall vegetables like beets, Brussels sprouts and butternut squash in simple, raw dishes. You might even want them on your table at Thanksgiving.

title: With Words on Muslims, Opening a Door Long Shut
description: BERLIN

title: An Affordable Lunch on a Day of Culture
description: This spinoff of Marc Murphys Landmarc bistro in TriBeCa opened in 2007 and offers one of the few reasonably priced dining options at the Time Warner Center, home to some of the citys most expensive restaurants. Furnished in sleek dark wood and glass, the room overlooks the foot of Central Park and attracts a lively crowd of tourists, shoppers, Lincoln Center patrons and media insiders with its French- and Italian-inspired menu. On Wednesday, the diners included two friends in town for one of their regular cultural excursions.

title: From Pornography to Real Estate Mogul
description: I HAVE never made a deal in the rain, said Fredrik Eklund, standing in bright sunlight in a $2.8 million apartment on the Bowery that offered 360-degree views of seemingly every landmark in New York City. People need to see a place in good weather to appreciate it.

title: To Greenmarket, to Greenmarket
description: Leonard Lopate is the host of a radio talk show,  covering subjects like crafting and quantum physics,  that is broadcast every weekday from noon to 2 p.m. on WNYC. Mr. Lopate, 70, spends Sundays with his girlfriend, Melanie Baker, an artist with whom he lives in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. That is the day that they usually restock the pantry with a visit to the local greenmarket and split the chores  and share the crossword puzzle. SARAH MASLIN NIR

title: Flu Shots: No Panic, Just No
description: Was it only last year that flu shots were the latest have-to-have-one, dont-know-where-to-get-one obscure object of consumer desire? With fears of an H1N1 pandemic on the horizon, the city even busted out the PODs  points of distribution designed to be activated during public health crises like bioterrorism or nuclear fallout.

title: Hard Times in Camden
description: The South Jersey city of Camden has long been a national symbol of urban blight.

title: In Camden, New Troubles on Top of Old
description: CAMDEN, N.J.  This city closed its dilapidated central library in the 1980s and never provided the money for restoration or demolition. So the landmark building rots on its weed-choked lot, with most of the roof caved in and a large tree growing up through its middle. It could be a metaphor for the city, said Jerome Szpila, the city library director.

title: 101 Quick and Simple Dishes for Fall
description: The filmmaker Gary Leib's animated recommendations for the best meals to make at home this season.

title: Dropping the Balls
description: THE cast of the Big Apple Circus burst into the tent for the shows opening number, clad in confetti-bright colors. The big bands trumpets shrilled, and the performers separated by gender into Sharks- and Jets-style packs, snapping and dancing.

title: Kanye West Was Coached for Today Interview Gone Awry
description: Kanye West can usually be counted on to say whats on his mind, but the rapper had some extra help formulating those thoughts when he was interviewed on NBCs Today show this week: he hired the public relations firm Rubenstein Communications to coach him on his response to former President George W. Bush, and the firm and the rapper are no longer working together following Mr. Wests feud with Today, according to several people familiar with the arrangements of the interview.

title: Queso Fundido With Chorizo, Jalapeo and Cilantro
description: Time: 25 minutes

title: A Dip to Sustain the Cook Till Thanksgiving Dinner
description: FOR the cook, Thanksgiving Day lunch is usually had standing over the stove  maybe a handful of chips, a few crackers, or marshmallows that havent been baked into casseroles or pie, a nibble on a fingernail and a few swallows (or glasses) of wine. Who has time to eat when theres a mountain of food to cook?

title: Shunning Life as a Performer, to Write the Songs
description: Old Brookville, N.Y.

title: Wallenbergs Heroism Becomes a Musical
description: Annette Jolles says that until seven years ago she knew almost nothing about Raoul Wallenberg.

title: Bored at Work? Try Creepypasta, or Web Scares
description: THERE is a video gaining steam on YouTube called The Scariest Picture on the Internet (REAL). Aside from a short introduction, the bulk consists of a single, still image of a painting set to ominous music.

title: The Perils of Psychoanalyzing Mugabe
description: Imagine a modern-day Macbeth, haunted by the ghost of Banquo, attempting to sort out his blood-stained fears with the help of a therapist.

title: The Pinks and Purples of an Exotic Eden
description: In the 18th century, artists went to Rome. Or, if they could afford it, on a whole Grand Tour of Europe. By the 19th century, art travel had gone global: the French painter Eugne Delacroix went to North Africa, the Americans Frederic Church and Winslow Homer to South America and the Caribbean. And John La Farge, a New Yorker who grew up in a French-speaking family, headed for the South Pacific, spending nearly a year there before Gauguin had even arrived.

title: Playing Favorites, Day and Night
description: PAZ DE LA HUERTA, 26  an actress (most recently in Boardwalk Empire on HBO); a SoHo native; a model and a muse to Zac Posen, the designer and a fellow St. Anns alumnus  recently shared a week of wardrobe changes with Chloe Malle, who conducted and condensed this interview.

title: To Dad, Life Is a Game, a Really Ugly One
description: The teenagers-dad character in Howard Meyers Welcome: This Is a Neighborhood Watch Community has a name, Harris Campbell, but I like to think of him simply as Hedge Fund Guy. Maybe its the way his eyes light up during a telephone conversation when he says, You think we have grounds? For Hedge Fund Guy, life is just a series of opportunities to sue, cheat or generally get the better of his fellow man. As played by David Deblinger, he is effectively unlikable from Day 1.

title: This Time, Cavett Answers the Questions
description: HOW did that happen? Dick Cavett asked, sounding amused, and a bit surprised, as he contemplated the date of his upcoming appearance on Friday at the Cinema Arts Center in Huntington, N.Y.

title: A Dance Display to Remember
description: JULIA RITTER, chairwoman of the dance department at the Mason Gross School of the Arts at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, compares the schools DancePlus Fall event to a historic rock show.

title: Rebuilding Lags in Pakistan Area After Offensive
description: DRUSHKHELA, Pakistan  People here felt a surge of optimism last year when the military declared the Swat Valley cleared of Taliban insurgents, who had bullied their way to power by publicly whipping and beheading opponents.

title: Lost Generation in Swat Valley
description: The Pakistani government has yet to rebuild any of the 159 fully destroyed schools that were bombed by the Taliban. As a result, students are furious.

title: The State of Schools in Swat
description: What happens to a generation of students who miss two to three years of school because of war?

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Sunday Preview
description: In this Sundays Travel section, Seth Kugel tries to visit Los Angeles on $100 a day. Turns out the best way to do that is on two wheels, on a rented bike. The trip afforded me a more unfiltered view of Los Angeles than I would have gotten behind the wheel, he wrote, buffered from my surroundings by a windshield and a loud radio.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: The Acquisition of Tina Brown
description: The partnership of Newsweek and The Daily Beast may be billed as a simple 50-50 joint venture, but many agree that the real target for the struggling weekly magazine is Tina Brown.

title: Weekly Pick Em: Crunch Time in the SEC
description: There is plenty happening off the field in the Southeastern Conference, but on the field Saturday there is no bigger game than South Carolina at Florida. The Gamecocks, led by Steve Spurrier, will head into the Swamp against the resurgent Gators. Whichever team is victorious will be the champion of the SEC East and secure a spot in the conference championship game. On the other side of the SEC, Alabama will try to get back on the winning track when it takes on Mississippi State, which has rapidly improved under Dan Mullen. In other action, Missouri will look to remain in second place in the Big 12 North when it hosts Kansas State, Syracuse hopes to become bowl eligible when it travels to Rutgers, and Florida State and Clemson face off in a key Atlantic Coast Conference Atlantic Division game.

title: In the Remote Pacific, Glimpses of Pristine Corals
description: Thursday, Nov. 4

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to the Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Prudential Sells Stock to Raise $1 Billion
description: Prudential Financial sold stock at $54.50 a share, below Thursdays closing price, to raise about $1 billion to help pay for two units it is buying from the American International Group. Prudential sold more than 18.3 million shares, according to Bloomberg. Prudential agreed on Sept. 30 to buy AIG Star Life Insurance and AIG Edison Life Insurance, two Japanese businesses, for $4.8 billion.

title: The Ways of Empathy
description: It seems that just about everybody has had experience with babies or bullies  or both. Which is why the commentary that followed this weeks Fixes column about Roots of Empathy  an organization that decreases bullying by bringing babies into school classrooms  was so rich, personal and detailed. At the end of the column, I asked readers if they had ideas for ways to reduce bullying. Many offered suggestions about organizations, techniques and books (some of which I list at the bottom of this column), but many more readers reflected on their own experiences having witnessed bullying or the surprising effect babies can have on children and teenagers.Christine, from Montpelier, Vt., (35), recounted her experiences driving a school bus accompanied by her baby boy in a car seat behind her. When necessary, she would place unruly students  mostly in grades four through eight  near her, as well. [T]hey started to ask to sit in the front  so that they could play and read and talk to him during the ride. I observed that they softened and gentled with my son and seemed to feel safe expressing that tender side of their natures.

title: Gov. Perry to Lead Republican Governors
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, the countrys longest-serving governor, expects to be named the new chairman of the Republican Governors Association, his spokesman said Friday afternoon.

title: A Relentless Opponent Stalks the Locker Room
description: On Saturday, when Penn plays Harvard at Franklin Field, much will be the same as a year ago. A share of the Ivy League title will be at stake  Harvard (4-1 in the league) must beat Penn (5-0) to get the tie  and the teams return 26 starters combined.

title: Quad Q&A: Sienas Ryan Rossiter
description: The Siena senior Ryan Rossiter was named the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference preseason player of the year last month. When the Saints season begins Saturday against Vermont, Rossiter, a Staten Island native, will attempt to become the programs third straight postseason player of the year, following Kenny Hasbrouck and Alex Franklin. Tenacious, intelligent, hard worker was how Siena Coach Mitch Buonaguro described Rossiter at the leagues media day, adding that he was a terrific person and a wonderful player to coach.

title: Training Grounds for a Chancellor?
description: A COMMON complaint from teachers is that people believe they are experts in education just because they once went to school. Cathleen P. Black, Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs choice to head the New York City school system, has less direct experience working in education than any chancellor or superintendent in a major city in memory. But she, too, has been to school. Here is a look at three schools Ms. Black knows best:

title: Facebook to Start an E-Mail Service
description: Facebook has more than 500 million users around the world. And Americans spend more of their time online with Facebook than with any other Internet company, including Google and Yahoo.

title: On His First Day, Iraqs Parliament Speaker Was Tested by Own Alliance
description: BAGHDAD  It was not long after Osama al-Najafi officially became the top Sunni politician in Iraq that he faced his first crisis: dozens of Sunni lawmakers abruptly walked out of Parliament.

title: Mayor Will Push Senators to Pass 9/11 Health Bill
description: Hoping to generate last-minute momentum for a long-stalled health care bill for ground zero rescue workers, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg plans to travel to Washington next week to lobby several crucial Republican senators who are believed to be undecided.

title: Myth of Baseballs Creation Endures, With a Prominent Fan
description: The old chestnut about Abner Doubledays inventing baseball in a cow pasture in upstate New York has been so thoroughly debunked that it has taken a position in the pantheon of great American myths, alongside George Washingtons cherry tree, Paul Bunyan and Johnny Appleseed.

title: How Cities Pick School Chiefs, for All to See
description: It is not always pretty. It may resemble a beauty pageant or a paintball contest more than a government exercise to determine how to go about educating a generation of children. But despite the unusual secrecy surrounding New York Citys recent search for a convention-defying schools chancellor, other cities have managed to get unorthodox results through more orthodox means.

title: Scotland Yard Move Stirs Questions on Phone-Hacking Case
description: LONDON  Scotland Yard said Friday that it had sent a new file on allegations of phone hacking by the newspaper The News of the World to the Crown Prosecution Service, which reviews police files for possible criminal prosecutions. The newspaper, one of Britains most highly circulated publications, is owned by News International, part of Rupert Murdochs global media empire.

title: Two More Defendants in Galleon Case to Cooperate
description: Thomas Hardin and Franz Tudor, two defendants in the Galleon Group insider-trading case, agreed to cooperate with prosecutors after pleading guilty last year to conspiracy and securities fraud, the United States attorneys office said. Mr. Hardin is a former trader at Lanexa Global Management. Mr. Tudor worked at Galleon. The Securities and Exchange Commission said it sued Mr. Hardin, Lanexa and Mr. Tudor over insider trading that netted profits of about $715,000. More than 20 people have been charged in two insider trading cases involving the Galleon Group founder Raj Rajaratnam.

title: Homeless, but Hoping for a Return to College
description: Like many people his age, Steve Demain checks his Facebook page, reads the news, writes e-mails and surfs the Web on his laptop. But unlike a typical 20-year-old with a laptop, Mr. Demain is homeless.

title: The Burning Bush Theyll Buy, but Not ESP or Alien Abduction
description: Practically anything goes at the American Academy of Religions annual conference, where scholars of dozens of religions convene annually to debate, relate and on occasion mate. Conversation ranges from the Talmud to tantra, from Platonism to Satanism. This year, from Oct. 30 to Nov. 1 in Atlanta, nearly 5,000 people attended panels including Seeking New Meanings of God and Dao and Madness, Smallpox, and Death in Tibet.

title: Focusing on Next Step, Tea Party Rallies Congressional Freshmen
description: BALTIMORE  The campaign is over, but the Tea Party members have not yet begun to fight.

title: France: National Railway Apologizes for Its Role in Deporting Jews in War
description: Frances national railway, the S.N.C.F., has issued its first public apology for its involvement in the deportation of tens of thousands of Jews to Nazi death camps during World War II. Guillaume Pepy, left, the railways director, expressed the companys profound sorrow and regret for the consequences of its acts in a statement released last week but first reported Friday. The Nazis and their French (Vichy) collaborators directed these terrible actions, determining the composition of the trains, the types of wagons and even the train schedules, Mr. Pepy said. The statement, published in English, came after lawmakers in California and Florida moved to block the S.N.C.F. from winning contracts for high-speed rail projects in their states if it did not recognize its role in the Holocaust. From 1941 to 1944, the S.N.C.F. shipped 76,000 French and other European Jews to the French-German border in 76 railcars originally designed for cattle. German trains later took the prisoners to Nazi death camps.

title: Russia: Brutally Beaten Journalist Regains Consciousness, Wife Says
description: Oleg Kashin, 30, a journalist savagely beaten a week ago, regained consciousness on Friday, though he was still breathing on a ventilator, his wife said. Mr. Kashin, a reporter for the daily newspaper Kommersant, was attacked by two men outside his apartment. They used a metal club hidden in a bouquet of flowers. His grip is strong, Mr. Kashins wife, Yevgenia Milova, wrote on her Facebook page. About 400 protesters gathered Thursday to demand that Mr. Kashins assailants be found, and opposition groups were planning another event on Saturday. State-controlled television devoted unusual attention all week to the attack on Mr. Kashin, and President Dmitri A. Medvedev told reporters that the assailants would be found no matter who is behind it  right-wing, left-wing or centrist forces.

title: Newsweeks Printing Press Was a Top Draw for Diller
description: Barry Diller, who has spent the better part of a decade amassing a collection of Internet companies  a search engine here, a dating Web site there  has figured out how to help make the Internet work a little better for him. He is going into the magazine business.

title: I Wrote It, Must I Also Hustle It?
description: There is a price to be paid when your book comes out.

title: Once Palaces, Now Chain Stores
description: Many of New York Citys old movie theaters have evolved into other businesses.

title: A Moment With Oprah
description: The Oprah Winfrey Show has become regarded as an express lane to the American dream. Here are some of Ms. Winfreys endorsement beneficiaries, as well as those who wish they were.

title: Hand Wraps Draw Boxings Eye, and Scrutiny
description: GRAPEVINE, Tex.  For Freddie Roach, wrapping the hands of boxers is a daily ritual, governed by rules and regulations, done quickly and efficiently, a simple form of art.

title: For Catholics, Interest in Exorcism Is Revived
description: The rite of exorcism, rendered gory by Hollywood and ridiculed by many modern believers, has largely fallen out of favor in the Roman Catholic Church in the United States.

title: When a Safety Net Is Yanked Away
description: November is long-term care awareness month, and to celebrate, a big player in the long-term care insurance industry announced on Thursday that it wanted to get as far away from the business as possible.

title: Who Will Be Oprahs Last Star?
description: EVERY time Stacy Igel concludes a meeting with her staff, she ends it roughly the same way: O.K., Ill see you on Oprah!

title: Harbinger and Falcone Are Said to Face U.S. Inquiry
description: Federal authorities have begun an inquiry into whether a prominent hedge fund gave an improper advantage to its founder and certain clients and whether disclosures were made in a timely fashion, according to a person who has been interviewed by regulators about the matter.

title: Defying Trend, Canada Lures More Migrants
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba  As waves of immigrants from the developing world remade Canada a decade ago, the famously friendly people of Manitoba could not contain their pique.

title: House G.O.P. to Vote Next Week on Earmarks Ban
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans, including newly elected representatives, will vote next week to ban the lawmaker-directed spending items known as earmarks at the start of the next Congress, and party leaders called on President Obama to demonstrate his commitment to the cause by immediately promising to veto any spending bill that contains earmarks.

title: Taking Aim at the Mortgage Tax Break
description: By proposing to curtail the tax deduction for mortgage interest, the presidents deficit commission is sounding an alarm.

title: On the Street | Style Wars
description: A renegade point of view came into focus at the recent New York and Paris Fashion Weeks with the return of large numbers of young people outside the shows for the first time in decades.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,363 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Friday:

title: Cindy McCain Calls for Repeal of Dont Ask
description: Speaking in a video for an ad campaign aimed at ending the bullying of gay teenagers, Cindy McCain, the wife of Senator John McCain of Arizona, broke with her husband and called for a repeal of the militarys dont ask, dont tell policy.

title: I.R.S. Sits on Data Pointing to Missing Children
description: For parents of missing children, any scrap of information that could lead to an abductor is precious.

title: Briton Loses Twitter Case, but Wins Following
description: DONCASTER, England  The troubles of Paul J. Chambers began on a cold night in January, when his attempt to visit a woman from Northern Ireland he had met online was thwarted by a snowstorm that grounded flights at his local airport. Mr. Chamberss first reaction, as in many things in his life, was to address the issue on Twitter.

title: Looking to 2012, Republicans Vie for Big Donors
description: Mitt Romney is not running for president, yet. But a handful of big donors have each contributed in the realm of $100,000, or more, to Mr. Romney this year through a network of state political action committees he has set up that enable him to avoid federal campaign finance limits.

title: Italy Senses Berlusconi Era Is Nearing End
description: ROME  Italys center-left opposition called Friday for a confidence vote against Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, ushering in a chapter that until recently seemed unthinkable: the end of the Berlusconi era.

title: Ireland: Vatican Sending Team to Check Effectiveness of Its Response to Abuse
description: The Vatican offered new details on Friday about its investigation into how effective its response to the sexual abuse scandals in Ireland has been. It said it was sending a team of prelates and nuns to four archdioceses in Ireland to verify that procedures instated to respond to abuse cases and assist victims have been effective. The team, it said, would not interfere with the activity of local officials or commissions set up by the Irish Parliament after the government issued two scathing reports of systematic abuse by clergy members and a widespread cover-up.

title: 3 Republicans Say Report on Spill Was Manipulated
description: WASHINGTON  Three Republican senators demanded Friday that the White House explain last-minute editing changes to an Interior Department report on the BP oil spill that falsely implied that a group of independent experts had endorsed a political decision to temporarily halt all deepwater oil drilling.

title: Lincolns Mailbag
description: The election of Nov. 6 was big news, to put it mildly. In the days following, newspaper headlines screamed it from one city to another, across the not very united states. As Adam Goodheart wrote earlier, the telegraph allowed the results to be known nearly as quickly as we would know today. Now, thanks to another marvel of technology  the Internet  we can see the private telegrams and letters that Lincoln himself was seeing, as Americans exhaled and realized, to their amazement, that he had pulled it off. In the days following the verdict, an enormous range of Americans, from all walks of life, wrote to their president-elect to express their feelings about where the country was headed. These letters present a remarkable documentary portrait of a nation at a crossroads.

title: Anheuser-Busch Files Suit Against M.L.B.
description: Budweisers decades-long connection to Major League Baseball frayed Friday when the giant brewers parent company, Anheuser-Busch, alleged in a federal lawsuit that baseball reneged on an agreement reached earlier this year to extend the beer makers sponsorship.

title: Colleges Reporting Rise in Early Applications
description: With some colleges permitting students to wait until Nov. 15 to file early applications for next years freshman class, it is too soon to draw broad conclusions on whether such programs continue to grow in popularity over all. And yet, those selective colleges with Nov. 1 deadlines are beginning to release results. Among those with binding early decision programs  in which those applying have consented to attend if admitted  Northwestern is reporting that early applications increased by 24 percent, to about 2,100, when compared with last year; submissions to the University of Pennsylvania are up 18 percent, to 4,557; Duke and Johns Hopkins are each up by nearly 14 percent, having received 2,282 and 1,314 applications, respectively, and Rice is up about 15 percent, with about 1,000 early applications. Among colleges with nonbinding early action programs  in which those accepted can wait until spring to make their decisions  early applications to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology are up about 15 percent; the University of Chicago, 18.5 percent; Georgetown, nearly 9 percent, and Boston College, 7 percent. For a more complete, running tally, go to nytimes.com/thechoice.

title: The Trouble With Long-Term Care Insurance
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I address in more detail a theme that I first touched on in our special section on the sandwich generation: Should we really have faith that long-term care insurance is a product that will work over the long haul?

title: Russia: President Seems to Confirm Report on Ring of Sleeper Spies
description: President Dmitri A. Medvedev on Friday appeared to confirm a report in a Russian newspaper that said that the United States had arrested a ring of Russian sleeper spies in June based on information from a senior Russian official who later defected. The newspaper, Kommersant, reported on Thursday that the official had worked in Russias Foreign Intelligence Service. Asked about the article at the Group of 20 meeting in South Korea, Mr. Medvedev did not dispute it, saying that it was not news to him. He declined to say how the government would respond to the security lapse, but said that an inquiry was under way. The relevant lessons will be learned, Mr. Medvedev said.

title: Mets Fire Clubhouse Manager Samuels
description: The Mets fired their longtime clubhouse attendant, Charlie Samuels, amid allegations that he was tied to an organized-crime gambling ring and that he stole money from the team.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Municipal Bond Market Shudders
description: Has the reckoning arrived for municipal bonds?

title: Throwing Free Trade Overboard
description: Washington

title: Immigrants Welcomed in Manitoba
description: The Canadian province of Manitoba won new power to bring foreigners in, handpicking ethnic and occupational groups judged most likely to stay.

title: Saturday: Calisthenics for Show-Offs
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  If youre like me, this puzzle by Mark Diehl requires patience. Well, thats what you want for a Saturday crossword.

title: Schools Chancellor Pick to Quit Corporate Boards
description: Cathleen P. Black will have to give up more than the sweeping Midtown views from her office if she becomes New York Citys next schools chancellor: She will have to walk away from three lucrative sources of income that have made her a multimillion-dollar fortune over the last decade.

title: Lottery Numbers
Lee to Have Elbow Surgery
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Wilson Chandler, who had a top front tooth broken by an elbow from David Lee on Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden, was not kidding at practice Thursday when he said, I think I got him worse than he got me. The collision left a deep gash in Lees left elbow, and the wound proved problematic.

title: Nov. 12: Sports Replay

That would put the lives of many vulnerable people at risk, and it wont save a dime.

title: Henryk Gorecki, Polish Composer, Is Dead at 76

He was 76.

The pudgy little boy, Ardi Rizal, smoked up to two packs a day, and his parents, who had started him at 18 months, said he threw tantrums if denied. That path never appealed to me. Growing up, I was a tomboy and hung out mostly with the guys. Im athletic, and I played rough. Ive never been afraid to get dirt under my nails, so no one who knows me was surprised that I went into mining.

title: Who Will Stand Up to the Superrich?
description: IN the aftermath of the Great Democratic Shellacking of 2010, one election night subplot quickly receded into the footnotes: the drubbing received by very wealthy Americans, most of them Republican, who tried to buy Senate seats and governors mansions. Americans dont hate rich people. They admire and often idolize success. But Californians took a hearty dislike to Meg Whitman, who sacrificed $143 million of her eBay fortune  not to mention her undocumented former housekeeper  to a gubernatorial race she lost by double digits. Connecticut voters K.O.d the World Wrestling groin-kicker, Linda McMahon, and West Virginians did likewise to the limestone-and-steel magnate John Raese, the senatorial hopeful who told an interviewer without apparent irony, I made my money the old-fashioned way  I inherited it.

Its striking to me how many leaders and nations are behaving today as though they think they can fly  and ignoring that sudden stop at the end thats sure to come.

A few weeks ago I started discovering enoki mushrooms  first on tree stumps in upper Manhattan, then again on Staten Island.

title: Reader Comments on Microfinance in Pakistan
description: My Sunday column is about Roshaneh Zafar and her microfinance organization, Kashf, in Pakistan. Ive been frustrated to see so much American money pouring into the Pakistani army, accomplishing nothing as far as I can see, while economic development has been starved. As I wrote in my previous column, the best way for America to create jobs and promote the business sector in Pakistan would be to ease tariff barriers on Pakistani garment exports (Pakistan is a huge manufacturer of socks and similar products). But economic development programs like Kashf are also a mechanism to create jobs, boost civil society and undermine extremism.
