description: JAY LENO

title: Fighting Words
description: As the Obama administration was trying to revive Israel-Palestinian negotiations, Israeli plans to build 1,000 units of housing on contested land in East Jerusalem became widely known last week. The plans were published by Israel Nov. 5 and were widely reported on Monday by an Israeli newspaper.

title: A Journey From Lawmaker to Lobbyist and Back Again
description: WASHINGTON  When Cooper Industries, a century-old manufacturing company based in Texas, moved its headquarters to Bermuda to slash its American income tax bill, it had to turn to a Washington insider with extraordinary contacts to soothe a seething Congress.

title: Where Will the G.O.P. Go Digging?
description: WITH the Republican takeover of the House, Representative Darrell Issa of California will become the chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, Capitol Hills top watchdog panel. As the lead Republican on the panel the last two years, Mr. Issa, a hard-charging, quick-witted former car-alarm company owner, has been the Obama administrations most aggressive antagonist on spending under the $787 billion economic stimulus package. Starting in January, armed with the power to call hearings and issue subpoenas, he will play lead conductor to the new majoritys other committee chairmen in investigating what he says is a long list of oversight targets.

title: What the Director Needs
description: James Clapper Jr., the relatively new director of national intelligence, is trying to claim the authority that the independent Sept. 11 commission said was essential to protecting the United States. Speaking at a conference this month, he disclosed a conceptual agreement with Defense Secretary Robert Gates to take over $53 billion of the $80 billion annual intelligence budget that has long been the Pentagons domain.

title: Doubleheaders
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Patrick Berry is considered a master of modern word puzzles. This is his 134th crossword in The New York Times alone. I have an interview with him further down.

title: The Turkey Standard
description: In case you dont like the CPI:

title: Leaves of Grass
description: Eureka, Calif.

title: Word After Word After Word
description: November is National Novel Writing Month. Perhaps you know that already. Perhaps youre trying to reach word 23,338 by nights end. If you dont know NaNoWriMo, think of it as a literary marathon with nearly 200,000 mostly amateur writers. The goal? To write a 50,000-word novel in 30 days.

title: Questioning Bjorn Lomborg
description: As promised, below you can read responses from Bjorn Lomborg to questions I posed related to Cool It, the new documentary on his approach to global warming.

title: How to Make the Dollar Sound Again
description: BY disclosing a plan to conjure $600 billion to support the sagging economy, the Federal Reserve affirmed the interesting fact that dollars can be conjured. In the digital age, you dont even need a printing press.

title: Names in the News, Before They Can Read
description: TWO questions, one answer.

title: Smoke Got in Their Eyes
description: FRANK SINATRA, exuding crisp sophistication, a squared pocket handkerchief peeking out of his suit jacket, a fedora tilted back from his forehead, eased into the opening words of I Get a Kick Out of You. Behind him, in this 1950s black-and-white television appearance, was a giant blowup of what looks like an album cover, with the title Music for Smokers Only.

title: In Hunt for Nazis, an Incomplete History
description: Compare passages from an unredacted report chronicling the secret internal history of the Justice Departments Nazi-hunting unit.

title: A Torrent of College Applications
description: To the Editor:

title: Selecting Judges
description: To the Editor:

title: Repealing Dont Ask
description: To the Editor:

title: Nazis Were Given Safe Haven in U.S., Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  A secret history of the United States governments Nazi-hunting operation concludes that American intelligence officials created a safe haven in the United States for Nazis and their collaborators after World War II, and it details decades of clashes, often hidden, with other nations over war criminals here and abroad.

title: Travels of a Teenage Prince
description: English Channel, Nov. 14, 1860

title: Chinas Mentally Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: The New Start Treaty
description: To the Editor:

title: The Improper Use of Antibiotics
description: To the Editor:

title: After Midterms, Even Opposites Can Sound Alike
description: ESTES PARK, Colo.  How are Americans thinking about the future after the great reshuffling of the deck on Election Day that carried Republicans into power in the House of Representatives and across the constellation of state capitals?

title: The Faces Change for the Knicks, but the Results Dont
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Donnie Walsh, the Knicks president, envisioned a struggle, but witnessing it was a whole different matter. The Knicks, he said on Saturday, are still a work in progress, which has been the case for what feels like an eternity.

title: Democrats Reach Accord on Leadership in the House
description: WASHINGTON  Representative James E. Clyburn of South Carolina agreed Saturday to fill a new leadership position when Democrats become the House minority party next year, averting a fight that threatened to divide lawmakers still reeling from severe midterm election losses.

title: Richard Bing, Pioneering Heart Researcher, Dies at 101
description: Dr. Richard J. Bing, a pioneering cardiologist whose research led to new understandings of blood flow, congenital heart disease and the mechanics of the heart, died on Monday at his home in La Caada, Calif. He was 101.

title: Spokes | A Struggle to Stay Upright (and Cool)
description: I know how to ride a bike. Ive been doing it for about 25 years now. But I recently found myself wobbling down Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn, trying to get the knack of pedaling again. I was riding, or at least trying to ride, while practically lying down.

title: Penn Tops Harvard for Share of Ivy Title
description: PHILADELPHIA  Pennsylvania won at least a share of its 15th Ivy League championship Saturday by routing Harvard, 34-14, but Quakers Coach Al Bagnoli made sure to point out afterward that this had not been just another championship season.

title: Now, Will China Get It?
description: American economic leadership seems to be on its heels. At the meeting of 20 leading economies in Seoul last week, China resisted Washingtons demands to stop manipulating its currency and rallied Germany and Brazil to criticize the Federal Reserves plan to inject billions into the economy. G-20 leaders also shrugged off an American proposal to set targets to reduce trade surpluses and deficits, calling instead for vague guidelines.

title: Deaths in County Jails Raise Calls for Health Care Standards
description: Robert Foster did not budge when a Gregg County jailer slid open the bean hole to deliver his lunch one day last August. The obese inmate was sprawled on the floor, his breakfast untouched. When the jailer opened the door, a stench wafted out of the cell. Mr. Fosters flesh was cold. He had no pulse.

title: Psychologist in Terror War Is Subject of Complaint
description: The decision about whether an architect of Bush-era interrogation tactics will keep his license as a psychologist is in the hands of a Texas government agency.

title: Texas G.O.P.s Inescapable Truth: We Have Met the Enemy and He Is Us
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

title: Pats Pick
description: I admit I was dubious. Parking near an elevated section of Interstate 10 and picking my way along a sketchy, near-downtown Houston street, I was on the verge of backpedaling when I got my bearings: Oh, I recognize these warehouse lofts and art studios. Stepping into Latin Bites Caf, I found a jubilant mood, as customers chatted and sipped their B.Y.O.B. wine. Theres nothing like stumbling on a cool hole-in-the-wall to make you feel smug.

title: They Know Where You Are
description: To the Editor:

title: The Mets Search Is Narrowing
description: With the Mets looking to conduct their second round of interviews for managerial candidates next week at the general managers meetings in Orlando, Fla., Terry Collins and Bob Melvin are expected to get callback interviews, and they may be the only ones who get them.

title: Auburn Ignores Allegations and Steamrolls Over Georgia
description: AUBURN, Ala.  Auburn quarterback Cam Newton has been stalked by news reports that his father shopped him to Mississippi State, asking for money for his son to play football. The rumors seemed to be everywhere over the past two weeks, except inside Jordan-Hare Stadium.

title: As Glaciers Melt, Science Seeks Data on Rising Seas
description: TASIILAQ, Greenland  With a tense pilot gripping the stick, the helicopter hovered above the water, a red speck of machinery lost in a wilderness of rock and ice.

title: Reading Earths Future in Glacial Ice
description: Researchers have been startled to see signs of rapid melting in Greenland and Antarctica, but lack data to precisely calculate how much flooding could result.

title: Thought of Shifting Police Officers Reopens Debate
description: As city elections approach, Superintendent Jody Weiss proposal to shift more police officers to crime-ridden areas has reignited an intense debate among aldermen.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: A Nighttime Epiphany on Sea Level
description: As I report in Sundays Times, many climate scientists are frustrated by the lack of good information about the status of the worlds land ice. Yet they have nonetheless come to an informal consensus about the extent to which the sea may rise in the course of this century: roughly three feet.

title: Win Over Amherst Is Perfect for Williams
description: For Williams, a season could not end any better.

title: Q. and A. With Brian Leetch
description: Brian Leetch helped the Rangers win the Stanley Cup in 1994, when he became the only American-born player to win the Conn Smythe Trophy as the most valuable player in the N.H.L. playoffs. He was twice awarded the Norris Trophy as the leagues top defenseman and was inducted into the United States Hockey Hall of Fame in Minnesota in 2008 and the Hockey Hall of Fame in Toronto in 2009.

title: Under a New Scoring System, Fewer Ties and Drawn Games
description: A two-year-old scoring system may be the solution to two problems that have long bedeviled chess.

title: Obama Calls Arms Treaty a Priority
description: YOKOHAMA, Japan  President Obama ended a 10-day diplomatic and economic journey through Asia on a personal note Sunday, visiting a colossal copper Buddha that he had seen as a 6-year-old boy, then headed for Washington to confront the lame-duck Congress on Monday. He told President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia here that his top priority on foreign policy for the Congressional session is ratification of their new arms control treaty, which is stalled in the Senate.

title: With Sound Investments, Harp Company Endures
description: In a recession that shuttered longtime manufacturers, reshaped whole industries and sent millions of people looking for work, one might expect a company that makes $100,000 harps to be wobbling at the knees, if not toppled over by now.

title: Mayor Daley Pitches Chicago in Asia, but Who Is Buying?
description: Soon after announcing he would not run for another term, Mayor Richard M. Daley went on a trip to Asia that he said was aimed at rounding up investors for infrastructure projects in the city.

title: Expos Hits Hard at Death Penalty System
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative

title: Love and Dirty, Sexy Ducats
description: They belong to worlds that, in the normal course of events, would never intersect. But Shakespeare, as the creator of their universe, saw fit to let their paths cross just once. And when Portia finally meets Shylock, in Daniel Sullivans absolutely splendid production of The Merchant of Venice at the Broadhurst Theater, the collision lights up the sky.

title: Raw Statistics Belie a Crackdown on Gangs
description: On West Street in North Oakland, a short residential block within the borders of Oaklands gang injunction zone, a bloodstain marks a spot on the sidewalk where a woman was killed last month in a drive-by shooting.

title: Twain Found His Calling in San Francisco Stories
description: Gary Kamiya wrote this clumn for The Bay Citizen.

title: Winfield Street Slides
description: Hidden by trees near Esmeralda Avenue in Bernal Heights is a semi-secret joy ride where daredevils can propel themselves. The adjoining 40-foot Winfield Street Slides were constructed by local volunteers in the late 1970s, with city assistance.

title: Two Candidates Stand Out in Mets Search
description: With the Mets looking to conduct their second round of interviews for managerial candidates this week at the general managers meetings in Orlando, Fla., Terry Collins and Bob Melvin are expected to get callback interviews, and they may be the only ones who get them.

title: Councilman Opposes Appointee for Schools
description: The head of the City Councils education committee and a vocal critic of mayoral control is now speaking out against the mayors choice of Cathleen P. Black to oversee New York City schools.

title: Lone Isaksen Dies at 68; Dancer of Fierce Elegance
description: Lone Isaksen, a Danish-born ballerina who brought a distinctive mix of traditional classical training and fierce projection to contemporary works in American companies like the Harkness Ballet and the Joffrey Ballet, died on Nov. 2 at her home in Manhattan. She was 68.

title: Netanyahu Agrees to Push for Freeze in Settlements
description: WASHINGTON  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has agreed to push his cabinet to freeze most construction on settlements in the West Bank for 90 days to break an impasse in peace negotiations with the Palestinians, an official briefed on talks between the United States and Israel said Saturday evening.

title: Vows: Jeremy & Antonette
description: Jeremy Cohen and Antonette Balestreri met in college as aspiring artists. They fell in love while performing and creating a musical together.  Ever since, theater and music has inspired their romance.

title: Philip Carlo, Who Wrote About Killers, Dies at 61
description: Philip Carlo, who produced novels and nonfiction accounts of serial killers and hit men before writing about his own struggles with disease, died on Nov. 8 in Manhattan. He was 61.

title: Oregon Holds Off California to Stay Perfect
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  There are quirks to a football game at the University of California that make it a quintessential Berkeley experience. There is an announcement before the game advising fans where to exit in case of an earthquake. And on a knoll perched over Memorial Stadium  known as Tightwad Hill for fans considered too cheap to buy tickets  the fans watching the game are known to produce plumes of marijuana smoke.

title: Robbins Barstow, Home-Movie Maven, Dies at 91
description: Robbins Barstow, a Connecticut man who, movie camera whirring, documented every aspect of his familys life for decades, yielding a vast body of work that formed the cornerstone of the recent home-movie revival and has lately garnered a huge following online, died on Nov. 7 at his home in Hartford. He was 91 and previously lived in Wethersfield, Conn.

title: College Football Replay: Nov. 13
description: The week in college football saw a star performance by Auburns embattled quarterback and a rare win from Notre Dame.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Nov. 14
description: Expect a healthy helping of lame-duck politics and fiscal discipline on this weeks talk shows, with a side of nostalgia. Continuing to promote his new book, former President George W. Bush appears on CNN Sunday evening.

title: Bruising Win by Pacquiao Pits Speed Over Size
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  As Manny Pacquiao bruised, bloodied and disfigured the face of Antonio Margarito late Saturday inside a boxing ring at Cowboys Stadium, he turned a far larger man into another small obstacle on his march toward history.

title: Myanmar Dissident Calls for Change
description: YANGON, Myanmar  On her first full day of freedom after more than seven years of house arrest, Myanmars pro-democracy leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, demonstrated the enduring power of her popularity on Sunday, drawing thousands of jubilant supporters to a rally at which she pledged to lead them in a struggle for political change.

title: Less Surprise, More Spice at the Off-Camera Oscars
description: LOS ANGELES  By and large, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences did it again  made a success of its now-annual, teary, easygoing, slightly off-color dinner show, the Governors Awards.

title: Obama and Asia-Pacific Leaders Vow to Work Toward Freer Trade
description: YOKOHAMA, Japan  President Obama and other Asia-Pacific leaders wrapped up a two-day meeting on Sunday with sweeping pledges to rectify global economic imbalances and move toward creating a regional free-trade zone, but with few concrete gains.

title: A Museums Bounty at London Art and Antiques Fair
description: Roaming the numerous exhibitions at the Winter Fine Art and Antiques Fair (Olympia Exhibition Center, Hammersmith Road, www.olympia-antiques.com), running from Nov. 15 to 21, might very well remind visitors of a world-class museum. A cornucopia of impressive and unusual works offered by 140 prestigious British dealers, the show is offering for sale John Singer Sargents romantic painting Head of a Woman with Gold Earring (on sale for 1.7 million, or about $2.6 million) and Francis David Millets tender work A Girl on a Marble Garden Seat Playing a Lyre, as well as a large selection of more conventional antiques.

title: Santonio Holmes, the Jets Difference Maker
description: In conventional terms, Jets receiver Santonio Holmes hasnt made a huge impression with the Jets this season. He couldnt make any impression at all in the first four games  he was serving a suspension. In the four games he has played, he has had 15 catches for 245 yards, with no touchdowns and with one clumsy fumble in which he ran into a teammates back.

title: Sarkozy Appoints a More Rightist Cabinet in Reshuffle
description: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy of France reappointed Franois Fillon the countrys prime minister and named a new, more rightist cabinet on Sunday, a day after Mr. Fillon and the previous government resigned.

title: One on One: Tim Wu, Author of The Master Switch
description: Tim Wu, the Columbia law professor who came up with the term net neutrality in a research paper, has just written a new book, The Master Switch: The Rise and Fall of Information Empires, published by Knopf. The book chronicles the rise and fall of companies that develop new technologies, and discusses the future of the Internet. The following Q&A is an edited version of an interview with Professor Wu:

title: 3 Credit Cards Without Foreign Exchange Fees
description: Attention international travelers: there are a few more credit cards worth tucking into your wallet before you take off.

title: Somali Pirates Free British Couple for Ransom After More Than a Year in Captivity
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  A British couple who had been kidnapped by Somali pirates and held in captivity in a remote, sweltering patch of central Somalia for more than a year was finally released, Somali officials said Sunday, apparently after a ransom was paid.

title: No, Really  Nobody Cares About the Deficit
description: Via Steve Benen, a post-election poll shows essentially nobody, regardless of party affiliation, making the deficit a priority.

title: Is Peak Oil Behind Us?
description: Peak oil is not just here  its behind us already.

title: Announcing the Subway Announcement Lady
description: The next time you are standing there waiting for the subway, late for work and worried your boss will notice, think of this: The voice that tells you a train is two stations away, and then one station away, is up in Maine, about as far from the Penobscot River as you are from the front of the train. When it finally comes.

title: AOL Creates a Hub for E-Mail
description: Its not uncommon for Internet users to have multiple e-mail accounts  one for personal messages, another for online shopping and perhaps a third for registering with various Web sites. The strategy helps to protect privacy, but it also causes frustration because people have to log in to several in-boxes.

title: Live Analysis: Jets 26, Cleveland 20, OT Final
description: The Jets won a thrilling and draining game in overtime against the Browns on Sunday.

title: Death Panels and Sales Taxes
description: I said something deliberately provocative on This Week, so I think Id better clarify what I meant (which I did on the show, but it cant hurt to say it again.)

title: Deficit Remains Focus of National Attention
description: Senator Kent Conrad of North Dakota, a member of the bipartisan commission on reducing the national debt, warned Sunday that America will become a second-rate economic power unless it begins to deal with that debt.

title: 'The Merchant of Venice'
description: Photos from the Broadway production starring Al Pacino and Lily Rabe.

title: A 90-Day Bet on Mideast Talks
description: JERUSALEM  The pledge by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to push for a new, one-time-only freeze of 90 days on settlement construction in the West Bank represents a bet by the Israelis and the Americans that enough can be accomplished so that the Palestinians will not abandon peace talks even after the freeze ends.

title: N.H.L. Rule on Hits to the Head Survives a Review
description: As medical research teams announce increasingly alarming findings on the consequences of head trauma in sports, the N.H.L.s Rule 48 continues to come under scrutiny. That new rule mandates a major penalty and game misconduct for a lateral or blindside hit of an opponent in which the head is the target or the principal point of contact, or both.

title: Live Analysis: Cowboys 33, Giants 20, Final
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Halfway through their schedules, the Giants and the Dallas Cowboys arrived at Sunday heading in opposite directions. The Giants were winners of five straight, while the Cowboys were simply hoping for their first win since a new coach was installed to help salvage a lost season.

title: Ireland Rejects European Bailout Efforts
description: BRUSSELS  European ministers worked over the weekend on a financial rescue plan for Ireland, as pressure mounted on Dublin to seek a bailout to prevent the markets from spreading turbulence to other European countries, officials said on Sunday.

title: Enduring All Tests, Time Included
description: The only runner who could beat him was Seabiscuit, said Louie Zamperinis coach at the University of Southern California, as this track star, who had competed in the 1936 Berlin Olympics, trained for the 1940 Olympics in Tokyo. But a deeply unfunny thing happened to him on the way to Japan. The 1940 games were canceled. Mr. Zamperini became an Air Force lieutenant. And he wound up going to Japan not as a miler but as a savagely abused prisoner of war.

title: Parents Die, and Twins Turn Creepy
description: Its hard to buy a sinister tale set in an isolated house on the edge of the woods when it looks as if its been staged in a discount corner of Crate & Barrel. White sofa and shag rug dont exactly spell menace.

title: Unusual Antics Unfold in a Church Basement
description: Topped with a dollop of thick whipped cream, the luxurious hot chocolate at Blue Marble Ice Cream in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, is an event in itself.

title: This Is Your Brain on Metaphors
description: Despite rumors to the contrary, there are many ways in which the human brain isnt all that fancy. Lets compare it to the nervous system of a fruit fly. Both are made up of cells, of course, with neurons playing particularly important roles. Now one might expect that a neuron from a human will differ dramatically from one from a fly. Maybe the humans will have especially ornate ways of communicating with other neurons, making use of unique neurotransmitter messengers. Maybe compared to the lowly fly neuron, human neurons are bigger, more complex, in some way can run faster and jump higher.

title: Anatomy of a Number: 'Elf'
description: The composer Matthew Sklar and the lyricist Chad Beguelin narrate a look at a number from the new Broadway musical.

title: On One Play, a Life Is Forever Changed
description: On Oct. 16, Chris Norton ran onto the field as part of Luther Colleges kickoff unit in the third quarter of a game against Central College, a rival in Division IIIs Iowa Intercollegiate Athletic Conference. Norton, an 18-year-old freshman defensive back at the tiny liberal arts college in northeast Iowa, raced down the sideline, a blur of arms and limbs.

title: Through the Seasons With Glass and Vivaldi
description: When the violinist Robert McDuffie asked Philip Glass to compose a concerto for him, he had a plan that would ensure performances beyond the premiere. What he wanted was a companion piece for Vivaldis Four Seasons that could be performed on its own or with Vivaldis popular set of programmatic concertos.

title: Jets Win in Overtime for Second Week in a Row
description: CLEVELAND  Santonio Holmes never doubted that the Jets were going to beat the Cleveland Browns. Even when the clock showed 24 seconds left in overtime, he said he did not lose faith.

title: BHP Withdraws Potash Takeover Offer
description: Geoff Howe/Bloomberg News

title: A Collaboration Embraces the Sacred and the Saxophone
description: At the heart of the White Light Festival, the ambitious, multidisciplinary performing-arts series now at Lincoln Center and a few satellite locations, is the idea that art can illuminate the presence of the ineffable. An agnostic might argue that Lincoln Centers real aim is to nudge the invisible hand of commerce. Both notions were evident during two events presented under the White Light banner on Friday night.

title: Philharmonic at Carnegie: What a Difference a Hall Makes
description: As a running story line, the badness of the acoustics at Avery Fisher Hall is exaggerated. The hall is far from ideal, and a renovation is planned (though to what extent has yet to be decided). Still, on any given night, when the New York Philharmonic is at its best, the sound of the orchestra comes through with brightness, clarity and presence.

title: Long Braids That Bind to an Indian Identity
description: Tom Pearson and Donna Ahmadi ended their split bill on Thursday night with their backs pressed together, slowly spinning under the fading lights. They stared out at the surrounding audience impassively, maybe even a bit defiantly, while she undid one of her dark braids and he twirled a red hoop on one arm.

title: The Older Side of Hollywood Gets Its Due
description: LOS ANGELES  It was a wistful, aging Hollywood that showed up on Saturday night to honor both its own and some outsiders at the second annual Governors Awards of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

title: Cool Restraint Leading the Way to Explosiveness
description: With three seasons behind her and a fourth under way, Marin Alsop appears to have settled in comfortably as the music director of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, and the orchestra itself seems to have mellowed. The relationship started unpromisingly when it was announced in 2005, with some players protesting Ms. Alsops appointment. But it warmed up as Ms. Alsop, the musicians and the orchestras management quickly addressed pressing problems like expanding the audience and trimming a longstanding deficit.

title: Putting Some Muscle in Chopin Along With the Poetry
description: Anyone who went to Garrick Ohlssons recital at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday evening thinking of Chopins music as the perfumed effusions of a dreamy, sickly Romantic must have been jolted out of that assumption by Mr. Ohlssons muscular playing.

title: Sweat, Tears, Rubies and a Song
description: Inspired by the Yiddish short stories of I. L. Peretz (1852-1915), the National Yiddish Theater  Folksbiene is mingling modern arts and the mythic past in two one-act allegorical pieces, one starring the gifted Rafael Goldwaser. Mr. Goldwaser, a longtime actor with the Habimah Theater in Israel, now runs a troupe in France that also aims to employ multimedia techniques as it mixes tradition and innovation.

title: Neil Young Tribute to Draw Familiar Faces
description: Patti Smith, the  Roots and Mason Jennings will perform at a tribute concert to Neil Young on Feb. 10 at Carnegie Hall. Michael Dorf, founder of the Knitting Factory and the owner of City Winery, has put together the seventh in his series of concerts to benefit six music-education nonprofit organizations. Others scheduled to appear include Vernon Reid, DeVotchKa, Shawn Colvin, Bettye LaVette, Bebel Gilberto, Aimee Mann, Larry Campbell and the Cowboy Junkies.

title: Seeking a Shutout Against the Rangers
description: When St. Louis goalie Ty Conklin shut out the Rangers, 2-0, at Madison Square Garden last Sunday, it was the first time the Blues had blanked the Rangers, going all the way back to the Blues founding in 1967.

title: Monday: Crossword Golf
description: Years ago, when I used to commute into New York City on the train, Id sometimes play crossword golf, a simple game I concocted to add an extra challenge to early-week puzzles. Ill explain how it works, but first todays debut by Emily L. Lilly.

title: Footnotes
description: Rajiv Josephs play Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo has found a theater for its Broadway run this spring, the producers announced. As previously reported, Robin Williams will make his Broadway acting debut in the production, which is to be directed by Moiss Kaufman (33 Variations), at the Richard Rodgers Theater. Previews begin on March 11, with the official opening on March 31. ... Another star has joined the cast of Chekhovs Three Sisters, which is scheduled to run this winter at the Classic Stage Company. The theater announced that Jessica Hecht would join Maggie Gyllenhaal and her husband, Peter Sarsgaard, in the production, to be directed by Austin Pendleton. Previews begin on Jan. 12, with an opening scheduled for Jan. 27.

title: Megamind Remains a Box-Office Hero
description: Megamind, left, has legs. For the second weekend in a row, this DreamWorks Animation picture was No. 1 at the North American box office, selling an estimated $30.1 million for a total of $89.8 million and vanquishing worries about its staying power. Unstoppable, starring Denzel Washington (20th Century Fox) was second with $23.5 million. Some analysts had expected more from the movie, about a runaway train and made for roughly $100 million, because it garnered strong reviews. The Robert Downey Jr. comedy Due Date (Warner Brothers) was third with $15.5 million for a total of $59 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing statistics. Skyline (Relativity Media) opened in fourth place with about $11.7 million. While marketed like a blockbuster, Skyline, an effects-driven science-fiction thriller, was made for a bargain-basement price of $10 million. The fluffy comedy Morning Glory (Paramount Pictures) was in fifth place with $9.6 million ($12.2 million total), a poor result for a picture with two major stars, Diane Keaton and Harrison Ford. Negative reviews and a crowded marketplace were probably to blame.

title: Computer Programs Battle for Bragging Rights
description: After 49 of the 64 boards in the final of the World Computer-Bridge Championship in Philadelphia last month, WBridge5 from France led Jack from the Netherlands by 32 international match points.

title: Suu Kyi Addresses Thousands
description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi used her speech to call for freedom of speech in Myanmar and urged her supporters to stand up for their rights.

title: Rangers Win Amid a Brawl, a Return and a Hat Trick
description: It was not what Tom Renney had in mind for his return to Madison Square Garden, an 8-2 trouncing of his road-weary, last-place Edmonton Oilers on Sunday by the Rangers, the team he used to coach.

title: For Pacquiao, Next Step Is Unclear
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  By early Sunday, Manny Pacquiao looked more like a beaten fighter than a history-making one. Bruises dotted his face above a lip fattened by Antonio Margarito. Pacquiao gripped the lectern tenderly, his left hand swollen some twice its normal size.

title: Vettel Becomes Youngest World Champion
description: They call him Baby Schumi, as he resembles his German countryman physically and, above all, as a winner.

title: Vettel Becomes Youngest World Champion
description: They call him Baby Schumi, as he resembles his German countryman physically and, above all, as a winner.

title: Last Word: Ted Kheel
description: For decades the mediator Ted Kheel was a dominant force in labor disputes.  He developed his unique technique mediating teacher, transit and press strikes.

title: Wrestling Pendulum Swings Farther East, Toward Cornell
description: It is the first weekend of November, and a light snow glazes narrow country roads that zigzag through miles of cornfields. On a sprawling campus that overlooks this rural scene, the countrys top-ranked college wrestling team is in a gym working out with an eye on a national championship.

title: At Cornell, Arena Proves Sports Value
description: Cornell Universitys wrestling coach, Rob Koll, calls his on-campus wrestling center a fraternity house without the vices. It has a $35,000 sound system that would be the envy of any party scene. There are 40 custom-made maple lockers for the brothers of this frat, in addition to two whirlpools, a study hall, a lounge, a fitness room and walls that are lined with the portraits and pictures of the buildings past inhabitants.

title: Oklahoma Surprise: Islam as an Election Issue
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  Cory Williams, a Democratic state representative from Stillwater, expected his opponent in the recent election to label him a free-spending liberal allied with President Obama.

title: Theodore W. Kheel, Labor Mediator, Dies at 96
description: Theodore W. Kheel, who was New York Citys pre-eminent labor peacemaker from the 1950s through the 1980s, a mediator and arbitrator sought after by both City Hall and the White House to help avert or end strikes of crippling consequence, died on Friday. He was 96 and lived in Manhattan.

title: For Emanuel, Obstacles in Path to Chicago Mayor
description: CHICAGO  Rahm Emanuel pulled off his suit jacket and led a parade of television cameras down 26th Street the other day, carrying himself  with his confident wave to passing cars and his unswerving message for the microphones  every bit like this citys next mayor, and not so unlike its current one.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,365 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Seeking a Free-Agent Bargain Who Will Pay Off
description: In each of the last two World Series, the No. 3 hitter for the champions was a freshly signed first baseman who led his team in homers and runs batted in. In 2009, it was Mark Teixeira, who had just signed an eight-year, $180 million contact with the Yankees. In 2010, it was Aubrey Huff, who had just signed a one-year, $3 million deal with the San Francisco Giants.

title: Great Holiday Expectations for E-Readers
description: This could be the holiday season that American shoppers and e-readers are properly introduced.

title: Record-Setting Track Star Wes Santee Dies at 78
description: Wes Santee, a record-setting track star who never ran the sub-four-minute mile expected of him and whose running career was ended by a suspension for accepting too much expense money, died Sunday at his home in Eureka, Kan. He was 78.

title: A Superabundance of Velocity
NBC Ad Urges Recording News
description: Of all the news commercials on the networks this year, one running this fall for NBC Nightly News might be the most unorthodox. In it, the anchor Brian Williams recommends that people record the 6:30 p.m. newscast if they will not be home in time to watch live.

title: App to Tailor News Streams Gets Boost
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Publishers offices at print newspapers and magazines are tension-filled places these days, as executives watch readers and advertisers flock to the Web and cellphone screens.

title: Obama Returns, Facing Unpredictable Congress in a Lame-Duck Session
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama returned from Asia on Sunday to face the new post-election reality at home: in an unpredictable lame-duck session of Congress starting Monday, emboldened Republicans are poised to try to force an extension of the Bush-era tax rates for the wealthy and block action on a variety of domestic and foreign initiatives.

title: Johanna Skibsruds Novel Draws Acclaim, Despite Small Run
description: While the 50,000 Canadian dollars that accompany the Scotiabank Giller Prize are always welcome, the bigger gain for novelists who win the highly publicized literary award comes later.

title: Cholera Deaths Up in Haiti, With Worst to Come
description: MEXICO CITY  The death toll in Haitis cholera epidemic has reached more than 900, the government reported Sunday, as aid groups rushed soap and clean water to a disaster-wracked population to fight the disease.

title: The Jaguars Crash the Boards and Win
description: Would you believe that Sundays best play, the Jaguars last-second, what-the-heck, 50-yard, bank-shot pass to Mike Thomas, worked exactly as it was designed?

title: Eras Collide: Kennedy on iPad
description: There are outtakes from one of John F. Kennedys last television interviews, a lengthy appearance on The Huntley-Brinkley Report. There is a scene in Fort Worth as the president cheerfully accepts a gift of a cowboy hat, but declines to try it on for the cameras. There is even a rare glimpse of an impeccably dressed Jacqueline Kennedy happily smoking a cigarette, at a dinner party in Australia.

title: Timeline: Legal Path to Lawsuit Lending
description: Investors are pouring money into other peoples lawsuits, hoping to share in the winnings. The practice once was banned in most states. But those barriers have been eroded by the rising cost of litigation, and investors hungry for new and profitable frontiers.

title: Investors Put Money on Lawsuits to Get Payouts
description: Large banks, hedge funds and private investors hungry for new and lucrative opportunities are bankrolling other peoples lawsuits, pumping hundreds of millions of dollars into medical malpractice claims, divorce battles and class actions against corporations  all in the hope of sharing in the potential winnings.

title: Shadows Follow Newton Into Spotlight
description: As the college football season enters its finishing kick, there are four major events left on the calendar. There is No. 2 Auburns game at No. 10 Alabama on Nov. 26, the Southeastern Conference championship game between Auburn and No. 17 South Carolina on Dec. 4, the Heisman Trophy ceremony on Dec. 11 and the Bowl Championship Series title game on Jan. 10.

title: BHP Billiton Drops Bid for Potash
description: BHP Billiton said on Sunday that it withdrew its $38.6 billion unsolicited takeover offer for the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan, the worlds biggest producer of a key fertilizer ingredient, after the Canadian government blocked the potential deal.

title: Haitian School Fights to Survive in Battered System
description: Collge Classique Fminin (known as C.C.F.) and many independent schools are in danger of collapsing financially.

title: School, Interrupted
description: The Collge Classique Fminin is widely considered to be one of the best schools for Haiti's struggling middle class. Now, just as it starts a new school year, CCF is in jeopardy of closing.

description: Chantal Kenol, a principal at College Classique Feminin, gives a parable about coping with adversity - one she's applied to life after the January earthquake.

title: A School Fights for Life in Battered Haiti
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  In mid-October, when fresh-faced girls in starched uniforms skipped through the gates of the Collge Classique Fminin to start the first post-earthquake school year, their desire to seek sanctuary inside was palpable.

title: Guiding Train Riders, All the Way From Maine

When it finally comes.

Two power outages darkened the New Meadowlands Stadium during the third quarter of Sundays game between the Giants and the Dallas Cowboys interrupting play and disrupting the Fox television broadcast of the game. Stadium officials said two separate power interruptions occurred.

title: North Pole Naf Tries to Thaw Hearts
description: In some remote corner of Santas kingdom up at the North Pole, elves are whistling show tunes as they work. Instead of sewing button eyes on dolls and fiddling with the circuitry of game consoles, a small but dedicated cadre of Santas tireless helpers are manufacturing splashy, peppy, sugar-sprinkled holiday entertainments destined for Broadway. The latest product to be shipped south for family consumption is Elf, a musical adaptation of the popular Will Ferrell movie that opened Sunday night at the Al Hirschfeld Theater.

description: To the Editor:

description: WASHINGTON  When insider-trading scandals plagued the financial markets in the late 1980s, lawmakers created a bounty program for whistle-blowers, allowing regulators to reward tipsters who uncovered evidence of manipulation.

title: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Tries to End Flow of Bomb Item to Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  With roadside bombs by far the leading killer of American troops in Afghanistan, the Obama administration has started a worldwide effort to stop the flow of ammonium nitrate, the fertilizer that is their basic ingredient, into the war ravaged country.

title: Gerry Adams to Run for Seat in Ireland
description: LONDON  After 40 years of participation in Irish republican politics in the British-controlled counties of Northern Ireland, Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, said Sunday that he planned to shift the focus of his political activity to the Irish Republic and seek election there.

title: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data this week will include retail sales for October and business inventories for September (Monday); the Producer Price Index for October and industrial production and capacity utilization for October (Tuesday); the Consumer Price Index for October and housing starts for October (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, the Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index, and leading economic indicators for October (Thursday).

title: The World as He Finds It
description: On Wednesday David Axelrod, President Obamas top political adviser, appeared to signal that the White House was ready to cave on tax cuts  to give in to Republican demands that tax cuts be extended for the wealthy as well as the middle class. We have to deal with the world as we find it, he declared.

title: Depression, a Cruel Bully
description: To the Editor:

title: Ethics in the New House
description: As he approaches the duties of speaker of the House, Representative John Boehner is generously asking one and all for ideas on how we can make this institution function again. Mr. Boehner did not mention dysfunction, but thats apparently in the works, too, according to reports that he will likely dismantle the quasi-independent Office of Congressional Ethics.

title: Investing in Our Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Donald S. Kellermann, Who Led Public Research Group, Dies at 83
description: Donald S. Kellermann, who gained wide attention as a young newspaper reporter by committing a crime so that he could report on life in jail, then went on to help start an influential public opinion research organization, the Times Mirror Center for the People and the Press, died on Tuesday at his home in Washington. He was 83.

title: Grand Disillusion
description: Up in the soft blue night sky at Grand Central Terminal, the heavens have been improved upon. The ceilings gold-leaf constellations were not considered bright enough, so their fiber-optic stars are now LEDs. Castor, Pollux, Pisces, Pegasus dazzle 125 feet above the main concourse.

title: Safer Social Security
description: Social Security is not the key fiscal problem facing the nation. Payments to its beneficiaries amount to 5 percent of the economy now; by 2050, theyre projected to rise to about 6 percent. Over the same period, federal health care costs will increase six times as much.

title: The Party of No
description: By offering up their joint recommendation last week for balancing the budget, the co-chairmen of Barack Obamas fiscal commission didnt solve our deficit problem once and for all, or clear a path through the political thickets facing would-be budget cutters. But Erskine Bowles and Alan Simpson performed a valuable public service nonetheless: the reaction to their proposals demonstrated that when it comes to addressing the long-term challenges facing this country, the Democrats, too, can play the Party of No.

title: A Culture of Carelessness
description: Though its final report is two months away, the presidential commission investigating the gulf oil spill is beginning to confirm what we already suspected and feared. The April blowout on the Deepwater Horizon was not some unfortunate occurrence. It was the result of a series of bad decisions by companies less concerned about safety than about finishing a project that was over budget and 38 days behind schedule.

title: Immigration Hardball
description: Republicans will have the next two years to set the immigration agenda in the House of Representatives. If their legislation looks anything like their campaign ads, there will be no way for illegal immigrants to get right with the law and no real solution to the problem of illegal immigration. Just a national doubling-down on enforcement, with still more border fencing and immigration agents, workplaces locked down, and states and localities setting police dragnets on what always was  and still ought to be  federal turf.

title: Aid Fuels Change of Fortunes on Silk Road
description: KASHGAR, China  The brochure promised a piece of heaven, but Shangri-La, a half-built apartment complex on the dusty outskirts of this oasis town, was hardly that. The landscape was parched, and the most notable sign of life was a pack of goats chewing their way through a mound of trash.

title: Sports Replay: Nov. 14
description: A look at the day in sports, including some nice moves and some blunders.

title: How Smoky Plume in Sky Drew the Eyes of the World
description: Gil Leyvas has been a photojournalist on board a television news helicopter for more than a decade. He has seen countless airplanes and their wispy contrails. What he saw  and recorded  near Los Angeles on Nov. 4 and 8 looked nothing like the trail from an airplane. It looked, to him, like the launching of a missile.

description: 8:42 a.m. | Updated As expected, Clear Channel on Monday named Robert W. Pittman as a senior adviser for its radio business, and confirmed that he will make an investment in the company.

description: One week after pounding Utah in Salt Lake City and seemingly taking control of the No. 3 slot in the Bowl Championship Series rankings, Texas Christian saw everything fall apart. Although No. 4 Boise State still trails No. 3 T.C.U. in the B.C.S. standings, the Horned Frogs lead took a significant hit. T.C.U. leads Boise State by a margin of .897 to .863, but that is one week after leading, .925 to .866.

It was hard to tell what had Brady upset. He was barely touched by the Pittsburgh Steelers, who possess one of the most harrowing defenses in the N.F.L. And the expectations for the running game against a defense that had not yet allowed a 75-yard game had to be minimal.

title: When Do You Remember Learning a New Word?
description: There are many places in The New York Times to learn new words every day. Not only will almost any article you read in The Times introduce you to several SAT-level words, but The Learning Network has a Word of the Day feature, the Magazine section features a weekly On Language column, and the Opinion section has a blog called Schotts Vocab. Tell us about a time you remember learning a new word, whether it was recently or long ago. What was the word? How did you learn it? In general, how do you think vocabulary should (or shouldnt) be taught in school? Why?

description: The recent rebound in mergers and acquisitions is expected to strengthen significantly next year, according to a new report, with global deal activity on track to rise 36 percent, to $3.04 trillion.

title: Fisker Karma to Weigh More Than 5,000 Pounds
description: The Fisker Karma plug-in hybrid is a relative heavyweight at more than 5,000 pounds, said a board member and the chief executive of the companys powertrain supplier.

title: Strong Car Data Helped Retail Sales Jump 1.2%
description: Sales at the nations retailers and food service establishments rose in October, according to government figures released on Monday, providing a glimmer of hope that consumer spending was set to improve in the fourth quarter.

title: The Election Isnt Over Quite Yet
description: Heres what were reading on this temperate, gray start to the week.

title: Liquidationists of the World, Unite!
description: OK, so now its official: conservatives arent just against any effort to boost demand with fiscal policy, they dont want the Fed doing anything positive, either.

title: This Weeks Health Industry News
description: Cardiologists, not to mention Wall Street analysts, will be closely monitoring the results of several major studies being presented at the American Heart Association meeting this week.

title: Live-Blogging the Rangel Hearing: Rangel Walks Out
description: The public ethics trial of Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, on 13 charges of unethical behavior took a stunning turn Monday morning when Mr. Rangel walked out of the hearing 40 minutes after it began, complaining that it would be unfair to continue the process because he could no longer afford a lawyer.

title: A Simple Plan
description: Western paper turns away the light, while our paper seems to take it in, to envelop it gently, like the soft surface of a first snowfall, wrote the Japanese author Junichiro Tanizaki in In Praise of Shadows, his 1933 manifesto on the aesthetic differences between the East and West. His observations on subtlety, the play of light and dark, and, for that matter, all things Japanese, have lately been on the minds of Alexa Adams and Flora Gill, the design duo behind the label Ohne Titel. While I was reading his work, I felt like I was experiencing this slice of traditional Japanese aesthetics visually, Adams says. Adds Gill, Its almost a goal toward perfect design, which as designers were always searching for. In their spring 2011 collection, the pair softened their usual aggressive silhouettes with nods to the Orient: striped ribbed knitwear inspired by the Japanese woodblock print artist Utagawa Kuniyoshi, linen tie-front pants, jackets with kimono-style volume in the sleeves. The two recently made their inaugural trip to Japan, traveling to Kyoto to take in tea ceremonies, ancient temples and Noh theater. As Tanizaki saw it, the purity of great modern design comes, first, with an appreciation for the old.

title: Roundup: Surveys Find Increases in Chinese Students at American Universities, and Millionaire College Presidents
description: The number of Chinese students studying in the United States surged 30 percent in the 2009-10 academic year, making China, for the first time, the top country of origin for international students, Tamar Lewin writes in todays Times, citing Open Doors, the Institute of International Educations annual report.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Pity the robo-signer: These videotaped depositions show the Kafkaesque absurdity of their jobs, representing companies they cannot remember, claiming addresses they have never seen and signing documents they do not understand.

title: Dexter Watch: No More Secrets
description: To begin the discussion of Sundays episode of Dexter off topic, Id like to level a complaint about Harrisons sleeping situation. Not only is Dexters son inexplicably still sleeping in the living room in a Pack n Play, apparently he also doesnt wear pajamas.

title: For Frequent Fliers, a Radiation Risk in the Skies
description: Despite recent concern about whether airline passengers get a potentially dangerous dose of radiation from the new security scanners at the airport checkpoints, the real risk is after you board the plane, according to two new publications.

title: How to Succeed Rounds Out Its Broadway Cast
description: A Broadway newcomer, Rose Hemingway, will play one of the most coveted ingnue roles of the season, Rosemary Pilkington, opposite Daniel Radcliffes J. Pierrepont Finch in this winters revival of the Frank Loesser musical How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying, the producers announced on Monday. Ms. Hemingway appeared in the Donmar Warehouse production of Parade in Los Angeles last year. Also new to the cast is Christopher J. Hanke (In My Life) as Bud Frump, the role that won a featured actor Tony Award for Charles Nelson Reilly in the original production, which ran from 1961 to 1965 and won seven Tonys in all (including best musical) as well as the Pulitzer Prize in drama.

title: In Search of the Chancellor-to-Be, Park Ave., 5 A.M.
description: The doormen at 941 Park Avenue, where Cathleen P. Black occupies a penthouse apartment, have quickly transformed her morning ritual into an art form.

title: Video of Kidnapped British Couples Journey to Freedom After a Year With Somali Pirates
description: Although it is a long way from their home in suburban England to the Somali bush, throughout their long ordeal, Paul and Rachel Chandler  a retired British couple released on Sunday, 13 months after they were kidnapped by Somali pirates  were a surprisingly frequent presence on British television.

title: Win Doesnt End Cowboys Troubles
description: There was a moment late in the Dallas Cowboys rebirth against the Giants on Sunday when Jason Garrett was presented with another teaching moment in what is going to be two months of them. David Buehlers field-goal attempt sailed wide with 5 minutes 45 seconds remaining, and the Cowboys tentative steps back from the precipice and toward, well, mediocrity threatened to end up in a face plant.

title: Numberplay: Egg Drop Soup
description: A few weeks ago we did a pizza puzzle involving a bet between two fictitious math graduate students. That week we also had the Gathering for Gardner Celebration of Mind on what would have been Martin Gardners 96th birthday. At the enjoyable little gathering that I hosted, we actually had New Haven pizza. Coincidentally, a real Yale mathematics graduate student presented a classic puzzle that involved another of my favorite foods  eggs. Here it is.

title: Odd Court Routine: Being the Judge of Whether to Be the Judge
description: WASHINGTON

title: Tweet of the Week: An Unpredictable Game of Musical Chairs
description: To which we might add Janice Min running The Hollywood Reporter and Michael Wolff running Adweek, Brandweek, and MediaWeek. These are heady, unpredictable days in the corner offices of media.

title: Porto Party
description: Bustling with commerce, the design-savvy city of Porto, Portugal, plays a convincing Milan to Lisbons Rome. (Its pristine beaches, 10 minutes from downtown, give it a touch of Malibu, too.) And suddenly the citys long-neglected downtown  with its vertiginous hills and elegant spires towering over the Douro River  is all the rage again. Sleek new galleries, restaurants and boutiques have the old cobblestone streets buzzing anew.

title: Sugarland Settles Lawsuit With Ex-Founding Member
description: Kristen Hall isnt about to be Pete Best-ed out of Sugarland. Though Sugarland, the best-selling award-winning country music act, is now the duo Kristian Bush and Jennifer Nettles, Ms. Hall, a singer-songwriter who founded the group, has obtained a settlement from her former bandmates after suing for profits she said she was owed after she left, The Associated Press reported.

title: Monday Reading: Hurdles in Getting a Mortgage Preapproval
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Brady in Charge in New England
description: We have reached the point in the N.F.L. season when we are all required to fix our gaze on New England quarterback Tom Brady and commence swooning. (Really, its in the rules. Decline at your own risk.) Forget for a second that a week ago, he and his mighty Patriots were being crushed by the Browns and instead be mesmerized by the game-turning tantrum Brady unfurled on his own team in Sundays victory over Pittsburgh. That he did it with the Justin Bieber hair swaying from side to side was just a bonus.

description: Last year, New York City Transit released a report that admitted what many riders already knew: The F train, the ugly duckling of the subway system, was a mess.

title: Screening of Gay Zombie Film Leads to Police Raid in Australia
description: Could there eventually come a day when our popular cultures disposition toward all things zombie-related goes from fixation to saturation, from saturation to revulsion, and from revulsion to a point where people are actually persecuted for showing zombie movies? Richard Wolstencroft, the director of the Melbourne Underground Film Festival in Australia, might argue that the day is already here. But then again the zombie movie he tried to show at his festival over the summer is not exactly your ordinary horror flick.

title: MAN and Scania in Merger Talks

description: An off-duty police sergeant shot a man who tried to steal his motorcycle in Brooklyn early Monday morning, the police said.

description: The situation: over the past decade, households ran up what is almost universally regarded as an excessive amount of debt  shown here for the United States, but also in the UK, Spain, and elsewhere. They are now being forced to pay down that debt by cutting spending.

As a trend, minimalism seemed to come out of left field this season, ubiquitous on the runways for no better reason than, well, Phoebe Philo is doing it, so it must be right.

Thats what Adelaide Lancaster says happened recently toIn Good Company, a three-year-old community that offers educational programs and office space to women who own businesses.

title: Truck Stop | Austins Moveable Feast
description: Like other cities around the country, Austin, Tex., recently tightened its rules for its ever-expanding mobile-food contingent. New regulations include needing to provide proof of a state sales tax permit, passing a fire-department inspection and filing an itinerary of truck routes. (Apparently Twitter doesnt count.) Despite these new regulations, the food-trailer scene is still thriving: the city estimates that there will be 1,620 mobile food vendors by the end of 2011; in 2006, there were only 648. Here are a few highlights:

title: McConnell to Support Earmarks Ban
description: The Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, a longtime defender of the Congressional authority over federal spending, said on Monday that he would support a proposed ban on earmarks, the lawmaker-directed spending items, in the next Congress.

title: Rangel Ethics Committee Begins Private Deliberations
description: The House panel deliberating ethics charges against Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem returned to the hearing room Monday afternoon just long enough to announce that it had determined that the facts in the case were undisputed and that it would begin its closed-door deliberations to determine whether those facts add up to proof that Mr. Rangel violated House ethics rules. Read and leave comments on our live-blog coverage of the hearing.

title: 50 Years of Chimpanzees
description: Jane Goodall went to the Gombe Stream Reserve near Lake Tanganyika in East Africa when she was 26. By living among the animals and quietly recording their interactions, she was able to show that the chimp world included love, hate, fear, jealousy, tool use, brutality, even warfare. I spoke with Dr. Goodall last month at Western Connecticut State College, where she was giving a lecture, and then later by telephone. A condensed version of the conversations follows:

title: Drinking Water to Lose Weight
description: Does drinking water before a meal help you lose weight? Thats the question explored by Anahad OConnor in todays Really? column.

title: Get It Done: Learning to Be Your Own Homework Coach
description: Overview | What skills and strategies can help students become more efficient managers of their time and coursework? In this lesson, students learn how to act as their own homework coaches by becoming familiar with various organization and time management tools. They then select a tool that appeals to them and track the impact that usage has on its effectiveness.

title: NBC Scrambles Jets: 30 Rock Moves to 10; Event On Hold
description: NBC announced wholesale changes to its struggling prime-time schedule Monday, highlighted by an all-comedy night on Thursdays, which includes a move of the much-awarded 30 Rock to 10 p.m., followed by the new comedy Outsourced, which has been the networks best-performing new series this fall.

description: Fifty years ago, the average bride was a little older than 20 when she married, and the average groom was just shy of 23. Today the average for brides is 26 and for grooms is nearly 28.

title: The Money Trail
description: While checking in at the hotel that first afternoon in the French Alps, I met a fine, terrier-like dog named Al Capone. He was admirably groomed, pearl coat nearly glowing, and he proceeded through the lobby with such aplomb  did he realize that he stood only a foot and a half?  that I was filled with immediate admiration for him, if not a scintilla of envy. Judging by the clientele here, his owner might have been a Russian oligarch, a Euro titan or a celebrity scion of some sort, and so could only offer me a wan smile and a few brief words. But that was to be expected. Women sashayed past in ski outfits that would have cost your average proletarian a months wages; men sat by the fireplace drinking bottles of Cognac whose sticker price resembled that of a compact car. And Al Capone followed his curious nose, snuffling for nonexistent crumbs, until he bumped up against my alien, American shoe.

title: The Triumph Of Reagan Over Friedman
description: Brad DeLong is exercised, and rightly so, over the fact that some good economists have joined the crazies in signing the Republican anti-QE letter. How is this possible? he asks. After all, were not even talking about Keynesianism here, were talking about monetarism  at least in terms of the spirit of the thing. For Friedmans whole case against the Fed was not, fundamentally, about monetary aggregates; they were just intermediate targets. It was that the Fed was supposed to do whatever it took to avoid an economic plunge, and didnt. So calling on the Fed not to act now is a betrayal of Friedmanism as well as Keynesianism.

title: Fraunces Tavern Getting Close to Reopening
description: There is still cardboard on the floor and newspapers lining the windows. But the much-delayed reopening of Fraunces Tavern, the historic financial district spot where Gen. George Washington bid his officers farewell at the end of the Revolutionary War, appears to be on the horizon: the museum associated with the tavern has been closed to accommodate the final renovations on the restaurant, according to a sign taped to the door.

title: Redskins Sign McNabb for Five More Years
description: Two weeks ago, Washington Redskins quarterback Donovan McNabb was benched by Coach Mike Shanahan because he didnt know the two-minute offense as well as Rex Grossman or he didnt have the cardiovascular conditioning necessary to execute it or because Shanahan felt like showing him who is boss.

title: Excerpt: 'Glory Daze'
description: A new TBS comedy is set at a college in the 1980s.

title: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Washington, Haiti, and Guinea.

title: College Humor, Mined for Nostalgia
description: Women often see strategies of patriarchal control in pornography, right-leaning social programs and husbands who refuse to empty the dishwasher, but the pernicious hand of male domination is also evident in juvenilia of the kind that feels like felony assault on the female comic sensibility. The latest offense is committed by Glory Daze, a series beginning on Tuesday on TBS that taxes the patience for about 43 of its 45 minutes and 17 seconds.

title: A Palin Flub Becomes a Word of the Year
description: At the start of the year the word refudiate didnt exist. In mid-July Sarah Palin, Alaskas former governor, changed that when she used the word in a Twitter message, somehow mashing up refute and repudiate, while trying to say something like reject.

title: It Turns Out That a Classical Staple in December Can Be Jazzy in November
description: For a few weeks each December you can barely turn a corner in New York without tripping over a performance of a certain great seasonal oratorio by Handel. But Messiah returned early and in unusual company on Sunday afternoon when the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, in its second Carnegie Hall appearance of the weekend, gamely played second fiddle to a trio of starry singers, a funky rhythm section and an enormous choir of New York high school students.

title: Romanticism With Russian Passion
description: The cello is said to have been Rachmaninoffs favorite string instrument. In his lushly romantic Sonata for Cello and Piano in G minor he wrote sweepingly lyrical lines that unfold against a virtuoso piano part.

title: A Political Persona as Big as the Crowd Will Allow
description: WASHINGTON

title: An Early Dalliance by Beethoven, Before He Was Smitten With Others
description: It seems that in regard to string trios, threes a crowd, with little appeal for composers who since the Baroque era have preferred to write for string quartets or other chamber formations.

title: Hong Kong Seeks Bigger Role in Global Finance
description: Hong Kong is making a bold bid to challenge London and New York as global financial centers this week. And judging by its gains in recent years, it might be in the running soon.

title: We Made It Ourselves | Beyond Kombucha
description: When Spiro Theofilatos says oolong, it sounds like a Sanskrit incantation. Theofilatoss chanty-shanti tendencies might make some leery of his small-batch kombucha. Instead, it should alert you to the fact that this Spiro knows his tea  and this is what makes his Beyond Kombucha fizzy tonics so incredible.

title: Familiar Faces, New Agenda: No Woman, or Guitar, Is Spared
description: Nick Cave describes women a lot in the company of his tall, hairy, dark-suited, middle-aged new band, Grinderman. At times he does proper literary comparison: someone is put forth as a lupine child or with hands as white as milk. But at better times he rams a chute between appearance and reality, as if he doesnt even know what hes saying.

title: M.R.I.s Help Fight High Risk of Cancer
description: For women with a high risk of breast cancer because of genetic mutations or family history, yearly M.R.I. scans in addition to mammograms and breast exams may save lives, a new study finds.

title: Adding M.R.I.s to Mammograms for High-Risk Women
description: A combination of annual mammograms and M.R.I. scans for women at high risk of breast cancer appears to saves lives, new research shows. The New York Times medical reporter Denise Grady reports on the research in todays Science Times.

title: Fire in the Dancers Heels and Flares From the Guitarists Hands
description: Some performances of flamenco feel inauthentic: too arty, too unspontaneous, too choreographed. That feeling never once arose at Flamenco Festival Gitano!, presented over the weekend by the World Music Institute at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts at New York University. Enough approving calls of ol! came from the audience, even after subtle feats of musicianship, to make both performances feel intimate. The programs will be repeated this week in Boston and Berkeley, Calif.

title: Critics Picks Video: The General
description: In this weeks Critics Pick, A. O. Scott looks back at the 1927 silent film The General, a movie that turns the intractable and cruel laws of physics into cinematic poetry, he says. The film was written by, directed by and stars Buster Keaton. Although Mr. Keaton was usually associated with comedies, Mr. Scott sees The General as more of an action movie, one of the purest and, still, one of the best of its kind, he says. Have you seen The General? Please share your thoughts on this and other Buster Keaton films.

title: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Washington, Haiti and Guinea.

title: The Downside of a Cancer Study Extolling CT Scans
description: Are lung cancer scans really ready for prime time?

title: When the Mind Wanders, Happiness Also Strays
description: A quick experiment. Before proceeding to the next paragraph, let your mind wander wherever it wants to go. Close your eyes for a few seconds, starting ... now.

title: Critics Choice: New CDs
description: RIHANNA

title: Another R2D2 for Floors
description: Robotic cleaning devices, despite their veneer of science-fiction, are hardly new to the scene. IRobot has popularized the category with its Scooba floor washers and its Roomba robotic vacuums. Neato Robotics came onto the scene earlier this year with its XV-11 vacuum cleaner.

title: Economics for the People
description: Is economic growth a means, or an end?

title: A Castle Commute, Minus the Royal Coach
description: The stars of Castle, the hit police drama on ABC, posted a series of online videos Monday about trying to go car-free in one of the most car-dependent cities in the world  Los Angeles. Named the Alternative Travel Project, the series aims at encouraging viewers everywhere to give up their cars for at least one day a week.

title: Colorless, Tasteless but Not Dangerous
description: Being white these days is not what it used to be, Nell Irvin Painter wrote near the end of her monumental survey, The History of White People, published earlier this year. Ms. Painter, an emeritus history professor at Princeton University, noted the achievements of the Obamas and Oprah Winfrey and many other blacks and Latinos and asked, tongue only slightly in cheek, Is this the end of race in America?

title: The Spike and Other Improv Lessons
description: For all the words in the 25-minute monologue of megalomania that Mark Rylance delivers in the Broadway play La Bte, many of the comic payoffs flow from the stunned or dumbfounded looks, the tense or foolish body language, traded among Mr. Rylances crude street clown and the high-minded characters played by David Hyde Pierce and Stephen Ouimette. You can rehearse and rehearse such moments, but at their best they flow from instinct and risk-taking.

title: Idealists Wanted to Help Create Ads
description: Another effort to help marketers produce advertising campaigns without the use of traditional agencies is getting under way after months of tests.

title: Yahoo Seeks News From Its Users
description: Yahoo is opening the door to more citizen journalism on its Web site.

title: Lincoln Center Scrambles After Visa Problems
description: Visa problems have forced Lincoln Center to delay the culminating performances of its White Light Festival, dedicated to transcendence in music, until next week. The Manganiyar Seduction, which was scheduled for Wednesday and Thursday, will now take place on Monday and Tuesday. Manganiyars are a caste of Indian musicians of Muslim origin from western Rajasthan state whose songs celebrate Hindu deities. Jane Moss, Lincoln Centers vice president for programming and the organizer of the festival, said that visa applications were made in May and that about half of the 50-member troupe involved in the show had received visas by Oct. 13, but the rest were sent for further review by State Department officials. By Friday a dozen members still had not received visas, so the performances were postponed. Word came over the weekend that the remaining visas had been granted. The Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center was available Monday and Tuesday for the shift. Tickets can be used for the new dates, refunded or exchanged.

title: An Era Ends at Forbes Magazine
description: The era of the Forbes family at Forbes magazine has ended.

title: When Opera Stars Show Their Frisky Side
description: The great Brooklyn-born tenor Richard Tucker died in 1975, and by the end of that year a foundation bearing his name was up and running. Since then the foundation, which fosters the careers of emerging singers, has earned the good will of major artists, who contribute their services to an annual gala concert.

title: A Jamesian Pays Tribute in a Retelling
description: Cynthia Ozick, whose sixth novel, Foreign Bodies, has just been published, is still in the thrall of Henry James. He was the idol of her youth and also, she has said, its ruination. At the age of 22, she once wrote, she became Henry James: Even without close examination, you could see the light glancing off my pate; you could see my heavy chin, my watch chain, my walking stick, my tender paunch, she said. She wrote her masters thesis on Jamess late novels, including one, The Ivory Tower, that James never finished and that most people have never heard of.

title: A Producer, His Telephone and Desperation
description: A satisfyingly whole play is not easily constructed from half of a conversation, even when an actor as formidably talented as Michael Shannon is the man onstage with the phone surgically attached to his ear.

title: Paulson Cuts Bets on Bank of America and Citi
description: For much of the post-crisis recovery, John A. Paulson has bet big on the nations banks, wagering that with the worst of the financial meltdown behind us, the sector was full of promise.

description: Verne G. Kopytoff reports that Yahoo is opening the door to more citizen journalism on its Web site.

title: F.D.A. Expected to Act on Alcoholic Energy Drinks
description: A year after it began reviewing whether energy drinks that combine alcohol and caffeine are safe or legal, the Food and Drug Administration is expected to take a stand on the drinks as soon as Wednesday, according to law enforcement officials in several states.

title: As His Ethics Trial Begins, Rangel Meets With Farm Workers
description: WASHINGTON  Thirty minutes into his Congressional ethics trial on Monday, all that remained of Representative Charles B. Rangel was the conspicuous presence of his absence.

title: New Hurdle for California Condors May Be DDT From Years Ago
description: BIG SUR, Calif.  Four years ago, in a musky, leaf-lined cavity halfway up a 200-foot redwood tree here, two California condors made the regions first known nesting attempt in more than a century.

description: I DIDNT fly on my first airplane until I was almost 20 years old.

title: An Edge on Dividends for Goldman
description: Goldman Sachss shareholders have little to grumble about. Sure, the banks plan to buy back $5 billion in expensive preferred stock held by Warren E. Buffett appears to have been delayed because of an industrywide debate with the Federal Reserve over how to manage capital. That includes deciding when dividends can go up. But investors in Goldmans common stock already have an advantage over the competition.

title: Britain to Measure Happiness
description: In an attempt to make good on a centuries-old idea, that the happiness of a nations citizens is the ultimate goal of all government, British Prime Minister David Cameron is planning to ask for a survey of the general well-being of residents of the United Kingdom.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,368 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

title: A Little Extra on the Road
description: Corporate accountants have long known that otherwise law-abiding people commit travel expense fraud.

title: Court Rules Gun Use in Drug Crimes Means Added 5 Years
description: WASHINGTON  People convicted of possessing a gun while selling drugs are subject to five-year mandatory minimum sentences on top of most of other sentences, the Supreme Court ruled Monday.

title: Schmidt: Android Phones Will Be Credit Cards
description: Google wants the next generation of Android phones to replace credit cards, Eric E. Schmidt, Googles chief executive, said Monday at the Web 2.0 Summit in San Francisco.

title: Researchers Dispute Report on Early Butchers
description: A report in August that the early ancestors of humans used stone tools to butcher meat at least 3.4 million years ago is being challenged by other researchers, who say that the study misinterpreted cut marks in animal bones.

title: Bats Gauge Sounds With Neural Teamwork
description: One of the keys to the keen ability of bats to process sound is that the neurons in a bats brain work as a team to convey the importance of certain signals  like an anger call or a distress call  while diminishing the effect of less-important sounds, researchers at the Georgetown University Medical Center reported this past weekend in San Diego at the annual meeting of the Society for Neuroscience.

title: The Shrinking Data Storage Sector
description: Gurinder Osan/Associated Press Joe Tucci, EMCs chief executive, is seeking to become a larger player in big data.

title: Seven Charged in Kosovo Organ-Trafficking Ring
description: PRAGUE  At least seven people have been charged with participating in an international organ-trafficking network based in Kosovo that sold kidneys and other organs from impoverished victims for up to $200,000 to patients from as far away as Israel and Canada, police and senior European Union officials said Monday.

title: The Full-Body Backlash
