title: 45 Years Later, an Apology and 6 Months
description: James Bonard Fowler is 77 now, but in 1965 he was a young Alabama state trooper facing the rising tide of the civil rights movement.

title: New Nickname for a New Season
description: Allow me to introduce myself as the new blogger for the Quad. My name is Joe Duffy, I am a senior at Vanderbilt majoring in economics and basketball and I admit that I am a first timer in this realm they call the blogosphere. So far, the accommodations have been great, and the people are swell. If you will have me, I will try my best to make your blogsperience a special one. I hope to carry on the Quads rock-star reputation, as my predecessors  Stephen Danley, Zach Hillesland and Patrick Behan  did so nobly before me.

title: Europe Fears That Debt Crisis Is Ready to Spread
description: LONDON  European officials, increasingly concerned that the Continents debt crisis will spread, are warning that any new rescue plans may need to cover Portugal as well as Ireland to contain the problem they tried to resolve six months ago.

title: Caterpillar Digs Into Mining
description: Caterpillar agreed to buy Bucyrus for $7.6 billion in cash at $92 a share. The purchase of Bucyrus will help Caterpillar expand its global footprint in the mining equipment industry.

title: Posey and Feliz Go From World Series to Rookie Honors
description: Buster Posey spent his Saturday in Tallahassee, Fla., watching Florida State defeat Clemson in football. By Monday, Poseys Sunshine State whereabouts were a little murkier. He was en route to the Keys for what he called a welcome vacation with his wife, Kristen, as he marveled at his latest dose of good fortune. Posey, the slugging catcher for the San Francisco Giants, added the National League rookie of the year award to the Giants World Series title.

description: OTTAWA  Based on his past, Stephen Harper, the Conservative prime minister of Canada, should have been the least of BHP Billitons worries when the company began a bid to acquire the Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan, the worlds largest fertilizer maker.

description: To the Editor:

title: Katrina Victims in Mississippi Get More Aid
description: GULFPORT, Miss.  Federal and state officials and housing advocates announced on Monday the creation of a $133 million program to address housing problems that remain for poor Mississippi residents five years after Hurricane Katrina.

description: A slight bright side from losing, perhaps.

description: DETROIT  The sharp look and urgent words sent a clear message. Ray McCallum, the University of Detroit Mercy mens basketball coach, wanted his point guard to push the ball  now.

description: Jeff Sharlet, left, of Harper's and Amy Sullivan of Time debate Democratic losses with religious voters.

title: Opposition Growing to Bloomberg Pick for Schools
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been frank about why he took pains to keep his search for a new schools chancellor secret, saying he wanted to avoid a public spectacle.

title: Palestinian Blogger Angers West Bank Muslims
description: QALQILYA, West Bank  It is hard to imagine that a dingy Internet cafe buzzing with flies in this provincial Palestinian town could have spawned a blogger who has angered the Muslim cyberworld by promoting atheism, composing spoofs of Koranic verses, skewering the lifestyle of the Prophet Muhammad and chatting online using the sarcastic Web name God Almighty.

title: Cats Superior Drinking Habits Make Me Love Dogs
description: The news reported in Science magazine last week of the exquisite timing and elegant physics displayed by cats in their drinking habits has reinforced once again the obvious truth that cats are superior to sloppy-go-lucky dogs, and no doubt to people as well, at least the ones with whom I drink water (and I include myself). And that very superiority and elegance is yet another reason to have a dog as a pet  if, that is, there is anything wanting in your personal eating or housekeeping habits.

title: Juror Asks to Be Excused in Embassy Bombing Trial
description: A juror in the trial of the first former Guantnamo detainee tried in the civilian court system asked the judge to excuse her on Monday, saying she was alone in her view of the case and felt she was being attacked for my conclusion.

title: UConn Faces Baylor With Streak Intact but Five Freshmen
description: HARTFORD  When Connecticut last met Baylor, at the womens basketball Final Four in April, Tina Charles summoned her inner Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, while Brittney Griner mostly summoned her inner freshman.

title: Fred Goldhaber, 63, Dies; Taught at School for Gays
description: Among Mr. G.s first students back in 1985 were runaways who had been sleeping in a shed down by the docks in Lower Manhattan where the city stored mountains of road salt.

title: Clean Water at No Cost? Just Add Carbon Credits
description: In America, I turn on the faucet and out pours water. In much of the world, no such luck. Nearly a billion people dont have drinkable water. Lack of water  and the associated lack of toilets and proper hygiene  kills 3.3 million people a year, most of them children under five.

title: New York City Police Photograph Irises of Suspects
description: The New York Police Department has begun photographing the irises of people who are arrested in an effort to prevent escapes as suspects move through the court system, a police official said Monday.

description: For the next generation of Beatles fans, the wait could soon be over.

title: Phillies Again Give Sandberg Route to Majors
description: The plaques in the Baseball Hall of Fame are painstakingly specific. Directly under each players name is the complete list of his teams. You might not remember Warren Spahn as a Met or Eddie Murray as an Angel, but Cooperstown does.

title: Justice Thomass Wife May Be Exiting Advocacy Group
description: WASHINGTON  Liberty Central, the conservative organization founded last year by Virginia Thomas, the wife of Justice Clarence Thomas, appears to be confronting major changes, including the possibility that Ms. Thomas will step aside.

title: Google Search That Leads to Brand Marketing
description: A year ago, Google introduced a smartphone application that lets users take photos of objects and get search results in return. On Tuesday, the company will take that capability into the world of marketing with an experiment allowing five national brands to use the application in their promotional materials.

title: Try a Terrorist? The Politicians Turn Timid
description: An important anniversary for New Yorkers came and went over the weekend with barely a flicker of attention.

title: There Is No College Cost Crisis
description: There is no college cost crisis. That at least is the conclusion reached by the economists Robert B. Archibald and David H. Feldman in their new book, Why Does College Cost So Much? The title question is a teaser, for the books message is that it doesnt. In fact, say the authors, for most families higher education is more affordable than it was in the past.

title: Apple Said to Reach Agreement on Beatles Catalog
description: For the next generation of Beatles fans, the wait could soon be over.

title: Left, Right and Wrong on Taxes
description: GIVEN the furor from both the left and the right, one would be tempted to think that the initial proposal from the co-chairmen of President Obamas fiscal commission, Erskine Bowles and Alan Simpson, must offer an excellent starting point for a discussion of deficit reduction.

title: G.M. Rising: Who Should Get Credit?
description: Evan Agostini/AGOEV, via Associated Press Malcolm Gladwell credits a surprising person for G.M.s turnaround.

title: At Hearing, Rangel Follows Predecessors Path
description: The veteran congressman appeared before a House ethics panel that held his political future in its hands, but refused to testify because he claimed his constitutional protections had been abridged. Taken aback, members on the committee rebuked him, hurriedly adjourned behind closed doors and emerged vowing to complete their hearing with or without him.

title: G.M. Raises Price Range for Stock Sale
description: DETROIT  First it was the Ford Motor Company that convinced skeptical investors that the Detroit automakers could make big profits again.

title: Two Catholic Churches in Brooklyn Will Close
description: Facing a drop in attendance and a shortage of priests, the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn plans to close two churches, fold six parishes into three and impose strict budget constraints on all 198 of its parishes.

title: How to Kill the Meth Monster
description: Newport, Ore.

title: A Sputtering Start Tests Knicks Patience
description: The losses are accumulating, the discontent is deafening and now, at the Knicks latest low point, their presumed savior will greet them in the wrong place, at the wrong time, in the wrong uniform.

title: Lottery Numbers
Injured Cotchery Gains 10 Yards and Jets Praise
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Jets receiver Jerricho Cotchery was back on his feet Monday. He said he felt better than he did Sunday night, hours after he partly tore a groin muscle before making a reception that his teammates said was much more significant than a 10-yard gain.

title: This Raging Fire
description: When I was a kid my Uncle Robert, for whom I was named, used to say that blacks needed to fight on all fronts, at home and abroad.

title: In Russia, Jury Is Something to Work Around
description: MOSCOW  Iosif L. Nagle was watching a final curtain at his small theater company when he saw two young men waiting for him in the audience. They didnt look like patrons of the arts  something about their faces marked them as law enforcement  and Mr. Nagle bundled up and followed them out into the cold.

title: Slow Start Does Not Color Walshs View of DAntoni
description: Donnie Walsh, president of the Knicks, said it would be unfair to make any judgments on Coach Mike DAntoni based on the previous two seasons because of the frequently changing roster Walsh handed his coach. This season, after purging salary and failing to lure last summers biggest free agents, the roster is stabilized but the results have so far been the same.

title: Off-Duty Sergeant Shoots Man in Brooklyn
description: An off-duty police sergeant shot a man early Monday who tried to steal the sergeants motorcycle in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Despite Gains, Night Raids Split U.S. and Karzai
The Two Cultures
description: Many of the psychologists, artists and moral philosophers I know are liberal, so it seems strange that American liberalism should adopt an economic philosophy that excludes psychology, emotion and morality.

title: Giants Hope to End a History of Fading Down the Stretch
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In the wake of their humiliating 33-20 loss to the Dallas Cowboys on Sunday, the Giants have hit a familiar crossroads.

title: British Premier Plans Deep Cuts in Aid for Civil Litigants
description: LONDON  In its latest effort to cut public spending, Prime Minister David Camerons government took aim on Monday at Britains system of state-financed legal aid for litigants in civil cases  and, indirectly, at the countrys 150,000 lawyers.

title: Judge Withdraws Plea Deal for Probation in a Rape Case
description: The plea deal had been agreed upon; the rally protesting the expected sentence had been booked for lunchtime.

title: If It Werent Yellow, Youd Hardly Know It Was a Taxi
description: Lots of headroom, sloping picture windows, a spacious trunk and a roof resembling a top hat. Is this the new look of the New York City taxi?

title: Searching Your Laptop
description: Federal courts have long agreed that federal agents guarding the borders do not need a warrant or probable cause to search a travelers belongings. That exception to the Fourth Amendment needs updating and tightening to reflect the realities of the digital age.

title: Coffee Brandy Escapes Energy Drinks Troubles
description: BELFAST, Me.  Long before the combination of alcohol and caffeine in cans marketed as energy drinks created national concern about possible health hazards, there was Allens Coffee Flavored Brandy, the drink of choice for generations of Mainers.

title: Tuesday: Happy Pencil
description: The puzzles from yesterday and today have one thing in common. I found them both a hair more stubborn to solve than usual, although Im not entirely sure why that is.

title: Stand by Lebanon
description: Tensions have risen dangerously in Lebanon, as Syria, Iran and Hezbollah try to pressure Prime Minister Saad Hariri to repudiate an international investigation into the 2005 assassination of Mr. Hariris father, Rafik Hariri, a former prime minister. The inquiry is likely to issue indictments implicating Hezbollah, and perhaps its Syrian sponsors, in the crime.

title: Mr. Rangel Walks Out
description: The investigation of Representative Charles Rangel for violation of Congressional fund-raising rules has been going on for two years. The hearing before the House ethics committee  which Mr. Rangel insisted would exonerate him  has been scheduled for weeks. Yet on Monday, the day the hearing began, Mr. Rangel demanded a delay, claiming he needed to raise money for a new lawyer. When the committee refused, he walked out the door and into a new embarrassment.

title: Leaders Arrest Jolts a Maryland County
description: WASHINGTON  A federal bribery investigation continued to roil Prince Georges County, Md., on Monday, three days after the authorities arrested its county executive, Jack B. Johnson, on charges of taking bribes, and his wife, Leslie Johnson, on charges of flushing evidence down the toilet.

title: Two Easy Moves for the Lame Duck
description: The lame-duck Congress has a lot of work to do, including wrestling with the Bush-era tax cuts, repealing the Pentagons discriminatory dont ask, dont tell policy, and ratifying the New Start arms reduction treaty. It also needs to approve two food-related measures that are badly needed to protect the nations health. The good news is that a version of each has already passed one chamber, and both have strong bipartisan support.

title: Conflict of Interest Is Cited in Steroid Case Dismissal
description: In a sharp rebuke of the Albany County district attorney, a state judge on Monday dismissed a criminal case against the operators of a pharmacy in Florida at the center of a national steroid scandal that implicated major sports figures.

title: Image Rights vs. Free Speech in Video Game Suit
description: When Sam Keller, a former quarterback at Arizona State, sued the video game publisher Electronic Arts last year, he was seeking compensation for himself and other college athletes whose names were not used but whose images he contended were being illegally used by the company.

title: With Tea Party in Mind, Republicans Have Change of Heart About Earmarks
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Republicans opened the lame-duck session of Congress on Monday by signaling their commitment to the antispending posture that fueled their big gains on Election Day, underscoring the Tea Party movements influence on the Republican leadership.

title: Still Mourning, Alderson Visits the G.M. Meetings
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  With a heavy heart and a businesslike resolve, Sandy Alderson reported to work Monday, honoring his commitment to the Mets in general and to Jose Oquendo specifically. Less than two days after learning that his father had been killed in a traffic accident, Alderson arrived at Major League Baseballs general managers meeting for a scheduled interview with Oquendo for the Mets field managers job.

title: Luis Garca Berlanga, Spanish Filmmaker, Dies at 89
description: Luis Garca Berlanga, an influential Spanish filmmaker who tweaked the fascist regime of Gen. Francisco Franco and its censors with shrewdly subversive social satires, died on Saturday in Madrid. He was 89.

title: The Islanders, Losers of 10 Straight, Fire Their Coach
description: The Islanders 10th straight loss Saturday also turned out to be Scott Gordons final game as the coach. He was replaced before practice Monday by Jack Capuano, who coached the Islanders top farm team, the Sound Tigers, an American Hockey League club in Bridgeport, Conn.

title: Rangers Fall Apart, Then Bounce Back
description: PITTSBURGH  It was one of the wildest finishes in the Rangers 84-year history. In the blink of an eye, they clung to a one-goal lead, lost it, then seemed to lose the game, then tied it  all in the last 2 minutes 31 seconds of regulation.

title: Sanders Tells Regulators to Block Comcast-NBC Deal
description: Comcast is expected to announce a new management lineup for NBC Universal as soon as Wednesday, in anticipation of completing its takeover of the company by the end of the year or early next year.

title: Obama Picks a Director for the A.T.F.
description: Nearly two years into his term, President Obama on Monday finally chose a director for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives. Mr. Obama will submit the name of Andrew Traver, the special agent in charge of the bureaus Chicago field division, to the Senate for consideration, the White House said. He may face a confirmation fight; after Congress changed the position to make it one requiring Senate confirmation, President George W. Bushs nominee was blocked by senators who used it to criticize the enforcement of gun laws against firearms dealers.

title: How Clickers Work
description: At Northwestern University and on hundreds of other campuses, professors are arming students with hand-held clickers that look like a TV remote cross-bred with a calculator. Here is how they work:

title: Ability Seen in Toddlers to Judge Others Intent
description: Understanding anothers intent is an important skill for lawyers, and perhaps politicians and businessmen as well, but according to a new study, it is an ability that even toddlers have.

title: Voices of Foreclosure Speak Daily About Desperation and Misery
description: SIMI VALLEY, Calif.  If the mortgage mess had an address, it could be 450 American Way.

title: Under Attack, Fed Officials Defend Buying of Bonds
description: With the Federal Reserve under attack at home and abroad, it is making an unusual public bid to keep itself away from the political crossfire.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Word of the Day | sardonic
description: sardonic \sr-d-nik\ adjective

title: Murkowski Officially Ahead in Alaska
description: Since Election Day, the leading candidate in the Alaska Senate race had been Write-in Votes. That changed on Monday, when a new candidate moved ahead: Senator Lisa Murkowski.

title: Foreclosures Raise New Concerns About Banks, Panel Says
description: The foreclosure documentation crisis could have severe consequences for the housing market and economy, a Congressional panel warns in a report scheduled to be released Tuesday.

title: New Delhi Building Collapses
description: Rescuers rushed to pull survivors from the remains of a four-story apartment building that collapsed in a New Delhi neighborhood.

title: Delhi Building Collapse Tied to Bad Construction
description: NEW DELHI  Rescue workers searched frantically on Tuesday through the rubble of a five-story tenement a day after it collapsed, killing at least 64 people, many of them migrant workers from eastern Indias countryside.

title: News Quiz | November 16, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Free at Last
description: WHO is Daw Aung San Suu Kyi?

title: Russian Arrives in U.S. to Face Arms Charges
description: BANGKOK  Thailand extradited Viktor Bout, a Russian accused of arms trafficking, to the United States on Tuesday, abandoning the diplomatic balancing act it had conducted for more than two years between Washington and Moscow.

title: Daily Lexeme: Froppish
description: Todays word, in association with the first-class Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Voices of Foreclosure Speak Daily About Desperation
description: If the mortgage mess had an address, it could be 450 American Way.

title: Test Yourself | English, Nov. 16, 2010
description: Test your vocabulary skills with todays question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the Times article Kindness of a Stranger That Still Resonates.

title: How Should Parents Handle a Bad Report Card?
description: Thats the question the Motherlode blog asked adults last week, and now were asking you. How do your parents react to your report cards? Do you think you should be punished in some way for bad grades? Rewarded for good ones? How?

title: Britain to Compensate Former Guantnamo Detainees
description: LONDON  Bidding to restore the reputations of MI5 and MI6 and to rebuild damaged intelligence links with the United States, the British government said on Tuesday that it had agreed to pay compensation running into millions of dollars to 15 former detainees at Guantnamo Bay and one man still held there who have accused Britains intelligence agencies of colluding in their torture in the American-run detention system.

title: Photographing Choleras Awful Toll in Haiti
description: If you thought that Emilio Morenatti would have had enough of the worlds hot spots after he lost his left foot in a roadside bomb attack in Afghanistan 15 months ago, then youre not thinking like a photojournalist.

title: Clan in Philippines Accused of More Killings
description: MANILA  Members of a powerful political clan in the southern Philippines whose leaders have been charged in the massacre of 57 people last November are implicated in dozens of other killings dating back decades, Human Rights Watch alleged in a report released Tuesday.

title: E.U. Talks on Budget for 2011 Deadlock Again
description: BRUSSELS  The breakdown of talks on a European Union budget for 2011 could threaten some of the work of the blocs new financial supervisors and of its diplomatic service, members of the European Parliament and officials said Tuesday.

title: Vallar to Invest in Indonesian Mining
description: Vallar, the publicly traded investment vehicle set up by Nathaniel Rothschild, says it intends to spend $3 billion purchasing 25 percent of the shares of Bumi Resources, and 75 percent of Berau Coal Energy, Indonesias largest and fifth-largest coal producers respectively.

title: Economics Offers Tactics, Not Strategy
description: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

title: Beyond Paris Photo, Fringe Exhibitions
description: Though the Paris photo season culminates in the prestigious Paris Photo show at the Carousel du Louvre, no fewer than 100 more modest, but no less intriguing, events are also scheduled, scattered across the city. A handy, pocket-sized guide to these fringe shows, Mois de la Photo Off, can be picked up in any of the galleries taking part. This booklet proposes itineraries by district, on specific dates, leading to offbeat places and discoveries  and a drink if youre lucky. For those without access to the booklet, here are some highlights of the fringe photo fairs.

title: The Early Word: The Trouble With Earmarks
description: From Todays Times:

title: A Defense of the Electronic Mortgage System
description: The American Securitization Forum, a trade group that lobbies for the industry that managed to convert subprime mortgages into a financial crisis, released a report on Tuesday defending how those home loans were made into bonds and more explosive financial instruments.

title: Q&A: Mapping Out an Update Plan
description: Q.

title: Baidu Struggled in China, Too
description: Google failed in China because it did not understand the Chinese Internet market, not because the playing field was unfairly tilted against it, said Robin Li, the chief executive of Baidu, the Chinese search engine that dominates in China.

title: Dianas Ring Seals Prince Williams Marriage Plans
description: LONDON  Years of fevered anticipation and premature speculation ended on Tuesday morning when Prince William, the heir to the heir to the British throne, said that, yes, he did plan to marry his girlfriend of many years, Kate Middleton.

title: 100, 75, 50 Years Ago
description: 1910 England Welcomes U.S Fleet

title: Fire Trips Alarms About Chinas Building Boom; Censors Respond
description: BEIJING  A day after a devastating fire gutted a 28-story Shanghai apartment tower, China faced angry questions on Tuesday about whether this nations breakneck construction boom had sown the seeds of similar accidents in years to come.

title: Sarah Kane Still Shocks, Athol Fugard Rages Anew
description: LONDON  Can you go home again?

title: Handel's Enchantress Makes an Entrance
description: VIENNA  Handels operas are now so thoroughly a part of modern musical life that you might think every major opera house welcomes them. But until last Sunday, when it introduced an absorbing new production of Alcina, the Vienna Staatsoper resisted them, not having done a Baroque opera since Monteverdis Poppea in the 1960s.

title: In Sports, a Boost for Rural Indian Women
description: NEW DELHI  The stories come in from all over India. In the northeastern state of Manipur, Mary Koms boxing academy gets queries every week from young girls in the insurgency-torn region who hope to train with Ms. Kom and emulate her achievements as World Boxing Champion.

title: Meet the New Small-Business Owners in Congress
description: In the class of 2008, there were 11. Last Tuesdays elections will send 33 small-business owners and entrepreneurs to Washington, according to The Agendas exhaustive (and exhausting) search. All are Republicans. Two are women.

title: Steve Young Says Vicks Performance Was Transformational
description: From 1991 to 1997, Steve Young led the N.F.L. in passer rating in each year but one. He also kept defenses on edge with his skill as a runner.

title: Growth Overseas Lifts Wal-Mart Profit
description: The tepid economic recovery does not seem to be extending to many of Wal-Marts customers in the United States, lower-income consumers who are not yet spending. The nations largest retailer reported Tuesday that sales in its American stores open at least a year, a crucial measure of retail health, had declined for the sixth consecutive quarter.

title: McCain, Who Battled Earmarks, Watches Others Ban Them
description: There is almost nothing that Senator John McCain of Arizona talked more about during his 2008 campaign for president than his desire to eliminate budget earmarks.

title: Genius Has Company in Messi and Ronaldo
description: LONDON

title: Something Is Expensive in the State of Denmark
description: Bang & Olufsen has a proud tradition of high-design audio equipment. In the 1980s, nothing came close to the Danish companys sleek BeoCenter phonograph systems. (Nakamichi was in the running, but they followed a different aesthetic chunkier, more brutalist than B&Os Modernist slickness.)

title: Number Trouble
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: Number Trouble
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: To Help With a Diagnosis, Software That Spots Patterns
description: Autonomy, Britains largest software maker, is an intriguing company. Founded in 1996, Autonomy traces its origins to research done by its co-founders, Michael Lynch and Richard Gaunt, computer scientists from the University of Cambridge. The companys software technology is adept at making inferences based on probabilities as it sifts through all kinds of data, not just in databases, but also text, e-mail, Web pages, voice and video  so-called unstructured data.

title: Why Are We Going Blind in Space?
description: It has got to be the coolest student job on the planet  or for that matter, in the solar system.

title: Healthy Capitalism
description: I applaud Nicholas Kristof for decrying the disturbing levels of inequality that exist in the United States (Another banana republic, Views, Nov. 10). But I wish he would have pointed out that a major cause of this economic polarization is the weakness of the nations labor movement. It is no coincidence that it was in the mid-1970s that the U.S. began to move toward becoming a less equal society; this is the same time that the labor movement was weakened by corporations. Until the U.S. labor movement gets better organized, the economic polarization will likely continue.

title: Pressure Grows on Ireland to Accept Rescue From Europe
description: With its political survival at stake, the Irish government was locked in discussions with its European partners and the International Monetary Fund on Tuesday over a financial rescue package intended to support Irelands failed banks, a top official from the European Union said.

title: Boies Schiller Dismisses 3 Lawyers
description: Three lawyers who until recently worked at Boies, Schiller & Flexner, the firm founded by the famed trial lawyer David Boies, have had a tough couple of weeks.

title: Shares Drop on Wall Street Amid Global Worries
description: Worries about Europes debt crisis and possible moves by the authorities in Asia to slow fast-paced growth there swept the worlds markets on Tuesday and pushed stocks in the United States sharply lower.

title: Alec Baldwin Is Mark Twain: Reports of His Depth Have Been Greatly Exaggerated
description: Among the fun facts we learned about Mark Twain from PBSs broadcast honoring Tina Fey as the 2010 recipient of the Kennedy Centers Mark Twain Prize for American Humor: they didnt call him Samuel Langhorne Clemens for nothing (thank you very much, Betty White), and the quintessential American satirist and creator of Tom Sawyer and Huckleberry Finn bore a remarkable resemblance to Ms. Feys 30 Rock co-star Alec Baldwin. (Hes also eerily familiar with modern technology.) But in a world where Tracy Morgan and Thomas Jefferson are dead ringers, we suppose anythings possible.

title: Murkowski Says Palin Lacks Intellectual Curiosity
description: 8:51 p.m. | Updated

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Who will foreclose on the foreclosers? In the case of David Sterns notorious Florida law firm, it was Bank of America that came knocking.

title: Studies Find Success in Use of Privacy Icons
description: One of the biggest areas of contention in the online privacy debate is whether online advertisers have the ability to regulate themselves sufficiently. Privacy advocates claim that privacy policies are not enough to inform consumers about an advertisers data collection practices because they are complex documents that users dont read.

title: Are the Jets Great or Just Good?
description: Chase Stuart contributes to the Pro-Football-Reference.com blog and to Footballguys.com.

title: Digital Keys for Unlocking the Humanities Riches
description: A history of the humanities in the 20th century could be chronicled in isms  formalism, Freudianism, structuralism, postcolonialism  grand intellectual cathedrals from which assorted interpretations of literature, politics and culture spread.

title: Digitally Mapping the Republic of Letters
description: As the historian Dan Edelstein explains in the video above, he and his colleagues have used todays digital technology to reconstruct the network of Enlightenment correspondence that linked thinkers like Locke, Voltaire and Rousseau.

title: Up at the Villa
description: At summers end, for more than a century, a group of Americans have traveled to a hilltop in Rome. They are invariably an eclectic bunch  scholars of antiquity, architects nursing ambitious projects, artists and designers of various disciplines  who have each been selected to spend a year living at the American Academy in Rome, a lush compound overlooking the citys storied spires and ancient basilicas. Known as the Rome Prize, the fellowship is considered one of the most prestigious and envy-inducing within the world of the humanities and fine arts.

title: A Royal Wedding in the Age of Austerity
description: Updated | 4:34 p.m.  As my colleague Sarah Lyall reports, Britains royal family announced on Tuesday that Prince William, the heir to the heir of the British throne, plans to marry his longtime girlfriend, Kate Middleton, next year.

title: Drug Companies Pursue Personalized Medicine Approach
description: Personalized medicine  often described as providing the right drug to the right patient at the right time  has long been considered an ideal. But it is also a threat to some pharmaceutical companies wedded to the idea of blockbuster drugs that could be taken by potentially all patients with a given disease.

title: The Mirror of the Soul Confirms the ID, Too
description: The New York Police Department has begun photographing the irises of people who are arrested in an effort to prevent escapes as suspects move through the court system. [NYT] The new program was instituted after two prisoners arrested on serious charges tricked authorities into freeing them by posing at arraignment as suspects facing minor cases. (Also see The Daily News and The New York Post .)

title: Climate Skeptic Seeks Energy Committee Chairmanship
description: In January, the Republican Party will take control of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, giving the new majority considerable influence over federal energy policy and climate change regulation and legislation. By virtue of seniority, Fred Upton of Michigan is considered the likeliest candidate to head the committee.

title: Wendell August Forge
description: A fire destroyed this metals design gift store in Pennsylvania, but the owner was able to rebuild in a matter of months. He credits the rapid turnaround to Christianity and community support.

title: Shorter Limit to Limited Run: La Bte to Close Five Weeks Early
description: After bombing on Broadway the first time around in 1991, David Hirsons play La Bte has fared better with the critics and at the box office in its current revival, yet has not emerged as the smash hit that the producers had hoped for. They announced on Monday night that the revival would close on Jan. 9, five weeks ahead of schedule.

title: Pai Ma Pi
description: Chinese term used to describe flattering those in a position of power  literally, stroking the horses bottom.

title: Carroll Wins England Call-Up Despite Barroom Bust-Up
description: A week after we asked who would provide goals for a defanged England team against a still sputtering France, Manager Fabio Capello offered an answer: Andy Carroll will get his first cap for the national team after a goal-drenched start to the Premier League season. The Newcastle striker will be one of three debutants for England at Wembley on Nov. 17. Carroll will be supported in midfield by Jordan Henderson of Sunderland while Arsenal defender Kieran Gibbs makes his first start.

title: 55 Questions for Students
Hudson Tunnels Demise Cheers Some Businesses
description: As someone who designs fancy hats for women to wear to horse races, Christine A. Moore says she tends to see the silver lining in everything.

title: A Mechanical Manifesto
description: So David Brooks claims that

title: Irelands Big Mistake
description: Ive been thinking about the ongoing Irish mess, and I suddenly realized the true nature of Irelands big mistake.

title: Tuesday Reading: The Rising Number of Uninsured
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Apple Begins Selling Beatles Downloads
description: After years of stalled negotiations, the effort to bring the Beatles music into the download age finally began to come together on July 14  Bastille Day.

title: Nissan Will Sell 500,000 Electric Cars a Year by 2013, Says Chief
description: On the eve of the market debut of the Nissan Leaf electric car, Carlos Ghosn, chief executive of the Renault-Nissan alliance, said the only constraint on sales for the next three years will be how many battery packs the factories could churn out.

title: Beatles for Sale: Heres What Youll Pay
description: As expected, Apple has announced that the Beatles music is finally up for sale.

title: Sunny Predictions for the Electric Car Market
description: The chief executive of the Renault-Nissan alliance predicts that sales of the Nissan Leaf will reach 500,000 units a year in 2013, Matt Wald reports on the Wheels blog.

title: Where Did God Go in Afghanistan? An Atheist Writes.
description: Kathleen Johnson is the Vice President of American Atheists and founder of the Military Association of Atheists and Freethinkers. She is a veteran of the Iraq and Afghanistan conflicts and retired as a First Sergeant after more than 20 years service. She is now a Department of the Army civilian. This is her response to the At War post Where Did God Go in Afghanistan? by Capt. Michael Cummings.

title: Wary of Demanding Lead Role, Spider-Man Producers Eye Use of Backup
description: The producers of the coming Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark are planning to tap the cast member Matthew James Thomas to serve as an alternate for the leading man, Reeve Carney, in the role of Peter Parker/Spider-Man for as many as two performances a week after the show opens, executives involved with the production said on Tuesday.

title: Michelin Stars Come Out for Chicago, a Day Early
description: The Michelin guides inspectors are supposed to surprise restaurateurs. But in Chicago it was Michelin officials who were most surprised, after a user on Yelp, who claimed to have received the guide early, revealed the companys star ratings for the city on Monday, about two days before they were to be announced.

title: Obama Should Focus On Executive Powers, Liberal Group Says
description: President Obama should refocus his administration to concentrate on executive actions he can take independent of Congress, after two years in which voters have become disgusted with the sausage-makingof legislation, according to a report released today by a liberal policy group.

title: Fete Accompli | Model Behavior
description: Celebrities, schmlebrities. Models can still draw in a crowd. Witness the event Model Behavior, held on Friday at Christies for the nonprofit organization One Frickin Day. The idea was to ask some of the worlds top models to donate one dress they have worn on the red carpet, says the co-founder and model Elettra Wiedemann. The money raised goes towards buying solar panels and equipment for clinics in Haiti and Rwanda.

title: Dolan Chosen as President of U.S. Bishops Group
description: BALTIMORE  The United States Conference of Catholic Bishops elected Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan of New York to be its president on Tuesday in a surprise move that reaffirmed the conservative direction of the Roman Catholic Church in America.

title: After Cracking Down on Debt Collectors, New York State Is Now Set to Hire Them
description: In these hard times, New Yorks future governor, Andrew M. Cuomo, has made a point of standing alongside consumers who are down on their luck. As attorney general, he conducted a statewide crackdown on debt collectors who ran afoul of consumer protection laws, and his office encouraged consumers with their own tales of woe to contact it.

title: Never Interview on a Cloudy Tuesday; Its Bad Luck
description: As the private school admissions process rolls into full gear, so, too, does the parental rumor mill, churning out dubious claims about the meaning of each move a school makes as the anxious mothers and fathers of applicants seek to read the tea leaves of their childs academic future.

title: For Treasury, a Hidden Cost for Helping G.M.
description: Ive somewhat modified my contention that the government had done nothing in the automotive bankruptcy cases that secured lenders had not been doing for years.

title: The Rookies Are Coming
description: Weve reached the point in the season when many teams are looking to reshape their rosters. And with trades tough to come by and virtually no talent available via free agency, that means hockey fans can expect to start seeing some rookies called up over the next few weeks.

title: Los Angeles Auto Show: New Models and New Lineups
description: LOS ANGELES  Automobile shows are usually about introducing new models. The script is changing for this years Los Angeles Auto Show in that some brands  Chrysler, Dodge and Lotus among them  are wiping the slate clean and introducing new lineups.

title: Hospital Errors Plague Medicare Patients
description: The Times reports this morning on a study finding that one of every seven Medicare beneficiaries who is hospitalized is harmed as a result of problems with the medical care there. These errors affect 180,000 patients annually and cost the government $4.4 billion a year.

title: Paul Calello of Credit Suisse Dies at 49
description: 2:51 p.m. | Updated Paul Calello, the chairman of the investment bank at Credit Suisse Group who helped navigate the Swiss bank through the financial crisis, died on Tuesday at his home in Brooklyn Heights. He was 49.

title: Senate Leader Deals Blow to President on Arms Treaty
description: President Obamas hopes of ratifying a new arms control treaty with Russia this year appeared to unravel on Tuesday as a Senate Republican leader moved to block a vote in what could be a devastating blow to the presidents most tangible foreign policy achievement.

title: Google Sees Rules Violations in Limits on Internet Access
description: With China evidently in its sights, Google has released a policy paper contending that countries that limit Internet users access to information providers outside their borders violate their World Trade Organization commitments.

title: Rangels Ethics Violations
description: Updated, 12:47 p.m. | A House ethics panel has convicted Representative Charles B. Rangel of all but one of the 13 ethics violations he faced, for offenses ranging from accepting a rent-stabilized apartment from a Manhattan developer to failing to pay taxes on rental income from his Dominican villa to raising charitable donations from companies and corporate executives who had business before the committee he led.

title: McNabb Extension Raises Questions and Eyebrows
description: In todays scandal-a-minute age, its difficult to produce truly surprising news in sports, the kind that makes you rub your eyes and ask everyone within earshot whether you could possibly be reading it right. Sadly, even most mayhem does not register on the shock meter. Massive marital infidelity by Mr. Perfect? An eyeroll, at most. In that vein, the Redskins performed something truly remarkable on Monday, stopping the sports world in its tracks, if only momentarily.

title: Billy Reid, Designer, Wins Major Fashion Award
description: When the actress Carey Mulligan announced last night that Billy Reid had been voted the winner of the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund winner for 2010  in front of a crowd that included the designers Michael Kors, Olivier Theyskens, Jason Wu, Zac Posen and Alexander Wang; the True Blood stars Stephen Moyer and Anna Paquin; the ubiquitous Kim Kardashian; and the evenings co-chairwoman Anna Wintour, the editor of Vogue  there was a brief, seemingly stunned silence, followed by a burst of enthusiastic applause and whoops and hollers from the back of the room, from which the 46-year-old designer shakily made his way toward the stage.

title: More Sideline Fireworks in Detroit
description: Yes, youve heard this before: Pistons starting forward Tayshaun Prince and Coach John Kuester are arguing.

title: Sam Gold, Director of Circle Mirror, Joins the Roundabout Team
description: Sam Gold, the director of two Off Broadway productions that received major praise last season, Annie Bakers plays Circle Mirror Transformation and The Aliens, has been named an associate artist of Roundabout Theater Company, where he directed its current black box hit Tigers Be Still. That production has been extended through Nov. 28 but is now sold out, Roundabout said on Tuesday in a statement announcing Mr. Golds appointment.

title: Rangel Violated Ethics Rules, Committee Finds
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, was found to have violated 11 of the 13 ethics charges against him, a Congressional panel announced today after deliberating for less than 24 hours.

title: The State of the Mets, According to Paterson
description: Gov. David A. Paterson knows a thing or two about facing a crisis, and more than a few things about his favorite baseball team, the Mets, who have been in crisis mode since their colossal collapse in September 2007. Last Thursday, Mr. Paterson, attending a fund-raising event in Harlem, gave his 2010 Postseason State of the Mets address to an audience of one reporter.

title: Israel Exempts E.U. Pilots From Security Program
description: An Israeli security program that requires commercial pilots on airlines from some countries, including the United States, to transmit special identification clearance codes before entering Israels airspace will not be enforced on pilots with airlines based in the European Union, aviation officials say.

title: New Details on McNabbs Contract
description: Donovan McNabb isnt necessarily the Washington Redskins quarterback of the future after all, ESPN has reported - and it has nothing to do with the Redskins implosion against the Philadelphia Eagles on Monday night.

title: Danish Bakery Chains Turn Carbohydrates to Gold
description: COPENHAGEN  In Denmark, a country famed for its pastry, baking is serious business. And in recent years, two bakery chains, Lagkagehuset  which translates as The Cake House  and Emmerys, have proved that in hard economic times carbohydrates are as good as gold here .

title: Trout Serving in America
description: Yes, officer, I was going too fast. Im sorry. I have to get to Iaconos before they close and I wasnt paying attention.

title: Owner of Lipstick Building Seeks to Reorganize
description: The owner of the landmark Lipstick Building in Manhattan  also known as ground zero for the $65 billion Ponzi scheme of Bernard L. Madoff  filed for Chapter 11 reorganization on Monday.

title: 2010 CFDA Awards
description: The fashion set gathered for the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund awards at Skylight Studios in New York.

title: A Social Experiment and a Failed Blog-to-Book Proposal
description: Facebook may have e-mail now, but in Upper Manhattan the real social media development on Monday was the start of the social experiment at Columbia University.

title: Previewing the L.A. Auto Show
description: A glance at some of the notable cars to be shown at the 2010 auto show in Los Angeles.

title: A Poet Well Versed in Grief
description: Born to a family who ran a funeral home in small-town Michigan, the poet Thomas Lynch began pondering aging and death at a young age, as a child leafing through the gory pages of his fathers mortician texts.

title: On Our Radar: Diesel Shortage Hits China
description: Surging demand for diesel fuel leads to shortages of the fuel throughout China. The Chinese government is rationing electricity with the goal of meeting energy efficiency and environmental goals by the end of the year, spurring demand for diesel-powered generators. [Financial Times]

title: First Look | Bergdorfs Holiday Windows
description: On Monday afternoon, Bergdorf Goodmans display guru David Hoey gave The Moment an exclusive peek at the department stores holiday windows, which wont be unveiled until later this week. As Hoey drew up the heavy tarps covering each of them, a crowd of flash-happy tourists appeared (not to mention our very own Bill Cunningham, who was on the street, as is his wont). Still works in progress, the windows are being pored over by a team of artists. Hoey oversees the whole production, the culmination of a years efforts, and he often can be seen on Fifth Avenue, instructing his minions. Can they hear him through all that glass? If I stand exactly at 14-and-a-half inches from the window, the glass becomes a natural megaphone and they can hear me perfectly, he says. This year the windows are dedicated not so much to the act of travel as the fantasies that trip-taking might engender: flying horses, flying machines, and a journey to the moon. Bergdorfs best windows over the past two decades are collected in a new $550 hand-made book by Assouline, part of its exquisitely crafted Ultimate Collection, which weighs a ton and goes on sale this week at Bergdorf and bergdorfgoodman.com.

title: New Senate Leadership, a Lot Like the Old
description: New Congress! Same leaders. More or less, anyway.

title: When Parents Intervene With Bullying
description: Two reports from around the country raise the question: How far should a parent go when their child is bullied?

title: House Panel Finds Rangel Guilty
description: A House panel on Tuesday found Representative Charles B. Rangel guilty of 11 counts of ethical violations, ruling that his failure to pay some taxes, improper solicitation of charitable donations and failure to accurately report his personal income had brought dishonor on the House.

title: Army-Notre Dame Stirs Yankee Stadium Ghosts
description: To understand how universally significant the Yankee Stadium football games between Army and Notre Dame once were, it is worth revisiting World War IIs Battle of the Bulge. During the winter of 1944-45 in Belgium, American troops were surrounded and being infiltrated by English-speaking German spies dressed as American soldiers.

title: TimesCast | November 16, 2010
description: Rangel found guilty; medal of honor awarded to a living soldier and The Beatles come to iTunes.

title: New Voting System for Hall May Benefit Steinbrenner
description: Thirteen days after George Steinbrenners death in July, the National Baseball Hall of Fame altered the procedures for voting on executives, managers, umpires and longtime retired players by its veterans committee in a way that seemed to favor the Bosss swift election next month.

title: Boeing and Airbus Waver on Reworking Their Smaller Jets
description: The latest high-stakes maneuvering by Boeing and Airbus does not involve their top-of-the-line models, the 787 Dreamliner and the A380 jumbo jet, but instead their aging smaller workhorses.

title: Sasha Frere-Jones, New Yorkers Music Critic, Will Be Editor at News Corp.s iPad Newspaper
description: Sasha Frere-Jones, a music critic at The New Yorker, will become the culture editor of The Daily, the News Corporations so-called iPad newspaper, which is in development, according to two people involved in the project who did not speak for the record because the hiring had not been announced. Mr. Frere-Jones had no comment.

title: The Renault F1 Title Victories
description: With all the praise for the Red Bull chassis designed by Adrian Newey and for Sebastian Vettel, the young man who drove the chassis to the drivers title, there is a little something that has been taking bows in the wings, a little invisible to the audience, it seems to me.

title: The Renault F1 Title Victories
description: With all the praise for the Red Bull chassis designed by Adrian Newey and for Sebastian Vettel, the young man who drove the chassis to the drivers title, there is a little something that has been taking bows in the wings, a little invisible to the audience, it seems to me.

title: Fete Accompli | RxArt 10th Anniversary
description: The powers that be and spree came out for RxArts 10th anniversary celebration Monday night at the Art Directors Club. The organization, started by Diane Brown in 2000, helps to bring original art work into health care facilities around the country. Brown, a former private dealer and indefatigable force, has enlisted the likes of Jeff Koons, Rob Pruitt and Will Cotton to create art that inspires and gives hope to patients, families and medical staff alike. Her do-gooding paid off as a glittery crowd of artists and A-listers including James Franco, Terry Richardson, Jenny Shimuzu and the multitasking Simon de Pury, who D.Jed and served as the events auctioneer, showed up to imbibe and bid on some impressive works of art. All for a very good cause, indeed.

title: Yahoo Adds Daily Deals
description: Yahoo is joining the bandwagon of local daily deals. On Tuesday, Yahoo said that it teamed with more than 20 daily deal sites  including Groupon, the best known among them  to make the offers available to Yahoos millions of users.

title: Merchants of Misery
description: The attack on the Fed for having the temerity to actually try to do something about the economy continues. Now Republican politicians are pointing out that the Fed has failed to reduce unemployment  and therefore, it should no longer even try to do anything about unemployment, and focus only on price stability. And this makes sense because .?

title: Packard Factorys Last Tenant Soon to Leave
description: DETROIT  A city long pockmarked by the hulks of shuttered factories will soon get another one when the giant, historic Packard plant loses its last tenant.

title: American Speech: A Dozen with a Black Cat, a Pair of Hobos and a Fin (1960)
description: by Jessie Ryon Lucke, North Texas State College

title: Knicks President Has Hip Surgery
description: Donnie Walsh, the Knicks team president, had surgery to repair his right hip Tuesday morning and is expected to spend a few days in the hospital before starting a rehabilitation program at home.

title: The Sandwich Generation: A Live Event
description: Your Moneys coverage of the unique problems facing the sandwich generation  those stuck financially supporting both aging parents and adult children  continues with a live event at the New York Times building on Dec. 1.

title: Art that Looks Backward
description: A New York University photography professor will have a camera surgically implanted in the back of his head for several months as part of an art project commissioned by the government of Qatar, The Wall Street Journal reported. The project, called The 3rd I and organized by a new Qatari museum called Mathaf: Arab Museum of Modern Art, will involve the camera taking pictures at one-minute intervals with the images being streamed to a computer database and then appearing in different sequences, some in real time, on monitors in an exhibition space in Doha between December and May.

title: Bush and Cheney Reunite at Library Groundbreaking
description: DALLAS  Joined by an all-star cast from his days in the White House, former President George W. Bush plunged a shovel into dirt on Tuesday and kicked off construction of his presidential library.

title: Difficult Issues Clamor for Advocates Attention
description: BANGKOK  The jubilant throngs that greeted Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the pro-democracy leader, this past weekend in Myanmar confirmed that her huge popularity remains intact. But as she steps gingerly back into the swirl of political combat, she confronts difficult realities that will limit her ability to translate that popularity into fundamental change.

title: U.P.S. Impostor Seeks to Take, Not Deliver, Police Say
description: Sign here, please  and then stick em up.

title: Turnover on the First Ladys Staff
description: Midterm staff turnover hits the first ladys office: Michelle Obamas chief of staff, Susan Sher, is returning to Chicago after the first of the year, the White House announced on Tuesday.

title: Winter Sonata
Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Bangladesh, Guinea and Britain.

title: Q&A: Fiftieth Birthday in British Virgin Islands
description: My wife and I are going to the British Virgin Islands in January for my 50th birthday. Were bare boating a 47 catamaran and have several couples onboard. What are the do not miss party spots around the islands as well as adventures that we must do?

title: Bruins Goalie Tim Thomas Back on Track
description: Maybe its an every-other-year thing with Boston Bruins goalie Tim Thomas.

title: Climate Lessons From a Master Mediator
description: I got to know Ted Kheel over the final decade of his remarkable life, which ended at age 96 on Sunday. To get a sense of the man and his accomplishments, including his mediation of tens of thousands of disputes (thats not a typo), read The Times obituary and click on the brief Last Word discussion above, in which he discusses the core challenge of conflict resolution.

title: Blackstone Raises Its Offer for Dynegy
description: Nov. 17, 8:11 a.m. | Updated Dynegy said on Wednesday that it has accepted Blackstones new $5-a-share offer and urged shareholders to approve the deal. The new proposal carries a $16.3 million breakup fee. Shareholders are set to vote on the deal at 11 a.m. Eastern time.

title: I Was Deprived of Due Process
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel released a statement Tuesday afternoon deploring a Congressional panel for convicting him of 11 ethics violations after a hearing conducted in his absence. Mr. Rangel walked out of the hearing Monday morning minutes after it began, saying that he could not afford a lawyer. Here is his statement, unabridged:

title: Nicole Kidman Renting Out West Village Condo
description: The actress Nicole Kidman has listed her West Village condominium for rent for $45,000 a month. The full-floor apartment is in the south tower of Richard Meiers two Perry Street buildings, the architects first foray into Manhattan residential real estate.

title: Iran Calls German Journalists Spies for Reporting on Stoning Case
description: As Reuters reports, an Iranian judiciary official said on Tuesday that two German reporters, who had traveled to Iran posing as tourists to interview the son of a woman sentenced to death by stoning, have been charged with espionage.

title: Glee Reality Show Sets Its Casting Calls and Ground Rules
description: If your fondest aspiration in show business is a recurring role on Glee you could pursue it by toiling for years in semi-obscurity until you finally catch the attention of Ryan Murphy. Or, if youre more the instant-gratification type, you could try out for The Glee Project, an Oxygen reality series that was announced over the summer and which on Tuesday revealed the dates and locations for its open casting calls as well as its eligibility requirements.

title: Macys Wants to Wake Up Black Friday
description: As retailers gear up to woo budget-conscious consumers for the holiday season, the traditional distinctions between discount and department stores are getting fuzzier.

title: Week 11 in Fantasy Football: The Waiver Wire
description: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 11. Check back on Thursday for their weekly matchup analysis and their reader Q. & A. and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

title: New York State Ranks Last for Voter Turnout
description: Despite contests for every statewide office for the first time in decades, a smaller share of eligible voters turned out two weeks ago in New York than in any other state. New York turnout was lower than in any midterm election for at least three decades.

title: What Were Reading
description: Manhattan Users Guide: In tiny yellow letters, the Web sites hot list of restaurants open on Thanksgiving in Manhattan and Brooklyn  Glenn Collins

title: Apple and the Beatles: A Long and Winding Road
description: As long as the Beatles and Apple have co-existed, fans of both have wondered: when are these crazy kids finally going to get together?

title: Currency Fight With China Divides U.S. Business
description: ZHUJI, China  For American business, the United States currency dispute with China is a two-sided coin.

title: A Big Task: Attempting to Solve the National Deficit
description: Overview | What is a budget deficit? How big is the current national deficit, and how can it be fixed? In this lesson, students use The Timess Budget Puzzle to develop their own approach to solving the national deficit and write letters to Congressional representatives arguing for their favored approaches.

title: The Real Meaning of Inheritance
description: In his Sandwich Generation special report essay, A Childs Legacy Is More Than Money, Paul Sullivan wrote that inheritance isnt necessarily just about simply passing down money. Rather, he noted that its also about passing down life tools like good judgment and passion.

title: Dracula Will Rise Off Broadway, With a Count by Way of Italy
description: New York theaters last major attempts at vampire shows  the Elton John musical Lestat in 2006, Dracula, the Musical in 2004, and the musical Dance of the Vampires in 2002  were among the biggest Broadway flops of that decade. But the monster success of the Twilight book and film series  about young love between a well-coiffed vampire and a pretty, sulky human  since 2008 has led to a host of movies, television series, and books featuring vampires.

title: Royals Show Little Affinity for Rank as They Take Spouses
description: PARIS  The Facebook page looks like any other  give or take a fancy royal crest. But the father happens to be Prince Charles, who put out a simple online announcement that William, his son, is to marry his long-term partner, Miss Catherine Middleton, less formally known as Kate.

title: Photo Replay: Nov. 16
description: A view of the day in sports, with a lot of action at the Asian Games in China.

title: Nations Face Off Warily on  Bluefin Tuna
description: International fisheries conferences dont necessarily make for high drama. But a meeting that opens on Wednesday on the fate of the Atlantic bluefin tuna could leave some officials, including those of the host country, squirming in the spotlight.

title: Green Mashed Potatoes
description: Mark Bittman mashes potatoes with dandelion greens  arugula, watercress, escarole, radicchio, spinach, mustard, turnip greens, collards or kale can stand in  and bakes til the dish is golden brown.

title: Paterson Is Set to Approve Deal on an Indian-Run Casino in the Catskills
description: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson is poised to sign off on an Indian-owned casino development project in the Catskills, state officials said Tuesday, opening the door to the states first full-fledged casino in close proximity to New York City.

title: Investors Set for Dynegy Fight
description: The Blackstone Group raised its offer for Dynegy, amid stiff opposition from two of the energy company's biggest shareholders.

title: The Nutcracker Chronicles
description: Readers shared photos and memories of appearing in or attending the holiday classic The Nutcracker.

title: Beet Salad With Garlic-Walnut Sauce
description: Mark Bittman demonstrates a nearly mess-free technique for roasting beets, which can then be tossed with a basic dressing.

title: Vain Glorious | Gym Equipment Thats Molto Bello
description: What: Technogym, an Italian purveyor of high-concept fitness equipment, has just set up shop on American shores with a sleek SoHo showroom practically spitting distance from Design Within Reach, Kartell, the Alessi flagship and Armani Casa. (Giorgio Armani, for the record, is reportedly a proud owner of Technogyms mirrored Kinesis system.)

title: An Award-Winning Chef Reinvents the Classics
description: Stuffing, cranberry sauce and mashed potatoes are standard fare at most Thanksgiving celebrations. But in the hands of an award-winning chef like Daniel Humm of Eleven Madison Park in New York City, these ordinary dishes can become the talk of the table.

title: Top R.N.C. Strategist Resigns, Condemning Steele
description: The top political strategist at the Republican National Committee resigned his position on Tuesday and delivered a scathing condemnation of the partys chairman, Michael Steele, declaring that new leadership is urgently needed if Republicans hope to win back the White House.

title: Stir-Fried Sweet Potatoes
description: Mark Bittman makes an easy side dish with grated sweet potatoes, brown butter and sage.

title: Barley 'Risotto' With Turkey
description: Mark Bittman uses leftover Thanksgiving turkey in a hearty dish that replaces arborio rice with hearty barley.

title: Lance Armstrong Doping Inquiry Intensifies
description: Federal investigators and antidoping officials from the United States, including the federal agent Jeff Novitzky, have intensified their investigation of Lance Armstrong and are in France to meet with antidoping officials and members of Interpol, according to a person briefed on the investigation who spoke on condition of anonymity.

title: In the Heartland, Still Investing in Coal
description: Lively Grove, Ill.

title: Walnut Tart
description: Mark Bittman skips pecan pie in favor of a traditional French walnut tart.

title: Sunset for a Solar Subsidy?
description: When the economy hit the skids in 2008, one of the casualties was the federal governments main mechanism for subsidizing renewable energy, tax credits.

title: Students Point Radar Guns and Learn a Lesson
description: The Bloomberg administration wants to teach New Yorkers about the dangers of driving over the speed limit. Its latest weapon? Kids with radar guns.

title: The Nutcracker Chronicles: Of Mice and Ballet Men
description: With the Times dance critic Alastair Macaulay about to embark on a marathon of coast-to-coast productions of The Nutcracker, we asked readers to share their memories  in words and photos  of the holiday ballet.

title: Cabbage Salad
description: Mark Bittman uses cabbage  a crisp and flavorful alternative to tasteless winter lettuce  in a salad with a distinctive crunch.

title: DVDs
description: The big development in home video for this holiday season is the surge in 3-D releases, which will finally give all those early adopters something to play on their expensive new systems. By the end of the year 36 stereoscopic titles will be available, according to the Digital Entertainment Group, a trade association, including Imax documentaries and classical music offerings.

title: Frank Gehry (a Part Owner) Helps Develop a Landmark
description: Its not every day that Frank Gehry designs lobby furniture for an office building.

title: No-Knead Bread
description: Jim Lahey, the owner of Sullivan Street Bakery, shows Mark Bittman how to make his no-knead bread, a simple method that produces a loaf with incredible flavor and an enviable, crackling crust.

title: President of World Chess Federation Responds to Readers Questions
description: The president of the World Chess Federation says he hopes to open a chess academy in New York City in the near future and double the number of people who play chess worldwide. And, yes, he believes that the game was invented by extraterrestrials.

title: Apple Approves Google Voice iPhone App
description: 5:05 p.m. | Updated  to add Apple comment.

title: Democratic Congressman Defends Debt Commission
description: WASHINGTON  Since releasing their preliminary report last week, Erskine Bowles and Alan Simpson, the co-chairmen of President Obamas fiscal commission, have been about as popular in the capital as the stinkbugs that recently swarmed the place. But they have at least one admirer in Earl Blumenauer, the cerebral Democratic congressman from Oregon, who took to the House floor today to urge his colleagues on the left to reconsider their almost universal hostility toward the plan.

title: Displaced in the Desert
description: How developers deal with a host of protected plants and animals like the desert tortoise has become crucial to getting vast renewable energy projects built.

title: Landmarks Panel Approves Change to De Niros Hotel
description: As an actor, Robert De Niro has made a name for himself playing characters who lash out at authority.

title: Asked & Answered | Samuel Bourdin
description: Now on view at the French Embassy (located at 972 Fifth Avenue, at 79th Street) are about 30 rarely seen black-and-white prints by Guy Bourdin. The works evoke the same spirit of his wildly iconic color photographs, except that they are distilled to their essence  maintaining their boldly graphic nature, and imaginative discourse, and packed full of playful elegance. Also on display is a slide show of Bourdins recently released monograph, In Between, published by Steidl Dangin. The exhibition was largely made possible by the perseverance of Shelly Verthime, the shows curator, and Guy Bourdins son Samuel Bourdin. Samuel endured many challenges gaining control of his fathers estate to be able to exhibit the works freely and worldwide. T caught up with him to find out more about his insights about his father and to congratulate him on the show, which closes Dec. 10.

title: Brussel Sprouts With Bacon and Figs
description: Mark Bittman cooks Brussels sprouts with bacon and figs  a combination made in heaven.

title: Concerns as Solar Installations Join a Desert Ecosystem
description: NIPTON, Calif.

title: Popovers
description: Mark Bittman makes easy popovers, custard-like on the inside, golden brown and crisp on the outside.

title: Pricing Used Goods for Sale
description: When you want to sell a used good, figuring out how much to sell it for can be a laborious process involving checking multiple sites and sources online.

title: Womens Pro League to Play Another Year
description: Womens Professional Soccer will live to play a third year.

title: New Attorney General Asks for Hiring Advice
description: The New York attorney general-elect, Eric T. Schneiderman, will have a big role in policing Wall Street, and on Tuesday he tapped several prominent Wall Street lawyers and senior aides of predecessors to help him find staff lawyers to do the job.

title: The Politics of Simpson-Bowles (II)
description: Via Reihan Salam, Steve Teles tries to game out the likelihood of the deficit commissions recommendations leading to an actual bipartisan deal of some sort:

title: Medal of Honor for Bravery in Afghanistan
description: In an emotional ceremony today, President Obama awarded the Medal of Honor to an Army staff sergeant who placed himself in the line of fire in Afghanistan to try to save his fellow squad-mates and to protect and comfort a dying American soldier.

title: G.M. Expands I.P.O. by 31%; U.S. Stake Cut Even More
description: Nov. 17, 7:52 a.m. | Updated General Motors confirmed in a regulatory filing that it was expanding the size of its initial public offering by about 31 percent, with the Treasury Department and the United Automobile Workers union selling more shares.

title: There Will Be Fuel
description: HOUSTON

title: Alumni Interview, The Home Version
description: When I conduct one of my alma maters alumni interviews with a prospective student, I draw from a long list of questions. Over a cup of tea or a latte, Ill ease the student in, trying to get a glimpse of some nonapplication material  some trait or passion that will help me get to know them just a little better off paper.

title: Spill Commission Defends Its Top Lawyer
description: The panel named by President Obama to investigate the BP Deepwater Horizon blowout on Tuesday rejected a call by a consumer activist group for the resignation of its chief counsel, Fred H. Bartlit Jr. The group, Consumer Watchdog, said that the panel should dismiss Mr. Bartlit because his law firm, Bartlit Beck Herman Palenchar & Scott, once represented Halliburton, one of the companies involved in drilling the BP well.

title: Florida Governor Will Seek Pardon for Jim Morrison
description: This is the strangest life Ive ever known, Jim Morrison sang on one of the hits he recorded with the Doors, but his afterlife continues to astound, too.

title: Comcast Defends Merger in Response to Sanders
description: Comcast released a statement Tuesday in response to a letter that Senator Bernie Sanders, Independent of Vermont, sent to the Federal Communications Commission seeking to block the upcoming takeover of NBC Universal by Comcast.

title: Hong Kong Official Stands Up for U.S. Dollar
description: A top official with Hong Kongs monetary body put to rest on Tuesday any concerns that the Hong Kong dollar would be delinked from its American counterpart, saying that Chinas renminbi did not meet the criteria needed to be an anchor currency.

title: Diesel, Cleaner, Is Set to Make a Comeback
description: WHEN Kenneth Ray Earley, a sophomore at the University of Missouri-St. Louis, went looking to replace the gas-guzzling, 1998 Chevy Silverado hed inherited from his family, fuel efficiency, he said, was top of mind. He looked at Hondas Civic and Fit models, as well as a Chevy Cobalt and the Toyota Prius hybrid.

title: At VPL, Wispy Clothes for Your Inner Ballerina
description: MOST new Manhattan boutiques tend to be pigeonhole-able into one of two categories. One of two decorative objects will be present, either literally or in spirit, which will harmonize all other aesthetic notes: (1.) stuffed white peacocks; or (2.) vintage leather medicine balls.

title: RIM Is Not App-Happy
description: Jim Balsillie, chief executive of Research In Motion, doesnt see apps as a key part of the mobile Internet. You dont have the make the Web an app, he said at the Web 2.0 conference in San Francisco Tuesday. I dont need a YouTube app to go to YouTube.

title: When Uranium Outshines Gold
description: EARLIER this month, Global X Funds of New York announced plans for two exchange-traded funds  one for gold stocks, the other, uranium. Initially, Bruno del Ama, its chief executive, figured he knew which would capture the markets attention. After all, gold prices have surged in recent months.

title: Rachel Comey | Dressing for the Expected
description: The designer Rachel Comey and her boyfriend, Sean Carmody, are two months away from having their first child, and the mom-to-be is bumping up her wardrobe accordingly. The maternity trend seems to be not buying any clothes, Comey says with a laugh. That excludes the flea market, because its been fun to shop and try on shapes that I wouldnt normally try on now that my body is so different. Comey, who is known for her flirty prints and cool shoe designs, transformed a thrift shop cat suit into a pair of cool trousers. Day wear has become jumpsuits, overalls and stretchy knits, especially knit dresses paired with a sharp tailored blazer from Ellsworth for a more defined shape. With my changing body and changing lifestyle, I am also changing my need for clothing to be practical for a womans body at any stage, she says. We are looking forward to see how this new sensibility plays out in Comeys next collection. Great expectations indeed.

title: Naked Lusts and Natural Painkillers: Portrait of a Literary Outlaw
description: Death smells. That pronouncement, delivered by William S. Burroughs with the granite hauteur of a smirking Grim Reaper begins William S. Burroughs: A Man Within, Yony Leysers sympathetic documentary portrait of the formidable proto-Beat author of Naked Lunch.

title: F.D.A. Panel Backs Drug for Lupus
description: What could become the first new drug approved to treat lupus in more than half a century moved a big step closer to the market on Tuesday by winning an endorsement from a federal advisory committee.

title: G.O.P. Gains on Capitol Hill May Not Advance Nuclear Power
description: WASHINGTON

title: Maple Pear Upside-Down Cake
description: Mark Bittman updates the canned pineapple upside-down cake with more sophisticated, seasonal flavors.

title: Safety Inspectors to Assess More Spider-Man Flying Sequences
description: State safety inspectors are scheduled to visit Broadways Foxwoods Theater on Wednesday to assess more flying sequences that director Julie Taymor has conceived for the forthcoming musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, a New York State Department of Labor spokesman said on Tuesday.

title: New Archbishop Represents a Shift for the Church
description: Archbishop Andr-Joseph Lonard has taken a self-imposed vow of public silence until December, but his conservative comments are still managing to rile the flock, from Roman Catholics in the pews and bishops to Prime Minister Yves Leterme of Belgium.

title: Neil Youngs Hybrid LincVolt Survives Fire
description: Neil Youngs much touted custom-built series hybrid, the LincVolt, was damaged in a fire on Nov. 9 while it was being recharged in a warehouse where the vehicle was stored.

title: The Football Rivalry and the Baseball Stadium
description: The first college football game in the new Yankee Stadium will be held Saturday and feature Notre Dame and Army, who played nearly every year from 1925 to 1946, in games that were like todays Super Bowls.

title: Solar Storm Risks Bring Disaster Plans
description: ON a March night 21 years ago, a storm brought Quebecs electric power grid to its knees.

title: Unlikely Alliance Results in an All-Electric RAV4
description: It was over glasses of red wine on a May evening in Palo Alto, Calif., that Akio Toyoda, president of Toyota, and Elon Musk, founder of the electric vehicle start-up company Tesla Motors, first talked through the particulars of a partnership they had just announced.

title: Some Exceptions to the Rule, but Pipelines Are Safer
description: UNDERGROUND oil and gas pipelines are an often-forgotten part of the nations energy infrastructure  until problems occur. This year has seen a spate of attention-getting accidents. In San Bruno, Calif., a gas pipeline exploded in a residential area in September, killing eight people. In Texas, two gas pipeline accidents within a day of each other in June killed three people. In Michigan, an oil pipeline ruptured this summer, spilling hundreds of thousands of gallons of oil into a river.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Bangladesh, Saudi Arabia and Britain.

title: Comptroller Expects Another Good Year on Wall Street
description: Although Wall Streets payroll is shrinking, its profit machine is alive and well.

title: The Benefits of Solar With the Beauty of Trees
description: DAVIS, Calif.

title: Wyndham Plans TRYP Hotel in New York
description: Midtown Manhattan will get a brand-new hotel next spring when TRYP by Wyndham unveils its first property in North America. The TRYP New York City-Times Square South is scheduled to open in April at 345 West 35th Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues.

title: Health Care and Bailout Votes May Have Hurt Democrats
description: Im giving a speech tonight at St. Olaf College in Northfield, Minn., (its nice to see some snow on the ground!) which has necessitated my taking a little bit of a step back and reviewing what happened two Tuesdays ago.

title: Dan Rather to Sum Up in a Memoir
description: Dan Rather will write a wide-ranging memoir about his journalism days, a book planned for release by Grand Central Publishing in spring 2012, the publisher said on Tuesday.

title: Catholics in Belgium Start Parishes of Their Own
description: BUIZINGEN, Belgium  Willy Delsaert is a retired railroad employee with dyslexia who practiced intensively before facing the suburban Don Bosco Catholic parish to perform the Sunday Mass rituals he grew up with.

title: Bacon From Provence, Wearing a Fringe of Herbs
