description: The bacon deluge has yet to be exhausted. Now there is a new bacon with an unusual and very felicitous flavoring: herbes de Provence. Unlike bacon made with the more commonplace boosters, like pepper or sugar, these porky, subtly smoked strips fringed with thyme and such are indeed richly herbaceous. They do wonders in a sandwich with mild Cheddar, alongside an omelet filled with goat cheese, in a spinach salad or to wrap filet mignon or medallions of monkfish.

title: A Timer for Turkey Roasting
description: Pop-up turkey timers often lead to overcooked disasters. The reason was clear after I called a manufacturer: the timers are set to pop when the meat is 180 degrees, by which point it is hopelessly dry.

title: Off the Menu
description: Openings

title: Pomp and Pu Pu and All That Noise
description: REMEMBER Trader Vics in the Plaza Hotel, all dark wood and sweet drinks, steel guitar and Polynesian dreams? Donald Trump closed the restaurant in 1993 when he bought the hotel, calling it tacky, but it had 25 years under its grass skirt before that day. Trader Vics served pu pu platters and mai tais to generations of New Yorkers delighted to dream of the South Pacific and all its naked, willing charms.

title: Dining Calendar, Nov. 17 to 21
description: Help for a Queens Co-Op

title: Pizza Goes to France on the East Side
description: Adil Fawzi (shown in the white jacket) and Anthony Raggiri (in black), owners of Bistro 61, grabbed a nice double storefront a block or so from their restaurant and have turned it into a little French market, March du Sud.

title: Is It Time for an Oil Change in the Kitchen?
description: WHATS the best oil for everyday frying? Some markets where I shop offer more than a dozen oils, from argan and avocado to tea seed and walnut. Id long figured that the choice is a matter of taste and price. I usually use canola oil because its neutral in flavor, a good source of omega-3s and inexpensive. Like soy oil, it costs about a dime a tablespoon, whereas extra-virgin olive oils can run well over a dollar.

title: FoodParc
description: OF all the big ideas packed into FoodParc, a food court that slices through the ground floor of the new Eventi Hotel on Sixth Avenue (between 29th and 30th Streets), the most riveting is the design. The elliptical columns and white banquettes are from the mind of Syd Mead, the designer behind Blade Runner and Tron.

title: Apple Green-Chili Pie With Cheddar Crust and Walnut Streusel
description: Adapted from Chile Pies and Ice Cream, San Francisco

title: Pie to Cupcake: Times Up
description: San Francisco

title: Bakeries That Will Do the Pie Baking for You
description: Suppose youd rather let someone else do the baking? Here are some bakeries that will allow New Yorkers to fetch and carry instead of roll and crimp:

title: Reviewing the Hurricane Club
description: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

title: A Star Who Needs Help, or at Least a Hand
description: Dont you hate it when puppets make eye contact and just glare at you? This is especially unnerving when the puppet is life-size and looks like Marlene Dietrich in her later years.

title: Leaders Meeting Is Off, but Still On
description: When President Obama said he would like to meet with legislative leaders this Thursday to discuss tax policy and other matters, apparently he failed to synch his smart phone with that of Senator Mitch McConnell.

title: Take the No. 7 to Secaucus? Thats a Plan
description: Ever since Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey killed an expensive plan for a new commuter rail tunnel to Manhattan, the Bloomberg administration has been working on an alternative: run the No. 7 subway train under the Hudson River.

title: U.S. Ends Inquiry of UBS Over Offshore Tax Evasion
description: The Internal Revenue Service on Tuesday dropped its legal push to force the Swiss bank UBS to disclose the names of scores of American clients suspected of offshore tax evasion, but the agency said it was ramping up its scrutiny of other banks.

title: Its a Big Night in the Country for a Family to No Manners Born
description: When the curtains part at Theater 80 at the beginning of Ghosts in the Cottonwoods, a backwoods melodrama written and directed by Adam Rapp, a naked young man covered in glaring red welts stands before us. Also onstage is a woman administering homespun first aid by sucking the leeches from the young mans flesh, spitting each into a bucket with a tinny clank.

title: Acoustics Meet Excess on Road to Who Knows Where
description: Sufjan Stevens went from God to nearly Gaga at the Beacon Theater on Monday night, the last show in his latest American tour. He began, banjo in hand, with Seven Swans, a folky song about visions out of the Book of Revelation. Two hours later, in Impossible Soul, he was wearing a silvery costume complete with a shiny headdress, a drum machine was pounding, his backup singers were shimmying, balloons were dropped from the ceiling and Mr. Stevens was singing Do you wanna dance?

title: Sweet Potatoes Wrapped in Prosciutto
description: Mark Bittman makes a Thanksgiving appetizer that you can prepare in advance.

title: 1953 Politics, Paranoia and a Family Torn Apart
description: Its probably significant that John Osborne never kept a copy of Personal Enemy, the play he wrote in 1953 (with Anthony Creighton) three years before storming the barricades of sedate postwar British drama with Look Back in Anger.

title: Turkey Curry
description: Mark Bittman uses leftover Thanksgiving turkey in a dish flavored with Indian spices.

title: Courting Women, Playboy TV Puts Emphasis on Intimacy
description: LOS ANGELES  Playboy TV is putting (some of) its clothes back on.

title: An Israeli Novelist Writes of Pain, Private and Public
description: MEVASSERET ZION, Israel  In the middle of David Grossmans latest novel, To the End of the Land, now out in English, the main character, a middle-aged Israeli Everywoman named Ora whose son has gone off to battle with the Israeli Army, stands with her ex-lover atop Mount Meron in northern Israel and looks out at the Hula Valley.

title: Pampered Critics? No, Critics in Pampers
description: WATCHING a critic watch a show to gauge his reactions and then speculate on how hell review it is a dubious occupation best left to theater press agents. But when the critic in question is unlikely ever to file a review because he still has his baby teeth, theres nothing to do but guess at his review of a theatrical experience, in much the same way all parents of toddlers constantly search the moods and whims of their young charges: Bottle? Diaper? Intermission?

title: To Boldly Go Beyond the Limits of Sacred Music
description: Spirituality is in the eye of the beholder and, perhaps as important, in the ear: a truism embraced by the White Light Festival at Lincoln Center. But whereas many of the events included in the series have featured performances of explicitly sacred works, Credo, a concert presented at the Church of St. Paul the Apostle near Lincoln Center on Monday night, stood as a bold departure. At the heart of this event were new compositions by members of Sigur Ros, an Icelandic alternative-rock band not known for espousing any particular creed.

title: Dunkin Brands Adds to Debt
description: The buyout barons behind Dunkin Donuts are partly cashing in. Nearly five years after one of that eras most aggressive leveraged buyouts, Bain Capital, the Carlyle Group and Thomas H. Lee Partners are adding onto the debt on Dunkin Brands, which owns the doughnut chain and the ice cream retailer Baskin-Robbins. They are taking out a $500 million dividend in the process. The equity holders may get a short-term buzz, but debt investors should beware.

title: A Precious Haul of Toxic Snapper
description: Thursday, Nov. 11

title: A Roundabout Route to Columbias Coaching Job
description: In the dimly lighted subterranean office inhabited by Kyle Smith, Columbias new mens basketball coach, a videocassette from his playing days at Hamilton College rests behind his desk. He has yet to watch it.

title: Young Ballet-Makers Elaborate on Technique
description: For a low-key, low-budget event featuring relatively unknown dance-makers, the Young Choreographers Showcase at the Manhattan Movement & Arts Center on Sunday night included an impressive number of stars and an enviable buzz. Ballet luminaries studded the audience, and a crowd waiting for ticket returns considerably delayed the start of the program.

title: Songbook Standards Flavored With Barbecue in an Escargot Cafe
description: A decade ago who would have thought that a Texas growl would supplant la-di-dah elegance at the Caf Carlyle as the holiday season approaches? That growl belongs to Steve Tyrell; the lofty airs were those of Bobby Short, the much-missed jazz piano man who died in 2005.

title: After an Adventure in Newspapers, a Publisher Returns to P.R.
description: BRIAN P. Tierney is leaving the world of media to return to his roots in marketing communications.

title: A Free-for-All at Dynegy
description: As hard as it is to run a public company, it may be even more difficult to sell it.

title: Explaining the Modern World and Keeping It Short
description: In his happily provocative new book of aphorisms, the fiscal prophet and self-appointed flneur Nassim Nicholas Taleb aims particular scorn at anyone who thinks aphorisms require explanation. And he differentiates the aphorism from the equally short-form sound bite by noting that the aphorism enhances knowledge while the sound bite shrinks it.

title: Bush and Cheney, Together Again at Groundbreaking
description: DALLAS  With the turn of a shovel and a few turns of phrase, former President George W. Bush culminated an elaborately orchestrated return to the public stage on Tuesday with a presidential library groundbreaking and a reunion with former Vice President Dick Cheney.

title: Hit Is Still Affecting Player and League
description: Eight months after Pittsburghs Matt Cooke delivered a blind-side check to the head of Boston center Marc Savard, the effects linger.

title: Bryant Park Finds Bright Spots Amid the Gloom
description: When the technical school Katharine Gibbs shut its doors last year at 50 West 40th Street, it appeared to be another blow for the tiny Bryant Park office submarket. The blocks that bracket the 9.6-acre park were already facing the partial departure of HSBC, a longtime anchor tenant; a largely vacant landmarked office tower; and the fire sale of a stalled development site.

title: Was Roy Halladay Good? Its Unanimous
description: Voting for baseballs major awards must be completed before the first game of the playoffs. This means that Roy Halladay earned every first-place vote for the National League Cy Young Award  and then pitched the game of his life.

title: Boehner Gives Freshmen More Goodies
description: John Boehner, the presumptive new speaker of the House, has gone out of his way to be nice to his incoming freshmen, even offering them added positions usually reserved for more senior folks. But now he has gone beyond offering his new housemates fresh towels and fancy soap and has practically moved them into the Congressional equivalent of the master bath.

title: Finally, Google Voice for iPhones
description: Well, one of the weirder mysteries of the modern tech age finally ended Tuesday. Oh, it was never solvedit just ended.

title: Senate Parties Keep Leaders for New Session
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats and Republicans kept their leadership teams intact Tuesday while House Democrats gathered behind closed doors to assess what misfired in elections that cost them at least 60 seats and control of the House.

title: Video Gallery: Thanksgiving Cooking With Mark Bittman
description: A collection of Minimalist column videos for Thanksgiving recipes, and other dishes that would fit perfectly within a turkey feast.

title: Panel on Deficit Proposes Smithsonian Charge Fees
description: Admission to the museums of the Smithsonian Institution (above, the National Portrait Gallery and the Smithsonian American Art Museum), which is 70 percent federally financed, has long been free. That would change under a proposal by the national commission charged with reducing the deficit. In its draft report last week it recommended that the Smithsonians federal appropriation be cut by $225 million, or roughly 30 percent, and that the institution make up the loss by charging a $7.50 admission fee. The Smithsonians spokeswoman, Linda St. Thomas, said by telephone that the Smithsonian had studied the idea of charging admission several times in recent decades and rejected it. The regents have said repeatedly we dont want to charge admission because it then makes it difficult for all people to come and visit the collections, which in theory are held in trust for the American people, Ms. St. Thomas said. She pointed out that because the Smithsonian is federally financed Americans are in a sense already paying to visit through their taxes.

title: F.B.I. Seeks Wider Wiretap Law for Web
description: WASHINGTON  Robert S. Mueller III, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, traveled to Silicon Valley on Tuesday to meet with top executives of several technology firms about a proposal to make it easier to wiretap Internet users.

title: Dancers Lift ABC
description: The remaining four couples on Dancing With the Stars competed in a 90-minute episode on Monday as that ABC reality show topped the nights ratings with 20.6 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. No other program came close to matching that audience as ABC easily led the night over all. CBS placed second, garnering strong ratings for its sitcoms Two and a Half Men (14.1 million) and Mike & Molly (12.3 million) at 9 and 9:30. Fox was third, earning 10.8 million at 8 for House, but only 6 million at 9 for Lie to Me. NBC was fourth.

title: Footnote
description: James Conlon, music director of the Los Angeles Opera, has extended his contract for two more seasons, through 2013, the company announced. Its general director, Plcido Domingo, recently extended his term for a similar period.

title: Yahoo in Four Words
description: What is Yahoo? Thats the question Carol A. Bartz, Yahoos chief executive, gets incessantly in Silicon Valley, where technology industry insiders closely follow her companys struggles and second-guess the direction it is headed this month.

title: F.B.I. Questions Ex-Quarterback in Cam Newton Inquiry
description: The various inquiries into the recruitment of Auburn quarterback Cam Newton continued Tuesday. Federal and state officials met with former Mississippi State quarterback John Bond in Mississippi, and news emerged that the N.C.A.A. spoke with a former Mississippi State employee with knowledge of Newtons recruitment.

title: Jim Crow on West Broadway
description: New York, Nov. 17, 1860

title: In B.C.S., No Reward for Sportsmanship
description: Two days after college football fans watched in amazement as Wisconsin defeated Indiana by an astonishing 63 points, the Hoosiers were still dealing with the fallout.

title: Publicist in Hollywood Is Fatally Shot Post-Premiere
description: BEVERLY HILLS  It was like a scene out of a Hollywood thriller: Gunshots rang out in the middle of the night in one of the wealthiest neighborhoods in Los Angeles County, leaving a Hollywood publicist dead inside her Mercedes-Benz with no witnesses, suspects or obvious motive.

title: Pretty Good for Government Work
description: Omaha

title: By Slimmest Margin, UConn Extends Streak
description: HARTFORD  So many games in Connecticuts winning streak had been a breeze, all but one previous victory having come by 10 points or more. What would happen when the Huskies were truly challenged? If they got knocked down, could they get up?

title: Canada to End Combat Role in Afghanistan at End of 2011
description: OTTAWA  The government of Canada confirmed Tuesday that its military would end its combat mission in Afghanistan at the end of 2011.

title: A New G.M., but Not an End to the Bailout Era
description: After the bailout, now comes the bail-in.

title: U.S. Seeks to Retry Ex-State Senate Leader Bruno
description: Federal prosecutors will seek a new trial of the former State Senate leader Joseph L. Bruno, after a Supreme Court ruling that limited the law under which he was convicted last year, according to a letter sent to Mr. Brunos lawyers by Richard S. Hartunian, the United States attorney for the Northern District of New York.

title: TV Shows on DVD
description: The DVD pickings are slimmer than usual this holiday season for those who like to consume television shows in huge gulps. The complete-series category is thin, and the new Sex and the City box doesnt count, less deluxe versions of which have been available since 2005. But the Larry Sanders Show collection is a must, more than 40 hours of razor-sharp satire.

title: Destroying to Save Lives
description: NATO forces in Kandahar Province, Afghanistan, have been blasting their way through homes and other structures booby-trapped by the retreating Taliban, in the wake of a troop surge by the American-led troops.

title: Facing Scrutiny, Officials Defend Airport Pat Downs
description: WASHINGTON  The official subject of the hearing Tuesday was screening air cargo. But senators seemed equally interested in hearing about a new procedure for airline passengers that involves a full-body pat down.

title: Recipes for Pies and Tarts
description: Pecan, brandied pumpkin, apple green chili and other pies from the Dining section of The Times.

title: New Push for Ireland to Consent to a Bailout
description: As Ireland tried to fend off pressure to accept a bailout on Tuesday and other European nations raised objections to participating in a rescue plan, Europe again found itself confronting a crisis of confidence in the euro and, ultimately, in its ability to manage its economic problems.

title: G.O.P. Opposition Dims Hope for Arms Treaty With Russia
description: President Obamas hopes of ratifying a new arms control treaty with Russia by the end of the year appeared to come undone on Tuesday as the chief Senate Republican negotiator moved to block a vote on the pact, one of the White Houses top foreign policy goals, in the lame-duck session of Congress.

title: Lone Star Bailout
description: Re Texas and the S&L bailout: A reader has sent me a copy of a 1990 article by Edward Hill in Challenge, estimating which states gained and lost from the bailout. Heres a table:

title: Music Boxed Sets
description: Completists with deep pockets can revel in the 2010 bounty of boxed sets. This year fans can collect John Lennons entire 1970s solo career, all of Michael Jacksons video clips, all of Elvis Presleys master recordings and all of Bob Dylans 1960s albums in vintage mono mixes, not to mention the entire output of the techno producer Plastikman. Perhaps recording companies are recognizing the ever-expanding capacity of digital storage on portable music players, all those extra gigabytes awaiting more music. Perhaps theyve decided to release these substantial physical packages before consumers completely abandon the CD.

title: Holiday Music
description: Like gifts themselves, Christmas albums shouldnt be obligations, though they all too often are. And also like gifts, the ones worth receiving and embracing are those that in spite of the familiar structure, find new ways to deliver old thrills. Or even, sometimes, new thrills. Or even more rarely, something not thrilling, but bracing; not all holiday experiences are cheerful. Here, the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times look for meaning, and hidden presents, in this years crop of holiday releases. JON CARAMANICA

title: The Way They Were
description: WASHINGTON

title: Lottery Numbers
Worst Miss Ever?
description: No words are necessary (O.K., a few, Uzbekistan vs. Qatar in an Asian Cup quarterfinal game on Monday). Take a look:

title: Too Good to Check
description: On Nov. 4, Anderson Cooper did the country a favor. He expertly deconstructed on his CNN show the bogus rumor that President Obamas trip to Asia would cost $200 million a day. This was an important story. It underscored just how far ahead of his time Mark Twain was when he said a century before the Internet, A lie can travel halfway around the world while the truth is putting on its shoes. But it also showed that there is an antidote to malicious journalism  and thats good journalism.

title: Knicks Seeking More Star Play From Gallinari
description: DENVER  For 12 riveting minutes last March, Danilo Gallinari was a star. A demonstrative, chest-thumping, certifiable N.B.A. star, with a mission and a menacing glare and a rival in his path.

title: As Bloomberg Fought Sodas, Nominee Sat on Coke Board
description: By her own account, Cathleen P. Black, Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs choice to be the next New York City schools chancellor, has had almost no experience with the public education system.

title: Rare Honor for a Living Service Member
description: WASHINGTON  In an emotional ceremony, President Obama on Tuesday awarded the Medal of Honor to an Army staff sergeant who placed himself in the line of fire in Afghanistan to try to save his squad mates and to protect and comfort a dying American soldier.

title: Bank of America Settles Bias Suit
description: Bank of America has settled a lawsuit filed by a broker who claimed that the banks Merrill Lynch unit discriminated against women through its partnership model.

title: The Empty Earmarks Pledge
description: Millions of Americans are out of work. The government is running a $1.3 trillion deficit. We just had an election that sent at least one clear signal: cut that deficit. So what is Washington talking about? Earmarks, the $15.9 billion in projects designated by Congress in the last fiscal year for favorite projects. Thats less than half of 1 percent of federal spending.

description: Amazon.com, having conquered online retail, wants to become a player in Hollywood movie- making?

title: A Hurried Announcement for a New Michelin City
description: CHICAGO  A strange thing happened on the way to Wednesdays grand announcement of the restaurants capturing top ratings in this citys first Michelin guide. An Old World tradition met a modern one  a leak on the review Web site Yelp.

title: Republican Proposal Takes Aim at Feds Dual Role
description: WASHINGTON  Criticism of the Federal Reserve intensified on Tuesday as conservative Republican lawmakers called for limiting the central banks mandate to keeping inflation low. They said that the Fed should stop trying to pursue the twin goals of balancing inflation and unemployment, as it has been required to do since 1977.

title: At Alinea, Three Stars Come With a Mischievous Taste of Autumn
description: CHICAGO  The oak leaves were smoldering when the waiter set them down on the table at Alinea at the start of November, and their fragrant smoke made the dining room smell something like backyard chores in Evanston.

description: The contrast could not be more distressing.

title: A Footnote Explains a Dispute Over Treasurys Bailout Figures
description: Government auditors said on Tuesday that they had found problems with the United States Treasurys accounting for its bailout of the financial system, but that they believed the audited numbers were sound.

title: New York States Voter Turnout This Year Was Lowest in U.S.
description: Despite contests for every statewide office for the first time in decades, a smaller share of eligible voters turned out two weeks ago in New York than in any other state.

title: Wednesday: Ten Letters
description: Todays theme has a very intriguing concept at work. Robert W. Harris has chosen five two-word phrases that can morph into five other two-word phrases  just remove the initial letters of each word. Ill give an example below.

description: An excerpt from the composition Riceboy Sleeps by members of the Icelandic alternative-rock band Sigur Ros, part of Lincoln Centers White Light Festival.

title: And Noisily Flows the Arno
description: How do you say Angry Young Man in Italian? A classic specimen of that breed  and I do mean the type that warrants capital letters  shows up on the banks of the Arno, teaching English to mid-20th-century Florentines, in Peter Nicholss Lingua Franca, which is receiving its American premiere at 59E59 Theaters.

description: For a drug operation, this one appears to have been a poorly kept secret.

title: Chinese Immigrant Hopes Sight and English Both Improve
description: Slowly, Li Bin Zhang, 24, walked through her surroundings, feeling the wood-paneled walls with her walking stick. A jade talisman hung from the handle. She grazed the edge of the couch, the worn, carpeted stairs and an out-of-place chair before cautiously kicking her feet forward.

description: FRONT PAGE

title: NATO Is Razing Booby-Trapped Afghan Homes
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  In the newly won districts around this southern city, American forces are encountering empty homes and farm buildings left so heavily booby-trapped by Taliban insurgents that the Americans have been systematically destroying hundreds of them, according to local Afghan authorities.

title: Garber Committed to M.L.S. Meritocracy
description: Don Garber wants Major League Soccer to be the ultimate meritocracy.

title: Neediest | A Teacher in Training
description: After losing her eyesight, Libin Zhang, alone in a new country, rediscovers an old dream.

title: Parking Rules for New York City
description: Because of Id al-Adha,

title: All Together Now
description: On Tuesday, Apple released the entire Beatles catalog on the iTunes store  as individual songs, as albums, and as a box set without the box, and all in the remastered versions made available last year. Getting to this digital offering wasnt easy. It took years of negotiations, a lawsuit with the Beatles own Apple Corps over the Apple trademark, and agreements with Paul McCartney, Ringo Starr, the widows of John Lennon and George Harrison, and EMI, which controls the right to release Beatles recordings.

title: What the New Arms Treaty Would Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Immigration Overload
description: To the Editor:

title: At Hearing, Chancellor Is but One Worry
description: More than 8,000 people have signed online petitions opposing Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs selection for the next city schools chancellor, Cathleen P. Black. But at the first public meeting to take up the question on Tuesday night at Brooklyn Technical High School, only about a dozen people testified directly against her appointment.

title: For Katrina Victims, Relief at Last
description: It took five long years. The Department of Housing and Urban Development has finally persuaded Mississippi to do right by Hurricane Katrina survivors who were unfairly shut out of a federally financed disaster aid program designed by the state. Congress needs to rewrite disaster aid regulations so that a travesty like this one never happens again.

title: For-Profit College

description: To the Editor:

title: Earmark Ban Exposes Rifts Within Both Parties
description: WASHINGTON  In leading his colleagues in a vote on Tuesday to ban the lawmaker-directed spending items known as earmarks, Mitch McConnell, the Senate Republican leader and consummate Congressional appropriator, averted a divisive clash within his caucus over the question of joining the new House Republican majority in enacting an earmark moratorium for the next Congress.

title: Company to Drop Caffeine From Alcoholic Drinks
description: The company that produces the Four Loko beverage said it will remove the caffeine and two other ingredients from its products after facing a cascade of criticism and regulatory scrutiny for producing the energy drinks, which combine high levels of the stimulant with alcohol.

title: Lunching in So Paulo
description: In the six years since I first came to Brazil, it has transformed from a place worth visiting for the favorable exchange rate (3 reais to the dollar) to a must-visit destination despite the obliterated greenback (1.7 to the dollar) and steady inflation.

title: Taxing Soda to Close the Deficit
description: The second bipartisan panel to issue a big deficit report has come out in favor of a tax on soda and other sweetened beverages.

title: One Way to Trim Deficit: Cultivate Growth
description: We look back on the late 1990s as a rare time when the federal government ran budget surpluses. We tend to forget that those surpluses came as a surprise to almost everybody.

title: Obama Deficit Panel Gets Some Competition
description: WASHINGTON  A bipartisan group will present a deficit-reduction plan on Wednesday that goes beyond the spending cuts and tax proposals from the chairmen of President Obamas fiscal commission. It also calls for a one-year holiday from Social Security payroll taxes to encourage hiring and for a national sales tax to reduce deficits.

title: Jim Morrison Is Candidate for Pardon in 69 Arrest
description: This is the strangest life Ive ever known, Jim Morrison sang on one of the hits he recorded with the Doors, but his afterlife continues to astound, too.

title: Uggla Goes to Braves, and Mets Pick Finalists
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Major player transactions are rare at baseballs general managers meetings, but on Tuesday two National League East teams created a small buzz with a trade during the first full day of the annual gathering.

title: BP and Minerals Agency Faulted in Gulf Spill
description: A breakdown in BPs management system and a failure to strongly consider risk contributed to the Deepwater Horizon rig explosion that killed 11 workers and flooded the Gulf of Mexico with oil, a preliminary report by a team of scientific experts found on Tuesday.

title: A Costly Quest for the Dark Heart of the Cosmos
description: After 16 years and $1.5 billion of other peoples money, it is almost showtime for NASA and Sam Ting.

title: Yanks Search for Pitching Coach Starts in Video Room
description: Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman does not have an obvious candidate for a new pitching coach, but he does have a unique approach to finding a replacement for Dave Eiland.

title: Obama Sails Trade Sea, Where Friends Are Foes
description: WASHINGTON  Conventional wisdom in Washington says that trade policy is one of the few areas where President Obama and Congressional Republicans can work together in the next two years. But making progress will require Mr. Obama to navigate opposition from within his own party, and could test how far he is willing to go in compromising and building new coalitions in the wake of the Republican victories.

title: Phys Ed: The Workout Enigma
description: Recently, researchers in Finland made the discovery that some peoples bodies do not respond as expected to weight training, others dont respond to endurance exercise and, in some lamentable cases, some dont respond to either. In other words, there are those who just do not become fitter or stronger, no matter what exercise they undertake. To reach this conclusion, the researchers enrolled 175 sedentary adults in a 21-week exercise program. Some lifted weights twice a week. Others jogged or walked. Some did both. Before and after the program, the volunteers fitness and muscular strength were assessed. At the end of the 21 weeks, the results, published earlier this year in Medicine and Science in Sports and Exercise, were mixed. In the combined strength-and-endurance-exercise program, the volunteers physiological improvement ranged from a negative 8 percent (meaning they became 8 percent less fit) to a positive 42 percent. The results were similar in the groups that undertook only strength or only endurance training. Some improved their strength enormously, some not at all. Others became aerobically fitter but not stronger, while still others showed no improvements in either area. Only a fortunate few became both fitter and more buff. As the researchers from the University of Jyvaskyla wrote with some understatement, large individual differences exist in the responses to both endurance and strength training.

title: Word of the Day | bicker
description: bicker \bi-kr\ verb

title: Officials in Haiti Defend Focus on Cholera Outbreak, Not Its Origins
description: MEXICO CITY  Medical authorities in Haiti defended their decision Tuesday not to focus on finding the origins of a cholera outbreak that has killed more than 1,000 people and stoked violent demonstrations against United Nations peacekeepers, whom many people blame for introducing the disease.

title: Unesco Hails French Food, Oil Wrestling and Flamenco
description: PARIS  Lest one fear the end of Frances centuries of culinary panache, Unesco officials on Tuesday enshrined the gastronomic meal of the French as part of the intangible cultural heritage of humanity, alongside Azerbaijani carpet weaving, an annual Belgian bread and fire feast, and Turkeys Kirkpinar oil wrestling festival. I think that cooks have done a lot for the cultural radiance of our country, said Francis Chevrier, the director of the European Institute of History and of Cultures of the Diet, who led the effort to see French cuisine recognized.

title: Carlsen, Aronian Lead World Blitz Championship
description: Skill at blitz chess  where players have a few minutes to make all their moves  does not necessarily go hand-in-hand with the ability to play classical or slow chess well. But after the first day of the World Blitz Championship in Moscow, Magnus Carlsen of Norway, the worlds No. 1 player and the defending champion, and Levon Aronian of Armenia, No. 3 in the world, are tied for the lead with 10 points each.

title: Top Republican Official, Breaking With Party Chairman, Resigns
description: WASHINGTON  The political director of the Republican National Committee resigned Tuesday, delivering a scathing condemnation of Michael Steele, the embattled party chairman, whom he criticized as spending too much, raising too little and failing to fully capitalize on the breadth of Republican opportunities in the midterm elections.

title: Tough Law Reduced Immigrants, Study Shows
description: WASHINGTON  A study of an Arizona-style immigration policy in Prince William County, Va., has found that it reduced the number of illegal immigrants in the county, but that its effect on violent crime was inconclusive.

title: Talking to the Locals and Finding a Citys Soul Food
description: ATLANTA  If you want to eat great food in an American city, it is sometimes best to throw out the guidebooks, forget the reservation and simply ask one question: what does this town do best?

title: Mysteries of Tiny Bodies From 1930s Will Linger
description: LOS ANGELES  Three months after the mummified corpses of two infants were found wrapped in 1930s newspapers in a basement steamer trunk here, the police said DNA evidence showed them to be the children of a Scottish-born nurse who owned the trunk and lived in the building during that time.

title: Neither Anthony Nor Knicks Are at Their Best
description: DENVER  Carmelo Anthonys troubled path at last intersected with the Knicks troubled season, and everyone left with a bad impression.

title: Prelate, Crowd-Pleaser and Defender of Faith
description: He will become the face of the Roman Catholic Church in the United States.

title: Allan Sandage, Astronomer, Dies at 84; Charted Cosmoss Age and Expansion
description: Allan R. Sandage, who spent his life measuring the universe, becoming the most influential astronomer of his generation, died Saturday at his home in San Gabriel, Calif. He was 84.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,373 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Baby Marie Osborne, Silent-Film Child Star, Dies at 99
description: They called her Baby Marie Osborne, and in silent films nearly a century ago she was Americas little sweetheart, a precocious, chauffeured, $1,000-a-week prodigy who could turn on the tears or a sunshine smile and break your heart. She had sparkling eyes and dimpled arms. She also had a lisp, but no matter.

title: Paul Calello, Leader of a Credit Suisse Unit, Dies at 49
description: Paul Calello, the chairman of the investment bank at Credit Suisse Group in Manhattan who helped navigate the Swiss bank through the financial crisis, died on Tuesday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 49.

title: News Quiz | November 17, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Ukraine: Kiev Mayor Removed From Power
description: The mayor of Kiev, known for his impulsive behavior and political stunts, was effectively removed from power on Tuesday by Ukraines president, who has been seeking to tighten political control over the country. The mayor, Leonid M. Chernovetsky, left, had seemed to survive in office because Ukraines squabbling political factions did not know how to handle him and could not agree on a successor. But the president, Viktor F. Yanukovich, who was elected this year, ousted Mr. Chernovetsky as head of the citys administration and appointed a senior municipal official, Oleksandr Popov, to succeed him. Through a quirk in the law, Mr. Chernovetsky will continue for now as nominal head of the city, but Mr. Popov will wield the authority, officials said.

title: The Philippines: Powerful Family Is Accused in More Killings
description: Members of a powerful political family in the southern Philippines whose leaders have been charged in the 2009 massacre of 57 people are implicated in dozens of other killings that date back decades, Human Rights Watch said in a report released Tuesday. No one in the Ampatuan family, long a dominant political force in Maguindanao Province, was charged in the older killings, whose victims included political opponents and their relatives, public officials, people whose land the family wanted, and members of the Ampatuans own organization who disobeyed orders, the report said. Andal Ampatuan Jr., son of the family patriarch, is on trial for the Nov. 23, 2009, killings in Maguindanao, whose 57 victims included about 30 journalists and media support staff members who were with a group of people on their way to file candidacy papers for a political rival of Mr. Ampatuan.

title: Iran: France Protests Assault of a Diplomat at a Concert
description: Plainclothes Iranian security forces violently assaulted a high-ranking French diplomat in Tehran, French officials said Tuesday after summoning Irans ambassador to France in protest. Iranian forces arrived unannounced outside a Persian music concert at an official French residence in Tehran on Monday, turning away or arresting young Iranians invited to the event, according to the Foreign Ministry. The diplomatic officer was struck in the head as he tried to intervene. A French official, speaking on condition of anonymity in keeping with government policy, said the Iranian authorities had in recent weeks asked that foreign embassies and missions in Tehran inform them of any cultural events they intend to hold, a request with which the French have complied. The episode on Monday was thus a trap, the official said.

description: Todays word, in association with the glorious Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: U.N. Urges Food Aid for North Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Despite a relatively good autumn harvest, North Korea remains in dire need of food aid, especially for its youngest children, pregnant women and the elderly, according to two United Nations agencies.

title: A Footnote on Treasurys Bailout Figures
description: Government auditors said on Tuesday that they had found problems with the United States Treasury Departments accounting for its bailout of the financial system, but that they believed the audited numbers were sound, Mary Williams Walsh reports in The New York Times.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Nov. 17, 2010
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the Times article China Wrests Supercomputer Title From U.S.

title: Mets Name Final Four
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  After speaking with 10 candidates for their vacant managerial post over the past two weeks the Mets arrived at a final four on Tuesday, all of whom currently work for the team.

title: U.S. Ends Inquiry of UBS Over Tax Evasion
description: The Internal Revenue Service has dropped its legal push to require the Swiss bank UBS to disclose the names of scores of American clients suspected of offshore tax evasion, but the agency says it is ramping up its scrutiny of other banks, Lynnley Browning of The New York Times reported.

title: A Royal Engagement
description: WHO is Kate Middleton?

title: Google Fashion Shopping Site Makes Debut
description: YOU know how remote and strange the fashion world is when you go to Googles headquarters in Mountain View, Calif. For one thing, employees are zipping around the sprawling campus on scooters and bicycles, so that pretty much eliminates platform shoes and minis. And for another, there are way too many snack stations at Google. Fashionistas are funny about food.

title: S. Korea Rejects Talks on Border Tours
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The South Korean government on Wednesday rejected a North Korean request for talks about restarting cross-border tours to the Diamond Mountain resort in the North.

title: Fixing the Budget, and Deciding on Inequality
description: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of 13 Bankers.

title: The Palin Network
description: On the night of the midterm elections earlier this month, Sarah Palin stayed up until 3 in the morning. From her hotel bedroom in Manhattan, she and her husband, Todd, followed the returns while she wrote e-mails on her iPad  congratulating winners, consoling losers  while reading others from people who wanted her to know that they had cast their vote for her daughter Bristol on Dancing With the Stars the evening before. Like much of her recent life, Palins day had been replete with reminders of the clout she had rapidly acquired. She had spent most of her time ensconced at the Fox television studios, though she managed to squeeze in a jog in Central Park  which she promptly chronicled on Twitter: Beautiful! Also at the studios was her fellow Fox News contributor Karl Rove, who had recently questioned in a British newspaper whether Palins new reality TV series, Sarah Palins Alaska, made her appear Oval Office-worthy. The building was abuzz over what would ensue when the two would inevitably bump into each other. The moment came after Palin finished a segment with the anchor Bret Baier and saw Rove lingering stageside with Brit Hume, a Fox colleague, holding a well-marked copy of Alaska for Dummies  a prop clearly intended to mollify Palin. She laughed, used her phones camera to take a picture of Rove with the book, traded brief hellos and then left the studio without mentioning Roves earlier comment.

title: Eleanor Roosevelt, on Her Own
description: There are times when a photograph grabs your attention simply by its sheer inscrutability. The mystery is its appeal. Here is Eleanor Roosevelt, the former first lady, carrying her luggage at an airport, seemingly alone. No entourage. No Secret Service. No press. No onlookers.

title: What Tech Tools Do Your Teachers Use?
description: Increasingly, college and university professors are using technology tools in their classrooms to engage students. How are your own teachers using technology? Does it help you learn? Do you have any suggestions for ways that your school can better use technology to promote learning and class participation?

title: Kerviel: Bosses Never Said a Thing
description: Joel Saget/Agence France-Presse  Getty ImagesJrme Kerviel, right, the former Socit Gnrale trader.

description: One in seven Hong Kongers will this month file past an animated recreation of a 900-year-old work. The exhibition, River of Wisdom, showcases the star exhibit from the China pavilion at the recently ended Shanghai World Expo.

description: From Todays Times:

title: Chamber Softens Rhetoric but Will Fight Obama Regulations
description: 9:55 a.m. | Updated The U.S. Chamber of Commerce appears ready to hit the reset button on its stormy relationship with the White House even as its leaders vow to begin a new battle against what they call excessive regulation by the Obama administration.

title: How to Run a Slant Route at the Goal Line
description: More analysis on a key play from the Giants-Dallas game. The video of the play is at bottom.

title: Unexpected Findings on Elderly Drivers
description: There are a lot of different pieces to this puzzle, said Deborah Hersman, chairwoman of the National Transportation Safety Board, which last week sponsored a two-day forum called Safety, Mobility and Aging Drivers.

title: Two Midwesterners Walk Into a Reading
description: When Jonathan Franzen and Lorrie Moore met Monday night at the 92nd Street Y for a joint reading, the vibe among the sold-out crowd was a bit like that at the Margarito v. Pacquiao bout at Cowboys Stadium. Nobody got hurt, but that didnt mean things werent a little competitive.

title: Two Midwesterners Walk Into a Reading

title: Would You Pay $925,000 for This Business?
description: Pool season may be over for most of us, but theres something about a backyard oasis that has year-round appeal. This business caught my eye not only because of its products and services but its desirable location. Several cities in middle Tennessee, like Nashville and Franklin, rank high on national best places lists.

title: The Bakers Apprentice: Banana Cream Pie
description: Emily Weinstein, who wrote a series on this blog about learning to cook, is now learning to bake with Dorie Greenspan, a food writer and the author of several cookbooks, including the recent Around My French Table.

title: Britain Pledges to Support Ireland in Debt Crisis
description: BRUSSELS  The British government Wednesday signaled its willingness to offer direct financial assistance to Ireland, as a team from the International Monetary Fund and the European Union was preparing to descend on Dublin on Thursday to work with the Irish on a rescue package aimed at defusing the latest European debt crisis.

title: Israel Approves Withdrawal From Part of a Village on Lebanon Border
description: JERUSALEM  Israels inner cabinet approved a plan in principle on Wednesday to withdraw from the northern part of a village straddling the border with Lebanon, addressing an American concern and a longstanding point of contention between Israel and Lebanon.

title: Booz Allen Hamilton Prices I.P.O.
description: General Motors is the not the only I.P.O. this week.

title: Wall St. Barely Budges Amid Concerns for Europe
description: Stocks were little changed on Wednesday as concerns about debt problems in Europe persisted, and new reports showed inflation remaining low and the housing sector in the United States remaining weak.

title: Onion Declares N.F.C. West a Disaster Area
description: Someone has to win the N.F.C. West, and chances are that team wont deserve a playoff berth. But the satirical Web site The Onion leads off the links this morning with compassion, not disapproval:

title: A Look Inside Palin World
description: In his cover story on Sarah Palin in this Sundays New York Times Magazine, the writer Robert Draper takes an intimate look inside Palin World and talks to the potential 2012 presidential contender about everything from her love of Twitter (I just tweet; thats just the way I roll, Ms. Palin said) to whether she is weighing a run for the White House. I am, Ms. Palin said. Im engaged in the internal deliberations candidly, and having that discussion with my family, because my family is the most important consideration here. Ms. Palin went on to say that there werent meaningful differences in policy among the field of Republican hopefuls but that in fact theres more to the presidency than that.

title: For Saudi Women, Biggest Challenge Is Getting to Play
description: After the 18-year-old Saudi equestrian Dalma Malhas won a bronze medal in show jumping at the first Youth Olympic Games in Singapore in August, she was singled out for praise by Jacques Rogge, chairman of the International Olympic Committee, in a news conference at the Games conclusion.

title: AT&T: Your (Original) Social Network
description: Facebook is a mere infant compared with another social networking colossus that came earlier.

title: Because the (Late) Night: Springsteen Rocks Jimmy Fallon
description: First of all, who else but Jimmy Fallon would have Bruce Springsteen walk onto his set to the theme song from Whos the Boss? And who else but Mr. Fallon would invite him on for the entire show and then proceed to perform his (affectionate) impression of Mr. Springsteen straight to his face? Nobody, thats who. Yes, Mr. Fallon, looking even more excited than when he got to introduce Guns N Roses at the 2002 MTV Video Music Awards, devoted nearly an hour to the Boss, whos out hawking an album of Darkness on the Edge of Town rarities and outtakes called The Promise. In his interview segments (the first of which appears above), Mr. Springsteen came across as a pretty gosh-darn regular kinda guy: He has an awkward relationship with his brother-in-law! Hes perplexed by modern technology! And on top of that, he stuck around to perform two songs with Mr. Fallons house band, the Roots. But why are we sitting here jibber-jabbering when you could be watching video from the show?

title: Cap-and-Trade Exchange Calls It Quits
description: The only national carbon cap-and-trade exchange in the United States is shutting down because of Congressional inaction on limiting emissions, company officials say.

title: Quad Q&A: George Dohrmann
description: George Dohrmann, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist, is a senior writer at Sports Illustrated. His newly released book, Play Their Hearts Out: A Coach, His Star Recruit and the Youth Basketball Machine, delves into the murky world of A.A.U. basketball, focusing on a star player, Demetrius Walker, and the coach who discovered him, Joe Keller. Walkers dream is to make it to the N.B.A., while Kellers is to become a basketball power player. In a phone interview, Dohrmann discussed what led him to want to write the book and what he thinks of A.A.U. basketball after spending eight years in its orbit.

description: What were reading on this bright autumn morning, which could be one of the last warm days of the season. High in the low 60s.

title: The Dark Ages, Returned In Full
description: Theres a famous passage in Schumpeters writings during the Great Depression, in which he lays out the extreme liquidationist position, arguing not just against the use of fiscal policy to fight unemployment but even against monetary policy, lest it get in the way of the work of depressions. That passage has been held up by many people as an example of the wrong-headedness that prevailed at the time. Here it is:

title: Beijings Focus on Food Prices Ignores Broader Inflation Risk
description: HONG KONG  China took steps Wednesday to control rising prices at the most basic consumer level. But Beijing faces a severe challenge in preventing higher global commodity prices from igniting broader inflation that could threaten Chinas streak of powerful economic growth.

title: Mercks New Cholesterol Drug Shows Promise
description: Merck has a potential blockbuster in anacetrapib, an experimental cholesterol drug that dramatically increases HDL, or good cholesterol even as it lowers LDL, the bad cholesterol.

title: U.S. Consumer Prices Tame in October
description: Consumer prices inched up in October, driven almost entirely by rising gasoline costs, according to government statistics released on Wednesday.

title: Homework Was Never Quite Like This: Gwyneth Paltrow Does Glee
description: Forget Love and Other Disasters. Forget Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow. Forget Running With Scissors, forget Iron Mans 1 and 2, forget GOOP and forget that she named her first-born child Apple. To watch Gwyneth Paltrow on Glee Tuesday was like being transported back to the late 1990s, when she could do no wrong and to see her on a screen was a guarantee of a compelling performance (and maybe the possibility of seeing her decapitated head in a box).

title: The Frat Pack
description: Sometimes the most incongruous partnerships yield the most inspired results. Case in point: J. Press, known for its preppy sportswear for men, has teamed up with Urban Outfitters. While J. Press has a history steeped in Ivy League lore, its partnership with the hipster powerhouse might be just the thing to loosen up its staid image. Conversely, Urban Outfitterss disheveled-chic aesthetic could benefit from a bit of polishing. The J. Press designer Mikito Takeshima sprinkled some references to Happy Days and Animal House into its classics and, faster than you can say toga party, a pairing worthy of the coolest slacker at Yale was born: a collection of trim wool slacks, plaid bomber jackets, blazers with gold hardware, slim button-down oxfords in faded hues and plush crew necks. Add some WASP-y accessories (rep ties and nautical belts) and youll be on your way to graduating with a major in style with a minor in effortless cool. J. Press for Urban Outfitters will be available starting Nov. 19.

title: Postwar Growth and the Debt
description: I didnt have room for more history in this mornings column, but Austan Goolsbee, chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, points out that the 1990s were hardly the only time when rapid growth brought down the budget deficit and the national debt.

title: Michael Findlay, Former Merrill Banker, Joins Moelis
description: The boutique investment bank Moelis & Company has added Michael Findlay, who was previously a head of corporate broking in Europe at Merrill Lynch, to its growing London office.

description: Alternative term to racial passing that shifts the focus from the viewed to the viewer.Reviewing Wayde Comptons After Canaan: Essays on Race, Writing and Region, for Quill & Quire, Adebe DeRango-Adem argued:

title: Google Strikes Deal With French Publisher
description: PARIS  Google said Wednesday that it had reached a deal with the publisher Hachette Livre, which has broken ranks with its French rivals and agreed to allow Google to scan thousands of out-of-print books for its digital library project.

title: A Record Low for Inflation
description: Score one for the Federal Reserve, which some economists have accused of jumping the gun on deflation worries.

title: Wednesday Reading: Whats in the Deficit Reduction Plans
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Barnes & Noble Shareholders Back Poison Pill
description: Shareholders of Barnes & Noble on Wednesday approved a shareholder rights plan that would limit stakes in the company to 20 percent.

title: Ernest Cole: Photographer
description: Images from the exhibition in South Africa.

title: Houses of the Holy
Homecoming for Stark Record of Apartheid
description: JOHANNESBURG  When he was only in his 20s Ernest Cole, a black photographer who stood barely five feet tall, created one of the most harrowing pictorial records of what it was like to be black in apartheid South Africa. He went into exile in 1966, and the next year his work was published in the United States in a book, House of Bondage, but his photographs were banned in his homeland where he and his work have remained little known.

title: For the Desert Tortoise, a Threat and an Opportunity
description: In an article in The New York Times on Wednesday, I write about how the fortunes of big solar power plants in the desert Southwest can hinge on the way developers handle imperiled wildlife in the path of their projects.

title: Allegheny Technologies Buys Ladish for $778 Million
description: Allegheny Technologies, a maker of specialty metals products, said on Wednesday that it had acquired a rival, Ladish, in a cash and stock deal worth about $778 million.

title: L.I. Study Rebuts Perceptions on Immigrant Workers
description: The growing immigrant population on Long Island has made a disproportionately large contribution to the regions economy, with immigrants employed across the spectrum of occupations and more than half of the immigrant labor force holding white-collar jobs, according to a study released on Wednesday.

title: Mideast Talks May Hinge on Fiery Rabbi
description: Ahead of a delayed Israeli cabinet vote on a proposal to freeze West Bank settlement construction for 90-days in order to restart peace talks, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and opponents within his own governing coalition are both trying to win the support of two ministers from an ultra-Orthodox party who appear to hold the crucial swing votes.

title: FIFA Report Finds Enough Risk All Around
description: On the day the United States national team defeated 2010 World Cup host South Africa, 1-0, and Argentina beat Brazil by the same score in Qatar, FIFA released details of a report that finds fault with both the American and Qatari bids to host the 2022 World Cup.

title: The Money Gap in the Climate Fight
description: 11:56 a.m. | Updated A core scene from Jerry Maguire, in which a football star challenges his agent to get serious, holds the same message poor countries have placed directly in the face of the worlds established industrial powers in climate treaty negotiations that resume next month: Show me the money.

title: Rangels Fall, as Dickens Would See It
description: The House ethics panel weighing Charles B. Rangels fate left little doubt Tuesday about whether Mr. Rangel took part in unethical conduct. But one crucial sidebar remains unresolved: Was Mr. Rangels situation with his former lawyers really like something out of the Dickens novel Bleak House?

description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2011 Chevrolet Camaro Convertible

description: ORLANDO, Fla.  It has been understood for weeks that Bud Selig, the commissioner of baseball, encouraged the Mets to hire Sandy Alderson as their general manager after they fired Omar Minaya on Oct. 4. But on Wednesday Selig disclosed how strong his endorsement was.

description: Allan Meltzer wept (and so did Glenn Beck, but he always does):

description: ATLANTA  Threats against his wife. A rock crashing through his office window. An administration that he thinks pulled the chair out from under him.

title: Heres to the UConn Womens Streak
description: As college basketball kicks off its season in earnest with a day so saturated with games to remind us that, yes, television will go along with just about any gag, including round-the-clock games, we are reminded that while almost everything else about the sport changes from year to year, we can be comforted (or annoyed, depending on your point of view) by the constant that is the Connecticut womens program. And Geno Auriemmas hair.

title: Now Shopping | Very Vignelli
description: For the fall issue of T Design, I wrote the Timeless page on Massimo Vignellis supersized, supergraphic Stendig calendar of 1966. It started me thinking about other vintage but evergreen designs from Vignellis office, where he and his wife and partner, Lella, have been frequent collaborators. Arguably their best-known product design is their plastic dinnerware for Heller. Now produced only in white (brightly colored older versions can bring high prices on the secondhand market), the stacking plates, bowls and mugs look as snappy  and are just as practical  as when they first appeared in 1964. From $10 to $12 per piece at the Conran Shop.

title: Republican House Gain Now at 61 Seats
description: The Republican triumph in the House of Representatives has grown a little wider, with the party now capturing 61 seats in this months midterm elections. The latest victory comes in Illinoiss Eighth Congressional District, where Representative Melissa Bean, a Democrat, conceded to Joe Walsh, a Republican.

title: Dynegy Postpones Vote on Blackstone Takeover Bid
description: The energy company Dynegy said Wednesday that it had postponed a shareholder vote on a proposed $4.7 billion takeover by the Blackstone Group after the firm raised its bid in the face of opposition from two big Dynegy shareholders.

title: For California, a New Month, a New Deficit
description: LOS ANGELES  Five weeks after the Legislature passed a budget that promised to close a $19 billion budget shortfall, California has sunk back into yet another fiscal crisis, this time facing a $26 billion gap that is posing a major new challenge for the incoming governor, Jerry Brown, and seems almost certain to force deep cuts in a state already reeling from three years of financial turmoil.

title: Activist Artist Goes on Trial in Beijing
description: BEIJING  In a case that has galvanized the Chinese arts community, a prominent artist who helped lead a short-lived demonstration along the nations most politically hallowed thoroughfare went on trial Wednesday on assault charges that supporters say are aimed at punishing him for his political activism.

title: Hulu Drops Prices to Compete With Netflix
description: In a compromise of sorts with its television network parents, Hulu is lowering the price of its TV subscription service to $7.99 a month from $9.99.

title: Murkowski Wins Alaska Senate Race
description: ANCHORAGE  Senator Lisa Murkowski won a historic victory on Wednesday in her long-shot run for re-election as a write-in candidate.

title: Paul Jacobs at Alice Tully Hall
description: Paul Jacobs, chairman of the organ department at Juilliard, re-inaugurated the Alice Tully Hall 4,192-pipe Kuhn organ with a performance of J.S. Bachs "Clavier-bung III."

title: Another Accolade for Austan Goolsbee
description: Austan Goolsbee, the chairman of the Presidents Council of Economic Advisers, can add yet another plaudit to his highly decorated rsum: one of Salons sexiest men of the year.

title: Keeping Calm: Politics, Business and Sports Edition
description: First it was New York magazine, which floated the exceedingly hypothetical idea that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg could be singularly responsible for making Sarah Palin president. That is, if he ran as a third-party candidate.

title: Murkowski Heads Home
description: Senator Lisa Murkowski flew home to Alaska on Wednesday, and could claim victory as early as Wednesday evening in her historic write-in bid for re-election, William Yardley reports.

title: 'Phil Ochs: There But for Fortune'
description: The trailer premiere of the documentary "There But for Fortune," about the musician Phil Ochs.

title: Disque D. Deane, Real Estate Investor, Dies at 89
description: Disque D. Deane, a financier and real estate investor who at one time controlled the General Motors Building, shopping centers in New York, Massachusetts and Georgia, and the nations largest federally subsidized housing complex, Starrett City in Brooklyn, died on Nov. 8 at his home in Boston. He was 89.

title: Yao on the Mend, Again
description: Its the proverbial good news-bad news situation for injured Houston Rockets center Yao Ming. The happy news is, his sprained left ankle doesnt appear to be nearly as serious as his litany of other foot injuries.

title: Praising Second Place
description: Two follow-ups to the conversation here last week about whether to ground a child who brings home less than an 85 on her report card.

title: Bail in Insider Case Set at $3 Million
description: A French doctor accused of illegally leaking sensitive material about a clinical drug trial to a hedge fund manager will be held on $3 million bail, a magistrate judge said on Wednesday.

title: Bean Counters to the Rescue!
description: Gail Collins: David, did you do the budget puzzle in The Times on Sunday? I really enjoyed seeing if I could eliminate all the shortfalls for the next 20 years. (Thank you, David Leonhardt and Co.) The first time I did it, about two-thirds of my savings came from increased tax revenue rather than spending cuts. But in the end, I got it down to 50-50. How about you?

title: Report Faults BP and Contractors for Rig Explosion and Spill
description: WASHINGTON  Inadequate training and supervision of key personnel aboard the Deepwater Horizon drilling rig and a lack of focus on safety were among the factors that contributed to the explosion that killed 11 workers and sent millions of barrels of oil gushing into the Gulf of Mexico, according to a preliminary report released Wednesday by a team of scientific experts.

title: 2012 VW Eos: If at First You Dont Succeed, Get a Face-Lift
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2012 Volkswagen Eos

title: From Ancient Rome to a Valley in Virginia: More Digital Humanities Projects
description: A majority of academics may view with suspicion whats come to be called the digital humanities, but as I explain in this article (the first in a series on how technology is changing scholarship), the new alliance of techies and fuzzies is producing all sorts of experiments in presenting information.

title: Long Missed and Awaited, Tully Hall Organ Greets Its Public
description: Lincoln Center could have been forgiven if it had gone a little crazy in celebrating the reinstallation of the lovable Kuhn organ in the renovated Alice Tully Hall, now the only pipe organ in a major concert hall in New York. From the time of the instruments removal in 2006 until it was finally put back in place in recent months, fearful, not to say paranoid, organ fanciers greeted the centers repeated assurances that the instrument would return in all its glory, and then some, with unalloyed skepticism.

title: Gotham Chronicle: Sharp Eye, and Pencil
description: IF there is a single constant in the creative world, it is that fame has a nasty habit of disappearing overnight. One prime example is the cartoonist Denys Wortman, who from 1924 to 1954 contributed six drawings a week to The New York World and its successors.

title: Get Me Redraw!
description: Denys Wortman, a New York reporter who drew, is being rediscovered.

title: Social Coupons and Small Businesses, Part 2
description: Last week, I wrote about Ron Weiss and his experiences using a Groupon discount at Jeffreys Restaurant and Bar, in Austin. (If you havent seen it, the post ignited a lively debate on the uses and misuses of Groupon.)

title: Consumers Say Theyll Spend More This Christmas
description: A holiday spending boost  which many retail stores desperately need to put them in the black  may be in the cards this year, at least if a recent survey of consumers is to be believed.

title: Expanded Return Periods for Those With Buyers Regret
description: American Express recently announced a new service that gives shoppers 180 days to return eligible purchased goods. It also covers certain return shipping and restocking fees.

title: Brooklyn Winery Opens in Williamsburg
description: BEFORE Duane Reade landed on Williamsburgs shore, the trucker-hatted and ironically T-shirted drank cheap beer in cavernous spaces along North Eighth Street.

title: An Aid Worker Writes: Afghanistan, Disability, and the Wests Limiting Labels
description: KABUL  Ive learned that Afghans are prone to pragmatism when it comes to what we Westerners refer to as disability. Despite what you might think, our obsession with identity politics doesnt play very well in Afghanistan, at least about this it doesnt.

title: Museum of Modern Art Gets on the iPad App Bandwagon
description: Ab Ex now has its own app. In conjunction with its Abstract Expressionist New York exhibition, the grand tour through the Museum of Modern Arts holdings of (mostly) New York School masterpieces, the museum has just released its first application for the Apple iPad, which is rapidly becoming a museum-going staple.

title: Interview With the President of the World Chess Federation, Part 2
description: After his recent re-election as president of the World Chess Federation, Kirsan Ilyumzhinov offered to answer questions from readers of The Times about the federation, which is also known by the acronym FIDE (for Fdration Internationale des checs), and about his plans for the future of the game. Part one of the interview appeared Tuesday and addressed the federations plans to build a chess center in New York City and the recent election. This is part two. Part three will appear Thursday.

title: The Takeaway: Cavett Talks
description: Dick Cavett appeared on The Takeaway to discuss his show and his new book, and reflect on a little-known fact: his time as gold-medal state gymnastics champion in Nebraska.

title: TimesCast | November 17, 2010
description: The Europe debt crisis looms; Cable news stars defend their journalistic integrity; and a first look at another installment in the series "A Year at War"

title: House Democrats Wont Delay Leadership Vote
description: House Democrats today rejected a call to delay leadership elections, clearing the way for Nancy Pelosi to return as party leader.

title: Your Comments on Clicking in Class
description: 1:52 p.m. | Updated For an interesting coda on this discussion, scroll to the bottom of this post, where Professor Bill White, the subject of the original article, provides the results of a survey on the efficacy of clickers that he conducted with his students  using their clickers, of course.

title: Revisiting a Republican Deficit Plan
description: In the last week, two different bipartisan groups have released their plans for reducing the deficit, and a liberal coalition in Washington will soon do the same. Arguably the first in this spate of deficit plans came from Representative Paul Ryan, the Wisconsin Republican now in line to become chairman of the House Budget Committee.

title: Rep. Ryan on His Medicare Plan
description: The following was submitted by Representative Paul Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin. More on Mr. Ryans plan to change Medicare and reduce the deficit is here.

title: On Our Radar: Worlds Largest Biodiesel Plant Opens in Singapore
description: What is being billed as the largest biodiesel plant in the world started production this week in Singapore. Operated by Neste Oil, the plant has the capacity to produce 800,000 metric tons of fuel per year. The fuel is made from vegetable oils or a combination of oils and waste animal fat sourced from the food industry. [Marketwatch]

title: Contemporary in Luxembourg
description: This 550-square-meter house with an indoor pool is in Luxembourg, just outside the city center. Its on the market for 3.9 million euros (about $5.3 million)

title: Accused Arms Dealer Pleads Not Guilty
description: A man accused of being one of the worlds most prolific arms dealers swaggered into a Manhattan courtroom on Wednesday, sizing up his surroundings after a two-year fight between the United States and Russia over his extradition from Thailand.

title: A Business Creator Sees Big Returns From Social Media
description: Asked to name the worlds wealthiest entrepreneurs, few people would think of Eric Lefkofsky, who is 40 and keeps a deliberately low profile in his hometown of Chicago. But Mr. Lefkofsky has an impressive entrepreneurial track record, one that recently led Forbes to estimate his wealth at $750 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Luxembourg
description: A FIVE-BEDROOM HOUSE WITH AN INDOOR SWIMMING POOL

description: The Book of Mormon, the first Broadway musical from Trey Parker and Matt Stone, the creators of South Park, has found its Mormons.
