description: Q.

title: F.D.A. Issues Warning Over Alcoholic Energy Drinks
description: The Food and Drug Administration cracked down Wednesday on four manufacturers of caffeinated alcoholic drinks, giving them 15 days to stop adding caffeine to the products or stop selling them altogether.

title: New Director for  Schomburg Center Named
description: Khalil Gibran Muhammad, a history professor at Indiana University, has been named the new director of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, to begin in July 2011. New York Public Library officials made the announcement on Wednesday, ending a sometimes contentious search.

title: Out of Work, Spider-Man Gets Advice From Bloomberg
description: A team-up is often called for when superheroes face problems too big for them to handle on their own. In a new comic book, Peter Parker, the alter ego of Spider-Man, gets a little help from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to deal with one of his toughest foes: unemployment.

title: What Were Reading: Monetary Policy, in Comic Book Form
Microsoft Gives the Cloud to Scientists
description: 2:07 p.m. | Updated  This post was updated to clarify Microsofts pricing model around the Azure for science services.

title: Academy Tallies Missteps by Gulf Drillers
description: Initial findings have been released by the panel convened by the National Academy of Engineering to assess decisions, or the lack of them, that led to the deadly oil rig explosion and gulf gusher. Unsurprisingly, there are strong signs that concerns about money outweighed concerns about sources of risk. The full report will be issued next year.

title: Sofalising
description: Socialising from a sofa, using smartphones and laptops. (Sofa + socialising)

title: Homes for $800,000
description: A three-bedroom historic house in West Palm Beach, Fla., a two-bedroom floating house in Seattle and a four-bedroom Queen Anne in Barrington, Ill.

title: What You Get for ... $800,000
description: SEATTLE

title: Goldman Names 110 New Partners
description: 5:13 p.m. | Updated Goldman Sachs has selected 110 executives to become partners, one of the most lucrative tickets on Wall Street.

title: Volvos New Chief Says, Things Can Only Get Better
description: Why did Stefan Jacoby leave the top job at up-and-coming Volkswagen of America to become chief executive of beleaguered Volvo Cars last year?

title: On the Record: Praise for Burris
description: When Roland Burris, a Democrat from Illinois, was appointed to the United States Senate in late 2008, a cloud of impropriety hung over his selection, and not even fellow Democrats were eager to welcome him into their ranks. But now, as Mr. Burriss time in Congress is coming to an end, Senate Democrats had nothing but kind words for him in Tuesdays Homeland Security hearing about closing gaps in air cargo security.

title: Massey Will Review Any Offer, Chief Says
description: The chief executive of Massey Energy, Don L. Blankenship, acknowledged for the first time on Wednesday that directors of the mining company were seriously considering takeover bids.

title: Pictures of the Day: Italy and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Italy, Myanmar and Israel.

title: Dear Mr. Bernanke: No Pressure, but
description: No pressure, really. Just a little input from Capitol Hill.

title: Senate to Take Up Food Safety Bill
description: The Senate voted on Wednesday to take up consideration of a bill to improve the nations food safety system.

title: Subduing the Korengal Valley
description: For Capt. Dan Kearney life in Afghanistan's Korengal Valley is full of difficult decisions and bloody consequences.

title: Kleins Waiver, and the Citys Chief Street Monitor
description: On an August morning in 2002, a panel of education experts from across the state came to Manhattan to decide a pressing matter: Did Joel I. Klein have the experience needed to lead the New York City school system?

title: Cord Cutting? Cable Subscriptions Drop Again
description: 7:37 p.m. | Updated

title: An N.B.A. Move That Crossed an Ocean
description: Growing up, Roger Mason Jr. practiced the moves that were created by Americas basketball imagination. There was the crossover dribble, with the player moving the ball from one hand to the other, and the fadeaway jump shot, with the player leaping backward while shooting to create distance from the defender. But only after he became a professional did Mason decide to expand globally, adding fakes and feints and other moves that were manufactured elsewhere.

title: Building Relationships, Capturing Lives
description: Rachel Mummey, 27, has been an intern at The Palm Beach Post since October. Last week, Mummey, a School of Visual Communication graduate student at Ohio University, was named College Photographer of the Year. Her story, For Better or For Worse, about Bernard and Mary Triplet, won an award from Pictures of the Year International. For the last year, Ms. Mummey has been photographing low-income families from Chicago who relocated to Iowa City. Her conversation with Kerri MacDonald, part of the Turning Point series, has been edited.

title: Free Rides, Minus the Smoking Tires, Courtesy of Top Gear
description: To promote the premiere on Sunday of the American version of the BBC program Top Gear on the History channel, free rides in several hot cars were offered around Bryant Park and Times Square in Manhattan on Wednesday. (More details about the new show will be in the Automobiles section of The New York Times on Sunday.)

title: House Democrats Re-Elect Pelosi as Their Leader
description: 4:09 p.m. | Updated  The House speaker, Nancy Pelosi of California, was re-elected on Wednesday to lead the Democrats in the next Congress, despite her partys loss of more than 60 seats and its majority control of the House in the midterm elections.

title: Music and Transcendence: Lets Talk About the White Light Festival
description: Marketing device or access to our inner souls?

title: Warner Music Reports Fourth-Quarter Loss
description: The Warner Music Group posted a $46 million loss in its fourth quarter as increased digital sales were not enough to offset declines from CDs.

title: Mets Manager Interviews Proceed in Orlando
description: ORLANDO  The Mets are gathering their final four managerial candidates at the Waldorf Astoria and will begin the second round of interviews Wednesday afternoon. They expect to get all four interviews completed by Thursday afternoon.

title: Cuomo Seeks Courts Help in Undecided Senate Races
description: Governor-elect Andrew M. Cuomo is asking the states chief judge to expedite the handling of the three undecided State Senate races to avoid a leadership stalemate when the next legislative session begins in January.

title: The Cloud Batters the Buddy Punch
description: Workers of the world unite and bemoan the end of the buddy punch.

title: U.S. Lags in Reducing Traffic Fatalities, Report Shows
description: The debate over which countries produce the best drivers will continue unabated, but the National Research Council weighed in Tuesday with an opinion about which countries have the safest drivers  and the news is not good for Americans.

title: 2011 Dodge Charger: Coke Light?
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2011 Dodge Charger

title: Coal Plants, Rising and Retiring
description: While many believe that far stricter regulation of carbon dioxide emissions is inevitable in the next few years, coal plants are still under construction around the country, as I wrote in The New York Times on Wednesday. Plans for even more plants have been scrapped, partly because of the recession. Keeping score can be tough.

title: Asked & Answered | Claire Denis
description: On November 19, the French director Claire Deniss latest film, White Material opens in New York. Its her 10th feature and, like her first and fifth films, Chocolat, (1988) and Beau Travail, (1999), it was shot in Africa, where she grew up. You can usually recognize a Denis production due to its minimal dialogue, evocative sense of place, long, lingering shots, non-linear narrative flow and intense focus on complex human relationships. These are provocative slow burns that leave unanswered questions in their wakes. We asked Denis to answer a few.

title: A New Genre of Photo Apps Competes for Time
description: Given a few minutes of extra time, I like to jump into a methodical game of app hopscotch on my iPhone, skipping between the square icons looking for something to catch my attention.

title: Kucinich Makes Bid for Oversight Committee
description: Representative Dennis J. Kucinich of Ohio, a two-time long-shot Democratic presidential candidate, is known for ideas that come out of left field.

title: Coup Attempt by Military Is Reported in Madagascar
description: JOHANNESBURG  Military officers in Madagascar on Wednesday proclaimed that they had seized the government. The mutinous group included some of the same men who had taken over the country last year and handed power to the president they now seek to topple.

title: An E-Book Bonanza: 12 Saramago Novels
description: In another digital publishing experiment Houghton Mifflin Harcourt will publish 12 of Jos Saramagos novels  plus a novella  in an e-book collection for $36.

title: Biology in Film: Using Animation to Study Cell Structure
description: Overview  | How can animations help convey the dynamic nature of cellular processes? What can we learn from animation that cannot be learned as easily from still images? In this lesson, students watch high-definition animations that depict the processes of DNA transcription and translation, and then write voice-over scripts.

title: Rational Discussion of Climate on Capitol Hill?
description: Maybe its the nature of lame duck congressional sessions. Maybe its Democrats seeking ways to reach out to Republicans before the shift in power in the House.

title: RockMelt: The User Manual
description: Last week, a start-up company called RockMelt unveiled a free browser for PCs and Macs, customized for people who live on Facebook, Twitter and other social-networking sites. RockMelt has gotten a lot of attention, because the companys management and investors include several of the Netscape mafia who built the first widely successful browser in the early 1990s, including the Silicon Valley wunderkind Marc Andreessen.

title: Ailes to Kurtz on Donations and Obamas Belief System
description: Some people in the television world were outraged when Keith Olbermann donated money to three Democratic candidates ahead of the midterm elections, prompting a short suspension by MSNBC. Roger Ailes was not among them.

title: For Euro Nations, There Are Strings Attached
description: FRANKFURT  Even as British officials and other Europeans bear down on a resolution to Irelands debt crisis, there is a lingering unease in the markets about whether one or more countries might eventually bolt the currency union.

title: Going to Market in the Shadow of G.M.
description: The initial public offering of General Motors has been getting all the headlines and dominating the airtime on the financial news networks. But what about the other companies that are scheduled to go public on Thursday?

title: Boehner Officially on the Path to Be Speaker
description: House Republicans, fresh off their tremendous victories this month, have given the official nod to John A. Boehner of Ohio, setting him on the path to be speaker of the House for the 112th Congress.

title: Guilty Plea in Cantor Threat Case
description: A Philadelphia man pleaded guilty on Tuesday to threatening Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, the No. 2 Republican in the House, earlier this year.

title: Yep, Its Regressive
description: Jon Chait takes another look at Bowles-Simpson, this time with numbers from the Tax Policy Center, and is disillusioned. As I surmised, it redistributes income upward: the bottom 80 percent of families would pay higher taxes than they did in the Clinton years, while the top 20 percent  and especially the top 5 percent  would pay less; not what youd call shared sacrifice.

title: An Iranian Directors Impassioned Defense
description: At his trial in Tehran last week, Jafar Panahi, an internationally celebrated Iranian filmmaker who supported opposition protesters after last years disputed presidential election, accused the authorities of sending the message: You will repent if you dont think like us.

title: HomeAway Returns to the Super Bowl
description: Another advertiser has identified itself as a sponsor of Super Bowl XLV, to be broadcast on Fox on Feb. 6.

title: White Light Festival: A Commercial Endeavor
description: Over the past several weeks, Lincoln Center has presented the White Light Festival, billed as an exploration of the spiritual in music. The classical music critics and a reporter are discussing the merits of the festival, music and transcendence on ArtsBeat. Read all posts.

title: Debating Social Securitys Cost of Living Adjustment
description: You could almost hear the collective groan from Social Security recipients after they learned that their benefits would not increase in 2011 because of the low rate of inflation.

title: How I Saved My Company: Wendell August Forge
description: On March 4, Wendell August Forge, a family-owned company that makes and sells metal giftware, booked the largest order in its history  for commemorative tickets to be given away the next month by the Pittsburgh Penguins at the last regular-season hockey game played at Mellon Arena.

title: Kanye West, Still Unfiltered, on Eve of Fifth Album
description: KANYE WEST prefers his narratives linear, uninterrupted, undistressed. Thats why, when hes been in the news media lately, his interlocutors have largely stayed out of his way. On everything from radio shows to record-label-sanctioned conference calls simulcast on the Internet, the pattern has been pretty much the same: Mr. West speaks until he is done, and only then does someone ask another question.

title: Austerity In Action
Mark Bittmans Sustainable Thanksgiving
description: The New York Times food writer Mark Bittman sometimes calls himself a less-meatarian to explain how his diet has changed over the years.

title: What Were Reading
description: YouTube: Parathas, the Indian flat bread, take to the air.  Nick Fox

title: In the Examination Room, an Effort to Prevent Financial Abuse
description: Can doctors and other medical professionals be trained to spot elderly patients who are at risk of being ripped off?

title: 2011 Ford Focus Global Touring Car
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2011 Ford Focus Global Touring Car race car

title: Vain Glorious | Sweet (Smelling) Charity
description: Who: Six designers (Alexis Mabille, Mary Katrantzou, Juun J., Rad Hourani, N. Hoolywood and Ohne Titel) and six perfumers (Rodrigo Flores-Roux, Shyamala Maisondieu, Natalie Gracia-Cetto, Christophe Raynaud, Stephen Nilsen and Yann Vasnier).

title: Fearing Terror Threat, Germany Raises Security
description: Germany dispatched heavily armed police officers and bomb-sniffing dogs to train stations, airports and key landmarks on Wednesday as a new picture emerged of the terrorist threat that had already provoked security alarms relating to Britain and France.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Do Not Disturb Kanye West
description: On the cover of this weeks Arts & Leisure Jon Caramanica looks at the rapper Kanye West, who is capping off weeks of controversy with a new album, My Beautiful Dark, Twisted Fantasy, out on Monday on Roc-A-Fella/Def Jam. While the album is terrific, as Mr. Caramanica writes, that doesnt matter nearly as much as it should, at least partly because of Mr. Wests insistence on his own greatness. By not allowing for responses to his work other than awe, the value of the work itself is diminished; it becomes an object of admiration, not of study. Read his story here.

title: Google TV, Usability Not Included
description: Google Mail. Google Phone. Google Voice. Google News.

title: Lemon and Lime from Quincy Jones
description: Quincy Jones knows subtle: his arrangements for Count Basie and Frank Sinatra on Fly Me to the Moon were subtle. His Oscar-nominated scores for In Cold Blood and The Color Purple were subtle. O.K., so maybe Thriller, the album he produced for Michael Jackson, wasnt so subtle.

title: Is Pelosi Americas Most Unpopular Politician?
description: House Democrats voted Wednesday to keep House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California as their leader, despite a challenge from Representative Heath Shuler of North Carolina, a Blue Dog Democrat.

title: Plan to Extend No. 7 Train Surprised the M.T.A.
description: The Bloomberg administration stunned the citys transportation establishment on Tuesday evening as reports trickled out about an ambitious plan to extend the No. 7 subway train under the Hudson River and into New Jersey.

title: Older Job-Seekers More Willing to Take a Pay Cut
description: We recently wrote about the latest survey report on displaced workers from Heldrich Center for Workforce Development at Rutgers. Now the Sloan Center on Aging and Work of Boston College has drilled down deeper into the data to investigate the differences between older and younger unemployed workers, given that older workers have tremendous trouble finding re-employment once they have become displaced.

title: Andrews Adds to Giants Injury Worries
description: Giants offensive lineman Shawn Andrews, who started the past two games at left tackle in place of the injured David Diehl, did not practice on Wednesday because of his own nagging back injury.

title: Bloomberg Rallies Business Leaders Behind Black
description: Hoping to fend off skepticism about his choice for schools chancellor, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has turned to a familiar and reliable ally: the business community.

title: New Releases on DVD
description: AVATAR Eight months after the first home video release heres another edition of the James Cameron blockbuster, which contains three different cuts  the original theatrical version, a special edition rerelease that is 8 minutes longer and a collectors extended cut that adds 16 minutes to the original. Still no 3-D, though. (Fox, Blu-ray, $54.99; standard definition, $34.98; PG-13)

title: Cellphone Carriers Try to Control Signal Boosters
description: When Sean Kirkland, an executive vice president for sales and marketing for a company that plans corporate meetings and events, moved into a new house in San Diego last year, he loved everything about the place.

title: Repackaged Favorites on DVD
description: THE AFRICAN QUEEN Long unavailable on home video, John Hustons 1951 romantic adventure, starring Katharine Hepburn as a starched missionary and Humphrey Bogart as a grizzled riverboat captain, returns in a handsomely restored print. (Paramount, two-disc Blu-ray commemorative edition, $57.99; two-disc standard definition, $50.99; Blu-ray, $39.99; standard definition, $25.99; not rated)

title: A Bear Fights Soros and a Bullish Tide on InterOil
description: Is InterOil a great way to play Asias commodity boom or a overhyped company worth a fraction of its $3.4 billion market value?

title: 4 Towns, 4 Tasty New Reasons to Visit
description: Chicago

title: Medicare Panel Backs Prostate Drug
description: A federal advisory committee said Wednesday that there was adequate evidence that the drug Provenge prolongs the lives of men with advanced prostate cancer, an endorsement that makes it more likely that Medicare will pay for the $93,000 treatment.

title: Tools to Do Your Travel Homework Before Booking
description: When online travel agencies started rolling out smartphone apps, I was dubious. Mobile phones are great for killing time or completing small tasks  not for sifting through pages of flight times and travel dates.

title: Sharpening the Type in Windows 7
description: Q. I know you can adjust the ClearType settings in Windows 7 to make the type on the screen look sharper. But is it possible to save these settings and switch back and forth between two users with different sets of eyes and opinions about what looks best?

title: Seasonal DVDs
description: BING CROSBY: THE TELEVISION SPECIALS, VOLUME 2  THE CHRISTMAS SPECIALS A two-disc selection of our national crooners Christmas shows, ranging from the first, from 1961, to the final 1977 show, featuring Crosbys duet with David Bowie, Peace on Earth/Little Drummer Boy. (Infinity Entertainment, $29.98, not rated)

title: Midterms Threaten Obamas Rail Plans
description: The Obama administrations signature transportation initiative is almost always described as high-speed rail. But more than half of the $10.4 billion the administration has awarded for rail so far has not gone toward real bullet trains, but to build slower, conventional train lines that it hopes will form the foundation of a nationwide high-speed rail network.

title: Quote Unquote | A Friend Indeed
description: Karl Lagerfeld praises the social media interfaces design. I wish I was friends with Karl so I could like this statement.

title: 2011 Porsche Cayman R: R is for Radical?
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2011 Porsche Cayman R

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Social Networking in the Workplace
description: When social networking and the workplace meet, complex issues often arise. On this weeks New York TimesTech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein speaks with Bill Milani, a lawyer who represents employers, about how companies are addressing the social media boom  and what you might want to consider if you post to social media sites while at work. Mr. Milani, who teaches at the School of Industrial and Labor Relations of Cornell, says more companies are adopting or considering policies on social networking.

title: Hunting for Looted Art in Paris
description: IN Room 38 of the Louvres Richelieu Wing hangs The Astronomer by the Dutch master Jan Vermeer. It is an exquisite painting. The stargazer sits before a celestial globe, his fingers spanning the constellation Pegasus. He wears a teal Japanese silk robe, a style favored by Dutch burghers in the late 17th century. He is lost in thought and bathed in a golden light.

title: Skin Deep: A Late-Night Tanning Session
description: Self-beautifying options of the wee hours have expanded well beyond trims and manicures.

title: G.M. Shares Surge on Market Debut
description: 4:20 p.m. | Updated Shares of General Motors surged on Thursday in their New York Stock Exchange debut.

title: Seeking Clarity and Truth at a Drunken Reunion
description: The introduction of the supernatural doesnt interrupt Heidi Schrecks dining-room drama There Are No More Big Secrets. Talk of witches and spirits is woven into the fabric of the otherwise realistic world, which, like the plays of Annie Baker, whose Circle Mirror Transformation starred Ms. Schreck in a breakout role, includes lingering pauses between lovely bursts of offhand dialogue.

title: Superstar Horse Is Retired With Hope She Bears Another
description: The great mare Zenyatta was retired Wednesday and will be sent in early December to her new home at Lanes End farm near Versailles, Ky. Her owners, Jerry and Ann Moss, have yet to pick a stallion for her first date in the breeding shed sometime in 2011.

title: In Panama, a Haven for Expats
description: ON a humid morning in Panama City earlier this year, three Americans, two Swedes, two Portuguese, two Irish and three Israelis sat down together for breakfast. The diverse group was united by a single interest: free pancakes, a standard perk at Lunas Castle Hostel in the citys historic district.

title: Beauty House Calls in the Wee Hours
description: NEWSPAPER deliverers show up on your doorstep at dawn. At that hour, the woman you pay to spray you with a fake tan usually would not. But recently Tamar Vezirian of Gotham Glow arrived at a clients apartment in Murray Hill in Manhattan to bronze her before a vacation. She had to leave at 6 a.m. to go to J.F.K., Ms. Vezirian said. So I tanned her, and then her car service picked her up and took her away.

title: When Dancing on Pointe Isnt Hard Enough
description: While dance fans eagerly await the release next month of Black Swan, Darren Aronofskys melodrama about rival ballerinas, heres a version of Swan Lake you wont see often. Its not new, but it has lately been making the rounds, wowing some balletomanes and horrifying others. You decide.

title: Match Making | Just for Erdem Lovers
description: The British store Matches has stocked its virtual and digital racks with Erdem for quite some time now. Now the designer behind the brand, Erdem Moralioglu, has created an exclusive pre-spring collection just for the Matches Web site. The five pieces, available now through March 2011, come in an Erdem signature floral print and a range of styles including a jean blouse, a maxi skirt and a couple of dresses. The special collection is targeted toward cocktail wear, hence the Deco feel to the pieces, says Ruth Chapman, a co-founder of the store. Here is a sneak peek behind the making of this stellar match by the photographer Errol Rainey and featuring the model Valentine Fillol-Cordier.

title: Need Solar Power? Buy a Garden Plot
description: In an article in the special Energy section of The New York Times on Wednesday, I write about a developer who wants to sell garden plots in a 15-megawatt photovoltaic farm in Davis, Calif., so that residents can go solar without having to cut down trees in the citys urban forest to install rooftop arrays.

title: DVDs for Cinephiles
description: CHAPLIN AT KEYSTONE 34 short comedies and a full-length feature (Tillies Punctured Romance) from Charlie Chaplins first year in motion pictures, presented in revelatory high-grade restorations. (Flicker Alley, $79.95, not rated)

title: George H.W. Bush to Get Medal of Freedom
description: President Obama will present the Medal of Freedom, the nations highest civilian honor, to former president George H. W. Bush and 14 others with careers in politics, the arts, business and sports.

title: Laurence Tribe Is Leaving Justice Job
description: After nine months as the Justice Departments senior counselor for access to justice, Laurence H. Tribe, a prominent Harvard law professor and mentor to President Obama, will leave his position and return to Massachusetts early next month.

title: Palin Tells Barbara Walters She Can Beat Obama
description: On the heels of a New York Times magazine article in which she acknowledges considering a run for president, Sarah Palin has told Barbara Walters that she believes she could defeat President Obama.

title: Police! Step Away From the Chess Table
description: Updated, 6:10 p.m. | Wherever you find yourself in the city, there is probably an outdoor chess table nearby. According to the parks department, there are more than 2,000 public chess or checkers tables spread among 536 parks, offering the perfect spot to sacrifice a queen or promote a pawn.

title: White Light Festival: Define Spiritual
description: Over the past several weeks, Lincoln Center has presented the White Light Festival, billed as an exploration of the spiritual in music. The classical music critics and a reporter are discussing the merits of the festival, music and transcendence on ArtsBeat. Read all posts.

title: Pictures of the Day: Italy and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Indonesia, Myanmar and Israel.

title: A Spanish Master
description: Still buzzing over Billy Reids win at the CFDA Awards and the news of the royal engagement, various fashion cognoscenti trekked up to the landmark townhouse occupied by the Queen Sofia Spanish Institute (684 Park Avenue, at 68th Street) to get a sneak peek at the exhibition, Balenciaga: Spanish Master. Oscar de la Renta, the Institutes Chairman of the Board explained that the influences in his world were very Spanish because even after his big success in Paris he still remained very Spanish as a person. He went on to say that Balenciaga was deeply influenced by all the culture and folklore of Spain from the religious to the gypsy and the flamencos and bullfighters. T caught up with Hamish Bowles, who curated the show but who also has an impressive collection of Balenciaga all his own.

title: Fashion on eBay, Spoken by Annabel Tollman
description: ANNABEL TOLLMAN, a celebrity stylist, has a simple message for clients like Scarlett Johansson, Anne Hathaway and the Olsen twins when it comes to fashioning head-turning looks. Make a fairy tale and go and live in it, she said.

title: Playwrights Shuttle to TV and Back
description: ONE of the strangely enduring laments of the American theater concerns playwrights leaving for television. Critics and theater people regularly sigh about how the lure of riches hurts the growth of playwrights and contemporary drama.

title: Senator Asks: Cant Fox and MSNBC Just Go Away?
description: Theres a part of Senator Jay Rockefeller, Democrat of West Virginia, that would like to see Fox News Channel and MSNBC vanish.

title: Steering With Knees, Cuffed Fugitive Drives Off in Police Car
description: The police were searching for a fugitive wanted for questioning in a Bronx shooting and other charges on Wednesday, after he escaped from police custody and  using his knees to steer because his hands were cuffed  sped off in an unmarked police car in Fort Lee, N.J.

title: New Plugs for an Electric Car
description: The effort by the Chevrolet division of General Motors to familiarize drivers with the 2011 Chevrolet Volt  an electric car with a gasoline engine  is accelerating with additional commercials.

title: Where Hepburn Might Shop
description: CHRISTINA FRENCH HOUGHTONS great-great-great-grandfather was the legendary actress Katharine Houghton Hepburns uncle.

title: Southern-Flavored Rock Comes to Town, Complete With a 70s Feel
description: On the plus side Kings of Leon albums are improving. Come Around Sundown (RCA), which was released last month, is the bands best and also its loosest. Gone is the underskilled tension of its early albums, which felt lashed together with twine. Finally, the groups shaggy Southern rock boogie is beginning to feel earned and confident.

title: Report Casts Doubt on Contadors Claim
description: A Spanish newspaper reported that the World Anti-Doping Agency discredited Alberto Contadors claim that tainted beef he ate caused him to fail a drug test at the Tour de France last summer.

title: Just Your Conventional Mix of Rachmaninoff, High Kicks and High Heels
description: As an example of High Junk at its showiest, look no further than Complexions. The company  it bears the subtitle Contemporary Ballet and its artistic directors are Dwight Rhoden and Desmond Richardson  is now installed at the Joyce for its annual season. On Tuesdays opening night, all the choreography was by Mr. Rhoden; all was efficiently horrid.

title: Want to Play Chess in the Park? It Could Be a Crime
description: Playing chess in New York City parks is a well established custom, so much so that the city has installed more than 2,000 tables among its 536 parks. But, if adults want to play on those tables  and those are typically the people who do  and those tables happen to be in a playground, the players may run into trouble. With the police. That is evidently what a group of players found out at the Emerson Playground in Inwood Hill Park in Manhattan.

title: David Burke To Open a Restaurant in the James New York
description: David Burke has just signed on to do the restaurant in the James New York, a new hotel at Grand Street and Avenue of the Americas in SoHo. It is expected to open in February on a site, 32 Grand Street, that is essentially where the Moonstruck Diner used to be, Mr. Burke said.

title: Mixing Old and New in Lebanon
description: The owners saw the potential in a pile of rubble, filling it with modern furniture and contemporary art.

title: Focusing in on Dreams and Meditations
description: The young French pianist David Fray approaches music very seriously. Though his performances of works by Schubert and Bach on Tuesday night at Zankel Hall were musically refined and technically elegant, searching out the meditative qualities of the music was Mr. Frays top priority. In the first of Schuberts Four Impromptus (D. 899), he immediately summoned the attention of his audience by playing the bare double octave that begins the piece with sternness and steely sound. But then, as the wistful theme began, Mr. Fray played it with such aching delicacy that the music seemed almost too sad to speak. As the piece evolved into haunting episodes with endless streams of repeated triplets, Mr. Fray revealed the musics obsessive, hypnotic core even while playing with remarkably soft dynamics.

title: India Microcredit Faces Collapse From Defaults
description: MADOOR, India  Indias rapidly growing private microcredit industry faces imminent collapse as almost all borrowers in one of Indias largest states have stopped repaying their loans, egged on by politicians who accuse the industry of earning outsize profits on the backs of the poor.

title: Why Im Soft On Sales Taxes
description: Theres a lot of backlash against the new Rivlin-Domenici proposal for suggesting a significant VAT  and people are right, sales taxes are regressive taxes. But while I havent had time to evaluate the whole thing, the sales tax itself isnt a killing point in my view.

title: Bristol Palin Survives
description: Despite posting the lowest scores from the judges for the third straight week, Bristol Palin survived another elimination round of Dancing With the Stars on Tuesday as she beat out the singer Brandy Norwood to advance to the finals. The ABC show garnered an impressive 17.2 million viewers at 9 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates, enough to lift the network to second place on the night. CBS led the night as usual with 19.4 million viewers for NCIS at 8 followed by 15.8 million at 9 for NCIS: Los Angeles. Although Foxs Glee, with a guest appearance from Gwyneth Paltrow, attracted the nights top ratings among viewers 18 to 49, in total viewers the 8 p.m. episode drew a more modest 11.6 million as Fox placed third over all, ahead of NBC.

title: In Beirut, a Town House Rises From Rubble
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon

title: 2010 L.A. Auto Show
description: Highlights from the auto show in Los Angeles.

title: Susan Boyle Returns to Top of Chart
description: Susan Boyle, below, has bumped Taylor Swift from the top of the Billboard album chart. But Ms. Boyles success is not nearly as splashy as it was a year ago, when her debut album broke sales records and went on to dominate the chart for weeks. The Gift (Syco/Columbia), Ms. Boyles second CD, which includes lush versions of holiday standards as well as gloomy-but-still-possibly-inspirational songs like Lou Reeds Perfect Day and Leonard Cohens Hallelujah, sold 318,000 copies in the United States in its first week, Nielsen SoundScan reported. That was far from the 701,000 her first album opened with last year, but it was enough to take the top spot from Ms. Swift, whose Speak Now (Big Machine) moved 212,000 in its third week out. Some new releases placed high on this weeks chart: the rapper Kid Cudi opened at No. 3 with 169,000 sales of his second album, Man on the Moon II: The Legend of Mr. Rager (Dream On/G.O.O.D./Universal Motown); Volume 36 of the pop compilation series Now Thats What I Call Music! bowed at No. 4 with 89,000; and Bon Jovis Greatest Hits (Island) opened at No. 5 with 88,000.

title: Afraid, Betrayed, Mistreated and Optimistic
description: The camaraderie of the road filled the concert by the English band Mumford & Sons on Tuesday night at Terminal 5, finishing a long United States tour. Marcus Mumford and his band (whose members are not related to him) didnt wait for their headlining spot to get onstage.

title: Sunny Approach To Mordant Lyricist
description: The song lyrics of Lorenz Hart offer a singer any number of possible interpretive paths to follow. You can sink into their quicksand of wistful urbanity as Mary Cleere Haran does. Or lovingly deconstruct them as Karen Akers does. Or you can stand aside and admire their rhymes and polished turns of phrase as Stefanie Powers does in her New York cabaret debut, Hart of My Heart, at Feinsteins at Loews Regency. The Hart refers not only to Lorenz but also to Ms. Powerss long-running television series, Hart to Hart.

title: Newly Released Books
description: Some women love czars, while some find true love with a gay best friend. Others are drawn to those who behead kings, while the next gal will flee from a good thing. Some arent even women yet, just teenagers, taken in by creepy men. The stories in this months crop of new books belong to the women and the girls  and the men in their lives.

title: Historian Will Direct Schomburg Center in Harlem
description: Khalil Gibran Muhammad, a history professor at Indiana University, has been named the new director of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, to begin in July. New York Public Library officials made the announcement on Wednesday, ending a sometimes contentious search.

title: Final Scenes From a Life of Bully Adventure

Edmund Morris has devoted more than half that time to writing a magisterial three-volume Roosevelt biography. He began by writing a screenplay about the young Roosevelts cattle ranching years in the Dakota Territory. This led to the biographys Pulitzer Prize-winning first volume, The Rise of Theodore Roosevelt, in 1979. It took more than two decades for Mr. Morris to complete his installment about the Roosevelt presidency, Theodore Rex, which arrived in 2001.

title: Cooking With Dexter: Dads Weird Suppers
description: Bacon sh is the kind of dinner that doesnt lend itself to a recipe, but heres how I made it, more or less. Last Saturday, a friend from Oregon came to visit, and we served him bacon and eggs for lunch around noon, with a quince crisp after. The eggs were full of spinach with a flicker of nutmeg, and the bacon was roasted in the oven, just before the crisp went in. This was bacon from real pigs, old-fashioned pigs, and a pound gave off nearly a cup of grease, for which I said silent thanks. I poured it off into a dish, where it now sits in the refrigerator, white and waxy, until I call it up for corn bread. But I didnt wash the hotel pan I used because I thought it would come in handy for something. And it did when I found some glossy hake fillets for dinner. The oven went on low, the hotel pan went into the 325-degree heat just long enough to melt the bacon grease, the hake was swiped on each side in the slick of fat before going into the oven and 12 minutes later we were all eating bacon fish.

title: Beauty Spots

Im absolutely thrilled to finally introduce me in a bottle, said Ms. Perry in a recent press statement. Its available exclusively at Nordstrom ($45 to $65).

title: Daniel Libeskind on a New Show of Menorahs
description: Daniel Libeskind might be known to most New Yorkers as the architect who won the World Trade Center design competition. But to design aficionados, Mr. Libeskind, a Warsaw-born son of Holocaust survivors, is a veritable rock star, responsible for a variety of high-profile projects, from the Jewish Museum in Berlin to the extension of the Denver Art Museum. This week brings the unveiling of yet another project: the installation of an exhibition at the Jewish Museum called A Hanukkah Project: Daniel Libeskinds Line of Fire, featuring 40 hanukkiahs (or menorahs) from the museums collection.

title: All Aboard an App for Suburban New York Commuters

title: Exxon Mobil Settles State Suit on Newtown Creek Cleanup
description: Exxon Mobil has agreed to pay $25 million and commit to a more thorough cleanup of its huge oil spills along Newtown Creek and a faster timetable for the process, according to a settlement announced on Wednesday by Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo.

title: Is Their Pest Your Clean Conscience?
description: TREATING nutria as a kind of guilt free fur is tough when youre cutting the pelt and fur gets caught in your eyes. Thats what Micha Michelle Melancon, a fashion designer in New Orleans, found out when she was making a cloak from what is commonly known as a swamp rat.

title: Zena Rommett, Ballet Dancer Who Developed Floor-Barre, Dies at 90
description: Zena Rommett, a ballet dancer and teacher who developed Floor-Barre, an influential training method promoting bodily alignment for both dancers and nondancers, and whose students included Tommy Tune, Patrick Swayze and Judith Jamison, died on Nov. 10 in Manhattan, where she lived. I want people to experience modern domestic architecture, Mr. de Botton said. Whats lacking in the U.K. are publicly accessible homes. The few modern houses that exist are almost all in private hands and cannot be visited.

title: Scavolini Opens a New York Showroom for Kitchens
description: Scavolini, the Italian kitchen manufacturer, chose New York City as the place to open its first American retail showroom, although homes here generally are not known for their large kitchens. Thats true, said Francesco Farina, chief executive officer of Scavolini USA. But our products are very modular, so we can offer big kitchens for big houses, like the ones in Long Island, the Hamptons or New Jersey, and we can also offer urban kitchens.

title: Blending Like the Brady Bunch? Lets Not Go Too Far

Perhaps the new partners have children, too. Add them. Oh, and the new partners exes. Factor in an equitable (say, nearly 50-50) physical custody arrangement for all the parties.

For the Brooklyn Renaissance Collection (her second), that means pillows, wallpaper and shower curtains in sharp African kuba prints, as well as pillows, above, printed with the winsome watercolors of Samantha Hahn, a Brooklyn artist.

title: Winter Squash, Warts and All
description: THE problem with squash is squunk. Not a word? I know. But there ought to be an unsavory term for the off-taste of a winter squash. It curls the tongue and purses the lips. And it haunts the gardener who aims to make a pie out of fresh pumpkin or winter squash for Thanksgiving.

description: Julius Genachowski, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said on Wednesday that he did not welcome a recent proposal by Google and Verizon about how to regulate Internet service. I would have preferred if they didnt do exactly what they did, when they did, Mr. Genachowski said at the Web 2.0 Summit conference in San Francisco. It slowed down some of the processes.

description: FOR many longtime readers of W, the elite society bible, the appearance of the reality television star Kim Kardashian on the cover of its November issue was an outrage  No iteration of W should give credence to such banalities, wrote one angered reader. For many residents of SoHo, the appearance of a Kardashian-owned clothing boutique in their neighborhood two weeks ago was also an unwelcome event, made more upsetting when a mob of fans turned up and prompted calls to 911. (Sean Sweeney, the director of the SoHo Alliance, was quoted in The Villager describing those fans as a generation of classless, tasteless and clueless sheep.)

description: As a National Guard reservist and the mother of a 4-year-old, Amelia Dingman, 23, has a lot to juggle. Luckily, she happens to be talented with her hands: she is a licensed massage therapist who has been working at Eastside Massage Therapy in Manhattan since last summer.

title: Search for Manager Narrows Mets Focus

description: Deron Williams had 23 points and 8 assists, Paul Millsap had 19 points, 15 rebounds and 4 assists, and the Utah Jazz used balanced scoring and an efficient fast break to beat the Nets, 98-88, on Wednesday night in Salt Lake City.

description: Larry Evans, a five-time United States chess champion and prolific writer who helped Bobby Fischer win the world championship in 1972, died Monday in Reno, Nev. He was 78.

title: Trial Omitted Statements by Ghailani
description: Of all the potential evidence against Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani, one thing that was never introduced or considered during his trial was Mr. Ghailanis own words about his role in the 1998 bombing of the American Embassy in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania.

title: Advance for Food Bill
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate voted 74 to 25 on Wednesday to consider a bill to improve the food safety system. One Democrat, Senator Ben Nelson of Nebraska, joined Republicans in opposition to debating the measure.

title: Patti Smith Wins National Book Award
description: Patti Smith, the musician and artist, won the National Book Award on Wednesday night for her evocative memoir of bohemian New York, Just Kids.

title: Gaza: Airstrike Kills a Militant and His Brother, Israeli Military Says
description: An Israeli airstrike killed a Palestinian militant and his brother in their car in Gaza on Wednesday. The Israeli military said the target of the attack was the militant, Islam Yassin, a senior member of the Army of Islam, an extremist group inspired by Al Qaeda. Mr. Yassins brother, Muhammad, was also said to have been a member of the Army of Islam, according to Palestinian reports. The attack appeared to be similar to one earlier this month in which another leader of the group, Muhammad al-Nemnem, was killed. The Israeli military said that Mr. Yassin and Mr. Nemnem had been planning an attack involving the kidnapping of Israelis in the Sinai in Egypt. In 2006, the Army of Islam joined Hamas, which now controls Gaza, in capturing an Israeli soldier, Gilad Shalit, from an army base near the enclave. In 2007, the Army of Islam held Alan Johnston, a BBC reporter, hostage for 16 weeks.

title: Fox Goes for Big Ten
description: Fox Sports acquired the rights to carry the new Big Ten Conference football championship game from 2011 to 2016. Financial details were not disclosed. The championship game was added this year when Nebraska joined the conference as its 12th member. The conference was then split into two divisions.

title: Britain: Security Official Is Cleared
description: A senior official of Britains domestic security service was cleared by government prosecutors on Wednesday of complicity in the mistreatment of a former Guantnamo Bay detainee, Binyam Mohamed, in Pakistan in 2002. The prosecutors acted a day after the Justice Ministry announced a multimillion-dollar compensation deal under which 15 former Guantnamo detainees, including Mr. Mohamed, and one man still held there, agreed to drop lawsuits alleging complicity in torture and other abuse against MI5 and MI6, Britains domestic and foreign intelligence agencies. The compensation payments were explained in Parliament as part of a government plan to free MI5 and MI6 from the threat of extended litigation, and to protect relations between the British intelligence agencies and their American counterparts. Jonathan Evans, MI5s director general, said in a statement that he was delighted with the decision not to prosecute the unnamed MI5 official. Prosecutors are still investigating the possible criminal prosecution of an MI6 officer for complicity in detainee abuse.

title: National Book Award for Patti Smith
description: The rock musician Patti Smith won the National Book Award for nonfiction on Wednesday night for Just Kids, a sweetly evocative memoir of her relationship with the artist Robert Mapplethorpe and life in the bohemian New York of the 1960s and 70s.

He knows hes not allowed to eat these things, but like any 9-year-old, he hopes that somehow, this once, my wife, Evelyn, or I will make an exception.

He was 65.

title: California: Whitman Pays Back Wages
description: Meg Whitman, who was defeated this month in the governors race, agreed Wednesday to pay $5,500 to settle a claim brought by her former housekeeper, Nicandra Daz Santilln, whom Ms. Whitman employed for nine years but fired in 2009 after discovering she was in the country illegally. Tucker Bounds, a spokesman for Ms. Whitman, said that the accusations that Ms. Whitman and her husband stinted on wages were baseless, but that, This is simply the most practical and cost effective way to put the issue to rest.

title: Texas: Murder Verdict Thrown Out
description: The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals threw out the conviction of a man who has been on death row for 11 years, ruling Wednesday that the prosecution had withheld important evidence. The man, Richard D. Newton, was convicted of the kidnapping and killing in 1999 of Jesus Montoya, 20. Key to the conviction was the testimony of a second defendant, Julian Paul Williams, who was given a 10-year sentence. But last year, Dallas County authorities discovered a police questionnaire that Mr. Williams had filled out but that had never been turned over to the defense. In it, Mr. Williams asserted that he knew nothing of the killing, though he changed his story on the witness stand. Prosecutors must now decide whether to retry Mr. Newton.

title: Stocks Surge Worldwide on the Prospect of a Rescue for Ireland
description: Stocks in the United States rose Thursday after Ireland indicated that it would seek billions in aid from international lenders to rescue its banks. That eased concerns about the health of Europes financial system and helped buoy investor sentiment globally.

title: Hong Kong Records First Bird Flu Case in 7 Years
description: HONG KONG  Health authorities here said on Thursday that they are increasing their checks on poultry coming from mainland China and at farms and markets across the region after government officials confirmed the first case of bird flu in seven years in the territory.

title: Paris Show Comments on Arab Politics and Art
description: It takes a supremely confident artist to take on so comprehensive and controversial a subject as the history of art in the Arab world. But Walid Raad, a Lebanese-born artist who lives and teaches in New York, has never shied away from challenges. In his last project, in collaboration with the Atlas Group, a fictitious, pseudo-collective/think-tank, he researched and documented the history of Lebanon between 1989 and 2004 with text and images, intentionally blurring the line between fact and fiction to underline the ambiguity and inadequacy of memory.

Mr. Assange has strongly denied the accusations.

title: What to Dip?
description: My column on Wednesday was all about Thanksgiving dips that can pull double duty as ingredients for a harried cooks lunch. But even if youre not up to a whole lunch, dips make excellent snacks for cooks because you can make them ahead, and steal little bites all day long while you whip up the rest of the meal.When Im dip-sneaking before the guests arrive, I usually just use a spoon. Guests get a more refined spread. I like to mix it up, pairing old standbys with something new. Below are some of my favorite dippers. What are yours? Id love to know. The Usual Suspects:

title: Interview With the President of the World Chess Federation, Part 3
description: After his recent re-election as president of the World Chess Federation, Kirsan Ilyumzhinov offered to answer questions from readers of The Times about the federation, which is also known by the acronym FIDE (for Fdration Internationale des checs), and about his plans for the future of the game. Part one of the interview appeared Tuesday and addressed the federations proposal to build a chess center in New York City and the recent election. Part two was Wednesday and focused on the recent history of the world championship and Mr. Ilyumzhinovs efforts to find long-term sponsors for chess. The final part of the interview is below.

This year, the museum decided to focus on its own menorah collection  the largest in the world  and asked the architect Daniel Libeskind to design the installation. A Hanukkah Project: Daniel Libeskinds Line of Fire opens Friday and runs through Jan. 30.

title: Nimble Fugitive Caught in Connecticut Casino Capital
description: Updated, 10:04 a.m. | The fugitive who stole a police car while handcuffed and drove off steering with his knees was recaptured early Thursday morning in Uncasville, Conn., hometown of the Mohegan Sun casino, the New York police said. The fugitive, Jose Rodriguez, 27, was arrested without incident at 3:18 a.m., the police said, after 14 hours and at least 120 miles of freedom.

description: Walter Energy, an American coal producer, said on Thursday that it was seeking to buy Western Coal of Canada for $3.24 billion. The two companies have entered into an exclusivity agreement for the next 14 days.

Dane Cook, the standup comic and a featured actor in films like Dan in Real Life and Mr. Brooks, has become the latest funnyman to enlist for a tour of duty of Broadway: hell star opposite Josh Hamilton in a production of Neil LaButes Fat Pig that is planned for the spring, press representatives for the show said on Thursday.

title: So Why Arent You Opening Your Books, Jay?
description: I think its fair to say that most business owners think that open-book management makes sense for their business  at least at some level. Sure, there will always be skeptics, but its tough to argue with the 30 years of results that weve seen at SRC. At the risk of repeating myself, I believe that by opening the books and empowering everyone in our organization to have a say in how we approach the future, we have found a way to deal with the risk of operating a business and also share the rewards that come with success.

title: Notes from the Underground | Emily King
description: Twenty-five-year-old Emily King, who already has a Grammy nomination to her name, took to the stage at Rockwood Music Hall to debut her new repertoire of soulful alternative R&B-esque pop songs. Supported by a full band and a back-up singer, King masterfully glided through an hours worth of material, bringing the tiny audience to cheers and whistles. Even her rendition of the Pointer Sisterss classic, Automatic, carried her passionate sincerity and energy. King regularly performs at the venue for free.

title: The 39 Steps Reaches Its Conclusion

title: Erte, a Master of Fashion, Stage and Art Deco Design, Is Dead at 97
description: Erte, the Russian-born Art Deco designer whose prolific career in theater, sculpture and the graphic arts spanned most of the 20th century, died here today after a short illness. He was 97 years old.

title: As Vick Soars, Stigma of Conviction Fades
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Even Michael Vick did not see this happening. Vick, the Eagles starting quarterback, is one of the N.F.L.s most electrifying talents and possibly its most valuable player in 2010. The fact that he is a convicted felon just more than a year out of prison simply makes him this seasons most complicated story.

title:
President's Assassin Shot To Death In Jail Corridor By A Dallas Citizen; Grieving Throngs View 
Kennedy Bier
description: Dallas, Nov. 24--President Kennedy's assassin, Lee Harvey Oswald, was fatally shot by a Dallas night-club operator today as the police started to move him from the city jail to the county jail.

title: Dale Carnegie, Author, Is Dead
description: Dale Carnegie, whose book "How to Win Friends and Influence People" was one of the world's most phenomenal bestsellers, died yesterday at his home, 27 Wendover Road, Forest Hills, Queens. He had been ill for some time. He would have been 67 years old on Nov. 24.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1'
description: The director David Yates discusses a battle sequence from Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1.

title: Iran Payment Found Diverted To Contras; Reagan Security Adviser And Aide Are Out
description: Washington, Nov. 25--President Reagan said today that he had not been in full control of his Administration's Iran policy, and the White House said that as a consequence up to $30 million intended to pay for American arms had been secretly diverted to rebel forces in Nicaragua.

title: Carnegie Started as a Bobbin Boy
description: Until he was a septuagenarian, Andrew Carnegie believed that he was born in 1837. Then on a return visit to his native town in Scotland he learned that the date 1837 in the church records merely meant that the records were commenced in that year, and he was listed as a living child in the first census. He announced his correction of the date of his birth by clicking the news to his brother telegraphers on a miniature telegraph instrument at his plate at the dinner they were giving in his honor, supposing it to be his seventy-first when it was really his seventy-third birthday.

title: On Chess, Rangel and Lokos Dwindling Days
description: As Four Loko disappears from stores and the hoarding begins, a small group of New Yorkers organized on Facebook and gathered in Union Square on Wednesday night to mourn  not entirely seriously  the passing of the new drink that everyone loves to hate.

title: Full 'Gas' Rationing Dec. 1 Ordered by the President
description: Washington, Nov. 26--President Roosevelt served notice tonight that, Congressional upheavals and sectional objections notwithstanding, the government must and would begin the nationwide rationing of gasoline to conserve rubber on Dec. 1, as scheduled.

title: Charles M. Schulz, 'Peanuts' Creator, Dies at 77
description: Charles M. Schulz, the creator of ''Peanuts,'' the tender and sage comic strip starring Charlie Brown and Snoopy that is read by 355 million people around the world, died in his sleep on Saturday night at his home in Santa Rosa, Calif., just hours before his last cartoon ran in the Sunday newspapers. He was 77.

title: For Pegasus, British Retail Has Shifted
description: Over the years, David Yarrow, the manager of London-based hedge fund Pegasus, has made money betting on companies that thrive on the vicissitudes of the British economy.

title: Chaim Weizmann Of Israel Is Dead
description: TEL AVIV, Israel, Sunday, Nov. 9--President Chaim Weizmann of Israel died at 6:30 this morning in his home in Rehovot, near here, after a long illness. He would have been 78 years old on Nov. 27.

title: Ford Is Approved By Senate, 92-3; House Set To Act
description: Washington, Nov 27--The Senate approved today, 92 to 3, the nomination of Gerald Rudolph Ford of Michigan as the 40th Vice President of the United States.

title: An Inconvenient Mind
description: Behavioral researchers at the University of California, Berkeley, have found thatdire descriptions of global warming, in isolation, can cause people to recoil from acceptance of the problem. The work certainly supports criticisms of communication efforts such as the video shown at the opening ceremonies in climate talks in Copenhagen last year:

title: Nurses Role in the Future of Health Care
description: At the start of my surgical training, I helped to care for a middle-aged patient who was struggling to recuperate from a major operation on his aorta, the bodys central artery, and the blood vessels to his legs. As the days wore on, the surgeon in charge began consulting various experts until the once spare patient file became weighted down with the notes and suggestions of a whole roster of specialists.

title: Live Blog: Committee Recommends Censure for Rangel
description: Update, 6:29 p.m. | The House ethics committee has recommended censure for Representative Charles B. Rangel for ethics violations. The vote was 9 to 1.

title: Berlusconis Statue of Mars and Venus Are Made Whole Again
description: The statue of Mars and Venus that greets visitors to the official residence of Silvio Berlusconi, the Italian prime minister, is a striking example of classical Roman sculpture but to certain observers it seemed incomplete. Dating back to 175 A.D., the representation of Venus was missing one of her hands, and her companion, Mars, was missing the very feature that some might say made him such a manly god of war. But the work at Palazzo Chigi in Rome has been restored to anatomical completeness, The Guardian reported: Venus now has all of her digits and Mars was given a new penis. The Italian newspaper La Repubblica said Mr. Berlusconi had requested the restoration of the statue, but Mario Catalano, the prime ministers architect, told The Guardian, I took the decision. Mr. Catalano added that the replacement parts were attached using a magnetic system and were removable but declined to provide additional details.

title: Tiger Woods Gets the Message Out
description: The message dropped into the Twitter pool like a little lob shot from out of nowhere  Whats up everyone. Finally decided to try out twitter!  and created waves like a cannonball. Thats because it came from an account long given up for irrelevant, the idea of Tiger Woods doing social media being as absurd as John Daly doing Project Runway.

title: 12th-Grade Reading and Math Scores Rise Slightly After a Historic Low in 2005
description: Reading scores for the nations 12th-grade students have increased somewhat since they dropped to a historic low in 2005, according to results of the largest federal test, released Thursday. Average math scores also ticked upward.

title: What Were Reading
description: Brooklyn Guy Loves Wine: Brooklyn Guy sits down for a Q. & A. with the wine importer Neal Rosenthal.  Eric Asimov

title: Chinese Woman Imprisoned for Twitter Message
description: BEIJING  A Chinese woman was sentenced to one year in a labor camp on Wednesday after she forwarded a satirical microblog message that urged recipients to attack the Japanese Pavilion at the Shanghai World Expo, human rights groups said Thursday.

title: Bush Tax Cuts: Reader Responses
description: In response to my post on the Bush tax cuts and slow growth in the last decade, Steve from San Jose writes: the choice of 5-year periods seem slightly cherry-picked, since we were in a recovery mode in 2001 (and 2002?) How would the graph look if you showed years ending in 8-2 and 3-7?

title: Saying I Love You, Man With Lots of Grooming
description: The human tendency to form close bonds with people other than kin may have primal roots. Researchers from Germany report in the journal Current Biology that male macaques exhibit a social bonding behavior similar to human friendship.

title: The Higher Mass Transit Tax Benefit Thats Expiring
description: Last year, as part of the stimulus package, Congress nearly doubled the maximum amount workers could deduct from their paychecks, before taxes, to apply toward monthly mass transit commuting costs. That meant rail and bus commuters could deduct the same amount each month as commuters who drive and pay for parking.

title: Weekend Miser
description: Cyclists, dont be afraid of a little chill in the air, especially when dressed in your best houndstooth check coats and wool vests for the Big Apple Tweed Fall Ride on Sunday. The organizers have devised a ride that combines old English style with bicycling, to create what they call a unique and memorable social experience that pays homage to a timeless era. Your ride fee, a $10 suggested donation, will go to Virginias House of Hope, a nonprofit group that helps New York families with food, clothing and social services. The ride begins at 11 a.m. at Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn, followed by a stop at the Brooklyn Circus, a clothing boutique in Boerum Hill, to find out who will be named the days Most Distinguished Lad and Most Ravishing Lass, among other contest titles. Bikers finish with a free brunch at the Flatbush Farm Restaurant in Park Slope, where live Gypsy jazz and Dixieland music will be played until 5 p.m. (Prospect Park, intersection of Flatbush Avenue and Prospect Park West; bigappletweed.com)

title: Polls Show No Consensus on How to Address Major Issues
description: While voters appeared to send a clear message to the Democratic-controlled Congress on Election Day, new polls out this week find no apparent public consensus about how to deal with some of the key issues facing the country, and underscore the obstacles facing Congress as it tries to reduce the budget deficit.

title: Theater Talkback: When the Stage Goes Two-Dimensional
description: One great and glorious advantage that the theater used to have over the movies was the third dimension. You knew that when you watched actors on stage that they were just as fully rounded  physically, I mean  as the people in the lobby at intermission. Actors on film, no matter how big they looked in 10-foot close-ups, were as hopelessly flat as the screens on which their images flickered.

title: The Future of Nursing
description: In todays Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline Chen explores the important role that nurses play in the health care system.

title: The Texas Fix Is Unlikely for Ireland
description: Texas may not look much like Ireland. But at different times, each was deemed a model of rapid economic growth, envied and resented by neighbors. During those boom times, each had banks that went crazy, making so many speculative loans that the banking system was doomed when the bubble burst.

Wed like to take a walking tour of the city with a native, who would show us around. Perhaps a professional travel agent would be the right person? But we dont want big groups of people.

description: Jonathan Lippman, the chief judge of New York State, on Thursday moved to expedite vote counting in three State Senate races that remain undecided, a step aimed at resolving the Senates leadership before the start of the new legislative session in January.

description: Poor Nevada.

title: A Wave of Bank Prosecutions Is Unlikely
description: The inspector general of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation told The Wall Street Journal recently that the agency had opened criminal investigations into about 50 banks that had failed since the financial collapse in 2008. While that makes it sound like prosecutors will soon be filing charges against a number of bank executives, do not hold your breath waiting for a flood of prosecutions.

title: A Whirlwind Start for St. Johns and Lavin

title: Georgina Bloomberg Buys Co-op on Central Park West
description: BEFORE being injured in a riding competition this month, Georgina Bloomberg, the younger daughter of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, was immersed in what even the most seasoned brokers would describe as a highly intense apartment hunt: She saw almost 150 properties in six months, before closing on a co-op on Central Park West on Thursday, according to someone with knowledge of the deal who was not authorized to speak publicly about it.

title: House Republicans Back No-Earmarks Rule
description: Republicans in the House of Representatives voted on Thursday to ban the special-purpose spending provisions known as earmarks from being inserted in legislation in the next Congress. While the caucus has approved similar motions before, this time, because the new Congress will have a Republican majority, what they say now goes: Under the rule, House Democrats will not be allowed to insert earmarks either.

title: My 10 Favorite iPhone Apps
description: I noticed that the No. 1 most e-mailed New York Times article for all of last week was Bob Tedeschis list of great iPhone apps. Its still on the most-e-mailed list. Wow  hot topic, eh? O.K., fine  two can play that game. Here are my top 10 iPhone apps.

title: The Marrying Kind
description: Prince William and Kate Middleton announced their engagement just as the latest cover story in Time magazine (the one on the stands tomorrow) was being put to bed. I can only imagine the rewriting scramble that took place, given the long-planned topic of that cover. It pictures a generic bride and groom (with a tiny insert of the Royal Happy Couple) and the title Who Needs Marriage? Inside, the writer Belinda Luscombe explores how the role of marriage is changing  in society in general and in the shape it takes in individual households.

title: On Our Radar: African Pelicans in Russia
description: A flock of African pelicans lands in Siberia after being thrown off course by abnormally warm weather this autumn throughout Russia. They just lost their way and went in exactly the opposite direction: Instead of Africa they somehow chose the Altai region, a zoologist says. [Reuters]

title: SoHo Building Where Heath Ledger Died Is Turned Into Condo

title: Afghan Hero Dog Is Euthanized by Mistake in U.S.

Target and two other dogs snarled, barked and snapped at the man, who detonated his bomb at the entrance to the facility but did not kill anyone.

title: Will Congress Repeal the 1099 Expansion?
description: When we last checked in on efforts in Congress to roll back the expansion of 1099 reporting that passed as part of the health care overhaul, we found the parties deadlocked. Not on whether the new provision should be eliminated  both agreed that it should (at least in the House; in the Senate, Democrats proposed softening it rather than eliminating it). The argument, rather, was over how to pay for eliminating it. Now, in the wake of a disastrous midterm election, Democrats seem ready to avoid that fight by not paying for the repeal at all. But it is unclear that Republicans will go along.

title: A Weekend in Cambridge, England
description: The storied university town has evolved into a sophisticated haven of museums, art galleries and cafe collectives.

title: A Private Network for Recharging Cars
description: A utility with operations around Texas is planning a network of 50 to 150 charging stations for electric cars in the Houston metropolitan area to eliminate range anxiety, and is talking with Nissan, Toyota and others about offering auto buyers a package that includes network access and a home charger.

title: 36 Hours in Cambridge, England
description: CAMBRIDGE, with its narrow medieval passageways and 801-year-old university, is more than just a college town. Students today are sticking around after graduation to run alternative art galleries and cafe collectives. The famous antiquities museum is proudly displaying contemporary works of art, and lively new restaurants and watering holes are rising to the standards of those down the road in London. Even the venerable university is throwing open its doors and admitting the common folk as hotel guests.

title: Rental Car Company Rated Highest by Customers
description: Enterprise ranked highest in customer satisfaction among rental car companies for a seventh year in a row, according to a new J.D. Power and Associates study of customer satisfaction with airport car rentals.

title: Dispute Over Dead Sea Scrolls Leads to a Jail Sentence
description: A man convicted of impersonating a New York University scholar in a debate over the Dead Sea Scrolls was sentenced on Thursday to six months in jail and five years probation.

title: In Greenwich Village, Pop-Up Pizza
description: Artichoke Basilles Pizza is adding more slices to its empire. Hot on the heels of its big new restaurant in Chelsea, Francis Garcia and Sal Basile, will satisfy those in Greenwich Village who need to take a break from making stuffing. On Wednesday (Thanksgiving Eve), they plan to open a small pizzeria mainly for takeout: 111 Macdougal Street (Minetta Lane). And if you need to wait for a table at Minetta Tavern, this may be the answer.

title: A Dallas Chef Does Thanksgiving
description: Growing up in France, Chef Bruno Davaillon didnt celebrate Thanksgiving. Now, as the executive chef of the celebrated Rosewood Mansion on Turtle Creek restaurant in Dallas, he has a new appreciation for the holiday.

title: Reading List | Venice
description: Perhaps theres something in the water  or, more to the point, in the canals  that can explain the recent surge of architectural activity in Venice. Beyond the Biennale, which continues through Sunday, the Italian government is hoping to stem the sinking citys rapid structural decay by  proposing to charge visitors, who number 20 million annually, about $1.40 upon entry. These events coincide with the release of three architecturally premised books about the crumbling city.

title: As Ireland Nears Bailout, Portugal Waits in Wings
description: LISBON  As Dublin moves begrudgingly toward accepting a European Union bailout, attention is rapidly shifting to Portugal, the country perceived to be as weak a link in the euro zone as Ireland, though for different reasons.

title: The Caucus: G.O.P. Plans for 2012

title: Lighthead, by Terrance Hayes: A.D.D. Poet Wins N.B.A. Poetry Award
description: Patti Smith may have been the big-name winner at last nights National Book Awards (her memoir, Just Kids, took the nonfiction prize), but I was pleased to see that the poetry award went to Terrance Hayes for his fourth collection, Lighthead, which Stephen Burt reviewed for us in April.

title: Sloan Awards Are Given to Eight Teachers
description: Eight city public high school science and math teachers who engage their students with animation, epidemiological studies of the black death, billiards and field trips to waterways clean and befouled are to receive Sloan Awards for Excellence in Teaching Science & Mathematics today.

title: Shawn Andrews Sits Out Practice Again
description: The Giants are uncertain who will play left tackle on Sunday with Shawn Andrews sitting out a second consecutive practice Thursday with soreness in his back. Andrews had started at left tackle the past two games in place of the injured David Diehl.

title: TimesCast: Rumblings of 2012
description: In todays TimesCast, Matt Bai reports on the Republican Governors Association meeting from San Diego, and Nate Silver considers Sarah Palin.

title: Argentinas Napa Valley
description: THE sunlight sliced through the clear glass of the gazebo-like restaurant at Familia Zuccardi, one of dozens of wineries located in the small town of Maip, just outside the city of Mendoza, Argentina. The purple-red malbec and torronts grapevines glistened in the early afternoon sun. Inside, a waitress poured us chardonnay as bread sticks and an appetizer of ham ravioli arrived. She brought a different chardonnay for the cannelloni filled with sweetbread. Then a hearty malbec, Argentinas signature wine, accompanied the main course of baby goat rolls filled with sun-dried tomatoes and aubergine.

title: Perceptions: UV Radiation Poses Hidden Risk for Skiers
description: Skiers, beware: youre exposed to more ultraviolet radiation than you think. Hot chocolate at midday  preferably somewhere shady  may be a good idea.

title: Hazards: Work Stress Raises Womens Heart Risk, Study Says
description: Women who are stressed at work are more likely than other working women to have a heart attack or other forms of heart disease, a new study suggests.

title: Brian Williams and Jimmy Fallon Team Up to Rib Future Boss

Roberts, chairman and chief executive of Comcast.

title: Japan Pushing the Mob Out of Businesses
Client 9 on the Oscar Documentary Short List;  Joan Rivers Not
description: LOS ANGELESThe Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences announced its so-called short list for documentary features, those being the 15 films that make the first cut of a screening process and are officially in the running for Oscar nominations. Not in the running are Joan Rivers: A Piece of Work. But the list includes many of the films that average film buffs would expect to be there. And that has not always been the case with the short list, which last year omitted Tyson and Capitalism: A Love Story.

title: Christie Urges Republican Governors to Spend Political Capital
description: SAN DIEGO  Most of the chatter at the Republican Governors Associations annual meeting here has focused on chest thumping over the partys recent wins. So, during a panel titled Good Policy = Good Politics, most of the sitting governors encouraged newly elected state executives to trust their instincts and have faith that doing the right thing would only help them in the long run.
