description: Do gay couples count as a family? What about unmarried straight couples? What if they have children? A survey of American attitudes towards this term:

title: Apothkes Fiery Bartender Says in Suit That His Partners Attacked Him
description: Fiery eruptions continue from Apothke, the Chinatown bar, where the celebrity mixologist Albert Trummer once set the alcohol-rich bar top ablaze in pyrotechnic bartending displays. Word of a lawsuit filed on Friday by Mr. Trummer against two of his partners, Heather Tierney and her brother Christopher Tierney, in response to their suit aganist him, has surfaced some lurid allegations.

title: The Nutcracker Chronicles: First Stop West Point
description: WEST POINT, N.Y.  The show that is currently touring the States under the name of The Great Russian Nutcracker isnt great (except in its lengthy tour schedule, which is extraordinary). It isnt even entirely Russian. Flaws abound, but its a happy start to my Nutcracker tour of America. (More details on my mad coast-to-coast plan here.)

title: Raptors Evans Thrives in One Dimension
description: For anyone who considered Dennis Rodman or Ben Wallace to be the most egregious of one-dimensional rebounders, Reggie Evans of the Toronto Raptors should end any debate.

title: At a Rhinebeck Getaway, Hating the Mice, Loving the Quirks
description: WHAT Three-bedroom 1790 house of 2,300 square feet with two barns on nine acres.

title: ADRIAN PIPER: Past Time: Selected Works 1973-1995
description: Elizabeth Dee

title: JOHN CURRIN: New Paintings
description: Gagosian Gallery

title: MARLENE MCCARTY: im into you now: some work from 1980-2010
description: 80WSE, New York University

title: PAUL LEE: Lavender
description: Maccarone

title: CHARLOTTE PARK
description: Spanierman Modern

title: 'Metropolis II'
description: A look at Chris Burden's kinetic sculpture in progress, filmed in 2009 at the artist's studio in Topanga, Calif. (Video courtesy of CB Studio)

title: Hanging on for a Dear Way of Life
description: Early in Claire Deniss powerful, agonized film White Material, you see a woman in a short pink dress, Maria  played by a sublime Isabelle Huppert  hanging off the back of a bus. The setting is a contemporary unnamed African country being torn to pieces by government troops, marauding rebels and the enduring ravages of European colonialism. As she holds on tight, her short-sleeved dress fluttering, the camera moves in close enough for you to see the muscles in Ms. Hupperts thin arms popping, straining with the terrific effort that encapsulates the will to survive.

title: Publicist Putting Away One of Her Caps
description: Sloane Crosley, the book publicist and essayist, said on Thursday that she would leave her job at Random House next month to focus on writing full time. When it comes to book publishing, my colleagues are the most passionate people I have ever encountered outside of clinically insane religious zealots, Ms. Crosley said in a farewell e-mail. I thank them for their boundless support both inside the office and out. Ms. Crosley spent nine years at Vintage/Anchor Books, part of Random House, while writing two well-received books on the side, I Was Told Thered Be Cake and How Did You Get This Number.

title: Bowlmor Lanes in Former Newsroom
description: IN the dozen years I spent working in the newsroom of the historic New York Times building, just off Times Square, I must have contemplated my future a hundred times, a thousand times. Would I become a national correspondent? A foreign correspondent? An editor? Should I chuck journalism and embark instead on a career in interpretive dance?

title: 2010 Los Angeles Auto Show: a Dearth of Diesels
description: 6 p.m. | Updated

title: Bowlmor Times Square
description: Recently, though, there came exciting word from Bowlmor Lanes: Bowlmor was opening a new location in the Times Square district! In the old New York Times newsroom!

title: Of Brunch and Its Avoided Discontents
description: E-mails spilled forth questions from nice people about birthdays and brunch, and I responded as best I could  with a few orders of pique on the side. As always, send your questions to dinejournal@nytimes.com or Twitter.com/samsifton.

title: Alone When the Bedbugs Bite
description: A COUPLE of months ago when I woke up with small clusters of insect bites on my elbows, hands and knees, it happened to be the opening day of the first-ever North American bedbug summit, held in Chicago.

title: Officials Ponder Gentler Ways to Handle Geese
description: Officials at Prospect Park are mulling ways to reduce the number of Canada geese at the park without actually killing them, ranging from coating goose eggs with oil, to forbidding the feeding of geese, to chasing them off with border collies patrolling from boats.

title: Exotic Cars Roll Out to Promote U.S.  Top Gear
description: Years of efforts to produce an American version of the popular offbeat British television show about cars, Top Gear, are coming to fruition when the History cable channel presents the first episode of the United States Top Gear on Sunday night. To stimulate interest in the show, History is underwriting an elaborate campaign that is, not surprising, heavy on the Hemis and other exotic cars.

title: CBS Owns the Night
description: Survivor, Criminal Minds and The Defenders lifted CBS to No. 1 in the ratings on Wednesday night as the shows led their respective time slots in prime time. According to Nielsens estimates Criminal Minds delivered the largest audience with 14.3 million viewers at 9 p.m. Survivor: Nicaragua garnered a somewhat more modest 12 million viewers at 8 while at 10 The Defenders attracted 9.4 million. NBC edged ahead of ABC to finish in second place over all, getting a boost from back-to-back episodes of Law & Order: SVU at 9 (7.6 million) and 10 (7.8 million). Fox ranked fourth.

title: Time-Shifting Holidays
description: ITS that time of year: the endless holiday parade of cooking, shopping, wrapping and congregating that in my family commences the Friday after Thanksgiving, when we sit down for a traditional meal of turkey, stuffing and canned-fruit compote  and concludes, well, the following day when we celebrate all eight nights of Hanukkah in one madcap afternoon.

title: Q & A
description: Equal Treatment for All Shareholders

title: Reforming Health Care Reform
description: Now is the time for bold attempts at bipartisan policymaking, apparently. In the wake of the Simpson-Bowles blueprint comes an even more detailed vision for deficit reduction from the Bipartisan Policy Center, which some of the liberal wonks who snarked at Simpson-Bowles have decided is a budget-balancing proposal they can get behind. (Thats a good thing, to my mind, because the B.P.C. report and Simpson-Bowles are both much closer to one another than either is to the current left-wing vision of how to bring the budget into balance.) Meanwhile, Wisconsin Republican Paul Ryan has persuaded Alice Rivlin, Bill Clintons former O.M.B. director, to join him in championing a sweeping overhaul of Medicare, which would transform the program from an open-ended entitlement into a means-tested system that provides vouchers to purchase health insurance.

title: Fishing Nations Gain Ground on Bluefin
description: International fisheries officials have barely started their meeting to decide the fate of the endangered Atlantic bluefin tuna, but the European Union may have already torpedoed efforts to lower a hotly contested limit this year.

title: Bad Guys Singing Of Love And Power
description: There are many reasons not to miss the production of Monteverdis Incoronazione di Poppea that opened the Juilliard Opera season on Wednesday night at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater. Beyond the musical excellence and dramatic effectiveness of the production, it is inspiring to see a new generation of musicians so captivated by this seminal work, first produced in Venice in 1643. Monteverdis opera emerges vividly in this impressive production, as musically stunning as ever, with its all-too-pertinent tale of power grabs and political corruption driven by sex.

title: Laurent Gras Says His New York Restaurant Will Take a Casual Turn
description: Laurent Gras, who just won three Michelin stars for his restaurant L2O in Chicago, a couple of weeks after he left it, has a few more details on his return to New York.

title: Politics Podcast: Deficit Duels
description: Click to Listen

title: A New Home for St. Anns Warehouse
description: St. Anns Warehouse, the Dumbo-based theater best known for presenting work from the Wooster Group and other downtown favorites, has been conditionally designated by the Brooklyn Bridge Park Corporation to become the primary tenant of the Tobacco Warehouse, located across the street from the theaters current home.

title: Racewalking Workouts in Central Park
description: AFTER the New York City Marathon and so much focus on running, walking workouts might seem pass, but racewalking can test even the most avid marathoner.

title: After Reprimand, College Coach Receives Support From Soccer Peers
description: The Florida State womens soccer team will play Saturday for a berth in the quarterfinals of the N.C.A.A. tournament, having made a provocative tactical decision that raised intriguing questions about sportsmanship, integrity and the autonomy of a coach to choose a lineup.

title: Seating All the Americas at the Same Table
description: BOSTON  Five years after breaking ground, the new Art of the Americas Wing at the Museum of Fine Arts here is opening on Saturday, and its a wow. Almost double-wow. Really good.

title: New London Schools to Brokers: Get to Know Us
description: NEW LONDON

title: From a Trojan War Hero, Lessons About Aging
description: Jonah Bokaer  the former Merce Cunningham dancer, a choreographer, co-founder of two arts spaces and, at 29, already the subject of a book  is clearly a man of many talents. But his most notable gift may be his instinct for picking the right collaborators. His new Anchises, which opened at the Abrons Arts Center on Wednesday night, is a subtle tour de force, a slowly accruing succession of images that owes its power not just to the chemistry of the exceptional performers and designers that Mr. Bokaer has assembled, but also to the rigorous focus that all bring to their task.

title: Obama Hails G.M. Success Story
description: President Obama took a rare and welcome victory lap on Thursday, hailing General Motors return to the stock market as a sign that his controversial decision two years ago to bail out the beleaguered automaker has paid off.

title: A Slow Rollout for Life-Care Communities
description: Port Washington

title: Entertaining, Edifying And Reassuring Listeners
description: Whatever you were looking for when you attended a recital by the Welsh bass-baritone Bryn Terfel at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night, you most likely found it. Unless what you sought was evidence that Mr. Terfels rough singing and odd detachment as Wotan in the Metropolitan Operas season-opening Rheingold were cause for concern. If you were worried, Mr. Terfel set you at ease with a program that offered refinement and engagement in roughly equal measure.

title: Bayfront Perth Amboy Recovers
description: PERTH AMBOY

title: Pictures of the Day: Wall Street and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from New York, Washington, Haiti and Colombia.

title: Karachi Turns Deadly Amid Pakistans Rivalries
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  This chaotic city of 18 million people on the shores of the Arabian Sea has never shrunk from violence. But this year, Karachi has outdone even itself.

title: Coco Rocha Lowers Price on Condo in Gramercy Park Area
description: VOGUE.com featured a flattering and splashy photo spread last month of the model Coco Rochas Gramercy Park-area apartment, in a new feature on the celebrities of the fashion world  the magazines favorite people  and the places they live.

title: From Poverty to Luxury
description: In the Basilicata region of Italy, hotels and restaurants built in caves that housed poor families in decades past are drawing tourists to a once impoverished region.

title: When the Pratts Decamped for Manhattan
description: EVERYONES moving to Brooklyn! At least thats what people have been saying for a dozen years, as young people migrate to Williamsburg and Greenpoint, and other neighborhoods Manhattanites had never heard of a few decades back. But the moving van was on the other foot a century ago, when Brooklyn residents were setting off for Manhattan. A good example of this is the Pratt family, builders of a string of mansions on Clinton Avenue. Impressive as they were, they could not hold the younger generation once they decided the action was across the river.

title: Week 11 in Fantasy Football: Matchups and Q. & A.
description: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 11. They also answered reader questions earlier in the week. Read their answers below and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

title: Counting Up G.M.s I.P.O. Tab
description: Bill Pugliano/Getty Images

title: New Lending Guidelines From Fannie Mae
description: NEW lending guidelines being rolled out by Fannie Mae will make securing a mortgage a lot easier for some borrowers but harder for others.

title: Tommy Guns and Other Crime World Curiosities
description: LORCAN OTWAY was sitting at Al Capones table at Lanzas in the East Village, a congenial spot to explain why he opened the Museum of the American Gangster.

title: Dance Listings for Nov. 19-25
description: Dance

title: Time-Shifting the Holidays
description: Time waits for no one, the saying goes. But Tivo has proved that adage wrong, no?

title: Asian Art in Juxtaposition
description: Although the Art of the Americas installation is the main event, the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, is using the special exhibitions gallery in the new, Norman Foster-designed wing to spotlight another of its institutional strengths: Asian art. In 2006 the museum invited nine Chinese artists and a Chinese-American artist each to select a work from the collection and create a response to it. Both the pieces chosen and the new art have been assembled in an ingenious and engrossing show called Fresh Ink: Ten Takes on Chinese Tradition (through Feb. 13), organized by the museums curator of Chinese art, Hao Sheng.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Nov. 19-25
description: Classical

title: Prince Charles Dishes Dirt (the Organic Kind)
description: The heir to the British throne prunes brambles with a hand sickle and empties buckets of compost in Harmony, a documentary on NBC that showcases Prince Charless pet environmental causes.

title: Developers Restore a Bowery Landmark
description: ONE of the first historic buildings to be awarded landmark status in the city, the Samuel Tredwell Skidmore House has been renovated and converted to 10 rental apartments.

title: Keeping It Real: A Show Made of Fakes
description: Museums are letting the public in on some of their most embarrassing moments. Half a dozen exhibitions this year have revealed how forgers fooled curators, and a show of about 50 inauthentic or questionable objects dating back to a supposedly Sumerian statuette opens on Sunday at the Detroit Institute of Arts.

title: An Old Hand Plucking At the Heartstrings
description: A gutsy soul singer backed by a band rooted in gospel, reggae and funk, playing songs about love, loss and faith  those are the parameters for a known quantity, the bluesy local bar band. Black Dub, led by the guitarist and producer Daniel Lanois, also fits the description. But in its concert on Wednesday night at the Bowery Ballroom, as on its new album, Black Dub, released by Jive, it warped nearly every expectation to make music that was far more volatile and haunted.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Nov. 19-25
description: Pop

title: Designed for Efficiency, New Computer Software at Health Dept. Misfires
description: In July, the San Francisco Department of Public Health started using an $11.2 million electronic medical records system, Avatar, that was designed to streamline billing and improve care for tens of thousands of clients. Thus far, however, it has brought administrative chaos to the mental health and substance abuse services in the city.

title: Photography: A Coming-of-Age Story
description: Like other major American museums, the Metropolitan was slow to recognize photography, but Alfred Stieglitz gave it a big push in the right direction. In 1928 this Photo-Secession pioneer donated 22 of his own works to the Met. They were the first photos to enter the collection.

title: Stripes of Intimacy Several Layers Over
description: A sizable crowd fills the Chocolate Factorys narrow lobby, where the slanted floor affords partial views of both its white-brick theater and raw basement space. And the choreographer Anneke Hansen gives her audience something to look at: visible on the upper level are swinging arms that send bodies into seemingly casual turns. On the lower level, torsos line up in a row as feet execute crossover steps. There are brisk runs. Other dancers watch surreptitiously from a doorway, giving the experience the air of a studio visit.

title: Jazz Listings for Nov. 19-25
description: Jazz

title: Douglas C. Steiner
description: Mr. Steiner is the president of the Steiner Equities Group in Roseland, N.J., which has developed retail and office space nationwide, including the expansion of AT&Ts research headquarters in New Jersey.

title: Tawkon App Measures Phone Radiation
description: The debate over whether mobile phones emit cancer-causing radiation may rage on unabated, but even if you doubt the danger, you might like to know how much radiation youre being exposed to.

title: Dean Camp Courts Chicago Progressives
description: As the influence of ward organizations wanes amid the larger decline of patronage politics in Chicago, followers of Howard Dean are trying to provide a new model for progressive activism in Chicago.

title: Split Pairing of Curators for 2012 Whitney Biennial
description: So much attention has been paid recently to the Whitney Museum of American Arts eventual move to the meatpacking district in downtown Manhattan that it is easy to forget that curators are busy plotting the next biennial in their Upper East Side home.

title: Something Blue
description: With the engagement of William and Kate still a topic of conversation, we, like everyone else, couldnt help but ogle the future queens 18-carat oval blue sapphire ring from Garrard. The Issa dress might be sold out (along with the dream of marrying the future king of England), but there are plenty of accessories from the spring collections in what is surely to be the most regal shade of the season.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Nov. 19-25
description: Art

title: Win Clears Gloom Over Notre Dame for a Day
description: As the final seconds of Notre Dames 28-3 victory over Utah ticked away in South Bend last Saturday, the Irish student section cascaded onto the field, as if swept along by an avalanche. Ebullient students danced among smiling players or rode piggyback through the Irish marching band as it entertained the departing crowd with robust repetitions of the Notre Dame fight song.

title: App Smart Extra: Priceline Kung Fu for Android
description: New apps will convince you to try booking an airline ticket with your smartphone  or so I explain in Thursdays App Smart column. And the new Orbitz app is good enough to challenge Kayak with hotel booking and car rentals.

title: Spare Times for Nov. 19-25
description: Around Town

title: Alternative Film Examined in Radical Light
description: In 1994, Rebecca Barten and David Sherman, an experimental filmmaking couple, began showing avant-garde films in a grungy space underneath their Mission District apartment. They built 10 unfinished pine benches that could seat two people apiece and cut a hole in the wall to fit a projector. The adjoining room, which housed the electric meter, became the grotto  a makeshift wine bar.

title: Spare Times: For Children, for Nov. 19-25
description: SQUIRM BURPEE CIRCUS

title: 2011 Mitsubishi i-MiEV Is Coming to North America
description: Introduced on Thursday: 2011 Mitsubishi i-MiEV

title: Feds Stress Tests Have Shortcoming in Disclosure
description: The newly powerful Federal Reserve may have missed a trick. The central bank, charged under the Dodd-Frank overhaul bill with broad oversight of the banking system, is asking the 19 biggest American financial institutions to submit to a series of stress tests. Thats a good thing. The trouble is the regulator plans to keep the results and the criteria used in the tests private.

title: A Quake, a Collapse and No Responsibility
description: In the overturned gray Volkswagen Beetle, under the dim glow of the dashboard light, Tom Mariani studied the still body of his wife beside him. I was pretty sure she was dead, he said of that night, 30 years ago this month.

title: Pictures of the Day: Wall Street and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from New York, Washington, Haiti and Colombia.

title: Out of the Dark Shadows, Arty Toil and Trouble
description: The director Philip Ridley scares up a sinister-spooky atmosphere straightaway in Heartless, a horror movie thats art-house aspirational and involves violence, madness, faith and the evil that men, demons or just filmmakers do. Set in a contemporary East London churning with dark shadows and inexplicable savagery, this digitally shot, visually murky movie is a muddle of tones ranging from the grotesque to the queasily comic to the absurd. Among the horrors paraded across the screen is a gang of toughs in hoodies who set innocents afire for no real reason other than that it suits the directors overwrought imagination.

title: Movie Listings for Nov. 19-25
description: Movies

title: A Stumble on Wrigley Renovation, but Dont Be So Quick to Scoff
description: When my first grader drops a thrown ball, he implores me for a re-do. It was the same for Tom Ricketts, the Cubs chairman, as he sought to avoid being a pinstriped public-policy piata.

title: New Home for American Art
description: A look at the new Art of the Americas Wing at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.

title: 60s Sweatshop Girls Fighting Ford
description: Vivid, stirring and entirely predictable, Made in Dagenham is a grown-up feel-good movie plunked into a feel-bad age. Directed by Nigel Cole, whose 2003 film, Calendar Girls, told a similarly upbeat story of indomitable female pluck, Made in Dagenham is a feminist fairy tale based on actual events. Uplifting it may be, but to swallow it whole is to believe in happily ever after.

title: The Bell Tolls for Waco, Caught in Election Day Seismic Shift
description: As it turns out, one of the biggest losers on Election Night wasnt a Democrat. It was Waco.

title: Have You Heard the One About the Rabbi Who Didnt Memorize His Lines?
description: Usually an Off Broadway theater company trumpets its production starring an Academy Award winner. But not so the Culture Project with its production of Colin Greers play Imagining Heschel, running through Nov. 28 at the Cherry Lane Theater and starring Richard Dreyfuss (a 1977 Oscar winner for best actor in The Goodbye Girl) as the prominent 20th century Jewish theologian Abraham Heschel.

title: In Italy, Luxury Transforms Caves Into Hotels
description: IT was early evening in Matera, a city in the southern Italian region of Basilicata, and swallows circled the sky, their melodious calls interrupted only by the clanking of bells worn by cows drinking from a stream deep within a canyon.

title: Please Pass the Spotlight
description: Last year, my father manipulated a Thanksgiving invitation from my mother-in-law by whining that he had no place else to go. I love my father, but he is very self-centered, and he dominated the entire dinner conversation with stories about himself. Id like to stop him from attending this years event so that my wifes family can enjoy the day. How can I tactfully make that happen?

title: An Everymans Guide to Engineering a Jail Break
description: One of the strictures of the old Motion Picture Production Code was that methods of crime should not be explicitly presented and that in particular, theft, robbery, safe-cracking, and dynamiting of trains, mines, buildings, etc., should not be detailed in method. The censors of the Hays Office did not want motion pictures to become teaching materials for criminals. The Next Three Days, a new thriller written and directed by Paul Haggis, is in many respects an old-fashioned movie, but it also amounts to a kind of cinematic Illegal Activity for Dummies.

title: A Spectacle With a Message
description: The German artist Anselm Kiefer knows how to put on a show. The dour and dusty copse of art with which he has forested the vast Gagosian Gallery in Chelsea may elicit awe, skepticism or disdain  or perhaps a conflicted combination of all three. But its initial power is hard to deny.

title: Next Year in Jerusalem
description: Images from a new exhibition of works by Anselm Kiefer.

title: Lifes Work Is a Talmud Accessible to All Jews
description: JERUSALEM  In the 1960s, when a young Rabbi Adin Steinsaltz embarked on the mammoth task of translating the ancient Jewish texts of the Talmud into modern Hebrew and, even more daringly, providing his own commentary alongside those of the classical sages, the state of Israel was still in its teens, there were no home computers, and man had not yet landed on the moon.

title: 2-D Avatar Is a Benchmark Blu-ray
description: If Avatar has become the 3-D theatrical release by which all others must be judged, then arguably the same can be said of the films 2-D Blu-ray Collectors Edition, which went on sale last Tuesday.

title: Milestones: Cathleen P. Black
description: A timeline of the life and career of the executive.

title: Doctors to Get Brief Respite on Medicare
description: 7:34 p.m. | Updated

title: A Meat Store Grandmother Would Love
description: A bell jangled as the young woman opened the door to G. Esposito & Sons Jersey Pork Store in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. In her 20s, fashionably hipsterish, she seemed unsure as she ordered.

title: A Postwar Woman Foiled by Men
description: The marriage between film and theater is beginning to look like a shotgun affair, forced and loveless, at least on the evidence of the fall season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Thomas Ostermeiers version of The Marriage of Maria Braun, the second entry in the double feature of films onstage at the Next Wave Festival, is roughly as tedious and precisely as pointless as last weeks  Ping Chongs Throne of Blood.

title: The Basics of Perfect Pie Crust
description: Melissa Clark shows how easy it can be to make a light and flaky pie crust.

title: House Panel Recommends Censure for Rangel
description: WASHINGTON  The House ethics committee on Thursday recommended that Representative Charles B. Rangel be formally censured for ethical misconduct, the most serious punishment the House can mete out to a member short of expulsion.

title: Reids Spokesman Is Leaving Senate
description: Jim Manley, a popular veteran among Senate communicators and the spokesman for Senator Harry Reid the past six years, is leaving the Senate after two decades and untold numbers of phone calls, news tips, denials, press releases, arguments, laughs and efforts to guide wayward reporters.

title: Sport and Grim Reality
description: There must be chief executives and millionaire athletes in Austin, Tex., whom Bob Ray could make documentaries about, but he doesnt seem to be interested. Hell on Wheels, from 2007, and the new Total Badass, playing in repertory at the ReRun Gastropub Theater in Brooklyn, focus on a lower-middle-class world where drugs, beer and tattoos compete for attention with paying the rent and getting the kids to school.

title: Time Warner Cable to Test Cheaper TV Package
description: In an apparent attempt to retain cable customers who are thinking of canceling, or to woo back people who have already canceled, Time Warner Cable will start a trial of a lower-cost cable subscription package next week in New York City.

title: Lingerie, Cone Bras and Odd Pregnancies
description: You dont get much closer to drag heaven on earth than Everett Quinton in diaphanous baby-doll lingerie and kitten heels, transformed from ignant trailer-trash hausfrau into hardboiled alien sex slave.

title: How Economic Brawn Transformed a Nation
description: It has often been noted that while the American union was established by the Revolution, the American nation was forged only upon the awful anvil of the Civil War. Far less noted, however, is that this nations extraordinary power and influence in the 20th century and beyond has been largely a product of the remarkable 35 years that followed the Civil War.

title: An Odd-Couple Friendship
description: Fiction films with disability as a central theme (especially those that feature disabled actors) are not only tricky to assemble but also minefields to critique. Praise can sound patronizing and criticism cruel, the disability casting a bulletproof cloak of political correctness around the entire project.

title: The Feast of Sacrifice in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqis this week are celebrating Id al-Adha, like millions of Muslims across the world. The festival, also known as the Feast of Sacrifice, is one of the principal holidays in the Islamic calendar and comes as a relief for a city that has been hit hard by bombs and killings in recent weeks. In large numbers, Iraqis flocked to Al Zawraa Park in the center of the capital, to enjoy carnival rides, cotton candy, a Ferris wheel and a boating lake.

title: Burger With Apocalypse and Some Cheese Fries
description: Tension and incongruity make for an uneasy pairing in Edgewise, a bloody drama by Eliza Clark at Walkerspace.

title: Balenciaga Exhibition Opening on Park Avenue
description: Nobody who buys a Ralph Lauren prairie skirt or cowboy jacket really thinks a personal history of the West informs the clothes. Mr. Lauren grew up in the Bronx. The late Alexander McQueen loved Scottish history, but in practical terms, the links were as crumbly as an old castle. Even for the most sensitive of designers, fashion changes too often to supply a narrative of a single place or culture.

title: Theater Listings: Nov. 19  25
description: Theater

title: Growing Deficit, Measured in Wait Time at D.M.V.
description: On a recent Tuesday morning at the San Francisco office of the Department of Motor Vehicles, there was a line to park, a line to sit (including handicapped seating), a line to use the restroom  even a line to obtain a number to be directed to another line.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,380 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

title: Food, Family and Follies
description: A lifetime ago, which is to say in 1998, Aasif Mandvi performed Sakinas Restaurant, a well-received one-man Off Broadway play he had been working on since 1991. A film inspired by it, Todays Special, is now in theaters, helped no doubt by Mr. Mandvis current popularity as a satirist on The Daily Show With Jon Stewart. But fans of his pointed television commentary may find themselves, in growing confusion and alarm, asking what happened as they watch Todays Special.

title: From Russia Expert, a Gloomy Outlook
description: William F. Browder was speaking at Columbia Business School several weeks ago when he was asked a question he gets asked a lot: Wheres the next Russia?

title: Allegations Complicate Heisman Trophy Voting
description: The 925 ballots for the 2010 Heisman Trophy were mailed Monday from New York. The voters, mostly journalists, have until Dec. 6 to return the ballot, although in recent years the vast majority have been submitted online.

title: Inquiry Finds Corruption at Agency for Probation
description: BOSTON  The hiring and promotion practices of the Massachusetts Probation Department are rife with systemic abuse and corruption, according to an independent report released Thursday.

title: Reconnecting the Dots of a Scattered Family
description: This film is designated as a Critics' Pick

title: Balenciaga: Spanish Master Exhibit
description: Balenciaga: Spanish Master is an exhibition at the Queen Sofa Spanish Institute on Park Avenue.

title: Diaper Wars: State Wants Bid Process for Vendors
description: Call it a bad case of adult diaper drama: Vendors of incontinence products are facing off against the state comptrollers office over plans to competitively bid underpads, catheters and other supplies for Medicaid patients.

title: Gearing Up for Distant Royal I Dos
description: MARIETTA, Ga.  In this Atlanta suburb 4,200 miles from London, Tina Barnes is already planning a wedding-watching party. Never mind that the bride and bridegroom have not announced a date.

title: Tensions Between Companionship and Solitude
description: Willfully withholding and maddeningly enigmatic, Nothing Personal may be parsimonious with words, but its sights are almost embarrassingly effusive. Dwarfed but not diminished by the stupefying beauty of the films western Ireland location, the two leads act out a story as simple and ancient as the hills that surround them.

title: Enough to Cause Art Lovers to Swoon
description: Boston

title: Masked Military Man Is Superhero for Troops
description: WASHINGTON  Faster than a fleeting bullet point in an Army briefing slide. Able to leap Pentagon jargon in a single bound. While hes not a classic superhero like the Man of Steel, hes certainly a man of irony.

title: Ex-Director of Miami Art Museum to Curate Biennale in China
description: Terence Riley, the former director of the Miami Art Museum, has been appointed chief curator for the 2011 edition of the Shenzhen & Hong Kong Biennale of Urbanism\Architecture. The appointment makes Mr. Riley the first non-Chinese curator for the event, which started in 2005.

title: Passion at the Piano
description: Regina Spektor: Live in London  thats what its called, and thats what you get. Eighteen songs, performed in December 2009 at the Hammersmith Apollo, with an absolute minimum of onstage chatter and dollops of stylishly grainy, MTV-like filler: Ms. Spektor on the plane from New York, driving through London, applying makeup before the show. Its perfectly tasteful, a fine showcase for her music and, more important, a fine promotional tool for the accompanying CD and DVD (which  surprise  contain four additional songs).

title: Cynthia Ozicks Homage to Henry James
description: Cynthia Ozicks longstanding and perceptive enthrallment with Henry James once made her declare the pivotal truth of his last novels to be not that he chooses to tell too little . . . but that he knows too much, and much more than we, or he, can possibly take in. Among those books it is The Ambassadors that has most preoccupied Ozick, who admits that her first novel, Trust, published in 1966, was heavily influenced by compulsive reading and rereading of it.

title: Saul Bellows Quest for the Vernacular Sublime
description: We often stopped before a display of childrens shoes. My mother coveted for me a pair of patent-leather sandals with an elegantissimo strap. I finally got them  I rubbed them with butter to preserve the leather. This is when I was 6 or 7 years old, a little older than Rosie is now. Amazing how it all boils down to a pair of patent-leather sandals. Saul Bellow recorded that ancient memory, stirred to it by play with his little daughter, in a letter on Feb. 19, 2004, when he was 88 years old. It is the last letter in this magnificent book. The old master died a year later.

title: Republicans Rise to Power, With Enmity for Health Law
description: MADISON, Wis.  Until Election Day, when Wisconsin turned from navy blue to crimson red, this state aspired to lead the nation in carrying out the federal health care law and using its incentives to regulate and reshape the medical delivery system. The current governor, Jim Doyle, a two-term Democrat, praised the law as a great benefit to Wisconsin.

title: Despite Daunting Illness, a Provider Forges Ahead
description: Linda Goldsteins apartment is a treat for the eye: Framed portraits of divas  Diana Ross, Madonna and Barbra Streisand  anchor one wall, while mirrors in the shapes of stars, butterflies and spiky suns hang from another. Personal photographs from various eras perch on a bookshelf beneath a row of multicolored snow globes.

title: Cost-Saving State Law Endangers Growth of Wind Industry
description: Chicago is the nations wind industry economic hub, home to about 80 wind companies from corporate headquarters to turbine component factories. Illinois has ample farmland well-suited for wind farms, and a law mandating that the state get at least 18 percent of its electricity from wind power by 2025.

title: Bears Defense Overwhelms Ailing Dolphins in Shutout
description: Brian Urlacher and the swarming Chicago Bears defense allowed only 187 yards and a single third-down conversion Thursday night, winning 16-0 to send the injury-ravaged Miami Dolphins to their second home shutout in 40 years.

title: Perry Makes It Clear, He Is Not Your Bush Republican
description: To the list of things for which Gov. Rick Perry shows contempt  Barack Obamas leadership abilities, excessive federal regulation, coyotes that interrupt his morning jog  add this surprising one: George W. Bushs brand of conservatism.

title: Yankees Keep Cool, Lest Jeter Talks Boil Over
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Hal Steinbrenner, the Yankees managing general partner, stood in a warm breeze in the portico outside the Waldorf Astoria hotel here Thursday and did his best to project a calm outlook regarding what still has the potential to be a stormy issue for his team.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Expanding Postseason to be Discussed
description: Commissioner Bud Selig said his 14-man committee to discuss on-field matters would meet at the winter meetings in early December to discuss expanding the postseason by two teams, an idea that seems to be without opposition.

title: New Budget Director Confirmed
description: 10:41 p.m. | Updated  The Office of Management and Budget has a director again  and he looks familiar.

title: F.D.A. Approves a Bone Drug for Cancer Patients
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the use of Amgens bone drug denosumab as a treatment for cancer patients whose disease has spread to their bones.

title: W. Howard Lester, Williams-Sonoma Owner, Dies at 75
description: W. Howard Lester, who in 1978 bought Williams-Sonoma, a small supplier of items for gourmet kitchens with four stores and annual sales of $4 million, and transformed it into a retail home furnishing and mail-order giant with 609 stores and annual sales of $3.4 billion, died Monday at his home in Indian Wells, Calif. He was 75.

title: Extending a Subway Line, Linking 2 Worlds
description: At the corner of Main Street and Roosevelt Avenue, where the No. 7 train terminates in Flushing, Queens, a barrage of people chat in dozens of languages, jostling for space on the sidewalk. Steps from the subway is an international smorgasbord of restaurants and shops, most splashed with Chinese characters and Korean lettering.

title: Maryland Attacker Flashes Skill That Defies Her Size
description: Seven years ago, the University of Marylands field hockey coach, Missy Meharg, noticed a group of high school students shooting around during halftime of a Terrapins game. One of them was ripping shots at the cage with a power that defied her age and size.

title: Rattner Seeks Damages From Quadrangle
description: Steven L. Rattners antagonists include not only the New York attorney general but also Mr. Rattners former business partners.

title: Struggling Islanders Revoke Bloggers Credentials
description: Chris Botta, who publicized the Islanders for 15 years, had his credentials to cover the team on his blog revoked Tuesday, a day after the last-place franchise fired Coach Scott Gordon.

title: Worm Was Perfect for Sabotaging Centrifuges
description: Experts dissecting the computer worm suspected of being aimed at Irans nuclear program have determined that it was precisely calibrated in a way that could send nuclear centrifuges wildly out of control.

title: Echoing Obama, Bernanke Presses China on Imbalances
description: FRANKFURT  Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, argued Friday that currency undervaluation by China and other emerging markets was at the root of persistent imbalances in trade that represent a growing financial and economic risk.

title: The Chain of Energy
description: This is the tenth in a series.

title: Cuomo Sues Rattner in Pension Case
description: The New York attorney general sued Steven L. Rattner in a kickback case. It came as Mr. Rattner settled charges with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Read the full article here.

title: Punishment in the House
description: Censure is the most serious punishment the House of Representatives can mete out, short of expulsion. When members are censured, they must stand in the well of the House while the speaker reads a resolution rebuking them for misconduct.

title: October Was New York States Best Month for New Jobs in Years, Data Show
description: Employers in New York State added more jobs in October than in any month in more than five years, as the state and New York City continued to rebound from the long recession faster than the rest of the nation, according to jobs data released on Thursday.

title: Pat-Downs at Airports Prompt Complaints
description: In the three weeks since the Transportation Security Administration began more aggressive pat-downs of passengers at airport security checkpoints, traveler complaints have poured in.

title: A Trailblazer With Her Eye on the Bottom Line
description: She grew up sheltered and privileged, in a middle-class Irish enclave of Chicago at midcentury, attending Catholic schools and riding horses at a country club where blacks and Jews were not allowed. Yet from age 28, she blazed a trail for working women, persuading male-dominated Madison Avenue to get behind an upstart magazine called Ms.

title: Democrats Struggling to Make Any Headway
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, the Connecticut independent, said Thursday that he and other opponents of the militarys dont ask, dont tell policy on gay service members had secured the votes to authorize its repeal  provided that Senate leaders allow a free-flowing debate on the wider military policy bill that includes the repeal.

title: House Republicans Block Unemployment Benefits Extension
description: The House failed to pass an extension unemployment insurance benefits for another three months Thursday afternoon. The vote was 258 to 154, short of the two-thirds needed for passage.

title: N.Y.U. Scraps Plan for Tallest Tower in Greenwich Village
description: New York University abandoned plans to build the tallest tower in Greenwich Village on Thursday after the influential architect I. M. Pei made his opposition known, and is now proposing to build a shorter but bulkier building on a different site.

title: An Unsealed Lawsuit Indicates Dell Hid Faults of Computers
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Documents unsealed Thursday in a three-year-old lawsuit against Dell have raised more questions about how the company handled an unprecedented number of faulty computers sold to governments, schools and corporations from 2003 to 2005.

title: List of Candidates at 4, Mets Begin Deliberating
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  The Mets front office staff concluded the interview phase of its search for a manager Thursday and huddled for about 45 minutes afterward to begin dissecting the four candidates. The process is expected to take about three days.

title: Courting Hispanic Customers With Texts and Web Sites en Espaol
description: AS the Hispanic population in the United States continues to grow, major advertisers are seeking new ways to attract Hispanic customers. These advertisers are increasingly trying to deliver their message in Spanish through Web sites, special sites for mobile phones and texting campaigns.

title: Ghailani Verdict Reignites Debate Over the Proper Court for Terrorism Trials
description: WASHINGTON  Fierce criticism erupted Thursday over the split verdict on terrorism charges against the first Guantnamo detainee to be tried in civilian court, casting new doubts on the Obama administrations goal of trying cases against other prisoners in the civilian criminal justice system.

title: Lottery Numbers
U. of California Will Raise Tuition by 8 Percent
description: SAN FRANCISCO  With none of the protest that marred previous meetings, the University of Californias Board of Regents approved an 8 percent fee increase on Thursday, the second straight year that students have faced higher tuition.

title: G.O.P. Governors Gather, and Some Debate the Size of Their Deficits
description: SAN DIEGO  This is a really bad year, the would-be governor from South Carolina remarked. Weve got huge problems, said her counterpart from Oklahoma. And from the governor-elect of Wisconsin: There are serious issues we have to deal with now.

title: European Import Has Cars Spinning. Heads, Too.
description: Traffic is going in circles. Armed with mounting data showing that roundabouts are safer, cheaper to maintain and friendlier to the environment, transportation experts around the country are persuading communities to replace traditional intersections with them.

title: Intelligence Bodies Faulted on Disclosure
description: WASHINGTON  The House Intelligence Committee said Thursday that it had found 16 cases since the 1990s in which the intelligence agencies failed to provide Congress with complete, timely and accurate information about their activities, as the law requires.

title: The Debtor of the Western World
description: Dublin

title: Thank the Courts
description: America has reached a fork in the road, and the time has come to make a decisive choice, Daniel J. Popeo, chairman of the Washington Legal Foundation, wrote this week in his monthly column in The Washington Examiner. The choice he posited was between continuing to endure judicial intervention in the conduct of the war on terrorism and returning control over national and homeland security decisions to the executive and legislative branches.

title: The Hidden Costs of Extra Airport Security
description: I recognize that the outcry over the T.S.A.s new security procedures  which has been both broad and deep in technology, travel and political blogs, but which has beenless acute elsewhere in the country  has a bit of a Brooks Brothers Riot quality to it. That is because its effects are felt most manifestly among those relatively few Americans who have the means to travel (and the wherewithal to write about it).

title: At Terror Trial, Big Questions Were Avoided
description: One of the striking aspects of the case of Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani, the first former Guantnamo detainee tried in a civilian court, was how little the federal jury in New York City heard about the issues that had made his case so fiercely debated.

title: Friday: Nixon Pal Rebozo
description: Once again, a contributor from our comments section, Barry Franklin, is sitting in as todays guest solver. If that name doesnt ring a bell, Im sure his alias does, KarmaSartre.

title: A Gaudy Swashbuckle Through History
description: Theatergoers looking to experience the wittiest part of John Guares Free of Man of Color, the spangled white elephant now rampaging at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, need only pick up a program. You know how practically every Playbill handed out on Broadway these days features a list of producers as long as Shaquille ONeals arm?

title: Requiem for Man Whose Ideas on Transit Arent Past
description: Theodore W. Kheel made his bones as a labor arbitrator, a reputation so sturdy that it obscured the trainload of ideas he had about how to transport New Yorkers around their city.

title: Hong Kong: Bird Flu Checks Increase
description: Health authorities said Thursday that they were increasing their checks on poultry coming from mainland China and at farms and markets across the region after government officials confirmed the first case of bird flu in seven years in the territory. The regions top health official said there was no increased risk of contracting bird flu after a woman was hospitalized here last weekend with a variation of the disease. The worlds first outbreak of bird flu among people occurred here in 1997 and claimed six lives.

title: Audit Says Police Fall Short in Providing Interpreters
description: When Esther Jimenez called the police to her Staten Island home last year, she showed them the scratches on her arm. She told them that her husband had attacked her in front of their children. He had pushed her into a wall, she said, and knocked their youngest child from her arms.

title: Azerbaijan: Blogger Is Released Early
description: An Azeri blogger who was imprisoned on dubious charges of hooliganism 18 months ago was released Thursday, a year early. The blogger, Adnan Hajizada, was arrested after he posted satirical videos slyly critical of the government, including one in which he played a donkey holding a news conference. After he and a fellow blogger, Emin Milli, were confronted by young men at a restaurant, the two complained to the authorities, only to have prosecutors open a criminal case against them. Many Azeris feared this was the beginning of a crackdown on online media, the last venue available to the opposition after television, radio and newspapers have backed off critical commentary. Mr. Milli remains in custody, with six months left in his sentence.

title: Bloomberg Plans to Cut 10,000 City Jobs by 2012
description: Acknowledging the bleak financial future the city faces, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced plans on Thursday to eliminate the jobs of thousands of teachers and other city workers in the next two years.

title: After Breakthrough Games, Gallinari Disavows Stardom
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Over the span of six quarters, played over two nights, in two time zones, Danilo Gallinari unleashed a small arsenal of offensive artistry: swift drives, clever fakes, fadeaways, dunks, layups, 3-pointers and a steady string of free throws.

title: Men Plead Guilty in Ticket Conspiracy
description: Two men pleaded guilty to conspiring to evade computer security by buying and reselling more than a million seats for events like the Rose Bowl football game.

description: Washington

title: Repeal It. Now.
description: Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, made the right call this week in pledging to push for repeal of the dont ask, dont tell policy during the lame-duck session of Congress. The odds of ridding the country of the destructive ban on gay soldiers serving openly will diminish greatly in the next Congress when Republicans take over the House and gain strength in the Senate.

description: To the Editor:

title: Axis of Depression
description: What do the government of China, the government of Germany and the Republican Party have in common? Theyre all trying to bully the Federal Reserve into calling off its efforts to create jobs. And the motives of all three are highly suspect.

title: Weekness and Endurance
description: Just over a week ago, Newsweek announced that it is going to merge with the online magazine The Daily Beast. Since then, cyberspace has echoed with pessimistic commentary about the future of this new entity. After all, why should anyone think that two money-losing organizations will start making money simply because they have banded together?

title: C.I.A. and Former Nazis
description: To the Editor:

title: Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: To the Editor:

title: With All Disrespect, Mr. President
description: There was supposed to be a bipartisan summit at the White House on Thursday, but only the Democrats showed up. The Republican leadership of the House and Senate somehow couldnt find any time in their schedules to meet with the president of the United States. If this is what cooperation and mutual respect is going to look like over the next two years, then settle in for more trench warfare and far less progress.

title: Its Not Over
description: The recession that began in late 2007 ended officially in June 2009, but much of the country is still suffering.

title: The Ghailani Verdict
description: The verdict in the first federal trial of a former Guantnamo detainee has unleashed the usual chest-thumping and fear-mongering from the usual politicians. They are disappointed that the defendant was only convicted of one count of conspiring to blow up American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania in 1998  a crime for which he will probably serve a life sentence.

title: Germany: An Advance for Google
description: After months of public opposition, Google Street View went online on Thursday with panoramic images from 20 large German cities, including Berlin, Munich, Hamburg and Frankfurt. As a result of resistance from politicians and privacy advocates who said that the service violated privacy by providing detailed images of buildings and front yards, more than 244,000 residents  about 3 percent of the households in those cities  requested that their homes be blurred, as Google had offered.

title: Minority Report
description: As the speaker of the House of Representatives, where Democrats just lost 60-odd seats as well as their controlling majority, you led your party into the worst electoral defeat in decades. And yet you chose to run for Democratic leader in the next Congress. Why not just step down?  Well, dont forget that I led the party into the strong victories of 06 and 08. And now we are prepared to win again.

title: Driving the Jaguar C-X75
description: Jerry Garrett takes Jaguar's C-X75 for a spin.

title: Financier Is Sued by Cuomo in Fraud Case
description: Steven L. Rattner, the financier who oversaw the federal rescue of the auto industry, was formally accused by New Yorks attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, on Thursday of engaging in a kickback scheme involving the states pension system.

title: Gates Urges School Budget Overhauls
description: Bill Gates, the founder and former chairman of Microsoft, has made education-related philanthropy a major focus since stepping down from his day-to-day role in the company in 2008.

title: Nathan Oliveira, 81, Dies; Painted Human Conflict
description: Nathan Oliveira, a leading Bay Area artist who achieved national prominence fusing Abstract Expressionism and figuration in psychologically charged canvases that explored human isolation and alienation, died on Saturday at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 81.

description: Through J. K. Rowlings seven Harry Potter books, many readers have grown up alongside Harry, Hermione, Ron and the other characters. Are you one of them? Do you like reading about characters who develop into maturity, or do you prefer characters to stay the same age throughout a series? Why or why not?

title: Lollapalooza Expands to Chile
description: Lollapalooza began in 1991 as a summer package tour, solidifying the idea of alternative rock as a commercial format. In 2005, it was reborn as a weekend event in Chicago. And next year Lollapalooza will begin its next phase, with a branch of the festival opening in Santiago, Chile.

title: Earning the Trust of Haitians With H.I.V.
description: For the past nine months, Andre Lambertson and I have been reporting in Haiti, focusing mainly on H.I.V. and AIDS. At first glance, it seems to be a doubly depressing topic. As if the earthquake  with its death, displacement and lost limbs  were not enough, weve had to turn our attention to those who are even more vulnerable, and who, because of their disease, are often forced to live in the shadows.

title: N. Korea Seen Working on New Reactor
description: SEOUL, South Korea  New satellite images of a North Korean nuclear site and a recent visit to the North by two American experts suggest that North Korea has started work on a new reactor.

description: Aidan Crawley/Bloomberg News

title: Blast Traps New Zealand Coal Miners
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand  At least two dozen men were trapped underground after an explosion on Friday rocked the countrys largest coal mine in a mountainous region in the countrys South Island.

title: Tip of the Week: Distinguishing Gmail Chat Accounts
description: Not sure if you are chatting with a fellow Gmail user on a computer or one running around on a mobile phone? The Green Robot can tell you. This experimental feature from Gmail Labs displays a small robot icon next to the names of chat buddies tapped in from their Android phones.

title: NATO Agrees to Build Missile Defense System
description: LISBON  NATO leaders agreed on Friday evening to establish a missile defense shield that would cover all NATO member states, and on Saturday they expect Russia to agree to discuss the possibility of cooperating on the systems development.

description: College newspapers have always been home to short-tempered columnists raging against the establishment, but Tony Manfred, a history major at Cornell, struck an especially bitter tone this week.

description: For years, Democratic Senator Mark Warner of Virginia nurtured a wonky, centrist brand as a businessman-turned-politician whose great skill was at deal-making with his partisan adversaries.

title: The Lunch Box: A Sandwich on the Fly
description: Samantha Storey is trying to make her packed lunches less boring, one box at a time.

title: How Much Reality Will Homemade Millionaire Offer?
description: The latest in the spate of entrepreneurship-themed reality competition shows debuts tonight on the TLC channel and will feature female contestants exclusively. Eric Black, TLCs director of production, said the program, Homemade Millionaire, was inspired by the frequent requests for guidance that show host Kelly Ripa received from women eager to develop and market their products. The entrepreneurs will compete for the chance to offer their wares on the interactive, multichannel retailer HSN, which reaches more than 94 million homesin the United States and had 2009 sales of more than $2.7 billion.

title: Complaint Box | The Stupor Market
description: I remember fondly those weekly trips with my mother to the grocery store as a young boy. My father would drop us off, then wait in our black Chevy station wagon, reading the paper and smoking half a pack of Pall Malls.

description: There is a new contender in the the digital living room calledOrb TV, which can stream content from Hulu and other online services directly to a television.

title: Harrahs Cancels I.P.O., Citing Market Conditions
description: Jacob Kepler/Bloomberg NewsHarrahs Casino in Las Vegas, Nevada.

title: At Age 29 and Backed by a Brain Trust, Federer Digs In
description: PARIS  Not long ago, Roger Federer had no official coach. Now, intent on remaining a major force in the majors, he finds himself with two: Severin Luethi, his longtime confidant from Switzerland, and Paul Annacone, the former American player turned mentor who has worked with Pete Sampras and Tim Henman.

title: Detonator at Namibian Airport Was a Test Device
description: BERLIN  Germanys interior minister said Friday that a laptop case rigged with wires, a clock and a detonator found at a Namibian airport was really a mock bomb built in the United States to test airport security.

title: A Call to Action on Ocean Acidity
description: States bordering water bodies that are becoming more acidic from the absorption of carbon dioxide should list them as impaired under the Clean Water Act, the Environmental Protection Agency declared in a memo this week.

title: Despite Commodity Worries, Shares Bounce Back
description: Stocks ended slightly higher on Friday as encouraging reports about the prospects for an Irish financial rescue appeared to outweigh concerns about the prospect of slower growth in China.

title: Uncle Sam Wants You (Yes, You)
description: The Class Act always flew a bit under the radar. Its a big idea  the first voluntary public plan for long-term care insurance, a legacy of the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy  that was overshadowed by bitter debates over the rest of the health care legislation in which it was included.

title: Agenda | Boom Boom Rooms, Part One
description: Tough times dont seem to have stopped the hotel rush. New properties, along with smartened-up amenities and pioneering designs, keep popping up from Buenos Aires to Bangkok. T surveys the next hotel hot spots.

title: E-Commerce Reaches Record Share of Retail Sales
description: E-commerce sales in the third quarter of 2010 accounted for 4 percent of total retail sales, according to a Census Bureau report released on Friday. Thats the highest share on record since the government began keeping track in 1999. (And, to be honest, it seems unlikely that e-commerce ever accounted for a higher share of retail sales pre-1999.)

title: The Google Maps War That Wasnt
description: Heard the one about Nicaragua accidentally invading Costa Rica because of a Google Maps error?

title: Band Practice
description: Jean-Luc Godard is one eminently quotable auteur. He said, All you need for a movie is a gun and a girl. And my aesthetic is that of the sniper on the roof. And also, there is no point in having sharp images when you have fuzzy ideas. This last quotation, while less famous, is a roundabout way of introducing Scott Sternberg, ex-Hollywood talent agent, film nerd and serious Godard fan. Not only was Godards 1967 film La Chinoise the inspiration for Sternbergs fall 2009 collection, but his fashion labels own name, Band of Outsiders, comes from the English title of Godards canonical 1964 film Bande  Part. Sternberg has himself shot all of the Band of Outsiders look-books with a Polaroid camera, which means hes probably willing to take Godards axiom a step further: Theres no point in having sharp images when you can have fuzzy ones.

title: Haves, Have-Nots and Health Care
description: Aaron Carroll, a professor of pediatrics at Indiana University School of Medicine, has a post on the Incidental Economist blog about access to medical care. Dr. Carroll highlights data from the journal Health Affairs that shows that even households with above-average income often struggle to afford the medical care they want. He writes:

title: Fashism, a Social Shopping Site, Gets Cash
description: The hardest part of any shopping spree  other than handing over your credit card  is figuring out whether or not that vintage fringe leather jacket is a flattering addition to your fall collection.
