description: Each week, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: White Light Festival: An Act of Testimony
description: Over the past several weeks, Lincoln Center has presented the White Light Festival, billed as an exploration of the spiritual in music. The classical music critics and a reporter are discussing the merits of the festival, music and transcendence on ArtsBeat. Read all posts.

title: Planning for Temporary Home Care After the Hospital Stay
description: ANNIE BRUMBAUGH has become a bit of an expert on recuperating at home. Over the last two years, the 65-year-old wardrobe consultant has had two serious operations on her foot, plus a bone graft, each of which left her homebound for weeks at a time. This is not easy, said Ms. Brumbaugh, who lives alone in Manhattan. Most people have no idea what they are in for.

title: The Cost of Recuperating at Home
description: Even common surgical procedures, like C-sections and hip replacements, can involve longer than expected recuperation periods, but many patients arent prepared for the added cost, reports todays Patient Money column.

title: Abstract Expression
description: For her first artistic collaboration for the new brand Chance, the designer Julia Leach decided to work with the photographer Jarret Schecter, who is known for his documentary-style take on subjects as diverse as Romany Gypsies and the Russian countryside, shot from a trans-Siberian railway car. When Leach discovered his series Stalking Paris, she says, she was struck by the mood of the photos, which dovetailed nicely with her aesthetic for Chance  a mix of classic design and modern graphics. Instead of showing the typical touristy side of Paris, Schecter created an almost abstract view of the city he photographed people walking with umbrellas from above, the shadows of chairs in the Luxembourg Gardens and the Eiffel Tower in a layer of mist. His photos capture a Paris thats not a postcard-perfect city, says Leach, who served as the longtime creative director for Kate Spade. Its a raw Paris that shows history and modernity wrestling with each other. The prints will be available starting today at  www.chanceco.com ($250 for each 17-by-24-inch unframed image from the limited edition of 250).

title: U.S. Oil Imports Shrink, Yet Worries Loom
description: Good news on the energy security front?

title: 4D Man
description: A new archetypal 21st-century man.

title: China Restarts Rare Earth Shipments to Japan
description: HONG KONG  China resumed exports of crucial minerals to Japan on Friday for the first time in almost two months, Japanese government officials and an industry executive said.

title: FrontPoint to Shut Health Care Fund
description: The hedge fund FrontPoint Partners will liquidate its $1.5 billion health care fund in the wake of allegations that a manager at the firm received insider information from a French doctor, a person familiar with the matter said.

title: Bernanke Plays Offense
description: In a speech today in Frankfurt, the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, brought out the big (rhetorical) guns. He:

title: You Talkin' to Me?
description: Lauren LoGuidice, an actress, takes lessons from a voice and diction coach, Lynn Singer, to learn how to drop her Queens accent.

title: Some Verdicts Just Make You Scratch Your Head
description: How could jurors convict Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani of conspiring to blow up buildings, but not of conspiring to murder the people in them?

title: India Stocks Sink on Telecommunications Scandal
description: NEW DELHI  A widening corruption scandal that has touched Indias prime minister sent the countrys stock markets down sharply on Friday and threatened to tarnish the countrys image as a rising economic power.

title: Payments Appreciated
description: In my solo medical practice, I treat children from diverse socio-economic backgrounds. I dont participate in any insurance plans, but I routinely use a downward-sliding scale to help parents in financial difficulty afford care. Many of my patients come from families with extremely high net worth. A friend suggested I charge them more. Is it ethical to use the sliding scale in both directions? NAME WITHHELD, NEW YORK

title: Agenda | Boom Boom Rooms, Part Two
description: Playing It CoolNothing draws a crowd like a boldface designer. Yet these five high-style hotels have managed to fly under the radar  until now.

title: Unlearning to Tawk Like a New Yorker
description: ANDREW RAMOS always believed it made him more charming, an endearing characteristic integral to his identity. But, finally, after too many people mocked him, he began seeing a therapist.

title: Friday Reading: Free Wireless Internet in the Sky
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: New Don Carlo, That Ever-Changing Opera
description: TOMORROW evening, for the first time in more than 30 years, the Metropolitan Opera will unveil a new production of Verdis Don Carlo. The director is Nicholas Hytner, working with designs by Bob Crowley, both in their Met debuts. Roberto Alagna leads a starry cast as Don Carlo, the unstable son of Spains icy King Philip II. Yannick Nzet-Sguin conducts.

title: More Than a Car, Its a Co-Star
description: TESTED 2011 Suzuki SX4 SportBack

title: City Critic: Slaughtering Your Turkey
description: If you consume a turkey, you should know where it comes from. Should you also participate in its death? The City Critic reports from a slaughterhouse in Queens.

title: The Main Course Had an Unhappy Face ...
description: She was a beautiful bird, a Bourbon Red turkey whose rich brown feathers were flecked with white, and she had spent her days roaming free around an organic farm that overlooked the Hudson River. But as I stood watching her, she did not seem happy. Instead, with her almond eyes downcast, her subdued manner suggested a kind of forbearance.

title: This Ballerina Found History In Her Footsteps
description: IT is not the typical academic who studies the political and cultural history of nations by trying to locate those histories within her body. Yet that was precisely the approach taken by Jennifer Homans, a former professional ballet dancer turned historian and critic, whose enormous new history of classical ballet, Apollos Angels, was published this month.

title: 2011 Suzuki SX4 Sportback
description: The SX4 SportBack is a compact wagon that daydreams of being a rally car.

title: New Roads = Traffic = Emissions?
description: This week I was in Kenya and ended up spending a lot of time sitting in traffic. Even at night, a trip to the Nairobi airport that should have taken 30 minutes took three times that. In reporting trips to large cities of the developing world, I have noticed that one feature most now have in common is this jarring traffic and attendant smog, from Nairobi to New Delhi to Beijing.

title: Ann Beattie, Distilling Her Generation
description: One thing that this collection of short stories by Ann Beattie makes it possible to do is imagine your way into the head of a New Yorker fiction editor at the moment of discovery. Roger Angell turned down more than a dozen stories sent to the magazine over 22 months by a very young Beattie, who was then in the process of dropping out of a graduate English program. But he wrote encouraging rejections (I hope you will let us see more of your work, and that you will address your future submissions directly to me) and finally accepted A Platonic Relationship (What I like most about the story is its sparsity. Almost everything except the essential has been done away with, leaving one with the vision of a Giacometti). The story was published on April 8, 1974, when Beattie was 26 years old. Reading it all these years later, you may have to work a little to pick up the electrical currents pulsing beneath its dry, self-contained surface  Beatties style wasnt called minimalist for nothing  but if you do, you will see some of what Angell must have seen.

title: Up Front: John Adams
description: The composer John Adams reviews Begin Again, Kenneth Silvermans biography of John Cage, in this issue.

title: The Zen of Silence
description: John Cage was one astonishing individual. A composer we commonly associate with coin tossing, whose most famous piece called for the performer not to make a single sound, he upended long-held conventions about the listening process and prodded us to re-evaluate how we define not only music but the entire experience of encountering art. He was, in the words of Kenneth Silvermans new biography, driven by an ideal of nonmythic listening and seeing, of perceptual innocence; his goal was to compose a prelapsarian music untainted by history.

title: The Missing Piece
description: Suzanne Bernes father lost his mother to cancer when he was still a small boy. Not only did she leave her children bereaved  she also left them perplexed: We were told she was gone. No one ever said where.

title: The O Word
description: Wed better address one textual issue up front, and without italics. This book opts for the iconic form: OK.

title: Asked & Answered | David Armstrong
description: For Mad About the Boy, his new exhibition at Half Gallery, the photographer David Armstrong has sifted through more than 25 years of his archives looking for the male muses who have inspired him over the years. Appropriately for a photographer who has moved fluidly between fine art and fashion work, these muses are models, lovers and friends, and the photographs Armstrong has chosen to exhibit include classic black and white portraits, moody shadow-dimmed color images and cut-up contact sheets exhibited in scrapbooks. The Moment recently caught up with Armstrong for a tour through his personal archive.

title: Leaving Money on the (Conference) Table
description: Thank you to everyone who took the time to comment on my recent posts. Id like to share my reactions to a few of the comments. Because each day of the series had a different theme, Ill address each days comments together.

title: Week 12 College Football Matchups
description: The No. 1 and No. 2 teams are off this week, so dont expect any earth-shaking changes at the top of the college football world this weekend. But do expect a lot of conference races to begin to sort themselves out and do expect some entertaining football. Its a big weekend in the Big Ten, with Ohio State and Wisconsin jockeying for B.C.S. positioning, while Nebraska and Texas A&M meet up in what could be a very exciting Big 12 matchup. In the A.C.C., Maryland (yes Maryland) controls its own destiny in the Atlantic division, while Virginia Tech looks to wrap up the Coastal with a victory in Miami. There are also some great traditional rivalries on Saturday afternoon with The Big Game in Berkeley and The Game in Cambridge. Theres even a game at the new Yankee Stadium as Army and Notre Dame will square off on Saturday evening in the latest edition of one of the most historically important rivalries in college football. Its getting down to it. Pay attention. Lets get to the matchups.

title: Race for House Office Space Begins
description: The race for space is on.

title: Wrigley Set for Football, With Odd Ground Rules
description: CHICAGO  Saturdays college football game at Wrigley Field between Northwestern and Illinois was shaping up to be an unusual game. But on Friday the Big Ten announced a series of safety-related changes that promise to make the game even more memorable, no matter its location.

title: Cover to Cover: The Why and Wherefore
description: Justin Bieber

title: Daddys Little Protagonist
description: Charles Eltons first novel, Mr. Toppit, begins and ends with Luke Hayman, son of Arthur Hayman, an unsuccessful British screenwriter who has written an outlandishly popular series of childrens books called The Hayseed Chronicles. That Arthurs brilliant career is posthumous, the result of the coming together of improbable people and a cement truck, is only one of the novels many ironies, some funny, others heartbreaking. (A few are forced: a June bug is ushered out of a bathroom in a tooth mug inverted on the ripped-off cover of Seven Types of Ambiguity.) Only wisps of the Hayseed books are shown directly, but occasional descriptions hint at what might have happened if Roald Dahl had invaded Narnia. The villain of the series, Mr. Toppit, is an unseen sinister force who sets cryptic tasks for its hero, Luke Hayseed, and is never satisfied.

title: Reality TV Pours Itself A Cold One
description: AT this advanced reality-TV moment  what with shows about crab fishermen and cake decorators and extreme eaters its a little surprising that no one has gotten around to beer. A multibillion-dollar industry responsible for seemingly half the advertising on television, beer would appear to be a natural subject, not to mention a marketable one. As Stephen Reverand, a vice president for development at the Discovery Channel, framed it recently, The planet is divided into rice cultures and bread cultures, but everyone makes beer.

title: Never Mind The Question, Heres the Answer
description: WRITERS have to know things, Fran Lebowitz says near the start of Public Speaking, a new documentary about her. Well, not exactly about her  though she discusses her upbringing, there is no montage of a young Fran, astonishingly cigaretteless, at play as a child in New Jersey, and only a few clips of her early years in New York, as part of the downtown demimonde she chronicled for Interview magazine. The documentary, which has its premiere on HBO on Nov. 22, is about what Ms. Lebowitz, 60, knows. Which, as she will be the first to tell you, is a lot.

title: Translating Top Gear Into American
description: IRVINE, Calif.

title: The Week Ahead: NOV. 21  27
description: Pop

title: Welcome to the Casino
description: Two of our finest business journalists have written a thorough account of the origins of the financial crisis of 2008. More than offering just a backward look, it helps explain the most troubling business headlines of the moment, as well as those that are certain to come. For starters, there is the unfolding foreclosure-paperwork fiasco. Next up will be a clash over whether big banks should be forced to take back billions of dollars in contaminated mortgages they sold. Down the road, we will no doubt confront the danger of the next asset bubble inflating as a result of the Federal Reserves use of extreme monetary policy to stimulate the economy. These continuing and future problems are all symptoms of a larger syndrome whose origins Bethany McLean and Joe Nocera ably chronicle in All the Devils Are Here: The Hidden History of the Financial Crisis.

title: In a Cult Bronx Film, Hints of Hip-Hop
description: In the summer of 1979, Gary Weis and six film crew members drove from Manhattan to the South Bronx every day for two weeks, a journey that each day left Mr. Weis in awe and despair.

title: Pregame Huddle: How to Beat Oregon
description: California failed to pull off a big upset against Oregon, but they may have laid the groundwork for another team to knock off the No.1 team in the country.

title: Waiting for the Next Act in the Madoff Inquiry
description: The Justice Department and Securities and Exchange Commission have filed criminal and civil complaints against two former employees of Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities, accusing them of providing the support needed for Mr. Madoff to pull off his huge Ponzi scheme.

title: Reviewing the Bidding on the Climate Files
description: 9:10 p.m. | Updated One year ago today, I was immersed in preparations for covering the Copenhagen round in climate treaty negotiations when a Facebook message popped up from Steven Mosher, a marketing consultant and software developer in San Francisco.

title: Shaking the Family Tree
description: This summer, an idealistic young New Yorker spent several weeks working with poor children in India. Just before she left, a little girl ran up and pinched her so hard she drew blood. When a translator asked why shed hurt someone whod been kind to her, the girl explained, This way she wont forget me after she leaves. That startling child already knew the inscriptive power of pain.

title: Reviewing the Suzuki SX4 SportBack
description: In this weeks Automobiles section, Jonathan Schultz evaluates the Suzuki SX4 SportBack, describing it as a compact wagon that daydreams of being a rally car. He continues:

title: Zamperinis War
description: While the body counts mount in Afghanistan and Iraq, another military tally, less wrenching and tragic but poignant nonetheless, quietly proceeds. Every day more than 700 veterans of World War II die, and with each one goes a story, or dozens of them. Laura Hillenbrand reached Louis Zamperini just in the nick of time  he was in his mid-80s when she found him, and 93 now and its an excellent thing, for his is surely one of the most extraordinary war stories of all.

title: A Preview of the American Top Gear
description: After months years of development, a teaser trailer, a 60 Minutes special and a pilot episode for NBC that was not picked up, an American version of Top Gear will make its debut on Sunday on the History Channel. The History Channels show is at least the third attempt to begin an American edition of the wildly popular BBC show hosted by Jeremy Clarkson, Richard Hammond and James May.

title: Palin to Start Book Tour as Details Leak Out
description: Sarah Palin, the political celebrity and former Alaska governor, will start her second book tour next week as she continues to tease the media about a possible presidential run in 2012.

title: T.S.A. Screening Measures Draw Virtual Protests
description: The Transportation Security Administrations new security measures to screen travelers at airports have drawn complaints, including virtual campaigns by a few especially vocal critics who have called for protests that could disrupt Thanksgiving holiday travel.

title: Five-Link Friday: Mayor of Nowhere Edition
description: Its a beautiful fall Friday out there. So New Jersey Transit riders, now that youre stopped, be sure to smell the roses, or at least admire the crisp, clear sky from your stalled train car window.

title: Ireland Is Said to Discuss Bailout of Nearly $70 Billion
description: PARIS  The financial support program being discussed between Ireland and potential donors should amount to at least 50 billion euros, officials briefed on the talks said Friday.

title: An Affair to Remember
description: Years after the death of loved ones, we may find ourselves dreaming that they are alive. How happy we are to see them, to hear their voices, to realize how absurdly mistaken we were to think them lost forever. Then we wake, remember the truth and feel a pang as sharp as any we suffered in the early days of mourning.

title: The More Convenient Gift Card
description: Its easy to forget to bring a gift card when you go shopping, and its simple, too, to lose track of gift cards received during holidays past.

title: Allman Brothers Band Plans Announcement at Beacon Theater
description: Is the Allman Brothers Band ready to end its rambling and return to the Beacon Theater?

title: K.K.R. in Talks for Del Monte
description: In 1989, after the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company closed its landmark $25 billion buyout of the food and cigarette giant RJR Nabisco, it swiftly moved to sell its food brands. Among the first sales was Del Monte, which K.K.R. offloaded to a group of private investors.

title: Fete Accompli | Lanvin for H&M
description: On Thursday night, underneath the shabby opulence of a dozen or so sparkling chandeliers, mismatched and hanging at different heights from the ceiling of one of the ball rooms at the Pierre Hotel, an array of top models  Dree Hemingway, Siri Tollerod and Lindsey Wixson among them  wore one-of-a-kind versions of Alber Elbazs new Lanvin for H&M collaboration, slinking, flirting and vamping down the runway in bright patterned tights, amazing costume jewelry and gowns made up of sexy mishmashes of bows, ribbon and poofy fabric. Set against the Pierres rarefied setting, this didnt feel like fashion for the masses so much as an exclusive collection narrowed down to its more tarty elements. It isnt always clear exactly what brands dripping in luxury hope to get out of such dips into the more shallow end of the pool. But they clearly are getting something. And if there were any doubt, Anna Dello Russo, dressed in a hot-pink one-shoulder number, prancing under the bright lights with a poodle in tow, made things crystal clear: these were true Lanvin girls.

title: Naked Irish Sleepwalker Wins Libel Suit
description: An Irish jury awarded nearly $14 million in damages on Thursday to a man who claimed that his former employers had slandered him by insinuating that he had made improper advances to a female colleague during a business trip.

title: The New Great Game
description: Maps often reveal more about those who draw them than they do about the reality they purport to represent. The Mercator projections that typically hang on the walls of classrooms and Pentagon offices place the United States in the middle, separated from Europe to the east by the Atlantic Ocean and from Asia to the west by the vast expanse of the Pacific. Our preference for this perspective no doubt reflects a certain national egocentrism, but for the better part of the last two centuries it has also made a good deal of strategic sense.

title: What if Captured Carbon Makes a Getaway?
description: The political clout of the fossil-fuel industries was driven home this year with the death of cap-and-trade legislation in Congress. Among those flexing their muscles was the coal industry, which is responsible for more than 45 percent of the countrys generating capacity.

title: What Were Reading: If Chinese Growth Slows
What If Campbell Was Still Sending E-mails?
description: The hits just keep on coming for N.H.L. director of hockey operations Colin Campbell. Earlier this week he was at the center of a storm when internal e-mails revealed that he had called Marc Savard a little fake artist and criticized calls made against his son Gregory.

title: Whos No. 1?
description: This is the 13th year of the Bowl Championship Series, the byzantine and unpopular system that is supposed to guarantee that the college-football season ends with a championship game between the sports two best teams. Comparing teams that usually do not play one another  there are 120 major college-football programs, and each one competes in just 12 games each season  was never going to be easy. Like three egg rolls served to a party of four at a Chinese restaurant, the portions never seem to divide up quite as neatly as they should. This year, for instance, four programs  Oregon, Auburn, Boise State and Texas Christian  have spent much of the season in contention for the two positions in the championship.

title: Who Can Resist a Man Who Sings Like a Woman?
description: One afternoon last July, a small, anxious crowd gathered in the lobby of Amsterdams Concertgebouw, hoping for a glimpse of Philippe Jaroussky, the young French countertenor who was to give a Baroque recital later that night. Among them were a Japanese woman in a black-and-white houndstooth coat, carrying a candy-pink shopping-bag with a DVD of a Kurosawa film that she intended to present to him, and a Russian violin teacher from Bremen wearing a sapphire ball gown. This was the kernel of die-hard Jaroussky admirers who follow the singer around the world, posting live videos of his concerts on YouTube and commiserating on his fan sites with fellow devotees whod been unable to get to Sydney or Basel.

title: The Real Supermarkets of Orange County
description: In August, to be closer to my aging parents, my husband and I moved from Northern California to Orange County. My family settled there more than 30 years ago, not long after coming to the United States from Iran. I was 12, and the culture shock was pretty severe. There were moms in tennis skirts, dads in pastels, good-looking blond boys who surfed and good-looking blond girls who were born to wear bikinis. We were the only dark-haired people theyd ever met who didnt speak Spanish. When I left for college, I told myself that Id never live in such a homogeneous place again. Today the beaches are still beautiful and surfers still ride the waves, but the blonds are in the minority.

title: Midterm Maneuvers
description: My daughter was looking at President Obamas picture in the paper the morning after the midterm elections. Daddy, she asked, why does he look so frustrated? Explaining divided government to a 3-year-old turns out to be harder than youd think. But she did seem to get the point that, while Obama was still the president, his job was about to become much more difficult.

title: The Attention-Span Myth
description: We seem to know a great deal about attention spans, those constituents of character that have become the digital-age equivalent of souls.

title: Letters: Slick on Slick
description: As a practicing trial lawyer, I was offended by Douglas McCollams article, which appears to define trial lawyers to be those who, like Tony Buzbee, actively seek to represent victims of mass or even individual disasters. While there are many such lawyers, there are at least as many trial lawyers who earn their livelihood prosecuting and defending business and personal disputes in the highest tradition of the bar. This is a much higher and more-noble end of the profession than readers would understand from McCollams description. Our legal system is unsurpassed (except possibly by Britains), and that is because, in no small part, of the skill and dedication of thousands of trial lawyers, who should not be tarred by the same brush as those depicted by McCollam.

title: Letter: The Headache That Wouldnt Go Away
description: We were disturbed to read, in Lisa Sanderss Diagnosis column, about the reluctance to perform CT scanning due to concerns about fetal exposure to radiation. Head CT is considered safe in pregnancy, because the uterus is outside the area of radiation exposure and can be easily shielded with lead. Magnetic resonance imaging is also considered safe. On the other hand, undiagnosed and untreated neurologic disorders do put the mother and her unborn child at considerable risk. A seizure during pregnancy can be dangerous for mother and child.

title: Weekend Competition: Crossword Clueless
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to devise self-solving crossword clues.

title: 2011 Audi A7: Audi Joins the 4-Door Coupe Parade
description: Introduced on Thursday: 2011 Audi A7

title: No Offense, Mariners, but ...
description: Today we shall sponsor a debate over just whose offense is the worst: the Miami Dolphins, the Seattle Mariners and U.C.L.A. being the featured contestants. With Miami led (nowhere) by a quarterback named Tyler Thigpen, the Mariners being so otherworldly bad that pitcher Felix Hernandez won the Cy Young Award in a landslide despite only 13 victories and the Bruins getting crushed in a game when the opposing quarterback outshined them with 68 yards, there are no wrong answers.

title: Holidays After Divorce
description: Holidays are a reaffirmation of our families, and reminders of their imperfections. Its a time to find strength in existing bonds, and also to mourn the ones weve lost.

title: Glimpsing the Brains Powers (and Limits)
description: A once-living example of the most complicated object in the universe is mounted in a case at the beginning of the ambitious exhibition Brain: The Inside Story, which opens on Saturday at the American Museum of Natural History. And a sorry-looking object it is, if we put aside the symbolism and portentousness that have grown around it, and the research that barely has begun to dissect its innermost workings.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Absolute Morrison
description: The hardcover list has a double dose of Grant Morrison this week. The British writer takes on two of the biggest heroes published by DC Comics: Superman and Batman. In All-Star Superman Mr. Morrison took the Man of Steel, stripped him of years of continuity and came up with some ingenious adventures. This deluxe Absolute edition (at No. 4 on the list) reprints the 12 stories, illustrated by Frank Quietly, and includes bonus sketch material. In reviewing the second volume for The New York Times Book Review, Doug Wolk wrote, Grant Morrison is one of the deftest superhero-comics writers of the moment. He added, Nearly every visual detail and line of dialogue has some subtler implication or resonance that emerges on rereading.

title: Obama and the Book of Job
description: Unfortunately for the powerful, the plight of the biblical Job is a story with perennial resonance. A man seemingly rich in the gifts life has to offer, happy and blessed, finds himself  unjustly, from his perspective  bereft. Protected and apparently invincible one day, he is buffeted as God turns his back on his former beloved, producing rage, confusion and self-pity. In the history of the American presidency, reversal happens time and time again: Lyndon Johnson declining to run four years after his landslide victory in 1964, George H. W. Bush losing re-election after winning the Persian Gulf war of 1991, Bill Clinton in the 1994 midterms, and now Barack Obama.

title: Bar Mitzvah Studies Take to the Web
description: AT Eli Kapsacks bar mitzvah, he chanted in the ancient tones of the Hebrew Bible about a sorcerer named Balaam, the angel of the Lord descending to earth and a talking donkey who tries to clue her owner in to the miracle at hand. He read the prayers for the Saturday morning service, and took his place as a religious adult, as Jewish children generally do at 13.

title: 2011 Nissan Quest: Now Made in Japan
description: Introduced on Wednesday: Fourth-generation Nissan Quest minivan.

title: Thais Show Resolve at Protest 6 Months After Crackdown
description: BANGKOK  Thousands of antigovernment demonstrators blocked a major intersection in the commercial heart of the Thai capital on Friday to mark the passage of six months since a bloody military crackdown on street protests.

title: An Eye for an Eye
description: Whatever the weaknesses of their free-form plots, Walter Mosleys crime novels are redeemed by the earthy vitality of his characters: an exuberant pageant of fast-talking rogues and unrepentant sinners, high-stepping women, sharp young blades and children wise beyond their years. Meanwhile, on the sidelines, are his philosophical old souls, shaking their heads and laughing at the parade of fools.

title: Incivility Can Have Costs Beyond Hurt Feelings
description: COURTESY means a lot to me. I am keenly aware when someone fails to say please or thank you. Waiters or clerks who ignore me or respond snippily do so at their peril. My children know well my glare when they fail to give their bus or subway seat to an elderly person.

title: Decline is a Choice
description: Bad news from ESPN:

title: Video: How to Beat Oregon
description: California failed to pull off a big upset against Oregon, but they may have laid the groundwork for another team to knock off the No.1 team in the country. And was T.C.U.s close victory as bad as the score says it was? Connor Ennis and Paul Myerberg discuss on this weeks edition of the Pregame Huddle.

title: Marriage and the Monarchy: Lessons From the British Royal Family
description: Prince William, second in line to the British throne, announced his engagement this week, immediately sparking a media frenzy, especially in the United Kingdom. We think the news brings up some interesting possibilities for teaching and learning across the curriculum, in history, media studies and economics.

title: Blazers Stand by Ailing Oden
description: Its hard not to feel empathy for Portland Trail Blazers center Greg Oden, who is facing his third career-threatening knee surgery in three years. He came into the league with much fanfare, selected by the Blazers as the No. 1 overall pick of the 2007 draft.

title: Odey Plays a Familiar Role, the Contrarian
description: The London hedge fund manager Crispin Odey produced bumper profits for his investors by betting on bank stocks during the depths of the financial crisis.

title: TimesCast | November 19, 2010
description: The Pope prepares to install 24 new Cardinals; Baghdad's Muslims celebrate the holy holiday of Id al-Adha; and Harry Potter inspires good.

title: After the Feds Action, Watching Inflations Trajectory
description: THE core rate of inflation fell to a record low in the United States last month, rekindling fears of deflation and warnings that the Federal Reserve might have to take even more aggressive steps to keep inflation as high as it wants it to be.

title: Paperback Row
description: CROSSERS,  by Philip Caputo (Vintage Contemporaries, $16.) The sins of the father are visited on the children in Caputos novel of drugs, desperation and illegal immigration. Set in the borderlands of the Southwest, Crossers revolves around a multigenerational feud between Arizona cattle ranchers and the audacious head of a Mexican cartel.

title: Boehner Adamant: Well Oppose Partial Tax Relief
description: The Houses top Republican, John A. Boehner of Ohio, said that his party would firmly oppose any effort by Democrats to allow the Bush-era tax cuts expire on annual income above $250,000 for couples and $200,000 for individuals.

title: Editors Choice
description: LIFE,  by Keith Richards with James Fox (Little, Brown, $29.99.) Reading Richardss autobiography is like getting to corner him in a room and to ask everything you always wanted to know about the Rolling Stones, and have him be completely honest with you.

title: U.S. Women in Unfamiliar Place
description: It was not supposed to be this way.

title: Senate to Vote on Banning Earmarks
description: The full Senate will vote on a proposed ban on lawmaker-directed spending items known as earmarks, as an amendment to a food safety measure that is currently being debated on the floor. But it will need the support of a super-majority of 67 senators to be approved.

title: On Our Radar: Landrieu Drops Hold on Budget Nominee
description: Senator Mary Landrieu, Demcrat of Louisiana, dropped her hold on Jack Lew, President Obamas nominee for director of the Office of Management and Budget, on Thursday evening. Mr. Lew was confirmed by the Senate immediately after the hold was relinquished. Ms. Landrieu had blocked the nomination for nearly two months to pressure over concerns that drilling permits were not being issued quickly enough in the aftermath of the BP oil spill. [Politics Daily]

title: Fighting the Closing of a High School on the Brink
description: A school bus driver honked and pumped his fist around 7:30 Friday morning, steering along Stillwell Avenue beneath the elevated D train. Outside the tree-lined campus of John Dewey High School, a swirling crowd of students, teachers and alumni cheered, many hoisting handmade signs.

title: Lotus to Work on Next-Generation IndyCar for 2012
description: When General Motors officials announced last week that Chevrolet would resume supplying engines to the IndyCar Series in 2012, open-wheel-racing fans were delighted that Honda finally would have some competition. Now another motorsports giant is joining them.

title: Agenda | Boom Boom Rooms, Part Three
description: SHOW ME THE MONEY

title: Inside the List
description: HIS TURN: Things might be a little less tense in Crawford this Christmas now that George W. Bush has his own No. 1 best seller. Decision Points, the former presidents new memoir, enters in the top spot, just as his wifes Spoken From the Heart did last spring. But dont worry, ladies, Laura Bush isnt totally ceding the stage. Her memoir, which spent 12 weeks on the printed list, is still hanging around at No. 28 on the extended list, six months after publication.

title: New Daisy Ad Warns Against Delay in Arms Treaty
description: More than 40 years ago, President Lyndon Johnson used images of a little girl, a daisy and a mushroom cloud to urge people to vote for him, saying the stakes are too high.

title: Joe Scarborough Suspended for Two Days for Political Donations
description: Joe Scarborough, a co-host of MSNBCs Morning Joe, was briefly suspended Friday after Politico uncovered donations he had made to political candidates.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Harry Potter'
description: The director David Yates discusses a battle sequence from the movie.

title: Lead Producer of Spider-Man Hit With Lawsuit by Live Nation
description: Michael Cohl, the lead producer of the troubled Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, is being sued for more than $5 million by his former employer, Live Nation Entertainment, over what that company says are violations of the deal they struck when he left in 2008.

title: MSNBC Suspends Joe Scarborough for Campaign Donations
description: Joe Scarborough, a co-host of MSNBCs Morning Joe, was suspended for two days after he acknowledged making political donations that he had not disclosed to the network. For more, read the full post on Media Decoder.

title: Why Are Women in Some Countries Oppressed?
description: Theres much debate about why women in some countries are presidents and business executives, and women in others are locked up in the home and beaten or brutalized if they try to stand up for themselves. Obviously the differences are rooted in culture, but there are diverse theories about why some cultures resulted in more emancipated women and others in more oppressed women.

title: China Move Could Counter Feds Efforts
description: HONG KONG  Chinas central bank unexpectedly announced on Friday night that it would require commercial banks to set aside a bit more money. It was the second such move by Beijing this month and the clearest sign yet that China means to counter the Federal Reserves monetary easing in the United States.

title: Darvon Pulled From Market by F.D.A.
description: The painkilling drug propoxyphene, sold under the Darvon and Darvocet brands and used by about 10 million Americans last year, will be removed from the market because of serious heart risks, the Food and Drug Administration said on Friday.

title: Something to Celebrate in Baghdad
description: For the first time since the Iraq war started, Baghdad's Id festival went off without a hitch.

title: Sept. 11 Workers Agree to Settle Health Lawsuits
description: After a wrenching seven-year battle, more than 10,000 workers who sued New York City over health damages they claimed after the 9/11 recovery efforts have approved a settlement, clearing the way for payouts totaling at least $625 million, lawyers said Friday.

title: Wells Fargo Pays Citi $100 Million for Wachovia Claims
description: Nearly two years after Citigroup was outfoxed for the troubled Wachovia Corporation, Citi is walking away with an unexpected prize: a $100 million check from Wells Fargo to resolve claims that it had unfairly wrestled Wachovia out of Citis hands.

title: Buy American? Upscale Investors Look Abroad
description: Well-heeled American investors have been doing something lately that they resisted for decades  becoming more like their European, Asian and Latin American counterparts and substantially diversifying their portfolios outside their home country.

title: In Line at the Movies, Hoping for Good Enough
description: WHO goes to the movies? And why?

title: Audi Hedges on New Models
description: LOS ANGELES  Audi buffs must have been buoyed by a story in Automotive News last week, in which company officials said that Audi would bring the next generation of its new small coupe, the A1, to the United States, along with a diesel variant for every model. Its volume seller, the A4, is likely to receive a four-cylinder diesel engine by 2015, an official was quoted as saying.

title: Panel Named to Weigh Waiver for Schools Chief Appointee
description: The states education commissioner, David M. Steiner, on Friday named the panel of experts he has asked to consider whether Cathleen P. Black, the media executive chosen by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, to be the citys next schools chancellor, should be granted a waiver.

title: No Security Pat-Downs for Boehner
description: 3:37 p.m. | Updated Representative John A. Boehner, soon to be the Speaker of the House, has pledged to fly commercial airlines back to his home district in Ohio. But that does not mean that he will be subjected to the hassles of ordinary passengers, including the controversial security pat-downs.

title: Book Review Podcast: Keith Richards
description: This week: A conversation with Keith Richards about the Rolling Stones and his new memoir, Life; the composer John Adams reviews a new biography of John Cage; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: S.E.C. Readies Hedge Fund Rules
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed regulations on Friday that would require the registration of hedge funds and other private funds, the first such move regarding the private asset pools since the passage of the Dodd-Frank Act on financial regulation.

title: The Night of the Living Lawmakers
description: The left-leaning Center for American Progress has published a survey identifying those it terms climate zombies  people who question the science of global warming  who will be stalking the halls of Congress come January.

title: Peace, and Rides, During Id al-Adha
description: Its Id al-Adha, one of the biggest festivals of the Muslim year, and the holiday has started in earnest. This is Zawraa Park, which lies between the monuments of the Green Zone on one side, and the skyline of central Baghdad on the other.

description: YouTube: You peeling chestnuts for the stuffing this year?  Sam Sifton

title: 2011 Chrysler 200: A New and Improved Sebring

title: Judge Schedules Court Hearing in Cabbies Case
description: Updated, 5:58 p.m. | An appeals judge threw out part of a lower court order on Friday that would have blocked administrative hearings against cabbies accused of overcharging passengers based on GPS data from their taxis.

title: Its the Relationships, Stupid
description: THE director Edward Zwick has faced many challenges in his career. For his Civil War drama, Glory, he built an entire fort on a Savannah, Ga., beach and then laid siege to it. While shooting his domestic terrorism thriller, The Siege, he shut down the Brooklyn Bridge for an entire day. But these pale, perhaps, before the latest challenge he has set for himself: persuading men to shell out for a romantic comedy. Thats what people are calling Love and Other Drugs, even if the label is a loose fit. Adapted from Jamie Reidys best-selling memoir about the Viagra gold rush in the late 1990s, it stars Jake Gyllenhaal as a womanizing pharmaceutical representative who falls in lust, and then in love, with a beautiful young woman (Anne Hathaway) with Stage 1 Parkinsons disease. It would be a plunge deep into disease-of-the-week territory, if not for the raunch  sex scenes, sex tapes, nudity, an orgy  that Mr. Zwick has seasoned the film with and that may leave some in the audience wondering whether they are watching a film about Viagra, or on Viagra.

title: 2011 Saab 9-4X: The Cadillac of Saabs
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2011 Saab 9-4X

title: Viewpoints: Bernankes Only Choice?
description: The Federal Reserves plan to inject more than $600 billion into Treasury securities  otherwise known as Quantitative Easing Part Two, or Q.E.2  is an unconventional effort to stimulate the American economy.

title: Viewpoints: Bernanke's Only Choice?
description: Is the Federal Reserve using monetary policy to replace fiscal policy with its plan to pump $600 billion into securities? Columnist Joe Nocera and blogger Felix Salmon discuss the plan's merits.

title: A Collector Bets on the Dark Side
description: IT wouldnt be hard to look back on the turn-of-the-millennium art boom and think, for lack of a more articulate and reasoned term, Shiny!

title: Whats Your Take on Brunch?
description: Friday mornings newspaper brought a highlight reel of some recent Hey, Mr. Critic columns Ive written for Diners Journal, including a little rant about brunch, which I abhor as a concept and a reality. I eat an early breakfast, a midday lunch and dinner whenever I can get a reservation to do so, which is most nights, some time between 5 p.m. and 10 p.m.

description: The outstanding matchups around the world this weekend:

title: Michigan Senator to Head Agriculture Committee
description: Senator Kent Conrad has decided to remain chairman of the Budget Committee in the next Congress, a move which clears the way for Senator Debbie Stabenow to claim the top spot on the Agriculture Committee.

title: Its Overlords vs. Lower Depths in a Future City
description: OVER the years Ive seen Fritz Langs Metropolis countless times in various states of ruin and restoration, and for the most part found it hard to disagree with the conventional wisdom: beautiful images, trivial plot, nave politics.

title: In New Interview, Winfrey and Franzen Trade Hatchets for Hugs
description: Two titans of literature, each with the power to move books by the thousands, settled any remaining differences on Friday as Jonathan Franzen taped a much anticipated appearance on The Oprah Winfrey Show.

title: Sharpton and Kelly Are as One Against Guns
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton, once known as one of the Police Departments most dependable critics, joined Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly at 1 Police Plaza this morning to announce a Dec. 18 gun buyback and an ongoing program, financed by the Police Foundation, to pay people for information leading to an arrest on gun-possession charges.

title: Regulating Artisan Cheesemakers
description: By applying standards used in industrial-style food plants, advocates of small farmers and artisan producers say the Food and Drug Administration may quash small, innovative food makers.

title: Mazda Shinari Concept: Best in Flow
description: Introduced on Wednesday: Mazda Shinari

title: Water World
description: At the governments request, the tribes that populate the remote Indonesian island of Sumba stopped hunting heads in the 1950s. Or at least that was what was supposed to happen. In reality, a head was lopped off in an intratribal war as recently as last March. We had to stop sending people on trips to the waterfall for months until things settled down, says Claude Graves, one of three Westerners living permanently on the island. Graves and his wife have spent the last 20 years building Nihiwatu, the most exclusive and lavish surf destination in the world. The hideaway resort draws ultrarich, ber-athletic adventurers, who come to test themselves against a legendary wave and to be surrounded by one of the last Stone Age cultures on Earth.

title: On the Street | A Fall Staple
description: The jacket was back in force during last week's mild weather, proving yet again that it is the wearers who are the final arbiters of style, not the designers.

title: Italy Learns the Price of Rocking With Elton
description: LONDON  Each year thousands of projects get financing from the European Union, which lavishes billions of euros on its less prosperous regions. The bloc finally drew the line Friday, asking for a refund of money used to pick up the tab for an Elton John concert.

title: Coming to Grips, in a Queens Basement
description: Every Thursday night, for more than 20 years, the best arm-wrestlers in the New York area have gathered in a small room at a house in Queens, N.Y., for some serious hand-to-hand combat.

description: MONTESANO, Wash.  The foodies raved. The feds raided.

title: As Cheesemaking Blooms, So Can Listeria
description: Listeria can pose special challenges for artisan cheesemakers. Many make their cheese right on the farm, where the bad bacteria are right outside the cheese room door. And small producers often lack the safety training and resources available at bigger companies.

title: With Her, Its Love at First Sound
description: When last heard from on a Broadway stage, in the blissful 2008 revival of South Pacific, Kelli OHara exultantly and repeatedly told the world, Im in love with a wonderful guy. This weekend at City Center, in the somewhat-less-blissful Encores! concert production of Bells Are Ringing, Ms. OHara proclaims in her opening number, Im in love with a voice. Having heard both these declarations, I can now say with confidence that if Ms. OHara chose to sing that she had fallen in love with a desiccated turnip, I would believe her unconditionally.

title: Shopping Regionally in Rome
description: Rome is hardly food heaven; a travel agent I was directed to, for example, was next door to the Burger King. There are sandwiches that are worse than any you see this side of a 7-11. Ninety percent of the pizza looks as if someone came to New York, walked through Times Square, and said, Well make pizza like that, because obviously the Americans prefer it.

title: Have Large Canvases; Must Move Someday
description: John Ransom Phillips, a painter, had outgrown his place in TriBeCa. But his search for a larger home and studio took close to 10 years.

description: Shown on Wednesday: Kia POP concept

title: Space Wanted for Living and Painting
description: FOR a decade, John Ransom Phillips knew he needed a new home. Mr. Phillips, a painter, was slowly outgrowing his place, the top two floors of a building on Warren Street in TriBeCa.

title: Are VATs Too European?
description: As Paul Krugman wrote yesterday on his Times blog, the prospective House majority leader, Eric Cantor, has rejected the idea of a value-added tax because it sounds too European. According to The Wall Street Journal:

title: Maker of Dummy Bombs Is Quiet About Business
description: Since 1988, deep in the pocket of Californias old gold-mining country, Larry Copello has been laboring at what he loves: manufacturing devices that resemble bombs, that are used to test the alertness of security personnel around the world.

title: Habitats | Upper West Side
description: Lee Rolontz and Ernie Fritz live with their daughters in a Classic 6, renovated so as to become an unClassic 7.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Cher, Fran Lebowitz and More
description: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

title: A Gently Edited Classic, Pirate Included
description: OF all the types of apartments available in New York City, few are more iconic than the so-called Classic 6, the mazy configuration that includes two bedrooms, a dining room and a maids room, complete with its own bath. For decades, the Classic 6 was the ultimate symbol of gracious living, a vivid reminder of the style in which many well-heeled New Yorkers lived generations ago.

title: Now Online | T Winter Travel 2010
description: Ts winter travel edition begins with a fairy tale, by way of a cover shoot in the snowy Swedish countryside. Then its off to another kind of winter wonderland: the high-rolling peaks of Courchevel (wheres there as much ice on the skiers as on the slopes). Ready for a thaw? Theres serious surfing on Sumba Island, home to some of the worlds best breaks and the ultimate eco-resort. For more beach time, we drop in on St. Lucia before heading to Rio, where the art scene is heating up. Its a season of pilgrimages, too: In the temples of Tamil Nadu, India, Guy Trebay partakes in bathing rituals that give a whole new meaning to taking the waters. In Taipei, the designer Jason Wu goes home looking for inspiration for his next collection. And in Los Angeles, Frank Bruni eats his way through what has become Americas great food city. Wash it all down with the artisanal cocktails of Sydney, then sleep it off at the latest slumber spas. Plus: check into the hottest new hotels, from Buenos Aires to Bangkok.

title: Weekend Fare
description: A class in Indian street food will take place on Sunday at the James Beard Foundation, 167 West 12th Street. Rati Lohti, an Indian street-food expert, will demonstrate how to make everything from chicken kathi rolls to mango lassi. The workshop is $60 for members and $75 for non-members. Call (212) 627-2308 to reserve.

title: A Powerful Lineage
description: To the Editor:

title: The Harry Potter Alliance
description: Hours before the midnight premiere of the new Harry Potter film, fans met in New York's Columbus Circle to stage a flash mob duel but for The Harry Potter Alliance, the message goes beyond fantasy.

title: Five Ways to Love Lentils
description: Chefs, food writers and nutritionists often sing the praises of lentils. But for those of us who didnt grow up eating lentils, cooking with the small, flat seeds can seem like a challenge.

description: Images from the exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Living Around | Tompkins Square Park
description: Fans of the Tompkins Square Park area in the East Village say one of the best things about it is the broad spectrum of residents it accommodates.

title: Grit, Glam and Green, in One Vibrant Package
description: NISHA KEWALRAMANI, 34, moved with her parents to the East Side of Manhattan when she was 8 months old, and has enjoyed jumping around the city, exploring different neighborhoods, ever since. Since March, though, she has found herself roaming less. Its not that shes tired of New York. On the contrary, she said recently, its that after a lifetime, she has finally settled in a neighborhood she does not want to leave.

title: When the Critic Says an Art Form Is Dying
description: Is Ballet Over? Thats the question that greeted readers of The New Republic in an article adapted from the epilogue of Apollos Angels, a history of classical ballet by Jennifer Homans that was published this month. Ms. Homans, the dance critic for The New Republic, a scholar at New York University and a former professional ballet dancer, is profiled in the Arts & Leisure section on Sunday.

title: Cathie Black, Now Seen on The Apprentice
description: The remaining contestants had endured the usual round of criticism that punctuates every episode of NBCs The Apprentice when Donald J. Trump, the shows boardroom master, announced the prize reserved for the leader of the nights winning team:

description: To the Editor:
