description: Photographs from Haiti, Portugal, Washington and Rome.

title: After Record Win, John Force Racing Loses Crew Chief
description: John Force, the legendary drag racer, won his 15th Funny Car championship on Sunday at the season-ending race in Pomona, Calif. At 61, Force is the oldest national champion in the history of the National Hot Rod Association. On Tuesday, his teams crew chief of 26 years, Austin Coil, unexpectedly resigned.

title: Is the Market for Muscle Toning Up?
description: PRICES of vintage American muscle cars peaked, along with real estate values, in early 2008 or late 2007  the year when a 1971 Plymouth Hemi Cuda convertible sold for an astounding $2.4 million at auction.

title: Honoring the Surfer Andy Irons With a Paddle-Out
description: ITS not uncommon for the number of surfers near the Huntington Beach Pier in Southern California to reach triple digits. But last Sunday, the headcount swelled to more than 500. The surfers were not jockeying for waves, though. They were bobbing on boards in the open water, holding hands in a large circle.

title: High-Rises Cede Rental Ground to Brownstones
description: IT is not a sentiment commonly associated with New York City landlords, but for Malcolm Smart, some things are more important than money.

title: Weekly Pick Em: Plenty to Play For
description: While Oregon, Auburn, Texas Christian and Boise State are firmly entrenched in the race for the national championship, there are a multitude of teams with one, two or three losses that still have plenty to play for. Ohio State has just one blemish on its record  a loss to Wisconsin  but it still has its eye on the Big Ten title and a Rose Bowl berth. The Buckeyes will need to win out, starting Saturday at Iowa, and get some help from the Badgers, but the goal is still a realistic one. Virginia Tech  which began the season with two losses, including an embarrassing defeat at the hands of James Madison  has won eight in a row and has its sights set on the A.C.C. title. Miami would love to give the Hokies their first conference loss. Nebraska is kicking itself for the egg it laid against Texas. If not for that, the Cornhuskers would be in the middle of the race for the national title. As it is, they will travel to College Station on Saturday to take on Texas A&M, which has won four in a row. Neither Arkansas nor Mississippi State is going to win the SEC, but both teams have enjoyed successful seasons. A win over the Razorbacks would get the Bulldogs to eight victories in their second year under Coach Dan Mullen. And, finally, there is Southern California, all but forgotten in the wake of the N.C.A.A. sanctions that followed the Reggie Bush mess. But Lane Kiffin has had the Trojans playing well of late. Now they will try to win at Oregon State, whose season has been a disappointment.

title: A Week in Congress
description: While the newly elected members of Congress arrived in Washington this week for freshmen orientation, lawmakers of the 111th Congress began a lame-duck session, electing party leaders, attending meetings and voting on various pieces of legislation.

title: When Helping Your Child Hurts
description: Once every three or four months my son, Sam, grabs a cookie or a piece of candy and, wide-eyed, holds it inches from his mouth, ready to devour it. He knows hes not allowed to eat these things, but like any 9-year-old, he hopes that somehow, this once, my wife, Evelyn, or I will make an exception.

title: A Girlie Show
description: On Wednesday night a crowd of New York creative types, including Terry Richardson and Patrick Demarchelier, were privy to a sneak preview of 4 Sale, a collection of mostly photographic nudes by four Eastern European female artists who were the subject of one anothers photos, a project on which the photographers  Aneta Bartos, Elle Muliarchyk, Yana Toyber and Martynka Wawrzyniak  collaborated for a year. The four-day exhibition, curated by Anne Huntington, opens to the public Friday and runs through 6 p.m. Monday night at 8 Bond Street.

title: Milton Robson Cars on Auction
description: An auction in Gainesville, Ga., may have verified an upturn in muscle car prices.

title: One Highlight From the Life Of a Master
description: Thomas M. Smith, who died on Monday in his hometown of Bennington, Vt., at 72, was a great player and true gentleman.

title: A Long Road From Come by here to Kumbaya
description: Nearing 40 and nearly broke, ousted from his last job as an English professor, a folklore buff named Robert Winslow Gordon set out in the spring of 1926 from his temporary home on the Georgia seacoast, lugging a hand-cranked cylinder recorder and searching for songs in the nearby black hamlets.

title: In Canada, You Drive G.M., but Trade GMM
description: At a casual glance, it would appear that Canadian investors are far more pessimistic about General Motors new stock than their American counterparts.

title: Look of the Moment | Painted Lady
description: The Look: Garden variety  not your average floral print.

title: Ideas Almost Lighter Than Air
description: EACH year, the auto design studios of Southern California compete in the Design Challenge in conjunction with the Los Angeles auto show. Because the entries are digitally produced  no full-size or scale models required  participants can let their imaginations run free.

title: Week in Pictures, Nov. 19
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

title: Have Citron, Will Travel
description: IN 2003, two Frenchmen, Edouard Cortes and Jean-Baptiste Flichy, drove a 1977 Citron 2CV from Paris to Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon. They subsequently wrote a book about their 10,000-mile adventure across Europe and Asia, and in the epilogue they told readers they had left the car in Cambodia. If anyone wanted to bring it back to Paris, they added, they would gladly hand over the keys.

title: As Technology Deals Boom, the Talk Turns to Bubbles
description: Is the world ready for another Internet bubble?

title: F.C. Dallass Ferreira Named M.L.S. M.V.P.
description: TORONTO  David Ferreira, F.C. Dallass diminutive midfield maestro, became the second Colombian and fourth South American to win the Major League Soccer Most Valuable Player award on Friday.

title: Flea Enterprise
description: Now in its third installment, The Pop Up Flea, a temporary mens-wear market curated by Michael Williams, the founder of A Continuous Lean and friend of T, opens tonight at Openhouse Gallery, 201 Mulberry Street. The event, which runs through Sunday, is an assembly of some of our favorite (and often hard to find) mens labels. It also allows punters the opportunity to meet some of the names behind the brands, including Maurizio Donadi, head of Levis Vintage Clothing, and Alex Carleton, creative director for L.L. Bean Signature. And just in time for gift-shopping season, Stanley & Sons will occupy a booth with their signature work aprons and one-of-a-kind bags.

title: Yankees Pick Larry Rothschild as Pitching Coach
description: The Yankees filled their pitching coach vacancy on Friday, agreeing with Larry Rothschild on a three-year contract.

title: Casting Spells at Columbus Circle
description: Columbus Circle was the scene on Thursday night of a Harry Potter flash mob, created to mark the premiere of Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1.

title: Centerpiece Dishes Without the Turkey
description: The Thanksgiving table is often filled with vegetarian side dishes, but many home cooks also want to prepare a stunning vegetarian centerpiece dish for the holiday meal.

title: Dear S.E.C., Please Make Brokers Accountable to Customers
description: Dear Mary Schapiro:

title: Beyond Baba Ghanouj
description: With most shore-side clam shacks now shuttered for the season, one of Mystics better options for quick, wholesome eats is the Pita Spot. Billing itself as a Mediterranean grill, this restaurant offers a full menu of Middle Eastern foods, with a Lebanese accent.

title: 2010 Los Angeles Auto Show: The Bubbly Is Back
description: LOS ANGELES  A funny thing happened on the way to the debut of the all-new 2012 Volkswagen Eos at the Los Angeles Auto Show.

title: Dishes That Know How to Accessorize
description: IN more ways than one, my dinner and my lunch at Nicholas Roberts Gourmet Bistro in Norwalk were like night and day.

title: And Now for the Pie
description: One of the best parts of a traditional Thanksgiving dinner comes at the end  the pie  and one of the best traditional pie makers in the Hudson Valley comes from Croton-on-Hudson: Dave Tuttle.

title: Mark Twains Autobiography Flying Off the Shelves
description: When editors at the University of California Press pondered the possible demand for Autobiography of Mark Twain, a $35, four-pound, 500,000-word doorstopper of a memoir, they kept their expectations modest with a planned print run of 7,500 copies.

title: The Moments Holiday Gift Guide
description: The seasons first rule of giving  the more the merrier.

title: Holding Fast to a Vision of Fresh and Local
description: HENRY CABRAL, owner of Tarry Tavern, a winning new restaurant just a block down from the popular Tarrytown Music Hall, may finally have lucked out. Plagued by delayed openings and a rapid turnover of more and less successful chefs, Mr. Cabral has held fast to his vision for the restaurant and has most recently engaged Adam Strong, late of the Flying Pig, to help bring stability to the kitchen.

title: Recounting War
description: A Year at War

title: Taste Grape? Think Again
description: Some East End wineries, like their counterparts elsewhere, dont stop at grapes: They turn pears, apples, boysenberries and blueberries into beverages that easily find their place at the dinner table.

title: Modern Italian Fare, With Warmth
description: FOR more than 40 years, the building at 15 New Street in Huntington has been home to an Italian restaurant. For decades, it was Orlandos, a Huntington institution. The Iannucci family took over the premises 13 years ago, running Tellos and then Mangiamo there. The familys latest entry is Bel Posto, which opened in September.

title: Driver of School Bus Arrested After Accusations of Sex Abuse
description: The driver of a school bus has been arrested on charges that he sexually abused three elementary school students in Queens, the police and prosecutors said Friday.

title: The Old-School Style, Unafraid to Be Imperfect
description: The problem with the soul revival of the last few years has been precision, too much of it. The bass now has to sound like the bass then, except somehow more so. Same for the drums, the guitar, the keys, the vocals. Its an idealized take on the past, so much feckless mimicry.

title: Requiring Brokers to Put Their Customers First
description: In this weeks Your Money column, I wrote an open letter to Mary Schapiro, the chairwoman of Securities and Exchange Commission, on behalf of average investors.

title: Christies and China: An Artful Diplomacy
description: SHANGHAI  Two months ago, during Asian Art Week, Christies auction house invited hundreds of wealthy collectors, scholars and art patrons to its New York headquarters in Rockefeller Center for what it described as a special exhibition and symposium about the rise of Chinese contemporary art.

title: When the Pie Line Grows Long
description: Every Thanksgiving season has gotten progressively worse for Tod Wilson, the owner of Mr. Tods Pie Factory in Somerset. But by that I mean better, he added.

title: Deep in the Flavor Pool, Korean Style
description: FOR many Westerners, Korean dining takes a degree of effort. It requires familiarity with the range of Korean casseroles, stews and hot pots. A comfort level with ingredients like intestines, bones or fish heads, and flavors heavy on the red chili pepper, garlic, vinegar and onion. Not to mention a dry cleaner after sitting around a grill.

title: Setting the Bar Very High And Leaping Toward It
description: Julian Barnett sets the stakes high in the program notes for his new Super Natural, which opened at Dance New Amsterdam on Thursday night.

title: Incoming House Members Pick Their Offices
description: Most people take a few weeks to find a home or office. Freshman House members had a few hours.

title: Waves of Movement, Ever Flowing
description: As the fourth movement of a Brahms piano quintet begins, a man slides a woman along the floor. Theyre both seated, and he  propelling them with his knees, her wrapped across his back  is treading backward. This image of effort and dejection, a strange, dreamlike response to the music, at once lodges in the head.

title: From Bucks: The More Convenient Gift Card
description: From Jennifer Saranow Schultz, our colleague over at the Bucks personal-finance blog:Its easy to forget to bring a gift card when you go shopping, and its simple, too, to lose track of gift cards received during holidays past.

title: Pairing Wolfgangs From Two Eras
description: Many prominent musicians dutifully commission the occasional new piece, but the German violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter genuinely seems to relish the challenge. She has commissioned and championed works from composers including Krzysztof Penderecki, Sofia Gubaidulina and Andr Previn.

title: Spains R-Rated Election Campaign
description: Updated | Saturday | 10:21 a.m. Apparently desperate to pique the interest of young voters ahead of local elections in Catalonia scheduled for later this month, political parties in the Spanish region are engaged in what is starting to seem like a race to see which of them can get their entire campaign banned for excessive use of sex, violence or porn film soundtracks.

title: Big Companies Hiring, Small Companies Arent, Gallup Finds
description: Despite the usual trope that small businesses are the engines of job growth, larger companies actually seem to be doing the most hiring these days, according to new Gallup survey data.

title: Sunday Preview
description: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

title: Now Showing | Ann Agee
description: Ann Agee: Rules of the Pattern, at the Locks Gallery in Philadelphia until Dec. 30, offers a look at recent work by the artist, who is known for her playful, subversive treatment of traditional decorative porcelain archetypes, like blue-and-white patterns (which she has applied to ceramic sex toys, or an entire bathroom) or 18th century figurines (which she re-imagines in contemporary clothing, doing things like carrying shopping bags). In this show, Agee continues to give domesticity her own spin, in hand-painted and stenciled, large-scale wallpaper drawings that depict idealized interiors, and which allude to models as diverse as 19th century scenic wallpaper, Matisses The Dessert: Harmony in Red, and the spaces depicted in Roy Lichtensteins paintings. Along with a display of intricate white porcelain vases, the exhibition includes three works that are groups of hand-made porcelain platters and bowls arranged on a steel armature. Traditional pieces like this are decorated with floral patterns or pastoral scenes, but Agees depict modest domestic interiors, including everyday items like washing machines and stoves.

title: 'Tiny Furniture' by Lena Dunham
description: A new indie film by Lena Dunham features her mother, the famous artist, Laurie Simmons.

title: South Africa Fears Millions More H.I.V. Infections
description: DAVEYTON, South Africa  South Africa, already home to 5.7 million H.I.V.-positive people, more than any other nation, can expect an additional five million to become infected during the next two decades even if the nation more than doubles its already considerable financing for treatment and prevention and gives prevention a higher priority, according to a report presented here Friday to the countrys leading advisory body on AIDS policy.

title: Earbuds With a Mic That Sound About Right
description: If you listen to music on your phones MP3 player, you have to make a choice. Either choose headphones that sound good, or headphones with a microphone on them.

title: Monsoon
description: Chapter One: China Expands Vertically, India Horizontall

title: Bypass Planned for Leaky New York Aqueduct
description: New York City plans to build a three-mile-long tunnel to divert water from a leaking aqueduct that carries from the Catskills about half of the citys drinking water, officials announced on Friday.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 19
description: Images of cultural events from this week.

title: Satellite Radio Without the Clutter
description: Despite the crummy economy, 20 million people are still willing to plunk down between $7 and $17 per month to listen to satellite radio. Thats up from 18.5 million subscribers about one year ago, helped no doubt by an increased number of vehicles that leave the assembly line with satellite radio capability.

title: Coconut-Sweet Potato Pie
description: Mark Bittman makes a light, rich sweet potato pie with a slightly exotic crust.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 19
description: More Photographs

title: Toys for Boys, With an American Accent
description: At the beginning of each episode of Top Gear, History Channels adaptation of the popular British automotive show, the host Adam Ferrara lists things that the American version will not do. No makeovers, no cooking, no singing and dancing, no emotional journeys, no Snooki.

title: Apps to Amuse Children for Miles and Miles
description: I dont write much about childrens apps because I dont know anything about children, but after speaking to someone who had a rather extraordinary challenge keeping an infant entertained, I am going to pass along a recommendation.

title: A Rock n Roll Story Is Finally Told
description: CEDAR GROVE, N.J.

title: Chic In Review | Blake Lively, Bargain Hunter
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 19
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a Corduroy Appreciation Club meeting, men who sleep in trees, and a visit from the first lady.

title: Coconut-Sweet Potato Pie With Spiced Crust
description: Time: 1 hour 20 minutes

title: Sweet Potato Pie: Tradition, Plus
description: SWEET potato pie is a lovely concept, for a variety of reasons: it beautifully marries sweet and savory, it uses a vegetable as the foundation of a dessert, its color is stunning and its creamy and crisp all at once.

title: Getting Touchy at the Airport
description: Ah, Thanksgiving is almost upon us. We can look forward to a full belly, good wine, bad football and the worst travel day of the year. And in 2010, apparently, it will be the worst travel day in the history of mankind: In the three weeks since the Transportation Security Administration began more aggressive pat-downs of passengers at airport security checkpoints, traveler complaints have poured in, reports The Timess Susan Stellin. Some offer graphic accounts of genital contact, others tell of agents gawking or making inappropriate comments, and many express a general sense of powerlessness and humiliation It remains to be seen whether travelers approve of the pat-downs, especially as millions more people experience them for the first time during the holiday travel season.

title: Potatoes With Crunch, Without the Cabin
description: A FEW years ago, I accidentally made perfect roasted potatoes.

title: A Warning About Climate Change From a Departing Republican
description: An outgoing Republican congressman used a House science and environment subcommittee hearing this week as an opportunity to chide his party for its growing skepticism about the threat of global warming and to warn of missed economic opportunities in clean energy development if climate change is ignored.

title: Fearless Preschoolers Lack Empathy?
description: THE GIST Fearless children are more unfeeling.

title: Meditating on the Meaning of Main Street
description: Riverhead, N.Y.

title: Asked & Answered | Laurie Simmons
description: Tiny Furniture is Lena Dunhams breakout indie, a picture so promising that, after its debut at the South by Southwest film festival in March, it landed Dunham, 24, work on both an HBO series with Judd Apatow and a film project with Scott Rudin. Last week, Apatow was in the audience at the Museum of Modern Art for the premiere of Tiny Furniture, and during a question-and-answer session afterward, he asked something of Laurie Simmons, who is Dunhams mother, both in the movie and in real life. Will you raise my kids?

title: Keeping Up Tradition, Sugar Plums and All
description: DOUGLAS MARTIN, the new director of the American Repertory Ballet, is no stranger to detractors of The Nutcracker. People whove been dancing it their whole lives and have moved on to other things, or a new form of dance, will make a comment like, Oh, that old thing? he said.

title: The 800-Pound Mama Grizzly Problem
description: In last weeks blog post on Tim Pawlenty, we noted that Mr. Pawlentys Google search traffic  which may be a reasonably good proxy for how much interest the candidate generates among the public at large  somewhat lags behind that of several other potential Republican contenders, such as that of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey.

title: Urban Majestic
description: Unoccupied for a decade and largely unused, a Lower Manhattan building retains aspects of its grandeur.

title: Open Court
description: I SAID, We live so close, and we never hang out down here; we should be tourists for a day, she remembered later. I played right into his hands.

title: The New Club Kids
description: WHOEVER said New York night life is dead hasnt been out recently.

title: Israel to Get Security Guarantees in Return for Freeze
description: WASHINGTON  A week after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton worked out an agreement for a 90-day freeze on Israeli settlement construction, the deal remains hung up in Mr. Netanyahus Cabinet, with Israeli and American officials haggling over details like how generous a subsidy the United States will give Israel for 20 advanced fighter aircraft.

title: At Home, Jets Look for Noise and Hope to Roar
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Jets have won all five of their road games this year but are a plebeian 2-2 at New Meadowlands Stadium, where they will host Houston on Sunday.

title: For American Women, Its Win or Stay Home
description: The United States womens soccer team, recognized as a world powerhouse for at least the past 20 years, must win a home-and-home total-goals series against Italy to qualify for next summers Womens World Cup in Germany.

title: Recipes for Holiday Side Dishes
description: Roasted potatoes with figs and garlic, Brussels sprouts with bacon, and other dishes that may just upstage the main course.

title: As You Await Your Invitation...
description: KATE

title: Art That Can Depict a Starvation Diet
description: From prehistoric cave paintings of beef on the hoof to Renaissance canvases depicting the Last Supper to Andy Warhols picture of a Campbells soup can, food has inspired art. But the most striking images in Art and Appetite, a small, thought-provoking exhibition of prints and photographs at the Davison Art Center, on the campus of Wesleyan University in Middletown, are less about food than they are about its absence.

title: Fleeting Autumns, Captured on Canvas
description: Arriving at the Hudson River Museum on a golden afternoon about a week ago, I felt compelled to pull out my cellphone and take a picture. Right above my parked car, vivid scarlet branches were overlapped with chromium yellow ones, backed by a pure-blue sky; the colors seemed to insist on being noticed and recorded before the winter  or the next rainstorm  erased them.

title: With Grit and Polish, Sanchez Emerges as a Leader
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Teammates often describe Jets quarterback Mark Sanchez more like a male model than a model quarterback. Inevitably, they mention his wavy black hair, handsome face, famous girlfriends. Pretty boy, they call him.

title: Steve Israel to Lead Democrats Comeback Efforts
description: WASHINGTON  Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Friday named Representative Steve Israel of New York to lead the House Democratic campaign committee into the next election, putting him in charge of the partys effort to regain the majority it lost in November.

title: Adults Behaving Childishly
description: THEY seem like such lovely people. With their nice clothes and their art books and their careers in fields like corporate law and wealth management. But children will be children, and one couples son has had a playground altercation with the other couples son, and teeth were lost. So now the adults are getting together to work it all out, in a civilized manner, over espresso.

title: Thanksgiving: A Users Manual
description: A collection of videos and slide shows with recipes for the bird and everything else.

title: No Threats Here, Firms Tell the U.S.
description: Leading money managers and mutual funds have a message for Washington: We may be big  but we arent too big to fail.

title: Tales of a Changed City
description: LIFE, Richard Goodman writes, is a startling combination of the unexpected and the inconceivable. Every door we walk through introduces us to a strange land, and then we set about seeing if this is a place where we can grow. For me, New York City has been the great opened door.

title: In a Surprise, Fox Moves Idol to Thursdays
description: In a major shake-up of Foxs prime time schedule, American Idol will move to Wednesday and Thursday nights this winter.

title: Kathryn Bertine and George Varhola Jr.
description: KATHRYN BERTINE, an elite cyclist, had been chasing something most of her life. Her timing, it seems, had always been off.

title: Answering Your New York Questions
description: Honoring the Rialto

title: Your Worst Apartments
description: A selection of photos sent in by readers showing the compromises they had to make in their living quarters.

title: A Nontraditional Sweet Potato Pie
description: Sweet potato pie doesnt have to be a heavy affair housed in a cardboard crust. Skeptical? Check out this weeks Minimalist column. This version has coconut milk and a flavorful crust.

title: Merck Not at Fault in Fosamax Trial, Jurors Say
description: Merck on Friday won a signature jury trial against Judith Graves, a Florida woman who had sued the company and claimed that its osteoporosis drug, Fosamax, caused her jawbone to disintegrate.

title: Worm Can Deal Double Blow to Nuclear Program
description: The German software engineer who in September was the first to report that a computer worm was apparently designed to sabotage targets in Iran said Friday that the program contained two separate digital warheads.

title: Judy Tsang and Jeffrey Chow
description: Judy Siu Wai Tsang and Jeffrey James Chow were married Thursday at the Marriage Bureau in Manhattan. Blanca Martinez, an employee of the City Clerks office, officiated. On Friday, Deborah Chow, the bridegrooms sister, presided over an exchange of vows and a traditional Chinese tea ceremony at the Westin Jersey City Newport hotel in Jersey City.

title: Florice Engler, Joshua Pressman
description: Florice Ezor Engler, the daughter of Wendy Ezor Engler and Dr. Mitchell S. Engler of Teaneck, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Joshua Benjamin Pressman, a son of Shari L. Pressman and Ronald A. Pressman of Marblehead, Mass. Rabbi Kenneth E. Berger performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in Closter, N.J.

title: Meredith Bronfman, Jason Kaufman
description: Meredith Lillian Bronfman and Jason Kaufman were married Saturday evening in New York. Rabbi Arthur L. Schwartz officiated at the W Hotel in Union Square.

title: Ann Garment, Santosha Vardhana
description: Dr. Ann Rebecca Garment, the daughter of Suzanne Rose Garment and Leonard Garment of New York, was married Thursday to Santosha Adipudi Vardhana, the son of Rajyalakshmi and Vinaya Vardhana of Cherry Hill, N.J. Blanca Martinez of the City Clerks office officiated at the Municipal Marriage Bureau in New York.

title: Jon Summers and Kyle Murdoch
description: Jon Jay Summers and Kyle Philip Murdoch were married Saturday at the Universalist National Memorial Church in Washington. Marisa Demeo, an associate judge of the Superior Court of the District of Columbia, officiated.

title: Robyn Raber, Nathaniel Borgelt
description: Robyn Ann Raber, the daughter of Marie J. Raber and Roger W. Raber of Washington, was married Saturday to Nathaniel Wilson Franklin Borgelt, a son of Karen L. Borgelt and Dr. Bruce B. Borgelt of Hanover, Mass. The Rev. Joseph Flynn, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Catholic Church in Washington.

description: Sara A. Kaplan and Harrison A. Levy were married Saturday evening at the Doubletree Hotel in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Melvin N. Sirner officiated.

description: George Steven Fender and Judge John Karl Olson were married Saturday evening at the Harvard Faculty Club in Cambridge, Mass. Judge Michael G. Williamson of the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Middle District of Florida at Tampa officiated, after receiving permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

title: Emily Petkun, Michael Ast
description: Emily Laura Petkun and Dr. Michael Paul Ast were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Elliot J. Holin at the Ballroom at the Ben in Philadelphia.

title: Hannah Zelman and Matthew Gorski
description: Hannah Rebecca Zelman and Dr. Matthew Gabriel Gorski were married Saturday evening at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, N.Y. Rabbi Martin S. Cohen, the congregations leader, performed the ceremony, and Rabbi Myron Fenster  who married each of the couples parents  participated.

title: Sarah OBrien, Samuel Fraidin
description: Sarah Howes OBrien and Samuel Neil Fraidin were married Saturday evening at the 21 Club in New York. Matthew I. Fraidin, the bridegrooms brother, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Melissa Kurtz, James Anderson
description: Melissa Lauren Kurtz and James Christian Anderson were married Saturday evening at Highlawn Pavilion in West Orange, N.J. Adam Walker, a Spiritual Humanist minister, officiated.

title: Danna Grunwald, David Gelles
description: Danna Rina Grunwald and David Philip Gelles are to be married Sunday afternoon. Rabbi Neil S. Cooper is to perform the ceremony at Temple Beth Hillel-Beth El in Wynnewood, Pa.

title: Bridget Dorney, Hussam Chater
description: Bridget Kathleen Dorney and Hussam Chater were married Friday evening at the Clarks Landing Yacht Club in Point Pleasant, N.J. George Korbelak, a Roman Catholic deacon, officiated.

title: Samantha Fennell and Colin McGreal
description: Samantha Marie Fennell and Colin Patrick McGreal were married Saturday evening at the Stone Mill at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. The Rev. Joseph W. Tolton, a Pentecostal minister, officiated.

title: Dara Seidman, David Grossman
description: Dara Elizabeth Seidman, the daughter of Linda Seidman and Stuart A. Seidman of Ramsey, N.J., was married Saturday night in New York to David Benjamin Grossman, a son of Patti Grossman and Louis Grossman of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Todd A. Markley led the ceremony at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers.

title: Carrie Choi, John Ahn
description: Dr. Carrie Eunjung Choi and John Ahn were married Saturday at Riverside Church of New York. The Rev. Dr. Arnold Thomas, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony. The Rev. Danny Han, a senior pastor with Joy Christian Fellowship Church, took part.

title: Julie Guyot, Bitra Diangone
description: Julie Guyot and Bitra Diangone were married Saturday evening at their home in Washington. Judge Zinora Mitchell-Rankinof the Superior Court of the District of Columbia officiated.

title: Jessica Exelbert, Justin Rubin
description: Dr. Jessica Lynn Exelbert and Justin Steven Rubin are to be married Sunday evening at the Ritz-Carlton in Washington. Rabbi Lyle A. Fishman is to officiate, with Rabbi Dr. Barry S. Wimpfheimer participating.

title: Rachel Liebov, Aaron Miller
description: Rachel Liebov, a daughter of Amy Liebov and David Liebov of Brooklyn, is to be married Sunday to Aaron Scott Miller, the son of Dale Miller and Dr. Kenneth Miller of Waverly, Pa. Rabbi Alvin Kass is to officiate at Bridgewaters, an event space in Manhattan.

title: Brooke Lampley, Christopher Papagianis
description: Brooke Mallis Lampley, a daughter of Joanne Lampley Metcalf of London and Jim Lampley of Del Mar, Calif., was married in Nassau, the Bahamas, Saturday afternoon to Christopher Papagianis, the son of Cynthia F. Mire of Memphis and Chris Papagianis of St. Louis. Lester M. Cox, a Pentecostal minister, officiated at the One & Only Ocean Club.

title: An Orphan in Her Teens, Determined to Get an Education
description: Ernestine Grants mother, Ethel, adored Christmas. And so it was not surprising that one morning a week before the holiday she was heading out of her Brooklyn apartment in search of additional gifts. Ethel Grant got as far as the door before she cried out for her husband and crumpled to the floor. She had been stricken by a massive stroke. She lasted a week in the hospital. She died on her beloved Christmas Eve.

title: Mine Owners Flair Rankles Chilean Elite
description: CALDERA, Chile

title: Canada Using M.L.S. to Improve Its Play
description: TORONTO  After the referee blew the final whistle in the Soviet Unions 2-0 victory against Canada in the 1986 World Cup, Bruce Wilson, Canadas 35-year-old captain, kept his sweaty No. 3 jersey, eschewing the ceremonial postgame shirt swap with his opposite number.

title: Bomb Explodes Near Convoy of Iraqi Lawmakers, Killing a Guard
description: BAGHDAD  A roadside bomb exploded Friday morning beside a convoy carrying three members of Parliament in the northern city of Mosul. The lawmakers escaped without injury, but a bodyguard died in the attack, and two were wounded.

title: Helen Boehm, the Princess of Porcelain, Dies at 89
description: Helen Boehm, a self-made businesswoman known as the Princess of Porcelain for her companys elaborate sculptures, which have graced the coffee tables of royalty and heads of state for six decades, died on Monday at her home in West Palm Beach, Fla. She was 89.

title: Robin Day, Designer Whose Work Graces Waiting Rooms, Dies at 95
description: Robin Day, perhaps Britains most influential furniture designer since World War II, whose spare, practical and affordable inventions were exemplified by the now ubiquitous polyprop chair, died Nov. 9 at his home in Chichester, England. He was 95.

title: Patience at Notre Dame Despite a Trying Season
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  A year marred by bad luck and bookended by tragedies for the Notre Dame football team will, one way or another, come to a close in the coming weeks.

title: Haitians Plunge Into Muck to Stem Cholera
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Duquesne Fils-Aim, stripped to the waist, stepped gingerly into the canal, drawing stares of astonishment from the spectators above. When he ducked his head under the water  if one could call it that  an audible gasp rose from the crowd.

title: Chamomile Tea and Legal Briefs
description: Weekdays are so hectic for New York States chief judge, Jonathan Lippman, 65, that he rarely has time for reading the endless motions, briefs and memos that go with the job. So a big pile of paper goes with him whether he and his wife, Amy, also a lawyer, spend Sunday in their East Side apartment in Manhattan or their home in Rye Brook in Westchester County, where they raised their two children, now 34 and 31. WILLIAM GLABERSON

title: Cost and Goals at Center of Arms Treaty Debate
description: The standoff this week over ratification of a new arms control treaty centers on a simple phrase: nuclear modernization. Those two words conceal a little known, enormously ambitious plan to do nothing less than rebuild the nations atomic complex for the 21st century.

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: THE SETAI FIFTH AVENUE, between 36th and 37th Streets, is the latest in a string of large luxury hotels built during the recession to open in recent months. Its sprawling penthouses rent for a very nonrecessionary $15,000 a night (rates for the rest of the 157 rooms and 57 suites start at $545).

title: TV Channel Draws Viewers, and Threats, in Iran
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In little more than a year, the Persian-language satellite television channel beamed into Iran by Rupert Murdochs News Corporation and a prominent Afghan family has rapidly become one of the most popular stations in the country.

title: Ovechkin Ties Crosby, in DVDs Made
description: The season of Alex Ovechkin and Sidney Crosby is about to begin.

title: Incoming Speaker Takes Commercial Flight, but Skips the Pat-Down
description: WASHINGTON  Representative John A. Boehner, the soon-to-be Republican speaker, pledged recently that he would fly commercial airlines back home to Ohio, passing up the military plane used by the current speaker, Nancy Pelosi, a Democrat. But that does not mean he will endure the hassles of ordinary passengers, including pat-downs and other new security screenings.

title: No Boo-boos or Cowlicks? Only in School Pictures
description: Oliver Tracy showed up for his first-grade portrait with a crisp white shirt tucked into navy slacks, a striped tie slightly too long for his tiny frame, and not a lock of his sun-streaked blond hair out of place.

title: Below 14th, Center Stage
description: A gallery of 12 stylish New Yorkers on bikes, part of a project documenting all 200 streets in downtown Manhattan.

title: Rear Views, Downtown
description: ONE is wearing a couture gown, another just a pair of red underwear. One is lugging a huge bouquet of flowering rhododendrons on his shoulder, another a suckling pig. They are all riding bicycles in the middle of streets downtown, and they are all shown from behind, having passed by, headed toward some unknown destination  a party, a garden, a pig roast.

title: Green Strategies for the Poorest
description: On Tuesday I wrote about the LifeStraw Family, an in-home water purification device. The product itself is interesting, but what I wanted to highlight in the column is how its manufacturer, Vestergaard Frandsen, is planning to make money with it. Not from the poor families who use it  they will give it away in western Kenya. Instead, the company plans to be paid in credits they can sell on the global carbon markets. In this system, credits are awarded to projects that reduce greenhouse gas emissions. They may then be then bought by polluting companies or governments to offset their own emissions. LifeStraw Family users no longer have to boil their water to make it safe to drink. Less boiling means fewer emissions.

title: In Negotiation of Jeters Worth, Stock Is an Option
description: The haggling between Derek Jeter and the Yankees centers on what he should be paid for the next three, four or five years. What is a 36-year-old player worth coming off a subpar season?

title: Thai Police Find 2,000 Illegally Aborted Fetuses
description: BANGKOK  Two thousand fetuses from illegal abortion clinics have been found hidden at a Buddhist temple here, igniting calls for stricter abortion laws in a nation that is both socially conservative and sexually tolerant.

title: Like Black Friday, but Without the Fights
description: Black Friday, which in the retail industry refers to the day after Thanksgiving, has traditionally been the day that kicks off the holiday shopping season with big sales, store openings well before the first hint of daylight and the occasional fisticuffs over precious parking spots. But for some shoppers, a cheap cashmere sweater just does not justify taking an elbow to the rib at 6 a.m.

title: SEC Suspends Vols Coach for First 8 League Games
description: In what could be a harbinger for stiffer penalties for rules breakers in college sports, the Southeastern Conference announced Friday that the Tennessee mens basketball coach, Bruce Pearl, would be suspended for the first eight league games.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Comedy

title: Republicans Stymie Democrats on Top Measures
description: WASHINGTON  Empowered by their election gains, Congressional Republicans are giving little ground to President Obama and weakened Democrats in the final weeks of the 111th Congress, imperiling Democratic efforts to pass major tax and spending legislation, unemployment aid and a nuclear nonproliferation treaty among other issues.

title: The World This Week
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

title: Lawsuit Claims ATP Knew Stars Were Tied to Betting
description: In 2007, as the Association of Tennis Professionals began a crackdown on gambling and disciplined five lower-ranked Italian players for making bets on matches, it knew that gambling accounts were maintained in the names of some of its top-ranked players, who bet on matches, and did not follow up and discipline them, according to evidence revealed in a federal lawsuit.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Pat Burns Dies at 58; Won Stanley Cup With Devils
description: Pat Burns, a tough-minded, tight-lipped coach of four National Hockey League teams who led the New Jersey Devils to a Stanley Cup title in 2003, his first season with the team, died on Friday in Sherbrooke, Quebec. He was 58.

title: Naming of Alaska Winner Delayed
description: A federal judge in Alaska on Friday placed a conditional hold on the certification of the results of the contentious Senate race between Joe Miller and Senator Lisa Murkowski, telling the Miller campaign to take its legal challenges to state court.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Nevada Senators Parents Cleared in Election Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Election Commission on Friday dismissed a complaint charging that the parents of Senator John Ensign, Republican of Nevada, violated election law by paying $96,000 in 2008 to the family of the senators former mistress.

title: Yankees Make Cubs Pitching Coach Theirs
description: Larry Rothschild lives in Tampa, Fla., a mile or two from the Yankees complex. He can expect an easy commute now that he will be working there every day this spring.

title: Senate Approves Payment of Black Farmers Claims
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Friday approved $4.55 billion to settle longstanding charges that the federal government had denied or underpaid aid to black farmers and mismanaged trust funds for American Indians.

title: A New Look in Detroit for the Newly Public G.M.
description: DETROIT  It is out with the old and in with the new at General Motors as the federal governments ownership stake in the company was cut in half this week. Even the automakers sign atop its corporate headquarters has gotten a makeover.

title: For Judges, Lawyers and Fellow Jurors, the Challenges of Dealing With a Holdout
description: Two days before the jury at the embassy bombing trial of Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani would reach a verdict, it seemed to be on the verge of a deadlock.

title: Bloggingheads: Love Big Government?
description: Bill Scher, left, of the Campaign for America's Future and Melissa Clouthier of Liberty Pundits debate whether Americans want smaller government.

title: Damage Worse Than Thought in Qantas Blowout
description: WASHINGTON  The A380 superjumbo aircraft whose engine blew apart on departure from Singapore on Nov. 4 was far more seriously damaged than initial reports indicated, with hydraulic and electric failures and serious damage to the planes skeleton, according to independent experts who examined newly available photographs of the jet and leaked accounts of the investigation.

title: Indianapolis Honors Its Literary Native Son
description: INDIANAPOLIS  In Kurt Vonneguts novel Cats Cradle, the narrator meets a woman on a plane who is delighted to discover that he is from Indiana. Holding his arm tightly, she tells him, We Hoosiers got to stick together.

title: Unions Yield on Wage Scales to Preserve Jobs
description: MILWAUKEE  Organized labor appears to be losing an important battle in the Great Recession.

title: Lottery Numbers
Justice for Spill Victims, Like It or Not
description: A few days ago, I had breakfast with Kenneth R. Feinberg, the former pay czar and 9/11 fund administrator, who is now grappling with one of the most difficult assignments of his career: doling out as much as $20 billion of BPs cash to residents of the Gulf Coast who suffered as a result of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill.

title: Vatican Preparing New Guidelines to Deal With Sexual Abuse
description: VATICAN CITY  The Vatican announced on Friday that it was preparing a new set of guidelines to help bishops offer a coordinated and efficient response to sexual abuse, one that emphasizes protecting children, cooperating with civil authorities and careful selection of future priests.

title: New E-Mails Delay Ethics Trial of Lawmaker
description: WASHINGTON  A newly discovered exchange of e-mails led the House ethics committee on Friday to delay its trial of Representative Maxine Waters, a California Democrat accused of helping steer bailout money to a bank in which her husband owned shares.

title: Debt Rising, a City Seeks Donations in Michigan
description: DETROIT  A Michigan city is pleading with churches, schools and a hospital for donations to help cover its staggering budget deficit.

title: Agency Failed to Oversee Deadly Race
description: LOS ANGELES  The federal Bureau of Land Management failed to enforce its safety regulations for an off-road race where a truck rolled over spectators, killing eight people.

title: 2 Idle Towers May Test the Winds Power to Keep a Bit of Brooklyn Moving
description: About two years ago, Debra Salomon was on her way to the new Fairway market in Red Hook, Brooklyn, when she took a wrong turn and found herself on a windblown pier that had two 90-foot Eiffel-like towers rising into the sky for no apparent purpose.

title: Britain: Adviser Resigns After Remarks on Recession
description: Prime Minister David Cameron on Friday first reproved then effectively dismissed a prominent economic adviser who gave an interview in which he said the vast majority of people in Britain have never had it so good since this recession  this so-called recession  started. The remarks by Lord David Young, 78, a multimillionaire businessman, were in an interview published on Friday in The Daily Telegraph in which he discussed Britains effort to impose 20 percent across-the-board cuts in government spending, its biggest peacetime cuts ever. Lord Young said many Britons had gained from historically low mortgage rates, allowing them to spend more freely on other things, thus buoying the economy through the banking crisis.

title: Saturday: Grid Art
description: For the third and final day, we have a guest solver picked from our esteemed pool of Wordplay commenters. Its John Farmer, whos had 25 puzzles published in The New York Times. He also posts a new puzzle monthly on his Web site.

title: Hunting for Returns Abroad
description: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan reports on a growing trend among well-to-do American investors: a hunt for investment returns abroad that they cannot find at home in the wake of the financial crisis and the recession.

title: Panel on Pick for Schools Has Close Ties to Bloomberg
description: New York States top education official on Friday named an advisory panel of eight experts, at least half of them with strong connections to the Bloomberg administration, to help him decide whether to approve Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs controversial choice to run the citys school system.

title: The Next Mets Manager: A Handicappers Guide
description: In only a matter of days, if not hours, the Mets will make a decision about their next field manager. It has been a race that started with 10 entrants, with 4 of them then separating themselves from the pack. Most people think its now down to just two candidates, Terry Collins and Bob Melvin, and that they are heading for a photo finish.

title: As M.V.P. of the Lee Trade, Knicks Turiaf Adds a Spark
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  When the Knicks sent David Lee to the Golden State Warriors in July, they got back one potential star, one injured shooting ace and a big man known mostly for his wild energy and his wild beard.

title: Deportees Who Came Back Are Caught in Dragnet
description: In a four-day immigration dragnet stretching from the suburbs north of New York City to eastern Long Island, federal law-enforcement officers arrested 54 illegal immigrants with criminal records who had previously been deported but had secretly re-entered the country, officials said Friday.

title: New Zealand: Explosion Traps Coal Miners
description: At least two dozen men were trapped underground after an explosion on Friday rocked the countrys largest coal mine in a mountainous region on the South Island. The authorities said it was too early to determine a cause of the explosion at the collapsed mine, operated by the Pike River Coal company near the town of Atarau. Before entering the mine, rescue teams were trying to make sure that vents were clear and that gas would not build up inside. Pike River Coal officials said the trapped miners had breathing devices that would last for 30 minutes and that were intended to provide time to get to a longer-lasting source of oxygen.

title: Madagascar: Army Chief Holds Talks With Dissident Officers
description: The army chief of staff, Andre Ndriarijoana, held talks on Friday with dissident military officers who had tried to take over the government earlier in the week but are now holed up in their barracks. No resolution was announced. In the morning, the government had ordered civilians to evacuate the area near the barracks for their own safety. The island nations current president, Andry Rajoelina, was placed in power after a coup in March 2009, and there have since been a handful of efforts to oust him.

title: The Southwest Way
description: No longer a start-up, Southwest seeks to balance growth and traditions as it approaches its 40th anniversary.

title: Chess in the Playground
description: To the Editor:

title: A False Target in Yemen
description: Cairo

title: Opt-Out Illusion
description: Texas and several other states are flirting with the idea of dropping out of the Medicaid program and trying to shift most of the burden of providing health insurance for the poor to the federal government.

title: How I Stopped Smoking
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Airport, Security vs. Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Lets Rescue the Race Debate
description: There is another class of colored people who make a business of keeping the troubles, the wrongs, and the hardships of the Negro race before the public. ... Some of these people do not want the Negro to lose his grievances, because they do not want to lose their jobs ... There is a certain class of race-problem solvers who dont want the patient to get well.

title: Hiding From Reality
description: However you want to define the American dream, there is not much of it thats left anymore.

title: Terror Verdict: Did the Civilian Court Pass the Test?
description: To the Editor:

title: Lesson in Hero Dogs Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Paterson and the (Latest) Casino
description: Gov. David Paterson of New York has only a few weeks left in office. But that hasnt stopped him from making a bad deal with an out-of-state Indian tribe to build a casino in the Catskills.

title: The Zombie Jamboree
description: Zombies are in. This cannot possibly be a good sign.

title: Honoring Liu Xiaobo
description: Chinas autocrats have tried pretty much everything they can think of to stop the world from celebrating the courage of Liu Xiaobo, the imprisoned democracy activist. It tried to bully the Nobel committee into not awarding Mr. Liu this years Nobel Peace Prize. When the committee went ahead, China confined Mr. Lius wife to her home, barred others from attending the ceremony, and warned governments not to go.

title: Roadblock for Arms Treaty
description: To the Editor:

title: The Uproar Over Pat-Downs
description: Americans understand the need for security screenings at airports and are remarkably patient. So there is no excuse for the bumbling, arrogant way the Transportation Security Administration has handled questions and complaints about its new body-scanning machines and more aggressive pat-downs.

title: Subway Signal Inspections Found to Be Falsified
description: Safety workers at New York City Transit falsified thousands of inspections of the track signals that direct trains in the subway system, deeming the signals safe even though those inspections had never taken place, according to an investigation by the inspector general of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Before Moving On, Minaya Would Talk With Alderson
description: Omar Minaya has had several offers since he was let go by the Mets on Oct. 4. But before joining another team he plans to meet with Sandy Alderson, his replacement as the teams general manager, about the possibility of returning to the Mets.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,383 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

title: Very Busy Next Few Days
description: Posting will be intermittent at best.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: William Self, Television Producer, Dies at 89
description: William Self, a prolific producer who brought a long list of successful shows to television  Daniel Boone, Peyton Place, Batman and M*A*S*H among them  transforming 20th Century-Fox Television into a leading supplier of programming to the networks in the 1960s and 70s, died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 89.

title: Photo Replay: Nov.19
description: A look at the day in sports with championships in China, Spain and Madison, Wisc.

title: Knicks Prevail in a Shootout With the Warriors
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  The pace was frantic, the scoring incessant, the defense nonexistent. The shots flew and the scoreboard whirred, stopping only briefly when the ball became stuck on top of the shot clock. Even that was entertaining.

title: The Neediest Cases | Veronica Harris
description: Veronica Harris fell behind on her rent because she lost her job. The Neediest Cases Fund helped her pay off her arrears.

title: NATO Sees Long-Term Role After Afghan Combat
description: LISBON  NATO and Afghanistan agreed Saturday to the goal of a phased transfer of security responsibility to the Afghan government by the end of 2014, but NATO officials acknowledged that allied forces would remain in Afghanistan, at least in a support role, well beyond that date.

title: The Weekend Word: Pushing for a New Start
description: From Todays Times:

title: Classic Ad: General Motors, the Day After
description: Two cars race across an arid plain, hurling clouds of desert dust. A Casio keyboard goes silent as in tandem the drivers shift to neutral. The older car slows, then crawls to a stop; its driver emerges, still helmeted, and watches the newer model glide into the ashen distance.

title: Playing on Thanksgiving, and Skipping the Turkey
description: Thanksgiving is one of my favorite holidays. Most families enjoy turkey, stuffing, mashed potatoes and the works. But my favorite part is all of the sides, like green bean casserole, broccoli casserole, collard greens and my moms famous chocolate chip cookies.

title: How Yankee Stadium Got Ready for Football
description: So what will football in the new Yankee Stadium look like when Army and Notre Dame take the field tonight? The Fighting Irish and the Black Knights will be moving the ball from home plate to center field and back.

title: Ride, Bernanke, Ride
description: In a speech Friday, Ben Bernanke asked for some help in the form of expansionary fiscal policy:

title: Pope Elevates Cardinals in Festive Ceremony
description: ROME  Pope Benedict XVI elevated 24 new cardinals in a festive ceremony in St. Peters Basilica on Saturday, bestowing quadrangular red hats on the new members of a group that will one day elect his successor.

title: A Forecast That Obama Could Love
description: THINGS are looking up for Barack Obama.

title: Lottery Deal Bid Process Is Attacked
description: Citing performance problems and a perceived conflict of interest, critics blasted a decision announced Friday by the Texas Lottery Commission to renew a 10-year operations contract with the Gtech Corporation, the primary vendor for the states lottery since its 1992 inception.

title: The Pain of Change at Boeing
description: ONCE upon a time, major American companies and their employees treated each other as family. The companies provided job security and lifelong benefits; in general, workers were loyal and engaged in their jobs, the occasional strike notwithstanding.

title: Acrostic Made in a Blender
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Second Sunday puzzles dont get enough respect, or at least enough attention. Acrostics, in particular, deserve a wider audience. Many regular crossword solvers I know regularly cross over to the next page when the Second Sunday puzzle appears. Maybe this incentive will help: the skills you hone on these puzzles will make you a better solver on the straight puzzles too. I know, Im not talking about you or that throng whose biggest regret in life is that acrostics arrive but once a fortnight, but if you have a friend who could benefit from some congenial prodding, this is a good one to try. For one thing, its all about food, and you dont have to be an EPICURE or a legendary chef like ESCOFFIER to appreciate that. Be sure to remind your friend that the puzzle is way easier if you do it on the computer.

title: A Hint for the Final Passage
description: For the first time, Jim Sanborn, the creator of Kryptos, releases clues for the final section of the 865-character coded message in the sculpture.

title: When Unemployment Hits, and Lingers
description: Joblessness in New York is not a recent phenomenon. Since the Sept. 11 terror attacks, the city has been shedding jobs. But as recently as two years ago, the citys jobless rate was 5.8 percent; it is now 9.3 percent, down from 10.6 percent in January.

title: Zambia Uneasily Balances Chinese Investment and Workers Resentment
description: NKANDABBWE, Zambia  Hundreds of angry coal miners pushed toward the locked gate at Shaft 3, shouting and cursing as they neared the mines Chinese managers, who understood neither the English nor the Tonga words of the mob. As the workers butted up against the fence, the bosses grew more fearful and finally two fired their shotguns.

title: Trying to Put a Price on Bank Errors
description: KUDOS to the Congressional Oversight Panel for publishing a thoughtful and thorough report last week on the mortgage documentation mess. It argued that, yes, in fact, these paperwork problems may have significant implications for banks, investors and the stability of the financial system.

title: For an Online Marketplace, Its Better Late Than Never
description: BACK in the deranged days of dot-com mania, a company called Ariba could do no wrong.

title: Notepads That Keep You on the Same Page
description: THREE-BY-FIVE index cards, those hallmarks of research, may be fading away in these digital times, but the need to take notes endures.

title: Irish Prime Minister Says Budget Plans Are Already in Place
description: ARRANMORE ISLAND  As Irish and European officials engaged in tense talks over the weekend on terms of a multibillion dollar rescue package, Irelands Prime Minister Brian Cowen asserted that the countrys low corporate tax rate and four-year plan to reduce the budget would not be substantially changed.

title: Can QVC Translate Its Pitch Online?
description: WEST CHESTER, Pa.

title: Can You Handle the 100-Day To-Do List?
description: This interview with Geoff Vuleta, C.E.O. of Fahrenheit 212, an innovation consulting firm in Manhattan, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: The Blur Between Spending and Taxes
description: SHOULD the government cut spending or raise taxes to deal with its long-term fiscal imbalance? As President Obamas deficit commission rolls out its final report in the coming weeks, this issue will most likely divide the political right and left. But, in many ways, the question is the wrong one. The distinction between spending and taxation is often murky and sometimes meaningless.

title: Letters: Standards in Neuromarketing
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters: The Promise of Microlending
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Open Doors to Holiday Jobs
description: Q.  You would like to find temporary work over the holidays. Where should you look?

title: Leading From an Early Age
description: MY parents divorced when I was a toddler and too young to remember us living together. Alternating between them actually created dual privileges for me.

title: Pushing 40, Southwest Is Still Playing the Rebel
description: Dallas

title: Fast Times at Woodside High
description: A shift is taking place at the intersection of education and technology.

title: Happily Adding to a Rsum of Eclectic Jobs
description: When the rest of us go to bed, Veronica Harris goes to work.

title: For Musial, a Birthday and a Medal
description: Happy birthday, Stan Musial.

title: A Stack of Bills, and No Paycheck or Savings
description: For Carol Ann Fuoco, 58, things are not the way they used to be.

title: After a Landlord Dispute, Finding a New Home
description: Last June, Zaida Paris-Mendez was at the beauty salon when a neighbor called to tell her that people were moving things out of her apartment.

title: In N.F.L., Expecting More Surprise Onside Kicks
description: New Orleans Saints Coach Sean Payton called for an onside kick to open the second half of the Super Bowl in February. It caught the Indianapolis Colts off guard, changed the momentum of the game and stunned the football world.

title: Students and Technology, Constant Companions
description: Students from Woodside High discuss their relationship to technology.

title: Fear of Failure, and Mother, Motivated Falcons Star Receiver
description: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga.  Five games into the 2006 season, Joenethia White answered the phone at her home in James Island, S.C., and heard the shamed voice of her son, Roddy.

title: Nascar Has the Finish, if Not the TV Viewers
description: Trash talk, some petulant whining and a points race unlike anything Nascar has seen in years has given the sport exactly what it desperately needs heading into the final race of the 2010 season. There will be drama on Sunday at Homestead-Miami Speedway, with three drivers in contention for the championship and a realistic chance for somebody other than Jimmie Johnson to win the Chase for the Sprint Cup title.

title: Umenyiora Resumes a Dominant Role
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The boldest statement that Giants defensive end Osi Umenyiora has made all season can be read on the towel that hangs from his waistband at practices: Greatness.

title: Father of Texans Cushing Stands Fast in Sons Defense
description: Brian Cushing will play football Sunday at the Meadowlands, and his parents, Frank and Antoinette, plan to drive 20 minutes or so from their home in Park Ridge, N.J., to watch. They will sit with relatives of one of Cushings college teammates, Mark Sanchez.

title: Study Suggests a Cholesterol Pill Benefits Kidney Patients
description: Patients with chronic kidney disease who took Vytorin, a cholesterol-lowering pill, had one-sixth fewer heart attacks, strokes or operations to unblock their arteries than patients taking a placebo, according to the results of a new study presented on Saturday.

title: Original Decoding Charts for Kryptos
description: Kryptos, a sculpture on the grounds of the Central Intelligence Agency, has a secret code embedded in the letters that are punched into its four panels of curving copper. As the accompanying article points out, only three of its four messages have been deciphered.

title: T.S.A. Grants Airline Pilots an Exception to Screenings
description: WASHINGTON  At least one group of air travelers will get a break from the body scans and pat-downs that have provoked a national outcry.

title: Two Illinois Teams, but Wrigley Takes Sides
description: CHICAGO  The streets around Wrigley Field began to fill up Saturday afternoon with fans clad in Northwestern purple and Illinois orange. Inside, orange yardage markers were laid along the sidelines closest to the first-base line and deep into the right-field corner, where pads had been hung on the wall.

title: Clues to Stubborn Secret in C.I.A.s Backyard
description: It is perhaps one of the C.I.A.s most mischievous secrets.

title: In Wake of Losses, New Powers for a Political Master
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional Democrats engineered a leadership change in response to the election devastation, but the shakeup did not come in the House, where Nancy Pelosi held on to power in her caucus despite having lost more than 60 seats, the Democratic majority and the speakers gavel.

title: Fighting Words
description: The House ethics committee recommended last week that Representative Charles B. Rangel be formally censured for ethical misconduct.

title: Laugh Lines
description: JAY LENO

title: A History of Dealing With Footballs Dangers
description: Months before the 1910 football season, a major series of rule changes defined the modern game. They established 15-minute quarters and allowed for substitutions. To address violence, they banned pushing and pulling, and the flying, or diving, tackle. To eliminate the deadly mass plays that hid brutalities from view, like rugby-type scrums that pushed the ball carrier forward, the rules required seven men on the line of scrimmage.

title: Chuck Bednariks Hit on Frank Gifford Still Echoes
description: Its an anniversary that Frank Gifford does not celebrate. Fifty years ago this weekend, as the Giants All-Pro running back, he lay crumpled at Yankee Stadium after having fumbled away a pass reception when blindsided by Eagles linebacker Chuck Bednarik late in a 17-10 loss. Unconscious, Gifford was carried off the field on a stretcher and examined. Wrapped in blankets with an ice-cold compress above his closed eyes, he was soon rolled on a gurney to an ambulance that hurried him to St. Elizabeths Hospital.

title: Germany Seeks Suspects in Terrorist Plots
description: BERLIN  German law enforcement officials said on Saturday that they were looking for two suspected terrorists thought to be in or around the capital city in one of several investigations aimed at thwarting what the authorities believe are myriad plans by Islamic radicals to attack the nation.

title: Choleras Second Fever: An Urge to Blame
description: If United Nations peacekeepers from Nepal are going to be blamed for bringing cholera to Haiti, its important to remember that the blame game for pandemics eventually involves everyone.

title: Man Killed in Wrong-Way Crash on Major Deegan Expressway
description: A 42-year-old New Jersey man was killed early Saturday when a vehicle driven by a drunken driver going the wrong way on the Major Deegan Expressway in the Bronx slammed into his car, the police said.

title: Jeter Talks Shadowed by Yankees 2000 About-Face
description: Hardly an off-season goes by that the Yankees do not agree to a long-term contract with a star or two. It has been that way for some time now, although the winter of 2006 was something of an exception.

title: Study Suggests a Cholesterol Pill Benefits Patients With Kidney Disease
description: Patients with chronic kidney disease who took Vytorin, a cholesterol-lowering pill, had one-sixth fewer heart attacks, strokes or operations to unblock their arteries than patients taking a placebo, according to the results of a study presented on Saturday.

title: U.S. Is Said to Pursue Broad Insider Trading Inquiry
description: Federal authorities are at an advanced stage of insider trading investigations that could result in criminal charges or significant civil fines against Wall Street traders and executives, a government official said Saturday.

title: The Pilgrims Were ... Socialists?
description: Ah, Thanksgiving. A celebration regardless of creed; a time for all Americans to come together after a divisive election year.

title: Realclimate on the Climate Hack
description: Gavin Schmidt, the NASA climatologist and indefatigable curator of the Realclimate.org blog (photographed above by Keith Myers of The New York Times), has weighed in on the year of attacks, defense and reappraisal that he and dozens of other climate researchers experienced following the unauthorized release of folders containing hundreds of their e-mail exchanges and files last November.

title: Fired Referee to Press Favoritism Allegation Against Campbell
description: A case that got Colin Campbell in trouble for vitriolic e-mails just will not go away.

title: William and Kate: A Fairy Tale, Ending Unknown
description: LONDON  A girl meets a prince. The prince needs a wife. The glass slipper fits: she is young, dewy, inexperienced, eager  swept up and blinded by the romance of it all. He proposes within months. Their wedding is watched by 750 million people worldwide and features at least five clergymen, 3,500 guests and one spectacularly frothy pearl-encrusted wedding dress whose 25-foot train has to be stuffed into the bridal carriage, where it threatens to suffocate the bride.

title: The Democrats Treaty Slump
description: WASHINGTON  To Walter B. Slocombe, there was something hauntingly familiar about the political sinkhole President Obama found himself in last week.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Prime Number
description: 261: The number of members of Congress who were millionaires last year, according to the Center for Responsive Politics, which analyzed Congressional financial disclosure reports. The number is a slight increase over 2008. Of those 261 millionaires, 55 were worth $10 million or more, and 8 were worth at least $100 million. Median wealth for all 535 members of Congress reached $911,000, up from $785,000 in 2008. Rules dont require members to report certain assets, including their homes.

title: My Florida Recount Memory
description: Ten years ago this month, all eyes were on Florida as lawyers, election officials and campaign workers bickered over the hanging chads and dimpled ballots, the suits and countersuits, that would determine whether the next president would be Al Gore or George W. Bush. The Op-Ed editors asked some of the people at the center of the recount to share their reminiscences.

title: The Louvre Takes Its Tin Cup Out
description: Paris may have a claim on being the art capital of the world, but one of its most hallowed cultural institutions, the Louvre, has gone to the French public with its hat in hand. According to Agence France-Presse, the museum is asking the public to contribute money to help buy The Three Grces, an exceptionally well-conserved 1531 work by the German painter Lucas Cranach the Elder.

title: Beasley Is Proving to Be a Find for Timberwolves
description: In putting together three superstars, the Miami Heat may have discarded one.

title: Why America Chases an Israeli-Palestinian Peace
description: JERUSALEM  Lt. Gen. Keith W. Dayton, who left Israel last month after overseeing the training of Palestinian security forces for five years, liked to tell the story of his first assignment in the Middle East. Charged with locating Iraqs elusive weapons of mass destruction after Saddam Hussein was deposed in 2003, General Dayton found no weapons but kept coming upon something else inside Iraqi military barracks  drawings of Al Aqsa Mosque in Jerusalem being squeezed by a serpent labeled Israel.

title: How an Old Writer Learned a New Trick About Stats
description: With everyone from schoolchildren to retirees, laymen to scholars, seemingly doing a blog, it was a few months ago that my son and I thought we could provide interesting baseball perspectives writing from the same site  he being the professional ballplayer David Newhan, and I having written about baseball for almost 50 years, starting in 1961 when the expansion Los Angeles Angels joined the American League.

title: A Quiet Mans Arrival
description: Charleston Harbor, Nov. 21, 1860

title: In Rare Cases, Pope Justifies Use of Condoms
description: ROME  Pope Benedict XVI has said that condom use can be justified in some cases to help stop the spread of AIDS, the Vaticans first exception to a long-held policy banning contraceptives. The pope made the statement in interviews on a host of contentious issues with a German journalist, part of an unusual effort to address some of the harshest criticisms of his turbulent papacy.

title: From Violin to Skateboard
description: At 42, Tony Hawk remains an icon to skateboarders one-quarter his age. He was widely regarded as the worlds best by the time he was a teenager, and has spent most of the past two decades building his name into the sports biggest brand, including video games, a skate company (Birdhouse Skateboards), a clothing line, even roller coasters. Hawk, a father of four, played himself on The Simpsons and skateboarded last year in the White House. Hawk, who lives near San Diego, was in New York recently to discuss his second book, How Did I Get Here? The Ascent of an Unlikely CEO, and Tony Hawk Shred, the latest in a billion-dollar line of video games.

title: The Hunt for Jobs Sends the Irish Abroad, Again
description: DUBLIN  Antoinette Shields had a plan to keep her tall, blue-eyed son, Kevin, close at hand. When she took over her bosss construction company in 2002, she hoped to retire at 55 and give her son the business.

title: How Twitter Users Balanced the Budget
description: Here are the budget preferences of 6,989 Twitter users who posted solutions to our deficit puzzle.

title: How Readers Chose to Fix the Deficit
description: Reduce the size of the military rather than reduce pay for noncombat members of the military. Impose a millionaires tax rather than cut deductions for high-income households. Cap the growth of Medicare spending rather than raise the eligibility age.

title: Consumer Risks Feared as Health Law Spurs Mergers
description: WASHINGTON  When Congress passed the health care law, it envisioned doctors and hospitals joining forces, coordinating care and holding down costs, with the prospect of earning government bonuses for controlling costs.

title: On TV, an Afghan Unit Tackles the Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  They break up child suicide-bomber rings, take down drug lords and government ministers (even when they are the same thing) and kick in doors to rescue kidnapped diplomats  all with little or no help from the Americans and NATO.

title: A Killing Set Honor Above Love
description: DOKAN, Iraq  Serving small glasses of sugary tea, Qadir Abdul-Rahman Ahmed explained how things went bad with the neighbors. It was not true, he said, that his brothers had threatened to drown his niece if she tried to marry the young man down the street.

title: Storm Upon Storm for South Dakota
description: VIVIAN, S.D.  The storm slammed into this dusty prairie town with the clatter of falling bricks. Hail shattered windows, punched holes in roofs and mangled cars. The clumps of ice were left to melt, but one, an unusual spiked orb the size of a cantaloupe, was preserved in the freezer of an old ranch hand.

title: Sunday: Having Aspirations
description: Clive Proberts debut and sophomore puzzles ran several months ago in The Times. Both were daily puzzles, but apparently he had higher aspirations, some of which spilled over into todays theme. Hes taken six common phrases and added an aspirate, or H sound, to one word in each. Real men dont eat quiche and, according to Mr. Probert, they dont heat it either.

title: In Death, Burns Is Again a Top Twitter Topic
description: Pat Burns, who coached the Devils to the 2003 Stanley Cup and was a three-time N.H.L. coach of the year, died Friday. He succumbed to lung cancer two months after his death was erroneously reported the morning of Sept. 17, the word spreading widely by Twitter.

title: Could She Reach the Top in 2012? You Betcha
description: THE perception I had, anyway, was that we were on top of the world, Sarah Palin said at the climax of last Sundays premiere of her new television series, Sarah Palins Alaska. At that point our fearless heroine had just completed a perilous rock climb, and if she looked as if shed just stepped out of a spa instead, dont expect her fans to question the reality. For them, Palins perception is the only reality that counts.

title: Nuking the White House
description: WASHINGTON

title: When Donations Go Astray
description: This holiday season, Americans will dig into their pockets for good causes. But these gifts will sometimes benefit charlatans or extremists, or simply be wasted.

title: Now, for Some Leadership
description: If Congress fails to rein in the deficit, it will be because of a lack of political courage  not any shortage of ideas out there on how to get the job done.

title: Russias Dictatorship of Law
description: Russias newly outrageous legal treatment of Mikhail Khodorkovsky, the former owner of the countrys largest oil company, is a reminder that Russia has yet to grasp the idea of equal justice under law  especially when the Kremlin decides someone is in the way.

title: The Lesson From Mr. Rangel
description: It was painful watching Representative Charles Rangel face censure in the House last week. But the wounds were self-inflicted. The evidence proved that Mr. Rangel, a New York City Democrat, repeatedly and arrogantly cut ethical corners, solicited favors and failed to pay his taxes. He still might have skated if he hadnt made a show of proclaiming innocence and demanding an investigation, finally rousing the usually somnolent ethics committee.

title: Sweat | Bulging Biceps and Fractured Limbs
