description: Every Thursday night at a single-family house in Bellerose, Queens, they file in the side door and down the stairs, men with ham-hock forearms, and a few sturdy women, too. They duck into a cramped basement room and gather around padded platforms equipped with handles for waging hand-to-hand combat.

title: Lost Boys of Sudan Fill in the Blanks of Their Past
description: PHOENIX  It has been 10 years since Malek Deng and thousands of other young men known as the Lost Boys of Sudan left war behind for new lives in the United States. But a new digital archive of their refugee records is taking Mr. Deng and the others back to the harrowing days of their youth.

title: Teaching for America
description: When I came to Washington in 1988, the cold war was ending and the hot beat was national security and the State Department. If I were a cub reporter today, Id still want to be covering the epicenter of national security  but that would be the Education Department. President Obama got this one exactly right when he said that whoever out-educates us today is going to out-compete us tomorrow. The bad news is that for years now weve been getting out-educated. The good news is that cities, states and the federal government are all fighting back. But have no illusions. Were in a hole.

title: Take a Closer Look
description: Starting in 2012, cigarette packages and advertisements will have to carry new warning labels that pound home the message that smoking sickens and kills. The message isnt new, but it will be presented in a bigger, starker format  including images of tobaccos devastating effects  that should be harder to ignore than the tiny, text-only warning labels that have lost their punch.

title: A Proposal to Reform Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Security and Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Taxi Design
description: To the Editor:

title: A Court for Veterans: An Idea Whose Time Has Come
description: To the Editor:

title: Illini Find the Way at Wrigley
description: CHICAGO  When Illinois defensive end Clay Nurse forced a fumble by Northwestern quarterback Evan Watkins early in the first quarter at Wrigley Field on Saturday, his Illinois teammates looked momentarily confused.

title: Romney, Weighing Run, Leans on State PACs
description: The fact that Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor who is weighing a run for president in 2012, has an active political action committee in Alabama might seem puzzling.

title: What We Must Do for Iraq Now
description: Washington

title: Kickoff Return by a Tenacious Senior Sends Harvard Over Yale
description: BOSTON  Marco Iannuzzi, a 24-year-old senior wide receiver at Harvard with a wife and a 2-year-old daughter, broke his collarbone six weeks ago for the second time in his college career and was cleared to play against Yale only on Thursday.

title: Colorado Scoring Tandem Takes Third Run at Dallas Defensive Duo
description: TORONTO  The tandem of Conor Casey and Omar Cummings was the most productive in Major League Soccer this season. The Colorado Rapids strikers combined for 27 goals  the most by two players in team history  and their partnership is peaking with a championship at stake here Sunday in the M.L.S. Cup.

title: Messier Has Mixed Results in Pro Coaching Debut
description: The education of Mark Messier continues.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Nov. 21
description: As President Obama and other world leaders wrap up the NATO weekend summit meeting, White House officials fan out on the talk shows to discuss the coalitions strategy in the war in Afghanistan.

title: Exhausting String of Storms in South Dakota
description: South Dakota is nearing the end of an unusually punishing year of weather.

title: Richards Glove, Kates Hand
description: Sandwich, England

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: North Koreans Unveil New Plant for Nuclear Use
description: WASHINGTON  North Korea showed a visiting American nuclear scientist earlier this month a vast new facility it secretly and rapidly built to enrich uranium, confronting the Obama administration with the prospect that the country is preparing to expand its nuclear arsenal or build a far more powerful type of atomic bomb.

title: If the Game Is Not a Sport, It Certainly Can Be a Workout
description: The idea that chess is a sport seems to be gaining wider acceptance.

title: Dining Out on Different Budgets
description: Views from readers, responses from the staff and thoughts from Arthur S. Brisbane, the public editor.

title: Religious Donations Going Awry
description: My Sunday column is about charitable contributions, particularly by Christians, Jews and Muslims, that are well-intentioned but poorly thought out  and thus not nearly as effective as they might be. This is of course also a problem with secular contributions, but were entering a season for religious giving and I think this is a particular problem for religious charities because of a false assumption that a charity that shares ones faith also shares ones values and bona fides.

title: Vows: Jason & Meredith
description: Jason and Meredith became fast friends as soon as Meredith boarded the school bus in fourth grade. Years later, their friendship turned into a romance that they were determined to keep alive.

title: A Border Fact of Life: High-Speed Chases
description: On a quiet November morning, Trooper Johnny Hernandez patrolled the dusty back roads along the Rio Grande in Hidalgo County. In the back seat, his M4 rifle sat within arms reach. In the trunk, he stored a bulletproof vest.

title: Will She or Wont She? Hutchison Keeps Them Guessing
description: Ross Ramsey, managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column

title: With Words on Paper, Independent Defies Trend
description: The threat came in 2002. Borders, the chain retailer of books and music, had announced plans to open a store a couple hundred feet from Austins largest independent book seller, BookPeople, but Steve Bercu, the chief executive, was not going down without a fight.

title: With Oden Out, Roy Is Also Concern for Blazers
description: Most of the news coming out of Portland last week centered on another knee operation for the former No. 1 pick Greg Oden that will keep him out for the entire season. But more troublesome for the Blazers might be the knees of guard Brandon Roy.

title: A Dilemma for Schools Seeking to Reform
description: On the eve of a Board of Education meeting in February where the death knell was to sound for five schools, Ron Huberman, the chief executive of Chicago Public Schools, granted an 11th-hour reprieve.

title: In a Parallel Universe, Campaign Candor
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative

title: As Election Nears, Time to Remake That Sows Ear
description: John Quinns campaign Web site promotes how he is prepared to be the next alderman of the 41st Ward because of the 14 years he spent as a city employee, an experience that taught him to navigate the intricate systems that make up city government.

title: A Soul Singers Life of Highs and Lows Soars Anew
description: Andre Williams sat drinking coffee in his usual corner booth at Roys Soul Food one morning last week. Despite the early hour, he was decked out in a black broad-brimmed hat, red satin shirt, cobalt-blue blazer, black slacks and two-toned leather shoes with spats.

title: Bills Mount for Travel by Trustees of Pensions
description: Grappling with a $919 million shortfall and looming insolvency, six of nine trustees overseeing San Mateo Countys pension system needed an oracle. So they decamped to Honolulu last week for a conference that cost the retirement plan an estimated $23,570.

title: City Wants Americas Cup, but Analyst Warns About Costs
description: For at least 43 days, Mayor Gavin Newsom proposes to turn San Francisco Bay into an arena for the Americas Cup, the worlds most prestigious yacht race. The water would be cleared of unauthorized boats and a no-fly zone imposed 6,000 feet above the Golden Gate Bridge, Fishermans Wharf and Angel Island.

title: Love for Wynne in Toronto, Bitterness to Greet Cunningham
description: TORONTO  Fans of the local Major League Soccer club, Toronto F.C., have been some of the most enthusiastic supporters in North America, despite the underwhelming performance of the team.

title: Internet Giants Foster, and Threaten, Innovation Economy
description: Jonathan Weber writes a regular column for The Bay Citizen

title: Philippe Starck Streetlamps
description: Ten iron and aluminum columns with glass cyclopean eyes stand sentinel on Howard Street between Third and Fourth Streets, intersecting the Moscone Center in the South of Market district. At night, the lamps faces blaze with light as the necks swivel down, morphing into Parisian-style streetlights.

title: Lottery Numbers
On the Set of Eagle Four
description: Eagle Four is a popular new police show on Afghanistans Tolo TV.

title: Tantalizing Talent Is Stuck on the Bench
description: The search for Anthony Randolph and his ever-tantalizing talents led to a familiar resting spot: to the sideline at Oracle Arena in Oakland, Calif., to a row of seats lining the court, to the end of a crowded bench, lost but not forgotten.

title: Gawker Ordered to Remove Palin Book Excerpts
description: When Sarah Palin found out that some Web sites had posted excerpts from advance copies of her new book, she took her lament to Twitter.

title: Gawker Ordered to Remove Palin Book Excerpts
description: HarperCollins, publisher of America by Heart, is vigilantly protecting the books contents until it comes out on Tuesday. Read more on Media Decoder

title: Notre Dame Stages a Revival at Yankee Stadium
description: The black-and-white photographs of the illustrious rivalry between Notre Dame and Army came alive Saturday night in the Bronx.

title: A Homecoming for a Few Rangers, and a Milestone for Their Coach
description: ST. PAUL.  The Rangers visit the State of Hockey only once every two years, so their 5-2 victory at the Xcel Center on Saturday was a treat.

title: Qaeda Branch Aimed for Broad Damage at Low Cost
description: In a detailed account of its failed parcel bomb plot last month, Al Qaedas branch in Yemen said late Saturday that the operation cost only $4,200 to mount, was intended to disrupt global air cargo systems and reflected a new strategy of low-cost attacks designed to inflict broad economic damage.

title: Football at Yankee Stadium
description: The first football game at the new Yankee Stadium, and the first Army-Notre Dame game in the Bronx since 1969.

title: In Knockout, Martinez Keeps Belt and Raises Profile
description: ATLANTIC CITY  The punch that floored Paul Williams, that landed square on his jaw and knocked him cold and momentarily appeared to knock him out, came in the second round on Saturday at the Boardwalk Hall. It came from the left hand of Sergio Martinez, courtesy of a short, quick, devastating left hook.

title: Achieving a Healthful Digital Diet
description: Think of the Internet and other digital technology as food. Limit the intake of empty digital calories, and do not consume too much over all.

title: Growing Up Digital, Wired for Distraction
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif.  On the eve of a pivotal academic year in Vishal Singhs life, he faces a stark choice on his bedroom desk: book or computer?

title: Giving Robots the Heavy Lifting
description: Jobs like stacking heavy boxes or fixing power lines can be dangerous, so why not give some of that work to robots?

title: Blake Griffin Dazzles, but Knicks Beat Clippers
description: LOS ANGELES  One man stood between the Knicks and a successful trip Saturday night, though in truth Blake Griffin was not really standing or spending much time with his feet on the ground at all.

title: FDR, Reagan, and Obama
description: Some readers may recall that back during the Democratic primary Barack Obama shocked many progressives by praising Ronald Reagan as someone who brought America a sense of dynamism and entrepreneurship that had been missing. I was among those who found this deeply troubling  because the idea that Reagan brought a transfomation in American dynamism is a right-wing myth, not borne out by the facts. (There was a surge in productivity and innovation  but it happened in the 90s, under Clinton, not under Reagan).

title: At Berlin Museum, Reindeer, Art and Overnight Stays
description: One bed. Twelve live reindeer. Twenty-four canaries, eight mice, and two flies. Lots of Andy Warhol. Plenty of Joseph Beuys.

title: After Months of Resisting, Ireland Applies for Bailout
description: DUBLIN  Ireland has formally applied for a rescue package worth more than $100 billion, after months of trying to survive its financial crisis with austerity measures and strict budgetary planning. The much-anticipated step gave a lift Monday to global stocks as well as the euro.

title: Where A.T.M. Fees for Noncustomers Are Highest
description: Travelers to Seattle and certain other cities may want to make every effort to find and use their own banks A.T.M. Why? Banks in Seattle  and certain other cities on average charge noncustomers higher A.T.M. fees than the national average, according to a recently released Bankrate.com survey covered more generally in a recent Bucks post.

title: How Do You Stop Michael Vick?
description: The Giants-Eagles matchup Sunday night has the feel of something pivotal for the N.F.C.

title: U.S. Pursues Broad Insider Trading Inquiry
description: Federal authorities are at an advanced stage of insider trading investigations that could result in criminal charges or significant civil fines against Wall Street traders and executives, DealBooks Peter Lattman reports, citing a government official.

title: Ireland to Pursue a Bailout
description: The Irish finance minister, Brian Lenihan, confirmed on Sunday that Ireland had formally applied to Europe and the International Monetary Fund for a bailout package, The New York Timess Landon Thomas Jr. reports.

title: How Is Technology Affecting Teaching and Learning?
description: Todays installment of the Your Brain on Computers series is the article Growing Up Digital, Wired for Distraction, which looks at the challenges that technology presents for teaching and learning.

title: In the Footsteps of the Museums Gorillas
description: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

title: Air Force Slip Complicates Tanker Bids
description: The Air Force has made another potentially serious mistake in its effort to buy $35 billion of aerial tankers, by accidentally sending each bidder sensitive data about the others proposal, Pentagon officials said Saturday.

title: DiCaprio Urges Apple to Aid Wild Tigers
description: Nov. 22, 11:45 p.m. | Updated Leonardo DiCaprio is donating $1 million to anti-poaching programs organized through the World Wildlife Fund, according to the group. Theres more in The Times onthe allure of big cats, even as their numbers dwindle.

title: Caught on Tape, a Snippet of Afghan Voting Fraud
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  On the audiotape, two men are heard speaking in Dari, with the distinct accent of the western city of Herat, as they negotiate terms for rigging more than a dozen races in Afghans parliamentary elections.

title: From Some Teachers, Excitement About Classroom Tech
description: Megan Taber, a teacher at Culbreth Middle School in Chapel Hill, N.C., was taken by the instant gratification. She leads her students through a writing exercise at the beginning of each class, as they respond to a question she writes on a blackboard. In the past, they used notebooks that she would collect periodically. Then her school began using iPod Touches in class. Ms. Taber changed the routine so that the students submit their writing directly to a spreadsheet on her computer over a wireless network. She now responds to the work within minutes instead of weeks.

title: A Movie Critic Loses Her Screening Privileges (But Gets Em Back)
description: LOS ANGELES  Was it something I said?

title: Jets 30, Texans 27, Final
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Jets are difficult to figure. After two ragged overtime wins in two weeks, the Jets only consistency was their inconsistency. They showed explosiveness on offense, then sputtered. They looked stifling on defense, then struggled.

title: Arms Bid Seen in New N. Korea Plant
description: American defense officials said Sunday that the revelation of North Koreas new uranium enrichment facility confirmed longstanding suspicions that the country was seeking a second route to build atomic weapons. They dismissed the Norths claim that it was simply trying to build nuclear power plants denied to them by the West.

title: Obama Considers Speech to Business Group
description: The White House and the U.S. Chamber of Commerce are continuing their rapprochement by considering a speech by President Obama to the business group.

title: Thousands Mourn Victims of High-Rise Blaze
description: SHANGHAI  More than 10,000 people gathered here on Sunday to mourn the victims of last weeks high-rise apartment fire that killed 58 people and injured about 70 others, exposing potential safety hazards in this citys breakneck building boom.

title: Spains Prisa Turns to a SPAC for Help
description: Struggling under 4.8 billion euros in debt, Prisa, the largest media company in Spain, is hoping shareholders will support a plan to return it to financial health this week by approving a shift from family ownership to control by a group of financiers, hedge funds and investment banks, Raphael Minder of The New York Times reports.

title: Tax Filings Show Struggles for Guggenheim
description: The last two years havent been easy on New York museums, but theyve been particularly challenging for the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation. In a disastrous 2008, the museums net assets declined by 25 percent.

title: In the Footsteps of the Natural History Museums Gorillas
description: On the City Room blog, Shane Dixon Kavanaugh writes about a curator at the American Museum of Natural History who will travel to Africa for three weeks to try to find the exact site used to create one of that museums most well-known dioramas.

title: Palestinian Leader Insists on Halt to Settlements
description: JERUSALEM  The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, said Sunday that any American proposal for restarting Israeli-Palestinian negotiations must include East Jerusalem as part of a complete halt in Israeli settlement building.

title: Wanderer in Bewitching, Fractious Land
description: Riven with violence and haunted by the dead and the missing, Between Two Worlds is a hallucinatory experience. The worlds in question could be a number of things  heaven and hell, peace and war, past and present; but in a film this vivid and this oblique, the cumulative thrust of the images is what pulls us through.

title: Biden: What We Must Do for Iraq Now
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has contributed an op-ed for the Times in which he writes, we are not disengaging from Iraq  rather, the nature of our engagement is changing from a military to a civilian lead.

title: Beyond Understanding
description: I ought to have known better than to have lunch with a psychologist.

title: Harry Potter Has $330 Million Debut Weekend
description: LOS ANGELES  The seventh Harry Potter movie opened to a jaw-dropping $330 million in global ticket sales over the weekend, underscoring the magical powers of the Warner Brothers marketing and distribution departments.

title: Soccers Sparkle Missing From M.L.S. Cup
description: TORONTO  Is it bad luck, a conspiracy theory or just the sort of obstacles M.L.S. will have to overcome if it is to become a relevant part of the sport and the American sporting landscape?

title: Counseling Women on Self-Respect Amid Tunes of Punky Rage
description: I got dressed up for you, a bubbly Kate Nash told her fans at Terminal 5 on Friday night, preening a little in a tight sequined outfit. But a few songs later she announced that she had an unspecified (and unseen) wardrobe malfunction, and shortly after that she disappeared offstage for a clearly unscheduled costume change, returning in a striped, oversize outfit.

title: 104 Degrees of Spirited Dancing
description: Fans of New Chamber Ballet might use the word intimate to describe the companys salon-inspired performances, which are held regularly at City Center Studios. But after a long evening watching choreography with no theatrical lighting in close quarters, a different word came to mind: exposed.

title: Surprises From Someone Fans Thought They Knew
description: Glenn Brancas sound comes in two parts: the thing itself  notes and chords and beats  and the effect.

title: When Crowd Has Power of the Purse
description: If you had $10,000 to burn, which choreographer would you choose to support? This is the premise of The A.W.A.R.D. Show!, though the title doesnt refer to the cash prize but is instead a rather torturous acronym: Artists With Audiences Responding to Dance. Im not sure I know what that means, but it sounds ominous.

title: In Family Court, a Reckoning for Gibsons Career
description: LOS ANGELES  A family law judge here will soon decide how much time Mel Gibson will get to spend with his year-old daughter with the model-entertainer Oksana Grigorieva and how much money he should pay for the childs support.

title: Keeping Torch Songs Ablaze
description: Talk about wacky. When Andrea Marcovicci was 5, she recalls, her mother, Helen, a nightclub singer now in her 90s and still active, taught her to sing The Man I Love. In the Marcovicci home Stormy Weather was sung as a lullaby.

title: Lawrence: Fresh Look at Warrior of Desert
description: Michael Kordas long, sometimes secondhand but finally satisfying book about T. E. Lawrence starts in a strange way. He opens Hero in 1917, when Lawrence, an Englishman leading an Arab guerrilla force and using military tactics that proved to have enduring impact, devises the bold strategic move of attacking the port city of Aqaba, on the Red Sea, by approaching it from an unexpected direction. In the monumental film biography of Lawrence that Mr. Korda does his best not to mention, this is the very famous Aqaba  from the land! moment.

title: Collins Is Mets Choice for Manager
description: 7:48 p.m. | Updated The Mets have chosen Terry Collins, their minor league field coordinator, as their new manager, according to three baseball executives who have been briefed on the subject. A Mets spokesman said the team had made a decision but would not announce it until the terms of a contract were worked out.

title: Across the Table From a Well-Traveled Player
description: Which bridge player has traveled the most miles in his life?

title: Conjuring Up Wondrous Sounds
description: The theory that young people are instinctively curious about new music got a boost on Friday night when Alan Gilbert conducted the first of this seasons Contact! concerts, the New York Philharmonics contemporary- music series, at Symphony Space. A sizable audience turned up at the 750-seat Peter Jay Sharp Theater, and younger people (the whole college-age crowd) were everywhere. No doubt some in the audience were drawn by the specific program, which intriguingly paired a new work by Magnus Lindberg, the Philharmonics composer in residence, written in homage to his influential teacher, the French composer Grard Grisey, with a major score by Grisey, who died of a stroke at 52 in 1998.

title: Jet Returns Safely to J.F.K. After Alert
description: A Moscow-bound jetliner that took off from Kennedy International Airport on Sunday afternoon returned to the airport for an emergency landing after there were reports that it was on fire and that the pilot had complained of engine problems, the authorities said.

title: Opinions You Wont Find on Twitter: Fran Lebowitz Talks
description: To many Americans  millions, really  the name Fran Lebowitz doesnt mean much. But in certain precincts, vital to the cultural functioning of both coasts, she is famously a friend, a crank, a climber, a cautionary tale, an iconoclast and a mouth. In Public Speaking, Martin Scorseses enormously enjoyable and perceptive documentary about her, Ms. Lebowitzs endearing narcissism is a study in the notion that arrogance and insecurity are largely two sides of the same cocktail coaster.

title: Harlem Renaissance Man and His Family, Behind Closed Doors
description: The first act of Knock Me a Kiss, a dandy play about the ill-advised marriage of W. E. B. Du Boiss daughter, is such rollicking fun that you may find yourself worrying at the intermission about whether theres any way this production can successfully work itself around to the serious part of the story that you know lies ahead. But somehow it does, keeping its sense of humor but muzzling it just enough to allow some drama and poignancy to enter the mix.

title: Isnt It Rich? Isnt It Loud? Xylophones for Sondheim
description: Razzle-dazzle isnt a quality ordinarily associated with the music of Stephen Sondheim. But on Friday evening at Carnegie Hall, where the New York Pops orchestra gave what Steven Reineke, its frisky music director and conductor, called Mr. Sondheims last big birthday bash of the year, there were moments when, if you closed your eyes, you could imagine you were at a parade.

title: A Beethoven Warm-Up and a Liszt Workout
description: There were probably some disappointed Murray Perahia fans at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night. Because of a hand injury Mr. Perahia withdrew last month from a tour that was to have included a Carnegie recital. But the London-based pianist Stephen Hough took his place, and it is hard to imagine that Perahia admirers went home unhappy after this exciting recital.

title: Spiral Form and Other Compositional Modes of Fred Lerdahl
description: The engaging Composer Portraits series at the Miller Theater has highlighted the work of a wide range of composers, from the up and coming to the legendary. On Friday evening the spotlight was on Fred Lerdahl, a professor at Columbia University.

title: Footnotes
description: When Love Comes, a low-budget family drama from the Taiwanese director Chang Tso-chi, was the winner of the Golden Horse Film Festival, considered the Chinese-language Oscars, on Saturday night in Taoyuan, Taiwan, The Associated Press reported. The film was nominated in 14 categories, including best director and outstanding Taiwanese film, and defeated the popular martial arts epic Bodyguards and Assassins, from the Hong Kong director Teddy Chen. ... About 20,000 people gathered on Saturday at Leidseplein Square in Amsterdam to protest the Dutch governments plans to cut its arts budget, BBC News reported. The government said it would cut arts funds by more than $270 million over the next five years and raise taxes on theater, film and concert tickets to 19 percent from 6 percent.

title: Norris Church Mailer, Artist and Ally, Dies at 61
description: Norris Church Mailer, a woman bred in the rural poverty of Arkansas who married Norman Mailer and managed his career and family life over three decades while carving out her own niche as a writer, died on Sunday at her home in Brooklyn Heights. She was 61.

title: Historian and Actor Meet for Film About Lincoln
description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning historian Doris Kearns Goodwin and the Oscar-winning actor Daniel Day-Lewis, above, met on Friday in Springfield, Ill., to tour several historical sites, including the Abraham Lincoln Presidential Library and Museum, the Lincoln home, the Old State Capitol and the Lincoln-Herndon Law Offices, The State Journal-Register reported. Mr. Day-Lewis was preparing for the title role in Lincoln, a DreamWorks film to be directed by Steven Spielberg that is scheduled to begin production next fall, according to Kathleen Kennedy, who is producing the film with Mr. Spielberg. The screenplay, by Tony Kushner, who won a Pulitzer Prize for Angels in America, is based on Ms. Goodwins book Team of Rivals, about the president and his cabinet.

title: Vivaldi for Amateurs Is Found in Collection
description: Two previously unknown violin sonatas by Vivaldi have been discovered in a collection of works by famous composers, including Handel, Corelli and Purcell, where they had been sitting unnoticed for 270 years, BBC News reported. The Foundling Museum in London discovered the pieces while cataloging the anthology, a 180-page portfolio of music compiled between 1715 and 1725 that had been donated in 2008 from the estate of Gerald Coke, a British businessman. From their relatively simple technical demands, it appears the two sonatas were written by Vivaldi for amateurs, Michael Talbot, the Vivaldi expert who authenticated the pieces, told the BBC.

title: Monday: Meal Money in Manitoba
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Todays constructor, David Poole, brings us four slang terms for money that each happen to be a kind of food that each happen to have a variety identified by a prefixed location name. So, for example, that Manitoba meal money would be CANADIAN BACON.

title: A West End Debut for Ellen Burstyn
description: Ellen Burstyns rsum spans Broadway to Hollywood, but this Oscar-winning actress still has another frontier to claim: the West End in London. Ms. Burstyn, below, will make her debut there in January at the Comedy Theater, playing Amelia Tilford in The Childrens Hour, by Lillian Hellman, BBC News reported. She will join a cast led by Keira Knightley (Pride and Prejudice) and Elisabeth Moss (Mad Men), who play schoolteachers whose lives are torn apart by a vicious rumor spread by Tilford and her granddaughter. Carol Kane, known for her role as Simka Dahblitz-Gravas on the 1980s television show Taxi, and Tobias Menzies, who played Brutus in the BBC-HBO television series Rome, have also joined the production, to be directed by Ian Rickson (Jerusalem). Previews begin on Jan. 22.

title: Kurt Vonnegut
description: Kurt Vonnegut's dark comic talent and urgent moral vision caught the temper of his times.

title: Season Over, Coach Prepares for Afghanistan
description: It has been a whirlwind year for Clayton Kendrick-Holmes. His Maritime College team went 10-0 in the regular season. He was named the conference coach of the year. He became friendly with N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell.

title: A.I.G. Puts Rail-Car Unit on Auction Block
description: 6:47 p.m. | Updated The American International Group is shopping around its rail-car unit, a person with knowledge of the matter said on Sunday. The move would be part of the insurers effort to sell noncore businesses to pay down its $130 billion taxpayer-financed bailout.

title: Unlikely Person at the Heart of Indias Scandal
description: NEW DELHI  He was a small-town lawyer from a regional political party in a southern Indian state. By almost any measure, Andimuthu Raja, who had no background in telecommunications or in business, seemed an unlikely candidate to be the government minister presiding over the fastest-growing cellphone market in the world.

title: Jets Top Texans in Closing Seconds
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  After the Jets produced another candidate for most unlikely triumph, after they turbo-boosted 78,843 heartbeats and eliminated fingernails at New Meadowlands Stadium, they simply shook their heads. There were no answers. Not on Sunday. Not this season.

title: Iraqi Leaders Delay New Government
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs leaders met Sunday for only the fourth time since being elected in March and delayed for at least several more days the formation of a new government.

title: Activist Relies on Islam to Fight for Animal Rights
description: CAIRO  It is never easy to be an animal rights activist in the Arab world. But on Id al-Adha, the annual Muslim religious holiday when the streets run red with the blood of slaughtered sheep, cows and camels, it is a nightmare.

title: A Husbands Chronic Illness Changes a Couples Life
description: Priscilla Leontitsis first spotted her future husband, Nicolas, in 1989 at Oasis, a Greek restaurant in White Plains that he owned. She was a local choir director and soprano, and she had stopped in for dinner.

title: An Unsung Role in Vicks Success
description: Philadelphia

title: Cabby Chats and Wisdom on Ulcers
description: DEAR DIARY: Serving in the Army during the Vietnam War in the late 1960s, I spent a year in Washington learning Laotian. Since the United States was not officially in Laos at the time, I was sent to a linguist holding company at Fort Hood in Texas for the remaining two years of my enlistment, ready to ship out should the need arise.

title: Nations That Debate Coal Use Export It to Feed Chinas Need
description: Even as developed countries close or limit the construction of coal-fired power plants out of concern over pollution and climate-warming emissions, coal has found a rapidly expanding market elsewhere: Asia, particularly China.

title: Drama in Milledgeville
Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Meeting Aims to Turn Tiger Fascination Into Conservation
description: Ministers from several countries gathered Sunday in St. Petersburg at the invitation of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to begin a five-day meeting with the goal of protecting tigers. Only a little more than 3,000 are estimated to be living outside captivity.

title: Tau Epsilon Phi, Founded 100 Years Ago at Columbia, Is Convulsed by a Lawsuit
description: For Tau Epsilon Phi, this should have been a year filled with pride and reflection: the fraternity, founded at Columbia University on Oct. 10, 1910, turned 100.

title: Eagles 27, Giants 17, Final
description: An interception with a second left seals it for the Eagles  Eli Mannings third pick and fourth turnover tonight. The Giants may have trouble deciding what to focus on tomorrow. Will it be the fact that the Eagles dominated them in the first half? Or the fact that they showed some grit, overcame that and took the lead when Philadelphia put the game on a platter for them by missing chances to pad its lead? Or will it be the fact that, once they had the lead, they threw it away by blowing their defense on a fourth-and-1 and giving up a 50-yard touchdown run? And then kicked away their final chance with three  three!!  turnovers in the closing minutes, including two on one drive? That will be for them to chew over in the postgame. Feel free to weigh in with your comments, and thanks for reading.Pregame: Live coverage and analysis of the Giants game against the Philadelphia Eagles at Lincoln Financial Field in Philadelphia. Both teams are 6-3, but the winner will emerge in the drivers seat in the N.F.C. East.

title: Fantastic Friday Will Help Shape the Title Race
description: When the 2010 college football season is recalled in years to come, two dominant themes are likely to be remembered. The first began playing out long before the season began in September, pitting the upstarts Boise State and Texas Christian against the Bowl Championship Series and the blue-blood establishment.

title: As Officials Face Corruption Charges, California City Struggles to Move On
description: BELL, Calif.  At first glance, it is difficult to tell anything is amiss at the tiny City Hall here. The waiting area is filled with people trying to argue their way out of parking tickets. A City Council meeting agenda is tacked on the bulletin board. And golden-framed portraits of council members are prominently displayed in the lobby.

title: For Russias Poor, Blond Hair Is Snippet of Gold
description: MOSALSK, Russia  The road into town is a potholed track, passing villages of log cabins and fallow fields that speak to the poverty that has gripped this part of central Russia for as long as anyone can remember.

title: Promoting Learning, or Dependence?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ending Our Wars
description: To the Editor:

title: Wendys Rethinks Fries in Nod to More Natural Foods
description: Commercials for fast food hamburgers are ubiquitous on television, but French fries dont get nearly as much love.

title: Council to Report on New Yorks Food Industry, From Seed to Compost
description: New Yorks relationship to food revolves largely  if not obsessively  around buying and eating it, but the city and its role in the food system, from farming to distribution to the compost pile, is the subject of an 86-page City Council report to be released on Monday.

title: Young Patriots Defense Gives New Twist to Classic Rivalry
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Tom Brady strolled through the locker room Sunday night, one of his sons nestled in the crook of his left arm. A few minutes later, a relaxed Bill Belichick was back on the Gillette Stadium field with a lacrosse stick. There had not been too many occasions for family celebrations and playing around after recent vintages of the Patriots series with the Indianapolis Colts.

title: On Train to Meadowlands, View of Wasted Money
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It wasnt a pretty view on the 13-minute train ride Sunday from Secaucus to New Meadowlands Stadium  old landfills, mud flats, the garish bulk of the stalled Xanadu project. But it might as well have been paved with money.

title: In Less Than 2 Years, Sanchez Era Has Arrived

title: Well-Appointed Guest Rooms, and Tattoo Suite Down the Hall
description: The sun had long since set when the design  an intricate garland of roses and a few skulls drawn on the skin in Sharpie marker  finally dried and it was time to begin tattooing the client, who had arrived shortly before 4 p.m. The usual accoutrements  individually wrapped needles and tubes, containers of ink and antiseptic, and a smear of A+D ointment  were fanned out across a table next to the artist.

title: Knicks Look Past Dunk and Back on Telling Trip

title: Lottery Numbers
Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week

Reports due will include revised gross domestic product for the third quarter and October sales of previously owned homes (Tuesday); and new home sales for October, weekly jobless claims, personal income and spending for October, durable goods for October and the November Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer confidence index (Wednesday).

title: Administration to Seek Balance in Airport Screening
description: Caught between complaints that airport screening has become too intrusive and threats of new terror attacks on aviation, Obama administration officials say they are sensitive to criticisms that security measures go too far, but they are insisting that the measures now in place are justified by the risks.

title: An Old Industry Name Signals a Shift Into a New Era

title: For International Criminal Court, Frustration and Missteps in Its First Trial
description: THE HAGUE  The International Criminal Court has all the trappings of a weighty institution: 18 judges, a large corps of prosecutors, a multimillion-dollar budget and its own prison cells. But the court is facing mounting criticism over the handling of its first case, which may be coming apart after more than four years.

title: Close Watch on Casualties in Afghanistan and Iraq
description: EVERY morning I wake up and go looking for dead people, says Michael White, a computer programmer from Stone Mountain, Ga., who publishes the Web site iCasualties.org, which tracks deaths and injuries among coalition forces in Iraq and Afghanistan.

description: NAHR-i-SUFI, Afghanistan  From his rooftop position, Sgt. Santiago Zapata watched the firefight begin after prayer call ended, a rocket-propelled grenade exploding as the muezzins voice was still fading into the Afghan dusk.

title: Mired in Crises, Haiti Struggles to Focus on Election
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Crushed buildings from the January earthquake still spill out onto sidewalks here, people are collapsing from cholera at hospital doors and a wave of rioting last week reminded Haitians of political turmoil of the past.

title: Thai Fetus Morgue to Be Torn Down
description: BANGKOK  The morgue at a Buddhist temple where 2,000 fetuses from illegal abortions were discovered last week is to be dismantled and replaced by a meditation center, the government said Sunday.

description: TOKYO  Japans justice minister resigned on Monday over verbal gaffes that had stirred outrage in Parliament, dealing another blow to the increasingly unpopular government of Prime Minister Naoto Kan.

title: Room to Grow as Homes Add HD TVs
description: High-definition televisions have entered American homes with startling speed; 56 percent of households now have at least some HD channels and an HD set, according to Nielsen. Among consumer technologies, that speed of adoption is rivaled only by the VCR.

description: Comcast is still in negotiations with the government over its proposed takeover of NBC Universal, but that did not stop the cable company from announcing a new management slate for the entertainment giant last week.

title: For Obama, a Little Help From His Friends
description: WASHINGTON  As administration officials said farewell to one another upon returning from a two-day summit in Lisbon on Saturday night, they all but exchanged high-fives. The sense of success went to the top: President Obama, shirt-sleeved and smiling, made a rare, brief visit to the press cabin as Air Force One headed home.

title: Finding the Right Tool to Tell a War Story
description: Does it really matter what camera Damon Winter used to make these beautifully composed images? I dont think so. Its the images that are important.

description: On sale for about a week, Of Thee I Sing, President Obamas 31-page childrens picture book, an ode to 13 inspirational Americans written as a letter to his daughters, Malia and Sasha, is already on the best-seller lists on Amazon.com and BN.com.

description: PARIS  Academics are increasingly leaving France for the United States, which carries the risk of a brain drain in France, according to a report this month by an independent study group.

title: Hugh Prather, Popular Self-Help Author, Dies at 72
description: Hugh Prather, a self-help author whose first book, Notes to Myself, put an aphoristic finger on the pulse of the 70s, has sold more than five million copies and inspired the long-running Saturday Night Live segment Deep Thoughts, died on Nov. 15 at his home in Tucson. He was 72.

title: Lawrencia Bembenek, Bambi in Murder Case, Dies at 52
description: Lawrencia Bembenek, a former Playboy bunny and Milwaukee police officer whose conviction for the murder of her husbands ex-wife and audacious escape from prison became tabloid and TV-movie fodder and a cause clbre for supporters who insisted on her innocence  as she always did  died Saturday in a hospice in Portland, Ore. She was 52.

description: WASHINGTON  Thanksgiving week has temporarily stilled the capitals transition of power. For the incoming House speaker, John A. Boehner, that is just fine.

title: Irelands Paradise Lost
description: For an American tourist weaned on Gaelic kitsch and screenings of The Quiet Man, the landscape of contemporary Ireland comes as something of a shock. Drive from Dublin to the western coast and back, as I did two months ago, and youll still find all the thatched-roof farmhouses, winding stone walls and placid sheep that the postcards would lead you to expect. But round every green hill, theres a swath of miniature McMansions. Past every tumble-down castle, a cascade of condominiums. In sleepy fishing villages that date to the days of Grace OMalley, Irelands Pirate Queen (she was the Sarah Palin of the 16th century), half the houses look the part  but the rest could have been thrown up by the Toll brothers.

title: Giants Let Game Slip Through Fingers
description: PHILADELPHIA  Michael Vick emerged from an enormous inflatable Eagles head and through a dry-ice fog, a sort of rebirth for a once-fallen N.F.L. quarterback. Replica No. 7 jerseys adorned legions of vocal admirers in the seats and were featured prominently at the stadiums concession stands.

title: Lacking Star Power, Rapids Find Touch to Win M.L.S. Cup
description: TORONTO  The Colorado Rapids, one of the original Major League Soccer teams, won their first championship Sunday night, beating F.C. Dallas, 2-1, on an own goal in extra time.

title: What the Secret Donors Want
description: According to tax records unearthed by Bloomberg News, the health insurance lobby secretly gave $86.2 million to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce in 2009 to try to prevent the health care bill from becoming law. The huge contribution  40 percent of the chambers spending for that year  allowed the group to run ads against the bill without tainting the insurance industry, which was negotiating with Democrats on the bill at the same time.

title: Rooting Out Corruption in Albany
description: Governor-elect Andrew Cuomo faces many hurdles when he takes office in January, so heres one shortcut to ethics reform: He should hand over the power to investigate public corruption in Albany to the new attorney general, Eric Schneiderman.

Thats hard to believe amid the groan and bustle of tractor trailers delivering New York Citys daily sustenance round the clock to the vast Hunts Point distribution markets. This is the crossroads for the rich cornucopia shunted for retail dispersal from giant warehouse hangars to holiday celebrants in the five boroughs.

title: Another Historic Roman Site Hosts the Party

In antiquity, the vaulted space accommodated public functions, in the 16th century it was incorporated into a convent, and in the 1930s it was used for produce and flower markets. Now, through June, it will host Traiano Hour, a bi-monthly happy hour with presentations, D.J.s, and a bar stocked with wines from the surrounding Lazio region.

Yes, it has been almost exactly a year since the 2009 running of that annual record-industry trophy giveaway  not quite as prestigious as the Grammys, arguably preferable to the Peoples Choice Awards  which stirred up a sensation for a provocative performance by Adam Lambert and some otherwise inept musical numbers. So this much can be said about the confetti-laden 2010 show, which was held Sunday at the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles and broadcast on ABC: at least it was free of controversy.

title: The Empty Chair in the Dining Room
description: Every other weekend, I drive the 55 miles between Brooklyn and Tinton Falls, N.J., where my father lives at an assisted living facility called Renaissance Gardens. The director of Inferno, a planned film about the life of Lovelace, who starred in Deep Throat and other pornographic movies, said he had parted ways with Ms. Lohan and was pursuing another actress to play the role, The Hollywood Reporter said.

The girls flee the house when the boyfriend shows up in Miami, prompting fears of a kidnapping.

But a more ominous deadline looms this week. Tuesday is the beginning of the final 100 days of the collective bargaining agreement, which expires March 3.

title: Bad Sunday to Be a Manning
description: This happens so seldom that you immediately start suspecting some weird astrological retrograde moons in the wrong house explanation, but Sunday was decidedly a bad day to be a quarterback named Manning. Not that Peyton and Elis N.F.L. teams do not often lose on the same day, but rarely do both of them make the spectacularly horrendous play that seals the loss on the same day: the elder Manning botching a chance at a game-tying field goal by throwing an interception against the Patriots and the younger one trying to one-up him by fumbling away the Giants chance to catch the Eagles.

title: On Our Radar: 2010 May Set Emissions Record
description: Global carbon dioxide emissions may hit record levels this year, exceeding the previous high set in 2008, a new study estimates. Emissions have rebounded sharply this year in tandem with the recovery of the world economy. [Wired]

description: Let us now give thanks for Thanksgiving. Or not, as the case may be.

title: Fete Accompli | Cherry Vanilla Dinner at the Royalton
description: Cherry Vanilla has more scoops for you. The infamous 70s groupie, singer, writer and underground actress, who was also David Bowies publicist during his Mainman years, was in town over the weekend to celebrate the release of her autobiography, Lick Me: How I Became Cherry Vanilla. Among the downtown demimondaines and creative misfits who turned up to the dinner hosted for her by Tim Burton at Forty Four at Royalton on Saturday night were Patricia Field, Leee Black Childers, Kate Pierson of the B-52s, Agyness Deyn, Geordon Nicol, Greg K and Leigh Lezark. Seated next to Guinevere van Seenus (in vintage), Cherry held court, regaling her audience with stories about her myriad sexcapades, misadventures and all-around delish dish.

title: Running New Yorks Schools Once Came With a Nice House
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has played up Cathleen P. Blacks record of business success in nominating her to be the next schools chancellor. He has, perhaps wisely, omitted one asset Ms. Black brings to the job: a drool-inducing collection of homes in which to hold killer end-of-school-year parties. Ms. Black owns a Park Avenue penthouse with a gourmet kitchen, a five-bedroom Connecticut colonial and a Southampton weekend getaway.

description: A six-week initiative promoted by the Italian lingerie brand Intimissimi essentially exchanges one form of padding for another: used bras collected at its brand name stores throughout Italy will be recycled into insulated and soundproof panels used for construction.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: Danielle Arceneaux joined the New York office of Cramer-Krasselt as vice president and director for public relations. She succeeds Deborah Radman, who left, the agency said. Ms. Arceneaux had most recently been a senior vice president at Kaplow Communications, New York, overseeing the Target account.

title: What Did You Think About Top Gear?
description: The American version of Top Gear made its debut on the History Channel on cable last night. In reviewing the first three episodes  the only ones made available by the producers  Mike Hale of The New York Times wrote, The result  for the person with a casual interest in cars, anyway  is a show that at this point lacks the character of the British original but is, particularly in its second and third episodes, reasonably entertaining by American reality-TV standards.

title: S.E.C. Smarter About Insider Inquiries, Official Says
description: Reports that authorities are at an advanced stage of insider trading investigations are the talk of Wall Street.

title: Haslem Injury Potentially Devastating for Heat
description: There are few angles of the Miami Heat from which Udonis Haslem lies at the focus. After all, on a team thats glowing with star power and expected to be dazzling, it makes little sense to concentrate on a player who is, in many ways, unspectacular. Theres nothing sexy about below-the-rim rebounds or jumpers from the elbow, but that doesnt make Haslem anything less than invaluable for Miami.

title: Michelle Obama Gets a New Communications Director
description: Michelle Obama announced on Monday that Kristina Schake, a former aide to Californias first lady, Maria Shriver, and a co-founder of the California-based political consulting firm Griffin Schake, will be joining the East Wing as a special assistant to the president and the first ladys communications director.

title: Pumpkin: The Flavor of Late Fall
description: I never got around to carving a jack-o-lantern for Halloween. I bought the pumpkin, yes, but then decided to save it for cooking. The day after Halloween, I cut it into chunks  about eight pounds  put them on foil-lined baking sheets, covered the sheets and roasted them at 425 degrees until they were very soft, which took about 1 1/2 hours. Then I spent the week making pumpkin recipes.

title: Predicting the Economy, and Obamas Re-Election Chances
description: Saturdays Times had an  article by Jeff Sommer that highlighted the work of Ray C. Fair, a Yale economist who has designed a model to predict the outcomes of presidential elections based on a series of economic variables.

title: One Giants Power Failure Explained
description: The blackout that plunged the New Meadowlands Stadium into darkness for more than 10 minutes during last Sundays Giants game against the Dallas Cowboys was not the teams fault, officials said Monday.

title: How to Get a Home Buyers Discount
description: With the home buyers tax credit now expired, heres one way to still get an equivalent discount of sorts: ask your real estate agent to take it out of his or her commission.

title: Twins Suicide Pact and the Columbine Connection
description: Twin sisters from Australia, who complained of bullying as teenagers, might have chosen to shoot themselves at a gun range outside Denver last week because of its proximity to Columbine High School, site of the 1999 massacre that became a global news event.

title: Smashburger Is Coming to Town
description: Better burgers buffet Brooklyn!

title: Choosing Between a Hard Rock and a Place
description: The idea that all the worlds a stage has grown only more powerful with the advent of reality TV, gossip Web sites and the mainstreaming of entertainment industry news. So it ought to be no surprise that marketers are trying to capitalize on the trend by having ads speak in the language of show business.

title: Tanks to Afghanistan, a Soldier Writes
description: The United States military has announced that it will be sending a company of Marine Tankers to southwest Afghanistan, bringing a much-needed armor presence to an asymmetrical fight.

title: Allman Brothers Band Gets Back the Beacon, and Gets an Apology Too
description: The Gypsy may fly from coast to coast and concert hall to concert hall, but back home hell always run. On Monday the Allman Brothers Band announced that it would return to its homestead at the Beacon Theater after a one-year absence, at a news conference during which Gregg Allman and his bandmates received a surprising apology from executives at MSG Entertainment, which runs the theater.

title: Off the Menu: Villa Pacri
description: The soap opera that has been the opening of the multistory Villa Pacri complex continues.

title: TimesCast | November 22, 2010
description: Obama wins support abroad for the Start Treaty; killing the invasive lionfish for sport; and answering readers' questions about a story on high schools' fight for the attention of tech-savvy teens.

title: Off the Menu: Mas 2
description: Galen Zamarra, the chef and partner at Mas (Farmhouse) in Greenwich Village, plans to expand his brand with a second restaurant, Mas (La Grillade), in early summer.

title: With Its Move, City Gives Chess Players a New Spot
description: The accidental chess rebels of Inwood Hill Park now have a legal place to play  as long as they bring their own boards.

title: Dining at the New Bowlmor Lanes
description: No doubt you can work up an appetite flinging a bowling ball down the alley, so the 90,000-square-foot bowling complex in the former New York Times newsroom, off Times Square, has a 220-seat restaurant, Stadium Grill, with stadium-style seating and an 80-foot bar. The restaurant menu and the  menu available at the lanes are by David Burke.

title: New Pick-Me-Ups at Kennedy Airport
description: Fliers headed to Rome or Milan might be looking forward to a cappuccino waiting on the other side. Now Italians should look forward to landing in New York, as two high-end coffee machines have popped up at Kennedy Airport.

title: Industry and Government Were Unprepared for BP Spill, Study says
description: Government and the oil industry were both thoroughly unprepared for a deepwater blowout and oil spill like the one that occurred this year in the gulf, leading to significant delays in capping the well and major environmental damage, the staff of the presidential spill commission concluded in two reports published on Monday.

title: Former Nazi Guard, 89, Dies Before Trial in Germany
description: BERLIN  A former Nazi guard accused of aiding in the murder of 430,000 Jews at the Belzec death camp  and of personally shooting dead 10 people  died in his home near Bonn before he could stand trial next year, German court officials announced Monday.

title: Republican Bias Found in Polls That Exclude Cellphones
description: An analysis by the Pew Research Center of its midterm election polls found a pro-Republican bias in samples based on interviews conducted only by land-line telephones, compared with ones that also included cellphones. The finding sends a stark warning to pollsters across the country as attention turns to the 2012 presidential election.

title: BBC and Discovery Channel Join Forces for History of the World
description: The BBC and the Discovery Channel, which collaborated in the past on Planet Earth and Life, are starting work on another joint documentary, History of the World.

title: Scotiabank in Deal for DundeeWealth
description: Scotiabank plans to expand its asset management services with the acquisition of the 82 percent of the wealth management company DundeeWealth that it does not already own, the bank said on Monday.

title: How Parents Can Prevent Bullying
description: September 19: Billy Lucas, age 15, of Greensburg, Indiana, hanged himself from the rafters of his familys barn. September 19: Seth Walsh, 13, of Tahachapi, California, hanged himself from a tree in his yard. September 22; Tyler Clementi, 18, a Rutgers University freshman, jumped off the George Washington Bridge in New York City. September 23: Asher Brown, 13, of Houston, shot himself in the head. These four boys didnt know each other, but they did have something in common. Theyd been bullied and school, and one by one, they all apparently came to the same conclusion: If youre gay or thought to be gay, life just isnt worth living.

title: Legislator Says Panel Member Should Be Removed
description: State Senator Eric Adams on Monday called for the removal of a member of the education panel evaluating Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs choice for the next city schools chancellor.

title: In European Debt Crisis, Some Call Default Better Option
description: DUBLIN  Ireland has finally taken its medicine, accepting the financial rescue package European officials have been pushing for several weeks.

title: Vikings Fire Childress as Season Gets Away
description: Perhaps the first sign this was going to be an off-kilter season for the Minnesota Vikings came when Coach Brad Childress dispatched three players on a private jet to beg Brett Favre to return for one more run at the Super Bowl, a season after the Vikings reached the N.F.C. championship game. Favre did return, but the chaos was only beginning.

title: Jay-Z Deconstructs Himself
description: In the summer of 1978, when he was 9 years old and growing up in the Marcy housing projects in Brooklyn, Shawn Carter  a k a Jay-Z  saw a circle of people gathered around a kid named Slate, who was rhyming, throwing out couplet after couplet like he was in a trance, for a crazy long time  30 minutes straight off the top of his head, never losing the beat, riding the handclaps of the folks around him, transformed like the church ladies touched by the spirit. Young Shawn felt gravity working on him, like a planet pulled into orbit by a star: he went home that night and started writing his own rhymes in a notebook and studying the dictionary.

title: The Claim: Cellphones Can Cause an Allergic Reaction.
description: THE FACTS Talking on a cellphone for long periods can carry certain risks, like dirty looks from those around you. But allergies?

title: Guilty Verdict in Chandra Levy Murder Case
description: WASHINGTON  A jury convicted a Salvadoran immigrant of killing Chandra Levy, the government intern whose relationship with Gary A. Condit ended his Congressional career and made her disappearance a national media sensation.

title: Are You Allergic to Your Cellphone?
description: If youve noticed an itchy, bumpy rash along your jaw line, the culprit may surprise you. As todays Really? column reports, you may be allergic to your cellphone.

title: Sending Tanks to Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The byways of Afghanistan are still littered with burned and bombed out old Soviet tanks, T-55s too big and hulking to move economically, especially from their final resting places on narrow mountain roads and at the bottoms of deep gorges.

title: Jimmie Johnson Wins Fifth Sprint Cup Title
description: Jimmie Johnson won his fifth Sprint Cup championship on Sunday, after finishing second in the season finale at Homestead-Miami Speedway in Florida, behind Carl Edwards.

title: For a Cat, a Payback in a Shadowy Existence
description: Watch the full episode. See more Nature.

title: Deficit Puzzle: Wheres the Fair Tax?
description: Yesterdays Week in Review section published a whole bunch of charts showing how Twitter users chose to cut the deficit using our deficit puzzle. In an accompanying article, I also mentioned a few options that readers and bloggers told us they wish we had included in the puzzle.

title: Warthen to Return as Mets Pitching Coach
description: Dan Warthen will remain as Mets pitching coach and will not be replaced by new manager Terry Collinss good friend Dave Wallace, a former Mets pitching coach.

title: Lessons in Inefficiency, Learned in Airports Around the World
description: IM a problem-solver and pattern-recognizer. Traveling as much as I do is always an adventure. I have to admit that a lot of the time, Im wondering how we actually make it from Point A to Point B since everything is so inefficient.

title: Michael Savage to Write Two Thrillers
description: Michael Savage, the combative talk radio host, has signed a deal to write two thrillers for St. Martins Press, the publisher said on Monday. Until now Mr. Savage has stuck to nonfiction, with books like Liberalism Is a Mental Disorder, The Savage Nation and The Enemy Within. Mr. Savage, whose personal manifesto on his Web site calls for closing the United States borders, ending affirmative action and instituting a flat tax, attracts more than nine million weekly listeners to his syndicated radio show, according to Talkers magazine.

title: In Family Court With Mel Gibson
description: 9:36 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES  After a day of testimony and legal wrangling on Monday, the Mel Gibson-Oksana Grigorieva battle in family court adjourned for the day, with plans to resume in front of Judge Scott M. Gordon on Dec. 15. According to one person who was briefed on the closed-door proceedings, and who spoke on condition of anonymity because of their sensitivity, Ms. Grigorieva testified but Mr. Gibson did not. The core issues  who will have custody of the couples daughter, Lucia, and under what terms  are not likely to be settled until early next year.

title: SoFAS
description: Acronym for foods containing Solid Fats and Added Sugars.Reporting for The Monterey County Herald on the American Dietetic Associations Food and Nutrition Conference, Barbara Quinn wrote:

title: A Shift From Company Cars
description: Businesses are increasingly adopting car sharing as a cost-saving alternative for employee travel. Workers can step outside their companys front door and into a car they can drive to a business meeting or sales call, and  during breaks or lunch hour  use for errands or shopping.

title: Beyond Pumpkin Pie: Thankful for Dessert
description: All month long, Wells Vegetarian Thanksgiving series has offered delicious no-meat dishes for your holiday table. Now, its time for dessert.

title: Site Unseen: Comic-Con Ticket-Seekers Thwarted by Online Fiasco
description: Quick: Whos the superhero with ticket-selling powers? Comic-Con is in need of some.

title: Should Nations Bankroll Coal Plants Overseas?
description: My article in Mondays Times examines how many countries and communities that block new construction of coal-fired power plants at home are enabling their use in the developing world by exporting coal to Asia.

title: Islanders Drama Continues
description: To borrow a sentiment from the Bard, there is something very rotten indeed in New York Islander-land. Their losing streak has reached 13, and things remain bleak.

title: N.F.L. Encourages Children to Go Out and Play
description: What better time to remind people to exercise than during the annual Thanksgiving gorge-fest?

title: Wanderlust | Mexico Citys Common People
description: Monika Feldman used to walk by what she describes as this magnificent house  a 1940s Colonial-style mansion in Mexico Citys high-end Polanco district  every day on the way to Byzanz, the fabric shop she owns with her husband, Max. Now that building is home to their latest store, Common People, which they like to refer to as a place to be filled by uncommon things for common people, and that many other style watchers are calling Mexico Citys answer to Colette.

title: A Prescription for Abdominal Pain: Due Diligence
description: The stomachache people look with some envy at the headache people.

title: The Caucus: The New Start Treaty
description: President Obama has international support for Start, a nuclear treaty with Russia, but he has struggled in the last week to get Republican cooperation at home.

title: Understanding Childhood Stomachaches
description: In todays 18 and Under column, pediatrician Dr. Perri Klass navigates the challenges of diagnosing and treating children with chronic stomachache. She writes:

title: Behavior: Young Marijuana Users Pay Cognitive Price
description: Marijuana smoking often starts in adolescence  and the timing could not be worse, a new study suggests.

title: Pakistani Sentenced to Death May Get a Pardon
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A Christian woman who was sentenced to death by a municipal court for blasphemy against Islam could be pardoned by the president in the next few days, a senior government official said Monday.

title: For the Briners, Thanksgiving May Start Today
description: The Thanksgiving Help Line I run here at Diners Journal doesnt really get going until Wednesday afternoon, and doesnt kick into high gear until Thanksgiving morning itself, but already the mail has started to pour in: mostly people freaking out about brine.

title: A Web Retailer Starts Over
description: In July, She Owns It introduced readers to La Grande Dame, an online retailer of high-end, plus-size designer clothing for women. The post chronicled the start-ups experiences with Google AdWords and search engine optimization and its eventual decision to cut Googles pay-per-click advertising product from its marketing mix. Several readers commented that La Grande Dames Web site contributed to its S.E.O. challenges and urged an overhaul to address that issue and improve the sites appearance and functionality. La Grande Dame took the comments  and similar ones from its customers  to heart, and unveiled its new site last week. Our ultimate goal was to improve the user experience and make it easier for shoppers to find what they want, said Catherine Wood Hill, La Grande Dames chief executive.

title: Harvey Pitt Gives His Take on the Insider Trading Inquiry
description: A major insider trading inquiry is under way, and Harvey L. Pitt, a former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, says investment firms may be required to spend more time on compliance as a result.

title: Manning Is Most Frequent Fumbler
description: Giants quarterback Eli Manning, constantly compared to his quarterbacking brother on the Indianapolis Colts, leads Peyton Manning in one unsung career statistic: fumbles.

title: TimesCast: Obama and the New Start Treaty
description: In todays TimesCast, a conversation about President Obamas efforts to get enough votes in the Senate to ratify an arms treaty with Russia.

title: Wired Up at Home to Monitor Illnesses
description: As an aging population threatens to overwhelm the nations hospitals and doctors, thousands of seriously ill patients are relying on computerized health trackers to help keep them safe at home.

title: Its Time for Recess: Just Keep on Moving
description: We all know by now that we should be getting 30 minutes a day of moderate to vigorous physical activity on most days. Yet for all the proselytizing, wheedling and cajoling, only about 5 percent of the population has bought into the program.

title: A Man From Whom Viruses Cant Hide
description: Dr. W. Ian Lipkin was spending the afternoon prowling his empire of viruses. The Center for Infection and Immunity, which he directs, occupies three floors of the Mailman School of Public Health at Columbia University. Rather than wait for the elevator, Dr. Lipkin ran up and down the back stairs to move from floor to floor, leaning into the doorways of labs and glass-walled offices to get updates from a platoon of scientists.

title: On a School Rooftop, Hydroponic Greens for Little Gardeners
description: Shakira Castronovo stood in a classroom at the Manhattan School for Children on West 93rd Street on a recent afternoon and hushed a squirming group of kindergartners perched around a blue carpet.

title: Fungus Among Us
description: Soma, Carsten Hllers enormous installation at the Hamburger Bahnhof  Museum fr Gegenwart in Berlin, is quite a trip down the rabbit hole  complete with a host of special psychedelic effects and strange supporting characters. The title refers to the drink central to Vedic and greater Persian religious rites, the active ingredient of which some scholars believe was Amanita muscaria, a kind of psychoactive mushroom. Hller has constructed two long, fenced-in corrals with hay-lined floors, gigantic sculptures of magic mushrooms and an elevated, cushioned platform on which a limited number of visitors can sign up to spend the night. There are also freezers stocked with actual  enormous  samples of Amanita muscaria.

title: Lessons of Hate at Islamic Schools in Britain
description: LONDON  A British network of more than 40 part-time Islamic schools and clubs with 5,000 students has been teaching from a Saudi Arabian government curriculum that contains anti-Semitic and homophobic views, including a textbook that asks children to list the reprehensible qualities of Jews, according to a BBC documentary broadcast on Monday.

title: The Brown Apple
description: Q. What accounts for the difference among varieties of apple in how quickly slices turn brown?

title: Behind the Facade, Post-Traumatic Stress
description: A soldier returns from war unable to get the images of battle out of his head. An earthquake survivor rides out long, anxiety-filled nights. A young woman in a pretty floral dress walks her dog along the streets of Manhattan.

title: The Next Ailing Wild Cat in Apples Software Pipeline
description: 4:57 p.m. | Updated Craig Packer, a University of Minnesota biologist whose specialty is Africas lions, read my posts on the tiger as an imperiled wild cat and Apple marketing icon and e-mailed a reminder of the troubles facing the worlds other uber-charismatic feline predator. Ive added a couple of links for context:

title: After the Nuclear Plant Powers Down
description: ZION, Ill.  Twelve years ago, Commonwealth Edison found itself in a bind.

title: Pictures of the Day: Cambodia and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Cambodia, China and Algeria.

title: He Was Mr. Universe, but He Was Really in Love With the Stars
description: The first time I met the eminent cosmologist Allan R. Sandage, who died Nov. 13 at 84, he refused to talk to me.

title: Nissan Says Its Electric Leaf Gets Equivalent of 99 M.P.G.
description: DETROIT  The federal government has rated the Nissan Leaf, the battery-powered car scheduled to go on sale next month in five states, as getting the fuel equivalent of 99 miles a gallon, Nissan said Monday.

title: Tis the Season (for Law Firm Bonuses)
description: Its a good time of year to be a lawyer at a large New York firm.

title: Avoid the Investing Trap of Familiarity
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog, and other drawings are available on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

title: Massey Energy Board to Explore Potential Sale
description: 6:05 p.m. | Updated Massey confirmed in a statement on Monday that it was conducting a review of strategic alternatives.

title: Pictures of the Day: Cambodia and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Cambodia, China and Algeria.

title: Reptiles Pet-Store Looks Belie Its Triassic Appeal
description: As a femur-shaped island paradise that snapped away from the Gondwana supercontinent some 80 million years ago, New Zealand is famously home to eccentric forms of wildlife that look like pets for a Hobbit.

title: Video Shows Aftermath of Deadly Stampede in Cambodia
description: Updated | Tuesday | 1:00 p.m. At least 378 people were killed and hundreds more injured in a stampede at a festival in Phnom Penh, the Cambodian capital, on Monday.

title: H.P. Surpasses Forecasts With 5% Jump in Profit
description: For Lo Apotheker, his debut public appearance as chief executive of Hewlett-Packard could not have gone much better had he scripted it.

title: Rookie Has U.S. Team Debut and Meets Mandela
description: The whirlwind trip to South Africa left Tim Ream in a bit of a daze, a good daze.

title: From California, a Game Plan on Climate Change
description: As the push for national and international policies to arrest climate change was running into one obstacle after another, a separate discussion was coming to the fore: how to adapt to it.

title: Housecalls of Another Sort
description: In Tuesdays Science Times, Milt Freudenheim describes some of the high-tech medical devices now used to monitor the elderly in their homes.

title: A Lesser-Known Work by Gilbert and Sullivan Tells a Tropical Tale
description: Its not hard to understand what would entice the New York Gilbert & Sullivan Players to stage Utopia, Limited, the penultimate collaboration between their namesake librettist and composer. The company regularly dusts off lesser-known works from the ingenious Gilbert and Sullivan canon. And this one, which on Sunday opened a season transplanted to Symphony Space because of renovations at the troupes usual home at City Center, in at least one respect seemed squarely of the moment.

title: Studio Will Take Another Stab at Buffy the Vampire Slayer
description: 9:52 p.m. | Updated

title: Critics' Picks: 'The Ice Storm'
description: A. O. Scott revisits Ang Lee's period film about the collapse of moral authority in a wealthy New York City suburb.

title: Irish Leaders Statement on Bailout and Elections After Feeble Street Protest
description: Updated | 5:39 p.m. In a brief live address on Monday evening, Brian Cowen, the leader, or taoiseach, of Irelands government announced that he would not heed calls for his immediate resignation but intends to fight to pass a new budget next month and then call a general election for early next year.

title: Postponing the Inevitable vs. Denying the Inevitable
description: The latest Frontline documentary comes with a blunt, no-one-was-aiming-for-lyricism title: Facing Death. The name and the accompanying promotional materials, with an image of a corpselike hand on a hospital bed, suggest a resurrection of the kind of tired and unwinnable debates that surrounded the case of Terri Schiavo. But the film, produced by Miri Navasky and Karen OConnor, who paid such elegant tribute to the grim subject of mortuary work in The Undertaking, ambitiously explores the complex questions that arise about extending life when a patient is not merely in a persistent vegetative state.

title: Splashed, but Not Drowned
description: The splash of scalding coffee was painful enough, but the real source of my anxiety was on the floor: My iPhone was soaking in a little puddle of java.

title: (Virtual) Same-Sex Adoption
description: There is one corner of one realm it seems  one frequented by the same age group that struggles with bullying and exclusion  where homosexuality is just another matter-of-fact option.

title: Hakeem Nicks Out 3 Weeks With Leg Injury
description: The pain is spreading for the Giants.

title: Flu: Bird Flu Falls Off the Radar, but Cases Show Its Still a Threat
description: In the wake of last years pandemic of H1N1 swine flu  which turned into far less of a global threat than had been feared  the world has largely forgotten about the H5N1 bird flu.

title: Banks Face Big Test in New Capital Rules
description: Once again, whats good for banks  and their shareholders  may not be so great for consumers. The Federal Reserves new stress tests, along with the new Basel III international rules on capital requirements, are aimed at ensuring that big banks are well capitalized and, in the United States, finally allowing them to raise dividends to shareholders.

title: Philip K. Dicks Masterpiece Years
description: POINT REYES STATION, Calif.  Half a century later, Anne R. Dick still remembers the sunny October day she met a clean-shaven 29-year-old Berkeley exile who had just moved to this rural enclave in west Marin County, thick with eucalyptus trees and brooding owls.

title: A Voice of Post-Traumatic Stress
description: Most people associate post-traumatic stress disorder with military service during wartime. But increasingly, therapists are reporting that the typical patient with P.T.S.D. has experienced trauma in everyday life, reports Karen Barrow in todays Science Times.

title: In Cybertherapy, Avatars Assist With Healing
description: OTTAWA  His talk was going just fine until some members of the audience became noticeably restless. A ripple of impatience passed through the several dozen seated listeners, and a few seemed suddenly annoyed; then two men started to talk to each other, ignoring him altogether.

title: More Bicycle Lanes
description: A look at the growth of New York Citys network of bike lanes over the past decade.

title: Mavericks Ainslie Tells the Short of It
description: Some hedge fund managers pen long, windy letters to their investors, musing about everything from the pernicious effects of quantitative easing (David Einhorns recent letter) to what America needs to do to lower unemployment: fix the renminbi-dollar misalignment (Paul Tudor Joness latest missive).

title: Some Artist Favorites for Violin and Piano
description: In recent years the violinist and violist Pinchas Zukerman has often seemed afflicted with what could be called celebrity coasting syndrome. But on Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall, Mr. Zukerman, who is also the music director of the National Arts Center Orchestra in Ottawa, seemed back in form, offering committed performances in a thoughtful partnership with the excellent pianist Yefim Bronfman.

title: Printed Memories
description: The studio is one big ice cream factory, exclaims Gaby Basora, the designer behind Tucker. Fabric and prints everywhere. Baby boys playing hide and seek under remnants.

title: Simple Gravy You Can Make Ahead
