description: There's no need to wait until the turkey is done in the oven. Melissa Clark, the author of the Good Appetite column, demonstrates how to make simple lumpless gravy that you can prepare anytime.

title: Video Games: Joysticks to the World (and Kinect)
description: Now that millions of moms and other nongamer types are hooked on Facebook diversions like FarmVille and iPhone apps like Angry Birds (not to mention the legions of office workers still clinging to Minesweeper and Solitaire), the average age of people who play video games appears to be firmly north of 30.

title: A Culture of Mathematics
description: Images of Babylonian mathematical tablets from an exhibition at New York Universitys Institute for the Study of the Ancient World.

title: A Vegetarian Thanksgiving, Even for Carnivores
description: No turkeys were harmed in the writing of this column.

title: Plan to Bring Ship to West Side Hits Snag
description: New York City might not be the next home port for the S.S. United States, a historic luxury liner, if a casino development plan unveiled Monday in Philadelphia comes to pass.

title: Higher Deductibles, Lower Spending
description: As more families find themselves enrolled in health plans with high deductibles, they are increasingly likely to delay or forgo medical care because of the out-of-pocket cost, a new study shows.

title: White Light: Is It Driven by the Soul or by Sales?
description: Over the last several weeks, Lincoln Center has presented the White Light Festival, billed as an exploration of the spiritual in music. (The last festival event is The Manganiyar Seduction, a musical work in the Indian classical and folk traditions, on Tuesday at the Rose Theater; lincolncenter.org.) The classical music critics and a reporter at The New York Times discussed the works, transcendence and the merits of the festival on ArtsBeat. Here are excerpts from their conversation; the full text is at nytimes.com/artsbeat.

title: Are Attractive People More Employable?
description: Are good-looking people more likely to get jobs? That depends whether youre talking about men or women, according to a new working paper. From the abstract:

title: An Exhibition That Gets to the (Square) Root of Sumerian Math
description: Papyrus, parchment, paper ... videotape, DVDs, Blu-ray discs  long after all these materials have crumbled to dust, the first recording medium of all, the cuneiform clay tablet of ancient Mesopotamia, may still endure.

title: Casting Balanchine the Way the Master Did
description: WASHINGTON  When George Balanchine was alive, one of the many layers of the Balanchine adventure was casting. Each week when New York City Ballet would announce who was dancing what, fans would discover how he wanted to extend this dancer in ways nobody else had imagined, or which new dancer he wanted to test with a fresh challenge.

title: Sour Notes for ABC
description: ABCs broadcast of the 38th Annual American Music Awards on Sunday night saw a steep decline in its ratings compared with a year ago. According to Nielsens estimates, an average of 11.7 million viewers tuned in to the show from 8 to 11, down from its 2009 audience of 14.2 million. ABC ranked third on the night, well behind the first-place NBC and its Sunday Night Football coverage of the New York Giants-Philadelphia Eagles game. Although final ratings were not available on Monday, the preliminary estimate for the game was roughly 25 million. CBS placed second over all, as 60 Minutes (19.5 million) got a boost from the networks afternoon football coverage. Fox was fourth.

title: Spy Photo of 2012 VW Beetle, One of Oprahs Favorite Things
description: Hear that? Its the sound of a room of men and women (mostly women) screaming and hyperventilating after Oprah Winfrey told her studio audience that each one of them would receive a new 2012 Volkswagen Beetle, a car that wont be released until next year.

title: Now Come the T.S.A. Jokes
description: WASHINGTON  Cant see London, Cant see France, unless we see your underpants.

title: Critics Picks Video: The Ice Storm
description: Our Puritan ancestors gave us Thanksgiving, says A. O. Scott in this weeks Critics Picks video. They also passed down a rich tradition of sin, damnation and guilt. These elements are present in Ang Lees drama The Ice Storm. The movie takes place on Thanksgiving weekend in 1973 and follows the intertwining lives and various infidelities of two families in a wealthy New York City suburb. While it is possible to look at these characters as a collection of sinners deserving of punishment, Mr. Scott sees the film a different way. Its about what it takes to live in a world where moral authority has collapsed, he says. Have you seen The Ice Storm? Please share your thoughts.

title: Cape Wind Takes a Step Forward
description: Massachusetts utility regulators on Monday approved a contract under which a utility will buy half the electricity produced by Cape Wind, the proposed wind farm to be built in Nantucket Sound off the coast of Cape Cod, bringing the project substantially closer to construction.

title: On the Fine Art of Restaurant Criticism
description: William Grimes, a former restaurant critic for The Times, offers an interesting perspective in response to my most recent letters column, Dining Out on Different Budgets.

title: Critics Choice: New CDs
description: NE-YO

title: An Exotic Predator Threatens the Keys
description: This video, shot in 2010, documents an earlier tournament intended to remove lionfish.

title: In M.V.P. Voting, Votto Makes Pujols Second Best
description: Joey Votto knew he had a superb season for the Cincinnati Reds, one worthy of the National Leagues Most Valuable Player award, but he said he did not check his statistics until it was over. Then he compared them with those of another slugging first baseman, Albert Pujols of the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Florida Keys Declare Open Season on the Invasive Lionfish
description: KEY WEST, Fla.  Crawling through turquoise murk on the ocean floor near Tea Table Key, Rob Pillus glances at a half dozen lobsters that twirl their antennae in the fast-moving current. Mr. Pillus, an avid spear fisherman, would normally stuff the crustaceans into his mesh bag for dinner, but today he is after more exotic quarry: an invasive species called the lionfish that threatens to wreak havoc on this ecologically sensitive marine system.

title: Google Docs and Microsoft? Word.
description: On TechCrunch today, Jason Kincaid reveals a new plug-in for Microsoft Office that allows users to sync up their work in the popular productivity suite with Googles cloud-based word processor and spreadsheet. Right now, the plug-in is only for corporate users of Google Docs, but expect a consumer version soon.

title: Global Puck: N.H.L. Cool to Canada-Russia Summit Series Reprise in 2012
description: N.H.L. Deputy Commissioner Bill Daly said Monday that the league would not back a 40th anniversary renewal of the historic Canada-Russia Summit Series in September 2012.

title: The Popes Words on Condoms
description: Excerpted from Light of the World: The Pope, The Church and The Signs Of The Times, an interview with Pope Benedict XVI and Peter Seewald. All rights St. Ignatius Press (2010).

title: 'The Break of Noon'
description: David Duchovny performs an excerpt from Neil LaBute's new play. (Video courtesy of the production)

title: Placenta Structure and Gestation Linked
description: Some mammals have a longer gestation period than others in part because of the structure of the mothers placenta, according to new research published in The American Naturalist.

title: Palin Rules Out Another Couric Interview
description: Sarah Palin has a message for Katie Couric, the CBS anchorwoman: Dont even bother asking.

title: Video: A First Look at Spider-Man
description: A video posted Monday on the Facebook page of the new Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark offers a glimpse of what to date has been one of the seasons biggest secrets: what does the show look like?

title: For Jets Fans Who Left Early, Regrets and Recriminations
description: It was utter euphoria for New York Jets fans after Mark Sanchez drove the team downfield with less than a minute remaining and pulled out a miraculous victory over the Houston Texans at New Meadowlands Stadium on Sunday.

title: Defenders of Earmarks Point to Urgent Needs That Would Not Be Met
description: ST. LOUIS  With their vote last week to support a moratorium on earmarks, House and Senate Republicans are taking aim at a popular target: the much-criticized system for distributing federal money that reflects politicians clout as much as the merits of projects in their districts.

title: The Price of a Smile
description: Dentist and orthodontists have embraced a new technology in dental radiology. But some experts are concerned about excessive radiation exposure among younger patients.

title: The Neediest Cases | Jovins Lin Dorestan
description: Mr. Dorestan was standing in the doorway of his home in Haiti when the earthquake struck on January 12, killing hundreds of thousands. He came uncomfortably close to being one of them.

title: Small Player on Wall Street Carves Out a Niche
description: The energy industrys love for shale gas has been in evidence in recent years. Companies like Exxon Mobil, Royal Dutch Shell and Chevron have poured billions of dollars into deals to give them access to acreage in the Marcellus Shale and other shale formations.

title: Growing a Forest, and Harvesting Jobs
description: IXTLN de JUREZ, Mexico  As an unforgiving midday sun bore down on the pine-forested mountains here, a half-dozen men perched across a steep hillside wrestled back mounds of weeds to uncover wisps of knee-high seedlings.

title: Lincoln Speaks
description: The sphinx kept his silence as long as he could, even after his election to the presidency was established beyond all doubt. But though he tried to maintain the semblance of a normal life  he was observed buying hair tonic at the drug store on Nov. 10  he was in the maw of history now. Every act, every word commanded attention as the storm clouds gathered.

title: In Sliver of Indonesia, Public Embrace of Judaism
description: MANADO, Indonesia  A new, 62-foot-tall menorah, possibly the worlds largest, rises from a mountain overlooking this Indonesian city, courtesy of the local government. Flags of Israel can be spotted on motorcycle taxi stands, one near a six-year-old synagogue that has received a face-lift, including a ceiling with a large Star of David, paid for by local officials.

title: Stampede in Cambodia Leaves Hundreds Dead
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  More than 300 people were killed and hundreds more were injured in a stampede at an annual water festival in Cambodia that the prime minister on Tuesday called the nations worst tragedy since the murderous Khmer Rouge regime more than three decades ago.

title: Popes Comments on Condoms Sow Confusion
description: ROME  In a papacy troubled by communications missteps, Pope Benedict XVIs unprecedented new book of interviews with a German journalist sought to clarify matters by going straight to the source.

title: Adviser Pleads Guilty in Pay-to-Play Pension Scheme
description: Hank Morris, a central player in a pay-to-play scheme involving the New York State pension fund, will return $19 million to the fund as part of a plea agreement approved in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Monday.

title: New Poll Suggests Shift in Public Views on T.S.A. Procedures
description: The White House has begun to push back on the notion that there is a massive backlash against the T.S.A.s new security procedures, citing a CBS News poll, released last week, which had shown 4 out of 5 Americans in favor of full-body screening machines, which the government refers to as advanced imaging technology.

title: New Trade Groups Focus Will Be Marijuana Industry
description: DENVER  It is being called the green rush. With more states moving to legalize medical marijuana, the business of growing and dispensing it is booming, even as much of the rest of the economy struggles.

title: Philip Hoffman, Fearless Surfing Pioneer, Dies at 80
description: Philip Hoffman, whose pioneering big-wave riding in Hawaii in the 1950s charted the way for surfing pilgrimages to Oahus North Shore from around the world, died on Nov. 10 in Mission Viejo, Calif. He was 80.

title: Do Governors Influence Presidential Elections?
description: The Republicans ability to pick up governorships this year has been discussed as a potential setback for President Obamas presumed 2012 campaign for re-election  the idea being that a states governor can use his or her own political operation to boost the chances of their partys presidential nominee.

title: For Harrahs I.P.O., Investors Are Wary
description: Conventional wisdom holds that investors have poor memories: they can be duped every few years with variations on the same financial trick. Refreshingly, the market for initial public offerings may be prove to be an exception. In whats shaping up as the year of the see-through public offering, or C3PO for short, a record number of companies look set to abort their market debuts as investors wise up.

title: Affirmative Action in South Africa
description: Celia Dugger reports on how affirmative action policy at the University of Cape Town has turned into a national debate on how to erase racial divides that linger 16 years after the end of apartheid.

title: Jon Miller Declines ESPNs Radio Offer
description: Jon Miller, whose contract as the voice of ESPNs Sunday Night Baseball was not renewed earlier this month, has declined ESPNs offer to continue to call baseball on ESPN Radio.

title: What to Expect in the Holiday Travel Chaos
description: THE day before Thanksgiving is usually the busiest air travel day of the year, as leisure fliers flood into the system and many business travelers wrap up road trips. Holiday periods always bring some uncertainty, especially if theres bad weather. But now, the new procedures at security checkpoints have added to the confusion. So I thought some tips for travel during the holiday period might be in order.

title: Israel Enacts Bill to Force Referendum on a Treaty
description: JERUSALEM  Israels right-leaning Parliament approved legislation late Monday that could hamper the leaderships ability to seal future peace deals with the Palestinians or Syria.

title: Campus That Apartheid Ruled Faces a Policy Rift
description: CAPE TOWN  The University of Cape Town was once a citadel of white privilege on the majestic slopes of Devils Peak. At the height of apartheid, it admitted few black or mixed-race students, and they were barred from campus dormitories, even forbidden to attend medical school postmortems on white corpses.

title: Medtronic to Buy the Rest of Ardian
description: Medtronic Inc., the heart device maker, said it would acquire Ardian, a closely held company developing a hypertension device that kills nerves near the kidney.

title: Qantas Returns A380 Planes to Use
description: Qantas, Australias largest carrier, said it will begin to return its Airbus A380 superjumbo jetliners to service this coming Saturday, 23 days after the blow-out of an engine on one of the planes forced an emergency landing in Singapore.

title: A Manager to Push the Mets in the Right Direction
description: Terry Collins was hot. This was 1998, when Collins was managing the Angels, a team with a grinders mentality that clawed for a division title all summer. The Angels had handily beaten the lowly Detroit Tigers one night, and Collins caught the highlights on cable. He did not like what he saw.

title: In Texas Baseball Bankruptcy Case, an Annoyed Judge
description: On July 9, D. Michael Lynn, the judge in the Texas Rangers bankruptcy, called the lawyers in the case to his chambers. He was acerbic, witty and caustic. But most of all he was frustrated.

title: Dont Agree With Verdict? Its Injustice!
description: Peter T. King, the Republican congressman from Long Island, and the Rev. Al Sharpton rarely land in the same paragraph, let alone on common ground. But those two quite different men seem to be of one mind when it comes to the American court system. Justice for them means getting the results they want. Anything else qualifies, by definition, as injustice.

title: Dentists Embrace New Device
description: The cone beam CT scanners popularity has grown in part from misinformation about its safety and efficacy.

title: A Safe Haven in Cartoon Confidants
description: For months, psychologists struggled to reach the eight year old boy in the burn unit of the Pediatric Hospital of Tacubaya, in Mexico City. He had been discovered in the basement of a house, tied to a water tank after being burned along the backs of both legs with a clothes iron by his uncle and aunt, who were later arrested. Every time an adult tried to talk about his abuse, the boy would turn away and repeat, No, no, no, no. One day, a therapist said to a colleague, Nothing is working. Lets try Dulas.

title: A Cheaper Plan at Netflix Offers Films for Online Only
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Netflix said Monday that it was introducing a subscription plan for customers who want to watch movies only online, underscoring yet another step away from its roots in DVD rentals by mail.

title: A New Leader Confronts Catholics Disaffection
description: Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan of New York, elected president of the nations Roman Catholic bishops last week, said Monday that the bishops faced the urgent task of stopping the huge exodus of Roman Catholics from the church of their birth.

title: City to Solicit Proposals on Bike Sharing
description: The Bloomberg administration is set to move ahead on Tuesday with plans to create a large-scale bike-sharing program that would make hundreds or even thousands of bicycles available for public use throughout New York City  a nimble, novel form of mass transit that has already become mainstream in cities like Washington and Paris.

title: Viewers May Be Willing to Watch More Ads Online. Lots More.
description: VIEWERS of television shows on the Web have grown accustomed to 15- and 30-second commercial breaks  a fraction of the time given for commercials on traditional TV. Would they accept TV-style ad loads?

title: Edwards and Holmes Are Making Headlines for the Right Reasons
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  A pair of starting wide receivers obtained with considerable risk have rewarded the Jets. Neither Santonio Holmes nor Braylon Edwards will win any Mr. Congeniality awards, but in terms of productivity, in terms of value, they are becoming what the Jets envisioned when they acquired them.

title: What Patients Might Want to Ask the Dentist About X-Rays
description: The Food and Drug Administration and other experts suggest asking the following questions in order to reduce radiation exposure:

title: Radiation Worries for Children in Dentists Chairs
description: Because children and adolescents are particularly vulnerable to radiation, doctors three years ago mounted a national campaign to protect them by reducing diagnostic radiation to only those levels seen as absolutely necessary.

title: Fed Adopts Political Tactics on Critics
description: WASHINGTON  Faced with unusually sharp ideological attacks after its latest bid to stimulate the economy, the Federal Reserve now faces a challenge far removed from the conduct of monetary policy: how to defend itself in a hyperpartisan environment without becoming overtly political.

title: F.B.I. Agents Raid 3 Hedge Fund Offices
description: 8:42 p.m. | Updated

title: In N.B.A. Union Chiefs View, a Lockout Is Imminent
description: An N.B.A. labor stoppage next summer is all but inevitable, and the players are preparing accordingly, the head of the players union said Monday.

title: J. Crew Nears a Sale to Chairman and Buyout Firms
description: 9:15 p.m. | Updated J. Crew, the clothier of choice for the likes of Michelle Obama, is near a deal to sell itself for about $2.8 billion to the buyout firms TPG Capital and Leonard Green & Partners, people with direct knowledge of the matter told DealBook on Monday.

title: Stampede Kills Hundreds in Cambodia
description: Thousands of people stampeded during a festival in the Cambodian capital, leaving hundreds dead and injured.

title: Radiation in the Dentist Chair
description: A new scanning device that emits significantly more radiation than conventional methods is gaining popularity among dentists despite the potential risks to young patients, an examination by The New York Times has found.

title: Loss of Nicks Is Another Hit to Giants Receiving Corps
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  At the start of the season, the Giants had more receivers than they knew what to do with. Now they are hosting tryouts to try to help compensate for the loss of their top target.

title: On the Economy, Some Credit Is Due
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pilgrims America
description: To the Editor:

title: College Costs, the Sequel
description: The questions readers put to my previous column on the supposed college cost crisis are best answered by economists. Accordingly, the editors and I have asked the economists whose book formed the basis of my remarks, Robert B. Archibald and David H. Feldman, to reply.  Stanley Fish

title: Memories of Bush v. Gore
description: To the Editor:

title: Deliberations Have Begun in Case Against DeLay
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Jurors began deliberating Monday in the money-laundering trial of Tom DeLay, the former House majority leader who was forced to resign five years ago after he was indicted here.

title: Industries in Decline
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dim View of Betting on Start-Ups
description: Theres too much money chasing too few deals.

title: Blocking Illegal Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports Agents Loans to Poor Players Pose Concerns
description: The company of Scott Boras, baseballs pre-eminent agent, provided tens of thousands of dollars in loans and payments to the families of poor Dominican teenage prospects, according to people with ties to Mr. Boras, raising questions about whether the company exploited the prospects and violated the rules of the Major League Baseball Players Association.

title: New Rules Tell Insurers: Spend More on Care
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration issued new federal rules on Monday that will require many health insurance companies to spend more on medical care and allocate less to profits, executive compensation, marketing and overhead expenses.

title: Pardon for Jim Morrison?
description: To the Editor:

title: Time to Revive Privacy Board to Protect Civil Liberties
description: To the Editor:

title: Taliban Leader in Secret Talks Was an Impostor
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  For months, the secret talks unfolding between Taliban and Afghan leaders to end the war appeared to be showing promise, if only because of the appearance of a certain insurgent leader at one end of the table: Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour, one of the most senior commanders in the Taliban movement.

title: At a Checkpoint, Terror Fears and Testy Travelers
description: BALTIMORE

title: Miracle on 33rd Street
description: MAYOR MICHAEL BLOOMBERG and other dignitaries took up ceremonial sledgehammers and knocked over a ceremonial wall of blocks. This was last month, across Eighth Avenue from Pennsylvania Station, and the little drama was meant to symbolize the beginning of its end. Behind them were the wide stairs and Corinthian colonnade of the Farley Post Office, the intended home of Moynihan Station, a scheme that the mayor said reflects the splendor and majesty of the city. Representative Jerrold Nadler called the future station a space worthy of New York. Secretary of Transportation Ray LaHood was there to oversee this ridiculous impeachment as well. Another step out of historys shadow, he said.

title: Irish Debt Crisis Forces Collapse of Government
description: DUBLIN  The Irish government faced imminent collapse on Monday, only a day after it signed off on a $100 billion bailout, setting the stage for a new election early next year and injecting the threat of political instability into a European financial crisis that already has markets on edge.

title: Group Offers Cuomo Ideas to Promote Openness
description: In cities and towns across New York and in hundreds of pages of policy documents, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo relished deconstructing the dysfunction of Albany during his campaign for governor.

title: Sin and Taxes
description: This has been a great month for conversation. The Bipartisan Policy Center and the chairmen of the fiscal commission released big plans for reducing debt and reforming government. This has set off a deluge of interesting commentary about how we should govern ourselves in the coming century.

title: Lawsuit Filed by Estate of Immigrant Killed on Long Island
description: The estate of the Ecuadorean immigrant who was stabbed to death in 2008 in a racially motivated attack in Patchogue, N.Y., filed a federal lawsuit on Monday, accusing Suffolk County, its Police Department and other agencies of violating his civil rights by failing to protect Hispanics in the same manner that they protected whites.

title: Lottery Numbers
From Last Days With Angels to First Day at Citi Field
description: In the hours before his last game as a manager of a major league baseball team on Sept. 2, 1999, Terry Collins walked the streets of downtown Cleveland, ruminating over a way to end the dispiriting losing streak that had engulfed his splintered team, and what he would say to his players about it.

title: State Didnt Vet Advisers on Chancellor Pick for Conflicts
description: As new revelations surfaced about extensive ties between Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and members of the panel evaluating his choice for schools chancellor, state officials acknowledged on Monday that they did not screen the panel members for conflicts of interest or connections to the Bloomberg administration before appointing them.

title: In California, Birth Defects Show No Link
description: SAN FRANCISCO  After an investigation, California officials said Monday that they could not determine a cause for nearly a dozen sometimes deadly birth defects in the small Central Valley town of Kettleman City, echoing preliminary findings the state announced earlier this year.

title: Tuesday: Makeup of a Double Date
description: Oh, pooh. Im not afraid of you. Why, youre nothing but a pack of cards. Alice

title: Essence of Pinterland, a Terrain Both Warm and Flecked With Ice
description: What a joy to find actors so at ease with the uneasiness of Harold Pinter. In Karen Kohlhaass first-rate productions of Pinters Collection and A Kind of Alaska for the Atlantic Theater Company, five performers quietly send off distress signals with a fluency that leaves you grinning at such stylishly realized discomfort.

title: Cameras Monitor Trespassing in Bus Lanes
description: Candid camera shots can create smiles. But for drivers who meander into bus lanes, new and unseen cameras are more likely to produce frowns.

title: Rules of the Duel: When Facing Near-Certain Death, Employ an Impostor
description: Silly voices should be used sparingly in the theater, as they generally are in other realms of entertainment. There is a reason why the men of Monty Python and the various gagmeisters from Saturday Night Live deploy their comedy in sketch-sized doses. After listening to the shrill, artificial falsetto employed by Jeremy Strong in the title role of the new play The Coward for more than two hours, my ears were starved for silence. I felt as if Id been listening to a musically challenged youngster in a long and unpromising first encounter with the flute.

title: Hes Born-Again but Still Obnoxious
description: The road to salvation is flat and narrow in The Break of Noon, Neil LaButes single-tone study of a life after a near-death experience. In this new work from the prolific and undeniably talented Mr. LaBute, which opened on Monday at the Lucille Lortel Theater, the sole survivor of an office massacre (played by David Duchovny) hears the voice of God amid the carnage.

title: Oil Spill Findings Released by Panel
description: WASHINGTON  The oil industry and the government were unprepared for a deepwater blowout and oil spill like the one this year in the Gulf of Mexico, leading to significant delays in capping the well and major environmental damage, the staff of the presidential spill commission concluded in two reports published on Monday.

title: A Red-Carpet Jeweler Is Charged With Fraud
description: A Duchess of Newcastle diamond brooch, circa 1887. A gilded album commissioned by Marie Antoinette in 1781. A carved ivory, enamel and jeweled case made at the request of Czar Nicholas II in 1893.

title: Losing a Leg, but Keeping His Drive to Succeed
description: HAVERSTRAW, N.Y.  Jovins Dorestan is lucky, and he knows it.

title: David Nolan, 66, Is Dead; Started Libertarian Party
description: David Nolan, whose opposition to the Vietnam War and President Richard M. Nixons wage and price controls impelled him in 1971 to join with a few friends to found the Libertarian Party to fight against government power, died Sunday in Tucson. He was 66.

title: 2010: The Year in Images
description: The optimism generated by a new face in the White House eroded through the year as wars, economic turmoil and natural disasters spread pain across the globe. There were bright moments, most notably the soccer World Cup in South Africa and the dramatic rescue of Chilean miners.

title: A Gift From Long Ago
description: It was a half-century ago this month that John F. Kennedy won the presidency in a thrilling and heart-stoppingly close election against Richard Nixon. Youd probably be surprised at the number of Americans who are clueless about when Kennedy ran: It was 1970, right? Wasnt it in the 40s, soon after the war? Or whom he ran against: Eisenhower?

title: Brian Marsden, Tracker of Comets, Dies at 73
description: Brian G. Marsden, who for decades was the go-to guy for thousands of stargazers when a comet or an asteroid would streak through the heavens  or, by his calculations, was supposed to  died Thursday in Burlington, Mass. He was 73 and lived in Lexington, Mass.

title: Islamic Center Seeks 9/11 Recovery Grants for Lower Manhattan
description: The directors of the planned Islamic community center and mosque near ground zero have applied for grants from an agency tasked with helping Lower Manhattan recover from the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. The request was for about $5 million, said a person with knowledge of the grant application.

title: Germany: Reichstag Closed To Most Tourists
description: One of Berlins most popular tourist sites, the glass and steel dome and terrace of the Reichstag parliament building, was closed indefinitely to most tourists on Monday as part of Germanys continued security crackdown, a parliamentary spokeswoman, Birgit Landskron, said. The decision to close those parts of the building, which offer stunning views of Berlin and attract thousands of visitors daily, was announced two days after the magazine Der Spiegel reported that Islamic radicals were planning a commando-style attack on the building similar to the 2008 raids in Mumbai, India, which left 170 people dead and 300 wounded. Interior Minister Thomas de Maiziere criticized the report as irresponsible speculation.

title: Rangers Del Zotto Struggles in Uneven Second Season
description: Rangers defenseman Michael Del Zotto was asked after a game this month how he had raised his plus-minus mark as high as plus-6 after a rookie season in which he had gone minus-20.

title: Mexico: Doctor Mistakenly Killed By Police Seeking Assassins
description: An ophthalmologist in the Pacific state of Colima was accidentally shot dead by the police at a roadblock set up as part of the search for the assassins of an ex-governor, Colimas governor said on Monday. He said officers shot Dr. Mario Eduardo Robles Gil, 56, when the doctor made suspicious moves in his S.U.V. at the roadblock near the home of former Gov. Silverio Cavazos Ceballos in the city of Colima. Mr. Cavazos was gunned down earlier Sunday by armed men who wounded the states economic development secretary.

title: Massachusetts: Buyer Found for Wind Farms Energy
description: After five months of arguments, state utility regulators have approved a contract under which a utility, National Grid, will buy half the output of Cape Wind, which if built would be the nations first offshore wind farm. The initial price is 18.7 cents a kilowatt-hour, far above prevailing rates, but the state said that reduced pollution and stimulation of the economy made the price a good deal. The price could be lowered if the project gets a federal loan guarantee and its own costs fall. The per-kilowatt-hour charge will increase by 3.5 percent a year, for 15 years, and the company has the option of a 10-year renewal.

title: Energy and the Lame Duck
description: This Congresss record on energy and environmental issues is shameful. The Senate, paralyzed by Republican opposition and indifferent Democratic leadership, could not muster the 60 votes to pass legislation to reduce carbon emissions. It even failed to respond to the gulf oil spill.

title: Treasury Hires Adviser on Sale of A.I.G. Stake
description: The Treasury Department has hired Greenhill & Company, a boutique investment bank, to advise it on the eventual sale of its holdings in the American International Group, according to a contract posted on the departments Web site.

title: The Power of the Hispanic Voter
description: Democrats were hurt in the midterm election by low turnouts or faltering support from voters who were young, black or female. But overwhelming support from Hispanic voters appears to have helped elect Democratic senators in Nevada, California, Colorado and possibly Washington State. Hispanic voters may have kept the Senate in Democratic hands.

title: Our Constitutional Court
description: The Supreme Court ruling in the Citizens United case ranks with the woeful economy, the Tea Party and other forces that brought about tumultuous change in the recent elections. The case may prove more significant in the evolution of the courts role in American law.

title: Count the Ballots
description: Here we are, two weeks after the elections and five races in New York State still are not settled. Lawyers and party officials are camped out in boards of elections, and accusations of malfunctioning machines and flawed absentee votes grow more heated by the minute. Its time to count the paper ballots. That is the best way to settle these disputes and get on with governing.

title: Bloggingheads: Is Palin for Real?
description: Jacob Weisberg, left, of Slate and Ann Althouse of the University of Wisconsin Law School debate Sarah Palin's cultural presence.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Hip Surgery Doesnt Keep Knicks Walsh From Work
description: Donnie Walsh has a new right hip, an improving gait and an unambiguous message for anyone doubting his stamina: He is not retiring or slowing down and plans to be with the Knicks for the foreseeable future.

title: Effort for Liberal Balance to G.O.P. Groups Begins
description: In what may prove a significant development for the 2012 elections, David Brock, a prominent Democratic political operative, says he has amassed $4 million in pledges over the last few weeks and is moving quickly to hire a staff to set up what he hopes will become a permanent liberal counterweight over the airwaves to the Republican-leaning outside groups that spent so heavily on this years midterm elections.

title: Childrens Benadryl Tablets Recalled
description: Johnson & Johnson, the maker of health care products, has recalled about four million packages of cherry- and grape-flavored Childrens Benadryl allergy tablets and about 800,000 bottles of junior-strength Motrin caplets.

title: Word of the Day | magnanimity
description: magnanimity \mag-n-ni-m-te\ noun

title: Photo Replay: Nov. 22
description: From the Asian Games to Monday Night Football, photographs from the day in sports.

title: Myanmars Leading Dissident Reunites With Youngest Son
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  Myanmars leading dissident, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, was reunited with her youngest son on Tuesday after a decade-long separation during which she said she never felt that they had been apart.

title: News Quiz | November 23, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Crisis Status in South Korea After North Shells Island
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The South Korean military went to crisis status on Tuesday and threatened military strikes after the North fired dozens of shells at a South Korean island, killing two of the Souths soldiers and setting off an exchange of fire in one of the most serious clashes between the two sides in decades.

title: Test Yourself | English, Nov. 23, 2010
description: Test your reading skills with todays question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the Times Op-Ed Seasonal Slippage.

title: Daily Lexeme: Caitiff
description: Todays word, in association with the tremendous Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Scans, Pat-Downs and Frisks
description: WHY has the Transportation Security Administration introduced a new screening process for airline passengers?

title: Investor Concern Persists in Euro Zone
description: PARIS  Investor concerns persisted Tuesday about the possible need for additional financial aid for countries in the euro area as Ireland prepared to release details of additional budget-cutting measures and Greeces restructuring efforts met with approval from international lenders.

title: Anglo Irish Bondholders Back Debt Swap
description: The Irish governments plan to shift at least some of the burden of Anglo Irish Banks bad debt to bondholders has moved forward as one group has approved a deal that would leave the notes it holds worth one-fifth of their face value.

title: South of the Border, Unsettling Views
description: Julio Mitchel, 68, would be the first to admit that he is a bit prickly and has not been adept at managing his photographic career. His name is not branded. He doesnt have a blog. There are no camera company sponsorships. And he doesnt have gallery or agency representation.

title: 29 New Zealand Miners Are Feared Dead
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand  A second huge blast in a New Zealand coal mine on Wednesday would have killed any miners who may have survived an explosion days earlier, the authorities said.

title: Church of England Opposes News Corp. on BSkyB
description: The Church of England says  it opposes the News Corporations plan to take control of the British satellite television provider BSkyB.

title: How Do You Make the Best of Thanksgiving?
description: Disastrously comical? Isnt that the norm for Thanksgiving? writes Florence Fabricant in her introduction to a Diners Journal blog post called Dear FloFab: My Brothers Girlfriend Hijacked Thanksgiving. What cooking disasters and other comical moments have you experienced on Thanksgiving?

title: Degrees of Separation From Climate Goals
description: In the weeks after the chaotic United Nations climate change summit meeting last December in Copenhagen, 140 nations endorsed the meetings goal of limiting the rise in global temperature from pre-industrial levels to 2 degrees Celsius or less in this century. Of those countries signing onto the so-called Copenhagen Accord, 85 made pledges to reduce their own greenhouse gas emissions and participate in international programs to help developing countries slow the rate of growth of their emissions.

title: Indias Next Steps: Looking for a Stable Public Sector
description: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

title: The Exceptional Receiving of Roddy White and Brandon Lloyd
description: Chase Stuart contributes to the Pro-Football-Reference.com blog and to Footballguys.com.

title: The Early Word: An Israel Comparison
description: From Todays Times:

title: At Paris Wine Salon, Swirling Small Producers
description: On the heels of the grape harvest, a special wine event will take oenophiles beyond their local liquor store to discover new vintages, regions and labels. The Salon des Vignerons Indpendants, which runs from Nov. 25 to 29 at Porte de Versailles (1 Place de la Porte de Versailles), will feature wines from over 1,000 small, independent producers.

title: Cashman Speaks Mind a Second Straight Day
description: For Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman, late November was not supposed to be devoted to an increasingly public standoff with the teams star shortstop, Derek Jeter.

title: Survivors of Stampede in Cambodia Recall Panic
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  Injured survivors lay on the floors of hospitals here Tuesday, and the dead were loaded into coffins after one of the worst stampedes in recent years killed at least 378 people at a holiday celebration.

title: Q&A: Saving Inkjet Cartridges
description: Q.

title: Obama Heads to Kokomo to Tout Auto Bailout and Stimulus
description: If there was one message that appeared not to get through during the midterm elections, it was President Obamas efforts to help the struggling economies of the industrial Midwest.

title: Doing the Math on a Groupon Deal
description: I have been reading with great interest (especially here) the stories of retailers sharing their experiences using Groupon. For those of you not familiar with Groupon, the company partners with local businesses to send a daily coupon e-blast to its members. The members who buy the coupon get 50 to 70 percent off on a product or service, and Groupon splits the proceeds with the retailer  usually leaving the retailer with about 20 to 25 cents on the dollar of retail value.

title: Ending Blackstone Talks, Dynegy Seeks New Buyer
description: 7:09 p.m. | Updated  Dynegy said on Tuesday that it would seek new takeover bids after it failed to gain enough shareholder support for a proposed $4.7 billion deal to sell itself to the Blackstone Group.

title: Exhausted Obama Supporter Loses Her Job
description: The political supporter who told President Obama that she was exhausted of defending him, becoming a voice for disappointed Americans this fall, has now become another casualty of the weak economy.

title: A Winning, Cautious Don Carlo at the Met
description: Though not without flaws, Verdis Don Carlo is the Hamlet of Italian opera. Every production of this profound and challenging work is a major venture for an opera company. The Metropolitan Opera has to be pleased, over all, with its new staging by the eminent English director Nicholas Hytner in his company debut, which opened on Monday and earned an enthusiastic ovation. No booing of the production team on this premiere night.

title: South Korean Television Shows Damage From Exchange of Fire With North
description: Updated | 7:34 p.m. As my colleague Mark McDonald reports, North and South Korea exchanged artillery fire on Tuesday after dozens of shells fired from the North struck a South Korean island near the countries disputed maritime border. Officials in South Korea said two of their soldiers were killed, and at least 18 people were wounded, including three civilians.

title: A Talent Burning Too Brightly, Too Young
description: London

title: Conflict and Heartache in the I.C.U.
description: Id be glad if a zillion people tuned in to watch Facing Death, an hour-long Frontline documentary airing on PBS Tuesday (at 9 or 10 p.m. in most places  check your local listings, or watch it online). I know that wont happen; so many people still turn away from the subject. But half a zillion would be good, too.

title: Namath Comments on Early Exits by  Jets Fans
description: In his weekly video recap, Joe Namath was sympathetic with Jets fans who left early and missed the last-minute rally against Houston on Sunday.

title: Numbers in the News
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: Numbers in the News
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: Daily Pill Greatly Lowers AIDS Risk, Study Finds
description: Healthy gay men who took an anti-AIDS pill every day were well protected against contracting H.I.V. in a study suggesting that a new weapon against the epidemic has emerged.

title: China Sets Tough Line in Climate Talks
description: BEIJING  Senior Chinese officials said on Tuesday that next weeks climate talks in Cancn, Mexico, would succeed only if the West agreed to transfer technology to developing countries like China and to take the lead in cutting emissions.

title: Rattner Rails Against Cuomo
description: 9:50 a.m. | Updated When Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York filed charges against the financier Steven L. Rattner last week related to a kickback scheme involving the states pension fund, no one expected Mr. Rattner to take it sitting down.

title: Wall Street Falls, Unsettled by Debt Crisis and Korea
description: Shares on Wall Street declined on Tuesday as heightened uncertainty over conflict in Asia and the debt crisis in Europe sent investors fleeing for safer assets.

title: Take a Lesson, Schwarznegger Says on Climate Change
description: California is just one of 50 states, but its economy, measured individually, is the eighth-biggest in the world, larger than that of Spain, Canada, Brazil, Russia, India or South Korea.

title: Saudi Prince Says He Owns 1% of G.M.
description: Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia is known for his big bets on companies like Citigroup. Now it seems he is swinging for the fences with General Motors.

title: Yale and Peru Have Tentative Deal on Disputed Antiquities
description: For the second time in three years Yale University and the government of Peru have reached a tentative agreement on the return of a large group of artifacts excavated in 1912 at Machu Picchu by a Yale explorer.

title: HAMPing Europes Periphery
description: The markets dont seem impressed by the Irish bailout  nor should they be. As I read it, European policy makers are still  still!  viewing the crisis as a confidence problem, not a fundamental problem.

title: Corporate Profits Were the Highest on Record Last Quarter
description: The nations workers may be struggling, but American companies just had their best quarter ever.

title: Nocturnalist | The Ghost Boots of Central Park
description: There they were, just as the man had said they would be, just as they were almost every night: two brown boots.

title: The Nutcracker Chronicles: Where the Coyotes Dance and the Bats Roam
description: Its too bad most of the nations Nutcrackers are all performed on the same few days of November and December; I could probably see a different one every day of the year. Id already researched a wide range of productions when planning my Nutcracker marathon, which began last week.

title: British Royal Wedding Set for April 29
description: LONDON  The date and location have been set: the wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton is to take place on April 29 at Westminster Abbey.

title: Sabotaging QE
description: When short-term interest rates are up against the zero lower bound, whatever power the Fed has to influence the economy comes largely from its ability to affect expectations. This is true even for Bernanke-style quantitative easing: you cant really push down longer-term yields unless the market believes that youre going to keep buying until the rates are where you want them. Its even more true when it comes to credibly raising expected rates of inflation.

title: Off the Menu: Fish Tag
description: The name of Michael Psilakiss new restaurant, Fish Tag, opening on Monday at 222 West 79th Street, refers to the little metal or plastic label attached to each whole fish as it is delivered to the restaurant. Only Mr. Psilakis does not have any whole fish, head and tail included, on his menu. He said that whole fish might be offered as a special.

title: New Yorkers Are Wary of Black as Schools Chief, Poll Finds
description: While Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has steadfastly pressed the case that Cathleen P. Black, a publishing executive, is qualified to become the citys next schools chancellor, many New Yorkers seem to strenuously disagree.

title: Portrait of the Author as a Very, Very, Very Young Man
description: When you were 9 years old you probably spent your time, what, wondering whether Superman could outrun the Flash and which typewriter keys to press in what order to produce naughty words? (O.K., thats what we were doing.) Meanwhile, at that same age, a budding author who would later come to be known by his full name, David Foster Wallace, was already exploring multiple identities and experimental forms of fiction.

title: We Three Things | Follow the Grid
description: Grids might be the musical scales of the visual arts, the underlying metric by which space is paced, measured and intuited. We are confronted by grids every day, in design, science and nature. No surprise, then, that grids are a support system and an inspiration to many artists and craftspeople.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: John Gutfreund tells TheStreet that authorities now take a laissez-faire, attitude toward criminal activity. Its not necessarily a rule of law and order as it once was. Now whatever you do you can get away with, he says.

title: Pushing Back Against Bike Lanes
description: Tuesday will be balmy, with highs in the 60s, but overcast with a good chance of showers.

title: J. Crew Shares Pop; Could Another Buyer Surface?
description: J. Crew shares are up significantly in premarket trading on Tuesday, following DealBooks scoop that the company is near a deal to sell itself to its chief executive and its former owner.

title: What a Search Warrant Means
description: The execution of search warrants at three hedge funds marks a significant escalation of the government inquiry into insider trading. By using a search warrant rather than a grand jury subpoena, prosecutors have signaled there is a good chance that securities laws were violated, and they want evidence gathered quickly and in a way that avoids the possibility that some material might be destroyed.

title: A Line in the Sea Divides the Two Koreas
description: Updated | 5:21 p.m. The residents of South Koreas Yeonpyeong Island, who rushed to air-raid shelters on Tuesday as they came under attack from North Korea, are well aware that they live on the edge of a geopolitical fault line. The island is in disputed waters claimed by both countries, just two miles from the so-called Northern Limit Line, a maritime border the North has never recognized, and only eight miles from the North Korean coast.

title: Is It Big Brother or Just an Algorithm?
description: A reader just wrote to complain. In Gmail, he wrote, I have attached photo, but then clicked Send without actually attaching anything. A message popped up: You wrote I have attached in your message, but there are no files attached. Send anyway?

title: Saudi Prince Says He Owns 1% of G.M.
description: From our colleagues at DealBook:

title: Municide
description: Term describing the economic (and political) death of a city.

title: Tuesday Reading: The Impact of Deductibles
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: F.D.I.C. Says Many Small Lenders Are Still at Risk
description: Even as the nations biggest banks have rapidly recovered, hundreds of small lenders remain at risk, according to the governments latest report card on the financial industry.

title: U.S. Home Sales Fell Sharply in October
description: Over the last few years, buyers have been lured into the troubled housing market by two unusual opportunities: cash subsidies in the form of government tax credits, and rock-bottom prices on millions of foreclosed homes.

title: Its Official: J. Crew to Sell Itself for $3 Billion
description: Millard S. Drexler, J. Crews chairman and chief executive.

title: Macys Can Give Thanks Its Parade Is on a Thursday
description: The citys parades have felt the sting of cost-cutting this year. In February, citing the need to trim overtime costs, the Police Department announced that parades would have to shorten their length by 25 percent. Organizers grudgingly obliged. The first-to-be-affected Tartan Day parade, celebrating the nations Scots, gamely trimmed its route by three blocks, to 10. The National Puerto Rican Day Parade lost seven blocks. The Gay Pride parade lost 16.

title: Art on the Scale of the Climate Challenge
description: With the next round of climate treaty negotiations nigh, Bill McKibbens 350.org is holding an art show gauged to the dimensions of a planet-scale issue, with many of the works visible from space.

title: Where a Bird Played Sax, Now Others Find Refuge
description: There are two signs in front of 151 Avenue B, a row house in the East Village facing Tompkins Square Park. One is a bronze plaque identifying the building as a former home of the jazz legend Charlie Parker, who lived in the ground-floor apartment from 1950 to 1954.

title: Tudor City, Manhattan, 7 A.M.
Mayors Flaunt Resolve in Advance of Cancn
description: With less than a week to go before global climate talks begin in Cancn, mayors from many of the worlds largest cities met in Mexico City over the weekend and declared, What about us?

title: Adventures in Communicating a New Alice
description: A look at some of the poster art concepts for the Broadway musical Wonderland.

title: On assignment with: Todd Heisler
description: Lens series "On Assignment" - journalist Mariana Vasconcellos follows staff photographer Todd Heisler on a tour of the East Side Access Project, underneath Grand Central.

title: Australia Drops Criminal Investigation of Paul Hogan
description: While it may not be the best time to be an actor who has lived in Australia  Russell Crowes latest movie just tanked, and lets not even get started on Mel Gibson  things are looking up somewhat for Paul Hogan. On Tuesday Australian officials said they had dropped a criminal investigation into the finances of Mr. Hogan, the Crocodile Dundee star who shaped 1980s-era Americas perception of the Land Down Under, The Associated Press reported.

title: Appetizers From Americas Test Kitchen
description: How many times does it take you to get a recipe just right?

title: An Art Show With Cosmic Dimensions
description: At the Dot Earth blog, Andy Revkin describes a series of art installations organized by the advocacy group 350.org to call attention to the global nature of the climate change challenge. Some of them are visible from space.

title: Behind the Poster: A Grown-Up Alice in Wonderland
description: Lewis Carrolls Alice gets an extreme makeover in the coming Broadway musical Wonderland. The show, which is to begin performances at the Marquis Theater on March 21, is about a frazzled childrens book writer named Alice who travels to a place called Wonderland in an attempt to revive her relationships with her estranged husband and distant daughter.

title: Theater Books
description: The ephemeral nature of theater makes it hard to give gifts that will endure even as long as a tie or a bottle of cologne, but this fall has seen a handful of new theater-related books that make fine gift choices for a footlight addict.

title: After J. Crew, Whos Next?
description: With the J. Crew sale to TPG Capital, Leonard Green & Partners and Millard S. Drexler now official, investors and analysts are already looking forward to the next possible buyout in the retail industry.

title: With Southwest, Microsoft Takes Photos on the Fly
description: In another example of its efforts to behave more like a consumer marketer, Microsoft is teaming up with Southwest Airlines for a holiday promotion that will take place in 26 airports around the country as well as online.

title: Week 12 in Fantasy Football: The Waiver Wire
description: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 12. Check back on Thursday for their weekly matchup analysis and their reader Q. & A. and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

title: Vikings and Titans Troubles Mount
description: Its time to look objectively at the two infernos blazing in the N.F.L. this week and decide: which one is uglier?

title: A Pattern of Aggression
description: TOKYO  North Koreas artillery bombardment of a South Korean island on Tuesday follows what analysts call a pattern of aggressive actions by the secretive government when it feels under stress or threatened.

title: Hockeys Code Uncovered
description: Every fan has heard about hockeys unwritten code  the set or traditional rules of engagement that determine when, who and how players are expected to fight. Most players follow it. A few dare to break it. But everyone knows about it.

title: Good Touch, Bad Touch, T.S.A. Touch
description: As parents of young children prepare to join the throngs at the nations airports on the upcoming Mother of All Travel Days, theres a new complication. In addition to remembering to pack snacks and toys and diapers, worrying about changing those diapers on a plane with no table in the restroom, and averting the glares of other travelers as your own toddler melts down, now there is another potential obstacle between you and your turkey  the new T.S.A. screening procedures.

title: Now Curating | Olivia Palermo for Boutiques.com
description: Last week, Google unveiled its e-commerce fashion venture, Boutiques.com, at the heart of which are online stores curated by celebrities and tastemakers. The Moment asked Olivia Palermo, whose boutique is already the second most followed, about her involvement with the much ballyhooed new site. The process was a ton of fun, Palermo said, but I actually spent hours playing with it. Its quite addictive! No stranger to online shopping, Palermo has mostly been browsing on net-a-porter.com and matchesfashion.com for Giambattista Valli, Christopher Kane and the French label Maje to feature in her boutique, her goal being to make scouring the racks easy and accessible for shoppers with similar taste. Whether its a Marchesa gown straight off the runway or a basic Topshop piece, everything is at your fingertips, she says. She appreciates Googles complex algorithms, which show browsers alternative items should the ones they want be unavailable or too pricey. The downside? Its accessible and free  until you start buying all the items you find.

title: Steven Rattner Dishes on the Chevrolet Volt
description: Steven L. Rattner, as President Obamas former auto bailout chief, worked with General Motors as it struggled to find its footing amid a bankruptcy reorganization in 2008. During that time, the company was also developing the Chevrolet Volt, an innovative plug-in hybrid car that is going on sale soon.

title: North and South Korea Clash
description: WHAT happened on Tuesday to make the South Korean military go to crisis status?WHAT did South Korean President Lee Myung-bak say would warrant strikes on North Koreas missile base?

title: Theater Tickets
description: Whether you like it or not, every gift received this season will be read as a coded message, even an innocuous crewneck sweater or that cute dancing-cats calendar. So why not take a more forthright route and let some masters of eloquence  playwrights and the accomplished actors who interpret them on Broadway  deliver your message for you? Here, some alternative ways of saying it with tickets.

title: Microsofts Kinect Spawns Hacks and Apps
description: 5:04 p.m.  | Corrected Mr. Hodgins first name from Roger to Robert.

title: Saving Is the New Cool in N.B.A.
description: N.B.A. players live in interesting times.

title: North Korea Relies on China, but Tends to Resist Its Guidance
description: BEIJING  North Koreas unending appetite for confrontation has left many wondering what its bottom line is, none more so than its supposed patron and big brother, China.

title: Asking for an Extra Discount
description: As holiday shopping season kicks into high gear, heres a reminder to always ask for a discount on top of whatever price an item or service is selling for.

title: A Doctor Goes to Cancer Camp
description: I recently had the opportunity to spend a week as the doctor at the Imus Ranch for Kids With Cancer in Ribera, N. M., founded by radio personality Don Imus and his wife, Deirdre Imus.

title: For One Day, the Chancellor Pick Was a Principal
description: She patrolled the halls of a Bronx public school, mediated a fight between students and went an entire workday without lunch. Though Cathleen P. Black, the chancellor-nominee of New York Citys public schools and the chairwoman of Hearst Magazines, has been criticized for her lack of experience in her new field, 10 years ago, she got something of an education in education  at least eight hours worth  at what is now Junior High School 125 Henry Hudson.

title: Visualizing Booming Profits
description: 5:12 p.m. | Updated

title: Gore Riles Corn Ethanol Lobby
description: Al Gore has apparently irked some members of the ethanol lobby by suggesting during a panel discussion at a green business conference on Monday that his earlier support for corn-based ethanol subsidies was a mistake.

title: University of Virginia Explains Its Return to Early-Admissions Arena
description: 5:14 p.m. | Updated See below for a statement from Harvard on its review of its decision three years ago to eliminate its non-binding early action program.

title: Share Your Airport Security Story
description: To say that the Transportation Security Administrations new scanners and pat-downs are controversial is an understatement. The complaints grew so loud and vociferous that even President Obama was forced to address the backlash from Lisbon on Saturday.

title: Developing 'Tangled'
description: Nathan Greno and Byron Howard, the co-directors of "Tangled," discuss the progression of one scene from its early sketches to its final look.

title: A Peek Into New Yorks Bike-Sharing Future
description: So what will the great New York City bike-sharing experiment look like?

title: Point (Backwards) and Shoot: Professor Says Camera Has Been Installed in His Head
description: Wafaa Bilal, a New York University photography professor who announced that he would have a camera inserted in the back of his head for an art project, issued a statement on Tuesday saying that the camera was successfully installed.

title: Tanks to Afghanistan: The More Things Change
description: The New York Times, Aug. 27, 1980Hundreds of Soviet tanks and other vehicles based near Kabul were reported rolling toward Sarobi.

title: Tanks to Afghanistan  Analysis
description: From Kabul to Kandahar, the Afghan countryside is dotted with the burned-out hulks of Soviet tanks. They are an obvious reminder of failed strategy, a nimble foe able to outfight big armored vehicles on rough terrain, and a lost war.

title: Nontraditional Black Friday Deals
description: It seems Black Friday and Cyber Monday deals increasingly arent just about televisions, toys and appliances. Here are a host of nontraditional items you may be able to find discounts on this weekend.

title: Erruh in duh Noo Yawk Times
description: OK, not sure its exactly an error. But I finally caught up with this piece on unlearning your New York accent, and it has people pronouncing water wattuh.

title: Another Longtime Democratic Congressman Concedes
description: In an upset in southern Texas, Blake Farenthold, a former radio show co-host with no experience in politics, has officially beaten Representative Solomon P. Ortiz, a Democrat who has held his seat in the 27th Congressional District, a Democratic stronghold, since 1982. Mr. Ortiz had demanded a recount after trailing Mr. Farenthold by roughly 800 votes on Election Day; a six-county recheck did not significantly alter the results. Mr. Farentholds victory brings the Republican gains in the House of Representatives to at least 62 seats.

title: The Twitterverse Reacts to Its Inability to Purchase Kanye West Tickets
description: Even faster than the spread of the news that Kanye West would be playing a hitherto-unannounced show at the intimate Bowery Ballroom in Manhattan on Tuesday night was the speed with which those tickets sold out on Tuesday afternoon.

title: TimesCast | November 23, 2010
description: North and South Korea exchange artillery fire; American  companies have their most profitable quarter ever; and News Corps invests in an iPad-only newspaper.

title: Fabulous Dead People | Mary Wells
description: While not every Motown aficionado thinks Chris Clark got all the obscurity she deserved, there is other glue that binds. No one disputes that romanticizing the eat-or-get-eaten early days of the labels artists was a great act of myth building. Diana Rosss father got so tired of hearing what a rough childhood she had in Detroits Brewster Projects, he told one of her biographers how nice the lawns and courtyards there were. The apartment we were in had three bedrooms, a full basement, a living room, kitchen and dinette, Fred Ross said. It wasnt so terrible at all, believe me.

title: Q&A: Spending the Holidays in Africa
description: Q.

title: Whats Baffling Is Nastiness of Jeter Talks
description: Hal Steinbrenner and Casey Close agree that Derek Jeter is a classic Yankee. So lets look to a classic movie for guidance on the mess that has become Jeters contract negotiations.

title: Fraud Inquiries Focus on Public-Works Hiring in New York
description: Two of the nations major construction companies are under federal investigation, suspected of defrauding government programs on some of the biggest public-works projects in and around New York City, according to people briefed on the inquiries.

title: Irish Leader Beats Back Early Move to Oust Him
description: DUBLIN  As fears about Irelands political stability rattled Europe on Tuesday, the party of Prime Minister Brian Cowen brushed aside calls for his immediate ouster on Tuesday and urged the government to approve wrenching budget- and deficit-reduction plans in order to secure a $100 billion bailout from the European Union and the International Monetary Fund.

title: Chic Peek | Nicki Minaj Interview
description: Ts Online Director Horacio Silva grills hip-hop sexplosion Nicki Minaj this morning about Pink Friday, her new CD and limited-edition MAC lipstick of the same name (and her feud with Lil Kim). Log on next Friday to read the interview and to watch an exclusive behind-the-scenes video of Minaj being photographed by the legendary Paul Jasmin for Ts Holiday 2010 issue.

title: Nevada Retains Highest Unemployment Rate
description: With a jobless rate north of 14 percent, Nevada had the highest state unemployment in the country once again last month, according to a Labor Department report.

title: After Condom Remarks, Vatican Confirms Shift
description: VATICAN CITY  Pope Benedict XVI clearly acknowledged on Tuesday that the need to prevent diseases like AIDS could outweigh the churchs long opposition to the use of condoms.

title: Condoms, Catholicism and Casuistry
description: Amid the ongoing furor surrounding Pope Benedicts comments about condom use in his latest book-length interview with Peter Seewald, its worth noting that this isnt the first time that Seewald and Benedict (then Joseph Ratzinger) have discussed the question of contraception. In their first interview, published as Salt of the Earth in 1996, Seewald asked Ratzinger if he understood why so many Christians find the Churchs teaching on birth control so incomprehensible. The then-cardinal replied as follows:

title: Yankees Wont Offer Arbitration to Jeter
description: The Yankees have decided not to offer salary arbitration to shortstop Derek Jeter, according to two people in baseball briefed on the matter. The two spoke on condition of anonymity because they did not want to jeopardize their access to sensitive information.

title: Partisan Rift Mires Product Safety Database Plan
description: For decades, the Consumer Product Safety Commission has gathered a trove of complaints about potentially dangerous products, from cribs to Chinese-made drywall. But for the most part, the information has not been made public because of a federal law that requires a manufacturers approval before it can be released.

title: Somalis in Twin Cities Shaken by Charges of Sex Trafficking
description: MINNEAPOLIS  When the girl now identified as Jane Doe 2 came under their control in 2006, at age 12, the Somali Outlaws and the Somali Mafia gangs set a firm rule: Their members could have sex with her for nothing; others had to pay with money or drugs.

title: A Baby Incubator Made From Car Parts
description: It is said that coffee, Coke and cigarettes can be found anywhere in the world. The presence of another C  car parts  recently led a team of industrial designers, doctors and rural heath care experts to conceive a device that could significantly lower infant mortality rates in developing nations.

title: Burris May Join the Chicago Mayor Mix
description: CHICAGO  There may be an unlikely addition to the long list of people who wish to replace Mayor Richard M. Daley, who has ruled this city for two decades. Supporters of Roland W. Burris, who is packing up his United States Senate office this week to come home to Chicago, have filed the necessary paperwork for him to seek the citys top job.

title: Cancun, Congress and Hard Climate Facts
description: In a news conference in Washington on Monday, Todd Stern, the Obama administrations lead negotiator in talks aimed at a new climate treaty, provided some insights into issues and (limited) opportunities that will shape the next round of negotiations, which begins in Cancun, Mexico, at the end of the month. (I learned about the briefing through the Earth Journalism Network, which you can follow on Twitter.)

title: Chancellor Nominee Has Sold Her Connecticut Home
description: As Cathleen P. Black endures scrutiny of her proposed appointment to become New York Citys next schools chancellor, she has one less house to escape from the pressures of her appointment this holiday weekend.

title: Collins Begins Job With a Nod to Leyland
description: Terry Collins introduced himself as the Mets 20th manager on Tuesday by saying, Im not the evil devil that people made me out to be. The Mets and their fans will tolerate a dark side if Collins is the man to reverse the franchises steep decline since it was one victory from the World Series in 2006.

title: American Speech: The Language of Traffic Policeman (1962)
description: by Don Dempsey, San Diego State College

title: Report: Banks Selling Off More Troubled Assets
description: Banks across the country are increasingly unloading toxic investments as stronger capital levels allow the institutions to clear their books, according to a report issued Tuesday.

title: Fed Debated a Target for Inflation
description: WASHINGTON  Nearly three weeks before they announced a $600 billion effort to shore up the economy, Federal Reserve officials debated whether to adopt formal targets for inflation and long-term interest rates, and whether the Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, should hold occasional press briefings.

title: Police Arrest Suspects in Plot Against Belgium
description: BRUSSELS  In a series of early morning raids, the police in three European countries arrested 11 people on Tuesday, saying that some were part of an international jihadist group planning a terrorist attack in Belgium and that others were members of a Chechen group.

title: USA Network Extends Tolerance Campaign
description: The cable channel USA Network is sharing details of how it plans to extend Characters Unite, a public service campaign that seeks to promote tolerance and respect while fighting discrimination.

title: Adrien Brody Prevails in Horror-Film Lawsuit
description: Not coming soon to a theater or video store near you, by order of a federal court: the Dario Argento horror movie Giallo, which one of its stars, Adrien Brody, has successfully blocked from distribution or sale in the United States, The Associated Press reported.

title: Pictures of the Day: Cambodia and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Cambodia, South Korea and Algeria.

title: Airgas Gets January Meeting Invalidated
description: The Delaware Supreme Court unanimously reversed a lower court holding on Tuesday that Airgas shareholders had properly amended their bylaws to have the next annual meeting on Jan. 15.

title: The M.V.P. and the Missing Month
description: As Ben Shpigel of The Times reports, Josh Hamilton of the Texas Rangers collected 22 of 28 first-place votes in balloting announced Tuesday to win the American League Most Valuable Player award, beating Miguel Cabrera of Detroit, who received five, by 96 points. Robinson Cano of the Yankees finished third, and Torontos Jose Bautista, who earned the other first-place vote, finished fourth.

title: Monthly Record Seen for Chinese Coal Imports
description: After my Monday article on the striking growth of coal exports to China and the implications for greenhouse gas emissions, I heard from Commodore Research and Consultancy, a New York-based firm that tracks the flow of coal to China on a week-by-week basis.

title: Babies on Airlines: Safety Seats Are Safer Than a Lap
description: SHOULD babies be buckled into a safety seat on airplanes instead of sitting in their parents laps?

title: General Greenes Morgenstern to Open Goat Town in the East Village
description: Nicholas Morgenstern, who just sold his interest in the General Greene in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, to his partner, will open Goat Town on Dec. 2 with Joel Hough, a former chef de cuisine at Cookshop. The restaurant will move into the space that had been Butcher Bay and Seymour Burton in the East Village.

title: What Were Reading
description: Chowhound: A lively thread, started by a home cook facing a 35-pound turkey.  Julia Moskin

title: No Bomb Found at Boston Airport After Evacuation
description: Bomb-sniffing dogs alerted authorities to a suspicious package on Tuesday in the Delta Cargo building at Boston Logan International Airport, forcing the evacuation of the building, airport officials said.

title: S Is for Self-Promoter: Cookie Monster Wants to Host Saturday Night Live
description: If Saturday Night Live can extend a hosting invitation to Scarlett Johansson  who didnt even have a new project to promote on her most recent go-round  then why not Cookie Monster, who is out there busting his blue fur on Sesame Street five days a week? In this latest video from Sesame Workshop (which we were pointed to by Mashable.com), that lovably greedy Muppet makes his best case for why he deserves the nod, sending up S.N.L. segments like MacGruber and Weekend Update, and giving a musical performance in the guise of Monster Gaga. Most shrewdly, Cookie Monster also remembers to thank the S.N.L executive producer Lorne Michaels in his closing credits.

title: Your Worst New York Apartments, Remembered Fondly
description: Two weeks ago, Constance Rosenblum wrote about several 20-something New Yorkers who were struggling to live comfortably in the citys rental market and asked readers to share their stories and photos of terrible New York apartments.

title: Corporate Profits Hit Record High
description: New numbers from the U.S. Commerce Department show record-breaking corporate profits this quarter.

title: Obama, in Indiana, Says Jobs Policy Worked
description: KOKOMO, Ind.President Obama came to this manufacturing town in the Midwest on Tuesday to say that his jobs agenda and economic policies were putting the economy on the right track.

title: Deal for J. Crew Allows It to Go Shopping
description: J. Crew is on sale for the holidays.

title: What Really Happened? Comparing Stories of the First Thanksgiving
description: Overview | Why are there so many different interpretations of what happened on the first Thanksgiving? What values do the various versions reflect? In this lesson, students will examine different versions of the story of the first Thanksgiving, evaluate the evidence that supports each version and discuss why the history of Thanksgiving is so contentious.

title: Aggrieved Fliers Ask, What Now?
description: As if air travel could get any worse.

title: U.S. Firm in Support of South Korea
description: WASHINGTON  In response to the artillery exchange between North and South Korea, the Pentagon on Tuesday stuck closely to a carefully calibrated diplomatic script offered overnight by the White House.

title: Theres Sweeps Week, and Then Theres Palin Week
description: For the blossoming Sarah Palin media empire, this week is the busiest to date.

title: Beatles Sales Strong, But Not Blockbuster, So Far
description: The Beatles on iTunes are a hit. Sort of.

title: A Steep Drop in Ratings for Sarah Palins Alaska
description: As Sarah Palin prepared to start a book tour Tuesday for her next best-seller, America by Heart, there was sobering news about one of her other products, a reality show called Sarah Palins Alaska.

title: Irelands Debt to Foreign Banks Is Still Unknown
description: Ireland is deeply in debt to British and German banks, but just how much is a mystery. Is it hundreds of billions, as official figures suggest? Or are the sums more modest, as many banks insist?

title: Salazar Aims to Streamline Offshore Wind
description: Secretary of the Interior Ken Salazar announced a broad-based initiative on Tuesday aimed at accelerating the development of offshore wind power projects on the Outer Continental Shelf along the nations Atlantic coast.

title: Hamilton Named M.V.P. Of the American League
description: Josh Hamilton missed 25 of the Texas Rangers final 30 games because of two broken ribs. His absence during the stretch run barely mattered to voters from the Baseball Writers Association of America, who followed a forceful precedent set last year with Joe Mauer of Minnesota, Hamiltons predecessor as the American Leagues most valuable player.

title: 'Metamorphosis'
description: A scene from a reimagining of the Kafka novel from Vesturport Theater of Reykjavik and the Lyric Hammersmith of London. (Video courtesy of the production)

title: Holiday Party Treats
description: A collection of appetizers that can be prepared in 20 minutes or less. Recipes by Mark Bittman.

title: The Latest on the White House Staff Shuffle
description: President Obamas top political advisers are planning an earlier-than-expected swap even as the White House moves to reshape the administrations economic team.

title: A Luxury Leader Shies From an Unwelcome Suitor
