description: PARIS  In the world of luxury brands, Herms International has cultivated an image of purity by remaining true to its roots, shunning the mass production and outsourcing that many rivals have employed to improve profitability.

title: Using Public Spaces as a Potty
description: As the mother of two sons, I have been grateful more than once over the years for the things that are easier about boys.

title: Pictures of the Day: Cambodia and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Cambodia, South Korea and Algeria.

title: Analyst Tells Why He Rebuffed the F.B.I.
description: One of the figures in the governments widening investigation of suspected insider trading discusses how he was visited by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. He says he refused to cooperate in the investigation, and he asserts that as a result of having to disclose his involvement, his business has been destroyed.

title: Ex-Chief of Comverse to Forfeit Nearly $48 Million
description: 7:51 p.m. | Updated  Jacob Alexander, the one-time chief of a telecommunications software maker who fled to Namibia to avoid charges related to stock option backdating, has agreed to forfeit nearly $48 million to settle a civil action by federal prosecutors.

title: Because the Fat Lady Has to Eat
description: LINCOLN RISTORANTE is a large and glittery Italian restaurant that opened this fall under a swooping grass roof on the campus of Lincoln Center at a reported cost of $20 million, under the direction of the chef Jonathan Benno and his partners, the Patina Restaurant Group.

title: Reviewing Lincoln Ristorante
description: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

title: Krakatau Eruption From Space
description: NASA has released a photograph taken by its Earth Observing-1 satellite of the ongoing eruption at Anak Krakatau, one of many active Indonesian volcanoes, but one of particular interest because of its explosive history.

title: 'Don Carlo'
description: Marina Poplavskaya and Roberto Alagna in an excerpt from Verdi's opera. (Video courtesy of the Metropolitan Opera)

title: Unwelcome Spotlight Follows Tennessee Coach
description: Tennessee came to Manhattan this week hoping to alter the narrative of negativity surrounding Coach Bruce Pearl, shifting the focus to the Volunteers play on the court, not their issues off it.

title: Tackling Mini-Med Policies
description: The recent decision by the Obama administration to allow health insurance companies to continue to sell so-called mini-med policies, those plans that sharply limit coverage, remains controversial. The plans, which often cap benefits at just a few thousand dollars a year, do not comply with some of the new rules under the federal health care law.

title: Eviction of Palestinian Family, After a Legal Battle, Underlines Tensions Over Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli police officers evicted a Palestinian family from their home in a predominantly Arab neighborhood of East Jerusalem on Tuesday morning, and a group of Jewish settlers moved into the property at night.

title: U.N. Reports Decrease in New H.I.V. Infections
description: Fewer people are being infected with the virus that causes AIDS than at the epidemics peak, but progress against the disease is still halting and fragile, the United Nations AIDS-fighting agency reported Tuesday.

title: Dwight Garners Top 10 Books of 2010
description: THE BEST OF IT: NEW AND SELECTED POEMS by Kay Ryan. Kay Ryans poems are as slim as runway models, so tiny you could almost make them Twitter messages. They are also, as it happens, riddled with heartbreak and loss, and possess an essential gawkiness that, despite their wit, draws you close. Ms. Ryans poems are, in 2010, about as good as American poetry gets. (Grove, $24)

title: Michiko Kakutanis Top 10 Books of 2010
description: LIFE by Keith Richards with James Fox. Written with uncommon candor, eloquence and humor, this electrifying memoir channels its authors love of music, even as it creates an indelible portrait of the era when rock n roll came of age. Its a book that does a high-def, high-velocity job of conjuring the past, be it the authors small-town childhood or the madness that was life on the road with the Rolling Stones  a book in which Mr. Richards has magically translated the fierce emotion of his guitar playing to the page. (Little, Brown & Company, $29.99)

title: Janet Maslins Top 10 Books of 2010
description: THE IMPERFECTIONISTS by Tom Rachman. This debut novel by a former journalist is a splendid original, the hilarious yet wrenching half-century story of a newspapers rise and fall. But this book is bigger than the life cycle of any one profession. Mr. Rachman structures his story so wittily and unpredictably that figuring out where its headed is half the fun. (Dial Press, $25)

title: Choosing Favorites From the Books of The Times
description: We three daily book critics for The New York Times dont make 10-best lists at the end of each year. Instead we make lists of favorites, and selecting them is harder than it sounds. Theyre about gut feelings. Brass tacks. Guilty pleasures. What each of us might actually send, lend or recommend to a friend.

title: Art and Commerce
description: For those not in the market for a million-dollar Warhol, theres Exhibition A, a new online art platform offering limited edition pieces by big-name artists  all in a nicely priced range from $100 to $500. Each week, the Web sites creators, Bill Powers, Cynthia Rowley, Laura Martin and Gabby Munoz, will offer new editions of work from the likes of Terence Koh, Richard Phillips, Geoff McFetridge and Rene Ricard. While some of the artists will offer a set number of signed works, others will offer open editions for a limited amount of time (usually between two and four weeks). Though the flash sales require budding art enthusiasts to think quickly on their feet, it allows people new to collecting a point of entry that isnt super scary on the financial side, Powers said.

title: Apple Computer Sells for $213,600 at Auction
description: This month, I wrote about an Apple-1 computer that was set to be auctioned for $150,000 by the auctioneer Christies. The bidding is now closed, and the computer that debuted in 1976, for $666.66, built by Steven P. Jobs and Steve Wozniak, Apples co-founders, sold for $213,600.

title: Hanukkah Recipes
description: Recipes for potato latkes, babka, jelly doughnuts and other holiday classics.

title: Pentagon Reassigns 2 Officials in Mix-Up Over Confidential Tanker Data
description: The top Air Force general said Tuesday that he had reassigned two officials who had mistakenly sent confidential data to the companies bidding for a $35 billion tanker contract.

title: Republican Senator Says Arms Treaty Isnt Tough Enough
description: 6:55 p.m. | Updated The top Republican on the Senate intelligence committee said Tuesday that he opposes ratification of a new arms control treaty with Russia because he considers its verification measures inadequate, dealing a blow to President Obamas chances of winning approval this year.

title: The Energy Chain
description: James McMullan demonstrates how to see relationships between parts rather than just pieces of the body. Video by Drew Beebe.

title: In Insider Case, the Odd Couple Wont Meet
description: 7:43 a.m. | Updated Next Tuesday, the Franklin & Marshall College alumni association will hold a discussion at the Waldorf Astoria hotel on Park Avenue entitled American Finance: Where Do We Go From Here?

title: CNBC: Interview with John Kinnucan
description: The founder of Broadband Research LLC, John Kinnucan, is one of the figures in the series of ongoing inquiries into insider trading. He spoke to CNBC's "The Strategy Session" about why F.B.I. agents approached him to cooperate in the investigation, and why he turned them down.

title: Back to the Castle, Where Its All About the Hair
description: To watch Tangled, in three dimensions or two, is like entering a familiar old neighborhood that has been tastefully and thoroughly renovated. Not gentrified, exactly, and certainly not razed, but modernized.

title: A Brooklyn Civics Lesson, Offered in Word and Song
description: As subjects for musical comedy go, it would be hard to fathom anything less promising than the legal intricacies of the concept of eminent domain. Or, for that matter, the socioeconomic diversity of the crazy quilt of Brooklyn neighborhoods. The great Stephen Sondheim himself might find it tricky work to make lyrical magic of the relationships among the various civic entities charged with approving land-use deals in New York City.

title: 'In the Footprint'
description: Photos from the new show by the Civilians.

title: Tonight Show Says It Will Credit Bloggers for Taylor Swift Montage
description: When Rich Juzwiak saw a series of video clips that Jay Leno played for Taylor Swift on Mondays broadcast of The Tonight Show, showing the country star reacting with similar expressions of surprise to a series of awards-show victories, he knew it looked more than familiar: he argued on his blog that the Tonight Show segment was taken directly from a similar Web video he made with a colleague. And now NBC says it will acknowledge the work of Mr. Juzwiak and his co-worker on Tuesdays Tonight Show.

title: A News Corp. Newspaper, Minus the Paper
description: Related: A News Corp. Newspaper, but Not in Print

title: Charlie Rose Show: Rattner Blasts Cuomo
description: Troubled financier Steve Rattner criticized New York Attorney General Andrew Cuomo's lawsuit, saying he had no evidence beyond what the Securities and Exchange Commission had already presented.

title: Wall Street Regains Its Swagger
description: Two years after the financial crisis, the moneyed elite of finance finally feel they can exhale. There are signs that wallets are beginning to open up, DealBook reports.

title: Collins Officially in Race to Head R.N.C.
description: Gentry Collins, the former Republican National Committee official who recently blasted Michael Steeles leadership as chairman, announced in an e-mail today that he will seek Mr. Steeles job.

title: Know What to Expect Before Your Trip
description: Traveling during the holidays this year can mean long lines snaking through security checkpoints, delayed flights and airport parking lots with no space to leave the car.

title: N.H.T.S.A. Opens Audit of Rental Car Repairs
description: Citing troubling reports of injuries and deaths in rental cars, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has begun investigating whether millions of rental cars are being fixed when they are recalled for safety problems.

title: Artifacts | Ghost Dance
description: People in the art world love an off-site exhibition. A decrepit theater, an abandoned warehouse, an old church, a darkened cave  anyplace that isnt a white-cube gallery  only adds to their adventure in art, and the more underground it is the better. Try six feet under.

title: Education Chief Raises Doubts on Pick by Bloomberg
description: The candidacy of Cathleen P. Black, Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs choice to be chancellor of the New York City schools, was in jeopardy on Tuesday as both a panel weighing her credentials and the state official who will determine her fate expressed deep doubts about her readiness for the job.

title: Video: Developing Tangled
description: For the 50th animated film from Walt Disney Pictures the filmmakers made the transition from hand-drawn animation to 3-D CG animation, while keeping the traditional look and feel of a Disney movie. Here, the directors Nathan Greno and Byron Howard narrate a look at the process of bringing one scene from the film to life. Read more about the journey of Tangled to the big screen.

title: Ai Fiori Is Set to Open on Monday
description: On Monday, Michael White, this seasons energizer bunny, opens Ai Fiori, his grand Italian restaurant with flavors of the Riviera.

title: For Women Amid Waves, Shared Fears and Rhythm
description: Bright, appealing dance is the signature of the Alpha Omega Theatrical Dance Company, which has existed for an impressive 38 years. It is directed now by Enrique Cruz DeJesus, a former member of the Eleo Pomare Dance Company and the choreographer of two pieces on Sundays nights program at the Manhattan Movement & Arts Center.

title: Pregame Huddle: Defining Week in B.C.S.
description: The annual Iron Bowl between Auburn and Alabama is one of the showdowns this week that will shape the B.C.S. rankings.

title: The Palins Ensure They Stay in the News
description: For the booming Sarah Palin media empire, this week is the busiest to date.

title: Report Suggests Problems With Irans Nuclear Effort
description: Atomic inspectors reported Tuesday that Iran mysteriously stopped feeding uranium into thousands of centrifuges at its main enrichment plant this month, and independent experts suggested that the computer worm suspected of being aimed at Irans nuclear program had caused the spinning machines to break down.

title: Muslim Troupe Arrives With Splash and Age-Old Ecumenical Traditions
description: Over the course of the White Light Festival at Lincoln Center, the notion of music as a conduit to spirituality has taken a variety of forms: individual contemplation, communal praise, the physical discipline of dance, a rock stars beatific charisma. With The Manganiyar Seduction, which arrived belatedly at the Rose Theater on Monday night after a visa-related delay, came still another facet of spirituality: communion with God achieved in a manner embracing the sensual and the ecstatic.

title: London Underground | Art Meets Fashion
description: Just when you dont think you cant visit one more pop-up store, along comes one that is not only inspired, but relevant, too. House of Voltaire, in the heart of Mayfair, is a temporary store that was opened by the South London contemporary arts space Studio Voltaire to finance its artist program and education work.

title: Iran Lawmakers Complain About Ahmadinejad
description: TEHRAN  Iranian Parliament members recently sent a letter detailing a long list of complaints against President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad to Irans powerful Guardian Council, Iranian news media have reported, marking a new phase in an effort by traditional conservatives to rein in the administration and reassert the powers of Irans legislative body.

title: A Strong Showing for Dancing With the Stars
description: While the Palin brand lost some ratings luster on TLC on Sunday night with a stark decline in viewers for Sarah Palins Alaska, it continued to be a strong draw Monday night on ABC as a crowd that even surpassed football fans turned up to watch the first half of the Dancing With the Stars finale.

title: Privacy Groups Fault Online Health Sites for Sharing User Data With Marketers
description: QualityHealth is a popular health Web site with more than 20 million registered users that offers online medical information and e-mail newsletters on a variety of topics, including diabetes, allergies, asthma and arthritis.

title: Small-Town Girl Trades Her Navet for Lingerie
description: The old bump and grind receives a squeaky-clean workout in Burlesque, a backstage tease-o-rama about life in and out of corsets and garters. Sparkly and smiley and thoroughly goofy (sleepy and dopey make appearances too), the story turns on an Iowan refugee for whom the Big Time means doing the hoochie-coochie in a Los Angeles club. There, where the dancers are dollies with Pilates physiques, the mistress of ceremonies should be Alan Cumming (who shows up now and again, giggling on the sidelines), but turns out to be Cher, trying her darnedest to play older and wiser but without, you know, the wrinkles and gray.

title: SAP Ordered to Pay Oracle $1.3 Billion
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A clash of technology titans and two of the most powerful executives in Silicon Valley ended on Tuesday with a $1.3 billion federal jury award against SAP for stealing software from Oracle to try to woo away customers.

title: Spider-Man Starts to Emerge From Secrecy
description: Nine years in the making, the moment came on Saturday to try running through the first act of the new musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark without stopping. As the band struck up an ominous tune that wailed like an ambulance siren, the enormous stage curtain rose to reveal a young woman dangling under a mock-up of the Brooklyn Bridge. Above her appeared a masked man, clad in skin-hugging tights, red and blue and all-American.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: The Chancellors Official Job Description: What a Difference 8 Years Make
description: Last week, in asking the state education commission to give Cathleen P. Black a waiver from the state law requiring that school district leaders have certain education credentials and experience, the Bloomberg administration had to file a description of the chancellors job she has been tapped to fill. City Room compared that job description, basically a list of bullet points, to the one City Hall submitted in 2002, when it asked for a similar waiver for Joel I. Klein.

title: Gaining an Edge in Female Rap Race
description: Its virtually impossible to think of Kesha as anything other than a star manqu. At the American Music Awards on Sunday night, her affect was a lot of Lady Gaga, a little bit of Rihanna, maybe some Lita Ford. Her  performance of Take It Off and We R Who We R was Daft Punk by way of Mad Max.

title: Dance-Struck Little Girls: Run! Run in Horror!
description: Come and meet these dancing feet. If you dare.

title: 'The Red Shoes'
description: Photos from the show by the Kneehigh Theater Company.

title: Don Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera
description: Photographs from the new staging of Verdis opera, directed by Nicholas Hytner.

title: A Young Viagra Salesman Sees Lust Turn Into Love
description: Since most romantic comedies take place in a perky, generic present, you may be surprised to see a note in the opening titles informing you that the action in Love & Other Drugs starts in 1996. Why so specific? Is there some world-historical event looming on the horizon that will change the characters lives forever? Or does the director, Edward Zwick, simply want to evoke a bygone-but-not-too-distant era when a young person could have a lot of fun and make a lot of money without worrying too much about whatever it is young people nowadays worry about (war, terrorism, recession, Facebook)?

title: Power Struggles and Riddles, in Romance and Political Intrigue
description: The name of the Albanian novelist Ismail Kadare regularly comes up at Nobel Prize time, and he is still a good bet to win it one of these days. He writes in a language that is not English. He comes from a country that most of us know next to nothing about, where he was oppressed not just by a run-of-the-mill totalitarian but by the bizarre and paranoid Enver Hoxha. He is fluent in the styles of modernism and postmodernism both. And, an unlooked-for bonus, he is seemingly incapable of writing a book that fails to be interesting.

title: Innocent Man, Releasing His Inner Mime
description: IT doesnt get more gee-whiz wholesome than Steven Banks. Boyish, middle-aged and suburban, he married early, swore off alcohol and drugs, and works as a writer for SpongeBob SquarePants. If thats not vanilla enough, his e-mail address includes the name of a character from The Music Man. (More on that particular passion later.)

title: Pale Male Takes a Star Turn
description: This meeting of the fellowship of the bench was called to order at 10:04 a.m. at the bench, facing Conservatory Water, the model-boat basin in Central Park.

title: From Tooth Fairy to High-Speed Human Tank
description: Faster, a turgid, ultraviolent parable of revenge and forgiveness, is as muscle-bound as its monosyllabic antihero, Driver (Dwayne Johnson), an indestructible human Superman with a metal plate in his head. Released from prison after serving time for a bank robbery, this high-speed tank runs over anything in his path or shoots it on the spot. Befitting his name, he has a knack for driving a car in reverse into oncoming traffic and at the last second spinning the vehicle 180 degrees and rocketing forward.

title: A Breathless Boccherini, an Unnerving Shostakovich
description: The Moscow Virtuosi lived up to their name on Sunday afternoon, offering dynamite performances for a large and enthusiastic, mostly Russian-speaking audience at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Messing With J.R., Take Four
description: Not so fast, J.R.

title: In 12 Plays, 150 Years of Afghan History
description: BY the time the seven-plus hours of The Great Game: Afghanistan have concluded (over three successive nights or in one all-day weekend marathon), audiences will have received a vigorous crash course on a country that has gotten relatively little attention in the West even in the midst of a war that has taken more than 1,300 American lives.

title: Unwrapping Red Tape to Find the Gift of Family
description: TARAZ, Kazakhstan  He was first placed into their arms nearly a year ago, an underweight 9-month-old baby in a gray sweatshirt. They were at an orphanage behind a crumbling housing project here in Central Asia, unimaginably far from their home in suburban Philadelphia, but immediately, they knew that they did not want to let him go.

title: The Interplay of Politics and the Heart
description: Kawasakis Rose, the new film from the Czech director Jan Hrebejk, is the chronicle of two betrayals, separated by three decades and a revolution. In the busy, placid present, Ludek (Milan Mikulcik) is cheating on his wife, Lucie (Lenka Vlasakova), who is undergoing tests and then treatment for what turns out to be a rare but nonfatal disease. Ludek informs her of his affair (with Radka, a younger co-worker played by Petra Hrebickova) with a grating mixture of insensitivity and concern, his cowardice and selfishness marking him as a thoroughly ordinary modern man.

title: Bird of Prey and His Adoring Fans: A New York Love Story
description: When the red-tailed hawk known as Pale Male landed in New York City, he would experience some of the things New Yorkers hope to avoid (homelessness, the wrath of a co-op board) and a few they can only fantasize about (the attention of Mary Tyler Moore, sex on the terrace of Woody Allens penthouse). Chronicling close to two decades in the birds  and its fan clubs  eventful life, The Legend of Pale Male is a sugary, aggressively anthropomorphized story of one avian interloper and a whole bunch of human obsessives.

title: A Dynasty Diva Regales Us With Her Own Life Stories
description: Behold Joan Collins! The ur bitch goddess and resplendent proto-cougar (on the prowl long before that noxious term was invented) is doing her thing in the flesh at the ballroom of Loews Regency Hotel. Would that thing be singing? Dancing? Acting? None of the above, unless acting means embodying a woman named Joan Collins who has the blessing and the curse of being confused with Alexis Carrington, her notorious, shoulder-padded alter ego on Dynasty.

title: Jeters Predictable Predicament
description: Tyler Kepner, who covers baseball for The Times, has an excellent article on the contract negotiations between the Yankees and their Hall of Fame shortstop, Derek Jeter. Few players have had a more harmonious relationship with their employer than Mr. Jeter, who has rarely caused controversy in his 16 seasons with the Yankees. But the contract negotiations have turned ugly, as Mr. Kepner reports, with both Mr. Jeters representatives and Yankees management having provided their fair share of juicy quotes to the media.

title: A Dystopian Aftertaste to Those Sugarplums
description: There are a few things that Nutcracker fans need to know about the new holiday extravaganza The Nutcracker in 3D, which, according to the production notes, was inspired by the beloved ballet. First, theres no ballet, though there is a rudimentary waltz on ice skates.

title: Driving to See Geological Traffic Accidents
description: George E. Harlow, curator of gems and minerals at the American Museum of Natural History, has been studying jadeite for many years and returned earlier this month to the fault line that is the Motagua Valley in Guatemala. He previously wrote two posts about his expedition. Here is his summary of the remainder of the trip.

title: Sarkozy Called Journalists Pedophiles
description: Updated | Wednesday | 9:16 a.m. Apparently enraged by allegations of scandal that he has dismissed as ridiculous and grotesque, French President Nicolas Sarkozy exploded during an off-the-record briefing last week, calling the reporters present pedophiles, the French magazine LExpress reported on Monday.

title: Cario
description: 82 South Fourth Street (Berry Street), Williamsburg, Brooklyn; (718) 384-8282, carinonyc.com.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Broadway Festival

title: Loving Coffee Without Being a Drip
description: THE crimes that can be hung on the automatic drip coffee machine are many, not all of them petty misdemeanors. It hogs counter space. It sends a wash of water too indiscriminate over a hillock of grounds too large. And its oversize carafe often overheats its contents, turning your morning upper into an acrid downer.

title: Tiella
description: 1109 First Avenue (61st Street), Upper East Side; (212) 588-0100, tiellanyc.com.

title: Smoked Soy Sauce
description: The penetrating allure of smoke does not require a grill.

title: Searching for Ingredients Beyond the Garden
description: The ingredients that chefs are seeking out are not the ones everyone can order; theyre the ones that few have ever heard of.

title: A Lineup Change at Sushi Yasuda
description: THAT Naomichi Yasuda, among the hundreds of sushi chefs in New York, is one of the very few who is known by name gives a clue as to why so many connoisseurs took personally the news that he would be moving to Tokyo by the end of January. Its like telling a Yankees fan that Derek Jeter is about to retire.

title: Chefs Look for Wild Ingredients Nobody Else Has
description: LAST Thursday, Adam Kopels walked into Torrisi Italian Specialties in NoLIta, opened his messenger bag and pulled out Ziploc bags filled with wild greens he had gathered on the North Fork of Long Island, near where he lives. Mario Carbone, one of the restaurants chefs and owners, sat with Mr. Kopels and sorted through clumps of baby peppercress and sheep sorrel, red bay and shepherds purse. The two picked up some sea rocket, a plant that grows only on exposed dunes, and crunched through the peppery leaves.

title: Kasha Varnishkes With Confit of Gizzards
description: Adapted from Mile End, Brooklyn

title: In Battery Park City, Another Option for Stocking the Pantry
description: Battery Park City has a well-stocked 4,500-square-foot market that even more well-provisioned neighborhoods might envy. One owner is Edmund Choi, who started March Madison. The manager, Ken Jackson, held a similar post at Fairway.

title: Seafood Raised on Land
description: The Local Ocean fish farm in Hudson, N.Y., may be an aquaculture game-changer, raising saltwater fish, mostly sea bream (similar to porgy and orata), in tanks on land.

title: Barbarescos That Are Good Now, but Just Wait a Bit
description: LETS face it, if you havent gotten your Thanksgiving plans together by now, then you must be the sort of last-minute organizational genius who needs no help. So lets look past the holiday to the future, to something much more fun to contemplate. May I suggest Barbaresco, the 2005 vintage?

title: For Executives Seeking Absolution, a Double Standard
description: This is a tale of two worlds.

title: To Revive Jewish Dishes, Some Cooks Look to the Shtetl
description: GROWING up in Montreal, Noah Bernamoff had an issue with his mothers kasha varnishkes.

title: Life Expectancy in China Rising Slowly, Despite Economic Surge
description: A quick quiz: Which of the following countries has had the smallest increase in life expectancy since 1990  Bangladesh, China, Pakistan, South Korea or Sudan?

title: Why Do Bank Results Slump in the 4th Quarter?
description: We all know that retailers make all their money in the final quarter of each year. But why are banks much more likely to report losses in the fourth quarter than in any other quarter?

title: Why Do Bank Results Slump in the 4th Quarter?
description: We all know that retailers make all their money in the final quarter of each year. But why are banks much more likely to report losses in the fourth quarter than in any other quarter?

title: Dancing Tops Skating
description: Part 1 of the Dancing With the Stars finale topped the ratings on Monday night, but ABCs nearly two-hour series premiere of Skating With the Stars struggled to duplicate the success. According to Nielsens estimates, 23.3 million viewers tuned in to Dancing during the 8 p.m. hour. The show also extended 13 minutes into the 9 p.m. hour in an effort to attract viewers for the start of ABCs new skating show. The network garnered 19.4 million viewers from 9 to 9:30, but Skating earned just 8.3 million from 9:30 to 11 and only 6 million viewers in its final half-hour. Still, for the night ABC outperformed second-place CBS with its comedy lineup and Hawaii Five-0 (12.1 million). Fox was third and NBC fourth.

title: Five City Officers Cleared in Shootings of Bystanders
description: Five New York City police officers involved in a shootout with a suspect in Harlem in 2005 cannot be held negligent in the wounding of two bystanders, the states highest court ruled on Tuesday, ending a five-year legal battle before it went to trial.

title: Thanksgiving Ritual Gives Rangel a Respite
description: Last week, he stormed out of a crucial hearing in Washington and nearly broke down when he was found guilty of ethical violations involving his finances and fund-raising.

title: Classical Music
description: So much for the death watch on the major classical record labels, and on the CD itself. If the New York Times classical music writers choices for records of the year are any indication, at least one of the traditional majors scored a significant comeback this year: Deutsche Grammophon, which claims 6 of the 25 places. Harmonia Mundi, which has become a major player in recent years despite a generally more specialized repertory, comes in second, with 4. But excellent recordings keep coming out from smaller sources as well, and they dot the list that follows. JAMES R. OESTREICH

title: Afghanistan May Indict Voting Officials
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The government of President Hamid Karzai threatened on Tuesday to indict two top election officials, on the eve of the announcement of the final results from the countrys September parliamentary elections.

title: Johnson Is Nascars Dynasty of One
description: Jimmie Johnson was whisked from one New York television studio to another Tuesday to talk about his fifth straight Nascar Sprint Cup championship, which, he said, has turned out to be a little different from the first four  or since people started saying he is bad for racing.

title: BBCs Popular Media Player Going Global
description: More than three years after it was rung up as a immense success in Britain, the BBCs super-sophisticated media player, the iPlayer, will begin streaming both television and radio globally next year, including in the United States.

title: Church Has Role in Newton Inquiry
description: NEWNAN, Ga.  As the N.C.A.A. investigates the recruitment of Auburns star quarterback, Cam Newton, a central figure in the unfolding story is his father, Cecil Newton Sr., and the church he runs not far from their home in Atlanta.

title: Experiments in Field Philosophy
description: Back in September, Joshua Knobe of Yale University, writing here at The Stone, outlined a new experimental approach to doing philosophy in his post, Experiments in Philosophy. Philosophers, he argued, have spent enough time cogitating in their armchairs. Knobe described how he and a group of like-minded colleagues in the discipline have undertaken a more engaged approach, working with cognitive scientists and designing experiments that will test peoples intuitions about traditional philosophic puzzlers such as the existence of God, the objectivity of ethics and the possibility of free will. The result: new, empirically-grounded insights available to philosophers and psychologists.

title: Another House Democrat Concedes
description: Make that an even 63  for now at least.

title: The Mets New Manager Has Some Fans in Buffalo
description: It never hurts when looking into an audience of hard-core skeptics to also see the smiling faces of true believers, of people who go back with you more than two decades and who would board a plane on a days notice to endorse you with insights that few others could have.

title: Turning Around an Indian State
description: SHERGHATI, India  Out in the flat, dusty plains of eastern India, Nitish Kumar stood before several thousand farmers at a recent campaign rally and described his turnaround of Indias poorest and once most ungovernable state, Bihar. Law and order had been restored. Roads and bridges had been built. More women were holding elective office and fewer and fewer girls were dropping out of school.

title: The Sound of Lincolns Silence
description: Less than a month after Abraham Lincolns election to the presidency, the nations reigning bible of technology, Scientific American, shone a startling new light on the incoming chief executive. Lincoln, it revealed, was an inventor. Eleven years earlier, he had secured a federal patent (the first and only for a president) for a device to buoy up imperiled ships over dangerously shallow rivers. Amid a growing secession crisis already awash in comparisons to foundering ships of state, the invitation to metaphor must have seemed irresistible.

title: Big Hits, No Flags
description: One player was tackled square in the face with the helmet of an onrushing opponent. Another, fighting for one last yard, took a polyurethane bash to the head. Still another player spent 10 minutes mostly motionless among dozens of praying players before medics carried him away on a stretcher after a helmet-to-helmet hit.

title: Scientists Back Early Government Report on Gulf Spill
description: An early government assessment of the fate of the oil from the BP spill in the Gulf of Mexico that was criticized as overly optimistic by some independent scientists was largely accurate, according to a revised report by federal scientists released Tuesday.

title: The Public Confessions of a Disgraced Dogfighter
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Photo Replay: Nov. 23
description: A view of the day in sports, with gold medals galore at the Asian Games.

title: Subway Extension Draws Support, if Not Financing
description: Extending the No. 7 subway line to New Jersey is an idea that seems to pick up support among government officials with each passing day. But the $5.3 billion question is: Who would pay for it?

title: Military Strike in the Waters Between North and South Korea
description: The island that was shelled by North Korea on Tuesday lies in disputed waters.

title: Alderson on Minaya, Coaches, Feliciano and K-Rod
description: Sandy Alderson addressed several items of business at the Mets news conference to introduce Terry Collins as the new manager on Tuesday, including that he hopes to speak to the former general manager Omar Minaya soon about serving the team in some capacity. Minaya has offers from a half dozen other teams.

title: Worse Than Vietnam
description: We did the Cole and we wanted the United States to react. And if they reacted, they are going to invade Afghanistan and thats what we want  . Then we will start holy war against the Americans, exactly like the Soviets. Mohammed Atef, military commander of Al Qaeda, in November of 2000

title: An American Thanksgiving, Skewered and Roasted
Wallets Out, Wall St. Dares to Indulge
description: 7:35 a.m. | Updated Exuberance made a comeback this year at Josh Koplewiczs annual Halloween party. More than 1,000 people packed into a 6,000-square-foot space at the Good Units night club in Manhattan, a substantially larger crowd than in the last several years.

title: SAC Capital and 2 Mutual Funds Are Subpoenaed
description: 9:04 p.m. | Updated SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund giant run by the billionaire investor Steven A. Cohen, received an extraordinarily broad subpoena from federal authorities on Monday, according to a letter sent to its investors on Tuesday.

title: At a 2008 Stop, Obama Promotes His Policies
description: KOKOMO, Ind.  President Obama came to this manufacturing city in the Midwest to make the case for the effectiveness of his economic policies, telling workers that the return of jobs to auto plants in the area is a harbinger of a nationwide recovery.

title: All That Time Serving the Public? Very Sexy
description: He is hailed as a paragon of timeless male beauty. His face is likened to the chiseled visages of Antonio Banderas, David Beckham and Ricky Martin. He is called, without irony, a sizzling stalwart.

title: Brooklyn Actor Held in Killing of His Mother
description: In a rampage loud enough to be heard by alarmed neighbors, an actor killed his mother with a three-foot sword early Tuesday in their apartment in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Families Grieve Over Stampede Victims
description: Injured survivors lay on the floors of hospitals in Cambodia after one of the worst stampedes in recent years killed at least 378 people at a holiday celebration.

title: Peace, Love and Puritanism
description: Arlington, Mass.

title: Lower Manhattan Gains Ground as Publishing Hub
description: The first moving vans pulled up to 7 Hanover Square in Lower Manhattan early in the evening last Thursday.

title: The Great Game Imposter
description: WASHINGTON

title: South Koreans and U.S. to Stage a Joint Exercise
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and South Koreas president agreed Tuesday night to hold joint military exercises as a first response to North Koreas deadly shelling of a South Korean military installation, as both countries struggled for the second time this year to keep a North Korean provocation from escalating into war.

title: Telling Consumers Whats Inside
description: S. C. JOHNSON wants to step up its green game with advertising intended to convey to consumers a commitment to disclose the ingredients of its familiar household cleaning products, like Glade, Pledge and Windex.

title: Real Estate Investors Look to the Future, and See Signs to Buy Apartment Towers
description: At the start of the year, David Neithercut, the chief executive of Equity Residential, a real estate investment trust, set a target of $1 billion to spend on apartment buildings across the country. By the middle of this month, after buying 15 properties that included a troubled condominium tower in San Diego and three apartment buildings in Manhattan, Mr. Neithercut had invested $1.4 billion.

title: U.S.G. and P.T.A.
description: For me, the most frightening news in The Times on Sunday was not about North Koreas stepping up its nuclear program, but an article about howAmerican kids are stepping up their use of digital devices: Allison Miller, 14, sends and receives 27,000 texts in a month, her fingers clicking at a blistering pace as she carries on as many as seven text conversations at a time. She texts between classes, at the moment soccer practice ends, while being driven to and from school and, often, while studying. But this proficiency comes at a cost: She blames multitasking for the three Bs on her recent progress report. Ill be reading a book for homework and Ill get a text message and pause my reading and put down the book, pick up the phone to reply to the text message, and then 20 minutes later realize, Oh, I forgot to do my homework.

title: A Very Risky Game
description: North Korea is again bullying its way into the headlines. On Tuesday, it shelled a South Korean island, killing two South Korean soldiers. Earlier this month it flaunted a new plant that could allow it to significantly increase the size of its nuclear arsenal.

title: After Years Caught Up in Violence, a Second Chance to Reflect on Fate
description: Words flowed from Raheem Watson in a stream, thick with assurance, buttressed by years of quiet introspection. But one question gave him pause, forcing his gaze down to his lap.

title: Lottery Numbers
No Country for Second Chances
description: Washington

title: In J. Crew Buyout, an Effort to Gain a Retail Visionary
description: The buyout firms that are paying $3 billion for J. Crew are not just bidding on the retailers array of sequined blazers and gingham work shirts. They are trying to acquire the man whose vision inspired them: the companys chairman and chief executive, Millard S. Drexler.

title: Large Banks Still Have Financing Advantage
description: What happened to ending too big to fail? That was one objective of the financial overhaul bill, the Dodd-Frank Act, that was passed this year. Central to the legislation were rules intended to make big banks less exciting and safer. It also created an authority meant to smoothly wind down even the largest institutions without greatly disrupting the financial system.

title: Pentagon Report Cites Gains in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  The United States and its partners are making modest gains in some key areas of Afghanistan, but the insurgency is still strong and expanding across the country, a Pentagon report to Congress this month has concluded.

title: Waiting at the Airport? Read This
description: To the Editor:

title: Hospitals and Health Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Beware of Cleric in Yemen
description: To the Editor:

title: A Word From Dublin: Ireland Will Recover
description: To the Editor:

title: Danny McDevitt, Dodgers Pitcher, Dies at 78
description: Danny McDevitt, who pitched, and won, the Brooklyn Dodgers final game at Ebbets Field in 1957, a 2-0 shutout, died Saturday in Covington, Ga. He was 78.

title: Wednesday: Numbers 1 Through 6
description: Note: When this puzzle is done, read the eight circled letters clockwise, starting with square No. 24, to identify this puzzles theme.

title: Politicizing Airport Security
description: In their eagerness to pin every problem in America on President Obama, prominent Republicans are now blaming his administration for the use of full-body scanners and intrusive pat-downs at airports. Those gloved fingers feeling inside your belt? The hand of big government, once again poking around where it should not go.

title: Thanksgiving Closings and Schedule Shifts
description: NEW YORK

title: Positive Economic Reports Push Dow Up 150 Points
description: The major indexes rallied on Wednesday, buoyed by several economic reports that suggested improvement in the economy, including in the job market.

title: Pat-Down Dispute Shows Mistrust of Government
description: WASHINGTON

title: No Time to Wait for Justice
description: It is only a days difference, but the Pentagons decision to release its report on gays in the military next Tuesday instead of Wednesday lends a significant sense of urgency to a Congressional vote on the verge of collapse. If there is any hope of repealing the militarys discriminatory dont ask, dont tell policy, legislative action must begin immediately. Even an extra day can mean a great deal.

title: News Corp., After Hiring Klein, Buys Technology Partner in a City Schools Project
description: Greg Gunn and Larry Berger met as Rhodes scholars at Oxford University and, after stints teaching computer skills and mathematics to children in Harlem and Stamford, Conn., they came upon an idea: create a business that would put technology in the hands of teachers and into classrooms.

title: Terry Collins Discusses Past as He Takes Mets Job
description: Eleven years worth of waiting for a third chance to manage in the major leagues came bursting forth at a Citi Field podium Tuesday after Terry Collins was introduced as the 20th manager of the Mets.

title: Theater Owner Is Charged With Fraud
description: A businessman who once ran a chain of New York City cinemas was arrested on Tuesday and charged with orchestrating a scheme to steal a half-million dollars from investors in his theaters, the authorities said.

title: Saving the Wild Tiger
description: A century ago, there were an estimated 100,000 tigers living in the wild. Now there are perhaps 3,200 left. The best chance  probably the only remaining chance  to save them from extinction is being worked out during a five-day summit meeting this week in St. Petersburg, Russia, staged by Prime Minister Vladimir Putin and Robert Zoellick, president of the World Bank. The meeting includes representatives from major conservation groups and all 13 nations with tigers living in the wild, including India, Indonesia, Thailand and Russia.

title: As Anger Over Body Scanners Grows, Their Developer Comes to Their Defense
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Thirty years ago, Martin Annis devised an X-ray technology for body scanners that unsettled some people. He had so much trouble finding a woman to test the machine on that he had to pay a family member $20 to try it.

title: Report Finds Low Graduation Rates at For-Profit Colleges
description: A new report on graduation rates at for-profit colleges by a nonprofit research and advocacy group charges that such colleges deliver little more than crippling debt, citing federal data that suggests only 9 percent of the first-time, full-time bachelors degree students at the University of Phoenix, the nations largest for-profit college, graduate within six years.

title: Buenos Aires, the Frugal Way
description: Graciela, Ofelia and Pedro from Patagonia stood around the counter with me in Buenos Aires, chomping on pizza slices and trying to explain why Argentines dine so late. It was 8 p.m. and they were snacking on their way home from work to tide them over before dinner. We were at Guerrin, an institution where you get to know the strangers standing next to you because youre in close quarters and theres nothing to do but talk. (My primary rule for lone travelers: always talk to strangers. At the very least you could end up with a bit of conversation over pizza. At best, you end up getting set up on a blind date. But more on that later.)

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,419 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,385 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: With a Swagger, Wallets Out, Wall Street Dares to Celebrate
description: Exuberance made a comeback this year at Josh Koplewiczs annual Halloween party. More than 1,000 people packed into a 6,000-square-foot space at the Good Units night club in Manhattan, a substantially larger crowd than in the last several years. The open bar was sponsored by Russian Standard vodka, and Mr. Koplewicz, an investment analyst at Goldman Sachs, was able to snag a big headliner: the hip-hop star Lil Kim, who performed dressed in a black cat costume.

title: Remake of Obama Economic Team Broadens Scope
description: WASHINGTON  The departure of a number of administration officials is giving President Obama broader scope to remake his economic team even as the White House prepares to carry out a long-planned shuffle involving two of his closest political advisers.

title: Jennifer Grey Wins Dancing With the Stars
description: Nobody puts Baby in the corner, but you can put her in the winners circle: Jennifer Grey, the Dirty Dancing star, was named the winner of ABCs Dancing With the Stars on Tuesday night, fending off a late challenge from her fellow competitor Bristol Palin.

title: New Zealand Mourns Miners After Second Blast
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand  A second huge blast in a New Zealand coal mine would have killed any survivors of the initial explosion, the authorities said on Wednesday.

title: Felton Seals Knicks Four-Win Streak
description: The emotions came first, then the pain and finally some combination of physical and mental fatigue. Raymond Felton pushed through it all, pushed through traffic and put himself exactly where he wanted to be.

title: Boras Says Players Loans Are Part of Goodwill Story
description: Scott Boras, baseballs most prominent agent, said Tuesday that his company had indeed made loans of $70,000 to a young Dominican prospect and that they were actually part of a goodwill story and within the rules for agents set out by Major League Baseballs players union.

title: G.O.P. Gets 2 More Seats; Democrats Hold On to 1
description: Republicans have officially racked up two more victories in House races with the concessions of Democratic incumbents in Texas and New York.

title: The Thanksgiving Help Line Is Open for Business
description: And maybe youre already reaching for the Valium as if they were Tic Tacs, worried that the brine isnt working or is working too well, or that Aunt Katies going to start crying the way she did last year, not five minutes into the house and still stinking of the Virginia Slims she hotboxed out on the sidewalk before working up the nerve to come in. Do you not know what to do with that murderous-looking butternut squash? What about these blessed chestnuts or that balky oven, this weird desire of your fathers for apple pie, this command of your cousins for ham? Did you make the Ruhlman stock yet? Get going!

title: The Shoppers Republic of China
description: Most Chinese spend little on consumer items, but when people do buy, they buy big.

title: Phys Ed: The Benefits of Weight Training for Children
description: Back in the 1970s, researchers in Japan studied child laborers and discovered that, among their many misfortunes, the juvenile workers tended to be abnormally short. Physical labor, the researchers concluded, with its hours of lifting and moving heavy weights, had stunted the childrens growth. Somewhat improbably, from that scientific finding and other similar reports, as well as from anecdotes and accreting myth, many people came to believe that children and adolescents should not practice weight training, said Avery Faigenbaum, a professor of exercise science at the College of New Jersey. That idea retains a sturdy hold in the popular imagination. As a recent position paper on the topic of children and resistance training points out, many parents, coaches and pediatricians remain convinced that weight training by children will result in short stature, epiphyseal plate  or growth plate  damage, lack of strength increases due to a lack of testosterone and a variety of safety issues.

title: Final Settlement Phase Starts for BP Oil Spill
description: Now comes the hard part.

title: In China, Cultivating the Urge to Splurge
description: When the Wuqi International Hotel was completed this spring, it immediately dominated the modest skyline of Wuqi, a small city in north central China. The hotel stands 21 stories tall and is wrapped in gleaming gray metal, with two glass elevators running up the outside. On a recent stay there, I had a clear view of the nearby mountains from my 19th-floor room.

title: Word of the Day | episodic
description: episodic \e-p-s-dik also -z-\ adjective

title: Gawker Agrees Not to Repost Palin Excerpts
description: 9:49 a.m. | Updated HarperCollins appears to have prevailed in a legal tussle with Gawker over the Web sites posting last week of lengthy excerpts from Sarah Palins book America by Heart, a move that HarperCollins said violated copyright law.

title: Anxiety in Seoul as Civilian Deaths Are Reported
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The forests on Yeonpyeong Island were still ablaze on Wednesday afternoon when news broke that rescuers had recovered the burned bodies of two civilians, casualties of the ferocious artillery exchange a day earlier between North and South Korean military units.

title: Chalmers Johnson Dies at 79; Criticized U.S. Role in World
description: Chalmers Johnson, an Asian studies scholar who stirred controversy with books contending that the United States was trying to create a global empire and was paying a stiff price for it, died Saturday at his home in Cardiff-by-the Sea, Calif. He was 79.

title: William Hohri Dies at 83; Sought Money for Internees
description: William Hohri, a veteran of a World War II internment camp for Japanese-Americans who became the lead plaintiff in a politically charged class-action suit that claimed $27 billion in damages for internees, died Nov. 12 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 83.

title: Brazil: Gangs Battle Police in Rio de Janeiro Slums
description: The police raided more than a dozen slums in Rio de Janeiro on Tuesday in an effort to quell violent attacks by gangs that have raised questions about security in the city chosen to host the 2014 World Cup and the 2016 Olympic Games. Heavily armed criminals have blocked busy streets, robbed drivers and burned at least nine cars since Sunday, according to the police and the Brazilian news media. The Rio State secretary of public security, Jos Mariano Beltrame, said the attacks were a retaliation by gang members for a government program to pacify violent slums, in part by installing a special community police force.

title: Canada: Court-Martial for a General
description: The former commander of Canadas troops in Afghanistan will face a court-martial, the defense department said Tuesday. The commander, Brig. Gen. Daniel Mnard, was relieved of his command in May for inappropriate conduct involving a female officer. He faces two charges under military laws concerning fraternization, and four charges of obstructing justice under criminal law. Earlier, General Mnard was fined more than $3,000 for accidentally firing an automatic rifle just before boarding a helicopter with Canadas top military commander.

title: Greece: Group Says It Sent Parcel Bombs
description: A Greek extremist group, Conspiracy of the Cells of Fire, has claimed responsibility for parcel bombs this month that caused one injury and widespread alarm, the police said Tuesday. In a letter to the news network Indymedia, two of the seven suspected members of the group who have been arrested said it had sent parcel bombs to President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, the International Court of Justice in The Hague, and the Belgian and Mexican Embassies in Athens. The Greek police also found 10 other explosive devices.

title: 1,000 Yards Later, Its O.K. to Ask, Who Is That Guy?
description: Atlantas Roddy White and Denvers Brandon Lloyd have more than 1,000 receiving yards through 10 games, the first receivers with that level of production since 2007. Both have scored seven touchdowns this season. Both are 29 years old. But thats where the similarities end.

title: 2011 (Next) Year In Review
description: An illustrated look into next year by Patrick Chappatte.

title: News Quiz | November 24, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Daily Lexeme: Limitanean
description: Todays word, in association with the exemplary Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Analysts Puzzle Over Cause of Flare-Up
description: SEOUL, South Korea  As nerves began to calm the day after a prolonged and deadly artillery exchange between North and South Korea, focus turned on Wednesday to the possible motivations for the assault and whether the South might have provoked it.

title: Do You Plan to Shop on Black Friday?
description: The day after Thanksgiving is called Black Friday because it is traditionally thought of as the day retailers begin to see a profit, or move into the black. Its also the color the sky will be as many shoppers head out to the stores early in the morning this Friday in search of bargains. Will you be one of them?

title: Test Yourself | Math, Nov. 24, 2010
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the Times article NASAs Quest to Send a Robot to the Moon.

title: On Page 1 by Breaking the Rules
description: Our assignment on Aug. 13, 1969, was to cover the ticker-tape parade for the Apollo 11 astronauts  Col. Michael Collins, Col. Edwin E. Aldrin Jr. and Neil A. Armstrong  who had returned from their pioneering trip to the Moon.

title: Report Issued on Deadly Cambodia Stampede
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  Investigators in Cambodia said Wednesday that a stampede that caused the deaths of 350 people who were suffocated or crushed Monday night was probably touched off by the slight swaying of a short suspension bridge packed on the last evening of an annual water festival.

title: Dublin Poised to Take Over Bank of Ireland
description: The Irish press was abuzz with reports on Wednesday morning that the countrys government, fresh off its request for a bailout from the European Union, would take control of Bank of Ireland, the last large Irish lender to stay outside government control.

title: New Focus on Norths Food Shortage
description: PARIS  As outsiders from Beijing to Washington struggle to see a pattern in the secretive dynamics of the North Korean leadership, one part of the tangled puzzle seems beyond dispute: the countrys 25 million people cannot feed themselves and face acute food shortages as they have done for many years.

title: Thursdays Week 12 N.F.L. Matchups
description: Bengals (2-8) at Jets (8-2)8:20 p.m.Line: Jets by 9

title: The Other Taxes: Who Pays Them?
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Londons Covent Garden Comes Alive for the Holidays
description: Around the holidays, Londons West End is a particularly festive spot. But this years activities bring the age-old tradition of kissing under the mistletoe into the 21st century with the addition of a little digital interactivity  all right in the middle of Covent Garden.

title: A VW Beetle Made in Africa
description: Displayed in the lobby of the Museum of Arts and Design is one of BMWs famed Art Cars, a 1991 BMW 525i by Esther Mahlangu, a South African artist.

title: The Early Word: Conflict in Korea
description: From Todays Times:

title: Ruling Coalition Wins in Indian State
description: NEW DELHI  Nitish Kumar, the chief minister credited with reviving Indias poorest state, won a landslide victory on Wednesday as voters endorsed his pro-development platform and returned his coalition government to power in a statewide election that is likely to reverberate across Indias political map.

title: Electrifying and Bewildering, a Classic Kanye West Event
description: It started, as all huge-star-in-a-tiny-Manhattan-club concerts must, with a ticket rush and a spike in Craigslist prices. In the middle of the story there was lots of pushing and shoving at the door followed by an hour and a half of celebrity-spotting and electrifying music, and it ended with a bewildering rant. In other words, it was a classic Kanye West event for the lucky few who got to see him perform late Tuesday night.

title: Q&A: Make the iPhone Screen Stop Spinning
description: Q.

title: The TV Watch: Dancing in Circles
description: It must be embedded in the Palin genetic code. Sarah Palin made a virtue of inexperience in the 2008 presidential campaign, baiting her critics for being elitist. On Dancing With the Stars, so did Bristol Palin.

title: Video: Iron Bowl Highlights a Defining Week
description: The annual Iron Bowl between Auburn and Alabama is one of many showdowns that will shape the national title picture. Paul Myerberg and Connor Ennis discuss in the weeks edition of the Pregame Huddle.

title: A Post-Thanksgiving Breakfast
description: After a lavish Thanksgiving meal, the morning-after breakfast of cold cereal or toast may feel like a letdown. For home cooks who want to continue the holiday feast, considering serving up one of these festive, healthful breakfasts from James Distefano, executive pastry chef at the Rouge Tomate restaurant in New York.

title: Whats Wrong With the Crazy Bakers Web Site?
description: Hall Hitzig, who has branded himself The Crazy Baker, offers his sweet delicacies  blondies and brownies, sticky toffee pudding, tortes and other baked goods  through his Web site. They are the kinds of goodies you find in upscale bakeries in major metropolitan areas. Thats a good thing, but it also presents a problem: Mr. Hitzig is about as far from a major metropolitan area as you can get.

title: Live Blog: The Race to Grandmas House
description: Day: Wednesday before ThanksgivingJourney: Brooklyn, N.Y., to Athens, Ga.Modes: Car, plane, carTravelers: A Times reporter, her husband, and their sons, ages 1, 3 and 5.

title: Japanese Firm in Rare Earths Deal With Australian Miner
description: TOKYO  Less than a week after China resumed exports of crucial industrial minerals to Japan, a top Japanese trading company on Wednesday announced a deal to reduce reliance on Beijing for mineral supplies.

title: The Nutcracker Chronicles: A Sons Progress
description: Among the many phenomena surrounding The Nutcracker are the mothers of the ballets innumerable child performers. Joan Acocella of The New Yorker became a dance critic after spending time following her sons performances as Fritz in the Balanchine production at New York City Ballet.

title: New Palin Book Offers a Road Map for a Run Against Obama
description: The ever-expanding media-publicity empire that is headed by former Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska got a bit larger Monday with the official release of her second book, America by Heart.

title: German Business Confidence Jumps
description: PARIS  Despite economic crises in some parts of Europe, things apparently could not be better in Germany.

title: Drilling Session Disappoints Landrieu
description: A meeting between Interior Secretary Ken Salazar and offshore drilling executives on the Gulf Coast orchestrated by Senator Mary Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, failed to yield much progress on streamlining the permitting process for new wells in the aftermath of the BP oil spill, Ms. Landrieu said this week.

title: Madoff Trustee Sues UBS to Recover $2 Billion
description: 7:11 p.m. | Updated  The trustee charged with trying to recover money for the victims of Bernard L. Madoffs huge Ponzi scheme sued the Swiss bank UBS and its affiliates on Wednesday, accusing it of enabling the fraud.

title: Hey, Mr. Critic!
description: Turns out its not all Thanksgiving questions out there in the world of New York dining this week. The virtual mailman delivered questions today about eating in Brooklyn and about the perils of finding a restaurant to satisfy everyone, as well as from an Australian visitor and some runners who want to celebrate their marathon experience together in style. As ever, you may send me your own dining questions.

title: White House Seeks Chinese Help With N. Korea
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Wednesday began a broad effort to enlist China to help rein in North Korea in the wake of its deadly attack Tuesday on South Korea.

title: Week 12 N.F.L. Game Probabilities, and the Santonio Effect
description: Brian Burke, a former Navy pilot who has taken up the less dangerous hobby of N.F.L. statistical analysis, operates Advanced NFL Stats, a blog about football, math and human behavior.

title: Lands of Ice and Ire
description: Back in early 2009, it was supposed to be gallows humor:

title: Glee': So Glad We Had This Time Together
description: Even a veteran Glee viewer had to feel a sting in his or her sweet tooth after the opening minutes of Tuesday nights episode: Kurts dad and Finns mom are engaged! Sue Sylvester is engaged  to herself! Quinn and Sam are, like, engaged to be engaged  or something! Thats a lot of saccharine to ingest right before a Thanksgiving dinner. And just when Kurts bully threatens to rear his ugly head again, hes rendered inoperative for the episode through a deus ex machina and the teamwork of the New Directions crew. (Well, most of them, anyway.)

title: Euro Zone Government Bonds Draw Few Investors
description: PARIS  Investors fled euro zone government bonds on Wednesday, putting further pressure on policy makers as they grappled with decisions over emergency financial bailouts and who should bear the costs.

title: Devaluing History
description: Menzie Chinn goes after Paul Ryans challenge: Name me a nation in history that has prospered by devaluing its currency. But why go back to the 1930s?

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Felix Salmon on the Treasurys plan to fix the mortgage mess.

title: A Glimpse of Chinese Health Care
description: The Chinese health clinic that I mention in my column today is in the northern part of Shaanxi province, not far from the border with Inner Mongolia. It is part of a larger community center that includes a preschool, a small police station, an outdoor table for table tennis and  somewhat ominously, given the one-child policy  a family-planning office.

title: Huang Hua, 97, a Diplomat Who Served China, Dies
description: SHANGHAI  Huang Hua, a Communist Party revolutionary who was Chinas foreign minister during the 1970s and early 1980s and helped China restore diplomatic relations with the United States, died Wednesday in Beijing. He was 97.

title: Vain Glorious | Cosmetics in 3-D
description: The collaboration between the cosmetics powerhouse MAC and the Dutch industrial designer Marcel Wanders came about when a mutual friend suggested it to MACs creative director, James Gagner. A year and a half in the making, the collection includes glossy black multifaceted compacts, a jacquard brush roll, and a solid-perfume bauble. This is the first time Ive ever really had someone design a three-dimensional collection for us, says Gagner, who, for the record, owns Wanderss Crochet Table and Knotted Chair.

title: Welcome to the Courtroom: Axl Rose Sues Over Guitar Hero Game
description: If youve ever wondered just how much Axl Rose dislikes Slash, his long-ago bandmate from the hard rock band Guns N Roses, its now possible to attach a quantifiable figure to that antipathy: $20 million. Thats the amount that Mr. Rose is suing the video game maker Activision for, saying that the company reneged on an agreement not to use any depictions of Slash in its popular game Guitar Hero III: Legends of Rock, according to the THR, Esq. blog of The Hollywood Reporter.

title: Schools Chancellor Appointment Totters
description: It will be a sunny, cooler day in the city, with a high temperature around 50.

title: The Case of the Nissan Leafs Unexpected Sticker
description: Two federal agencies say they know how far the new Nissan Leaf will go on a fully charged battery. They just dont agree.

title: Ireland Unveils Austerity Plan to Help Secure Bailout
description: DUBLIN  Acting to secure a $114 billion international bailout, the Irish government announced plans on Wednesday for steep tax increases and sharp cutbacks in its social welfare state.

title: Temperate Pragmatists
description: The economic approach of Baby Boomers who have outgrown of conspicuous consumption.

title: A Search for Enduring, But Upended, Scientific Ideas
North Korean Radio Explains Clash
description: On Wednesday, North Koreas international shortwave radio service, Voice of Korea, broadcasting in English to the outside world, put its spin on Tuesdays exchange of fire between the two Koreas across their contested sea border.

title: Obama: I Dont Think About Sarah Palin
description: It was just days ago that former Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska told ABCs Barbara Walters that she believed she could beat President Obama in a hypothetical 2012 matchup.

title: Exercise: For Type 2 Diabetes, 2 Types of Training
description: People with type 2 diabetes can significantly lower their blood sugar with an exercise program that combines aerobics and weight lifting, a study reports.

title: British Students Leave Classes Over Cuts
description: LONDON  Thousands of students in cities across Britain walked out of classes on Wednesday and marched to protest the governments plans to cut education spending and steeply increase university tuition. It was the second such protest this month.

title: A Thanksgiving Arrangement
description: Not all flower arrangements need a vase  especially come Thanksgiving, when you can tap falls bounty for a cool still life. It could be arranged on your mantel, or a maybe a sideboard, or even a centerpiece for your dining table (if theres room). I can arrive at my friends house with a bag of produce from the market and a few items from my garden and do up an arrangement quickly and easily while sipping a drink. Heres how you can, too.In the example here, Im using white pumpkins  one big, several small  plus bittersweet vine, lady apples, small pears and a few leaves. Persimmons and quince would have made this grouping that much better, for the fuzz and color they bring. Ultimately, its all about the mix, the color palette and a balance of big and small, linear and round.

title: Wednesday Reading: Mini-Med Policies
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Bloggers Get Their Due From The Tonight Show
description: It was almost a blink-and-you-missed-it moment, but early Wednesday morning The Tonight Show made good on its word and gave credit to two bloggers for providing a montage of Taylor Swift video clips that Jay Leno had played for the country singer on Mondays broadcast.

title: Ask an Elder Law Attorney: Medicaid and the Primary Residence
description: Q.

title: Appeal Opens for U.S. Student Convicted in Italy
description: PERUGIA, Italy  Nearly a year after they were found guilty of murdering a British exchange student, Amanda Knox, a Seattle college student, and her onetime Italian boyfriend returned Wednesday to an underground courtroom in this hilltop town to begin their appeals.

title: Can a Publisher Run Schools? The Experts Debate
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, in his successful bid to become mayor, sold himself as an expert manager, a businessman who had made a fortune in private industry. He has now named Cathleen P. Black, a magazine executive, to be the next chancellor of New York Citys public schools. Why?

title: Womans Body Is Found in Harlem Park
description: Updated, 3:42 p.m. | A womans nude body was found in a city park in Harlem this morning, according to the police and the man who discovered it.

title: Growth: The U.S. vs. Europe
description: Economic growth in the United States has been quite disappointing over the last decade, as weve discussed before. Yet growth here has still been noticeably better than growth in Europe.

title: Clashing Numbers for the Nissan Leaf
description: On the Wheels blog, Matt Wald writes about an interesting disparity between two federal agencies estimates about how far the new Nissan Leaf will go on a fully charged battery.

title: Passengers Unmoved by Protests Against Scan
description: ATLANTA  Americans celebrated National Opt-Out Day in relative quiet on Wednesday, partaking peacefully in the traditional running of the airport security line, even when that tradition included full-body scans and pat-downs.

title: Arrest in Insider Trading Inquiry
description: Federal agents on Wednesday arrested an executive of a research firm on charges that he helped hedge funds obtain improper information about publicly traded companies, the first of what is expected to be a new round of cases related to insider trading.

title: Africa and Its Spheres of Influence
description: IT was late September, and Lowery Stokes Sims, a curator at the Museum of Arts and Design, was on the phone in her small white office, working out the shipping details for a piece in The Global Africa Project, which opened on Nov. 17. Through her window, the giant silver globe in Columbus Circle glistened.

title: Reader Photos: The Thanksgiving Countdown
description: Send us photos as you prepare and serve Thanksgiving dinner today and tomorrow. We want to see the bird in the brine; grandma preparing her famous stuffing; the family Labradoodle dressed as a turkey; your 3-year-old showing the guests the Pilgrim hat he made at preschool; and Uncle Petes carving technique. Theyll be collected at nytimes.com/dining.

title: How to Succeed in the Arts Business: Made Here Series Is Returning
description: Amid a wave of stories about the difficulties of the citys creative class, an online documentary series offers a few tales of success, or at least some guiding principles. Money, inspiration, and career longevity will all be addressed in the second season of Made Here, which chronicles the lives of performing artists in New York. Kate Valk and Elizabeth LeCompte of The Wooster Group, Oskar Eustis of The Public Theater, the puppeteer Basil Twist, and the musical comedian Reggie Watts  are among its subjects.

title: They Promote Bike Lanes and Use Them, Too
description: A hot issue has trickled down the steps of City Hall in recent years and washed through the streets of New York City, borough by borough. It is not hard to spot: Many of its standard bearers are awash in bright colors, and every one of them is powerful enough to reroute a minivan  at least in theory.

title: Texting During Labor
description: Push. Push. Text.

title: No Thanks in South Beach
description: Apparently the day before Thanksgiving is the proper time to stop and diagnose what is wrong with the Miami Heat. We are not sure why this is the proper time  maybe the Pilgrims are posthumously deciding they should have brought their talents to South Beach  but the memo was circulated so widely that even Lakers Coach Phil Jackson decided to spread some of his wisdom on the matter during a radio interview.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Wall Street Journal: Did the spam ever leave the cans? A cruise-line mystery.  Sam Sifton

title: Judge Allows Wiretaps in Galleon Case
description: A federal judge on Wednesday ruled that federal prosecutors can use wiretap recordings in their criminal case against Raj Rajaratnam, the founder of the Galleon Group hedge fund.

title: Risqu Writing in Pakistan
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Sabiho Bano, a wealthy Pakistani socialite with a penchant for martial arts, crawls out of her Mercedes and hops onto a crummy public bus picking up schoolgirls across this sprawl of a city.

title: In Dancing Finale, a Loss for Palin and a Win for ABC
description: ABC got everything it wanted out of its Dancing with the Stars finale Tuesday night: a huge rating  up about 25 percent from last year  and a winner that most of the shows legion of fans will feel is worthy.

title: Popcast: Kanye West and Best Boxed Sets
description: This week on Popcast, The Timess music podcast, our critics Jon Caramanica and Nate Chinen talk about the brilliant music and maddening-slash-entertaining public persona of Kanye West.

title: More on the Most (and Least) Expensive Vehicles to Insure
description: In a Bucks post earlier this year, The Most (and Least) Expensive Vehicles to Insure, I wrote about how Insure.com ranked the Porsche Carrera 911 GT2 two-door coupe the most expensive 2010 vehicle to insure, and that minivans and smaller sport utility vehicles tended to be least expensive to insure.

title: Candy, or Mothballs? E.P.A. Cautions Public
description: Mothballs that look like candy?

title: Jonathan Safran Foers Book as Art Object
description: The jackets of Jonathan Safran Foers books (Everything Is Illuminated, Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close, Eating Animals), designed by John Gray, helped set off a revival in hand-lettering. Graphic-design quirks have also figured in each of Foers narratives.

title: Jonathan Safran Foers Book as Art Object
description: The jackets of Jonathan Safran Foers books (Everything Is Illuminated, Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close, Eating Animals), designed by John Gray, helped set off a revival in hand-lettering. Graphic-design quirks have also figured in each of Foers narratives.

title: Seeing Things | More Wine
description: The Winter 2010 issue of T Design & Living contained a preview of the exhibition How Wine Became Modern: Design and Wine 1976 to Now at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. The exhibition opened last weekend, and while drinking wine in museum galleries is strictly prohibited, the design of the show brings wine into the galleries in other, ingenious ways. The museums architecture curator, Henry Urbach, collaborated on the installation with the New York architecture firm Diller Scofidio and Renfro, whose design for The American Lawn: Surface of Everyday Life, a 1998 exhibition at the Canadian Center for Architecture, convinced him that the architects would help bring something as banal as fermented grapes to life. For their part, the architects were intrigued by the idea of tackling a subject thats not traditional museum fare. Elizabeth Diller, one of the firms partners, said, Certain aspects of the story of wines transformation were more obvious  the branding of wineries with star architecture, design of stemware, labels, etc.  while it was less apparent how to present the experiential aspects of wine.

title: Auditors Report Says Turkish Federation Paid for Votes to Win 2012 Chess Olympiad
description: A recent audit of the Turkish Chess Federation reported that the federation paid voters to help win an election for the right to host the Chess Olympiad in 2012.

title: Nancy Mitford, Author, Dead; Satiric Novelist and Essayist
description: LONDON, July 1--Nancy Mitford, the prolific essayist, novelist and historian whose writing was enlivened by satire and a firm British aristocratic perspective, died yesterday at her home in Versailles, France. She was 68 years old.

title: ROOSEVELT, STALIN, CHURCHILL AGREE ON PLANS FOR WAR ON GERMANY IN TALKS AT TEHERAN; 1,500 MORE TONS OF BOMBS DROPPED ON BERLIN
description: London, Saturday, Dec. 4--The Moscow radio announced early this morning that President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin had met in Teheran, Iran, "a few days ago" to discuss questions relating to the war and the post-war period.

title: An Outcry Over Wall Streets Swagger
description: Jin Lee/BloombergDemonstrators at an April rally in New York against big banks.

title: Visualizing the Busy Skies
description: On Americas busiest travel day, its worth pulling back  or up  to marvel at how the globe has been so thoroughly knitted by aviation. About 2 million Americans are in the air on a typical day. In 2009, 4.796 billion passengers traveled through the worlds airports. A dizzying variety of products flows through the skies worldwide (the impact on commerce from the eruption of one volcano in Iceland illustrated this). And of course less welcome things move this way, as well. Its very likely that a jet carried West Nile virus to North America in 1999.

title: Weekly Pick Em: Celebrating the Season
description: Thanksgiving is Thursday, but the real holiday for college football fans comes on Friday.
