The days slate features three games (Auburn at Alabama, Arizona at Oregon, Boise State at Nevada) that have the potential to seismically shift the national championship race. Even if the Auburn, Oregon and Boise State win on Friday, Saturday offers plenty of intrigue. The Big Ten and Big 12 South have plenty of meaningful football left to play, with Michigan State at Penn State, and Oklahoma at Oklahoma State headlining the action in their respective conferences. And will also be plenty of interest in games that involve ranked teams that dont have a chance to win their conference (Louisiana State at Arkansas), in-state rivals (Florida at Florida State) and long-time foes who have seen better days (Notre Dame at Southern California). Its a holiday week, so take time to celebrate with perhaps the best weekend of the college football season.

title: A Weekend in Fort Lauderdale
description: While a smattering of lively bars still dot the beach, the former spring break haven has grown up.

title: 36 Hours in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.
description: FORT LAUDERDALE continues to mature beyond its spring-break days, with posh resorts now rising along the beach. Meanwhile, Las Olas Boulevard, the lively commercial strip that links the beach to downtown, has welcomed an array of new boutiques and restaurants. Sure, a smattering of raucous bars still dot the beach, and the rowdy clubgoers of Himmarshee Village can be three deep in the middle of the week. But at the end of a sunny, water-logged day, the resort town now offers a sophisticated evening that doesnt involve neon bikinis and syrupy daiquiris.

title: Riddle of the Wind at New Meadowlands Stadium
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  A familiar wind blew across the Meadowlands from the north at about 25 miles an hour on a recent weekday afternoon. It kept flags snapped at full attention and knocked over metal barriers in the parking lot. It was the type of wind known to blow fiercely around the old football stadium and swirl unpredictably inside it, making the former home of the Giants and the Jets a notoriously difficult place to punt, pass and kick. At times, it was like playing inside a vacuum canister.

title: High-Speed Train to Link Madrid and Valencia
description: For residents of  and visitors to  Madrid, a lunch spent gazing out at the Mediterranean will soon be only about 90 minutes away.

title: Knicks Show the Value in Mediocrity
description: Jake Appleman is a senior writer for SLAM Magazine and a contributor to NBA.com. You can read more at JakeAppleman.com

title: TimesCast | November 24, 2010
description: Busiest travel day; Lori Berenson speaks out and critic's take on Kanye West's new album.

title: Net-Price Calculator: The Latest Buzzword for College-Bound Families
description: How much will a particular college really cost you and your family?

title: Damaged Jewish Center Is Disputed 2 Years After Mumbai Attacks
description: MUMBAI, India  Days ahead of the second anniversary of a deadly terrorist attack on this bustling city, a Jewish center that was the site of some of the most brutal killings has become the subject of an awkward legal dispute.

title: Toyota iQ to Have Electric Variant in 2012
description: Toyotas urban electric car, shown in various guises at auto shows, will be based on the diminutive iQ when it arrives in Europe, Japan and the United States in 2012, the company says. Journalists in Japan drove prototypes of the car recently at Mega Web, a showroom with a small test track run by the Toyota Motor Corporation in Tokyo.

title: From India, the Manganiyars Offer a Spontaneous Song
description: Performers burst their boundaries Tuesday night at Lincoln Center.

title: Olga Koltelko in Action
description: The master athlete has been shattering track-and-field records all over the world.

title: Step Away From the Turkey, Maam
description: Its not just you with the Thanksgiving nightmares, friends. Stopped into work in advance of the big day to see what was what, and discovered that questions were already flowing in like the tide.

title: Covering the Civil War
description: Jamie Malanowski, a contributor to Disunion, appeared on The Takeaway to discuss the series and his effort to cover one of the most intensely political periods in United States history.

title: New York Has Worst Traffic in U.S. and Canada, Report Says
description: 10:43 a.m. | Updated

title: ASSEMBLY VOTES PALESTINE PARTITION; MARGIN IS 33 TO 13; ARABS WALK OUT; ARANHA HAILS WORK AS SESSION ENDS
description: The United Nations General Assembly approved yesterday a proposal to partition Palestine into two states, one Arab and the other Jewish, that are to become fully independent by Oct.1. The vote was 33 to 13 with two abstentions and one delegation, the Siamese, absent.

title: Louisa M. Alcott Dead
description: BOSTON, Mass., March 6.--Miss Louisa M. Alcott died this morning. Coming so soon after the death of her father the suddenly announced decease of Miss Alcott brings a double sorrow to the many friends of the family, while the loss of this talented writer will be felt far and wide among the many readers of her favorite books. For a long time Miss Alcott had been ill, suffering from nervous prostration. Last Autumn she appeared to be improving and went to the Highlands to reside with Dr. Rhoda A. Lawrence. She drove from there into town to visit her father on Thursday last, and caught a cold, which on Saturday settled on the base of the brain and developed spinal meningitis. She died at the Highlands early this morning. Miss Alcott was born on her father's birthday, and it is singular that she should have followed him so soon to the grave.

title: Trained for Battle, Now Operating a Small Business
description: In November 2004, during Justin Bajemas second tour of duty in Iraq, his LAV-25 infantry fighting vehicle was hit by an improvised explosive device. Surrounded by heavy machine-gun fire, he was pinned under 28,000 pounds in a drained canal for 40 minutes. It threw my vehicle in the air like a toy, he recalled. I almost lost my leg, almost bled out and died.

title: Venice in Winter
description: I HADNT been back to Venice in years when I found myself there on assignment. It was November; the citys scattered trees had begun to turn brown. The light, as always, was beyond compare and there was a watery chill in the air. I loved it immediately.

title: Enjoying Winters Chill in Venice
description: Let the summer crowds have July. The city slows down to reveal its soul to a visitor with sweaters, boots and a book.

title: On a Day of Peace in Belfast, Faiths Join to Cheer Clinton
description: Belfast, Northern Ireland, Nov. 30 -- President Clinton ranged across a remarkably transformed Northern Ireland today, promising the once bitterly hostile Catholic and Protestant communities that if they persevered in their search for peace, 'the United States of America will proudly stand with you.'

title: Churchill Dies at 90 At Home in London
description: LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 24--Sir Winston Churchill is dead.

title: Boyle Album Picks Up Steam
description: With a strong second week of sales Susan Boyles holiday album, The Gift, leads an almost entirely new crop of titles on Billboards album chart. The Gift (Syco/Columbia) had 335,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan, a gain of 5 percent over its first week  and since second-week drops are the norm for new albums this suggests that Ms. Boyles will have staying power.

title: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
description: 1. Not if I could avoid it: Hillary Clinton regarding a full-body pat-down, or Hillary Clinton on whether shell see Burlesque?

title: Video: Spider-Man on 60 Minutes
description: Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark will get some national exposure on Sunday night when 60 Minutes takes a behind-the-scenes look at the making of the technologically complex musical, which is directed by Julie Taymor and has music by Bono and The Edge of the rock band U2. Lesley Stahl, the 60 Minutes correspondent, started following the development of the show 18 months ago; the curtain goes up on the first preview on Sunday at 6:30 p.m., a half-hour before the program is to air on CBS.

title: Fewer New Yorkers Get Health Insurance Through Employers
description: In the depressing-but-not-surprising category, a recent study finds that the percentage of New York state residents who get health insurance through their jobs has dropped considerably, from 69 percent in 2003 to 58 percent in 2009.

title: 12-Nation Pact Makes Antarctic Science Reserve
description: Washington, Dec. 1--A region equal in area to Europe and the United States combined was made into a preserve for scientific research today, immune from political and military strife.

title: Gerard Swope, 84, Ex-G.E. Head, Dies
description: Gerard Swope, former president of the General Electric Company and onetime chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, died yesterday at his home, 161 East Seventy-ninth Street. He was 84 years old.

title: A Chinese Minister on Chinese Health
description: Tsung-Mei Cheng, a health policy expert at Princeton (whos quoted in my column on Wednesday), interviewed Chen Zhu, Chinas health minister, for the journal Health Affairs in 2008. Health Affairs has removed its normal gate from the interview for a week, for anyone who wants to hear about Chinas health system from a top Communist Party official.

title: Apple and Cider Live On to See Another Thanksgiving
description: He could hardly say his lines with a straight face, but President Obama pardoned two turkeys on Wednesday morning, saying it feels pretty good to stop at least one shellacking this November.

title: Hirotaka Inoue | Natural Wonder
description: I was conditioned to try to become a doctor just as my father  I even majored in Political Science in college, said the jewelry designer Hirotaka Inoue during a visit to Ts offices. The transition from political theorist to jeweler started in Paris where Inoue studied how to select and set stones before returning to Japan working for a jewelry firm. Designing his own line in 2009, Inoues first collection, available at the Nolita boutique Eva (355A Bowery, between Third and Fourth Streets, (212) 925-3890), showcases his intricate craftsmanship and his whimsical nature. One of his creations is a new beige-colored gold. Its not flashy but a very chic choice of metal  it took six months to get the right percentage of silver, copper and some platinum to make the sand gold color, he says. More playful designs include the Vanit collection of skull charms ($477 and up), some with black diamond teeth accents, to the classic Serpent and Naja rings (starting at $550), featuring intricate scaling detailwork. Inoue says, My jewelry can change its color like a chameleon  classic to funny to cool to chic.

title: The Barbershop Renaissance
description: EARLIER this month, Tristan Chirico was trying to do some last-minute errands in New York before flying back to Jordan and his job teaching theater at a prep school there. The most pressing item on his list was a haircut.

title: Barbershops Offer a Snippet of Nostalgia
description: Crowds line up at Manhattans new crop of retro barbershops for solid, classic cuts.

title: Thanksgiving as a Teachable Moment
description: Like teachers and students across the country, we too are celebrating Thanksgiving with a long weekend.

title: Final Vote Condemns M'Carthy, 67-22, For Abusing Senate and Committee; Zwicker Count Eliminated in Debate
description: Washington, Dec 2--The Senate voted 67 to 22 tonight to condemn Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican Senator from Wisconsin.

title: Maria Callas, 53, Is Dead of Heart Attack in Paris
description: Maria Callas, the soprano whose intensely dramatic portrayals made her the most exciting opera singer of her time, died of a heart attack yesterday at her home in Paris. She was 53 years old.

title: Pension Parasites
description: Low income, middle-aged (Japanese) people who rely on their parents pensions for financial support.

title:
GAS LEAK IN INDIA KILLS AT LEAST
410 IN CITY OF BHOPAL
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 3 -- Toxic gas leaking from an American-owned insecticide plant in central India killed at least 410 people overnight, many as they slept, officials said today.

title: Anna Freud, Psychoanalyst, Dies in London at 86
description: Anna Freud, daughter of Sigmund Freud and an eminent psychoanalyst in her own right, died at her London home today at the age of 86, her family said.

title: Manly, or Close
description: IN the end, it was the pool ball  faded, impaled on a rod, stuck to a small platform  that almost got me. A few of them ($28 each) were clustered on a table near the back of Modern Anthology, like immobilized, castrated gearshifts from a 1950s rebel flick.

title: Extreme Makeover for Home of the Royal Shakespeare Company
description: 3:49 p.m. | Updated

title: Homes for $350,000
description: A four-bedroom house in Vermont, a three-bedroom house in New Mexico and a two-bedroom condo in Chicago.

title: Out of the Crucible of Civil War, Franco's Iron Hand Forged a Modern Spain
description: One of the most durable, canny and empirical of modern dictators, Francisco Paulino Hermenegildo Teodulo Franco y Bahamonde became master of Spain as a result of a military conspiracy, a dash of luck, timely help from foreign corporations, the influence of the Roman Catholic hierarchy and crucial armed assistance from Hitler and Mussolini.

title: UNO Bill Approved By Senate, 65 to 7, With One Change
description: Washington, Dec. 4--The Senate passed by a 65-to-7 vote this evening the legislation to give the United States full, active participation in the United Nations Organization in accordance with the San Francisco Charter that it ratified, 89 to 2, last July.

title: What You Get for ... $350,000
description: LA UNION, N.M.

title: A Cairo Street Free From Traffic and Haggling
description: Tourists tired from haggling in Cairo can now find respite steps away on the recently renovated, pedestrian-only street of Al Muizz li Din-Allah.

title: Paterson Urges Bloomberg to Accept Deal on Chancellor
description: With the candidacy of Cathleen P. Black, Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs choice for the citys next schools chancellor, suddenly in trouble, the Bloomberg administration is now considering its next moves.

title: Thats Me on Screen, but I Still Didnt Do It
description: IF there were one person youd expect to take issue with All Good Things, the new movie directed by Andrew Jarecki, it would be Robert A. Durst, since it implicates him in three killings, two of which he is depicted as committing and a third as orchestrating.

title: Dig Out Those Pocket Combs
description: IN the last couple of years, the tops of mens heads have provided one of those ironies that make fashion so endearingly silly. It started in the late 1990s, when fashionably antifashion guys began leaving their hair messy and matted, as if they had just rolled out of bed. A product even appeared called Bed Head to help naturally neat hair fall into a perfect rats nest.

title: A Villa With Caribbean Views
description: A four-bedroom villa with cathedral ceilings is on the market for 2.9 million euros ($4 million).

title: House Hunting in ... St. Barts
description: A FOUR-BEDROOM VILLA WITH CARIBBEAN VIEWS

title: 6 Peacekeepers in Somalia Arrested in Civilian Deaths
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The African Union peacekeeping force in Somalia has arrested six of its own peacekeepers after two civilians were killed in a burst of indiscriminate gunfire, African Union officials said Wednesday.

title: Please Dont Eat the Mothballs
description: Look out for mothballs packaged to resemble delicious Chinese candies. Theyre poisonous, to humans as well as, presumably, moths. Thats the message from the federal Environmental Protection Agency, which says that an importer in Brooklyn tried to bring the product, Fuji Lavender Moth Tablets, into the country.

title: Suicide Attack Strikes Shiites in Yemen
description: SANA, Yemen  A suicide car bomb ripped through a convoy of civilians traveling to a Shiite ceremony in northwestern Yemen on Wednesday, killing 17 members of the Houthi clan and leaving 5 wounded, officials said.

title: East 67th Street, 10:05 A.M.
Artifacts | Squeeze Therapy
description: A womans work is definitely never done in a Mika Rottenberg video. I mean really never. The women in her latest, Squeeze  one of the bigger attractions in Chelsea right now  submit to the drudgery of their assembly-line labors without a peep, as if that were all life was about. Seen in Arizona and India and confined to a spa-from-hell in Rottenbergs Harlem studio, they pick lettuce, collect rubber sap, stretch it into latex, massage sore hands and manufacture blush from the scrapings of their own reddened cheeks. And all they get out of it is more work.

title: On Will Saletans Abortion Compromise
description: Speaking of contraception-related debates, Slates Will Saletan recently made yet another attempt to persuade the pro-life movement to champion contraception and sex education instead of focusing on throwing up legal impediments to abortion. He and I have been over this ground many times before. (You can read my response to an earlier iteration of his argument here, with follow-ups here and here and here.) But this time, Saletan pushed things a bit further, by suggesting that his own side should reconsider the legality of second-trimester abortions. He quoted the pro-choice historian David Garrow, speaking at the Princeton conference on abortion that occasioned Saletans reflections, and making what seemed to be a substantial concession on this front. Heres Garrow:

title: Your Turkey Questions, Answered
description: Need assistance with the bird, the sides, the wine, the timing? Sam Sifton is manning the Thanksgiving Help Line on Diners Journal. He writes:

title: Arhoolie at 50
description: The influential American roots music label is celebrating its anniversary.

title: Tips for Thanksgiving Shopping
description: Forget Black Friday. Its all about Thanksgiving shopping now. With consumers growing weary, and perhaps more cynical, of Black Friday and Cyber Monday deals, many retailers are now trying to turn Thanksgiving into a new shopping holiday.

title: Shakespeare's New Stage
description: A documentary about the redesign of the Royal Shakespeare Company's home in Stratford-upon-Avon. (Video courtesy of the company)

title: In Argentina, Touring the Tigre Delta
description: THE stunning belle-poque building that houses the Museo de Arte Tigre in the Tigre Delta of Argentina opened as a social club a century ago, when rich bohemians would visit the region to give themselves a respite from Buenos Aires. The building eventually fell into disuse before reopening as a museum in 2006, newly refurbished with marble, bronze and stained glass as part of a municipal improvement project.

title: Is Issa in Line for Throne?
description: THE announcement of Kate Middletons engagement to Prince William loosed the inevitable flurry of speculation. What will her royal title be? Will she one day be known as Queen Kate? Will her dress vie in splendor with the satin-and-pearl confection that Diana, Princess of Wales, wore on her wedding day? Most urgently, who will design it?

title: Still the Address of Down-Home Sounds
description: EL CERRITO, Calif.

title: Iverson and Francis Testing Overseas Markets
description: Its a tale of two continents and two former N.B.A. All-Star guards trying to keep their careers alive.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from South Korea, Iraq and Brazil.

title: 'The Global Africa Project'
description: A look at some of the artists in a new exhibition at the Museum of Arts and Design.

title: A Spanish Bailout Would Test Europes Strained Finances
description: MADRID  Europe so far has survived the bailout of Greece. The financial rescue of Ireland also is manageable. Even if Portugal becomes the third country to succumb and seek aid, as many people widely predict, it is unlikely to push Europe to the financial brink.

title: Searching for Authentic Thai Cuisine
description: Thai food moves from Bangkoks sidewalk stalls and into enterprising new restaurants.

title: Authentic Thai Cuisine Moves in From Sidewalk Stalls
description: CAN you breathe? I asked my husband who, panting and flushed, seemed to be having a heart attack. I wasnt faring much better. Tears streamed down my cheeks as I used our menu to whip up a breeze from the sultry city air at Bo.lan, an attractive and ambitious Bangkok restaurant. The dish was hot. Very hot. But I couldnt resist going back for more.

title: R&R Challenges for the Camouflage Set
description: DURING eight tours of duty in Iraq and Afghanistan over nine years, Air Force Maj. Zach Barker flew numerous AC-130 gunship flights, gathering intelligence and providing fire support for ground troops. When the time came for some R & R, he didnt choose to decompress on a secluded beach. He went trekking, kayaking and white-water rafting. And for his final midtour leave in 2008, he climbed Mount Kilimanjaro.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from South Korea, Iraq and Brazil.

title: 100 Notable Books of 2010
description: FICTION & POETRY

title: Lone Star Set for Korean Deal
description: 7:36 a.m. | Updated Lone Star, the buyout firm, is finally riding off into the sunset on a Korean investment.

title: Choosing the 100 Notable Books of 2010
description: Today, we published our 100 Notable Books of the Year online (they will appear in print on Dec. 5). The task of choosing them  or rather of excluding other superb books  grows harder each time. Consider it in terms of arithmetic: If we limited ourselves to a single work of fiction and nonfiction chosen from each of the issues published since Dec. 6, 2009, when the previous Notables list appeared, we would exceed our self-imposed limit.

title: Choosing the 100 Notable Books of 2010
description: Today, we published our 100 Notable Books of the Year online (they will appear in print on Dec. 5). The task of choosing them  or rather of excluding other superb books  grows harder each time. Consider it in terms of arithmetic: If we limited ourselves to a single work of fiction and nonfiction chosen from each of the issues published since Dec. 6, 2009, when the previous Notables list appeared, we would exceed our self-imposed limit.

title: Whats in a Name? Fashisms Founder Explains
description: On Friday, I wrote about Fashism, a start-up in New York with a social shopping service that lets people get instant feedback on clothes they want to buy.

title: A Street for Adults in Orlando
description: INTERNATIONAL DRIVE in Orlando, Fla., a shaded boulevard lined with inexpensive hotels, theme restaurants and sundry entertainments (most notably, SeaWorld), is already one of many areas in the city dedicated to keeping children happy. But to many adults traveling without kids  certainly a sizable chunk of the millions who attend events at the nearby Orange County Convention Center  the attraction of I-Drive, as its known, has been limited to a handful of bewilderingly large shopping malls.

title: Americas Funniest Airport Screening Videos
description: Just in time for the holidays, a new genre of home movie is sweeping the nation, or at least YouTube: the bizarre security checkpoint pat-down video. Fueled by hysteria over new screening techniques at Americas airports, an informal competition seems to have started, the aim of which is to film the funniest, or most outrageous, or most outrageously funny example of over-reach, or under-reach, by an employee of the Transportation Security Administration.

title: Squinkies Maker Savors Demand for Holidays Hot Toy
description: Midway through last year, as analysts tried to predict where the economy was going, the toy maker Bill Nichols decided he had the answer. He bet that the economy would still be so shaky this holiday season that a bargain-priced plastic toy would take off.

title: Hotel Review: Soho Beach House, Miami Beach, Fla.
description: BASICS

title: Dont Ask Hearings Set for Next Week
description: The nations top two defense officials are scheduled to head to Capitol Hill next week to discuss a Pentagon report gauging the potential effects of repealing the militarys dont ask, dont tell policy.

title: Our Far-Flung Correspondents
description: Oh, its coming up roses and daffodils over here at Diners Journal. I suppose at some newspapers and newsgathering organizations the Thanksgiving questions would mostly concern the proper preparation of yams and apple pies. We get those, to be sure, but also much more.

title: Restaurant Review: Ttedoie, in Lyon, France
description: Long a gastronomic darling of French food critics, the city of Lyon still pulses with the work of adventurous chefs. Earlier this year, it was a startling reinvention by the celebrated Christian Ttedoie that dominated headlines.

title: Similar Genes, Different Personalities
description: I had an NPR driveway moment earlier this week, listening to a piece by Alix Spiegel about why siblings are so different.

title: Reader Photos: The Thanksgiving Table
description: Hundreds of photos of Thanksgiving preparation and dishes from around the globe.

title: Trespassing for a Last View of the Dodge Mansion
description: EVERYONE has a Lost New York, to riff on Nathan Silvers influential book of 1967 cataloging New Yorks architectural losses. Often its just a favorite cafe or shop.

title: Newly Arrived | Chinti and Parker
description: The eco-minded label Chinti and Parker, by the London-based cousins, designers and co-founders Anna Singh and Rachael Wood, is making its way across the pond and into the American market. The label got the attention of Natalie Massenet from the luxury site Net-a-porter.com, which will carry an exclusive capsule collection. Singh and Wood took a detour to Ts offices for a brief chat. Were not complete granolas, said Wood with a laugh. Equipped with their third season and Net-a-porter selections, Wood said, our core value is that we are very particular about our fabrics. That translates into organic jerseys and cashmeres in a variety of weights, like flimsier feels for a sexy slouch trouser and weighty textiles for a more structured dress.

title: Soldier Shatters the Smug Peace on the Home Front
description: Its not uncommon for a foreign drama to change before it opens in New York. If the play is not in English, its often translated. Culturally specific details are massaged out; elements are changed to appeal to an American audience. When Copenhagen transferred from London, for instance, the sound of the nuclear explosion became louder. Broadway likes its bombs big.

title: Casement Windows Are Architects New Darling
description: FOR a long time, mullioned steel casement windows, the gridded kind that swing out like a door, had fallen out of fashion. They leaked badly, and a stiff wind could blow out their panes or knock their hinges askew. Over the years they have been replaced in many buildings by single-pane aluminum casement or double-hung windows.

title: Wednesday for Thursday
description: The meaning of Thanksgiving, explained.

title: On Location With Nora Ephron
description: Nora EphronAge: 69 Occupation: Writer and director

title: U.S. Firms Up Critical Habitat for Polar Bears
description: The Interior Department designated 187,157 square miles of Alaskan seas and lands as critical to the survival of the polar bear on Wednesday. More than 95 percent of it is offshore, including some areas that may have large undersea oil deposits.

title: F.H.A. Rule Changes for Mortgage Borrowers
description: HOME buyers with sketchy credit who are unable to qualify for conventional mortgages may now find it more costly and difficult to obtain loans insured by the Federal Housing Administration.

title: Kyl Lays Out  Objections to Arms Treaty
description: 5:14 p.m. | Updated The Obama administrations plans to modernize the nations nuclear weapons complex remain inadequate and should be further refined before the ratification of a new arms control treaty with Russia, the lead Senate Republican negotiator said on Wednesday.

title: Small Club, Big Star, Short Notice
description: It started, as all huge-star-in-tiny-Manhattan-club concerts must, with a ticket rush and a spike in Craigslist prices. In the middle of the story there was lots of pushing and shoving at the door followed by an hour and a half of celebrity spotting and electrifying music, and it ended with a bewildering rant: a classic Kanye West event, in other words, for the lucky few who got to see him perform late Tuesday night.

title: Getting the Crunch From Cilantro
description: Anybody whos too lazy to pluck cilantro (or parsley) leaves off their stems before chopping knows that theres plenty of flavor in those stems  which is one reason they go into the stockpot or a bouquet garni.

title: Borrowed for Tonight, Credited Later
description: When Rich Juzwiak saw a series of video clips that Jay Leno played for the country star Taylor Swift on Monday nights broadcast of The Tonight Show, depicting her reacting with repeated expressions of surprise to a series of awards-show victories, he knew it looked more than familiar. He argued on his blog that the segment had been taken directly from a similar Web video he made with a colleague. The result: NBC acknowledged the work of Mr. Juzwiak and his co-worker on Tuesdays Tonight Show.

title: Traveler of the Day
description: This is Thembi the hedgehog. He was encountered on the tarmac this afternoon at Kennedy International Airport, aboard a Delta flight bound for Burlington, Vt.

title: Wild Tigers on a Crowding Planet
description: The first International Tiger Conservation Forum has wrapped up in St. Petersburg, Russia. Dignitaries and participating organizations pledged new support for controls on poaching, efforts to limit tiger-human clashes in populous areas and steps to conserve habitat, with money coming both from the 13 countries where tigers still roam and nations whose citizens desire a world with room for wild tigers. (Money is coming from individuals, as well, including $1 million from Leonardo DiCaprio, who was enthusiastically greeted by the meetings host, Russian Prime Minister Vladimir Putin.)

title: With Facebook Claiming the Word Face, Some Alternatives
description: Facebook is a few steps away fromgetting a trademark onthe word face with the United States Patent and Trademark Office, according to a document discovered by the technology blog TechCrunch, which it wrote about on Tuesday.

title: Militaristic Undercurrents Amid Brittens Seascapes
description: Before conducting the Juilliard Orchestra in Brittens Four Sea Interludes from Peter Grimes at Alice Tully Hall on Monday evening, Nicholas McGegan said from the stage that it was a very special day for music lovers, being both Brittens birthday and the feast day of St. Cecilia, the patron saint of music. Britten would have been 97 this year, Mr. McGegan added, still younger than the American composer Elliott Carter, who turns 102 next month.

title: The Last Blacksmith on Blacksmith Street
description: Nguyen Phuong Hung is the last blacksmith on Blacksmith Street in the rapidly modernizing ancient quarter of Hanoi.

title: 1963: Fyrstekake (Royal Cake)
description: This recipe appeared in The Times in an article by Craig Claiborne.

title: 2010: Royal Cake Bisteeya
description: By Mourad Lahlou, the chef and owner at Aziza in San Francisco.

title: Recipe Redux: Fyrstekake (Royal Cake), 1963
description: Midcentury Scandinavian food never had the second life that Scandinavian furniture did. And if youd like to know why, imagine the opposite  a world in which we savor salted herring and forget about Saarinen tables. No! But if we were to bring back just one worthy dish, Id vote for fyrstekake, also known as royal cake.

title: Living In | New Cassel, L.I.
description: The residential blocks of this central Nassau County hamlet are lined with World War II-era Capes, high ranches and split levels.

title: ABC a Champion, Too, Thanks to Bristol Palin
description: ABC got everything it wanted out of its Dancing With the Stars finale Tuesday night: a huge audience, up about 25 percent from last year, and a winner that most of the shows legion of fans will most likely feel is worthy.

title: Kate the Great
description: Everyone wants a piece of Kate Moss. A kitten heel short of most modern glamazons, Moss has been one of the most in-demand fashion models for two decades  and one of the most talked about. Now theres a bit more of her to go around. For the past year and a half, Moss has been collaborating with James Danziger, of Danziger Projects, on curating a portfolio of 11 images of her by 11 of her favorite photographers. The result, a limited edition of 30 portfolios designed by Ruth Ansel and priced from $75,000 each (the figure is expected to go up as the series sells out), is being exhibited for the first time at the Pulse art fair in Miami Dec. 2 to 5. The images, by a stellar lineup of fashion and art world luminaries, including Chuck Close, Juergen Teller and Annie Leibovitz, showcase not only Mosss preternatural beauty but also her undeniable versatility. The Moment recently phoned Moss at her country home in England.

title: Enticing Readers to a Long Road With Sudden Shocks of Self-Recognition
description: At first you might wonder why the stories seem so disturbingly familiar. An alienated traveler, wandering through a deserted landscape, forges a brief, doomed relationship with an inscrutable, black-clad stranger. The same traveler, seemingly incapable of finding meaningful human connection, futilely scrambles after a remote possibility of romance. Years later the traveler, now middle aged yet still dissatisfied by his inability to engage meaningfully with others, discovers that he is powerless to alter the fate of a self-destructive friend.

title: A Plays Miners Dig for the Meaning Behind Their Art
description: If you love painting or think you could, consider seeing The Pitmen Painters, the British play by Lee Hall that the Manhattan Theater Club is presenting on Broadway at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater. It tells the true story of a group of northern England miners who joined an art appreciation class in 1934, but it is really a tutorial in looking at art, especially painting.

title: Study Finds No Progress in Safety at Hospitals
description: Efforts to make hospitals safer for patients are falling short, researchers report in the first large study in a decade to analyze harm from medical care and to track it over time.

title: Just Be Thankful It Didnt Happen to You
description: Earlier this week, City Room asked readers to recount Thanksgiving disasters from years past. Here are some of our favorites, lightly edited.

title: Skin Deep: Beauty Gift Guide
description: Holiday gift ideas for the very busy, the traveler, friends of the Earth, tween and teens and others on your list.

title: Beauty Gifts for All Ages
description: SKIN creams, scents and cosmetics usually make reliable and affordable holiday gifts, but they also can go horribly wrong, as anyone who has had a baby-powder-scented body-splash gift set idling on her latrine for years can attest.

title: Theater Talkback: Giving Thanks in a Thankless Season
description: A distinct gloom has descended upon conversations among those of us whose business it is to attend the theater as often as some people turn on the television set. By which I mostly mean critics, although I do number among my friends a few obsessive civilians who see almost as much as I do. As the fall season dwindles to a close, the general opinion is that this has been an unusually grim and often grueling couple of months for New York theater, with the more hollow-eyed and enervated among us even suggesting that its the worst season in memory.

title: Letters: Crybabies
description: To the Editor: Please Refrain From Tantrums Onboard (Nov. 14) discusses how crying infants disturb other passengers during flight but says virtually nothing about why infants cry and what can be done about it. I have interviewed hundreds of parents who traveled by air with infants. Some of my findings:

title: Tornadoes of Anarchy and AutoTune
description: FARMINGDALE, N.Y.  Of the many troubling things at Brokencydes show at the Crazy Donkey here Monday night, the most troubling were the apologies. They came from Mikl, one of the groups vocalists, who was apologizing for his voice, his fatigue, his limited range of movement, for the fact that maybe hed started off the show a little drunk but was more engaged now.

title: 3 Numbers to Rate Volts Fuel Economy
description: DETROIT  Shoppers trying to determine the fuel efficiency of the Chevrolet Volt will see a window label that offers multiple ratings for different driving patterns, General Motors said on Wednesday.

title: Evolution of a Beard
description: How Abraham Lincoln went from a clean-shaven candidate to a bearded president.

title: Photo Replay: Nov. 24
description: A view of the day in sports, from the Asian Games to chilly football in Canada.

title: Art Inflation: Macys Murakamis
description: It is not uncommon for people to react with awe to their first up-close encounter with a balloon from the Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade. But when Takashi Murakami saw his contributions to Thursdays event, he bowed. Twice.

title: Selling History With 50s Pulp Pow and Punch
description: The rendezvous was set for 2 p.m. sharp at Cafe Sabarsky on the teeming island metropolis of Manhattan. This Old World outpost was dark and silent as a tomb  except for the music, lively chatter and oversize windows. Near the bar sat a white-haired gentleman in black and a vivacious blonde with a slash of blood-red lipstick. On the table in front of them lay a plate of sptzle mit schwammerln and a knife that glinted like the sharpened steel of a scimitar. Actually, the only thing it was used for was butter, as the team at this cafe, the brother and sister team of David and Margaret Talbot, save the gore for print. They are the mild-mannered creators of a new book series called Pulp History, rip-roaring nonfiction tales with enough purple prose, gory illustrations and va-va-va-voom women to lure in even reluctant teenage male readers.

title: World Dangerously Close to Food Crisis, U.N. Says
description: Global grain production will tumble by 63 million metric tons this year, or 2 percent over all, mainly because of weather-related calamities like the Russian heat wave and the floods in Pakistan, the United Nations estimates in its most recent report on the world food supply. The United Nations had previously projected that grain yields would grow 1.2 percent this year.

title: A TV Vote Seasoned With Politics
description: It must be embedded in the Palin genetic code. Sarah Palin made a virtue of inexperience in the 2008 presidential campaign, baiting her critics for being elitist. On Dancing With the Stars, so did Bristol Palin.

title: Somali Pirates Convicted in Virginia
description: Five Somali men, who were captured by the U.S. Navy in April after they shot at an American guided-missile frigate off the coast of Africa, were convicted of piracy by a federal court in Virginia on Wednesday.

title: A Hamlet on the Long Road to Renewal
description: ITS been a long, long, long journey, said Bishop Lionel Harvey, the president of the Unified New Cassel Community Revitalization Corporation. When he took over as senior pastor of the local Baptist cathedral 12 years ago, what he found in this 1.5-square-mile unincorporated wedge of the otherwise well-heeled Long Island town of North Hempstead was blight.

title: Big Night for ABC
description: With the two-hour season finale of Dancing With the Stars averaging more than 24 million viewers, ABC easily won the night, even as its 8 oclock episode of No Ordinary Family (7 million) struggled opposite its competition, including CBSs NCIS (18.8 million) and Foxs Glee (10.4 million), with a guest appearance by Carol Burnett. CBS placed second on the night, earning solid results for NCIS: Los Angeles (14.9 million) and The Good Wife (10 million). Fox was third, and NBC ranked fourth with The Biggest Loser from 8 to 10 (6.8 million), followed by Parenthood (4.5 million).

title: Opening the Mysterious Winmail.dat
Finding That One Chance to Do the Impossible
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  The Fall North American Bridge Championships begin here on Thursday at the Marriott World Center Resort and will end on Dec. 5.

title: Trading on Sentiment at Dominick Dunnes Estate Sale
description: Hudson, N.Y.

title: Shopping Apps That Can Point You to Lower Prices
description: At first, there is something unsettling about skulking around a store with a cellphone, using it to scan bar codes and check prices. The behavior is novel enough to draw glances from other shoppers and, more to the point, occasional glares from store clerks.

title: Official Objections to Emanuel Candidacy
description: CHICAGO  Rahm Emanuel has made it perfectly clear that he wants to be mayor of this city. Now the question is: Does he qualify?

title: Charting a Friendship Through a Lifetime of Films
description: If you squint a little, Break Ke Baad doesnt look much different from an average  in 2010, perhaps slightly above average  Hollywood romantic comedy. This being an Indian movie, the stars are more attractive but less naturally funny than the Hollywood norm.

title: Its Getting Hot in Here
description: But things could be worse, as you shall see. Im off to review a restaurant and then get some sleep. Please come back in the morning and check in often. Happy Thanksgiving, one and all.

title: Bon Voyage | A New Line From Azzaro
description: Since she joined the Azzaro French luxury brand as artistic director eight years ago, Vanessa Seward has brought it out of the exclusive realm of fancy-wear and into every-wear  pieces that meet the sundry needs of the everywoman. Not that she is opposed to the glamour. It was an unconscious move for the line, says the designer and new mom. I think having a baby brought a youthfulness, freshness and versatility to the collection. As she revisited the generations of inspirational women before her, photographs from the 1930s of her grandmother and friends vacationing along the Tigre River in Argentina resurfaced. Their clothing were all the things I wanted: timeless, comfortable and pretty, she says. The Voyage capsule collection, Azzaros latest diffusion line, is designed with comfort and a more carefree agenda in mind. It includes wrinkle-free materials like jerseys, knits and cashmere, introduced in sophisticated separates (think playsuits and pantsuits) and dresses, like a wrap model with embroidered cord detail. The Azzaro woman is a woman that shows her femininity, Seward says. Nowadays women dont have to be in a power suit to be in power.

title: Hitchcock Wouldve Had a Web Site
description: IN June 1941 a moviegoer named David Stephens wrote the director Frank Capra a letter about the his film Meet John Doe. Although Mr. Stephens worried that writing the letter might make him late for work, the force of his feelings kept him scribbling until 3 a.m. All this talk of pessimism that all high school graduates get must be wrong, he wrote. We are told that we go out to meet a cruel, hard, debasing world, of men that will cut your heart to sunders if they possibly can.

title: Novelists Self-Portrait, Distilled on Screen
description: IN this country Mordecai Richler is probably best known for the movie The Apprenticeship of Duddy Kravitz, based on his novel of the same name. (With Lionel Chetwynd, he also wrote the screenplay.) But for some unaccountable reason Richler, who died in 2001, was immensely popular in Italy, where was last novel, Barneys Version,was a best seller. And in his native Canada he was a national institution, cherished because of the way he indiscriminately poked fun at Canadians in general, but especially the Jews, the French separatists and the Anglophile nationalists, who were locked in mutual antagonism.

title: A Renter With Piano-Sized Issues
description: THOUGH she had rented in both Boston and Pittsburgh, Vivian Choi had no idea what she would be facing in a hunt for an apartment in New York.

title: Breaking Into the Smartphone (Risks Included)
description: Keith Medenblik is captivated by the iPhone. He bought his first iPhone, the 3G model, two years ago. A year later he upgraded to a 3GS and more recently to Apples newest creation, the iPhone 4.

title: DeLay Is Convicted in Texas Donation Case
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Tom DeLay, one of the most powerful and divisive Republican lawmakers ever to come out of Texas, was convicted Wednesday of money-laundering charges in a state trial, five years after his indictment here forced him to resign as majority leader in the House of Representatives.

title: Gay Progressive Republican on Air in Iowa
description: Its never too early to test the waters  especially for an openly gay progressive Republican trying to snag the partys 2012 presidential nomination.

title: Doing Time, a Kiss Is Still a Kiss
description: FROM very early on, the screenwriters turned directors Glenn Ficarra and John Requa had concerns about the commercial viability of their directorial debut, I Love You Phillip Morris.

title: A Small Apartment Where Simplicity Reigns
description: The owner of a high-end cleaning service in New York lives in a spare apartment decorated entirely in white.

title: A Tiny White Apartment for a Pared-Down Life
description: SEEING photos of the pristine white apartment of the home-cleaning queen Barbara Roche Fierman  an apartment so dust-, dirt- and stain-free it appears no human could possibly live there  makes a reporter think dastardly thoughts.

title: A Reprieve for Missing 9/11 Plaintiffs
description: Some 9/11 workers who did not accept a settlement offered by the city by last weeks deadline will have another bite at the apple: the federal judge overseeing the cases has appointed a lawyer to help those who may want to opt into the settlement after all to make that choice by Dec. 17.

title: Shopping Snapshots for Nov. 25
description: Four questions for Tatsugo Yoda, owner and founder of Aloha Rag; Janice Huminska has opened a shop in NoLIta; Diane Von Furstenbergs trench coat; and more.

title: The Lessons of 10 Years of Talking Tech
description: Its a special week in America. All over the country, families are gathering in warmly lighted homes. Theyre sitting down to fancy feasts at decorated tables. They smile, they pour libations, they raise their glasses.

title: O.K., Hippos, Grab Your Tutus
description: FOR generations now Fantasia has been both faulted for its highbrow pretensions and derided as low-brow kitsch, frequently by the same critics and sometimes in the same sentence. But this 1940 animated feature from Walt Disney remains unassailable, a cultural artifact that stands beyond simple categorization, perhaps Hollywoods closest brush with the avant-garde.

title: The Pacifier Gets an Upgrade: Apps and Gadgets to Soothe the Baby
description: I ACQUIRED my first piece of baby-related technology two months ago, just a few hours after the birth of my son. My wife, baby and I were all still in the hospital, and the baby  who looked a bit less confused than my wife and I about this new state of affairs  seemed to need help getting to sleep. After a bit of trial and error, I found that he appeared to be comforted by a gentle, continuous shushing sound near his ear. But how long could I keep shushing? Wasnt there some easier way?

title: Greatest American Houses in a Page-by-Page Tour
description: What makes Dominique Brownings and Lucy Gilmours book, Living Architecture: Greatest American Houses of the 20th Century (Assouline; $75), different from the hundreds of other coffee-table books about homes like Frank Lloyd Wrights Fallingwater? The photographs. They are stunning, and so plentiful they allow the reader to imagine living, breathing and eating in the homes.

title: Love, Loss and What She Cooked for Dinner
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J.

title: Look of The Moment | Cause Celeb
description: The Look: Boys Club  tailored, but with a feminine fit.The Girl: Ginnifer Goodwin, the star of next summers Something Borrowed, opts for a slick jacket and patent booties as a rebel with a cause at the luncheon at Tods in Beverly Hills to benefit the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles.

title: 16-Year-Old Who Needs Transplants Opens Richardsons Heart
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  On the phone from Texas Childrens Hospital in Houston, 16-year-old Tyler Nelson sounded worried. Only he never mentioned cystic fibrosis, which he was born with, or lung and liver transplants, which he desperately needs.

title: All Is Sparkly for Tiffany
description: Europe may be burning and the United States is smoldering, but the comfortably off are splurging on their blue-boxed trinkets. Tiffany & Company is reaping the benefits, posting double-digit sales growth across the globe in its third quarter, most notably in Europe where receipts rose 22 percent in the period. Together with a bright outlook, that suggests well-heeled and aspirational consumers are not expecting another painful downturn.

title: An East Village Guy, Up in Lights
description: A FEW minutes before the premiere of The Break of Noon, the Neil LaBute play that opened Monday night at the Lucille Lortel Theater in the West Village, the actress Ta Leoni scooted up to Gillian Anderson. The star of the play is David Duchovny, Ms. Leonis husband and Ms. Andersons former co-star on The X-Files.

title: Scene City: At David Duchovnys After-Party
description: An actors friends are there when he makes his New York stage debut.

title: Texas Falls From Title Contender to Big Disappointment
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Leading by a touchdown but frustrated that its opening drive had failed inside the 1-yard line, Texas was looking for a big play to ignite an expected blowout of Florida Atlantic on Saturday.

title: Tablets, Compared
description: 2010 was supposed to be the Year of the Tablet, a prediction that did not quite pan out. So, once more, with feeling: 2011 will be the Year of the Tablet. Sort through the offerings.

title: Israels Unorthodox Facebook Campaign
description: Israels military said this week that it has used Facebook to catch about 1,000 women who falsely claimed that they were Orthodox Jews in order to gain exemptions from military service.

title: N.Y.C. Party Preview, Nov. 28 to Dec. 5
description: A PREVIEW of the must-attend parties, talked-about openings and fashionable night spots for the week ahead.

title: Shopping With David Monn
description: A party planner offered ideas for bringing glamour to your home this holiday season.

title: Discounts on Herman Miller and Other Furnishings
description: Select Herman Miller pieces will be 15 percent off at Sam Flax from Friday until Dec. 13 (the Eames lounge chair and ottoman, above, regularly about $3,900, will be about $3,315); 900 Third Avenue (54th Street), 3 West 20th Street (Sixth Avenue) and Sam Flax Small Office Home Office Furniture Gallery at Bloomingdales, 1000 Third Avenue (59th Street), samflax.com.

title: Alessi Designs on Display
description: A new exhibition at the Philadelphia Museum of Art documents the Italian appliance companys design collaborations since 1955.

title: Celebrating Hamptons Homes and Italian Design
description: The East Hampton Historical Societys 2010 House and Garden Tour will open with a cocktail party on Friday. The tour will take place the next day. It includes six homes, the oldest of which is a 1920s colonial revival designed by Aymar Embury II; the newest is a shingle-style house completed this year and designed by Barnes Coy and Associates of Bridgehampton, N.Y. In between is Michael Katzs home, above, designed in 1965 by Daniel Chait, the architect who renovated the Queens Museum of Art in 1964. This is not your typical Hamptons cottage, said Mr. Katz, an interior designer who bought and restored the house in 2007. It was kind of bohemian. The ceiling has a glass skylight that runs the entire length of the house. Information: easthamptonhistory.org or (631) 324-6850.

title: Holiday Decorations in Gold
description: THE United States has gone off the gold standard, but to the party designer David Monn, gold is still the standard by which glamour is measured. To spruce up a home for holiday entertaining, Mr. Monn has a particular fondness for it.

title: In SoHo, a New Outpost for High-Style Outdoor Furniture
description: Anyone who has lounged poolside at an expensive resort is likely to be aware of Dedon. The companys minimalist outdoor furniture has graced stylish spaces as varied as La Mamounia in Marrakesh, Morocco, and the W South Beach hotel in Miami Beach, Fla. And as of last week, Dedon could also be found in SoHo, at the companys first retail showroom.

title: An Empty House Where Time Stands Still
description: ON a neighborly block in Mobile, Ala., an old brick house with a weathered slate roof sits on a sun-beaten lawn. Leading to the front door with the blue-green shutters on each side  Mom varied the color a few times  are three steps and a small porch.

title: Shepard Fairey Puts His Mark on a Miami Restaurant
description: Shepard Fairey, the artist responsible for the Barack Obama Hope poster, has created a series of murals for the Wynwood Kitchen and Bar, a restaurant opening on Friday in Miami, just in time for the DesignMiami fair next week. Mr. Faireys work, which dominates and defines the restaurants space, is a combination of screen-printed and painted images pieced together into a kind of mosaic. The W.P.A. posters are definitely one of the inspirations, Mr. Fairey said. And propaganda art.

title: Alberto Alessi on Everyday Appliances and Big Ideas
description: Clad head to toe in black and carrying a black zippered attach case, Alberto Alessi sat in the lobby of the Gramercy Park Hotel one morning this week looking every bit a member of the Italian design intelligentsia. Mr. Alessi, who is the president and director of marketing strategies and design management of Alessi S.p.A., a company started by his grandfather Giovanni in 1921, was in town after the opening on Sunday of Alessi: Ethical and Radical at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. The exhibition documents the companys collaborations since 1955 with Ron Arad, Michael Graves, the Campana brothers, Ettore Sottsass, Philippe Starck, Alessandro Mendini (who also designed the exhibit) and others.

title: A Chronicler of Fashion Turns to the Heart
description: Golden Beach, Fla.

title: Bruce Webers Exhibition
description: His first major show in an American museum is an exhibition of portraits of the Haitian community in Miami at the Museum of Contemporary Art.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Burn Calories
description: The holiday season begins this week, and for those looking to keep the calories in check or burn off the extra stress of family visits and air travel, the New York Times Tech Talk team takes a look at apps and gadgets that can help. The roundup includes a discussion of MP3 players that have integrated pedometers, stand-alone fitness trackers and smartphone apps that let you record your workouts and calories.

title: Life as a Runway: I Know I Am, but What Are You?
description: Pee-wee Hermans Broadway show is a magnet for mavericks of every persuasion.

title: Harbingers Falcone Sells Down Stake in Times Co.
description: 8:58 p.m. | Updated Harbinger Capital Partners, the large hedge fund run by the embattled manager Philip A. Falcone, has sold off a significant chunk of its stake in The New York Times Company, bringing its ownership in the newspaper company down to about 2.6 percent.

title: Karzai Government Challenges Election Results
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The announcement of final results from parliamentary elections deepened a confrontation between election officials and the government of President Hamid Karzai, which vowed to challenge the outcome even as it was endorsed by international officials.

title: For Google, the Browser Does It All
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  When a Google engineer gave top executives computers running the companys new Chrome operating system, Sergey Brin, Googles co-founder, tried to hold on to his computer running an older version.

title: Palins Publisher and Gawker Settle Case
description: If Gawker Media had wanted to avoid a legal dispute over publishing leaked pages from Sarah Palins new book, it could easily have tried what media outlets have done countless times before when copies of an unreleased book or article have fallen into their hands: paraphrase and use direct quotations sparingly.

description: Chicago, Nov. 25, 1860

title: G.O.P. Senators Detail Objections to Arms Treaty

title: Fed Considered Setting Target for Interest Rates on Some Bonds
description: WASHINGTON  Tucked into minutes released this week by the Federal Reserve was a disclosure that came as a surprise to economists and historians alike: on Oct. 15, Fed policy makers discussed whether to set a target for interest rates on certain government bonds.

title: A Lone Blacksmith, Where Hammers Rang
description: HANOI, Vietnam  He is the last blacksmith on Blacksmith Street, dark with soot, his arms dappled with burns, sweating and hammering at his little roadside forge as a new world courses past him.

description: In a matter of months, the movie delivery company Netflix has gone from being the fastest-growing first-class mail customer of the United States Postal Service to the biggest source of streaming Web traffic in North America during peak evening hours.

It is one of the reasons  along with her working-class background and the sense of authenticity that she can often convey  that she is so popular with some voters.

title: Robert B. Daugherty, Who Helped Irrigate the Plains, Dies at 88
description: Robert B. Daugherty, a Nebraska businessman who helped transform the rural landscape into a patchwork of circular fields by popularizing a means of irrigation that used a pipe on wheels pivoting around a central point, died on Wednesday at his home in Omaha. He was 88.

description: The arrest of a research firm executive on charges that he helped hedge funds obtain improper information about publicly traded companies is the first of what is expected to be a new round of cases related to insider trading.

title: The Film Projectionist Who Looks Away
description: On day one of a recent vacation, Joseph J. Micherdzinski was home in Yonkers with his wife, Mary Ann, watching the original black-and-white version of The Night of the Living Dead. Mr. Micherdzinski, 67, has been a film projectionist since 1968, so this seemed a bit like a pizza-maker going out for a holiday meal and wolfing down a dozen slices of Sicilian, but no.

title: Memories of Meals Past
description: To honor Phyllis Van Dyke, who died of cancer in February at age 69, her family has been cooking her favorite recipes, at least one a day since her birthday, Sept. 26. Here are a few:

title: Suffering, Haitians Turn to Charismatic Prayer

Certain women in his parish say so many Hail Marys on their own that he no longer assigns them the prayers as penance for sins; instead, he may prescribe a pedicure. On a Saturday night in the basement of his mostly Haitian church in Queens, in a bare white room vibrating with hymns and exclamations, a young woman may find herself channeling the Holy Spirit to reveal news from Haiti.

description: He has been having trouble sleeping, gazing at a print of Rembrandts Philosopher in Meditation in his apartment and taking solace in Schuberts Opus 100.

Blacks qualifications to become the New York City schools chancellor, state officials and the Bloomberg administration held secret talks about the possibility of appointing an experienced educator to her side, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

title: A Jury Convicts Tom DeLay
description: After a year of increasingly depressing news about the unbridled, unaccountable influence of big money in political campaigns, a Texas jury stood up for honesty in campaign finance on Wednesday and convicted Tom DeLay, the former House majority leader, of money laundering. Unfortunately, there are now many new ways for politicians to commit acts similar to those for which Mr. DeLay was convicted, all of them perfectly legal.

title: Close Your Eyes and See With Your Heart
description: Marcus Yam, 26, was born and raised in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. He had a degree in aerospace engineering when he decided to pursue photography. He is now a regular contributor to The Times, has worked for The Washington Post and The Associated Press and is finishing his thesis at the Ohio University School of Visual Communication. This conversation, part of the Turning Point series, has been edited and condensed.

title: The Mayor and the Chancellor
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg scored a huge victory for New York City public education in 2002 when he won control of the school system, but parents and state officials often complained that outside voices were not heard. On Tuesday, a panel of state educators essentially upbraided him for failing to listen to those who wanted a professional educator as the systems new chancellor.

title: Greece, Ireland, and Then?
description: In May, the International Monetary Fund and the European Union thought they had solved Europes financial troubles. They crafted a $150 billion bailout for Greece, part of a $1 trillion rescue fund for vulnerable countries using the euro. With defenses like that, no investor would bet against Europes financial stability.

title: Thanksgiving Scripture
description: In 1936, with the Great Depression persisting, the governor of Connecticut issued a Thanksgiving Proclamation so inspiring that people in the state learned it by heart as if it were scripture. It was common then to memorize stirring speeches and other texts, but not public decrees. The proclamations message and 2010s turmoil make this a very good year to re-read the document.

title: Belgium: Talks Remove Obstacle to W.T.O. Membership For Russia
description: Russian and European Union negotiators said Wednesday that they had resolved crucial differences on trade, removing a significant obstacle to Russias long-delayed plans to join the World Trade Organization. After talks in Brussels, the two sides issued a joint statement saying they were confident their deal would greatly facilitate the overall process of accession of Russia to the W.T.O. The two sides resolved differences over tariffs on the export of raw materials, including timber, and railway freight transit.

title: Brazil: Economic Team Named
description: President-elect Dilma Rousseff assembled her new economic team on Wednesday, nominating Alexandre Antonio Tombini, left, an economist and Central Bank official, to succeed Henrique Meirelles as head of the Central Bank. Mr. Meirelles had rejected another term at the Central Bank unless he were given full autonomy to set monetary policy, as he has had since he assumed the position in 2003, according to Brazilian news media. Nominating Mr. Tombini, 46, and keeping Guido Mantega as finance minister, a decision that she also announced Wednesday, suggest that Ms. Rousseff will stay the course of economic policy set by her predecessor, Luiz Incio Lula da Silva.

title: Gratitude the Hard Way
description: An aspect of Thanksgiving Ive always had trouble with is the part about giving thanks. Im not against gratitude, but things to be grateful for just dont naturally spring to mind.

title: The Incredible Flying Nonagenarian
description: On the third floor of the Montreal Chest Institute, at McGill University, Olga Kotelko stood before a treadmill in the center of a stuffy room that was filling up with people who had come just for her. They were there to run physical tests, or to extract blood from her earlobe, or just to observe and take notes. Kotelko removed her glasses. She wore white New Balance sneakers and black running tights, and over her silver hair, a plastic crown that held in place a breathing tube.

Ms. Pitt, who had spent her childhood in a Nazi concentration camp, later scoured Europe in search of her vanished father and still later was forced to flee East Germany a step ahead of the police, chose horror. It was a genre she knew firsthand.

Sat on the platform for 45 minutes waiting with the whiners trying to get to Penn and wondering if they should leave the station and go find a yellow cab, reading the tabs and realizing how different my life is from theirs.

description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs president formally nominated Nuri Kamal al-Maliki for a second term as the countrys prime minister on Thursday, giving him 30 days to cobble together a government from competing factions that remain deeply divided and suspicious of his return to power.

But, the bank said, German institutions continue to engage in risky practices that make them vulnerable to a rise in interest rates.

title: Taking Bets on the Royal Dress
description: The British royal family may not be the medias only compass, but the needle certainly moved at the announcement that Prince William and Kate Middleton will wed, on April 29 at Westminster Abbey. Goodbye Strictly Come Dancing, luminaries in the broken-down zoo of celebrity  hello Kate! You sensed a collective surge of relief in the young ladys direction  that her wedding might be good not only for the downsized economy but also maybe good for the country as a whole.

title: Russia Expresses Anger Over European Visa Proposal

Im particularly interested in visiting the ancient Greek and Roman ruins, which Im told are very well preserved because of the desert climate. Whats the official State Department policy? Do you know of reliable cruise or land tours that take U.S. citizens to Libya?

title: A Happy Thanksgiving to Sad Person

title: Junking Junk Food
description: Earlier this month, Sarah Palin showed up in Bucks County, Pa., with dozens and dozens of cookies, suggesting that the states schoolchildren risked losing the right to the occasional classroom treat because of a high-minded anti-sugar edict from the board of education. Pretty much everything about the setup was wrong. Pennsylvania wasnt, as Palin tweeted, in the midst of a school cookie ban debate. And the school she turned into a photo op wouldnt have been subject to such a ban had one existed; it wasnt a public school but a private Christian academy. And while Palin might have been seizing an opportunity to intro kids 2 beauty of laissez-faire, she wasnt just visiting with schoolchildren but was delivering a paid speech at a fund-raiser.

Klein, a former federal prosecutor and Bertelsmann executive, was appointed chancellor of New York Citys public schools. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had just won control of the schools from Albany, and while Ms. Donlan was happy with her own childrens school, she knew that parts of the system were badly broken.

title: E.U. Seeks Strategy to Reduce Reliance on China for Rare Earths

title: Appreciating the Atmosphere
description: Theres something a bit circular about celebrating the qualities of this livable planet that we call home, given that its livable qualities enabled life to catch on, take hold and (Homo sapiens included of late) become an integral part of the dynamics shaping Earth. But, hey, its Thanksgiving. So heres a videotaped Scene From a Livable Planet, which I shot during a flight awhile back but just re-discovered in my laptop.

title: THOMAS NOZKOWSKI: Recent Work
description: Pace Gallery

title: Here Comes the Rain Again
description: Light rain falling over Manhattan right now, and at least Im not standing in a yard somewhere worrying about it as five gallons of peanut oil come up to heat over a propane hob screaming like a jet engine. Oh, yes, Ive fried turkeys before. And will again.

title: For Chinas Women, More Opportunities, More Pitfalls
description: BEIJING  The question that dashed Angel Fengs job prospects always came last.

title: The Public Warhol in a Public Square
description: Although winter hasnt even started, there is already a lineup of public art projects scheduled for New York this spring. The Public Art Fund will be installing three sculpture exhibitions: at Union Square, City Hall Park and Doris C. Freedman Plaza, at Fifth Avenue and 60th Street.

title: The Kings English, Albeit With Twisted Tongue
description: British films that make it to American screens these days often fall into two distinct niches: life is miserable and life is sweet (to borrow a title from the director Mike Leigh, who oscillates between the two). Given its quality headliners and high commercial profile (ding-dong, is that Oscar calling?), its no surprise that The Kings Speech, a buddy story about aggressively charming opposites  Colin Firth as the stutterer who would be king and Geoffrey Rush as the speech therapist  comes with heaping spoonfuls of sugar.

title: You Are on Your Own, Little Ones
description: This is the last set of questions Im answering today. I need to get back to Kings County to whip up some gravy for the turkeys my friends and family made while I was at work. Well have a drink or two, eat a huge meal, take a walk down the damp streets in the dark and watch a movie, just as President Washington intended. Thanks for playing along. You may of course continue the conversation in the comments below. Recipes for leftovers will be in great demand tomorrow, after all.

title: Dilemma for Spanish Federation in Contador Case
description: Alberto Contador heads to training camp next week in the Canary Islands as Spains cycling federation continues its investigation into charges that he doped during his third Tour de France victory last summer.

title: Elling to Close on Broadway
description: So much for little-known Norwegian comedies surviving on brutal commercial Broadway. The new play Elling, which opened on Sunday and stars Denis OHare (a Tony Award winner for Take Me Out) and Brendan Fraser (The Mummy movies), will close this Sunday after 22 previews and nine regular performances, a spokeswoman for the production said on Thursday.

title: Habitats | Lower East Side
description: Daniel and Dasha Faires, newlyweds with a shared design sense, did not let the size of their apartment limit their imaginations.

title: 375 Square Feet? Just Think of the Possibilities!
description: TO reach the apartment where Daniel and Dasha Faires live, you pass through the vestibule of a small century-old brick building on Ludlow Street and head down a dingy tile-lined hallway. But hang a left near the trash can, and you will find something amazing.

title: Constructing Happiness With a Carnal Ghost
description: A small movie with a full heart, Undertow takes an old idea  the loving, lingering ghost  and gives it reverberant, resuscitated life. The story unwinds gracefully and with slow-building emotion in a tiny seaside village in remotest Peru, where, save for a few modern conveniences, people live much as they probably did decades earlier, pulling fish from the sea and bound by communal interdependence. There, a young fisherman, Miguel (Cristian Mercado), awaits the birth of his first child, an event that fills him with so much happiness that he shares his bliss generously with his beloved wife and his more adored male lover.

title: In Many Configurations, Trio Tackles the Moderns
description: The classical offerings at Le Poisson Rouge usually explore either experimental corners of new music or the growing part of the repertory that borrows liberally from rock and jazz. But the clubs laid-back atmosphere makes it an appealing place to hear more conventional programs too, and on Wednesday evening, the Parnas/Kohlberg Trio presented a straightforward overview of the more conservative side of the 20th-century repertory, with a brief foray into the early 19th century along the way.

title: Acrobatics Amid Flakes: Its Cirque du Snowfall
description: In the finale of Wintuk the audience disappears in a noreaster of crepe-paper snowflakes. Until then, though, the wonderment of Cirque du Soleils fourth (and final) holiday visit to the cavernous Theater at Madison Square Garden occurs despite, not because of, the seasonal trappings.

title: Q & A
description: When a Spouse Seeks Board Membership

title: Chalk Up Wednesday to CBS
description: Survivor and crime-show repeats lifted CBS just ahead of ABC to lead the ratings on Wednesday in prime time. According to Nielsens estimates CBSs rerun of Criminal Minds delivered one of the nights largest audiences, with 9.3 million viewers at 9 p.m., building on the 8 million who tuned in to the networks Survivor: Nicaragua at 8. At 10 p.m. a repeat of CBSs Defenders won the time slot with 7.3 million viewers, finishing ahead of ABCs Primetime with 6 million. ABC ranked second, benefiting from new episodes of Modern Family at 9 (10.5 million) and The Middle at 8 (8.2 million). NBC finished in a virtual tie for third with Fox.

title: Billy Joel Has Hip Surgery
description: Billy Joel, the 61-year-old Grammy-winning singer and songwriter, is recovering from double hip replacement surgery, according to his spokeswoman, Claire Mercuri, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Mercuri told People magazine on Wednesday that Mr. Joel had undergone surgery on both hips last week to correct a congenital condition, and that he was doing extremely well. There was no word about when Mr. Joel might return to any of his numerous projects. He recently wrapped up both a concert tour with Elton John and promotion for the documentary The Last Play at Shea, which tells the story of Mr. Joels relationship with Shea Stadium, including the last two concerts he played there in 2008 before the stadium was torn down. In April Mr. Joel told Rolling Stone magazine that he was working on thematic music, orchestral music that could be used for new songs, a film score or the television show Glee. I was in chorus in high school, so I know what that stuffs all about, he said. I love stuff like that.

title: Ana Maria Matute Wins Cervantes Prize
description: The novelist Ana Maria Matute has won the Cervantes Prize, the leading literary award for works in Spanish, Agence France-Presse reported. I am happy, enormously happy, Ms. Matute, 85, said at a news conference in Spain on Wednesday. I take it as a recognition, if not of the quality of my work, then at least of the effort and dedication that I have devoted to writing throughout my life, she said. Ms. Matutes novels, like School of the Sun and Soldiers Cry by Night, are known for their lyrical style and reflect the themes of social injustice and oppression experienced by the Spanish during the rule of Franco and the aftermath of the Spanish Civil War. King Juan Carlos will present Ms. Matute with the award, which comes with a $167,000 prize, on April 23, the anniversary of the death of Cervantes, in Alcala de Henares, Cervantes birthplace. Ms. Matute is the third woman to win the prize, which is administered by the Spanish Ministry of Culture.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Nov. 26-Dec. 2
description: Pop

title: Bruce Willis, the New Face of Russian Banking
description: Bruce Williss next big role wont be in Hollywood, or even the United States. Mr. Willis, 55, has been recruited by a Russian bank to be the face of its new advertising campaign, BBC News reported. According to a statement from Trust Bank, Mr. Willis will be featured in ads over the next year, replacing the banks former spokesman, the Russian weight lifter and actor Vladimir Turchinsky, who died in 2009. The bank said it chose Mr. Willis because he embodied its slogan of trust and dignity. On Monday the campaigns first posters went up in Moscow, featuring a picture of Mr. Willis with the slogan Trust is just like me, but a bank.

title: Construction Has Halted at Los Angeles Museum
description: The directors of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art have ordered work to stop on the second phase of a three-part, $450 million renovation and expansion plan until they can raise more money, The Los Angeles Times reported. The decision to halt the project was prompted by a report on the museums finances issued by Moodys Investors Services last week. The report showed that while the museum retained its A2 investment rating, considered a good credit risk, on its $383 million in construction bonds, a negative rating was expected in the future should it be unable to maintain a certain degree of liquidity. Construction costs and a drop in private donations during the recession have both taken a toll. The museum is hoping to raise an additional $100 million in donations before continuing work. Under Phase 1 the Broad Contemporary Art Museum and the BP Grand Entrance were opened in 2008 and the Resnick Exhibition Pavilion in September. The second phase will turn a former department store into new offices and galleries. Specifics about the third phase, which involves renovations to older buildings, have not yet been disclosed.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Nov. 26-Dec. 2
description: Classical

title: Art Thats Best Seen Through the Bottom of a Glass
description: With notable exceptions like long-distance running, any-distance driving and matters of personal hygiene involving sharp blades, most activities go down easier and happier with a drink in hand.

title: Jazz Listings
description: Jazz

title: Developers Compromising, but Carrying On
description: EVEN though the market remains troubled and financing is as elusive for projects as for individual mortgages, at least two residential developers in Westchester are forging ahead, despite the compromises being forced on them by the economy.

title: Dance Listings for Nov. 26-Dec. 2
description: Dance

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Nov. 26-Dec. 2
description: Art

description: Movies
