description: WINTERS EVE AT LINCOLN SQUARE

title: Theater Listings: Nov. 26  Dec. 2
description: Theater

title: A Tiny Restaurant Ceases and Desists, but
description: Patrice Carter and Doreen Simpson tasted the love, though briefly.

title: Fishermans Wharf, Primed at Last for Makeover
description: Dean Macris, San Franciscos former planning director, delivered a blunt message to Fishermans Wharfs powerful restaurant owners last year: Accept the citys plan to overhaul the wharf or risk being left behind.

title: Looking to Make Even Prosaic Food a Little More Festive
description: FORGET visions of sugar plums. The treats dancing in the heads on Madison Avenue are the prosaic products found on supermarket shelves.

title: Gold Fever: Pondering the Causes
description: It is part religion, part politics. It is a way to voice a lack of confidence in the central banks of the world and a yearning for the world as it used to be.

title: Spare Times for Nov. 26-Dec. 2
description: Around Town

title: Swing Dancing in Queens, Free Dancing at Ailey
description: If the darker nights have you missing the long days of summer, you dont have to hide inside. Instead you can head to the Bohemian Beer Hall in Queens, where a little denial and a lot of jive have meant the extension of its Sam Adams Summer Sunday Swing nights through the winter. This week the Solomon Douglas Swingtet will keep things jumping from 7 to 10 p.m. Free swing lessons are open to everyone, but the free drinks are only for those hep cats and kittens decked out in zoot suits or other period threads. (29-19 24th Avenue, Astoria, Queens; 718-274-4925, bohemianhall.com; $5 cover charge.)

title: Agency Sold by One Private Equity Firm to Another
description: Apax Partners has agreed to acquire Advantage Sales and Marketing from J. W. Childs Associates and BAML Capital Partners, the latest large leveraged buyout in which a company would pass from one private equity group to another. The deal values Advantage at about $1.8 billion, according to a person close to the deal who requested anonymity because he was not authorized to discuss it publicly. Apax will acquire about 85 percent of the company, with Advantages existing management owning the rest. Advantage, based in Irvine, Calif., is a leading sales and marketing agency for consumer goods, working with clients like J. M. Smucker and Johnson & Johnson to maximize the value of their brands. The company has about $1 billion in annual revenue and is expected to generate about $180 million in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization this year, according to this person. J. W. Childs and BAML Capital Partners, formerly Merrill Lynch Global Private Equity, acquired the closely held Advantage in 2006 for $1.05 billion. The firms are expected to make roughly three times their cash investment on the deal, which is expected to close by year-end.

title: House Tour: Garrison, N.Y.
description: HOW MUCH $2.95 million; annual taxes, $23,724.

title: Weekly Matchups: The Day After Thanksgiving Blockbuster Edition
description: N.F.L. football on Thanksgiving is wildly overrated. There, I said it. What are your favorite Thanksgiving pro football memories? Thats what I thought. Maybe its the tryptophan or the in-laws putting me to sleep, but I cannot remember many great ones.

title: Public Anger Has British Bankers Fretting About Bonuses
description: LONDON  Investment banking revenues are down and irritation at large bonuses is up, and that has bankers in London bracing for a drop in their annual payouts.

title: Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade
description: Thousands came out to watch the 84th annual Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade.

title: A Crisis Needing More Sacrifice
description: Rahm Emanuel, President Obamas former chief of staff, popularized the idea that a good crisis should not be wasted. But there is a severe risk that this is precisely what the world has been doing by being excessively soft when bailing out banks and countries.

title: 2 Brothers Will Rule in Wisconsin
description: MADISON, Wis.  Like brothers anywhere, Jeff and Scott Fitzgerald tend to interrupt each other. They share season tickets to University of Wisconsin Badgers football games. They bicker, jokingly, over work  who has the larger office, the tougher hours, the more complex job.

title: Twentysomethings in Memphis
description: Kentucker Audleys $17,000 third feature, Open Five, has a shape to it, as well as a look and a rhythm, and at that price, those are accomplishments. The coherence of the story, about four twentysomethings hanging out and hooking up during a weekend in Memphis, and the relative polish of the camerawork and editing may indicate either growth or capitulation on Mr. Audleys part, depending on your point of view. They certainly reflect a valuable contribution by the better-known director Joe Swanberg, who served as cinematographer.

title: Latino Family Drama
description: A close-knit Latino family unravels under financial and medical pressures in Willets Point, a rough but well-meaning drama about facing fears and hanging on.

title: Another Christo Project, to Engage and Divide
description: SALIDA, Colo.  When two decades ago the artist Christo proposed a gigantic art installation spanning 42 miles of the Arkansas River with sections of suspended luminescent fabric, he knew it would incite public debate. He said those discussions  over nature, its place and its purpose  would be part of the art.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,387 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: New York City Crime Dips but Violent Crime Is Up
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly, within six weeks of the years end, faced questions about the state of crime in New York City with what has become a familiar and welcome answer: Overall crime in the city is down again in 2010.

title: Local Politics in Action: Considering a Pawnshop
description: Alderman Joe Moore called a community meeting at the Rogers Park Library on Tuesday evening only to learn, along with about 60 attendees, that city budget cuts and shortened hours meant it was closed.

title: Petitions for Mayor Offer First Clues of Campaign
description: When aides to Rahm Emanuel recently wheeled a cart loaded with tall stacks of his nominating petitions into the city election boards downtown offices, the more than 90,000 voter signatures were a show of force meant to prove deep grass-roots support across the city for the former White House chief of staff.

title: Lives of Music and Physics, Lovingly Bound
description: In the Printers Row apartment shared by Srgio Assad and Angela Olinto, two Latin Grammy awards occupy an inconspicuous spot in the office. In the kitchen, Stephen Hawkings latest opus, The Grand Design, rests next to a MacBook containing Ms. Olintos review of the book written for the journal Physics Today.

title: Generation Text, Living on a Screen
description: To the Editor:

title: A Near-Forgotten Casualty of AIDS: The Haights Gay Identity
description: Arthur Evans is dying. His doctors have told him that his long struggle with cardiovascular disease will soon take his life. Mr. Evans has heard such pronouncements before, and survived, so he is a bit skeptical.

title: Live Analysis: Jets 26, Bengals 10, Final
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  By late Thursday night, the Jets were able to relax. They joked with each other on the sideline and lounged on benches. On the field, they kneeled to a 26-10 victory over the Cincinnati Bengals. It was a rare sight for this team.

title: Chronicling Oddness in Union Square Park
description: Normal Bob grew up in normal little towns in the Midwest. But after visiting Union Square Park, where normalcy is recognized more in the breach than the observance, he decided to move to New York in 2002.

title: Bishops New Leader
description: To the Editor:

title: In Los Angeles, Mayoral Aide Weighs Bid for Higher City Hall Perch
description: LOS ANGELES  About a year ago, Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa turned to a Wall Street investment banker, Austin Beutner, to become first deputy mayor. He was put in charge of 13 city agencies and asked to help shepherd the citys ailing economy back to health.

title: Tax Cuts for the Wealthy
description: To the Editor:

title: China and Censorship
description: To the Editor:

title: Microfinance in India
description: To the Editor:

title: Strategies to Get You There
description: This is the eleventh in a series.

title: The Bedfellows Reunion
description: Chicago, Nov. 26, 1860

title: Pit Stop for U.F.O.s, and Humans Who Love Them
description: HOOPER, Colo.  I like humans, theyre fun, Judy Messoline said as she showed a visitor through her vortex garden, which psychics have said contains not just one, but two separate portals to a parallel universe.

title: Admiring the Floats From a Few Feet Off the Ground
description: New York being New York, it is probably inevitable that parade watching gets competitive, with people bringing footstools, ladders and other elevation devices to ensure a good view.

title: Seeking a Faster Way Down the Mountain
description: VAIL, Colo.  Forget podium ceremonies, World Cup trophies or Olympic medals. Perhaps the best way to judge the stature of top Alpine racers is to count the pairs of skis allotted them for testing, training and racing during a year.

title: Court Rules Against Candy Labeled Pure Chocolate
description: Italian rules allowing candy makers including Nestl to label their products as pure chocolate breach European Union law, the blocs highest court in Luxembourg said. The law makes no provision for the sales name pure chocolate, the court said. Allowing an extra sales name for chocolate that contains no vegetable fat is likely to mislead consumers and thus interfere with their right to obtain correct, neutral and objective information. Chocolate rules have led to legal battles since 1973, when Britain, Ireland and Denmark joined the European Union in resisting standards that required chocolate to contain only cocoa fats. Under the old rules, countries like Italy were allowed to block imports of chocolate made with alternative fats.

title: Trophy Tells a Tale of Rivalry and Race
description: Before there was a Floyd of Rosedale Trophy, given annually to the winner of the Iowa-Minnesota college football game, there was a live, snorting prize hog called Floyd of Rosedale, named for the governor of Minnesota and the Iowa farm where the animal once lived.

title: In Haiti, Waiting for the Grand Bayakou
description: Los Angeles

title: In Los Angeles, Big Step Ahead for Mass Transit
description: LOS ANGELES  This auto-obsessed city  a place where people love their cars almost as much as they hate the traffic  has embarked on the biggest expansion of its mass transit system in decades, an effort to change the way people navigate its sprawling and clogged streets and freeways.

title: Three Boys Feared Lost Are Found in Pacific
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand  Three teenagers who were adrift in the South Pacific for 50 days have been found alive by a fishing vessel, officials here said Thursday.

title: Eating the Irish
description: What we need now is another Jonathan Swift.

title: Handguns for 18-Year-Olds?
description: The National Rifle Association keeps coming up with clever new ways to undermine public safety.

title: Hard Work, Big Dreams and Help
description: Gregory Moore always wanted to work in the World Trade Center.

title: Voting in a New Haiti
description: Haitians will vote in presidential and parliamentary elections on Sunday. The new leaders will determine whether and how soon a functioning nation emerges from the rubble of Januarys earthquake.

title: Mr. Feinberg and the Spill
description: Kenneth Feinberg is making solid progress as the administrator of BPs $20 billion compensation fund for victims of the gulf oil spill. Tuesday was the deadline for filing claims for emergency payments, equal to six months of lost income. Mr. Feinberg estimates that he has handed out more than $2.2 billion to some 150,000 individuals and businesses from a total of more than 400,000 claims. This is a great improvement over the stingy BP operation he replaced.

title: Still Not Free
description: In September, Sarah Shourd was freed from Irans infamous Evin prison, but shes not really free. Her fianc, Shane Bauer, and their friend, Josh Fattal, are still languishing in a tiny cell in Tehran.

title: Familys Fall From Affluence Is Swift and Hard
description: WAMEGO, Kan.  Grateful to have found work in this tough economy, Nick Martin teaches grape growing and winemaking each Saturday to a class of seven students in a simple metal building here at a satellite campus of Highland Community College.

title: A Notorious Name, Cast in a New Light
description: Two Fisher boys, about 40 years apart, grew up in Bronx housing projects, playing basketball on the nearby playgrounds.

title: Inquiry Into Sell-Off of Taseko in Canada
description: OTTAWA  A Canadian securities regulator said on Thursday that it was investigating whether leaked information about a governmental review of proposed gold and copper mine led to a huge sell-off of a mining companys stock last month.

title: That Cabby Dress Code? Its Getting a Makeover
description: There is a dress code for New York City cabdrivers. Seriously. It is right there on Page 23 of the 62-page manual the city issues to cabbies detailing the rules and regulations regarding their conduct and comportment.

title: With Victory in Hand, Dallas Cant Hold On
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Should the New Orleans Saints return to Cowboys Stadium to defend their Super Bowl title, images of Malcolm Jenkins desperately chasing Roy Williams will surely flash across the giant video screen hanging over the field.

title: The Public Square Goes Mobile
description: We dont need more leaders. We need more followers. Wherever & however you can enter public life is ok.

title: Description Is Prescription
description: One hundred years ago, Leo Tolstoy lay dying at a train station in southern Russia. Journalists, acolytes and newsreel photographers gathered for the passing of the great prophet. Between 3:30 and 5:30 on that freezing November morning, Tolstoys wife stood on the porch outside his death chamber because his acolytes would not let her in. At one point she begged them to at least admit her into an anteroom so that the photographers would get the impression she was being allowed to see her husband on his final day.

title: Del Monte to Be Sold to K.K.R. and Others for $5 Billion
description: Del Monte Foods agreed on Thursday to sell itself for $5.3 billion, including debt, to a group of private equity firms led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts in what is the biggest leveraged buyout this year.

title: A Parade for Everyone? Depends on Where Youre Standing
description: Wait till next year.

description: A quick programming note:

title: Children Ease Alzheimers in Land of Aging
description: SEONGNAM, South Korea  They were stooped, hobbled, disoriented, fumbling around the house. They got confused in the bathtub and struggled up stairs that seemed to swim before them.

title: On Arms Treaty, White House Seeks a Republicans Ear
description: WASHINGTON  The White House might as well install a red-telephone hot line in Senator Jon Kyls house.

title: For Retailers, Black Friday Expectations Are High
description: Buy more, save more seems to be the mantra going into the holiday shopping season.

title: Auburn Is Seeing Crimson Over Questions and Rivalry
description: The most anticipated day of every year in the state of Alabama has arrived with Auburn football devotees caught in a riptide of emotions.

title: Lottery Numbers
In California, Carports That Can Generate Electricity
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  And California begat cars, and the cars begat asphalt parking lots. And the lots spawned electricity, transforming the hills and the deserts.

title: Changing Circumstances for Women in China
description: Three decades after China embarked on dazzling economic reforms, much has changed for women. Yet along with freedom has come risk.

title: Front-Line City in Virginia Tackles Rise in Sea
description: NORFOLK, Va.  In this section of the Larchmont neighborhood, built in a sharp u around a bay off the Lafayette River, residents pay close attention to the lunar calendar, much as other suburbanites might attend to the daily flow of commuter traffic.

title: On a Farm in Maine, a Woodcock and Its Secrets Are Revealed
description: BOWDOINHAM, Me.  Clink. Clank. The bell falls silent.

title: Western Wall Feud Heightens Israeli-Palestinian Tensions
description: JERUSALEM  The prime minister of Israel, Benjamin Netanyahu, on Thursday strongly denounced a Palestinian Authority paper that denies any Jewish connection to the Western Wall, the iconic holy site and place of Jewish worship in the Old City of Jerusalem, describing the report as reprehensible and scandalous.

title: Rebelling Against Spain, This Time With Words
description: MEXICO CITY  The Royal Spanish Academy is lopping two letters off the Spanish alphabet, reducing it to 27.

title: Plaintiffs in Chile Wont Appeal Dismissal of Sexual Abuse Case
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  The plaintiffs in a sexual abuse case against a prominent Chilean priest will not appeal a court ruling dismissing the case, their lawyer said Thursday.

title: Ease of Mind and Security at a Price
description: In two of San Franciscos lowest-crime neighborhoods, dozens of families pay up to $6,500 a year for armed off-duty or retired police officers, who provide such services as walking them from the sidewalk to their front doors. If asked, the officers will also accompany clients into their homes, and check closets and under beds for intruders.

title: A Small, Young Theater Company Aims High
description: In Coraline, a dark fantasy novel by Neil Gaiman, a young girl explores a surreal parallel universe where life resembles the world she knows, and yet defies all of her expectations.

title: Cities Are at Odds With California Over Beach Curfews
description: LOS ANGELES  Like many other coastal California cities, Los Angeles has a nighttime beach curfew.

title: Beyonc and Taylor Swift Offer Thanksgiving Specials
description: In 2009, when Kanye West interrupted Taylor Swifts MTV Video Music Awards acceptance speech to say Beyonc should have won the award for best female video, perhaps he planted an idea with prime-time programmers. Thanksgiving night brought successive specials by Ms. Swift, at 8 p.m. on NBC, and Beyonc, at 9:30 on ABC. Both featured billowing golden hair, live performances and pop image-polishing: Ms. Swift as careful as could be, Beyonc confident enough to loosen up.

title: Wide-Open N.C.A.A.s Show Growth of Womens Soccer
description: Oklahoma State midfielder Krista Lopez was on her way to the mall when she heard the news via text message from a teammate that Notre Dame had upset the womens soccer power North Carolina, 4-1, in the third round of the N.C.A.A. Division I tournament. That meant the Fighting Irish would travel to Stillwater, Okla., for the quarterfinals.

title: On a Crowded Rap Sheet of Politicians, DeLay Stands Apart
description: Ross Ramsey, managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

title: Friday: Action and Adventure
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Some solvers prefer the crosswords with themes that we see Sunday through Thursday. Others like the so-called themeless puzzles that arrive on Friday and Saturday. But why should we have to choose? The fun of the themeless crossword is not the lack of a common thread. Its the joy of all the great clues and answers that can emerge when constructors are unconstrained by having to symmetrically fit four or five (or more) similar entries into a tiny grid. If you can make a great Friday puzzle and squeeze in a theme to tie it together, then everyone wins. Gary Steinmehl accomplishes just that today. Its statistically a typical Friday, the clues are delightfully nefarious, and three long answers are names of Z-full action/adventure films.

title: Texas A&M Stakes Claim as Leader in Pharmaceuticals
description: One hundred miles from the nearest major city, where there was nothing but flat earth seven months ago, a 145,000-square-foot facility has sprung up on the Texas A&M Health Science Center campus. Starting in January, its cavernous rooms will be filled with racks of tobacco-like plants expected to produce as many influenza vaccines in a single month as a traditional lab does in one year, at a fraction of the cost.

title: Cuba-Texas Trade Is Languishing in Poor Economy
description: When the global shipping giant CMA CGM announced in April that it had obtained a license to ship container vessels to Cuba via the Port of Houston, business executives and trade experts marveled: Unabashedly Republican Texas would soon become the Communist island nations leading United States trade partner.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Canada: Orthodox Church Leader is Charged With Sexual Assault
description: The archbishop for Canada of the Orthodox Church in America was charged with two counts of sexual assault, the police in Winnipeg, Manitoba, said on Thursday. The allegations against the archbishop, Kenneth William Storheim, who is known as Archbishop Seraphim within the church, date back 30 years, according to a statement issued last month by the church. The police declined to give any details about the charges, citing a publication ban.

title: The Pulse: Adding Enticements for a Younger Crowd
description: The Steppenwolf Theatre Company may be approaching middle age, but that does not mean the troupe has given up on befriending the cool kids.

title: The Pulse: Public Library Makes a Daley Exception
description: The public library branch under construction in the West Humboldt Park neighborhood has already been christened in honor of the retiring mayor.

title: Frank Fenner Dies at 95; Tracked End of Smallpox
description: Frank Fenner, an Australian scientist who played an important role in the World Health Organizations decade-long campaign to eradicate smallpox and who made the official announcement, in 1980, that the disease had been conquered once and for all, died Monday in Canberra. He was 95.

title: Poland: Three Men Charged In Theft of Auschwitz Sign
description: Two Polish citizens and a Swede have been charged with crimes connected to theft of the infamous Arbeit Macht Frei sign at the Auschwitz concentration camp, prosecutors in Krakow, Poland, said. The German-language sign, which hung over the camps gate and whose words mean Work Sets You Free, was stolen Dec. 18. The Swedish suspect, Anders Hogstrom, a former neo-Nazi leader in his homeland, was extradited to Poland in April. He and the two Poles, who have been identified only as Andrzej S. and Marcin A., could face up to three years in prison.

title: Pakistan: Courts Help is Urged in Blasphemy Death Sentence
description: The Pakistani government has asked the lawyers for a Christian woman who has been sentenced to death for blasphemy against Islam to seek exoneration from a High Court. The federal minister for minorities, Shahbaz Bhatti, said the woman, Asia Bibi, 45, should try to get her death sentence overturned by the Lahore High Court before the president considers a pardon. Ms. Bibi is the first woman in Pakistan to be sentenced to death for blasphemy. She is accused of denigrating the Prophet Muhammad after fellow agriculture workers protested that a Christian had been asked to bring them a container of drinking water.

title: France: New Search for Wreckage In 2009 Air France Crash
description: The French government said Thursday that investigators would mount a fresh search for the wreckage of an Air France jet that crashed in the mid-Atlantic 18 months ago. The effort, which is expected to begin in February, will follow three previous attempts by the government, Air France and Airbus, the manufacturer of the plane, an A330-200. All 228 passengers and crew members were killed when Flight 447 went down in heavy thunderstorms while flying from Rio de Janeiro to Paris on June 1, 2009. The searches yielded more than 600 pieces of debris, but the flight recorders have not been found.

title: Canada: Asylum Overturned for White South African
description: The Federal Court of Canada overturned the refugee status granted to a white South African who said that he faced persecution, discrimination and possibly death because of his race if he returned home. The decision, which was released on Wednesday, ordered a new hearing by the Immigration and Refugee Board for the South African, Brandon Huntley. His initial success with the board was controversial in Canada, and the South African government filed a formal protest. The court acknowledged that violence and crime were widespread in South Africa, but it found that Mr. Huntley did not demonstrate that previous attacks against him were racially motivated.

title: Photo Replay: Nov. 25
description: A Thanksgiving day in the world of sports.

title: G.O.P. and Tea Party Are Mixed Blessing for Israel
description: WASHINGTON  When Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel came to the United States recently for another round of tense talks with the Obama administration, he got a decidedly warmer welcome from one of the rising Republican stars on Capitol Hill, Representative Eric Cantor, the incoming majority leader of the House.

title: Turkish Federation President Says Olympiad Bid Money Was Spent Legitimately
description: The president of the Turkish Chess Federation denied Thursday that his group paid delegates to support Turkeys successful bid to play host to the 2012 Chess Olympiad.

title: Jets Win Without Last-Gasp Drama
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  On Thursday night, for the first time in forever, the Jets triumphed without a comeback, without a seeming miracle, without the divine intervention from the football gods that seemed to guide them over the past month.

title: Taking Flight
description: It has never been done, what Jennifer Homans has done in Apollos Angels. She has written the only truly definitive history of the most impossibly fantastic art form, ballet, this most refined, most exquisite art of aristocratic etiquette, this science of behavior toward others, as a 17th-century ballet master put it, in which lovely young women perch upon their 10 little toe tips (actually, it is really just the two big toes that alternately support the entire bodys weight: think about it) and waft about where the air is thinner  but heaven is closer. She has taken this world where wilis, virgins, sylphs, sleeping princesses, the women in white embody the eternal  the eternally unattainable  and set it into the fabric of world history, and we see, miraculously, their pale tulle and satin pointes peeking out from the crevices of war, of revolutions, of political machinations, and on the stages of the monarchies and empires of the kings and czars who gave birth to this improbable art.

title: Jets Replay, Nov. 25
description: The Jets beat the Bengals at home on Thanksgiving Day, 26-10.

title: Inquiry Into Sell-Off of Taseko in Canada
description: A Canadian securities regulator said on Thursday that it was investigating whether leaked information about a governmental review of proposed gold and copper mine led to a huge sell-off of the stock of the mining company Taseko last month.

title: China Addresses Rising Korean Tensions
description: BEIJING  China engaged in a flurry of diplomatic activity on Friday, three days after a North Korean artillery attack on South Korean civilians, but its most public message was directed at the United States, which is about to begin joint exercises with South Koreas Navy.

title: Inside Track on Wine and Tapas in Madrid
description: For the uninitiated, the tapas options in Madrid can be overwhelming. Fortunately, Gourmet Madrid, an organization devoted to providing wine and food tourism options, knows where to go, offering day and evening wine and tapas tours, or a few that combine both. Its not only about finding the places but also about learning about what youre eating and drinking, from experts who know Spanish gastronomy well.

title: Taiwan Elections May Hinge on China
description: BEIJING  Taiwans citizens will vote Saturday for leaders of its five biggest cities after a long campaign in which the issues  good governance, petty corruption, empathy with the average man  have not been just domestic, but often rigorously local.

title: Tip of the Week: Undoing Undo
description: The keyboard shortcut for Undo  also known as Control-Z in Windows or Command-Z on a Mac  has saved many Microsoft Word files from accidental deletions or unintended formatting over the years. But what if you move too quickly and actually meant to keep the text or formatting the way it was? In Word, the cure for a premature Undo command is Control-Y or Command-Y, which repeats your last action before you undid it.

title: Weekly Matchups: Rivalry Saturday
description: Ah, rivalry weekend. Saturday is filled with games like Michigan-Ohio State, South Carolina-Clemson, Kansas-Missouri. In some, like Oklahoma-Oklahoma State, a lot is on the line, while others, like Brigham Young-Utah, just promise to be entertaining games between teams that genuinely do not like each other. Sadly, is one of the last great days of football. So enjoy it. Lets get to the matchups.

description: Stewart Mandel of Sports Illustrated offers a theory for why Fridays consumer spending numbers may be disappointing:

title: A Black Friday Push, From Twitter to Beijing
description: Twitter can be a remarkable tool. For me, its kind of like having a planet-spanning two-way sensory apparatus tracking sources of information or insights ranging from Stan Lee to the Dalai Lama, NASAs Asteroid Watch program to the hashtag #SaveSharks.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Chinas strange attraction for private equity.

title: A Case Study in N.B.A. Expectations: Rudy Gay
description: When Rudy Gay re-signed with Memphis this summer, he wasnt worth the five years and $80 million that the Grizzlies gifted him. Gay wasnt productive enough to warrant such a lavish deal, and the combination of contract length and value seemed like certain salary cap doom for the Grizzlies.

title: Think Twice Before Signing Up for That Medical Credit Card
description: IF you are like most people, you have probably used a credit card to pay some of your medical bills. With rising health costs and gaps in insurance coverage, its almost unavoidable.

title: Men of Words
description: In 2010, we lost four towering figures in the world of words. They all shared a deep and abiding love of the English language, though they expressed that love in distinctly different ways. Two made impassioned public cries against perceived abuses of English, while two others worked meticulously behind the scenes to record the ever-evolving richness of the linguistic landscape.

title: Vanity Unfair
description: I used to anticipate each issue of Vanity Fair with an enthusiasm that bordered on frantic. Ive been hoping to remember that buzz now that I have the lustrous-looking Vanity Fair app for my iPad.

title: Highfliers
description: In March 2008, Gulfstream Aerospace, the maker of private jets, announced that it was working on its biggest, fastest and most luxurious model yet: the G650. The list price, $64.5 million, would set an industry benchmark. Given the direction of the global economy since, the timing seems pretty bad. But the private-jet business is unusual. Gulfstream, a division of General Dynamics, has held up fairly well through the Great Recession and recently announced surprisingly strong quarterly sales figures. The G650, meanwhile, made its first flights last year, and even though its F.A.A. certification process will take another year or so, Gulfstream already has contracts to make these planes for about 200 customers, which means that if youd like to sign up right now, the earliest you would get yours is 2017.

title: Attention: Deficit
description: As a billionaire investor who has been fixated on the federal deficit for years and was secretary of commerce under President Nixon, are you surprised to see deficit-reduction become such a hot topic this fall?  Well, I dont want to end up in self-aggrandizement here. I do have a large number of people saying, Youve been talking about this long-term problem for 20 years, and its here.

title: The Professor of Micropopularity
description: ON A MONDAY evening in September, James Schamus and a dozen students in his graduate seminar in film theory at Columbia University were discussing the dialogues of Plato. Each participant who spoke called on the next speaker, and Schamus gave the group plenty of leeway to tussle with the text, but every once in a while he raised his hand and intervened to guide the conversation. The course was called Seeing Narrative, and the discussion centered on Platos skepticism about the ability of any visible thing to represent ideal truth  a skepticism that, say, a bunch of beautiful images strung together in a movie could communicate the perfect, invisible idea of Beauty.

title: Killing a Dead Horse in Ireland
description: Two years ago, when I found myself temporarily retired by a jobless universe, I moved back in with my parents, who live on a farm in Ireland. Many a stressed-out New Yorker would kill for the chance to unwind in an emerald paradise remote enough that a strange car passing up the road was a thrill, but I found myself floundering, unable to make peace with the fact that I was no longer a contributing member of society.

title: Letters: Lives
description: I was deeply touched by Frederick Woolvertons disclosure of being the most-hated son and having testified at his 10-year-old sisters custody trial. He talked about the horrors of living with his alcoholic mother and the culture of fear that permeated the existence of his siblings. Until this reading I had not ever heard of another situation similar to my own. I testified at a custody trial at age 12 along with two other siblings, to choose which parent with which to spend the rest of my childhood. Fifty years later, we remain puzzled at the estrangements and disconnections from one another. This pivotal stage of court appearances changed much in our lives and ultimately, I believe, drove my brothers and sister and I apart. Not fully understanding why, I think Woolverton touched on issues that I can now reflect on, shake out and perhaps present to willing family members. Thanks to this article, my family might be willing to take another look at a time that weve all tried in our own ways to bury. Dianne Murphey Keystone Heights, Fl.I thank Frederick Woolverton for his Lives essay and The Times Magazine for publishing it. In a world with so much hurt and where many parent-child relationships are complicated by addiction, Woolverton is able to transcend his own past and be kind to his mother (and as a mental-health professional, help others with addiction). Although the author doesnt believe that he forgives his mother, his treatment of her shows that at least part of him has forgiven  even if he will never forget.Betsy Garman Washington I was touched by Frederick Woolvertons desire to reconcile with his elderly mother. Most of us understand his desire for closure, made more pressing by his mothers age and frailty, though many would not share his ability to be so gracious in that situation. But it troubled me to read of his decision to visit his nursing-home-bound mother unannounced, since she couldnt communicate and could no longer refuse me. The nursing-home culture change movement teaches us to respect individuals autonomy, however we feel about their choices. A broken relationship between mother and son is an extreme example of a choice; but it is, nonetheless, a choice. No matter her past behavior, Woolvertons mother became the vulnerable one in their relationship. Rosa BaierProvidence, R.I.

title: Letter: The Hacker Who Went Into the Cold
description: James Verinis amazing story of Albert Gonzalezs cybercrimes underplays the fact that they were possible only because of lax security measures. Gonzalezs targets left consumers financial information out in the open for anyone with know-how to steal. Gonzalezs techniques were not novel  unsecured wireless networks and S.Q.L. injections are notorious within the technical community as gaping security holes. Clearly, his actions were illegal and unethical, but institutions that process millions of transactions each day must take a modicum of responsibility for failing to protect against well-known means of attack. The victims  individual consumers, taxpayers and affected businesses  should expect no less.

title: Full Disclosures
description: My same-sex partner and I are legally married in another country, a marriage not recognized by our state or (obviously) federal government, with significant negative consequences to our modest financial situation. My partner would be eligible for some government aid if she applied as a single person, but it feels disingenuous to do so, because as a family, we make well above the poverty line. In some sense, however, the government owes us this money since it unjustly disregards our marriage. Should she apply? NAME WITHHELD, PORTLAND, ME.

title: Letter: On Language
description: Ben Zimmer may be thankful that the worldwide Web has developed in a highly decentralized fashion, but similar comforting beliefs have always been a core element of spider-web imagery. The 15th-century Burgundian chronicler Jean Molinet named the French king Louis XI the universal spider because of his political cunning: his opponents didnt realize they were trapped until it was too late. Let us hope the modern Internet doesnt live up to its name.

title: Letter: The Ethicist
description: In Randy Cohens column The Anti-Antibiotics Doctor, he finds it disturbingly conservative when a doctor refuses to prescribe standby antibiotics to a patient with frequent bronchial infections planning a trip to Peru. As infectious-disease physicians, we respectfully disagree. Indeed, the overprescribing of antibiotics is disturbingly common, especially for respiratory infections of viral origin, which make up the vast majority of these bronchial infections. (Antibiotics do not work against viruses.) This overuse leads to antibiotic resistance, a dangerous and very real phenomenon. The Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta has been trying for years to educate the public and physicians about the risks of misusing antibiotics. Antibiotics are a nonrenewable resource: for this reason and others, they are not available over-the-counter in our country. In many South American countries like Peru, antibiotics are available over-the-counter, contributing to widespread resistance in these countries. Doctors that prescribe antibiotics only when really indicated  anti-antibiotics doctors, in Cohens words  are actually the ones helping the most to keep these wonder drugs effective when they are really needed.

title: Letters: Think About Pink
description: Thank you to Peggy Orenstein for articulating a sentiment about breast-cancer awareness that I had not quite found the words to express. When I was 12 years old, my sister and I tried to beat chemo to the punch by cutting off all of our mothers thick, unruly brown hair in the weeks after she began intensive treatment for Stage 2 breast cancer. Theres nothing cute or fun about being a young girl and seeing your beautiful, vibrant mother suddenly lose the trappings of her health and femininity, and knowing that its only the beginning of a long and harrowing ordeal. But her sense of humor, courage and quiet dignity were  and still are  fully intact, and thats what really matters.

title: Radical Constitutionalism
description: Of the newly elected Tea Party senators, Mike Lee, a 39-year-old Republican from Utah, has the most impeccable establishment legal credentials: the son of Rex Lee, a solicitor general under President Reagan, he attended law school at Brigham Young and later clerked for Samuel Alito on the U.S. Court of Appeals and then the Supreme Court. But on the campaign trail, especially during his heated primary battle with the three-term Republican incumbent Bob Bennett, Lee offered glimpses of a truly radical vision of the U.S. Constitution, one that sees the document as divinely inspired and views much of what the federal government currently does as unconstitutional.

title: Letters: Idea Lab
description: What a sensible article by David Frum! His observations are rooted in historical reality and eschew the ideological ranting of the Republican right wing. If such views were to prevail among the Republican leadership in Congress, I have no doubt that the next two years could see a constructive partnership between the president and Congress. Then, perhaps we might have a contest between Mitt Romney and Barack Obama in 2012, in which the main issue would be: who can best lead America out of the darkness and into the light? But I fear that the Republican leadership is more intent on settling scores than on following Frums advice.

title: A Guide to Union Square Park
description: Happy Cathie Black Friday. Attention fair-weather shoppers: any lingering rain should cease by 1 p.m., according to the Weather Channel. Heres what we read.

title: Europeans Striving to Calm Nerves in Markets
description: MADRID  Officials across Europe scrambled on Friday to speed measures aimed at easing the fears of investors even as borrowing costs flirted with new highs in the euro zones frailer countries.

title: The Instability of Moderation
description: Brad DeLong writes of how our perception of history has changed in the wake of the Great Recession. We used to pity our grandfathers, who lacked both the knowledge and the compassion to fight the Great Depression effectively; now we see ourselves repeating all the old mistakes. I share his sentiments.

title: Fear and Lawyering Up on Wall Street
description: James B. Stewart, in his book Den of Thieves, described the mood when the Securities and Exchange Commission announced its historic $100 million settlement with Ivan Boesky for insider trading: Paranoia swept Wall Street.

title: Veritas Buys CPI International
description: CPI International, the telecommunications equipment maker, said Friday that it would be acquired by Veritas Capital, the New York private equity firm, for $525 million.

title: A War on Dementia
description: The Times reports this morning on efforts in South Korea, one of the fastest-aging nations, to grapple with an epidemic Alzheimers disease.

title: Complaint Box | Sitting Tight
description: I still remember the first time I flew. Meals were served, blankets were plentiful  it was great fun, and not just because I was 7 at the time.

title: Weekend Competition: Define Family
description: This Thanksgiving weekend, Schotts Vocab is soliciting definitions of family.

title: The Social Security Deficit
description: Several readers have taken issue with our deficit puzzles description of Social Securitys finances, arguing that the program does not have serious problems. This post explains the details behind our description.

title: The Little Irelands of Structured Finance
description: 3:08 p.m. | Updated The bailout of Ireland arrived hand in hand with a panicky pullout of bank deposits, providing yet more proof of how hard it is for financial institutions to brace themselves against panics and crises.

title: Friday Reading: Figuring Out Colleges Cost
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Cash Registers Will Ring Before Wedding Bells: The First William-Kate Book Is Out
description: And so it begins.Ten days after the announcement of the engagement of Prince William and Kate Middleton, the first of an expected rash of books about their relationship was published in Britain on Friday, The Associated Press reported. William and Kate: A Royal Love Story, by James Clench, The Sun newspapers royal reporter, was published by HarperCollins and The Sun, both owned by Rupert Murdochs News Corporation. It is due to be published in the United States on Dec. 17, well in advance of the couples April 29 wedding at Westminster Abbey for those who just cannot wait for that frothy spectacle.

title: A Camp Classic of 19th-Century Ballet
description: If the notion of camp had existed in late-19th-century Italy, the wildly successful ballet Excelsior would have been a prime example. In Apollos Angels: A History of Ballet, Jennifer Homans says:

title: Medical Panel Urges a Low-Carbon Diet
description: A network of the worlds leading medical academies on Friday urged nations to adopt policies to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gas pollutants because it would have a salutary effect not just on the planet but on human health.

title: Formula One Season Review, and a Todt Interview
description: The Formula One season is getting longer and longer  its nearly December, yet the season has only been over for 2 weeks. And next year it will go on even longer still.

title: Formula One Season Review, and a Todt Interview
description: The Formula One season is getting longer and longer  its nearly December, yet the season has only been over for 2 weeks. And next year it will go on even longer still.

title: The Small Print of Medical Credit Cards
description: Medical credit cards, marketed through doctors, dentists and even veterinarians, offer consumers a chance to spread out large payments over many months, often with promises of zero interest and other attractive options. But the cards may not be such a bargain, explains Walecia Konrad in todays Patient Money column:

title: Health Law Faces Threat of Undercut From Courts
description: WASHINGTON  As the Obama administration presses ahead with the health care law, officials are bracing for the possibility that a federal judge in Virginia will soon reject its central provision as unconstitutional and, in the worst case for the White House, halt its enforcement until higher courts can rule.

title: Built to Last
description: The title of this hefty volume is a little misleading. It doesnt select anything, strictly speaking, but merely assembles the stories from William Trevors last four collections, so that in effect its a sequel to the huge edition of his collected stories that came out in 1992. Together the two books add up to almost 2,000 pages of short fiction  an enormous, Kiplingesque quantity of work  and they are more than ample proof that Trevor is one of the two greatest short-story writers working in English right now. The other is Alice Munro, and no one else is even close.

title: Only Collect
description: As Woody Allen used to be indistinguishable from Manhattan, so Steve Martin has long been associated with Hollywood. Big-budget romantic comedies; tuxedoed pratfalls at award ceremonies; a long-running genial middle age. Banged out between screenplays, wives and banjo-playing sessions (there seems no form of entertainment he hasnt mastered, though he abandoned stand-up comedy years ago), Martins first novel, Shopgirl, centered on a winsome employee at the Beverly Hills Neiman Marcus glove counter. His second, The Pleasure of My Company, was about an obsessive-compulsive lonely-hearts in Santa Monica. Both explored sharp corners of the soft-focus world he usually inhabits.

title: Flyers Three-goalie Circus Led by Bobrovsky
description: Perhaps Philadelphias goalie situation is the new-school hockey spin on the tale of Goldilocks and the three bears.

title: FrontPoint Investors Ask for $3 Billion Back
description: FrontPoint Partners, a $7 billion hedge fund under fire for allegations that a manager there benefited from insider information, has received about $3 billion in redemption requests, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.

title: Motion, Sensitive
description: WHAT does it mean to play a game?

title: Pinning the Loss on Someone
description: We interrupt the shopping frenzy of Black Friday to console the N.F.L. teams that lost on Thursday in varying degrees of ridiculousness, to whom it must feel like a very black Friday.

title: How the N.H.L. Tackles Scandals: A Flowchart
description: Gary Bettman and the N.H.L. took some heat this week when it became clear that the league would take no action as a result of the Colin Campbell e-mail scandal. Many observers accused the league of ignoring the controversy.

title: The Oft-Examined Life
description: Nora Ephrons new book of essays is titled I Remember Nothing, but thats a sop. She remembers everything, and while some of the material in this book is tantalizingly fresh and forthright, some of it weve seen before. Which doesnt mean its not just as entertaining the second or even third time around, offered in each new iteration with a few more spicy details. Which is all just another way of saying: Does Carl Bernstein lie awake at night wondering how the hell his ex-wife of so many years ago (they were divorced in 1980) turned his marital indiscretion into a multimedia juggernaut spanning the decades?

title: Pumpkin for Breakfast, Dinner and Dessert
description: Instead of carving a pumpkin, Martha Rose Shulman decided to cook it up. The result is a week-long pumpkin feast, with recipes for every time of day.

title: Eighth Ave. and 39th St., Thanksgiving Eve, 8 P.M.
description: Bridget Farrison, 45, was sitting on the corner as commuters rushed to the Port Authority and tourist families bustled by. She said she had spent years working these streets as a prostitute to pay for her crack addiction. She said she had recently met a good man who was convincing her that she should clean up her life.

title: A Dying Bankers Last Instructions
description: BURLINGAME, Calif.

title: Adam and Eve Return to Prado
description: Albrecht Durers 1507 oil paintings of Adam and Eve are back on display at the Prado Museum in Madrid after a two-year absence to allow for the restoration of the works, Agence France-Presse reported. The restoration was completed by an international team of experts in a project coordinated by the Prado and the Getty Foundation in Los Angeles.

title: Fruitful Talent Who Made Art World Multiply
description: Robert Rauschenberg, the subject of a chock-a-block time capsule of a show at Gagosian Gallery in Chelsea, was an optimist and a doer. He not only did what artists normally do: make paintings, sculptures, prints and photographs. He also did the work of performers, musicians, philanthropists and career politicians.

title: A Headlong Life
description: For my paternal grandfather, born in 1884, Theodore was the Great Roosevelt. He always regretted hed been too young to vote for him in 1904, rushed to the polls to do so when Roosevelt ran as a Bull Moose in 1912 and to the end of his long life proudly called himself a progressive Republican in honor of his hero. For my father, who was born in 1910 and first went to the polls in the midst of the Great Depression in 1932, Franklin was the Roosevelt to admire; to him, the younger Roosevelts dead fifth cousin seemed shrill and overwrought, a perpetual adolescent.

title: Skepticism Stays as Glazer Familys Teams Rebound
description: This time a year ago, the Glazer family was a piata for sports fans on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Book Review Podcast: On William Trevor
description: This week: Charles McGrath discusses William Trevors new collection of short stories; Patricia Cohen reports on the digital humanities; Alexandra Jacobs and Julie Bosman discuss Steve Martin and his new novel, An Object of Beauty; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)
