title: Banks Start to Dig Out From Troubled Loans
description: AFTER several years of decline, this is shaping up to be the year in which the problems of Americas banks began to recede.

title: Champions League Chalkboards
description: This is Goals second installment of a feature that offers statistical and graphic representations of select matches (courtesy of OPTA) from the European Champions League. At the end of each week when matches are played, the editor of zonalmarking.net will provide analysis powered by the Total Football iPhone/iPad app, which is available at totalfootballapps.com and the iTunes App Store. Similar chalkboards can be found on the Web site of The Guardian and at zonalmarking.net.

title: Jets Already Thinking About Patriots
description: The leftovers from the Jets 26-10 victory over the Cincinnati Bengals on Thanksgiving did not have much shelf life. Even in a victorious locker room at New Meadowlands Stadium, there was less reflection and more focus on what was ahead.

title: Black Eyed Peas Land Super Bowl Gig
description: Seven years after Janet Jacksons wardrobe malfunction at the Super Bowl, is the National Football League finally ready to return to somewhat racy halftime shows by people under 40?

title: Up Front: Geoffrey C. Ward
description: Over the course of a phenomenally prolific career, Geoffrey C. Ward has written more than a dozen scripts for public television documentaries; articles for Vanity Fair, Smithsonian, The New York Review of Books and numerous other publications; and a shelfful of books, including biographies of Franklin Roosevelt and Jack Johnson.

title: TimesCast | November 26, 2010
description: Two small businesses still facing the fallout from BP's oil spill; and a conversation with the distributor of BP's $20 billion fund.

title: Your Deathbed Financial Instructions
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I profile Gordon Murray, a Wall Street banker who is dying and had a late-in-life conversion to the religion of passive investing. He believes that no one can predict what the financial markets will do over the long haul and has written a book giving people instructions on how to invest in a more sensible fashion, say using mutual funds from companies like Vanguard or Dimensional Fund Advisors, where he was once a consultant.

title: Tip, Tip, Tip
description: My daughters and I have been going to the same hairstylist for 10 years. She doesnt own the salon. Recently, shes taken on an assistant who applies the color after our stylist mixes it; then the stylist cuts our hair. Our bills are over $200. Do we have to tip the assistant, as well as the stylist and shampoo girl? I know she works for tips, but dont we all? Shouldnt the stylist be responsible for paying her?

title: This Old World
description: Three of the four people who care for my 94-year-old grandfather in his home near Washington were born outside America. None migrated to the United States to do this kind of work. But all remain, and earn a decent living, thanks to senior citizens like my bionic Pop-Pop, a retired doctor powered by a pacemaker and a defibrillator.

title: This Weekends Top European Matchups
description: The outstanding matchups in European league soccer this weekend:

title: Desert Song
description: For a squeamish, atheistic, arachnophobic Easterner  one who, as a child, slept guarded by a stuffed owl to scare away all the pythons and black widows of Washington, D.C.  reading Leslie Marmon Silkos memoir, The Turquoise Ledge, was a disconcerting experience. Silkos book is less an autobiography than an exploration of her relationship with the natural and spiritual worlds  and its a very close relationship. In her house in the Tucson Mountains, pack rats make a home in the copy machine, a rattlesnake hides under the chaise longue, spiders are welcome and the appearance of a grasshopper is seen as a sign from Lord Chapulin, the Grasshopper Being.

title: Fairy Tales, Royal and Otherwise
description: EVEN though I write about weddings, I have never fully understood peoples fascination with them.

title: Throwing Punches in a Church Basement
description: NEW YORK is full of closed doors, hidden communities and secret places. We pass by them all the time, without a hint of what lurks within, above or, in this case, below.

title: Marco Rubio: Catholic or Protestant?
description: Marco Rubio, the charismatic senator-elect from Florida, is in many ways similar to other Cuban-American politicians from his home state: conservative, Republican and a practicing and devout Roman Catholic, in the words of his spokesman, one who regularly attends Catholic Mass and was baptized, confirmed and married in the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Throwing Punches in a Church Basement
description: New York is full of closed doors, hidden communities and secret places. We pass by them all the time, without a hint of what lurks within, above or, in this case, below.

title: A Celebrity Bank Card, if Not the Bankroll
description: THEYRE the faces of everything unapologetically excessive about pop culture: from Rodeo Drive shopping sprees to sex tapes to Nascar. So why wouldnt the Kardashian sisters, nouveaux-celeb stars of the reality show Keeping Up With the Kardashians, promote a prepaid debit card?

title: Those Undulating Swan Arms? Not So Easy to Do
description: TEN years of serious training and then five more toiling in the ranks. Thats how many years of dedicated study it takes on average to become a principal ballerina at a top company. But Hollywood isnt willing to wait. So when several actresses signed up to portray professional dancers in new movies, they had to play a very intense game of catch-up.

title: One Size Doesnt Fit
description: Many of the reactions to my writing, both in comments here and more generally, seem to be along one of the following lines:

title: Binary Breakthrough
description: You know the story of the invention of the computer? one character asks another midway through Jane Smileys best-selling 1995 novel Moo. The speaker, an animal scientist, dreams of striking it rich by pioneering a new dairy-farming technology. To that end, he hopes to pry major grant money out of the agricultural industry, and he wields the history of the computer as both cautionary tale and crowbar. The short version, he explains, is that the guy at Iowa State who invented the computer in the late 30s never patented a thing. . . . And the university . . . forgot about the old machine, and threw it out.

title: Animal Lovers, Beware of Ownership Costs
description: PEOPLE love their pets, but how often do they think about the costs? The question is akin to asking which child we love more.

title: Next Financial Crisis May Start in Washington, Says Bair
description: You can add one more item to the list of problems keeping Sheila C. Bair up at night. The nations capitol, she fears, will be ground zero of the next financial crisis.

title: Explaining Norfolks Creeping Tides
description: Some readers responded skeptically to my Friday article about how Norfolk, Va., is handling encroaching seas. Many argued that auxiliary factors that I highlighted in my article like the compacting of landfill and natural land sinkage explained Norfolks problems in full and dismissed the notion that global sea rise played a role.

title: BMG Acquires Chrysalis In Music Publishing Deal
description: In a deal between two of the worlds largest independent music publishers, BMG Rights Management has agreed to acquire Chrysalis for 107.4 million ($168.6 million), the companies announced on Friday.

title: Wait. Dash. Buy. Nap.
description: Shoppers across the country withstood cold weather and crowds for Black Friday deals on electronics and the seasons most popular toys.

title: Elhaam Yavari and Mat Steel
description: ONE of the many things Elhaam Yavari and Mat Steel have in common is almost zero body fat. He is the lead guitarist for Your Vegas, a British pop band, and his jeans seem barely wider than guitar strings. She is a petite D.J. with ringlets in her dark hair and eyes the color of Coca-Cola; she tiptoes about in ballet slippers and, when typing on a computer or telephone, doesnt make a sound.

title: Fifth Ave. and 54th St., 10:24  A.M.
description: The annual Volunteers of America Sidewalk Santa parade took place in Midtown Manhattan, as it has since 1902.

title: 2006 Honda CR-V in Inquiry on Possible Fire Hazard
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has opened an investigation into a possible fire hazard on 150,000 Honda CR-Vs from the 2006 model year.

title: Other Peoples Divorces
description: YOU dont have to be divorced to be sucked in by the new HuffPost Divorce section on The Huffington Post; you just have to have thought about getting one. Which basically includes every married person on the planet.

title: A Home Field Advantage for In the Heights
description: It was one of the best performances in the history of Tony Awards telecasts: Lin-Manuel Miranda accepting in 2008 for best score for In the Heights by delivering a speech of lyrical rap, in the style of his character Usnavi from the musical, and then pulling a small Puerto Rican flag from his pocket and dedicating the award to the homeland of his parents and relatives.

title: Cult of Motherhood: The Confessional
description: IT feels like cheating.

title: To Listen To Schumann, Bring a Couch
description: AND you were feeling overwhelmed by the 118 different diagnoses recently tallied for Mozarts final illness? Consider Robert Schumann, whose bicentennial is being celebrated this year and whose medical history has occasioned even more impassioned debate.

title: Playing It More Marlowe Than Marple
description: FOR six seasons, Kyra Sedgwick has sated fans of The Closer with her portrayal of Brenda Leigh Johnson, the Los Angeles deputy police chief whose candy-coated exterior masks a withering intelligence.

title: One-Woman Pipa Jam Session
description: LIKE archeologists constructing a whole from fragments, ethnomusicologists who research ancient scores must translate extinct musical languages into contemporary Western notation.

title: From Haiti to Canada, Tunes Personal and Political
description: Jazmine Sullivan

title: Ombra Cara: Arias of George Frideric Handel
description: OMBRA CARA:

title: Path of Least Resistance
description: One of my favorite songs is Les Chemins de lAmour by Francis Poulenc, a great composer who could turn his hand to anything from high operatic tragedy in Dialogues of the Carmelites to a boulevard ballad like this one, and when I used to cover the Tour de France, I would play the original recording by the adorable Yvonne Printemps as I pottered along one route nationale or another. Then one day I glanced at the liner notes and saw when and where it was made: Paris, November 1940. While my parents generation in London nightly awaited the air-raid sirens, across the Channel, the bands still played.

title: The Week Ahead: Nov. 28-Dec. 4
description: Television

title: What Evil Lurks
description: From the start  even before a young man I can now hardly comprehend started writing The Long Walk in his college dormitory room  I felt that the best fiction was both propulsive and assaultive, Stephen King writes in a chatty afterword to Full Dark, No Stars, his new collection of longish stories. It gets in your face. As if we didnt know.

title: Darth Vader No Match for James Bond
description: Darth Vader, zero. James Bond, $437,000.An original Darth Vader costume  a jet-black helmet, mask and armor  did not sell at auction Thursday while the Walther air pistol held by Sean Connery in a 1963 James Bond film fetched 277,250 pounds (or $437,206) at Christies in London.

title: Youre O.K., but Im Not. Lets Share.
description: IF, like me, you are not in the habit of sharing highly personal tidbits of your life with 148 strangers for 13 hours a day, three days in a row, then let me, uh, share with you what that experience feels like. It feels like intergalactic jet lag, or like someone has pumped your head full of a global weather system, heavy on the cumulonimbus. Some of the 148 strangers were crying so much, they looked as if they had been boiled.

title: We Should Dance While We Can
description: WE have reached that recognizable wedding-reception moment when the D.J. queues up Brown Eyed Girl, the grooms great-aunt grinds down to the floor in her silk pantsuit, and then needs a lift up. The caterers have replenished the empty steam trays with cheeseburger sliders, and the bridesmaids have removed their shoes. Anything could happen.

title: Letters
description: Online Bar Mitzvahs

title: Statesman, Fixer
description: Felix Rohatyns memoir, modestly titled Dealings: A Political and Financial Life, is the sort of vaulting success story that makes one yearn for the big-hearted America of the mid-20th century, a less mean and more innocent time when not every career seemed calculated and not every banker was a subject of scorn, and when the country welcomed enterprising immigrants.

title: Diet: Good-for-You Things Come in Orange
description: Eat your carrots. And have some leftover pumpkin pie.

title: Neighborhood Joint | Kokushi Budo Institute
description: A dojo for training in the traditional Japanese martial arts, secluded in the basement of the New York Buddhist Church.

title: Spider-Man': Turn on the Commercials
description: Given that the coming Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark is the most expensive in history, at $65 million and counting, it comes as no surprise that the producers are willing to spend money on two flashy commercials that will be broadcast on cable and network television in the New York area starting on Monday.

title: Aging: Unsteady on Your Feet? Try Moving to Music
description: Elderly people in a new study cut their risk of falling by more than half after they took classes in eurhythmics, an exercise-and-music program designed for young children.

title: What Was I Thinking?
description: In Self Comes to Mind, the eminent neurologist and neuroscientist Antonio Damasio gives an account of consciousness that might come naturally to a highly caffeinated professor in his study. He emphasizes wakefulness, self-awareness, reflection, rationality, knowledge of ones own existence and of the existence of surroundings.

title: Oil Spill Imapact Lingers in Louisiana
description: A look at two small businesses in Louisiana seven months after the Gulf oil spill.

title: Obama Gets 12 Stitches in Lip
description: 5:14 p.m. | Updated 4:46 p.m. | Updated President Obama had to get 12 stitches in his upper lip after getting a blow from an opposing players elbow during a basketball game Friday morning, White House officials said.

title: The Voyager
description: Writing in The Atlantic last year, presumably while finishing work on The Passages of H. M., a novel based on the life of Herman Melville, Jay Parini declared that the historical novel has become our primary form of fiction. The present, he speculated, can seem too bright, too close, requiring the filter of memory to sort out and deliver the profound insights readers hope to find in novels. Going a step farther, he argued that it is in fiction like Gore Vidals Lincoln or Russell Bankss Cloudsplitter that one gets real history.

title: At Least the Weed Man Is Honest. Or Is He?
description: Stop right there, barked the officer stationed next to the X-ray machine at the entrance to 1 Police Plaza.

title: Veritas Returns
description: Veritas, the high-end wine-centric jewel box in the Flatiron district, will reopen on Tuesday with a bit more reasonably priced.

title: The Man Who Would Be Taliban
description: Turnabout is fair play. Thats as true in Afghanistan, where fair play is a rather flexible concept, as it is anywhere. In any place where they fight, a man who knows how to drill men can always be a king insisted Dravot, one of the two Europeans in Kiplings Man Who Would Be King who manage to hoodwink an Afghan tribe into believing in their royal status, at least for a while. Indeed, historically, Westerners of dubious character have had a knack for bluffing their ways to positions of prominence during times of strife. Consider Dravots real-life inspiration: Josiah Harlan, an American charlatan who in 1848 declared himself the prince of Ghor in central Afghanistan. (One of Harlans descendants, a horror-movie actor, is convinced that the royal title remains in the family.)

title: Russian TV Kowtows to Kremlin, Critic Says
description: MOSCOW  A well-known television personality on Thursday used the occasion of an awards ceremony to deliver a blistering critique of Russian television, saying its journalists had bent so completely to the will of the government that they were not journalists at all but bureaucrats, following the logic of service and submission.

title: A Crazy Bad Day in Beijing
description: Last week I wrote about the global environmental impact of rising coal exports to China. Sea shipments of thermal coal, used for heating and electricity generation, are skyrocketing, undermining attempts to tamp down the growth of global greenhouse gas emissions.

title: Giants Andrews Hospitalized With Back Pain
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants may turn to their third left tackle this season after the travails of their banged-up offensive line worsened when Shawn Andrews was held in a hospital Thursday night into Friday afternoon with back pain.

title: The Devils Playground
description: For most Americans, who remember World War II as beginning in 1941, it is necessary to recall that Europe had succumbed to an infatuation with violence long before the United States entered the conflict. Timothy Snyder, a professor of history at Yale, compels us to look squarely at the full range of destruction committed first by Stalins regime and then by Hitlers Reich. Each fashioned a terrifying orgy of deliberate mass killing.

title: An American in Peru, Out of Jail but in Limbo
description: LIMA, Peru

title: Our Unlettered Landscape
description: We come to books, David L. Ulin writes in The Lost Art of Reading, to be challenged and confounded, made to question our assumptions. With this principle in mind, here is the news that Ulin brings in this slim, meandering book: that reading is an act of contemplation; that such an act becomes more difficult in our overnetworked society, where every buzz and rumor is instantly blogged and tweeted, and it is not contemplation we desire but an odd sort of distraction; that the analphabetic anger of anonymous Internet comment threads is emblematic of a degraded cultural conversation in which the ability to carry out a logical argument has been lost; that technology brings a boon but also a burden: We are never disconnected, never out of touch; and lastly, coming full circle, that in this landscape of distraction, reading becomes not just an act of contemplation but one of resistance.

title: Failure to Communicate
description: In Iraq, the United States Army often lacked the Arabic translators desperately needed to decipher documents captured from insurgents who were planting hidden explosive devices that killed and maimed American soldiers by the hundreds. In New York City, the opening of a charter school where pupils might master the intricacies of Arabic was all but thwarted by vociferous critics, many of them vocal supporters of Israel, who made it sound as if a terrorist training camp was opening in Brooklyn.

title: C.I.A. Agents, Blowing Their Own Cover
description: This summer, a former spy who calls himself Ishmael Jones got into trouble with his old bosses at the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Skipping the Stores on Black Friday
description: When I was younger, I used to love going to the stores on Black Friday, braving the mall crowds, buying an item or two and viewing all the holiday decorations.

title: Editors Choice
description: FOREIGN BODIES,  by Cynthia Ozick (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $26.) This nimble homage to Henry Jamess Ambassadors, in which an American heads to Paris to retrieve a wayward son, brilliantly upends the theme, meaning and manner of its precursor.

title: That 2BR Frame of Mind
description: Two-bedrooms are back in demand, after a wallflower period when smaller, or larger, places were commanding the attention. Prices are coming back, too.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Natalie Portman, All Good Things, Arhoolie Records and More
description: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

title: Paperback Row
description: THE COMPLETE STORIES OF J.G. BALLARD. (Norton, $24.95.) Ballard, who died in April 2009 and is perhaps best known for the novels Empire of the Sun and Crash, was once praised by Kingsley Amis as the brightest star in British postwar SF. The 98 stories collected here span an entire creative life, one spent relentlessly exploring the desolate landscapes and nightmare metropolises of what Ballard called our visionary present. Each story is like a dream more perfectly realized than any of your own, Jonathan Lethem wrote in the Book Review. Ballard is simply a master story writer.

title: An Industrial Project That Could Change Myanmar
description: DAWEI, MYANMAR  The vast, pristine stretch of coastline here is almost deserted, save for fishermen hauling their bountiful catches onto white-sand beaches. But a deal signed this month would transform these placid waters into a seaport for giant cargo ships. Cashew nut groves and rice fields would be plowed under and replaced with a warren of factories, refineries and an expansive coal-burning power plant.

title: Inside the List
description: SCHOOL OF RAP: Why is every self-respecting pop star suddenly clamoring to play the New York Public Library? First, Keith Richards shows up to confess his youthful dreams of becoming a librarian. Now, Jay-Z  whose Decoded hits No. 3 on the hardcover nonfiction list this week  checks in to talk hip-hop and philosophy with Cornel West.

title: After Del Monte, Whos Next on the Shopping List?
description: The buyout of Del Monte Foods is the latest in a series of multibillion-dollar deals in the food industry this year, including the $19.5 billion takeover of Cadbury by Kraft Foods,and Coca-Colas $13.6 billion purchase of Coca-Cola Enterprises North American operations.

title: Art Basel Miamis Big-Buzz 10
description: ART BASEL MIAMI BEACH, that bacchanal disguised as the Western Hemispheres most prestigious art fair, takes place Dec. 2 to 5. Once again, there will be a dizzying whirl of glamorous dinners, hush-hush viewings and after-hour soirees  a Herculean scavenger hunt crammed into four days. To help, here are 10 must-do spots to schmooze, party, dine and, oh, see art.

title: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from New York, Seoul and Brazil.

title: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from New York, Seoul and Brazil.

title: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 26
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

title: Obama Gets 12 Stitches After Basketball Game
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama had to get 12 stitches in his lip after getting a blow from an opponents elbow during a basketball game Friday morning, White House officials said.

title: Preview: 'The Kimchi Chronicles'
description: A look at the new PBS series on Korean food featuring Marja Vongerichten, the chef Jean-Georges Vongerichten's wife.

title: The Making of Fashions Latest It Girl
description: ON a recent afternoon at the Bowery Hotel, over a burrata caprese salad, green beans and a Coke, the British television host, model and pop-culture phenomenon Alexa Chung was explaining her hair color, which often calls to mind a grown-out dye job. I said I want to look like Kurt Cobain, said Ms. Chung, 26. I said, Im going to America and theyre going to try and make my hair shiny and I dont want it. I want to look like Kurt Cobain.

title: Alexa Chung, Fashions Latest Darling
description: The British television host, model and pop-culture phenomenon sets her own definition of style, and moves in various fashion circles.

title: Keith Richardss Life
description: To the Editor:

title: First the Parade, and Then the Apocalypse
description: Visitors to the Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade may have been surprised to learn that not only were there only 30 shopping days left till Christmas, there were also only 177 days left until the world ends.

title: Justice Jacksons Path
description: To the Editor:

title: An Ever Expanding Web
description: To the Editor:

title: Palin Debate Aside, Does Dancing Need Electoral Reform?
description: The TV tuner at the Silver household is usually stuck on politics, sports, or  if truth must be told  The Real Housewives of Atlanta. So I cant acknowledge having spent much time watching Dancing With the Stars this year. From what little I caught, it was clear that each of the 12 couples on the show were far more capable dancers than I ever might be. (Im saving my reality television karma for when CNBC debuts Spreadsheet Idol.)

title: In Christene Barberichs Closet
description: The founder of and the editorial director for Refinery29.com chronicles what she wore for a week.

title: Fashion Goes, Keds Stay
description: CHRISTENE BARBERICH, 41, is a founder of and the editorial director for Refinery29.com, a fashion and shopping Web site in TriBeCa. She consults for brands including Yves Saint Laurent, Prada Beauty and Nike.

title: Mayor and State Reach Deal to Pave Way for Schools Chief
description: The states education commissioner, David M. Steiner, and the Bloomberg administration have reached a deal that will allow Cathleen P. Black, a media executive, to become the next schools chief.

title: The First 50,000 Words
description: To the Editor:

title: Sunday Preview
description: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

title: From the Former Eastern Bloc, Wielding Color
description: SOON after entering the common studio space at the Universitatea de Arta si Design in Cluj Napoca, Romania, Livia Straus spotted a dreadlocked young man working alone in a corner. All of his canvases were facing the wall, recalled Ms. Straus, the director and co-founder with her husband, Dr. Marc Straus, of the Hudson Valley Center for Contemporary Art in Peekskill. And, of course, if a canvas is facing the wall, I want to see it.

title: Robert Rauschenberg
description: The Gagosian Gallery in Chelsea is putting on a survey of the prolific artist's career.

title: The Nominees for the 2010 World XI
description: FIFA and FIFPro this week released the list of 55 players who are on its list to be included in the 2010 World XI squad that will be announced on Jan. 10.

title: Demand Returns for 2-Bedroom Apartments
description: TWO-BEDROOM apartments have long been the workhorse of the New York City real estate market, accounting year after year for the largest percentage of apartments sold.

title: App Smart Extra: Deals in the Malls
description: This weeks App Smart column arms you with a few good apps for finding the best prices on your next shopping trip.

title: To Help Donors Choose, Web Site Alters How It Sizes Up Charities
description: Charity Navigator, perhaps the largest online source for evaluating nonprofit groups, recently embarked on an overhaul to offer a wider, more nuanced array of information to donors who are deciding which organizations they might help.

title: A New Push to Rescue Xanadu Mall Project
description: Lenders and state officials in New Jersey are desperately trying to cobble together the second rescue of Xanadu, one of the nations largest, most expensive and still incomplete retail and entertainment malls.

title: A Ring Returns: Scalas Rheingold at Symphony Space
description: For me and perhaps others who overdosed on Robert Lepages new production of Wagners Rheingold at the Metropolitan Opera this fall, a repeat showing of a Rheingold from the Teatro Alla Scala in Milan, originally broadcast live in May and to be presented at Symphony Space on Sunday afternoon, provides relief of a sort from any remaining withdrawal pangs. The film, seen in a preview this week, also reopened windows on staging possibilities obscured in my case by a three-pronged experience of the juggernaut Met production (the opening, on big screens in Times Square through a teeming rain; the third performance, in the house; and the fourth, via HD broadcast at a theater in Ellsworth, Me.

title: Singer for Whom the Hard Knocks Were All Gifts
description: Baby Jane Dexter might be considered a bad girl of cabaret, blending the occasional nightclub standard into a frothy emotional mixture of pop and rock songs, always with her eye on the unsuspecting audience.

title: Grown-Up Granita
description: Mark Bittman makes a cold, sweet cocktail with gin and sorbet.

title: In Iraq, Were Still Getting Hit
description: FORWARD OPERATING BASE WARHORSE, Iraq  Soldiers were playing football in the sunset of a long day and a longer war, their shadows tilting across fields of packed dirt. It was Monday, and this base in Diyala Province had the casual air of a heavily armed college campus:

title: Pop Queens on TV, One Careful and One Exuding Confidence
description: In 2009, when Kanye West interrupted Taylor Swifts MTV Video Music Awards acceptance speech to say Beyonc should have won the award for best female video, perhaps he planted an idea with prime-time programmers. Thanksgiving night brought successive specials by Ms. Swift, at 8 on NBC, and Beyonc, at 9:30 on ABC. Each featured billowing golden hair, live performance and pop-image polishing: Ms. Swift as careful as could be, Beyonc confident enough to loosen up.

title: Drug Maker Cited on Quality Issues
description: Months after McNeil Consumer Healthcare, a unit of Johnson & Johnson, recalled millions of bottles of Tylenol and other over-the-counter drugs, the division is still plagued with manufacturing flaws, according to the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Apollos Angels
description: Chapter 1: Kings of Dance

title: A Sophisticated Slushie
description: THERE are three things I love about this cocktail: it has gin in it (always a good thing), it takes less than a minute to make (ditto) and it doubles as dessert. Whats not to love?

title: A Collaboration Far More Than the Sum of Its Parts
description: Early in the 20th century, soloists occasionally assembled programs that were part recital, part chamber performance. That hybrid approach had fallen out of favor by the 1950s, but Xiayin Wangs collaboration with the Fine Arts Quartet at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening suggested that it might be worth reviving.

title: Small Latkes, Large Toppings
description: ABOUT a decade ago I held a Hanukkah party with more people than I could fit around my dining table. I wanted to serve latkes, but the ones I typically made were saucer size, requiring plates and forks. Thats when it occurred to me to serve hors doeuvres-size instead.

title: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 26
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a school garden, a tattoo artist and Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade.

title: The Big Surprise Is Saved for the Groom
description: Last week Time magazine in association with the Pew Research Center released the results of a survey on the state of American marriage, which found what all but the purveyors of giddy popular culture already know: the institution is in decline. Among men and women in their 20s in 2008 only 26 percent were married (as opposed to 68 percent in 1960). Moreover, a full 39 percent of those questioned said they believed marriage was becoming obsolete, which in itself indicates that no one aspiring to a certain kind of reality-television stardom was even interrogated.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A New Look at a Classic
description: An adaptation of The Little Prince, the 1943 parable by Antoine de Saint-Exupry, is new to the hardcover list this week. This version of the tale, about a pilot who crash lands in the desert and meets an enigmatic young boy, was translated by Sarah Ardizzone and written and illustrated by Joann Sfar.

title: Good Day for Parade
description: This years Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade attracted its best television ratings since 2004. Although final audience figures were not available on Friday, Nielsens preliminary overnight estimates from local markets nationwide show NBCs parade broadcast up roughly 2 percent from a year ago, when 22.3 million viewers tuned in. During prime-time on Thursday, however, network television drew meager ratings for mostly repeats and concert specials. Fox led the night by a slim margin, benefiting from an audience of more than 15 million viewers between 8 and 8:30 p.m. because of an overrun of its football coverage. Following it The Simpsons Movie averaged about five million viewers for Fox. CBS placed second over all with comedy repeats from 8 to 10 and a rerun of The Mentalist (7.6 million), which won the 10 p.m. hour ahead of The Apprentice on NBC (3.4 million) and the last hour of ABCs special Beyoncs I Am ... World Tour, which drew 4.1 million from 9:30 to 11. NBC finished fourth behind ABC, with 4.4 million viewers for Taylor Swift: Speak Now at 8 and NBCs People of the Year 2010 at 9.

title: Full Dark, No Stars
description: From A Good Marriage in Full Dark, No Stars

title: Self-Referential in Its Own Right
description: Four characters are onstage, in conversation. Jeff turns to his colleague and says, with courteous concern, Susan, youre quiet.

title: How the Sugarplum Fairy Presides Depends on the Nutcracker Narrative
description: Tradition in America has it that performances of The Nutcracker begin only after Thanksgiving. Not so, however, for the two productions this year with which Ive begun a sampling of the nations Nutcrackers. They also demonstrate two quite separate versions of the ballets story.

title: Honors for Alumnus of Saturday Night Live Band (Guess When)
description: BOB CRANSHAWS name may not be familiar to many people, but his bass playing is. Anyone who can hum the Sesame Street theme song knows it  he played on the recording  and so does anyone who watched the early years of Saturday Night Live, when he was in the house band.

title: Masters of Math, From Old Babylon
description: If the cost of digging a trench is 9 gin, and the trench has a length of 5 ninda and is one-half ninda deep, and if a workers daily load of earth costs 10 gin to move, and his daily wages are 6 se of silver, then how wide is the canal?

title: Music Publisher BMG Buying Chrysalis in $168 Million Deal
description: In a deal between two of the worlds largest independent music publishers, BMG Rights Management has agreed to acquire Chrysalis for 107.4 million ($168.6 million), the companies announced on Friday.

title: In a Sleepy Russian City, Not All Welcome a Cultural Revolution
description: PERM, Russia  This homely city on the edge of the Ural Mountains  once a place of political exile  is the unlikely forum for a furious, even bitter, debate about the role of culture in public life.

title: Which Black Suit to Play First? One Is Right, the Other Wrong
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  The premier event at the Fall North American Championships taking place here is next weekends Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams. The defending champions are Nick Nickell and Zia Mahmood of New York; Ralph Katz of Hinsdale, Ill.; Bob Hamman of Dallas; Jeff Meckstroth of Tampa, Fla.; and Eric Rodwell of Clearwater Beach, Fla. They will be trying for a threepeat (excluding Katz, the replacement for Richard Freeman, who died in June 2009).

title: One Nutcracker, but Many Interpretations
description: WITH its annual profusion of year-end performances across Long Island, The Nutcracker is one of the sure signposts of the season. Yet even a dependable chestnut like this one undergoes change  as shown, for example, by recent developments at the Eglevsky Ballet.

title: Dramas to Color, Cut and Produce
description: The Ugly Stepsisters gape as Cinderella triumphs, surrounded by explosions of flowers and jubilant floating fairies.

title: Russia: Stalin Called Responsible for Katyn Killings
description: Russias Parliament on Friday approved a statement holding Stalin responsible for ordering the 1940 murder of more than 20,000 Polish officers in a forest near the village of Katyn. Against the protests of Communist Parliament members, the State Duma acknowledged that archival material not only unveils the scale of his horrific tragedy but also provides evidence that the Katyn crime was committed on direct orders from Stalin and other Soviet leaders. The Soviet government argued that Nazis were responsible for the massacre, a stance that created a passionate division between Poland and Russia. This year, however, Moscow has taken a series of steps to patch up a relationship that had become an obstacle to European integration.

title: Thrills and Chills (Except for the Guy Behind the Elephant)
description: Marc Chagall once wrote that the circus seemed to him like the most tragic show on earth.

title: Bowl Streak For Rutgers Is Ended In a Rout
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  His team was losing by three touchdowns and most of the crowd had gone home Friday when Rutgers Coach Greg Schiano suddenly stopped pacing the sideline, fished a pen out of his pocket and scribbled notes. He had another problem to solve.

title: Precarious Survival on the Lower East Side
description: Memories of the sounds and smells of the synagogues of Julio Mitchels childhood in Havana led him to document the dwindling Jewish presence on the Lower East Side of Manhattan in the 1980s. While his upbringing influenced his decision to photograph the neighborhoods Jews, he believes that the images are about more than a single culture.

title: Burgers Selling Fast, but the Restaurant Is Not
description: ATLANTA  As real estate deals go, the sale of Anns Snack Bar may be a true test of the value of cult food in a bad economy.

title: The Fading Cry of Bingo!
description: Nostrand Bingo Hall in the Midwood section of Brooklyn is among 10 remaining venues for the game in New York City.

title: The Give and Take of Liar Loans
description: Did you hear the one about Countrywide Financial demanding that mortgage originators buy back many of the so-called stated-income loans that it had purchased from them during the late great housing bubble?

title: Newton Leads Auburn to Comeback Win
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  The mischievous sound operators at Bryant-Denny Stadium tried to establish a theme for No. 9 Alabamas game against No. 2 Auburn on Friday afternoon during pregame warm-ups. When the embattled Auburn quarterback Cam Newton took the field, the songs Take the Money and Run by Steve Miller and Son of a Preacher Man by Dusty Springfield filled the speakers  not-so-subtle reminders of the N.C.A.A.s investigation into Newtons recruitment.

title: Bingo in the Blood
description: LIKE other regulars, Cynthia Klivan got there early, needing a couple of hours to get settled. She had to claim her preferred seat by the snack bar. Then she had to unload her supplies from her pink bingo bag  her daubers to mark her paper sheets with circular smudges, her transparent tape to hold the sheets together so they would not disperse, her bingo chips for the lap boards and the magnetic wand that scoops them up. She likes to grab breakfast  rye toast and a cup of coffee  to refuel before play begins.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 26
description: Images of cultural events from this week.

title: New Jerseys Tiniest Towns Fight Push to Merge
description: TETERBORO, N.J.  At 1.1 square miles, this town is smaller than Central Park  smaller even than Teterboro Airport, which spills past its borders. It has no schools, no police or fire department, far more aircraft than residents, and a bone to pick with the Census Bureau.

title: Pat-Downs: Enhanced but Hardly Thorough
description: It does not take much to come face to face  or hand to buttock  with the controversial inner cordon of our nations antiterrorist strategy. You dont have to break into Langley or crack open an encrypted file. All you have to do is snake your way through the airport security line, then step up to the person monitoring the metal detector or the full-body scanner and say, Manual, please.

title: Lounging With a Complexion Queen
description: Dr. Patricia Wexler, she of the snowy complexion and stiletto heels, belongs to that clique of dermatologists with faces as familiar as those of their famous clientele. (She keeps Christie Brinkley, among others, incandescent.) Dr. Wexler, 58, lives on the Upper East Side with her husband, Dr. Eugene Wexler, 60, a cosmetic surgeon, and two bichons friss. Sunday is often the day when the Wexlers spend downtime with their two daughters and their grandson. ROBIN FINN

title: Enjoying the Herring-Sashimi Connection
description: In a multicultural, polyglot city with seemingly boundless options for ethnic dining, this temple of Scandinavian cuisine stands out as much for its refined cooking and namesake beverage as for its celebrity investor and former chef, Marcus Samuelsson, an Ethiopian who grew up in Sweden. The dining room in the Park Avenue Tower on East 55th Street offers precisely composed plates during the week, but on Sunday serves a traditional smorgasbord brunch for $48 a person, which covers a beverage and all the herring, meatballs and pyttipanna (hash with fried eggs and beets) you can eat. Last weekend, the crowd included two friends catching up on business and life.

title: Microsoft Recruits Santa for Free-Photos Program
description: Now your children can get that squirming-in-Santas-lap experience at the airport instead of the mall, courtesy of Microsoft. The company has teamed up with Southwest Airlines to give travelers the chance to take photos with Santa at 26 airports nationwide.

title: Excerpts From the Ethnic Press
description: Crime is to newspapers what bread is to the human meal: a staple across continents and cultures. During the past month, a Caribbean paper in New York reported on sex trafficking involving minors; a Mexican daily carried an article about a brutal beating of a pizza deliveryman; and an Arab-American publication chronicled reaction to a campaign to arm bodega owners. KIRK SEMPLE

title: Saudi Arabia Arrests 149 Qaeda Suspects, Many With Ties to Yemen, Over 8 Months
description: CAIRO  Saudi Arabia announced Friday that it had arrested 149 suspected militants from Al Qaeda over the past eight months, including many with ties to Yemen.

title: On the Street | Thanksgiving Day Parade
description: Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade signals the city's turn from autumn  and the stylish looks that abound  to winter coats.

title: How to Judge a Dance Contest, Accurately
description: Last night, Nate Silver announced to readers that he would take advantage of a post-midterms lull in political news to explore issues in sports, culture and other subjects.

title: U.S. Shuts Down Web Sites in Piracy Crackdown
description: In what appears to be the latest phase of a far-reaching federal crackdown on online piracy of music and movies, the Web addresses of a number of sites that facilitate illegal file-sharing were seized this week by Immigration and Customs Enforcement, a division of the Department of Homeland Security.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 26
description: More Photographs

title: Debt Crisis Highlights I.M.F.s Renewed Role
description: WASHINGTON  Irelands reluctant acceptance of a bailout supported by the International Monetary Fund is the latest in a string of developments since 2007 that have thrust the monetary fund into a new position of authority and prominence.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,388 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: Robert B. Daugherty Dies at 88; Helped Irrigate the Plains
description: Robert B. Daugherty, a Nebraska businessman who helped transform the rural landscape into a patchwork of circular fields by popularizing a means of irrigation that used a pipe on wheels pivoting around a central point, died on Wednesday at his home in Omaha. He was 88.

title: Ann's Snack Bar
description: Kim Severson traveled to Atlanta, Georgia to taste Ann Price's famous "Ghetto Burger."  She opened her restaurant in 1972 and has since operated by her own rules to produce burgers worth waiting for.

title: Betty Jean Lifton Dies at 84; Urged Open Adoptions
description: Betty Jean Lifton, a writer, adoptee and adoption-reform advocate whose books  searing condemnations of the secrecy that traditionally shrouded adoption  became touchstones for adoptees throughout the world, died on Nov. 19 in Boston. She was 84 and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Shipping Christmas to the Caribbean
description: Barrels full of gifts, and everyday items, too, are sent to relatives and friends in the Caribbean.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Crises Shake German Trust in Euro Zone
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel has tried to assure business leaders and investors that Germany is committed to a strong, stable euro, while at the same time assuring the German public that it is time to get tough with investors and demand that other euro zone nations fix their finances.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to the Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Jeter Said to Be Asking $23 Million to $24 Million a Year
description: Derek Jeters agent, Casey Close, is currently asking the Yankees to agree to a new contract of either four or five years at $23 million to $24 million a year, according to a person in baseball who had been briefed on the matter.

title: G.M. Finds a More Receptive Public
description: McHENRY, Ill.  One of the years biggest weekends for car dealers is also doubling as a coming-out party for General Motors, just a week after the company shed the governments majority ownership. Evidence is emerging on car lots that consumers are starting to feel more positive about G.M. and less angry about the billions of dollars in federal aid it received.

title: Second Rail-Equipped Drug Tunnel Found at Mexican Border
description: LOS ANGELES  Federal investigators discovered a sophisticated cross-border tunnel Thursday in an industrial part of San Diego. The half-mile tunnel was the second found this month equipped with rail tracks and carts to funnel drugs to and from Tijuana, Mexico.

title: Profusion of Insiders Aid Gov.-Elect in Transition
description: When Andrew M. Cuomo named members to his transition committees this month, he described them as experienced leaders with broad experience in the public and the private sectors, selected to help him recruit the best and brightest New Yorkers to his new administration.

title: A Hidden Beauty
description: Karma Lounge is one of the prettiest adult watering holes around. The entrance is a bit hidden along the walkway leading to the Old Croton Aqueduct, but Karmas seclusion is part of its appeal. Inside, polished dark and light woods, brick niches and dramatic draped fabrics provide a Zen-like backdrop for minimalist floral arrangements, gentle candlelight and subdued pictures of geometric textile designs.

title: Hartfords A.H.L. Team Adopts Whale Heritage
description: HARTFORD  Bringing the Hartford Whalers back to this city is a task that could be described as difficult at best, hopeless at worst. But Howard Baldwin has a unique qualification for the job: he brought the Whalers here in the first place.

title: Giants Shawn Andrews Is in Hospital With Back Pain
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants may turn to their third left tackle this season after the travails of their banged-up offensive line worsened when Shawn Andrews was held in a hospital with back pain.

title: Cuisine in Flux? Yes. But Dont Change It All!
description: AFTER two happy visits to Blackboard Bistro, in Carmel, I read the following blog post, from early November, on the restaurants Web site: The Bistro is taking a poll, would you like to see the organic part of the restaurant flourish and stay on track, or would you want to see more of a gastro pub style menu, please vote and give us your feedback??

title: Colleges Tell High Schools Logos Are Off Limits
description: Glades Day School sits on the edge of swampland in Belle Glade, Fla., and its headmaster, Dr. Robert Egley, often drives past alligators lazing in canals on his way to work. When the school was founded in 1965, its location made the Gator an ideal mascot, and its logo, aside from being green and gold, was nearly identical to the University of Floridas.

title: From Queens Busboys to Manhattans Big Time
description: They were four friends celebrating: two of them brothers, two of them like brothers. Early this week, in their new, gleaming restaurant at Park Avenue and 39th Street, the four men, their ages ranging from 29 to 35, circulated, smiling nervously, dressed in jackets and their best-pressed shirts. They moved restlessly among the leather booths of the Park Avenue Tavern as friends and family, many of them in from Rockaway Beach, sampled the food. Had Grandma tried the crab cakes? Would their old basketball buddy, still boyish but now in a priests collar, like another beer?

title: Brazil Military Says It Cornered Rio Drug Gangs
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Police and Brazilian Army soldiers, struggling to take control of a second huge slum complex here, were fired on by drug gangs on Friday, but by nightfall they had managed to trap the traffickers inside, a military spokesman said.

title: Slices of Childhood, Melted and Mobile
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Not Just Hamburgers
description: Jennifer Anicito, 34, of Plainview, sat at a table at the Burger Spot, a 20-seat, order-at-the-counter cafe in Garden City, and offered a bite of burger to her 3-year-old son, Daniel.

title: McCartney Wants to Coach in Boulder Again
description: BOULDER, Colo.  Bill McCartney said he weighed the same, at 70, as he did in 1982, when the University of Colorado hired him to rebuild its sunken football program.

title: Death and Dancing Coexist on Haitis Tense Streets
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  One body gets a light kick and tumbles into the pit.

title: Pan-Asian Classics, Packed With Flavor
description: NO Long Islander who likes Chinese food has to be told that the opening of a new Chinese restaurant is practically unheard of on the Island these days. Chinese restaurateurs are still here, and they still open restaurants, but they dont serve Chinese food exclusively.

title: On Nassau Street, the Present Closes In on a Bikini-Clad Past
description: The sign inside Nassau Bar raises more questions than the single one that it attempts to answer. It reads: No Pictures of Bartenders.

title: Secrets Shared Must Be Handled With Care
description: When I was in Mexico City last month doing research on the Antenas program  the subject of my Fixes column earlier this week  I had the opportunity to sit in Antenas room and have a conversation with the animated character used by psychotherapists to communicate with children. I found the effect surprising. Antenas, guided by a therapist named Elsa Molina in the next room, began by asking me simple questions, as he does with all children. Antenas asked: Why did you come to Mexico City? I replied, Im a writer and Im doing research. Antenas asked: What is a writer?

title: Veteran Detective Charged With Attempted Murder
description: A veteran detective assigned to the mayors security team was charged on Friday with attempted murder, accused of shooting a man while off duty and then failing to report it, prosecutors said.

title: A Lifelong Caregiver, Always With a Smile
description: Until Sept. 11, 2001, Dianne Romano was the one doling out charity, not the one receiving it.

title: More Than Moussaka
description: At Think Grill, a sleek, casual spot in Union, there is typical Greek fare, like moussaka and spanakopita. But there are also all-American dishes, like ribs and macaroni and cheese.

title: Northern Italian Classics, and Some Surprises
description: IN the vast continuum of Italian restaurants stretching across New Jersey, places like DOro in Chatham are instantly familiar yet oddly hard to pull off: authentically Italian but neighborhoody in spirit, reliably satisfying but eager to surprise, ambitious in the kitchen but not too far beyond the comfort zone of well-worn classics like veal scallopine and penne alla vodka.

title: Architects Take On Museums in Doha and Abu Dhabi
description: I.M. Pei, Frank Gehry, Norman Foster and Jean Nouvel discuss their work in the Persian Gulf.

title: Building Museums, and a Fresh Arab Identity
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates  It is an audacious experiment: two small, oil-rich countries in the Middle East are using architecture and art to reshape their national identities virtually overnight, and in the process to redeem the tarnished image of Arabs abroad while showing the way toward a modern society within the boundaries of Islam.

title: Adriana Kertzer and Barry Goldman
description: Adriana Kertzer and Barry R. Goldman were married Saturday evening at the Foundry, an event space in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Jo Hirschmann officiated.

title: Jennifer Breeden and Joedan Okun
description: Jennifer Ann Breeden, a daughter of Josie Chao-chih Breeden and Douglas T. Breeden of Chapel Hill, N.C., was married at her parents home Saturday to Joedan Charles Hampton Okun, a son of Melva Fager Okun and Michael G. Okun, both of Carrboro, N.C. The Rev. David Harvin, a Methodist minister, officiated, and Will Okun, a brother of the bridegroom and a Universal Life minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: Benjamin Zumsteg, Michael Leamer
description: Benjamin Brett Zumsteg and Michael Drucker Leamer were married Tuesday in the Town Hall of Darien, Conn. Mary Pugh, a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated.

title: Grace Fan, Thomas Delatour Jr.
description: Grace Fan, the daughter of Evelyn Du of Shanghai and Felix Fan of San Francisco, was married Friday to Thomas Russell Delatour Jr., a son of Grace W. Delatour and Mr. Delatour Sr. of Dallas. The Rev. Crystal D. Walker, a minister of the Church of God and a cousin of the bridegroom, performed a Methodist ceremony at the home of the bridegrooms parents.

title: Erin Thomas and Anthony Garvan III
description: Erin Lorraine Thomas and Anthony Nicholas Brady Garvan III were married Saturday at the Buccaneer Hotel in Christiansted on St. Croix in the Virgin Islands. Louise L. Leard, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Carol Skriloff, Pierce Starr
description: Carol Lee Skriloff and James Pierce Starr were married Friday at the Four Seasons Resort on Peninsula Papagayo in Costa Rica. William B. Muoz, a notary public there, officiated.

title: Sharon Elghanayan, Jon Corzine
description: Sharon M. Elghanayan, a psychotherapist, and Jon S. Corzine, a former governor of New Jersey, were married Tuesday evening in Mr. Corzines apartment in Hoboken, N.J. Judge Edward McBride of the Camden County branch of the Superior Court of New Jersey officiated at a ceremony that was primarily led by Chief Justice Stuart Rabner of the New Jersey Supreme Court. Before taking their current posts, Judge McBride was the governors chief of staff and Justice Rabner was New Jerseys attorney general.

title: Irina Vaysman, Corey Bobker
description: Irina Vaysman, a daughter of Rosa Vaysman and a stepdaughter of Roman Betega of Brooklyn, was married Saturday evening to Corey Brett Bobker, a son of Tina W. Bobker and Dennis S. Bobker of Livingston, N.J. Cantor Anna S. Berman officiated at the Palace at Somerset Park in Somerset, N.J.

title: Tiffany Slaughter and Jed Freeland
description: Tiffany Slaughter and Jed Freeland were married Wednesday evening by the Rev. Richard Walsh at St. Margaret Mary Catholic Church in Winter Park, Fla.

title: Agnes Pasternak, Michael Zaro
description: Agnes Jennifer Pasternak, a daughter of Eva E. Pasternak and Ivan Pasternak of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married Saturday evening to Michael Toby Zaro, a son of Keri Zaro and Stuart D. Zaro of Armonk, N.Y. Rabbi David Greenberg officiated at Capitale, an event space in Manhattan.

title: Mayor and State Reach Deal on a Schools Chief
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg reached a deal Friday to save the tottering candidacy of Cathleen P. Black to be the next chancellor of New York City schools, agreeing to appoint a career educator who started as a classroom teacher to serve as her second in command.

title: Bloggingheads: No Mo' Loko?
description: Corby Kummer, left, of The Atlantic and Katherine Mangu-Ward of Reason debate the government action against Four Loko.

title: A Bully Finds a Pulpit on the Web
description: SHOPPING online in late July, Clarabelle Rodriguez typed the name of her favorite eyeglass brand into Googles search bar.

title: The Power of Failure
description: Despite the very dire consequences of the latest financial crisis that Wall Street perpetrated on the world, America cannot seem to shake its infatuation with Wall Street bankers and traders.

title: On an Edge of Brooklyn, New Hopes for a Park in Neglect
description: The hangar on the edge of Floyd Bennett Field has the familiar, post-apocalyptic look of urban decay, with Danger Keep Out spray painted in red across one of the buildings doors.

title: The World This Week
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

title: Saturday: Aging Establishment
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  We finally have a real themeless puzzle this week. On Saturdays, the test for me is whether the clever answers are worth the extra effort of solving such hard clues. I found this one utterly charming, except for one answer that made me wince. First, the highlights, and are there ever a lot of them!

title: Death Sentence Is Upheld in Cheshire Murder Case
description: A judge on Friday upheld the death sentence of the man convicted in a home invasion in Cheshire, Conn., that left a woman and her two daughters dead.

title: Lottery Numbers
Educator in Chief
description: Under the deal reached between New York City and the state, the city school system will have a chief academic officer, who will have extensive responsibilities, including many that the top official in a school district would typically carry out:

title: An Eclectic Shopping Hub Wonders Whats Next
description: A trickle of shoppers wandered the repaved sidewalks of the Fulton Street Mall one recent evening, under new streetlamps, a model the city calls the Fulton Pole, and freshly planted Kentucky coffee trees. They walked past the pizzeria that will close soon to make way for a Shake Shack, Danny Meyers hyper-popular hamburger chain, and past the workers putting the mannequins in the windows of Aeropostale, the teenage clothing store that opened last week.

title: A Subway That Crosses State Lines
description: To the Editor:

title: The Man With Credentials To Complement the New Bosss
description: When it comes to education credentials, Shael Polakow-Suransky fills a lot of the holes in Cathleen P. Blacks rsum. He is a byproduct of a public school system, and his idea of climbing the career ladder was to start as a mathematics teacher and work his way up to become a top executive in New York Citys Department of Education.

title: Fans Dig in Heels in Contract Debate
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Mark Twains Big Book
description: Mark Twains autobiography  Volume 1  released in mid-November, is an enormous hit, apparently much to the surprise of its publisher, the University of California Press. Bookstores across the country and online retailers sold out almost immediately, never mind that its a work of sobering scholarship and more than 700 pages of very small print.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: The Arbitration War
description: Unexpected wireless charges are a chronic affliction of life on the grid. The industry triggers more complaints from consumers than any other. AT&T Mobility, by consumer rankings, is the worst. Its performance in a case the Supreme Court heard recently has done nothing to improve that reputation.

title: Outstanding Debt From 9/11
description: Surely there is one more Republican in the United States Senate willing to do the right thing for the brave Americans who rushed to help at the ground zero site after the attacks on Sept. 11, 2001.

description: To the Editor:

title: Costs of Fuel Extraction
description: To the Editor:

title: Memo to Albany: Its Your Job
description: Gov. David Paterson has called legislators back to Albany on Monday to tidy up a few matters before Andrew Cuomo, the governor-elect, takes office in January. So far, the prospects look bad.

title: Winning the Class War
description: The class war that no one wants to talk about continues unabated.

title: To Combat the Rising Sea
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraqs Troubles Drive Out Refugees Who Came Back
description: BAGHDAD  A second exodus has begun here, of Iraqis who returned after fleeing the carnage of the height of the war, but now find that violence and the nations severe lack of jobs are pulling them away from home once again.

title: Neediest | When A Caregiver Needs Help
description: Dianne Romano is the principal care giver for her mother, who has Alzheimer's, and her brother, who has a brain injury. When Ms. Romano was evicted, The Neediest Cases Fund helped.

description: A view of the day in sports, from the Asian Games to the ATP World Tour Finals.

description: BUSINESS DAY

title: Election Nears in Haiti as Cholera Toll Mounts
description: The final day of campaigning for the candidates running for office in Haiti was filled with activity.

description: From Todays Times:

title: A Super Bowl With Black Eyed Peas. Are You Pleased?
description: Sure, Jets-versus-Patriots is a good debate, but there are more profound things to discuss.

title: U.S. and South Korea Begin Joint Naval Exercises
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The United States and South Korea began naval exercises on Sunday that were meant as a warning to North Korea for recent provocations, including last weeks deadly artillery attack on a island populated by South Koreans in the Yellow Sea.

title: When Bankers Met Their Waterloo
description: Napoleon Bonaparte, in response to a request for a bailout of Banque Recamier:

title: Man And Supermacro
description: It seems that I have to raise my game: Brad DeLong manages to bring Friedrich Nietzsche into a discussion of the failure of macroeconomic policy.

title: We Model Nutria Fur in Brooklyn
description: Leanne Shear, an occasional City Room contributor, was invited to model so-called guilt-free fur in Brooklyn last weekend. She had never walked a runway before. Here is her report:

title: Afghan Police Building Hit by Bombers in Uniforms
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two suicide bombers wearing police uniforms blew themselves up inside the police headquarters of Paktika Province in southeastern Afghanistan on Saturday, killing at least 10 officers and wounding 13 others, according to NATO officials and the emergency physician on duty at the hospital where some victims were taken.

title: Griffin Dunking His Way Into the Spotlight
description: Before the season, ESPNs Sports Guy, Bill Simmons, was mocked for declaring that Blake Griffin, the Clippers rookie power forward, was already among the leagues best players. Seventeen games into his N.B.A. career, Griffin, right, seems to be living up to that prediction.

title: F.B.I. Says Oregon Suspect Planned Grand Attack
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  A Somali-born teenager who thought he was detonating a car bomb at a packed Christmas tree-lighting ceremony downtown here was arrested by the authorities on Friday night after federal agents said that they had spent nearly six months setting up a sting operation.

title: Legacy Need Not Divide Jeter and the Yankees
description: Babe Ruth? Really?

title: Diagramless Chops
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  One of the keys to solving diagramless crosswords is to be even more willing than usual to give up answers you feel certain of. It also, and this will surprise nobody, pays to read the clues. Let me give you a few examples.

title: Demonstrators in Ireland Protest Austerity Plan
description: DUBLIN  After a week that brought Ireland a pledge of a $114 billion international rescue package and the toughest austerity program of any country in Europe, tens of thousands of demonstrators took to Dublins streets on Saturday to protest wide cuts in the countrys welfare programs and in public-sector jobs.

title: Putting Down Textbooks to Provide for Triplets
description: Devon Armstrong and Winifred Oldham do not hear the doorbell anymore. They say they get eight hours of sleep each night but barely have the energy to rise from the couch when company arrives. And though cheerful and polite, they wear the dreamy, shell-shocked expression familiar to anyone who has learned to tune out the persistent wailing of a newborn. Or three.

title: Taking Lead, Iraqi Premier Vows to Forge Government
description: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki sought Saturday to show he was in control of a tenuous new governing coalition, saying that he would have the decisive word in forming a new Iraqi government, and would move forward with or without potential allies.

title: Boise State Drops Out of Race as Season Nears Finish Line
description: As last call loomed at barrooms on the East Coast early Saturday, one kickers gaffes changed the complexion of the race for the Bowl Championship Series title game.

title: A Casting Call for Hollywoods Chief Lobbyist
description: LOS ANGELES

title: When the Software Is the Sportswriter
description: ONLY human writers can distill a heap of sports statistics into a compelling story. Or so we human writers like to think.

title: Finance Ministers to Set Irish Bailout Terms
description: BRUSSELS  European finance ministers will gather here Sunday to complete a multibillion-euro bailout for Ireland as financial markets waited to see if a restructuring of Irish banks would mean losses for bondholders.

title: Taxing the Rich: Its All Relative
description: ITS not just Tea Party activists who are angry about taxes. A much larger and more diverse group appears outraged that Congress is considering allowing the Bush tax cuts to expire at year-end for families earning more than $250,000 and for individuals earning more than $200,000.

title: Defensive? It Leads to Destructive
description: This interview with Bob Brennan, president and C.E.O. of Iron Mountain, an information management company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

description: To the Editor:
