description: To the Editor:

title: Poland, Lacking External Enemies, Turns on Itself
description: WARSAW  It was 9:30 at night, under a chilly, steady rain. The Presidential Palace glowed brightly in the background as a cluster of men and women huddled under umbrellas, saying prayers, holding small wooden crosses against their bodies, facing a large picture of Jesus Christ on the cross and a lighted statue of the Virgin Mary.

title: Dont Just Tell Us. Show Us That You Can Foreclose.
description: AFTER examining their foreclosure practices for flaws in mortgage documentation and other procedures, many of the nations largest banks have resumed  or will soon resume  trying to evict defaulted borrowers.

title: Fighting Words
description: Bristol Palin finished third on last weeks finale of Dancing With the Stars, behind Jennifer Gray and Kyle Massey, but not before she had this to say:

title: Donald Nyrop, Who Led Northwest Airlines, Dies at 98
description: Donald W. Nyrop, a former federal airline regulator who went on to run Northwest Airlines with a keen focus on keeping costs down and improving safety, died on Nov. 16 at his home in Edina, Minn. He was 98.

title: U.S. Presses Iceland Over Whale Meat Trade
description: The Obama administration has strongly criticized Iceland for resuming international trade in the meat from its expanding hunt for fin whales, the second largest whale species and one still listed as endangered under the United States Endangered Species Act. Heres a summary and statement issued this week by the Department of Commerce:

title: Bond Between Generations, With Football on the Side
description: The bond between grandmother and grandson began with vacations through the American countryside when he was 5. Later, she took him to Europe and beyond.

title: Laugh Lines
description: JAY LENO

title: Prime Number
description: 50: The percentage increase, in inflation-adjusted dollars, that graduating college students in 2008 borrowed compared with their counterparts in 1996, an analysis of National Center for Education Statistics data found. More college students are borrowing (60 percent in 2008 versus 52 percent in 1996) and theyre borrowing more ($23,000, compared with $17,000 in 1996), according to the analysis by the Pew Research Centers Social and Demographic Trends project.

title: As San Franciscos Mayor Departs, a Handful of Votes Will Usher In a New One
description: SAN FRANCISCO  This is a city of some 815,000 people, about 49 square miles and exactly one World Series championship. And how many votes does it take to get elected mayor?

title: U.S. Expects Soccers Rise if It Hosts Cup in 2022
description: Interest in soccer has grown considerably in the United States since it hosted the 1994 World Cup. Major League Soccer is on solid footing, having just completed its 15th season of competition. And American television viewership for the quadrennial World Cup final now outdraws the average audience for the World Series.

title: Broncos Fined for Videotaping 49ers Practice in London
description: Three years ago, the videotaping scandal called Spygate convulsed the New England Patriots and captivated the N.F.L., as the integrity and success of one of the games premier franchises and coaches were questioned when it was revealed that the Patriots had illicitly recorded opponents hand signals during games.

title: To Fight Climate Change, Clear the Air
description: AS the curtain rises tomorrow in Cancn, Mexico, on the next round of international talks on climate change, expectations are low that the delegates will agree on a new treaty to reduce emissions that contribute to global warming. They were unable to do so last year in Copenhagen, and since then the negotiating positions of the biggest countries have grown even further apart.

title: Penn Says Farewell to 50 Years of Echoes
description: PHILADELPHIA  C. T. Alexander was not a public-address announcer. He was the Voice of Franklin Field, and at the University of Pennsylvania, that qualified him as a celebrity.

title: On Global Warming, Start Small
description: THE conference on climate change that begins tomorrow in Cancn, Mexico, will be the 13th such annual meeting since 1997, when the Kyoto Protocol, the first and only international agreement to place a cap on emissions of greenhouse gases, was written. This year there will be no such treaty. Why not? Excuses will abound, but finger-pointing misses the crux of the matter, which is that climate change is the most complicated and challenging problem mankind has ever faced.

title: Assault on a Formidable Passing Peak
description: In the days before playing San Diego, Denver Coach Josh McDaniels declared Chargers quarterback Philip Rivers the best deep-ball passer he had studied  startling praise, given that the Broncos faced Peyton Manning and the Colts this season.

title: They Are Not Like Ireland. Really.
description: Last week Ireland joined Greece as the second country in the euro zone to get a bailout  to the grand sum of $100 billion.

title: An Almanac of Extreme Weather
description: Rushford, Minn.

title: Back Then: 1950
description: On June 25, 1950, North Korea invaded South Korea. The Timess Richard J.H. Johnston filed this report from the battle zone on July 13:

title: From 8-Point Bucks to a 3-Point Stance
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Rich Seubert has a Super Bowl ring from the Giants victory against the New England Patriots after the 2007 season. His off-field accomplishments are celebrated with a collection of deer skulls.

title: At 63, Its Time for a Career Move
description: WALDWICK, N.J.  Lada St. Edmund made mens hearts flutter as a 17-year-old go-go dancer on the NBC musical variety show Hullabaloo in 1965. On black-and-white and even some color televisions, she was a 5-foot-3 -inch bundle of energy perched in a cage, arms swinging, hips shaking, blonde hair bouncing, the fringe on her minidress flying.

title: Oregon Bomb Plot
description: A Somali-born teenager was arrested for allegedly plotting to bomb a crowded Christmas tree lighting ceremony in downtown Portland, Oregon.  NBC's Pete Williams reports.

title: Bridging Present and Future
description: MY father was a first lieutenant in the United States Army who spoke Japanese. After World War II, the Army sent him to Japan as part of the occupation, and I was born there.

title: Adam Carolla, World-Class Complainer
description: IN this episode, a Haggler first. The column welcomes a guest ranter  Adam Carolla, of radio (Loveline), TV (The Man Show) and podcast fame (The Adam Carolla Show, an iTunes chart topper). Most recently, he was the author of In Fifty Years Well All Be Chicks, which was briefly perched ahead of Mark Twains autobiography on the New York Times best-seller list.

title: How Bad Apples Infect the Tree
description: A FEW years back, a Silicon Valley executive  I will call her Ruth  told me about her experiences working in a mean-spirited office. Ruth said her colleagues repeatedly put her down, interrupted her and glared at her, and shot down her solutions to problems while offering few ideas of their own.

title: Is the Feds Plan Working? Look Abroad
description: HOW will you know whether the Federal Reserves plan to reinvigorate the economy by buying Treasury debt is working?

title: Farewell, Digital World. (Its All for a Cause.)
description: ON Wednesday, Kim Kardashian is going to die a little. So is her sister, Khlo, not to mention Lady Gaga, David LaChapelle, Justin Timberlake, Usher, Serena Williams and Elijah Wood.

title: Senator Lugar Charts His Course Against the Winds
description: WASHINGTON  Mavericks are not in vogue these days on Capitol Hill, a place where hyper-partisanship and obduracy seem to be their own rewards.

title: Still the Best Congress Money Can Buy
description: SO Americas latest crisis  until it wasnt  was airport screeners touching our junk. As this long year lurches toward its end, we all agree that something has gone wrong in America, and were desperately casting about for a coherent explanation for our discontent, if not a scapegoat. Alas, the national consensus that the T.S.A. and full-body scans might be the source of all evil fizzled in less than a week. Most everyone got to Grandmas house for Thanksgiving without genital distress.

title: Some Very Creative Economic Fix-Its
description: We are not going to shop our way out of this mess.

title: Asking China to Act Like the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  A fundamental tenet of foreign policy says that nations will seldom voluntarily act against what they have determined, for whatever reason, to be their own national interest.

title: Madoff Relatives Sued for $69 Million
description: The trustee seeking to recover money for people who were defrauded by Bernard L. Madoff filed lawsuits Friday against investors, employees and Madoff family members.

title: Got to Get This Right
description: On Nov. 19, Rasmussen Reports published results from a national telephone poll that showed that 47 percent of Americas likely voters said the nations best days are in the past, 37 percent said they are in the future. Sixteen percent were undecided. Just before President Obama was inaugurated, 48 percent said our best days were still ahead and 35 percent said they had come and gone. This is a disturbing trend.

title: Pro Hockey Takes Shot at Legitimacy in Brooklyn
description: The New York Aviators, a minor league hockey team based in Brooklyn, lost their first three games of the season on the road. After another long bus ride  from Chenango, N.Y., to Alexandria Bay near the Canadian border  they arrived later than expected for a game against the Thousand Island Privateers.

title: A Woman. A Prostitute. A Slave.
description: Americans tend to associate modern slavery with illiterate girls in India or Cambodia. Yet there I was the other day, interviewing a college graduate who says she spent three years terrorized by pimps in a brothel in Midtown Manhattan.

title: As for Good Behavior
description: A few years ago, teachers at Ellis Middle School in Austin, Minn., might have said that their top students were easy to identify: they completed their homework and handed it in on time; were rarely tardy; sat in the front of the class; wrote legibly; and jumped at the chance to do extra-credit assignments.

title: Streak Ends With the Knicks Feeling Out of Sorts
description: Amare Stoudemires mood had been ruined long before he unwittingly spilled a protein shake at his locker stall. The sight of pinkish goop in his designer shoes just served as a final, lasting irritant.

title: An AIDS Advance, Hiding in the Open
description: In the war against AIDS, a new weapon has emerged.

title: A New Generation of Robotic Weapons
description: Several manufacturers and research facilities are changing the face of the battlefield with robots designed to help transport equipment, gather intelligence and attack enemy forces.

title: The Catholic Church, Condoms and Lesser Evils
description: When Pope Benedict XVI said last week that using condoms could be justified in some cases, like preventing AIDS, his remarks caused an uproar because some thought they signaled a turnabout in longstanding church doctrine against artificial birth control.

title: The Remains of the Day
description: Middlebury, Vt.

title: Dear First Lady Michelle,
description: EVER since Barack Obamas inauguration, the staff members and tutors at our nonprofit writing programs have marveled at how this presidency has percolated through student essays, stories and poems.

title: The Unemployed Held Hostage, Again
description: It is hard to believe, as the holidays approach yet again amid economic hard times, but Congress looks as if it may let federal unemployment benefits lapse for the fourth time this year.

title: Untenable Judicial Ethics
description: When Pennsylvanias Chief Justice Ronald Castille came to New York Citys Waldorf Astoria last December for the 111th annual meeting of the Pennsylvania Society, a booster club for the state, a law firm picked up the $1,900 tab. As The Philadelphia Inquirer reported, that is one of many gifts of dinners, event tickets, golf outings and plane rides the chief justice has gotten, some from people with cases decided by his court.

title: Note to Hugh Prather
description: Notes to Myself began as a sheaf of yellow papers written by a guy, Hugh Prather, trying to figure some things out. That it became a book, then a best seller, and its author a self-help guru, a 1970s icon, an American Kahlil Gibran, is perhaps best understood if you were around back then.

title: What the G.O.P. Missed
description: If you did not spend last weekend tuned in to news from the NATO summit meeting in Lisbon, you probably missed the breakthrough on European missile defense.

description: To the Editor:

title: Taiwan Ruling Party Wins 3 of 5 Votes
description: BEIJING  Taiwans ruling Kuomintang captured mayoral posts in three of the nations five largest cities in special elections held Saturday, reaffirming national support for a party that has made improved relations with the Chinese mainland the center of its political agenda.

title: Group Votes to Keep Fishing Levels of Bluefin Tuna Stable
description: PARIS  International fisheries negotiators agreed Saturday to maintain the 2011 catch of endangered Mediterranean and eastern Atlantic bluefin tuna at essentially the same level as in 2010, eliciting a stinging rebuke from conservationists, who had been calling for a fishing moratorium.

title: Staged Fights Draw Scrutiny in Major Junior Leagues
description: The Rangers Hall of Famer Rod Gilbert  was once asked if hockey fights were fixed. He replied, If they were, I would have been in more of them.

title: Power Line Project Faces Challenges in California Valley
description: EL CENTRO, Calif.  The sun is so strong here that people often talk about the temperature being in the teens, meaning 113 or above. The wind is so powerful that west of town, signs on an Interstate display the number of miles remaining in which drivers will face dangerous winds, like signs that give the distance to the next city.

title: Margaret T. Burroughs, Archivist of Black History, Dies at 95
description: Margaret T. Burroughs, a founder of the DuSable Museum of African American History in Chicago, one of the first museums devoted to black history and culture in the United States, died on Sunday in Chicago. She was 95.

title: A Shining Moment
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Even before you start solving, you might notice a couple of details about this grid. For one, at 2323, its larger than normal, which is becoming increasingly rare. We havent had one this big since Caleb Madisons Book Binding in March (Across Lite, Solution, blog.) Today there are 171 clues to work through. Thats 30 more than in a typical Sunday.

title: New Chairman Seeks More Power for Watchdogs
description: WASHINGTON  The Republican who will lead the chief investigative committee in the House is planning to vastly expand scrutiny of the Obama administration by seeking new subpoena powers for dozens of federal agency watchdogs in hopes of using their investigations and his own in an aggressive push to cut spending and shrink the government.

title: Hindu Group Stirs a Debate Over Yogas Soul
description: Yoga is practiced by about 15 million people in the United States, for reasons almost as numerous  from the physical benefits mapped in brain scans to the less tangible rewards that New Age journals call spiritual centering. Religion, for the most part, has nothing to do with it.

description: National security looms large on the Sunday talk shows as the busy travel season gets under way and tensions heat up between North Korea and South Korea.

description: At the recently opened farmers market outside Houstons City Hall, Laura Spanjian, the citys peppy new sustainability director, was in her element.

title: In Budget Process, Warnings of Carnage
description: Heres how State Representative Jim Pitts interprets the Election Day results: Were making huge cuts, the Waxahachie Republican who heads the House Appropriations Committee told a hometown Tea Party group last week.

description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative

title: The Pulse

title: A Dangerous Eyesore Endures, Hostage to Financial Concerns

Wind-blown litter dances over the grounds like tumbleweeds, and gang tags adorn the hospitals walls.

title: Bears May Be 7-3, but Skeptics Remain
description: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative

title: Ex-Justice Criticizes Death Penalty
description: WASHINGTON  In 1976, just six months after he joined the Supreme Court, Justice John Paul Stevens voted to reinstate capital punishment after a four-year moratorium. With the right procedures, he wrote, it is possible to ensure evenhanded, rational and consistent imposition of death sentences under law.

title: Willingham Filmmakers Will Speak for the Dead
description: Yes, this is West 11th Street, Corsicana, Texas. Its about 10 oclock in the morning. Those are the arson investigators, and theyll soon decide that I set this house on fire and burned my three young children to death just before Christmas 1991. But before you hear it all distorted or blown out of proportion, maybe youd like to hear the facts, the whole truth. The governor likes to quote my own defense attorney about how I am  or should I say: was  a monster. Because, you see, I was executed six years ago when he wouldnt grant a stay.

title: Relics of Film and Paper Retain Their Grip Even in a Digital Era
description: I recently saw some of my familys home movies from the 1940s and 1950s for the first time.

title: Stretch | Bending With a Holy Twist
description: I sat on my mat inside the parish center at St. Paul the Apostle, a Roman Catholic church just around the corner from Columbus Circle, and began the evenings yoga class, not with a long om but with the simple words of St. Francis of Assisi.

title: Manager Blames Marriage for His Stars Slump
description: Marriage seems to have hurt Veselin Topalovs career, for now.

title: To Create a Star, Add Hip-Hop to Hoops and Post to YouTube

title: Actor Playing a Dying Freud Collapses During a Performance
description: An actor playing a dying Sigmund Freud in the Off Broadway play Freuds Last Session collapsed onstage at an Upper West Side theater Saturday afternoon and was hospitalized.

title: Jews Expect Proposed Ban Wont Stop Circumcision
description: Over the last decade, Rabbi Moshe Trager has performed more than 3,000 circumcisions on Bay Area Jews, he estimates. Mr. Trager, 45, said he sometimes performs as many as five in one day  driving as far as Lake Tahoe to snip a foreskin, helping modern Jews fulfill a commandment they believe was first issued by God to Abraham thousands of years ago.

title: War Machines: Recruiting Robots for Combat
description: FORT BENNING, Ga.  War would be a lot safer, the Army says, if only more of it were fought by robots.

title: For Lost Boy, Vote in Sudan Is Homecoming
description: NYAL, Sudan  Joseph Gatyoung Khan made a vow, uttered in the back seat of a Land Cruiser on a very bumpy road, as he headed home for the first time in 22 years: I will not cry.

title: Islais Creek
description: In the 1890s, Islais Creek was the largest body of water in San Francisco, providing recreation, transport and drinking water to the citys residents. Today, Glen Canyon and the Bayview districts Islais Creek Channel are the only visible remnants. HANK PELLISSIER

title: Shift to State System on Care Management Draws Fire
description: For years, the state paid private providers who care for people with disabilities to help the clients decide how many services they needed and how intensive they should be.

title: A Lost Boy Returns Home
description: Joseph Gatyoung Khan was reunited with his family in southern Sudan after 22 years away from home.

title: South Korea Experiences a Stirring for Revenge
description: INCHEON, South Korea  The explosions from North Korean artillery shells sent Hong Kwang-sun and other members of his construction crew rushing into the basement of their half-finished building on Yeonpyeong Island. As he ran, he saw two workers still standing outside just as another round of blasts engulfed the construction site in flames.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Haiti Election Marred by ID Card Problems
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  With some candidates already crying fraud, and the delivery of voter identification cards mired in delays and confusion on Saturday, Haiti braced for one of its most pivotal presidential elections in decades.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: With All Due Respect to Frosty, Please Request a Different Song
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  On Thanksgiving Day, Dave Stephens prepared to do something he had promised he would never do as a professional musician. Reluctantly, determined to suppress his embarrassment beneath a practiced gusto, Mr. Stephens agreed to sing Frosty the Snowman.

title: Ohio State Routs Michigan; Big Ten Has 3-Way Tie at Top
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Ohio State secured a share of a sixth straight Big Ten title Saturday with a resounding 37-7 victory over Michigan. And then the eighth-ranked Buckeyes and the rest of their Big Ten rivals had to wait.

title: Vows: Adriana and Barry
description: A romance was sparked between Adriana and Barry at a charity event. She liked his fedora and he liked her laugh and sense of adventure. While on safari in Kenya, he proposed. She said "Of course!

title: One-of-a-Kind Designs and Gifts Created Under Watchful Eyes
description: FLORENCE, Ariz.  As long as the price is right, holiday shoppers typically rush for the checkout without a thought for who has made their gifts. That is not the case at a humble shop in central Arizona where the difficult lives of the craftsmen are among the main selling points.

title: U.S. in 2011 Womens World Cup, but Knows It Has Work to Do
description: BRIDGEVIEW, Ill.  The unthinkable was remote, but the United States still needed at least a tie against Italy in Saturdays playoff here to avoid the embarrassment of not qualifying for the 2011 Womens World Cup.

title: How Lovely Are Your Polyethylene Branches
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo.  Larry and Cathy Tuccis Christmas tree arrived in a box via FedEx last week with detailed instructions and a handy pair of white gloves that intrigued Mr. Tucci immensely. But he did not put them on during the 10 minutes of assembly.

title: Game 2s Continue to Smile on Rangers
description: The Rangers are still far from the N.H.L.s elite, but they are nothing if not spirited and fit. Case in point: their excellent record in Game 2s of back-to-back sets is the best in the league since the start of last season.

title: On the Hunt for Ambience, but Not Gifts, on Rodeo Drive
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  There they were, a gaggle of contestants from the National American Miss pageant and their mothers, scrambling in front of the fountain at the foot of Via Rodeo, the entrance to one of the grandest stretches of shopping in the nation: Rodeo Drive.

title: This Holiday Season, Traditions With a Twist
description: FOR many people, the holiday season is a sugar rush beyond coping. It can all seem too sweet, or too calculated, and thus easy to dismiss as a humbug or a thing to be endured in some sighing, tinsel-tinged burden of commercial or family expectation.

title: UConn Is Savoring a Season Saved
description: EAST HARTFORD, Conn.  Moe Petrus, the starting center on a resurgent Connecticut football team that is now within a victory of a Bowl Championship Series berth, acknowledged hearing chants of B.C.S. drifting down from the upper rows at windswept Rentschler Field on Saturday.

title: Toy Soldiers and Sugar Plums Aplenty
description: A sampling of Nutcracker performances on Long Island, listed chronologically.

title: Palin Sidesteps Politics at Iowa Book Signing
description: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa  The visit was, according to the official line, just a book signing  a chance for Sarah Palin to scrawl her signature for a few hundred fans on copies of her latest work.

title: College Football Replay: Nov. 27
description: Conference titles and national championship hopes were at stake on Saturday.

title: Q. and A. With Joe Klecko
description: Joe Klecko, a member of the New York Sack Exchange defense in the 1980s, was among the first six inducted into the Jets Ring of Honor at New Meadowlands Stadium. He was the first player to be selected for the Pro Bowl at three positions defensive end, defensive tackle and nose tackle  and has been nominated for the Pro Football Hall of Fame. Klecko, 57, is a Jets analyst on SNY and a consultant for Trinity Solar, a designer and integrator of solar electric systems in Freehold, N.J.

title: Rangers Feast on Seconds
description: The Rangers may still be far from the N.H.L.s elite, but they are nothing if not spirited and fit. Case in point: their excellent record in Game 2s of back-to-back sets is the best in the league over the last season and a quarter.

title: Suspicious Fire in Bronx Leaves 1 Dead and 7 Injured
description: A fire in a Bronx apartment building on Saturday night left at least one man dead and seven people injured, the Fire Department said.

title: Game Is Lacking Glamour, but for Irish Its a Treasure
description: LOS ANGELES  There were no Heisman Trophy contenders trying to win a game, or maybe a few more votes, when the University of Southern California hosted Notre Dame on a cold and rainy Saturday night. The programs have a combined 24 national titles, but for the first time in nine years, neither team brought a national ranking into the matchup.

title: Hard-Working Nevers Did It All One Day in 1929
description: Judy Battista writes in todays Times that one of the leagues most enduring records  Dan Marinos single-season mark of 5,084 passing yards  could be in danger if Chargers quarterback Philip Rivers continues his amazing season. But today happens to be the 81st anniversary of another enduring record  Ernie Neverss single-game mark of 40 points.

title: Iraq: Moments of Release
description: Sports

title: The Kooky (and Pricey) Royal Monceau Reopens in Paris
description: The Royal Monceau, now part of the Qatari-owned Raffles group, was once one of the most glamorous Paris palace hotels. When it closed two years ago for a top-to-bottom renovation, the last-night destruction party, at which the cream of Paris society was invited to trash the place, was the talk of the town. Now it has finally reopened its doors.

title: China Seeks Talks to Ease Korean Tension
description: BEIJING  China moved over the weekend to defuse the latest crisis on the Korean Peninsula, publicly calling on Sunday for emergency consultations while beginning what amounted to high-level shuttle diplomacy between North and South Korea.

title: In Georgia, Smart Football, and Not
description: Georgia Tech, a university with an emphasis on science and technology, almost embarrassed rival Georgia with a demonstration of basic math on Saturday night.

title: A Hard Road to 70 Goals for Stamkos
description: Will Steven Stamkos, Tampa Bays red-hot third-year forward, become the first player to break the 70-goal barrier since Teemu Selanne of Winnipeg and Alexander Mogilny of Buffalo scored 76 in 1992-93?

title: Brazilian Forces Claim Victory in Gang Haven
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  In a quick and decisive military sweep, Brazilian security forces seized control of this citys most notorious slum on Sunday, claiming victory in a weeklong battle against drug gangs that has claimed dozens of lives.

title: BP to Sell Majority Stake in Pan American Energy
description: 8:14 p.m. | Updated

title: Europe Approves Irish Rescue and New Rules on Bailouts
description: BRUSSELS  Fighting to prevent an accelerating debt crisis from engulfing Portugal and Spain, Europes finance ministers approved an 85 billion euro bailout package for Ireland, while also agreeing for the first time to hold private investors accountable for losses in future crises, beginning in 2013.

title: An Encyclopedia Sure to Please and Irritate
description: Joe DiMaggio made it this time. So did Amadou Diallo, ground zero, CompStat, the Halloween parade, the African Burial Ground, Chelsea Market, Michael R. Bloomberg. The Gates, the MetroCard and Pale Male are in there, too  each an idiosyncratic totem of New York Citys evolution in less than a generation.

title: Obama Gets Back on the Basketball Court
description: WASHINGTON  Well, as the saying goes, when you fall off the bike, you have to get right back on.

title: Live Analysis: Giants 24, Jaguars 20, Final
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In Week 4, the Giants reached a crossroads after a pair of losses, and they responded with five straight wins. In Week 12, they met another tipping point after they opened the second half of their season with back-to-back losses.

title: WikiLeaks Reports Attack on Its Web Site
description: WikiLeaks, the whistle-blowers Web site that has announced plans to begin publishing another tranche of secret American documents, reported on Sunday that its Web site was under attack. The message posted on Twitter said: We are currently under a mass distributed denial of service attack.

title: Robotic Rodeo
description: John Markoff reports from Fort Benning, Ga., where he attended a demonstration by military contractors of robots intended for surveillance, logistics and war fighting.

title: Fears of a Nuclear Iran
description: Middle East leaders speak about their powerful neighbor with a directness seldom, if ever, heard in public.

title: Leaked Cables Offer Raw Look at U.S. Diplomacy
description: WASHINGTON  A cache of a quarter-million confidential American diplomatic cables, most of them from the past three years, provides an unprecedented look at back-room bargaining by embassies around the world, brutally candid views of foreign leaders and frank assessments of nuclear and terrorist threats.

title: Around the World, Distress Over Iran
A Note to Readers: The Decision to Publish Diplomatic Documents
description: The articles published today and in coming days are based on thousands of United States embassy cables, the daily reports from the field intended for the eyes of senior policy makers in Washington. The New York Times and a number of publications in Europe were given access to the material several weeks ago and agreed to begin publication of articles based on the cables online on Sunday. The Times believes that the documents serve an important public interest, illuminating the goals, successes, compromises and frustrations of American diplomacy in a way that other accounts cannot match.

title: U.S. Expands Role of Diplomats in Spying
description: WASHINGTON  The United States has expanded the role of American diplomats in collecting intelligence overseas and at the United Nations, ordering State Department personnel to gather the credit card and frequent-flier numbers, work schedules and other personal information of foreign dignitaries.

title: Iran Fortifies Its Arsenal With the Aid of North Korea
description: This article is by William J. Broad, James Glanz and David E. Sanger.

title: WikiLeaks Archive  Cables Uncloak U.S. Diplomacy
description: A cache of diplomatic cables provide a chronicle of the United States relations with the world.

title: Reaction to Leak of U.S. Diplomatic Cables, Day 1
description: On Sunday, The Lede tracked the global reaction to the release of a trove of American diplomatic cables by WikiLeaks, the whistle-blowers Web site.

title: Haitian Candidates Call to Void Election
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Two-thirds of Haitis presidential candidates said Sundays election was so tainted by fraud that it should be invalidated, but late in the evening, national election officials ordered the vote to stand, saying that problems at most polling sites had been minor.

title: Curtain to Rise on Spider-Man
description: Update: Spider-Man Takes Off, With Some Bumps

title: Through Feast of Goals, Stealthy Genius Is Revealed
description: LONDON  The cold snap of Europes winter arrives, but nothing warms the true European soccer fan more than a day out at the stadium when his team is afire.

title: Melancholy Reflection of Faint Shadows
description: Repetition and constraint fascinate Jos Gonzlez, the Swedish songwriter who led Junip at Irving Plaza on Wednesday night. Mr. Gonzlezs two solo albums presented him as a disciple of British folk modernizers like John Martyn, Nick Drake and Bert Jansch. They were skeletal productions for voice, acoustic guitar and very little else, setting modal tunes to nimble, meticulous picking, and they quietly sold more than a million copies worldwide.

title: Okinawa Re-elects Opponent of U.S. Base
description: TOKYO  Voters on the southern Japanese islands of Okinawa re-elected a governor on Sunday who campaigned for the removal of an American Marine base there, throwing a wrench into a deal between Japan and the United States to relocate the base and posing a challenge for the United States as it grapples with a response to North Korean aggression.

title: The Irish Non-bailout
description: So, a credit line at 5.8 percent interest. Considering that Ireland was able to borrow at that rate as recently as mid-September, and was falling off a cliff then, why is this supposed to solve the problem?

title: Giants Finish Strong and End a Skid
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It was only halftime of a single game, but in the Giants locker room, it felt like the fourth quarter of a once-promising season collapsing into mediocrity.

title: A New York Tale of Art, Money and Ambition
description: An Object of Beauty follows the New York art world climb of Lacey Yeager. She is a charismatic character yet a very odd one to have emerged from the imagination of Steve Martin. Although Lacey is treated as this books main source of fascination, its less interesting to look at her point-blank than to look at her while wondering what Mr. Martin sees.

title: Lacking All Conviction
description: Mark Thoma directs us to an appalling story  apparently Obama held a meeting after the midterm to debate whether our unemployment problem is cyclical or structural.

title: When a Skinny Singer Crooned to Knock Your Bobby Socks Off
description: In Frank: The Voice, James Kaplans riveting 786-page biography of Frank Sinatras early years, the author pinpoints the moment in 1943 when the crooners new publicist, George B. Evans, came up with his first defining sobriquet.

title: Familiar Americana, but Still Full of Life
description: When Uncle Toms Cabin landed in theaters in the early 1850s, it quickly became ubiquitous. One of the first things it did, wrote Henry James, who saw it repeatedly, was to flutter down on every stage, literally without exception, in America and Europe.

title: Disney Spins Tangled Hair Into Box-Office Gold
description: Four wide-release movies arrived at already crowded multiplexes over the Thanksgiving holiday, and three of them  Burlesque, Love & Other Drugs and Faster  appeared to be in tryptophan torpors. But Rapunzel, above, came to the rescue at the weekend box office: Tangled, an updated take on the long-haired princess, performed sharply better than expected. Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (Warner Brothers) was No. 1 at the North American box office for a second week, selling about $76 million in tickets over the five-day holiday period for a new domestic total of $220 million. Tangled (Walt Disney Studios) sold about $69 million, validating Disneys controversial decision to play down this films musical and princess elements in marketing materials; strong reviews and premium-priced 3-D screenings also helped. DreamWorks Animations Megamind (distributed by Paramount) was third with $17.6 million for a new total of $130.5 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office statistics. Burlesque, a musical starring Cher and Christina Aguilera that Sony Pictures Entertainment backed with a hefty marketing campaign, was fourth with about $17 million. Denzel Washingtons runaway-train thriller, Unstoppable (20th Century Fox), took fifth place in its third week with about $16 million for a total of over $60 million. Opening out of the Top 5 were Love & Other Drugs, a romantic comedy from 20th Century Fox starring Jake Gyllenhaal and Anne Hathaway that took in $14 million, and Faster, a thriller from CBS Films and Sony that had about $12 million in sales. The Kings Speech, a drama from the Weinstein Company that is considered an Oscar contender, opened in four theaters to $349,791, a total that is considered quite strong for such a limited release.

title: Brubecks Back, Conserving Resources
description: Dave Brubeck made his way to the Blue Note stage with apparent effort on Friday, the first night of a sold-out weekend run. My doctors told me Im rushing things, he said, a little breathlessly, once he had reached the piano bench. He didnt go on to explain that he had undergone heart surgery in October, when he received a pacemaker, or that a handful of other concert dates had been postponed. He was back and eager to proceed, and that was what mattered, judging by the ensuing clatter of grateful applause.

title: Galleries Join Virtual Fair
description: Organizers have announced that 139 art galleries worldwide will participate in the V.I.P. Art Fair, an online-only fair, from Jan. 22 to 30. Each gallery will be able to show 8 to 20 artworks in its virtual booth and to store others in a virtual back room, from which it can bring pieces out to show to individual collectors. Browsing the fair is free, but chatting online with the dealers requires a ticket, which will cost $100 the first two days and $20 after that. The fair is the idea of the dealers James and Jane Cohan and the Internet entrepreneurs Jonas and Alessandra Almgren. AXA Art Insurance Corporation will offer information about art insurance to fair visitors, and the PBS program Art21 will provide videos of studio visits with major artists and tours of major private collections.

title: Coty, a Fragrance Giant, to Buy OPI, the Nail Polish Maker
description: 8:19 p.m. | Updated

title: Thom Yorkes Designs for Climate Change
description: About 2,000 people served as the medium on Saturday for a live sculpture designed by Thom Yorke of Radiohead and the artist Stanley Donwood in Brighton and Hove, England. The installation was part of a project organized by Earth 350, a nonprofit group working to address climate change. The group has unveiled installations around the world in the past week, most of which were visible from space. The exhibition was timed to the United Nations Climate Change Conference, which begins on Monday in Cancn, Mexico. The sculpture, of King Canute, was inspired by the legend of the king who put his throne at the edge of the sea only to have it become soaked when the waves would not be still, as he had commanded. We need politicians today to have a Canute moment, Bill McKibben, the American author, environmentalist and founder of Earth 350, said in a statement on the groups Web site.

title: Paradoxical Truth
description: Professor Greene is lecturing. Down the hall, her arch-rival, Professor Browne, is also lecturing. Professor Greene is holding forth at length about how absurd Professor Brownes ideas are. She believes Professor Browne to be lecturing in Room 33. So to emphasize her point, she writes on the blackboard the single sentence:

title: Donation Helps Bring Dance Institute to Life
description: The National Institute of Dance Medicine and Science has received a donation of almost $47,000 from British Harlequin, a dance floor specialist, bringing the organization  the first of its kind in Britain  closer to fruition, according to Stage News, a British trade publication. The institute aims to provide high-quality, dance-specific health care and dance science support services equal to those offered to elite athletes. When you look at squash, football and rugby, if you apply the same definition of injury to those other populations, dancers get injured much more, and we are just not doing enough, not just in this country but worldwide, said Emma Redding, head of dance science at Trinity Laban Conservatoire of Music and Dance. Dance UK, a dancer advocacy organization, will work with organizations including Trinity, the Birmingham Royal Ballets Jerwood Center for the Prevention and Treatment of Dance Injuries and the University of Wolverhampton to form a network that will collectively make up the institute. Its first project will be a two-year, real-time study of the health of working professional dancers. This is significant, Ms. Redding said, because the only research that has ever been done on injuries has been retrospective. Guy Dagger, the managing director of British Harlequin, said he hoped its donation would encourage other companies to contribute.

title: Timeless Alchemy, Even When No One Is Dancing
description: We go to the theater to watch and hear things happen. The ballets of George Balanchine are among the ultimate examples of this, and their most archetypal passages occur when all thats happening is dance.

title: Funny Man Finds Himself in Unfunny Circumstances
description: An impressive amount of melodrama, activity and funny voices is packed into the hectic hour of Being Sellers, a solo biographical play by Carl Caulfield about the actor Peter Sellers that is part of the annual Brits Off Broadway festival at 59E59 Theaters. Telling the old story of the sad clown, the play, which begins in 1980 at a hospital bed where the chameleonic actor is dying by himself, is filled with references that will make fans of movies like The Pink Panther and Dr. Strangelove nod their heads knowingly.

title: Survivors Celebrate a Family Reunion
description: We paying respect to the dead right now, Juelz Santana told the Hammerstein Ballroom crowd Friday night, urging a moment of silence for the friends he had lost in recent months. We gotta get this right.

title: Scholar Has Theory on Mozart the Debtor
description: The documents of Mozarts life  letters, memoirs of friends, portraits, bureaucratic files  have long been scrutinized at a microscopic level. So when his name was discovered two decades ago in a Viennese archive from 1791, it caused a stir.

title: Haymakers in Houston
description: Texans receiver Andre Johnson and Titans cornerback Cortland Finnegan were ejected from their game Sunday after they squared off in what amounted to a hockey fight in the fourth quarter.

title: Sometimes, a Modest Deal Can Secure a Championship
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  On Saturday at the Fall North American Championships here the winners of the Smith Life Master Womens Pairs were Disa Eythorsdottir of Huntsville, Ala., and Valerie Westheimer of New York. They finished one-third of a board ahead of Lynn Deas of Schenectady, N.Y., and Judith Shulman of Delmar, N.Y. Third were Brenda Bryant of Ferndale, Mich., and Kathleen Sulgrove of Twinsburg, Ohio.

title: Monday: Nonsense!
description: Weve got some Wordplay news at the end of this post but, first, a grid-paper sketch inspired by todays puzzle.

title: Subtlety and Power, With Dash of Drama
description: Rafael Frhbeck de Burgos had the New York Philharmonic sounding its best on Saturday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, with impeccable ensemble and raw power among the performances most striking attributes.

title: Poets Grim Prophecies, With Drama and Music
description: You have only to hear Ute Lemper declaim Charles Bukowskis apocalyptic poem Dinosauria, We to be reminded that Bukowski, who died in 1994, had a gift for gimlet-eyed prophecy. He imagines a 21st century in which people are born into hospitals which are so expensive that its cheaper to die/Into lawyers who charge so much its cheaper to plead guilty/Into a country where the jails are full and the madhouses closed/Into a place where the masses elevate fools into rich heroes.

title: B.C.S. Bowl Picture Clears Up
description: With one weekend left in college footballs regular season, the bowl picture has cleared up. Here are the projections for the five Bowl Championship Series games.

title: Mexican Drug Gang Leader Confesses to Killings
description: MEXICO CITY  A notorious drug gang leader has been captured and has confessed to ordering most killings in the battle-scarred border city of Ciudad Jurez since August 2009, including the drive-by shootings of a United States consular employee and her husband, Mexicos federal police said Sunday.

title: Spider-Man Takes Off, With Some Bumps
description: All $65 million of the new Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark took flight on Sunday night at its first preview performance, but not without bumps. The show stopped five times, mostly to fix technical problems, and Act I ended prematurely, with Spider-Man stuck dangling 10 feet above audience members, while Act II was marred by a nasty catcall during one of the midperformance pauses.

title: For City Dwellers, a Taste of the Orderly Life
description: SURABAYA, Indonesia  Replicas of Singapores iconic monuments, like the Merlion and the Fountain of Wealth, stand beguilingly at key entrance points to the 5,000-acre city within a city. Roads meander around well-planned parks, along tree-lined boulevards, and through residential areas with familiar names like Raffles and Newton. Cars move in orderly fashion through streets that are wide, smooth and protected by guards ready to pounce on traffic violators and litterers alike.

title: Robust Sales for Holiday Weekend
description: More Americans went shopping over the Thanksgiving weekend than in recent memory, and online shopping accounted for the highest percentage of the weekends sales yet.

title: Calls From Man With Terror Links Prompted German Alert, Official Says
description: BERLIN  Germanys recent decision to declare a terrorism alert and dispatch heavily armed police around the nation was set off by phone calls from a man who said he wanted to quit working with terrorists and warned of a pending Mumbai-style attack, according to a law enforcement official with firsthand knowledge of the alert.

title: BP to Commission Film About Oil Spill
description: BP is commissioning a feature-length film about the Deepwater Horizon oil spill  but the company says it is not intended to scrub its reputation clean.

title: Will Mad Men Take a Reality Twist? And 19 Other Questions
description: IT is time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, marketing, the media and popular culture.

title: A Media False Alarm Over the T.S.A.
description: If a squadron of mad scientists surrounded by supercomputers gathered in a laboratory to try to conjure a single news topic that would blow up large, they could not touch the T.S.A. pat-down story.

title: Gates Seeking to Contain Military Health Costs
description: WASHINGTON  Francis Brady enjoys a six-figure salary and generous benefits at the consulting firm Booz Allen Hamilton, but as a retired Marine lieutenant colonel he and his family remain on the militarys bountiful lifetime health insurance, Tricare, with fees of only $460 a year. He calls the benefit phenomenal.

title: Off the Record, Behind the Scenes
Beer With Kick Is Caught in F.D.A.s Net
description: COHASSET, Mass.  When Rhonda Kallman set out to create a beer that would draw a crowd, she never expected the attention her Moonshot 69 brew received this month.

title: Judges Budget Will Seek Big Expansion of Legal Aid to the Poor in Civil Cases
description: As part of his annual budget, New Yorks chief judge will propose a $100 million increase in state financing for lawyers who represent the poor in civil cases that deal with the essentials of life like eviction and child support, according to people who have worked on the plan.

title: For PayPal, the Future Is Mobile
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  When Scott Thompson, the president of PayPal, chats with executives at its parent, eBay, he is diplomatic about the size of his business compared with eBays marketplace.

title: Suspect in Oregon Bomb Plot Is Called Confused
description: CORVALLIS, Ore.  Mohamed Osman Mohamud had seemed to be a well-adjusted American teenager: a solid student whose interests included basketball, girls and the night life at Oregon State University, where he studied engineering.

title: Former Nets Try to Put Losing Season Behind Them
description: Avery Johnson, the new Nets coach, approached Courtney Lee after one of the most painful seasons in N.B.A. history had finally concluded. Johnson gave Lee an option: he could have a significant role with the Nets while the organization rebuilt, or he could seek a fresh start with another team through a trade.

title: Selling Caribbean TV Network From the Island of Newark
description: NEWARK

title: Liberal Groups to Propose Routes to Smaller Deficit
description: WASHINGTON  As President Obamas fiscal commission faces a deadline this week for agreement on a plan to shrink the mounting national debt, liberal organizations will unveil debt-reduction proposals of their own in the next two days, seeking to sway the debate in favor of fewer reductions in domestic spending, more cuts in the military and higher taxes for the wealthy.

title: Google Grows, and Works to Retain Nimble Minds
description: When a product manager at Google told his bosses this year that he was quitting to take a job at Facebook, they offered him a large raise. When he said it was not about the money, they told him he could have a promotion, work in a different area or even start his own company inside Google.

title: Catalonia Vote Reflects Desire for Less Obligation to Madrid
description: MADRID  Catalonia, Spains northeastern region, is set to be led by a government demanding greater fiscal autonomy from Madrid, adding a further challenge for Jos Luis Rodrguez Zapatero, the countrys embattled Socialist prime minister.

title: In Magazine World, a New Crop of Chiefs
description: For the magazine business, 2011 will be a year to watch  and not just because it could hold answers to lingering questions about the financial health of the industry.

title: A Stale Food Fight
description: THE best opportunity in a generation to improve the safety of the American food supply will come as early as Monday night, when the Senate is scheduled to vote on the F.D.A. Food Safety Modernization bill. This legislation is by no means perfect. But it promises to achieve several important food safety objectives, greatly benefiting consumers without harming small farmers or local food producers.

title: Fraud Charges Mar Egypt Vote
description: CAIRO  Egyptians went to the polls on Sunday to vote in a parliamentary election that seemed to unroll according to a wearily familiar script: scattered violence, widespread accusations of fraud and intimidation, and a sense among many here that Egypts long-dominant governing party was bent on entrenching its hold on power in a period of looming political uncertainty.

title: Michigan Mens Basketball Has Three Sons of N.B.A. Players
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  At first glance, the Michigan mens basketball roster calls to mind an N.B.A. starting lineup: Dumars, Horford and Hardaway, with an agent (Bartelstein) thrown in for good measure.

title: One More Game Device (but This Ones Tiny)
description: With Microsofts Xbox 360, Nintendos Wii and Sonys PlayStation 3 duking it out for dominance of the video game console market, can there possibly be any room for yet another machine?

title: Sanctions Leave Trojans Playing Just for Themselves
description: LOS ANGELES  Like a football play, life does not always go according to plan, as Mitch Mustain, a senior quarterback at Southern California, knows achingly well.

title: The Spanish Prisoner
description: The best thing about the Irish right now is that there are so few of them. By itself, Ireland cant do all that much damage to Europes prospects. The same can be said of Greece and of Portugal, which is widely regarded as the next potential domino.

title: Britton Chance, Olympian and Biophysics Researcher, Dies at 97
description: Britton Chance, a biophysicist who did pioneering research on how living organisms produce and manage energy and helped develop diagnostic tools, like one for the detection of breast cancer, died on Nov. 16 in Philadelphia.

title: Magazines Take a Shot at the Net
description: So which is better: a print magazine or its digital version?

title: The Partisan Mind
description: Imagine, for a moment, that George W. Bush had been president when the Transportation Security Administration decided to let Thanksgiving travelers choose between exposing their nether regions to a body scanner or enduring a private security massage. Democrats would have been outraged at yet another Bush-era assault on civil liberties. Liberal pundits would have outdone one another comparing the T.S.A. to this or that police state. (In an outrage worthy of Enver Hoxhas Albania ...) And Republicans would have leaped to the Bush administrations defense, while accusing liberals of going soft on terrorism.

title: Alfred Balk, Journalist and Author, Dies at 80
description: Alfred Balk, a reporter, author and magazine editor who wrote groundbreaking articles about housing segregation and the Nation of Islam, and whose refusal to identify a confidential source led to a landmark court case, died on Thursday at his home in Huntley, Ill. He was 80.

title: Coors Cameo in a Futurist Film
description: During the first 30 minutes of Tron: Legacy, the forthcoming science fiction film from Walt Disney Studios, the hunky computer whiz at the center of the action struts to his refrigerator and pulls out a Coors. Yes, a Coors.

title: "The Sunset Tower" by SNL
description: "The Sunset Tower, "a holiday short by Saturday Night Live.

title: Swimming to Las Vegas
description: Synchronized swimmers have found a home in the theatrical pursuits of Las Vegas, in shows like Le Rve and Cirque de Soleils O.

title: Synchronized Swimming as a Show
description: LAS VEGAS  Ludivine Perrin-Stsepaniuk and 13 other former elite synchronized swimmers perform in two shows a night five times a week at the Wynn Las Vegas, showing off world championship legs and red spike heels.

title: A Very S.N.L. Greeting
description: How many businesses can boast that their holiday video greeting card was made by a Saturday Night Live threesome?

title: After Thwarted Attack, Question Is Why Portland?
description: Portlanders call Pioneer Courthouse Square the citys living room.

title: Intolerance and the Law in Oklahoma
description: For a few days this month, it was illegal in Oklahoma for a state judge to base a court decision on Islamic religious law or consider any form of international law. It was a manufactured problem; the issue has never come up in the states courts. But more than 70 percent of voters in Oklahoma still approved a state constitutional amendment to that effect, apparently persuaded by anti-Islamic activists, and a few cynical politicians, that Oklahoma was about to be brought under Islams heel.

title: Buccaneers Fall to Ravens in Their Latest Test
description: BALTIMORE  The Tampa Bay Buccaneers are the N.F.L.s youngest team, which means they should be contenders for several years to come. At 7-4, they remain contenders now, too. But on a Sunday that offered tests of legitimacy for several front-running N.F.C. teams, the Buccaneers failed theirs, losing to the Baltimore Ravens, 17-10.

title: Long Living Countries Apart, Now Under One Roof  Neediest Cases
description: Separation is Julio Santanas birthright.

title: Leslie Nielsen, 84, Romantic Hero Turned Comic, Dies
description: Leslie Nielsen, the Canadian-born actor who in middle age tossed aside three decades of credibility in dramatic and romantic roles to make a new, far more successful career as a comic actor in films like Airplane! and the Naked Gun series, died on Sunday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 84.

title: States Diverting Money From Climate Initiative
description: In New York, government officials found $90 million to pay for schools by dipping into money generated by a multistate greenhouse gas initiative.

title: Belt-Tightening Across Europe
The Fed and Foreclosures
description: There are two sides to every delinquent loan  a lender who made a bad lending decision and a borrower who cannot repay. Yet, banks have never acted as if they bear responsibility for the mortgage mess.

title: Dutch Composer Wins Grawemeyer Award
description: The fund that produces the University of Louisvilles Grawemeyer Award for musical composition, among the most prestigious in classical music, has declined so much that the prize has been cut in half, its administrator said. Even so, now at $100,000, it is one of the fields richest. The winner this year is Louis Andriessen, 71, the Netherlands most prominent composer, the university said Sunday night. Mr. Andriessen won specifically for his multimedia opera La Commedia, which is based on Dantes Divine Comedy and had its first performance in Amsterdam in 2008. The work was also performed last spring at Carnegie Hall, where Mr. Andriessen, left, was the subject of a series of concerts. The last five Grawemeyer winners in music were Gyorgy Kurtag, Sebastian Currier, Peter Lieberson, Brett Dean and York Hller. The awards are granted in four other areas: religion, education, political science and psychology. The Grawemeyer fund dropped to $17 million from about $29 million over six months in 2008 because of the stock market decline, said Allan Dittmer, the programs executive director. If we continued to give a $200,000 award, we would be deeply into our principal, which was dropping, Mr. Dittmer said. We had to do something.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Marketers Discover Trucks Can Deliver More Than Food
description: When the Heavenly Mountain Resort in Lake Tahoe, Nev., wanted to promote its ski passes this season, it bypassed the usual advertising media like billboards, radio and print ads and instead chose a truck filled with snow cones driven by two improv actors to publicize its message.

title: Wolf Politics
description: These days, the gray wolf is in trouble in the Rocky Mountain West and in Washington, D.C. Several members of the House have introduced a bill that would permanently remove wolves from the protection of the Endangered Species Act. A more moderate proposal sponsored by two Montana Democrats, Senators Max Baucus and Jon Tester, would exempt only wolves in Montana and Idaho. Both bills could be pushed hard in the remaining days of Congresss lame-duck session.

title: Chaos at the Polls in Haiti
description: In many places, voters in Haitis first presidential election since the January earthquake encountered confusion, delays and intimidation, along with accusations of fraud.

title: Repatriating Tut
description: When King Tutankhamens tomb was discovered in 1922, the world instantly craved a first-hand sighting of the golden sarcophagus, exquisite funerary jewels and divine chariots accompanying the Boy King through the Big Sleep. Nearly 90 years later the enthusiasm  and the entrepreneurial desire to exploit it  continues.

title: Behind the Scenes at Monday Night Football
description: Two years ago, I was on the sideline hours before a Monday night gamein Foxborough, Mass. (my first live N.F.L. game). I mustered thecourage to introduce myself to the ESPN president George Bodenheimer.What I remembered most from a few minutes of conversation was hissaying that the best part of the Monday Night Football experiencewas those few hours leading up to kickoff when everyone  players,coaches, reporters, fans  is trickling into the stadium and buildinga buzz.

title: Adults Are Not So Inclined to Check In
description: So-called location services like Foursquare or Gowalla seem ubiquitous. These services use a smartphone, often GPS-equipped, to broadcast the users location, find friends nearby, and pick up deals or information linked to the location. In August, Facebook introduced its own location service, Places.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data this week will include the Standard & Poors/Case-Shiller home price index for September and the third quarter, the Chicago purchasing managers index for November, and consumer confidence for November (Tuesday); ADP employment for November, revised third-quarter productivity, the ISM manufacturing index for November, and construction spending for October (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims and pending home sales for October (Thursday); and unemployment for November, the ISM service index for November, and factory orders for October (Friday).

title: Giants Defense Makes Stand With Three Straight Sacks
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  As Jaguars quarterback David Garrard slowly peeled himself from the field again and again and again, his teammates patted his shoulder pads. His gait was creaky, and his left wrist was sore.

description: Hoping to avoid the lasting stain of Congressional censure and the indignity of the public scolding that accompanies it, Representative Charles B. Rangel has embarked on a last-ditch campaign to convince colleagues that he deserves the far less serious punishment of a reprimand for his ethics violations, according to two people close to Mr. Rangel.

title: Cause Sought in Fatal Fire; 130 Left Homeless in Bronx
description: Investigators were trying on Sunday to determine the cause of a fire that broke out in the lobby of a Bronx apartment building on Saturday night and leapt up a staircase, forcing many residents to flee down fire escapes. A man was killed, and a woman was injured when she jumped from a second-floor fire escape.

title: News Quiz | November 29, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Europe Approves Irish Rescue and Rules on Bailouts
description: Fighting to prevent an accelerating debt crisis from engulfing Portugal and Spain, Europes finance ministers approved an 85 billion euro bailout package for Ireland, while also agreeing for the first time to hold private investors accountable for losses in future crises, beginning in 2013.

title: Bombings Hit Atomic Experts in Iran Streets
description: TEHRAN  Unidentified assailants riding motorcycles carried out separate bomb attacks here on Monday against two of the countrys top nuclear scientists, killing one and prompting accusations that the United States and Israel were again trying to disrupt Irans nuclear program.

title: What Top Ten List Would You Make?
description: This time of year, The Times publishes lists by critics and columnists across desks that sum up what theyve learned, admired or enjoyed this year. For instance, this weekend there was a list of the 100 most notable books of the year in the Book Review, while restaurant critic Sam Sifton made a list of favorite New York City restaurants  and David Pogue wrote about the lessons he has learned in ten years of talking tech. And, of course, the annual Holiday Gift Guide lists everything from the best video games to the best beauty products.

title: Wal-Mart Formalizes $2.4 Billion Massmart Bid
description: Wal-Mart, looking to tap growth in Africa, said on Monday that it had made a formal offer of about 17 billion rand ($2.4 billion) for a majority stake in Massmart, the South African retail chain.

title: Children Heading Households in Moldova
description: Andrea Diefenbach was shocked by what she saw in a first-grade classroom in a village in the south of Moldova, in 2008. When asked whose parents had emigrated to Italy, two-thirds of the students raised their hands.

title: The Early Word: Leaked
description: From Todays Times:

title: Drama at News Conference After Montreal Wins Grey Cup
description: A postgame news conference took a dramatic turn after the Montreal Alouettes victory in the Grey Cup on Sunday night. Quarterback Anthony Calvillo led the Alouettes to a 21-18 victory, Montreals second straight win over the Saskatchewan Roughriders in the Grey Cup, then surprised reporters with an announcement.

title: Lutetia Capital: A Young Fund Coming of Age
description: A hedge fund had its first birthday this weekend. Its name is Lutetia Capital, and for a fund of its type, it has the worlds highest Sharpe ratio, a measure of risk-adjusted returns. The fund beat out nearly 300 rivals, according to Bloomberg data.

title: Curtis Martin, Bettis and Faulk Among Hall Semifinalists
description: The Pro Football Hall of Fame released the list of 26 semifinalists for its Class of 2011 on Sunday, and as usual it is an impressive group.

title: A London Show Celebrates the Book Cover
description: At a time when e-readers may be displacing the good, old-fashioned print book, an effort to revive interest in the art of the book cover is taking place in London. The gallery StolenSpace gave a simple task to a group of more than 30 artists, designers, ceramic artists and photographers: design a cover for your favorite book. Participants were free to paint, print, etch, sculpt, photograph, or use any medium of their choice, as long as the result was in the size of an average book (defined as 198mm by 129mm).

title: Irish Banks to Seek More Capital
description: Bank of Ireland said on Monday that it would seek to raise 2.2 billion euros ($2.9 billion) by the end of February in order to comply with new capital requirements made in conjunction with the Irish bailout package approved by European finance ministers on Sunday.

title: Petersons Public Break From Private Equitys Line on Taxes

description: A coalition of progressive think tanks has released a plan for dealing with the deficit. Its at least as responsible as any of the other plans being advanced, with a very different emphasis: more reliance on revenue, no attack on Social Security. Some of the revenue comes from indirect taxes  green taxes and fuel taxes  but the rest comes from measures that would raise taxes mainly on upper-income Americans.

And though there are already plenty of good indicators  including studio campaigns and the mailing of those highly-coveted screeners  about which films will be in the mix for the top 10, there is also plenty of time for winds to shift. The race, as we see it, is still Kansas-size wide open.

title: Good Habits
description: Priests and nuns are not the most likely fashion inspirations, but the first hint that I remember of the clerical collar as a subversive take on the prim and the perverse was at the Prada mens collection in January 2008. I remember watching the guys, in their streamlined tailoring, walk a weird cats cradle of a wooden runway. They were close enough for the audience to spot chests covered with what resembled pastors bibs, tied over bared shirt backs. Other looks, as if of a priest defrocking himself, were neckties used as nooses and visible underpants rising from trousers. But it was the abstract collars  and the sly sexuality that the enigmatic Miuccia Prada drew from them  that stayed in my mind.

title: Chinese Export Regions Face Labor Shortages
description: BEIJING  Two of Chinas main export manufacturing areas are suffering from an acute shortage of migrant workers, giving laborers more leverage over wages and curtailing the expansion plans of some companies, according to a report published Monday in China Daily, an official English-language newspaper.

title: Answers to Readers Questions About States Secrets
description: The New York Times is publishing States Secrets, a series of articles about a trove of more than 250,000 American diplomatic cables that were originally obtained by WikiLeaks, an organization devoted to exposing official secrets. The cables reveal the daily traffic between the State Department and more than 270 diplomatic outposts around the world and offer a secret chronicle of the United States relations with other nations in an age of war and terrorism.

title: Waiting on the Teenage Brain
description: I spent the Thanksgiving weekend with four teenagers and one preteen. I adore all of them. But lets just say that by Sunday I was more than ready to read Judith Newmans article in Parade Magazine  the one titled Inside the Teenage Brain, which begins: I would rather give birth to a baby elephant than raise a teenager again. It would be less painful.

title: The Post-Oscar Whirlwind
description: Before we plunge headlong into all the news and nonsense of this years race, lets indulge in a bit of where-are-they-now for last years winners. The Bagger caught up with Kathryn Bigelow and Mark Boal, the director and writer, respectively, of The Hurt Locker, at a recent benefit at the Museum of Modern Art, where Ms. Bigelow was being honored. (The museum has acquired her print archives, and a retrospective of her work is planned for June.)

title: A Touch of Norway at Carnegie Hall
description: Since 1991 the Risor Chamber Music Festival has been attracting internationally renowned artists and emerging Scandinavian musicians to a charming coastal fishing village in southeastern Norway for a cram-packed week in late June. On Wednesday evening the festival begins its first Carnegie Hall residency, with four concerts through Saturday: an enticing sampling of typically diverse Risor programs.

title: Clinton Says U.S. Diplomacy Will Survive Attack

description: One threatened fellow lawmakers with a pistol. Two others assaulted their colleagues with canes, an old weapon of choice on Capitol Hill. title: Wasted Youth | Skye Parrott at Capricious Space
description: Skye Parrott, the photographer, curator and one half of the duo behind the art and fashion journal Dossier, regularly shoots for the likes of Dazed and Confused and Vogue. First Love, Last Rites, now on view at Capricious space in Brooklyn, however, finds Parrott operating on a more personal level. Recreating events from her drug-fueled teens, Parrott has tried to dive headlong into her own blurry history  something more difficult than you might imagine. In doing this work, I was keenly aware that what I remembered might not be real,  she says. Curious about what actually happened, after making the photographs she interviewed her boyfriend from that period to see what he remembered. There was a lot of overlap, she says, but there were huge discrepancies, too. I think it points to the way that memories form us, and as we form, we reshape them to fit.

title: James Franco and Anne Hathaway to Host the Oscars

He was 87.

title: Casting Director Dismissed From Hobbit
description: Youd think a movie project whose roster of characters runs from dwarves to dragons would need to be as inclusive as possible in its casting. But on Monday a casting agent was let go from Peter Jacksons planned film adaptations of The Hobbit, after placing newspaper advertisements seeking extras with light skin tones and a prospective performer said she was told she was too dark to appear in the movies, Agence France-Presse reported.

title: Fishing Banned in Stretch of Gulf

title: Numberplay: Scrambled Controls
description: Last year in The Good, the Bad and the Ugly, we presented a puzzle suite that showed what happens when you are given random information. Simple tasks become difficult, and hard problems doubly difficult when information is scrambled. In spite of this, however, it is usually possible to achieve your goals. Todays puzzle is of this type. Like the Egg Drop Soup puzzle, it too came to me via a graduate student at the recent Gathering For Gardner.

title: Being Happy in a Sad Place
description: In these quantitatively grim times, with unemployment high and growth low, the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco has made something of a (small) cottage industry of examining existential questions, not the least what makes us happy, sad, and perhaps suicidal.

description: Yep, thats exactly what we needed: a transparently cynical policy gesture, trivial in scale but misguided in direction, and in effect conceding that your bitter political opponents have the right idea.

title: Asthma Symptoms? Try Caffeine
description: Todays Really? column explores whether caffeine from coffee or strong tea can work as a home remedy for asthma symptoms.

title: Head Out for a Daily Dose of Green Space
description: First, the bad news: Americans are suffering from an acute case of outdoor deprivation disorder, and the effects on physical and mental health are rising fast. Children aged 8 to 18 today spend more time than ever using electronic media indoors  seven and a half hours a day, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation  and less time in outdoor unstructured activity. In response to the No Child Left Behind law, 30 percent of kindergarten classrooms have eliminated recess to make more room for academics.

title: Womens World Cup Draw; U.S. Opens Against North Korea
description: The United States, which faced an uncharacteristic struggle to qualify for soccers 2011 Womens World Cup, was drawn into a first-round group with North Korea, Colombia and Sweden in Frankfurt, Germany on Monday.

title: National Dance Institute Finds a New Home
description: A Harlem real estate development will become the new home of the National Dance Institute, which provides dance training for public school children. The institute, currently on Broadway near Houston Street, said on Monday that it would take up residence at P.S. 90, a former school building at 220 West 148th Street between Adam Clayton Powell and Frederick Douglass Boulevards that is being turned into condominiums. The institute, founded in 1976 by the dancer Jacques dAmboise, said it would have offices and studios at the space and would be able to expand its programs. More than half of the $20 million needed to carry out the project has been raised, the institute said.

title: Fuel Lines of Tumors Are New Target
description: For the last decade cancer drug developers have tried to jam the accelerators that cause tumors to grow. Now they want to block the fuel line.

title: Boehner Invites Republican Governors-Elect to Meet in D.C.
description: Stretching his influence beyond the Beltway, Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the incoming House speaker, said Monday that he would host a meeting on Capitol Hill next week with the nations new Republican governors-elect.

description: 8:00 p.m. | Updated  Today saw the official opening in Cancn, Mexico, of talks over a new treaty aimed, theoretically, at avoiding dangerous human interference with the climate system. But Chinese coal and American politics pretty much guarantee that negotiators, despite a relaxed dress code this year, will only nibble at the edges of the climate challenge. [8:00 p.m. | Updated  Theres more from me on the climate talks and congressional tussles over climate policy in an interview I did earlier today with Barbara Bernstein of KBOO radio in Corvallis, Ore.]

description: An outbreak of mysterious blisters in Liberia illustrates how panic can be stirred by a combination of overwrought journalism, listless government and traditional witchcraft.

description: Narcissists, much to the surprise of many experts, are in the process of becoming an endangered species.

title: Foot Injury Sidelines N.B.A.s Top Rebounder
description: Weeks ago, Justin Kubatko noted the rebounding excellence of the Toronto Raptors Reggie Evans in this space, as Evans rebounding ethic is obscured by more conventional rebounding measures, but is resplendent under the light of more detailed statistics. Evans is still third in the league in rebounds per game, even though rebound percentage - a percentage estimate of the rebounds a player grabbed while they were on the floor - shows the Raptors forward to be far and away the most efficient rebounder in the league. When the noise from pace factors and varying opportunities are wiped clean, Evans is the leagues indisputable best on the boards.

title: Narcissism No Longer a Psychiatric Disorder
description: Narcissistic personality disorder, characterized by an inflated sense of self-importance and the need for constant attention, has been eliminated from the upcoming manual of mental disorders, which psychiatrists use to diagnose mental illness.

title: The Mystery of the Red Bees of Red Hook
description: Cerise Mayo expected better of her bees. She had raised them right, given them all the best opportunities  acres of urban farmland strewn with fruits and vegetables, a bounty of natural nectar and pollen. Blinded by devotion, she assumed they shared her values: a fidelity to the land, to food sources free of high-fructose corn syrup and artificial food coloring.

title: Back to the Costly Skies
description: As American companies negotiate airline and hotel rates for 2011, they are encountering a market much different from a year ago, when the economy, and business travel with it, were still feeble.

title: Its No Simple Matter Before a Tree Joins Rockefeller Center History
description: In November 1986, a man in a hard hat took a chain saw to the trunk of the tree that had stood outside Mary and Vinnie Frohlings home in Rockland County for half a century. The man with the saw was no ordinary lumberjack. He was from Rockefeller Center.

title: In a Holiday Indicator, Retailers Say Online Sales Remain Strong
description: Online shoppers started buying on Thanksgiving and did not let up on so-called Cyber Monday, the day retailers designated for more discounts and promotions. By 6 p.m. on Monday, Eastern time, sales were 20 percent higher than during the same time period on the Monday after Thanksgiving a year ago, according to Coremetrics, a research firm owned by I.B.M. that tracks online sales.

title: Rothenberg Looks Back, and Ahead to 2022 World Cup in the U.S.
description: Alan I. Rothenberg presided over a startlingly successful World Cup in the United States in 1994. And with FIFAs all-powerful 24-man executive committee (minus two suspended members) poised to announce the host countries for the tournaments in 2018 and 2022 Thursday in Zurich, Rothenberg remains an unabashed booster of America.

title: Samurai Shopper | Batting Practice
description: The Samurai Shopper is not easily beguiled by bread and circuses. Ever steadfast, I remain impervious to the flashy and trivial vanities that litter the cultural landscape. But those Burlesque posters of Cher and Christina Aguilera are getting to me, along with the overexposed Kardashian klaque. Its not their beauty or fame that distracts me, its those fake eyelashes I love.

title: Kids Giving Gifts
description: In response to our conversation here last week about gift ideas for children who have too much stuff, a reader left a question in the comments. We talk a lot about children getting presents, but how about the flip side: shouldnt children be GIVING them?

title: CBS Renews The Young and the Restless
description: CBS is not giving up on the daytime soap entirely. The network announced Monday that it had renewed The Young and the Restless for three more seasons, keeping the daily drama on the network through 2014.
