description: With some House Republicans gunning for the stimulus bill, especially the portion that went to the Energy Department, the energy secretary went on a pre-emptive offensive of sorts on Monday in advance of the Republican takeover over the chamber, telling an audience at the National Press Club that that money was merely a down payment.

title: Sign of the Times': Dylans Lyrics for Sale
description: Come gather round, people: if your cash to you is worth spending on a one-of-a-kind piece of Bob Dylan memorabilia, you might consider saving the date of Dec. 10. Thats when Sothebys plans to auction Mr. Dylans handwritten lyrics to The Times They Are a-Changin' as part of a larger sale of books and manuscripts, the auction house said on Monday. In a catalog listing, Sothebys described the item as a sheet of unruled three-hole notebook paper on which Mr. Dylan wrote four verses of the famous protest song in simple block lettering (which you can see in closer detail here). He later recorded it for his 1964 album of the same title. (The verse that begins, Come writers and critics who prophesize with your pen, does not appear in the document, though a fragment of lyrics from Mr. Dylans song North Country Blues can be seen on the reverse side.)

description: Photographs from Egypt, Haiti and South Korea.

title: Judge Blocks Oklahomas Ban on Using Shariah Law in Court
description: HOUSTON  An Oklahoma constitutional amendment aimed at stopping the use of Islamic law in its courts was dealt a serious blow on Monday when a federal judge temporarily blocked the state from putting it into effect.

title: G.M. Sells Parts Maker to a Chinese Company
description: DETROIT  General Motors said on Monday that it had completed a deal to sell a subsidiary that makes power-steering components to an affiliate of the Beijing municipal government.

title: A To-Do (and To-Dont) List for Parents
description: This whole going-off-college-thing goes so much better when theres a true partnership between parent and child. I do get concerned when parents cross the line and begin taking on Juniors role in the process  because theres plenty enough to do for both Junior and Mom and Dad.

title: Fast-Food Options for Kids
description: Jim Skinner, the chief executive officer of the McDonalds Corporation, believes that his company is doing its part to provide healthy meal options for its customers, children included. In a recent interview with USA Today, Mr. Skinner was asked what McDonalds has done to help combat obesity. I like to say that weve been part of the solution, Mr. Skinner said.

title: The Guantnamo Diaspora
description: President Obama signed an order shortly after taking office to close the prison within one year. But the deadline passed as it became harder than the administration expected to transfer the detainees. Some detainees cannot be prosecuted or released, and there is opposition to moving the detainees to American soil.

title: Cables Depict U.S. Haggling to Clear Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON  Last year, King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia proposed an unorthodox way to return Guantnamo Bay prisoners to a chaotic country like Yemen without fear that they would disappear and join a terrorist group.

title: North Korea Keeps the World Guessing
description: WASHINGTON  With North Korea reeling from economic and succession crises, American and South Korean officials early this year secretly began gaming out what would happen if the North, led by one of the worlds most brutal family dynasties, collapsed.

title: Musicals Give Thanks After Fat Holiday Week
description: Thanksgiving tourists picked true to form on Broadway last week, opting for big musical blockbusters like Wicked  which grossed a rare $2 million for eight performances  and The Lion King, which, with $1.87 million, had its highest-grossing week in the 13-year history of the Disney musical on Broadway. The good tidings extended to holiday-themed shows like the new musical Elf, which, after Wicked, notched the largest one-week jump in grosses, earning $1,406,283 last week compared to $862,995 for the previous week.

title: Recount Begins to Determine Governors Race in Minnesota
description: Election officials in Minnesota began a massive recount on Monday to determine the winner of the only gubernatorial race that is still undecided from the 2010 midterm elections.

title: Critics' Picks: 'Point Blank'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at John Boorman's revenge film about the fate of the individual in the corporate world.

title: Seagate Ends Leveraged Buyout Talks
description: A Seagate employee testing drives at an assembly plant.

title: From 16 Leading Britons, a Plea for the Arms Treaty
description: To the Editor:

title: A Few Financial Matters You Can Control
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog, and other drawings are available on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

title: Portraits of the Mind
description: The Times's assistant science editor interviews Carl Schoonover, a neuroscientist at Columbia University, about his book,  "Portraits of the Mind," featured in Tuesday's Science Times.

title: Why Mahler?
description: In August 1991 Mikhail Gorbachev was meeting military ofcials at his holiday home in the Crimea when, resisting a demand for a return to totalitarian rule, he was placed under house arrest. The phones went dead, and he was held incommunicado for three days. His wife, Raisa, collapsed with a hypertension attack. In Moscow protesters massed in the streets, and the president of the Russian republic, Boris Yeltsin, led an armed vigil outside Parliament, televised live around the world. The coup crumbled, and Gorbachev was restored to ofce, only to be deposed at the years end by the drunken and rapacious Yeltsin.

title: The Beautiful Mind
description: Images from Portraits of the Mind: Visualizing the Brain From Antiquity to the 21st Century show new techniques in trying to understand the mysteries of the brain.

title: An Odyssey Through the Brain, Illuminated by a Rainbow
description: Who has seen the mind? Neither you nor I  nor any of the legions of neuroscientists bent on opening the secrets of that invisible force, as powerful and erratic as the wind.

title: Celebrating a Man With Many Acolytes
description: Norman Lebrecht, in his new book, Why Mahler?: How One Man and Ten Symphonies Changed Our World, speaks of Mahlers capacity to pierce human defenses. And it is certainly true that Mahlers music can unhinge the susceptible.

title: A Dirge for the Bluefin Tuna
description: International fisheries negotiators dashed hopes for protection of the bluefin tuna over the weekend in Paris, agreeing to leave fishing quotas for the endangered fish essentially unchanged next year. Conservationists did claim small victories in measures to protect sharks and turtles, however.

title: Courts Curious Decision on Airgas
description: The Delaware Supreme Courts opinion in favor of Airgas in its battle with Air Products and Chemicals is notable for what it does not say or do. The court finds that Delawares staggered board statute is ambiguous; so the court looks to see what Airgass certificate of incorporation states. The court then finds that the certificate is also ambiguous.

title: Europes Crisis of Liquidity
State Grants Waiver for Schools Chancellor
description: Cathleen P. Black, the publishing executive picked by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to be the next schools chancellor, cleared a final hurdle on Monday as the state granted her the waiver she needs to take office.

title: Murder! Intrigue! Astronomers?
description: When Danish and Czech scientists exhumed the remains of the astronomer Tycho Brahe in Prague this month, they dug up much more than some bones and hairs. They found something that has eluded astronomers for thousands of years: a story with major box-office potential.

title: Cowboys of Madagascar
description: Tuesday, Nov. 23

title: Critics Picks Video: Point Blank
description: This week, A. O. Scott looks at one of the high points in the revenge film genre, 1967s Point Blank, directed by John Boorman. Though many films have focused on a wronged character seeking payback, there arent many characters who embody vengeance as forcefully, as purely, as nastily as Lee Marvins Walker, he says. The film fills the screen with enemies for Walker to confront and take down on his way to retribution, but Mr. Scott sees a deeper side too, calling it an allegory about the fate of the individual in a world dominated by corporate power. Have you seen Point Blank? Please share your thoughts.

title: Google Earth Pushes Boundaries Between Real and Virtual
description: In late September, Sergey Brin, a co-founder of Google, explained at a press event that he wanted Google to be the third half of your brain. Mr. Brin wasnt just referring to the companys search products when he made that somewhat eerieproclamation. He was also alluding to a number of products that should be expected in the coming years.

title: Question for Big Film: Its Not a Comedy?
description: LOS ANGELES  Harrison Ford glowered. Daniel Craig glared.

title: Airlines Getting New Top Lobbyist
description: Ever since the economic crisis hit in 2008, Nicholas Calio has taken his share of lumps from Washington as a top lobbyist for Citigroup, the financial giant. Now, Mr. Calio is moving from high finance to high altitudes to become the face of another beleaguered industry  the airlines.

title: A Nephrologist and Patient
description: Dr. Julian L. Seifter, 61, a nephrologist at Brigham and Womens Hospital in Boston and a Harvard Medical School professor, specializes in treating patients who have chronic kidney disease.

title: Breaking Away From Coal
description: HOUSTON  Progress Energy Carolinas, one of the Souths larger utilities, faced a dilemma last winter.

title: 2 Hedge Funds Say Theyre Not Inquiry Targets
description: 7:13 p.m. | Updated Diamondback Capital Management and Level Global, two of three hedge funds raided by federal authorities last week in a widening investigation of insider trading on Wall Street, say the firms are not the target of the governments inquiry, according to letters that the firms sent to investors on Monday.

title: A Tax Strategy for Athletes
description: This summer we wrote about how tax considerations might have figured into a decision by LeBron James to leave the Cleveland Cavaliers and join the Miami Heat, since Florida does not have personal income taxes. There is, however, an even more advantageous tax strategy that he missed out on entirely.

title: The Twilight Zone
description: Q. Why do deer get transfixed by car headlights and just stand there in harms way?

title: Mammal Growth Spurt After Dinosaurs Died
description: Mammals exploded in size after dinosaurs went extinct and continued to grow for about 25 million years, according to a new study that appears in the journal Science.

title: Celebrating Mark Twain With a Piano
description: With so many pianists commemorating the bicentenaries of Chopin and Schumann this year, it is refreshing to find a player whose fascinations lie elsewhere. John Davis has been spending the year celebrating Mark Twain on the 175th anniversary of his birth and the centenary of his death.

title: Tall Fliers Get Sympathy, but Not From Everyone
description: Travel has become less glamorous as the airline industry braves an unstable economy and terrorist threats. Enhanced security, fewer flights, longer waits and cutbacks in amenities make keeping both feet on the ground an attractive option to those who can get to their destination without hitting the tarmac.

title: Flexible Scales Add to Speed of Shortfin Mako Shark
description: The shortfin mako shark is one of the fastest sharks around, perhaps because of the variation in size and flexibility of the teethlike scales embedded in its skin.

title: Netflix Partner Says Comcast Toll Threatens Online Video Delivery
description: 9:45 p.m. | Updated

title: Trove of Picassos Surfaces, and So Do Questions
description: PARIS  Pablo Picasso gave them as a gift.

title: Its a Bird. Its a Plane. No, Its a Flying Snake.
description: When paradise tree snakes, found in South and Southeast Asia, leap from trees, they dont tumble to the ground in disarray. They gracefully glide long distances through the air.

title: The Simpsons Explains Its Kinda-Sorta Feud With Fox News
description: The Simpsons has certainly never been shy about biting the corporate hand that feeds it  witness the recent opening credit sequence of that Fox animated comedy, produced by Banksy, that imagined 20th Century Fox as a nightmarish third-world sweatshop.

title: As Penny-Pinchers Hover, Business Trips Rebound
description: THE annual Zagat survey of customer attitudes toward airline service came out on Monday and, as usual, some reviews are not good.

title: The Downside of Traveling With Stylish Jewelry
description: MY sister Jodie and I are always traveling for work. As jewelry designers, we need to go to a lot of shows. We cant pack lightly and usually bring about four suitcases filled with our work.

title: Moved by the Spirit: Celebrating Revelations at 50
description: Members of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater perform Revelations nearly as often as ordinary people brush their teeth. This magnificent work, created by Alvin Ailey in 1960, is a dance on land and in water, a journey through African-American spiritual music and, for dancers, an act of reverence for the generations that came before.

title: Farmers Find Organic Arsenal to Wage War on Pests
description: DAVIS, Calif.  Mark Van Horn, director of the student farm at the University of California, is nearly lost as he walks through a yellow cloud of wild sunflowers around the edge of a field of tomatoes and sweet corn.

title: G.M. Completes Sale of Parts Maker to China
description: General Motors said Monday that it had completed a deal to sell a subsidiary that makes power-steering components to an affiliate of the Beijing municipal government, The New York Times reports.

title: Adding Some Oddities to an Eccentric Rsum
description: Bob Saget is a kind of comedy X-Man: the peaceful human of Full House and Americas Funniest Home Videos who has transformed into the razor-clawed mutant of HBO specials and The Aristocrats.

title: Sit. Fetch. Heal. (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Greenpeace Sues Chemical Makers, Alleging Spy Effort
description: Contractors working for Dow Chemical and Sasol North America, a chemical manufacturer, hired private investigators to conduct a two-year corporate espionage campaign against the environmental group Greenpeace, according to a lawsuit filed on Monday in federal district court in Washington.

title: Stephen J. Solarz, Former N.Y. Congressman, Dies at 70
description: Stephen J. Solarz, a nine-term Democratic congressman whose concerns went beyond traffic lights and beach erosion in his Brooklyn district to nuclear weapons, the Middle East and his revelation that Imelda Marcos owned 3,000 pairs of shoes, died on Monday in Washington. He was 70 and lived in McLean, Va.

title: Q&A: Make Your Own Word Templates
description: Q.

description: WASHINGTON

title: The Peas and What Follows E.N.D.

title: A Towns Stop Signs Yield Legal Questions
description: CRANSTON, R.I.  What happens if stop signs, those unmistakable symbols of traffic laws, are themselves unlawful?

title: Barcelona 5, Real Madrid 0
description: Barcelona humbled Real Madrid, 5-0, in Mondays Clsico at the Camp Nou, a stunningly one-sided result to a game many had thought would be among the best played in Europe this year.

title: Kirk Adds to Republican Numbers in Senate
description: Make that 42: Mark S. Kirk of Illinois was sworn in to the Senate on Monday, boosting Republican numbers in the chamber as Congress slogs its way through a lame-duck session.

title: Next WikiLeaks Target: Big Business
description: DealBook has been admiring our Times colleagues States Secrets series, a collection of articles about the trove of American diplomatic cables that were originally obtained by WikiLeaks, the organization devoted to exposing state secrets.

title: Global Climate Change Talks Begin in Cancn
description: WASHINGTON  Global talks on climate change opened in Cancn, Mexico, on Monday with the toughest issues unresolved and little expectation of a breakthrough on shaping an international treaty to curb emissions of the heat-trapping gases linked to global warming.

title: Anticorruption Group Claims Harassment in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The head of the Pakistani branch of Transparency International, the global advocacy group that monitors corruption, has alleged intimidation and harassment by government officials for its monitoring of American aid in Pakistan.

title: Apollo Names Spilker President
description: Apollo Global Management has named Marc Spilker, a former Goldman Sachs Group executive, to the new position of president, as the private equity firm bolsters its management ranks to ready itself for life as a publicly traded company.

title: On Iraqi Television, Crying Out for the Missing
description: BAGHDAD  For an hour every Saturday, with a short break for the evening call to prayer, a modestly dressed woman appears on television here and takes phone calls from Iraqis whose relatives have vanished.

title: What The T.S.A. Hasnt Told Us
description: Despite widespread anticipation of chaos at airports over the Thanksgiving holiday weekend  some of it prompted by concerns that passengers would opt out of new full-body scans in favor of more time-consuming pat-downs  most media accounts suggested that travel went rather smoothly instead, with few passengers declining such screenings, and short waits at most airport security stations.

title: Rattner Assails Cuomo Offer
description: In a strongly worded, previously undisclosed correspondence, a lawyer for Steven L. Rattner, the financier ensnared in a wide-ranging investigation of suspected kickbacks, described a proposed payment of at least $20 million to the New York attorney general office as excessive, misconceived and wholly untethered from the facts in the case.

title: Bloggingheads: Palin's Feminism
description: Michelle Goldberg, left, of The Daily Beast and Rebecca Traister of Salon.com discuss Sarah Palin and gender.

title: Celebrating Secession Without the Slaves
description: ATLANTA  The Civil War, the most wrenching and bloody episode in American history, may not seem like much of a cause for celebration, especially in the South.

title: The Best of the Best, Digitally Speaking
description: AN organization that honors creativity in advertising has named 10 digital campaigns as the best in their field from 2001 from 2010.

title: In U.S. Sting Operations, Questions of Entrapment
description: WASHINGTON  The arrest on Friday of a Somali-born teenager who is accused of trying to detonate a car bomb at a crowded Christmas tree-lighting ceremony in Portland, Ore., has again thrown a spotlight on the governments use of sting operations to capture terrorism suspects.

title: An Enlightened Exchange in Iran
description: This is a story about a courageous policy in an unexpected place. In this place homeless shelters have vending machines selling clean syringes for injecting drugs. Drug users are not prosecuted as long as they are in treatment programs. Drug addicts are given clean needles and methadone maintenance therapy  available on a widespread basis even in prison. These tactics have worked to reduce crime, lower H.I.V. rates among drug users and keep AIDS from spreading out into the general population. The place is not Amsterdam. It is Tehran.

title: Senators Cannot Agree on Fix to the Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Monday failed to repeal an unpopular element of the health care overhaul even though Democrats and Republicans agreed it needed to be jettisoned to prevent businesses from being saddled with undue tax paperwork.

title: Acupuncturist Treats 40 N.F.L. Players in 4 Cities
description: Stretched out on a massage table in his Long Island City condominium, Jets fullback Tony Richardson closed his eyes. Over the next hour, he groaned and grimaced and eventually fell asleep, as Lisa Ripi, the traveling N.F.L. acupuncturist, went to work.

title: Justices to Assess Arizona Campaign Financing
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to hear a First Amendment challenge to an Arizona law that provides matching funds to candidates who accept public financing.

title: Enduring, Thriving, and Now a U.S. Citizen
description: When he was a child, Jin Zheng could not eat pizza without feeling sick.

title: With Starters Sitting Out, the Giants Try to Keep It Simple
description: Battling injuries in the receiving corps and on the offensive line, the Giants were forced to tweak their offense on Sunday against the Jacksonville Jaguars to smooth the transition for players thrust into leading roles, using simplified blocking and two-tight-end formations.

title: Fewer Millions for Jeter? Say It Aint So!
description: Heres this well-known, well-paid public figure, a proven leader, someone who is hugely admired by the mayor, a person who can boast of impressive accomplishments but who is ready for new challenges. Yet none of that has stifled a loud chorus of critics who insist that this solid record of achievement does not herald future success.

title: One State Takes a New Look at Causes of War
description: ATLANTA  The 150th anniversary of the Civil War is prompting some states to change the way they confront their unsettling past.

title: Just Tidbits, or Material Facts for Insider Trading?
description: On Wall Street, it is called the mosaic theory.

title: With Deal, Bloombergs Pick Wins Helm of City Schools
description: Cathleen P. Black, a publishing executive, won the helm of New York Citys public school system on Monday with a waiver from the state education commissioner that said her inexperience in education would be offset in part by the appointment of a chief academic officer to serve by her side.

title: Man Is Held in Larceny; Columbia Lost Millions
description: A Bronx man was indicted Monday on charges that he stole $5 million from Columbia University.

title: Drug Maker Hired Writing Company for Doctors Book, Documents Say
description: Two prominent authors of a 1999 book teaching family doctors how to treat psychiatric disorders provided acknowledgment in the preface for an unrestricted educational grant from a major pharmaceutical company.

title: Report Questions Need for 2 Diet Supplements
description: The very high levels of vitamin D that are often recommended by doctors and testing laboratories  and can be achieved only by taking supplements  are unnecessary and could be harmful, an expert committee says. It also concludes that calcium supplements are not needed.

title: Rangers, in Need of a Catcher, Sign Torrealba
description: Pitcher Javier Vazquez and the Florida Marlins have agreed to terms on a one-year, $7 million contract. The deal is subject to Vazquezs passing a physical. Vazquez, a 34-year-old right-hander, was 10-10 with a 5.32 earned run average in 2010 for the Yankees, who acquired him from Atlanta in the deal for Melky Cabrera. The Yankees will receive a draft pick as compensation next June.

title: At 41, Defying Age and Batters
description: Age beats everybody, eventually. The only question is when. Trevor Hoffman turned 41 just after the 2008 season, and the San Diego Padres let him go. He signed a two-year deal with the Milwaukee Brewers and made the All-Star team in the first year. Early in the 2010 season, he fell apart.

title: Wiretaps Said to Widen Insider Trading Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  Secret, court-approved wiretaps put in place more than two years ago are now being used by prosecutors in a widening inquiry of securities fraud and insider trading involving hedge funds and consultants that provide industry research, according to court documents and interviews with people close to the investigations.

title: Mario Monicelli, Italian Director, Dies at 95
description: Mario Monicelli, an enormously popular director and screenwriter whose bittersweet films, notably Big Deal on Madonna Street and The Great War, blended humor and tragedy to create a new genre known as Italian-style comedy, died on Monday in Rome. He was 95.

title: Hoping to Avoid Bombs and Win Afghan Minds
description: DEH-E KUCHAY, Afghanistan  For the American soldiers charged with bringing security to southern Afghanistan, heavily mined villages like this one are a most dangerous challenge.

title: A Footstep, Then an Explosion and an Urgent Call: Medic!
description: CHECKPOINT 16, Afghanistan  Joao Silva, a photographer for The New York Times, and I set out on patrol at 7 a.m. on Oct. 23 with a squad of 10 or 15 American soldiers and a unit of Afghan soldiers and police officers.

title: Entrapment Is Argued in Defense of Suspect
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Lawyers for Mohamed Osman Mohamud, the teenager accused of trying to detonate a bomb at a crowded Christmas tree-lighting ceremony here, suggested on Monday that the government might be manufacturing crime and accused the authorities of timing the plot for maximum publicity and effect.

title: Bob Wolff, at 90, a Strong, Steady Voice
description: Bob Wolff, thought to be the worlds oldest still-active sportscaster in the United States if not the known universe, turned 90 on Monday.

title: On Patrol in Kandahar
description: Soldiers patrolled Arghandab District of Kandahar Province, one of the most heavily mined areas of southern Afghanistan.

title: Baseball Asks Union for Explanation on Loans by Boras
description: Major League Baseball has sent a letter to the players union seeking an explanation for the tens of thousands of dollars in loans that Scott Boras, the sports most prominent agent, made to teenage Dominican prospects.

title: Construction Giant Admits Fraud Over Minority Firms
description: A heavy construction company that has been involved in some of New Yorks biggest infrastructure projects admitted on Monday that it had defrauded government programs for five years, and agreed to forfeit $20 million for crimes it committed while performing $691 million in public contracts.

title: Moses Last Exodus
description: Wilmington, Del., Nov. 30, 1860

title: Severity of Problems in Haiti Vote Is Disputed
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  With Haiti on edge after widespread reports of voting irregularities in its presidential election Sunday, the chief of a team of international election observers acknowledged the problems on Monday, but said they did not appear serious enough to invalidate the election.

title: Tuesday: William Tell Composer
The Diplomatic Cables, Secret No More
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets and Patriots Mind Their Manners
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  With the latest, greatest installment of the Jets-Patriots rivalry only a week away, linebacker Bart Scott remained on his best behavior Monday. Reporters asked him questions for more than 25 minutes, and throughout, Scott sounded more like a Patriot than a player modeled after Coach Rex Ryan.

title: Lottery Numbers
Where Anonymity Breeds Contempt
description: Palo Alto, Calif.

title: France: Terrorism Suspect Is Extradited From Italy
description: A French citizen of Algerian descent who was arrested recently in southern Italy while carrying bomb-making materials was extradited to France on Monday, judicial officials said. The suspect, Ryad Hannouni, had been taken into custody after returning from the war zone around the border between Pakistan and Afghanistan. He was accused by French authorities of participation in criminal networks aimed at supplying jihad in the Pakistani-Afghan zone, and appeared later Monday before a French antiterrorist magistrate for questioning. Mr. Hannounis arrest last month near the central train station in Naples was followed by the arrests of 12 people in southern France in what the French Interior Ministry said was part of a campaign against terrorism.

title: Gil McDougald, Ex-Yankee, Dies at 82
description: Gil McDougald, the Yankees versatile All-Star infielder who played on five World Series championship teams but was remembered as well for a single at-bat resulting in one of baseballs most frightening moments, died Sunday at his home in Wall Township, N.J. He was 82.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,390 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Wisconsin Gunman Shoots Himself After Standoff
description: CHICAGO  A student armed with a handgun held 23 other students and a teacher hostage for several hours on Monday before shooting himself at a high school in Marinette, Wis., which borders the Upper Peninsula of Michigan, the authorities said.

title: Crosbys Assist Helps Penguins Top Rangers
description: Fifteen minutes into Pittsburghs 3-1 victory over the Rangers at Madison Square Garden on Monday night, Ryan Callahan was tangled up with Sidney Crosby away from the puck, and they both fell to the ice.

title: Massachusetts: Oxford Scientist Is Expected to Lead Tufts
description: Tufts University is expected to announce on Tuesday that it has appointed as its president Anthony P. Monaco, an American-born neuroscientist who has spent the last two decades at the University of Oxford in England. Dr. Monacos research has focused on the genetic basis of autism, language impairment and dyslexia. A native of Wilmington, Del., he received his bachelors degree at Princeton, and his M.D. and Ph.D. at Harvard. He would succeed Lawrence S. Bacow, who announced in February that he would stop down as president after 10 years.

title: An Inspector General Is Leaving
description: After a decade as the inspector general of the Justice Department, Glenn A. Fine told President Obama and Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Monday that he would step down at the end of January. In letters to the two men, Mr. Fine said, It is time for me to pursue new professional challenges. He had already served about five years in the office of the inspector general when President Bill Clinton appointed him to become its top official in 2000. His office attracted particularly widespread attention for its investigations during the Bush administration  including documenting politicized hiring practices in the departments Civil Rights Division and the circumstances behind the firing of nine United States attorneys in 2006.

title: Using World Cup Veterans, Barcelona Routs Its Rival
description: LONDON  In the summer, they were friends. But come winter, the seven Barcelona players who won the World Cup with Spain have dealt ruthlessly with the three Real Madrid teammates with whom they shared that triumph.

title: Dreaming of Reform
description: The Dream Act, the immigration bill that opens a path to legalization for undocumented young people who go to college or serve in the military, has a shot at passing the lame-duck Congress. Not a clear or sure shot, given the danger of Republican filibustering and Democratic wobbliness, but a shot.

title: Night Vision
description: I pull into the farm from the city. It is early in the evening but well after nightfall, and the moon hangs over the hills like a hypnotists watch. I drop a few things in the house and then wander out to check on the animals.

title: The Public School Bargain
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg avoided a dispute that would have paralyzed New York Citys school system when he agreed to appoint a career educator to serve as second in command to his pick for schools chancellor, Cathleen Black. Her lack of education experience had made it almost certain that the state education commissioner would veto her appointment. Ms. Blacks chief academic officer will be Shael Polakow-Suransky, a respected, hard-driving educator who has worked his way from middle school math teacher, to high school principal, to his most recent post as the school systems accountability officer.

title: WikiLeaks and the Diplomats
description: The business of diplomacy is often messy and when private communications become public, it can also be highly embarrassing.

title: AIDS in South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: How U.S. Can Help Iraq at the U.N.: An Envoys View
description: To the Editor:

title: Broken Beyond Repair
description: You can only hope that you will be as sharp and intellectually focused as former Supreme Court Justice John Paul Stevens when youre 90 years old.

title: The Fragile Community
description: Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, had moved 37 times by the time he reached his 14th birthday. His mother didnt enroll him in the local schools because, as Raffi Khatchadourian wrote in a New Yorker profile, she feared that formal education would inculcate an unhealthy respect for authority.

title: Winters Bone Dominates at Gothams
description: True to form, the Gotham Independent Film Awards remained scrappy and unpredictable, awarding its biggest prizes Monday night to Winters Bone. Debra Graniks film, a drama about an Ozark family, won awards for best feature and best ensemble performance.

title: James and His Coach Deny a Rift
description: MIAMI  LeBron James and Miami Heat Coach Erik Spoelstra might have literally clashed  biceps to shoulder, presumably accidentally  but they say they are not otherwise at odds.

title: Bella Akhmadulina, Bold Voice in Russian Poetry, Dies at 73
description: Bella Akhmadulina, a poet whose startling images and intensely personal style, couched in classical verse forms, established her as one of the Soviet Unions leading literary talents, died on Monday at her home in Peredelkino, outside Moscow. She was 73.

title: At Vanderbilt, Much To Be Thankful For
description: This Thanksgiving was a particularly special one for the Vanderbilt basketball team. It marked the first time in four years that we were actually able to spend Thanksgiving in Nashville and enjoy a traditional home-cooked holiday meal. Weve had dinners on Thanksgiving before, but none like this. We starved ourselves for 24 hours beforehand and showed up to Coachs house Joey Tribbiani style, in our maternity elastic-waistband pants. Then, of course, as we lay on the couch in a food coma, we reflected on the great things in our lives that we were thankful for.

title: Lawmakers Resist Patersons Spending Cuts
description: ALBANY  Lawmakers who gathered here for a special session appeared almost certain on Monday night to set aside a package of spending cuts proposed by Gov. David A. Paterson, leaving this years state budget hundreds of millions of dollars out of balance as the governor-elect, Andrew M. Cuomo, prepares to take office on Jan. 1.

title: Ryan Seacrest and Clear Channel in Expanded Radio Deal
description: LOS ANGELES  Clear Channel Communications is expected to announce on Tuesday that it has signed Ryan Seacrest to an expanded radio deal worth $60 million over three years, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

title: Levine and Berlioz on Tanglewood Slate
description: James Levine, who returned to conducting this season after back surgery, plans to lead the Boston Symphony Orchestra in performances of the Berlioz Requiem and Mahlers Symphony No. 5, along with a student performance of Debussys opera Pellas et Mlisande at the Tanglewood music festival next summer, officials there said on Monday. Mr. Levine is the music director of the Boston Symphony, which takes up a summer residence at Tanglewood, in Lenox, Mass. Mr. Levine will also conduct all-Italian, all-Ravel and all-Sibelius programs. The festival, which runs from June 28 to Sept. 4 and brings in young musicians as students, will include appearances by Lorin Maazel, Yo-Yo Ma, Rafael Frhbeck de Burgos, Susan Graham, Joshua Bell and James Taylor. The Mark Morris Dance Group will also present a new work.

title: A Facebook Founder Begins a Social Network Focused on Charities
description: Chris Hughes, one of the founders of Facebook and the chief digital organizer for Barack Obamas presidential campaign, knows a thing or two about building online communities.

title: U.S. School Graduation Rate Is Rising
description: The nations high school graduation rate, which declined in the latter part of the 20th century, may have hit bottom and begun to rise, according to a report to be issued Tuesday by a nonprofit group founded by former Secretary of State Colin L. Powell.

title: Word of the Day | crotchety
description: crotchety \kr-ch-te\ adjective

title: Photo Replay: Nov. 29
description: The day in sports included a big soccer game in Barcelona and a somber event in Montreal.

title: Corrections
description: NEW YORK

title: Mets Murphy and Martinez Are Hurt Again
description: Daniel Murphy and Fernando Martinez of the Mets are injured again, and both returned to New York on Sunday to undergo examinations at the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan.

title: Google Is Said to Be Poised to Buy Groupon
description: Google is near a deal to acquire Groupon, the pioneering online discounter, for as much as $6 billion, people with direct knowledge of the matter told DealBook on Monday.

title: News Quiz | November 30, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Marlins Agree to Terms with Vazquez
description: Pitcher Javier Vazquez and the Florida Marlins have agreed to terms on a one-year, $7 million contract. The deal is subject to Vazquezs passing a physical. Vazquez, a 34-year-old right-hander, was 10-10 with a 5.32 earned run average in 2010 for the Yankees, who acquired him from Atlanta in the deal for Melky Cabrera. The Yankees will receive a draft pick as compensation next June.

title: U.S. and South Korea Balk at Talks With North
description: WASHINGTON  The United States, South Korea and Japan are all balking at Chinas request for emergency talks with North Korea over the crisis on the Korean Peninsula, as high-profile military exercises between South Korea and the United States in the Yellow Sea continued on Monday in a show of force.

title: Test Yourself | English, Nov. 30, 2010
description: Test your reading skills with todays question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the article No Boo-boos or Cowlicks? Only in School Pictures.

title: Who Are Your Favorite Comedians?
description: Comic actor Leslie Nielsen, star of the Airplane movies and Naked Gun series, died on Sunday. Have you seen any of his work? What are your favorite lines or moments? Who are your favorite comedians, or comic actors, in general? Why?

title: ABB to Buy Baldor for $3.1 Billion
description: Wolfgang von Brauchitsch/Bloomberg NewsWorkers at an ABB plant

title: Daily Lexeme: Nod-Crafty
description: Todays word, in association with the meritorious Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Arman Show in Paris Puts Spotlight on Everyday Objects
description: If you spot collections of shoes, saws, dentures, broken-down bikes and a life-size car hanging on the walls of the Pompidou Center in Paris, dont be surprised. Its all part of a retrospective of the artist known as Arman, who had a lifelong preoccupation with objects.

title: The Early Word: Pay Freeze
description: From Todays Times:

title: A Winning Economic Strategy for the G.O.P.
description: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard and the author of the forthcoming book Triumph of the City.

title: Analyzing the Five New  Candidates for Canton
description: A few comments on the five players who are in their first year of eligibility as semifinalists for the Hall of Fame class of 2011:

title: Europe Opens Antitrust Inquiry Into Google
description: BRUSSELS  Europe opened a formal antitrust investigation on Tuesday into accusations that Google had abused its dominance in online search, exposing the companys zealously guarded technology to unwelcome scrutiny.

title: Q&A: Picture Editing Outside the Photo Booth
description: Q.

title: First the Rain, Then the Rain of Insects
description: Thursday, Nov. 25

title: Is Consumer Panel Arbitrarily Funded?
description: Banks arent the only ones anxious about the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

title: Is Real Estate on Sale?
description: A friend of mine told me that his landlord was trying to raise his commercial rent from $3.25 to $5 per square foot per year. I was surprised, because most people I know are either having their rent reduced or at least frozen. My friend explained that he really didnt want to move his company because the location was convenient for him and for his employees.

title: Winning Over Shareholders to the Management-Led Buyout
description: To win over an audience, performers are advised to make em laugh.

title: Unemployment Rises in Europe
description: Unemployment in the euro zone rose in October to its highest level in more than 12 years, an official report showed Tuesday.

title: Calls Grow for FIFA to Delay World Cup Vote
description: Continued allegations of corruption involving top officials at FIFA, soccers world governing body, have called into question the integrity of Thursdays votes that will decide the host countries for the 2018 and 2022 World Cup tournaments  the latter of which is being sought by the United States.

title: Describing Orientation
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: Describing Orientation
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: Mr. Obama and the G.O.P. Meet
description: The shotgun marriage between President Obama and Congressional Republicans officially begins Tuesday morning, when emboldened Republicans and wounded Democrats take their seats in the Roosevelt Room of the White House for their first face-to-face meeting since the midterm elections changed the balance of power in Washington.

title: 2022 World Cup Decision: Play It Safe, or Risky?
description: London

title: 2 Republicans Hint at Hope for Russia Pact
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas hopes of winning Senate approval for a new arms control treaty with Russia by the end of the year were encouraged on Tuesday by two Republican senators, including John McCain.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Nomura is building its proprietary trading desk, not selling it.

title: Wall Street Shares Decline Again
description: Stocks on Wall Street declined on Tuesday as well as for the month of November as concerns over Europes financial health lingered.

title: Quantifying the Importance of Jets-Patriots
description: Chase Stuart contributes to the Pro-Football-Reference.com blog and to Footballguys.com.

title: Now Showing | I Saloni Milano
description: This week marks the start of a six-week program in New York that celebrates Italian design and culture. I Saloni Milano, or the Milan Furniture Fair  sponsored by Federlegno Arredo, an Italian federation of wood and cork furnishings manufacturers; Cosmit, the fair organizer; the Italian Trade Commission; and the Italian Ministry of Economic Development  includes events at 20 Italian furniture showrooms until Jan. 8, as well as two special installations. On Monday night, Perchance to Dream, an exhibition by the artist and director Robert Wilson, opens at Center 548 in Chelsea, where it will run through Dec. 18. In the exhibition, Wilson has installed his video portrait of the Italian ballet star Roberto Bolle on 31 screens in seven different rooms, through which are interspersed pieces of Italian furniture that Wilson chose for their form, shape, color and shadows.

title: Where Does That Starbucks Cup Go?
description: So when you finish drinking that Starbucks coffee and toss the cup into the trash or even the recycling bin, what happens to it?

title: The Italian Job
description: OK, folks, this is getting really serious. Spain is bad enough, but Italy

title: Date Set for Nuclear Talks With Iran
description: TEHRAN  Iran and the European Union agreed Tuesday on a date for nuclear talks in Geneva next week, but President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad insisted in a speech that Iran would not give one iota in the discussions.

title: JAccuse! Craig Ferguson Meets an Ardent French Admirer
description: If youre an American talk-show host who discovers your late-night program in Los Angeles is being copied by an imitator nearly 6,000 miles away in Paris, your avenues of recourse would seem to be limited. You could write threatening letters in hopes that your doppelganger finds new material, or you could just grin and bear it. Or you could do what Craig Ferguson did and invite your copycat onto your show.

title: Learned Helplessness
description: This WSJ article about economists in search of a model takes it as given that all our models have failed completely in the crisis  which is a gross exaggeration.

title: China Bars U.S. From American Geologists Appeal
description: BEIJING  The United States Embassy was denied access to an appeal hearing for an American geologist sentenced in July to eight years in prison for buying a database on Chinas oil industry, an American official said here Tuesday.

title: Air Products Extends Offer for Airgas
description: The takeover battle for Airgas will continue to run on as both sides await a decision from the Delaware Chancery Court on the companys poison pill.

title: The Graying Work Force
description: My 73-year-old father is retired, sort of. He works as a greeter in a grocery store in Calgary, Alberta, juggling shifts at work with caring for my young niece, who stays with my parents after school until my sister finishes work. Youve likely seen someone like him in action  an elderly man or woman who says hello when you walk in, steers you to the right aisle and wishes you good day on your way out.

title: For Fannie, a Glimmer of Light in the Gloom
description: The housing market just earned a much-needed moral victory. Although more than 4 percent of loans held by Fannie Mae are still delinquent, the rate declined recently as banks and the government refined their foreclosure prevention programs, Fannies monthly housing summary showed.

title: Chancellor Appointee Gets Her  Waiver
description: Tuesday will be mild with highs in the 50s and a 50 percent chance of rain from the leaden skies. Brace yourselves for the storm headed our way.

title: A Celebration of Indie Film, Uninhibited
description: Independent film as salvation: that was the message of the annual Gotham Independent Film Awards on Monday night. Patricia Clarkson, a host, called out the director Lisa Cholodenko (The Kids Are All Right) for saving her from a lifetime of playing plucky friends and long-suffering girlfriends and mothers. She cast me as a German lesbian heroin addict in High Art, Ms. Clarkson said. Anne Hathaway, presenting an award to James Schamus, the chief executive of Focus Features, thanked him for changing her career path via Brokeback Mountain. Dont get me wrong, I loved playing princesses, she added, before praising Mr. Schamus for running a studio with spine, although she used a different, rather unprincessy anatomical word. (Mr. Schamus, a professor as well as a film executive, used a dry erase board and a philosophical metaphor during his acceptance speech.)

title: Wanderlust | Hamburg
description: In the last few years, the Karolinenviertel neighborhood has gone the way of many other former industrial enclaves  the meatpacking plant has morphed into galleries and cafes and the front windows of old tenement buildings now gleam with merchandise. But this being a microhood within the citys scruffy St. Pauli district (home also to one of Europes legendary red-light districts), Karolinens new coffee bars and design studios are cheek by jowl with punk hangouts and anarchist graffiti. It may be gentrified but its not glossed over.

title: Senate Defeats Earmark Ban
description: The Senate on Tuesday defeated a proposed ban on the lawmaker-directed spending items known as earmarks.

title: When Redesigning the Taxi, Dont Forget Roof Romance
description: Looking for a new single taxi design to replace the jumble of models now on the street, the Taxi and Limousine Commissions Taxi of Tomorrow competition is down to three finalists chosen from a larger group of contenders. One is based on a Nissan van, another on the Ford Transit Connect and the third one a model from Karsan, a Turkish company. Factors to be considered in the final decision, says the mayors office and the commission, are space, safety, energy efficiency and access.

title: The Nutcracker Chronicles: Where the Wild Sugar Plums Are
description: SEATTLE  One artificial Christmas tree, in lights, beams from the top of the Space Needle here; a real one stands in the foyer of the nearby Marion Oliver McCaw Hall, where Pacific Northwest Ballets Nutcracker is playing. Theres snow on the Cascade Mountains, and apparently the city ground to a halt last week with three inches of snow, now vanished. You dont need to know much about The Nutcracker to know that these things are fitting.

title: People You Dont Want to Friend on Facebook
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously offered their definitions of family.

title: On Our Radar: Senators Seek Extension of Clean Power Grants
description: A group of 26 senators have called for the extension of a renewable power grant program created by the 2009 stimulus law, which they describe as an effective job-creation tool. In a letter Monday to leaders of both parties, the 25 Democrats and one Republican requested a two-year extension of the program, which provides direct cash grants to renewable energy developers in lieu of tax credits, which have become difficult to use during the economic downturn. [The Hill]

title: Updates on Leak of U.S. Cables, Day 3
description: On Tuesday, The Lede continued to update readers on the global conversation about more than 250,000 American diplomatic cables released by WikiLeaks, the whistle-blowers Web site. (For updates on the conversation so far, see our two previous live-blog posts.)

title: Tuesday Reading: A Federal Pay Freeze
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Do Zombies Eat Ivy? The Undead Reach Academia
description: There is a zombie survival guide and a zombie etiquette guide, a best-selling version of Pride and Prejudice with zombies (soon to be a major motion picture), a collection of Zombie Haiku, at least two zombie-themed television series and, in time for the holidays, a book of zombie Christmas carols.

title: Investigation Finds FEMA Improperly Awarded Grant to Acorn Affiliate
description: The Federal Emergency Management Agency improperly awarded a $450,000 grant for fire safety and prevention to a New Orleans affiliate of Acorn, the embattled community organizing group, according to an investigation by the inspector general for the Department of Homeland Security.

title: Senate Passes Sweeping Law on Food Safety
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate passed a sweeping overhaul of the nations food safety system on Tuesday, after tainted eggs, peanut butter and spinach sickened thousands of people in the last few years and led major food makers to join consumer advocates in demanding stronger government oversight.

title: Hit No. 3,000: A Moment Finally Tailor-Made for Pinstripes
description: All of the contentiousness surrounding Derek Jeters contract negotiations with the Yankees has now inspired a card-collecting blog to depict him in the uniforms of the other 29 major league teams. Wonder no more how Jeter would look with a Braves tomahawk on his chest, or a Chief Wahoo adorning his cap, or in the red pinstripes of the Phillies.

title: Talking Tough and Drawing Viewers, Christie Is a YouTube Star
description: A little shaky, the camera shows Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey shedding his sport coat at a town-hall-style meeting as a teacher criticizes what she sees as his attacks on her profession. He begins to respond, the woman tosses her head in frustration, and Mr. Christie goes for the jugular.

title: CBS News Is Replacing Its Early Show Anchor Lineup
description: 8:16 p.m. | Updated

title: More Green Days at the Box Office? Billie Joe Armstrong Returning to American Idiot
description: 11:00 a.m. | Updated

title: Ristretto | The Kone
description: Of all the shiny objects I saw at WTF Espresso Bar, a tricked-out coffee shop that opened last month in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, the gadget that caught my eye was a filter cone made out of perforated stainless steel. It was sitting in a Chemex brewer, which looked significantly more awesome when equipped with a metal filter that could draw blood. It was a Kone, a reusable filter developed by Keith Gehrke of Coava, a small-batch coffee roaster in Portland, Ore.

title: The East Just Got Bigger
description: Today we have decided to begin a nationwide effort to rename all of the college conferences in response to the latest geographical absurdity that is Texas Christian University joining the Big East. It is not the first absurdity, geographical or otherwise, in college powers continuing game of Risk, of course, and it wont be the last. But it seems like a good time to give one last flush to the notion of tradition and make a statement for truth in advertising. The Big East, for example, could now be called the Saving Ourselves from B.C.S. Obscurity Because Notre Dame Wont Love Us Conference, although we do admit thats a bit unwieldy in a logo.

title: Handicapping the Oscar Hosts Oscar Chances
description: With the news Monday that James Franco and Anne Hathaway would be hosting the Oscars, award savants immediately began speculating on whether it would help or hurt the actors own statuette chances. Mr. Franco is a likely nominee for his role as the wounded hiker Aron Ralston in 127 Hours, a title which could also be milked for the this awards show is sooo long jokes (paging Bruce Vilanch!). Ms. Hathaway has a longer shot for playing a lusty Parkinsons patient in Love and Other Drugs, an Edward Zwick dramedy which performed poorly at the box office in its opening weekend.

title: Hey, Some Friars Members Are Younger Than the Jokes
description: For years, one of the funniest lines associated with the Friars Club, the legendary fraternal organization in New York that has catered to people in the entertainment industry for 106 years, was about itself.

title: Cures for a Dawdling Child?
description: A morning routine is an intricate and delicate thing. One misstep and the whole structure comes crashing to the ground, an implosion of backpacks and lunch bags and permission slips and Mommys train schedule and Daddys keys.

title: Off the Menu: Octavias Porch
description: Octavia Menu

title: On Senate Floor, McCain Praises Feingold
description: Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, did not spend a lot of time during his recent re-election campaign talking up the McCain-Feingold Act. The tough campaign finance legislation, which he sponsored in 2002 with a Democratic colleague, Senator Russell Feingold of Wisconsin, is unpopular with many conservative Republicans, and they have heaped scorn on Mr. McCain for his role in it ever since.

title: New Education Chief Visits Bronx School
description: In her first public appearance since receiving a waiver from the state, the schools chancellor designee, Cathleen P. Black, greeted a student at Public School 109 in the Bronx on Tuesday morning as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and other officials looked on.

title: Off the Menu: Porsena
description: Porsena Menu

title: The Spirit Awards and Oscar Tea Leaves
description: Winters Bone, Black Swan, 127 Hours and The Kids Are All Right were the big names recognized by Film Independents Spirit Awards, which announced their nominees today. Each got nods for best feature, best director, and some acting categories. Greenberg rounded out the list of best features, while John Cameron Mitchell earned a best director spot for Rabbit Hole, a wrenching story of a couple  Aaron Eckhart and Nicole Kidman  trying to cope after the death of their child. Ms. Kidman and Mr. Eckhart were also nominated as featured actors.

title: Vain Glorious | Creeds Spice and Wood
description: What: Spice and Wood, the latest fragrance from Creed.

title: The Nutcracker Chronicles: Clara in the Rockies
description: DENVER  The Colorado Ballet program has a Did You Know? checklist of five points about The Nutcracker. I was aware of only two. Well, I wish Id known when I was in Washington State that the Bavarian Village of Leavenworth there has a Nutcracker Museum with a collection of thousands. Its also good to learn that the ability of nutcrackers to crack nuts is based on the physics of Archimedes lever and moments of force. And Im happy to discover that the nutcracker is also a bird related to the jay and the crow, known in America as Clarks Nutcracker.

title: Savoring a Few Lasts, Amid a Flurry of Firsts
description: As we coast into the midpoint of Nicoles senior year in high school, it seems theres been a new and frequent focus on her last, well, everything. Her last Halloween in our pumpkin-laden town; her last birthday here at home (she turned 17 two weeks ago); her last Thanksgiving meal before leaving for college.

title: How to Improve Your Financial Willpower
description: Ramit Sethi runs the Web site I Will Teach You to Be Rich.

title: Health Dept. Puts Up Holiday Anti-Drinking Decorations
description: Just in time for the Holiday Binge season (less than 29 hours till Hanukkah!), the city health department has given us the gift of a highly visual public information campaign, this one about the dangers of excessive drinking, which the department recently linked to fully one-tenth of all hospitalizations and 3 percent of emergency-room visits in the city, as well as about 1,500 deaths per year.

title: First Seas, Now Trees, Added to Googles Earth
description: Last year, Google filled in the big blue blank spot on its online replica of the Earth with three-dimensional oceans. Whether theyll help inspire people to take care of the real oceans remains unclear, but it cant hurt. Now the company, in the latest iteration of Google Earth, is filling in some of the vast green blotches with three-dimensional trees.

title: What Were Reading
description: The New York Times: The senate passes an overhaul of food safety regulations.  Samantha Storey

title: Poll: Low Expectations for Tuesdays White House Meeting
description: A recent poll suggests that the public has low expectations for the bipartisan meeting at the White House on Tuesday morning. A broad majority of voters want Congressional Republicans to compromise with President Obama and other Democrats in order to get things done, but few think that will actually happen.

title: Europe Threatens Inquiry Into Phone and Cable Fees
description: BERLIN  The European Unions telecommunications commissioner on Tuesday threatened to crack down on member countries that allow powerful former telephone monopolies to charge steep fees that raise costs to consumers.

title: N.Y. Assembly Approves Fracking Moratorium
description: The New York State Assembly voted 93 to 43 Monday night to place a temporary moratorium on a controversial type of natural gas exploration that combines hydraulic fracturing with horizontal drilling. The goal is to give the state more time to address safety and environmental concerns.

title: Insect Metaphor Leads to Bad Sex-Writing Prize
description: The good news for Rowan Somerville: his novel The Shape of Her has just picked up a literary award that puts him in the company of previous winners like Norman Mailer, Tom Wolfe and Sebastian Faulks while vaulting him ahead of fellow nominees like Jonathan Franzen. The not-so-good news: he has won the 2010 Bad Sex in Fiction Award, a (dis)honor bestowed annually by the British publication Literary Review.

title: Heatley and James: Two Sports, Two Returning Villains
description: LeBron James and Dany Heatley have a lot in common. Both lead their teams to their first conference finals appearance last spring. Both shocked the sports world with the way they orchestrated their departures. And both are now hated by the former fans that they spurned.

title: A Taxi Roof With a View
description: Looking for a new single taxi design to replace the jumble of models now on the street, the Taxi and Limousine Commissions Taxi of Tomorrow competition is down to three finalists chosen from a larger group of contenders. Taxi buffs and historians, however, are also looking to past taxis as inspiration and asking for a touch of romance: a roof with a view.

title: A Failure of Care in Mexico
description: Randal C. Archibold goes inside two failing mental health facilities in Mexico City.

title: How Partisanship Works
description: After reading thoughtful critiques of my most recent column from  Jim Fallows and Daniel Larison, I think I should clarify exactly how I think the influence of partisanship on political opinions tends to manifest itself.

title: Abuses Found at Mexican Institutions for Disabled
description: MEXICO CITY  Ten years ago, a human rights group released a scathing, groundbreaking report on abusive, decrepit conditions in Mexican institutions for the mentally and physically disabled, moving the country to promise change and to take the lead in writing international agreements to protect the disabled.

title: A.I.G. Plans First Bond Sale Since Crisis
description: 6:41 p.m. | Updated A.I.G. will sell about $2 billion worth of bonds in its first debt offering since the financial crisis.

title: 2 Sides Clash in Trial Over Goldman Trading Code
description: Is Sergey Aleynikov an evil computer scientist who brazenly stole valuable, closely guarded trading code from Goldman Sachs, his former employer?

title: Nets Latest Sponsor Lights Up for Russia
description: Its been years since fans have been able to smoke in N.B.A. arenas, but that hasnt stopped the Nets from selling a sponsorship to Zippo, makers of Americas most iconic lighters.

title: Merck Appoints a New Chief Executive
description: Kenneth C. Frazier, the president of Merck, is to become chief executive of the pharmaceutical giant at the beginning of next year, the company said Tuesday.

title: States Secrets: Teaching About WikiLeaks
description: A huge trove of confidential diplomatic cables  some 250,000 individual cables, the daily traffic between the State Department and more than 270 American diplomatic outposts around the world  were obtained by an organization called WikiLeaks and made available to several news organizations, including The New York Times. The Times began publication of articles based on the cables online on Sunday.

title: Citigroups Top Lobbyist Steps Down
description: 1:08 p.m. | Updated After seven tumultuous years as head of Citigroups government affairs group, Nicholas Calio is stepping down to become the chief lobbyist for the airline industry.

title: Senator Murray to Head Democratic Campaign Committee
description: Senator Patty Murray of Washington, the chambers No. 4 Democrat, will become chairwoman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee for the 2012 elections, taking on a steep challenge as her party seeks to defend more than twice as many seats as Republicans.

title: TimesCast | November 30, 2010
description: Executive Editor Bill Keller discusses the reaction to the leaked diplomatic cables; a report on living conditions of Mexico's  mentally disabled; and encouraging physical fitness for infants.

title: Q&A: The Galpagos for Christmas, With Children
description: I have two kids, 7 and 11, and were looking for a fun holiday over Christmas break, somewhere hot. Im thinking of the Galpagos or Costa Rica or anywhere in South America, as weve never been. Think these can be combined? Do you know a good travel agent and good hotels?

title: Shop, China, Shop
description: Ms. Li could never shop at Louis Vuitton. Shaking her head, the 50-year-old woman watched customers in one of Beijings fanciest malls glide past a velvet rope into the French fashion houses three-level store, where top-end handbags sell for more than twice Chinas per-capita annual income. Her problem, Li told me, wasnt that she was too poor, but too chic. Even common people have L.V. bags these days, said Li, who owns a hotel in Chinas northeast. Li chose what she considered a tasteful gift for the young man who accompanied her in the mall that afternoon: a $2,400 Prada bag. This was a mere trifle compared with the haul of Tian Mingqiao, a 38-year-old iron-ore importer I met later that day. Nodding toward his companion, who was laden with shopping bags, the plump businessman in a velvet blue blazer said that he had just dropped $8,000 on shoes and clothing. A special occasion? No, he said, I just had some free time.

title: Global Puck: Silver (or Gold) Lining for Brodeur?
description: Devils goalie Martin Brodeur made his N.H.L. debut on March 26, 1992, a year known in political circles for Queen Elizabeths famous annus horribilis speech that Christmas, a speech that looks increasingly applicable to Brodeurs 2010-11 season.

title: Quirky Tram Runs Again, Delighting Its Riders
description: In moments real and imagined, the Roosevelt Island Tramway can seem like a fragile way to get around town. In 2006, it left passengers stranded hundreds of feet in the air above the East River for as long as 10 hours; in the movies, it has a tendency to be hijacked by supervillains.

title: Scottsboro Boys to Close on Dec. 12
description: The Scottsboro Boys has become the first new commercial musical of the Broadway season to fall at the box office. The producers said on Tuesday that Scottsboro, which set the infamous 1930s Alabama rape trials to music and presented them subversively in the form of a minstrel show, would close on Sunday, Dec. 12, after 29 previews and 49 regular performances.

title: Week 13 in Fantasy Football: The Waiver Wire
description: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 13. Check back on Thursday for their weekly matchup analysis and their reader Q. & A. and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

title: Earthquake Off Long Island. I Felt It. Did You?
description: At first I felt a slight bouncy sensation, the kind of thing you could easily dismiss. Then it came again, a bit stronger this time, with an audible rattling of my desk and chair, before it petered out. The whole thing lasted maybe five seconds.

title: Toyota to Replace Coolant Pump in 390,000 Priuses in North America
description: Toyota announced Tuesday that it was replacing the coolant pumps on 650,000 Prius hybrids worldwide, The Associated Press reported. But the automaker has stopped short of calling the action a recall.

title: Jets Holmes Becomes a Game Changer
description: Florham Park, N.J.

title: States See a Rebound in Tax Receipts
description: In another sign that financial comparisons with 2009 will make almost anyone look good, state tax revenues in the third quarter were up 2.6 percent in inflation-adjusted terms compared with last year.

title: Obama Has Always Been At War With Eastasia
description: The organization formerly known as Obama for America is asking supporters to write letters in support of a federal pay freeze.

title: Keeping It Clean
description: Just a reminder  this is a Times blog, so obscenities  even mild ones that you use all the, um, fleeting time  will get your comment deleted.

title: Another Collapse at Pompeii Renews Calls for Better Care
description: ROME  Less than a month after Pompeiis so-called House of Gladiators collapsed into rubble, portions of a garden wall at the nearby House of the Moralist fell down on Tuesday, prompting new calls to better safeguard the city buried by an eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 A.D.

title: G.M. to Hire 1,000 to Engineer More Electric Cars
description: DETROIT  General Motors is adding 1,000 jobs in Michigan to develop more electric and hybrid vehicles similar to the Chevrolet Volt, which it officially introduced on Tuesday, the company said.

title: California Versus Spain
description: One commenter asks why the arguments for an independent Spanish currency dont apply equally to, say, California. See earlier post.

title: Phantom Twin
description: I dont like losing things. I keep a list of books I know I once had, and know Ive read, that I have somehow misplaced; The Magic Mountain, Loren Eiseleys The Star Thrower, The Complete Claudine by Colette are on it, along with at least 40 other titles. Even when I lose a pair of pants, a sense of vexation, a confusion arises in me that seems out of all proportion to the loss, and if the pants are suddenly presented to me apologetically at the dry cleaners I feel a strange giddiness, a tincture of the kind of joy displayed by reunited families in movies about Mormon heaven. It is strange that in this world in which everything is sooner or later lost, where losing is the only certainty, one gets attached to even the smallest things and wants to be able to say goodbye even to a pair of pants, rather than have it simply disappear. One wants to see a logic in disappearances, and to know when one is losing things. Even if, in the end, we get to keep nothing.

title: White House Meeting Ends in Kind Words but No Deals
description: President Obama and Republican Congressional leaders emerged from a high-profile, post-election meeting on Tuesday with gracious words and pledges of cooperation but no concrete agreements on the fiscal and national security issues that divide them.

title: Pass the Hairspray, Fight AIDS
description: Remember the old slogan for Clairol hair coloring, Only her hairdresser knows for sure? A campaign to help fight AIDS, which is to get under way on Tuesday, is based on the idea of hairdressers imparting to customers their knowledge of preventing the spread of H.I.V., which causes AIDS.

title: Miami and the Price of Anarchy
description: When utilized to its full potential, the pick-and-roll is not only among the most fluid and glorious displays of coordinated movement that the game of basketball has to offer, but also among the most potent. When operated by skilled practitioners, the pick-and-roll is a simple sequence with seemingly unlimited potential, so much so that defenders versed in limiting the pick-and-rolls options are worth their weight in gold in todays N.B.A. The various offensive systems in the league may stem from vastly different philosophies, but the pick-and-roll is something of a universal  a commonality too obvious, accessible, and useful for any scheme to ignore.

title: Isherwoods Singular Second Wind
description: I shall make a terrible old man, I fear, the English-American novelist Christopher Isherwood confided to his diary during the summer of 1961. He was only 56, but his fading looks and fear of being alone terrified him.

title: Pharmerging Markets
description: Emerging markets targeted by pharmaceutical companies.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from South Korea, Russia and Turkey.

title: FIA Releases List of Teams, Drivers and Engines for 2011
description: The 2011 Formula One season is already taking shape. The International Automobile Federation, the sports governing body, released on Tuesday the official list of teams, drivers and engines that have entered next years championship.

title: FIA Releases List of Teams, Drivers and Engines for 2011
description: The 2011 Formula One season is already taking shape. The International Automobile Federation, the sports governing body, released on Tuesday the official list of teams, drivers and engines that have entered next years championship.

title: Pentagon Sees Little Risk in Allowing Gay Men and Women to Serve Openly
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon has concluded that allowing gay men and women to serve openly in the United States armed forces presents a low risk to the militarys effectiveness, even at a time of war, and that 70 percent of surveyed service members believe that the impact on their units would be positive, mixed or of no consequence at all.

title: Trial Will Pause to Celebrate, at Site Decided by a Newborn
description: Its a boy, so Judge Kimba M. Wood will not have to carry out an unusual directive she issued in response to an unusual pretrial document filed by a Manhattan defense lawyer.

title: Afghan Killer of Six Americans Was Trusted Police Officer
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Fellow villagers claimed he was just a poor kid who had taken a police job to help his family get by. Superiors saw him as a reliable foot soldier in the Afghan Border Police who had inexplicably snapped. The Taliban claimed he was a sleeper agent they had planted to kill NATO soldiers.

title: WikiLeaks Next Target: Bank of America?
description: 3:33 p.m. | Updated with Bank of America statement

title: Top Lobbyist Leaves Business to Avoid Conflicts
description: ALBANY  The arrival of a new governor usually heralds boom times for those lobbyists lucky enough to enjoy ties to the new administration.

title: Nuclear Fuel Memos Expose Wary Dance With Pakistan
description: This article is by  Jane Perlez, David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt.

title: Despite ABB Deal, Europe Is Cautious on Mergers
description: The news that the Swiss group ABB is buying the Baldor Electric Company, an American motor maker,  points to a paradox in Europe that could bode well for mergers and acquisitions on the Continent next year.

title: Student Killed in Brooklyn Car Crash
description: Update, Dec. 3 | While Anel Kolenovic, the man charged in the car crash that killed Moshe Berkowitz in Brooklyn on Monday, was initially charged by the police with operating a motor vehicle under the influence, the Brooklyn district attorneys office decided not to immediately pursue the charge, based on the results of a Breathalyzer test administered three hours after the accident.

title: In Kazakhstan, Clinton Defends Openness, but Condemns Diplomatic Cable Leaks
description: ASTANA, Kazakhstan  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton spoke about the virtues of an open society here on Tuesday, at the start of her first overseas trip since the release of thousands of confidential diplomatic cables containing blunt appraisals of foreign countries and leaders.

title: Europe Examines Ways to Quell Its Debt Crisis
description: LONDON  Fears over the European financial crisis began to spread Tuesday from the weaker countries to healthier ones, including Italy and Belgium, and even much stronger Germany, spurring a stepped up search for a solution to the economic problems putting a strain on Europes decade-old monetary union.

title: How an Anonymous Graffiti Artist Voted
description: Alaskas Senate election may still be somewhat in dispute back home, but the result is written in stone in Washington  literally.

title: Britains Mouthwatering Deal That May Never Happen
description: London arbitragers are betting that Simon Property will make a play for Capital Shopping Centers of Britain. But theres no offer on the table  and potentially little shareholder support

title: Jimmy Carter Visits the White House
description: Former President Jimmy Carter returned to the White House on Tuesday for the first time since President Obama took office.

title: Osteria Morini
description: MICHAEL WHITE cooks pasta and people go crazy. This has been the case since he was the chef at Fiamma Osteria on Spring Street in the early years of the century, and it remains the case at Osteria Morini, a casual new restaurant on Lafayette Street.

title: Michael Douglas Enters the Awards Fray
description: When the Bagger attended the premiere of Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps in the otherwise woefully unglittery months before awards season began, the star of the afterparty was the billionaire Warren Buffett, who has a cameo in the film and, it turns out, a quick wit. (Asked if his money ever slept, Mr. Buffett replied, My money doesnt even take cat naps.)

title: Reviewing Osteria Morini
description: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

title: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from South Korea, Russia and Turkey.

title: Bakers Secret | Tell Tale Preserve Company
description: There is a bag of oak-bourbon caramels to my right, smoked-almond brittle to my left. I will try to ignore their siren calls and relay the account of their maker, William Werner, a pastry chef who was last seen at Quince and who, in September, re-emerged as the founding father of San Franciscos Tell Tale Society, a kind of CSA for treats. This Society is an offshoot of a grander venture still, a patisserie and delicatessen that will open its doors at 33 Maiden Lane in February under the name Tell Tale Preserve Company.

title: Speed Camera Lottery Wins VW Fun Theory Contest
description: To compel drivers to obey posted speed limits, traffic authorities generally wield but one stick: the law book. However, a San Francisco father of three says he believes that if motorists were given positive incentives to check their speed, they would not only do so, but would have fun doing it.

title: A Solar Installation Spree as the Deadline for Federal Grants Approaches
description: Owners of commercial buildings are rushing in such numbers to meet an end-of-the-year deadline for a federal Treasury grant program for solar energy installations that inventories of some equipment have dried up, solar energy experts said.

title: Drafts Vagaries on Display at the Garden
description: Based on their pedigree, or draft position, we might have envisioned Terrence Williams to be a Nets starter by now and the Knicks Landry Fields to be an apprentice in the N.B.A. Development League. But scouting reports are not the most effective indicators, given their preoccupation with vertical leap and 3-point range.

title: Naughty and Nice Retailer Return Policies
description: Updated | Dec. 1, 2010

title: Beauty Discrimination During a Job Search
description: How much do looks matter during a job search? A new study suggests that while handsome men do better while looking for work, good looks can end up hurting a womans chances of scoring a job interview.

title: On Her First Day, Black Reads to First Graders
description: Cathleen P. Black spent part of her first morning on the job as schools chancellor-designee on Tuesday reading to a classroom of first graders from a wooden rocking chair, a purple stuffed dog cradled in her lap.

title: F.C.C. Investigates Complaint Against Comcast
description: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said Tuesday that the agency was looking into claims by Level 3 Communications that Comcast had unfairly erected a toll booth that threatens the open Internet.
