title: Public Opinion on Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: The Pentagon on Tuesday released its long-awaited report on dont ask, dont tell, the policy that allows gay men and women to serve in the military as long as they keep their sexual orientation quiet. The report, the result of a nine-month study, said that repealing the law would present a low risk to military effectiveness. It also found that 70 percent of service members believe that the impact of repealing the law would be positive, mixed or of no consequence at all.

title: Video of Students and Police Clashing in Italy
description: Updated | 7:57 p.m. As Reuters reports, Italian students took to the streets of several cities on Tuesday to protest government plans to cut spending on education.

title: Google Energy Guru Will Head Policy Center at Stanford
description: Dan W. Reicher, a former assistant secretary of energy, has left Google, where he spent the last four years as director of climate change and energy initiatives. In that post he helped develop Googles goal of seeking to make renewable energy less expensive than coal, abbreviated as RE<C.

title: Through the Eyes of a Foster Mom
description: In the British newspaper The Guardian this weekend, an unnamed foster mother (in Britain, she is called a carer) wrote an account of a year of her life.

title: A Seat With a View Returns
description: The Roosevelt Island tram glided back into action on Tuesday morning, after a $25 million, eight-month makeover that disrupted the commute for those who regularly travel back and forth from the East River enclave.

title: Historical Bleg
description: If anyone can help me with this, please weigh in: Theres a fact or maybe factoid I havent been able to pin down. Im pretty sure that someone  Jean Monnet?  once joked that there should be a statue of Stalin in front of the European Commission building at Berlaymont, since hes the man who made it all possible.

title: First Look | Duchess of Windsor Auction
description: Its official: royal fever is in full swing. QVC and the supermarket chain Tesco are selling synthetic versions of Catherine Middletons engagement ring from Wednesday and Sothebys London is auctioning the jewels of the Duchess of Windsor on Tuesday. It is still the highest valued private jewelry collection ever sold, said David Bennett, Sothebys chairman of Europe and the Middle East for International Jewelry. The last sale of the Duchess of Windsors jewelry was held in Geneva nearly a quarter of a century ago in 1987. The treasures include a 1935 gold Cartier cigarette case with gems denoting the royals exotic destination spots and the 1957 emerald, ruby and diamond 20th anniversary brooch. Now is a chance to buy a piece of eternal style. Lucky ones may get a chance to pair it with an invite to next years eagerly anticipated nuptials.

title: Novels About Losing Your Job
description: 5:29 p.m. | Updated

title: Photo Replay: Nov. 30
description: A view of the day in sports, from snowy slopes to hardwood courts.

title: Director of Jewish Museum to Step Down
description: Joan Rosenbaum, who has led the Jewish Museum since 1981, will step down as director at the end of June, the museum plans to announce on Wednesday.

title: Cables Praise French Friend With Mercurial Side
description: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy is an unusually solid French friend of America. He is also a mercurial man operating in a zone of monarch-like impunity surrounded by advisers often too fearful to give honest counsel, according to leaked cables from the United States Embassy in Paris.

title: Blackwater Aimed to Hunt Pirates
description: WASHINGTON  Besieged by criminal inquiries and Congressional investigators, how could the worlds most controversial private security company drum up new business? By battling pirates on the high seas, of course.

title: What Were Reading: Marijuana Price Index
Principal of School Where Girl Drowned Is Removed
description: A Manhattan school principal who kept his job after a student drowned on a field trip last summer was removed from his position on Tuesday after an investigation found he had used a school employee, with whom he later became romantically involved, as a nanny, and allowed her to live rent-free in his apartment, the authorities said.

title: Broadway Cowboy of Australia
description: It seems like only a year or two ago that David Campbell, the shape-shifting Australian pop singer, was hailed as the next big thing when he became the youngest performer ever to open at the Rainbow and Stars cabaret, now defunct, in Rockefeller Center. But the year was actually 1997, and Mr. Campbell was a 24-year-old eager beaver of seemingly boundless confidence and ambition. Although American stardom eluded him, he went on to establish himself as a top-of-the-line musical theater performer in his homeland while continuing to pay visits to the United States.

title: Swiping, Linking and Highlighting: A Few New Features
description: On a site as big as NYTimes.com, changes and updates occur on a daily basis. Heres a look at some of the features weve added in the past six months.

title: Prince Street and Broadway, 1:21 P.M.
ReTweet | The Buzz From Design Miami
description: Keep tabs on Art Basel Miami Beach on our Twitter feed (search the #abmb hash tag).

title: Biden Meets With Rep. Issa
description: It was a day for summit meetings at the White House.

title: Tales Within Tales Create a Tale of Two Nutcracker Productions
description: The original source of the Nutcracker story, E. T. A. Hoffmanns novella Nutcracker and Mouseking (1816), is a good example of whats called metafiction. Its a story within a story within a story: some characters pass from one layer to another, while others dont. We can see why the heroine, Marie, is perplexed that most of those she knows and loves cant see or believe the things she experiences; we can also see why they dont believe her.

title: A Rallying Cry in Support of an Immigration Bill
description: Activists across the country rallied on Tuesday in a day of support for the Dream Act, the long-languishing bill that would open a path to legalization for young people and may finally come up for a vote in the next several days.

title: Assembly Passes Ban on Fracking
description: The Assembly voted Monday night to place a temporary moratorium on hydraulic fracturing, also known as fracking or hydrofracking, the controversial type of natural gas exploration that has divided property owners upstate. The goal of the ban is to give the state more time to address safety and environmental concerns. The measure has already been approved by the State Senate and so awaits only the governors signature. Read about the fracking ban on the Green blog.

title: First Round of Voting Ousts Islamists From Egypts Parliament
description: CAIRO  As the results of Egypts parliamentary elections trickled in Tuesday, no one was surprised that the governing party of President Hosni Mubarak won a huge victory. Nor were they surprised that the candidates of the Muslim Brotherhood, Egypts only sizable opposition, took a beating.

title: Will Top Firings Change Barneys Cool?
description: No department store in the 1990s had the cool factor of Barneys New York. It had the edgiest designers (Martin Margiela, Helmut Lang, Comme des Garons), the kookiest windows and a team of buyers and merchandisers that made the store something of a hip event. Even when the store filed for bankruptcy protection, in 1996, it kept its cool.

title: At the Gotham Awards
description: Images and quotes from attendees of the Gotham Awards, the independent film celebration that kicks off awards season.

title: The Gold Mines Behind Padlocks
description: Thousands of people are going to quit their jobs on Thursday morning because of a zippy new reality series called Storage Wars, which has its premiere on Wednesday night on A&E. Why go to work when you can be a full-time storage-locker buyer?

title: Untested Musicals Take Over Broadway
description: The 2010-11 Broadway season is shaping up as a bounty of new musicals with ambitious original scores. But new songs, untested on Broadway, come with risk, both artistically and  especially this season  financially.

title: Dodd, Retiring, Has Some Final Words
description: In a stirring rhetorical capstone to his 30-year career, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, lamented that our political system at the federal level is completely dysfunctional but urged younger lawmakers to overcome the intense partisan polarization and respect the traditions of the Senate, particularly the rights of the minority.

title: Friendly Enemies on Fox: Simpsons and OReilly
description: The Simpsons has certainly never been shy about biting the corporate hand that feeds it  witness the recent opening-credit sequence of that Fox animated comedy, created by the underground artist Banksy, that imagined 20th Century Fox as a nightmarish third-world sweatshop.

title: Land of the Talking Knish
description: A roundup of links for your edification or distraction as the evening rolls in.

title: A Series Homage Lovingly Wrapped in Plastic
description: By 11 p.m. on Wednesday (10 p.m., Central), the people who catalog such things will have already ferreted out and posted the many homages to Twin Peaks in Dual Spires, the new episode of Psych on USA that will have just ended.

title: Checking In on Those Lingering Midterm Races
description: Since our last update, closure (or something close to closure) has come to seven of the nine midterm contests that were unresolved.

title: Catholics Fire Back in Christmas Billboard Battle
description: The latest salvo in the Christmas wars has landed, blocks from the New York entrance of the Lincoln Tunnel.

title: The Gotham Awards in Pictures
description: Now that were in our sophomore year as Oscarologists, the Bagger agrees with the assessment that the Gotham Awards are the high school reunion of the season. The red carpet, held indoors Monday night, had all the bright lights, noise and shoving of a school hallway (which would make the publicists what? The hall monitors?). There were freshman  newly-anointed indie stars like Lena Dunham and Greta Gerwig; seen-it-all seniors, like the director Darren Aronofsky; impossibly cool kids (Anthony Mackie); and the wise-cracking elders (Fran Lebowitz). As promised, heres our yearbook.

title: Debt Panel to Delay Vote Until Friday
description: The chairmen of President Obamas debt-reduction commission say they will release a final plan by Wednesday morning, technically meeting the presidents deadline, but they delayed the panels vote until Friday to give members time to consider the far-reaching tax and spending proposals.

title: Farewell to Reefs, Salt Ponds and Milkfish
description: Stuart Sandin of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography traveled to the Line Islands in early November to examine the coral reefs of inhabited and uninhabited islands. Here are the final two entries from his expedition.

title: Now Open | C.H.C.M.
description: It seems as if men can get their work wear from any mall that has a J. Crew these days, but it turns out that the best of that lot has been hiding in plain sight for a year and a half on the expertly curated, under-the-radar menswear Web shop C.H.C.M. The owner, Sweetu Patel, knows a little something about timeless design after putting in five years on the floor of Cappellini, the SoHo Italian design emporium; for C.H.C.M.  which stands for Clinton Hill Classic Menswear  he has carved a niche with classic American and European brands as well as hard-to-find Japanese ones. Last week, he brought those labels even closer within reach when he opened a fashionably minimalist, brick-and-mortar shop in NoHo. The store shares its raw, slightly underground space with the fashion designer Tunji Dada and the curator-about-town Josee Lepage, who was setting up her creative consultancy within plain view of the merchandise on Friday, opening day. I wanted a nice space, good music, nothing pretentious  like the stores I grew up around in Northampton, England, in the late 80s and early 90s, says Patel.

title: New Arrivals Strain Indias Cities to Breaking Point
description: NEW DELHI  Mahitosh Sarkar came here from his distant village in West Bengal 12 years ago looking for a better life, and he found it. He abandoned the penniless existence of a subsistence fisherman to become a big-city vegetable seller. His wife found work as a maid. Their four children went to school. Their tiny household, a grim but weather-tight room in a dilapidated tenement, had a color TV and a satellite dish.

title: A Melting Pot of All Kinds of Rhythms, Harmonies and Vamps
description: Harris Eisenstadt, a drummer and composer originally from Toronto, takes a fixers approach to music making, looking for ways to fit the pieces together. He works along jazzs progressive fringe but doesnt generally set out to make a ruckus. In his own music especially, he often seems intent on extracting consonance from dissonance or forging ungainliness into grace.

title: Farewell to a Great Web Effort at Worldchanging
description: When I dove into the blogosphere with Dot Earth in 2007 after a quarter century of conventional journalism, I was excited to find some veterans  if that word is remotely appropriate online  actively pursuing a vision of a humanized, but thriving, planet over at the Web site Worldchanging.com.

title: Midwest Emerges as Center for Clean Energy
description: CIRCLEVILLE, Ohio  With surprising speed, and with the help of ample public incentives, a solar energy manufacturing center has emerged in the upper Midwest that is helping to supply the worlds growing demand for clean power.

title: Producer Says Spider-Man Has Strong Ticket Sales
description: The new Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark sold more than $1 million in tickets within 24 hours after the shows first preview on Sunday night, the lead producer, Michael Cohl, said on Tuesday. The shows maiden performances have drawn comment since the creators are still working on technical sequences; at the first preview the show had to stop five times to deal with glitches. That shaky performance came as some theater producers said that Foxwoods Theater, the landlord for Spider-Man, had inquired whether they had shows in the works that might be fits for the theater. Late on Monday the theaters general manager, Erich Jungwirth, said in a statement that he had indeed talked to producers to see if there are any shows coming up that may be able to play in our venue. Such conversations are customary, Mr. Jungwirth said. The producers found the outreach unusual because it came when Spider-Man was already delaying its first preview by two weeks and involved a theater with a $65 million show that needs a multiyear run to turn a profit. A spokesman for the production, Rick Miramontez, also said late on Monday, We are looking forward to Spider-Man being at the Foxwoods Theater for years to come.

title: Missing Dancing, ABC Loses Top Spot
description: Without Dancing With the Stars on its Monday schedule, ABC fell to second place in the nights ratings as CBS and its all-repeat lineup took the lead. According to Nielsen estimates, just six million viewers watched ABCs spinoff series Skating With the Stars from 8 to 9:30 p.m. Reruns of sitcoms including Two and a Half Men (11.2 million) and How I Met Your Mother (8.5 million) lifted CBS to No. 1 over all. NBC was third with new episodes of Chuck (6.2 million), The Event (5.8 million) and Chase (6 million); Fox was fourth.

title: $60 Million Radio Deal for Seacrest
description: LOS ANGELES  Ryan Seacrest, pop culture curator?

title: For Start-Ups, the Ultimate Goal: Becoming a Verb
description: When starting a new Web site or Internet service, mosttechnologists are aiming to sell to a larger company or gain hundreds of millions of users. But for some there is an even bigger glory than cash: their company name becomes a verb.

title: New Music on Broadway
description: A look at some of the new shows of the season.

title: Art Basel Miami Beach | Surreal Reveal
description: Despite the slew of peripheral events on Tuesdays calendar (dont forget to R.S.V.P. for tonights Gaetano Pesce for Melissa shoes launch), the day before the official vernissage for Art Basel Miami Beach is relatively calm. For the last few years, its also been the day for early out-of-towners (Jane Holzer, Adam Lindemann) and locals (Tiqui Atencio, Ella Cisneros) to attend a preview hosted by Sothebys at Miamis Fairchild Tropical Botanic Garden. This years show, Les Lalanne at Fairchild, is the largest outdoor exhibition of works by the French sculptors Claude and Franois-Xavier Lalanne. The display includes over 20 sculptures dotted throughout the 83-acre sylvan paradise, including the couples well-known flock of epoxystone and bronze sheep and lambs. Claudes favorite, however, is Dimetrodon II (1998), a copper and steel topiary dinosaur, which spouts water through its teeth. How can you not love it? asked Claude, whose husband died in 2008. Its a prehistoric monster who somehow finds himself in a big modern grotto.Les Lalanne at Fairchild runs through April 1, 2011.

title: Goldmans $20 Million Consequence
description: Goldman Sachs made its bed. Now Judge Jed S. Rakoff says the Wall Street firm has got to lie in it.

title: Colleges Are Producing New Style of AIDS Activist
description: NEW HAVEN  David Carel was never a rabble-rouser. But amid the clutter of his dorm room at Yale University, Mr. Carel, baby-faced and slight-shouldered at 19, keeps evidence of his new life as an AIDS activist: posters, banners and the flier demanding $50 bn for Global AIDS that he concealed in his fleece jacket one Saturday in late October when, heart pounding, he sneaked past security into a Democratic campaign rally in Bridgeport.

title: When a Trusted Brand Disappears
description: MY mother discovered Camay soap 64 years ago, when she immigrated to New York from London at the end of World War II after marrying my father, an American soldier. She has seen much change in her 86 years, but her devotion to Camay has remained constant.

title: The Mysteries of Naming Tech Products
description: Heres a note from a reader:

title: Proxy Firms Need More Rules, Companies Say
description: HARRY CAMPBELL

title: Design Miami | Loitering Within Tents
description: Visitors to Design Miami, the citys annual design fair, can finally save on town cars and taxis. In a long overdue move Craig Robins, Design Miamis co-founder, has erected the fairs tent (designed by Moorhead & Moorhead) in the parking lot across the street from the Miami Convention Center, where the concurrent Art Basel Miami Beach fair is held, saving collectors and admirers of contemporary furniture from having to trek across town to get to Miamis far-flung design district.

title: End Ethanol Subsidies, Senators Say
description: Subsidies and tariffs to promote domestic ethanol production are fiscally irresponsible and environmentally unwise and should be ended, a bipartisan group of United States senators declared in a letter to the chambers leaders on Tuesday.

title: Angels in America To Play Five More Weeks, With New Cast Members
description: Michael Urie (ABCs Ugly Betty) and Adam Driver (Mrs. Warrens Profession) will take over the central roles of Prior Walter and his unfaithful lover Louis Ironson in the current Off Broadway revival of Angels in America on Feb. 2, 2011, and play for a new five-week extension of the production through March 27, Signature Theater Company announced on Tuesday.

title: For Every Holiday Party, the Right Drink
description: Cocktails that will match the food, match the company, match the feeling in the air.
